headline: Bowl Games to Watch on New Year’s Day
abstract: Other than the national championship game, the Rose Bowl offers the most anticipated matchup of the season, but the Capital One Bowl and Fiesta Bowl should also be intriguing.
lead_paragraph: ROSE BOWL

headline: New Year’s Eve, Stuck in a Church in Bangui
abstract: The building has become a small island of refuge in the Central African Republic’s rapidly unraveling capital.
lead_paragraph: In the brutally violent week before Christmas, dozens of families poured into a church in Bangui in the Central African Republic, my colleague Carlotta Gall reported last week. Run by Archbishop Dieudonné Nzapalainga, the building had become a small island of refuge in the Central African Republic’s rapidly unraveling capital.

headline: House Prices Rise Again, but the Pace Could Slow
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Home prices have risen steadily since the spring of 2012, but are now slowing a bit. The Fed’s coming taper, and how it affects mortgage rates, may contribute to that, economists say.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was a great year for the stock market. And it was also a pretty good year for many people’s biggest investment: their homes.

headline: Jaywalking Rules and Habits: L.A. vs. New York
abstract: Readers react to an article about a crackdown on pedestrians in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Drawn Back Into Iraq
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Iraq War (2003-11)']
abstract: Stuart Gottlieb of Columbia University criticizes President Obama’s decisions on Iraq.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Egypt Says 3 Journalists Will Be Held 15 More Days
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Terrorism', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: The journalists from Al Jazeera English face charges that include belonging to a terrorist group and harming Egypt’s reputation abroad.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egyptian prosecutors on Tuesday ordered three detained journalists from the news channel Al Jazeera English to be held in custody for 15 more days, on charges that include belonging to a terrorist group and harming the country’s reputation abroad.

headline: Killing With Kindness
keywords: ['Land Use Policies', 'Invasive Species', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Gardens and Gardening']
abstract: On Oahu, one man is clearing the way for native plants and animals to thrive.
lead_paragraph: WAIKANE, Hawaii — On days he can round up at least one volunteer to help him in his mission to restore native species to the forest, Paul Zweng commutes in an all-wheel-drive pickup from the home he shares with his wife and children in suburban Honolulu. Hugging the coast north toward the striking mountain terrain on the windward side of Oahu, he stops to pick up Sam or Charlotte or Jim. The regulars.

headline: Spiders That Went to Design School
abstract: John Derian turns natural motifs into wallpaper for Studio Printworks.
lead_paragraph: John Derian, who sells antique furnishings and curios in his East Village shops, got his start with decoupage. He decorated gridded glass panels with drawings of sea plants or parrots and hung them as murals. Now, thanks to a new line of wallpapers, those images will adhere directly to the wall.

headline: Hello, Here’s Your Closet
abstract: Good things came to a lawyer who waited — and waited — to renovate his apartment.
lead_paragraph: Good things came to a lawyer who waited — and waited — to renovate his apartment.

headline: Love in the Wings
abstract: Good things came to a lawyer who waited — and waited — to renovate his apartment.
lead_paragraph: On the theory that if you build it, whomever you’re waiting for will show up, Jay Dubiner decided to renovate his apartment.

headline: Evaluating Teachers
abstract: A former principal discusses a new evaluation system in New York City.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Hawaiian Roots
abstract: Armed with hatchets and herbicides, Paul Zweng and his volunteers thin a forest of invasive trees one section at a time. Their mission: to return the land to its natural state.
lead_paragraph: Armed with hatchets and herbicides, Paul Zweng and his volunteers thin a forest of invasive trees one section at a time. Their mission: to return the land to its natural state.

headline: Does the Garage Interior Matter to Home Buyers?
abstract: It needs to look organized and clean.
lead_paragraph: Q. Does it matter how the interior of my garage looks when it’s time to sell?

headline: Making Way for the Real Hawaii
abstract: One man’s efforts would restore a part of Oahu to the days before invasive plants and animals altered the land.
lead_paragraph: One man’s efforts would restore a part of Oahu to the days before invasive plants and animals altered the land.

headline: Regulating Supplements
keywords: ['Dietary Supplements and Herbal Remedies', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The American Herbal Products Association responds to an Op-Ed essay questioning the safety of supplements.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Obamacare We Deserve
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'States (US)', 'Medicare', 'Medicaid', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Now that Obamacare has finally arrived, liberals can stop defending its flaws and argue instead for universal health care.
lead_paragraph: TODAY marks the beginning of health care coverage under the Affordable Care Act’s new insurance exchanges, for which two million Americans have signed up. Now that the individual mandate is officially here, let me begin with an admission: Obamacare is awful.

headline: Anxious Youth, Then and Now
abstract: Today’s millennials face many of the same concerns and challenges of the late 19th century, when the booms and busts of the Industrial Age tore apart the accepted order.
lead_paragraph: FOR years now, we’ve heard the gripes by and about millennials, the offspring of the Great Recession, caught between childhood and adulthood. Their plight seems so very 21st century: the unstable careers, the confusion of technologies, the delayed romance, parenthood and maturity.

headline: A Guide to Years Ending in 4
keywords: ['Nineteen Hundred Forties', 'Nineteen Hundred Fifties', 'Nineteen Hundred Sixties', 'Nineteen Hundred Seventies', 'Nineteen Hundred Eighties', 'Nineteen Hundred Nineties', 'Two Thousands (Decade)', 'New Year', 'Two Thousand Fourteen']
abstract: Does history give us reason to be optimistic about 2014?
lead_paragraph: War, famine, pestilence and death — the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse — have been well represented in years ending in “4,” but probably not disproportionately so. A look at memorable moments in the last seven of these just might lead to optimism for the one that’s upon us. Or not.

headline: Make of It Whatever You Will
abstract: Peter Korn, a woodworker and educator, on the virtues and terrors of craft.
lead_paragraph: The son of a lawyer and a historian, Peter Korn was a likely enough candidate for an Ivy League education. But a career in the trades?

headline: My Jewish State
abstract: Here is one prediction for 2014: This will be another year in which peace is not reached in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A year ends, another begins, time for reminiscences and resolutions, regret and hope, best-of and worst-of lists, confessions and crystal-ball gazing — most of it pretty excruciating. It will take a nanosecond longer to scroll back to one’s year of birth. So it goes.

headline: Sales at Waggo, Wolf Home and Others
abstract: Bargains on dog leashes, sofas and more.
lead_paragraph: Some of Michele Quan’s ceramic bells are 50 percent off while supplies last (extra-small thrown bells, originally $100, are $50; medium Teardrop thrown bells, originally $180, are $90); mquan.com.

headline: The New Year Within
abstract: How do you sum up the ritual of turning a new page in the calendar? The change we hope for might have to be constructed day by day.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes the New Year comes in feeling merely newish, a matter of changing months and not much else. But sometimes the New Year brings with it a powerful sense of regeneration, as if, like certain insects, you were entering a new stage of complete metamorphosis.

headline: Saying ‘I Do’ Amid the Roses
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Parades', 'Editorials']
abstract: After a historic year for marriage equality, a same-sex wedding on the first day of 2014 is scheduled to take place on a float at the Tournament of Roses Parade.
lead_paragraph: By all accounts, the standout entry in Wednesday’s Tournament of Roses Parade in Pasadena, Calif., will surely be the marriage of two men, Danny Leclair and Aubrey Loots, beaming amid the array of lavishly flowered floats to be viewed on national television and beyond.

headline: ‘Safe From Fire, Rats, Weather and Waste’
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'World War I (1914-18)', 'Military Bases and Installations']
abstract: In the 1940s, R. Buckminster Fuller converted grain bins into emergency housing. It seemed that these structures had disappeared, but at least a dozen have survived in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: In the 1940s, R. Buckminster Fuller converted grain bins into emergency housing. It seemed that these structures had disappeared, but at least a dozen have survived in New Jersey.

headline: War Shelters, Short-Lived Yet Living On
keywords: ['Military Bases and Installations', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: In the 1940s, R. Buckminster Fuller converted grain bins into emergency housing. For a long time it seemed they had disappeared from the earth, but at least a dozen have survived in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: Camp Evans, a decommissioned Army base in Wall Township, N.J., is frozen in midcentury, its brick administration buildings and boarded-up Quonset huts on hold from World War II. Fred Carl, 59, a former high school science teacher and the unofficial keeper of the site, leads a visitor to other throwbacks from that era: a collection of corrugated metal houses with porthole windows and conical roofs. They look like alien habitations dropped from the sky.

headline: Only the Purest Water Will Do
abstract: New silver goods from Puiforcat hold wine or water, or anything else that pours.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Jouin was a pioneer in 3-D-printed furniture, but he also likes working with basic tools and materials. The French designer’s new collection for Puiforcat, the venerable silver house, was inspired by water. Each piece is meant to contain liquid, but go ahead, toss in a few flowers.

headline: Homecoming of a Sort
abstract: The William, an extended-stay hotel, opens on East 39th Street, in a building that used to house Williams College’s alumni club.
lead_paragraph: The William, an extended-stay hotel, is to open next week at 24 East 39th Street in a 1924 building that for decades was home to the Williams College alumni club.

headline: Cameroon: Kidnapped French Priest Is Released
abstract: Georges Vandenbeusch, 42, who was reported to have been held in Nigeria by Boko Haram, a group with ties to Al Qaeda, was released on Tuesday, according to French authorities.
lead_paragraph: A French priest kidnapped in November by Islamist militants in northern Cameroon was released on Tuesday, according to French authorities. The priest, Georges Vandenbeusch, 42, was reported to have been held in Nigeria by Boko Haram, a group with ties to Al Qaeda. He described his captivity as “terribly boring,” according to Reuters. He paced circles under a tent beneath a tree, he said.

headline: Gaza: Hamas Lawmakers Approve Large Budget Deficit
abstract: Hamas lawmakers on Tuesday approved a 2014 budget totaling $589 million for the Gaza Strip that included a staggering 75 percent deficit.
lead_paragraph: Hamas lawmakers on Tuesday approved a 2014 budget totaling $589 million for the Gaza Strip that included a staggering 75 percent deficit. The Islamist Hamas movement has said that Egypt’s closing of hundreds of smuggling tunnels beneath its border this summer had cost the strip $460 million in taxes and broader productivity. Gaza gets significant funding from the Palestinian Authority and donor nations, but Hamas has rarely made budgetary specifics public.

headline: For Stocks, an Amazingly Good Year
keywords: ['Dow Jones Stock Average', 'Nasdaq Composite Index', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Despite turbulence in Washington, China and Europe, which threatened to pull the world into another recession, stock prices just kept rising in 2013.
lead_paragraph: It was the market rally that defied gravity and left many with a case of vertigo.

headline: Don’t Knock These Faux-Bois Accessories
keywords: ['Wood and Wood Products', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Fake-wood items are often very fine, and they can add interest to bland spaces.
lead_paragraph: In the society of fake wood, there are many classes. Materials doctored to have the look of wood grain may be as humble as plastic laminate or as luxurious as silk — in which case the counterfeiting is more likely to be described as “faux bois.”

headline: In Tiny Houses, Hope Lives
abstract: Designed to benefit typhoon victims, the houses shelter flickering candles.
lead_paragraph: Kenneth Cobonpue, a Filipino furniture designer with offices in New York, Germany and his native Cebu island, has produced miniature vernacular metal houses that hold tea lights. Proceeds from their sale will help Habitat for Humanity Philippines build shelters for victims of the typhoon that devastated the Visayas region in November.

headline: Arkansas Lieutenant Governor Faces Calls to Quit Over Ethics Violations
abstract: Gov. Mike Beebe called on Lt. Gov. Mark Darr to resign amid findings that he repeatedly broke campaign finance laws.
lead_paragraph: Lt. Gov. Mark Darr of Arkansas, who said this week that he would settle with his state’s Ethics Commission amid findings that he repeatedly broke campaign finance laws, on Tuesday defied mounting calls for his resignation, including one from Gov. Mike Beebe, and said he intended to remain in office.

headline: Preserving Wireless Competition
keywords: ['Cellular Telephones', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Wireless Communications', 'Editorials']
abstract: A combination of Sprint and T-Mobile could raise prices and hurt consumers.
lead_paragraph: The corporation that controls Sprint, the third-biggest cellphone company in the country after Verizon and AT&T, is reportedly planning to make an offer to buy the smaller rival T-Mobile in a move that would reduce competition in an important industry that already has too little of it.

headline: Phish Fans Encounter Crackdown at Garden
abstract: At least 228 people were arrested or received summonses on the first three nights of a four-night stand by the jam band that was to end Tuesday with a New Year’s Eve performance.
lead_paragraph: The arrests began almost as soon as the concertgoers amassed outside Madison Square Garden on Monday evening. Uniformed and plainclothes police officers moved through the crowd, picking off targets and leading them to a police van parked around the corner where they were patted down and loaded in.

headline: Supporters of $15 Wage Seek Appeal of Ruling
abstract: Voters in SeaTac, Wash., approved an increase last month, but a county judge struck down part of the statute.
lead_paragraph: SEATAC, Wash. — Supporters of a $15 minimum wage, approved by voters here in November but partly struck down last week by a county judge, asked the state’s highest court to hear an appeal.

headline: Kerry’s Peace Ambitions
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry’s remarks on Middle East peace talks have changed over time.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry’s remarks on Middle East peace talks have changed over time.

headline: More Guns Will Not Save Iraq
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials']
abstract: Washington needs to press Baghdad to commit to democracy as well as security.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has done the predictable thing by sending more weapons to Iraq to counter an alarming rise in violence. But arms alone will not solve a problem that has its roots in the political alienation of Sunnis and other minorities and the undermining of democratic processes, especially by Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki.

headline: College, Not Just for Himself, but for His Son
abstract: The stresses of school exams and parenthood could crush any 21-year old, but Giovanni Classen seems to have found a way to make it work.
lead_paragraph: The load on a full-time college student is a heavy one. Finals and midterms, especially when paired with the duties of fatherhood, could crush any 21-year old, but Giovanni Classen, who recently became a single father to his 1-year-old son, Ezio, seems to have found a way to make it work.

headline: Power Curbed, Detroit Mayor Faces Big Job
abstract: Mike Duggan must share power with an appointed emergency manager and confront vexing questions about the future of a city that has been losing population for decades.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — For some who have been around this city the longest, expectations for a new mayor have by now become understandably low: Turn some streetlights on. Do not get indicted. Wait for the lawyers to get Detroit out of bankruptcy.

headline: U.S. Solar Panel Maker Seeks to Close Loophole in Duties on Chinese Products
abstract: Expanding a long-simmering dispute, SolarWorld Industries America has asked the Commerce Department to impose duties on solar modules containing parts made in China or Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: A major maker of solar panels opened another chapter in a long-simmering trade dispute on Tuesday, asking the Commerce Department to impose new duties on imported modules made of certain components from China or Taiwan.

headline: Snow May Deal a First Test to de Blasio One Day After He Takes Office
abstract: Snow has been dealing punches to mayors since New York’s earliest days, and residents will be watching how the new mayor handles the predicted six to eight inches.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, Bill de Blasio watched as a heavy layer of snow accumulated outside his Park Slope rowhouse during a post-Christmas blizzard, and waited — and waited — for the city’s plows to arrive. Three days passed before his block was cleared.

headline: Kerry to Press for ‘Framework’ Accord to Keep Mideast Peace Effort Moving
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry hopes to secure a broad pact encapsulating basic agreements on core issues as a first step, but critics brand the move as an effort to play for time.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an intensifying diplomatic effort, Secretary of State John Kerry is making a major push to secure what Obama administration officials are calling a “framework” accord that would be a critical first step to a comprehensive Middle East peace agreement. But critics are already branding it as an effort to play for time.

headline: Millions Gaining Health Coverage Under Law
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The new moment will test the health law’s central premise — that extending coverage to far more Americans will improve the nation’s health and help many avoid crippling medical bills.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Millions of Americans will begin receiving health insurance coverage under the Affordable Care Act on Wednesday after years of contention and a rollout hobbled by delays and technical problems. The decisively new moment in the effort to overhaul the country’s health care system will test the law’s central premise: that extending coverage to far more Americans will improve the nation’s health and help many avoid crippling medical bills.

headline: Jets, at Least for Moment, Put Entertainment Aside
abstract: Rex Ryan appeared very much on an imaginary leash as General Manager John Idzik set the conservative agenda for a news conference Tuesday, two days after the Jets wrapped up an 8-8 season.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Off the top of his head, John Idzik could think of several reasons he still wanted Rex Ryan to be his head coach two days after a third consecutive Jets season of not making the playoffs. After all, they shared a legacy as sons of men who served as coordinators in the organization. They had “similar views” on how to build a team and, Idzik said, had developed a synergy on doing it together.

headline: Old Rivalries Reignited a Fuse in South Sudan
abstract: The conflict in South Sudan is rooted partly in a failure to achieve a lasting reconciliation between rival factions when the country was created in 2011.
lead_paragraph: JUBA, South Sudan — Few moments conjure as much fear in South Sudan as the massacre of Bor.

headline: Cuomo Prods Assemblymen to Resign
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo called on the State Assembly to “seriously consider” expelling Micah Z. Kellner and Dennis H. Gabryszak if they did not leave of their own accord.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — In a strongly worded statement about the seemingly endless series of allegations of sexual misconduct in the State Assembly, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo called on Tuesday for two assemblymen facing such allegations to either immediately deny the reports’ veracity or resign.

headline: Bowden Adjusts to His Life as a Dadgum Retiree
abstract: Bobby Bowden has come to terms with being forced out after leading the Florida State football program for 33 years, and praises the accomplishments of Jimbo Fisher.
lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — Bobby Bowden still lives in the cream-colored brick house he and his wife, Ann, fell in love with in 1976. There was a pool out back, a golf course beyond that and, in the front yard, a sprawling oak tree that canopied the driveway. Its limbs were so big and low that Bowden could walk up them.

headline: 2 Slashed at Port Authority Bus Terminal
abstract: Two men suffered apparently non-life-threatening wounds around 8:50 p.m., as New Year’s Eve festivities were underway in Times Square, fire officials said.
lead_paragraph: Two men were injured in slashings at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in New York on Tuesday night, sending frightened people running from the station, just a block from the New Year’s Eve celebration in Times Square, officials said.

headline: Cuomo Issues Pardons for First Time in Office
abstract: Mr. Cuomo on Tuesday granted pardons to three men who had already completed their sentences.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced the first pardons of his term on Tuesday afternoon, granting clemency to three New Yorkers whose lives, he said, continued to be “hampered by their criminal records.”

headline: City Makes Deal to Keep Market at Hunts Point
abstract: After years of negotiations, the city and the produce market’s owners reached an agreement that keeps the market and its 3,000 jobs in the South Bronx until 2021.
lead_paragraph: On the last day of the Bloomberg administration, city officials bought some time in their long-running effort to keep the Hunts Points Terminal Produce Market from leaving the Bronx for New Jersey or elsewhere.

headline: A’s for Athletes, but Charges of Fraud at North Carolina
abstract: Some classes never met and some grades were illicitly changed in a University of North Carolina department that attracted numerous athletes, and a respected professor now faces a criminal charge.
lead_paragraph: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — In the summer of 2011, 19 undergraduates at the University of North Carolina signed up for a lecture course called AFAM 280: Blacks in North Carolina. The professor was Julius Nyang’oro, an internationally respected scholar and longtime chairman of the African and Afro-American studies department.

headline: Not Shy About Expressing Opinions
abstract: Peter A. Collins gets firsties.* *Usually, when a person posts a comment “first” in a forum, but in this case, first puzzle of the year.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — If you do the puzzle online, you will no doubt see this post before you ring in the New Year, but many people don’t, so let’s pretend it’s Wednesday morning and New Year’s Day. Ready?

headline: De Blasio Draws All Liberal Eyes to New York City
abstract: Bill de Blasio has energized the national left, which is hoping that an assertive, tax-the-rich liberal can transform the nation’s most prominent municipal office into a laboratory of populist theories of government.
lead_paragraph: Liberals across the country are looking to Bill de Blasio, who was sworn in as mayor early Wednesday, to morph New York City’s municipal machinery into a closely watched laboratory for populist theories of government that have never before been enacted on such a large scale.

headline: As Alumni Meet at the Winter Classic, Even 74-Year-Old Likes to Have Coach’s Confidence
abstract: The former Red Wings’ star Red Berenson, 74, helped defend a victory in one of two Winter Classic alumni games pitting teams from Detroit and Toronto.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — So many former Detroit Red Wings and Toronto Maple Leafs wanted to play in the Winter Classic alumni game that they staged two games. So all the old Wings and Leafs converged Tuesday afternoon on Comerica Park, a baseball stadium transformed into a wintry ice arena, where some 35,000 fans in tuques and gloves and red sweaters or blue sweaters stamped their feet and thrilled to the sight of their heroes skating down the ice again.

headline: Justice Blocks Contraception Mandate on Insurance in Suit by Nuns
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Religion-State Relations']
abstract: Justice Sonia Sotomayor is giving the government until Friday morning to respond to her decision on President Obama’s health care law.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Sonia Sotomayor on Tuesday temporarily blocked the Obama administration from forcing some religious-affiliated groups to provide health insurance coverage of birth control or face penalties as part of the Affordable Care Act.

headline: McDonagh Is Expanding His Game, and Adding Admirers
abstract: Defenseman Ryan McDonagh, always eager to deflect credit to teammates, has been difficult to overlook this season as he has emerged as an offensive force for the Rangers.
lead_paragraph: Since defenseman Ryan McDonagh made his debut with the Rangers midway through the 2010-11 season, he has been eager to deflect credit to teammates and has rarely sought the limelight.

headline: Boy, 15, Charged With Murders in Newark
abstract: A New Jersey boy is accused in the deaths of two teenagers who were among five people shot and killed around Newark on Christmas Day, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A 15-year-old New Jersey boy was charged on Tuesday with the murders of two teenagers who were among five people shot and killed around Newark on Christmas Day, the Essex County prosecutor’s office said.

headline: Con Ed Agrees Not to Raise Its Residential Electricity Rate for 2 Years
keywords: ['Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: The utility company had requested a $450 million rate increase, which would raise electricity rates by as much as 8 percent.
lead_paragraph: Consolidated Edison has agreed to spend about $650 million to prepare for another storm like Hurricane Sandy without raising its rates for residential electricity for two years, the company and state officials announced on Tuesday.

headline: Barbara Bush Hospitalized for Pneumonia in Texas
abstract: Mrs. Bush, 88, was admitted to Houston Methodist Hospital on Monday for treatment of pneumonia and remained there Tuesday evening.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Barbara Bush, the former first lady, has been admitted to a hospital here for treatment of pneumonia. She is recuperating at the same hospital where her husband, former President George Bush, spent weeks overcoming bronchitis-related illnesses in 2012.

headline: North Korean Leader Says He Wants Better Ties With South
abstract: In his New Year’s Day speech, Kim Jong-un called for improved ties with his country’s wary neighbor, while boasting of his regime’s tighter grip on power.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, on Wednesday called for improving relations with South Korea and boasted of his regime’s tightened grip on power in his first public speech since the purge and execution of his uncle, Jang Song-thaek, last month.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Dec. 31, 2013
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Nets End Year Gaining Nothing but Sympathy
abstract: Spurs’ Coach Gregg Popovich said Brooklyn has been hit with so many different problems, “You can almost not even begin to deal with that.”
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — The 31st game of a team’s schedule may be an arbitrary checkpoint in the N.B.A. season, but as it fell for the Nets on the final day of the calendar year, it seemed to warrant at least a moment or two of reflection.

headline: West Nile Virus Is Behind Bald Eagle Deaths in Utah
abstract: Officials believe that the birds contracted the virus by eating infected waterfowl that died in the Great Salt Lake.
lead_paragraph: The mysterious deaths of at least 27 bald eagles in Utah were caused by the West Nile virus, state officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Patricia Ryan, a Managing Editor at Time Inc., Dies at 75
abstract: Initially making her mark as a secretary at Sports Illustrated who knew horses, Ms. Ryan was among the first women to lead major publications.
lead_paragraph: Patricia Ryan, who started at Time Inc. as a typist in the secretarial pool and rose to become the managing editor of People and Life, a rare ascent for a woman in what was then a male-dominated company, died on Friday at her home in Boothbay, Me. She was 75.

headline: Corrections: January 1, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on January 1, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Navigating Our World Like Birds and Bees
abstract: How we move around in our world is deeply hard-wired, a new study suggests, sharing patterns that echo the movements of scavenging birds, flocking insects and gliding sharks.
lead_paragraph: African tribesmen walk through their landscape in a pattern that eerily echoes the movements of scavenging birds, flocking insects, gliding sharks and visitors to Disneyland, a new study finds, suggesting that aspects of how we choose to move around in our world are deeply hard-wired.

headline: Shorter Workweeks Are Likely in New Year
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Part-Time Employment', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Working Hours']
abstract: More employees are likely to be working shorter workweeks in 2014, as government policies nudge them and employers in that direction, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: What’s on Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 11 A.M. (HGTV) ROSE PARADE 2014 The new year is once again coming up roses for HGTV, which heralds 2014 from its traditional perch at the 125th annual parade. Vin Scully, the hall of fame sports broadcaster and grand marshal, will lead nearly 50 floats, centered on the theme “Dreams Come True” and adorned with more botanical elements — including orchids (above), black lichen, Spanish moss, safflower blossoms, coconut flakes and even chive and onion seed — than the average florist might go through in five years, down Colorado Avenue in Pasadena, Calif. The “Property Brothers” — Drew and Jonathan Scott — and Nancy O’Dell will provide a play-by-play of the nuptials of Danny Leclair and Aubrey Loots on the AIDS Healthcare Foundation’s wedding cake float with the tagline “Love Is the Best Protection.” And eight former Women Airforce Service Pilots from World War II are expected to ride atop a float titled “Our Eyes Are on the Stars.” (Stanford will take on Michigan State in the Rose Bowl game at 5 p.m. on ESPN.) The HGTV programming moves into prime time at 8 with a tour of the latest “Dream Home” giveaway: a three-bedroom modern mountain house with soaring ceilings and wilderness views near Lake Tahoe. The winner also gets a GMC Yukon Denali and $250,000.

headline: De Blasio Sworn In as New York Mayor
abstract: The oath of office was administered by Eric T. Schneiderman, the attorney general of New York, in a brief ceremony inside the front yard of the mayor’s rowhouse in Park Slope, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio was sworn in as the 109th mayor of New York City early Wednesday, at two minutes past the stroke of midnight.

headline: Mike O’Connor, Journalists’ Advocate, Dies at 67
abstract: Mr. O’Connor, a veteran war correspondent, became an advocate for threatened journalists in Mexico, one of the world’s most dangerous countries for the press.
lead_paragraph: Mike O’Connor, a longtime foreign correspondent who had worked in recent years to protect journalists in Mexico, died on Sunday in Mexico City. He was 67.

headline: De Blasio Is Sworn In as Mayor
abstract: Bill de Blasio was sworn in as the 109th mayor of New York City on Wednesday morning, at two minutes past the stroke of midnight.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio was sworn in as the 109th mayor of New York City on Wednesday morning, at two minutes past the stroke of midnight.

headline: Need Some Greens? Then Eat This Pork Belly
abstract: How they do it at a nose-to-tail restaurant in London.
lead_paragraph: Since opening nearly 20 years ago, St. John, Fergus Henderson’s famous nose-to-tail restaurant in London, has developed a justifiable reputation for using underappreciated parts of many different types of animals (rolled pig’s spleen, anyone?). Henderson also helped popularize serving unusual vegetables and vegetables in unusual forms. I remember ordering “English peas” and watching a kitchen worker reach into a crate, pile a couple of handfuls of unshelled peas onto a plate and send them to the table.

headline: The Quest for a Natural Sugar Substitute
abstract: Why is it so hard to make a low-cal soda that actually tastes good?
lead_paragraph: On a Sunday evening last September, stevia became famous. In the final episode of “Breaking Bad,” an image of the sweetener filled the TV screen. Lydia emptied the packet into her mug of camomile tea, not knowing that Walt, her former partner, had poisoned it. “How are you feeling?” he later asked. “Kind of under the weather, like you’ve got the flu? That would be the ricin I gave you. I slipped it into that stevia crap that you’re always putting in your tea.”

headline: Rebels Seize Portions of Strategic City in South Sudan
abstract: On the eve of negotiations to end the conflict in the country, rebel forces took major sections of Bor, giving them a foothold for a possible march toward the capital.
lead_paragraph: AWERIAL, South Sudan — On the eve of negotiations to end the conflict in South Sudan, rebel forces on Wednesday seized major sections of the city of Bor, giving them a strategic foothold for a possible march toward the capital and transforming the banks of the White Nile into an impromptu camp for the tens of thousands of people who have fled the fighting.

headline: Europeans United, in Hating Europe
abstract: Right-wing parties work across borders – to undermine the European Union.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It may seem bizarre that two far-right, nationalist politicians — Marine Le Pen of France and Geert Wilders of the Netherlands — have reached across borders to form a Pan-European group dedicated to weakening the European Union. Their aim is a transnational political alliance that would compete in the May elections for the European Parliament; once in power, they would cooperate to try to rein in the power of Brussels.

headline: Putin Visits Volgograd, Site of Two Suicide Attacks
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin vowed that Russia would continue to fight terrorists until “their complete destruction.”
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin flew Wednesday to Volgograd, the site of two suicide bombings this week, to hold a meeting with national and regional security officials and visit victims of the bombings in a hospital.

headline: 2013, by the Numbers
abstract: A look at the news events, babies, hacking and diplomacy that defined the year.
lead_paragraph: A look at the news events, babies, hacking and diplomacy that defined the year.

headline: The Best Small-Business Posts of 2013
keywords: ['E-Commerce', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Executives and Management (Theory)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business', 'Social Media', 'Start-ups', 'Work-Life Balance']
abstract: Another year in the trenches with the You’re the Boss blogging team.
lead_paragraph: Once again, here at You’re the Boss, we spent the year in the small-business trenches. Rather than hyping the stories of rock star entrepreneurs who never seem to struggle, we focus on the struggle.

headline: Daily Report: Judge Upholds Searches of Travelers’ Devices at Border
abstract: Judge Edward R. Korman of the Eastern District of New York ruled that the government did not need reasonable suspicion to examine or confiscate a traveler’s electronic devices.
lead_paragraph: The government’s right to search travelers’ electronic devices at the border was upheld in a ruling released by a federal judge on Tuesday, which dismissed a lawsuit challenging this policy, Susan Stellin reports.

headline: Lebanon Arrests Leader of Qaeda-Linked Group, Reports Say
abstract: The group, the Abdullah Azzam Brigades, claimed responsibility for a suicide attack on the Iranian Embassy in Beirut in November.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Lebanese military authorities have detained the Saudi leader of a Sunni militant group linked to Al Qaeda that claimed responsibility for a double suicide bomb attack on the Iranian Embassy in Beirut in November, according to Lebanese news media.

headline: In Our Pages: January 2
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Furniture', 'Science and Technology', 'Trees and Shrubs']
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune
lead_paragraph: 1914: Aero Club Prize to Mr. Wright

headline: A Tale of Two Subway Platforms
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: In the midsection between West Fourth Street subway platforms, two strangers shared the duty of watching for the next train.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: After Leukemia, New Year’s Lipstick-Marked Beginnings
abstract: This Jan. 1 marks the third year of my daughter’s remission from leukemia. Many who thought they would survive her, like my father, have preceded her into death, but together, we are survivors.
lead_paragraph: It was New Year’s 2013, and I was preparing to take my little girl to see the lights on the Champs-Élysées. Bathed, toweled but not yet dressed, she loitered at my side, twirling her chestnut locks around her fingers and making funny faces as I applied lipstick in the mirror.

headline: Security Scare Delays Hearing for Musharraf
abstract: For a second time since treason proceedings were opened against him, Pakistan’s former military ruler Pervez Musharraf failed to appear before judges, after explosives were again found along his route to a hearing.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — For the second time since treason proceedings were opened against him, Pakistan’s former military ruler Pervez Musharraf failed to appear before judges, after explosives were again found along his route to a hearing on Wednesday.

headline: Freewheeling Fun
abstract: Two new picture books take cars as their inspiration for onomatopoetic fun and automobilic verse.
lead_paragraph: Reading a poem like Byron’s “The Destruction of Sennacherib” (beloved by previous generations of schoolchildren), you can practically feel hooves beating the ground beneath you. But in most contemporary children’s books, cars have replaced horses as the source of exciting noises, rhythms and vibrations.

headline: Big Data Shrinks to Grow
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: It was a good year for Big Data — the term at least, and quite possibly the industry. But as masses of data and its subsequent analysis comes of age, many companies have found that they need to focus on a few specifics, rather than promise to change everything.
lead_paragraph: What’s next for Big Data? Maybe a little thinning down of the industry and a little more focus.

headline: The State of the Euro, In One Graph
abstract: Has the Draghi effect saved the day?
lead_paragraph: Happy New Year! I’m trying to organize my thoughts and data on matters European, and I think I’ve come up with a useful way to summarize what has been happening in the euro area. In the figure below I compare the ratio of government debt to GDP (from the IMF — year-end number) with the 10-year interest rate (from the ECB) for a number of euro nations; I show two dates, the peak of the euro crisis in 2011 and a relatively recent observation:

headline: Up Early and in Line for a Marijuana Milestone in Colorado
keywords: ['Marijuana', 'Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Hundreds of tourists and residents across Colorado eagerly took part in the country’s first-ever sales of state-regulated recreational marijuana.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — They lined up before dawn and in the snow on Wednesday, baby boomers from Nebraska, retirees from Denver and a young man who had driven all day from Ohio. Some were longtime marijuana users. Some had been arrested for marijuana possession.

headline: Rules of Style | Lou Doillon on Looking Kooky and Staying True to Yourself
abstract: The French chanteuse and style icon shares her beauty secrets, tips for winter dressing and more.
lead_paragraph: The model and actress Lou Doillon recorded her first album “Places,” which came out last summer, in just 10 days with no money and zero expectations. Half the songs were written over the previous seven years just sitting around the house. “I always lived with guitarists,” she said over a cappuccino last fall in the lobby of the Dream Downtown hotel in New York, the morning after a show at the Highline Ballroom. “When they would leave, I would just pick up their acoustic guitars and start doing finger picking and write.” When she decided to record the album, she told her producer, “Let’s do it petite. If it works out, good.” And if it doesn’t? “Then I can die in a corner without anyone noticing.”

headline: ... In Which a Bat Flies Into the Schlag
abstract: The Met’s traditional New Year’s Eve “Die Fledermaus” is heavy on shtick and good humor.
lead_paragraph: Real Champagne tends to provoke sticker shock in cash-strapped young people hoping to drink their way through New Year’s Eve. A popular solution is André, the saccharine, mass-produced sparkling wine that sells for about $4 or $5 a bottle.

headline: Blast Kills Palestinian, a Diplomat, in Prague
abstract: The Palestinian ambassador to the Czech Republic died of injuries from an exploding booby-trap security system in his home’s safe, the police said.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The Palestinian ambassador to the Czech Republic died on Wednesday after suffering severe injuries caused by an explosive booby trap security system in a safe at his Prague residence that he apparently had triggered by mistake, the police reported. They said there was no indication the explosion was sabotage or a terrorist attack.

headline: Highlights From the de Blasio Inauguration
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s formal inauguration ceremony, on the steps of City Hall, is scheduled to begin at noon.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio was sworn in as the 109th mayor of New York City on Wednesday, a few minutes after midnight, but his formal inauguration ceremony on the steps of City Hall began at noon. Times reporters and photographers arrived early to capture the scene, and will continue to cover the event.

headline: Next Stop on Odyssey: The Knicks
abstract: Jeremy Tyler, once considered a can’t-miss prospect who failed in going from high school to the Israeli pro leagues, will get another opportunity after signing with the Knicks on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Jeremy Tyler was back on the practice court for the Knicks on Tuesday morning as the 15th man. It was no small victory for him.

headline: NASA Responds to Beyoncé’s Use of Challenger Audio
abstract: The space agency said that the Challenger space shuttle explosion should “never be trivialized.” Beyoncé included a NASA audio sample in her new song “XO.”
lead_paragraph: Beyoncé’s new self-titled album has won raves from critics and fans, but now it has come under indirect fire from an unexpected authority: NASA.

headline: A 10th Play Is the Charm
abstract: “Outside Mullingar” is the 10th John Patrick Shanley play to be produced by the Manhattan Theater Club.
lead_paragraph: In an impressive and unusually enduring relationship spanning three decades, the Manhattan Theater Club has produced nine plays by John Patrick Shanley, none of which started on Broadway. But with the 10th, the romantic comedy “Outside Mullingar,” which is in previews at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater, that streak will change. This show, about two neighboring misfits whose families are in a land dispute in rural Ireland, reunites some of the same Tony-winning artists who worked on Mr. Shanley’s only drama to transfer to Broadway, the celebrated “Doubt”: the superb actor Brian F. O’Byrne, here playing an introvert living on a cattle farm, and the veteran director Doug Hughes. Debra Messing, who played the scarf-favoring lyricist in the NBC series “Smash,” makes her Broadway debut as Mr. O’Byrne’s love interest. (261 West 47th Street, Manhattan; 212-239-6200, manhattantheatreclub.com.)

headline: The Hazards of Moving Oil By Rail Again on Display, This Time in North Dakota
keywords: ['Drilling and Boring', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Railroad Accidents and Safety', 'Railroads']
abstract: Another fiery rail accident reveals the hazards of moving America’s newfound oil resource by rail.
lead_paragraph: The fiery derailment of a 106-car oil train in North Dakota on Monday is the latest manifestation of the perils that come with expanding shipments of the country’s Bakken oil bounty by rail. The Wall Street Journal has a good update, as does NPR. An Associated Press report included this context:

headline: Schumacher’s Condition Unchanged, Manager Says
abstract: The former racecar driver Michael Schumacher was stable, with no significant changes in the 24 hours since his doctors met reporters on Tuesday, his manager said on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The former grand prix racing driver Michael Schumacher was in a stable condition, with no significant changes in the 24 hours since his doctors met with reporters on Tuesday, his manager said on Wednesday. The doctors had described Schumacher, 44, as being in critical condition, in a medically induced coma and on life-support systems, after two brain operations.

headline: To Play a Rooster, Do the Research
abstract: For his role as a bird in “Year of the Rooster,” Bobby Moreno did some unusual research.
lead_paragraph: Bobby Moreno studied birds once he was cast as Odysseus Rex, the title bird of Eric Dufault’s dark cockfighting comedy “Year of the Rooster.” He researched how they walk (sharp and jerky), look (his hair becomes a punk cockscomb in the show) and kiss (more on that later). But he also got into their heads.

headline: Finding a King’s Mind, Not Losing It
abstract: Frank Langella plays the title role in Angus Jackson’s production of “King Lear” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: One of the many problems with the role of King Lear, Shakespeare’s oldest and most irascible monarch, is that by the time an actor is old enough to play it, he may be too old to pull it off.

headline: Taking Office, de Blasio Vows to Fix Inequity
abstract: Bill de Blasio claimed his place as the 109th mayor of New York City, promising in his inaugural speech that the attention he gave to the subject of inequality while running for office was not merely rhetoric.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio, whose fiery populism propelled his rise from obscure neighborhood official to the 109th mayor of New York, was sworn into office on Wednesday, pledging that his ambition for a more humane and equal metropolis would remain undimmed.

headline: 36 Hours in Chicago
abstract: From the historic high-rises of the Gold Coast to regal Hyde Park, to the bohemian barrios of Logan Square and Pilsen, Chicago demands hard choices.
lead_paragraph: Chicago is a city that changes noticeably with the seasons. It is endlessly beautiful in the warm months, when the sidewalks transform into cafes, the Lakefront Trail becomes a Divvy Bike highway and the beaches along Lake Michigan might be mistaken for Miami. As the temperatures fall, the city changes from a playground to a cultural promised land — a place of fine and varied food, inventive theater and one of the country’s great live music scenes. From the historic high-rises of the Gold Coast to regal Hyde Park, from Bronzeville to Boystown, from the Indian and Puerto Rican enclaves of Devon Avenue and Humboldt Park, respectively, to the bohemian barrios of Logan Square and Pilsen, Chicago demands hard choices. It rarely disappoints.

headline: Classical Playlist: Boston Baroque, Rafal Blechacz, Alexandre Tharaud and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: HAYDN: ‘Lord Nelson Mass’ (with Symphony No. 102 in B flat)Boston Baroque; Martin Pearlman, conductor; Mary Wilson, Abigail Fischer, Keith Jameson and Kevin Deas(Linn)The political turmoil of the Napoleonic Wars raged across Europe when Haydn wrote this “Missa in Angustiis” (“Mass in a Time of Anxiety”), which came to be named after Admiral Lord Nelson of Britain. Boston Baroque, led by Martin Pearlman, performs the stormy opening movement with rhythmic verve and intensity. A fine quartet of soloists, including the bright lyric soprano Mary Wilson and the magnanimous bass-baritone Kevin Deas, jostle for the spotlight with the orchestra, which shines in the rambunctious Symphony No. 102. (Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim)

headline: Why Hire a P.R. Firm When There’s TaskRabbit?
abstract: As smartphone apps like TaskRabbit and Sidebar create a new, freelance labor force, some are starting to use the services in lieu of public relations or traditional advertising to market their businesses and show off their skills.
lead_paragraph: Several months after Olton Rensch lost his information technology job in a round of layoffs, he heard about a host of new smartphone apps like Sidecar, a ride-sharing app, TaskRabbit, the app marketplace for odd jobs and chores, and Airbnb, a website that connects travelers with housing.

headline: At Newark Airport, a 3-D Distraction
abstract: Travelers passing through Newark Liberty International Airport can take in a six-minute film, “New Work: Newark in 3-D,” while they wait.
lead_paragraph: Post-holiday travelers facing delays at Newark Liberty International Airport currently have something other than departure screens to stare at, thanks to a recently added distraction: a free 3-D movie.

headline: Snowboarders Push Into Alaska, by Foot
abstract: After spending 15 years exploring the peaks of Alaska by helicopter and snowboarding down them, Jeremy Jones started to discover remote mountains under his own power.
lead_paragraph: After spending 15 years exploring the peaks of Alaska by helicopter and snowboarding down them, Jeremy Jones started to discover remote mountains under his own power.

headline: French Leader Would Reward Companies That Hire More People
abstract: President François Hollande says businesses will win more flexibility in return for hiring more workers and reducing layoffs.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President François Hollande, seeking to reduce France’s punishingly high unemployment rate, has called for a “responsibility pact” with businesses that would reward companies that hire more people with lower taxes and greater flexibility.

headline: Danielle Steel Awarded French Legion of Honor
abstract: The writer, who has sold some 600 million books worldwide and lives in San Francisco and Paris, was made a “chevalier” of the Legion of Honor.
lead_paragraph: Danielle Steel joined the ranks of Douglas MacArthur, Julia Child, Walt Disney, Alan Greenspan and Bob Dylan on Wednesday when she became the latest American to receive France’s highest award, the Legion of Honor.

headline: Big Chill in the Big House for Toronto’s Winter Classic Win
abstract: What happens when the National Hockey League puts a game outside in freezing, snowy weather? A record crowd of more than 105,000 people shows up.
lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Toronto’s Jonathan Bernier wore heat packs inside his goalie pants and blocker pad. Several players wore black balaclavas under their helmets; a few wore knit caps atop them. Water bottles froze on the benches. Amid falling snow and bitter cold on New Year’s Day, more than 100,000 fans packed the Big House to watch the Maple Leafs and the Detroit Red Wings play in the N.H.L.’s sixth Winter Classic.

headline: Video: Snowboarders Push Deep Into Alaska — by Foot
abstract: After spending 15 years exploring the peaks of Alaska by helicopter and snowboarding down them, Jeremy Jones began discovering remote mountains under his own power.
lead_paragraph: In the past six years, Jeremy Jones has collaborated with Teton Gravity Research to create a trilogy of films: “Deeper,” “Further” and now “Higher.” These films document his efforts to explore and snowboard remote mountains under his own power.

headline: Cocktail Culture | A Spot of (Spiked) Tea
abstract: In New York, cold-weather menus are heating up with warm, tea-based drinks.
lead_paragraph: Around New York, boozy versions of “a spot of tea” are warming up winter drink menus this season as Manhattan mixologists blend green, black and white tea leaves with a range of spirits and wines.

headline: Text of Bill de Blasio’s Inauguration Speech
abstract: Read the text of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s inaugural address, as prepared for delivery.
lead_paragraph: The following is the complete text of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s inaugural address, as prepared for delivery.

headline: E.U. Labor Market Opens for Romanians and Bulgarians
abstract: Citizens of two of Europe’s poorest states became officially eligible on Jan. 1 to seek jobs in Germany, France, Britain and several other countries.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The lifting of labor restrictions on Wednesday for Bulgarians and Romanians in nine European Union countries, including Germany, France and Britain, was greeted as both an opportunity and a threat, touching off fear among some about unchecked immigration from Bulgaria and Romania, two of the poorest states in Europe.

headline: Showstopper in What May Have Been Manziel’s Last College Game
abstract: It would be hard to fathom how quarterback Johnny Manziel, a redshirt sophomore, could raise his N.F.L. draft status through another college season.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Johnny Manziel flung his helmet to the ground, raced to the equipment cart on the Texas A&M sideline and climbed atop it on Tuesday night. He raised his arms over his head and rubbed the tips of his fingers together, sign language for a payday that has just arrived.

headline: ‘Tony n’ Tina’s Wedding’ Coming Back to New York
abstract: The participatory show, which first ran Off Broadway in 1988, will be back in a new production in March.
lead_paragraph: After an interim of apparent wedded bliss elsewhere, the participatory Off Broadway play “Tony n’ Tina’s Wedding,” last seen flinging ziti and zingers near Times Square in 2010, will be bringing its raucous participatory spirit back to New York City.

headline: For New York, a Winning Year. Really.
abstract: From Jan. 1 to Dec. 31, 2013, the nine professional teams in the New York metropolitan area had a winning record: 394-392. Feel better?
lead_paragraph: Yes, 2013 was not much of a year for sports teams in the New York metropolitan region. The nine major local sports franchises had more downs than ups and, in addition to being mediocre or worse, were often just plain boring.

headline: The Inaugural Address of Bill de Blasio
abstract: In his inauguration speech in front of City Hall, Bill de Blasio laid out a mayoralty that emphasized social and economic justice.
lead_paragraph: In his inauguration speech in front of City Hall, Bill de Blasio laid out a mayoralty that emphasized social and economic justice.

headline: Minneapolis Fire Injures More Than a Dozen
abstract: Most of the injuries occurred after people jumped, or were blown, out of rooms on the second and third floors of a building that housed apartments and a grocery.
lead_paragraph: An explosion and fire on Wednesday destroyed a Minneapolis building that housed 10 apartments and a grocery, injuring at least 14 people, the authorities said. Most of injuries were burns or broken bones suffered by people who jumped — or were blown — out of rooms on the second and third floors.

headline: The 109th Mayor of New York
abstract: Bill de Blasio claimed his place as mayor on Wednesday. On the steps of City Hall, he was ceremonially sworn in by former President Clinton.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio claimed his place as mayor on Wednesday. On the steps of City Hall, he was ceremonially sworn in by former President Clinton.

headline: Young Poet Speaks at Inauguration
abstract: Ramya Ramana, the New York City Youth Poet Laureate, delivered the poem “New York City” at Mayor Bill de Blasio’s inauguration ceremony.
lead_paragraph: Ramya Ramana, the New York City Youth Poet Laureate, delivered the poem “New York City” at Mayor Bill de Blasio’s inauguration ceremony.

headline: Settlement News to Wait Until Kerry Leaves Israel
abstract: An Israeli official said the delay was intended to avoid a high-profile clash over new settlement construction in the West Bank and East Jerusalem.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli government will delay an expected announcement of bids for new settlement construction for the next few days while Secretary of State John Kerry is in the region, an Israeli official said Wednesday, avoiding a potential high-profile clash over the contentious issue.

headline: As Latvia Adopts Euro, Future Growth Is Slowing
abstract: Though the process of euro enlargement has not ended, is it set to slow after Lithuania next adopts the currency in 2015.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Dace Utinane, a doctor at a private health center, frowned during a stroll this week through Riga, the capital of Latvia, as she contemplated her country’s move to become the newest member of Europe’s currency union.

headline: Vote on New Boeing Contract Highlights a Rift in the Machinists’ Union
keywords: ['Organized Labor', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Relocation of Business', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: International and local union leaders are sharply divided over a vote set for Friday on Boeing’s revised contract offer to machinists in Washington State.
lead_paragraph: After Boeing’s workers in Washington State voted down an eight-year contract extension in November, Boeing wasted little time in soliciting offers from other states to build its new 777X aircraft.

headline: 2 Conservatives Join Iran Nuclear Panel
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: The additions to a supervisory council responsible for monitoring the country’s nuclear negotiating team appeared to strengthen the influence of critics of the talks between Iran and world powers.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Two members of Iran’s hard-line-dominated Parliament were added to a supervisory council responsible for monitoring the country’s nuclear negotiating team, Iranian news media reported Wednesday. The additions appeared to strengthen the influence of critics of the talks between Iran and world powers.

headline: Would You Rather Run a Restaurant or Sell Tomato Sauce?
abstract: To test the waters for his house sauce, Carlos Vega dropped off samples at Whole Foods, Trader Joe’s, and other specialty food stores. He got encouraging reviews from many buyers.
lead_paragraph: We just published a case study about the owner of an eight-table Italian restaurant on the cusp of a major decision. Carlos Vega bought the 900-square-foot Father and Son Pizzeria in Guttenberg, N.J., in 2007 and worked long hours perfecting the restaurant’s house sauce, expanding the menu options and building a vibrant takeout trade. Though the business was profitable, revenues plateaued well short of where he had hoped. Two years in, Mr. Vega found himself debating the pros and cons of two very different paths forward.

headline: Some Hefty Chops, Seasoned by Antics
abstract: The comedic musicians Igudesman & Joo were on hand (and foot) for the New York Philharmonic’s New Year’s Eve concert.
lead_paragraph: During the New York Philharmonic’s New Year’s Eve concert at Avery Fisher Hall, the pianist Hyung-ki Joo revealed the three simple steps necessary to make it in the music business: 1. Always smile. 2. Play only music that everyone knows. 3. Show off.

headline: A Cleaned-Up Hotel in a Cleaned-Up Times Square
abstract: The Hotel Carter, on West 43rd Street, has been under new management for eight months and will be offered for sale in 2014.
lead_paragraph: It isn’t easy for hotels to stand out from their competitors. In 2006, however, the Hotel Carter, at 250 West 43rd Street, found a new way to do so when TripAdvisor readers named it the dirtiest hotel in America.

headline: Ariel Sharon, Former Prime Minister of Israel, Is Said to Be Near Death
abstract: The condition of Mr. Sharon, who has been comatose for nearly eight years, has deteriorated recently, the hospital treating him said.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Ariel Sharon, the former prime minister of Israel who has been comatose for nearly eight years, edged closer to death on Wednesday evening, suffering from kidney failure.

headline: A Stock Exchange Expands Its Global Reach
keywords: ['Financial Brokers', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: BATS Global Markets is aiming to serve as an evangelist for the American way of trading, focusing on low costs, competition and high-speed trading.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:36 a.m. | The face of the global stock market used to be the classically proportioned exchange building on Wall Street.

headline: Civilian Photography, Now Rising to New Level
abstract: With a high-res camera slung under its belly, the Phantom 2 Vision drone takes video and stills from vantage points the photographer can’t reach.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, the DJI Phantom 2 Vision would have seemed like a science fiction film prop or a piece of surveillance hardware flown only by the sexiest of superspies. But it is the first camera-carrying drone you may want to own — and you could do that without spending thousands of dollars.

headline: Two Graphic Narratives, Inspired by the Fab Four
abstract: Two new works, “Nowhere Men” and “The Fifth Beatle: The Brian Epstein Story,” have their roots in the music of the Beatles.
lead_paragraph: “Science is the new rock ’n’ roll.” Or so the four scientists at the center of the beguiling new Image Comics series “Nowhere Men” would have you believe. These men have banded together to form World Corp., a research and development company that has a profound influence on the planet through advances in things like cyberoptics and genetics. But ideological shifts and personality clashes cause their alliance to fracture.

headline: Cleaning the Mobile Germ Warehouse
abstract: Tablets and cellphones can transmit disease, so cleaning them regularly should be more than an aesthetic preference.
lead_paragraph: TAKE a look at your mobile device. Do you see oily fingerprints and lint on the touch screen? Dust and crumbs forming particulate frost in the corners? Is that a hair stuck at the screen’s edge?

headline: Markets Buoyant, Merger Activity Picks Up
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The United States accounted for 43 percent of all deals worldwide, the biggest proportion since 2001.
lead_paragraph: What may have been the most auspicious deal of late was not the biggest or the most groundbreaking of mergers. It was just one that took a little gumption.

headline: Removing Edits in a Document, and Minimizing a Bar of Icons
abstract: Deleting tracked changes and shrinking the Mac OS X Dock.
lead_paragraph: Cleaning Up

headline: Resolve to Pay Attention to Resolution Reminders
abstract: Apps to help you set and stick to goals for the new year.
lead_paragraph: I find New Year’s resolutions tricky and have avoided them in the past. I have difficulty dreaming up resolutions in the first place, and then I have problems sticking to them.

headline: Regaining Footing, and a Leader
abstract: Dan Harmon, the creator of the NBC sitcom “Community,” is back as its leading light, and his influence helps improve the show’s fifth season.
lead_paragraph: It seems too simple, too easy somehow, but there’s no denying the evidence before our eyes: “Community” is a worthwhile show again now that Dan Harmon, its creator, is back in his office doing whatever it is he does so obsessively.

headline: Friday A/X Pairs at Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional
abstract: The Friday A/X Pairs, which ended Monday, was won by Joan Brody of Morristown, N.J., and Kent Mignocchi of New York City.
lead_paragraph: The Friday A/X Pairs at the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in New York City, which ended Monday, was won by Joan Brody of Morristown, N.J., and Kent Mignocchi of New York City. They finished two-fifths of a board ahead of John McAllister of Charlottesville, Va., and Ishmael Del’Monte from Australia, whose 75 percent second session was not quite enough to snatch victory. Third were R. Jay Becker of New York City and Michael Kamil of Holmdel, N.J.

headline: A Mole in Deepest Beige
abstract: The ABC mini-series “The Assets” focuses on the hunt for the C.I.A. mole Aldrich Ames.
lead_paragraph: Acting, like spying, is the art of lying persuasively.

headline: New Detroit Mayor Sworn In
abstract: Mike Duggan, a former hospital executive and prosecutor, begins his effort to renew a city long in decline.
lead_paragraph: Mike Duggan, a former hospital executive and prosecutor, begins his effort to renew a city long in decline.

headline: Analyzing de Blasio’s Inaugural Address
abstract: Follow along with this interactive replay of Bill de Blasio’s inaugural address, as reporters from The New York Times offer context and analysis on the mayor’s first speech.
lead_paragraph: Follow along with this interactive replay of Bill de Blasio’s inaugural address, as reporters from The New York Times offer context and analysis on the mayor’s first speech.

headline: Banned at Home and Noticed by Oscars
abstract: “Pussy Riot: A Punk Prayer” and “The Square,” set in Cairo, are on the shortlist for possible Oscar nominations in the documentary category, but they can’t be shown in their home countries.
lead_paragraph: Maxim Pozdorovkin thought that once he made it past the airport in Moscow, he’d be home free. Mr. Pozdorovkin is a director, with Mike Lerner, of the documentary “Pussy Riot: A Punk Prayer,” and after two members of that Russian activist group were released from prison in late December, they all put together a screening of the film in their home country, Russia. It was to be the film’s first showing there, and the first time the two group members, Maria Alyokhina and Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, were to see the documentary, which traces the story of their collective from little-known artists to globally famous political rebels.

abstract: Oscar Ibarra, who entered the shelter system with his mother and several siblings, is the first member of his family to attend college.

headline: A Business Owner Seeks an Alternative to Seven-Day Workweeks

Opened in 1971, it was bought in 2007 by Carlos Vega, now 45, from its aging founder. Mr. Vega soon doubled sales by expanding the menu, improving service and selling the restaurant’s “gravy,” or red sauce, over the counter in 12-ounce Mason jars.

Boehner, taken on Tiger Woods and found time to steal away for a round in political good times and bad.

headline: The Campaign for a Bigger Paycheck
keywords: ['Minimum Wage', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: Raising the minimum wage is good politics and even better economics.
lead_paragraph: Aided by a vast flow of corporate and right-wing money, Republicans have spent years persuading the public that the deficit is the nation’s biggest financial problem and that austerity is the answer to it. Their success in making that argument — keeping taxes and government investment low — has helped increase American income inequality to crisis proportions: 95 percent of the income gains since 2009 have gone to the top 1 percent. The majority of the country has stagnated or lost ground, leaving the economy sluggish.

headline: Edward Snowden, Whistle-Blower
keywords: ['Whistle-Blowers', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Editorials']
abstract: Considering the value of his leaks and the N.S.A. abuses he has exposed, Mr. Snowden should be offered clemency or a plea bargain.
lead_paragraph: Seven months ago, the world began to learn the vast scope of the National Security Agency’s reach into the lives of hundreds of millions of people in the United States and around the globe, as it collects information about their phone calls, their email messages, their friends and contacts, how they spend their days and where they spend their nights. The public learned in great detail how the agency has exceeded its mandate and abused its authority, prompting outrage at kitchen tables and at the desks of Congress, which may finally begin to limit these practices.

headline: Burning the Midnight Oil
abstract: A most puzzling puzzle by Todd Gross, and Will Shortz comes to the rescue.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — You learn a lot doing this job. Besides learning how to care for the emus and emergency-handcode JSON at midnight (which they definitely don’t teach in humor writer’s school), I am lucky enough to learn about all sorts of things that come out of the crossword puzzles. It goes on constantly, and that perhaps explains why, on the last day of the year which is when I am writing this post, my brain just couldn’t find the will to tease Todd Gross’s theme out of today’s puzzle. When I finally found out what it was, however, I thought it was brilliant.

headline: New Year’s Day, 1864
abstract: Americans greeted another year of the Civil War with a mix of optimism and fear.
lead_paragraph: It is easy enough to conclude in hindsight that 1863 was a year of “turning points” — the Emancipation Proclamation, Gettysburg and Vicksburg most prominent among them — on the Union’s road to victory. Indeed, the sesquicentennial commemorations of 2013 featured a wide array of programs, articles, symposiums, forums and blogs with “turning points” as their theme. But as the year draws to a close, we should pause to remember how uncertain “the situation” still looked to Northerners in the first days of 1864.

headline: Sticking Point in Peace Talks: Recognition of a Jewish State
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu argues that Palestinian recognition of Israel as a Jewish state underpins all other issues in peace negotiations, and this focus is exactly what makes it unacceptable to Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — As Middle East peace talks churn on, Israel has catapulted to the fore an issue that may be even more intractable than old ones like security and settlements: a demand that the Palestinians recognize Israel as a Jewish state.

headline: Peruvian Style Gets a Contemporary Update
abstract: Even as Mario Testino pays tribute to the traditional costumes of his native country, a number of current designers are taking cue from Peru’s style legacy.
lead_paragraph: Mario Testino isn’t the only notable celebrating Peruvian style right now. In his exhibition “Alta Moda,” on view now through March 29 at the Queen Sofia Spanish Institute in New York, the fashion photographer celebrates the country’s early ornate fashion with a series of images of its traditional costumes. Meanwhile, fashion designers are adding to the country’s style legacy, taking cues from early and modern Peruvian artisans. Saturated colors, rich textures and intricate detailing have become urban-jungle-friendly thanks to a slew of ready-to-wear pieces and accessories, like Chloé’s nubby boucle sheath in playful pastels and Tabitha Simmons’s multicolored Peruvian silk espadrilles. Pom poms, tassels and beads appear on many of the playful accessories, including a knit bag from Mochila and a handmade clutch from the Muzungu Sisters, which could almost pass for souvenirs from a trip to Machu Picchu.

headline: Cleverly Made Carpets That Look Good Enough to Eat
abstract: The up-and-coming Brooklyn designers Chen Chen and Kai Williams devised their own rugmaking technique that combines multiple disparate fibers into whimsical assemblages.
lead_paragraph: Since joining forces in 2011, the Brooklyn designers Chen Chen and Kai Williams have created a number of surprising products derived from experiments with process. One of the most interesting was their cold-cut coasters, made by wrapping materials such as fishnet and rope around a central wooden rod or “bone” and then slicing it, like a maki roll. The resulting multicolored disks really do look almost edible. The coasters were the inspiration for a set of four circular rugs the duo created for the luxury custom carpet company Tai Ping, which was unveiled last month at Design Miami. Using a technique the designers came up with to combine multiple fibers, the carpets were fabricated in wool, cotton, chenille, bamboo, PVC, silk and more, giving the appearance of a cross section of a living organism beneath your feet.

headline: What’s on Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7 P.M. (Syfy) PAUL (2011) He looks like any other extraterrestrial, with his otherworldly cast, bald bobble head, big eyes and stick limbs. Until you get to the board shorts and the backpack. In other words, Paul, voiced by Seth Rogen and the title character of this comedy from Greg Mottola, is a little green dude. And he comes in peace, man, despite causing havoc while he tries to phone home. Simon Pegg, above with Paul, and Nick Frost are the best friends, fresh from a Comic-Con convention in San Diego, who run into Paul as they guide their recreational vehicle toward Area 51, the military base in Nevada where the conspiracy minded think the government stashes aliens. Jason Bateman is one of the men in black hunting Paul; Kristen Wiig is the love interest who wears a T-shirt depicting Jesus blowing away Darwin; and John Carroll Lynch is her daddy, a member of the Bible and gun club. “As genial, foolish and demographically engineered as it sounds (hailing all fan boys and girls),” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, “ ‘Paul’ is at once a buddy flick and a classic American road movie of self- (and other) discovery, interspersed with buckets of expletives and some startling (especially for a big-studio release) pokes at Christian fundamentalism.”
