abstract: The consulate said an attacker poured two buckets of gasoline onto the front door and set it on fire, causing severe damage. No one was injured in the attack.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. is leading an investigation into a fire that was set Wednesday night at the main entrance of the Chinese Consulate General in San Francisco, the authorities said Thursday. No injuries were reported.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | A Dialect Map of the United States
abstract: What are the most surprising differences in regional pronunciations and words used to describe the same thing?
lead_paragraph: The map above is linked to an interactive quiz called “How Y’all, Youse and You Guys Talk.” Take the quiz and pay attention to the map that will display on the left of the screen as you go in order to answer the following questions. You may need to return to certain quiz questions a second time, choosing different answers, in order to display the information needed for some of the questions.

headline: Chinese Copter Rescues 52 From Ship in Antarctic Ice
abstract: The evacuation of the 52 passengers began after more than a week of attempts to approach the stranded research vessel, the Akademik Shokalskiy.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a dramatic operation displaying unusual international harmony in one of the world’s most remote and inhospitable places, a red-and-white Chinese helicopter on Thursday rescued 52 passengers trapped for more than a week aboard an icebound Russian research ship in Antarctica, ferrying them a dozen at a time to an Australian icebreaker.

headline: A Speck in the Sea
abstract: John Aldridge fell overboard in the middle of the night, 40 miles from shore, and the Coast Guard was looking in the wrong place. How did he survive?
lead_paragraph: Looking back, John Aldridge knew it was a stupid move. When you’re alone on the deck of a lobster boat in the middle of the night, 40 miles off the tip of Long Island, you don’t take chances. But he had work to do: He needed to start pumping water into the Anna Mary’s holding tanks to chill, so that when he and his partner, Anthony Sosinski, reached their first string of traps a few miles farther south, the water would be cold enough to keep the lobsters alive for the return trip. In order to get to the tanks, he had to open a metal hatch on the deck. And the hatch was covered by two 35-gallon Coleman coolers, giant plastic insulated ice chests that he and Sosinski filled before leaving the dock in Montauk harbor seven hours earlier. The coolers, full, weighed about 200 pounds, and the only way for Aldridge to move them alone was to snag a box hook onto the plastic handle of the bottom one, brace his legs, lean back and pull with all his might.

headline: Photographing Hiroshima, Fukushima and Everything in Between
keywords: ['Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Photography', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: The career of Kikujiro Fukushima, who is still an active photojournalist at 92, spans from the aftermath of the dropping of the atomic bomb in 1945 to the Fukushima disaster of 2011.
lead_paragraph: Kikujiro Fukushima’s life in photography took off when he promised to avenge the Hiroshima bombing. It was 1952, and Mr. Fukushima — a watchmaker, volunteer social worker and photographer — met Sugimatsu Nakamura, a 43-year-old fisherman, who was gravely ill from the atomic bomb’s effects.

headline: Portraits of a Rust Belt Mill Town
abstract: With portraits, landscapes and found objects, Zoe Strauss shows the history and socioeconomic topography of Homestead, Pa., site of a fabled Carnegie-owned steel mill.
lead_paragraph: Zoe Strauss loves monumental undertakings. She embarked on her first photographic project, “Under I-95” — spanning a decade and encompassing “literally everything” — without knowing anything about making pictures. Her new project, “Homesteading,” is similarly all-encompassing, tracing the history and socioeconomic topography of Homestead, Pa., the site of a fabled Carnegie-owned steel mill that closed in 1986.

headline: What Hobbies Have Been Passed Down in Your Family?
abstract: What activities and hobbies are shared among members of your family?
lead_paragraph: As the holiday break comes to a close, think about how you spent your time. Did you see a movie, attend a sports event, take a hike or enjoy other favorite activities? Where, when and with whom did you first do those things? What about now? What role did family members play in shaping the hobbies and pursuits that are today a big part of your life?

headline: For Messi, the Best Medicine Is Time
abstract: Lionel Messi’s club, Barcelona, and his national team, Argentina, want him back as he recovers from an injury, but he should not let eagerness push him too far, too soon.
lead_paragraph: Welcome back, Lionel Messi, when you are good and ready.

headline: New York Today: Big Snowstorm
abstract: What you need to know for Thursday: six to eight inches of snow, bitter cold and Mayor de Blasio’s first day.
lead_paragraph: Updated 12:20 p.m.

headline: Complex Effort for Antarctic Rescue
abstract: Video and images shared on social media show the long-awaited rescue of the 52 passengers of a Russian ship, the Akademik Shokalskiy, which has been trapped in ice off the coast of Antarctica since Dec. 24.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:01 a.m. The red-and-white Chinese helicopter with dual rotors hovered over the ice, then settled gently on a flat patch at one of the earth’s southernmost points. At least seven men in puffy orange jackets clambered out and onto the Antarctic polar cap.

headline: Times Minute | Milestone for Obamacare
abstract: On the Minute, the impact of the Affordable Care Act on patients, physicians and the political landscape.
lead_paragraph: On the Minute, the impact of the Affordable Care Act on patients, physicians and the political landscape.

headline: Musharraf Is Hospitalized, Delaying His Day in Court
abstract: Pervez Musharraf, the former military ruler of Pakistan, was abruptly hospitalized while on his way to a hearing on treason accusations.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The former Pakistani military ruler Pervez Musharraf was taken to a military hospital on Thursday over concerns about an unexplained heart condition, Pakistani officials said, derailing for a third time a scheduled court hearing in treason proceedings against him.

headline: Daily Report: Two Views on the E-Book Reading Experience
abstract: Two authors — Mohsin Hamid and Anna Holmes — discuss the merits and flaws of e-books.
lead_paragraph: As e-books gain in popularity — and as many of us download new e-books on our shiny, new tablets —  two authors consider whether reading through technology affects the experience of reading.

headline: Delhi Grocers Recall 50 Years of Changing Indian Tastes
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Family Business', 'Food', 'Meat', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Volunteers and Community Service']
abstract: The Steakhouse was one of the first stores that catered to a growing and aspiring middle class that sought the opportunity to partake in a slice of Western culture.
lead_paragraph: These days, it’s easy to find once-exotic foods like spaghetti and Parmesan cheese at grocery stores in India. For that, food lovers can thank the proprietors of Steakhouse in central Delhi, one of the first stores that catered to a certain aesthetic of consumerism in India, where an aspiring and growing middle class sought the opportunity to partake in a slice of Western culture.

headline: Body of Former Rwandan Spymaster Is Found in Johannesburg Hotel
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The former military intelligence chief, Patrick Karegeya, showed signs of strangulation, and his supporters blamed the Rwandan government.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — The South African police said on Thursday that they had opened a murder investigation into the death of an exiled former spy chief from Rwanda, who was found dead in a hotel room with signs of possible strangulation.

headline: Fiat Gaining Full Ownership of Chrysler
abstract: Fiat reaches a $4.35 billion deal for Chrysler with the U.A.W. retiree health care fund. | The animal spirits appear to be finally returning to the corporate world. | With its merger with Direct Edge closes, BATS Global Markets is likely to be the biggest stock exchange company in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The Italian carmaker Fiat said on Wednesday that it had reached an agreement to take full ownership of Chrysler, the smallest of the three American automakers, in a $4.35 billion deal with the United Automobile Workers retiree health care fund. The deal to buy out the trust’s 41 percent stake, expected to close on Jan. 20, would make Fiat the world’s seventh-largest automaker, Jaclyn Trop reports in The New York Times.

headline: Shanti Atkins, on the 30-Second Approach to Decision-Making
abstract: Shanti Atkins is president and chief strategy officer of Navex Global, which handles ethics and compliance issues.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Shanti Atkins, president and chief strategy officer of Navex Global, which handles ethics and compliance issues, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Life Goes On, at Long Last
abstract: The gripping “Downton Abbey” is back on PBS’s “Masterpiece” for its long-awaited fourth season.
lead_paragraph: NEWBURY, England — We have raged against fate and come through our stages of grief. We have accepted that no matter how much we miss him — his limpid blue eyes, his good sense in marrying Lady Mary after his tiresome fiancée finally succumbed to the flu — Matthew Crawley is never coming back. He is dead, having been hit by a truck while driving inattentively in the waning moments of last season on “Downton Abbey.”

headline: Repsol Completes Sale of Natural Gas Assets to Shell
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Nationalization of Industry', 'Natural Gas', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: Shell, which beat out more than a dozen bidders, will pay $3.8 billion in cash to the Spanish energy company and assume about $1.6 billion in leases related to ship charters.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The energy company Royal Dutch Shell said on Thursday that it had completed its $5.4 billion acquisition of Repsol’s liquefied natural gas business outside North America, a deal originally announced last February.

headline: Obama's Golfing Style
abstract: The president plays a slow and methodical game of golf, taking multiple practice swings and spending up to six hours on the course.
lead_paragraph: The president plays a slow and methodical game of golf, taking multiple practice swings and spending up to six hours on the course.

headline: A Smile Defuses Subway Wrath
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: As a human sardine fumed on a packed No. 6 train, a young girl changed the mood with charm.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Tribalism, Biology, and Macroeconomics
abstract: Politics trumps evidence.
lead_paragraph: I’m a bit late to this party, but Pew has a new report about changing views on evolution. The big takeaway is that a plurality of self-identified Republicans now believe that no evolution whatsoever has taken place since the day of creation — let alone that evolution is driven by natural selection. The move is big: an 11-point decline since 2009.

headline: App Smart: Resolutions
abstract: A selection of great apps to help you keep your new year's resolutions.
lead_paragraph: A selection of great apps to help you keep your new year's resolutions.

headline: Jehane Noujaim on Filming History as It Happens
abstract: Jehane Noujaim, director of “The Square,” about the uprising in Cairo, discusses filming an ongoing story and trying to show her movie in Egypt.
lead_paragraph: The Egyptian-American director Jehane Noujaim had already made several prize-winning documentaries about Egypt when massive protests against the dictatorship of Hosni Mubarak erupted in Cairo in January 2011. She knew she had to remain there to chronicle the uprising, and spent the next two and a half years filming “The Square,” which has won awards at festivals from Sundance to Dubai and has been shortlisted for the Oscar for best documentary feature.

headline: A Winter Weekend in the North Fork
abstract: Affordable lodging is just one of the advantages of hitting this stretch of Long Island when temperatures are low.
lead_paragraph: It’s free to watch the sun set over the wetlands that fringe the causeway connecting East Marion and Orient, near the eastern tip of Long Island’s North Fork. If the weather has been dry enough in this wine country just across the bay from the Hamptons, there’s a good perch on the marshy land near Latham Farms, by a little cabin on stilts known locally as the crab shack. The wine is also free, if your friend Jeanny Pak happens to have brought along a bottle of malbec and some plastic cups without telling you.

headline: Why Walk?
abstract: The writer Robert Macfarlane talks about the transformative power of seeing the world one step at at time.
lead_paragraph: “The Old Ways: A Journey on Foot” by Robert Macfarlane caps off a trilogy of books that examine the subtle links between landscape, history and the imagination. Having already ventured into wilds, high and low, this third book focuses on the ancient routes and countless communal pathways that mark the world, connecting people to places, one another and the landscapes they inhabit.

headline: Image of the Day: January 2
abstract: Members of Indian Army band rehearsing for the Republic Day parade in New Delhi.

headline: Disinformation on Inequality
abstract: In the Wall Street Journal? I’m shocked, shocked.
lead_paragraph: Miles Kimball catches Bret Stephens pulling a fast one on Wall Street Journal readers – but it’s much worse than Kimball says.

headline: Deadly Bombing in Beirut Suburb, a Hezbollah Stronghold, Raises Tensions
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: The explosion of a car bomb in a Beirut suburb appeared to be the latest in a string of bombings in Lebanon linked to the civil war in neighboring Syria.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The second deadly car bomb to strike the Beirut area in less than a week exploded on Thursday in a southern suburb of residential apartment buildings that is home to top Hezbollah offices and heavily populated with the group’s supporters.

headline: Father Requests Forgiveness for Teenage Shooter Who Killed Daughter
abstract: Video of Michael Davis at a memorial service, asking people to forgive the 17-year-old student who shot and killed his daughter, Claire, at Arapahoe High School in Colorado last month.
lead_paragraph: The father of Claire Davis, the 17-year-old Colorado girl who was shot and killed by a fellow student at Arapahoe High School last month, asked people during a New Year’s Day memorial service to honor his daughter by forgiving the gunman and showing empathy and compassion to troubled individuals.

headline: In Our Pages: January 3
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune
lead_paragraph: 1914: Aeroplane Line Inaugurated

headline: Avoiding the Midwinter ‘Back to School’ Slump
abstract: How to spark some excitement for the second “back to school” season of the year.
lead_paragraph: It’s back-to-school time again. No, not the exciting September return, with all its newness and promise, but the other one, the January return. The one that arrives not with a bang but a whimper.

headline: Missing a Cancer Diagnosis
abstract: Like many women, I misinterpreted the muted symptoms of ovarian cancer. By the time a CT was ordered, the cancer had progressed to a stage that is treatable but not curable. I was furious at myself and upset with my doctor.
lead_paragraph: Stories of misdiagnoses circulate throughout the testimonies of people contending with all sorts of cancers. Such errors, made by patients as well as doctors, bring in their wake a sense of betrayal, self-recrimination and anger. Should we accept them as inevitable?

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Ode’
abstract: 2014’s first Poetry Pairing features “Ode” by Arthur O’Shaughnessy and the article “The Revolution Will Have Live Music” by Colin Moynihan.
lead_paragraph: The first Poetry Pairing of 2014 features “Ode,” a poem written by Arthur O’Shaughnessy in the mid-1800s, and the article “The Revolution Will Have Live Music” by Colin Moynihan.

headline: A King’s Counselor, Whittled to Size
abstract: Hilary Mantel’s two Man Booker-winning historical novels, “Wolf Hall” and “Bring Up the Bodies,” are being adapted and condensed for the stage in Britain.
lead_paragraph: STRATFORD-UPON-AVON, England — When Hilary Mantel was writing “Wolf Hall” and “Bring Up the Bodies,” her best-selling novels about the court of Henry VIII, she was so scrupulous about accuracy that she created a card catalog of dates and events to ensure that her characters were never out of joint with the past. But when the Royal Shakespeare Company began cutting her 500-page books into two-and-a-half-hour plays, Ms. Mantel had to act as “the history police,” as she put it.

headline: New York Times to Unveil Redesigned Website Next Week
abstract: The new platform, which will be rolled out Jan. 8., will be available immediately to some readers in a test group.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times said on Thursday that it would launch its redesigned website on Jan. 8.

headline: Video of Second Bombing in Beirut in Less Than a Week
abstract: The explosion in Lebanon appeared to be the latest in a spree of bombings over Hezbollah’s support for the government of neighboring Syria in that country’s civil war.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Anne Barnard reported from Beirut, a large explosion hit the southern suburbs of Beirut on Thursday in an area populated by supporters of Hezbollah. It appeared to be the latest in a spree of bombings over Hezbollah’s support for the government of neighboring Syria in that country’s civil war.

headline: Concern Over an Increasingly Seen Gesture Grows in France
abstract: Some say the hand gesture known as the “quenelle,” popularized by a comedian criticized as anti-Semitic, strongly resembles a downward-facing Nazi salute.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — No one seems to know just what is meant by the “quenelle,” the vaguely menacing hand gesture invented and popularized by a French comedian widely criticized as anti-Semitic, but it is clearly nothing very nice, and it appears to be spreading.

headline: Trying to Sing Their Way to the Oscars
abstract: The backup singers who are the focus of “20 Feet From Stardom” have been taking the stage wherever they can to help win over Academy voters. Recent stops include the Rose Bowl and a bar in Times Square, where Glenn Close and Steve Buscemi sang with them.
lead_paragraph: The singers of “20 Feet From Stardom” took to the stage of the Rose Bowl on Wednesday to perform a four-voiced rendition of the national anthem. It was part of a campaign by Radius, the division of the Weinstein Company that distributed that documentary about backup singers, to inject some more verve into the movie’s chances with Academy members.

headline: Michael Counts to Join 3-Legged Dog Theater Company
abstract: Mr. Counts, a director and visual artist, will help oversee the company’s immersive productions and installations.
lead_paragraph: Michael Counts, a director and visual artist known for his imaginative multimedia opera and theater productions, is joining the avant-garde theater company 3-Legged Dog as creative director of the 3LD Special Projects Group. The company, which specializes in immersive productions and installations that combine live performance and video, announced the appointment on Thursday.

headline: Kerry Quietly Makes Priority of Climate Pact
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: While public attention has been fixed on the Middle East, Secretary of State John Kerry has started a push to create an agencywide focus on global warming.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As a young naval officer in Vietnam, John Kerry commanded a Swift boat up the dangerous rivers of the Mekong Delta. But when he returned there last month as secretary of state for the first time since 1969, he spoke not of past firefights but of climate change.

headline: Art and Life on the Border
abstract: Artists explore gang violence and the politics of immigration on the Mexican border.
lead_paragraph: Artists explore gang violence and the politics of immigration on the Mexican border.

headline: A Vale of Terror, Transcended
abstract: Artists on both sides of the border in the Rio Grande Valley are using their work to call attention to immigration issues and a rise in drug violence in the region.
lead_paragraph: MATAMOROS, Mexico — The artist Patricia Ruiz-Bayón recently met with three migrants in a shelter in this ravaged border city and invited them to take part in one of her performance works. The piece, “70+2...,” commemorated an act of extreme brutality that continues to traumatize the region: a 2010 massacre of 72 migrants in nearby San Fernando that the Mexican authorities say was carried out by the Zetas criminal gang.

headline: Qaeda-Aligned Militants Threaten Key Iraqi Cities
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Sunni Muslims', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Radical Sunni militants freed prisoners, set fire to police stations and seized mosques in Falluja and Ramadi, two of Iraq’s most important cities.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Radical Sunni militants aligned with Al Qaeda threatened Thursday to seize control of Falluja and Ramadi, two of the most important cities in Iraq, setting fire to police stations, freeing prisoners from jail and occupying mosques, as the government rushed troop reinforcements to the areas.

headline: Distracted Drivers and New Drivers a Perilous Mix
keywords: ['Cellular Telephones', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Text Messaging', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: Among teenage drivers, eating, texting or looking at an object on the side of the road dramatically increased the risk for a crash, but dialing a phone was the most dangerous activity of all.
lead_paragraph: An inexperienced driver who reaches for a cellphone increases the risk for a crash by more than 700 percent, a new study found.

headline: Blast Inquiry in Prague Finds Weapons
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Firearms', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Explosions']
abstract: Officials investigating an explosion that killed the Palestinian ambassador to the Czech Republic at his residence found illegal weapons, the Prague police chief said.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Officials investigating an explosion that killed the Palestinian ambassador to the Czech Republic on Wednesday at his residence in Prague found illegal weapons in a search of the compound, the Prague police chief said Thursday.

headline: Russell Banks: By the Book
abstract: The author, most recently, of “A Permanent Member of the Family” steers clear of any book described as fantasy, “which to me says, ‘Don’t worry, Reader, Death will be absent here.’ ”
lead_paragraph: The author, most recently, of “A Permanent Member of the Family” steers clear of any book described as fantasy, “which to me says, ‘Don’t worry, Reader, Death will be absent here.’ ”

headline: Joseph Lieberman Joins Private Equity Firm
abstract: The former senator from Connecticut and onetime vice presidential candidate is expected to help Victory Park Capital with his regulatory expertise.
lead_paragraph: Over lunch in Manhattan several months ago, Brendan Carroll, a partner and co-founder of the private equity firm Victory Park Capital, had a proposition for his former boss, Joseph I. Lieberman, the former senator from Connecticut and onetime vice-presidential candidate: Would Mr. Lieberman be interested in joining his firm?

headline: Chrysler Deal Puts Fiat Chief in the Fast Lane
abstract: The price of $3.65 billion for the almost 41.5 percent of Chrysler looks to be a fair one, writes Antony Currie of Reuters Breakingviews. And the deal with the union trust fund ends a dispute that had been festering almost 18 months.
lead_paragraph: Sergio Marchionne could not have wished for a better start to 2014.

headline: Bratton Takes Helm of Police Force He Pledged to Change
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Search and Seizure', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: In his first address as commissioner, William J. Bratton said the department’s progress in reducing crime should long ago have given way to fewer confrontational encounters with the public.
lead_paragraph: Minutes after the bagpipes faded and he took the oath of office on Thursday, Police Commissioner William J. Bratton signaled that he intended to shift the nation’s largest police department away from an aggressive style of patrolling New York City that had alienated many minority residents.

headline: Leonardo DiCaprio Explains ‘Wolf of Wall Street’
abstract: The star and producer of the film discusses what he and director Martin Scorsese were aiming for with the controversial film.
lead_paragraph: Leonardo DiCaprio has been on a charm offensive, or maybe defensive, explaining to many awards-watchers why the brutally divided reaction to “The Wolf of Wall Street” has been all wrong, or at least slightly premature.

headline: Castoffs Become Keepers as the Suns Defy Expectations
abstract: A rookie general manager, Ryan McDonough, and coach, Jeff Hornacek, have created a winning spirit around the Suns, who were projected to win only about 20 games this season.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — This is how Phoenix is eclipsing expectations: with a 3-point shooter who once won an N.B.A. dunk contest, a gaptoothed defender who is a former Israeli Super League most valuable player, a center who has recorded as many blocked shots this season as he had minutes in 2012-13, and a two-headed monster of a backcourt.

headline: The Gun Report: January 2, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Today we return from our holiday break. Here are some notable shootings that occurred while we were gone:

headline: Bodyguard of Zombies, Counterattack by Cockroaches
abstract: No argument is ever taken off the table.
lead_paragraph: The bit about the WSJ’s continuing denialism on rising inequality brings to mind a point I think I’ve made before, but which seems especially appropriate for recent debates. It is this: Today’s right wing never gives up on a politically convenient argument, no matter how thoroughly it may have been refuted by analysis and evidence. It may downplay that argument for a while — though often even that doesn’t happen — but it always comes back.

headline: In North Carolina, an Earl Scruggs Museum
abstract: The Earl Scruggs Center, which celebrates the late bluegrass star, is scheduled to open this month in Shelby, N.C.
lead_paragraph: The bluegrass legend Earl Scruggs, whose three-finger banjo-picking technique became known as “Scruggs style,” is celebrated at a new museum near his childhood home of Flint Hill, N.C., in the foothills of the Blue Ridge mountains. The Earl Scruggs Center, in the restored 1907 Cleveland County courthouse in downtown Shelby, covers the life, time and community of the musical innovator, who died in 2012 at the age of 88.

headline: Newark Recalls Its Lustrous Metals Past
abstract: An exhibition at the Newark Museum focuses on objects manufactured when Newark was a precious-metals epicenter.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Artisans specializing in precious metals largely left this city decades ago, and their buildings have been razed, renovated beyond recognition or converted into apartment complexes with names like Tiffany Manor.

headline: Probabilities in Wild-Card Round: Close-Up on Chiefs-Colts
abstract: With two teams so closely matched, the difference comes down mostly to home-field advantage, which is why the Colts are rightly the favorites.
lead_paragraph: When the Colts host the Chiefs on Saturday in the first of this weekend’s four wild-card games, each team will feel as if it is looking into the mirror. The two teams are nearly statistically identical and tend to play disciplined, low-risk, ball-control football while letting their opponents make mistakes.

headline: Producers Pick Their Top 10
abstract: The Producers Guild of America unveils the 10 nominees for its best film prize.
lead_paragraph: The Producers Guild of America has unveiled nominees for its top prize, the Darryl F. Zanuck Award. It’s a list filled with much-discussed titles:

headline: Bruno Mars Tops Illegal Download Chart
abstract: A study finds that the music of Bruno Mars was illegally downloaded nearly 6 million times in 2013.
lead_paragraph: It is a dubious distinction, as chart listings go, and no doubt an infuriating one: Bruno Mars was the musician whose work was illegally downloaded the most in 2013, according to a study that was prepared by Musicmetric. The company, based in London, analyzes consumer behavior, and its report has been published in Billboard.

headline: Battle for Survival May Yield the Rain Forest’s Diversity
keywords: ['Biodiversity', 'Flowers and Plants', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: Warfare between plants and insects is responsible for remarkable tropical biodiversity, two ecologists contend.
lead_paragraph: The diversity of a tropical rain forest can be hard to fathom for people who have not seen one. Three acres of jungle may be home to more than 650 species of trees — more species than grow in the entire continental United States and Canada combined.

headline: Weeks in the Making, an Editorial on Snowden May Go ‘Beyond What Is Realistic’
abstract: The editorial page editor tells the public editor how the editorial came about.
lead_paragraph: Most newspaper editorials don’t generate a great deal of heat. Even fewer can be considered newsworthy.

headline: Allowed to Join the Bar, but Not to Take a Job
keywords: ['Legal Profession', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Supreme Courts (State)', 'States (US)']
abstract: A 36-year-old brought to the country from Mexico as a child can be admitted to the state bar, the California Supreme Court said. But, under federal law, no law firm can legally hire him.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As a teenager in Northern California, Sergio Garcia worked in the almond fields and in a grocery store, earning his way through college and then law school. He passed the California bar exam on his first try, something just half of all candidates do.

headline: Diving Into the Wreck
abstract: Chang-rae Lee’s new novel imagines a future after the breakdown of society.
lead_paragraph: Watching a talented writer take a risk is one of the pleasures of devoted reading, and “On Such a Full Sea” provides all that and more. It’s a wonderful addition not only to Chang-rae Lee’s body of work but to the ranks of “serious” writers venturing into the realm of dystopian fantasy. Colson Whitehead, Cormac McCarthy and Margaret Atwood (in her recently concluded MaddAddam trilogy) have all tackled this genre. Doris Lessing’s “Mara and Dann” is a classic, as is Anthony Burgess’s “Clockwork Orange.” Further back in time, one has only to think of Orwell, Huxley and Wells, even Jack London and Mary Shelley. As the author of such carefully realist fiction as “Native Speaker” and “A Gesture Life,” Lee has always been preoccupied by the themes of hope and betrayal, by the tensions that arise in small lives in the midst of great social change. His marvelous new book, which imagines a future after the breakdown of our own society, takes on those concerns with his customary mastery of quiet detail — and a touch of the fantastic.

headline: Mr. Shteyngart’s Planet
abstract: A son’s story of moving from Leningrad to Queens with parents unburdened by any understanding of American life.
lead_paragraph: Early in his hilarious and moving memoir, Gary Shteyngart reveals that his mother’s post-collegiate nickname for him is Little Failure, which would seem more insulting if his father didn’t already call him Snotty. In this Russian Jewish family — the Shteyngarts moved from Leningrad to Queens in 1979, when Gary was 7 — barbed jokes, or shutki, are tokens of love: weird, hostile tokens, but tokens nonetheless. The shutki continue to fly in Shteyngart’s direction even after — or maybe especially after — he becomes a successful novelist (“The Russian Debutante’s Handbook,” “Absurdistan,” “Super Sad True Love Story”). Treating his parents to dinner at the revolving restaurant atop the Marriott Marquis to celebrate his mother’s birthday, Shteyngart is a sitting duck as his father fires off this one: “I read on the Russian Internet that you and your novels will soon be forgotten.” While that may not sound exactly like a joke, it’s riotous compared with what he tells his son at another dinner: “I burn with a black envy toward you. I should have been an artist as well.”

headline: A Girl Named Ruby
abstract: A biography traces Barbara Stanwyck’s evolution from Brooklyn dancer to screen star.
lead_paragraph: Start with the voice, which seems to have been around since the world began: lush, weary, tender, worldly, skeptical, ranging nimbly between hard and soft. It could be metallic, mannish and brittle or gentle as a down pillow, sometimes within the same film, as befits an actress who was at ease in every genre, from woman’s melodrama to the western, with noir and screwball comedy in between. Though film buffs have treasured her for years, Barbara Stanwyck has burned less brightly among general moviegoers for whom a higher voltage is synonymous with stardom.

headline: Emergency Visits Seen Increasing With Health Law
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicaid', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Hospitals']
abstract: A new study conducted in Oregon found that after getting health insurance, people went to the emergency room more often than their uninsured counterparts.
lead_paragraph: Supporters of President Obama’s health care law had predicted that expanding insurance coverage for the poor would reduce costly emergency room visits because people would go to primary care doctors instead. But a rigorous new experiment in Oregon has raised questions about that assumption, finding that newly insured people actually went to the emergency room a good deal more often.

headline: Lawyer Is Fined for Revealing Rowling as Author of Detective Novel
abstract: The lawyer, Chris Gossage, was fined and rebuked for breaking client confidentiality rules.
lead_paragraph: Chris Gossage, the lawyer whose indiscreet chatter led to the public unmasking of J. K. Rowling as the author of “The Cuckoo’s Calling” — the detective novel that she published under the pseudonym Robert Galbraith — has been fined £1,000 (about $1,645) by the Solicitors Regulation Authority for breaking the authority’s client confidentiality rules. Mr. Gossage, a partner at Russells Solicitors, also received a written rebuke. The ruling was issued by the authority on Nov. 26, but was not made public until this week.

headline: Letters: Norman Rockwell, New Yorker
abstract: Readers respond to a recent review of Deborah Solomon’s “American Mirror” and more.
lead_paragraph: A Larger Understanding

headline: The Getting Was Good
abstract: I’m settling into my new life, though perhaps not as well as my dog.
lead_paragraph: The very day I turned 66, 177 of you wished me well on a decision to take the advice I’d been giving others: To leave a house I loved as one loves something animate, not merely a construction of clapboard and stone, before the inevitable crisis that would make it too hard to live there and also too hard to leave under my own steam.

headline: New Director Named for Newark Museum
abstract: Steven Kern, executive director of the Everson Museum of Art in Syracuse, will become director and chief officer of the Newark Museum.
lead_paragraph: Steven Kern has been appointed director and chief executive officer of the Newark Museum, the museum announced Thursday. Mr. Kern, who is currently the executive director of the Everson Museum of Art in Syracuse, will take up his new position in February. He succeeds Mary Sue Sweeney Price, who retired in May.

headline: A Plea for Patience as Plows Fan Out Across the City
abstract: Sanitation trucks were working to clear the roads as New York’s new mayor, Bill de Blasio, told residents to “be extremely careful going outdoors.”
lead_paragraph: A menacing storm that had charted a relentless course across the Midwest churned into the New York region on Thursday evening, delivering an overnight barrage of heavy snow and high winds.

headline: Alicia Keys Leaves Job With BlackBerry
abstract: Alicia Keys has lost her job as BlackBerry’s global creative director. She got the job last year in connection with the company’s introduction of the BlackBerry 10 line of phones. But she continued to use an iPhone to post on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: While grappling with a $4.4 billion loss in its last quarter, the smartphone maker BlackBerry has fired several senior executives, including its chief executive, and is in the midst of laying off about 40 percent on its employees. On Thursday, the musician Alicia Keys also left the company, where she had been global creative director.

headline: Uganda’s Antigay Bill vs. a Documentary on Homophobia
abstract: A bill passed by the Ugandan Parliament could have dire consequences for a shortlisted documentary about the role of American evangelicals in stirring up homophobia there.
lead_paragraph: “The Square” and “Pussy Riot: A Punk Prayer” are not the only Oscar-shortlisted international documentaries that have run into trouble at home. “God Loves Uganda,” about the role of American evangelicals in stirring up homophobia in that African country, has suffered an arguably even more difficult fate. On Dec. 20, the nation’s Parliament passed a strict antigay bill, which mandates life in jail for engaging in “aggravated homosexuality,” as well prohibiting any form of same-sex contact. Though it has yet to be signed into law by the country’s president, it also carries harsh penalties for anyone promoting or even discussing gay material like that covered by the film, and demands that Ugandans inform on gay people or risk jail themselves.

headline: Beyoncé Closes Out Year on a High Note
abstract: Beyoncé’s new album is No. 1 on the Billboard chart again, and was one of the top sellers of 2013.
lead_paragraph: At the end of the year the music charts belonged to Beyoncé.

headline: Gone Guy (Personal)
abstract: Taking a bit of a break.
lead_paragraph: Just FYI: No columns tomorrow or Monday. Taking a break from deadlines.

headline: Clip: 'Kill Your Darlings'
abstract: A scene from John Krokidas's film.
lead_paragraph: A scene from John Krokidas's film.

headline: A Snow Day Coming? Dante’s Friends Want to Know
abstract: Being the son of a mayor has its advantages. Friends of Dante de Blasio apparently hope they include influencing decisions on school cancellations, or at least knowing about them ahead of time.
lead_paragraph: Being the son of a mayor unquestionably has its advantages. Dante de Blasio will have four years or more to learn what those advantages are, and to decide how he will play them. But it has taken just one day – the one frozen and overcast day since his father’s inauguration on – to experience the drawbacks.

headline: Wheelies: The Moose-Proof Jeep Edition
abstract: The updated Jeep Grand Cherokee passes a “moose test,” and N.H.T.S.A. submits proposed backup camera rule to the White House.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: A Season’s Worth of Cheap Thrills
abstract: In honor of the new year, Weekend Miser looks at free (or nearly free) events throughout the winter.
lead_paragraph: By its very nature, the vocation of the Weekend Miser entails a certain myopia, a laserlike focus on discrete three-day periods. To kick off the new year, let’s switch things up, shall we, with a more seasonal view of free or nearly free things to do in New York City: a Winter Miser, if you will.

headline: Lauren Luloff: ‘Recent Paintings’
abstract: As a painter, Ms. Luloff excels at the extremes of ideas and touch.
lead_paragraph: Show Room Gowanus

abstract: Steichen, the great Pictorialist photographer known for his misty image of the Flatiron building, also had a sharp commercial eye.
lead_paragraph: Whitney Museum of American Art

headline: Aaron Curry: Melt to Earth
abstract: “Melt to Earth” is an installation of 14 painted aluminum sculptures on the Josie Robertson Plaza of Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: Josie Robertson Plaza,

headline: Helmut Federle: The Ferner Paintings
abstract: Mr. Federle’s “The Ferner Paintings,” circles drawn in vegetable oil on small raw-linen canvases, are in conversation with art history.
lead_paragraph: Peter Blum

headline: Raqib Shaw: Paradise Lost
abstract: The pointlessly bejeweled paintings and histrionic sculptures of the artist Raqib Shaw are now hyperventilating in all three of the Pace Gallery’s spaces on West 25th Street.
lead_paragraph: Pace Gallery

headline: Eureka: William Wegman Photographs 1970-1975
abstract: Mr. Wegman’s deadpan-profound photographs from the early 1970s are sampled here, delightfully.
lead_paragraph: Craig F. Starr Gallery

headline: Ebullience Over 2013 I.P.O. Market Spills Into New Year
abstract: The business of taking companies public soared last year, jumping 40 percent over 2012, and enthusiasm for 2014 remains strong.
lead_paragraph: The next 12 months may not prove as rich for initial public offerings as the last year. But to Wall Street bankers, 2014 still promises an abundance of opportunity.

headline: Clip: 'Before Midnight'
abstract: A scene from Richard Linklater's film.
lead_paragraph: A scene from Richard Linklater's film.

headline: Regulator Plans to Increase Visibility of Its BrokerCheck Website
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Financial Brokers', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Financial industry regulators are hoping to enact a rule this year that would make it easier for investors to find out if a broker pushing to sell them a stock, bond or other investment product has a clean record.
lead_paragraph: Financial industry regulators are hoping to enact a rule this year that would make it easier for investors to find out if a broker pushing to sell them a stock, bond or other investment product has a clean record.

headline: A Puppy Predicament
abstract: Etiquette questions about breeder puppies, a mother’s second helping, waiting for a table and arranging your own birthday dinner but asking guests to pay.
lead_paragraph: I am in my late 20s and have devoted my adult life to saving homeless animals. I work at a shelter, volunteer and even started a rescue organization. I strive to prevent animals from being euthanized. One of my best friends just bought a puppy from a breeder. She has no allergies or any reason not to have adopted a dog. I feel betrayed and angry, and find it tone-deaf when she sends me pictures of the puppy. She knows I weep over animals I can’t save. Am I right to think we’re not compatible as friends?

headline: Clip: 'Enough Said'
abstract: A scene from Nicole Holofcener's film.
lead_paragraph: A scene from Nicole Holofcener's film.

headline: Shingles Can Increase Heart Attack Risk
abstract: A British study has found that having shingles can increase the risk for heart attacks, strokes and other problems.
lead_paragraph: A British study has found that having shingles can increase the risk for heart attacks.

headline: FireEye Computer Security Firm Acquires Mandiant
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Cyberwarfare', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Computer Security']
abstract: The deal, melding detection of hacking with sophisticated response to the threat, is worth more than $1 billion.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In a deal that may have broad repercussions for companies and governments fending off sophisticated hackers and state-sponsored digital attacks, FireEye, a provider of security software, has acquired Mandiant, a company known for emergency responses to computer network breaches.

headline: Clip: 'Her'
abstract: A scene from Spike Jonze’s film.
lead_paragraph: A scene from Spike Jonze’s film.

headline: Cooking for the Cold
abstract: When a cold snap or a snowstorm hits, you need a pot of something steamy on the stove, or a pan of something bubbling in the oven.
lead_paragraph: Weather is a terrific source of cooking inspiration. Stock up before the snow accumulates and put something warm and comforting on the stove.

headline: A Trans-Atlantic Romance Continues
abstract: In its new season, starting on Sunday, “Downton Abbey” continues to depict class divisions in a way that panders to contemporary notions of democracy and equality.
lead_paragraph: “The Sopranos” was once the quintessential American television show. Now, it’s “Downton Abbey.”

headline: What Should Happen to Edward Snowden?
abstract: Some readers think he’s a hero. Some say he’s a traitor.
lead_paragraph: There’s not much appreciation for nuance in the public discussion about Edward Snowden. Our editorial today tried to avoid the usual hero/traitor dichotomy of the cable news debates, saying that the public service value of his leaks outweighed the crime he committed by revealing to journalists the abuses of the National Security Agency. We called for some form of reduced punishment — a plea bargain or clemency — though we didn’t say he should be given a presidential pardon or a medal.

headline: New Ad Campaign Criticizes Senators for Support of Health Law
abstract: A conservative advocacy group backed by the billionaire Koch brothers said Thursday it will spend $2.5 million on television advertisements targeting three vulnerable Democratic senators.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – A conservative advocacy group backed by the billionaire Koch brothers said Thursday it will spend $2.5 million on television advertisements targeting three vulnerable Democratic senators who supported President Obama’s health care law.

headline: The Hard-Won Lessons of the Solitary Years
abstract: Relationships are work, I realize, but so is being single, and I became pretty good at it.
lead_paragraph: When my then-boyfriend Mark lost the lease on his Brooklyn apartment, moving in together made good sense. We were in our 40s, both battle-scarred from decades of romantic unhappiness, and had finally found the relationship we had longed for our entire lives. So even though the timing was bad (we had been dating for only six months), we knew where this was headed. Why wait?

headline: Pictures of the Day: Lebanon and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Lebanon, Central African Republic, South Sudan and Antarctica.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Lebanon, Central African Republic, South Sudan and Antarctica.

headline: There’s Room for One More Aboard the R.V.
abstract: A reluctant mother finds that having a baby doesn’t slow her momentum as a filmmaker.
lead_paragraph: Promises, promises. While color palettes and canapés are deliberations made months before a wedding, a couple’s vows can sometimes sound like a tired recitation of have, hold, sickness and health.

headline: De Blasio Defends His Inauguration’s Sometimes Harsh Tone Toward Bloomberg
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio said he had no qualms about the criticism that others directed at his predecessor, former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Thursday that he had no qualms about the harsh words directed at his predecessor, Michael R. Bloomberg, at Mr. de Blasio’s inauguration ceremony.

headline: Smoked Barbecue, for Every Appetite
abstract: Tennessee Jed’s tries to appease all barbecue preferences with its Texas’s brisket, Memphis baby back ribs, St. Louis-style ribs and Carolina pulled pork.
lead_paragraph: Barbecue is a personal thing, and every style has its partisans, but Tennessee Jed’s in Wantagh has all the bases covered. For Texans who think barbecue means beef, the menu has brisket, beef ribs and smoked beef sausages. Those who go for the more typical pork barbecue will find Memphis baby back ribs, St. Louis-style ribs and Carolina pulled pork. Every table has four bottles of house-made sauce: regular, sweet, hot and mustard. The classic North Carolina vinegar-based sauce was dropped because of a lack of popularity, according to Julie Gonzalez, the co-owner with her husband, Francisco, speaking on the phone after my visits.

headline: Karzai Is Warned Over Release of Detainees
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: President Hamid Karzai was told by visiting United States senators that relations would be damaged if Afghanistan released prisoners accused of attacking American forces.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — American senators visiting Kabul on Thursday intensified pressure on President Hamid Karzai to sign a long-term security deal with the United States. And responding to a new crisis between the allies this week, they warned the Afghan government away from plans to summarily release dozens of detainees accused of attacking American forces.

headline: Phantasms of an Analog Twilight
abstract: “Images of an Infinite Film,” at the Museum of Modern Art, is a showcase of 16-millimeter works mainly from the Conceptual 1970s onward.
lead_paragraph: If you’re of a certain age and reading this, you probably grew up watching educational filmstrips and going to the movies, where you would witness the occasional projector malfunction or celluloid meltdown. The rise of digital technology and the waning of analog film — which wasn’t even called “analog” until digital came along — made these problems largely disappear. But at the very onset of film’s decline, artists embraced it as a medium — particularly 16-millimeter film.

headline: Sanity of Psychologist’s Killer Is Again at Issue
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: The lawyers for David Tarloff said an examination had found him unfit to stand trial for the 2008 killing; a first trial ended in a hung jury.
lead_paragraph: The mental health of a man accused of killing a psychologist in her Upper East Side office was once again in question on Thursday, just as a judge in Manhattan was about to set a date for a new trial because the first one ended in a hung jury.

headline: Should Schools Cancel Based on the Forecast?
abstract: Across the Northeast, it is snowing, and schools that are back in session are debating the weather. Should they make the call to close early, based on the forecast, or wait on the night’s weather?
lead_paragraph: I’m betting on school being canceled Friday. Betting on it so hard that I’m not making lunches, I’m not setting alarms, and I’ve already made promises and plans for a snow day.

headline: The Silent Totems of a Restless Quest
abstract: “The Forgings,” an exhibition of vertical sculptures that David Smith created in 1955, is possibly his least familiar series but his most singular.
lead_paragraph: There is always more to be learned about the hard-won, groundbreaking and singular art of the American sculptor David Smith (1906-65). The latest schooling is “The Forgings,” a revelatory exhibition of 10 narrow, adamantly vertical sculptures from 1955 that are on view at the Gagosian Gallery.

headline: Myanmar’s Leader Backs Change to Constitution
abstract: President Thein Sein said he would support changing the Constitution to allow “any citizen” to become president, apparently a reference to Daw Aung San Suu Kyi.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Myanmar’s president said Thursday that he backed changing the country’s Constitution to allow “any citizen” to become president, apparently a reference to Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel Prize-winning democracy advocate whose political ambitions have been thwarted for decades by the military.

headline: Eons Before the Yoga Mat Became Trendy
abstract: Yoga is the subject of an immensely pleasurable exhibition at the Arthur M. Sackler Gallery in Washington.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Pain is a problem. So is pleasure, which causes pain — discontent, confusion, depression — when it ends, as it always does. Escape from this cycle has been a goal of spiritual disciplines universally. And one of those disciplines is the subject of an immensely pleasurable exhibition called “Yoga: The Art of Transformation” at the Arthur M. Sackler Gallery here.

headline: Egyptian Puppet Called Terrorist Mouthpiece
abstract: Egypt’s crackdown on support for the Muslim Brotherhood has turned surreal as prosecutors agreed to investigate the allegation that a puppet in a phone ad was sending coded instructions to Islamist terrorists.
lead_paragraph: Egypt’s crackdown on support for the Muslim Brotherhood turned surreal this week as prosecutors agreed to investigate the allegation that a puppet that babbles nonsensically in an advertisement for a multinational phone company was in fact sending coded instructions to Islamist terrorists.

headline: Putting His Stamp on England
abstract: “William Kent: Designing Georgian Britain” brings to mind the social, political and power elements of an 18th-century era.
lead_paragraph: “William Kent: Designing Georgian Britain,” at the Bard Graduate Center Gallery, should thrill Anglophiles as least as much as the return of “Downton Abbey.” Brimming with art and antiques from some of Britain’s most storied estates, it surveys an important but underappreciated 18th-century artist, adviser, designer, illustrator and architect of buildings and landscapes through his work over four decades (1709-48). And it brings to life the social and political machinations of the Georgian era, most of all the new elite’s cementing of power and status through Italianate country houses filled with Grand Tour souvenirs. Britain fancied itself a New Rome, and Kent aspired to be its “Raphael Secundus,” or second Raphael.

headline: Heritage in All Its Rich Hues
abstract: The Washington Heights artist M. Tony Peralta, who has a show at Renaissance Fine Art in Harlem, talks about the ways his Dominican roots have infused his work.
lead_paragraph: BRIGHT colors pop against the white walls at Renaissance Fine Art, a gallery in Harlem. M. Tony Peralta’s “Reconnected” exhibition is on display, and the Caribbean seems to wash through the space.

headline: Turning an Easy Mark Into a Street Fighter
abstract: Some New Yorkers are turning to krav maga, a self-defense technique, as a safety measure and a good workout.
lead_paragraph: “MOVE slowly,” the instructor cautioned as students of the Krav Maga Institute, grouped in twos, moved menacingly toward each other. “We don’t want to hit our partner.”

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: nail polish dangers, distracted driving, and vitamin E for Alzheimer’s disease. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: nail polish dangers, distracted driving, and vitamin E for Alzheimer’s disease. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: With the New Year, New Consumer Protections on Mortgages
abstract: Making sure borrowers can afford their loans and understand the statements they get.
lead_paragraph: NEW rules for consumers seeking home loans are arriving in the new year. And if you already have a mortgage, new borrower protections take effect for you, too.

headline: Tweaking Hot Chocolate With Wild Flavors
abstract: By adding raspberries, hazelnut and even cheese, cafes in New Jersey are moving the winter classic beyond boring old marshmallows.
lead_paragraph: It may not sound like the best thing that could ever happen to a cup of hot chocolate, but those who know Maricel E. Presilla might be inclined to take her advice when she suggests dunking cheese into the chocolate served at Zafra restaurant in Hoboken.

headline: Martha Stewart Living and Macy’s Settle Dispute and Keep Partnership
abstract: The companies were involved in a lawsuit over whether J.C. Penney had the right to sell certain Martha Stewart-branded housewares.
lead_paragraph: Macy’s and Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia have ended their legal battle over whether J. C. Penney had the right to sell certain Martha Stewart branded housewares.

headline: Big Portions, Not-So-Big Checks
abstract: El Pulpo and Tapas Bar in Southington offers generous helpings of Spanish food at modest prices.
lead_paragraph: In an atmosphere that hints at the sumptuous, with crystal chandeliers, linen-draped tables and bottles of wine displayed ornamentally, El Pulpo and Tapas Bar, in Southington, serves well-prepared Spanish cuisine that is, happily, very modest in price.

headline: Table for Two (Countries)
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States International Relations', 'Table Tennis', 'Cold War Era']
abstract: “Ping-Pong Diplomacy” builds up to the events of 1971, when an American team was unexpectedly invited to visit China to participate in a table tennis competition.
lead_paragraph: When the game of table tennis became the focus of diplomatic efforts to defuse Cold War tensions between the United States and China, no detail was too small to warrant careful scrutiny. As Nicholas Griffin demonstrates, in a book filled with well-chosen examples, the Chinese team visiting Colonial Williamsburg in 1972 was comfortable eating apple pie and singing “Home on the Range.” But “Row, Row, Row Your Boat” was dicier: the line “life is but a dream” was politically incompatible with the teachings of Chairman Mao. Thanks to some fancy footwork on the part of a translator, the line quickly turned into “life is full of steam.”

headline: Little Praise for Former Mayor
abstract: After 12 years in office, former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg sat through an hour of subtle attacks on his policies before hearing kind words from former President Bill Clinton at the mayoral inauguration.
lead_paragraph: After 12 years in office, former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg sat through an hour of subtle attacks on his policies before hearing kind words from former President Bill Clinton at the mayoral inauguration.

headline: McSorley’s for Food
abstract: One of the oldest taverns in New York City offers a simple but satisfying menu.
lead_paragraph: One of the oldest taverns in New York City offers a simple but satisfying menu.

headline: Comfort From the Cold Winds
abstract: Taking a meal (and a drink) at McSorley’s.
lead_paragraph: Traditionally speaking, you don’t go to McSorley’s for the food.

headline: New Orleans and New York, Onstage
abstract: Henry Butler is combining jazz forces with Steven Bernstein and the Hot 9 at Jazz Standard.
lead_paragraph: The time machine was set on shuffle for Henry Butler with Steven Bernstein and the Hot 9 on Wednesday night at Jazz Standard, where they are performing together through Sunday. Their collaboration is both historically aware and fully prepared to cut loose.

headline: A Blender of Genres Squeezes More Juice
abstract: Billy Joel is making an effort at concerts to generate new value from his extensive catalog.
lead_paragraph: Before midnight on New Year’s Eve at Barclays Center, in his first Brooklyn concert since he played in a Long Island garage band, Billy Joel sat at a Steinway grand between two guitarists. He wore a dark suit and tie, sang clearly and evenly, and spoke to the audience by announcing the name of a song, the album it came from, the year it was released. About a third of those songs, going back to his first record from 1971, were not hits, and he hadn’t performed some of them much or at all in recent decades. At least for the first hour — before the concert grew looser and more obvious — he seemed consumed by the task of generating new value, and he was formidable, no joke at all.

headline: Mob Machinations Crueler Than Pain
abstract: Beat Takeshi is back with “Beyond Outrage,” a sequel to the 2011 “Outrage.”
lead_paragraph: The men in Takeshi Kitano’s latest yakuza drama, “Beyond Outrage,” are not ones for closure. While professionals in less bloody careers try to move from strength to strength, these mobsters in suits tend to move from outrage to outrage as part of their daily business. In this relentless, insular sequel to Mr. Kitano’s 2011 hit, “Outrage,” actual physical violence is often less shocking than the scheming and betrayal that routinely shake up the traditional hierarchies behind these criminal enterprises.

headline: Within This Chapel, Many Gods May Appear
abstract: The Gotham Chamber Opera performed the hourlong “La Descente d’Orphée aux Enfers” at St. Paul’s Chapel.
lead_paragraph: When the score of Marc-Antoine Charpentier’s “La Descente d’Orphée aux Enfers” was rediscovered in the French National Library, The New York Times reported the news in a brief article in 1930 that ended with an assessment of the work’s quality: “It is, we are told, worthy of the composer.”

headline: Fiat’s Challenge Is to Improve Performance in Italy and Asia
abstract: To reach its goal, Fiat must enter a partnership with an Asian automaker that would give it access to the Chinese car market, the analyst Massimo Vecchio said.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Fiat boss, Sergio Marchionne, has finally won complete ownership of Chrysler and can begin trying to realize his dream of building a world-class carmaker to compete with the industry leaders Toyota, General Motors and Volkswagen. At the top of the to-do list: Stanch the deterioration in Fiat’s home market and fix a glaring hole in its Asia business.

headline: Harmonic Complexity That Moved Its Maker
abstract: At Trinity Wall Street, a performance of Rachmaninoff’s Vespers, a work that touched even its composer.
lead_paragraph: Even the most gifted composers have been insecure about the merit of their works, with Rachmaninoff among the self-doubting contingent. But he felt confident about his glorious Vespers; after the first performance in 1915, he was so moved he told the singers that he could never imagine having written such a piece, even in his dreams.

headline: In Legislature, Swaps of Names but Not Parties
abstract: When Texans vote this fall, most seats for the State Legislature are likely to remain in the hands of the parties that hold them now, even if the names of the officeholders change.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for The Tribune.

headline: Creating Neon Poetry With a Patient Camera
abstract: “In No Great Hurry” follows the photographer Saul Leiter, who created painterly images of New York in color, when black and white still ruled.
lead_paragraph: Now considered among the very best of the New York School street photographers, and a leading exponent in the artistic use of color film, Saul Leiter came to this acclaim rather late. While much of his most powerful work was made in the 1950s, it wasn’t truly rediscovered until nearly a half-century later.

headline: CMAX Solar Technology
abstract: A diagram provided by Ford illustrates its new solar technology.
lead_paragraph: A diagram provided by Ford illustrates its new solar technology.

headline: Heating Up From the Inside Out
abstract: Jewel of Himalaya, the sister restaurant to the Yorktown Heights original, serves mouth-tingling curry and large bowls of searing chicken soup crammed with noodles.
lead_paragraph: In these frosty months, Westchester diners might keep cozy by following the diets of those who call the icy, rocky terrain of the Himalayas home. When winter stings your cheeks, turn to hot chilies, meat proteins, grains and breads. Go for mouth-tingling curry, vindaloo so spicy that tears come to the eyes and large bowls of searing chicken soup crammed with noodles. Think about stopping into Jewel of Himalaya in Harrison, sister restaurant to the Yorktown Heights original, for dinner or a sampling from the new lunch buffet. The food here is to climb mountains by.

headline: When Spidey Flies No More, Will Business?
abstract: As “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” closes, nearby businesses like delis and bars contemplate the effect.
lead_paragraph: BROADWAY today is an international brand, drawing audiences from around the world for some razzle-dazzle and, ideally, plenty of pre- and post-show spending. But each Broadway theater is also a local business, whose seasonal ebb and flow leaves its mark on the neighborhood.

headline: From Ford, a Plug-In That Tracks the Sun
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Solar Energy', 'International Consumer Electronics Show']
abstract: A solar-powered Ford C-Max concept maximizes energy by finding its own place in the sun.
lead_paragraph: If Stonehenge had been built with a visitor’s parking lot, the spaces might have looked something like what Ford proposes for its C-Max Solar Energi, a plug-in hybrid with a rooftop solar panel.

headline: Paying for Foreclosure Delays
abstract: A mortgage fee eliminated elsewhere will remain in place in the tristate area and in Florida, states that process foreclosures via judicial systems.
lead_paragraph: The long foreclosure timelines in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut may translate into slightly higher borrowing costs for consumers in those states.

headline: Comedy Listings for Jan. 3-9
abstract: A guide to stand-up, improv and other comedy shows in New York.

headline: Near Singapore’s Concrete, an Oasis of Nature
abstract: Pulau Ubin, a small island where fewer than 50 people live, offers an antidote to Singapore’s crowded urban experience.
lead_paragraph: After cycling a half-mile along a soggy clay track that sliced through a corridor of rubber trees, tailed by an electric-crimson-colored dragonfly, arches of bamboo creating a canopy, I emerged by a small, silty lake. A dilapidated jetty reached out into the water, a mint-green fishing boat loosely tied to it; a splintery, whitewashed wooden sign nailed to a sea grape tree announced “Cold Drinks.”

headline: From Chicago to Boston, Winter Storm Creates Havoc for Travelers
abstract: Thousands of flights were delayed or canceled, and drivers faced treacherous driving conditions as the storm dumped piles of snow overnight.
lead_paragraph: Updated, Friday, Jan. 3, 4:00 p.m. A winter storm that brought bitter cold, strong winds and two feet of snow to parts of New England overnight snarled air travel across the country Friday and created treacherous road conditions for motorists from Chicago to Boston.

headline: Photography on the Move
abstract: A photography exhibit displays works from the Spanish and Portuguese diaspora while examining how the medium transcends “a single place and time.”
lead_paragraph: At a glance, “The Itinerant Languages of Photography” at the Princeton University Art Museum looks like a handsome, if compact, survey of photography from the Spanish and Portuguese diaspora. There are 19th-century Brazilian photographs and modernist classics like Tina Modotti’s Mexican “Workers’ Parade” (1926); masterpieces of Spanish street photography; and works by contemporary artists like Graciela Iturbide and Joan Fontcuberta.

headline: Movie Listings for Jan. 3-9
abstract: A critical guide to movies playing in New York, including film series.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Raising a Pole on the ‘Islands of the People’
abstract: On Haida Gwaii, an archipelago off the coast of British Columbia, a 40-foot “Legacy Pole” is lifted to celebrate a key moment in the history of the islands.
lead_paragraph: The ocean grew choppy and storm clouds darkened the southern sky as we paddled the final miles toward an abandoned Haida village site at the heart of a wedge-shaped archipelago 175 miles in length, 70 miles off the northwest coast of British Columbia. Until recently, this remote chain of islands was known as the Queen Charlotte Islands, but three years ago, the Haida Nation returned that colonial name to the provincial government, in a ceremony using the same style of bentwood box that once housed the remains of the dead. The place is now Haida Gwaii (pronounced HI-duh GWY) — Islands of the People — both officially and, unquestionably, in spirit.

headline: A Fresh Eye on Fall River, Mass.
abstract: The town, where interest in Lizzie Borden endures, is about to get a bump in attention thanks to a new movie about the notorious murder case.
lead_paragraph: About 50 to 300 visitors a day descend on the Lizzie Borden Bed & Breakfast Museum in Fall River, Mass., a three-story Victorian with dark green shutters and the site of one of America’s most infamous — and most aggressively researched and marketed — murder cases. At times, tourists arrive by the busloads, from “all over the world,” said the house’s co-owner, Lee-Ann Wilber.

headline: In Your Seat but on Your Toes
abstract: True aficionados of inventive theater know exactly where they need to be every January: far Off Broadway.
lead_paragraph: TRUE aficionados of inventive theater know exactly where they need to be every January: far Off Broadway. Despite the bitter cold of this post-holiday period, there is an abundance of off-kilter theater in important festivals that have become annual events on the cultural calendar. And each year, it seems, more presenters and organizers are joining the fray.

headline: A Pair of Bluebloods With Blueprints
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Books and Literature', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Mary Mason Jones has some renown as a developer, thanks to her great-niece Edith Wharton. Somehow another builder great-aunt, Rebecca Jones, got much less mention.
lead_paragraph: Edith Wharton’s corpulent great-aunt Mary Mason Jones served as one of the most memorable inspirations in literary New York: the model for Mrs. Manson Mingott in Wharton’s novel “The Age of Innocence.”

abstract: The New York Times movie critics on "Lone Survivor," "Grudge Match" and "47 Ronin."
lead_paragraph: The New York Times movie critics on "Lone Survivor," "Grudge Match" and "47 Ronin."

headline: 21st Century Fox Sells Stake in Chinese TV Company
abstract: The move was the latest step that the company has taken to reduce its position in China.
lead_paragraph: The television, cable and movie conglomerate owned by Rupert Murdoch, 21st Century Fox, said on Thursday that it would sell its 47 percent stake in Star China TV. The move was the latest step the company has taken to reduce its position in China.

headline: Farms Aren’t Going Away, but a Lot of the Little Ones Are
abstract: Texas farmers are selling their land and leaving the occupation behind, suggesting a future not only of less farmland but also of more corporate holdings and larger parcels than before.
lead_paragraph: SPEARMAN — Inside Mike Skinner’s house in this town in the northern part of the Texas Panhandle is a cage with finches and parakeets — the only livestock he has left, he says, smiling, now that he has sold the family farm.

headline: A Tablet for Children That Comes With Its Own Penguins
abstract: The DreamTab, produced by Fuhu and DreamWorks Animation, will regularly update with custom content from the animation studio.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Calif. — DreamWorks Animation first captivated children in movie theaters. Then it branched into TV, piping cartoons based on hits like “Madagascar” and “How to Train Your Dragon” into homes through outlets like Nickelodeon and Netflix.

headline: Bob Grant, a Combative Personality on New York Talk Radio, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Grant, long a dominant voice on the airwaves, took advantage of the repeal of the Fairness Doctrine and thrived on the radio despite racist remarks.
lead_paragraph: Bob Grant, the right-wing talk radio host whose testy, confrontational manner made him a dominant voice during the drive-time hours in New York for decades, died on Tuesday in Hillsborough, N.J. He was 84.

headline: George Jacobs, Memoirist and Valet for Sinatra, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Jacobs had a close-up of Frank Sinatra’s inner circle in the 1950s and ’60s and wrote about it in a 2003 book.
lead_paragraph: George Jacobs, a former valet whose memoir revealed his longtime employer, Frank Sinatra, to be both a hero and a villain, died on Dec. 28 in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 86.

headline: Risky Work in Indonesia’s Gold Fields
abstract: A cottage industry uses mercury to refine the metal, with alarming effects on the environment and human health.
lead_paragraph: A cottage industry uses mercury to refine the metal, with alarming effects on the environment and human health.

headline: Small-Scale Gold Mining Pollutes Indonesian Lands
abstract: Indonesian villagers use mercury to process the ore from small-scale mines, work that carries risks to themselves and the environment.
lead_paragraph: CISITU, Indonesia — In the remote mountains of West Java, workers like 15-year-old David Mario Chandra are an integral part of Indonesia’s gold industry.

headline: Mercury Trade Eludes International Controls
abstract: Despite its signing of a United Nations treaty on mercury, Indonesia acknowledges that actual imports far exceed official figures.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA — Tracking illicit mercury imports into Indonesia is all but impossible, officials say. But data clearly shows that far more is being carried into the country than is officially recorded, even as the United Nations and other groups try to halt its use globally.

headline: Walk to Train Essential
abstract: Gary Kuchta went looking for a two-bedroom in Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: By the time Gary Kuchta moved to New York two years ago for a new job, he had owned three houses — two in Chicago, his hometown, and one in Los Angeles. “I kind of just believe in owning,” he said.

headline: Micky Lay, a Source for ‘Jerusalem,’ Dies at 73
abstract: Mr. Lay’s hard-drinking, rebel persona was an inspiration for Mark Rylance’s Tony- and Olivier-winning performance in Jez Butterworth’s play “Jerusalem.”
lead_paragraph: Micky Lay, a bibulous retired builder who helped Mark Rylance craft his performance in Jez Butterworth’s hit play about British outcasts, “Jerusalem,” for which Mr. Rylance won a Tony, died on Friday in the village of Pewsey, Wiltshire, England. He was 73.

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Snapchat Breach Exposes Weak Security
abstract: After a breach that exposed 4.6 million Snapchat usernames and phone numbers, Snapchat’s security issues were laid bare.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:25 p.m. |This post now includes Snapchat’s response to a request for an interview.

headline: Tracing Oysters’ Path From Plentiful to High-Priced
abstract: In photographs, paintings and implements of the trade, a Greenwich exhibition explores the centuries-old interaction between the oysters of Long Island Sound and the people who have lived beside them.
lead_paragraph: If you ingest a medium-size oyster — as many revelers did during the holiday season — you get about 10 calories, 1 gram of protein and the pleasure derived from savoring a luxurious treat. If you take in the oyster exhibition at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, you miss out on the calories, the protein and the cost, but you still get to enjoy a treat. “Oysters, Pearls of Long Island Sound” is a fascinating stew of oyster lore, oyster science, oyster commerce and oyster history — not to mention a bit of oyster porn, in the brief but vivid video of several bivalves in turn spraying clouds of eggs and sperm into the water.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Fired? Speak No Evil
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Giving up the right to speak and write freely strikes me as the unholiest of deals for a writer to accept.
lead_paragraph: I WAS fired the other day. I believe the preferred phrase is “terminated,” which is how my former employer, Byliner, a digital publishing company and subscription service in San Francisco, put it. I was informed that our “burn rate” was too high, that we needed to show investors that we were serious about reducing it, and that while my loss of a job was unfortunately going to be a part of that reduction, this had nothing to do with the quality of my work. Soon thereafter, an email arrived from the company’s founder and chief executive saying how much he had enjoyed working with me.
