lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Since the Time of the Shogun and the Samurai
abstract: An exhibition at the Hofstra University Museum explores the cultural evolution of Japan from the 16th to the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: “Land of the Rising Sun: Art of Japan,” the current exhibition at the David Filderman Gallery of Hofstra University Museum, does not lack for ambition. Its 41 works, all from the museum’s permanent collection, explore the cultural evolution of Japan from the 16th to the 20th century.

headline: Without Jury, Judge Warned That Stop-and-Frisk Ruling Would Be Disputed
keywords: ['Search and Seizure', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Racial Profiling', 'Discrimination', 'Jury System']
abstract: Judge Shira A. Scheindlin, who ruled that the New York police tactic violated the Constitution, seemed to foresee the type of fallout that such a decision would produce.
lead_paragraph: With the trial over the New York Police Department’s stop-and-frisk practices just months away, Judge Shira A. Scheindlin expressed concern at the decision by the lawyers who had filed the suit to have her, not a jury, decide the case.

headline: Delivering an Opinion Is Tebow’s New Test
abstract: ESPN introduced Tim Tebow as a college football analyst Tuesday, but in a conference call he showed a knack for providing more nonanswers than insight.
lead_paragraph: When he was introduced to the news media by ESPN as its newest analyst on Tuesday, Tim Tebow suggested through his remarks that he might be the nicest, politest, humblest person ever to hold a microphone.

headline: Can Animals Help Limit Concussions?
abstract: Woodpeckers and bighorn sheep offer clues for how to protect N.F.L. players.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — THE N.F.L. playoffs start tomorrow. During the regular season, the conversation about traumatic brain injuries in sports among doctors, players, league officials, politicians and parents seemed to gain in volume and intensity with each passing week. New revelations from retired N.F.L. players who announced that they had the progressive neurodegenerative brain disease chronic traumatic encephalopathy, or C.T.E., helped fuel these discussions.

headline: As the Working Poor Become More Common in Britain, So Does Hunger
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Food Aid', 'Food Banks and Pantries', 'Recession and Depression', 'Unemployment', 'Floods', 'Poverty']
abstract: Five years of economic weakness, austerity and rising prices have left a mark, with at least 500,000 people in Britain reliant on food aid, three times more than a year ago.
lead_paragraph: HULL, England — To her colleagues at the day care center, Charlotte Burton is an independent woman who works full time and manages just fine. They admire her for biking to work at this time of year, when chilly winds blow and the River Hull swells with rainwater, intermittently swallowing parts of this northeastern city.

headline: Food Need Grows Among Britain’s Working Poor
abstract: In Britain, sluggish growth and rising prices have left a mark: earnings have stagnated while the cost of living has gone up by almost 20 percent.
lead_paragraph: In Britain, sluggish growth and rising prices have left a mark: earnings have stagnated while the cost of living has gone up by almost 20 percent.

headline: Disrespect to Bloomberg, or Truth to Power?
abstract: Were speakers at Wednesday's inaugural rude to the former mayor or just voicing the frustrations of millions of New Yorkers who are rarely heard?

headline: Houston and Its Strip Clubs Call a Truce
keywords: ['Human Trafficking', 'Strip Clubs and Strippers', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: After 16 years of litigation, the city reached a settlement with 16 strip clubs that does away with a number of rules, angering religious leaders and advocates for sex-trafficking victims.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — As 2013 wound down, this city appeared to finally free itself from one of its longest-running legal battles.

headline: Johnny Orr, Coach Who Turned Iowa State Into Contender, Dies at 86
abstract: Orr, who led Michigan to the N.C.A.A. men’s final in 1976, left for Iowa State in 1980 and turned around a moribund program by emphasizing speed over size.
lead_paragraph: Johnny Orr, who chose more money but far less prestige when he gave up his high-profile role as basketball coach at the University of Michigan to coach lowly Iowa State — and went on to lead the Cyclones to multiple appearances in the N.C.A.A. tournament — died on Tuesday in Des Moines. He was 86.

headline: Saving New Jersey’s Coast
abstract: Property owners who are resisting plans to build protective dunes are putting lives and property at risk, including their own.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Sandy made a direct hit on New Jersey just over a year ago, killing 34 people and devastating much of the state’s Atlantic coast. Now, communities that want to build sand dunes to provide protection when (not if) another storm hits are being thwarted by landowners who have refused to allow the dunes to be built on their property. Areas with dunes fared better in the storm than those without them.

headline: Fearless Fullback Makes Sure Auburn Has Room to Run
abstract: Jay Prosch, a 6-2, 258-pound H-back and fullback, is a perfect escort for the run-first Auburn offense. The Tigers play Florida State in the B.C.S. title game Monday.
lead_paragraph: Auburn’s Jay Prosch had an inelegant style as a boy and would sometimes forget about the basics, he said, like common sense. He would take any dare from friends in Saraland, Ala., like building the highest tree fort, hurtling over the biggest dirt piles with his bike, or back flipping into any pool of water he could find. He was muscular and unyielding.

headline: Hey, Is That a BMW Racing Down the Bobsled Course?
abstract: BMW of North America has built six two-person bobsleds for the United States men’s and women’s Olympic teams and wants to see them win.
lead_paragraph: THE last time the United States men’s team won an Olympic gold medal in the two-man bobsled competition was 1936, when Franklin D. Roosevelt was in the White House and a gallon of gas cost 10 cents.

headline: Scouting’s Incomplete Evolution
abstract: An overdue step toward inclusion of gays and lesbians in the Boy Scouts that went into effect on New Year’s Day was welcome but did not go far enough.
lead_paragraph: The new year brings a positive change in the membership practices of the Boy Scouts of America. In May, delegates attending the Boy Scouts’ national convention voted to allow openly gay boys to participate in the group’s activities. That overdue step toward inclusion went into effect on New Year’s Day, a welcome — though incomplete — turn for an organization that until quite recently rejected any change in its discriminatory ways.

headline: Ezra Klein Is Said to Plan to Leave Washington Post
abstract: Ezra Klein, an analyst, columnist and television commentator who runs The Washington Post’s Wonkblog, is said to have failed to win backing for a new website.
lead_paragraph: Ezra Klein, an analyst, columnist and television commentator who runs The Washington Post’s Wonkblog, is making plans to leave the newspaper after failing to win support for a new website he wanted to create within the company, according to four people with knowledge of the negotiations.

headline: When a 2nd-Term President and a Divided Congress Made Magic
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Taxation', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A look at the 1986 deals offers a measure of how much has changed in the way Washington works.
lead_paragraph: The modesty of last month’s federal budget deal, and the difficulty of achieving even that, make Washington’s more ambitious 2014 goals appear out of reach.

headline: While Kerry Pushes Peace Talks, Israeli Leader Airs Criticism
abstract: Upon the arrival of Secretary of State John Kerry in Israel, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu questioned the Palestinian commitment to peace.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel delivered a harsh assessment of his Palestinian counterpart and implicitly the prospect of a Middle East peace agreement as Secretary of State John Kerry arrived here on Thursday to intensify his push for a “framework” accord that would define the principles of a comprehensive treaty.

headline: Regulator of Wall Street Loses Its Hard-Charging Chairman
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Gary Gensler became known during his tenure at the Commodity Futures Trading Commission for his long work hours and aggressive oversight of the derivatives industry.
lead_paragraph: Gary Gensler squeezed into a Washington auditorium last month, mingling with the 300 guests at his farewell party and basking in the attention as a who’s who of finance recounted his campaign to rein in Wall Street risk-taking.

headline: Rewriting the City’s Record on Prisons
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Inaugurations', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Search and Seizure', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: Harry Belafonte’s comments at the inauguration of Mayor Bill de Blasio grievously mangled the facts about New York and its prison population.
lead_paragraph: First to the microphone at the inauguration of Mayor Bill de Blasio, Harry Belafonte got 60 seconds into his talk before grievously mangling history.

headline: No Burden on Religion
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Editorials', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Justice Sonia Sotomayor’s perplexing decision to issue a stay on enforcing the rules of the contraception mandate should be lifted.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is expected to file a brief on Friday in opposition to Justice Sonia Sotomayor’s perplexing decision to issue a temporary injunction against requiring an order of Colorado nuns to fill out paperwork required by the health care reform law’s contraception mandate.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Looks Forward
abstract: The new mayor promises to take on inequality and injustice in New York City, while also calling on unity and optimism.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio took charge of New York City on Wednesday with a forceful Inaugural Address and pledged to begin the head-on attack on “the inequality crisis” as he had promised. He repeated the bullet points from his campaign, but insisted that progressive talking would now give way to progressive governing, without dilution or dithering. “We won’t wait,” Mr. de Blasio said again and again. “We’ll do it now.”

headline: Snowfall So Far in the Northeast
abstract: Map showing which areas got the most snow.
lead_paragraph: Map showing which areas got the most snow.

headline: Weed: Been There. Done That.
abstract: It is one thing for kids to experiment with marijuana, but it’s something else for it to be legal for adults to use anywhere, everywhere.
lead_paragraph: For a little while in my teenage years, my friends and I smoked marijuana. It was fun. I have some fond memories of us all being silly together. I think those moments of uninhibited frolic deepened our friendships.

headline: At Work, de Blasio Finds Full Plate of Headaches
abstract: The day after his inauguration as mayor of New York, Bill de Blasio introduced himself to a wary police force and confronted a major winter storm, the city’s first of 2014.
lead_paragraph: In a hectic first full day as New York’s mayor, Bill de Blasio introduced himself to a wary police force on Thursday, navigated unfamiliar hallways with a skeletal staff and confronted an imminent winter storm that might have rattled even the most experienced municipal manager.

headline: Central African Republic: Violence Forces Aid Group to Curtail Work
abstract: Doctors Without Borders said it had drastically scaled back operations at an airport encampment in Bangui, the capital, because of a growing political and sectarian crisis.
lead_paragraph: Doctors Without Borders, the international medical charity known for its resilience in some of the world’s most inhospitable crisis zones, said Thursday that it had drastically curtailed operations at an airport encampment in the Central African Republic, where violence has imperiled about 100,000 displaced people taking refuge. The group said in a statement that its clinic at the airport in Bangui, the capital, which had been treating more than 100 wounded people a day, would now treat “only the most severe cases” with an emergency crew. It was an unusual but not unprecedented retreat for the group, which has remained active in the country throughout a growing political and sectarian crisis, and will continue to work in two hospitals and two other camps in Bangui. Last August the organization completely withdrew from Somalia after having worked there for 22 years, attributing the decision to repeated attacks on its staff.

headline: High Above the Water, but Awash in Red Tape
keywords: ['Bridges and Tunnels', 'Ships and Shipping', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Environment']
abstract: The approval process for elevating the deck of the Bayonne Bridge is a case study, critics say, in environmental bureaucracy.
lead_paragraph: It seemed ingenious at the time: Elevate the deck of the existing Bayonne Bridge to accommodate the giant cargo ships that will begin passing through the Panama Canal in 2015 after the project to widen and deepen it is scheduled to be finished. Building a new bridge or tunneling under Kill Van Kull would have been much more expensive and would have required years of regulatory reviews.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 2, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: She Once Worked on a Roller Coaster, and Now Her Life Resembles One
abstract: With discipline and poise, Sharae Turner, 24, has survived a life marked by abuse, unemployment and homelessness, including as a single mother.
lead_paragraph: Sharae Turner did not care much for roller coasters before she took a job at an amusement park in Florida. But since her job required it, she managed to strap herself into one every day for a test run.

headline: Chemistry Lab Fire Injures 2 at a Manhattan High School
abstract: A teacher’s science demonstration for a 10th-grade class exploded at Beacon High School, hospitalizing a boy with severe burns. A girl was hospitalized and released.
lead_paragraph: A teacher’s chemistry experiment exploded during a demonstration at Beacon High School in Manhattan on Thursday, creating a fireball that burned two 10th graders, one severely, according to Fire Department and school officials.

headline: Steroids and Sports in India
abstract: Nearly 500 athletes from India have tested positive for banned substances since 2009, when the country’s National Anti-Doping Agency became fully functional.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 500 athletes from India have tested positive for banned substances since 2009, when the country’s National Anti-Doping Agency became fully functional.

headline: Banned Substances Claim an Outsize Role in Athletics in India
abstract: Indian athletes, with easy access to legal steroids and minimal support from their nation, lead the world in suspensions for performance-enhancing drug use.
lead_paragraph: PATIALA, India — The crumbling Old Moti Bagh Palace houses the National Institute of Sports, the training ground for India’s best athletes. One sweltering spring afternoon, the sprinter Ashwini Akkunji ran laps around its sprawling grounds, past broken fountains, a murky pool and monkeys that occasionally charged people with bared teeth. She and the palace, once home to Patiala’s royal family, had seen better days.

headline: Concern Over Safety Grows as More Oil Rides the Rails
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Railroad Accidents and Safety', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Pipelines']
abstract: A drilling surge in oil fields has generated a heavy volume of traffic on North America’s rail networks, prompting concern over accidents.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Safety officials have worried for years about hazardous materials carried on trains, but concern has intensified recently as a drilling surge in remote oil fields has generated heavy traffic on North America’s aging rail-freight networks.

headline: In a State of Nirvana
abstract: Barry C. Silk and Brad Wilber return with a great Friday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Just gorgeous, not really a misstep in the entire grid. This is what a Friday puzzle should be. The entries in today’s puzzle are so nice that you just want to say them out loud as you fill them in.

headline: Anthony Hits Roof, Then Hits Court for Knicks
abstract: Carmelo Anthony’s sprained left ankle had shown enough improvement that he started for the Knicks against the Spurs, two days after insulting a fan on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — Seconds after Carmelo Anthony capped Thursday morning’s shootaround at AT&T Center by plopping down on a courtside folding chair, a trainer rushed over to wrap ice packs around both his knees. His knees were not really the problem, though.

headline: Without Lopez, Nets Redefine Strategy and Go With a Smaller Lineup
abstract: The Nets are trying to redefine themselves as they have to compensate for the loss of center Brook Lopez.
lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — The Nets have faced an identity crisis since last summer’s expensive roster overhaul.

headline: Hezbollah Moving Long-Range Missiles From Syria to Lebanon, an Analyst Says
keywords: ['Military Bases and Installations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems']
abstract: The Shiite militia has been moving long-range missiles to Lebanon from bases inside Syria, according to an Israeli national security analyst, who said the missiles could strike deep inside his country.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Amid the chaos of Syria’s civil war, Hezbollah has been moving long-range missiles to Lebanon from bases where it had stored them inside Syria, including long-range Scud D missiles that can strike deep into Israel, according to an Israeli national security analyst.

headline: Coach of Giants’ Offense Retires After Dreary Year
abstract: Kevin Gilbride, the Giants’ offensive coordinator, called the plays in two Super Bowl victories.
lead_paragraph: Three days after the Giants co-owner John Mara called the team’s offense “broken,” the longtime offensive coordinator Kevin Gilbride announced his retirement Thursday.

headline: What You Need to Know About the Snowstorm
abstract: Estimates on snowfall totals, and information on public transportation, roads and schools.
lead_paragraph: The National Weather Service estimates that up to nine inches of snow will accumulate in the city, New Jersey and Westchester County by Friday. The mix of wind and snowfall will create limited visibility throughout the region, and motorists can expect slippery, snow-covered roads. Winds of up to 35 miles an hour are expected to create a windchill as cold as 20 degrees below zero. Residents were urged to stay indoors, but those who must go outside were advised to dress warmly, carry emergency supplies and use public transportation. The Red Cross has advice for staying safe in such weather.

headline: Support for Gay Rights Led to Harassment, Ex-Viking Says
keywords: ['Football', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Discrimination', 'Homosexuality', 'Free Agents (Sports)']
abstract: Chris Kluwe, a punter for the Minnesota Vikings for eight seasons, wrote a first-person article alleging that team officials asked him to stop speaking about gay rights.
lead_paragraph: The free-agent punter Chris Kluwe, whose outspoken views on gay rights and other issues of equality have drawn widespread attention, accused a Minnesota Vikings assistant of harassment and homophobia in a first-person account published Thursday on the website Deadspin.

headline: U.S. Military Ship Readied for Mission to Destroy Syria’s Chemical Weapons
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Ships and Shipping', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations']
abstract: The entire process, which officials said they hoped would begin within the next two weeks, would take roughly 90 days to complete, allowing for weather and other factors.
lead_paragraph: PORTSMOUTH, Va. — Months after diplomats declared that they had come up with a plan and a timetable to dispose of Syria’s lethal chemical weapons — and with the Nobel Peace Prize awarded to the weapons inspectors — the centerpiece of the mission, a workhorse American military ship that will ferry the weapons to sea for destruction, remains here in port, waiting like a sad bride for her groom.

abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, January 3, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “There’s a lot to celebrate. I can open my own law firm and that’s exactly what I intend to do. There’s no law in this country restricting entrepreneurs.”

lead_paragraph: Brandon Jacobs, a fourth-round draft pick of the Giants nine years ago who became one of the franchise’s most charismatic running backs, announced his retirement on his Twitter account late Thursday.

abstract: Changes to payments to Medicare Advantage plans introduced by the Affordable Care Act are more equitable for all taxpayers, an economist writes.

headline: Attack on Chinese Consulate Puts U.S. on Defensive
abstract: The New Year’s Day arson attack in San Francisco has prompted Chinese media to criticize United States security measures, as American officials have vowed to apprehend those responsible.
lead_paragraph: A New Year’s Day arson attack at the Chinese Consulate in San Francisco continued to reverberate on Friday, with Chinese state media faulting both United States security efforts and American attitudes toward China, while United States officials vowed to apprehend anyone connected with the attack.

headline: Manhattan Real Estate Market Surging at Year’s End
abstract: Despite the flurry of sales activity, the median sales price of $855,000 was up just slightly from the same quarter of 2012, according to a report to be released on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The Manhattan real estate market continued a yearlong trend, ending the final quarter of 2013 with a scarcity of listings and surging sales, while prices remained relatively flat.

headline: Key Plays by Shumpert Help Knicks Shock Spurs
abstract: The Knicks looked like a new team against the perennial contender San Antonio, as Iman Shumpert scored 27 points and repeatedly came through in the clutch.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — Iman Shumpert recognized that everyone was focused on Carmelo Anthony. It had never been more apparent than when Anthony took a baseline jumper late in the fourth quarter Thursday night at AT&T Center, and when the ball caromed off the back of the rim, Shumpert saw his opening.

headline: Johnson Beats Buzzer, and Nets Pull Off a Stunner
abstract: Deron Williams’s season-high 29 points and Joe Johnson’s last-second jumper helped the Nets begin 2014 with a victory at Oklahoma City.
lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — Paul Pierce was in his late-game flow. Deron Williams showed a swagger he had lacked all season. But when the game was on the line Thursday night, it was clear who would get the ball.

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10:15 P.M. (TCM) A BEAUTIFUL MIND (2001) Russell Crowe, above, in a role for which he received an Oscar nomination, portrays John Forbes Nash Jr., the gifted mathematician who battled schizophrenia for decades before going on to win the Nobel in economic science. Jennifer Connelly won for best supporting actress as Alicia Larde, the M.I.T. student who became Nash’s wife. And Ed Harris plays Nash’s contact for a government project. The paradox of this film (which won for best picture), directed by Ron Howard from a script by Akiva Goldsman, and the emotions it elicits is that the story “is almost entirely counterfeit,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Still, “Mr. Crowe, with his superhuman powers of concentration, shows us a man who dwells almost entirely in an inner world, and he dramatizes that inwardness as if nobody were watching.” In the end, Mr. Scott added, “the governing dynamic of ‘A Beautiful Mind’ is sentimentality of a familiar and not altogether unwelcome kind. The movie can — indeed, should — be intellectually rejected, but you can’t quite banish it from your mind.”

headline: A Hunting Community in Nagaland Takes Steps Toward Conservation
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'ANIMALS', 'Biodiversity', 'Birds', 'Eco-Tourism', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Hunting and Trapping', 'Irrigation', 'Reservoirs', 'Water']
abstract: In 2012, people in the northeastern state killed about 150,000 federally protected Amur falcons. In 2013, the number dropped to zero, after a campaign by the state and nonprofit groups to promote the value of wildlife.
lead_paragraph: DOYANG, Nagaland — In the fall of 2012, the people in this northeastern state, which is known for its hunting traditions, killed about 150,000 federally protected Amur falcons, the highest number recorded in India, as the birds made their annual flight from Siberia at the end of October to stay in the Doyang reservoir for the month of November on their way to southern Africa.

headline: Workers Face Police Gunfire Amid Unrest in Cambodia
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Military police officers killed at least three people, officials said, as protests against the decades-old rule of Prime Minister Hun Sen entered a volatile new phase.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Military police officers on Friday fired on protesters demanding higher wages for Cambodian garment workers, killing at least three people, officials said, as protests against the decades-old rule of Prime Minister Hun Sen entered a volatile new phase.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Rescue on the Ice
abstract: Who were rescued from an ice-bound ship on Jan. 2?
lead_paragraph: In “Helicopter Rescues 52 Passengers From Ship Trapped in Antarctic Ice,” Alan Cowell and Edward Wong write about an “operation displaying unusual international harmony in one of the world’s most remote and inhospitable places.”

headline: U.S. Orders Evacuation of Staff Members From Embassy in South Sudan
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Evacuations and Evacuees']
abstract: The moved appeared to reflect a somber assessment of the country’s prospects, even as warring factions were said to have opened preliminary talks.
lead_paragraph: The United States on Friday ordered a further reduction of American Embassy staff members in strife-torn South Sudan and said it would cease to provide consular services for its citizens as of Saturday, apparently reflecting a somber assessment of the country’s prospects even as its warring factions were reported to have opened preliminary indirect talks in neighboring Ethiopia.

lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

headline: Otto Schenk’s Opera Stagings Still at Home in Vienna
abstract: The Vienna State Opera is presenting productions of “Die Fledermaus” and “Fidelio” by the Austrian director Otto Schenk.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — While operagoers in New York spent New Year’s Eve coming to grips with Jeremy Sams’s new staging of Johann Strauss’s “Die Fledermaus” at the Metropolitan Opera, which replaced a 1986 production by Otto Schenk, operagoers here still seemed to be enjoying an even older Schenk staging of the work, which dates from 1979, at the Vienna State Opera.

headline: What Words or Phrases Should Be Retired in 2014?
abstract: What words or phrases were overused in 2013? What expressions, catchphrases, neologisms or slang do you hope never to hear again in 2014? Why?
lead_paragraph: What words or phrases were overused in 2013? What expressions, catchphrases, neologisms or slang do you hope never to hear again in 2014? Why?

headline: Q. & A.: David Der-wei Wang on C.T. Hsia, Chinese Literary Critic
abstract: C.T. Hsia, who died in New York on Dec. 29 aged 92, was a cosmopolitan scholar who established a Chinese literary canon in the West, said his friend and colleague David Der-wei Wang.
lead_paragraph: C.T. Hsia, the Chinese literary critic who died in New York on Dec. 29, aged 92, had a “legendary career” as “a true cosmopolitan, shrewd, critical and brilliant,” says David Der-wei Wang, the Edward C. Henderson Professor of Chinese Literature at Harvard University, in an interview on the significance of the life and work of his mentor and friend.

abstract: What you need to know for Friday: city schools are closed, eight to ten inches expected and temperatures plummet.
lead_paragraph: Updated 12:13 p.m.

headline: Police Raid ‘Fortress’ of Drug Production in South China
abstract: The police arrested 182 suspects in a raid on a village in Guangdong Province suspected of supplying as much as one-third of China’s domestically produced supply of methamphetamine.
lead_paragraph: The police in the southeastern province of Guangdong raided a village they called a “fortress” of methamphetamine manufacturing that was protected by local Communist Party and law enforcement officials and criminals armed with assault rifles. Three tons of methamphetamines were seized along with more than 100 tons of methamphetamine ingredients and 260 kilograms, or 570 pounds, of ketamine, they said.

lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, doping in Indian sports and "Downton Abbey" returns.

headline: Prime Minister Rules Out Third Term
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Auctions', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Manmohan Singh said Friday that he would not be India’s next prime minister if his Congress Party-led coalition wins national elections scheduled for this spring.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Prime Minister Manmohan Singh said Friday that he would not be India’s next prime minister if the Congress Party-led United Progressive Alliance wins the national elections scheduled for this spring.

headline: Times Minute | Destroying Syrian Weapons
abstract: Also on the Minute, doping in Indian sports and “Downton Abbey” returns.

headline: Thatcher Debated Using Military in 1984 Miners’ Strike
abstract: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher considered calling out the British military to transport vital supplies during the strike, which became a defining confrontation of the Thatcher era, according to newly released documents.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As striking miners challenged her grip on power in 1984, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher secretly considered calling out the British military to transport vital supplies of food and coal around the country and declaring a state of emergency to bolster the government in one of the defining confrontations of her tumultuous years in office, according to previously classified documents released on Friday.

headline: Daily Report: A DreamWorks Tablet for Children, With Penguins
abstract: The DreamTab, produced by Fuhu and DreamWorks Animation, will regularly update with custom content from the animation studio.
lead_paragraph: DreamWorks Animation first captivated children in movie theaters. Then it branched into TV, piping cartoons based on hits like “Madagascar” and “How to Train Your Dragon” into homes through outlets like Nickelodeon and Netflix. Now, Brooks Barnes reports, DreamWorks has partnered with a technology company, Fuhu, on an even more immediate way to reach itty-bitty eyeballs, a highly coveted audience: a tablet computer for children that the studio will be able to program much like a cable channel. “We could push out a new character moment every day of the year,” said Jim Mainard, head of digital strategy and new business development for DreamWorks.

headline: Paris Embraces ‘Einstein’ Again
abstract: The opera “Einstein on the Beach,” directed by Robert Wilson, with music by Philip Glass, arrives in Paris.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “Einstein on the Beach,” the avant-garde opera composed by Philip Glass and directed by Robert Wilson, is nearing the end of a two-year revival tour with its arrival here. And the city has rolled out the red carpet for Mr. Wilson.

headline: N.F.L. Wild-Card Matchups
abstract: The red-hot Colts, who beat the slumping Chiefs in Week 16, will look to repeat that result.
lead_paragraph: Chiefs (11-5) at Colts (11-5)

headline: Books, Just Like You Wanted
abstract: Writers are now able to write books that give their readers exactly what they want. That might, or might not, be a good thing.
lead_paragraph: Anyone can publish a book these days, and just about everyone does. But if the supply of writers is increasing at a velocity unknown in literary history, the supply of readers is not. That is making competition for attention rather fierce. One result: ceaseless self-promotion by eager beginners.

headline: German, Jewish and Neither
abstract: From philo-Semitism to wanting to move on, a nation struggles with its past.
lead_paragraph: Laupheim, a small town in southern Germany, once boasted a large Jewish community and named a prominent street after one of its Jewish sons: Carl Laemmle, who went on to found Universal Studios. But all of that changed in the 1930s. By 1992, when I started fifth grade, Laemmle’s name had long since been removed from the map, and my mother and I were the only Jews in town.

headline: Shocking Truth About Piranhas Revealed!
abstract: These omnivores have always been among our favorite subjects for sheer, sputtering nonsense.
lead_paragraph: In the languid news week after Christmas, hungry media outlets swarmed over a report of piranhas attacking swimmers on a river in Argentina. “Massive Piranha Attack” cried The New York Post. “70 Christmas Day Bathers Are Savaged” added The Daily Mail, promising “the truth about the fish with a bite more powerful than a T. rex.” ABC News called it a “Christmas Day feeding frenzy.” In fact, the injuries ranged from minor cuts to at least one missing finger part — not exactly as newsworthy as, say, the 800,000 Americans who require medical treatment for dog bites each year.

headline: Teenagers in The Times | December 2013
abstract: The latest monthly collection of stories about young people published in The Times.
lead_paragraph: In this monthly feature we try to collect everything published in The Times about young people so you can find it in one handy spot. For ideas on how to use this series in your classroom, visit our lesson “Teaching With ‘Teenagers in The Times.’ ”

headline: Fighting to Kick the Habit
abstract: I replaced drugs and liquor with a craving to be a better man.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — IT’S the time of year for resolutions. Lose 20 pounds, get to the gym, eat healthier, be more productive, whatever. But in a few months, many people will let these goals fall by the wayside, to be revived next year. I belong to a group who can’t afford to make pledges we don’t keep. I’m an addict.

headline: Gensler Bids Farewell to Trading Commission
abstract: Gary Gensler leaves the Commodity Futures Trading Commission at an inflection point. | FireEye has acquired the cyberforensics firm Mandiant. | Bankers see an abundance of opportunity for I.P.O.’s this year. | A storm pummeled the New York region overnight.
lead_paragraph: GENSLER BIDS FAREWELL TO TRADING COMMISSION  |  Gary Gensler, who steps down on Friday as chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, leaves his agency at an inflection point, Ben Protess reports in DealBook. His aggressive streak thrust the once-obscure agency into the front lines of reform, but it also maddened colleagues and complicated his legacy. Now, Wall Street is hoping for a friendlier regulator.

headline: Babaru Memories
abstract: Is China the next Japan?
lead_paragraph: Lots of talk about China lately; and it’s still very worrisome. I am, however, mostly on vacation. But a brief note: what I haven’t seen many people mentioning is the obvious parallel, which is not so much to the US in the last decade as to Japan in the 1980s.

headline: After Antarctic Drama, Chinese Rescue Ship Is Threatened by Ice
abstract: The Snow Dragon, a Chinese vessel, requested help and an Australian icebreaker was placed on standby in case it became icebound.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — One day after a Chinese icebreaker played a central role in the rescue of 52 passengers from an icebound research vessel in Antarctica, crew members on the Chinese ship said it might itself become trapped by ice, according to Australian officials on Friday.

headline: A Well-Trained Guide Dog
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A blind musician’s Labrador was the object of attention from a tiny terrier in a subway rider’s bag.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Iraq Fighters, Qaeda Allies, Claim Falluja as New State
abstract: After what appeared to be a morning lull, Sunni fighters destroyed the Police Headquarters and mayor’s office as violence resumed.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Black-clad Sunni militants of Al Qaeda destroyed the Falluja Police Headquarters and mayor’s office, planted their flag atop other government buildings and decreed the western Iraqi city to be their new independent state on Friday in an escalating threat to Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, whose forces were struggling to retake control late into the night.

headline: Storm Slams East Coast, Leaving a Trail of Havoc
abstract: As plows cleared the way and buses with chains clanked down glazed streets, it seemed that the New York region had been spared the worst.
lead_paragraph: New York City joined its new mayor on Friday in digging out from a substantial but not overwhelming snowstorm that closed schools for the day and highways for hours, stranded travelers and left a chilly trail of disruption across the Northeast.

headline: U.N. Says Aid Crisis Worsens in Central African Republic
abstract: Fighting has forced more than 935,000 people to flee their homes, the United Nations refugee agency said, and it is making it harder to deliver relief.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The number of people displaced by fighting between Muslim and Christian militias and vigilantes in the Central African Republic has more than doubled in the past month, and increasing violence is making it harder to deliver humanitarian relief, the United Nations warned on Friday.

headline: A Killer Whale, a Dogged Filmmaker
abstract: Gabriela Cowperthwaite explains how she used journalistic techniques, like freedom-of-information requests, to dig up information for her film “Blackfish.”
lead_paragraph: In 2010, Tilikum, a bull orca, or killer whale, performing at SeaWorld in Orlando, Fla., killed his trainer, Dawn Brancheau, at the end of a show. Like many other people, the director Gabriela Cowperthwaite read news stories about the incident and wondered how it could have happened; unlike everyone else, she decided to investigate, and kept at it until she had finished a film, “Blackfish,” which has now been shortlisted for the Oscar in the documentary feature category.

headline: An Update for ‘On This Day’
abstract: For the first time since we introduced this feature in 1999, we have revised our master list of 366 featured New York Times front-page articles to add 26 new articles.
lead_paragraph: Men Walk on Moon.

headline: After Fleeing Violence, Many Indian Muslims Refuse to Return Home
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Hinduism', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Four months after a spasm of religious violence in the state of Uttar Pradesh, an estimated 15,000 displaced Muslims remain in tent cities, not believing it is safe to return.
lead_paragraph: LOI, India — Mohammed Akhtar’s former neighbors keep stopping by to tell him that it is time for him to come home, that there is really nothing to be afraid of.

headline: Despite Protests in Thailand, Vote Will Go On, Panel Says
abstract: The election commission ignored the demands of antigovernment demonstrators and said elections would go ahead on Feb. 2 despite efforts to sabotage them.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Thailand’s Election Commission ignored the demands of antigovernment demonstrators on Friday and said elections scheduled for next month would go ahead despite continuing efforts to sabotage them.

headline: Jerry Goodman Is Dead
abstract: A friend, gone too soon.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Goodman, better known under his nom de plume Adam Smith, has died of complications related to cancer. His son Mark contacted me with the news. He was a good friend, and I will sorely miss him.

headline: Resolved: The Best Moment of 2014? This One
abstract: Children are often champions at savoring the ordinary. Parents spend too much time looking ahead or looking behind.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to New Year’s resolutions, I fall firmly in the “love ’em” camp. I sit down every January with my notebooks and calendars to try to work out what would make my life better, happier, simpler in the year to come. Some things work: I’ve become more organized. I’m late far less often. My closet adheres firmly to the “one in, one out” rule.

headline: Audi’s Sport Quattro Concept Will Have Laser Eyes
abstract: One of the earlier adopters of LED lights, Audi has upped the ante on its Audi Sport quattro laser concept.
lead_paragraph: Just when the last of Detroit’s automakers were hopping on the LED lighting bandwagon, Audi had to one-up everyone again. The German automaker’s distinctive LED daytime running lights have become a trademark of sorts over the better part of the last decade, but it has added something new: lasers.

headline: Image of the Day: January 3
abstract: A vendor preparing tea at a roadside stall in old Delhi.

headline: Megan Ellison’s Good Day, Harvey Weinstein’s Difficult One
abstract: The Producers Guild nominations gave Megan Ellison two chances to win, while Harvey Weinstein was shut out.
lead_paragraph: The Academy opened voting for Oscar nominations just last week, so awards prognosticators are paying extra-close attention to the Producers Guild nominees, announced Thursday. Their 10 picks often dovetail with the Oscar best picture field, which means that Harvey Weinstein may be sweating now.
