lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “Lone Survivor,” “Grudge Match” and “47 Ronin.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Tomorrow’s Valhalla
abstract: The classical music critics of The New York Times identify the great new operas of recent decades.
lead_paragraph: Twice in the last decade, I attended premieres at the Royal Opera in London and left the house exhilarated, convinced that a major new work had been introduced to the repertory. The first time was in 2004, at a performance of “The Tempest,” Thomas’s Adès’s magical and musically audacious adaptation of the Shakespeare play.

headline: ‘I’m Here, I’m a Carpenters Fan, Get Used to It’
abstract: The Carpenters’ mellow ’70s pop music was at the center of my life — including the first punch I ever threw.
lead_paragraph: In the basement of my childhood home, there are stacks of old Billboard magazines, dating from the mid-’70s. Recently I rooted through them to find the issue of Jan. 5, 1974. At the top of the album chart inside is the greatest-hits collection by the Carpenters, No. 1 40 years ago this week.

headline: Ronan Farrow, Reluctant TV Star
abstract: A new MSNBC show for a man who’s tried to leave his looks — and family — in the background.
lead_paragraph: Ronan Farrow had a cold. “Probably from a source,” he joked. It wasn’t clear who gave it to him — the big pop star in L.A. or the Minnesotans fighting against terrorist recruitment in their community. Farrow had been out of town reporting pieces on both, and his voice was almost shot.

headline: The 12.22.13 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.

headline: The Christie’s Auctioneer Jussi Pylkkanen on Working the Room
abstract: And the delicate difference between asking $40 million and $50 million.
lead_paragraph: In November, you auctioned off a record-breaking $691 million worth of postwar and contemporary art in a sale for Christie’s. Is there a bubble in the art market?  We used to see high prices for our old-master paintings. We sold Van Gogh’s “Sunflowers” here in London in 1987 for $40 million, which was a record at the time. Really, over the last five years we have seen a steady march toward high prices in postwar art. At the same time, new buyers are entering the market from the Middle East, Asia, Russia and elsewhere.

headline: Back to the Future in Algeria
abstract: An appreciation of the architect Oscar Niemeyer.
lead_paragraph: An appreciation of the architect Oscar Niemeyer.

headline: Can Data Be Evil?
keywords: ['Ethics (Personal)', 'Ethics (Institutional)', 'Research', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)']
abstract: The ends, the means and that dark area in between.
lead_paragraph: Some knowledge about hypothermia comes from brutal Nazi medical experiments conducted on prisoners of war. Considering the data came from the destruction of others’ lives, are there ethical issues when modern-day scientists use it? Could it be considered a form of collaboration with the Nazis? Or does the origin of the data matter if the data is useful? Declaring the data off-limits could lead to preventable deaths, while using the data seems coldheartedly clinical. ISAAC MAYER, SAN DIEGO

headline: My High-School Hoax
abstract: I tricked my teacher, but the one I fooled was myself.
lead_paragraph: I had cut ninth-grade percussion class three weeks straight. But the top-floor music room overlooked the court where I was foolishly playing basketball, and my teacher summoned me from the window.

headline: Who Made That Nigerian Scam?
abstract: Those all-caps messages from Lagos in your spam folder actually predate email.
lead_paragraph: The Nigerian scam may seem like a scourge of the Internet age, but it actually predates email. Before we started getting all-caps proposals in our inboxes, con men in West Africa plied their trade by fax and paper letter. Some of the first scams to make their way to Western Europe arrived by telex in 1989 and 1990, when businessmen in Britain started hearing that a wayward tanker of Nigerian crude could have its cargo claimed for bargain prices — in exchange, of course, for some cash upfront. Before then, Nigerian fraudsters aimed their grifts at locals. One scheme was the “wash-wash,” a literal money-laundering in which the mark is shown a valise of supposed bills blackened with Vaseline and iodine and promised a cut if he pays for an expensive cleaning agent.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Rob Ford, the Best Mayor Ever
abstract: The notorious mayor of Toronto is running for re-election.
lead_paragraph: Rob Ford, the notorious mayor of Toronto who admitted to having smoked crack cocaine “probably in one of my drunken stupors,” is running for re-election.

headline: Food, Genes and the Feeling of Risk
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Food', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Labeling and Labels', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: A writer focused on sustainable eating gives a mostly clean bill of health to GMO’s. So what?
lead_paragraph: Updated below, Jan. 4, 4:57 p.m. | Six months ago, Nathanael Johnson, the author of “All Natural” and food blogger for Grist, an unabashedly liberal website, took on the task of digging deep on the risks and rewards of genetic modified organisms in agriculture. Grist summarized the results this way:

headline: Man on Fire
abstract: A search for the roots of Richard Pryor’s genius opens with a horrific incident.
lead_paragraph: The brothers David Henry and Joe Henry (the former a screenwriter and the latter a songwriter and singer) open this unorthodox paean to the legendary comedian Richard Pryor with a brief description of one of the most horrific incidents in their subject’s life.

headline: Richard Pryor, Thespian
abstract: The comedian didn’t think he could act, but others disagreed.
lead_paragraph: This week, Mel Watkins reviews “Furious Cool,” the new book about Richard Pryor by the brothers Joe and David Henry.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE TRIP TO ECHO SPRING: On Writers and Drinking,  by Olivia Laing. (Picador, $26.) A charming and gusto-driven look at the alcoholic insanity of six famous authors, among them Hemingway, Fitzgerald and Cheever.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: TOMBSTONE: The Great Chinese Famine, 1958-1962,  by Yang Jisheng. Translated by Stacy Mosher and Guo Jian. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $17.) Yang, a historian and veteran journalist in Beijing, estimates that 36 million Chinese starved to death during the Great Leap Forward. A landmark study of the disaster and the delusions and cruelties of Communist Party leaders, “Tombstone” is also a memorial for the uncle who raised Yang like a son and died of starvation in 1959.

headline: Cities
abstract: New books by Sudhir Venkatesh, Anthony M. Townsend, Lyanda Lynn Haupt, and Rebecca Solnit and Rebecca Snedeker.
lead_paragraph: FLOATING CITY  A Rogue Sociologist Lost and Found in New York’s Underground Economy  By Sudhir Venkatesh  Penguin Press, $27.95.

headline: A Ramshackle Modernity
abstract: A newly translated novel by a Turkish master satirizes his country’s 20th-century transformation.
lead_paragraph: We’re having a particularly good season for literary discoveries from the past, with recent publications of Volumes 1 and 2 of Ahmad Faris al-Shidyaq’s “Leg Over Leg” (1855), the marathon translation of Giacomo Leopardi’s 2,600-page “Zibaldone” (1898) and now “The Time Regulation Institute” (1962), the second great novel from Ahmet Hamdi Tanpinar. They arrive, such books, in a category all their own, in one sense new, in another sense old, as if to remind us that this thing called literature is much larger than our own little moment.

headline: Heal Thyself
abstract: A memoir examines the advice and improvement industry.
lead_paragraph: It’s ingrained in human nature to look at ourselves with a weary awareness of all that’s wrong within, and the optimism that someone, somewhere can tell us how to fix it. As Jessica Lamb-Shapiro points out in her ambitious if unfulfilling new memoir-cum-odyssey, “Promise Land,” we’ve been gobbling up self-help advice for nearly as long as the written word has existed, devouring it in the ancient Egyptian Sebayt writings and the Book of Proverbs. But our contemporary mania for the wisdom of Dr. Phil is different from what generations past gleaned from Epictetus or even Dale Carnegie, and Lamb-Shapiro aims to explain how. Along the way, she’s on a quest to fix herself.

headline: Regret to Inform
abstract: A military wife confronts the death of her husband.
lead_paragraph: One covets a gold star as a small child (chores done!), a student (great work!), an entrepreneur (superior service!). For a military spouse, however, gold star status is anathema, for it is a gold star, edged in blue and floating on a field of white bordered in red, that forms the flag indicating a family member has died during service. A gold star wife, like the author Artis ­Henderson, is a widow.

headline: The Brainteaser
abstract: Martin Gardner immersed himself in philosophy, religion and literature, even as he made a career of his fascination with science.
lead_paragraph: You can construct a Möbius strip from a piece of paper. You cut a strip, say, an inch wide and two feet long, twist one end 180 degrees, and join that to the other end with rubber cement. You now hold a physical paradox: If you trace a pencil line continuously down the middle of your strip, you end up with one continuous line down the middle of both sides. This proves that the paper has only one side, even though, when you pinch it between your fingers, you can feel both sides at the same time. Your intellect collides with your senses, and the result, if you are Martin Gardner, is inspiration.

headline: Mummy Dearest
abstract: An English aristocrat with vicious parents, a dead older brother and an enigmatic story.
lead_paragraph: Is it possible nowadays for otherwise intelligent Americans to reflect on England without thinking first of “Downton Abbey”? To put it another way: Can beleaguered American publishers expect to sell any English author without promising — however absurdly — a tie-in with Julian Fellowes’s opulent confection? I wonder. But in the case of Catherine Bailey’s stylish new book about one of England’s grandest dynasties, the link proves apt.

headline: Bad Marks
abstract: Inflation was only one of Weimar Germany’s economic woes.
lead_paragraph: Frederick Taylor’s “The Downfall of Money” promises, on its jacket, to deliver “an economic horror story.” A horror it was: We’ve all seen the photos from Germany with the wheelbarrows full of cash or the children playfully stacking bricks of worthless bills (by late 1923 the mark had deteriorated from a value of 4.2 to the dollar in 1914 to over 4 trillion). The monetary crisis was so traumatic that to this day, it renders the German people thoroughly allergic to price increases.

headline: Beautiful Minds
abstract: Darrin M. McMahon explores the concept of genius.
lead_paragraph: What does the genius have that the rest of us lack? What is that special “something” that sets him apart? That’s easy. It’s a little spirit, or daimonion, that takes over his mind, like the one that possessed Socrates. Or perhaps it has something to do with the birthday god that shapes a man’s personality, like the genius (from the Latin for “to beget”) who watched over Augustus Caesar.

headline: The Spy Who Came Into the Fold
abstract: A former C.I.A. lawyer is full of praise for the agency and its staff.
lead_paragraph: The main thing to know about “Company Man,” John Rizzo’s memoir of his three decades as a C.I.A. lawyer, including seven years as the agency’s chief legal officer, is that its title is not the slightest bit ironic.

headline: You Wouldn’t Want to Live There
abstract: “USA Noir” is an anthology of stories shrewdly culled from dozens of volumes of regional crime fiction published since 2004 under the “Noir” banner.
lead_paragraph: All the heavy hitters, from Michael Connelly in Los Angeles to Joyce Carol Oates in suburban New Jersey, came out for USA NOIR (Akashic, cloth, $29.95; paper, $16.95), an important anthology of stories shrewdly culled by Johnny Temple, Akashic’s editor in chief, from dozens of volumes of regional crime fiction published since 2004 under the “Noir” banner. Although there’s hardly a dud in the pack, some do elbow their way to the front.

headline: Greener Pastures
abstract: Charles Montgomery melds urban design and the science of happiness in this globe-trotting exploration of city living.
lead_paragraph: One of the most remarkable developments in social science in the past decade has been the emergence of happiness as a subject of serious scholarship and experimental study. This has been largely the work of behavioral economists, many of them psychologists by training, who have set out to investigate the everyday decisions people make and the repercussions those choices have on their future lives.

headline: The Year in Jazz
abstract: Ben Ratliff and Nate Chinen discuss the notable artists and themes in jazz in 2013.
lead_paragraph: Ben Ratliff and Nate Chinen discuss the notable artists and themes in jazz in 2013.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Donna Tartt and other authors of the Book Review’s Best Books of 2013 share their favorite reading experience from the year recently ended.
lead_paragraph: Best of the Best, Part II: Last week, this space featured reading recommendations from some of the authors of the Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2013, and promised more to come. Here now, a promise kept.

headline: Movie Review: '47 Ronin'
abstract: The Times critic Nicolas Rapold reviews "47 Ronin."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Nicolas Rapold reviews "47 Ronin."

headline: Movie Review: ‘Grudge Match’
abstract: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews "Grudge Match."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews "Grudge Match."

headline: Banksy Works Defaced Near Site of Sundance Festival
abstract: Two graffiti works by Banksy, the anonymous British artist, were defaced by an unknown vandal in Park City, Utah.
lead_paragraph: It may be time for Banksy, the anonymous British graffiti artist, to consider television. A sitcom, perhaps, or a detective show, or maybe reality TV. His politically pointed satirical stencil works seem to be everywhere in Britain and the United States, after all, and things are always happening to them.

headline: Jos. A. Bank Amends Its Poison Pill
abstract: The company reduced the ownership threshold of its shareholder rights plan to 10 percent from 20 percent, matching a similar plan at Men’s Wearhouse.
lead_paragraph: Jos. A. Bank Clothiers tightened its poison pill requirements on Friday, the latest move in its continuing takeover battle with Men’s Wearhouse.

headline: Movie Review: 'Lone Survivor'
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Lone Survivor."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "Lone Survivor."

headline: Two Who Got 2013 Right See 2014 as Much the Same
keywords: ['United States Economy', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Widespread optimism about the stock market, the economy, and corporate profits, but pessimism when it comes to the bond market.
lead_paragraph: After a banner year for stocks and a rocky one for bonds, market forecasters are remarkably consistent in their forecasts for 2014: more of the same.

headline: Justices Are Asked to Reject Nuns’ Challenge to Health Law
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Nuns', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The Justice Department said the requirements for birth control coverage did not impose a “substantial burden” on an order of Roman Catholic nuns who challenged them.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration urged the Supreme Court on Friday to reject a lawsuit filed by the Little Sisters of the Poor, an order of Roman Catholic nuns challenging requirements for many employers to provide health insurance coverage for birth control or face penalties under the new health care law.

headline: Carjacker Steals Truck From Owner Shoveling Snow in West Village
abstract: The owner was the superintendent of an apartment building who had left the keys in the ignition.
lead_paragraph: The superintendent of an apartment building in the West Village was carjacked Friday morning as he was shoveling snow, the police said.

headline: Football, War and the Workplace
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Football', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Sports Injuries', 'Veterans', 'Workplace Environment']
abstract: The National Football League and the United States military should be more honest about the high risks associated with their workplaces, Tony Schwartz writes in his Life@Work column.
lead_paragraph: I spend my days trying to make workplaces more humane, but recently I’ve been thinking a lot about why people would voluntarily choose to work in one that is dangerous, debilitating and often lethal. Actually, I have two in mind.

headline: Times Minute | Scenes From the Snowstorm
abstract: Also on the Minute, deadly clashes in Cambodia and yoga before it was trendy.
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, deadly clashes in Cambodia and yoga before it was trendy.

headline: Apartment for Sale, Taste Included
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Home Repairs and Improvements']
abstract: Homes with quirky renovations can be a tough sell, even if impeccably crafted.
lead_paragraph: Cindy Gallop lives in a black lacquer box of a loft. The walls and ceiling are painted glossy black. There is black carpeting galore, black cabinetry in the kitchen, black mosaic tile in the master bath, and a black curtain closing off the sleeping area. The singular look is courtesy of the specific instructions she gave her design team for the 3,800 square feet of raw space she bought a decade ago: “When night falls I want to feel I’m in a Shanghai nightclub” — the Glamour Bar, to be precise, where her desire to live in that kind of space crystallized as she sipped her second martini.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Chang-rae Lee
abstract: This week, Chang-rae Lee discusses his latest novel, “On Such a Full Sea”; Victoria Wilson talks about her new biography of Barbara Stanwyck; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Chang-rae Lee discusses his latest novel, “On Such a Full Sea”; Victoria Wilson talks about her new biography of Barbara Stanwyck; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Times Minute | Scenes From the Snowstorm
abstract: Also on the Minute, deadly clashes in Cambodia and yoga before it was trendy.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘On Such a Full Sea’
abstract: This week, Chang-rae Lee and Victoria Wilson.
lead_paragraph: This week, Chang-rae Lee and Victoria Wilson.

headline: Popcast: The Year in Jazz
abstract: Ben Ratliff and Nate Chinen discuss the year in jazz.
lead_paragraph: This week, starting from the top of our Top 10 lists and moving downward and outward, Nate Chinen and I look back on jazz in 2013.

headline: The Gun Report: January 3, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Mass shootings have tripled in recent years, from five a year between 2000 and 2008 to 16 a year from 2009 to 2012, according to a new study obtained by Yahoo! News yesterday. The authors, who are from the Advanced Law Enforcement Rapid Response Training Center at Texas State University, define mass shootings as incidents where a gunman opens fire in a public place with the motivation of killing many.

headline: In Your Ears: Covering Peter Gabriel
abstract: David Byrne, Randy Newman and others describe how and why they chose the Peter Gabriel songs they cover on “And I’ll Scratch Yours.”
lead_paragraph: The original plan, Peter Gabriel explained, was for two records to be released simultaneously: one of him singing songs that other artists had written, and another consisting of those same performers interpreting songs of his. “Scratch My Back,” with Mr. Gabriel singing and an orchestra backing him, was released in 2010, but “And I’ll Scratch Yours” is only coming out this week. So why the delay?

headline: Shoring Up Hamptons Beaches, and Prices, Too
abstract: A beach-erosion project underway in the Hamptons will help buffer homes from storms and also shore up prices.
lead_paragraph: Though waterfront usually sells at a premium, sometimes real estate prices in the Hamptons ebb and flow with the shifting sands. In Sagaponack, for instance, the price on Billy Joel’s four-bedroom six-bath shingle-style home with 145 feet of sandy beach was raised to $23.5 million recently, from $16.75 million in 2012.

headline: Big Ticket | Two Faces of Luxury, $15.5 Million Each
abstract: Two properties, built in different centuries and similar only in their abundance of luxury amenities, tied as the most expensive residential sales of the week.
lead_paragraph: In a photo finish for the most expensive residential sale in the final week of 2013, the two winning properties, built in different centuries and in different genres, are similar only in their abundance of luxury amenities. An impeccably renovated Upper East Side townhouse and a two-bedroom condominium at the predictably prestigious 15 Central Park West both traded for $15.5 million, according to city records.

headline: Not Quite All Spoonfuls of Sugar
abstract: Tom Hanks and Emma Thompson play Walt Disney and P. L. Travers, the author of “Mary Poppins,” in “Saving Mr. Banks,” which delves into the history of the movie.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 50 years, moviegoers have embraced “Mary Poppins” as a whimsical Disney classic about a magical English nanny, a twinkly chimney sweep and a London banker’s fractured family. But the new Disney film “Saving Mr. Banks,” written by Kelly Marcel and Sue Smith, shares two less cheerful tales. In flashback, it reveals the “Mary Poppins” author P. L. Travers’s sad past as an Australian girl with a hard-drinking father and a suicidal mother. The other story is of two weeks in 1961 when Walt Disney (Tom Hanks), who had been trying to secure the film rights from Ms. Travers (Emma Thompson) for nearly 20 years, finally lured her to California, where Disney staff composers, the Sherman Brothers (Jason Schwartzman and B. J. Novak), struggled to collaborate with her.

headline: Storm Shows Off a Less Stoic Mayor Now in Charge
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio, who took office Wednesday, was by turns joking and serious, assertive and playful in public appearances, far different from the gravity of his predecessor.
lead_paragraph: He trudged out with a shovel soon after sunrise, scraping the snow from his sidewalk and reminding New Yorkers to “lift with your knees.”

headline: Are Sugary Drinks Fattening? Depends Who You Ask
abstract: Studies paid for by beverage industry groups came to different conclusions than studies with no conflicts of interest, a new analysis found.
lead_paragraph: Are there good scientific studies that show that drinking sugar-sweetened soda increases the risk for obesity? The answer may vary depending on who is paying for the study.

headline: Knowing When to Compromise
abstract: A closer look at parking spaces, home inspections and questionable renovations.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a new weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Diving Into the Wreck
abstract: Chang-rae Lee discusses his new novel, “On Such a Full Sea.”
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Andrew Sean Greer reviews Chang-rae Lee’s new novel, “On Such a Full Sea.” Mr. Greer writes:

headline: Music Becomes a Real Game Changer
abstract: With The Banner Saga, “game music turns the player into a co-storyteller,” says the composer Austin Wintory.
lead_paragraph: The composer Austin Wintory’s office in Burbank, Calif., contains a desk, a chair and a life-size model of R2-D2. A windowless adjoining room, with an electric piano and two computers, is where Mr. Wintory, 29, says he spends up to 14 hours a day working on his music.

headline: A Makeover for the Affinia 50 in New York
abstract: A renovation of the Affinia 50 in New York is intended to have guests feel as if they are staying in a stylish apartment.
lead_paragraph: Affinia 50, a 10-year-old hotel property in Manhattan’s Midtown East neighborhood, has undergone a $20 million transformation. The 10-month renovation included an overhaul of the 251 guest rooms and public areas like the lobby, corridors and second-floor Club Room, which is a social space for guests.

headline: Divining a 5-Year Investment Strategy
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Stocks and Bonds', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'United States Economy']
abstract: Experts weigh in on where the economy is heading and what kind of strategies investors may want to explore.
lead_paragraph: FIVE years ago, it would have been easy to predict that the stock market would be higher today than it was then. But no one would have paid attention. Stocks were in a free fall and wouldn’t hit bottom for two more months.

headline: ‘It’s Just How He Carries Himself’
abstract: Chiwetel Ejiofor’s eyes and the way he carried himself made him the director Steve McQueen’s first choice for the lead role in “12 Years a Slave.”
lead_paragraph: A year before the actor Chiwetel Ejiofor, born in England to a Nigerian immigrant family, began filming “12 Years a Slave,” he was in Savannah, Ga., making another movie when he signed up for a tour of the city. One stop left a deep impression on him: a 19th-century slave pen, used to hold newly arrived Africans before they were sent to auction, and had, he recalled, “a sequence of bolts high on the wall.”

headline: Barberry and Orange Tea
abstract: A delicious drink made with sour, zingy, vitamin C-rich dried fruit.
lead_paragraph: I have in my pantry a rather large bag of dried barberries, bought at my Persian market, and I had been using them up slowly. Now I know where much of what remains of these sour, zingy vitamin C-rich dried fruits will go.

headline: Meyer Lemon and Ginger Infusion With Turmeric and Cayenne
abstract: You might want to reach for this tea if you feel a sore throat coming on.
lead_paragraph: There is a lot going on in this lovely infusion, with the tart lemon and pungent ginger. Turmeric contributes beautiful color, along with its nutritional benefits – it has been shown to have powerful anti-inflammatory and antioxidant attributes — and the tiny pinch of cayenne packs a small punch. If you feel a sore throat coming on I highly recommend this tea.

headline: Dried Apricot, Cherry and Cranberry Infusion
abstract: Simmering dried fruit with some sweet spices results in a great beverage for a snowy day.
lead_paragraph: Whenever I soak dried fruit in hot water, to plump it for another recipe, I am always reluctant to throw out the soaking water because it tastes so good. I decided to simmer dried fruit with sweet spices and orange to obtain a delicious infusion that I would decidedly not throw out. A great beverage for a snowy day.

headline: Coconut Ginger Tea With Lime, Honey and Turmeric
abstract: The smell of coconut inspired this infusion.
lead_paragraph: I love the fair trade teas produced by Zhena’s Gypsy Tea, especially her Coconut Chai. Inspired by the perfume of coconut in that tea, I infused shredded coconut and ginger and added a little fresh lime juice, honey and a smidgeon of turmeric. The idea of making a turmeric and honey paste comes from Heidi Swanson’s 101cookbooks.com.

headline: U.S. Winter Training Camp Tilts Toward M.L.S.
abstract: The call-ups for a national team training camp in January in Los Angeles included some notable names from Major League Soccer, such as Mike Magee, the league’s most valuable player.
lead_paragraph: Jurgen Klinsmann, the coach of the United States national soccer team, named a 26-man roster for the team’s January training camp on Friday, giving a mix of veterans and newcomers one last chance to make a case for a roster spot for next summer’s World Cup in Brazil.

headline: Is 2014 the Year of the Connected Home?
abstract: More people are adopting Internet-connected home devices, according to holiday gift trends and the news expected at the consumer electronics show next week, but analysts say they are still far from mainstream.
lead_paragraph: Tech companies have been talking for years about the so-called connected home, in which home appliances and accessories connect to the Internet. Judging from Christmas with my family — as well as the news expected at the International Consumer Electronics Show next week — this year it might become a reality.

headline: Justin Timberlake Album Was the Top Seller in a Diminished Market
abstract: Justin Timberlake’s album “The 20/20 Experience” was the top seller in 2013, a year in which album sales continued to fall.
lead_paragraph: The year-end chart news is mixed for Justin Timberlake. On the bright side, “The 20/20 Experience” (RCA), the comeback album he released in March, was the top selling album of 2013, according to Nielsen SoundScan.

headline: Back to the Future in Algeria
abstract: An appreciation of the architect Oscar Niemeyer.
lead_paragraph: The legacy of Oscar Niemeyer, the Brazilian architect who died in 2012 at the age of 104, is most familiarly seen in the Modernist buildings he designed for Brasilia, the planned city that became the country’s capital in 1960. But his work in Algeria — not nearly so well known — has also enhanced his reputation as one of the 20th century’s great architects. Niemeyer, a Communist who fled to France following the military takeover of Brazil in 1964, designed several buildings in Algeria in the late 1960s (as well as a library in recent years that is still being built). The plan for one, La Coupole, a sports arena in Algiers, which can be seen in the slide show here, was made on a napkin. Mekki Damerdji, an architect and professor in Algiers, says Mentouri University (shown here), in the city of Constantine, is a favorite of his for its stark contrast to the more traditional buildings that dominate the country’s landscape. “We’re not used to seeing this shape in our country,” Damerdji says. “We haven’t anything like this in Algeria. It’s very beautiful. It’s like a bird.” Julie Bosman

headline: What I Love | Jill and Jimmy Haber
abstract: The couple’s 25-foot-wide townhouse on the Upper East Side boasts six fireplaces and an indoor basketball court.
lead_paragraph: The couple’s 25-foot-wide townhouse on the Upper East Side boasts six fireplaces and an indoor basketball court.

headline: A Fine-Feathered Family Nest
abstract: The couple’s 25-foot-wide townhouse on the Upper East Side boasts six fireplaces and an indoor basketball court.
lead_paragraph: Jill and Jimmy Haber love every square inch of their five-story, 25-foot-wide townhouse on the Upper East Side. Brimming with pride and a palpable sense of contentment as they stand in their foyer with its welcoming fireplace, they worry only about whether to commence a visitor’s tour on the bottom or the top floor.

headline: Abortion Restrictions Passed by States
abstract: State legislatures enacted 70 restrictions on abortion in 2013; over the past three years, they passed more of these laws than they did from 2000 to 2010.
lead_paragraph: State legislatures enacted 70 restrictions on abortion in 2013; over the past three years, they passed more of these laws than they did from 2000 to 2010.

headline: In a Man’s Mind, Anything Goes
abstract: If you’re overwhelmed by the networks’ new series, GSN stands ready with a vacuous but often amusing new game show, “Mind of a Man.”
lead_paragraph: This is the week when television comes back to life after the holidays. New series like CBS’s “Intelligence” make their debuts. Shows that had their premieres this past fall, like “Marvel’s Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.” on ABC and “Almost Human” on Fox, start their “winter seasons”: i.e., new episodes after a spate of reruns. A few shows even have season finales, like CBS’s “Hostages.”

headline: Unemployed in Europe Stymied by Lack of Technology Skills
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Vocational Training', 'Science and Technology', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Thousands of jobs are languishing unfilled as many in the work force find that their skills are ill suited for posts in information technology.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Week after week, newspapers issue a stream of hopeful headlines: Microsoft, PayPal, Fujitsu and scores of other companies are expanding their investments in Ireland, creating thousands of jobs as unemployment hovers near record highs.

headline: Festival Opens With Soviet Tale
abstract: It seems apt that the New York Jewish Film Festival should open with a joke.
lead_paragraph: It seems apt that the New York Jewish Film Festival should open with a joke. This one, at the beginning of “Friends From France,” the opening-night film on Wednesday, goes like this:

headline: Captured in Time: A Certain New York
abstract: Unfettered optimism was the unofficial religion of the United States in the early 20th century, but the photographer Lewis Hine declined to buy in.
lead_paragraph: Unfettered optimism was the unofficial religion of the United States in the early 20th century, but the photographer Lewis Hine (1874-1940) declined to buy in, refused to be steamrollered by our natural cultural euphoria, as the retrospective “Lewis Hine” at the International Center of Photography clearly shows. The exhibition includes Hine’s earliest work, from Ellis Island (1905), and includes selections from his later major photographic essays, including those on immigration, child labor, working men and construction of the Empire State Building.

headline: Political Torment, Teenage Angst
abstract: Prototype: Opera/Theater/Now, an ambitious festival started in January 2013 by Beth Morrison Projects and the Here Arts Center, returns on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Prototype: Opera/Theater/Now, an ambitious festival started in January 2013 by Beth Morrison Projects and the Here Arts Center, returns on Wednesday for a second season, with four principal shows and a bevy of side attractions.

headline: Gems of Jazz for Winter’s Night
abstract: This year’s edition of Winter Jazz Festival runs five nights instead of two.
lead_paragraph: This year’s edition of Winter Jazz Festival runs five nights instead of two. It was already a significant jazz event in New York — now even more so. The first three nights are self-contained, concerts at Le Poisson Rouge and Town Hall: the drummer Bobby Previte’s all-star group, Terminals, on Tuesday; a head-to-head, double-piano concert involving Jason Moran, Robert Glasper and their various associates on Wednesday; and the Revive Big Band on Thursday.

headline: 20 Companies at Joyce and N.Y.U.
abstract: At the Association of Performing Arts Presenters meets in New York, one subject delegates are sure to ponder is the choosing of dance groups to present in coming months.
lead_paragraph: Every January, the Association of Performing Arts Presenters meets in New York, and one subject delegates are sure to ponder is the choosing of dance groups to present in coming months. No wonder dancers hope to attract attention by performing at conference time. Gotham Arts Exchange, which provides management assistance to artists, hopes to entice both presenters and the public with its Focus series at two theaters. Eight companies will appear at the Joyce Theater (opening Tuesday), and there will be 12 at the Skirball Center (opening Friday), with each performance offering at least two attractions.

headline: Stranded Antarctic Ship Story, Like the Ice, Will Not Let Go
abstract: The stranded ship Akademik Shokalskiy only had five days of food left when a Chinese helicopter rescued passengers. Now, the rescuers themselves may need to be rescued.
lead_paragraph: A team of rescuers from a Chinese icebreaker may need to be rescued themselves, soon after they plucked dozens of people from the Antarctic ice aboard a ship that had been stranded for more than a week.

headline: Duck Dynasty Diversifies
abstract: The Robertson clan is getting into guns.
lead_paragraph: Selling plain old duck calls — simple tools that lure prey with fake quacks — underpins the phenomenal financial success of “Duck Dynasty’s” Robertson clan, one of cable’s favorite families. Phil Robertson, the outspoken evangelical patriarch, got into trouble lately with some homophobic, fire-and-brimstone remarks, but after a brief suspension from the show, he was reinstated—in a fight between high-mindedness and ratings, ratings always win — and the duck calls kept selling by the millions. Actual hunters comprise a minority of sales, according to Willie Robertson, the family business executive who said most are bought by people who “put it on their desk and toot on it.”

headline: Writers Guild Unveils Picks for Screenplay Categories
abstract: The Writers Guild nominees include well-known names like David O. Russell, Woody Allen and Spike Jonze.
lead_paragraph: The Writers Guild of America has released its nominations for best screenplay. Here’s a quick look at its picks. Stay tuned for the Bagger’s analysis.

headline: Access to Abortion Falling as States Pass Restrictions
abstract: A surge in anti-abortion measures in more than half the states has made it far more difficult in many regions to obtain the procedure.
lead_paragraph: A three-year surge in anti-abortion measures in more than half the states has altered the landscape for abortion access, with supporters and opponents agreeing that the new restrictions are shutting some clinics, threatening others and making it far more difficult in many regions to obtain the procedure.

headline: AT&T Offers Customers Credit for Leaving T-Mobile
abstract: AT&T on Friday made an announcement aimed squarely at T-Mobile customers: If they switch to AT&T, they can receive up to $450 in credit to spend on devices or services.
lead_paragraph: Updated | This post now includes a statement from the chief executive of T-Mobile US.

headline: Daughter of Palestinian Envoy Killed in Czech Republic Suspects Foul Play
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Palestinians']
abstract: The daughter of Jamal al-Jamal, who was killed this week in an explosion at his home in Prague, said she believed he was murdered.
lead_paragraph: GAZA — The daughter of Jamal al-Jamal, 56, the Palestinian ambassador to the Czech Republic who was killed this week in an explosion at his home in Prague, said Friday that she believed he was murdered.

headline: World War II Bomb Kills One Person in Germany
abstract: A bulldozer operator set off the bomb during construction work in Euskirchen, near Bonn, the former capital, wounding at least 13 people.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The explosion of a World War II bomb in a town in western Germany killed one person and wounded at least 13 others on Friday, the police said.

headline: Momentum Builds for ‘Hustle’ and ‘Dallas’ as ‘Llewyn’ Lags
abstract: The Writers Guild nominees fleshed out the picture for awards watchers, with only “American Hustle” and “Dallas Buyers Clubs” among the contenders with nods from three guilds. Meanwhile, “Inside Llewyn Davis” was left off all three lists.
lead_paragraph: Not all Oscar-hopeful screenplays are eligible for the Writers Guild Awards: heavy hitters like “12 Years a Slave” and “Philomena” didn’t qualify (for lack of membership or other bureaucratic reasons), along with the indies “Short Term 12” and “Fruitvale Station.” But several of the top contenders for the Little Golden Guy got nods today from the guild. There were surprises like the inclusion of “Lone Survivor,” the director Peter Berg’s adaptation of a true story of a Navy SEAL mission gone terribly awry; and the omission of “Inside Llewyn Davis,” from the Coen brothers, whom the Writers Guild has favored before. (Perhaps the members were bothered by what the Coens themselves described as the film’s lack of a plot.)

headline: Court Grants Secrecy for Memo on Phone Data
keywords: ['Freedom of Information Act', 'Consumer Protection', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: A federal appeals court, endorsing a broad conception of executive branch secrecy, said the White House could withhold a Justice Department memo about the handing over of telephone records.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court on Friday ruled that the Obama administration may continue to withhold a Justice Department memo that apparently opened a loophole in laws protecting the privacy of consumer data.

headline: Israel and U.S. Test Interceptor Missile
abstract: The Israel and the United States carried out a second test of the advanced Arrow 3 antiballistic missile system over the Mediterranean Sea.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The missile defense agencies of Israel and the United States carried out a second test of the advanced Arrow 3 antiballistic missile system over the Mediterranean Sea on Friday, Israel’s Defense Ministry said in a statement.

headline: Questions About Inmates’ Holiday Food, Orange Cabs and Bogart’s Brooklyn Ties
keywords: ['Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Names, Geographical']
abstract: Answers to questions about the Christmas dinner at Rikers Island, the different color of some taxicabs and a Brooklyn street’s connection to Humphrey Bogart.
lead_paragraph: Q. Did the inmates at Rikers Island get a special Christmas dinner? I’m curious about the menu.

headline: Clip: 'Inside Llewyn Davis'
abstract: The song "Green Green Rocky Road" performed by Oscar Isaac in "Inside Llewyn Davis."
lead_paragraph: The song "Green Green Rocky Road" performed by Oscar Isaac in "Inside Llewyn Davis."

headline: Clip: 'Inside Llewyn Davis'
abstract: Oscar Isaac, Justin Timberlake and Adam Driver perform "Please Mr. Kennedy" in "Inside Llewyn Davis."
lead_paragraph: Oscar Isaac, Justin Timberlake and Adam Driver perform "Please Mr. Kennedy" in "Inside Llewyn Davis."

headline: Wooing Filmgoers Through Their Ears
abstract: The promoters of the film “Inside Llewyn Davis” have gone to extraordinary lengths in using the folk music at the movie’s center to attract audiences, woo Oscar voters and sell its soundtrack album.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the new film by Joel and Ethan Coen, a struggling folk singer, Llewyn Davis, plays a song for a music promoter. After listening intently, the promoter issues his review: “I don’t see a lot of money here.”

headline: Thrift Store Owner Finds His Calling and Salvation
abstract: Anthony Cody’s focus at his thrift shop is not on sales as much as on helping people, including homeless people and drug users.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Cody gained the nickname Tony Bargains after cleaning out a crack house on Boston Road in the Allerton section of the Bronx and opening Tony’s Bargain Basement Thrift Shop.

headline: A Lexicon of Instant Argot
abstract: Urban Dictionary has become a real-time archive for new and slang terms, particularly those that have risen because of social media and the web.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Millions watched and gossiped online as Miley Cyrus “twerked” on stage at MTV’s video music awards in late 2013. Then, they rushed to Urban Dictionary to figure out what that was — making “twerk” one of the most-searched terms on the site all year.

headline: Spinach Salad With Prosciutto
abstract: The addition of prosciutto, persimmon and croutons to a regular spinach salad makes light fare substantial enough for a full meal.
lead_paragraph: The addition of prosciutto, persimmon and croutons to a regular spinach salad makes light fare substantial enough for a full meal.

headline: Bradley, Former U.S. and Egypt Coach, Joins Norwegian Club
abstract: The two-year deal with Stabaek makes Bob Bradley, 55, the first American head coach of a top-tier European soccer team.
lead_paragraph: The career of Bob Bradley, the former national team soccer coach for the United States and Egypt, took another interesting turn on Friday when he was formally introduced as the manager of the Norwegian club Stabaek. The two-year deal makes Bradley, 55, the first American head coach of a top-tier European team.

headline: Obama Announces Gun Control Actions
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)']
abstract: Two new executive actions will make it easier for states to provide information about mentally ill individuals to the federal background check system.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:46 p.m. | HONOLULU — President Obama announced two new executive actions on Friday that nudge his gun control agenda forward by making it easier for states to provide information about people with mental illness to the federal background check system.

headline: An Artistic Armchair Travel Platform That Visits the World’s Most Amazing Places
abstract: Jungles in Paris, a new undertaking from two adventure-obsessed brothers, offers artistic examinations of subjects like the disappearance of the Aral Sea and the Japanese geisha tradition.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in rural Maine, the brothers Darrell and Oliver Hartman learned to love the outdoorsy, adventurous life from their dad, who was the director of the state’s parks. Trips in early adulthood to places like Greece, Nicaragua and India ensured their passion for wanderlust, as did the jobs they pursued: Darrell, 32, is a lifestyle and travel writer; Oliver, 30, is a director for the production company North. Last year, the pair decided to combine talents to create a website that celebrates the kind of travel they like to do.

headline: Chasing the Northern Lights in Alaska
abstract: A frosty family trip in pursuit of the aurora borealis slides between watching and waiting, panic and prayer.
lead_paragraph: We hurtled across the tundra in the dark. The old train chugged, rattled, occasionally whined. As the sun came up around 10 a.m., the world faded from black to cobalt to white and every shade between. All was snow; it was just a matter of how much, where, what shape. Black spruce trees draped in white rose up from the ground like crystals of hoarfrost.

headline: Traveling While Black
abstract: Exploring the many dimensions of what it’s like to see the world as a black traveler, from discovering liberation to experiencing healing.
lead_paragraph: As I walked through the Forbidden City, the majestic imperial palace at the center of Beijing, with a friend and her teenager, I scanned the crowd. In the maze of shrines and courtyards, there was no one quite like us: I am an African-American with long dreadlocks, and my friend, Maria, a Mexican-American, had her half-Dominican son in tow.

headline: A Big Salad That Stands In for Dinner
abstract: A big salad for dinner with the right proportions can be substantial and satisfying.
lead_paragraph: I’ve never been very good with New Year’s resolutions, especially the ones along juice-cleansing, teetotaling, diet-and-exercise lines. All those high expectations inevitably set me up to fail.

headline: Aloof Felines
abstract: Reverend Run, king of (sheet) rock; dual showering, considered.
lead_paragraph: Reverend Run, king of (sheet) rock; dual showering, considered.

headline: On the Market in the Region
abstract: A home in Fairfield, Conn., with views of inlets on Long Island Sound; and one in Manalapan, N.J., with a heated pool and a hot tub.
lead_paragraph: A home in Fairfield, Conn., with views of inlets on Long Island Sound; and one in Manalapan, N.J., with a heated pool and a hot tub.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: A Greenwich Village apartment with built-ins; an East Village home with exposed brick; and a Brooklyn Heights condo with harbor views.
lead_paragraph: A Greenwich Village apartment with built-ins; an East Village home with exposed brick; and a Brooklyn Heights condo with harbor views.

headline: Clip: 'Another Day Another Time'
abstract: Oscar Isaac, Marcus Mumford and the Punch Brothers perform “Fare Thee Well” in the documentary “Another Day Another Time,” which celebrates the music of “Inside Llewyn Davis.”
lead_paragraph: Oscar Isaac, Marcus Mumford and the Punch Brothers perform “Fare Thee Well” in the documentary “Another Day Another Time,” which celebrates the music of “Inside Llewyn Davis.”

headline: Cyberdeal Hits the Sweet Spot
abstract: FireEye’s acquisition of Mandiant combines two companies that are the best in their fields under the umbrella of a favorable takeover trend.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, the latest cybersecurity deal looks like a breach of logic. FireEye’s market value shot up by a third on Friday, a move worth $1.6 billion, more than it said it had spent to buy Mandiant. The deal marries FireEye’s threat protection with its target’s capabilities to respond to cyberattacks after they happen. Even with the industrial fit, the welcome from investors was unusually warm.

headline: Annual Sales for American Automakers Reach a 6-Year High
abstract: Automakers sold 15.6 million vehicles last year, the most since 2007, despite mixed results in the last month of the year.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — It was the best year for American auto sales since 2007, and among the biggest winners were the car companies from Detroit.

headline: Ballet Without Borders
abstract: At 45, the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky and his work have become internationally ubiquitous.
lead_paragraph: At 45, the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky and his work have become internationally ubiquitous.

headline: In Britain, Housing Prices Rise the Fastest Since 2006
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Prices rose 8.4 percent last year, the fastest pace since 2006, and mortgage approvals also hit a high level.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Housing prices in Britain rose last year at the fastest pace since 2006, adding to fears that the country’s real estate market is overheating.

headline: An App That Helps Users Cut Calories
abstract: CalCutter tries to help users find less caloric alternatives to their favorite recipes, but the app can be time-consuming to use with a specific focus on calories and not other factors.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s Department of Health and Mental Hygiene is proud of its technological prowess: The rotating banner of the agency’s home page features a link to the four smartphone apps that the agency has created. One of those apps, CalCutter, would seem a great download for this time of year, both to celebrate the now-concluded tenure of that most health-conscious of mayors and to aid in that ubiquitous resolution for a healthier diet.

headline: The de Blasios: A Simple Outfit
abstract: At Bill de Blasio’s inauguration, the clothes he and his family wore did not steal any scenes. That’s one of many signals sent by the new mayor.
lead_paragraph: Inaugurations are a bit like weddings in that clothing choices on the in-law side are suddenly and harshly on display. So that’s what they look like?

headline: Bundling Up With Lamb
abstract: A tagine is a warming Moroccan stew, with shank meat and dates, onions and a spice mixture with just enough cayenne.
lead_paragraph: This is not the season for roast lamb. Wouldn’t you rather have a warming stew during these bitterly cold days?

headline: British Company Names Year’s Best Album Covers
abstract: In a prize based on online voting, Art Vinyl, a British company that makes frames for record covers, named “Big TV” by the band White Lies the year’s best album art.
lead_paragraph: Music collectors have long lamented the effect that miniaturization – the move from 12-inch LP jackets to 5.75-inch CD booklets, and then to thumbnail photos on digital downloads – has had on record jacket art. But Art Vinyl, a British company that makes frames for record covers, has been encouraging performers and collectors to think more carefully about cover art since 2005, when it established its annual Best Art Vinyl award, with the winners chosen through online voting.

headline: Williams Continues Dominance of Sharapova
abstract: In an unusual early-season meeting, No. 1 Serena Williams defeated Maria Sharapova in the semifinals of the Brisbane International on Friday.
lead_paragraph: BRISBANE, Australia — Defying the conventional script, the two main characters in women’s tennis faced off in the first scene of the 2014 season.

headline: Steps Heard ’Round the World
abstract: At just 45, Alexei Ratmansky is making his mark as the most historically conscious choreographer alive, the most travel-hungry and the most prolific.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Alexei Ratmansky is 45. It’s safe to say that no choreographer in history at that age has made such pervasive inroads into the international ballet repertory. He has now created ballets for the leading companies of America, Australia, Britain, Canada, Denmark, France, Italy, the Netherlands and his native Russia. Most of those troupes, shopping around in the global supermarket of dance today, have also acquired other works of his. In 2013, he had no fewer than seven world premieres in five cities on three continents. It becomes increasingly evident that he is the most prolific choreographer alive, the most travel-hungry and the most historically conscious.

headline: Claire Danes’s Fashion Choices
abstract: Ms. Danes’s style includes clean shapes and flirty prints.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Danes’s style includes clean shapes and flirty prints.

headline: Arctic Temperatures for Players and Fans, but No Blackouts on TV
abstract: Frigid weather is making the N.F.L.’s first round of playoffs hard on fans traveling to games, but team sponsors bought big blocks of seats to avoid any TV blackouts.
lead_paragraph: The first winter storm of 2014 has largely come and gone, but it has left snow, frigid temperatures and untold delays in its wake. Caught in the mess are the thousands of N.F.L. players, fans and members of the news media trying to get to Cincinnati, Green Bay, Indianapolis and Philadelphia, where wild-card games will be played this weekend.

headline: On Journeys of Discovery, One Is Cut Short
abstract: Albums by Doe B, Sevyn Streeter, Burial, 7 Days of Funk and Lewis Watson.
lead_paragraph: Doe B

headline: How to Keep Your Resolutions
abstract: Four tips for keeping New Year’s resolutions, inspired by recent research on behavioral economics and health.
lead_paragraph: IT’S that time of year again. Maybe it’s your waistline you’re worried about, or maybe it’s the smoking habit you just can’t seem to kick. To improve your chances of keeping your New Year’s resolutions, we offer four tips inspired by recent research on behavioral economics and health. We focus on health, but our suggestions should help with other goals, too.

abstract: Subjects include a Police Department graduation ceremony, a new mayor and a police commissioner’s departure.
lead_paragraph: Subjects include a Police Department graduation ceremony, a new mayor and a police commissioner’s departure.
