keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Ponzi and Pyramid Schemes', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: George Canellos oversaw and closed some of the highest profile investigations into the financial crisis. His departure could portend a subtle shift in the agency’s enforcement agenda.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:08 p.m. |

headline: Family and Football, With a Few Audibles, for Music Executive
abstract: For Lyor Cohen, the former head of Def Jam Records who recently started a music company named 300, Sundays tend to revolve around the Green Bay Packers.
lead_paragraph: Since the 1980s, when Lyor Cohen was one of the young executives who helped establish the business infrastructure of hip-hop, he has been one of the music industry’s hardest-charging figures. The former head of Def Jam records and the recorded music division of the Warner Music Group, Mr. Cohen, 54, recently announced his new venture, a boutique music company named 300. But on weekends, he devotes himself to family — and football.

headline: Dazzling, on Screen and Off
abstract: Claire Danes, the Emmy-winning star of “Homeland,” showed styles ranging from seductive to chic to flirty in 2013.
lead_paragraph: WHO Claire Danes

headline: N.H.T.S.A Tells Child Seat Manufacturer to Conduct Recall; Chevrolet Pickups and Range Rovers Are Also Recalled
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Child Car Seats']
abstract: The company said that while the seats did not meet the federal safety standard, they were good enough to protect a child in a crash, an argument the agency rejected.
lead_paragraph: About 33,000 child safety seats are being recalled by Combi USA because the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration says the restraining straps could break during a crash. The recall comes after the safety agency rejected Combi’s request that it be excused from a recall because the failure to meet the federal safety standard was “inconsequential to motor vehicle safety.”

headline: More About Jerry Goodman
abstract: Random notes.
lead_paragraph: I see that Bloomberg has an obit up; still waiting on the Times. I’m not going to do a proper life, just say a few things.

headline: General Cleburne’s Radical Plan
abstract: Why one prominent Confederate leader wanted to enlist slaves as soldiers.
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 2, 1864, Gen. Joseph Johnston, the commander of the largest Confederate army outside Virginia, called an evening meeting of his subordinate generals in his headquarters in northwest Georgia. The purpose of the meeting was kept secret from all but a few. When they arrived, they found Gen. Patrick Cleburne, an Irish immigrant and one of Johnston’s best division commanders, who presented a radical proposal: to enlist slaves as rebel soldiers in exchange for their freedom.

headline: Videos of Fighters and Air Raids in Iraq’s Anbar Province
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Sunni Muslims']
abstract: Al Qaeda-affiliated groups battled security forces and tribal fighters in Anbar province.
lead_paragraph: Radical Sunni militants aligned with Al Qaeda fought for control of Falluja and Ramadi on Friday, escalating a battle over the two cities that have increasingly become centers of Sunni extremism since American forces withdrew from the country at the end of 2011.

headline: Evangelicals Find Themselves in the Midst of a Calvinist Revival
abstract: Increasing numbers of preachers and professors teach the views of the 16th-century French reformer John Calvin.
lead_paragraph: For those who are sad that the year-end news quizzes are past, here’s one to start 2014: If you have joined a church that preaches a Tulip theology, does that mean a) the pastor bakes flowers into the communion wafers, b) the pastor believes that flowers that rise again every spring symbolize the resurrection, or c) the pastor is a Calvinist?

headline: Bratton and Miller Back in Blue for Round 3
abstract: As New York City’s police commissioner, William J. Bratton will reunite with his friend and sidekick, John Miller, a prominent CBS News reporter.
lead_paragraph: Minutes after the news conference last month announcing that he would serve a second term as New York City’s police commissioner, William J. Bratton and a group of close friends sat down over rigatoni and meatballs at Ferdinando’s Focacceria, a subway-tiled Sicilian joint a few blocks from the docks in Red Hook, Brooklyn. The location and the lunch guests were classic Bratton. Gathered at a table in the back, under photos of Palermo and a stamped-tin ceiling, was a kind of kitchen cabinet: Mr. Bratton’s wife, his retired-detective bodyguards, some former aides from the Police Department, a few associates from his private security firm and the TV reporter John Miller.

headline: The Alien Hunter as Lounge Lizard
abstract: “Space Dandy,” an anime series on Adult Swim, created by Shinichiro Watanabe, features an intergalactic hunter of new types of aliens.
lead_paragraph: There’s plenty of reason to be curious, even excited, about “Space Dandy,” a new anime television series beginning on Adult Swim on Saturday night. Shinichiro Watanabe, credited as the show’s general director, is responsible for two of the best Japanese anime series to have made it to American TV in recent years, “Cowboy Bebop” (1998-99) and “Samurai Champloo” (2005-6). The animation studio behind it, Bones, has produced high-quality series like “Fullmetal Alchemist” and “Eureka Seven.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from New York, Indonesia, Egypt and Cambodia.
lead_paragraph: Photos from New York, Indonesia, Egypt and Cambodia.

headline: Dominant in Dome, Saints Face Tough Road as They Try to Defy Trends
abstract: New Orleans, which travels to play Philadelphia on Saturday, has never won a postseason road game, even in the previous seven years as one of the N.F.L.’s strongest teams.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — The New Orleans Saints’ victory over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in their final regular-season game Sunday featured their trademark passing game, key defensive stops and 70,000 rollicking fans fueled by brass bands and beer.

headline: Reclaiming Fatherhood After Afghanistan
abstract: After two combat tours in Afghanistan, an infantry rifleman readjusts to civilian life — and the paternal role he left behind.
lead_paragraph: During my enlistment, I had the privilege to serve as an infantry rifleman, the primary infantry job in the United States Marine Corps. My role was to locate, close with and destroy or repel the enemy, by fire and close combat. As I advanced through my career, I learned valuable teamwork, communication and leadership skills that I continue to use.

headline: A Circuitous Route to Outer Space
abstract: Alfonso Cuarón, the director of “Gravity” and “Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban,” has a reputation that rests on a small and eclectic body of work.
lead_paragraph: In a radio interview not long ago, Alfonso Cuarón compared his movies to ex-wives: He’s grateful, wishes them well, but has no desire to go back and visit. What he didn’t say, but could have, was that none of these wives bears much resemblance to any of the others.

headline: Ask About ‘The House Edge’
abstract: David Kocieniewski, a business reporter for The New York Times, and Gretchen Morgenson, an assistant business editor and columnist, are answering questions about their four-part series, The House Edge, which examined the challenges posed by Wall Street’s influence over markets and the prices consumers pay.
lead_paragraph: (Update: A post with the reporters’ replies has now been published.)

headline: Reprising a Lindberg: Same Cast, New Date
abstract: The New York Philharmonic is providing a chance to hear one of the 2011-12 season’s most prominent new works, Magnus Lindberg’s Piano Concerto No. 2.
lead_paragraph: For even the most successful and popular living composers, a truism exists: It’s much easier to secure a world premiere, with all the first-night appeal and media attention such an occurrence brings, than to gain a second performance of the same work, once the hubbub has faded. Even the most well-received contemporary piece can take some time to resurface, if, indeed, it ever does.

headline: Visual Portents of a Silent Bolt of Thunder
abstract: “There Will Never Be Silence,” an exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, examines the intersection of John Cage’s “4’33” ” with the work of contemporaneous visual artists.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 7, 1943, John Cage made his first New York public appearance at the Museum of Modern Art with a performance of percussion works that featured his wife, Xenia (whom he would divorce three years later), and Merce Cunningham (who would replace her as his life partner).

headline: Week in Pictures for Jan. 3
abstract: Watch a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a Police Department graduation ceremony, a new mayor and a police commissioner’s departure.
lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a Police Department graduation ceremony, a new mayor and a police commissioner’s departure.

headline: In Praise of Art Laffer
abstract: A surprisingly honest reply.
lead_paragraph: No, really. Business Insider contacted him about his 2009 warning that soaring inflation and interest rates were just around the corner — and he not only admits that he was wrong, he admits that his error signified something wrong with his overall economic model:

headline: Palestinian Teenager Dies of Wounds From Israeli Gunfire
abstract: The Israeli military said the teenager was one of a group of people who vandalized the fence between Israel and Gaza and ignored warnings to move back.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A Palestinian teenager died on Friday after being wounded by Israeli gunfire near the Israel-Gaza border a day earlier, according to medical officials in Gaza.

headline: Churro Shop Owner Serves Up a Spanish Tradition
abstract: Le Churro, on Lexington Avenue between 83rd and 84th Streets, offers a heady combination of fried dough flutes and hot chocolate for sweet lovers.
lead_paragraph: It was a singular procession that filed into Le Churro on Lexington Avenue between 83rd and 84th Streets one recent afternoon. Eyes wide, riveted on the menu hung high above the counter, children buckling under their backpacks and harried mothers all seemed transfixed by the weight of the decision: Chocolate or caramel sauce?

headline: Lightening the Load on an E.V.’s Batteries
abstract: When Nissan asked Bose for a sound system for the Leaf that would not impede the E.V.’s range, Bose designed a system that draws half the current of a conventional Bose stereo.
lead_paragraph: Small zero-emission city cars may have cute faces and small footprints, but they also pack more weight than you might expect, forcing engineers to come up with innovative diets.

headline: Electric Service From $199 a Month
abstract: Electric cars are getting cheaper, with the Chevrolet Spark E.V., Smart Electric Drive Cabriolet and Fiat 500e all available for lease at less than $240 a month.
lead_paragraph: Electric cars are getting cheaper. Although purchase prices vary, the Chevrolet Spark E.V. and Smart Electric Drive Cabriolet can be leased for three years at $199 a month, and the Fiat 500e at $239. That means consumers are likely to weigh factors other than the bottom line when deciding which — if any — of these small, stylish battery vehicles to put in their driveway.

headline: Cute, but Not Precious
abstract: The Fiat 500e, Chevrolet Spark and Smart Cabriolet, three tiny battery-powered urban runabouts, aren’t just fun, they’re fairly affordable.
lead_paragraph: The Fiat 500e, Chevrolet Spark and Smart Cabriolet, three tiny battery-powered urban runabouts, aren’t just fun, they’re fairly affordable.

headline: An Underground Portfolio
abstract: Patrick Cashin, a full-time photographer for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, has followed the building of transportation projects with his lens.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Cashin, a full-time photographer for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, has followed the building of transportation projects with his lens.

headline: A Night at the Opera, Lost in the Memory of Another
abstract: A New Year’s Eve at the Metropolitan Opera with a familiar conductor leads to thoughts of a cold, panicky evening in Michigan in 1985.
lead_paragraph: I was ready to end 2013 by looking in on a fancy New Year’s Eve party that was supposed to be unfolding in fin de siècle Vienna. The invitation was right there on a curtain that went up at the opening performance of the Metropolitan Opera’s new production of “Die Fledermaus.” But when the conductor walked into the pit and bowed, I was transported not to Vienna in 1899, but to Michigan in 1985.

headline: Bringing the Underworld to Light
abstract: Patrick Cashin, a full-time photographer for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, has followed the building of transportation projects with his lens.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Cashin, a full-time photographer for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, has followed the building of transportation projects with his lens.

headline: Qaeda-Linked Insurgents Clash With Other Rebels in Syria, as Schism Grows
abstract: The fighting punctuated a growing rift between seven homegrown rebel groups and a powerful Qaeda affiliate.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Deadly clashes were reported Friday in northern Syria between Sunni Islamist jihadists linked to Al Qaeda and insurgents in other alliances, punctuating a growing schism within the armed Syrian opposition over the power exerted by its religiously radicalized members, many of them from other countries.

headline: Love, the Universal Scenario
abstract: Excerpts from the original scripts of some Oscar contenders, with video clips from the films.
lead_paragraph: Enough Said

headline: Call Waiting ... and Waiting
keywords: ['Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Text Messaging', 'Social Media', 'E-Mail', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Telecommuting']
abstract: Those who work at home may go days without speaking a word aloud. For them, a bustling office consists of active Facebook and Twitter pages.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Kitsch, star of NBC’s “Friday Night Lights” and the new war movie “Lone Survivor,” doesn’t field many phone calls when he is in Austin, Tex., where he lives alone.

headline: German Politician’s Rush to Lobbying Brings Scorn
abstract: Ronald Pofalla, who ran the German chancellery, was reported to be taking a specially created lobbying post at the national rail network said to carry compensation of more than a million euros a year.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — If there is one hallmark of Angela Merkel’s chancellorship, it is that, despite her widely acknowledged tactical prowess and skill in winning, keeping and expanding her power, she is uninterested in the material trappings of office.

headline: Feeling For | The Ultimate Vintage E-Shop for Fashion Fanatics
abstract: On the recently launched Paris-based website RESEE, buyers can find designs from past seasons that they lusted after but let get away.
lead_paragraph: After the chaotic holiday months of planning the perfect gifts for others, it’s finally time to think about ourselves. For the fashion conscious, that means planning out your purchases for the upcoming season. But it’s hard to think of the future when you still haven’t crossed off dream items from wish lists of old, like, say those Balenciaga SS 2002 cargo pants or that black oversized Céline coat. Enter Resee, a website that helps track down coveted items that got away. Unveiled last fall by Sabrina Marshall, a former editor at Self Service magazine, and Sofia Bernardin, a Vogue advertising veteran, the secondhand e-shop specializes in vintage pieces by high-end designers like Alaïa, Hermès, Helmut Lang and Raf Simons. In addition to browsing the curated finds — sourced from some legendary sources, including the Paris vintage shop Nella, which gave Resee all its inventory when it closed last year, and the closets of some of the world’s most stylish women — guests can even fill out a virtual want ad for particularly elusive items. The site’s magazine-caliber design and photography is sure to suck you in for hours at a time — then send you forth into 2014 looking your very best.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Wonderland
abstract: Stylish yet sensible, New Yorkers bundled up, unrestricted by the dictates of fashion.
lead_paragraph: Stylish yet sensible, New Yorkers bundled up, unrestricted by the dictates of fashion.

headline: Not All the Days Were Good
abstract: At the Metropolitan Room, Stacy Sullivan’s cabaret show, “It’s a Good Day: A Tribute to Peggy Lee,” reveals that singer’s complexity.
lead_paragraph: The eye rolls, the swivel, the gowns and the platinum hair: The singer Peggy Lee has been parodied so often, especially by drag performers, that it is easy to confuse the caricature with the complicated pop-jazz singer who died 12 years ago this month. Sorting out the contradictions of Lee’s life and career, Stacy Sullivan’s show at the Metropolitan Room, “It’s a Good Day: A Tribute to Miss Peggy Lee,” paints an empathetic, melancholy portrait.

headline: A Sleeping Beauty of Ferraris
abstract: A rare 1967 Ferrari 330 GTS, hidden away for more than 40 years and that survived an engine fire in 1969, heads to auction in Arizona.
lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, CALIF. — After being knocked out of commission in 1969 by an engine fire and then spending the next 44 years hibernating in Pennsylvania, a graceful 1967 Ferrari 330 GTS will come under the glare of spotlights on Jan. 18 when it is auctioned in Scottsdale, Ariz.

headline: Fixes for Ticks, Clicks and Leaks
abstract: The latest technical service bulletins include Corvettes with oil problems and Audis that need new brake discs.
lead_paragraph: Audis needing new brake discs and Corvettes with low oil in their differentials are among the mechanical problems addressed in the latest technical service bulletins from automakers.

headline: Adventures in the Sub-Luxury Category
keywords: ['Oceans and Seas', 'Submarines and Submersibles', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: A California company has introduced a “sea flying” submersible craft that it says can dive to 120 meters, travel as fast as a cruising shark, and breach the surface like a whale. The craft is aimed at people with yachts, plus resorts.
lead_paragraph: In case Santa didn’t give you everything you wanted, there’s a new submarine in the water.

headline: Opening Champagne With a Saber at the Baroness
abstract: After a quick lesson, patrons at this Long Island City bar can open their bottles of bubbly in dramatic fashion.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of New Year’s Eve, one neighborhood bar was already celebrating — as usual. The Baroness, six weeks old, in a nearly 100-year-old building in Long Island City, was offering instruction in the French art of sabrage. That is to say, patrons could open their own Champagne bottles with a saber, after a quick lesson from Mélanie Lemieux, owner and sommelier.

headline: A Mixed Message From the Boy Scouts
abstract: The organization now allows openly gay scouts, but not openly gay troop leaders. That doesn’t make sense.
lead_paragraph: On New Year’s Day, the Boy Scouts of America began allowing openly gay boys to participate in its activities, while still prohibiting openly gay and lesbian adults from serving as troop leaders.

headline: The Power of Three
abstract: When trying to persuade, a study says, stop at three claims. Articles cited the recent deaths of Peter O’Toole, Tom Laughlin and Joan Fontaine as meaningfully connected.
lead_paragraph: THE GIST When trying to persuade, four claims are one too many.

headline: Bisexual: A Label With Layers
abstract: The announcement by the Olympic diver Tom Daley that he was dating a man but that he still liked women raised questions about the meaning of bisexuality.
lead_paragraph: “Of course I still fancy girls.”

headline: Bill Cunningham | Wonderland
abstract: See how New Yorkers braved the cold.
lead_paragraph: The holiday season ended with a blast of arctic air and several inches of snow, which hardly fazed the intrepid tourists in Times Square or the skaters at Rockefeller Center. Stylish yet sensible, New Yorkers bundled up, unrestricted by the dictates of fashion. The adventurous skied. The diligent shoveled. And winter showed its beauty, as in Bryant Park, where cascades of ice turned the fountain into art.

headline: De Blasio’s Next Task Is Turning Passion Into Policy
abstract: Liberals were excited about the mayoral win of one of their own, Bill de Blasio, but he has yet to crystallize his agenda.
lead_paragraph: A week after his election, the mayor-elect, a tall crane of a man, edged into a low-ceilinged conference room in Downtown Brooklyn to celebrate the city’s progressive movement and its progressive victory, which happened to be his own.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Facebook Privacy and Sharks on Twitter
abstract: Friday’s highlights from around the web include looks at the National Security Agency’s efforts to crack all encryption, why people skills — not only computer skills — are important for founders of start-ups and a shark-tracking by Twitter post.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: The Woody Allen Genome
abstract: An attempt, based on the emerging science of free-associative DNA testing, to establish a comprehensive Woody Allen genealogy.

headline: Inside the Tale of North Korea Execution by Ravenous Dog
abstract: Western news media pick up an old report that for the South Korean press, it seems, was too sensational.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:07 p.m. | BEIJING — There is no end to shocking stories from North Korea, many involving the myriad cruelties of the brutal police state as reported by defectors. But the latest tale — a news media report that the young North Korean leader might have had his uncle torn apart by ravenous dogs while he watched — may say less about the North than what outsiders have come to expect of it.

headline: At Lincoln Center, a Marriage (but Not for Figaro)
abstract: A couple promised their parents a special kind of show, the outcome was a surprise wedding.
lead_paragraph: By the time they decided to marry, neither Kristin Koslowski nor Holt Wilkins saw much appeal in a traditional wedding, particularly the part that often calls for spending a year in planning for that single day.

headline: Once Labeled a Traitor, Korean Aims to Be a Hero
abstract: Hong Yoon-hee, whose 1950 treason conviction in South Korea was recently nullified, says, “The truth is I helped save South Korea during one of its most critical times.”
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — HONG YOON-HEE had an extraordinary tale to tell, to anyone who would listen, about how he risked his life trying to save South Korea during a pivotal moment in the Korean War but was then condemned to death and had to flee to the United States.

headline: Liz Goldwyn: Making a Name for Herself
abstract: Just because she’s a Goldwyn does not mean she’s a moviemaker. For her, film, fashion and art overlap.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Gala in the Garden, a benefit given every October by the Hammer Museum here, draws a reliably motley cross section of this city’s art, fashion and film tribes. While those contingents mingled last fall on the museum’s third-floor balcony with some of the stiffness of the jocks, brains and beauties mixing at a high school dance, one guest navigated the crowd as effortlessly as a prom queen.

headline: Preparing for Coldest Weather in 20 Years
abstract: The National Weather Service warns people to prepare for “dangerously cold temperatures” in the coming days.
lead_paragraph: After digging out from a winter storm that disrupted air travel across the country and created treacherous road conditions, people from the Upper Midwest to New England are now preparing for the coldest weather they have experienced in years.

headline: Schools Chancellor Brings Joyful and Fierce Style
abstract: Carmen Fariña, a 40-year veteran of the city school system, gained a reputation as a stern manager. Ms. Fariña will lean on her experience in her new role.
lead_paragraph: Late in the afternoon of New Year’s Eve, Carmen Fariña was preparing to have 10 people over to dinner, a plan, she joked, she wouldn’t have made had she known that the next day would mark the beginning of her tenure as the city’s new schools chancellor. Perhaps out of a subliminal sense of premonition or foresight, or just grandmotherly efficiency, she had arranged for a caterer.

headline: Times Minute | Displaced in South Sudan
abstract: Also on the Minute, the latest on contraception and the Affordable Care Act, and the marketing of "Inside Llewyn Davis."
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, the latest on contraception and the Affordable Care Act, and the marketing of "Inside Llewyn Davis."

headline: Times Minute | Displaced in South Sudan
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Movies', 'Nuns', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Also on the Minute, the latest on contraception and the Affordable Care Act, and the marketing of “Inside Llewyn Davis.”
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Sending Artworks Home, but to Whom?
abstract: The Denver Museum of Nature and Science will return 30 totems to the National Museums of Kenya, which will decide whether to search for their owners.
lead_paragraph: The paleontologist Richard Leakey has called their removal a “sacrilege.” Kenyan villagers have said their theft led to crop failure and ailing livestock. It is little wonder, then, that the long, slender wooden East African memorial totems known as vigango are creating a spiritual crisis of sorts for American museums. Many want to return them, but are not finding that so easy.

headline: Quick, Get the Camera: Fido’s Levitating
abstract: “The Marked Ones,” the fifth film in the “Paranormal Activity” franchise, aims for a new market with the same special effects.
lead_paragraph: The “Paranormal Activity” franchise aims straight at its Latino fan base with the fifth installment of the series, “The Marked Ones,” and the changes — goodbye, white suburbia; hello, gritty diversity — recharge the batteries somewhat. But there’s no escaping that the found-footage phenomenon has gone from fresh and original to just plain annoying.

headline: Liberty Media Seeks Full Ownership of Sirius XM
abstract: Liberty proposed on Friday to acquire the 48 percent of Sirius it does not already own in an all-stock deal valued at more than $10 billion.
lead_paragraph: Liberty Media already controls Sirius XM. Now, it wants to own the entire company.

headline: Fear Keeps Thousands of South Sudanese on the Run
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: People trying to escape the conflict described scenes where former friends are targeting one another.
lead_paragraph: AWERIAL, South Sudan — As the city of Bor fell into chaos, Lual Alier watched a fellow teacher pick up a Kalashnikov rifle and kill a shopkeeper. Then the man turned and began firing at him, too.

headline: Fleeing the Bombs in Aleppo, Syria, and Ending Up in New Jersey
abstract: A Syrian family is in the vanguard of what is expected to be a small but gradually growing stream of refugees from the country’s war resettling in the United States this year.
lead_paragraph: PATERSON, N.J. — They had heard the bombs before, but never this close. They gathered whatever was at hand — a purse, a bag containing their passports — ran out of their house in Aleppo, in northern Syria and headed on foot to a quieter neighborhood. There, they figured, they would wait out the fighting and return home.

headline: Sunday A/X Pairs at Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional
abstract: The winners of the Sunday A/X Pairs at the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Manhattan last Sunday were Janet and R. Jay Becker of New York City.
lead_paragraph: The winners of the Sunday A/X Pairs at the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Manhattan last Sunday were Janet and R. Jay Becker of New York City. They were one day shy of celebrating their first wedding anniversary.

headline: Syrians Protest Assad and Islamist Militants
abstract: Video and images posted online by Syrian activists appeared to show that anti-Islamist protesters took to the streets in the city of Aleppo and in rural areas near the Turkish border on Friday.
lead_paragraph: As my colleagues Hwaida Saad and Rick Gladstone report, Syrian opposition activists said that an alliance of seven rebel groups launched attacks across northern Syria on Friday against the jihadist militants who call themselves the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, or ISIS — a powerful Qaeda affiliate that includes foreign fighters.

headline: Make a Resolution to Budget? Here Are Some Apps to Help
abstract: Several applications are available to help consumers set up a budget and track their income and expenditures.
lead_paragraph: There’s something brilliant, but also insidious, about services like Amazon Prime, where you don’t have to reach for your credit card to pay. Spending is painless.

headline: A Cult Motorcycle From India Takes On the World
keywords: ['Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: With models like the Bullet, an Indian-made avatar of an old British brand, Royal Enfield is making waves even as the competition for midsize bikes is heating up.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI, India — The Royal Enfield Bullet, often described as the oldest continuously produced motorcycle in the world, is a cult product for enthusiasts who love it for its vintage feel as much as for the thrum of its engine.

headline: Video and Images of the Crisis in South Sudan
abstract: Thousands have fled their homes in recent days as fighting between forces loyal to President Salva Kiir’s government have fought against a rebellion led by his former vice president.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Nicholas Kulish reported, thousands of South Sudanese have fled their homes in recent days as fighting between forces loyal to the government of President Salva Kiir have fought against a rebellion led by his former vice president, Riek Machar, plunging the young nation into chaos.

headline: Words to Banish From the New Year
abstract: Readers respond to a column by Timothy Egan about trite words.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Let It Snow
abstract: The first snowstorm of 2014 left nearly a foot of slush in some neighborhoods Friday, with freezing wind. As snowplows cleared roads, there were subway delays, but many New Yorkers made it to work.
lead_paragraph: The first snowstorm of 2014 left nearly a foot of slush in some neighborhoods Friday, with freezing wind. As snowplows cleared roads, there were subway delays, but many New Yorkers made it to work.

headline: Testimony of the National Intelligence Director
abstract: Robert S. Litt of the Office of the Director of National Intelligence responds to an editorial.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Future of Broadband
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: Mark Cooper of the Consumer Federation of America argues for a middle road on broadband deployment.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Employees and Arbitration
abstract: A lawyer writes about forced arbitration for employees.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Coughing at Concerts
abstract: A concertgoer says most audience members are trying hard to avoid causing a distraction.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: An Error Message for the Poor
abstract: The most vulnerable suffer when technology contracts are bungled.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — MORE than two million people have signed up for health insurance coverage under the Affordable Care Act, a tribute to the effectiveness of the “tech surge” the Obama administration deployed to overcome the highly publicized problems with HealthCare.gov that emerged in October. The website’s initial rollout will long stand as a monument to how badly technology contracting can go wrong. But the remarkable recovery also demonstrates what a determined response to such bungling can achieve.

headline: Brazil Is Abuzz About Snowden
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Asylum, Right of']
abstract: On a visit to Rio de Janeiro, asylum was the question of the hour. Could South America be his next stop after Russia?
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — When I visited China in June, my trip happened to coincide with the discovery that Edward Snowden was hiding out in Hong Kong. By then, Snowden’s revelations about the voracious data-collection operation by the National Security Agency was front-page news all over the world. Snowden hadn’t yet been charged for the leak of tens of thousands of pages of classified N.S.A. documents, but it was clear that it was coming. So it was only natural to ask — as many journalists did — would Hong Kong give Snowden asylum if he requested it?

headline: Visits With School Pals Are a Touchstone on President’s Trips to Hawaii
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: President Obama’s annual holiday trips to Hawaii include bonding time with the high school friends who have come to be known collectively as the Choom Gang.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama has called Hawaii his refuge, and so it has been throughout his political life. In 2006, Mr. Obama used the family Christmas holiday there to decide whether to run for president. For the past two weeks, he has been recharging on Oahu after an unpleasant year in the job.

headline: Susan Rasky, Award-Winning Reporter for The Times, Dies at 61
abstract: She shared a Polk Award for national reporting for coverage of Congress in 1990 and most recently taught at the University of California, Berkeley.
lead_paragraph: Susan F. Rasky, a former political reporter for The New York Times who won a George Polk Award for her coverage of the congressional budget crisis in 1990, died on Dec. 29 at her home in El Cerrito, Calif. She was 61.

headline: Prosaic Pipe Stymied Seattle’s Big Bertha
abstract: What stopped the world’s biggest tunnel-boring machine? A cottage industry of speculation yields to mundane metal.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The unknown object buried beneath this city, big enough to stop the world’s largest-diameter tunnel-boring machine in its tracks last month and tantalizing enough in its mystery to set off a cottage industry of wispy romantic speculation, turns out to be an ordinary metal pipe, tunnel engineers said Friday.

headline: Indoctrinating Religious Warriors
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Evolution (Biology)', 'Religion and Belief', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Republican party leaders employ a tactic to divert the attention of the rank-and-file from areas of common sense.
lead_paragraph: In 2009, the gap between the share of Republicans and Democrats who believed in evolution was just 10 percentage points, 54 percent and 64 percent, respectively.

headline: Mystery in Hezbollah Operative’s Life and Death
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations']
abstract: The assassination of Hassane Laqees, Hezbollah’s master technician and logistics expert, has exposed a convulsing region’s tangled and shifting alliances and enmities.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As a little girl, Noor did not know exactly what her father, Hassane Laqees, did for Hezbollah, but even then, she knew she might lose him early. During his long absences, she recalled recently, she would gaze at a photo of him lying asleep and imagine that she was seeing his corpse.

headline: Architect’s Sentence in Death of Firefighter Angers Fire Crews
abstract: A Hollywood Hills homeowner whose fire code violations ended in a deadly blaze pleaded no contest to involuntary manslaughter and was given a one-year jail term.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The blaze broke out in an opulent new Hollywood Hills home that was scheduled to be the set for a television series, “Germany’s Next Top Model,” just a few days later. Flames escaped from a fireplace — designed for outdoor use, but installed indoors in violation of the fire code on the home’s top floor by Gerhard Albert Becker, a wealthy German architect.

headline: Solar Power Craze on Wall St. Propels Start-Up
abstract: The rise of SolarCity, a provider of rooftop solar systems, is either a sign that solar power is finally having its day or that yet another mania has gripped the markets.
lead_paragraph: The first inklings of the idea came to Elon Musk and a cousin in an R.V. heading to the Burning Man festival in 2004.

headline: Pictures from The Week in Business
abstract: Latvia adopts the euro, small-scale gold mining in Indonesia poses risks and and the expansion of the Panama Canal may be halted.
lead_paragraph: Latvia adopts the euro, small-scale gold mining in Indonesia poses risks and and the expansion of the Panama Canal may be halted.

headline: George Goodman, Who Demystified the World of Money, Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Goodman was probably best known as the amiable but intellectually rigorous host of “Adam Smith’s Money World,” seen on PBS from 1984 to 1997.
lead_paragraph: George J. W. Goodman, who demystified financial complexities in best-selling books and on a long-running public television program under the name of one of history’s most famous economists, Adam Smith, died on Friday in Miami. He was 83.

headline: Chaplain’s ‘Plantation’ Reference at de Blasio Inauguration Gains Defenders
abstract: In a prayer by the Rev. Frederick A. Lucas Jr. that called New York a plantation, some listeners heard incendiary rhetoric, while others heard just a call for justice.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Frederick A. Lucas Jr. stepped to the dais at the inauguration of Mayor Bill de Blasio on Wednesday as a pastor with impressive mainstream credentials. A Harvard-educated minister, he was on clergy committees for President Bill Clinton and President George W. Bush and serves as a chaplain for the Sanitation Department.

headline: Tangled Role in G.O.P. War Over Tea Party
keywords: ['Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Campaign Finance', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Tea Party Movement']
abstract: The activities of Steven C. LaTourette, an ex-congressman who defends centrist Republicans from Tea Party challengers, have raised questions about whether he is profiting from his role and violating lobbying rules.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the year since he stepped down from Congress, Steven C. LaTourette, a Republican from Ohio, has emerged as one of the top generals in the establishment Republicans’ war against the Tea Party.

headline: Auburn’s Offense Runs to a Hip-Hop Beat
abstract: Tre Mason, the son of De La Soul’s DJ Maseo, pounds the Tigers’ opponents into submission with a punishing style.
lead_paragraph: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif. — It was early December, and Auburn had secured a berth in the national title game. The final minutes of the Southeastern Conference championship game ticked away. Two running backs stood together on the sideline.

headline: Medical Center Hires Lhota as an Executive
abstract: Joseph J. Lhota, the unsuccessful Republican mayoral candidate, will be a senior vice president with NYU Langone Medical Center.
lead_paragraph: As Bill de Blasio settles into City Hall, Joseph J. Lhota, the Republican who ran against him for mayor, is also getting a new job.

headline: The Ticking Mideast Clock
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry presses Israelis and Palestinians to stick to the peace negotiations timetable he set forth in July.
lead_paragraph: Five months into the latest American effort to nudge Israelis and Palestinians toward a peace agreement, the one party clearly committed to a deal is the United States. This week, Secretary of State John Kerry made his 10th trip to the region to get the two sides to stick the timetable he set forth when he started new negotiations last July.

headline: School Experiment That Burned Boy Was Focus of Federal Warning
abstract: A video produced by a safety agency warned of the dangers of a chemistry experiment that went awry at a Manhattan school this week.
lead_paragraph: Only weeks before a chemistry experiment sent a plume of fire across a Manhattan high school science lab, engulfing two students and leaving one with life-threatening burns, a federal safety agency issued a video warning of the dangers of the very same experiment, a common one across the country.

headline: Not Getting Their Money’s Worth
keywords: ['Government Procurement', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Editorials']
abstract: Taxpayers pay too much for federal contractors, and they get too little in return.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, two recent crises to hit the White House — the revelations about unlawful surveillance and the botched health care rollout — have nothing in common. But each is a reminder of the increasing extent to which government work has been contracted out to private-sector companies. Currently, Washington spends about $500 billion a year on private-sector contracts, more than twice the amount in 2000.

headline: Stopping Mentally Ill Gun Buyers
abstract: Two Obama proposals offer a promise of at least some relief.
lead_paragraph: Rebuffed by Congress on stronger gun safety laws, President Obama is wisely using use his executive powers in a more focused attempt to bar mentally ill people from eluding federal watch lists and purchasing firearms. Two sensible changes proposed for the background check system would allow states and mental health providers more discretion than they have now in reporting information about potentially violent people.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 3, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Governor Cuomo’s Stingy Pardons
abstract: Mr. Cuomo exercised his clemency power for the first time since taking office in 2011, pardoning just three men.
lead_paragraph: The power to grant clemency is a critical function of the executive branch. It serves as a last, case-by-case resort to remedy an unjustly long sentence, erase a wrongful conviction or show forgiveness where it is merited. But New Yorkers seeking clemency from Gov. Andrew Cuomo, either from within prison or after their release, have found virtually no consolation during the three years of his tenure.

headline: Academy Ballots of Our Own
abstract: The critics make their Oscar choices.
lead_paragraph: The critics make their Oscar choices.

headline: U.S. Is Facing Hard Choices in South Sudan
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: With no plans for American military intervention, the United States is frantically brokering peace talks between the warring factions while trying to fortify a United Nations peacekeeping force.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — South Sudan is in many ways an American creation, carved out of war-torn Sudan in a referendum largely orchestrated by the United States, its fragile institutions nurtured with billions of dollars in American aid. But a murky, vicious conflict there has left the Obama administration scrambling to prevent the unraveling of a major American achievement in Africa.

headline: A Brain Is Dead, a Heart Beats On
keywords: ['Life-Sustaining Support Systems, Withdrawal Of', 'Hospitals', 'Children and Childhood', 'APNEA (SLEEP DISORDER)']
abstract: A court was called to intervene after a California hospital pronounced a girl dead after complications from surgery but her family insists she is alive.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It started out as an operation to treat an increasingly common medical problem in America, childhood sleep apnea. It has become an anguished fight over the fate of a 13-year-old girl who, though pronounced legally dead by doctors, remains alive in the opinion of her religious parents.

headline: Family of Caddies and Players Stays Close
abstract: Mallory Blackwelder’s father has caddied for her and her mother on the L.P.G.A. Tour. She also has a husband and a brother who caddie on pro tours.
lead_paragraph: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — Long before the golfer Mallory Blackwelder was even a sparkle in their eyes, her mother, Myra, was playing on the L.P.G.A. Tour, and her father, Worth, was a professional tour caddie.

headline: A Desperate River Crossing
abstract: Residents of Bor, a city in the Republic of South Sudan, fled deadly violence there by taking ferries across the White Nile to Awerial, where an estimated 76,000 displaced people are stranded.
lead_paragraph: Residents of Bor, a city in the Republic of South Sudan, fled deadly violence there by taking ferries across the White Nile to Awerial, where an estimated 76,000 displaced people are stranded.

headline: Security Official Moves to White House
abstract: Rand Beers, a counterterrorism official at the Homeland Security Department, will leave the agency to work as a senior adviser to President Obama.
lead_paragraph: Rand Beers, a counterterrorism official at the Homeland Security Department, will leave the agency to work as a senior adviser to President Obama, administration officials said Friday. Mr. Beers will be a deputy assistant to the president on the National Security Council staff, the officials said. Mr. Beers served as acting secretary of homeland security for several months last year.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 4, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, January 4, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “For 63 years, I lived with the stigma of being a traitor. The truth is I helped save South Korea during one of its most critical times.”

headline: Corrections: January 4, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on January 4, 2014.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Offering Help in Passing
abstract: In which Kyle Dolan nearly gets the best of me.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I take back what I said yesterday about the question marks. There are quite a few of those today, but it’s O.K.; with those question marks comes a lot of fun wordplay.

headline: Lower East Side Students Have a Gift of Uniforms, and Better Focus
abstract: Educational Alliance, an agency that runs an after-school program at Public School 188, drew money from The Neediest Cases Fund to buy uniform shirts for 184 students there.
lead_paragraph: The school day is over, yet the majority of students at Public School 188 will happily continue to wear their uniforms well into the early evening hours.

headline: Once a Criminal, He’s Now a Victim, Shot Twice in a Year
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'New Year', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Richard Dunbar, 53, was one of the many anonymous faces of nonlethal shootings in New York City, and yet he stood out.
lead_paragraph: New Year’s Eve, 2012: Richard Dunbar, 52, spent the night in Brooklyn with his sister and her family, “two little-bitty nephews,” he recalled. They watched the ball drop on television. Nice night.

headline: Returning of Refugees to Bulgaria Worries U.N.
keywords: ['Asylum, Right of', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The United Nations refugee agency urged European countries to stop sending back asylum seekers, many of them originally from Syria, because they face poor treatment in Bulgaria.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — European countries should stop returning asylum seekers to Bulgaria, because they could face “inhuman and degrading treatment” in Bulgaria’s reception centers, which have been stretched thin by a rising number of arrivals, the United Nations refugee agency said Friday.

headline: Modesty, With a Little Smoldering
abstract: Ruth E. Carter, the costume designer for “Lee Daniels’ The Butler,” explains her vision of the butler’s wife as first lady of her home.
lead_paragraph: “I thought that if Nancy Reagan and Jackie Kennedy were the first ladies of the White House, then Gloria was the first lady of the Gaines house,” said Ruth E. Carter, the costume designer for “Lee Daniels’ The Butler.” Inspired by the real-life story of Eugene Allen, the film follows a White House butler, Cecil Gaines (portrayed by Forest Whitaker), and his wife, Gloria, as history, particularly the civil rights movement, unfolds over seven presidential administrations.

headline: Deadly Violence Erupts During Rallies Across Egypt
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: At least 13 people were killed as violence broke out during Muslim Brotherhood marches just days before a planned referendum on a draft constitution.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — At least 13 people were killed as violence broke out during Muslim Brotherhood marches in several Egyptian cities on Friday, health officials said, in the deadliest day of clashes in months.

headline: Councilwoman Bruised Feelings in Zoning Fight
abstract: After a nonprofit won a zoning change with help from Councilwoman Melissa Mark-Viverito, it donated to her campaign.
lead_paragraph: If she becomes, as appears likely, the next speaker of the New York City Council, Councilwoman Melissa Mark-Viverito of East Harlem has vowed to listen to all groups, treat everyone fairly and be a paragon of transparency.

headline: Knicks’ Shumpert Rediscovers His Shot, and His Smile
abstract: Iman Shumpert, often dejected during the first two months of the season, had a renewed confidence after scoring 27 points Thursday. He added 26 points Friday.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Even as Iman Shumpert was going scoreless against teams like the Toronto Raptors and the Boston Celtics in recent weeks, he tried to insulate himself from the noise.

headline: Turning Point for Nets? Victory Over Oklahoma City Did Trick Last Season
abstract: The Nets followed up a big loss to the Spurs with a stirring victory against the Thunder, just as they did last season to start a seven-game winning streak.
lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — It was hard to ignore the coincidence.

headline: Gunman Fires at Moving S.U.V. in Queens, Killing One and Wounding Three Others
abstract: A longtime friend of the rapper 50 cent was killed, according to the police and witnesses.
lead_paragraph: A gunman opened fire on an S.U.V. in Springfield Gardens in Queens on Friday afternoon, killing a longtime friend of the rapper 50 Cent and wounding three other people inside, according to the police and witnesses.

headline: Mental Lapse at Finish Wastes 47 Good Minutes From the Knicks
abstract: One night after a stirring victory in San Antonio, the Knicks lost in the final seconds, in part because of an ill-advised shot by J. R. Smith.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The Knicks had done what they could to survive against the Rockets for more than 47 minutes at the Toyota Center on Friday night. They had hustled. They had rebounded. They had defended, at least for stretches.

headline: Juanita Moore, Oscar-Nominated Actress, Dies at 99
keywords: ['ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Academy Awards (Oscars)', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Movies']
abstract: Ms. Moore found only limited work after becoming the fifth African-American performer nominated for an Academy Award.
lead_paragraph: Juanita Moore, who earned an Academy Award nomination in 1960 for the single major film role she ever landed, then fell through the cracks of a Hollywood system that had little to offer a black actress besides small parts as maids and nannies, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. She was 99.

headline: Dr. W.V. Cordice Jr., 94, a Surgeon Who Helped Save Dr. King, Dies
keywords: ['Surgery and Surgeons', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: Dr. Cordice was part of a team of surgeons who operated on the civil rights leader after he was stabbed in Harlem in 1958.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 20, 1958, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., then emerging as the leader of the civil rights movement, was autographing copies of his new book in a Harlem department store when a woman approached to greet him. He nodded without looking up. Then she stabbed him in the chest with a razor-sharp seven-inch letter opener.

headline: Winter Wallop
abstract: Scenes from across New York City on Friday after a powerful storm brought snow, bitterly cold temperatures and heavy winds.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from across New York City on Friday after a powerful storm brought snow, bitterly cold temperatures and heavy winds.

headline: How the Auto Industry Fared in December
abstract: How the auto industry fared in December 2013.
lead_paragraph: How the auto industry fared in December 2013.

headline: What’s On Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) ADMISSION (2013) Tina Fey (above, seated) portrays Portia Nathan, a Princeton admissions officer who seems to take a special kind of glee in controlling the fate of applicants aspiring to the university’s ivy-covered halls. She also has a goal of her own: to succeed the retiring dean of admissions (Wallace Shawn) and beat out her office rival (Gloria Reuben) while reclaiming Princeton’s place at the top of the U.S. News & World Report rankings. But just as her smug English-professor boyfriend (Michael Sheen) dumps her for an aggressive Virginia Woolf scholar (Sonya Walger), a fellow Dartmouth alum (Paul Rudd) comes along with an unusual student (Nat Wolff) he wants Portia to consider. “How could anyone make light of the brutal, capricious system by which our young people are judged and sorted?” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this comedy from Paul Weitz, adapted from the novel by Jean Hanff Korelitz. “And I must confess that I don’t know whether to be relieved or disappointed that ‘Admission,’ which had the potential to be a sharp, satirical jab at the soft belly of middle-class anxiety, chose instead to be a warm and wacky fable of wish fulfillment. Mr. Weitz lines up a target placed at the explosive intersection of class, race, region and every other source of societal anguish, and then does not so much miss as aim in another direction — or several — letting fly a volley of darts that land as lightly as badminton birdies.” Still, Ms. Fey and Mr. Rudd “are fun to watch, though not as much fun as they might have been in a riskier, crazier movie,” he said, adding that “the best scenes belong to Lily Tomlin, brilliantly cast as Portia’s mother, an unbowed second-wave woman warrior with a pair of borzois and a Bella Abzug tattoo.”

headline: Cambodia Cracks Down on Protest With Evictions and Ban on Assembly
abstract: Cambodian police officers on Saturday cleared protesters from a Phnom Penh park that has been the staging ground for antigovernment demonstrations, and organizers canceled a planned Sunday rally.
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — Seeking to quash one of the most serious challenges to the nearly 30-year rule of the country’s authoritarian leader, Cambodian authorities evicted antigovernment protesters on Saturday from a public square and banned all public gatherings as a court summoned two opposition leaders for police questioning.

headline: Obama Urges Congress to Restore Unemployment Benefits
abstract: President Obama insisted that lawmakers make restoring unemployment benefits for 1.3 million Americans their “first order of business” in the new year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, seeking the upper hand with Congress as he heads back from his Hawaiian vacation, insisted on Saturday that lawmakers make restoring unemployment benefits for 1.3 million Americans who are out of work their “first order of business” in the new year.

headline: Do Animals Have a Sweet Tooth?
abstract: Some animals appear to like sugar but have no response to artificial sweeteners.
lead_paragraph: No preference is so quick to form, and none so hard to lose, as a baby’s love for sweets. Give a newborn a drop of sugar water when he’s hours old, and he’ll suckle. At a dental school in Jerusalem in the early 1970s, a scientist named Jacob E. Steiner doled out sucrose to 175 infants before they’d had a drop of mother’s milk and saw clear signs of satisfaction: The babies showed “a marked relaxation of the facial muscle,” he wrote, and “a retraction of the mouth’s angles resembling a ‘smile.’ ” Then he tried the same experiment on several babies born without a cerebral cortex and found the same result. The joy of sugar needs no cogitation; it scarcely needs a brain.

headline: In Fervent Support of the ‘Gap Year’
abstract: I worried that my daughter’s decision to take a gap year would mean she’d never go to college. I shouldn’t have.
lead_paragraph: I wasn’t enthusiastic when my daughter first floated her plan to take a “gap year” before college. As someone who couldn’t wait to matriculate, I didn’t see the point of delaying that great intellectual awakening. I felt vaguely disappointed that she wasn’t more eager to embrace all those books and ideas and late-night conversations about the cosmos. And what if her gap year turned into a permanent crevasse and she never earned a degree?

headline: Putin Eases Protest Ban in Sochi for the Olympics
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin appeared to be acting in response to global criticism of Russia by human rights groups, but all demonstrations will still require approval.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin on Saturday eased a sweeping ban on public protests in Sochi, Russia, starting on Tuesday and continuing through the Olympic Games next month and the Paralympic Games in March. However, any demonstrations will require approval in advance from the authorities.

headline: Phil Everly, Half of a Pioneer Rock Duo That Inspired Generations, Dies at 74
abstract: Songs by Mr. Everly and his older brother, Don Everly, carried the close fraternal harmonies of country tradition into pioneering rock ‘n’ roll.
lead_paragraph: Phil Everly, whose hits with his older brother, Don, as the Everly Brothers carried the close fraternal harmonies of country tradition into pioneering rock ‘n’ roll, died on Friday in Burbank, Calif. He was 74.

headline: TabTale Cranks Up Its Game-Making Machine
abstract: The Israeli company isn’t worried about sophisticated games. It’s making games kids want to play and lots of them.
lead_paragraph: You’ve probably never heard of a company called TabTale. But if you’ve ever used an iPad or smartphone to entertain young children (as many parents do), you may very well have downloaded one of its hundreds of animated games or interactive books on topics like virtual cupcake baking and doctors who heal zombies. (I personally wasted an enjoyable hour this week playing Santa Rescue Challenge, one of the company’s recently released holiday titles.)

headline: Boeing Workers Approve 8-Year Contract Extension
abstract: The vote was an emotional, and very close 51 percent in favor of the contract extension to 2024, keeping aerospace jobs in Washington State.
lead_paragraph: Boeing workers narrowly approved an eight-year contract extension, their union announced late Friday, in a move that will assure production of Boeing’s new 777X aircraft in the Puget Sound area.

headline: Happy New Year?
abstract: I hate to say this, but it could happen.
lead_paragraph: There’s an alarming amount of optimism out there about US economic prospects for 2014. Let me make the situation even more alarming by saying that I basically share that optimism.

headline: 1914: Amazingly Popular Dance Causes Widespread Social Controversy
abstract: 100 years ago The New York Herald reported widespread outrage at the appearance of tango in Europe.
lead_paragraph: Never has a dance been so much discussed, defended and denounced as has the tango, the extraordinary terpsichorean craze which has swept over the whole of Europe and the United States. Society leaders have condemned unsparingly, bishops have shuddered, royalty has expressed uncompromising disapproval, and the tango is still danced with fervor by tens of thousands. It cannot be denied that the tango in its original form would have shocked the most Bohemian society. The very name — tango, “I touch”— has a significance which needs no comment. But it is a far cry from the original as it was danced in the most undesirable cafés of the Argentine to the severely Bowdlerized version tolerated in the modern ballroom. It is believed that the tango is of Spanish origin, and was taken to South America by Spanish settlers.

headline: Spate of Injuries in N.H.L. Keeps Olympic Rosters in Flux Worldwide
abstract: Potential Olympians like Canada’s Steven Stamkos, Slovakia’s Marian Gaborik, Sweden’s Alex Steen and Russia’s Evgeni Malkin are among the N.H.L. players out with injuries.
lead_paragraph: Picking an Olympic roster is tricky enough, but a rash of injuries in the N.H.L. this season is making it harder than ever. Toronto Coach Randy Carlyle noted at the end of December that 108 players were out, 15 percent of the league. That number includes some of the biggest stars among the medal contenders for the Sochi Games, players like Canada’s Steven Stamkos, Slovakia’s Marian Gaborik, Sweden’s Alex Steen and Russia’s Evgeni Malkin.

headline: Letters to the Sports Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines, including the Jets retaining Rex Ryan and head injuries in skiing.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: What A Good Year Won’t Prove
abstract: Neither a refutation nor a vindication.
lead_paragraph: A brief addendum to my last post. If 2014 is a year of relatively good growth, you know that many people will take that as somehow refuting Keynesianism — hey, didn’t you guys predict that the economy would never recover without fiscal stimulus?

headline: For Nets and Knicks Fans, a Midwinter Night’s Dream
abstract: After their teams won, improbably, in Oklahoma City and in San Antonio, two fans found reason for hope.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks fan and the Nets fan settled on the couch, in front of the television, on a snowy, frigid Thursday night. Each held a bottle of Pepto-Bismol, bracing for more stomach pain in a furiously retching season.

headline: Afghanistan’s Worsening, and Baffling, Hunger Crisis
abstract: Hospitals are reporting more and more cases, but doctors and other officials are not certain why, or even how many children are affected.
lead_paragraph: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan — In the Bost Hospital here, a teenage mother named Bibi Sherina sits on a bed in the severe acute malnutrition ward with her two children. Ahmed, at just 3 months old, looks bigger than his emaciated brother Mohammad, who is a year and a half and weighs 10 pounds.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, Jan. 5
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Automobiles', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Notable quotes from business articles that appeared in The New York Times last week.
lead_paragraph: “C.E.O.’s can look forward and say, ‘I don’t see any near-term economic bumps.’  ”

headline: How a First Career Enhanced a Second
abstract: A financial planner sees differences, but also various similarities, between his current work and his earlier years as a medical doctor.
lead_paragraph: What happens when the career you were born to pursue becomes the wrong career when you reach your mid-30s?

headline: Variety: A Lost Diagramless
abstract: Fred Piscop has lost it, but in a good way.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — I have a love/oh-no-not-again relationship with diagramless puzzles. They’re good for the ego in the sense that the clues are exceptionally easy, and the clues are easy because the main point is to figure out where the entries go. That’s the part that’s not so much fun for me.

headline: You Can’t Take It With You, but You Still Want More

abstract: A new study illustrates humans’ deeply rooted desire to earn more than they possibly can consume.
lead_paragraph: All work and no play may just be a result of “mindless accumulation.”

headline: Ice Dancing, Adored and Mocked, Could Give Americans a Lone Gold
abstract: Meryl Davis and Charlie White, the reigning Olympic silver medalists in ice dancing, are the sole Americans favored to win gold in Sochi in the four traditional skating events.
lead_paragraph: CANTON, Mich. — Olympic ice dancing is widely appealing to audiences, but it has been frequently mocked as a dubious competition, fraught with predetermined outcomes, almost impossible to judge objectively. An existential question lurks: Is rumba really a sport?

headline: Afghanistan’s Child Hunger Crisis
abstract: Hospitals around the country have been swamped by a wave of malnourished children in the past year, but the causes are unclear.
lead_paragraph: Hospitals around the country have been swamped by a wave of malnourished children in the past year, but the causes are unclear.

headline: Listen to Pandora, and It Listens Back
keywords: ['Online Advertising', 'Music', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Political Advertising', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: The Internet radio service has started to mine user data for the best ways to target advertising. It can deconstruct your song choices to predict, for example, your political party of choice.
lead_paragraph: Pandora, the Internet radio service, is plying a new tune.

headline: Afghanistan’s Unexplained Hunger Crisis
abstract: Throughout Afghanistan, there is what doctors call acute severe malnutrition. Most of the cases are seen in children under the age of 5.
lead_paragraph: Throughout Afghanistan, there is what doctors call acute severe malnutrition. Most of the cases are seen in children under the age of 5.

headline: Please, There’s No Need to Shout
abstract: A customer’s complaint to a cellphone equipment seller is met with stern language — complete with a sprinkling of capital letters.
lead_paragraph: The Haggler has been described by more than a few people as a congenital grump, and this is often framed in negative terms. The Haggler, though, believes that his congenital grumpiness is among his more appealing characteristics, right up there with this fondness for the word “congenital.”

headline: Help the Working Poor, but Share the Burden
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Minimum Wage', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Income Tax']
abstract: A higher minimum wage? It’s a tax on business alone, an economist says.
lead_paragraph: In a speech last month, President Obama brought renewed attention to economic disparities in the United States. The gap between rich and poor is indeed substantial — much larger than in most developed nations and much larger than it was 40 years ago. So what is the best way to help those struggling at the bottom of the economic ladder?

headline: A Roadblock to Brawny Bank Reform
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The calendar has turned, but tougher capital rules for the banking industry are still awaiting approval.
lead_paragraph: Regulators made some real progress last year attacking the risks of too-big-to-fail banks. The Volcker Rule and other Dodd-Frank reforms were completed, and, perhaps even more important, three big regulators devised a proposal for tougher capital rules intended to ensure that banks would never require a government bailout when their risky bets went bad.

headline: Karen Abramson, on Going to the Front Lines
abstract: The C.E.O. of Wolters Kluwer Tax & Accounting says that in new assignments, she always consults those on the front lines, “whether it’s our salespeople or a client or customer service people.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Karen Abramson, chief executive of Wolters Kluwer Tax & Accounting, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Finding Her Teaching Voice
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Education (K-12)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Charter Schools']
abstract: An assistant principal says the “teacher-student evangelical style” of the Jehovah’s Witnesses, which she learned at an early age, became “the foundation of my teaching ability later in life.”

headline: A Backward Rule and a Baseball Hall Backlog
abstract: Allowing each voter to endorse only 10 candidates seems to serve only to deprive worthy former players of enshrinement to the Baseball Hall of Fame.
lead_paragraph: It happens every winter. An overstuffed, unwieldy collection of voters, some much more qualified and conscientious than others, holds an election to bestow the highest honor of a cherished American institution. It is a secretive process in a world that, more and more, craves transparency.

headline: Denver’s McGee Not Just Any Tall Drink of Water
abstract: Besides being a font of highlights and blunders on the court, JaVale McGee has an unusual Twitter persona and promotes drinking water by the jug.
lead_paragraph: Explaining JaVale McGee to the uninitiated can be difficult.

lead_paragraph: To lure a younger consumer Marriott International is making a turn toward flash, partly by offering new hotel brands.

headline: Militant Tied to Bombings in Lebanon Dies in Jail
abstract: Majid bin Muhammad al-Majid, the leader of a Lebanon-based affiliate of Al Qaeda who was arrested recently, died Saturday while in custody in Lebanon, officials said.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The leader of a Lebanon-based affiliate of Al Qaeda who was arrested recently died Saturday while in custody in Lebanon, officials said.

headline: Packers Fever Cools a Bit, and the Explanation Is Complex
abstract: Even after the return of Aaron Rodgers and a fabulous ending to Week 17, it took until Friday for Green Bay to sell out Sunday’s N.F.C. wild-card game against the San Francisco 49ers.
lead_paragraph: GREEN BAY, Wis. — The Stadium View Bar & Grille, as the name implies, stands one long block from Lambeau Field, at the corner of Holmgren Way and Brett Favre Pass. Through large windows and behind a 20-foot-tall replica of the Lombardi Trophy, the brick facade of Lambeau rises in the distance down Armed Forces Drive, a sort of Champs-Élysées for cheeseheads.

headline: Qaeda-Linked Militants in Iraq Secure Nearly Full Control of Falluja
abstract: Sunni militants fighting under the banner of Al Qaeda appeared to make gains across Anbar Province, also capturing the strategic town of Karma.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Sunni militants fighting under the banner of Al Qaeda appeared to make gains across Anbar Province on Saturday, using snipers and rocket-propelled grenades in heavy street fighting as they secured nearly full control of Falluja and captured the strategic town Karma. Government forces and the tribal militias fighting with them seemed unable to resist the militants’ advances.

headline: But It Doesn’t Look Like a Marriott
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Business Travel']
abstract: To lure a younger crowd, Marriott International is making a turn toward flash, partly by offering new hotel brands.
lead_paragraph: J.W. Marriott Jr., the 81-year-old chairman of Marriott International, flew to London in September to inspect his company’s new jewel: Edition, a sumptuous boutique hotel intended to anchor a new 100-city chain — the next W, if Marriott has its way. But Mr. Marriott did not stay overnight at the London Edition, as the new property is known, with its laser-lighted nightclub and guest-room paintings of women wearing toilet-paper turbans. He bedded down at Grosvenor House, one of the company’s more traditional luxury hotels.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Treating Mental Illness
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Readers react to a call for better coverage for psychiatric care.
lead_paragraph: Readers react to a call for better coverage for psychiatric care.

headline: Making a Living (and a Life) Abroad
abstract: Some Americans have taken advantage of technology and a globalized economy to work and live in other countries.
lead_paragraph: Some Americans have taken advantage of technology and a globalized economy to work and live in other countries.

headline: The Roots Stay Strong at Auburn
abstract: A vandal poisoned two mighty trees at Auburn, but he could not kill what they represented.
lead_paragraph: AUBURN, Ala. — There is a tree sculpture inside the Auburn Art store, a replica of an oak that towered over the entrance to Auburn University for decades.

headline: A College Football Fan Is Born a Weekend at a Time
abstract: Two journalists travel across the country to watch games featuring teams steeped in tradition, in cities known for their food and history.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — When my wife, Betsy, and I walked out of our Canal Street hotel here Thursday night to head to the Sugar Bowl, we ran into a colleague of hers who happened to be in town for a wedding.

headline: For Obama, a Real and Rare Vacation in Hawaii
abstract: For the first time since President Obama took office and began making a regular Christmas sojourn to Hawaii, no urgent news broke while he was there.
lead_paragraph: KAILUA, Hawaii — After a two-week vacation on the windward side of Oahu, ensconced with his family in a private beachfront rental, President Obama prepared on Saturday to return to the chillier clime — both politically and weather-wise — of the nation’s capital.

headline: Management Be Nimble
abstract: How to keep your company as fresh as a start-up? In hundreds of interviews, executives shared the paths they took to energize their corporate cultures.
lead_paragraph: “We aspire to be the largest small company in our space.”

headline: The Loneliness of the Long-Distance Reader
abstract: The convergence of several trends leaves the book-buying public out in the cold.
lead_paragraph: “TO read a novel is a difficult and complex art,” Virginia Woolf wrote in a 1925 essay, “How to Read a Book.” Today, with our powers of concentration atrophied by the staccato communication of the Internet and attention easily diverted to addictive entertainment on our phones and tablets, book-length reading is harder still.

headline: Banished for Questioning the Gospel of Guns
keywords: ['First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Gun Control', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: A longtime columnist for a gun magazine questioned when the regulation of guns became infringement of the right to bear arms. He was quickly fired, squelching any debate.
lead_paragraph: BARRY, Ill. — The byline of Dick Metcalf, one of the country’s pre-eminent gun journalists, has gone missing. It has been removed from Guns & Ammo magazine, where his widely-read column once ran on the back page. He no longer stars on a popular television show about firearms. Gun companies have stopped flying him around the world and sending him the latest weapons to review.

headline: Bracing for Carp in Great Lakes, but Debating Their Presence
abstract: Asian carp, or carp DNA at least, may have arrived in the Great Lakes, and either way, the Army Corps of Engineers will issue a study proposing ways to keep the invasive species out.
lead_paragraph: After decades of increasingly dire warnings, countless studies and countermeasures, scientists are beginning to mull over hints of something that few of them wish to contemplate: The despised Asian carp may have finally arrived in the Great Lakes.

headline: Moves to Curb Spying Help Drive the Clemency Argument for Snowden
keywords: ['Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Whistle-Blowers']
abstract: The whistleblower-versus-traitor argument has taken on a new dimension with recent moves to curtail the programs that Edward J. Snowden revealed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — To the prosecutors pursuing him, Edward J. Snowden has committed espionage by divulging national secrets. But the growing backlash against government surveillance has spurred a spirited debate about whether he should be forgiven.

headline: Blast Hits Kabul Military Base, and Eastern Afghanistan Bombing Kills American
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'Assaults', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: An explosion hit one of the entrances of Camp Eggers, a predominantly American military base, but the extent of the blast or the cause was not immediately clear.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — An explosion hit one of the entrances to a predominantly American military base in the heart of Kabul on Saturday, hours after a separate suicide bombing in eastern Afghanistan killed an American service member — the first combat casualty of the year.

headline: The Invisible Hand Award
abstract: Economics humor. Really.
lead_paragraph: One last Jerry Goodman post. My friend, classmate, and fellow joke-writer Irwin Collier of the Free University of Berlin sends me the program of the 1976 Adam Smith dinner and Jerry’s writeup of his experience (both pdf).

headline: De Blasio’s Long Odds
abstract: Why liberals won’t be able to win their war on inequality.
lead_paragraph: THIS much can be said for Bill de Blasio’s inauguration, which featured a concentration of left-wing agitprop unseen since the last time Pete Seeger occupied a stage alone: If the waning years of Barack Obama’s presidency are going to be defined by a liberal crusade against income inequality, there’s no more fitting place to kick it off than New York City.

headline: Need-Blind Justice
abstract: How can we make sure lawyers defend poor clients with vigor and care? Experiments in two states are trying to offer solutions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — FIFTY years ago, in Gideon v. Wainwright, the Supreme Court ruled that poor people accused of serious crimes were entitled to lawyers paid for by the government. But the court did not say how the lawyers should be chosen, how much they should be paid or how to make sure they defended their clients with vigor and care.

headline: How Insecure Is Your Password?
abstract: What was your first pet’s last name?

headline: Compromise: Not a 4-Letter Word
