keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: There is a sensible path forward on America’s biggest challenges if Congress would only do the right thing and take it.
lead_paragraph: FORMER SENATOR ALAN SIMPSON likes to say that if you can’t learn to compromise on issues without compromising yourself, you should not be in Congress, be in business or get married. It is amazing how many people violate that rule, but especially in Congress and especially among the Tea Party types, where calling someone a “deal maker” is now the ultimate put down. What makes it crazier is that in American education, innovation and commerce today, “collaboration” is being taught and rewarded as the best way to do anything big, important and complex. Indeed, in Silicon Valley, a “collaborator” means someone with whom you’re building something great. In D.C., it means someone committing political treason by working with the other party. And that is why Silicon Valley is now the turbo-engine of our economy and D.C. is the dead hand.

headline: First Up, Mental Illness. Next Topic Is Up to You.
abstract: A question for Times readers: What neglected topics would you like to see explored in 2014?
lead_paragraph: THOSE of us in the pundit world tend to blather on about what happened yesterday, while often ignoring what happens every day. We stir up topics already on the agenda, but we falter at calling attention to crucial-but-neglected issues.

headline: Stephen Kellert
abstract: On connection to the natural world through architecture, birdsong and eating Strawberry the steer for dinner.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Kellert is a social ecologist and senior research scholar at Yale University’s School of Forestry and Environmental Studies. He has written several books and produced a documentary about so-called biophilic design, which goes beyond sustainability to integrate and connect people with the natural world.

headline: One Marine’s Dying Wish
abstract: The military found dishonor in Hal Faulkner’s homosexuality. He didn’t want that senseless verdict to survive him.
lead_paragraph: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — WE don’t get any say about the kind of world we’re born into — about whether it’s prepared for the likes of us, whether it will open its arms. Hal Faulkner certainly didn’t get the world he deserved. It was needlessly cruel to him, senselessly judgmental. For the most part, he made peace with that.

headline: The Commish, the 2nd Time Around
abstract: Can Bill Bratton, the old and new police commissioner, stop the “Bonfire of the Vanities” predicted by the Bloombergians?
lead_paragraph: BILL BRATTON’S biggest problem right now might not be stop-and-frisk.

headline: Can Upward Mobility Cost You Your Health?
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Medicine and Health', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Poor kids who succeed suffer from higher obesity, stress and blood pressure.
lead_paragraph: Americans love a good rags-to-riches story. Even in an age of soaring inequality, we like to think that people can still make it big here if they work hard and stay out of trouble. The socioeconomic reality of most of the last four decades — stagnant wages, soaring income and wealth inequality, and reduced equality of opportunity — have dented, but not destroyed, the appeal of the American dream.

headline: 50 Years Later, War on Poverty Is a Mixed Bag
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Poverty', 'Income Inequality', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Minimum Wage', 'Research', 'Families and Family Life', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The debate over the government’s role in creating opportunity and ending deprivation has flared anew, with inequality as acute as it was in the Roaring Twenties and the ranks of the poor and near-poor at record highs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — To many Americans, the war on poverty declared 50 years ago by President Lyndon B. Johnson has largely failed. The poverty rate has fallen only to 15 percent from 19 percent in two generations, and 46 million Americans live in households where the government considers their income scarcely adequate.

headline: Path to Casinos Turns Messy in Massachusetts
abstract: Casino operators are finding state legalization is but the first step in a difficult process.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — When Massachusetts finally gave in after decades of resistance and decided two years ago to legalize casino gambling, it seemed a relatively easy way to fill the state’s recession-battered coffers.

headline: A Lonely Quest for Facts on Genetically Modified Crops
abstract: When a bill to ban genetically engineered crops on the island of Hawaii was introduced, doubts nagged at Greggor Ilagan, a councilman, about what the risks were, if any, of the crops.
lead_paragraph: KONA, Hawaii — From the moment the bill to ban genetically engineered crops on the island of Hawaii was introduced in May 2013, it garnered more vocal support than any the County Council here had ever considered, even the perennially popular bids to decriminalize marijuana.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Jan. 5
abstract: The Sunday shows take a look at some issues coming up, including the White House’s effort to restore benefits for the long-term jobless; the Olympics in Sochi and the concerns about terrorist attacks there; and prospects for bipartisan cooperation in Congress.
lead_paragraph: As lawmakers return to Capitol Hill this week, President Obama urged them to restore unemployment benefits for 1.3 million Americans who are without work. The program was cut in the two-year budget passed before the holidays.

headline: Why Everyone Seems to Have Cancer
abstract: As heart disease and stroke are beaten back, cancer vies to become the final killer.
lead_paragraph: EVERY New Year when the government publishes its Report to the Nation on the Status of Cancer, it is followed by a familiar lament. We are losing the war against cancer.

headline: Declining Lethality
abstract: Since 1958, the death rates from heart disease and stroke have declined more than those from cancer.
lead_paragraph: Since 1958, the death rates from heart disease and stroke have declined more than those from cancer.

headline: Warming Up for Australian Open, Williams Beats Azarenka in Brisbane
abstract: The most recent of Serena Williams’s five titles in the Australian Open came in 2010, but with a victory over Victoria Azarenka, she has won 22 straight matches.
lead_paragraph: BRISBANE, Australia — Serena Williams began this season in the same pose she ended the last, her right heel lifted slightly off the ground, her arms high over her head, her hands grasping yet another trophy.

headline: Why Do We Fear the Blind?
abstract: I used to be certain I’d rather die than be blind.
lead_paragraph: BRISTOL, R.I. — A FEW years ago, when I mentioned to a woman I met at a party that I was teaching in a school for the blind, she seemed confused. “Can I just ask you one question?” she said. “How do you talk to your students?”

headline: Happy New Year, Politicians. Seriously.
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Two columnists spar over life, liberty and the pursuit of Obamacare.
lead_paragraph: GAIL COLLINS: Happy New Year, David! I’m glad you’re back and that we’re going to start conversing again. What are you expecting, politically speaking, for 2014? It doesn’t really seem possible that things could get much worse.

headline: Small Plane Makes an Emergency Landing on a Highway in the Bronx
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The plane landed on the Major Deegan Expressway around 3:20 p.m. near East 233rd Street, fire officials said, but none of the passengers had life-threatening injuries.
lead_paragraph: A single-engine plane made an emergency landing on the Major Deegan Expressway in the Bronx on Saturday afternoon, officials said. No one was seriously injured.

headline: Rampant Prosecutorial Misconduct
keywords: ['Prosecutorial Misconduct', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Legal Profession', 'Editorials']
abstract: Evidence is often withheld from the defense, and courts rarely hold prosecutors accountable.
lead_paragraph: In the justice system, prosecutors have the power to decide what criminal charges to bring, and since 97 percent of cases are resolved without a trial, those decisions are almost always the most important factor in the outcome. That is why it is so important for prosecutors to play fair, not just to win. This obligation is embodied in the Supreme Court’s 1963 holding in Brady v. Maryland, which required prosecutors to provide the defense with any exculpatory evidence that could materially affect a verdict or sentence.

headline: Putting Drones to the Test
abstract: Congress should enact privacy protections before commercial unmanned aircraft are allowed to take off.
lead_paragraph: Drones will soon take to the skies across the United States in federally approved tests that are meant to clear the way for the commercial use of unmanned aircraft. But before that happens, lawmakers and regulators need to deal with a host of unresolved privacy and safety concerns.

headline: The Marijuana Experiment
abstract: Colorado and Washington State will serve as test cases for full-on legalization.
lead_paragraph: On New Year’s Day, government-licensed recreational marijuana shops opened in Colorado, the first place in the world to regulate the drug “from seed to sale.” Later in 2014, marijuana retailers will open in Washington State. As public opinion shifts away from prohibition, these two states will serve as test cases for full-on legalization. Here’s what to watch for in the early stages of this experiment:

headline: Health Care in America
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Michael Moore called Obamacare both “awful” and a “godsend.” Readers offer their opinions.
lead_paragraph: Michael Moore called Obamacare both ‘awful’ and a ‘godsend.’ Readers offer their opinions.

headline: 50 Years of Poverty
abstract: While government programs have kept millions of people, especially the elderly, from falling into poverty, rates remain high for many groups of Americans, including children, blacks and Hispanics.
lead_paragraph: While government programs have kept millions of people, especially the elderly, from falling into poverty, rates remain high for many groups of Americans, including children, blacks and Hispanics.

headline: 'Tony Bargains' Helps Bronx's Needy
keywords: ['Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Thrift Shops']
abstract: Anthony Cody, a former inmate and homeless drug addict known as Tony Bargains, has turned a crack house on Boston Road into a thrift store for the needy.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Cody, a former inmate and homeless drug addict known as Tony Bargains, has turned a crack house on Boston Road into a thrift store for the needy.

headline: New York State Is Set to Loosen Marijuana Laws
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo plans to announce an executive action that would allow limited use of medical marijuana, moving the state a step closer to policies embraced by advocates and lawmakers elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Joining a growing group of states that have loosened restrictions on marijuana, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York plans this week to announce an executive action that would allow limited use of the drug by those with serious illnesses, state officials say.

headline: ‘Inside Llewyn Davis’ Gets Critics Society’s Vote
abstract: The film took best picture honors at the National Society of Film Critics’ vote on Saturday, with “American Hustle” and “12 Years a Slave” the runners-up.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 1:10 p.m. | The National Society of Film Critics crowned “Inside Llewyn Davis” as its best picture on Saturday, with the “Davis” filmmakers, Joel and Ethan Coen, taking the director prize.

headline: Your Submissions for “Most Neglected Topic”
abstract: Inviting readers to post their ideas about issues that are of national or international significance but don’t get adequate attention. I hope to write a column about your suggestions.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column invites readers to submit the issues they believe are most neglected by the news media and that deserve more coverage in 2014. My own suggestion, which my column focuses on, is mental health. So if you have a suggestion for an issue that you think is of national or global importance but isn’t getting adequate coverage, please post below and explain why. I hope to stitch together a column based on some of your best entries.

headline: N.F.L. Wild Card Saturday
abstract: Highlights from Saturday’s N.F.L. playoff games.
lead_paragraph: Highlights from Saturday’s N.F.L. playoff games.

headline: Clued In
abstract: Alan DerKazarian is playing a game with us.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Wow. Look at that grid. Are you intimidated by that grid?

headline: Harvey K. Littleton, a Pioneer in the Art of Glass, Dies at 91
abstract: Mr. Littleton, whose work has been acquired by the Metropolitan Museum of Art, founded what is considered to be the nation’s first college-level course in his field.
lead_paragraph: Harvey K. Littleton, an artist who helped found the so-called studio glass movement in the United States, developing and teaching do-it-yourself techniques that freed glassblowing from the cumbersome protocols of factory production and made molten glass almost as easy to work with in the studio as wet clay, died on Dec. 13 in Spruce Pine, N.C. He was 91.

headline: Ecuadorean Navy Delivers for Amazon Chief
abstract: Jeff Bezos, vacationing in the Galapagos Islands this week, felt some serious pain. And it wasn’t just because UPS had failed to make all of Amazon’s shipments by Christmas.
lead_paragraph: The Ecuadorean Navy offered Jeff Bezos same-day shipping on an Amazon Prime package: Mr. Bezos himself.

headline: Saul Zaentz, Producer of Oscar-Winning Movies, Dies at 92
abstract: Mr. Zaentz, an independent film producer, won best-picture Academy Awards for “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest,” “Amadeus” and “The English Patient.”
lead_paragraph: Saul Zaentz, an acclaimed independent film producer who adapted literary works for the screen and won best-picture Academy Awards for “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest,” “Amadeus” and “The English Patient,” died on Friday at his apartment in San Francisco. He was 92.

headline: Opposition Party Boycotting Bangladesh Election
abstract: Amid unrest and despite violence, the governing Awami League is going ahead with Sunday’s vote, while the main opposition party is refusing to take part.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — As Bangladesh prepared for general elections on Sunday, a truck driver named Nur Islam was trying to haul a load of potatoes to Dhaka, the capital, along a route he knew would be targeted by protesters allied with the opposition.

headline: Home From Tour and Back on Ballot, Singer Finds a Reason to Campaign
abstract: Kinky Friedman — the singer, humorist and hawker of tequila — is running for agriculture commissioner, his third attempt at statewide office in three election cycles.
lead_paragraph: MEDINA, Tex. — Kinky Friedman practiced his smile as he sat on the front porch of his cabin on a secluded Hill Country ranch in December, three dogs scampering around his legs. He said he had gotten an instructive tip from a former Miss Mississippi.

headline: Tunes for the New Year From the Home Team
abstract: The new year brings a wide range of brand-new albums from Texas recording artists, including Reverend Horton Heat returning to punk-infused rockabilly, Ray Benson going eclectic and Los Lonely Boys sounding like the Beatles.
lead_paragraph: Less than a month ago, a guide to prominent 2014 releases from Texas artists would have begun with a long-rumored Beyoncé album. Although she took that off the plate with her headline-grabbing stealth release on Dec. 13, a robust selection remains of Texans planning on ringing in the first part of the year with new albums. Our roundup — which ranges from a pair of Houston-based alternative rock acts to celebrated veterans branching out in new directions — hints at what the year may bring. And sets from Don Henley, the Austin rock band Spoon and the Old 97s, although still unscheduled, are on the horizon.

headline: Texas Right to Life Criticized for Playing Politics With Ratings
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Texas Right to Life is being criticized by the Roman Catholic bishops of Texas for giving low ratings on its 2013 scorecard to politicians who supported a particular end-of-life bill last year.
lead_paragraph: A rift on how to regulate end-of-life care that broke out during last year’s legislative session has carried over into this year’s election cycle.

headline: As Perry Exits, His Appointees Look for Havens
abstract: As Rick Perry’s time as governor draws to a close, many of those he has appointed since taking office in 2000 are seeking other government positions.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for The Tribune.

headline: Saying Farewell to a Rock Icon
abstract: Phil Everly, as half of the Everly Brothers, inspired the Beatles, Linda Ronstadt, Simon and Garfunkel and many others who recorded their songs and tried to emulate their ringing vocal alchemy.
lead_paragraph: Phil Everly, as half of the Everly Brothers, inspired the Beatles, Linda Ronstadt, Simon and Garfunkel and many others who recorded their songs and tried to emulate their ringing vocal alchemy.

headline: A League Less Nimble as Point Guards Go Down
abstract: Some of the best point guards in the N.B.A. are ailing, and the quality of play may be suffering as a result.
lead_paragraph: When the Los Angeles Clippers’ Chris Paul came careening off a screen — as he does so often during a game — and crashed to the floor Friday night in Dallas, separating his right shoulder, he joined what has become a distinguished list: ailing N.B.A. point guards.

headline: Donald H. Forst, Feisty Newspaper Editor, Dies at 81
abstract: Mr. Forst was the former top editor of New York Newsday, The Village Voice and The Boston Herald.
lead_paragraph: Donald H. Forst, the feisty former top editor of New York Newsday, The Village Voice and The Boston Herald, died on Saturday in Albany. He was 81.

headline: Overwhelmed Early, Colts Overcome Chiefs With Huge Comeback
abstract: The Colts trailed, 38-10, early in the third quarter but stormed back behind Andrew Luck, who threw for 443 yards and 4 scores, to beat the Chiefs in an A.F.C. wild-card game.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — The ball flew from the arms of Indianapolis running back Donald Brown, and with it, perhaps, went the Colts’ season. The ball bounced, though, off the back of an offensive lineman and then, like a trained dog, returned to the feet of quarterback Andrew Luck. He scooped it up, hopped and lunged, arms outstretched, into the end zone for a fourth-quarter touchdown.

headline: Webster Strengthens Grip on the Collegiate Game
abstract: Three teams from Webster University of St. Louis were among the top six finishers at the Pan-American Intercollegiate Championships in Lubbock, Tex.
lead_paragraph: The Pan-American Intercollegiate Team Chess Championship highlighted Webster University’s unchallenged dominance of collegiate chess.

headline: After Decades of Unexplained Mood Swings, a Quiet Place to Call Home
abstract: At age 54, when she was living in a homeless shelter, Cheryl McCray learned she had bipolar disorder.
lead_paragraph: For the first 54 years of her life, Cheryl McCray did not understand why she flew off the handle and suffered such violent mood swings.

headline: Charred Body of Kidnapped Man Is Found on Long Island
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Kidnapping', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The body of Menachem Stark, 39, a prominent Hasidic real estate developer who was abducted on Thursday, was discovered in a trash bin.
lead_paragraph: The charred body of a prominent Hasidic real estate developer who was kidnapped Thursday near his Brooklyn office has been found in a smoldering trash bin outside a Long Island gas station, the police said on Saturday.

headline: South Sudan and Rebels Open Peace Talks
abstract: The urgency of the talks was evident as gunfire rattled the nerves of residents in Juba, South Sudan’s capital, on Saturday evening after weeks of relative calm there.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The South Sudanese government and representatives of rebel forces met for the formal opening of peace talks Saturday evening in Ethiopia, part of the diplomatic effort to halt weeks of fighting in the young nation.

headline: Power Vacuum in Middle East Lifts Militants
abstract: The bloodshed that has engulfed Iraq, Lebanon and Syria exposes the emergence of a post-American Middle East in which no broker has the will or power to contain the region’s sectarian hatreds.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The images of recent days have an eerie familiarity, as if the horrors of the past decade were being played back: masked gunmen recapturing the Iraqi cities of Falluja and Ramadi, where so many American soldiers died fighting them. Car bombs exploding amid the elegance of downtown Beirut. The charnel house of Syria’s worsening civil war.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 4, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Plane Uses Bronx Highway for Runway
abstract: Bystanders described the scene after the pilot of a small plane pulled off a successful emergency landing on the northbound lane of the Major Deegan Expressway in the Bronx on Saturday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: Bystanders described the scene after the pilot of a small plane pulled off a successful emergency landing on the northbound lane of the Major Deegan Expressway in the Bronx on Saturday afternoon.

headline: A Struggle Over the Jordan Valley
abstract: As a strategic corridor along the West Bank border with Jordan, the Jordan Valley holds deep meaning for many.
lead_paragraph: As a strategic corridor along the West Bank border with Jordan, the Jordan Valley holds deep meaning for many.

headline: Strategic Corridor in West Bank Remains a Stumbling Block in Mideast Talks
abstract: As negotiators struggle to make headway in peace talks, they remain at odds over the strategic corridor that runs between the populous heartland of the West Bank and the border with Jordan.
lead_paragraph: BARDALA, West Bank — The residents of this neglected Palestinian farming village in the northern Jordan Valley area of the West Bank say they get running water once every three days, which they store in bottles and cisterns.

headline: New Year, New Nets With Back-to-Back Wins
abstract: Despite a third-quarter lull, the Nets beat the Cavaliers at Barclays Center and achieved consecutive victories for only the second time this season.
lead_paragraph: After beating Oklahoma City on the road Thursday, the Nets returned home Saturday feeling about as pleased with themselves as they had since — well, let’s say October, before the season, when hope and hype for the team were at an apex.

headline: Elizabeth Goff and Russel Santillanes
abstract: The bride works for a shirtmaker; the groom is in finance.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Jeanne Goff and Russel Edward Santillanes were married Saturday at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament in New York. Msgr. Robert B. O’Connor, a Roman Catholic priest and the church’s pastor, performed the ceremony.

headline: AnnaRose King and Michael Telis
abstract: The bride works at a film collective and writes and directs films; the groom is a law student at Georgetown.
lead_paragraph: AnnaRose McLaughlin King, a daughter of the Rev. Alison T. Moore of Brookline, Mass., and the late Roger M. King, was married Saturday to Michael Charles Telis, a son of Karen A. Telis and Dr. Sherman H. Telis of Washington. The bride’s mother, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Weylin B. Seymour’s, an event space in Brooklyn, with Rabbi Richard Davis assisting.

headline: Rochelle Behrens and Sacha Litman
abstract: The bride owns a shirtmaking company; the groom works in data analytics.
lead_paragraph: Rochelle Alexis Behrens and Sacha Frédéric Litman were married Saturday evening at the Rancho Bernardo Inn and Resort in San Diego. Rabbi Deborah R. Prinz officiated, with Rabbi Marc Baker assisting.

headline: Amira Ibrahim and Nathan Bliss
abstract: The bride works for a foundation; the groom works in economic development.
lead_paragraph: Amira Tumbaga Ibrahim and Nathan Joseph Bliss were married Saturday at the Liberty Warehouse in Brooklyn. The Rev. Constance Hulla, the pastor at the Coney Island Gospel Assembly Church, officiated.

headline: Teammates, On Court and Off
abstract: A summer-camp friendship grows into a marriage.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Esther Rosenberg and Evan Stuart Levine were married Saturday evening at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in New York. Rabbi Getzel Davis, a cousin of the bride, officiated.

headline: Alexandra Andrews, Christopher Beha
abstract: The bride is studying at the Pratt Institute; the groom is a deputy editor at Harper’s.
lead_paragraph: Alexandra Drury Andrews and Christopher R. Beha were married Saturday at the James Burden Mansion in New York. Sarah Ritchie, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated at the ceremony; James J. Beha II, the groom’s twin brother, led the couple in their vows and exchange of rings.

headline: Rebecca Garcia and Andrew Spiegel
abstract: Guests thought it was an engagement party. Surprise!
lead_paragraph: Rebecca Garcia and Andrew Jay Spiegel were married on the evening of Jan. 4 in what the guests had been told was going to be the couple’s engagement party. Rabbi Esther Lederman led the surprise wedding ceremony at the Four Seasons Hotel in Washington.

headline: Angelique Velez and Jeremy Sina
abstract: The bride helps develop affordable housing; the groom works with multinational corporations on tax planning.
lead_paragraph: Angelique Velez and Jeremy Daniel Sina were married Saturday at the Rincon Beach Resort in Añasco, Puerto Rico. Judge Rafael A. Ramos Sáenz of the municipal court in Aguadilla, Puerto Rico, officiated.

headline: Teresa LaBarbera, Brandon Dufour
abstract: The groom met the bride when he was a guest on her television show.
lead_paragraph: Teresa Anne LaBarbera and Brandon John Dufour were married Wednesday at the Basilica of the Immaculate Conception in Waterbury, Conn. The Very Rev. John J. Bevins, a Roman Catholic priest and the church’s rector, performed the ceremony.

headline: Daniella Rohr, Samuel Adelsberg
abstract: The bride is a law student; the groom is an adviser to an undersecretary of the Treasury.
lead_paragraph: Daniella Esther Rohr, a daughter of Pamela L. Rohr and George Rohr of Manhattan, was married Tuesday to Samuel S. Adelsberg, a son of Renée Adelsberg and Steven Adelsberg of Brooklyn. Rabbi Ruben C. Gober officiated at Spring Studios, an event space in Manhattan.

headline: A Romance Goes From Head to Heart
abstract: A long email correspondence turns into a real relationship.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Catherine Galletly and Grant Olney Passmore were married Saturday by the Rev. Davis Bailey, a Presbyterian minister, at the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia.

headline: After Long Wait, Good Things Come to Visiting Saints
abstract: The Saints earned their first road playoff victory 46 seasons after their debut in the N.F.L., beating the Eagles on a 32-yard field goal as time expired.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The New Orleans Saints joined the N.F.L. in 1967 and did not make the playoffs for 20 years. It took the Saints another 13 years to win a playoff game. And Saturday night, 46 seasons after their debut in the N.F.L., they finally won a road playoff game.

headline: Low on Funds, ‘Spider-Man’ Dims Its Last Lights
abstract: The $75 million production of “Spider-Man,” the most expensive musical in history and one of the most troubled, ended a run of three years and two months.
lead_paragraph: It wouldn’t have been a fitting final performance of Broadway’s “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” if something hadn’t gone wrong.

headline: Corrections: January 5, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on January 5, 2014.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: On Tour of Mideast, Kerry Says Iran Might Play Role in Syria Peace Talks
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry’s suggestion Sunday that Iranian diplomats might participate in peace talks on Syria was the first time a senior American official had indicated that Iran might have a role.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Secretary of State John Kerry said on Sunday that Iran might play a role at the peace talks on Syria in Switzerland this month.

headline: Michelle Obama Extends Her Hawaii Vacation
abstract: President Obama returned to Washington Saturday evening, but the first lady will be staying in Hawaii for several days to spend time with friends in advance of her upcoming 50th birthday.
lead_paragraph: HONOLULU — When President Obama departed Hawaii Saturday evening he left behind one notable thing — his wife, Michelle.

headline: My Year of Mom Rage
abstract: Is our collective, Internet-driven rage about everything from Miley Cyrus to gun control any more effective than my daughter’s temper tantrums over my insistence that she wear pants?
lead_paragraph: It’s time to put on pants, and my daughter is sprawled on the floor sobbing. “I don’t want them!” she cries. “I don’t wike dem!” My daughter is 2, and she refuses to wear anything except fancy dresses. Today she is wearing a white Easter dress with a green sash and a big pink flower. Never mind that it’s winter and we live in Iowa, where it’s 20 degrees outside. I’ve tried reasoning and pleading with her, and finally we reach a compromise. She can wear the dress as long as she wears pants underneath and a sweater. I get the sweater on her. It’s pink, so that helps. But not the pants.

headline: American Dialect Society Chooses ‘Because’ as Word of the Year
abstract: “Because” is increasingly being used to introduce a noun or adjective rather than a full clause, as in “because tired” or “because awesome.”
lead_paragraph: After a year dominated by upstarts like “selfie,” “bitcoin” and “twerk,” the American Dialect Society’s Word of the Year honor for 2013 has gone to a seemingly old-hat vocabulary item: “because.”

headline: Urban Dictionary’s Next Phase: Global and Mobile
abstract: Urban Dictionary, which has a large following online, is working to position itself as a mobile service too.
lead_paragraph: Urban Dictionary, the crowdsourced online dictionary, has slowly gained a cult following over the last decade and a half that has turned the bootstrapped site into the default dictionary for the Internet.

headline: Jet Skids Into Snowbank at J.F.K. Airport
abstract: No one was reported injured aboard the Delta regional flight from Toronto, but all flights were suspended for two hours Sunday morning at John F. Kennedy International Airport.
lead_paragraph: A plane skidded off a taxiway and into a snowbank at John F. Kennedy International Airport on Sunday morning, causing all domestic and international flights to be suspended for two hours while workers salted and sanded taxiways and runways, transportation officials said.

headline: In Our Pages: January 6
keywords: ['Berlin Wall', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Robberies and Thefts']
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: 1914: Hotel Jewelry Thieves Arrested In Paris

headline: Founder of Avant-Garde Theater Tackles a New Scene
abstract: Judith Malina, 87, a co-founder of The Living Theatre, had to move to an assisted-living facility in New Jersey after she lost her lease on the Lower East Side theater and the commercial space above it, where she had lived for six years.
lead_paragraph: “I couldn’t pay the rent,” said Judith Malina, 87, the artistic director and co-founder of The Living Theater, explaining why a year ago she lost the site of her Lower East Side theater company and the commercial space above it, where she had lived for six years.

headline: Low Turnout in Bangladesh Elections Amid Boycott and Violence
abstract: The main opposition group refused to participate in the voting, driving down turnout, and political violence left at least 19 people dead.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Amid a deepening conflict between Bangladesh’s two main political parties, the scene here in the capital as polls opened for the general elections on Sunday was ominous, with black-clad special forces units and soldiers in combat gear patrolling nearly empty boulevards.

headline: U.S. Vessel to Aid Ships Stuck in Antarctica
abstract: Australia said it had asked an American icebreaker to help rescue Chinese and Russian vessels surrounded by ice floes in Antarctica.
lead_paragraph: TAISHAN, China — Australian officials have asked an American icebreaker to help with the rescue of Chinese and Russian vessels that are surrounded by ice floes off Antarctica, according to an announcement on Sunday by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority.

headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13, 49) DOWNTON ABBEY A fourth round of the writer Julian Fellowes’s sudsy British hit about aristocrats and their servants begins as Lady Mary (Michelle Dockery) mourns the death of her husband, Matthew, who was killed on the day of the birth of their baby, George, at the end of last season. But Mary finds motherhood to be scant solace, and Matthew’s death has left the estate’s financial future shaky, since he apparently did not leave a will. Meanwhile, Lady Edith (Laura Carmichael) appears to have at long last found love with the editor Michael Gregson (Charles Edwards); Lady Rose (Lily James), the niece of the Earl of Grantham (Hugh Bonneville), stirs things up with her newfound fondness for jazz and her particular appreciation for the singer Jack Ross (Gary Carr); and Isobel Crawley (Penelope Wilton) struggles with her place in the family, now that her son Matthew is no longer in the picture. (Sophie McShera, as Daisy, is above.) “The narrative this time around is even more stretched, derivative and repetitive than Season 3’s, but almost ingeniously so: It is both utterly predictable and surprisingly addictive,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. “ ‘Downton Abbey’ is long past its sell-by date, yet is still remarkably palatable.”

headline: Eusebio, Who Represented the Best of Soccer and of Portugal, Dies at 71
abstract: Eusebio, an international sports icon, led Portugal to a third-place finish at the 1966 World Cup and was voted one of the 10 best players of all time.
lead_paragraph: Soccer fans called him the Black Panther, in the manner of the day, because he was from Mozambique, playing for Portugal, but there was little feline about Eusebio. He was big in the beams and solid around the middle even when he was 24 and, for a few magical weeks, the most captivating player of the 1966 World Cup.

headline: As Deep Freeze Hits, Moviegoers Return ‘Frozen’ to Box-Office Top Spot
abstract: After a six week run, “Frozen” sold an astounding $20.7 million in tickets.
lead_paragraph: “Frozen” became the rarest of hits over the weekend: Instead of shuffling off toward DVD, as most movies playing in wide release do after about a month, the Disney musical surged back to the top spot at the North American box office by selling an astounding $20.7 million in tickets. “Frozen” — benefiting from top-notch reviews, a shortage of family-friendly movies and, perhaps, the thematically appropriate extreme winter weather in much of the United States — has now taken in roughly $297.8 million over its six-week domestic run, for a global total of $639.9 million.

headline: Senators Differ Sharply on Penalty for Snowden
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Senator Rand Paul said he did not believe that Edward J. Snowden deserved the death penalty or life in prison for exposing national secrets, but Senator Charles E. Schumer said he should stand trial and face the consequences.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A debate over whether Edward J. Snowden deserves lenience or the strict treatment the Obama administration has demanded for divulging a vast array of national secrets drew sharply opposing views on Sunday from two prominent senators.

headline: Fire in Luxury High-Rise Kills One and Displaces Dozens in Hell’s Kitchen
abstract: A second resident was seriously injured in the fire, which broke out on the 20th floor of the 42-story building on West 43rd Street.
lead_paragraph: A 27-year-old man was killed and dozens of residents were displaced Sunday in a three-alarm fire at a luxury high-rise building in Hell’s Kitchen, officials said.

headline: Co-Pilot Killed in Plane Crash at Aspen Airport
abstract: Two other people were injured when the private plane crashed as it tried to land near the runway in Colorado, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A co-pilot was killed and two other people were injured after a private plane crashed as it tried to land at the Aspen airport in Colorado on Sunday afternoon, officials said.

headline: Fresh Fare Is Served Well Chilled
abstract: With 14 pieces by 13 different composers, this Here and Now program felt somewhat like a potluck dinner where the few tantalizingly accomplished dishes are finished all too soon.
lead_paragraph: Fourteen performers assembled on the old coffee barge under the Brooklyn Bridge during Thursday evening’s blizzard for Bargemusic’s Here and Now winter festival of contemporary fare. With 14 pieces by 13 composers, the program felt somewhat like a potluck dinner where the few tantalizingly accomplished dishes are finished all too soon, leaving you to pick at multiple versions of baked macaroni.

headline: U.S. Ambassador Renews Ties to His Ancestral Village
abstract: In December, Gary Locke, the departing United States ambassador to China, made his fifth visit to his ancestral village, in a region that was once the main point of departure for immigrants to America.
lead_paragraph: A light drizzle was falling on the village of Jilong on the afternoon of Dec. 17 when a large black sport utility vehicle pulled up to a parking area next to the pond. Out of it stepped Gary Locke, the American ambassador, who this month is expected to leave his post and return to his hometown of Seattle. This was Mr. Locke’s fifth visit to his ancestral village in the Taishan region of Guangdong Province, and his third and possibly final one as ambassador to China.

headline: In Love and Traffic
abstract: Teresa LaBarbera was the local traffic reporter at WTNH in Connecticut. Brandon Dufour was a driving instructor. When they met on-air during a news segment, the connection was immediate.
lead_paragraph: Teresa LaBarbera was the local traffic reporter at WTNH in Connecticut. Brandon Dufour was a driving instructor. When they met on-air during a news segment, the connection was immediate.

headline: N.F.L. Wild-Card Sunday
abstract: Highlights from Sunday’s N.F.L. playoff games.
lead_paragraph: Highlights from Sunday’s N.F.L. playoff games.

headline: In Palm Springs, 2 Bonos and Many Hopefuls
abstract: The film festival there is a chance for Oscar contenders facing long odds to make headway, and that’s just what Meryl Streep, Tom Hanks and others did.
lead_paragraph: PALM SPRINGS, Calif. — You know it’s not a standard Oscar whistle-stop when Bono (BAHN-oh) is the less revered Bono (BONE-oh), Julia Roberts does her best to disprove the orchestra’s “Oh, Pretty Woman” introduction music, and your silver-haired table mate introduces himself like this: “Hello. I have really bad sinuses.”

headline: De Blasio Holds Open House at Gracie Mansion, His New Home
abstract: New York’s new mayor, Bill de Blasio, like another populist leader, President Andrew Jackson, threw his official residence open to a long line of well-wishers.
lead_paragraph: Gracie Mansion, the buttercream-hued mayoral residence on a bluff overlooking the East River, has stood stately but mostly silent for more than 12 years, its elegant interiors reserved for the formal functions of a mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg, who chose to live elsewhere.

headline: Bengals Seek Respect, but Chargers Earn It
abstract: Capitalizing on three second-half turnovers by Andy Dalton, the upstart Chargers extended the Bengals’ playoff-victory drought to 23 years.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — Here along the banks of the murky Ohio River, where a generation has wallowed in the futility of the beloved Bengals, the paradigm has shifted: Respect is gained not by reaching the postseason but by winning there.

headline: Democrats Press Revival of Jobless Aid That Expired
abstract: Republicans responded that they would support renewing long-term supplemental benefits, which lapsed last month, if spending cuts offset the cost.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democrats continued on Sunday to argue for restoring long-term unemployment insurance for more than a million Americans who are out of work, days after the benefits lapsed, as lawmakers prepared to return from their recess.

headline: A Double Dose of Chekhov
abstract: The director and multimedia-theater pioneer Jay Scheib has created a live cinematic adaptation of Chekhov’s unfinished play.
lead_paragraph: A century and a half ago, Anton Chekhov wrote a play while still a medical student. Never performed or published in his lifetime, it was discovered in a locked box years after his death. This sprawling 20-character work, left untitled, has subsequently appeared as “Play Without Title,” “Without Fathers,” “A Country Scandal,” “Don Juan in the Russian Manner” and as the film “Unfinished Piece for the Player Piano.”

headline: Make It One for My Baby and One More for the Books
abstract: In “The Trip to Echo Spring,” Olivia Laing combines literary analysis, memoir and travelogue in examining six writers and their alcoholism.
lead_paragraph: In “The Sutton Place Story,” John Cheever describes Deborah, “not quite 3 years old,” who, because of her home environment, “had naturally come to assume that cocktails were the axis of the adult world. She made Martinis in the sand pile and thought all the illustrations of cups, goblets, and glasses in her nursery books were filled with old-fashioneds.” Cheever and five other writers who had alcohol much on their minds (and in their livers) are brought together in Olivia Laing’s “The Trip to Echo Spring,” a combination of literary analysis, memoir and travelogue that is most beguiling and incisive when rambling through the work and lives of Cheever, Raymond Carver, F. Scott Fitzgerald, Ernest Hemingway, Tennessee Williams and John Berryman.

headline: Waltzing Right Past History in Austria
abstract: At this year’s Vienna Philharmonic annual New Year’s concerts, the focus was again on the music, not the orchestra’s past.
lead_paragraph: VIENNA — A year ago, in the days surrounding the Vienna Philharmonic’s internationally televised New Year’s concerts, the orchestra was surrounded by turmoil. This year, not so much.

headline: Broken Bow Hairs, Puns and Idiosyncratic Style
abstract: Pekka Kuusisto and Nico Muhly make unexpected musical connections during their concert on Friday at Le Poisson Rouge.
lead_paragraph: It is increasingly common for adventurous musicians like Chris Thile to take a mix-and-match approach to programming. Instead of performing a Bach partita or complete sonata in reverential entirety, he might juxtapose movements with eclectic repertory to highlight unlikely connections.

headline: A Satire With Targets Not So Well Remembered
abstract: The New York Gilbert & Sullivan Players take on “Patience,” which takes aim at artists like the poet Algernon Charles Swinburne and the painter James McNeill Whistler.
lead_paragraph: If New York City did not have its very own Albert Bergeret, we would need to invent — or at least import — him. Since 1974, Mr. Bergeret, the artistic director of the New York Gilbert & Sullivan Players, has done yeoman’s work guarding and promoting the peerless operettas and traditions of the English duo for which his company is named. A life without opportunities to hear those witty, wise pieces performed faithfully is not something I care to think about.

headline: An Actor Dons His Singer-Songwriter Hat
abstract: Humor, storytelling and musicianship came through during the actor Jeff Daniels’s set at 54 Below in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Daniels’s folksy monologue “Recreational Vehicle” is only half as long as its prototype, Arlo Guthrie’s “Alice’s Restaurant.” But this rambling true story of a family road trip to the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y., in a 28-foot “Jayco Winnebago” driven by Mr. Daniels has a similar thread of absurdist, self-deprecating humor and is almost as funny.

headline: Seeking Loved Ones, Including Themselves
abstract: Two solo shows, “Hip” and “Darkling,” have their author-stars embodying many characters at the IRT Theater in the West Village.
lead_paragraph: The actresses Nora Woolley and Kim Katzberg bear a mild resemblance to each other, and that — along with a gift for writing their own material and quick-changing into an array of characters — make them suitable partners for “Hip” and “Darkling,” two audacious solo shows paired at the IRT Theater.

headline: Strip-Squeezing at the Truscott Board-a-Match Teams
abstract: The Truscott Board-a-Match Teams competition was held on Dec. 29 and 30, the last two days of the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The Truscott Board-a-Match Teams competition was held on Dec. 29 and 30, the last two days of the Edgar Kaplan Winter Regional in Manhattan.

headline: Eusébio, 71, Legend of Portuguese Soccer, Dies
abstract: Eusébio, a Portuguese soccer star of the 1960s and 1970s, died on Sunday at the age of 71.
lead_paragraph: London — Eusébio, the wonderful soccer player of the 1960s and 1970s, died on Sunday at the age of 71.

headline: Bit of Cheesecake
abstract: The return of Zhouquin Burnikel.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Cool Article Alert! Constructor extraordinaire Ian Livengood and his J.A.S.A. class were interviewed for “DNAinfo New York”. You can read more about the class and its members here.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Jan. 6
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: America and India
abstract: Reciprocity on diplomats’ rights just went out the window.
lead_paragraph: Reciprocity on diplomats’ rights just went out the window.

headline: The Children of ThinkFilm
abstract: ThinkFilm was founded in 2001 as an independent art-house distributor by several former executives at Lionsgate. The company became known for award-winning films like “Born Into Brothels” and “Half Nelson.” After the company closed in 2008, many former ThinkFilm employees went on to lead new film businesses.
lead_paragraph: ThinkFilm was founded in 2001 as an independent art-house distributor by several former executives at Lionsgate. The company became known for award-winning films like “Born Into Brothels” and “Half Nelson.” After the company closed in 2008, many former ThinkFilm employees went on to lead new film businesses.

headline: Does Immigration Mean ‘France Is Over’?
abstract: As an expatriate in Paris, I am not subject to the rising xenophobia directed at the country’s mostly African immigrants. But I am a witness to it.
lead_paragraph: I.

headline: Which Path to Control Drinking?
abstract: Readers respond to an Op-Ed article about ways to change drinking habits.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: It’s Time for Congress to Restore Jobless Benefits
keywords: ['Unemployment Insurance', 'United States Economy', 'Age, Chronological', 'Discrimination', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Readers take exception to the political forces at work in ending benefits for a million unemployed.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Judgments on Edward Snowden and the N.S.A.
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: Readers react to an editorial urging clemency for Edward J. Snowden.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Food and Social Media
keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Fast Food Industry', 'Social Media']
abstract: The Humane Society of the United States responds to a Business Day article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Japan Defends Shrine Visit
abstract: The consul general of Japan in New York defends the visit of its prime minister to a war shrine.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Freed Russian Oligarch Leaves Germany for Switzerland With Family
abstract: A statement from aides to Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the former oil tycoon, said he has “not yet made any plans about permanent residency in Switzerland or anywhere else.”
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the former oil tycoon recently freed after a decade in prison in Russia, has left Berlin and arrived by train in Switzerland, where he and his wife will oversee their teenage sons’ return to school, according to a statement from Mr. Khodorkovsky’s aides, who called the trip “a family matter.”

headline: Hawaii Makes Its Case for Obama’s Library: Why Not Bring It to the Beach?
abstract: Some in Hawaii, eager to claim President Obama as their own, have mounted a well-organized campaign to encourage him to place at least part of his postpresidential operation in the state.
lead_paragraph: HONOLULU — When Gov. Neil Abercrombie of Hawaii was asked to appear in a video urging President Obama to make the state the home of his presidential library, the governor’s appeal was simple and, he said, reflective of the state’s “Aloha spirit.”

headline: Federer Falls to Hewitt, but Australian Open Awaits
abstract: Although Roger Federer lost in the final of the Brisbane International, he said he was eager for the Australian Open to begin next week.
lead_paragraph: BRISBANE, Australia — This stage of Roger Federer’s career will primarily be measured by his success in fending off younger players, but he finished the first week of his 2014 season with a rare loss to an older foe.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Jan. 6
abstract: Samsung Electronics will report its fourth-quarter earnings estimates, the insider trading trial of Mathew Martoma will begin and the European Central Bank will review its monetary policy.
lead_paragraph: SAMSUNG EARNINGS 2014 will be a tough year for Samsung Electronics, the largest cellphone and television maker in the world. Its stock recently took a beating amid concerns of slowing profit growth from smartphone sales, and the company is under pressure to continue releasing innovative new products to compete with Apple and a crop of handset makers in China. On Tuesday, when the South Korean giant is expected to report earnings estimates for the fourth quarter, investors will keep a close eye on the company’s sales of cellphones, televisions and other items during the holiday shopping season, the most lucrative time of year for electronics manufacturers.

headline: Abolish the Corporate Income Tax
keywords: ['Corporate Taxes', 'Income Tax', 'United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: It might sound like a gift to the rich, but eliminating or at least lowering the corporate tax rate would help workers.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — JOBS don’t grow out of thin air, especially well-paying ones. They require, among other things, companies that are willing to operate where you live. Just ask the Seattle-based District 751 of the machinists’ union, which was worried that Boeing will build its new 777X airliner someplace far away where it is cheaper to produce. Last month the union offered contract concessions, as its president explained, to ensure “the long-term success” of Boeing in Washington State. And on Friday, Boeing machinists approved a contract with concessions to keep assembly of the plane in the area.

headline: Spain’s Solar Pullback Threatens Pocketbooks
abstract: The Spanish government has changed its mind on a law offering attractive rates for solar energy, and instead will make producers pay a charge on electricity they generate and use themselves.
lead_paragraph: ÁGUILAS, Spain — Six years ago, Justo Cruz Rodríguez, who runs a small business here designing signs, was looking for a way to generate a steady, if modest, pension for himself and his father.

headline: Give Rose a Shot at the Hall
abstract: Pete Rose was banished from baseball for gambling, but is still one of the game’s greats.
lead_paragraph: THE Baseball Hall of Fame will announce its new inductees on Wednesday — a burst of warmth in the cold, diamond-less winter — and the crop of potential inductees includes, for the second straight year, Barry Bonds and Roger Clemens.

headline: The Bubble Is Back
keywords: ['Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Mortgages', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Real estate prices are once again outstripping the cost of renting.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — IN November, housing starts were up 23 percent, and there was cheering all around. But the crowd would quiet down if it realized that another housing bubble had begun to grow.

headline: Two Decades of Change Have Boston Sparkling
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: Mayor Thomas M. Menino leaves office on Monday having presided over and facilitated one of the most successful urban renaissance stories in modern American history.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — During the 1988 presidential campaign, Vice President George Bush famously shined a spotlight on the “open sewer” that was Boston Harbor. He blamed his opponent, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, for failing to clean it up and called the harbor, which was choked with sludge and contaminated with chemicals, the dirtiest body of water in the country.

headline: Crack Cocaine Limbo
keywords: ['Mandatory Sentencing', 'Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Discrimination', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Congress repudiated the harsh penalties for crack cocaine use, but many sentenced under the old law continue to languish in prison.
lead_paragraph: President Obama earned a rare moment of bipartisan acclaim last month when he commuted the sentences of eight long-serving federal prisoners. Their crack cocaine offenses had resulted in the harsh penalties mandated by a sentencing formula that Congress repudiated when it passed the Fair Sentencing Act of 2010. The old formula, under which possession of a quantity of crack earned the same sentence as possession of 100 times that quantity of powdered cocaine, was “now recognized as unjust,” the president said.

headline: In Bid to Be Council Speaker, a Tenants’ Champion Fights an Uphill Battle
abstract: Daniel R. Garodnick is challenging Melissa Mark-Viverito, who is backed by a City Council majority, powerful labor unions and Mayor Bill de Blasio.
lead_paragraph: In eight years on the City Council, Daniel R. Garodnick has pushed for police reform, rallied with labor leaders in support of paid sick days and fought to preserve middle-class housing in his district.

headline: Acing the Course at Chapel Hill
abstract: The indictment of a former professor who ran bogus courses for football players is the latest example of how collegiate sports are warping academic life.
lead_paragraph: Another shameful lesson in the multibillion-dollar entertainment industry euphemistically referred to as collegiate sports is playing out at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. A former professor was indicted on fraud charges last month after running dozens of bogus and no-show courses heavily enrolled with student athletes looking for easy academic credits.

headline: Republican Disdain for the Jobless
keywords: ['Unemployment Insurance', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Senate will vote on unemployment benefits. But the House? It’s planning another meaningless, symbolic vote on health care.
lead_paragraph: One of the first votes the Senate plans to take when it returns Monday is on restoring unemployment benefits to 1.3 million people who lost them on Dec. 28. It’s hard to imagine a more important action for those who have been out of work the longest and for the economy.

headline: Iraqis Make Gains Against Militants in Key City
abstract: Iraqi security forces and their tribal allies reclaimed parts of Ramadi from Qaeda-linked militants, officials said, but the insurgents appeared to maintain control of much of Falluja.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Iraqi security forces and their tribal allies made gains in heavy fighting on Sunday in Ramadi, reclaiming parts of the city from Sunni militants aligned with Al Qaeda, security officials and tribal leaders said.

headline: Seminoles Tight End’s Competitive Drive Recalls His Grandfather Nicklaus
abstract: Nick O’Leary is known for three things: being the grandson of the great golfer Jack Nicklaus; being a favorite target of quarterback Jameis Winston; and surviving a horrific accident.
lead_paragraph: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif. — Nancy O’Leary named her second son Nicklaus, her maiden name. She figured he could go by Nick but wanted to honor her parents, Jack and Barbara Nicklaus.

headline: Another Step Forward on Okinawa
keywords: ['Military Bases and Installations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials']
abstract: If the United States is to maintain a military presence on the island for the long term, it will have to be responsive to residents’ concerns.
lead_paragraph: For nearly two decades, Japan and the United States have been mired in a dispute over the American military presence on Okinawa. Late last month,  the two sides took an important step toward resolving the issue when the Okinawa governor, Hirokazu Nakaima, approved a landfill permit clearing the way for construction of a new base on a remote coast of the island. There are still hurdles, but the permit was a significant breakthrough.

headline: NBC Begins Swarm of Ads to Lift ‘Today’ Back to Top
abstract: The NBC morning news program, which has been second to “Good Morning America” for 16 months, will open its offensive with a major promotional campaign.
lead_paragraph: The “Today” show, so accustomed to winning, has grown impatient with losing.

headline: $1 Billion as Milestone and Omen
abstract: Silicon Valley today is a huge, undulating bubble. But which companies are overvalued and which are not is the $1 billion question.
lead_paragraph: Fab.com, an online retailer selling affordable high design, last year seemed as if it could be the next Amazon.

headline: Before Signing a Strong Arm, Teams Should Heed Vick’s Dark Past
abstract: Eagles quarterback Michael Vick may wear a different jersey next season, but teams evaluating him should remember the horrors of Vick’s dogfighting ring.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Michael Vick, the quarterback known as much for his rap sheet as his athletic skill, watched the football tumble through the uprights not long before midnight on Saturday and knew his time was up.

headline: ThinkFilm, a Short-Lived but Wily Distributor, Still Influences Industry
abstract: Alumni of ThinkFilm have become a force in an industry that has been learning to think smaller, make do with less and live more by wit than a fat bankroll.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In two weeks, the feisty operatives of an ever tighter, tougher independent film business will gather at the annual Sundance Film Festival.

headline: A Developer Is Mourned and Vilified in Brooklyn
keywords: ['Kidnapping', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Bankruptcies', 'Building (Construction)', 'Hasidism', 'Asphyxiation, Choking, and Suffocation']
abstract: A day after the charred body of a prominent Hasidic real estate developer was found in a smoking trash bin on Long Island, more than a thousand mourners gathered for his funeral in the heart of Hasidic Williamsburg.
lead_paragraph: A day after the charred body of a prominent Hasidic real estate developer was identified in a smoking trash bin on Long Island, more than a thousand mourners gathered for his funeral in the heart of Hasidic Williamsburg. They grieved for the man they called a pillar of his synagogue and his community, a father of eight who had been quick to donate and quick to lend.

headline: Does the U.S. Need Another War on Poverty?
abstract: Fifty years after President Lyndon B. Johnson's declaration, much has changed, but much remains the same. Or does it?

headline: Print Starts to Settle Into Its Niches
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: At a time when e-book sales seem to be flattening, there is something to be learned from Kevin Kelly’s self-published print catalog, a collection of reviews accrued from a website over the years.
lead_paragraph: Kevin Kelly is not a dumb guy — far from it actually. As the founding executive editor of Wired and one of the people who helped build The Well, among the earliest online communities, he has done a good job of seeing what is coming next for decades.

headline: House G.O.P. Trims Agenda, Looking to Avert Election-Year Trouble
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The House majority leader, Eric Cantor, is quietly playing down expectations for any major legislative achievements in the final year of the 113th Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The “do nothing” Congress is preparing to do even less.

headline: Zero Tolerance, Reconsidered
abstract: Schools across the country are reforming a destructive disciplinary policy.
lead_paragraph: Schools across the country are rethinking “zero tolerance” discipline policies under which children have been suspended, even arrested, for minor offenses like cursing, getting into shoving matches and other garden-variety misbehavior that in years past would have been resolved with detention or meetings with a child’s parents.

headline: 49ers Feel Joy, if Not Their Toes
abstract: Phil Dawson kicked a 33-yard field goal as time expired, giving the 49ers a victory at frigid Lambeau Field and sending them to a second-round playoff game at Carolina.
lead_paragraph: GREEN BAY, Wis. — The bitterly cold forecast for Sunday’s N.F.C. wild-card game at Lambeau Field concerned San Francisco 49ers Coach Jim Harbaugh. So twice, on Saturday and again before kickoff, he asked his quarterback, Colin Kaepernick, to reconsider his plan to play in short sleeves and without gloves.

headline: The Muslim Brotherhood, Back in a Fight to Survive
abstract: Members of the Brotherhood, now outlawed and underground, said they were trying to bolster their ranks for a long struggle against Egypt’s military-backed government.
lead_paragraph: FAYOUM, Egypt — They hide in safe houses on the outskirts of this city, talk only fleetingly on cellphones and avoid the cafes where they used to meet. Heavy scarves obscure their identities when they venture out to join protests.

headline: New Campaign Markets Activia to Wider Audience
abstract: A new campaign for the yogurt brand aims to reach younger consumers and men, without the actress Jamie Lee Curtis.
lead_paragraph: A MUCH-NOTICED, much-parodied relationship between a star and a brand is ending as a campaign for Activia probiotic yogurt, scheduled to begin on Monday, replaces the actress Jamie Lee Curtis with three endorsers.

headline: Wild-Card Weather Balmy, Compared With the ‘Freezer Bowl’
abstract: The Bengals-Chargers game and the Packers-49ers matchup on Sunday were played in conditions far better than a 1982 playoff contest in Cincinnati.
lead_paragraph: CINCINNATI — The Cincinnati Bengals commemorated the franchise’s 1981 team before the current squad’s 27-10 loss Sunday in an A.F.C. wild-card game against the San Diego Chargers.

headline: Latin Jazz Stalwart Struggles to Make Sweet Sounds Again
abstract: The flutist Dave Valentin used to play around the world, but since 2012 he has been recovering from a stroke, without savings or health insurance.
lead_paragraph: The autographed posters and concert photos in Dave Valentin’s living room attest to his status as one of the pre-eminent flutists in Latin jazz. Tucked among 78s tacked to the wall, they show Mr. Valentin smiling alongside performers like Tito Puente and aficionados like Bill Cosby. Nearby, a bunch of “All Access” stage passes from concerts dangle from a nail like a good-luck charm.

headline: Fog-Wreathed Paradise, Built by a Billionaire Under a Cloud
abstract: Deng Hong, the founder of Jiuzhai Paradise, one of China’s biggest hotels, is a well-connected billionaire now under investigation by the Communist Party’s anti-corruption commission.
lead_paragraph: JIUZHAIGOU, China — Inside the hotel’s front entrance, a white mechanical yak nods and says “Moo.” Beyond it is the centerpiece of the compound: a vast glass atrium with a replica of a Tibetan and ethnic Qiang village filled with three-story stone and wood buildings, each housing a restaurant or bar. Corn husks sit atop the roofs.

headline: Southwest’s Dwindling Water Supply
abstract: If Lake Mead drops below 1,000 feet above sea level, millions of people will lose their source of water.
lead_paragraph: If Lake Mead drops below 1,000 feet above sea level, millions of people will lose their source of water.

headline: Colorado River Drought Forces a Painful Reckoning for States
abstract: Drought and population growth are driving a reassessment of how the 1,450-mile Colorado, the Southwest’s only major river, can continue to slake the thirst of one of the nation’s fastest-growing regions.
lead_paragraph: LAKE MEAD, Nev. — The sinuous Colorado River and its slew of man-made reservoirs from the Rockies to southern Arizona are being sapped by 14 years of drought nearly unrivaled in 1,250 years.

headline: 16-Year-Old Is Fatally Shot on His Way Home From a Party in Brownsville
abstract: Iquan Williams’s parents had set a firm curfew and no-parties rule, but the trouble forecast on Facebook ended his life.
lead_paragraph: Iquan Williams’s parents said they kept him close: an early curfew and no hanging out late at house parties. They knew what trouble could come to a 16-year-old boy at certain times in certain corners of the city. Days earlier a young gunman had fired into a group of teenagers in the lobby of a housing project in Brownsville, Brooklyn, wounding five, as a party thumped upstairs.

headline: Democrats Quote the Pope
abstract: Democrats are using the words of Pope Francis in their speeches about poverty, income inequality and social justice.
lead_paragraph: Democrats are using the words of Pope Francis in their speeches about poverty, income inequality and social justice.

headline: O.J. Who? Rogues Vanish From Annals of Sport
keywords: ['Heisman Trophy', 'Archives and Records', 'Football (College)', 'Athletics and Sports', 'College Athletics', 'Records and Achievements', 'Football', 'Tour de France (Bicycle Race)', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Basketball (College)']
abstract: Colleges and sports teams that love to celebrate their history have become masters at editing it.
lead_paragraph: Among college football’s many rituals, the annual Heisman Trophy presentation remains one of the highlights. Fans and coaches and former stars gather in Manhattan each December to honor the season’s outstanding player. This season, about two dozen former winners stood on the stage as another member was added to their exclusive club.

headline: Popular Voice in the Capitol? It’s the Pope’s
keywords: ['Popes', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Poverty', 'Minimum Wage', 'Unemployment Insurance']
abstract: Democrats and Republicans alike are seizing on Pope Francis’ messages of economic justice and tolerance.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Shortly before leaving the Capitol for the holiday recess, Senate Democrats gathered behind closed doors to lay out an agenda for 2014. When the majority leader, Harry Reid, exhorted colleagues to “deal with the issue of income inequality,” the talk took a spiritual turn.

headline: Sudan’s Lost Boys Are Drawn Into War at Home
abstract: South Sudan’s Lost Boys, who had escaped the violence in their homeland only to be drawn back, are trying to survive the crisis that is threatening to tear their new country apart.
lead_paragraph: AWERIAL, South Sudan — When Jacob Atem was just a young boy, his parents were killed during the long war for independence from Sudan, and he found himself among the legions of orphaned children known as the Lost Boys wandering hundreds of miles across this part of Africa.

headline: Ireland Stirs Homegrown Flavor Into Tech Scene
keywords: ['Start-ups', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Venture Capital', 'Entrepreneurship']
abstract: Irish officials are using grants and tax breaks to help small start-ups find room among the Silicon Valley giants that employ thousands in Dublin.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — The Grand Canal Docks, an upscale business district here in the center of town, is a kind of home away from home for the big Silicon Valley companies like Google and Facebook. These international behemoths, in large part attracted by the low Irish corporate tax rates, have big presences here. And with their thousands of workers and bustling offices, they have long overshadowed the local start-up scene.

headline: Study Suggests Recovery in U.S. Is Relatively Vital

lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Academic heavyweights have been debating whether the current United States economy is so sluggish because of too much government stimulus or not enough, or because slower growth had become the norm even before the recession.

headline: From Petraeus Scandal, an Apostle for Privacy
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Privacy', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'E-Mail', 'ADULTERY', 'Libel and Slander']
abstract: Jill Kelley, whose name was released in connection with a scandal that toppled the chief of the Central Intelligence Agency, has filed suit for damages and a formal apology.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Jill Kelley still glances around for cameras before she leaves her large, six-columned house on Hillsborough Bay, and she rarely goes to the grocery store. Since November 2012, when the government released her name in connection with a scandal that brought down the head of the Central Intelligence Agency, Ms. Kelley has yet to return to her children’s schools, she said, and could not even summon the courage to go to their holiday plays.

headline: Seeking Independence, Three Men Start in the Kitchen

lead_paragraph: Five men were playing pool recently in the sunny, airy lobby of the Next Generation Center in the South Bronx. One of the men offered pool tips to the others. Later, two men greeted each other with a tight hug.

headline: With Marijuana Access on the Horizon, Patients Fear Potential Restrictions
keywords: ['Medical Marijuana', 'Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Marijuana']
abstract: Gov. Andrew Cuomo is to announce that he will allow 20 hospitals across New York to dispense medical marijuana, but there is little insight into the details.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Rivera, a cancer survivor, has a bag of pills in her night stand — white, gold and rust, big and little, antidepressants, antiemetics and tranquilizers — given to her by doctors. So it always seemed hypocritical to her that while she could possess such powerful mind-altering pharmaceuticals in fairly generous quantities, she was not allowed to legally smoke marijuana to relieve the nausea and pain of her cancer and chemotherapy.

headline: The Road to the National Championship
abstract: This college football season had more twists and turns than a board game. Follow Auburn’s and Florida State’s paths to Monday’s B.C.S. title game.
lead_paragraph: Even by college football’s standards, this season was turbulent, taking more turns than a board game. Auburn was unranked when the season started; Florida State was 11th. The expected contenders Alabama, Oregon and Ohio State fell by the wayside. The Tigers survived on last-second victories, while the Seminoles won every game by at least 14 points. On Monday night, they meet in the national championship game, competing for the sport’s biggest prize.

headline: What’s on Monday

lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (TCM) PRIVATE SCREENINGS: ROBERT OSBORNE After 20 years as the network’s host and interviewer, Mr. Osborne slides into the guest’s chair for a conversation with Alec Baldwin. Four of Mr. Osborne’s favorite movies follow: “The Third Man” (1949), Carol Reed’s thriller about a penniless American writer (Joseph Cotten) whose investigation into the death of a friend (Orson Welles, above) uncovers corruption in post-World War II Vienna, at 9:30; “Libeled Lady” (1936), Jack Conway’s screwball comedy in which a newspaper editor (Spencer Tracy), his fiancée (Jean Harlow) and a former reporter (William Powell) try to compromise an heiress (Myrna Loy) before she can sue for libel, at 1 a.m.; William Dieterle’s “Love Letters” (1945), about a soldier (Cotten, again) who falls for the woman (Jennifer Jones) who may have killed his best friend, at 3 a.m.; and “The Band Wagon” (1953), Vincente Minnelli’s MGM musical with Fred Astaire as an aging star whose Broadway comeback is sabotaged by an overzealous director (Jack Buchanan) and his prima ballerina colleague (Cyd Charisse), at 5 a.m. Arthur Schwartz and Howard Dietz wrote the songs, which include “That’s Entertainment!”

In the rural areas, however, those who have bank accounts have to withdraw money by visiting the bank, which could be miles away from where they live. Serpentine lines at the tiny bank of a village or district make the simple task of withdrawing money an ordeal.

headline: The Curious, and Continuing, Appeal of Mark Twain in China
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Elections, Governors', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: A biting political satire by the quintessentially American author that has long enjoyed popularity in China can provide insights into how many Chinese view democracy and capitalism.
lead_paragraph: There are few authors regarded as quintessentially American as Mark Twain. With his preternatural gift for capturing vernacular expression and his roguish wit, Twain is still widely seen as the founder of the American voice. More than a century after his death, “The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn,” Twain’s most celebrated work, remains a mainstay of middle school and high school English classes. Ernest Hemingway famously declared it the book from which “all modern American literature comes.”

lead_paragraph: When the Lens blog made its debut in 2009, the newspaper industry was in free fall, the outlets for serious photojournalism rapidly disappearing. “There was a need to help promote photographers and photography in whatever way possible,” said James Estrin, the blog’s co-founder. “We wanted to write about the photographers; photos don’t happen by themselves.”

headline: Behind the Cover: Paul Tough on a Tale of Strategic Survival
abstract: The author of this week’s cover story explains his fascination with John Aldridge, who fell off a boat and kept himself alive for several hours before the Coast Guard finally found him.
lead_paragraph: Paul Tough, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover story about a fisherman named John Aldridge, who fell overboard 40 miles off the eastern end of Long Island last summer and survived nearly 12 hours in the water before being rescued by the Coast Guard. Tough’s most recent book is “How Children Succeed: Grit, Curiosity, and the Hidden Power of Character.”How did you first hear about this extraordinary survival story?

lead_paragraph: The TV industry has innovated itself into a corner, Brian X. Chen and Nick Wingfield report. Crisp, high-definition TVs as big as 50 diagonal inches can be had for a few hundred dollars. Why bother upgrading or paying more for a fancy new one? Many people don’t.

headline: $20 Million Donation for Jazz at Lincoln Center
abstract: Jazz at Lincoln Center has announced that Robert J. Appel, a financier and philanthropist, has pledged $20 million to benefit the organization’s performance, education and broadcasting efforts.
lead_paragraph: Jazz at Lincoln Center has announced that Robert J. Appel, a financier and philanthropist, has pledged $20 million to benefit the organization’s performance, education and broadcasting efforts. The gift, one of the largest single private contributions to date in support of jazz music,  will also be used to help promote the center’s global initiatives of audience development and jazz advocacy. Mr. Appel joined the Jazz at Lincoln Center board in 2008 and was appointed chairman in 2012.

headline: JPMorgan Near a Settlement in Madoff Case
abstract: JPMorgan Chase nears $2 billion settlement in Madoff Case. | Men’s Wearhouse starts hostile bid. | Investors are pouring money into start-ups, eclipsing the exuberance of the dot-com era more than a decade ago. | The S.E.C. announces a departure.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase is starting the year the same way it ended the last one: by whipping out its wallet, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess report in DealBook. The bank is preparing to reach roughly $2 billion in criminal and civil settlements with federal authorities who claim that it ignored signs of Bernard L. Madoff’s huge Ponzi scheme, bringing its settlement total to nearly $20 billion over the last year. The settlements come on the heels of a record $13 billion deal with the Justice Department in November related to the bank’s questionable mortgage practices leading up to the financial crisis.

headline: A Page of Beethoven May Fetch More Than $200,000
abstract: A page that Beethoven apparently carried around while composing the “Missa Solemnis” will be auctioned next week.
lead_paragraph: A rare Beethoven manuscript — actually, a leaf from a late-period sketchbook that the composer apparently tore out and carried in his pocket while composing the “Missa Solemnis” — will be auctioned on Jan. 15 at RR Auctions in Amherst, N.H. The leaf was unknown until 1996, when it was discovered among the papers of Anton Schindler, Beethoven’s friend and early biographer. It was authenticated and auctioned at Sotheby’s in London that year for $110,000.
