headline: Solomon Northup’s Legacy, on Film and in Life
abstract: Chiwetel Ejiofor said his first reactions to the “12 Years a Slave” involved caution and self-doubt, partly because of the real Solomon Northup’s legacy, as highlighted in a video of Northup’s descendants.
lead_paragraph: Chiwetel Ejiofor, the star of “12 Years a Slave,” initially feared that he would not be able to do justice to the life of Solomon Northup, on whose memoir the film is based.

headline: A Symbol of the Range Returns Home
abstract: Bighorn sheep, whose populations have dwindled, are the focus of extensive conservation work focused on relocating them to areas where the species once thrived.
lead_paragraph: BOULDER CITY, Nev. — The two-way radio crackled to life: “We’re coming in with three ewes and a young ram.”

headline: The Read Around: Nikki Giovanni
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: “Poetry prevents everybody from feeling lonely,” says Nikki Giovanni. Her latest book, “Chasing Utopia,” is a collection of poetry, recipes and short stories.
lead_paragraph: “Poetry prevents everybody from feeling lonely,” says Nikki Giovanni. Her latest book, “Chasing Utopia,” is a collection of poetry, recipes and short stories.

headline: Times Minute | ‘Polar Vortex’ at Work
abstract: Also in the Minute, Liz Cheney quits the Wyoming Senate Race and “Spider-Man” closes on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Also in the Minute, Liz Cheney quits the Wyoming Senate Race and “Spider-Man” closes on Broadway.

headline: Times Minute | ‘Polar Vortex’ at Work
abstract: Also in the Minute, Liz Cheney quits the Wyoming Senate race and “Spider-Man” closes on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: AT&T Allows Advertisers to Sponsor Mobile Data
abstract: Businesses working with AT&T can pay for the data that is used to consume their content or services so that it does not show up on a customer’s phone bill.
lead_paragraph: Say you want to watch a trailer for “The Wolf of Wall Street” on your smartphone. Why should you pay for the data required to display it when you are essentially viewing an advertisement?

headline: Daniel Finkel’s Stained Glass Window Problem
abstract: Can you help a pilgrim design stained glass windows for a shrine?
lead_paragraph: In this week’s puzzle by Daniel Finkel we continue to follow an itinerant nun who most recently made her way to a shrine in the holy town of Duona. We now join her in some construction work.

headline: Numberplay 2013: A Year in Review
abstract: A reflection on the past year of weekly Numberplay puzzles, including links to the 51 puzzles of 2013.
lead_paragraph: Happy New Year! We had quite an adventure in 2013, and I’m looking forward to continuing the quantitative fun this coming year (check out this week’s challenge below). Before we get too far — a short reflection on our recent travels. Numberplay in 2013 featured original problems from many prominent and emerging mathematicians — problems that served as terrific platforms for our weekly explorations. A connection to an original creator is a powerful experience, and we were fortunate to have had many, including understanding fundamental origami concepts with Barry Hayes; discovering combinatorics with Joel Spencer, Ron Graham and Béla Bollobás; exploring primes with Bernardo Recamán.

headline: Yellen Wins Backing of Senators to Lead Fed
abstract: As chairwoman, Ms. Yellen will face an arduous task overseeing the gradual unwinding of stimulus measures, despite an uncomfortably high unemployment rate of 7 percent and subdued inflation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate confirmed Janet L. Yellen as the chairwoman of the Federal Reserve on Monday, marking the first time that a woman will lead the country’s central bank in its 100-year history.

headline: British Regulators Open Investigations Into Co-operative Bank
abstract: The Financial Conduct Authority and the Prudential Regulation Authority both said they would examine the decisions that led to the bank’s near collapse last year, including the actions of the bank’s senior managers.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – British regulators said on Monday that they were starting formal investigations into Co-operative Bank after recent revelations about its former chairman and continuing questions about a capital shortfall of 1.5 billion pounds last year.

headline: Eurythmics to Reunite for Beatles Tribute
abstract: John Mayer, Keith Urban, Maroon 5 and others will also take part in the show to be broadcast on CBS on Feb.9, the 50th anniversary of the Beatles’ first appearance on “The Ed Sullivan Show.”
lead_paragraph: When you think of the Beatles, you think of classic pop harmonies delivered in a British accent and imaginative lyrics that have stood up for half a century. And when you think of these attributes, surely you also think of Eurythmics, John Mayer, Keith Urban and Maroon 5. Or, at least, CBS is hoping that you will, as those are some of the first artists they’ve lined up to perform in a television tribute to the Beatles that will be broadcast on the network next month.

headline: The Read Around: Video of Nikki Giovanni
abstract: Ms. Giovanni discusses her new book, “Chasing Utopia,” which includes poems, short stories and recipes.
lead_paragraph: In “The Read Around,” a weekly video feature, authors discuss the when, where and how behind their books. Above, Nikki Giovanni discusses her latest book, “Chasing Utopia,” the beer that inspired its title and why poetry keeps people from feeling lonely.

headline: Broad Strokes vs. Pinpoint in Martoma Trial
abstract: Prosecutors want to introduce evidence that they say demonstrates that Mathew Martoma, a former portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors, sought confidential information regularly. Mr. Martoma’s lawyers object strenuously, Peter Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: The trial of Mathew Martoma, a former portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors, is the big kahuna for federal prosecutors. While they have won convictions in a number of insider trading trials, this is among the most significant cases because of the dollar amount of the trading, approximately $276 million, and the involvement of Steven A. Cohen, SAC’s founder and owner.

headline: Prepping Food and Their Future
abstract: Next Generation Caterers in the Bronx helps prepare youth for careers in gastronomy. The Neediest Cases Fund paid the fees for its three interns to take the New York State food protection exam.
lead_paragraph: Next Generation Caterers in the Bronx helps prepare youth for careers in gastronomy. The Neediest Cases Fund paid the fees for its three interns to take the New York State food protection exam.

headline: MAN: Fall 2014 Menswear
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: Topman Lets the London Rains Pour Down
abstract: The unsettled weather also was reflected in styles by Lou Dalton, Jonathan Saunders and Hardy Amies.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The coat was a sheer sheet of plastic, revealing a bright red sweater underneath. This shoulders-to-ankles cover-up was just the thing to offset the water that stood in pools on the runway or had been streaming from above — although London’s drenching rains had stopped for a bit.

headline: Mutant Petunias Sing the Blues
keywords: ['Flowers and Plants', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Gardens and Gardening', 'Research', 'Color']
abstract: What makes some petunias blue? Researchers have discovered a genetic glitch that produces the different shade, and weakens the plants.
lead_paragraph: Blue petunias are a rarity in nature and a favorite among gardeners. Now, researchers say they have discovered the genetic glitch that produces the colored flowers.

headline: Rose Petal and Vanilla Tea
abstract: A sweet infusion made with just water and three ingredients.
lead_paragraph: This is a sweet infusion with nothing more than dried rose petals, a vanilla bean and honey. You can find dried rose petals in Middle Eastern markets.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: January 3-5, 2014
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: A week after we began the Gun Report, we decided to end each post with Slate’s gun death tally, an interactive feature which tracked shootings in the news since the Newtown massacre on Dec. 14, 2012. Slate partnered with a Twitter user, @gundeaths, who had been linking to news stories about people killed by guns. No one else in the media was sounding the daily drumbeat of gun violence, and Slate invited readers to contribute details about the shootings it featured every day, giving us a sense of exactly who was getting shot in America.

headline: Teodoro Zamora’s Commission
abstract: Was the Civil War America’s just deserts for the Mexican-American War? One Tejano rebel thought so.
lead_paragraph: On a humid November day in 1863, Teodoro Zamora and his two brothers rode to the mouth of the Rio Grande. After tying their horses to a lone tree, they walked to where Col. Edmund Davis of the First Texas Cavalry Regiment stood, waiting.

headline: These Females Prefer a Familiar (Fish) Face
abstract: A certain neuron prompts female medaka fish to consent faster to mating, researchers says, and may lead to further insights regarding social decision making.
lead_paragraph: Female fish are quicker to mate with a male they’ve seen before, thanks in part to a neuron that springs to life in the presence of familiar males, researchers say.

headline: Today in Small Business: Running Out of Marijuana
abstract: Looking into the small-business crystal ball for 2014.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Dakar Rally Underway in Argentina
abstract: Carlos Sousa takes the first stage of Dakar; Michael Schumacher, the seven-time Formula One champion, is still in a coma after a skiing accident.
lead_paragraph: Carlos Sousa of Portugal, driving a Chinese-made Haval H8, which looks something like a BMW X3, took the victory Sunday in the first stage of the 2014 Dakar Rally, which ran from Rosario to San Luis, Argentina. He was closely trailed by three entrants in all-wheel-drive Minis.

headline: Iran Urged to Use Influence With Syrian Leader
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'International Relations']
abstract: State Department officials said Iran could improve its chances of joining peace talks if it could get President Bashar al-Assad to stop bombing Aleppo.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Iran could improve its chances of playing at least a limited role in the upcoming peace conference on Syria if it persuaded President Bashar al-Assad to stop the bombardment of Aleppo and allow the delivery of humanitarian aid to besieged towns and cities, senior State Department officials said on Monday.

headline: Lea Seydoux’s Luxe Combo of Florals, Crystals and Satin
abstract: The French actress wore Prada and Miu Miu to accept a nomination for the EE Rising Star Awards today in London.
lead_paragraph: The Girl: The French actress and model, who earned raves for her performance in “Blue Is the Warmest Color” last year, was in London today, where she accepted a nomination for the EE Rising Star Award, to be presented next month at the British Academy Film Awards.

headline: Trial on Detroit Swaps Deal Is Delayed
abstract: A trial over how Detroit should end costly financial contracts with two big banks was suspended Monday after more than a foot of snow fell, paralyzing much of the city and closing the federal courthouse there.
lead_paragraph: A trial over how Detroit should end costly financial contracts with two big banks was suspended Monday after more than a foot of snow fell, paralyzing much of the city and closing the federal courthouse there.

headline: U.S. and Iran Face Common Enemies in Mideast Strife
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Shiite Muslims', 'Sunni Muslims', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: The United States and Iran are being drawn together by their mutual opposition to a movement of Sunni fighters raising Al Qaeda’s flag in Syria, Lebanon, Iraq, Afghanistan and Yemen.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Even as the United States and Iran pursue negotiations on Tehran’s nuclear program, they find themselves on the same side of a range of regional issues surrounding an insurgency raging across the Middle East.

headline: Anna E. Crouse, 97, Dies; Championed Discount Tickets for Broadway
abstract: Ms. Crouse, a force behind the creation of the 40-year-old TKTS booth, also helped revitalize the struggling Lincoln Center Theater.
lead_paragraph: Anna E. Crouse, a onetime actress whose fondest Broadway dream — a healthy Manhattan theater district and affordable tickets for young people — was realized when she helped establish the TKTS booth in Duffy Square, died on Dec. 29 in Manhattan. She was 97.

headline: 10 Years for Plot to Murder Cartoonist
keywords: ['Sentences (Criminal)', 'Terrorism', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists']
abstract: A federal judge sentenced a Pennsylvania woman for her part in a plan to murder a Swedish cartoonist whose images of the Prophet Muhammad offended Muslims.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — A federal judge on Monday sentenced a Pennsylvania woman to 10 years in prison for her part in a plan to murder a Swedish cartoonist whose images of the Prophet Muhammad offended Muslims.

headline: Jerry Coleman, 89, Yankee Infielder, Fighter Pilot and Voice of the Padres
abstract: A pilot in World War II and Korea, he was the most valuable player of the 1950 World Series when the Yankees swept the Phillies.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Coleman, a former fighter pilot who played in six World Series as an infielder for the Yankees but who made his most lasting mark as a broadcaster, first for the Yankees and then more indelibly for the San Diego Padres, died Sunday near his home in San Diego. He was 89.

headline: What Your Cat Is Thinking
abstract: What’s the meaning of that dead rodent in the house? This guide to our feline friends unravels the mysteries.
lead_paragraph: Cat owners speak to their cats, attribute many complex emotions to them and chide them when they bring small dead rodents into the house. People don’t pause to ask what is going on in the mind of the cat during these interactions, and perhaps that’s just as well. The role of a pet is to be relentlessly anthropomorphized.

headline: Inside the Cat Brain
abstract: An excerpt from “Cat Sense: How the New Feline Science Can Make You a Better Friend to Your Pet.”
lead_paragraph: Excerpt from the preface of “Cat Sense: How the New Feline Science Can Make You a Better Friend to Your Pet” by John Bradshaw.

headline: When Doctors ‘Google’ Their Patients
abstract: Doctors do look up their patients on Google. I don’t know of a single physician, resident or attending who hasn’t done so. But it surprises me that more physicians don’t pause and think about what it means for the patient-doctor relationship.
lead_paragraph: I remember when I first looked up a patient on Google. It was my last day on the bone marrow transplant unit, back when I was an intern. As I stood before the patient, taking her history, she told me she had been a painter and suggested I look up her work on the Internet. I did, and I found her paintings fascinating. Even though our paths crossed fleetingly, she is one of the few patients I vividly remember from that time.

headline: ‘Tis the Season to Compensate College Athletes
abstract: During the College Bowl season, the N.C.A.A. allows players to accept gifts.
lead_paragraph: The N.C.A.A. classifies Division I football players as amateurs, not professionals, student-athletes, not employees, which is how colleges get away with paying them nothing.

headline: The Disappearing Accent in Pop Music
abstract: The apparent presence or absence of an identifiable accent in a vocal performance could have many possible explanations.
lead_paragraph: Q. Why do pop music vocalists generally seem to sing without an accent?

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Dec. 31, 2013-Jan. 6, 2014
abstract: New Year’s resolutions, freezing temperatures and more: how many of this week’s 10 questions can you answer correctly?
lead_paragraph: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events making news this week.

headline: Gerlach Retirement Opens Up Swing District in Pennsylvania
abstract: Representative Jim Gerlach, Republican of Pennsylvania, announced he will not seek re-election, intensifying the fight for his suburban turf.
lead_paragraph: Representative Jim Gerlach of Pennsylvania, a perennial target for Democrats who covet his suburban district, announced on Monday that he will retire from the House after six terms.

headline: In Video and on Twitter, Glimpses of Rodman’s North Korea Trip
abstract: Dennis Rodman, who has repeatedly called his visits “basketball diplomacy,” brushed aside any suggestion that he will use his influence with the North Korean leader Kim Jong-un for anything other than sports.
lead_paragraph: Dodging tough questions about politics, Dennis Rodman is back in North Korea to play basketball, this time accompanied by former National Basketball Association players who will star in an exhibition game with a local team as part of celebrations Wednesday on the birthday of the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un.

headline: In Sirius Offer, John Malone Is Up to His Old Tricks
abstract: Liberty Media, where John C. Malone serves as chairman, is offering the satellite radio company’s minority investors a 3 percent premium and perhaps better liquidity in return for non-voting Liberty stock with inferior prospects. Sirius shareholders should hit back, contends Robert Cyran of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: John C. Malone is up to his same old tricks against Sirius XM.

headline: Czech Parties Agree to Form Center-Left Coalition
abstract: Bohuslav Sobotka, a former finance minister known for his uncharismatic personal style, was expected to become prime minister.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A leftist former finance minister was expected to become prime minister of the Czech Republic after three political parties signed an agreement on Monday to form a center-left coalition government. The deal helped to bring to a close one of the most acrimonious periods of political crisis in the country’s recent memory.

headline: Advertising Age to Reduce Its Print Frequency
abstract: The former weekly trade magazine will publish only 25 times a year and is following a similar move by New York magazine.
lead_paragraph: Advertising Age, the trade publication introduced in 1930, said Monday that it would publish its print edition 25 times a year rather than weekly.

headline: British Economic Debate Opens Ahead of 2015 Vote
abstract: Citing a robust economy, Prime Minister David Cameron’s government promised more austerity, while the opposition Labour Party demanded better protections for low-wage workers.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With elections 16 months away, British politicians have headed into battle over the economy.

headline: As New York Region Braces for Chill, Cuomo Declares Emergency
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo declared a state of emergency and closed roads in parts of the state, and travelers were told to expect transportation delays on Tuesday because of extreme cold and high winds.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Monday declared a state of emergency in 14 counties in western New York and announced that parts of the New York Thruway would be closed, as the Buffalo area braced itself for as much as three feet of snow and wind chills of 30 degrees below zero.

headline: Jared Leto, in Heels
abstract: Jared Leto explains how his character in “Dallas Buyers Club” came to inhabit him.
lead_paragraph: Jared Leto is receiving the first of what may be many honors this season, from the New York Film Critics Circle on Monday night, for his performance as the transgender AIDS patient Rayon in “Dallas Buyers Club.” Mr. Leto lost nearly 30 pounds for the role and shaved off his eyebrows, among other make-unders. And of course, he was put in women’s clothing and makeup, as well as being made to look ill and impoverished.

headline: Czech Officials Demand Explanation for Weapons at Palestinian Mission
abstract: The authorities in Prague said they found 12 illegal weapons during their investigation into the death of the Palestinian ambassador.
lead_paragraph: PRAGUE — The Czech authorities, investigating an explosion that killed the Palestinian ambassador to the Czech Republic at his residence in Prague on Wednesday, now say that they found 12 illegal weapons at the Palestinian Mission next door.

headline: The Confidence of Jerry Coyne
abstract: A few thoughts on an unpersuasive defense of scientific materialism.
lead_paragraph: One of the problems with belonging to a faction that’s convinced it’s on the winning side of intellectual history is that it becomes easy to persuade oneself that one’s own worldview has no weak points whatsoever, no internal contradictions or ragged edges, no cracks through which a critic’s wedge could end up driven. This kind of overconfidence has been displayed, at various points in the human story, by everyone from millenarians to Marxists, inquisitors to eugenicists. But right now its vices are often found in a certain type of atheistic polemicist, and in a style of anti-religious argument that’s characterized by a peculiar, almost-willed ignorance of why reasonable people might doubt the scientific-materialist worldview.

headline: Deadly Hell’s Kitchen Blaze Traced to Electrical Wire, Fire Dept. Says
abstract: Multiple appliances had been connected to a power strip in an apartment on the 20th floor of the Strand luxury building, according to a Fire Department official.
lead_paragraph: The fire that left one man dead and other residents displaced from a high-rise building in Midtown Manhattan over the weekend was traced to an electrical power strip, the Fire Department said on Monday.

headline: Never Mind the Predictions: What Did We Learn?
abstract: A look back at gold, home prices and stocks in 2013 confirms some old investment truths.
lead_paragraph: I’m not big on market predictions. In fact, if anyone asks, I’m pretty quick to say that I don’t know what the markets will do in 2014. If you absolutely must have predictions for the next year, then I recommend you check out Barry Ritholtz’s annual list. But if you are interested in something more useful than predictions, I suggest taking a look at what we learned (or had confirmed — again) in 2013.

headline: A Long, Frozen Rescue and Sharks on Twitter
abstract: It was a long wait for those on a trapped research vessel, and if any of 338 sharks get too close to the Australian beach, they’ll send out tweets.
lead_paragraph: Nobody had a longer week than the 52 scientists, journalists and tourists waiting to be rescued from a vessel trapped in the frozen waters of East Antarctica. But for fishermen in Maine, where the shrimping season has been canceled because of a dearth of the crustaceans, it will be an even longer winter.

headline: ‘The Good Wife’ and Peter Bogdanovich’s Surprise Cameo
abstract: Peter Bogdanovich explains how he came to appear in the final scene of Sunday’s “Good Wife.”
lead_paragraph: Warning: this post contains spoilers about Sunday’s episode of “The Good Wife.”

headline: Palo Alto Networks Acquires  Start-Up Morta Security
abstract: Palo Alto Networks has acquired Morta Security, a Silicon Valley start-up run by former employees of the National Security Agency and United States Air Force. It’s the second major acquisition in the security market in recent weeks.
lead_paragraph: Palo Alto Networks has acquired Morta Security, a two-year-old Silicon Valley security start-up run by former employees of the National Security Agency and the United States Air Force.

headline: Study Ties Diabetic Crises to Dip in Food Budgets
abstract: Researchers seeking to document whether running out of food stamps or money for food at the end of the month damaged people’s health found a high correlation.
lead_paragraph: Poor people with diabetes are significantly more likely to go to the hospital for dangerously low blood sugar at the end of the month when food budgets are tight than at the beginning of the month, a new study has found.

headline: The Forecast on GJ 1214b: Extremely Cloudy
abstract: Astronomers, using the Hubble Space Telescope, found the atmosphere of a “super-earth” planet so thick that observations of the surface were nearly impossible.
lead_paragraph: Astronomers from the University of Chicago have used the Hubble Space Telescope to observe the weather on a “super-Earth” planet orbiting a distant star for the first time. Conditions on GJ 1214b are cloudy, with an atmosphere so thick with water vapor or some other heavy molecule that observations of the planet’s surface are nearly impossible, they report in the journal Nature. Super-Earth planets, which are larger than Earth but smaller than Neptune, are among the most common planets in the Milky Way. To compile their forecast, the team analyzed 96 hours of telescope time over 11 months.

headline: Walkabout: Winter Storms Freeze U.S. Flights; How to Rebook if You’re Stranded
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, winter storms continued to hobble travel plans across the United States, as thousands of flights have been either canceled or delayed. There have also been flight snafus at  Kennedy International Airport, the Bronx and, sadly, Aspen. (USA Today, The New York Times)

headline: Laser Hair Removal’s Risks
keywords: ['Burns', 'Hair', 'Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)', 'Skin']
abstract: The treatments can cause severe burns and disfiguring injuries, and a rising percentage of lawsuits involve operators who are not physicians.
lead_paragraph: Her first two laser hair-removal sessions went smoothly, but the third ended with burning pain that persisted for weeks, a 26-year-old Brooklyn woman recalled. Then the marks appeared: long red stripes along the backs of her legs. Over the next few months, the stripes turned dark brown.

headline: Departing Broadway Shows Leave on a Box-Office High
abstract: “Spider-Man,” “Annie,” “Betrayal” and “700 Sundays” all wrap up with more than $1-million apiece at the box office.
lead_paragraph: Numerous Broadway shows started 2014 with million-dollar high notes at the box office, even as some of them ended their runs.

headline: After Agreement in N.F.L. Concussion Case, Retirees Will Look at Details
abstract: Assuming the judge approves it, the accord on the $760 million settlement could determine how retirees with head trauma are compensated.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. and lawyers for the more than 4,000 former players who said the league hid from them the dangers of repeated hits to the head have agreed on the details of a $760 million settlement that could determine how retirees with head trauma are compensated.

headline: 20 Winter Wines for $20
abstract: Eric Asimov selects 20 fantastic winter wines, all at the price point of $20, presented here in no particular order.
lead_paragraph: Eric Asimov selects 20 fantastic winter wines, all at the price point of $20, presented here in no particular order.

headline: When a (Partial) Tweet Becomes an Ad, What Are the Rules?
abstract: A film critic’s Twitter banter, over his objections, becomes a full-page movie ad.
lead_paragraph: The media world gets weirder every day, but this moment still stands out as something of a stunner – the kind of thing that merits a place on the eternal timeline of “How the Internet Flipped the Media World on Its Head.”

headline: Slow Growth in Health Spending
abstract: Experts at the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services said in a report that national spending on health care continued to be modest in 2012.
lead_paragraph: Experts at the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services said in a report that national spending on health care continued to be modest in 2012.

headline: A New Test for Malaria, No Blood Required
abstract: Rice University researchers have developed a rapid malaria test that uses a laser pulse and may be able to detect the disease when only one red blood cell in a million is infected.
lead_paragraph: Rice University researchers have developed a rapid malaria test that uses a laser pulse, eliminating the need to draw blood.

headline: Your 2014 Resolution: Drink Adventurously
abstract: Twenty winter wines for $20 apiece offer not only value but intrigue.
lead_paragraph: Here’s my resolution for 2014: Drink adventurously.

headline: Another Modest Rise for Health Costs
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Recession and Depression', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: National health spending grew slowly in 2012, posting a relatively small increase for a fourth consecutive year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — National health spending grew slowly for the fourth consecutive year, increasing 3.7 percent in 2012 to $2.8 trillion, the federal government said Monday. But officials disagreed over whether the Affordable Care Act or lingering effects of the recession were primarily responsible for the remarkable trend.

headline: Welcome to America. Enjoy the Free Napkins and Straws.
abstract: Gary Shteyngart’s memoir, “Little Failure,” tracks his family’s immigration to the United States from the Soviet Union.
lead_paragraph: Of the many enormously gifted authors now writing about the immigrant experience — including Jhumpa Lahiri, Edwidge Danticat, Dinaw Mengestu, Chang-rae Lee, Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie and Gish Jen — Gary Shteyngart is undoubtedly the funniest (with Junot Díaz a close runner-up).

headline: Adoption and All That Comes With It
abstract: Three families who have gone through the process of international adoption and know how difficult the adjustment can be.
lead_paragraph: Three families who have gone through the process of international adoption and know how difficult the adjustment can be.

headline: Energy Bars That Put a Chirp in Your Step
abstract: Banking that cricket-filled protein bars will jump off the shelves.
lead_paragraph: How do you make ground-up crickets taste good?

headline: Pictures of the Day: Britain and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Wales, Illinois, Bangladesh and Indonesia.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Wales, Illinois, Bangladesh and Indonesia.

headline: Giving Voice, and Finding Her Own
abstract: Race and the South have helped shape the novelist Sue Monk Kidd, whose new work, “The Invention of Wings,” is out this week.
lead_paragraph: The writer Sue Monk Kidd found the voice that her new book needed when she became smitten with an enslaved girl who is only a footnote to history. “I could hear Hetty in my head quite clearly,” Ms. Kidd said. “She would talk and talk and talk and talk to me.”

headline: Join Us on an Instagram Tour of Our Printing Plant
abstract: Sign up to participate in a New York Times “Instameet” for Instagram photographers who want to tour our newspaper printing facility.
lead_paragraph: Updated | January 10, 2014

headline: Translating a Fellow Passenger’s Vision of Doom
abstract: Carlos Menendez of MasterCard cuts it close on his way to the gate, and he once helped calm a woman shouting in Portuguese that the plane would crash.
lead_paragraph: I THINK I have flown on every airline existing on the planet at least once. Family members and people I work with call me a “risk” because I too often barely make it to flights on time. I like to maximize the time I have, so I do cut it close. On two occasions I had to get out of a taxi and walk along the highway, roller dragging behind me, briefcase tightly tucked under my arm and cellphone blasting calls for help, just to be sure I made my flight.

headline: Samsung Electronics Goes Big on Tablets
abstract: Samsung Electronics, the No. 1 handset maker, is trying to take on both Microsoft and Apple with two tablets aimed at professional users.
lead_paragraph: Samsung Electronics, the No. 1 handset maker, beat Apple to making smartphones with larger screens. Now the company wants to make an aggressive play in the tablet market with extra-large tablets.

headline: Rebel Infighting Spreads to an Eastern Syrian City
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, a Qaeda affiliate and onetime ally of Syrian insurgents, was routed from the eastern city of Raqqa, antigovernment activists said.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — An internal war between Syrian insurgents and their onetime allies, members of a transnational jihadist group that even some fighters affiliated with Al Qaeda reject as too extreme, widened on Monday from parts of northern Syria into Raqqa, the largest city in eastern Syria that had been under the group’s control, antigovernment activists and fighters said.

headline: Asking Siri About ‘Her’
abstract: Apple’s programmers were ready when users asked Siri about Samantha, the operating system in “Her.”
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:08 p.m. | Spike Jonze wrote his near-future love story “Her” before Apple introduced Siri, but comparisons are inevitable between Samantha, the computer operating system in the movie (voiced by Scarlett Johansson), and Siri, Apple’s digital assistant, originally voiced by Susan Bennett, a suburban Atlanta voiceover actor.

headline: Growth Returns to Tech, but Profits Will Not Be So Easy
keywords: ['Cloud Computing', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Data Centers', 'Enterprise Computing', 'Telephones and Telecommunications']
abstract: After a tough 2013 for information technology, a leading analysis company said Monday that spending worldwide is set to increase. Profitability, however, may not match the trend.
lead_paragraph: The good news for the information technology business is that in 2014 it should start growing at a significant rate again. The bad news? It may be less profitable.

headline: Bone-Chilling Cold a Crippling Blow to Air Travel
abstract: Airlines canceled 4,400 flights on Monday, bringing the total to more than 17,000 over the last week, as brutal winter weather engulfed much of the country.
lead_paragraph: The chaos in the nation’s air travel system worsened on Monday as a wave of frigid weather forced airlines to cancel thousands more flights, stranding passengers from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to Los Angeles.

headline: An Army of One, Enhanced by a Chip
abstract: The new CBS series “Intelligence” centers on an agent whose abilities have been broadened by a microchip implanted in his brain.
lead_paragraph: Gabriel Vaughn, the commando turned human computer at the center of CBS’s melodramatic new action series “Intelligence,” has multiple operating modes. The microchip in his brain makes him a walking Google as well as a one-man surveillance state, able to distract terrorists by reciting their emails to them. He’s also his own wireless hot spot — in Tuesday’s pilot, he works the digital lock of a Pakistani interrogation cell from across the room. Where was this guy when it was taking 10 years to find Osama bin Laden?

headline: Study Raises Questions for Employer Wellness Programs
keywords: ['Preventive Medicine', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Research', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: “Lifestyle” programs, which aim to reduce health risks via weight loss or stress management, resulted in no net savings, a RAND study says.
lead_paragraph: If you work for a big employer — or even a small one — you probably have encountered some sort of workplace wellness program. You most likely filled out a health questionnaire, which may have led to a recommendation that you attend exercise classes, quit smoking or participate in telephone coaching to help you control diabetes or asthma.

headline: A Woman Chasing Disasters, on and Off the News
abstract: “Being Mary Jane,” a new drama on Black Entertainment Television, stars Gabrielle Union as a cable news personality fielding crises.
lead_paragraph: All day long, Mary Jane Paul puts out fires: saving a friend from a possible suicide attempt, tough-talking a niece who wants to do pornography, squaring off against unscrupulous co-workers who want to damage her reputation, talking in depth about her sex life with the wife of the man she’s sleeping with.

lead_paragraph: “Saturday Night Live” concluded its search for a black female cast member on Monday when it hired Sasheer Zamata, a young sketch comedian who has been performing in the New York area for the last four years.

headline: A Case of Bad Cop, Good-Looking Cop
abstract: Two sides of the feminization of television crime shows come to the screen this week with “Chicago P.D.,” on NBC, and “Killer Women,” on ABC.
lead_paragraph: On second thought, maybe it should be a man’s world.

headline: In Nod to History, Two Ballet Rivals Spring to Life
abstract: The Bolshoi has opened a weeklong series of performances of Alexei Ratmansky’s “Lost Illusions” at the Palais Garnier in Paris.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Story ballets. Three acts, characters, costumes, scenery, melodious music. Beloved by mass audiences, they’ve been unfashionable with current, forward-thinking choreographers for years.

headline: Loft Life in a Building Once Evacuated Over Matzos
keywords: ['Lofts', 'Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Residents of 475 Kent Avenue in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, are more secure about their homes thanks to a law that gives loft buildings a path to residential status.
lead_paragraph: Bill Murray sublet for a summer. A contingent of dazzling Danes also moved in. So did the photojournalist Tim Hetherington, whose death in Libya in 2011 caused mourners to gather en masse at the building, known in their circle as the kibbutz because so many photographers lived there.

headline: Still Stuck in a Climate Argument
keywords: ['Ice', 'Ships and Shipping', 'Rescues', 'Global Warming', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The case of the Akademik Shokalskiy highlights a changing Antarctic, as well as the myriad questions that still surround the influence of climate change in the region.
lead_paragraph: When a ship carrying scientists and adventure tourists became stuck in ice in the Antarctic late last month, climate change skeptics had a field day. On Twitter and other social media sites, they pointed out that a group whose journey was meant to highlight the effects of global warming was trapped by a substance that was supposed to be melting.

headline: A Search for Self in a Brain Scan
abstract: I always felt that my “self” sat somewhere behind my eyes and between my ears, so I couldn’t shake the sense that there would be something special in seeing my brain.
lead_paragraph: St. Louis — I knew I wouldn’t find my “self” in a brain scan.

headline: Mapping the Highways of the Brain
abstract: Deanna Barch and her colleagues are trying to map connections in the human brain. The study is part of the Human Connectome Project.
lead_paragraph: Deanna Barch and her colleagues are trying to map connections in the human brain. The study is part of the Human Connectome Project.

headline: The Brain, in Exquisite Detail
abstract: Undertaking thousands of hours of work, researchers are working to create an interactive database of a healthy brain’s structure and activity, the first of its kind.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Deanna Barch talks fast, as if she doesn’t want to waste any time getting to the task at hand, which is substantial. She is one of the researchers here at Washington University working on the first interactive wiring diagram of the living, working human brain.

headline: Taking an I.V.F. Journey to Israel
abstract: After my last round of in vitro fertilization failed, Solomon and I knew it was time to move on to Plan I: Israel.
lead_paragraph: Our last round of in vitro fertilization failed.

headline: Israelis Document Incitement by the Palestinian Authority
abstract: Israeli officials noted negative statements about Israel and Jews in official Palestinian Authority media and textbooks.
lead_paragraph: Israeli officials noted negative statements about Israel and Jews in official Palestinian Authority media and textbooks.

headline: Israeli Official Points to ‘Incitement’ by Palestinians
abstract: As Israel sought to highlight negative portrayals of Jews in Palestinian Authority media and textbooks, Palestinians dismissed the accusation as a ruse to distract from issues like borders.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Adolf Hitler is quoted on the Facebook pages  of Palestinian Authority schools. A young girl appears on Palestinian television, describing Jews as “barbaric monkeys, wretched pigs” and the “murderers of Muhammad,” the Islamic prophet. Maps on the Facebook page of the Palestinian presidential guards do not show Israel. President Mahmoud Abbas himself embraced as “heroes” released Palestinian prisoners who killed Israelis.

lead_paragraph: Bobby Moreno plays Odysseus Rex, a rooster with anger issues, in Eric Dufault’s dark comedy “Year of the Rooster,” at the Ensemble Studio Theater.

headline: Online Retailer Zola Books Buys Bookish
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: Bookish, a book recommendation site started by three publishing houses, had faced difficulties since its debut early last year.
lead_paragraph: Bookish, a struggling website started by three large book publishers less than a year ago, has been sold to Zola Books, a start-up e-book retailer, the parties announced Monday. The purchase price was undisclosed.

headline: Prominent Bond Trader Leaves Morgan Stanley
abstract: Glenn Hadden, who was head of global rates, had been hired as part of Morgan Stanley’s efforts to balance in its fixed-income operations after the 2008 financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: A prominent bond trader who was hired to revitalize Morgan Stanley’s trading business but whose division racked up sizable losses has left the Wall Street firm.

headline: Going Shopping, Honey? Be a Dear and Pick Up My Arsenic
abstract: In “The Poisoner’s Handbook,” the PBS show “American Experience” looks at the poisons that were once sold as goods ranging from complexion enhancers to furniture polish.
lead_paragraph: Ah, for the days when you could stop by the local pharmacy and pick up some Radium Spray, advertised as “the new combination bug killer, disinfectant and furniture polish.” The days when you didn’t have to worry about your complexion because, as another product proclaimed, “a clear, white skin may positively be obtained by using LeFevre’s Arsenic Wafers.”

headline: A Device to Put You Into a Video Game
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'International Consumer Electronics Show', 'Sensors']
abstract: A sensor manufacturer has created a harness that reads a video gamer’s every move and transfers those motions to a character onscreen in a game. But to work with actual games, the software will have to be adapted by a developer.
lead_paragraph: One of the stories behind the stories at the 2014 International Consumer Electronics Show is how the drop in the price of sensors – the parts in phones and devices that read motion, temperature, pressure and such – has made whiz-bang gizmos possible and affordable.

headline: No Barbarians at the Gate; Instead, a Force for Change
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Hedge Funds', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: Activist investors were once thought of as greedy corporate raiders, but their efforts have become more sophisticated and they are often seen as doing good.
lead_paragraph: It’s no longer an insult to be called an activist investor.

headline: The Cult Filmmaker Alejandro Jodorowsky on Mandalas, the Aztec Calendar and Papa Freud
abstract: The Chilean director, renowned for beautiful and head-scratchingly strange works like “El Topo,” reflects on objects, ideas and people who have inspired him.
lead_paragraph: The cult Chilean director Alejandro Jodorowsky practically invented the midnight movie in the early 1970s. His seminal films “El Topo” and “The Holy Mountain,” both shot in Mexico (the latter was financed by John Lennon to the tune of $1 million), were spiritual, strange and visually spectacular. Offering decadent visions of alternate realities and mystic rituals, the films became a favorite with audiences of that era, as well as with generations of (often stoned) college students ever since. The 84-year-old director, who lives in Paris, recently returned to his hometown of Tocopilla, Chile, to make “The Dance of Reality,” an autobiographical film that also manages to be a hypnotic surrealist fantasia. The film, which hits American theaters in May, received a standing ovation when it premiered at the Cannes Film Festival last year.

headline: New York, the Silicon City
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: How Bill de Blasio can harness the Big Apple’s tech boom.
lead_paragraph: FOR all the talk of New York’s “tale of two cities” economic divide, last week Mayor Bill de Blasio took charge of a local economy that has far outperformed the rest of the country since the financial collapse — and not just in a small corner of Manhattan, but across the city. Driven by the expansion of the technology and information sector, New York City today has more private-sector jobs than during the 2007-8 peak of the finance-driven boom years.

abstract: After Pakistan and Afghanistan were accused of casting their votes for other cities in the competition for the 2020 World Expo, the score-settling started.
lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — From the start, Dubai took the competition to land the 2020 World Expo rather seriously.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Michael Bay’s C.E.S. Performance, and Charging Tech Shuttles
abstract: Monday’s highlights from around the web include an unexpected performance at Samsung’s press briefing at the Consumer Electronics Show. Plus, San Francisco’s mayor announced an initiative to make the operators of tech commuter buses pay the city for bus stop use.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Football’s Devastating Harvest
abstract: Emblematic of yet another brutal season in the N.F.L., the Chiefs-Colts game was at once breathtaking and queasy-making.
lead_paragraph: For a while he didn’t move. It wasn’t clear that he could. He was stretched out on his stomach, a few concerned people bending over him, a few others kneeling beside him, as if in prayer, which they may have been. It would have been an apt response.

headline: ‘Downton Abbey’ Returns and Sets Ratings Record
abstract: The audience of 10.2 million for the Season 4 premiere was a huge increase from the Season 3 premiere of 7.3 million.
lead_paragraph: By any standard, public television has a major hit in “Downton Abbey,” which returned for its fourth season Sunday night in triumph, setting a record for a season premiere with 10.2 million viewers, and dwarfing most of the shows across commercial television.

headline: In Hong Kong, a Glittering Exhibition
abstract: The show called Radiant Legacy: Chinese Gold from the Mengdiexuan Collection, at the Chinese University of Hong Kong, includes remarkable pieces of ancient art.
lead_paragraph: Newly minted Chinese millionaires may be rushing to buy Chinese art, but the Mengdiexuan family of Hong Kong has already assembled a brilliant collection all its own: hundreds of astonishing pieces from 1500 B.C. to the 18th century.

headline: Pitching the Yankees to Fans on Broadway
abstract: The play “Bronx Bombers” uses official team and Major League logos in ads at sports bars and on sports radio and TV.
lead_paragraph: BROADWAY shows typically advertise in New York publications, on websites like Ticketmaster and atop taxis, so regulars at dozens of Manhattan sports bars may be surprised to see a new play about the Yankees, “Bronx Bombers,” promoted on coasters under their beers.

headline: Florida State Defeats Auburn, 34-31, to Win B.C.S. Title Game
abstract: Auburn has used two miracles to get to the national championship game; Florida State has climbed on the back of the Heisman Trophy winner. Which team will claim the title? Times reporters will follow the action throughout the game. Follow along and join the conversation.
lead_paragraph: After trailing for most of the game, Florida State stunned Auburn with a late touchdown to win its first national championship since 1999, 34-31.

headline: When Airlines Are Quick to Hit the ‘Cancel’ Button
abstract: Airlines suffer no consequences when weather forces cancellations, and some industry watchers say they use claims of weather-related trouble as cover for systemic problems.
lead_paragraph: THERE is reason to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the first scheduled airplane passenger flight in the United States. That flight was right on schedule. After a week like the last one, you might wonder if things have gone downhill since.

headline: On a Changing East Village Street, a Source of Continuity Fights for His Job
abstract: Jerry Delakas had run the stand on Astor Place in the East Village for 26 years, but the city closed it in December because he never obtained the required license.
lead_paragraph: The changes unfolded over decades on Astor Place, slowly transforming the three-block stretch that has long separated the raffish expanse of the East Village and the more proper precincts to the west.

headline: High Stakes for Sudan in the South’s Conflict
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Defense and Military Forces', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat"]
abstract: With the flow of oil and border security at risk, the longstanding rivals discussed joint patrols of South Sudan’s oil fields, among other measures.
lead_paragraph: KHARTOUM, Sudan — The United States has demanded negotiations. Uganda has threatened to intervene. China has called for an immediate cease-fire.

headline: Cuomo Proposes $2 Billion in Tax Cuts
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Income Tax', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Property Taxes', 'Taxation']
abstract: The governor is going after the state’s high-tax image, and wants homeowners and renters as well as manufacturers outside the New York City area to see relief.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Sounding a refrain that will most likely echo through his re-election campaign this year, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Monday announced a sweeping $2 billion tax relief proposal, a catchall of cuts for property and business owners, renters and upstate manufacturers.

headline: Howard Permut, Metro-North President, Is Stepping Down
keywords: ['Railroads', 'Railroad Accidents and Safety', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The railroad suffered a year of problems, including four passenger deaths and more than 70 injuries from a derailment on Dec. 1.
lead_paragraph: After a year marred by a train collision, a worker’s death and the first passenger fatalities in Metro-North Railroad’s three-decade history, the agency’s president, Howard R. Permut, is stepping down, according to several sources with knowledge of the move.

headline: SAC Trader’s Co-Workers Were Deposed
abstract: A court filing hints that several of Mathew Martoma’s co-workers at SAC Capital Advisors may be called as witnesses.
lead_paragraph: The criminal insider trading case against Mathew Martoma, the former SAC Capital Advisors portfolio manager, was built in part on interviews and depositions by federal authorities with several of his former colleagues at the hedge fund, according to a recent court filing.

headline: A Makeover for Maps
abstract: Some graphic designers are trying to improve presentation of information using video and color rather than simple bar charts and graphs.
lead_paragraph: Like many designers, Eric Rodenbeck has had a long relationship with bar graphs and pie charts. He just thinks they are a little old school for today’s data-filled world.

headline: Africans Continue to Protest in Israel
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Strikes', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Law and Legislation', 'Deportation', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: Thousands of African asylum seekers flooded the streets of Tel Aviv for a second day on Monday to protest their treatment by the Israeli authorities.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — After years of living on the margins of Israeli society, thousands of African asylum seekers flooded the streets of central Tel Aviv for a second day on Monday to protest their treatment by the Israeli authorities and to demand recognition as refugees.

headline: A Delicate Balance for the Turnaround Chief of ThyssenKrupp
keywords: ['Company Reports', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Steel and Iron']
abstract: The decisions Heinrich Hiesinger makes in the coming years will go a long way in determining the future of one of Europe’s largest businesses.
lead_paragraph: Heinrich Hiesinger was hired as chief executive of Thyssen-Krupp in 2011 to clean up and modernize the storied German industrial giant after its disastrous attempt to go global during the financial crisis. Since then, he has been pushing through an overhaul plan that includes cutting the losses in steel while beefing up what he considers more promising businesses like elevators and factory design and construction.

headline: Jordan to Renew Appeal on Syrian Refugees
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'International Relations']
abstract: The ambassador to the United Nations from Jordan said he would renew his appeal to the governing body to visit countries that shelter millions of Syrian refugees, including his own.
lead_paragraph: The ambassador to the United Nations from Jordan, the nation thrust into the rotating presidency of a polarized Security Council, said Monday that he would renew his appeal to the 15-member governing body to visit countries that shelter millions of Syrian refugees, including his own, which hosts more than 500,000 Syrians. The ambassador, Prince Zeid Ra’ad Zeid al-Hussein, said he had made the request before to draw attention to the humanitarian crisis facing Syria’s neighbors, but received no response. The Council has been deadlocked on Syria, but he declined to ascribe blame. “Being on the Council hopefully will make a difference,” he said. Jordan took the rotating two-year seat after Saudi Arabia rejected it to protest what it saw as the weak stance of Western powers toward Syria and Iran, the Saudis’ chief regional rivals.

headline: Bodies of 2 American Climbers Found in Argentina
abstract: Francis Keenan, 28, and Jarod Von Rueden, 22, were trying to scale Mount Aconcagua when Mr. Von Rueden sent out a distress radio signal Dec. 31.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Two bodies discovered at the bottom of a 650-foot ravine on a mountain in Argentina are believed to be those of two missing American climbers, a local government official said Monday.

headline: Never Mind the Résumé. How Hot Is the C.E.O.?
abstract: A study suggests that investors give higher share values to companies run by attractive chief executives.
lead_paragraph: Call it the “C.E.O. beauty premium.”

headline: Germany Adds Lessons in Islam to Better Blend Its Melting Pot
abstract: Public schools for the first time are offering classes in Islam to primary school students to better integrate Germany’s large Muslim minority and to try to counter the influence of radical religious thinking.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — For the first time, German public schools are offering classes in Islam to primary school students using state-trained teachers and specially written textbooks, as officials try to better integrate the nation’s large Muslim minority and counter the growing influence of radical religious thinking.

headline: The Edamame Economy
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: The emergence of boutique hotels reflects a broader trend toward a more experientially rich commercial world.
lead_paragraph: In the age of rail, luxury hotels mimicked European palaces. When rich people arrived at their destination, they wanted to be treated like nobility.

headline: Forgetting It All
abstract: Without reliable memory, I’m a composer with notes but no melody, a sculptor with nothing but crumbled medium.
lead_paragraph: I’ve forgotten what it’s like to remember. I’ve lost the mindless confidence that a moment, an idea, a thought will be there for me later, the bravado of breezing through experience in the certainty that it will become part of my self, part of my story.

headline: In Jobless Youth, U.S. Is Said to Pay High Price
abstract: Unemployment among young adults takes a toll in missing tax payments and increased expenditures, a study finds.
lead_paragraph: Persistent high unemployment among young people is adding up to $25 billion a year in uncollected taxes and, to a much smaller degree, increased safety net expenditures, a new report says.

headline: Bangladesh’s Governing Party Wins Vote Amid Unrest
abstract: The Awami League won more than two-thirds of the seats in Parliament in a vote undercut by low turnout, a boycott by the main opposition party and deadly violence.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Bangladesh’s governing party celebrated its victory in general elections on Monday, dismissing critics who said the vote’s legitimacy was undercut by violence, low turnout and the absence of the country’s main opposition force from the ballots.

headline: Trial to Begin for Martoma, Ex-SAC Trader Who Cut No Deal
abstract: Mathew Martoma has resisted aiding a long-running federal investigation of SAC Capital Advisors and its founder, Steven A. Cohen.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors never thought their insider trading case against Mathew Martoma would go to trial.

headline: Saudis’ Grant to Lebanon Is Seen as Message to U.S.
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Foreign Aid', 'Sunni Muslims', 'Shiite Muslims', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'International Relations']
abstract: Saudi Arabia’s $3 billion gift to the Lebanese Army was intended as much to send a message to the United States as to shift the military balance, analysts said.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — If a wealthy patron were all the Lebanese Army needed to counter the Shiite militant group Hezbollah as the dominant force in the country, the recent $3 billion grant from Saudi Arabia might make a decisive difference in the country’s complex political landscape.

headline: Impromptu Coming Out for Olympic Star
abstract: Brian Boitano said his decision to announce he was gay days after being named to a delegation that will represent the United States at the Winter Games in Russia was a spur-of-the-moment decision.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 16, while skating on tour in the French Alps, Brian Boitano said he received a call from the White House gauging his interest in being named by President Obama to represent the United States at the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.

headline: The Next Council Speaker
abstract: The reputation and legislative record of Councilman Daniel Garodnick makes him the better choice.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, New York City Council members are expected to choose a speaker to lead them and, when necessary, unite them as a counterweight and an alternative voice to the mayor’s. Or that’s how it’s supposed to work.

headline: Polar Chicago
abstract: Stoic Chicagoans brave negative 38-degree wind chill for work and for leisure.
lead_paragraph: Stoic Chicagoans brave negative 38-degree wind chill for work and for leisure.

headline: Medical Marijuana in New York
abstract: A limited plan by Gov. Andrew Cuomo to loosen restrictions on its use should be expanded and strengthened by the State Legislature.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York is set to use his executive powers to loosen restrictions on the use of marijuana for medical purposes. The Legislature, where medical marijuana bills have stalled repeatedly in the State Senate, ought to expand and strengthen the governor’s effort through appropriate legislation.

headline: Rumors Fly Among Hasidim About Abducted Man’s Death
abstract: As family and friends ascended the steps of Menachem Stark’s brick rowhouse on Monday to pay their respects, they were abuzz with a single question: Why had he been killed?
lead_paragraph: The mourning for Menachem Stark, a Hasidic real estate developer from Brooklyn who was kidnapped and killed last week, was not a quiet affair. As family and friends ascended the steps of his red brick rowhouse on Monday to pay their respects, they were abuzz with a single question: Why had he been killed?

headline: Unfair Phone Charges for Inmates
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission took an important step to end price-gouging but more needs to be done.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Communications Commission ended a grave injustice last fall when it prohibited price-gouging by the private companies that provide interstate telephone service for prison and jail inmates. Thanks to the F.C.C. order, which takes effect next month, poor families no longer have to choose between paying for basic essentials and speaking to a relative behind bars. The commission now needs to be on the lookout for — and crack down on, if necessary — similar abuses involving newer communication technologies like person-to-person video chat, email and voice mail.

headline: Clash of Priorities Sets Up Cuomo-de Blasio Showdown on Pre-K Push
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio wants state officials to approve a tax on the rich to pay for prekindergarten classes, but Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo wants to cut taxes.
lead_paragraph: It was a political show of force. Nearly every top labor leader in New York City stood side by side on Monday in a Harlem classroom as Bill de Blasio, the newly installed mayor, looked on.

headline: Arctic Cold Blankets Midwest, Freezing Routines
abstract: A deep freeze not seen in decades swept through the center of the country, closing schools as well as some businesses as far south as Oklahoma.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Hildagard Omete, 36, a mother of three who has been unemployed for a year and a half, went job hunting on Monday.

headline: Will Digital Networks Ruin Us?
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Income Inequality', 'Books and Literature', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
abstract: Today’s profitable business model could be tomorrow’s disaster. Consider this food for thought.
lead_paragraph: The most important book I read in 2013 was Jaron Lanier’s “Who Owns the Future?” Though it was published in May, I came to it late in the year. But this turned out to be fortuitous timing. With unemployment seemingly stalled out at around 7 percent in the aftermath of the Great Recession, with the leak of thousands of National Security Agency documents making news almost daily, with the continuing stories about the erosion of privacy in the digital economy, “Who Owns the Future?” puts forth a kind of universal theory that ties all these things together. It also puts forth some provocative, unconventional ideas for ensuring that the inevitable dominance of software in every corner of society will be healthy instead of harmful.

headline: High-Speed Train in California Is Caught in a Political Storm
abstract: A high-speed rail line from Los Angeles to San Francisco, which Gov. Jerry Brown has made a personal crusade, is reeling from a court ruling on its financing and from slipping public support.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Gov. Jerry Brown of California is riding into an election year on a wave of popularity and an upturn in the state’s fortunes. But a project that has become a personal crusade for him over the past two years — a 520-mile high-speed train line from Los Angeles to San Francisco — is in trouble, reeling from a court ruling that undermined its financing, and from slipping public support and opponents’ rising calls to shut it down.

headline: Polar Vortex: Temperatures Fall Far, Fast
abstract: A mix of atmospheric ingredients was coming together to create a drop of about 50 degrees in a matter of hours in Central Park.
lead_paragraph: Meteorologists called it “weather whiplash” — a drop of roughly 50 degrees in a matter of hours that took temperatures from 55 in Central Park on Monday morning to a record low of 5 overnight and an expected high on Tuesday of only 10. The last time temperatures in New York fell that much in such a short time, Warren G. Harding was in the White House.

headline: Turning Away From Painful Chapters
abstract: What happens when we ignore ugly truths about the past -- when families bury their dark secrets, and nations try to forget their sins?

headline: A Hiring at Texas Is a Signal of Progress and Fairness
keywords: ['Football (College)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Coaches and Managers']
abstract: Racial barriers never seem to fall fast enough, but Charlie Strong now has one of the premier coaching positions in college football.
lead_paragraph: There were no tears in Texas, in contrast with four years ago when the impact of an overdue appointment was too much even for a man with the commanding name of Charlie Strong.

headline: $18 Billion Price Put on Effort to Block Carp
abstract: The most effective methods could take 25 years to put in place, the Army Corps of Engineers said.
lead_paragraph: The most effective methods of keeping Asian carp from invading the Great Lakes via Chicago’s web of waterways could cost up to $18.4 billion and take 25 years to put in place, the federal Army Corps of Engineers concluded in a study released Monday.

headline: Jagr Receives Olympic Spot As Roster Questions Swirl
abstract: Jaromir Jagr is headed to the Olympics for a fifth time, with the Czech Republic, but roster selections for the Sochi Games have not been without controversy and more is sure to follow.
lead_paragraph: Jaromir Jagr, the 41-year-old Devils wing playing like a man nearly half his age, is headed to the Olympics for a fifth time, as three countries named their rosters for the men’s hockey tournament at the Sochi Games next month. But the selections were not without controversy, and more controversy is sure to follow Tuesday, the deadline to submit Olympic rosters.

headline: Question Posed
abstract: Mark Bickham passes the sniff test.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Some people have signature words. Mine is “awesome.” If I like something, it is awesome. It’s convenient to have a signature word like this, because then you don’t have to remember all the other words that mean exactly the same thing and I can then use the extra space in my brain to figure out what I’m going to eat next. That’s a far more efficient use of space, in my opinion.

headline: Test Scandal in Atlanta Brings More Guilty Pleas
abstract: The focus is shifting to the former schools superintendent, who is being portrayed as the mastermind of a scheme that led to charges against 35 educators accused of manipulating test scores.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The cast of characters was mostly former teachers and principals, six of whom pleaded guilty on Monday in a Fulton County courtroom for their part in what has been described as the largest cheating scandal in the nation’s history. Their pleas bring to 17 the number of educators who have already pleaded guilty, with a handful more in active negotiations.

headline: Samsung Forecasts Greater Earnings Decline Than Expected for the End of 2013
abstract: The South Korean company, the world’s biggest maker of smartphones, predicted operating income of $7.8 billion for the final quarter, down from $9.5 billion in the third quarter.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Samsung Electronics, the world’s biggest maker of smartphones, said Tuesday that its earnings in the last quarter of 2013 fell from the previous three-month period as well as from the same period a year ago, heightening investors’ concerns about competitive pressures in the industry.

headline: Egyptian Bloggers Who Mobilized Support for 2011 Uprising in Jail or Under Threat

abstract: As the third anniversary of Egypt’s 2011 uprising approaches, many activists who helped mobilize support for the sit-in that drove Hosni Mubarak from power are facing extended prison terms for daring to protest the new military-backed government.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, Tuesday, 2:46 p.m. | Despite an apparent lack of evidence connecting her to the crime, Mona Seif, a scientist and blogger who is also one of Egypt’s most prominent rights activists, was convicted on Sunday of having taken part in a reported arson attack on the campaign headquarters of Hosni Mubarak’s last prime minister, Ahmed Shafik, nearly two years ago.

lead_paragraph: The office of Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, said in court papers Monday night that prosecutors had engaged in “hours of discussion in the hope of negotiating a plea” with the Indian diplomat whose recent arrest in New York led to an outcry in India.

headline: For Survivor of Political Strife, the Journey Continues in the Bronx

lead_paragraph: When they came for Angele Nogue, she was wearing a nightgown. Then 33, she was asleep with her family at their home in Douala, Cameroon, when the police arrived at her door, she says, and took her away. It was February 2008, and the nation was roiling.

headline: Run Run Shaw, Chinese-Movie Giant of the Kung Fu Genre, Dies at 106
abstract: Mr. Shaw and his older brother, Run Me, were movie pioneers in Asia, producing and sometimes directing films like “Five Fingers of Death.”
lead_paragraph: Run Run Shaw, the colorful Hong Kong media mogul whose name was synonymous with low-budget Chinese action and horror films — and especially with the wildly successful kung fu genre, which he is largely credited with inventing — died on Tuesday at his home in Hong Kong. He was 106.

headline: Judge Rejects Chicago’s Ban on Gun Shops
abstract: Chicago’s ban on gun shops violates the Constitution, a federal judge ruled on Monday, dealing the latest setback to politicians who had put in place some of the nation’s strictest limits on firearms.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — This city’s ban on gun shops violates the Constitution, a federal judge ruled on Monday, dealing the latest setback to politicians here who had put in place some of the nation’s strictest limits on firearms.

headline: Saying Police Fed ‘Lies,’ Witness to ’94 Murder Recants
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Witnesses', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: Nearly 20 years after Joan Purser-Gennace helped convict Robert Jones of a murder in Queens, she testified that her identification was false, and coerced by the police.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in nearly 20 years, Joan Purser-Gennace took the witness stand in a Queens courtroom, but this time her testimony was starkly different: Much of what she testified to two decades ago — words that helped convict a man of a murder — was a lie, she said, spoon-fed to her by police detectives.

headline: Halton Arp, 86, Dies; Astronomer Challenged Big Bang Theory
abstract: Mr. Arp was a provocative son of American astronomy whose dogged insistence that astronomers had misread the distance to quasars led to his exile from his peers.
lead_paragraph: Halton C. Arp, a provocative son of American astronomy whose dogged insistence that astronomers had misread the distances to quasars cast doubt on the Big Bang theory of the universe and led to his exile from his peers and the telescopes he loved, died on Dec. 28 in Munich. He was 86.

lead_paragraph: Bronson Binger, a New York architect and preservationist who helped wrest Union Square Park in Manhattan from drug dealers but was stymied in an effort to rebuild Wollman Rink in Central Park, died on Dec. 23 in Housatonic, Mass. He was 83.

abstract: Most members of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission indicated that storing spent nuclear fuel in pools was safer than moving it, despite concerns about terrorism.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Most members of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission indicated on Monday that they considered it safe to continue storing most spent nuclear fuel in pools, even though concerns remain about potential accidents and terrorist attacks.

headline: Lineup Set for Tribute to Music of Paul Simon
abstract: Among the performers for a concert at Carnegie Hall honoring the music of Paul Simon are Joy Williams and Bettye LaVette.
lead_paragraph: For the last nine years Michael Dorf, the owner of City Winery, has made an annual trip uptown to raise money for music education programs by way of a tribute concert at Carnegie Hall. This year’s installment, on March 31, the 10th in Mr. Dorf’s series, honors the music of Paul Simon. The preliminary lineup for the concert, which Mr. Dorf is expected to announce on Tuesday, includes Joy Williams (of the Civil Wars), the soul singer Bettye LaVette, the singer-songwriters Bob Mould, Dan Wilson and Ben Sollee, the composer Allen Toussaint and a collaboration between the jazz singer Madeleine Peyroux and Jon Herington, the lead guitarist of Steely Dan.

lead_paragraph: The N.B.A. has long hoped to be released from its financial obligation to Ozzie and Daniel Silna, brothers who owned the Spirits of St. Louis in the defunct American Basketball Association.

headline: Faulty Websites Confront Needy in Search of Aid
abstract: Efforts at modernizing the systems for government aid in many states have largely backfired in recent months, causing enormous cost overruns and delays for benefits.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Three months after the disastrous rollout of a new $63 million website for unemployment claims, Florida is hiring hundreds of employees to deal with technical problems that left tens of thousands of people without their checks while penalties mount against the vendor who set up the site.

headline: Detroit Pensions Are Frozen, Then Thawed
abstract: The city’s emergency manager, Kevyn D. Orr, issued the order on Dec. 30, but it was not released to news organizations or posted on Detroit’s website.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The city’s emergency manager, Kevyn D. Orr, in an unpublicized move last week, ordered that pension benefits for thousands of public employees be frozen, but said on Monday that he would delay the move to allow for a possible compromise in federally mediated talks.

headline: Charges Filed in Attack on Chinese Consulate in San Francisco
abstract: The Chinese citizen who was arrested in connection with the Jan. 1 arson attack faces federal charges of arson and damaging the property of a foreign government.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese citizen has been arrested in connection with the Jan. 1 arson attack at the Chinese Consulate in San Francisco, the F.B.I. said. According to a statement released by the F.B.I. in San Francisco, Yan Feng, 39, of Daly City, Calif., turned himself in to police officers on Jan. 3 and was arrested “without incident.” Mr. Feng made his first court appearance on Monday to face two federal charges, arson and damaging the property of a foreign government.

headline: Florida State Wins With Auburn-Like Comeback
abstract: In a game that went back and forth in the final minutes, the Seminoles outplayed the Tigers, securing the win in the final B.C.S. championship game.
lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — A furious second-half comeback. A 100-yard kickoff return. A touchdown drive led by a redshirt freshman quarterback that ended with 13 seconds on the clock.

headline: Senate Postpones Vote on Unemployment Benefits
abstract: The measure is expected to fall to a Republican filibuster.
lead_paragraph: Senate leaders on Monday night abruptly postponed a vote to take up a measure extending expired unemployment benefits. Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader, was about to call the vote when the Senate’s No. 2 Republican, John Cornyn of Texas, accused him of manufacturing a political issue by holding a vote with 17 senators absent, mostly because of weather delays. Mr. Reid than gruffly asked for consent to postpone it until Tuesday morning. The measure is expected to fall to a Republican filibuster.

headline: Jameis Winston Smiles All the Way Into Seminole Lore
abstract: Though the national championship game was more challenging than the signal-caller thought, he joins quarterback royalty at F.S.U.
lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — Late Monday, the celebration continued in the Florida State locker room. Championship hats and T-shirts were everywhere. The room was loud and the mood light.

headline: What’s on Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 5:45 P.M. (Sundance) AN EDUCATION (2009) Carey Mulligan stars as Jenny, a willful, Oxford-bound 16-year-old suffering from ennui in the London suburb of Twickenham in 1961. Peter Sarsgaard is David, the older man who introduces her to a world of art auctions and Champagne while appealing to the pretensions of her proper parents (Cara Seymour and Alfred Molina). But soon it’s apparent that David and his fabulous life aren’t quite what they seem, though that doesn’t stop Jenny from playing along. “The filmmakers themselves seem too intoxicated by the mystique of the period to take full account of the sad, bleak aspects of the story they have to tell,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this drama directed by Lone Scherfig, written by Nick Hornby and based on a memoir by Lynn Barber. Still, he added, in the end the film is “a pleasure — which I don’t mean entirely as a compliment.”

headline: California: Girl Declared Dead Is Transferred
abstract: The family of Jahi McMath, 13, who was declared brain-dead after complications from surgery last month at Children’s Hospital Oakland, said on Monday that she had been transferred to a facility that will provide her with care.
lead_paragraph: The family of Jahi McMath, 13, who was declared brain-dead after complications from surgery last month at Children’s Hospital Oakland, said on Monday that she had been transferred to a facility that will provide her with care.
