headline: Palestinian Pleasures
abstract: Instead of relying on familiar tropes to capture the contemporary Palestinian experience, Tanya Habjouqa chose to focus on the pleasure and the humor rather than the suffering.
lead_paragraph: Since the mid-1980s, the visual narrative of Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza has been predictable: photographs of stone-throwing teenagers confronting Israeli soldiers, refugee camps, mothers mourning children killed in conflicts, and long lines at border crossing points. Particularly dramatic variations on these visual tropes make the front pages and win awards.

headline: Should College Football Players Get Paid?
abstract: Should they be regarded as student athletes and amateurs, or as the labor force in a multibillion-dollar commercial enterprise?
lead_paragraph: The 2013-14 college football bowl season ended Monday night, and even if you missed the Little Caesars Pizza Bowl or the Sheraton Hawaii Bowl, it’s hard to miss the fact that college football is big business — a multibillion-dollar industry. Top coaches receive sky-high salaries, and many college athletic departments rake in huge sums. But college football players? Zero. N.C.A.A. rules bar college athletes from earning any compensation. Is this fair?

headline: Judge Accuses Spanish Princess of Money Laundering and Tax Fraud

She is the first close relative of a Spanish monarch in modern history to face the prospect of a criminal trial.

Or should he sell the business and start another one to manufacture his restaurant’s red sauce, which he had been selling over the counter as Jersey Italian Gravy?

headline: European Cable Operator Altice Plans $1 Billion I.P.O.

headline: Danglers Ahead
abstract: Danglers in their various forms are one of our most common grammatical lapses. Participle phrases, “like” comparisons, appositives and other modifying constructions generally must be adjacent to the noun or pronoun they refer to. Otherwise, they dangle — and leave a clumsy or confusing sentence.
lead_paragraph: As I’ve noted ad nauseam — here, here and here, for example — danglers in their various forms are one of our most common grammatical lapses. Participle phrases, “like” comparisons, appositives and other modifying constructions generally must be adjacent to the noun or pronoun they refer to. Otherwise, they dangle — and leave a clumsy or confusing sentence.

headline: Must This Lesbian Wear a Dress to an Orthodox Synagogue?
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Homosexuality', 'Synagogues', 'Gender', 'Women and Girls', 'Religion and Belief', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Baby Boomers']
abstract: A woman who dresses on the masculine side wants to know if she has to compromise her expression by dressing according to a religious code.
lead_paragraph: Q. Dear Civil Behavior: I am a gay woman who tends to dress and identify on the masculine side. I’ll soon be attending a religious service at my extended family’s Orthodox synagogue, requiring modest attire, which means that women are not allowed to wear pants and can be denied entry. I think that as long as I dress respectfully and in the spirit of the religious mandates I should not have to compromise on my gender identity and expression. My family says that I’m being difficult and that “when in Rome …” Of course, there is no chance my relatives would dress according to a code I prescribed for an event if it conflicted with their religious identity. So why am I considered “difficult” for not compromising in the expression of my gender identity when they would be considered justified in not compromising their religious expression? — Name withheld

headline: Labor Tactic Raises Fear for France
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Tires', 'Kidnapping', 'Corporations']
abstract: The kidnapping of two executives at a Goodyear factory have become one of the most potent symbols of the challenges companies face in France.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Negotiations broke down last weekend at a Goodyear tire factory scheduled for closing in northern France, so employees resorted to a brazen tactic: They kidnapped the bosses.

headline: Daily Report: Soft Smartphone Sales Lead to Decline in Samsung’s Profit

headline: Will Forte Is Just as Surprised as You Are
abstract: The co-star of “Nebraska” said discussions with his agents and managers over a long-term career strategy never included “get into an Alexander Payne movie.”
lead_paragraph: Will Forte was an unexpected winner with the National Board of Review; he’ll pick up his prize for best supporting actor, for his turn as a son on a road trip with his cantankerous father (Bruce Dern) in “Nebraska,” at the group’s ceremony Tuesday night.

headline: Trial Begins for Former SAC Trader
abstract: The insider trading trial of the former SAC trader Mathew Martoma begins. | Activist investors seen in more positive light. | Chief executives and the beauty premium. | A bond trader departs Morgan Stanley.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors had long hoped Mathew Martoma, a former portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors, would provide the missing link in their pursuit of the hedge fund’s owner, Steven A. Cohen. Instead, the insider trading case prosecutors never thought would happen is going to trial, Matthew Goldstein and Ben Protess write in DealBook. Prosecutors first confronted Mr. Martoma in November 2011, asking him to cooperate in their long-running investigation of Mr. Cohen, and they have continued to press him in a number of meetings since. But Mr. Martoma has baffled officials by refusing to cooperate against the boss who fired him in 2010.

headline: Christopher Kane’s Vision for His First Store
abstract: The Scottish designer talks about his winter 2014 men’s wear collection and plans for a London opening this summer.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Christopher Kane is getting ready to open his first store this summer on London’s Mount Street, a shopping area that already has drawn the fashion houses of Balenciaga, Lanvin, Marc Jacobs and Christian Louboutin, as well as Nicholas Kirkwood shoes and Stephen Webster jewelry.

headline: New Yorkers Struggle to Shrug Off the Icicles
abstract: On Tuesday, New Yorkers seemed to accept the record cold as just another trial in the gantlet of seasonal indignities city dwellers face.
lead_paragraph: It was 8 degrees at 4:30 a.m., but it felt like minus 12, a fact of which Mike Peters was grimly aware. Mr. Peters, a utility worker, stood neck deep in a two-foot-by-two-foot pit hacked into the pavement of Avenue of the Americas in Greenwich Village, the sidewalk around him slicked with ice that fringed the hole he was in with filthy icicles.

headline: Greek Police Hunt for Convicted Terrorist Who Disappeared on Furlough
abstract: Christodoulos Xiros, a member of the terrorist group November 17, is at large after failing to check in with the police, fueling fears of a resurgence in political violence.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — The Greek authorities on Tuesday began a nationwide search for a convicted member of the dismantled November 17 group, once the country’s deadliest guerrilla organization, after he failed to report to the police during a prison furlough, fueling fears of a resurgence of political violence.

headline: Low Inflation Worries the Euro Zone
abstract: Consumer prices in the euro zone barely increased last month, raising fears of deflation and putting pressure on the European Central Bank to take further action.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Consumer prices in the euro zone barely increased last month, raising fears of deflation and putting pressure on the European Central Bank to take further action.

headline: Charges for 106 in Huge Fraud Over Disability
abstract: Retired police officers and firefighters were among those accused in a decades-long scheme in which false mental disability claims cost taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars, according to court papers.
lead_paragraph: The retired New York City police officers and firefighters showed up for their psychiatric exams disheveled and disoriented, most following a nearly identical script.

headline: Lindsey Vonn’s Injured Knee Will Keep Her Out of Sochi Games
abstract: The skier, who tore two ligaments in a crash last year, said she would have surgery soon, sidelining her for the season and robbing the American team of much of its star power.
lead_paragraph: Lindsey Vonn sat on a stone wall at the United States Open in June, waiting for her boyfriend, Tiger Woods, to finish his second round. Four months after major knee surgery, Vonn, the defending Olympic champion in the women’s downhill, was already looking eight months ahead.

headline: Citizens Financial to Sell Chicago-Area Branches to U.S. Bancorp
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: As part of the deal, U.S. Bancorp’s banking unit will acquire about $5.3 billion in deposits and $1.1 billion in loans, giving it about $11.3 billion in deposits in the Chicago area. Citizens Financial is a unit of the Royal Bank of Scotland.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Citizens Financial Group, a unit of the Royal Bank of Scotland, said on Tuesday that it had agreed to sell 94 retail branches, as well as its small business operations in the Chicago area, to U.S. Bancorp.

headline: In Performance: Bobby Moreno of ‘Year of the Rooster’
abstract: The actor performs a scene from Eric Dufault’s cockfighting comedy at the Ensemble Studio Theater.
lead_paragraph: In Eric Dufault’s cockfighting comedy “Year of the Rooster,” Bobby Moreno plays a menacing bird with issues named Odysseus Rex. In this scene the rooster challenges the sun to a fight. Directed by John Giampietro, the show begins performances on Jan. 9 at the Ensemble Studio Theater, where it had a well-received run last year.

headline: Karen Carpenter: Voice of a Lifetime
abstract: Six takes on Carpenter’s voice.
lead_paragraph: As a sidebar to the Riff column I wrote for this past weekend’s issue, which drew from the book I’m writing about my appreciation of the Carpenters’ music and the life events of mine it surrounded, here are six takes on Karen Carpenter’s voice. They include early reviews of Carpenters albums and posthumous nods from the likes of the film director Todd Haynes and the novelist Mary Gaitskill. Their range is a testament to hers.

headline: Today in Small Business: Close the S.B.A.?
abstract: Business bankruptcies fall, how four businesses use YouTube creatively, and Zappos gets rid of managers.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

lead_paragraph: First chocolate, now cheese.

abstract: A convenient combination yields complex flavors and a variety of textures.
lead_paragraph: What’s for Dinner? answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

keywords: ['Cloud Computing', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Enterprise Computing', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Oracle’s purchase of Corente pushes the once web-shy technology giant further into the Internet age.
lead_paragraph: Oracle announced on Tuesday that it had agreed to purchase Corente, a cloud-based services company, in a move that pushes the once web-shy technology giant further into the Internet age.

headline: In Our Pages: January 8
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune
lead_paragraph: 1889: Is Waltzing Immoral?

headline: Bloomberg Failed to Meet 51% of Goals in His Last Fiscal Year in Office
abstract: By the mayor’s own measure – admittedly a high standard – his record at delivering city services by the end of his tenure seems middling.
lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg was elected mayor in 2001 in part because he promised to run the city as efficiently as he had his business. Eight years later, a federal judge let him run for a third term because, as a businessman, Mr. Bloomberg said he was best suited to steer the city through tough economic times. But by the mayor’s own measure – admittedly a high standard – his record at delivering city services by the end of his tenure seems middling.

headline: Mussina Deserves More Than ‘Almost’ From Hall
abstract: Mike Mussina, who retired after 18 seasons with a 270-153 record and a 3.68 earned run average, should someday be remembered as a Hall of Fame pitcher.
lead_paragraph: Scrawled on the dry-erase board by Mike Mussina’s locker one spring morning in Tampa, Fla., was this message: “Huey Bong Says Chicago Is Dusty.” The words made no sense. There had to be a story behind them.

headline: Vote in Senate Starts Talks on Extending Unemployment Benefits
abstract: Some see a political issue in a move to provide $6.4 billion in assistance to the unemployed, and Democrats were not optimistic that a deal could be reached.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate’s unexpected vote on Tuesday to advance legislation extending expired unemployment benefits touched off delicate negotiations to secure final passage in the chamber, even as Republicans and Democrats warily eyed the political motives behind the efforts.

headline: Through Nearly Third of Ballots, 4 Players Are on Track for Election
abstract: With nearly a third of ballots known, the two pitchers — plus Frank Thomas and Craig Biggio — appeared to clear the 75 percent threshold required for induction.
lead_paragraph: One year after writers failed to elect any players to the Baseball Hall of Fame, four candidates are polling strongly as voters make their selections public.

headline: Bounced From Hospice
abstract: Hospices are discharging increasing numbers of patients before they die.
lead_paragraph: It didn’t come as a complete surprise when a Pennsylvania hospice told Phyllis Fine’s family last year that she was no longer eligible to receive care.

headline: Amid Accusations of Department Misconduct, Los Angeles Sheriff Will Step Down
abstract: Lee Baca, the embattled sheriff, said he would retire at the end of January and not seek re-election, ending speculation about his future amid federal investigations of his department.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The embattled sheriff of Los Angeles, Lee Baca, announced Tuesday that he would retire at the end of the month and not seek re-election. His announcement ended weeks of speculation about his future amid federal investigations and accusations of widespread misconduct in his department.

headline: London Fashion Week: J.W. Anderson Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

headline: Chevrolet Introduces Corvette Performance Data Recorder at C.E.S.
abstract: The technology will allow owners to analyze their driving performance.
lead_paragraph: For this year’s Consumer Electronics Show, Chevrolet is installing technology that sounds like it belongs in a commercial airliner into the Corvette Stingray.

headline: On McQueen’s Night, Belafonte Steals the Show
abstract: At the New York Film Critics Circle dinner, Harry Belafonte’s tribute to “12 Years a Slave” brings the room to a standstill.
lead_paragraph: It was an awards ceremony as glitzy and clubby as anyone could hope: Cate Blanchett regal and resplendent in a sweeping silver gown; Adèle Exarchopoulos, the winsome young French star of “Blue Is the Warmest Color,” shyly flashing her slightly buck-toothed smile; Robert Redford accepting the best actor award with avuncular ease — all rubbing shoulders with the film critics who had bestowed upon them the latest in this season’s round of awards.

headline: Pay-Per-Like
abstract: Companies are paying small armies of people in developing countries to “like” their Facebook pages.
lead_paragraph: It turns out you can buy love, after all. Well, at least affection on social media sites. For a price as low as half a cent per click, companies, government agencies and entrepreneurs can get a small army of people in developing countries to “like” their Facebook page, endorse them on LinkedIn or follow them on Twitter, according to a recent Associated Press story.

headline: James Bond, Sherlock Holmes, Hercule Poirot: Why Do We Keep Resurrecting the Same Literary Characters?
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Bond, James (Fictional Character)', 'Holmes, Sherlock (Fictional Character)', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: James Parker and Pankaj Mishra discuss why certain characters keep returning to life.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, James Parker and Pankaj Mishra discuss why certain literary characters never seem to die.

headline: Lang Lang and Metallica Join an Offbeat List of Grammy Collaborators
abstract: The pianist Lang Lang will share a stage with Metallica at the Grammy Awards.
lead_paragraph: When Lang Lang joined forces with Herbie Hancock at the Grammy Awards in 2008, there may have been a few raised eyebrows, but it was not really much of a stretch: Mr. Hancock’s musical language is jazz and Mr. Lang’s is classical, but both are virtuoso pianists who easily found common ground in an arrangement of Gershwin’s “Rhapsody in Blue.”

headline: When Good Things Like the Playoffs Happen to Bad Teams Like the Knicks
abstract: The Knicks can take solace in the fact that several N.B.A. teams have recovered from an 11-22 record, or worse, to make the playoffs. But they didn’t get far.
lead_paragraph: The 11-22 Knicks, a team with Metta World Peace on its roster, might look to a team once led by World B. Free for inspiration to make the N.B.A. playoffs.

headline: Jane Campion to Lead Cannes Film Festival Jury
abstract: Ms. Campion is the only woman director to have won the festival’s highest honor, the Palme d’Or.
lead_paragraph: The New Zealand director Jane Campion will lead the feature film jury at this year’s Cannes Film Festival, the festival announced on Tuesday. In a statement, the organizers noted that Ms. Campion is the only female director to have won the festival’s highest honor, the Palme d’Or, for her 1993 film “The Piano,” starring Holly Hunter and Harvey Keitel.

Regulators scrambled to say they were considering changing the rule, but that was evidently not enough for some legislators.

headline: First Batch of Deadly Chemicals Exported From Syria
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: An international operation to oversee the destruction of Syria’s chemical arsenal began its most dangerous phase.
lead_paragraph: The first batch of the most dangerous materials in Syria’s banned chemical weapons stockpile was exported from the country on Tuesday, loaded onto a Danish commercial vessel in the Syrian port of Latakia in an operation overseen jointly by the United Nations and the group responsible for ensuring the arsenal’s destruction.

headline: The Pirate Bay Has a Plan to Avoid Blockades
abstract: The Pirate Bay, which is used to download copyrighted movies, music and TV shows, is going to build a so-called peer-to-peer network that will allow anyone to download and share files simultaneously.
lead_paragraph: The Pirate Bay’s website, which is used to download copyrighted movies, music and television shows, is often taken offline by authorities. Last year, the site changed its domain name six times, shuffling among .se, .sx, and .ac domains, after court orders to block the site.

headline: Soft Forecast by Samsung Points Out Challenges
abstract: The South Korean company, the world’s biggest maker of smartphones, predicted operating income of $7.8 billion for the final quarter, down from $9.5 billion in the third quarter.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — No wonder Samsung Electronics is so busy looking for a new hit product. Its signature device, the high-end smartphone, seems to be facing unanticipated challenges.

abstract: But even as men’s wear designers experiment, the focus is on practical and wearable clothes.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Noble, strong, a proud label with a feminist stance — the powerful J.W. Anderson show on Tuesday ignited the London Collections: Men and rekindled the masculine-feminine debate in 21st-century fashion.

headline: 200 Years of American Financial Crises
keywords: ['Gross Domestic Product', 'Recession and Depression', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Detail on the nine systemic financial crises the United States has suffered since 1814, taken from a new paper about post-crisis recoveries.
lead_paragraph: Shaila Dewan and I had an article on Monday about a study suggesting the American economy was doing reasonably well — at least compared with the aftermath of previous systemic financial crises. Some readers wrote me asking about what the previous crises were and how they’re defined, so here’s some more detail.

headline: The Gun Report: January 7, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: If more citizens were armed, criminals would think twice about attacking them, Detroit Police Chief James Craig said in a press conference last week. Craig, who served in the L.A.P.D. for 28 years, attributes a lack of confidence in his police department to the likelihood that someone with a concealed weapons permit will open fire, The Detroit News reported.

headline: Wolfram Wants to Connect the Internet of Things
abstract: Stephen Wolfram, a scientist and entrepreneur, announced the “Wolfram Connected Devices Project,” an initiative to provide and share knowledge about connected devices.
lead_paragraph: If all our gadgets and gizmos are going to be connected to the Internet, and in turn one another, they’ll need to speak the same language.

headline: Obama Speaks of Better Days for Economy, With Asterisk
abstract: President Obama faces a challenge as he seeks to advertise the nation’s financial recovery while arguing for action to help a still-besieged middle class.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Only moments after the Senate advanced an emergency extension of unemployment insurance benefits on Tuesday, President Obama stood on an East Room stage full of people without jobs and defied the traditional logic of White House strategy that normally emphasizes good news over bad.

headline: Lamb Tagine Demands a Red
abstract: The tagine’s sweet and savory flavors pair well with a red wine that is fruity yet dry and perhaps slightly bitter.
lead_paragraph: The sweet and savory bursts of flavor in this tagine call for a red wine that is fruity yet dry and perhaps slightly bitter. The fruitiness will echo and amplify the sweet spiciness of the dates, pomegranate seeds, cinnamon and ginger, while the dry, bitter flavors will serve to underline the savory elements and refresh the mouth between bites. Italian reds like dolcetto, Valpolicella and Montepulciano d’Abruzzo specialize in the tension between fruity and bitter flavors.

abstract: BYD announces plans to sell cars in the United States; Detroit automakers plan to distribute $800 million to workers.

headline: Directors Guild Names Its Top 5
abstract: Paul Greengrass makes the directors guild’s nominations; the Coen brothers do not.
lead_paragraph: The Directors Guild of America released its nominations for best feature director today, a list notable for the inclusion of “Captain Phillips” and the omission of “Inside Llewyn Davis,” continuing that film’s guild shutout. Stay tuned for the Bagger’s analysis. For now, here’s the list:

headline: Qaeda Group Leader in Syria Suggests Islamic Court to End Rebel Infighting
keywords: ['Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: The leader of the Nusra Front sought to end deadly violence among rebels as the United Nations reported progress on the purge of chemical weapons from Syria.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The leader of the Nusra Front, an affiliate of Al Qaeda in Syria, on Tuesday proposed an initiative aimed at halting the worst infighting yet between the armed opponents of President Bashar al-Assad since the start of the conflict nearly three years ago.

headline: Loaded With Centers, Team Canada Passes on Some Notables
abstract: Canada, the defending champion, and Russia, the host nation, and Finland announced men’s hockey teams loaded with N.H.L. stars for the Winter Games.
lead_paragraph: The pool of candidates from which the Canadian Olympic men’s hockey team was picked was like a Tim Hortons strawberry jelly filled doughnut. It was bursting with goodness at center. Given Hockey Canada’s formidable depth at the position, it was inevitable a worthy player would be squeezed out.

headline: Weight-Loss Companies Charged With Fraud
keywords: ['Consumer Protection', 'Dietary Supplements and Herbal Remedies', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Weight', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission said the companies made “unfounded promises” that consumers could lose weight using their products.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — “Get a gym body without going to the gym” by sprinkling a powder on your food. “Significantly slim your thighs and buttocks” using an almond-scented cream. Lose up to one pound a day with just two drops under the tongue.

headline: The Real Belfort Story Missing From ‘Wolf’ Movie
abstract: Jordan Belfort has had a great cinematic run in the new Martin Scorsese film “The Wolf of Wall Street,” but for many of his victims, the ending is beyond an insult, writes Joel M. Cohen in Another View.
lead_paragraph: Joel M. Cohen, a former federal prosecutor, is a partner in the New York office of Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher.

headline: Bipartisan Critic Turns His Gaze Toward Obama
abstract: Former Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates’s new memoir is the first describing the Obama administration’s policy deliberations written from inside the cabinet.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After ordering a troop increase in Afghanistan, President Obama eventually lost faith in the strategy, his doubts fed by White House advisers who continually brought him negative news reports suggesting it was failing, according to his former defense secretary Robert M. Gates.

headline: JPMorgan Settlement Documents in Madoff Case
abstract: Under a settlement between JPMorgan and federal prosecutors, the bank will pay $1.7 billion to victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme.
lead_paragraph: Under a settlement between JPMorgan and federal prosecutors, the bank will pay $1.7 billion to victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme.

headline: Turning Cheese Into a Cook’s Assistant
abstract: Its variety and unpredictability may be daunting, but a few tips can help harness its versatility.
lead_paragraph: The following confession may come as a surprise from someone who makes her living as a food stylist and writer: I’m slightly intimidated by the cheese counter.

headline: Sum of Batista Parts Still Doesn’t Add Up
abstract: It’s tempting to think there might be investment opportunities in a $2.5 billion collection of companies that were worth $60 billion just a few years ago. But that would be wrong, contends Christopher Swann of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to find a phoenix in the ashes of Eike Batista’s empire. There are real assets buried under the tycoon’s collapsed EBX Group. Even so, the group’s onetime flagship energy explorer will emerge with poor growth prospects. Investors have already priced in big things for the port and electricity arms. And too much depends on a resurgent Brazilian economy.

headline: Sandvik to Buy Texas Oil Drilling Equipment Company for $740 Million
abstract: The deal allows Sandvik, a Swedish company that provides specialized equipment for the mining and construction industries, to enter a new product area.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Swedish engineering company Sandvik said on Tuesday that it had reached an agreement to acquire the Texas oil drilling equipment company Varel International Energy Services for about $740 million.

headline: A Rare Visit With a Jailed Journalist in Egypt
abstract: A first-person account of a visit with Mohamed Fahmy, an Al Jazeera English journalist jailed in Cairo for his coverage of the Muslim Brotherhood, provides a rare glimpse into prison conditions in Egypt.
lead_paragraph: A first-person account of a visit with Mohamed Fahmy, part of a team of journalists from Al Jazeera English who were arrested 10 days ago on accusations that their coverage of the Muslim Brotherhood constituted “false news” and “incitement,” has provided a rare glimpse into prison conditions in Egypt as the government cracks down on the Brotherhood and anyone suspected of supporting it.

headline: Republicans Respond to the Pope
abstract: Newt Gingrich, Rush Limbaugh and Paul Ryan are having a tough time absorbing the Pope’s critique of today’s “impersonal economy.”
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis has reportedly struck a chord in Washington with his critique of today’s “impersonal economy.”

headline: Tips for Travel Savings in 2014
keywords: ['Budget Travel', 'Travel and Vacations', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Frequent Flier Programs', 'Mobile Applications', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: Budget travelers don’t have to conform to the same choices to save money. Here’s some advice you can customize.
lead_paragraph: Break a resolution yet? If any were travel-related, here’s some good news: In 2014, you can save while staying the traveler that you are.

headline: Travel Trends and the Year Ahead
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: Mark Rabe, a data-marketing executive, talks about notable shifts in how we research and book our trips.
lead_paragraph: Where do you plan to go in 2014? That’s a question advertisers in the travel industry are eager to find the answer to. And for a pretty good idea of that answer — and some insight into when and how to pitch you — they turn to data-marketing companies like Sojern.

headline: Obama Calls for Action on Unemployment
abstract: The president said Congress should pass legislation that would restore benefits to millions of people who are struggling to find work in an economy that is still recovering from a deep recession.
lead_paragraph: The president said Congress should pass legislation that would restore benefits to millions of people who are struggling to find work in an economy that is still recovering from a deep recession.

headline: Still Not Serious About Jobless Benefits
abstract: Benefit checks are still a long way from getting to the people who desperately need them, thanks to the callousness of Republican lawmakers in both the House and Senate.
lead_paragraph: The Senate agreed on Tuesday to hold a debate on extending unemployment benefits to more than a million of the long-term jobless, clearing the first filibuster hurdle. But those benefit checks are still a long way from getting into the mailboxes of the people who desperately need them, thanks to the callousness of Republican lawmakers in both the House and Senate.

headline: The Big Chill
abstract: The London’s men’s collections mark the beginning of the fall 2014 shows. A look at James Long, J.W. Anderson, Jonathan Saunders and others.

headline: Idaho Ballet Troupe to Shift Directions
abstract: The Trey McIntyre Project in Boise will mount a tour this spring and then cease operating as a full-time dance troupe, becoming a project-driven company.
lead_paragraph: The Trey McIntyre Project, a contemporary ballet troupe based in Boise, Idaho, will mount a tour this spring that ends with six performances at the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival, June 25 to 29, and will then cease operating as a full-time dance troupe and will instead be a project-driven company.

headline: The Top Twelve Motherlode Posts of 2013
abstract: From Mary Ingalls to helicopter parents to dieting 7-year-olds, here are the most-read, most-shared and most-talked about posts of 2013 on Motherlode.
lead_paragraph: If you read that headline aloud, it’s nice and alliterative. These 12 posts represent Motherlode’s “tops” of last year — the most read, most commented-upon, most-shared, and in general, the most “Motherlode.” They’re conversation starters: Entertaining, interesting and in some cases provocative.

headline: A Backup Drive Worth Staring At
abstract: The Sphere from LaCie is covered in actual silver plate, manually plated and polished in Normandy, France. Inside is 1TB of storage.
lead_paragraph: Backup drives are usually characterless bricks, far more function than form. But the drive maker LaCie has teamed with the French silversmith Christofle to make a drive that is pleasing to the eyes and has plenty of function to boot.

headline: The Lives They Lived: André Cassagnes
abstract: A tribute to the creator of the Etch A Sketch.
lead_paragraph: The creator of the Etch A Sketch gets his own treatment in the magazine’s Lives They Lived issue, which celebrates a selection of people who died in 2013.

headline: Listen Up | The Cinematic Sounds of Nashville’s Newest Indie-Pop Quintet
abstract: Wild Cub, the electro-pop project of the sometimes film-scorer Keegan DeWitt, trades Music Row sheen for world-influenced sounds on its debut album.
lead_paragraph: “I’m getting my world together at the moment,” says Keegan DeWitt, the 31-year-old frontman of the Nashville-based electro-pop quintet Wild Cub. Over the next two months, Wild Cub will play 23 shows across Britain and the United States, and release an expanded version of its debut album (the infectious “Youth,” streaming below) on Jan 21. Meanwhile, DeWitt — the band’s tireless songwriter — will squeeze in a trip to the Sundance Film Festival, where he scored two films in this year’s program. It’s a whirlwind start to 2014 for a band that formed less than two years ago, but DeWitt, who moved to Nashville from Brooklyn in 2008, has never been one to keep a light schedule.

headline: Entrepreneurial Lessons From ‘The Wolf of Wall Street’
abstract: Remove the corruption and some unnecessary vileness, and we can learn a lot about fast growth from this movie.
lead_paragraph: I went to see “The Wolf of Wall Street,” and I think Martin Scorsese, the famed director, just nailed how business cultures are created in fast-growth companies. He took it over the top with the Hollywood glamour, vulgarity and corruption, but he got a lot of it right — I just wish he could have left out the corruption.

headline: Will Hermes to Write Lou Reed Biography
abstract: The Rolling Stone writer will pen “Lou: A New York Life” for Farrar, Straus and Giroux.
lead_paragraph: Farrar, Straus and Giroux has signed the Rolling Stone writer Will Hermes to write “Lou: A New York Life,” a biography of Lou Reed.

headline: Airline and Rail Travelers Stranded During Severe Cold Weather
abstract: Stranded Amtrak and airline passengers document their travel ordeals on social media.
lead_paragraph: As the bitter cold moved east and continued to keep much of the center of the country in a deep freeze, travelers found themselves stranded at airports, on Amtrak trains and in their driveways.

headline: Revival for a Sauce That Never Left
abstract: Comeback sauce is a spicy, versatile reminder of the South’s connection to Greek culture.
lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — Comeback sauce, a spicy, versatile remnant of a bygone South, is making something of, well, a comeback. And it is reminding Southerners of an old connection to Hellenic culture.

headline: Samuel McCoy to Be Chelsea Opera’s Music Director
abstract: Chelsea Opera, a small Manhattan opera company, has appointed Samuel McCoy as its new music director and principal conductor.
lead_paragraph: Chelsea Opera — a small Manhattan opera company that calls itself “the little opera company that could” — has appointed Samuel McCoy as its new music director and principal conductor. For his first outing in the position, Mr. McCoy, who has worked on contemporary operas and classics, will conduct a production of Aaron Copland’s “The Tender Land” at Chelsea Opera in June, said Lynne Hayden­-Findlay, who formed the company in 2004 with Leonarda Priore.

headline: Make Music New York to Host Monthly Talks
abstract: Monthly talks at the Cornelia Street Café will bring musicians together for talks on subjects like the role of music under the rule of the Taliban and music in advertising.
lead_paragraph: Make Music New York continues to expand. It began in 1989, as a one-day event, held every year on June 21, the summer solstice, with performances by musicians and ensembles of every stylistic stripe at parks, atriums, street corners and concert halls all over New York City, from 10 a.m. to 10 p.m.  Then, in 2011, inspired by Phil Kline’s annual “Unsilent Night” boombox parade, a winter solstice (Dec. 21) event was added, with composers and performers parading through the streets making music.

headline: Twitter Co-Founder Unwraps Jelly, a Visual Social Query App
abstract: Biz Stone, who made his fortune on the 140-character messages of Twitter, has revealed his next act: an app that allows people to pose questions to their social networks using photos.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 6:26 p.m. | Added comments from an interview with Biz Stone, Jelly’s chief executive.

headline: Broadway’s ‘Glass Menagerie’ Recoups Investment
abstract: The critically acclaimed revival, with Zachary Quinto and Cherry Jones, has recouped its $2.6-million capitalization, the play’s producers announced.
lead_paragraph: The critically acclaimed Broadway revival of “The Glass Menagerie” has recouped its $2.6-million capitalization, the play’s producers announced on Tuesday. Only about 25 percent of Broadway shows turn a profit for their investors, and when plays do so, they usually feature Hollywood celebrities in the cast. While “The Glass Menagerie” has one such star, Zachary Quinto (the recent “Star Trek” movies) as Tom, the play’s box office has also benefited from strong buzz about the quality of the production and the performances of its four actors, particularly two-time Tony Award winner Cherry Jones as the mother, Amanda Wingfield. Directed by Tony winner John Tiffany (“Once”), “The Glass Menagerie” began performances at the Booth Theater in September and is scheduled to end its run on Feb. 23.

headline: 308 Thai Officials Face Anticorruption Inquiry
abstract: The investigation, connected with a constitutional amendment that was struck down in court, could destabilize the governing party.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — The anticorruption authorities in Thailand announced Tuesday that they were opening investigations of 308 lawmakers, most of them from the governing party, on suspicion of “malfeasance in office,” in connection with a constitutional amendment that was later ruled by a court to have been enacted illegally.

headline: Gluten-Free Ramen, Pullet Eggs and More
keywords: ['Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Writing and Writers', 'Eggs', 'Milk', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Coffee', 'ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES', 'Food']

headline: A Case for the iPhone Attracts Some Unwanted Attention
keywords: ['International Consumer Electronics Show', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Smartphones', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The Typo iPhone case provides users with a physical keyboard. But two other factors have allowed Typo to stand out from the crowd.
lead_paragraph: Typo is one of a vast array of iPhone cases introduced this week at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. Despite its name, it is intended to improve typing accuracy by providing users with a physical keyboard.

headline: Making the Restaurant Part of the Family
abstract: Some talented young French chefs are bucking tradition by insisting on a private life.
lead_paragraph: ROUEN, France — At first glance, Benjamin Lechevallier would seem to be the very soul of the ambitious, tireless French chef.

headline: In Westchester, Picturesque Prosperity
abstract: Buyers in these hamlets are typically Manhattanites who want to raise a family in a rural environment.
lead_paragraph: When Hatsy and Scott Vallar were living in Manhattan with toddler sons overtaking their three-bedroom Upper East apartment, they knew it was time to move to a place where the children could spend more time outdoors. So in 1997, they moved to Bedford, a rural community of narrow winding two-lane highways and many unpaved side roads, paying $1 million for a four-bedroom six-and-a-half-bath colonial on 4.25 acres near several horse farms.

headline: The Contradictions of Liberal Populism
abstract: The problem with conscripting the upper middle class into a war on inequality.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column, on Bill De Blasio and the new liberal crusade against inequality, took note of one of the internal tensions facing 21st century liberal populism: The movement tends to succeed politically when it mobilizes the upper middle class against the super-rich, but then its dependence on those same upper middle class votes significantly limits its ability to raise taxes and expand transfers to the extent that a true war on after-tax inequality would probably require.

headline: Economic Inequality in America: Developing a New War on Poverty
abstract: In this lesson students will learn about the problems of poverty and economic inequality in America, and then they will research possible solutions as they propose a new war on poverty for 2014.
lead_paragraph: Overview |  How big of an issue is poverty in America today, and what are the most effective ways to address it? Is America still the great land of opportunity — where if you work hard and play by the rules, you can make it?

headline: Empire Diner Opens in Chelsea
abstract: This familiar restaurant has new owners and a new chef; Brooklyn gains more barbecue; a pop-up speakeasy in Little Italy and more.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Syria, South Sudan, Indonesia and New York.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, South Sudan, Indonesia and New York.

headline: Lupita Nyong’o’s Bonding Moment and Steve McQueen’s Union Roots
abstract: At a luncheon for “12 Years a Slave,” Ms. Nyong’o, who plays the slave Patsey, explained how she worked with Michael Fassbender to go to “such dark places.” Meanwhile, Steve McQueen noted that he was especially honored by his Directors Guild nomination as he grew up with a father in the union.
lead_paragraph: New York was shivering on the outside, but all was warm and cozy at midday Tuesday inside the plush 21 Club, where a lunch was held to honor the female stars of “12 Years a Slave.”

headline: Overhaul of Israel’s Economy Offers Lessons for United States
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Income Inequality', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Economy']
abstract: With a single bill, Israel is looking to revamp its economy and hopefully reduce income inequality, showing that a democracy can achieve change, Steven Davidoff writes in the Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: Americans may talk about income inequality, but Israel has done something about it.

headline: New York Critics’ Group Apologizes for Heckling, but Armond White Says He Didn’t Yell Anything
abstract: After the director was heckled at an awards ceremony, the New York Film Critics Circle issues an apology to Fox Searchlight and Mr. McQueen. But the critic who reportedly did the heckling, Armond White, says he never yelled anything.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 6:42 p.m. |  New York film circles were abuzz early Tuesday with the spectacle that threatened to overshadow the awards ceremony held the previous night: an outburst at the New York Film Critics Circle awards.

headline: Tax Break as a Not-So-Secret Weapon
abstract: The retooled credit, called Grow New Jersey, allows any company to apply regardless of its size or type, as long as it is considering leaving the state or moving there.
lead_paragraph: The tax break wars are heating up again, as New Jersey aggressively pushes a revamped program to encourage businesses to stay or move within its borders.

headline: L.A. Sheriff to Retire
abstract: In an emotional statement, the embattled Los Angeles County sheriff, Lee Baca, said that he would not seek re-election to a fifth term and that he planned to retire at the end of the month.
lead_paragraph: In an emotional statement, the embattled Los Angeles County sheriff, Lee Baca, said that he would not seek re-election to a fifth term and that he planned to retire at the end of the month.

headline: Tosca Cafe
abstract: Inside the meticulously restored restaurant in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: Inside the meticulously restored restaurant in San Francisco.

headline: Revenge Takes on Life of Its Own
abstract: Dark themes are explored after most of a family is shot dead in “The Kept,” James Scott’s first novel.
lead_paragraph: James Scott’s debut novel, “The Kept,” opens on a scene of massacred children. It’s daring and bleak in a novel whose daring is found in its bleakness. Elspeth Howell, a midwife, returns to her family’s remote homestead in far upstate New York in a snowstorm to find four of her five children and her husband shot dead and left where they fell. Her fifth child, Caleb, has been hiding in a closet since three men came and gunned down the Howells. Thinking his mother is one of the gunmen returning to finish him off, Caleb shoots her, wounding her badly. If you’re expecting things to look up, read no further. What follows is an unrelentingly somber story of revenge played out across an austere landscape.

headline: Oldies Done in New Palettes
abstract: The Jupiter Symphony Chamber Players weighed in on Monday on the art of composers’ transcriptions of other composers’ works.
lead_paragraph: Given the plentitude of chamber music series in New York, it is easy to take low-visibility offerings for granted, despite the consistency, excellence and affordability of their programs. I had not been to a concert by the Jupiter Symphony Chamber Players in a long while when I attended Monday afternoon’s program at Good Shepherd Church. I will not let so much time slip by again.

headline: A Rite of Sexual Submission: Bed to Book to Off Broadway
abstract: The writer Toni Bentley and the actress Laura Campbell discuss preparations for a solo show based on “The Surrender,” Ms. Bentley’s erotic memoir.
lead_paragraph: Rehearsal rooms are not places of great sensuality, unless your tastes run toward fluorescent lighting, groaning heating pipes and bathroom cubicles with cracked toilets.

headline: ‘Downton Abbey’ Returns to a Record Audience
abstract: The season premiere for “Downton Abbey” drew more than 10.2 million viewers, a record for this British drama.
lead_paragraph: “Downton Abbey” has become event television.

headline: A Dream Fight Made Real Onstage
abstract: Reid Farrington splices together video footage and live performance to produce a theoretical matchup of Mike Tyson and Muhammad Ali in “Tyson vs. Ali.”
lead_paragraph: The sweat, the combativeness and even the body blows feel mighty real, but the fight itself is pure fantasy in “Tyson vs. Ali,” a sleek mixed-media meditation on a boxing bout that never was, and never could have been. Currently bobbing and weaving around a simulated ring at the 3LD Art & Technology Center in Lower Manhattan, the production is conceived and directed by Reid Farrington, who deftly splices together video footage and live performance to offer a prismatic take on a theoretical matchup of Mike Tyson and Muhammad Ali, two of the great names in boxing history.

headline: This Place Looks Familiar
abstract: Restaurateurs are finding historic interiors like Tosca Cafe’s worth saving.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When the man swayed into Tosca Cafe with the distant yet determined expression of a bar-stool poet 50 years late for a drink with Jack Kerouac, I thought he had to be a ringer. When he listed past the gleaming, monumental espresso machine and produced a bottle of off-brand tequila from his jacket, I was sure of it. Ken Friedman and April Bloomfield, the New York restaurateurs who converted this landmark dive bar into an Italian restaurant last year, had clearly put him on the payroll to keep up Tosca’s reputation as a haven where unmoored eccentrics raise glasses with actors, go-go dancers, politicians, heavy-metal drummers, cops and Russian ballerinas.

headline: Boston Globe Hires Journalist to Focus on Catholicism
abstract: The newspaper said it would hire John L. Allen Jr. from The National Catholic Reporter and explore starting a publication aimed at Catholics.
lead_paragraph: The Boston Globe announced on Tuesday that it would hire John L. Allen Jr., a journalist for The National Catholic Reporter, and explore starting a free-standing publication dedicated to Catholicism.

headline: A Cash Prize as Elusive as ...
abstract: Based on two new shows, the TV trend of 2014 may be reality shows about people hunting things, including other people.
lead_paragraph: It’s time once again to ponder that age-old philosophical question: Do sasquatches have access to televisions? Because if they do, and they channel surf their way to a new Discovery show called “Lone Target,” no one is going to win the $10 million.

headline: Andrea L. Olshan
abstract: Ms. Olshan, 33, is the chief executive of Olshan Properties, a private real estate company that owns and manages properties in 11 states.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Olshan, 33, is the chief executive of Olshan Properties, formerly known as Mall Properties, or M.P.I., a private real estate company that owns and manages retail, residential, office and hotel properties in 11 states, among them the mixed-use Parkchester development in the Bronx.

headline: Taking Along iCloud Calendars
abstract: Apple’s iCloud data service works best with Apple’s own devices, but it is possible to make it work with other companies’ hardware.
lead_paragraph: Q. Our family life depends on Apple shared calendars. If I go AWOL and get a non-Apple portable device, can I get access to the calendar? For that matter, can I get access to the calendar on a Windows laptop?

headline: The Point Men for Public School
abstract: A winning design team with New York in its DNA.
lead_paragraph: The Public School design duo was at Barclays Center in Brooklyn last month for an N.B.A. game between the Knicks and Nets. It was the first quarter, and they were drinking beer and eating hot dogs.

headline: London Fashion Week: James Long Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

headline: With Vonn Out, Other Olympians May Shine Brighter
abstract: Lindsey Vonn’s injury may mean athletes like the snowboarder Shaun White, the skier Ted Ligety, the figure skater Kim Yu-na and the curler Brad Jacobs will see more of the spotlight.
lead_paragraph: Admit it: You were dying to watch that 17-day made-for-TV “Lindsey & Tiger” special otherwise known as the Sochi Winter Olympics. Just think of NBC’s full-sepia treatment as Lindsey Vonn zoomed past the finish line and into the arms of her ear-muffed boyfriend, Tiger Woods.

headline: Diane von Furstenberg to Leave Lincoln Center
abstract: The decision by Diane von Furstenberg, the president of the Council of Fashion Designers of America, to leave Lincoln Center amid complaints about its Fashion Week atmosphere suggested the leader might be abandoning ship.
lead_paragraph: Diane von Furstenberg, the president of the Council of Fashion Designers of America, puts on one of the splashiest shows in the tents at Lincoln Center, with a front row of media stars and celebrity friends. So her decision to leave the space amid complaints about its atmosphere suggested the leader might be abandoning ship.

headline: The End of the Much-Debated B.C.S.
abstract: The Bowl Championship Series, debated and ridiculed during its existence, produced a thrilling last act before a new playoff system took over.
lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — The Bowl Championship Series, a postseason system that drew the ire of college football coaches, players and fans while enriching bowl directors and the establishment that profited from it, died Monday night after Florida State topped Auburn, 34-31, in the final championship game.

headline: The Missing Piece in the War on AIDS
abstract: Guest blogger Ellie Feinglass looks what is standing in the way of victory in the fight against AIDS.
lead_paragraph: One afternoon last spring I met a farmer named Salomão in a rural community in Southern Mozambique.  Salomão was in his late 30s, living with both HIV and tuberculosis, and very poor, with few possessions aside from the clothing on his back, some cooking pots, and his hoe.   In late March, he walked without shoes for eight hours in the pouring rain so that he could pick up his month’s supply of drugs.  When he got to the health center, he was tired and weak.  He was then humiliated and turned away because his health card was wet.  And in the process, Salomão’s HIV status – something that should be held in complete confidentiality – was disclosed to everyone who happened to be in the crowded waiting area at the outpatient clinic.   Upon returning to his village, Salomão was shunned by his family and many of his neighbors.  Without his medicine, his health deteriorated rapidly.  By May, he had developed several abscesses on his leg.  He resisted returning to the health facility.  Within a few weeks Salomão died at home, alone, and in silence.

headline: What the JPMorgan Settlement Means
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: JPMorgan Chase could have dug deeper despite an obligation to monitor accounts for suspicious activity, writes Peter J. Henning. But the victims of the fraud will be getting some repayment after prosecutors got creative, he says.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase’s latest criminal settlement shows that prosecutors are becoming more creative about getting money to victims of a fraud rather than just putting it into federal coffers.

headline: Who’s Helped — and Hurt — by the Directors’ Nods
abstract: Expect a few of the guild’s nominees — like David O. Russell, Steve McQueen and Alfonso Cuarón — to get Oscar nominations as well. The odds remain longer for “Inside Llewyn Davis,” “Nebraska” and “Her.”
lead_paragraph: The Directors Guild of America has historically been a fairly good predictor of both the eventual best director Oscar nominees, and a harbinger of the best picture field – that is, until the last few years. Generally, the guild matches up with the Oscar directing category in four of its five slots; last year, however, when the directors branch of the Academy threw a loop by not nominating Ben Affleck or Kathryn Bigelow, both guild honorees, that stat went out the window.

headline: That Uncertain Muse and Witness, Memory
abstract: Several current productions, from Tennessee Williams’s “The Glass Menagerie” to Harold Pinter’s “No Man’s Land,” navigate the malleable landscape of recollection.
lead_paragraph: “Blow out your candles, Laura,” Tom says. But she doesn’t.

lead_paragraph: The Russian soprano Anna Netrebko has withdrawn from the first two performances of Donizetti’s “L’Elisir d’Amore” at the Metropolitan Opera this month because she is suffering from the flu, the opera house announced Tuesday.

headline: Recalling a Disaster Without Uttering a Word
abstract: “The Great Flood” uses music and stark images to tell about the destruction and aftermath of the 1927 Mississippi River flood.
lead_paragraph: This probably isn’t the kind of compliment the filmmakers want to hear in the week of its theatrical release, but “The Great Flood,” a beautiful exploration of the Mississippi River flood of 1927, almost demands to be enjoyed using high-quality headphones. Its soundtrack is an artwork in its own right, one worth savoring as you would a fine recording.

headline: An Artist Who Turns Music and Movies Into Soundless Works
abstract: For his first solo exhibition in New York, the Berlin-based creator Gregor Hildebrandt made original pieces using recorded songs and films that meant something special to him.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the Berlin-based artist Gregor Hildebrandt will fill both floors of the Galerie Perrotin on the Upper East Side with his first solo show in New York, “Die Geschichte lauft uber uns” (“The Story Runs Across Us”). Music and film weave through his installations, sculptures and works on canvas, but the experience of the exhibition is completely visual: there is no sound.

keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Tear Gas']
abstract: South Korea’s government has reportedly decided to block the export of millions of tear gas shells to Bahrain, after months of pressure by human rights groups.

lead_paragraph: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam — When Intel went about setting up its chip factory in Vietnam, it found an oddity: Local laws did not govern every aspect of the building.

abstract: Sudan backed away from its foreign minister’s assertion that it had talked with South Sudan about creating a joint force to protect threatened southern oil fields.
lead_paragraph: KHARTOUM, Sudan — Sudan on Tuesday backed away from its assertion that it had held discussions with South Sudan about creating a joint force to safeguard oil fields in the South, the economic lifeblood for both countries that is being threatened by the fighting in South Sudan.

abstract: David Kocieniewski and Gretchen Morgenson answer questions about their series of articles examining the challenges posed by Wall Street’s influence over markets and the prices consumers pay.
lead_paragraph: In response to an invitation to readers, David Kocieniewski, a business reporter for The New York Times, and Gretchen Morgenson, an assistant business editor and columnist, are answering questions about their four-part series, The House Edge, which examined the challenges posed by Wall Street’s influence over markets and the prices consumers pay.

lead_paragraph: Most of the darlings of the last few years have been consumer-focused start-ups, like Instagram and Warby Parker.

lead_paragraph: At the International Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, long lines of people swerved around the blackjack tables, skirting the slot machines and doubling back around. No, people were not waiting to see the latest drones or curvy televisions. They were waiting to hear Marissa Mayer, the chief executive of Yahoo, speak about updates for a company that was once left for dead.

headline: New Agency, a Spinoff, Will Aim Its Message at a Hispanic Audience
abstract: The JeffreyGroup, an agency known mainly for public relations, is creating a new agency to provide cross-cultural marketing to Hispanics.
lead_paragraph: IT is hard to overstate the increasing influence of the growing Hispanic population upon Madison Avenue. Examples just so far this week include a ratings spurt on Monday night for “The Bachelor,” with its first Latin lead, Juan Pablo Galavis; special programming on Tuesday on ESPN Deportes, the Spanish-language version of ESPN, to celebrate its 10th anniversary; an announcement of a contest for youngsters to win a trip to the Copa Coca-Cola Soccer Camp during the 2014 World Cup in Brazil; and the debut on ABC on Tuesday night of a series, “Killer Women,” that is based on a drama from Argentina and includes Sofia Vergara among its executive producers.

headline: Maine: Man Pleads Guilty in Tusk Smuggling Case
abstract: A Tennessee collector of wildlife curios has pleaded guilty to three federal charges for his role in illegally bringing more than 100 narwhal tusks into the United States.
lead_paragraph: A Tennessee collector of wildlife curios has pleaded guilty to three federal charges for his role in illegally bringing more than 100 narwhal tusks into the United States. According to documents filed in Federal District Court on Tuesday, the collector, Jay G. Conrad, 67, admitted to one count each of conspiracy to smuggle goods, conspiracy to launder monetary instruments and smuggling. He was accused of working with co-defendants including Andrew J. Zarauskas of New Jersey and Gregory Robert Logan of Canada on a decade-long smuggling operation that brought the ivory tusks from Canada into the United States through Maine, in violation of the Marine Mammal Protection Act. No sentencing date has been set. Mr. Zarauskas is to be tried next month. Mr. Logan was arrested last month in Canada.

headline: Michigan: New Mayor Detroit Asks Detroit Residents To Stay
abstract: Mike Duggan delivered his first public address as the new mayor of Detroit on Tuesday, asking frustrated residents not to move out of the bankrupt city.
lead_paragraph: Mike Duggan delivered his first public address as the new mayor of Detroit on Tuesday, asking frustrated residents not to move out of the bankrupt city before giving his fledgling administration time to improve neighborhood services. “Give us six months to prove that we can turn things around,” said Mr. Duggan, who took office on Jan. 1. “Just push the pause button and don’t leave that house yet.” He said the success of his tenure as mayor would be determined by whether Detroit’s population — which has dropped by more than a million since 1950 — increases over the next four years.

headline: How Many Cheers for Cheerios?
keywords: ['Genetic Engineering', 'Labeling and Labels', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Food']
abstract: A new G.M.O.-free label is either a cynical marketing ploy or a huge deal or, possibly, both.
lead_paragraph: Well, a major and venerable American brand has gone and announced that it contains no genetically modified organisms (G.M.O.'s). Cheerios is G.M.O.-free! And will soon be labeled “Not Made With Genetically Modified Ingredients.”

headline: In Iraqi City Under Siege, More Support for Militants Than Officials
abstract: As the army prepared an assault on Falluja, many residents said they had more sympathy for the Qaeda-backed militants than for the government.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — On a good day, the drive from Falluja to Baghdad takes less than an hour. On Sunday morning, with his city under siege, its morgue filled with bodies and people running low on food, water and generator fuel, Osama al-Ani packed his family of seven into his car and set off for the capital. The trip, with its constant checkpoints and vehicle searches, took more than 12 hours, he said.

headline: What’s the Matter With Kansas’ Schools?
abstract: The state’s relentless cuts in education could hurt the whole country.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS, like every state, explicitly guarantees a free public education in its Constitution, affirming America’s founding belief that only an educated citizenry can preserve democracy and safeguard individual liberty and freedom.

headline: Ford Chief Out of Running to Lead Microsoft
abstract: Comments by Alan Mulally, the chief of Ford, are the most definitive sign yet that he is out of the running for the Microsoft job, though the prospects of such a change had dimmed in recent weeks.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Alan Mulally, the chief executive of Ford, said on Tuesday that he would not leave the automaker for Microsoft, ending months of speculation that he was a leading candidate to run the tech giant.

headline: Ethiopian Migrants Expelled by Saudis Remain in Limbo Back Home
keywords: ['Foreign Workers', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Deportation', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Remittances', 'International Relations', 'Poverty']
abstract: Many Ethiopians who were deported after seeking work in Saudi Arabia face bleak prospects at home and put a strain on the government that had benefited from their remittances.
lead_paragraph: LEGUAMA, Ethiopia — Mohammed Jemal left Ethiopia two years ago. He wanted to be independent, to support his family — and to escape the mockery of having squandered a big chance for a better life.

headline: Franky Cam
abstract: Franky, an easygoing 17-year-old tortoise, sauntered down an aisle of Lou's Pet Shop in Grosse Pointe, Mich., while broadcasting his movements online via Dropcam.
lead_paragraph: Franky, an easygoing 17-year-old tortoise, sauntered down an aisle of Lou's Pet Shop in Grosse Pointe, Mich., while broadcasting his movements online via Dropcam.

headline: Webcams See All (Tortoise, Watch Your Back)
keywords: ['Cameras', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Privacy', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: While the public is increasingly wary of the government recording their behavior, there has been little introspection about routinely monitoring people, pets or handymen.
lead_paragraph: In the Sahara, the African spurred tortoise lives for about a century. Thanks to modern technology, one named Franky has a shot at immortality.

keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
