lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 2,288 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Additional U.S. Battalion Going to South Korea
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations']
abstract: The nine-month deployment of 800 soldiers, battle tanks and other fighting vehicles was not tied to any specific security concern or provocation, the Pentagon said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon announced Tuesday that 800 soldiers, about 40 Abrams battle tanks and 40 armored infantry fighting vehicles would be deployed to South Korea next month as part of the Defense Department’s “rebalance” of forces across Asia and the Pacific.

headline: Mass Arrests During ’04 Convention Leave Big Bill and Lingering Mystery
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Republican National Convention', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Presidential Election of 2004', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Lawsuits over arrests at the time of the Republican National Convention in 2004 are likely to be among the costliest in New York’s history.
lead_paragraph: The final costs of settling civil rights lawsuits brought by hundreds of people who were swept up in mass arrests during the 2004 Republican National Convention — many of whom were breaking no laws whatsoever — are likely to be well over $35 million.

headline: What Happened to Transparency?
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Obama administration should stop fighting to hide legal advice.
lead_paragraph: When President Obama took office in 2009, he promised an “unprecedented level of openness in government.” In a memo issued the day after his inauguration, he wrote, “The government should not keep information confidential merely because public officials might be embarrassed by disclosure, because errors and failures might be revealed, or because of speculative or abstract fears.”

headline: U.S. Military Helicopter Crashes on Coast of England
keywords: ['Helicopters', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: All four people aboard were believed to have been killed after a helicopter on a training mission went down in northern Norfolk, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — An American military helicopter crashed on the coast of eastern England on Tuesday, and all four people aboard were believed to have been killed, the authorities said.

headline: New Leader at Billboard Sees Future in Visuals
abstract: Janice Min, 44, said Billboard faced challenges but could overcome them with a more visually arresting presentation and broader coverage.
lead_paragraph: Janice Min, who gave The Hollywood Reporter a renewed relevance by transforming the daily trade paper into a much-read weekly magazine and website, is about to see if that formula can put Billboard, the embattled music industry trade publication, back on the charts.

headline: Stuck Ships Break Free Near Antarctica
abstract: Chinese and Russian ships immobilized near Antarctica broke free Tuesday, news agencies reported, while a United States Coast Guard icebreaker called in to help rescue them was days away.
lead_paragraph: Two ships immobilized by ice floes near Antarctica broke free on Tuesday, news agencies reported. The Chinese icebreaker Xue Long was trapped Friday after its helicopter evacuated 52 passengers from a Russian research ship, the Akademik Shokalskiy, that had been icebound since mid-December. The BBC reported Tuesday that shifting winds had opened a path for the research ship to free itself. Xinhua, the Chinese state news agency, reported Tuesday evening that the Xue Long was also working its way out of the pack ice a short distance away. At the request of Australian maritime authorities last week, a United States Coast Guard icebreaker has been making its way toward the two ships, but was still several days away.

headline: Steep Penalties Taken in Stride by JPMorgan Chase
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: JPMorgan Chase has agreed to pay $20 billion the last year to settle legal cases filed by the government, an amount that doesn’t seem to have strained the bank much at all.
lead_paragraph: To settle a barrage of government legal actions over the last year, JPMorgan Chase has agreed to penalties that now total $20 billion, a sum that could cover the annual education budget of New York City or finance the Yankees’ payroll for 100 years.

headline: Biography Casts Critical Light on Fox News Chief
abstract: A 560-page biography about Roger Ailes being published this month aims to be an exhaustive look at the television executive’s life and monumental career.
lead_paragraph: Roger Ailes was so eager to influence national politics that in the run-up to the 2012 presidential election, he told fellow Fox News executives point-blank: “I want to elect the next president.”

headline: Pakistani Court Panel Weighs if Musharraf Is Fit for Trial
abstract: Five days after the former military ruler Pervez Musharraf was taken to a hospital, the panel began to debate whether he could be excused from attending treason proceedings.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD — A special court panel was shown on Tuesday a medical report on the former Pakistani military ruler Pervez Musharraf and began to determine whether he could be excused from attending treason proceedings against him. He was rushed to a military hospital for what was described as a sudden heart problem five days ago.

headline: Not Just About Us
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Books and Literature', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: As the headlines from the Arab world get worse and worse, there is talk of the “power vacuum” in the region. Getting overlooked is the “values vacuum.”
lead_paragraph: Every day the headlines from the Arab world get worse: An Al Qaeda affiliate group, aided by foreign fighters, battles with seven different homegrown Syrian rebel groups for control of the region around Aleppo, Syria. The Iranian Embassy in Beirut is bombed. Mohamad Chatah, an enormously decent former Lebanese finance minister, is blown up after criticizing Hezbollah’s brutish tactics. Another pro-Al Qaeda group takes control of Fallujah, Iraq. Explosions rock Egypt, where the army is now jailing Islamists and secular activists. Libya is a mess of competing militias.

headline: Palestinians Corner Jewish Settlers During Clash in West Bank
abstract: The confrontation in the northern West Bank was defused when the settlers, who said they had been hiking in the area, were handed over to Israeli forces.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A confrontation between a group of Jewish settlers and Palestinian villagers in the West Bank on Tuesday ended when Palestinian officials handed the settlers, who had been surrounded by other Palestinians, over to Israeli forces.

headline: Arctic Blast Proves Unwelcome Novelty, Especially Across South
abstract: The polar vortex took the jet stream for a turn in the South on Monday and Tuesday, bringing freezing temperatures as far south as Florida.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — The fountains turned into crystal still-lifes in Savannah, Ga. Ducks walked forlornly on iced-over swimming holes in southern Arkansas. School bus doors froze open in Beaufort, S.C. And pipes froze all over as Southerners, who are not born or made for temperatures in the Minnesota digits, had to consider things they typically take for granted.

headline: China’s Shadow Banking Problem
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Credit and Debt', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Editorials']
abstract: Policies that encouraged the growth of unregulated lenders should be altered before it is too late.
lead_paragraph: China’s top officials appear to be moving to address the risks posed by a fast-growing-but-shadowy part of the country’s financial system. The Chinese cabinet is seeking to increase government oversight of lending by companies that currently face little or no supervision, according to news reports based on an official document that was written last month.

headline: Temperatures Plunge in the East and South
abstract: The record-breaking polar air that has frozen the Midwest spread to cities from Boston to Nashville.
lead_paragraph: The record-breaking polar air that has frozen the Midwest spread to cities from Boston to Nashville.

headline: Germany: $8.2 Million in Drugs Found Among Fruit
keywords: ['Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Smuggling']
abstract: Supermarket workers in Berlin and Brandenburg State who were unpacking banana boxes found hundreds of pounds of cocaine, worth about $8.2 million, the police said Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Supermarket employees in Berlin and Brandenburg State were stunned when they started unpacking banana boxes and found hundreds of pounds of cocaine, worth about $8.2 million, the police said Tuesday. Seven crates unloaded on Monday contained an estimated 309 pounds of cocaine, the second-largest drug find in Berlin in 35 years, the police said. The crates were part of a shipment of more than 1,100 boxes from Colombia to a fruit wholesaler in Berlin. Olaf Schremm, a senior police officer, told reporters that drug smugglers had probably made a “logistical error.”

headline: Doubts Linger Over N.F.L. Concussion Settlement
abstract: Some players insist the $760 million proposed settlement by the N.F.L. is too small while others say that ailing former players need help now.
lead_paragraph: The ink on the N.F.L.’s proposed $760 million settlement had barely dried Monday before ex-players and their lawyers started sifting through hundreds of pages for clues about how the payouts and medical benefits will be distributed and whether there will be enough money for the claims brought by some of the 18,000 retirees.

headline: Venezuela: Death of Beauty Queen in Robbery Rattles Country
abstract: Mónica Spear, a soap opera actress and former Miss Venezuela, and her ex-husband were killed by robbers after their car broke down, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A soap opera actress and former Miss Venezuela, Mónica Spear, was shot to death by robbers after her car broke down on a highway, the authorities said Tuesday. Her ex-husband was also killed, and their 5-year-old daughter was wounded. Venezuela has one of the highest rates of violent crime in the region, but the killing of Ms. Spear, 29, provoked a particularly sharp outcry. President Nicolás Maduro called it “a massacre.” Ms. Spear was crowned Miss Venezuela in 2004 and was a soap opera star on the Spanish-language channel Telemundo. A United States citizen, she was in Venezuela on vacation, local media reported. A police official said five suspects had been arrested.

headline: Bridging the Compassion Gap
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Law and Legislation', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Why is John Boehner talking about supporting the extension of unemployment benefits, immigration reform and other ideas that are anathema to the Tea Party?
lead_paragraph: What’s going on with John Boehner, the speaker of the House?

headline: Iran: In Thaw, British Lawmakers Visit
abstract: A delegation of British lawmakers visited Iran on Tuesday, the first such trip in years and a reflection of the slowly improving ties between the countries.
lead_paragraph: A delegation of British lawmakers led by former Foreign Minister Jack Straw visited Iran on Tuesday, the first such trip in years and a reflection of the slowly improving ties between the two countries. Relations plunged near the breaking point in 2011 after Iranian protesters stormed the British Embassy. Mr. Straw was scheduled to meet with Iran’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, during the four-day visit. It comes a month after Britain’s new envoy to Iran, Ajay Sharma, traveled to Iran, the first diplomatic visit by a British official since 2011.

headline: Judge Blocks Part of N.Y.U.’s Plan for Four Towers in Greenwich Village
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A state judge on Tuesday unexpectedly blocked about half of New York University’s large and hotly debated expansion plan in the school’s leafy and largely low-scale neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: A state judge on Tuesday unexpectedly blocked about half of New York University’s large and hotly debated expansion plan to build four towers in the school’s leafy and largely low-scale Greenwich Village neighborhood.

headline: The Lessons of Physical Therapy
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Tucson Shooting (2011)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Physical Therapy']
abstract: My long rehab guides my way in the struggle against gun violence.
lead_paragraph: TODAY, the anniversary of the shooting in Tucson that put a bullet through my head and killed six of my constituents, is when I make my annual resolutions.

headline: New York State Supreme Court Ruling on N.Y.U. Proposed Expansion
abstract: Read the full ruling from the New York State Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: Read the full ruling from the New York State Supreme Court.

headline: Beautifying Abbey Road
abstract: As Americans decry a Dickensian class divide, they fawn over a British soap opera of manners.
lead_paragraph: In real life, Americans may keen about income inequality. But on TV, they’re keen for it.

headline: Pregnant, and Forced to Stay on Life Support
keywords: ['Life-Sustaining Support Systems, Withdrawal Of', 'Ethics (Institutional)', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Living Wills and Health Care Proxies']
abstract: A 33-year-old woman’s family is battling a Fort Worth hospital because the medical staff refuses to follow their instructions (and the woman’s) to take her off life support, because she is pregnant.
lead_paragraph: FORT WORTH — The diagnosis was crushing and irrevocable. At 33, Marlise Munoz was brain-dead after collapsing on her kitchen floor in November from what appeared to be a blood clot in her lungs.

headline: Saudis Back Syrian Rebels Despite Risks
abstract: The Saudis are bent on ousting Syria’s president, Bashar al-Assad, and his patron, Iran. But their only real means of fighting them is through a proxy war using fighters over whom they have almost no control.
lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — On his eighth trip to fight with the rebels in Syria, in August, Abu Khattab saw something that troubled him: two dead children, their blood-soaked bodies sprawled on the street of a rural village near the Mediterranean coast. He knew right away that his fellow rebels had killed them.

headline: The Cold This Time
abstract: Meteorologists warn us to expect severe weather conditions that used to occur rarely to happen more frequently. Is the world prepared?
lead_paragraph: By now, we all know that a polar vortex is a cyclone of frigid air centered on the Arctic. A rogue sweep of that air moved south and pushed the temperature in Central Park in New York City to a 118-year low of 5 degrees on Tuesday morning; records were similarly broken in scores of other American and Canadian cities; and flights were canceled across North America. Yet winter has barely begun, and, even before the icy cold of this week, it had already treated the eastern United States to snowstorms, southwest Britain to monster waves and northern Europe to unusually nasty weather.

headline: Uncertainty in Utah as Appeals Process Plays Out Over Gay Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Those who married during the two week-period when same-sex weddings were performed are left wondering whether their unions will be recognized by the state.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — Ever since it was a distant Western territory straining for statehood, Utah has been entwined in battles over what makes a marriage.

headline: For Some Tenants, Only Thing Heating Up Is a Temper
abstract: Thousands of New Yorkers complained of a lack of sufficient heat in their apartments, often a longtime condition.
lead_paragraph: In her chilly living room in the Crown Heights neighborhood of Brooklyn, Vernaline McFarlane on Tuesday read the most recent dates from a spiral notebook she has kept since October.

headline: Adult Beverages Not Supplied
abstract: A first that’s not really a first, from Sam Ezersky and Victor Fleming.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Sam Ezersky is one of our younger constructors and, according to his notes below, today’s puzzle was his first-ever submission to The New York Times. You can kind of tell from the theme, but since I happen to like the show that is highlighted in his theme, I’ll give that a pass.

headline: Preventing Civil War in South Sudan
abstract: Given the critical role the U.S. and other foreign entities played in the creation of South Sudan, what is their responsibility as the region faces another civil war?

headline: Cuomo, Joined by Biden, Details Disaster Aid Plans
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, cheered on by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., announced more than 1,00o projects that he said would make New York better prepared for future storms.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Drawing on lessons from Hurricane Sandy, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo outlined on Tuesday how New York would spend more than $16 billion in federal disaster aid on items like high-tech weather stations and seals for entrances to subway stations.

headline: Bothersome Ankles Sideline Nets’ Deron Williams
abstract: The star guard will miss Wednesday’s game against the Warriors after receiving cortisone and platelet-rich plasma injections around his ankles.
lead_paragraph: Even while riding a three-game winning streak, the Nets seem unable to avoid injuries that have undercut their recent success.

abstract: Investigators say that Mahuddin Mahmud, 57, was probably murdered and that they are looking for a tenant they describe as a “person of interest.”
lead_paragraph: The nearly decapitated body of a Brooklyn businessman was discovered early on Tuesday in the basement of a building he owned, police officials said.

headline: Long Island Man Gets $3.4 Million for 17 Years in Jail
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Martin H. Tankleff will receive $3.4 million under a lawsuit settlement after he was wrongfully convicted of murdering his parents 25 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Martin H. Tankleff, a Long Island man who served 17 years in prison for murdering his parents before a state appeals court vacated his conviction, will receive more than $3 million under a settlement of his wrongful imprisonment lawsuit.

headline: Seeking Clues to Gangs and Crime, Detectives Monitor Internet Rap Videos
keywords: ['Gangs', 'Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Music', 'Search and Seizure', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: As New York’s police force pulls back from stop-and-frisk tactics, it is pursuing deeper investigations against neighborhood gangs and finding clues in the rap videos they produce.
lead_paragraph: In the streets of Brownsville, Brooklyn, a local rap artist named Cuame Nelson was recording a new music video when someone called out his stage name.

headline: Corruption Trial Begins for a Bronx Assemblyman
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Retirement Communities and Assisted Living', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Politics and Government', 'Day Care Centers']
abstract: In the first trial stemming from a corruption scandal that shook Albany in April, Eric A. Stevenson is charged with taking over $20,000 to help build an adult day care center in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: At some point during his first term as an assemblyman, Eric A. Stevenson made a portentous decision: He decided “to sell official actions in exchange for thousands of dollars in cash,” a federal prosecutor told a Manhattan jury on Tuesday.

headline: Felton Returns, and Suddenly Surging Knicks Win Again
abstract: Raymond Felton played in his first game since Dec. 20 and Carmelo Anthony scored 34 points as the Knicks held off a late rally by the Pistons to pick up their third victory in four games.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks found a winning formula in Texas, and brought it home to New York — barely. After leading by 17 points late in the third quarter at Madison Square Garden, the Knicks nearly blew it Tuesday night. The Detroit Pistons almost stole a game that would have meant another night of misery for Knicks fans.

headline: De Blasio Fills Press Positions With Past Campaign Officials
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Mayors', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio appointed seven City Hall press aides, including several alumni of President Obama’s political operations and veterans of the mayor’s past offices and campaigns.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio, who rose to prominence as a behind-the-scenes caretaker of other politicians’ images, unveiled the new guardians of his own public persona on Tuesday, appointing a fleet of City Hall press aides.

headline: More Charges in Scheme to Defraud a Charity
abstract: Two former executives of the Metropolitan New York Council on Jewish Poverty were charged with grand larceny, money laundering, conspiracy and filing false documents.
lead_paragraph: Two additional former executives of one of the largest and most respected nonprofit social service agencies in the region were charged on Tuesday in connection with what prosecutors describe as a long-running scheme to defraud the organization of more than $7 million.

headline: Late Lobbying for Support as Speaker Election Nears
abstract: Supporters of Melissa Mark-Viverito, Mayor Bill de Blasio’s handpicked candidate, and Daniel Garodnick, her challenger, continued to campaign before the City Council picks its new speaker on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: With little time left in the contest to choose a new speaker of the New York City Council, the forces allied with Mayor Bill de Blasio were working furiously into the night on Tuesday to squelch any remaining chance that his handpicked candidate, Melissa Mark-Viverito, could be defeated.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 7, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Record-Low Belt
abstract: Records were set across the East and South on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Records were set across the East and South on Tuesday.

headline: When the Loss of a Job Feels Like the End of Life
abstract: A woman who taught elementary school for 20 years lost her position when she became ill. Without her job, she is depressed and even ashamed.
lead_paragraph: Neighborhood streets were once impromptu meeting places where Gail Dubins took immense pleasure conversing with the many students and parents she encountered. These days, those streets seem off-limits. Ms. Dubins, 53, has no desire to be seen, much less to fraternize in her Brooklyn neighborhood. Her social instincts have been stifled by her shame.

headline: On-Court Levity Puts J. R. Smith Back on the Defensive
abstract: J. R. Smith of the Knicks has again drawn attention from N.B.A. officials after an apparently unsportsmanlike act against a Mavericks player on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: J. R. Smith had no reason to do it, but that had never stopped him before.

headline: Jaromir Jagr a Last Link to a Golden Generation of Czech Hockey
abstract: That Jaromir Jagr, who will turn 42 next month, is still considered one of his country’s top players headed to Sochi says a lot about the state of the game in his country.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Jaromir Jagr, who will turn 42 during his fifth Winter Olympics next month, is part of a golden generation of Czech hockey that is slowly passing into history. Yet the fact that Jagr is still being looked to as one of his country’s top players headed to Sochi says a lot about the state of the game in his country.

headline: Elizabeth Jane Howard, Novelist of Mid-Century British Life, Dies at 90
abstract: Ms. Howard’s five-part series, The Cazalet Chronicles, traces a British family before, during and after World War II.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Jane Howard, a novelist known for her multivolume saga of a 20th-century English family and for her amorous entanglements with some of the 20th century’s foremost literary men, died on Thursday at her home in Bungay, England. She was 90.

headline: Report Finds More Flaws in Digitizing Patient Files
keywords: ['Electronic Health Records', 'Hospitals', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Medicare', 'Law and Legislation', 'Privacy']
abstract: The report is the second in two months to warn about flaws in the oversight of the ambitious federal program aimed at converting patient records from paper to electronic.
lead_paragraph: Although the federal government is spending more than $22 billion to encourage hospitals and doctors to adopt electronic health records, it has failed to put safeguards in place to prevent the technology from being used for inflating costs and overbilling, according to a new report by a federal oversight agency.

headline: How Being Heavy or Lean Shapes Our View of Exercise
abstract: Overweight women’s brains respond differently to images of exercise than do the brains of leaner women, a new neurological study finds, suggesting that attitudes toward physical activity may be more influenced by body size than has previously been understood.
lead_paragraph: Overweight women’s brains respond differently to images of exercise than do the brains of leaner women, a sophisticated new neurological study finds, suggesting that our attitudes toward physical activity may be more influenced by our body size than has previously been understood.

headline: Policies That Discourage Full-Time Work
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'Food Stamps', 'Part-Time Employment', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Payroll Tax', 'Social Security (US)', 'United States Economy', 'Working Hours']
abstract: The recovery of the average workweek since the recession has been held back by federal measures that make part-time work advantageous for employers or employees, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: Anbar’s Tribes Want to Join Other Provinces Against ‘Iranian Occupation’
abstract: The Military Council of the Anbar Tribes Revolutionaries released statements on social media about alliances with other Iraqi tribes to fight the government.
lead_paragraph: As my colleagues Yasir Ghazi and Tim Arango reported, the fighting in Anbar province has exacerbated the animosity among Sunni civilians and tribal militias toward the Shiite dominated government of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki.

headline: Sneaky Judges Find Their Pianist
abstract: The Polish pianist Rafal Blechacz will be announced on Wednesday as the winner of the $300,000 Gilmore Artist Award, given every four years to an unsuspecting pianist.
lead_paragraph: The Polish pianist Rafal Blechacz suspected nothing when, while preparing for three concerts in Switzerland in late 2012, he was bombarded with questions by the artistic director of the Lucerne Symphony Orchestra. He had no clue that a recital he gave that year in Schenectady, N.Y., was closely scrutinized and discussed and debated by a select few listeners.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER: SPECIAL VICTIMS UNIT Detective Benson (Mariska Hargitay) must reveal details about the attack on her by the psychopath William Lewis (Pablo Schreiber, above with Ms. Hargitay) — and cope with post-traumatic stress disorder — when he maneuvers to continue his winning streak at trial. In “Chicago P.D.,” a spinoff of “Chicago Fire,” created by Dick Wolf and Matt Olmstead, at 10, Jason Beghe stars as Hank Voight, the ruthless leader of the Chicago Police Department’s elite Intelligence Unit, created to deal with organized crime, drug trafficking and high-profile murders. His mantra: “You tell me the truth so I can lie for you.” Jon Seda, Jesse Lee Soffer, Sophia Bush, Elias Koteas, Amy Morton and Patrick John Flueger round out the cast. “ ‘Chicago P.D.’ is in many ways a throwback to an earlier, male-dominated era of crime shows,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times, “yet it carves out room for strong female characters who are good at their jobs and taken seriously by their colleagues — and the writers.”

headline: On Fighting the Last War (On Poverty)
abstract: It’s inequality, not social collapse.
lead_paragraph: Sorry about radio silence — I’ve been on the road, and busy. And I still am.

headline: To Lower Maternal Deaths, India Urged to Reconsider Role of Midwives
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Breastfeeding', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Hospitals', 'Hygiene and Cleanliness', 'Midwives', 'Millennium Development Goals', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Superstitions', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: Health experts and nongovernmental organizations are pushing the government to refocus its attention on community-based midwifery services as growing institutional deliveries strain the health care system.
lead_paragraph: PATRA, West Bengal — In this village 30 miles south of Kolkata, three generations of women have depended on Saira Bewa to deliver their babies.

headline: Turkish Government, Shaking Up Police, Now Seeks More Power Over Judiciary
abstract: Police chiefs in 15 cities were dismissed or reassigned, a move analysts saw as part of an effort to disrupt a corruption investigation.
lead_paragraph: The Turkish government reshuffled the police force yet again overnight, the police said on Wednesday, and sought to expand its power over the judiciary in a move that one former justice minister likened to a coup.

headline: How Do You Handle the Cold?
abstract: Temperatures that were 20 to 40 degrees below average were reported in the central parts of the country on Monday, and on the East Coast on Tuesday. How cold has it been where you live? How have you been handling it?
lead_paragraph: Temperatures that were 20 to 40 degrees below average were reported in the central parts of the country on Monday, and on the East Coast on Tuesday. How cold has it been where you live? How have you been handling it?

headline: Reprising the Storefront Gallery of the Greats
abstract: A new show at the Howard Greenberg Gallery revisits works exhibited from 1959 to 1962 at the Image Gallery, one of the first devoted to presenting photography as art.
lead_paragraph: There weren’t too many spaces in New York devoted to exhibiting photography when Larry Siegel was coming up as a young street photographer, apart from the Museum of Modern Art and the Limelight Gallery (and coffeehouse). But the sight of MoMA’s “The Family of Man” exhibit was enough to compel Mr. Siegel to do something drastic.

headline: Nature Enthusiasts Help Foster an Economic Revival in Portugal
abstract: Conservation efforts have brought more people and jobs to a poor region badly in need of both.
lead_paragraph: FIGUEIRA DE CASTELO RODRIGO, Portugal — On a rainy winter morning, Antonio Mónteiro and two colleagues were pushing and pulling an ailing, reluctant bull along a stony track in the Faia Brava nature reserve in northeast Portugal.

headline: Unemployment in Europe Stays High Amid Signs of Recovery
abstract: The jobless rate in November held at 12.1 percent in the eurozone, while retail sales improved and bond rates dropped.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Europe’s labor market remained stagnant in November, but analysts saw reason for hope elsewhere in the economy, including a surge in retail sales.

headline: ‘The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time’ Coming to Broadway in the Fall
abstract: The play, an adaptation of Mark Haddon’s best-selling novel, has been a hit in London, and will open this fall at the Barrymore Theater in a new production.
lead_paragraph: The hit London play “The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time” will open on Broadway this fall at the Barrymore Theater in a new production, executives at the National Theater of Great Britain said on Wednesday. Based on Mark Haddon’s best-selling novel, the drama follows Christopher — a 15-year-old mathematics savant with an often crippling antisocial disorder — as he pieces together clues to solve a neighborhood mystery and comes to a greater understanding of his own family. Last year, “Curious Incident” received seven Olivier Awards (London’s equivalent of the Tony Awards), the most ever earned by a play, winning for best new play (adapted by Simon Stephens), best director (Marianne Elliott) and best actor (Luke Treadaway as Christopher) among other categories.

headline: New York Today: Frozen Commute
abstract: What you need to know for Wednesday: delays expected again on mass transit, a bit warmer but still frigid, and the governor’s State of the State.
lead_paragraph: Updated 12:17 p.m.

headline: Terrorism’s Fertile Ground
abstract: We must capture the potential of urban youth before they are led to believe that the path of violence is their only option.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Terrorism is a global reality, and for me as a Kenyan, this struck close to home in September with the siege of the Westgate mall. Yet in many ways, growing up in Nairobi I was always in the midst of terror. As a boy living in extreme poverty in Kibera, one of Africa’s largest slums, I learned early on that I was disposable, that human life is not equally valued. Life expectancy in Kibera is estimated at 30 years, compared with 64 in the rest of Kenya and 70 worldwide. In Kibera, people are desensitized to death. Living is understood to be the exception.

headline: Negotiating Conflicts, Part 3: The Office Bully
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Baby Boomers', 'Workplace Environment']
abstract: Sheila Heen, an expert in negotiation, discusses an overbearing co-worker, family financial issues and rifts, and how to deal with them.
lead_paragraph: Sheila Heen, an expert in negotiation and difficult conversations, is answering reader questions about how to resolve disputes within families and in other parts of life.

headline: Why I Didn’t Give End-of-the-Year Bonuses
abstract: Last year, I didn’t offer an explanation. This year, I wanted to make sure people understand.
lead_paragraph: A couple of weeks ago, my production manager asked me a question that I have not looked forward to answering for several years now. “Are we going to be giving any bonuses this year?” asked Dale, who oversees 38 people in my picture-framing business.

headline: Citing Bad Weather, Egypt Postpones Morsi’s Trial
abstract: Officials say bad weather prevented them from flying Mohamed Morsi, the deposed president, to Cairo to face charges of inciting murder.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The trial of Egypt’s deposed president, Mohamed Morsi, on charges of inciting murder was postponed on Wednesday after the authorities said that bad weather had prevented them from flying Mr. Morsi to the courthouse in Cairo from prison near the port city of Alexandria.

headline: Daily Report: Webcams Become Small, Cheap and All-Seeing
abstract: Tiny cameras are recording the actions of people, animals and police departments.
lead_paragraph: In the Sahara, the African spurred tortoise lives for about a century. Thanks to modern technology, one named Franky has a shot at immortality, Quentin Hardy reports.

headline: India and U.S. Continue Fight Over Diplomacy
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: India accused the American Embassy in New Delhi of selling duty-free items to nondiplomats, which it said was a violation of the law.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Stepping up the pressure in an escalating diplomatic fight, India asked the American Embassy in New Delhi on Wednesday to stop selling liquor and other duty-free goods to nondiplomats by Jan. 16, acting before the American authorities are to decide whether to prosecute an Indian diplomat in New York who was arrested in a visa fraud case.

headline: A Growing Taste for U.S. Fast Food in India
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Fast Food Industry', 'Food', 'Restaurants', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Youth']
abstract: Despite India’s reputation as a tough place to do business, foreign restaurant chains like Burger King are looking to expand, having received an enthusiastic response from a young population.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — India has long had a reputation as being unfriendly to foreign businesses, but when it comes to fast food, international chains are being warmly welcomed by a young, upwardly mobile population.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — A group of former employees at the SAC Capital Advisors hedge fund in London has found a new home.

headline: Don’t Ask. Please Don’t Tell.
abstract: Think you’re aging? The real mark of age is your interest in your G.I. tract (and telling everyone else).
lead_paragraph: I turned 66 last week and started worrying that maybe I really was getting older, but whenever that sort of thing happens I hold my head erect and whistle a happy tune.

headline: China Cracks Open the Door for Video Game Consoles, but Doubts Abound
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Nintendo DS (Video Game System)']
abstract: While console systems remain popular in Western markets, the vast majority of Chinese players use computers and mobile phones or other handheld devices.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — For years, the Big Three makers of video game consoles — Sony, Microsoft and Nintendo — have coveted access to China, a potentially huge but mostly closed market. Finally, China has cracked open the door, but industry experts say console makers may still struggle to break through to the next level.

headline: From Denmark, a Hopeful Contends With His Own Legacy
abstract: Thomas Vinterberg, director of Denmark’s foreign-language Oscar hopeful, “The Hunt,” speaks about his involvement with the Dogma 95 movement and how his new film grew out of an earlier success.
lead_paragraph: The Danish director Thomas Vinterberg remembers the exact moment the idea for “The Hunt,” one of the nine films shortlisted in the Oscar competition for best foreign-language film, began percolating in his head. A psychological drama in which Mads Mikkelsen is cast as a timid kindergarten teacher unjustly dragged into scandal, “The Hunt” grew directly out of one of Mr. Vinterberg’s earlier films, “The Celebration,” a 1998 prizewinner at Cannes about a family rocked by allegations of sexual abuse.

headline: JPMorgan Settles Madoff Charges
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: JPMorgan’s legal penalties now total $20 billion. | A former SAC employee is expected to be the first witness called in insider trading trial. | Goldman Sachs is reshuffling its technology, media and telecommunications group.
lead_paragraph: JPMORGAN SETTLES MADOFF CHARGES  |  Over the last year, JPMorgan Chase has agreed to legal penalties now totaling $20 billion, but the settlements have not taken as large a toll on the bank as the numbers might suggest, Peter Eavis writes in DealBook. On Tuesday, Preet Bharara, the United States attorney in Manhattan, imposed a record $1.7 billion fine for felony violations of the Bank Secrecy Act for failing to report Bernard L. Madoff’s suspicious activities. On top of that, the bank agreed to pay $350 million to the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, bringing the total settlement to $2 billion.

headline: Speed Minimized as Factor in Schumacher Ski Accident
abstract: A French official said a video of the accident appeared to show “completely normal behavior by a good skier.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — French police officials said on Wednesday that speed was “not an important element” of their investigation into the Dec. 29 skiing accident in which Michael Schumacher, the most successful driver in the history of grand prix racing, sustained serious head injuries.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba Group said on Wednesday that it would not allow the sale of Bitcoins on its website.

headline: For Carlyle, Private Equity Business Is a Standout
abstract: The big investment firm said on Wednesday that its private equity funds rose in value by 9 percent in the fourth quarter of 2013, bringing the year’s gains to 30 percent.
lead_paragraph: The Carlyle Group manages a range of different investments, including private equity, hedge funds and real estate. But its bread-and-butter business of private equity was a standout last year.

headline: Administration Urges Restraint in Using Arrest or Expulsion to Discipline Students
abstract: The Obama administration recommended that public schools emphasize positive behavior and use law enforcement only as a last resort.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration issued guidelines on Wednesday that recommended public school officials use law enforcement only as a last resort for disciplining students, a response to a rise in zero-tolerance policies that have disproportionately increased the number of arrests, suspensions and expulsions of minority students for even minor, nonviolent offenses.

headline: Christie Faces Scandal on Traffic Jam Aides Ordered
abstract: A series of emails shows that aides to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey told officials to close lanes on the George Washington Bridge, in what appeared to be political retribution.
lead_paragraph: The mystery of who closed two lanes onto the George Washington Bridge — turning the borough of Fort Lee, N.J., into a parking lot for four days in September — exploded into a full-bore political scandal for Gov. Chris Christie on Wednesday. Emails and texts revealed that a top aide had ordered the closings to punish the town’s mayor after he did not endorse the governor for re-election.

headline: Official Suggests 2022 Cup Won’t Be in Summer
abstract: FIFA’s secretary general said the tournament in Qatar would probably be held between mid-November 2022 and mid-January 2023.
lead_paragraph: Speculation about a potential winter World Cup has percolated ever since the 2022 tournament was awarded to Qatar, the tiny, gas-rich nation in the Middle East, four years ago. On Wednesday, however, a top official with global soccer’s governing body indicated that the expected scheduling switch is all but inevitable.

headline: Nations With Fuel for Atomic Bombs
abstract: The number of countries with fuel for nuclear weapons has dropped since 1991.
lead_paragraph: The number of countries with fuel for nuclear weapons has dropped since 1991.

headline: Nuclear Materials Report Shows Better Safekeeping
keywords: ['Nuclear Energy', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT']
abstract: A report on the security of deadly nuclear materials worldwide found steady improvement, but the United States slipped.
lead_paragraph: A report issued Wednesday on the security of deadly nuclear materials found steady improvement, with seven countries in the last two years giving up most of their uranium and plutonium that could be readily turned into weapons. Their actions lowered the number of nations with appreciable fuel for atomic bombs to 25 from 32.

headline: Forest Labs to Buy Specialty Drug Maker for $2.9 Billion
abstract: Forest Laboratories is acquiring Aptalis, a privately held maker of treatments for cystic fibrosis and gastrointestinal disorders.
lead_paragraph: Forest Laboratories said on Wednesday that it had agreed to buy Aptalis, a privately held drug maker, for $2.9 billion in cash.

abstract: Rebel fighters have ejected the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria from its headquarters in Aleppo.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — For months, the patchwork of rebel brigades spread across northern Syria watched with foreboding as a new group gradually expanded its control, filling a vacuum left by nearly three years of war.

headline: 2 Parties Place Political Focus on Inequality
abstract: As Republicans and Democrats offer different prescriptions, income inequality is taking on unanticipated prominence at the beginning of a midterm election year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Kay Hagan, a North Carolina Democrat who is up for re-election, is admonishing Republicans back home as “irresponsible and cold-hearted” for slashing unemployment benefits. Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, says that her party’s thinking is “stale and old and doesn’t really address the magnitude of the problem.”

headline: The Meryl Streep-Emma Thompson Show
abstract: Ms. Streep had the audience roaring when she presented a National Board of Review award to Ms. Thompson, who was in equally fine form.
lead_paragraph: There is everyone else making introductions at awards shows, and then there is Meryl Streep. At the National Board of Review awards gala on Tuesday night, Ms. Streep was to introduce her friend Emma Thompson, the group’s best-actress honoree for her star turn in “Saving Mr. Banks.” And from the moment Ms. Streep took the stage, wearing a baseball cap that read “Prize Winner” (swag related to “Nebraska,” which features a similar one), she stole the show.

headline: L.P.G.A. Adds Points Race and a $1 Million Bonus
abstract: The L.P.G.A. Tour on Wednesday announced a season-long points race, offering $1 million to the winner.
lead_paragraph: The drama at the L.P.G.A. Tour’s season finale in Naples, Fla., in November was thick as a Broadway curtain, with Stacy Lewis and Suzann Pettersen battling for the Vare Trophy, given to the player with the lowest scoring average of the season, and with Shanshan Feng holding off Gerina Piller for a one-stroke victory.

headline: Insane Clown Posse Defends Fans, With F.B.I. Lawsuit
abstract: The rap group Insane Clown Posse filed suit against the government, charging that it unlawfully classified fans of the band as criminal gang members.
lead_paragraph: The Michigan rap group Insane Clown Posse filed suit on Wednesday against the Justice Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, saying that the United States government had made the “unwarranted and unlawful decision” to classify fans of the band as criminal gang members, leading to their harassment by law enforcement and causing them “significant harm.”

headline: Part of Something Big
abstract: “The Cart That Carried Martin” is about the day of Martin Luther King Jr.’s funeral, and “We Shall Overcome” tells the story of the civil rights movement through a popular song.
lead_paragraph: There are many books about Martin Luther King Jr. for reading aloud with children in celebration of his birthday on Jan. 15, including picture-book biographies like “Martin’s Big Words: The Life of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.,” by Doreen Rappaport, with illustrations by Bryan Collier, published in 2001. But the trend for looking at big events through the prism of small things (“The Civil War in 50 Objects,” “A History of the World in 100 Objects”) is particularly attractive for children, who may have an easier time understanding the parts than the whole.

headline: Rodman Serenades Kim With a Chorus of ‘Happy Birthday, Dear Marshal’
abstract: One day after he seemed to suggest that an American citizen detained in North Korea might deserve his fate, the retired basketball star Dennis Rodman sang to North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, on his birthday.
lead_paragraph: One day after he seemed to suggest that an American citizen detained in North Korea might deserve his fate, the retired basketball star Dennis Rodman serenaded North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, with a chorus of “Happy Birthday, Dear Marshal,” before an exhibition game in Pyongyang on Wednesday.

headline: Two Researchers Nominated to Investigate Trove of Nazi-Looted Art
abstract: Dr. Ingeborg Berggreen-Merkel, Germany’s former deputy state minister for culture, welcomed the nominations.
lead_paragraph: Two longtime provenance researchers have been nominated to join a task force created to investigate the history of more than 1,400 works of art stashed in a Munich apartment. The researchers, Sophie Lillie and Agnes Peresztegi, were recommended by the Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany and will serve on a panel led by Dr. Ingeborg Berggreen-Merkel, Germany’s former deputy state minister for culture, who welcomed the nominations.

lead_paragraph: The Landmarks Preservation Commission had strong words for the owner of an abandoned landmark in the South Bronx — the elegant and imposing “Castle on the Concourse” — which is so dangerously deteriorated that emergency demolition may be the only resort.

headline: Omaha Theater to Produce a Stage Adaptation of ‘The Shining’
abstract: Stephen King gave the Benson Theater company permission to adapt his book for two benefit performances in March.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve always wanted to unleash your inner Jack Nicholson, and will be in Nebraska this winter, then here’s an opportunity. The Benson Theater, an enterprising Omaha company, is hoping to raise the money to buy and renovate a 1923 theater to call home, and among its fund-raising projects is a new theatrical version of “The Shining,” Stephen King’s tale of a substance-abusing and increasingly crazed hotel overseer stuck with his family at a resort during the snowy off-season – the role Mr. Nicholson played to magnificently creepy excess in the 1980 Stanley Kubrick film. The company is holding auditions this week.

headline: Quite Dead, but Up for Grabs
abstract: The Red Bull Theater, which has demonstrated a stylish affinity for Grand Guignol, seems the proper troupe to exhume Joe Orton’s “Loot.”
lead_paragraph: Why bury your dead when you can play with them? That credo, so beloved of zombies and serial killers in popular fiction, was applied with unmatchable brio in the mid-1960s when Joe Orton’s “Loot” opened to scandalized press. This blithe comedy of desecration from Orton, Britain’s most brazen farceur, puts a respectable middle-class corpse center stage and then allows people, including the late lamented’s bank-robbing son, to make selfish and inventive use of the remains. The Red Bull Theater, which has demonstrated a stylish affinity for Grand Guignol, seems the proper troupe to exhume Orton’s improper attack on conventional pieties.

headline: T. Y. Hilton Is an Overshadowed but Integral Part of Colts’ Success
abstract: The Colts’ T. Y. Hilton had a strong regular season before shredding the Chiefs in the opening round of the N.F.L. playoffs.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — In the aftermath of the Indianapolis Colts’ spine-tingling comeback against the Kansas City Chiefs in the wild-card round of the A.F.C. playoffs, quarterback Andrew Luck has been exalted. He brought the team back from a 28-point third-quarter deficit to a remarkable 45-44 victory. He put the Colts on his back. He threw the game-winning 64-yard touchdown pass.

lead_paragraph: The aftereffects of a nonfatal shooting can linger for the rest of a victim’s life. Just ask Gabby Giffords.

The KND-7 features suicide rear doors, a 4-seat cabin, something along the bottom of the front doors called turning vanes and a 201-horsepower turbocharged gasoline engine. (Kia)
