headline: Smoking Guns at Fort Lee
abstract: Turns out Gov. Chris Christie’s staffers knew about the lane closings.
lead_paragraph: When Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey was asked recently about the sudden and inexplicable closings of the Fort Lee lanes of the George Washington Bridge — was this a manufactured traffic nightmare meant to punish the mayor of Fort Lee for not endorsing his re-election? — Mr. Christie answered in his usual way, with a sneer and sarcasm.

headline: The Dangerous Side of Fishing for Squid
abstract: A photographic remembrance of Donald Alversa, a Montauk-based commercial fisherman, who died off the coast of North Carolina last year.

headline: What We’re Reading Now
abstract: Food news, straight from the polar vortex.
lead_paragraph: New York City banned plastic foam food containers, which can take up to 500 years to break down. Also, the state raised the minimum wage to $8 an hour—still not enough.

headline: Spike Jonze Is on Hand, but Rob Reiner Accepts for Him Anyway
abstract: The director of “Her” farmed out the best-picture acceptance speech to Rob Reiner, who had nothing to do with the film and hadn’t even seen it. He proved adept anyway.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t easy competing with Meryl Streep, who had the audience roaring at the National Board of Review gala on Tuesday night. Spike Jonze, for one, didn’t even try when it was his turn to accept the best director prize for “Her.” “Meryl, you did the most incredible speech ever,” he said. “I was crying. You’re awesome.”

headline: Making Sure Your Website Is Ready for Smartphones
abstract: When people look up your business on a phone, they probably are not just browsing.
lead_paragraph: About half of all mobile searches — those done on a smartphone or on a tablet — have “local intent,” meaning the person searching is looking for a nearby business. That number has risen sharply over the last five years, said Todd Leeloy, general manager of OrangeSoda, a digital marketing company in American Fork, Utah, that was bought by Deluxe in 2012.

headline: In Search of the New Smartphone-Connected Boombox
abstract: As smartphone speakers stay small, electronic-makers hope to offer wirelessly connected speakers.
lead_paragraph: Is the portable speaker that can wirelessly stream music from a smartphone today’s version of an old-school boombox? Some electronics makers hope so.

headline: The Technology Behind the NYTimes.com Redesign
abstract: The NYTimes.com redesign is more than a fresh coat of paint — in addition to the new look, our article pages also rely on a new framework and codebase to run faster while making future changes easier.
lead_paragraph: The NYTimes.com redesign is more than a fresh coat of paint — in addition to the new look, our article pages also rely on a new framework and codebase to run faster while making future changes easier. Reed Emmons, the development lead on the project, explains how we made this possible.

headline: Q. and A. With ‘Frontline': How Do You Catch a Trader?
abstract: Peter J. Henning, who writes the White Collar Watch column for DealBook, moderated an online conversation with Martin Smith and Nick Verbitsky, the producers of the “Frontline” program “To Catch a Trader.”
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday evening, “Frontline” took a comprehensive look at the investigation of insider trading on Wall Street in “To Catch a Trader.” This is a report about how hedge funds, including Steven A. Cohen’s SAC Capital Advisors, sought an “edge” by gathering information about companies to trade ahead of other investors, reaping outsize gains. Interviews with federal investigators and reporters who followed the story, including The New York Times’s Peter Lattman, provide a clear view of how the government built cases that have led to more than 75 convictions.

headline: Pet Theories
abstract: Brooks and Collins on whether cats or dogs rule.
lead_paragraph: David Brooks: As is well known, the world is divided into two sorts of people: those who divide the world into two sorts of people and those who don’t.

headline: Man Arrested at Kennedy in Killing of Landlord
abstract: Rasel Siddiquee, 27, was arrested at Kennedy Airport in connection with the grisly death of Mahuddin Mahmud.
lead_paragraph: A Bangladeshi man wanted in connection with the killing of a Brooklyn businessman was arrested on Wednesday at Kennedy Airport, the New York Police Department said.

headline: Below the Line: The Makeup of ‘Bad Grandpa’
abstract: Stephen Prouty discusses his makeup design for “Jackass Presents: Bad Grandpa,” which is on the Oscar shortlist in that category.
lead_paragraph: Updated, Feb. 14 “12 Years a Slave,” “Gravity,” “American Hustle,” “Captain Phillips,” “Jackass Presents: Bad Grandpa.” One of these titles may seem the odd one out in the awards season conversation. But when the Oscar nominees were announced on Jan. 16, “Bad Grandpa,” Jeff Tremaine’s hidden-camera comedy, made the cut in the makeup category. It was on a shortlist of seven films that was narrowed to three nominees.

headline: Homes for $750,000
abstract: A look at a contemporary in Connecticut, a home in New Mexico built in a pueblo-style and a shingled house in North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: A look at a contemporary in Connecticut, a home in New Mexico built in a pueblo-style and a shingled house in North Carolina.

headline: Burberry’s Painterly Journey
abstract: Christopher Bailey’s collection, inspired by art, was a blend of the creative and the practical.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With painterly autumn leaves on silken scarves at Burberry and shined-up sneakers from that most unlikely of country bumpkins, Tom Ford, the London men’s wear shows for autumn 2014 seemed to reflect Britain’s current wet and windy winter.

headline: Cuomo Delivers the State of the State Address
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo delivered the 2014 State of the State address from Albany.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo delivered his annual State of the State address on Wednesday to a mostly supportive crowd, saying that the upstate economy had improved, unemployment had fallen in every region and taxes for every New Yorker were down. Bill de Blasio, the mayor of New York City, was in the audience in Albany on the first official visit of his administration.

headline: Letters: ‘Jack London’ and More
abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of books about Norman Rockwell and Jack London and essays about literary film adaptations.
lead_paragraph: Seeing Things

headline: Mayoral Ally Elected Speaker, Furthering City’s Liberal Shift
abstract: The election of Melissa Mark-Viverito as speaker of the City Council marked another swift and sharp shift in New York City’s political landscape.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Council unanimously elected a fiercely liberal Democrat from East Harlem as its powerful speaker on Wednesday, eschewing the moderate leadership that had overseen its ranks for a decade and eliminating the last barrier to a government fully in line with the undiluted liberalism embraced by the new mayor.

headline: Food Matters | A Peek Inside the Hottest New Restaurant in Paris
abstract: At his new place in the 7th arrondissement, the fast-rising chef David Toutain wows with his love for vegetables and sense of culinary drama.
lead_paragraph: No one could ever accuse the French chef David Toutain of forgetting his roots. Conveyed to the table by a very serious young woman in a well-cut black pantsuit, a gently curved rectangle of white bisque porcelain contained two salsifies, which had been roasted to a deep ivory color and were accompanied by a white-chocolate cream decorated with wood sorrel and other herbs. “You dip the roots into the sauce,” the waitress instructed, “and be careful, because they’re hot.”

headline: U.S. Treasury Secretary Urges Germany to Do More on Banks and Economy
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The German finance minister defends his country’s approach, even as Berlin finds itself at odds with much of Europe over a bank rescue system.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Jacob J. Lew, the U.S. Treasury secretary, urged Germany and its European partners on Wednesday to take even bolder steps in terms of banking reform, as his German counterpart, Wolfgang Schäuble, defended the complicated and still incomplete blueprint agreed to by European finance ministers in December.

headline: Steps of a Stage Career, Taken at a Run
abstract: Sheldon Best, the star of Atlantic Theater’s “The Loneliness of the Long Distance Runner,” speaks about his niche as an athletic actor.
lead_paragraph: Sheldon Best did his share of slashing in the play “Alice in Slasherland” and even more punching in “Sucker Punch.” Now, in Roy Williams’s modernization of the 1959 short story “The Loneliness of the Long Distance Runner,” Mr. Best is making good on yet another titular promise of physical exertion.

headline: Tupac Shakur Musical Sets Broadway Opening Date
abstract: The show, which is inspired by the late rapper but is not a biographical treatment of his life, is scheduled to open on June 19.
lead_paragraph: “Holler if Ya Hear Me,” a new musical inspired by the work of rapper Tupac Shakur, will begin performances on Broadway at the Palace Theater on May 26, the producers said on Wednesday. The $8 million production is not a musical biography about Shakur, who died in a drive-by shooting in 1996 at the age of 25; rather, the producers said in a statement, it is an original story about “friendship, family, revenge, change and hope” as poor urban residents struggle against challenges in their lives.

headline: Utah Says It Won’t Recognize Same-Sex Marriages It Licensed
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Some 1,300 newlywed same-sex couples in Utah were thrown into turmoil by the governor’s decision not to recognize their marriages while the state presses its legal efforts to ban them again.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — The fortunes of 1,300 newlywed same-sex couples in Utah were thrown into turmoil on Wednesday after the governor’s office announced that it would not recognize their marriages while it presses its legal efforts to limit marriages to one man and one woman.

headline: What You Get for... $750,000
abstract: Homes include a contemporary in a Connecticut village, pueblo-style in New Mexico and a shingled house in North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: ESSEX, CONN.

headline: Your Favorite Old Haunts
abstract: Where do you go for a taste of the good (or bad) old days?
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, it seems, you can’t keep a good place down.

headline: Classical Playlist: Simone Dinnerstein, Avi Avital, Mark Padmore and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: BACH: ‘Inventions & Sinfonias’Simone Dinnerstein, pianist(Sony)The pianist Simone Dinnerstein’s Bach recordings are characterized by her distinctive sound — soft-pawed but determined — and a certain melancholic disposition. But in these “Inventions & Sinfonias,” too often relegated to the teaching studio, it is the specific motion she gives each piece — as if every contrapuntal line had a physiognomy of its own — that makes this recording so arresting. (Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim)

headline: Dalio’s Bridgewater Associates Posts Lackluster Returns
abstract: Ray Dalio’s giant hedge fund firm had a largely underwhelming year in 2013, especially in its All Weather fund.
lead_paragraph: Ray Dalio’s Bridgewater Associates, one of the world’s biggest hedge fund firms, had a largely lackluster year when it came to the performance of its two main portfolios.

headline: Times Designers Are Monitoring Reaction to the Redesign, With Adjustments Possible
abstract: Readers voice a few complaints to a redesign of The Times’s website that is generally being praised.
lead_paragraph: It’s a big day for digital change at The Times, on both journalistic and business fronts, as the company unveiled a redesign that has been many months in the making, along with its first foray into native advertising. (The Times also updated its iPad app.)

headline: Teach the Cold: Science Ideas for Working With Winter Weather
abstract: In honor of this week’s weather — and to teach about the cold anytime — we offer ideas for exploring climate and weather patterns, human adaptations to temperature extremes, scientific research in the world’s frostiest regions, and winter-weather science fun.

headline: Support at Fed for Slow Stimulus Cuts
abstract: Federal Reserve officials say they believe the monthly purchases of Treasury and mortgage-backed securities are effective in stimulating job growth.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve’s decision in December to taper its bond-buying campaign reflected increased confidence in the economy and continued uneasiness about the stimulus effort, according to an official account of the December meeting.

headline: If Winter Takes Aim at the Plumbing
abstract: How to prevent pipes from bursting as temperatures plummet below the level you and your house are used to.
lead_paragraph: Homeowners in traditionally frigid regions have learned by necessity how to avoid burst pipes. But with temperatures plunging to record lows recently, people in otherwise temperate areas have heard horror stories of frozen plumbing and the watery, expensive aftermath.

headline: Greg Maddux, Tom Glavine and Frank Thomas Elected to Hall of Fame
abstract: Greg Maddux, Tom Glavine and Frank Thomas, stars with no connection to performance-enhancing drugs, were elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame on their first try, one year after writers chose no one for Cooperstown.
lead_paragraph: A year after delivering a sobering verdict on the game’s recent history, baseball writers on Wednesday found three players to celebrate. Greg Maddux, Tom Glavine and Frank Thomas, decorated stars with no connection to the performance-enhancing drug scandal that warped much of their era, were elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame on their first try.

headline: Millennials Want Children, But They’re Not Planning on Them
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Family Leaves', 'Paid Time Off', 'Parenting', 'United States Economy', 'Women and Girls', 'Work-Life Balance', 'Working Hours']
abstract: Far fewer millennials than Generation Xers say they plan to have children. Why?
lead_paragraph: As you’ve probably heard, the United States sorely lags behind most developed countries when it comes to support for working families, which makes it very difficult for parents (and, in particular, mothers) to work. But most of us can’t afford to stop working — our families need our income. So what options do we have?

headline: Former German World Cup Player Comes Out as Gay
abstract: Thomas Hitzlsperger, who retired in September after a career with prominent teams in Germany, Italy and England, revealed that he was gay in an interview with the weekly Die Zeit.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Thomas Hitzlsperger, a midfielder who made 52 appearances for Germany’s national team, helped Stuttgart capture the Bundesliga championship in 2007 and played for prominent teams in Germany, England and Italy, made perhaps the biggest news of his career on Wednesday by coming out as a homosexual.

headline: Knicks Better, but Miami Game Demands Their Best
abstract: The Knicks benefited from crisp ball movement and better team play for much of their game against the Pistons on Tuesday, but the Heat will present a tougher test Thursday.
lead_paragraph: For perhaps the first time this season, a sane person could argue that things are heading in the right direction for the Knicks. After winning two of three games on a trip to Texas, a swing that is usually brutal, the Knicks handled the Detroit Pistons, 89-85, at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night, punctuating their best stretch of the season.

headline: U.A.E. Releases American Who Was Jailed for Satirical Video
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Social Media', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: Shezanne Cassim of Minnesota was one of the creators of a video comedy sketch that attracted the disdain of United Arab Emirates authorities. The sketch was about the fictitious Satwa Combat School, set in the Dubai neighborhood of the same name.
lead_paragraph: An American man who was jailed in the United Arab Emirates for his part in a satirical video is being released this week after serving his sentence, a representative of the man’s family said.

headline: London Fashion Week: E. Tautz Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Barbara Anastacio.

headline: A Major Addition to Virgin Islands Park
keywords: ['Beaches', 'Eco-Tourism', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The National Park Service recently purchased the beach at Maho Beach and its surrounding hillside for the Virgin Islands National Park.
lead_paragraph: Virgin Islands National Park – which already encompasses 60 percent of the tiny Caribbean island of St. John — just got a little bigger.

headline: Should Republicans Talk About Poverty?
keywords: ['Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Poverty', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Unemployment', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Work-Life Balance']
abstract: The frame around a new G.O.P. agenda matters, but just developing the agenda matters more.
lead_paragraph: As Republicans marks the fiftieth anniversary of the War on Poverty by groping for a more compelling anti-poverty message, Byron York wonders about the political wisdom of this half-formed focus on the poor:

headline: Support for Metro-North Line in Bronx and to Penn Station
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, in his State of the State address, discussed a plan to connect the railroad’s New Haven line to Pennsylvania Station.
lead_paragraph: A sweeping expansion of the Metro-North Railroad that would add four stations in the Bronx and connect the New Haven line to Pennsylvania Station has won the support of a significant ally: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

headline: 30% of M.&A. Advisory Fees Went to Smaller Firms in 2013
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: In 2013, boutique and independent investment banks earned a combined 30 percent of fees for completed transactions, nearly twice what they did a decade ago. As the top banks continue to hold their own, it is the second-tier big banks that are getting squeezed.
lead_paragraph: The big investment banks, most notably Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase, continue to take the majority of fees from advising on mergers and acquisitions. But boutique and independent investment banks are gaining on them.

headline: J. R. Smith Fined $50,000 for Pulling Shoe Antics
abstract: The league fined the Knicks’ J. R. Smith $50,000 on Wednesday for ignoring its warning to stop trying to untie opponents’ shoelaces during games.
lead_paragraph: It was a totally reasonable request. After J. R. Smith was spotted untying one of Shawn Marion’s sneaker laces in the Knicks’ win over the Dallas Mavericks on Sunday, N.B.A. officials privately reprimanded him and told him not to do it again. Coach Mike Woodson issued Smith the same warning before Tuesday’s game against the Detroit Pistons.

headline: Leading Republicans Discuss Poverty
abstract: Fifty years after President Lyndon B. Johnson declared a war on poverty, the message from Republicans in Congress is that the government has failed in its efforts to address the problem.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years after President Lyndon B. Johnson declared a war on poverty, the message from Republicans in Congress is that the government has failed in its efforts to address the problem.

headline: Bayern Munich Official Suggests Summer Schedule for European Soccer
abstract: Karl-Heinz Rummenigge said Europe’s top leagues should consider a shift to play games over the summer.
lead_paragraph: Major League Soccer may have found a new best friend in Karl-Heinz Rummenigge, the top official at the German champion Bayern Munich and the chairman of Europe’s 207-member club association.

headline: Syria Reports 2 Attacks on Chemical Arms Sites
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The account by Syria’s delegate to the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons came as Syria began exporting the deadliest compounds.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Syria’s government said Wednesday that insurgents had assaulted two storage sites for some of the deadly chemical weapons components it has pledged to eliminate. It was the first time the Syrian authorities had reported such attacks in the three months since an international effort began to sequester and purge the country of the banned munitions.

headline: The Flaming Lips and Imagine Dragons to Join Amnesty International Concert in Brooklyn
abstract: Amnesty International will present a benefit concert at Brooklyn’s Barclays Center on Feb. 5.
lead_paragraph: Amnesty International knew it was on to something when it presenting its Conspiracy of Hope concerts in 1986: by fielding a starry cast of performers, it could not only raise money but, more importantly, bring attention to the slate of human rights issues it was fighting to redress. Amnesty continued to present concerts until 1998, drawing about 1.25 million concertgoers along the way, then bowed out of the concert business.

headline: Prison Violence Brings Scrutiny to State in Brazil
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: A video showing inmates gloating over decapitation victims is drawing scrutiny to the security situation in Maranhão State, run by one of Brazil’s most powerful families.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — A series of violent episodes at an overcrowded prison, and video showing inmates gloating over three decapitation victims during a riot there in December, are focusing scrutiny on the deteriorating security situation in Maranhão State, the bastion of one of Brazil’s most powerful political families.

headline: De Blasio Invokes Italian Theme for Bonding in Albany
abstract: Bill de Blasio, visiting the state capital for the first time as mayor, was surrounded by Democratic well-wishers.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — When Mayor Bill de Blasio met State Senator Diane J. Savino, a Staten Island Democrat, here on Wednesday morning, they kissed twice, once on each cheek, and shared a warm hug, in part because of something else they share: their heritage.

headline: Redefining What’s Possible for Skiers
abstract: For some professional skiers, helicopter pilots have emerged as essential partners. One such pilot, Tighe Daugherty, has come to specialize in helping skiers reach new terrain in Alaska.
lead_paragraph: For some professional skiers, helicopter pilots have emerged as essential partners. One such pilot, Tighe Daugherty, has come to specialize in helping skiers reach new terrain in Alaska.

headline: Wheelies: The G.M.’s Year of the Snake Edition
abstract: General Motors posted record sales in China during 2013; Buick said it sold more vehicles worldwide than it had since 1984.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Anger in London, as Killing of Unarmed Man That Sparked Riots Is Called Lawful
abstract: Angry protests occurred outside the Royal Courts of Justice, after an inquest jury decided that police officers had acted lawfully when they shot and killed an unarmed man they suspected of carrying a gun in 2011.
lead_paragraph: There was visceral anger outside the Royal Courts of Justice in central London on Wednesday, after an inquest jury decided that police officers had acted lawfully when they shot and killed an unarmed man they suspected of carrying a gun in 2011. Protests over the fatal shooting of the man, Mark Duggan, devolved into riots that spread across England shortly after his death.

headline: App Smart: Space Games
abstract: Space games form a class of game app that both harks back to the origins of video gaming and shows off the amazing graphics of a modern smartphone and tablet.
lead_paragraph: Space games form a class of game app that both harks back to the origins of video gaming and shows off the amazing graphics of a modern smartphone and tablet.

headline: Excuses, Excuses, for Not Extending Unemployment Insurance
abstract: Republicans will help the jobless…if Democrats agree to delay the individual mandate.
lead_paragraph: The president on Tuesday called on Congress to extend jobless benefits for the long-term unemployed, saying the insurance program keeps Americans from “falling off a cliff.” But the Republican leadership — convinced that Americans can pull themselves up and out of the ravine by their bootstraps — finds the extension unnecessary.

headline: Today in Small Business: The Most Hyped Start-Up of 2013
abstract: A four-year low for the trade gap, the five jobs that are most in demand, and America’s soft spot for con men.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Clothes and Character: ‘American Hustle’
abstract: The costume designer Michael Wilkinson discusses his inspirations for the looks in “American Hustle.”
lead_paragraph: To Michael Wilkinson, the costume designer for “American Hustle,” “the choices that people make when they dress themselves and the messages that they give out to the world, both consciously and unconsciously, these things matter deeply to me. I have a passion and a fascination for the way people present themselves.”

headline: ‘Frozen’ Soundtrack Hits Top of Album Chart
abstract: The soundtrack to Disney’s hit animated film “Frozen” reached No. 1 on the Billboard album chart.
lead_paragraph: The soundtrack to Disney’s hit film “Frozen” has shot to the top of Billboard’s album chart, becoming only the fourth soundtrack to an animated picture to reach No. 1.

headline: Carriers Step Up Battle for Wireless Customers
abstract: As competition grows among major wireless carriers, T-Mobile said it would pay the termination fees of new customers, and give them trade-in credit of up to $300 for their old cellphones.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — A tug of war has broken out among the major wireless carriers.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Philomena’
abstract: Stephen Frears narrates a scene from his film featuring Judi Dench and Steve Coogan.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Frears narrates a scene from his film featuring Judi Dench and Steve Coogan.

headline: Wrist Revolution
abstract: The Times’s Nick Bilton takes a look at smartwatches at the International CES in Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Nick Bilton takes a look at smartwatches at the International CES in Las Vegas.

headline: In Speech, Cuomo Pledges Lower Taxes and Statewide Pre-K
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo used the annual address to burnish his record and lay out proposals that would extend well into the second term he hopes to win this fall.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, entering an election year with no formidable opponent and an improving economy, claimed on Wednesday to have brought New York State back from the brink of financial ruin and unveiled proposed tax cuts and a promise of statewide prekindergarten classes, telling lawmakers that when he became governor, New York was “literally a joke on late night TV.”

headline: Video Game Nostalgic, and Gloriously Lost in Space
abstract: Space games hark back to the origins of video gaming and show off the amazing graphics of a modern smartphone and tablet.
lead_paragraph: There are games apps, and there are games apps. Some gamers like the imagination in fantasy games, some thrill to gory shoot-’em-ups, others love the wonderfully named MMORPGs (massively multiplayer online role-playing games). Each genre has unique characteristics.

headline: Video: Never Going Out of Style
abstract: Irwin Susskind, a Brooklyn Heights resident for 42 years, says he likes antique clothing and gets a lot of his clothes at thrift shops and street sales.
lead_paragraph: Irwin Susskind was strolling down Montague Street in Brooklyn Heights recently, wearing a black turtleneck, khakis and a boxy leather jacket. With the courthouse on one side and the Brooklyn promenade on the other, Montague Street is a shopping hub for Brooklyn residents. Mr. Susskind, who has lived in the neighborhood for 42 years, describes the brownstone-lined area as the “best place I know.”

headline: Adding Sex to the Chinese Dream
abstract: In a place where sex is still substantially mired in shame, some Chinese are trying to bring about a fundamental change in the way their culture views pleasure.
lead_paragraph: “Experts interpret the Chinese Dream,” ran a clinical-sounding headline in China Daily last month.

headline: Striking While the Iron Is Hot
abstract: Maria Chudnovsky and Daniel Panner went apartment-hunting on the Upper West Side.
lead_paragraph: When Daniel Panner and Maria Chudnovsky married two years ago, he moved to her two-bedroom co-op in Morningside Heights from his studio condominium in the Ansonia on the Upper West Side.

headline: Bolshoi to Visit Lincoln Center Festival
abstract: The 2014 Lincoln Center Festival will feature the Bolshoi Ballet as well as Heisei Nakamura-za, the Japanese Kabuki company.
lead_paragraph: New York ballet fans should get an unusual chance to see the growing globalization of dance careers this summer without leaving Lincoln Center: David Hallberg is scheduled to dance in June at the Metropolitan Opera House with American Ballet Theater, where he is a principal dancer, and in July at the David H. Koch Theater with the Bolshoi Ballet, which he joined in 2011.

headline: Video: Heli Pilot and Skiers Redefine What’s Possible
abstract: For some professional skiers, helicopter pilots have emerged as essential partners. One such pilot has come to specialize in helping skiers reach new terrain in Alaska.
lead_paragraph: Behind the Line is a video series produced by Teton Gravity Research that takes you into the minds of skiers. In each episode, the athletes will look back on a line, a jump or a session, and discuss the moment.

headline: Republican Pollster Teams With Madison Avenue Agencies
abstract: Frank Luntz is selling a majority stake in Luntz Global to MDC Partners, an agency holding group that owns more than 50 agencies.
lead_paragraph: A familiar name in politics — Frank Luntz, the Republican media strategist, consultant and pollster — is joining forces with Madison Avenue. His company, Luntz Global, which works for corporate clients as well as candidates, is being acquired.

headline: Two House Democrats Announce Retirement
abstract: Representative Carolyn McCarthy’s New York seat is considered safe for her party, but Representative Mike McIntyre’s of North Carolina appeared vulnerable to a Republican challenge.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two House Democrats, Carolyn McCarthy of New York, and Mike McIntyre of North Carolina, on Wednesday announced plans to retire.

headline: A Sampler Broad Enough for Voguing and Mary, Queen of Scots
abstract: Focus Dance, an annual sampler, brought works by Doug Elkins and Vicky Shick to the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: Each year in January, several of Manhattan’s smaller dance spaces present anthologies of work by different choreographers and companies. Out-of-town presenters arrive to shop for items they can show back home, while New York dancegoers can catch up on what they might have missed. At the Joyce Theater — whose weeklong season is called Focus Dance — eight troupes are sharing four programs. Tuesday’s opening night was a double bill by the choreographers Vicky Shick and Doug Elkins; the audience abounded with choreographers, presenters and dancers.

headline: London Fashion Week: Kent & Curwen Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Kasia Bobula.

headline: Dad, He’s Cute. Are You Sure He’s My Brother?
abstract: “The Spoils of Babylon,” a six-part series on IFC, is a broad parody of those overblown mini-series of yore about wealthy clans, starring some familiar names.
lead_paragraph: “The Spoils of Babylon” seems as if it ought to be funnier, or at least more daring, given the personnel involved. But it’s good for some dumb laughs, and — important in this age when complex television dramas consume so many of our brain cells — it doesn’t demand much of a mental commitment.

headline: What $250 of Prescription Drugs Looks Like
abstract: Being able to afford prescription medications in the United States often requires top-notch insurance or plenty of disposable income.
lead_paragraph: Being able to afford prescription medications in the United States often requires top-notch insurance or plenty of disposable income.

headline: Leadership Change May Signal New Start for Billboard Magazine
abstract: The magazine may see a colorful reinvention under Janice Min, who transformed The Hollywood Reporter from a dry trade paper to an influential glossy.
lead_paragraph: Billboard magazine first appeared in 1894 to cover the outdoor advertising market, reporting on “all that is new, bright and interesting on the boards,” as it proclaimed in its first issue. But for almost a century now it has been the indispensable organ of the music industry, dutifully covering every staffing change and label deal, and logging hits and flops on its charts.

headline: Police Cleared in 2011 Death That Incited British Riots
keywords: ['Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Police', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: A jury found that the victim probably had a gun in the moments before an officer shot him, and called his death lawful.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The man whose death at the hands of a police officer in 2011 set off riots that shocked Britain was killed lawfully, a jury found on Wednesday, issuing a decision that was sharply criticized by the dead man’s family.

headline: Same Injury, Different Costs
abstract: The cost of treating a cut finger in an emergency room varies widely across the country.
lead_paragraph: The cost of treating a cut finger in an emergency room varies widely across the country.

headline: For Fans of Photographer, a Window of Opportunity
abstract: The photographer Larry Clark, whose portraits can command thousands of dollars, is selling some of his smaller prints for $100 each.
lead_paragraph: Larry Clark’s lurid portraits of teenage sex, violence and drug taking hang at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Museum of Modern Art, and can sell for tens of thousands of dollars. Now, Mr. Clark, as a kind of thank you to the fans who have made his bleak 1971 photography book, “Tulsa,” and his 1995 movie, “Kids,” cult classics, is offering thousands of his one-of-a-kind color snapshots for purchase at $100 apiece at an East Village art space.

headline: A New Age for African Artists
abstract: With the expectations of democracy and liberated by the Internet, the Kenyan artist collective Just a Band has found an international audience for its mix of entertainment and political content.
lead_paragraph: With the expectations of democracy and liberated by the Internet, the Kenyan artist collective Just a Band has found an international audience for its mix of entertainment and political content.

headline: African Artists, Lifted by the Promises of Democracy and the Web
abstract: Technology, democratic aspirations and economic growth have created new spaces for young African artists to thrive.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — They built their reputation with wild music videos featuring a flying animated turtle  and a campy urban hero often considered Kenya’s first Internet sensation.

headline: Murder Is Just the Start
abstract: “True Detective,” new on HBO, subverts the clichés of the detective series genre and strives to reinvent the police procedural.
lead_paragraph: WESTLAKE VILLAGE, Calif. — Early in the first episode of “True Detective” two solemn cops, played by Matthew McConaughey and Woody Harrelson, arrive at a crime scene and confront a disturbing sight.

headline: After a Fall, Ashley Wagner Regains Her Balance
abstract: The figure skater Ashley Wagner, who just missed qualifying for the Vancouver Games, is favored to win the national championships and to earn a trip to the Sochi Olympics.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Even now, as a candidate for an Olympic medal four years later, Ashley Wagner cannot watch her stumbling performance. She has tried, but she always feels the drop in her stomach.

headline: Lessons in a Year of Crises
abstract: The lesson of a year that saw the demise of City Opera and other crises in classical music is, in short: Artistic excellence is not enough.
lead_paragraph: With all the crises in classical music during 2013 — orchestras grappling with ominous deficits, ensembles closing down, opera companies going out of business — have we learned anything? Somewhat surprisingly, Michael R. Bloomberg, when he was still the mayor of New York, may have gotten to the heart of the matter in some blunt comments in September.

headline: Ralph Lauren
abstract: The prefall collection included nude and earth tones.
lead_paragraph: The prefall collection included nude and earth tones.

headline: Cashing In on Body Parts
abstract: Judi Henderson-Townsend of Oakland, Calif., runs Mannequin Madness — repairing, recycling, renting and selling mannequins.
lead_paragraph: Judi Henderson-Townsend of Oakland, Calif., runs Mannequin Madness — repairing, recycling, renting and selling mannequins.

headline: Volkswagen to Introduce Golf R and Passat Concept in Detroit
abstract: A more powerful Golf R is scheduled to appear in the United States in 2015; VW’s highway fuel-economy estimate for the Passat concept is 42 m.p.g.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen announced on Wednesday that it would introduce the Golf R, which it said would be available in the United States by early 2015. Although the model for the European market is rated at 296 horsepower, the American model will get 290 horses and be available only as a 4-door.

headline: Chamber to Split With Tea Party in G.O.P. Primaries
keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Chamber of Commerce outlined its plans to intervene in Republican primaries in 2014 to help more pro-business candidates, who are not always likely to align with Tea Party ideals.
lead_paragraph: Ahead of primaries that will most likely serve as proxy wars for the overall direction of the Republican Party, the U.S. Chamber of Commerce announced its plans to take sides.

headline: ScienceTake: Fluorescing Fish
abstract: From sea horses that glow red to bright green eels, researchers have discovered 180 species of fish that fluoresce under blue light.
lead_paragraph: From sea horses that glow red to bright green eels, researchers have discovered 180 species of fish that fluoresce under blue light.

headline: Fluorescence Is Widespread in Fish, Study Finds
abstract: The findings, that at least 180 species and 16 orders of fish are biofluorescent, have implications for their evolution and behavior.
lead_paragraph: It was the green eel that did it. Scientists from the American Museum of Natural History had been exploring a reef off Little Cayman Island, investigating fluorescent coral and gathering photos for an exhibition.

headline: At CES, Waiting for a Wrist Revolution
keywords: ['International Consumer Electronics Show', 'Smartphones', 'Watches and Clocks', 'Wearable Computing']
abstract: The Wrist Revolution section of the International CES in Las Vegas is supposed to be at the forefront of smartwatches and wrist computers. Yet most of the gadgets on display do not seem ready for prime time.
lead_paragraph: The Wrist Revolution section of the International CES in Las Vegas is supposed to be at the forefront of smartwatches and wrist computers. Yet most of the gadgets on display do not seem ready for prime time.

headline: London Fashion Week: Burberry Prorsum Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Roberta Ridolfi.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the London Fashion Week photo diary of Roberta Ridolfi.

headline: More Security, Fewer Passwords
abstract: The International CES in Las Vegas is not only filled with shiny gadgets. There are also some products displaying software with advances to authentication, which could potentially make all those gadgets safer to use.
lead_paragraph: Among all the shiny gadgets at the International CES, software often gets short shrift, especially unglamorous software for things like authentication.

headline: Working Out With a Speedskater
abstract: The workout for Eddy Alvarez, a United States Olympic Team short track speedskater, is designed in part to keep his body balanced even though he relies on his left side when skating.
lead_paragraph: The workout for Eddy Alvarez, a United States Olympic Team short track speedskater, is designed in part to keep his body balanced even though he relies on his left side when skating.

headline: A Play Is Set in a Hospital, in Two Ways
abstract: A small Brooklyn company is producing Edward Albee’s play “The Death of Bessie Smith,” set in a whites-only hospital, at the Interfaith Medical Center, which serves patients from Bedford-Stuyvesant.
lead_paragraph: Seven actors sat rehearsing around a makeshift conference table in a Brooklyn hospital, passing around a pack of red Twizzlers. Snowplows grated against the pavement outside, and Long Island Rail Road trains thundered by on the elevated tracks as the actors recited brittle, ominous lines.

headline: The Meaning for Businesses in Delaware’s Judicial Nomination
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: The Delaware Supreme Court’s decisions have had a business-friendly bent, and that will probably not change if Leo E. Strine Jr., the head of Delaware’s Chancery Court, is confirmed as chief judge of the State Supreme Court, Steven Davidoff writes.
lead_paragraph: Given that Leo E. Strine Jr. has a reputation for being both brilliant and a workaholic as the head of Delaware’s Chancery Court, the nation’s leading court for litigation of business disputes, it is no surprise that he was nominated to become the state’s next chief judge. But what does that mean for corporate America?

headline: Diligence Promised in Studying Looted Art
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Art']
abstract: Ingeborg Berggreen-Merkel, head of a task force on Nazi-looted art, says revealing a timetable would create pressure.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Faced with the monumental task of tracing the owners of hundreds of artworks that resurfaced last year after they were hidden for decades in a Munich apartment, Ingeborg Berggreen-Merkel has a pretty firm idea of how long she and her staff will need. But don’t expect her to announce it.

headline: Layer It Now, Play in It Come Spring
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Sunglasses']
abstract: Wardrobe refreshers: Sweaters and accessories that take you from season to season.
lead_paragraph: We start the new year thinking ahead — imagine all the wonders we will accomplish in 2014 — so the idea of ‘wardrobe refreshers,’ as fashion retailers like to call them, makes total sense. Here are a few such refreshers, to help you through a frightful winter and to enjoy later, too.

headline: Ambitious Redesign of MoMA Doesn’t Spare a Notable Neighbor
abstract: The Museum of Modern Art unveiled a sweeping redesign of its Midtown building and reaffirmed its intention to demolish the former American Folk Art Museum.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Modern Art unveiled on Wednesday a sweeping redesign of its Midtown building, featuring a retractable glass wall, new gallery space and the opening of its entire first floor, including the beloved sculpture garden, free to the public.

headline: From Harvard, a Cheaper Storage Battery
abstract: In findings published in the journal Nature, Harvard scientists report that a carbon-based battery can double storage capacity.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Researchers at Harvard say they have developed a new battery technology that can store energy at lower cost, a development that Energy Department officials say could pave the way for a new generation of batteries.

headline: Bare Knuckles and High Heels
abstract: The supporting actor race is expected to be crowded. Jared Leto, Casey Affleck and Jake Gyllenhaal all underwent dramatic transformations to get into character and their work could mean an Oscar.
lead_paragraph: The supporting actor race is expected to be crowded. Jared Leto, Casey Affleck and Jake Gyllenhaal all underwent dramatic transformations to get into character and their work could mean an Oscar.

headline: The Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout in New York
abstract: The winners of the Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout over the decades have been a Who’s Who of players in region.
lead_paragraph: One of the most enjoyable events in the Greater New York Bridge Association calendar is the Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout. As the name suggests, a team must lose twice before being eliminated. Its winners over the decades have been a Who’s Who of players in region.

headline: A Rugged Camera, Despite Design Flaws
abstract: The Nikon AW1 is sturdy enough to take under water and carry on the ski slopes. But first you have to get past the confusing menu and design.
lead_paragraph: Nikon’s new AW1 is a tough little camera. You can bash it on rocks, take it under water and use it in the worst ski conditions. It is solid, workmanlike and it fills a niche between pocket cameras and expensive, professional rigs.

headline: Germany Charges Former SS Member in Wartime Killings
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The 88-year-old man was charged with 25 counts of murder in a 1944 massacre in France, while the murder case of another former SS member was dropped.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — An 88-year-old former member of an SS armored division that slaughtered 642 villagers in France in 1944 was charged with 25 counts of murder on Wednesday in Cologne, while a German court in another city dropped the case against a 92-year-old former SS member charged with killing a Dutch resistance fighter during World War II.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Egypt, Central African Republic, Syria and Indonesia.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Egypt, Central African Republic, Syria and Indonesia.

headline: My, How You’ve Changed!
abstract: Supporting actor Oscar hopefuls like Jared Leto, Bradley Cooper and Jonah Hill underwent a raft of physical transformations for their roles.
lead_paragraph: As the amoral, drug- and sex-addled right-hand man in “The Wolf of Wall Street,” Jonah Hill wore a set of gleaming false teeth. They were based on the look of the trader who helped inspire his character, but they made him talk funny.

headline: Tom Ford: Fall 2014 Menswear
abstract: London
lead_paragraph: London

headline: Fashion’s Polar Vortex
abstract: It may be cold outside, but that’s no reason not to don fashionable boots and outerwear.
lead_paragraph: Baby, it may be cold outside, but that’s no reason not to look fashionable.

headline: A Spot Painting With a Cartoon Past: Hirst Makes a Mickey
abstract: Damien Hirst, the painter, uses his well-known spot painting format to create an image of Mickey Mouse, for charity.
lead_paragraph: People see a lot of different things when they look at a Damien Hirst spot painting.

headline: Inside With the Outsiders
abstract: Rei Kawakubo’s Dover Street Market ties up the loose ends.
lead_paragraph: SO MANY MISFITS in this town — the skate brats and the wishy-washy actors and the ball children and the art slackers and the ectomorph poets and the hip-hop arrivistes. Twelve years of the Bloomberg administration may have done a number on middle-class aspirations in New York, but they built a hell of a machine to rage against. Or to aspire to.

abstract: Also on the Minute, the MoMA expands and an undersea light show.

headline: The ‘Girls’ From Brooklyn Take Manhattan
abstract: Anticipation about the show’s third season draws guests to Columbus Circle.
lead_paragraph: Why bother schlepping to Brooklyn when you can import its zeitgeist-y trappings to Columbus Circle? Such was the spirit at Monday night’s premiere of HBO’s “Girls,” now in its third season.

headline: The Brooklyn Beard Goes Mainstream
abstract: Facial hair has outgrown its underground connotations. Jay Carney, the White House press secretary, sported a beard that prompted barbs on Twitter: “Jay Carney rocks lumberjack-chic at the year’s first press conference.”
lead_paragraph: The gasps were audible when Jay Carney, the White House press secretary, strolled to the briefing room podium last Monday sporting the unthinkable, at least by Washington standards: a beard.

headline: The Deliberations of War
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In his fascinating new memoir “Duty,” former Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates provides highly revealing insights about decision making in both the Obama and Bush White Houses.
lead_paragraph: Robert M. Gates gives us a forthright, impassioned, sometimes conflicted account of his four and a half years as defense secretary in his fascinating new memoir “Duty,” a book that is highly revealing about decision making in both the Obama and Bush White Houses.

headline: Protecting the N.F.L. Brand
abstract: An encounter with Jaime Weston-Parouse, vice president for brand and creative at the N.F.L.
lead_paragraph: On the fifth floor of the N.F.L. offices in Midtown is an area designed to recreate for visitors the in-your-face feel of being on the football field. Giant screens stream live games, and larger-than-life photographs of players plaster the walls. The crowds roar, the music swells.

headline: For Martha Stewart, the Secret Is Routine
abstract: The lifestyle media magnate outlines her skin care, fitness and diet routine, which she says keeps her healthy and helps her prepare her for television appearances.
lead_paragraph: It turns out that the Bedford, N.Y., bathroom cabinet of Martha Stewart, 72, is as well stocked as its gardening shed. The many products help prime Ms. Stewart for on-air appearances like her show, “Martha Stewart’s Cooking School,” which began airing its third season on PBS last week.

headline: Wikipedia-Mania
abstract: If an “American Idol” also-ran can have his own page on the online encyclopedia, is there no limit? Apparently there is, as some people find out the hard way.
lead_paragraph: So this is how it begins. One day you’re perfectly content with your lot in life. The next, you’re browsing Wikipedia and thinking: Wait, how exactly did he get in there? Is he that much more noteworthy than I am? Paul Jolley, who finished ninth on “American Idol” last season with his rendition of “Eleanor Rigby,” has a page. Really?

abstract: Map of proposed changes
lead_paragraph: Map of proposed changes

headline: Sales and Events for the Week of Jan. 9
abstract: If the record cold temperatures this week have left you reluctant to leave home, there are still many sales you can shop from under the covers.
lead_paragraph: Sales

headline: For Sleep Apnea Patients, a Possible Alternative to Masks
abstract: Many patients, finding the mask an unwieldy or uncomfortable treatment, do not use it.
lead_paragraph: The standard treatment for people with moderate to severe obstructive sleep apnea is a mask worn at night that helps them breathe without interruption. The mask is unwieldy and uncomfortable, however; one study found that46 percent to 83 percent of patients with obstructive sleep apnea do not wear it diligently.

headline: When Pop Stars Go Into Rehab
abstract: Rev Run of Run-D.M.C. and Daryl Hall of Hall & Oates have nothing in common except die-hard fans and new home-renovation shows on the DIY Network.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to aging pop stars, we’re used to one sort of renovation — the kind that involves faces being buffed up. But the DIY Network has found a winning formula that involves a more conventional form of renovation and pairing older stars with older homes.

headline: The de Blasios: Dressed for (and by) New York
abstract: A venerable Manhattan name in men’s clothing stores surfaces at the inauguration.
lead_paragraph: Last Wednesday, as Bill de Blasio, the newly elected mayor of New York, gave his inauguration speech on the steps of City Hall, he did so in an overcoat and a dark blue Corneliani suit. Mr. de Blasio didn’t have to go too far to find that suit: It was stuffed away at home, purchased months ago at the men’s clothing store Rothmans.

headline: U.S. to List Libyan Groups and Militant Tied to Benghazi Attack as Terrorists
keywords: ['Benghazi Attack (2012)', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Terrorism', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The State Department was expected to apply the designation to two groups and an individual, the first formal accusations of responsibility for the 2012 attack that left an American ambassador dead.
lead_paragraph: The State Department is moving to apply the terrorist designation to two Libyan organizations and one militant believed to have played a role in the deadly attack on the American diplomatic mission in Benghazi in September 2012, senior United States officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Their Latest Act
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Leaving their most celebrated residence in Malibu wasn’t easy, but an almost net-zero house was one compensation for Tina Beebe and Buzz Yudell.
lead_paragraph: Leaving their most celebrated residence in Malibu wasn’t easy, but an almost net-zero house was one compensation for Tina Beebe and Buzz Yudell.

headline: Aspiring to Nothing
abstract: Leaving Malibu wasn’t easy, but an almost net-zero house was one compensation.
lead_paragraph: Tina Beebe, an architectural colorist, painter and landscape designer, and Buzz Yudell, an award-winning architect, have a sneaky way of making everything they touch look easy and inviting. But transitions can be difficult even for those who are accomplished in the art of living well in homes of their own invention.

headline: A Classic Rolls Back Into Production
abstract: A Danish company has reissued Hans Wegner’s 1955 Swivel desk chair.
lead_paragraph: The Danish designer Hans Wegner produced several hundred chairs in his long lifetime (he died in 2007 at age 92). “The good chair is a task one is never completely done with,” he said. No wonder that with such a vast trove to draw on, there has been a steady stream of reissues, most recently, the Swivel chair, revived by PP Mobler, a company in Denmark.

headline: Sales at Loll Designs, ABC Carpet & Home and Others
abstract: Bargains on furniture and more.
lead_paragraph: From Saturday through Tuesday, Brook Farm General Store will have a moving sale in its Brooklyn shop, discounting many items up to 85 percent (a Falcon enamelware pie set that was $98 is now $65); 75 South Sixth Street (Berry Street), Brooklyn; 718-388-8642.

headline: Curves Ahead, Paved in Gold
abstract: From Sarah Cihat, perfectly flawed porcelain dishes.
lead_paragraph: For her latest porcelain tableware, Sarah Cihat, a Brooklyn ceramist, purposely highlighted the imperfect. “I’ve been playing with a process for making this decayed look for years now, but wanted to do it on a completely usable product,” she said. The pieces feature smooth curves with ragged edges, which are emphasized by a paradoxical touch of 22-karat yellow or white gold.

headline: Bright Stripes, Big City
abstract: New vinyl wallcoverings for Wolf-Gordon are inspired by urban lights and digital noise.
lead_paragraph: The Danish textile designer Grethe Sorensen’s new collection of three vinyl wallcoverings for Wolf-Gordon are based on her “random-weave” technique, a method for faithfully translating digital patterns to woven fabric. As in her tapestry work, the patterns are inspired by photographed images of blurred city lights, including neon signs, street lamps and car lights.

headline: A New Leaf? How About a New Garden?
abstract: The writer makes New Year’s resolutions, but where will they be resolved?
lead_paragraph: This year, instead of ordering my favorite annual and vegetable seeds for my kitchen garden, I gave myself permission to imagine the garden I will create if Rock, my husband and gardening buddy, and I find the place of our dreams.

headline: Do Separate Tubs and Showers Appeal to Buyers?
abstract: Yes, and you can pull it off even with a small bathroom.
lead_paragraph: Q. Would our master bathroom be more appealing to buyers if it had a tub that was separate from the shower?

headline: Firewood Containers: Put a Little Love in Your Hearth
abstract: It’s going to be a long winter. You’ll need a place to store all those logs.
lead_paragraph: Most interior designers have what Stephen Sills calls “little obsessions”: small things that seem to merit special attention. For Mr. Sills, a designer based in Manhattan, one of those obsessions has to do with the fireplace.

headline: How to Help College Students Graduate
abstract: Better support systems lead to lower dropout rates.
lead_paragraph: AMERICAN students are enrolling in college in record numbers, but they’re also dropping out in droves. Barely half of those who start four-year colleges, and only a third of community college students, graduate. That’s one of the worst records among developed nations, and it’s a substantial drain on the economy. The American Institutes for Research estimates the cost of those dropouts, measured in lost earnings and taxes, at $4.5 billion. Incalculable are the lost opportunities for social mobility and the stillborn professional careers.

headline: Macy’s Plans to Lay Off 2,500, Though Its Holiday Sales Were Up
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Online and same-store sales rose 3.6 percent in November and December, but the company said it would improve “efficiency.”
lead_paragraph: While it reported solid holiday sales on Wednesday, Macy’s also announced several cost-cutting measures, including plans to lay off 2,500 employees.

headline: Israel’s Defense Minister Calls Settlers’ Attacks on Palestinians ‘Outright Terror’
abstract: Two cars were set on fire with Molotov cocktails and Hebrew graffiti was sprayed on the walls of a West Bank village, in apparent retaliation for an incident the day before.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s defense minister, Moshe Yaalon, denounced a campaign of attacks on Palestinian civilians and property by extremist Israeli settlers as “outright terror” on Wednesday, after two cars were set on fire with Molotov cocktails and Hebrew graffiti — reading “price tag” and “Esh Kodesh revenge” — was sprayed on the walls of a West Bank village.

headline: How to Talk to Kids About Death
abstract: Some people say it’s fun after we die and some people say it’s quiet.
lead_paragraph: Parenting Mistake #529: I promised my 5-year-old daughter, Sonya, that we could visit Grandma Joanie and Grandpa Roger “soon.”

headline: House Republicans Preparing Plan for Immigration Overhaul
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner and his Republican leadership team are developing their principles as a counterpoint to legislation that passed last year in the Senate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House speaker, John A. Boehner, and his Republican leadership team are preparing to release their principles for an overhaul of the nation’s immigration laws later this month, the speaker told his members at a closed-door conference on Wednesday.

headline: Greenpeace in New Feud With Russia Over a Ship Seized by Senegal
keywords: ['Ships and Shipping', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration']
abstract: After freeing a Greenpeace crew, Russia finds one of its ships captured by Senegal in a poaching dispute, but Moscow blames Greenpeace.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Having just quieted the furor over its seizure of a Greenpeace International ship in the Arctic, Russia is embroiled in a new dispute with the environmental organization, this time over a Russian fishing trawler accused of poaching in coastal waters off Senegal.

headline: As Winter Takes Hold, Plunging Temperatures Test Utilities
abstract: Several utility companies have recently announced increases in their retail electricity rate as they struggle to meet peak periods of demand.
lead_paragraph: The short-term price of natural gas in the Northeast eased on Wednesday after surging during the cold snap this week, but many consumers face the prospect of higher bills as utilities seek to pass along the added costs.

headline: Celebrating Deep Freeze, Insect Experts See a Chance to Kill Off Invasive Species
abstract: Entomologists have welcomed the below-zero temperatures as a good way to rid the region of some damaging pests.
lead_paragraph: While some people were cursing a canceled flight or wishing they had donned an extra layer on Tuesday, when temperatures in the region took a deep dive, entomologists, foresters and naturalists were rooting for the mercury to drop even lower. That is because the extreme cold has the potential to beat back some of the invasive insects threatening treasured local tree and plant species.

headline: As the Political World Turns
keywords: ['George Washington Bridge', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Roads and Traffic']
abstract: Chris Christie, the straight-from-the-hip paladin of the Palisades, is beginning to emerge as small, petty and vindictive.
lead_paragraph: Well, that didn’t take long.

headline: With Help of Victims From 1849, Scientists Decode Early Strain of Cholera
abstract: Scientists in Ontario used bits of human intestine stored in a Philadelphia medical museum to map a cholera strain linked to 19th-century pandemics.
lead_paragraph: Using bits of human intestine stored in a Philadelphia medical museum in 1849, scientists have decoded the genes of an early form of cholera, the deadly diarrheal disease that first swept the globe just a few decades earlier.

headline: New Mayor in Seattle to Overhaul Police Dept.
abstract: Two days after his inauguration, Mayor Ed Murray announced a plan that includes a new interim police chief, a nationwide search for a permanent chief and community outreach to parts of the city where trust has eroded.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Just two days after his inauguration, even as he joked that he was still waking up in wonder at his amazing new job, Mayor Ed Murray said on Wednesday that he was leaping into an ambitious and perhaps politically risky effort to overhaul the Seattle Police Department.

headline: Maytag Repairman’s New Job Keeps Him Busy
abstract: Semiretired in recent years, he is back in a new role and with a new name. He isn’t lonely anymore.
lead_paragraph: IN 1967, three years after Mr. Whipple began imploring shoppers to stop squeezing Charmin in the toilet paper aisle, another melancholic brand character was introduced, the Maytag Repairman, who described himself in his first commercial as “the loneliest man in town” — because the appliances never broke. Now the character, who was depicted by several actors over the decades, is getting a tuneup himself, with a new attitude, function — and name.

headline: N.Y.U. Project Is Stymied by Incidental Village Parks
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The parks grew out of unused land that had been mapped as streets to access a highway project that was defeated.
lead_paragraph: According to preservationists, Jane Jacobs may have just saved Greenwich Village. Again.

headline: Bird Flu Cited by Officials in Death in Canada
abstract: In the first known fatality from the illness in North America, a person died in Alberta this month, two days after returning from China, Canada’s health minister said.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Canada’s health minister said Wednesday that a person in Alberta died this week of the bird flu virus, the first known fatality from the illness in North America.

headline: Chinese Official Criticizes Japanese Shrine Visit
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'International Relations', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)']
abstract: The Chinese ambassador to the United Nations on Wednesday criticized the Japanese prime minister’s recent visit to a controversial shrine as an “affront to international justice.”
lead_paragraph: The Chinese ambassador to the United Nations, Liu Jieyi, on Wednesday criticized the Japanese prime minister’s recent visit to a controversial shrine as an “affront to international justice.” Speaking to reporters in a rare address in front of the Security Council chambers, Mr. Liu, in answer to a question, offered an impassioned attack on the visit to the Yasukuni Shrine. The shrine honors Japan’s war dead, including some convicted war criminals.

headline: Writer Gives Away Baseball Hall of Fame Vote to Deadspin
abstract: Dan Le Batard, a columnist for The Miami Herald and an ESPN host, agreed to turn his ballot over to the website Deadspin.
lead_paragraph: In November, the website Deadspin opened its campaign to buy the Baseball Hall of Fame vote of a member of the Baseball Writers’ Association of America and submit its choices under his name.

headline: Deaths of United Nations Personnel Rise
abstract: Deadly attacks against United Nations personnel increased last year, claiming at least 58 lives, according to the United Nations Staff Union.
lead_paragraph: Deadly attacks against United Nations personnel increased last year, claiming at least 58 lives, according to the United Nations Staff Union. The union said 33 of those killed were peacekeepers and 25 were civilians, including contractors working for the organization. In 2012, 37 United Nations personnel were killed, and in 2011, 36 were killed, the union said. The deadliest attack in 2013 was an ambush in Jonglei State, South Sudan, that killed 12 workers for the United Nations. According to the union, the deaths throughout the year included 16 peacekeepers killed in Darfur and seven in South Sudan.

headline: The Bully Was a Dupe
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey is ‘outraged’ to learn of a traffic-jam vendetta. How about ‘accountable’?
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has explanations to make, apologies to give and an administrative house to clean now that his top aides and political cronies were shown to have been fully and gleefully aware of the chaos they caused by ordering up lane closings — and a four-day traffic jam — in September at the George Washington Bridge.

headline: IBM Is Betting That Watson Can Earn Its Keep
keywords: ['Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: IBM says a new division, with 2,500 employees, will be devoted to the supercomputer’s so-called data analysis and recommendation technology.
lead_paragraph: IBM wants to build a large and profitable business from what has mostly been a triumph of computing bragging rights, so it is giving Watson $1 billion and a nice office.

headline: Gov. Cuomo Begins His Campaign
abstract: An anti-tax package is the keystone of his 2014 legislative package for New York.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s State of the State address on Wednesday was a campaign speech for re-election in both style and substance. Whether the policies he laid out are good for the people of New York is another matter. Mr. Cuomo proudly recounted his successes — on-time budgets, marriage equality, gun control. But the centerpiece was his plan to cut taxes by $2 billion over the next three years.

headline: After 2 Days, No Jury for Insider Trading Case
abstract: The judge raised concerns that he might have to call in a fresh group of candidates on Thursday, postponing opening statements by a day.
lead_paragraph: After a full day of questioning dozens of potential candidates in a federal courtroom in Lower Manhattan on Wednesday, lawyers still had not selected the 12-member jury for the insider trading trial of Mathew Martoma, a former hedge fund manager at SAC Capital Advisors.

headline: Abortion Restrictions in Texas and Beyond
abstract: Proliferating measures are making it harder for women to access abortion care.
lead_paragraph: The tenuous state of women’s basic right to make their own childbearing decisions was made clear on Monday when a federal appeals court in New Orleans heard arguments on a new abortion restriction enacted in July in Texas — one that requires doctors who perform abortions to have admitting privileges at a nearby hospital.

headline: NASA Extends the Life of the International Space Station
abstract: Instead of splashing into the Pacific Ocean in 2020 as planned, the International Space Station will continue circling Earth for at least an additional four years.
lead_paragraph: Instead of splashing into the Pacific Ocean in 2020 as planned, the International Space Station will continue circling Earth for at least an additional four years, NASA announced on Wednesday.

headline: Bridge Over Troubled Politics
keywords: ['George Washington Bridge', 'Roads and Traffic', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Never before has the nation been roiled by a conspiracy to create a traffic jam. Could you ever trust a politician who was implicated in a deliberate effort to ruin rush hour?
lead_paragraph: We have been through a lot of political scandals. But never before has the nation been roiled by a conspiracy to create a traffic jam.

headline: Libya Warns Oil Tankers Against Dealing With Militias
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Ships and Shipping', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Ports']
abstract: Prime Minister Ali Zeidan threatened to sink any foreign tankers attempting to load oil supplies from seized port terminals.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — In a further escalation of tensions with the militias occupying Libya’s oil facilities, Prime Minister Ali Zeidan on Wednesday threatened to sink any foreign tankers attempting to load oil supplies from seized port terminals.

headline: Progress in the War on Poverty
abstract: Opposition to government benefits is based on a false premise that aid fails.
lead_paragraph: America’s war on poverty turned 50 years old this week, and plenty of people have concluded that, as President Reagan put it: “We fought a war on poverty, and poverty won.”

headline: Blue and White of Duke’s Pep Band Gets a Touch of Gray
abstract: When Duke travels to neutral-site games in major cities or when its student band is on winter break, alumni sit in, reliving their undergraduate days.
lead_paragraph: Carl Pieper, a biostatistician at Duke, left his house in Durham, N.C., at 4 a.m. on Dec. 19 to drive to Madison Square Garden. That night, Pieper, who moonlights as a clarinetist, was to play the Garden, which bills itself as the World’s Most Famous Arena, for the third time in three weeks.

headline: Grim Sequel to Iraq’s War
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Contrary to President Obama’s statement “I ended the war in Iraq,” a resurgence by Islamic militants has been a reminder that the war is anything but over.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For two years, President Obama has boasted that he accomplished what his predecessor had not. “I ended the war in Iraq,” he has told audience after audience. But a resurgence by Islamic militants in western Iraq has reminded the world that the war is anything but over.

headline: At White House, It’s Biden Everywhere After a Memoir’s Lashing
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: After a new book by former Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates described Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. as “wrong on nearly every major foreign policy and national security issue over the past four decades,” White House officials went out of their way to praise Mr. Biden.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Wednesday was Joe Biden day at the White House.

abstract: A commission member says he was told he had a conflict and should not vote on a project Gov. Chris Christie supports. He was told the order was from Mr. Christie’s office.
lead_paragraph: Pity Gov. Chris Christie. He sounds so assertive, so obstreperous, so, so ... in charge.

headline: Tech Attire, More Beta Than Chic
keywords: ['Wearable Computing', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Wireless Communications', 'International Consumer Electronics Show']
abstract: Internet-connected watches and glasses, many of them less than fashionable, face hurdles to winning over consumers.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The next computer consumers buy will fit on a wrist or sit atop a nose. At least that is what many tech companies are hoping.

headline: Lonely at the Top? Try the Lower Rungs of Professional Tennis
abstract: James McGee, ranked No. 214 in the world, has competed in 26 countries and territories since the start of the 2012 season and lacks funding for a coach.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — James McGee did not last two hours at the 2014 Australian Open, but his brief stay Wednesday morning failed to dampen his mood.

headline: In Annual Speech, Vermont Governor Shifts Focus to Drug Abuse
abstract: Gov. Peter Shumlin devoted his entire State of the State speech to Vermont’s “full-blown heroin crisis.”
lead_paragraph: MONTPELIER, Vt. — In a sign of how drastic the epidemic of drug addiction here has become, Gov. Peter Shumlin on Wednesday devoted his entire State of the State Message to what he said was “a full-blown heroin crisis” gripping Vermont.

headline: Christie’s Carefully Devised, No-Nonsense Image in Peril
abstract: Embarrassing revelations suggest that the same elbows-out approach that the Christie administration brought to policy battles at the State House may have been deployed for a much less noble end.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has built a remarkable brand in Republican politics around a simple message: that his bluster and brashness, grating as they might be, were driven by a desire to transcend partisan rancor and petty politics in the service of the public good.

headline: Site of Slippage
abstract: Caleb Emmons cracks up.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Hang on tight. This is a slippery one, and I’m not talking about the tricky clues. I’m talking about the earthquakes. [Sudden rumble as pictures fall off the wall, black and white squares go flying, and emus run for their lives.]

headline: A Living Time Capsule Shows the Human Mark on Evolution
abstract: The resurrection of animals centuries old provides a look at how humans have affected the way wild species adapt.
lead_paragraph: Imagine you’re a looking for a place to shoot a monster movie. The plot involves animals kept in suspended animation for seven centuries springing back to life. Chances are you wouldn’t pick South Center Lake for your location. The charming 898-acre lake sits on the outskirts of the small town of Lindstrom, Minn., known as America’s Little Sweden. Gothic it’s not.

headline: BlackRock Agrees to End Wall Street Analysis Previews
abstract: The asset management company agreed to no longer ask analysts for their opinions of companies before that information is made public.
lead_paragraph: BlackRock, the world’s largest asset management company, has agreed to end its practice of surveying Wall Street analysts to glean clues about their views on companies before those opinions are publicly issued.
