lead_paragraph: In an upcoming episode of the TLC show, “Sister Wives,” the family is focused on planning a graduation party.

headline: Behind Inflammatory Email, Aide With a Low Profile
abstract: Bridget Anne Kelly, whose email appears to have instigated the controversial lane closures, has been a part of Gov. Chris Christie’s administration since 2010.
lead_paragraph: Bridget Anne Kelly, the embattled aide to Gov. Chris Christie whose email appears to have instigated the controversial lane closings at the George Washington Bridge in September, is a seasoned operative in New Jersey politics. Until the disclosures on Wednesday, she appears to have maintained a decidedly low public profile.

headline: Polygamy as Lifestyle Choice, and a Reality TV Brand
abstract: In their bid to become the new face of polygamy, Kody Brown, his four wives and their 17 children, who once fought penury, have turned their cause into a minor industry.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Kody Brown, his four wives and 17 children want to be the new face of polygamy, what some consider the next frontier after same-sex marriage.

headline: Why Wasn’t It ‘Grapes of Glee’? Study of Books Finds Economic Link
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Research', "Great Depression (1930's)", 'Libraries and Librarians']
abstract: British researchers who created a “literary misery index”concluded that the emotional mood of literature reflected the mood of the economy over the previous 10 years.
lead_paragraph: Could the emotional connotations of words in literature be a kind of lagging economic indicator? According to scientists who analyzed a century’s worth of writing, they might: After using big-data techniques to document the frequency of sad and happy words in millions of books, the researchers concluded that the emotional mood of literature reflects the mood of the economy over the previous 10 years.

headline: After Winning a Raise, 175 Casino Workers in Queens Lose Their Jobs
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Casinos', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: At Resorts World Casino, where employees’ average pay doubled last year, a buffet restaurant that recently increased its prices has now closed.
lead_paragraph: Scores of workers lined up after a meeting in a party room on the third floor of Resorts World Casino in Queens on Wednesday afternoon to turn in the uniforms they had worn in the casino’s buffet restaurant and pick up their final paychecks.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 8, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: In Babysitter’s Care, Boy, 4, Dies in Midtown
abstract: A 4-year-old found with bruising and signs of trauma was in the care of a babysitter when he was found.
lead_paragraph: New York City detectives on Wednesday were investigating the death of a 4-year-old boy in a Midtown apartment building.

headline: 8 Violations for School in Wake of Lab Fire
abstract: Fire Department investigators cited Beacon High School, where one student was severely burned in a chemistry demonstration, for violations of fire and building codes.
lead_paragraph: Fire Department investigators have cited Beacon High School in Manhattan for eight violations, finding that dangerous chemicals were being stored unsafely and that safety equipment and practices were lacking in at least three rooms. One was the makeshift lab where two students were engulfed in flames last week when a chemistry demonstration went horribly awry.

headline: Nets’ Kidd Earns Win Against Warriors and Jackson, a Coach Who Inspired Him
abstract: Jason Kidd, who followed Mark Jackson’s footsteps into coaching, led the Nets over the red-hot Warriors Wednesday night, their most impressive victory in a four-game streak.
lead_paragraph: When the Golden State Warriors last visited New York, almost a year ago, Jason Kidd, then a Knicks point guard, approached Coach Mark Jackson with a handshake and a simple message: “Thanks.”

headline: Fire From Latest Derailment Rages in Canada
keywords: ['Railroad Accidents and Safety', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Railroads']
abstract: Accident investigators were unable to approach a train near the border of Maine and New Brunswick, more than 24 hours after several tank cars derailed and burst into flames.
lead_paragraph: Accident investigators were unable to approach a train near the border of Maine and the Canadian province of New Brunswick on Wednesday, more than 24 hours after five tank cars containing crude oil and four cars filled with propane derailed and burst into flames. The accident came about five months after a runaway train carrying crude oil derailed and destroyed the downtown of Lac-Mégantic, Quebec, killing 47 people. Officials decided to let the fire from the latest accident burn itself out. This week’s derailment, on the Canadian National Railway, involved a 122-car train from Toronto and will most likely add to the current debate in Canada about transporting oil and petroleum products by train.

headline: After a Brush With Death, Focusing on the Next Step
abstract: Rescue workers were astonished that Azzura’e Wilson was alive after a brutal car accident that left her paralyzed, and now she is determined to walk again.
lead_paragraph: The summer before her junior year of high school, Azzura’e Wilson joined her father for a road trip to Baltimore to pick up her grandmother. Like many of her peers, Azzura’e, 17, decided to share the candid moment with her friends and family on Instagram.

headline: Andre Iguodala Lifts the Warriors to a Higher Level
abstract: Andre Iguodala, a versatile 29-year-old former All-Star, is a key reason Golden State looks like a team primed for a deep playoff run.
lead_paragraph: How do you improve a team that has a star at nearly every position? For the Golden State Warriors, the answer was getting Andre Iguodala, one of the few players capable of stepping into any role the team requires on any given night.

keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Kidnapping']

lead_paragraph: A day after a top-ranking police official visited the grieving family of a Williamsburg man kidnapped and killed last week, detectives released new video late on Wednesday said to show one of his abductors lying in wait hours before the crime.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A powerful Senate Democrat signaled Wednesday that he might allow the transfer of AH-64 Apache helicopters to Iraq as the government in Baghdad struggles to recapture key territory seized by Islamic extremists in the western part of the country.

headline: Carter Camp, Leader in Wounded Knee Uprising, Dies at 72
abstract: Mr. Camp was a leader of the American Indian Movement who led the first wave of the 1973 operation to seize Wounded Knee in South Dakota.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 29, 1890, United States cavalry, in the last battle of the American Indian wars, massacred as many as 350 Lakota Sioux at Wounded Knee in South Dakota. Three generations later, Carter Camp, a 32-year-old Indian militant, retaliated.

headline: Masahiro Tanaka Reportedly Arrives in U.S. for Talks
abstract: Masahiro Tanaka, a highly regarded pitcher, has until Jan. 24 to complete a deal with a major league team, and the Yankees are expected to be in the hunt.
lead_paragraph: The pursuit of Masahiro Tanaka moved into a new stage as Japanese news media outlets reported that Tanaka had arrived in the United States on Wednesday to begin meeting with teams interested in signing him.

headline: Al Porcino, First Trumpeter With Leading Jazz Bands, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Porcino held the first trumpet chair in bands led by Count Basie, Woody Herman, Stan Kenton, Buddy Rich and others.
lead_paragraph: Al Porcino, whose powerful sound and ability to hit the highest of high notes with ease brought him work as the lead trumpeter in some of the most celebrated big bands in jazz, died on Dec. 31 in Munich. He was 88.

headline: Varsity Blues (and Reds)
abstract: The sporty, all-American, college prep look abounds just in time for the Super Bowl next month.
lead_paragraph: A heavy dose of sporty prep is scoring big in resort collections. Oversize varsity letters, all-American shades of blue and red and pleated miniskirts are at the forefront of the trend. From Charlotte Olympia’s “Team Spirit” suede sandals, complete with a shiny pompom and large “CO” monogram, to Equipment’s collegiate sweater similarly emblazoned with the brand’s initial, the alumni-weekend style is not just for nostalgic coeds. And to bring it all together, simple stripes nod to standard-issue cheerleading uniforms and letterman jackets — just in time for the Super Bowl next month.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, January 9, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Thursday, January 9, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “Time for some traffic problems in Fort Lee.”

headline: A $4 Million Gift for Sphinx Organization
abstract: The Sphinx Organization has received a $4 million gift from an anonymous donor.
lead_paragraph: The Sphinx Organization, which provides music education programs and performance training for minority students and also presents an annual orchestral concert at Carnegie Hall, has received a $4 million gift from an anonymous donor, its executive and artistic director, Afa S. Dworkin, said on Wednesday. The gift is expected to be announced formally on Thursday. Ms. Dworkin said in an email that the gift would allow the organization to augment its “professional, career development and educational pursuits by launching scholarships at pre-college, collegiate and post-graduate levels.”

headline: The Fed Shifts Ground on Big Banks
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: As the Yellen era at the Federal Reserve approaches, there are signs that top officials are prepared to take a tougher stand on reining in large, complex financial institutions, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz professor of entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: The Workout: Speedskating With Eddy Alvarez
abstract: Eddy Alvarez, who will be competing in his first Olympics in Sochi in February, takes us through a speedskater’s workout.
lead_paragraph: Being a successful short-track speedskater is no easy feat. Members of the United States team follow a grueling schedule that involves up to eight hours of training, six days a week.

headline: C. T. Hsia, Who Brought Chinese Literature to the West, Dies at 92
abstract: Dr. Hsia helped introduce modern Chinese literature to the West in the 1960s while teaching at Columbia University.
lead_paragraph: C. T. Hsia, a scholar who helped introduce modern Chinese literature to the West in the 1960s, providing close analysis and the first English translations of writers who are now widely recognized, died on Dec. 29 in Manhattan, where he taught at Columbia University for three decades. He was 92.

lead_paragraph: How big a difference does cutting 78 calories out of an American’s daily diet make?

lead_paragraph: Three players were elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame on Wednesday.

headline: Divisional Round Probabilities: Statistics Are Important, but So Is Luck
abstract: Most playoff teams beat their regular-season expectations, but this showed that the season was too short for breaks to even out, not that an efficiency model was flawed.
lead_paragraph: Of the N.F.L.'s eight remaining playoff teams, the luckiest may be the Indianapolis Colts. Not only did they survive a 28-point second-half deficit in the wild-card round, but they were also the team that most overperformed statistical expectations in the regular season.

headline: What’s on Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (TCM) STAR OF THE MONTH: JOAN CRAWFORD Turner Classic Movies continues its tribute to Crawford, who made some 80 films in a 45-year career, with “Grand Hotel” (1932), Edmund Goulding’s movie about guests at a luxurious Berlin hotel where, a resident complains: “People come, people go. Nothing ever happens.” The ensemble for this film, an Oscar winner for best picture, also included Greta Garbo, John and Lionel Barrymore, and Wallace Beery, and was promoted by MGM as “the greatest cast ever assembled.” Writing in The New York Times, Mordaunt Hall said Crawford did “all that is possible to vie with the others in the cast.” Above, Crawford and Frederic March in “Susan and God,” also featured in the tribute.

headline: Dennis Rodman Regrets Comments on North Korea Prisoner
abstract: Although contrite for suggesting that an American sentenced to 15 years of hard labor by North Korea may have deserved his fate, Rodman continued his whirlwind tour of the country.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Dennis Rodman apologized Thursday for comments suggesting that an American jailed in North Korea deserved his fate. Rodman said he had been drinking at the time.

headline: Smoking Prevalence Steady in China, but Numbers Rise
abstract: Because of population growth, China added nearly 100 million new smokers between 1980 and 2012, though the rate of smoking in recent years has remained fairly stable, according to a new global study on the habit.
lead_paragraph: After decades of decline, the prevalence of smoking in China has held steady in recent years. Coupled with population growth, this means there are now more smokers in China than ever, according to a new study on global smoking prevalence published this month in the Journal of the American Medical Association.

headline: Police Find Dead Tiger in S.U.V. in Wenzhou
abstract: The police report said the authorities suspected the carcass to be of a Siberian, or Amur, tiger, one of the world’s most endangered animals, and had sent samples to be tested.
lead_paragraph: At first the police in the southeastern city of Wenzhou suspected the two men were loading a human corpse into their S.U.V. The person-shaped object they were carrying was wrapped in a striped tarpaulin, of the kind commonly seen on construction sites across China, and bound in rope.

headline: Novartis Faces Possible Criminal Inquiry in Japan
abstract: The government has called for a criminal investigation into ads that allegedly used flawed research to promote expanded use of a top-selling drug.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The pharmaceutical company Novartis said Thursday that it would cooperate with the authorities after Japan’s Health Ministry called for a criminal investigation into ads that allegedly claimed additional benefits of its best-selling medicine Diovan based on flawed research.

headline: North Korea Rejects South’s Bid for Family Reunions
abstract: The reunions would be a way to improve tense ties between North and South Korea, allowing meetings of relatives who have been split for decades.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea on Thursday rejected South Korea’s proposal to hold reunions of elderly relatives separated by the Korean War six decades ago, but it kept the door open for a possible thaw in relations between the two Koreas.

headline: JPMorgan Hires I.M.F. Official for Regulatory Role in Asia
abstract: Anoop Singh will be JPMorgan Chase’s head of regulatory strategy and policy for the Asia-Pacific region, according to an internal memo.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — JPMorgan Chase has hired the Asia head of the International Monetary Fund for a newly created senior regulatory role in the region, according to a copy of an internal memo sent on Thursday.

abstract: In their latest round of name-calling, China and Japan invoke the villain of children’s fiction also known as He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named.

Rowling, the villain Lord Voldemort is also known as He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named, a reference to magical powers so great that most fear to utter his name. But in the latest round of name-calling between China and Japan, Voldemort has become the insult of choice.

lead_paragraph: At the International CES this week, more than a dozen technology companies showcased Internet-connected watches and glasses capable of running software applications, Brian X. Chen reports.

headline: Flashing Red Symbols of Privilege Likely to be Tough to Turn Off
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Constitutions', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Indian Rupee (Currency)', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Traffic and Parking Violations']
abstract: The Delhi chief minister’s efforts to get rid of the red beacon used by government officials are likely to run into opposition from those used to using the lights to cut through traffic.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — After Arvind Kejriwal, leader of the Aam Aadmi Party, was sworn in as the chief minister of Delhi, one of the first election promises he kept was to get rid of two perks he said were a hangover from colonial times – the security motorcades that usually follow the chief minister’s official car and the flashing red light on the car roof, also known as a red beacon, which is used by government officials to cut through traffic.

headline: Turning Body Parts — Mannequin Body Parts — Into a Business
abstract: Judi Henderson-Townsend has been selling, renting and recycling mannequins for nearly 15 years. This year, she hopes to achieve an elusive goal, cracking a million dollars in revenue.
lead_paragraph: Judi Henderson-Townsend has a resolution for the new year: She wants to hit a million dollars in revenue.

headline: Cadwalader Picks Woolery as Next Chairman
abstract: Last February, James C. Woolery left investment banking to return to the practice of law. Less than a year later, he has been tapped to lead his new law firm.
lead_paragraph: Last February, James C. Woolery left investment banking to return to the practice of law. Less than a year later, he has been tapped to lead his new law firm.

headline: Rolls-Royce Approached Wartsila, but Talks Have Ended

lead_paragraph: LONDON – The aircraft engine maker Rolls-Royce said on Thursday that it had been in preliminary discussions about possibly acquiring the Finnish manufacturer Wartsila Corporation, but that those talks had ceased.

headline: Britain Keeps Interest Rates Unchanged Amid Signs of Recovery
abstract: The Bank of England said it would hold its benchmark rate at a record low 0.5 percent as headwinds continue to check the recent economic uptick.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Bank of England on Thursday left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at a record low as Britain’s economy sputtered toward recovery.

headline: Elliott to Accept Increased Tender Offer for Celesio
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']

lead_paragraph: Elliott Management said on Thursday that it would participate in a sweetened tender offer by the McKesson Corporation for the German pharmaceutical wholesaler Celesio, ending an impasse that threatened to block the $8.3 billion deal.

headline: The Shroud Over Rwanda’s Nightmare
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Evidence of whether the 1994 genocide could have been prevented remains classified.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Twenty years ago this Saturday, the commander of United Nations peacekeeping forces in Rwanda wrote a coded cable to his superiors in New York that has come to be known as the “genocide fax.” Citing inside information from a “top-level trainer” for a pro-regime militia group, Brig. Gen. Roméo Dallaire warned of an “anti-Tutsi extermination” plot.

headline: BlackRock Ends Early Surveys
abstract: BlackRock has agreed to stop pursuing nonpublic views through analyst surveys. | No Jury has been selected yet for the insider trading trial of a former SAC trader. | 2013 was a banner year for boutique and independent investment banks. | @GSElevator is writing a book.
lead_paragraph: For almost five years, BlackRock, the world’s largest asset manager, has been surveying Wall Street analysts to extract clues about their views on companies before the outlooks were announced publicly. Now, the tactic has been shut down, Gretchen Morgenson reports in The New York Times.

headline: As Indies Explode, an Appeal for Sanity
abstract: Flooding theaters isn’t good for filmmakers or filmgoers.
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 16, some 7,000 entertainment industry professionals and journalists will converge on Park City, Utah, hoping for a miracle. Distributors will push past exhibitors who will hustle past programmers, agents and critics, all of whom will be sifting through 117 features and 66 shorts at the Sundance Film Festival, looking for the next big thing: for the new Jennifer Lawrence (class of 2010 with “Winter’s Bone”) or for another “Beasts of the Southern Wild,""Fruitvale Station” or “Upstream Color,” three of the most talked-about titles from recent festivals. It will be exciting, exhausting and at times exasperating to be in the thick of such coordinated madness.

headline: So Many Indie Films, So Many Reasons
abstract: A casual survey of film veterans reveals wide differences in assessments of the state of indie cinema.
lead_paragraph: With nearly 900 films released in New York theaters last year, Manohla Dargis argues that there are too many lackluster, forgettable and just plain bad movies pouring into theaters. Is flooding theaters — especially with indie releases — good for movies and moviegoers alike? With another edition of the Sundance Film Festival about to start next week, she took a casual survey of some 70 film professionals, asking them about the state of indie film. Here is a sampling of their answers, edited and condensed:

headline: European Central Bank Set to Do Whatever It Takes to Bolster Recovery
abstract: The European Central Bank’s president said he would “consider all available instruments” if the threat of deflation persists.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank is ready to take decisive action to keep Europe’s tentative recovery afloat, the bank’s president, Mario Draghi, said on Thursday after the bank left interest rates unchanged at a record low.

headline: Mistaken for a Squeegee Guy
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: Noticing that a driver had left a window scraper on her trunk, a good Samaritan was waved away.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: The Rubber Duckie Has Hit the Road
abstract: Bathtubs are going out of fashion, a survey of bathroom trends indicates.
lead_paragraph: There’s a bit of a shocker coming out of the inaugural “2014 Winter Bathroom Trends Study” just released by Houzz, the home remodeling and design website. Bathtubs appear to be out of favor. More than 4 in 10 respondents said they were leaving them out of their new master bathrooms; among respondents 55 and older, more than half are going tub-less.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘Philomena’
abstract: Stephen Frears narrates a scene from his drama with Judi Dench and Steve Coogan.
lead_paragraph: “If you make a film in Washington, you do what Frank Capra did,” the director Stephen Frears explained. He was talking about a Lincoln Memorial scene in his drama “Philomena,” which received Golden Globe nods for best picture, screenplay and actress in a drama (Judi Dench). Based on a true story, it follows the title character on her search for the son she was forced to give up when she was a teenager living in a Roman Catholic home for unwed mothers in Ireland. In this scene she visits Washington with the journalist Martin Sixsmith (Steve Coogan). Mr. Frears commented on the scene and what was required to shoot in the nation’s capital.

headline: Q. and A. | Months After Beating Cancer, Sharon Jones Is Back on the Road
abstract: The charismatic frontwoman of the Dap-Kings has lost her trademark braids, but none of her charisma. Here, she reflects on conquering the disease.
lead_paragraph: Sharon Jones is a whirlwind performer. In concert, the energetic soul singer is known for whipping her braids across her face and darting about the stage while her backing band, the Dap-Kings, swings in the shadows. But Jones’s braids are gone now. After the 57-year-old was diagnosed last year with bile duct cancer, chemotherapy claimed her locks.

headline: K.K.R. Raises $2 Billion Credit Fund
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company is expanding its business of investing in distressed debt, and it said on Thursday that the amount of money raised for the new fund was double its initial goal.
lead_paragraph: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company is expanding its business of investing in distressed debt, with a new $2 billion fund.

headline: The Most Thought-Provoking Allowance Idea of 2013
abstract: A Seattle parent wants his son to think more like an entrepreneur and is paying him accordingly.
lead_paragraph: Should parents tie allowance to the completion of regular chores?

headline: Turns Out His Blood Runs Green
abstract: John Patrick Shanley drew on his Irish roots — a rare strategy for him — in writing “Outside Mullingar,” opening on Broadway this month.
lead_paragraph: I never wanted to write about the Irish.

headline: Holiday Sales Slide 60% at Struggling Barnes & Noble Nook Unit
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Company Reports', 'Barnes & Noble Nook']
abstract: Revenue in the Nook division, which includes digital content and devices, fell 60 percent, while sales in its bookstores dropped 6.6 percent, the company said.
lead_paragraph: In late 2009, Barnes & Noble introduced its first e-reader, the Nook, and within a relatively short time had picked up 25 percent of the e-book market, slicing into Amazon’s dominance.

headline: Nods to Casual, Chic and Carpet
abstract: Tom Ford keeps the lounge-lizard jackets but adds high-topped sneakers and weekend clothes to the mix.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “My life has changed,” Tom Ford said. “It is not just about moving to London — it is also having a child. Now I have to go out to the park with Jack. I need a different kind of shoe and casual clothes. I love casual weekends!”

headline: Updates on Bridge Scandal Surrounding Chris Christie
abstract: The Lede live blogged events related to the scandal surrounding the traffic jam ordered by aides to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey in retaliation for a mayor not endorsing the governor’s re-election.
lead_paragraph: The Lede filed live updates from New Jersey, where Gov. Chris Christie spoke and took reporters’ questions before meeting with the mayor of Fort Lee, N.J., to apologize for the traffic-clogging toll lane closures his aide and appointees had ordered.

headline: ‘Very Sad’ Chris Christie Extends Apology in Bridge Scandal
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, a likely candidate for the Republican Party’s presidential nomination in 2016, was forced on Thursday to address an act of political revenge by his staff that has threatened his political career.
lead_paragraph: TRENTON — In a remarkable day of swirling political drama, Gov. Chris Christie tried on Thursday to control the damage from revelations that his administration ordered the revenge-closings of traffic lanes at the George Washington Bridge by firing a top aide, cutting ties with a longtime political adviser and repeatedly apologizing in a nearly two-hour news conference.

headline: Legal Experts Weigh in on Citizen Sting Operations
keywords: ['Constitutions', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Fear (Emotion)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: Delhi residents are enthusiastic about a new initiative to help them catch corrupt government officials, but lawyers have mixed opinions.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI  — When Delhi’s chief minister, Arvind Kejriwal, announced on Wednesday evening that he had created a hotline to help citizens use their phones to conduct sting operations on corrupt state officials, the response from the public was immediate: nearly 4,000 calls poured in by 3 p.m. Thursday, Mr. Kejriwal said.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Whoops, My Gun Fired
abstract: A Kentucky lawmaker accidentally fired her gun in her office. “It happens,” she said.
lead_paragraph: Kentucky State Rep. Leslie Combs brought her Ruger 380 semi-automatic handgun to her office in the Capitol Annex on Tuesday. Nothing unusual about that: She often carries the weapon in her purse. But here’s the thing: She accidentally fired it. Whoops. “I’m a gun owner. It happens,” she said.

headline: For Couples Split by Distance, Two Screens Can Blink as One
abstract: In an age when solitary TV and movie viewing is easier all the time, some couples meet remotely to share their entertainment.
lead_paragraph: FAR-FLUNG lovers once took solace in sharing the same big sky. Now they take it in sharing the little screen. They count down — 3, 2, 1 — to begin “Breaking Bad” at the same second. While Facebook-messaging about it on another slice of the laptop screen. While glimpsing each other’s faces on cellphone video chat.

headline: Video: When Actors Sacrifice for Second Billing
abstract: On video, Jared Leto, Casey Affleck and Jake Gyllenhaal, all hopefuls for the Oscar for best supporting actor, talk about the work they put into their performances..
lead_paragraph: The Bagger is a competitive-minded professional, which is why, when Casey Affleck — most recently seen as a bare-knuckle boxer in “Out of the Furnace” — suggested that the two of us would make for a fair fight, we immediately agreed to test it out. Cut to: Mr. Affleck wrapping our hands with boxing tape.

headline: French Court Says Fugitive Kazakh Banker Can Be Extradited
abstract: Mukhtar Ablyazov has been accused of embezzling as much as $6 billion from the bank he once controlled. His lawyer says the charges are political.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A French court ruled on Thursday that Mukhtar Ablyazov, a Kazakh businessman accused of embezzling as much as $6 billion from a Kazakh bank he once controlled, should be extradited to Ukraine or Russia to face fraud charges.

headline: Ombudswoman for I.R.S. Tells Congress It Needs More Funding to Aid Its Work
abstract: The agency said the lack of funds had forced it to cut back on vital customer services like help over the phone.
lead_paragraph: The Internal Revenue Service would do a better job with more money to bolster collection and customer service efforts, the ombudswoman for the nation’s tax collector said on Thursday in delivering her annual report to Congress.

headline: Sue Monk Kidd: By the Book
abstract: The author of “The Secret Life of Bees” and, most recently, “The Invention of Wings” tries to read a poem every morning along with her coffee: “It’s the most important meal of the day.”
lead_paragraph: The author of “The Secret Life of Bees” and, most recently, “The Invention of Wings” tries to read a poem every morning along with her coffee: “It’s the most important meal of the day.”

headline: Eileen Martinson of Sparta Systems on Clarity of Leadership
abstract: The C.E.O. of Sparta Systems, which makes quality-management software, says that there’s such a thing as “being too careful.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with Eileen Martinson, chief executive of Sparta Systems, a maker of quality-management software, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Outkast to Reunite at Coachella Festival
keywords: ['Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival', 'Music', 'Rap and Hip-Hop']
abstract: Outkast’s Big Boi and Andre 3000 will reunite at this year’s festival in April.
lead_paragraph: Shake a Polaroid picture for a few minutes and it eventually develops; give Big Boi and Andre 3000 a little bit longer and eventually things develop for them, too. Those innovative hip-hop stars will reunite as Outkast, the pioneering duo who breathed new cultural life into Polaroids in the ubiquitous hit single “Hey Ya!”, and will perform as one of the headlining acts at this year’s Coachella festival, its organizers announced.

headline: In Our Pages: January 10
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune
lead_paragraph: 1964: Congressmen Assail Cuba Deal

headline: VH1 Offers Its Super Bowl Lineup
abstract: The cable channel VH1 announced a series of six concerts on the nights leading up to the Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: You might be so busy dancing you’ll forget about the kickoff. VH1’s Super Bowl Blitz, a series of six concerts on the six nights leading up to the Super Bowl on Feb. 2, will include a late-night (11 p.m.) performance in each of the five boroughs of New York, as well as Montclair, N.J., the station announced Thursday. Time Warner Cable has announced a series of Super Bowl events at its Manhattan studios that also include performances.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Ozymandias’
abstract: This Poetry Pairing features Percy Bysshe Shelley’s “Ozymandias” and the Op-Ed “Goodbye, Lenin?” by Sasha Senderovich.
lead_paragraph: This Poetry Pairing features the classic Percy Bysshe Shelley poem “Ozymandias” and the Op-Ed “Goodbye, Lenin?” by Sasha Senderovich.

headline: Rylance’s Shakespeare Shows Recoup on Broadway
abstract: A double bill of “Twelfth Night” and “Richard III,” starring Mark Rylance, has recouped its $3.1 million capitalization, the producers said.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t only plays with Hollywood stars like Daniel Craig and Billy Crystal that made money on Broadway this winter. A critically acclaimed double bill of Shakespeare, “Twelfth Night” and “Richard III,” starring Mark Rylance — a two-time Tony Award winner but hardly a household name — has recouped its $3.1-million capitalization, the plays’ producers announced on Thursday.

headline: Mikaela Shiffrin’s Swift, if Unplanned, Ascent to World Champion
abstract: Shiffrin, an 18-year-old American who has dominated the World Cup slalom and is an Olympic favorite, was raised with a focus on process, not results.
lead_paragraph: EAGLE-VAIL, Colo. — Sprinting from her small trophy-filled bedroom, Mikaela Shiffrin, the youngest American skier to be a World Cup champion, dashed around the kitchen looking for a headset to attach to her laptop.

headline: Student Crossword | Literary Terms
abstract: Test your knowledge of literary terms by playing our crossword, either online or in print. We are slowly updating our entire Student Crossword Archive, and will be publishing occasional crosswords throughout 2014.
lead_paragraph: Test your knowledge of literary terms by playing our crossword in print (PDF). You can find the answers here.

headline: Haynes and Trucks Leaving Allman Brothers Band
abstract: The lead guitarists of the Allman Brothers Band say they will leave at the end of 2014.
lead_paragraph: Two important, longstanding (though not original) members of the Allman Brothers Band, the guitarists Warren Haynes and Derek Trucks, announced on Wednesday evening that they would leave the band at the end of 2014, when the band completes its celebrations of its 45th anniversary. Both have bands of their own — Mr. Haynes leads the jam band Gov’t Mule, and Mr. Trucks shares the spotlight with his wife, the singer and guitarist Susan Tedeschi in the Tedeschi Trucks Band — and say that they hope to devote more time to them.

headline: Germany to Help in Disposal of Syrian Chemical Weapons
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The decision was in part to maintain international credibility in addressing Syria’s civil war, the foreign minister said.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — German experts will help destroy chemical weapons removed from Syria under the auspices of the United Nations and the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, the government said Thursday.

headline: Christie ‘Embarrassed’ by Bridge Scandal
abstract: In addressing the bridge scandal, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey said he felt humiliated by the conduct of some of his associates, adding that he had fired one of his top aides for lying to him.
lead_paragraph: In addressing the bridge scandal, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey said he felt humiliated by the conduct of some of his associates, adding that he had fired one of his top aides for lying to him.

abstract: Snow-capped rooftops in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir.
