headline: Blast in Pakistan Kills Senior Police Official
abstract: Muhammad Aslam Khan, widely known as Chaudhry Aslam, a police investigator involved in operations against the Pakistani Taliban, was killed in Karachi along with two others.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A senior Pakistani police investigator at the forefront of operations against the Taliban and other criminals in the sprawling, seaside city of Karachi was killed in a huge bomb blast there on Thursday, police officials said. His driver and a security officer were also killed in the attack, and at least 11 people were reported wounded.

headline: Vanya and Sonia and Abs and Pecs
abstract: Actors playing Christopher Durang’s Spike list the rigors.
lead_paragraph: Jefferson McDonald isn’t shedding tears for friends who made New Year’s resolutions to get in shape. This 26-year-old actor has committed to a routine that includes near-daily workouts, yoga several times a week and basketball in his free time. Say “pizza and beer,” and machetes shoot from his eyes.

headline: Critics Voice Objections to MoMA’s Plan to Take Down Folk Art Museum
abstract: The Museum of Modern Art’s decision to tear down the American Folk Art Museum as part of an expansion has led to criticism from architects and critics.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 6:09 p.m. | To the surprise of perhaps no one, including the Museum of Modern Art, the decision to take down the former home of the American Folk Art Museum as part of a redesign of MoMA’s Midtown Manhattan building provoked strong reactions on Thursday from architects and critics.

headline: Wheelies: The Vice Presidential Auto Show Edition
abstract: Vice President Joe Biden is expected to show up at the Detroit auto show next week; David Strickland steps down as the N.H.T.S.A. administrator.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: An Artist Who’s Truly Wired
abstract: For R. Luke DuBois, art has its basis in mounds of data.
lead_paragraph: For R. Luke DuBois, art has its basis in mounds of data.

headline: How British Members of the Academy May Be Leaning
abstract: “Gravity,” “12 Years a Slave” and “American Hustle” all did well in the Bafta nominations, while Harvey Weinstein’s films didn’t make a strong showing. Documentarians also weighed in with their Cinema Eye Honors.
lead_paragraph: Voting for the Oscar nominations has officially closed — the final clicks and ballots had to be accounted for by 5 p.m. Pacific Standard Time on Wednesday — which means that other groups’ prize choices will not have an effect. But they could still indicate which way the breeze is blowing at the Academy.

headline: Should Governor Christie Step Down?
abstract: The governor's aides retaliated against a foe by causing traffic tie-ups at the George Washington Bridge. Should Christie's involvement, or lack of involvement, end his career?

headline: A Way to Carrying Multiple Concealed Devices
abstract: TechSlinger’s products have a shoulder harness that suspends a tablet pocket with a quick-draw front opening on one side, and a phone holder and accessories bag on the other.
lead_paragraph: How would James Bond carry his electronic tablet – assuming he carried a tablet and wasn’t so cool?

headline: As Iran Nuclear Talks Resume, Ayatollah Criticizes U.S.
abstract: The remarks by Ayatollah Ali Khamenei may have been intended to strengthen Iran’s position at the negotiations.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s supreme leader harshly denounced the United States on Thursday as negotiations to conclude an interim agreement in the Iranian nuclear dispute resumed, saying those talks illustrated what he called the hostility of Americans toward Iran and the Muslim world.

headline: The Gun Report: January 9, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: First it was Instagram. Now, Reddit, the so-called “front page of the Internet,” has been exposed as an active marketplace for assault rifles, high-capacity magazines and other powerful firearms, according to an investigation by Mother Jones. The Guns for Sale page, which counts more than 7,200 subscribers, offers buyers and sellers a forum on the site, which boasts tens of millions of users and drives major traffic to other websites.

headline: How Did You Motivate Your Hibernating Teenager to Stay Healthy in Winter?
abstract: Seeking advice from parents who helped their teenagers inclined to be couch potatoes to stay active in winter.
lead_paragraph: It’s winter. In much of the country, it’s cold, often bleak, snowy, icy, rainy. It’s not appealing weather for getting outside and getting moving. Younger children see that differently: They see snow for sledding and ice for sliding, and really, why wouldn’t you want to go out? And teenagers who are already active in sports, dance, or enjoy a regular workout routine just keep going. But for teenagers who are even more inclined to hibernate in winter, how can you keep them moving and healthy?

headline: A Chunky, Cheerful Tracking Device to Keep Tabs on Your Child
abstract: The Filip phone, worn like a bracelet, keeps track of a child when paired with an app downloaded to a parent’s mobile device.
lead_paragraph: Tracking devices make me uneasy, but I have to defer to parental paranoia, which requires knowing where your children are. A watch/tracker/phone, Filip, may help.

headline: In Harlem, an African Tasting Plate
abstract: The Cecil offers dishes derived from the breadth of the continent’s diaspora, and tweaks some American classics, too.
lead_paragraph: First, respect: Bebop was born here, on West 118th Street at St. Nicholas Avenue, where in the early 1940s Minton’s Playhouse hired as house pianist an unknown named Thelonious Monk, who played the instrument as if nobody knew how before.

headline: Ex-SAC Trader Was Expelled From Harvard Law School
abstract: Mathew Martoma, the former SAC Capital Advisors trader charged with carrying out one of the largest insider trading schemes ever, was expelled from Harvard Law School more than a decade ago for creating a false transcript of his grades, newly unsealed court documents show.
lead_paragraph: A federal jury will decide whether Mathew Martoma, the former hedge fund manager, cheated when he worked at SAC Capital Advisors, but there’s no denying he cheated when he falsified his grades at Harvard Law School some 15 years ago.

headline: Mercedes-Benz to Reveal AMG-Tuned GLA45 and Concept S-Class Coupe in Detroit
abstract: The 2015 GLA45 AMG will feature a turbocharged 335-horsepower 4-cylinder, and the S-Class Coupe concept shows off sleek, low-slung styling.
lead_paragraph: Mercedes-Benz will show several new models at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit next week, among them the 2015 GLA45 AMG, the 2015 Concept S-Class Coupe and the 2015 C-Class.

headline: After Apparent Food Stamp Deal, Dairy Rift Moves to Fore in Farm Bill Talks
keywords: ['Farm Bill (US)', 'Crop Controls and Subsidies', 'Catfish', 'Milk', 'Food Stamps', 'Dairy Products']
abstract: A deal was said to have been reached on cuts of about $9 billion over 10 years to the food stamp program, but disagreements continued over dairy and catfish programs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Disagreements over a program to help dairy producers when milk prices drop have emerged as a major sticking point in negotiations on a new farm bill, which had been expected to be wrapped up this week. But lawmakers appear to have reached an agreement on cuts to the food stamp program, which is part of the farm bill and had been the most contentious issue in efforts to pass the legislation.

headline: Today in Small Business: Disloyalty Cards
abstract: A budget surplus. The hottest e-commerce businesses. Selling American products in China.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Letters to the Doctor
abstract: I suspect that family members sometimes send doctors letters because they aren’t sure they had done everything they could to help prevent a loved one’s death.
lead_paragraph: When I entered the exam room to see my first patient of the day, a doctor from another department at my hospital, I found her sitting in the chair I usually occupy, typing away at the computer on the tiny desk.

headline: Tempered Optimism for the Economy
abstract: There are grounds for optimism about the United States economy in the coming year, but many reasons for caution and concern about the prospects for sustainable and equitable growth, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Laura D’Andrea Tyson is a professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley, and headed the Council of Economic Advisers and the National Economic Council under President Clinton.

headline: E.U. Panel Invites Snowden to Testify on Privacy Breaches
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: A parliamentary committee asked Edward J. Snowden to speak via video about protecting citizens’ privacy.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A European Parliament committee has invited Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor who has leaked classified government documents and is now in hiding in Russia, to testify via video link as part of an investigation into how to protect the privacy of European citizens.

headline: Making Oprah’s Gift Count
abstract: Guest blogger Tererai Trent discusses the desperate need for a canteen to provide food to Zimbabwean schoolchildren.
lead_paragraph: I’ll never forget when Oprah Winfrey turned to me and said, “We are going to build a school!” This was my second time on her show, and Oprah had just named me her “all-time favorite guest” in 25 years of the show. As if that wasn’t enough, she had just informed me that she was donating $1.5 million to build a school in my home village in Zimbabwe!  When Oprah gave me the incredible news, my response – in the midst of overwhelming gratitude – was “It is achievable!”  (Tinogona means “it is achievable.”) With that, Tinogona Foundation was born.

headline: Skiing the Giant Slalom at Age 7
abstract: “She was a happy little kid,” Rika Moore, a youth coach at Vail, said of Shiffrin, “but she was unbelievably focused on making perfect turns, one after another.”
lead_paragraph: “She was a happy little kid,” Rika Moore, a youth coach at Vail, said of Shiffrin, “but she was unbelievably focused on making perfect turns, one after another.”

headline: Signs of Future Slalom Success
abstract: Youth coaches saw an evolving star in Mikaela, but the Shiffrins still strived for normalcy.
lead_paragraph: Youth coaches saw an evolving star in Mikaela, but the Shiffrins still strived for normalcy.

headline: Early Olympic Dreams
abstract: From unicycles to inline skates, Mikaela Shiffrin spent plenty of time off skis, as when she played in the garage with her brother at age 6.
lead_paragraph: From unicycles to inline skates, Mikaela Shiffrin spent plenty of time off skis, as when she played in the garage with her brother at age 6.

headline: Travel Site Will Emphasize Personal Advice
abstract: Virtuoso offers reviews–and travel advisors who can help plan trips.
lead_paragraph: Virtuoso, the luxury travel network with close to a 1,000 hotels and 335 affiliated agencies globally, introduced a site this week that aims to marry technology with the human touch.

headline: Christie’s Confrontational Style
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has been accused of bullying political opponents. On YouTube, there are clips of his confrontations with critics.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has been accused of bullying political opponents. On YouTube, there are clips of his confrontations with critics.

headline: Director of Britain’s National Theater to Form New Company
abstract: Nicholas Hytner, who is to step down from the National in 2015, announced plans to form a new theatrical production company.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Nicholas Hytner, the director of Britain’s National Theater, has announced plans to form a theatrical production company when he leaves his current position in 2015. (His successor is Rupert Norris, an associate director at the National Theater.)

headline: Discovery of Bombs and Corpses Rattles Tense Caucasus Region
keywords: ['Bombs and Explosives', 'Terrorism', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Olympic Games (2014)']
abstract: Improvised explosive devices and the bodies of six men who had been shot were found in the Stavropol area, stirring new worries about terrorism ahead of the Olympic Games planned for nearby Sochi.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The discovery of several improvised explosive devices and the bodies of six men shot dead put security forces on higher alert in the North Caucasus region of Russia on Thursday and added new concerns about violence ahead of the Olympic Games planned for the nearby resort city of Sochi next month.

headline: Bankers’ Bonus Blues
abstract: A mediocre fourth quarter means that bankers in New York and London are unlikely to improve on their total compensation from 2012 — and that could be the case for the next couple of years, say Antony Currie and Dominic Elliott of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Investment bankers will have to look backward, not forward, for joy this bonus season. A mediocre fourth quarter means Wall Street and City practitioners are unlikely to improve on their total compensation from 2012. With industrywide revenue growth expected to be tepid at best for the next couple of years, the trend could persist. Bank share price performance, though, should help make up some of the difference.

headline: Analyst Suggests UBS Spin Off Investment Bank and Revive Warburg Name
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: In a research report on Thursday, Christopher Wheeler, a banking analyst at Medicobanca, said, said that it was a “strategic consideration” for UBS to spin off its investment bank.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As Swiss banks faces more pressure from regulators to wall off their riskier activities, UBS should consider spinning off its investment bank, an analyst at Mediobanca said on Thursday.

headline: Bomber in Iraq Kills 22 Recruits Seeking to Fight Al Qaeda
abstract: The attacker infiltrated a line of men signing up to fight with government forces in Anbar Province.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — A suicide bomber detonated explosives on Thursday among a group of recruits who were joining the Iraqi Army to fight Al Qaeda in Anbar Province, the police said. Twenty-two recruits were killed, and 31 were wounded, officials said.

headline: The Memi Smart Bracelet: Wearable Tech That Lets You Disconnect
abstract: A smart bracelet without a screen, speaker or stylus is exactly what this gadget lover wants.
lead_paragraph: If one of your resolutions this year was to put down your gadgets more often when you’re with family, then the Memi smart bracelet, oddly enough, is a gadget that might make it easier to do just that.

headline: Darkness On the Edge of Trenton
abstract: Notes on the Chris Christie traffic scandal.
lead_paragraph: I’m not sure how much there is to add to what’s already being said about Chris Christie’s ongoing “traffic study” scandal, but now that his press conference has (I think) finally ended here are a few thoughts.

headline: ‘Lady and the Unicorn’ Tapestries Return to View in France
abstract: After a nearly two-year absence and a thorough cleaning, “The Lady and the Unicorn” tapestries have gone back on view at the Musée National du Moyen Age here, their rich colors more vivid than ever.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — After a nearly two-year absence and a thorough cleaning, “The Lady and the Unicorn” tapestries have gone back on view at the Musée National du Moyen Age here, their rich colors more vivid than ever.

headline: Woman Says Lane Closings Were Not to Blame for Her Mother’s Death
keywords: ['Roads and Traffic', 'George Washington Bridge', 'Emergency Medical Treatment']
abstract: Vilma Oleri, whose mother, Florence Genova, 91, died on the first day of a major traffic jam in Fort Lee, N.J., said, “I honestly believe it was just her time.”
lead_paragraph: FORT LEE, N.J. — The daughter of a 91-year-old woman from Fort Lee, N.J., who died on the day of a major traffic jam precipitated by top aides to Gov. Chris Christie said on Thursday that she did not believe the inability of an ambulance to reach her mother’s house was a factor in her death.

headline: Claim Against Indian Diplomat Has Echoes of Previous Cases
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Human Trafficking', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Domestic Service']
abstract: Although the arrest of an Indian diplomat has stirred strong reactions, there have been past criminal cases and lawsuits for similar allegations.
lead_paragraph: Sangeeta Richard, the housekeeper whose accusations of employer mistreatment led to the arrest of India’s deputy consul general in New York and an international furor, is not the first domestic worker to take issue with a diplomat who hired her.

headline: Questions for Christie
abstract: How can he still not know if there was a legitimate traffic study?
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie’s press conference on the manmade-traffic-jam lasted for almost two hours. He beat up on himself — he feels “embarrassed and humiliated” — and his staff — he called Bridget Anne Kelly “stupid and deceitful” — and did a pretty decent job of exhausting reporters, if not public interest in the story. A few questions remain that will likely play a part in the controversy going forward:

headline: Tunisia’s Premier Resigns, Formally Ending His Party’s Rule
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The resignation of Prime Minister Ali Larayedh was part of a carefully calibrated plan to end months of gridlock and prepare for new elections in the birthplace of the Arab Spring.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — Tunisia’s Islamist prime minister resigned Thursday, ending the two-year-old rule of his party, which has dominated the political scene since the popular uprising here that initiated the Arab Spring.

headline: Apple and Samsung Chiefs to Meet a Mediator Ahead of Next Patent Suit
abstract: In March, Apple and Samsung Electronics are scheduled to go to trial again to fight over smartphone patents. But after discussing settlement opportunities earlier this week, the companies have agreed to meet with a mediator.
lead_paragraph: In March, Apple and Samsung Electronics are scheduled to go to trial again to fight over smartphone patents. But after discussing settlement opportunities earlier this week, the companies have agreed to meet with a mediator.

headline: Blackstone Hires UBS Banker to Lead Energy Advisory Group
abstract: James R. Schaefer was most recently global head of the power and renewable energy group at UBS. He will be a senior managing director at Blackstone Advisory Partners.
lead_paragraph: The investment banking arm of the Blackstone Group has hired a UBS executive to lead its energy and power advisory practice.

headline: Chrysler Announces Mopar Custom Shop Display for Detroit
abstract: Visitors will have a chance to use iPads to see what Chrysler and Fiat vehicles look like customized with Mopar aftermarket parts.
lead_paragraph: Although Mopar has been Chrysler’s parts and service moniker since before World War II, it was during muscle-car craze of the 1960s that it came to be identified with performance aftermarket parts. At the North American International Auto Show in Detroit next week, Chrysler will have a sizable Mopar display as part of its 5,500-square-foot spread, showing off several vehicles laden with aftermarket parts.

headline: With Release of Prisoners, Afghan Leader Again Defies U.S. Wishes
abstract: Intensifying his showdown with Washington, President Hamid Karzai ordered the release of 72 detainees, citing insufficient evidence.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan on Thursday ordered the release of dozens of prisoners accused of having American blood on their hands, saying there was not enough evidence to hold them and intensifying his showdown with Obama administration officials after weeks of warnings that he risked losing American troop support.

headline: Jon Favreau’s ‘Chef’ to Open South by Southwest Film Festival
keywords: ['Movies', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: The South by Southwest film festival announces its opening-night film, written, directed by and starring Jon Favreau.
lead_paragraph: One more food truck will roll into Austin when “Chef,” a comedy written, directed by and starring Jon Favreau, has its premiere on opening night of the South by Southwest Film festival, organizers announced Thursday.

headline: A Comic Book Team Gets the Green Light
abstract: Ed Brubaker and Sean Phillips have signed a five-year deal with Image Comics in which Image will publish anything the team dreams up.
lead_paragraph: The life of a freelance comic book creator is all about pitching and survival: looking for a publisher and hoping an audience will be there to sustain a series. For the writer-artist team Ed Brubaker and Sean Phillips, things are about to get a little easier. Mr. Brubaker and Mr. Phillips have made a five-year publishing deal with Image Comics, the home of their most recent collaboration, the supernatural noir series Fatale. Image will publish whatever the team can dream up and Mr. Brubaker and Mr. Phillips will retain ownership of the property, a hallmark of the company.

headline: JPMorgan Lost Madoff in a Blizzard of Paper
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: Documents released in connection with the federal penalties imposed on JPMorgan Chase showed that many people simply filled out and filed forms, oblivious to what they might indicate.
lead_paragraph: Did JPMorgan Chase deliberately cover up Bernard L. Madoff’s fraud?

headline: Old Breakfast Buddies, From Tarzan to Snoopy
abstract: Sunday afternoon with the funnies: retro comic strips can make a comeback in a digital world, with new collections published as books.
lead_paragraph: ONE of the simple yet durable cultural traditions of the 20th century — a modest rite that transcended barriers of race and class — was the Sunday morning or afternoon spent lost in the newspaper funnies. There was always something for everyone: “Flash Gordon,” “Prince Valiant” and “Terry and the Pirates” for those craving pulpy adventure; “Archie” and “Peanuts” for laughs and chuckles; “Gasoline Alley” and “Blondie” for family life; and “Krazy Kat” and “Pogo” for the comic-strip intelligentsia.

headline: Wedding Q. and A.
abstract: Questions about who should pay for transportation and parking, and other wedding etiquette issues.
lead_paragraph: New York Transportation Etiquette

headline: A Sweet History: Doughnuts in New York City
abstract: An exhibition at City Reliquary traces the doughnut’s local history all the way back to the 17th century.
lead_paragraph: The Miser grew up just a few towns south of the birthplace of that symbol of American low cuisine, Krispy Kreme. So captivating were those confections’ sugary spell that it wasn’t until adolescence that he was even aware of the existence of other doughnuts. Doughnuts, for all he knew, simply were Krispy Kremes, and vice versa. Dunkin’ Donuts, he assumed, was merely a figure of speech, not a rival purveyor.

headline: National Park Proves a Hard Gift to Give
keywords: ['National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Land Use Policies']
abstract: A landowner’s plan to donate 75,000 acres for a national park in Maine has met fierce opposition, partly because many in the region loathe the idea of giving Washington a toehold there.
lead_paragraph: PATTEN, Me. — Lucas St. Clair pulled up to an overlook in Maine’s North Woods to a stunning vista of Mount Katahdin, the state’s highest peak and the endpoint of the Appalachian Trail. Stretched out below was a vast green carpet of pine and spruce flecked with golden aspens and blazing red maples; Millinocket Lake glistened in the distance.

headline: Portraits From Clips and Bytes
abstract: The artist R. Luke DuBois takes a data-mining approach to his work, drawing on Google searches and surveillance technology for video and graphics pieces.
lead_paragraph: When the visual artist and composer R. Luke DuBois was commissioned by the National Portrait Gallery in Washington to make a portrait of Google’s founders, Sergey Brin and Larry Page, he elegantly co-opted Google’s own technology for the job.

headline: Early Chekhov, Framed Anew
abstract: The experimental designer and director Jay Scheib is offering audiences two ways to view his raucous contemporary rewrite of an unfinished early Chekhov play.
lead_paragraph: The experimental designer and director Jay Scheib is offering audiences two ways to view his raucous contemporary rewrite of an unfinished early Chekhov play. You can see a live performance at the Kitchen in Chelsea, where it is called “Platonov,” the play’s traditional title, or you can watch a live simulcast of the performance at one of several theaters in New York and elsewhere, where it goes by another name, “The Disinherited.”

headline: ‘Captain Phillips’ Gets Another Vote of Confidence
abstract: “Captain Phillips” picks up some momentum with a script nomination, while the Art Directors and Costume Designers Guilds weigh in with their choices.
lead_paragraph: Is this another indicator that “Captain Phillips” is going to go far? The USC Libraries Scripter Award, a screenplay prize that includes the original material that adapted movies come from, announced finalists on Thursday, and the real-life captain’s memoir, along with the film version, made the list.

headline: After Being Indicted, Diplomat Is Allowed to Leave the Country
abstract: Devyani Khobragade, an Indian diplomat, was indicted on charges of visa fraud and making false statements in connection with her treatment of a domestic worker.
lead_paragraph: The legal battle over an Indian diplomat whose recent arrest in New York caused an uproar in her home country took an unusual turn on Thursday when she was indicted by a federal grand jury in Manhattan but was then allowed to leave the United States.

headline: Dish Shares Drop After It Withdraws Bid for LightSquared
abstract: Shares in Dish were down more than 2.5 percent on Thursday after a lawyer for LightSquared said in bankruptcy court that its suitor had terminated its offer.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 4:24 p.m. | For years, Charles W. Ergen had ambitions to buy LightSquared, the bankrupt broadband wireless company, to bolster his dream of creating a huge data services provider.

headline: National Board of Review Gala Red Carpet
abstract: Celebrities like Adèle Exarchopoulos and Leonardo DiCaprio attended the event.
lead_paragraph: Celebrities like Adèle Exarchopoulos and Leonardo DiCaprio attended the event.

headline: Teju Cole Puts Story-Telling to the Twitter Test
abstract: Teju Cole’s version of the old story-telling party game was effective in a strange, new way.
lead_paragraph: 6:50 p.m. | Update: Teju Cole, who is in India, responded to my email after this post originally went live. His comments were added later.

headline: Civil War Archive to Go on Sale
abstract: Documents and artifacts from Luis F. Emilio, a white officer from Massachusetts who led a black regiment during the Civil War, are going on sale.
lead_paragraph: A BLACK REGIMENT’S BATTLEFIELD STORIES

headline: Rubio Demands States’ Right to Ignore the Poor
abstract: The senator’s plan to alleviate poverty is remarkably retrograde.
lead_paragraph: For a senator who likes to hold himself out as the future of the Republican brand, Marco Rubio has come up with a remarkably retrograde contribution to the party’s chorus of phony empathy for the poor: Let the states do it.

headline: As Seals Return to Long Island, So Do Watchers
keywords: ['Seals (Animals) and Sealing', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Cruises']
abstract: Sightings, once few, come by the dozen for passengers on a seal-watching cruise in Hempstead Bay.
lead_paragraph: In 2000, when the Riverhead Foundation for Marine Research and Preservation began running seal-watching cruises on Hempstead Bay, passengers would typically see one or two seals, according to Robert A. DiGiovanni Jr., a biologist and the group’s executive director.

headline: Philadelphia Museum Lands a Major Gift
abstract: Keith L. Sachs and his wife, Katherine, have promised much of their art collection to the Philadelphia Museum of Art, including works by Jasper Johns, Ellsworth Kelly, Brice Marden and Gerhard Richter.
lead_paragraph: Since the 1970s, Keith L. Sachs, the former chief executive of Saxco International, a packaging distribution company, and his wife, Katherine, have been major supporters of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, he as a longtime trustee and she in a number of roles, including adjunct curator.

headline: Going Driverless at CES
abstract: Roy Furchgott explores the buzz around autonomous vehicles at this year’s International CES.
lead_paragraph: Roy Furchgott explores the buzz around autonomous vehicles at this year’s International CES.

headline: Survey of a Modern Form and a Friendship
abstract: An exhibition of Harry Holtzman’s paintings, sculptures and drawings tells the story of the artist’s work and his relationship with his friend Piet Mondrian.
lead_paragraph: You can tell by the primary colors and rectilinear grids in Harry Holtzman’s paintings and sculptures that the artist was a disciple of Piet Mondrian, the Dutch founder of Neoplasticism, an aesthetic philosophy that sought spiritual balance through simplified formal structure. Mondrian’s legacy in the United States is even owed in large part to Holtzman, who was 40 years younger and became the sole heir to and executor of his estate. The story of Holtzman’s work and their relationship, however, has been largely left untold. “Harry Holtzman and American Abstraction” at the Florence Griswold Museum in Old Lyme, Conn., offers a thorough and thoughtful recounting of that history.

headline: A Conductor Wields a Baton Across Cultures
abstract: Rossen Milanov, the music director of the Princeton Symphony Orchestra, also leads a group in Spain, among his other commitments.
lead_paragraph: The conductor Rossen Milanov balances two approaches when leading an orchestra.

headline: The Mind’s Jailer
abstract: In E. L. Doctorow’s new novel, a scientist tells the story of his puzzling life.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve always responded to the history of my times,” says the beleaguered narrator of “Andrew’s Brain,” almost ruefully, as if he wished it weren’t so. He has no choice, though: Responding to the history of one’s times is the sworn duty of a character in a novel by E. L. Doctorow, who has in his half-century of writing fiction placed a remarkable number of people, both real and imagined, in their history just to watch them respond. At first Andrew, whose time is the bewilderingly eventful opening decade of this century, doesn’t sound like much of a witness: A self-­described “freakishly depressive cognitive scientist klutz,” he seems far more interested in the workings of his own mind than those of the world outside, and for a long time speaks — to someone he calls Doc — only of his messy private life and his largely fruitless research into the mysteries of the human brain. He cracks cynical jokes, tells parts of his life story in the third person, indulges in a fair bit of glib self-analysis (“I am finally, terribly, unfeeling”) and generally plays the fool. “Andrew’s Brain” is cunning. It isn’t hard to figure out that Andrew is an unreliable narrator, but by the end of this sly book Doctorow has you wondering if there’s any other kind.

headline: I Read You Loud and Clear
abstract: An author drops in on a book club discussing his novel.
lead_paragraph: I love book clubs. I love reading for them, I love talking to them, and if I had my choice I’d probably do nothing but visit them to promote my books. Where else do you find people who have already made a commitment to read your book, and to read it closely enough to discuss it in a knowledgeable fashion with their friends? The best insights I’ve ever been offered about my work have come from book club members. In a world full of readings attended by the inevitable, random 5-to-10 bookstore browsers and 20-year-old assistant night managers who consistently mangle the title of your work, book clubs are an oasis of intelligent thought and discussion.

headline: Marvin Bileck: ‘Thimbledon Bridge’ and Emily Nelligan: ‘Drawings’
abstract: The two sets of drawings in this wonderful exhibition come from opposite yet complementary poles.
lead_paragraph: Alexandre Gallery

headline: Jury of 7 Women and 5 Men Chosen for Martoma Trial
abstract: An insurance underwriter, an employee of PricewaterhouseCoopers, an employment and labor lawyer and a New York bus driver are among the jurors chosen for the insider trading trial of Mathew Martoma, a former SAC Capital Advisors hedge fund manager.
lead_paragraph: A jury of seven women and five men was selected on Thursday to determine whether Mathew Martoma, a former SAC Capital Advisors hedge fund manager, is guilty of engaging in what the government has called the biggest insider trading scheme in history.

headline: Panel Recommends Transferring Yemeni From Guantánamo
abstract: A military panel has recommended transferring a Yemeni detainee in the first results of a long-delayed initiative to hold parole-like hearings at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the first results of a long-delayed Obama administration initiative to hold parole-like hearings at the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, a military panel has recommended transferring a Yemeni detainee who had been ordered held indefinitely without trial, the Pentagon announced on Wednesday.

headline: ‘Para-Real’
abstract: This philosophically catchy 14-artist show reflects a few forms.
lead_paragraph: 601Artspace

headline: A Chef in the Field | Olive Oil
abstract: In Ojai, California, the Mediterranean-like climate produces olives that make for a robust extra-virgin olive oil, much like the varieties from Spain and Portugal, that’s perfect for making olive oil cake.
lead_paragraph: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food — from its original source to a place on your table.

headline: Lucy Dodd: ‘Cake 4 Catfish’
abstract: This show stresses Ms. Dodd’s large and versatile ambition, which takes in painting, several kinds of eccentric sculpture and works on paper.
lead_paragraph: David Lewis Gallery

headline: The Feel, and Taste, of France
abstract: Saint George has taken over where Buffet de la Gare once reigned, bringing a more casual atmosphere and fresh approach to a classic bistro menu.
lead_paragraph: Saint George, a youthful new bistro that has taken the place of the beloved Buffet de la Gare, in Hastings-on-Hudson, is giving nervous loyal Gare patrons all kinds of reasons to take heart.

headline: Attorney General Vows to Crack Down on ‘Insider Trading 2.0’
abstract: The New York State attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, said he planned to investigate brokerage firms that might have provided early market-moving information to preferred clients.
lead_paragraph: Asset managers aren’t the only ones who should worry about BlackRock’s settlement with the New York State attorney general.

headline: Sarah Crowner: ‘The Wave’
abstract: Ms. Crowner’s third solo at Nicelle Beauchene is just what’s needed in the dark days of January.
lead_paragraph: Nicelle Beauchene Gallery

headline: Anke Weyer: ‘Du’
abstract: If the earliest painters making abstract gestural compositions had the shock of the new on their side, Ms. Weyer has the shock of the old.
lead_paragraph: Canada

headline: Looking Again at That Mars-Venus Thing
abstract: As HBO brings back “Girls,” the series about young female slackers, it is also offering “Looking,” about young gay slackers.
lead_paragraph: On HBO, it’s the guys who are airbrushed and Photoshopped, and the “Girls” who let their blemishes show.

headline: At the End of a Strip Mall, a Surprise
abstract: The owner of Verona, an Italian restaurant in an unremarkable setting, left banking to exercise his creative side.
lead_paragraph: Verona Restaurant is one of those proverbial gems, a first-rate traditional Italian restaurant in an unremarkable setting. Here, at the end of a strip mall that houses a Subway sandwich shop and a dry cleaner, ordinary dishes like eggplant rollatini and fried zucchini dominate. Prepared with skill and flair, they remind you why these standard items are beloved by so many diners.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: sleep apnea, torn arteries and Google searches. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: sleep apnea, torn arteries and Google searches. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Sudan and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from South Sudan, Central African Republic, Brazil and Turkey.
lead_paragraph: Photos from South Sudan, Central African Republic, Brazil and Turkey.

headline: Beyond Beefcake in the Work of a Gay Pioneer
abstract: “Devotion,” an exhibition at New York University’s 80WSE, shows a surprising range in the work by Bob Mizer, known for his erotic photographs of men.
lead_paragraph: In 1951, Bob Mizer began Physique Pictorial, a magazine loaded with photographs of muscular young men wearing little more than posing straps — G-strings for men. Its imagery ostensibly illustrated health and fitness, but was really aimed at what was then an underground gay market. Mizer (1922-92) was a pioneer in making explicit the genre’s erotic appeal, enough so to attract attention from legal authorities. In 1947, he was convicted of contributing to the delinquency of a minor by taking nude pictures of a 17-year-old, and he spent a year in prison. In 1954, he was convicted of distributing obscene material through the mail. (That conviction was reversed on appeal a couple of years later.) Those speed bumps didn’t stop Mizer’s enterprise as a commercial photographer and publisher from growing to the point at which it occupied four lots near downtown Los Angeles, like a Hollywood movie studio, earning him the nickname “the Hugh Hefner of gay publishing.” Mizer, evidently, was blessedly free of high-art pretension, but Physique Pictorial was nevertheless an inspiration for artists like David Hockney and Robert Mapplethorpe.

headline: At Issue in 2 Wrenching Cases: What to Do After the Brain Dies
keywords: ['Life-Sustaining Support Systems, Withdrawal Of', 'Coma', 'Brain', 'Ethics (Institutional)', 'Medicine and Health', 'Death and Dying']
abstract: Two recent cases involving a patient kept alive by ventilator despite a diagnosis of brain death raise questions about exactly what this term means.
lead_paragraph: In one way, the cases are polar opposites: the parents of Jahi McMath in Oakland, Calif., have fought to keep their daughter connected to a ventilator, while the parents and husband of Marlise Muñoz in Fort Worth, Tex., want desperately to turn the machine off. In another way, the cases are identical: both families have been shocked to learn that a loved one was declared brain-dead — and that hospital officials defied the family’s wishes for treatment.

headline: Hiding in Plain Sight
abstract: Even after three years in business, InThai is something of a secret beyond its area along Route 7 in Norwalk. The food is authentic, the prices low and the atmosphere friendly.
lead_paragraph: InThai Restaurant is handy for workers in several high-rise office buildings along Route 7 in Norwalk near the Wilton line, many of whom cross the road for a quick lunch or a takeout dinner. But even after three years in business, the restaurant is still something of a secret beyond that area, and those acquainted with its extremely low prices and good spicy Thai food may want it to retain its sleeper status a while longer.

headline: Amiri Baraka, Polarizing Poet and Playwright, Dies at 79
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Writing and Writers', 'Culture (Arts)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Theater']
abstract: Mr. Baraka’s work was widely anthologized, and he was also long famous as a political firebrand, with critical opinion divided in every arena.
lead_paragraph: Amiri Baraka, a poet and playwright of pulsating rage, whose long illumination of the black experience in America was called incandescent in some quarters and incendiary in others, died on Thursday in Newark. He was 79.

headline: Christie and the Bridge Scandal
abstract: Readers react to charges that political revenge was behind the lane closings on the George Washington Bridge.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Gary Shteyngart Offers Some Jokes, Some Self-Analysis
abstract: Mr. Shteyngart was at St. Joseph’s College in Brooklyn on Wednesday to promote his new memoir, “Little Failure.”
lead_paragraph: Gary Shteyngart was speaking on Wednesday night about the difficulties of recapturing his past on the page. “There was one acid trip I wanted to write about,” he said, “and in interviewing five people, I realized it never happened.”

headline: Punk, Skirts, Balaclavas: A Russian Revolution
abstract: In “Words Will Break Cement,” Masha Gessen explores the impact of the Russian musical activist group Pussy Riot.
lead_paragraph: The problem with staging a show trial is that the main actor has little incentive to follow the script. Yet that’s never tempered Russia’s thirst for judicial theater. In 1964, a Soviet court demanded to know who had given Joseph Brodsky permission to write poetry. That future Nobel laureate’s retort: “I think that it ... comes from God,” became a classic of artistic defiance.

headline: Obama Announces ‘Promise Zones’ in 5 Poor Areas
abstract: The president said that federal agencies will cut through red tape to give struggling residents a chance at a better life.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A year after promising to direct federal attention and support to needy areas across the country, President Obama said Thursday that the government would begin helping five economically hard-hit communities fight poverty and assist children.

headline: She’s Hard as Nails, He’s Noir and Nasty
abstract: “Cold Comes the Night” pits a young motel owner against a criminal who takes her and her daughter hostage to recover a fortune in cash.
lead_paragraph: There’s more mystery in the grammatically anguished title of “Cold Comes the Night” than in this low-voltage thriller, which asks you to guess, if not for long or terribly hard, which is the tougher of two combatants: a young and lovely single mother or a Polish criminal. In one corner is Chloe (Alice Eve), a hardworking, hard-bitten beauty who runs and lives in one of those motels that rent rooms by the hour. In the other corner is Topo (Bryan Cranston), a very bad man who stops at the motel one evening — the presumably cold night of the title (she puts on a parka) — a stopover that leads to a face-off that ends pretty much how you might guess.

headline: A Spot for Theatrics, or Serenity
abstract: Notable offerings at K60 Japanese Steak House, which has a lively hibachi room and a quiet sushi bar, include steak teriyaki and an arrangement of sliced white tuna.
lead_paragraph: The first thing to know about K60 Japanese Steak House is that this sprawling, neon-trimmed restaurant in a Lake Grove strip mall offers two entirely different dining experiences. The most popular, by far, is the raucous hibachi room, where flames leap, diners cheer (or cringe), servers scurry and impassioned chefs jump, juggle, chop and grill, all beneath the nonstop whoosh of overhead exhaust fans. And there is the adjacent, far quieter “sushi room,” as a hostess called it on a recent evening, with its sleek, sparsely populated tables and booths, serene sushi bar and attentive servers.

headline: When There Was a Mock Plantation in Brooklyn
abstract: The romanticized version of a plantation, whose performances were billed as largely educational, didn’t seem to elicit any disapproval in 1895.
lead_paragraph: All up and down de whole creationSadly I roam,Still longing for de old plantation,And for de old folks at home.

headline: I Remember Mama, the Pot Smuggler
abstract: A mother with two daughters finds work in Florida as a marijuana smuggler, in this semiautobiographical drama written and directed by Shana Betz.
lead_paragraph: In the opening moments of “Free Ride,” Christina (Anna Paquin), a young mother, impulsively flees her abusive boyfriend and dead-end factory job in an Akron, Ohio, suburb, to begin a new life in Florida. It is 1977, and the state, still in the throes of the blasé anything-goes spirit of the post-hippie era, is awash in imported drugs.

headline: Looking for the Hands-Free Driving Experience
abstract: One of the more curious self-driving vehicles at the International CES was something that looked more fit for a parade route than a highway.
lead_paragraph: At this year’s International CES, several automakers are showing off the latest and greatest technology in their vehicles, and much of the focus was on autonomous technology. Audi introduced a car that took steps toward self-driving, as did BMW and Bosch.

headline: The Good, the Bad and the ‘Ugly Betty’
abstract: Michael Urie and his partner, Ryan Spahn, live on the Far West Side.
lead_paragraph: When Michael Urie was cast in 2006 as Vanessa Williams’s slavishly devoted assistant on the television series “Ugly Betty,” it meant a move to Los Angeles. Relocating is an actor’s lot, of course, but Mr. Urie desperately missed New York. Clever guy, he came up with an effective treatment for homesickness: the purchase of an apartment in a very tall building. “Anytime friends came over,” he recalled, “they said, ‘This is just like home.’ ”

headline: What I Love | Michael Urie
keywords: ['Television', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: The Midtown West home of Michael Urie and his partner Ryan Spahn.
lead_paragraph: The Midtown West home of Michael Urie and his partner Ryan Spahn.

headline: Gillespie, Former Republican Chairman, Readies to Run for Senate in Virginia
abstract: Ed Gillespie has told senior members of his party that he will challenge Senator Mark R. Warner.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ed Gillespie, a former Republican National Committee chairman, has told senior members of his party that he will challenge Senator Mark R. Warner of Virginia and announce his candidacy as early as next week, giving Republicans a top-tier candidate in what has become one of the nation’s most competitive swing states.

headline: Designing the Next Wave of Computer Chips
keywords: ['Nanotechnology', 'Computer Chips', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: Scientists are looking for new ways to make computer chips and investigating materials that can self-assemble.
lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Not long after Gordon E. Moore proposed in 1965 that the number of transistors that could be etched on a silicon chip would continue to double approximately every 18 months, critics began predicting that the era of “Moore’s Law” would draw to a close.

headline: No Barbershops Here, Nor Violins or Cellos
abstract: In “a quartet,” Heather Kravas plays with patterns and the word “want.”
lead_paragraph: At the start of Heather Kravas’s “a quartet,” the work’s four dancers stand in line like serious kids pretending to be a train. As they repeatedly bend forward and arch back, their collective motion — switching between unison, relay and counterpoint — takes on the aspect of a stationary machine. Then, as their pelvises rock, they add a word — “want” — which becomes a mantra. Accelerating, the sequence approaches the edge of comedy.

headline: Coming-of-Age in Wartime
abstract: “In Bloom,” Georgia’s entry for the Best Foreign Language Film Oscar, tracks the lives of two girls in Tbilisi in 1992, during the newly independent country’s civil war.
lead_paragraph: Eka and Natia , the 14-year-old best friends at the heart of “In Bloom,” live in a place that seems to be crumbling at the edges. It’s 1992, and their homeland, the former Soviet republic of Georgia, is at war. The fighting, in the northern Abkhazia region, is far from the capital, Tbilisi, where the girls live, but the conflict pops up frequently in the adult conversations, at least when the grown-ups are not screaming and cursing about other things.

headline: Shifting His Tectonic Plates
abstract: In his show “New Sculpture,” at the Gagosian Gallery, Richard Serra continues along the road that emerged from the hugely successful “Torqued Ellipses” of the ’90s, but also circles back to his earlier oeuvre.
lead_paragraph: At the end of December, the PBS host Charlie Rose conducted a curious interview with Richard Serra about his new show in two locations of the Gagosian Gallery in New York, and it quickly became popular on the Internet. The conversation was notable mostly because it reached an uncomfortable deadlock over how to talk about Mr. Serra’s sculpture. (Mr. Rose thought one work in Mr. Serra’s new show looked like a cemetery; Mr. Serra disagreed. Repeat.)

headline: Celebrating Age as Well as Attitude at a Record Label’s Anniversary Party
abstract: Robert Glasper and Jason Moran headlined a 75th anniversary concert for Blue Note Records on Wednesday at Town Hall.
lead_paragraph: An anniversary concert for a record label, like an anniversary edition of a music festival, always comes preloaded with a burden of intention. What’s implicit is some form of brand reinforcement — but an album catalog contains its own narrative, and an artist roster has its own identity, and the two may not naturally converge. So one question for any label at a milestone is what to celebrate most: a corpus or an ethos?

headline: Ford Looks to Fiesta to Increase Sales in Japanese Market
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Automobiles', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: The Detroit automaker, which sold fewer than 4,000 cars in Japan last year, will advertise the small car in a tough market where the competition is stiff.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Ford might be an auto giant in America, but odds are you will not spot one of its cars on Japan’s busy roads. Last year, the Detroit automaker sold all of 3,896 cars in Japan.

headline: A Band of Brothers and Oddballs
abstract: “Enlisted,” a Fox sitcom making its debut Friday, centers on three brothers stationed at the same backwater base in Florida.
lead_paragraph: Any man who was of a devil-may-care age in 1981 will, if interrogated long enough, eventually drop his intellectual facade and affirm that the greatest movie of all time is not “Citizen Kane” but “Stripes,” the boot-camp comedy from that year starring Bill Murray and Harold Ramis. “Enlisted,” a Fox sitcom that begins on Friday night, really, really wants to be “Stripes,” but it has none of its panache. Where “Stripes” was full of memorable misfits, “Enlisted” is full of mismatched ones.

headline: E-Cigarette Shops Open Even as City Cracks Down
abstract: Six electronic-cigarette shops have recently opened in New York City, providing supplies, guidance and something of a scene.
lead_paragraph: A half-dozen people were gathered around the tasting bar at the Henley Vaporium in SoHo on a recent Friday evening. Behind the bar, two vapologists in white lab coats stood before a selection of dozens of tiny bottles, each containing liquid nicotine. The customers, all students or young professionals, leisurely inhaled on their so-called vape pens. Clouds of mist curled upward and vanished. A slightly sweet smell lingered in the air.

headline: Charting the Decline in Service at the I.R.S.
abstract: The customer experience in getting an I.R.S. representative on the phone, from year to year.
lead_paragraph: The national taxpayer advocate, the ombudswoman for the Internal Revenue Service, has released her annual report about the biggest issues facing the agency. One major concern that the advocate, Nina E. Olson, emphasized was declining customer service at the agency, driven by budget cuts.

headline: No Heavy Lifting for These Gym Rats
abstract: Were you longing for a gross-out comedy about fitness centers? Do you need to see more Fabio on screen? “Dumbbells” is here.
lead_paragraph: Because the time is long overdue for a gross-out comedy about the absurdities of gym culture, the first few minutes of “Dumbbells,” set at a Los Angeles fitness center, raised my hopes that here at last was the satirical takedown this subject deserves.

lead_paragraph: For over a half-century, the Washington law firm Patton Boggs has been a significant player in the nation’s legal, lobbying and business worlds.

headline: Unfinished Works
abstract: The Metropolitan Museum is dotted with paintings that have been left incomplete.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Museum is dotted with paintings that have been left incomplete.

headline: The Fascination of the Unfinished
abstract: The Metropolitan Museum is dotted with paintings that have been left incomplete, giving viewers hints into the impulses behind the genius of Degas, Bassano, Greuze, Rembrandt and others.
lead_paragraph: Unfinished paintings are enticing cracks in the facade of art history, lures along the path to a deeper understanding of artistic processes and impulses. For all the paintings that artists complete, countless others are left incomplete for any number of reasons — poverty or war, a change of plan or vision, the illness or death of the artist. While many of these works have been destroyed, and others forgotten, some are now recognized as significant works of art, accorded a special place in history and in an artist’s body of work, in part because they can bring us closer to understanding the mysterious process of painting, and, indeed, to painting’s future. After all, nothing inspires a young artist like a close look at how an earlier one worked.

headline: Apollo Secures $18.4 Billion War Chest for Private Equity
abstract: Apollo’s newest fund, the largest in its history, underscoring investors’ confidence that firm can find buying opportunities at a time when stock prices have risen drastically.

lead_paragraph: In designing his 1907 campus for the City College of New York at Amsterdam Avenue and 138th Street, George B. Post must have felt like the ham in a sandwich. He was working between McKim, Mead & White’s lofty, imperial Roman-style Columbia College and their demure Renaissance-style campus for New York University’s Bronx branch, now Bronx Community College.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It is hardly the kind of news that lawmakers in Congress would want to highlight during a week when unemployment benefits expired for more than a million Americans. But Congress has achieved something of a milestone.

headline: Tech vs. Tyke
abstract: Keeping a toddler away from someone else’s TV; regretting some teenage nastiness, decades later; when a friend doesn’t want your help.
lead_paragraph: Unlike almost everyone we know, my husband and I do not allow our 3-year-old to watch TV or movies, or use smartphones, tablets or other devices. We feel that “screen time” is unhealthy, and so far, the policy has worked for our family. I avoid this topic with other parents because our choice implies a negative judgment about their choices. If the TV comes on at someone else’s house, we quietly excuse ourselves. But what should I say when another parent asks me about this directly?

headline: A Third Ring, Bearing the Most Important Truth
keywords: ['Dating and Courtship', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Modern Love (Times Column)']
abstract: A ring can carry a promise, or sometimes something deeper.
lead_paragraph: My first engagement ring, a diamond, was given to me by Glenn on my 27th birthday. Although we had been dating only 10 months, I suspected a proposal was coming. Little clues tipped me off: a cut-short phone call, his nervousness at the restaurant.

headline: A Big Year for V.A. Loans

headline: If Bad Things Happen, Blame the 10-Year-Old
abstract: In “The Rocket,” a Laotian boy’s family faults him for the terrible circumstances they face when they are forced to relocate.
lead_paragraph: A pretty, somewhat sleepy and finally strange once-upon-a-time tale, “The Rocket” is the story of a Laotian boy who transcends adversity, partly because, if we’re being honest, few moviegoers would probably want to watch a film about a boy who doesn’t (unless it is a documentary). It opens with a villager, Mali (Alice Keohavong), giving birth to twins, one dead. An older relative, Taitok (Bunsri Yindi), wants to kill the surviving child because, she insists, twins are bad luck. Mali successfully begs for the boy’s life, and, after the dead newborn is clandestinely buried, the surviving child grows up to become the movie’s plucky 10-year-old hero, Ahlo (Sitthiphon Disamoe).

headline: Giants’ David Wilson to Have Neck Surgery
abstract: Running back David Wilson will have surgery this month to repair a herniated disk in his neck, although it is expected that he will be recovered sufficiently to play next season, the team said.
lead_paragraph: Giants running back David Wilson will have surgery this month to repair a herniated disk in his neck, although it is expected that he will be recovered sufficiently to play next season, the team said Thursday. The Giants had been hoping that rest and treatment might alleviate the injury, which sidelined Wilson for most of the season. Surgery has instead become the recommended option.

headline: The War Over Poverty
abstract: On its 50th birthday, the movement to aid the poor has a lot of progress to celebrate.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years have passed since Lyndon Johnson declared war on poverty. And a funny thing happened on the way to this anniversary. Suddenly, or so it seems, progressives have stopped apologizing for their efforts on behalf of the poor, and have started trumpeting them instead. And conservatives find themselves on the defensive.

abstract: China’s export machine has continued to run even as blue-collar wages have soared between fivefold and ninefold in dollar terms in the last decade.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Cheng Chunmeng, the general manager of a manufacturer of colorful children’s chairs in east-central China, gave his workers a 30 percent raise last year to keep them from leaving. His labor costs are rising even faster in dollar terms, as the Chinese currency slowly climbs against the United States dollar.

headline: A Race for More Than the Mayor of Istanbul

lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Engin Bayrak owns a hardware store near the shores of the Golden Horn waterway, where ferries connect the European and Asian sides of this vast city. He has witnessed for himself the vast improvements in services over the last decade as Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan and his Islamist-rooted Justice and Development Party reshaped this city in their image.

abstract: A pending free-trade agreement — and at least one Japanese farmer — is posing challenges to the elaborate system that protects the homegrown crop.
lead_paragraph: AGA, Japan — For decades, Japan has defended its 778 percent tariffs on rice with a kind of religious zeal. Rice is a sacred crop, the government has argued, not open to trade negotiations. Its farmers are not just defenders of a proud agrarian heritage, but form the nation’s spiritual center as well.

abstract: Pupils are not more likely to leave New York City charter schools than their counterparts at traditional public schools, but that is not the case for special education students, a study found.
lead_paragraph: Addressing a common criticism of New York City charter schools, a study released on Thursday said that in general their students were not, in fact, more likely to transfer out than their counterparts in traditional public schools.

headline: With Surplus in Hand, California Eyes Debt
abstract: Gov. Jerry Brown submitted a budget proposal that includes an 8.5 percent spending increase, but also $11 billion for debts and liabilities, including a $6 billion deferred payment to schools.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Ever since he came into office, Gov. Jerry Brown has promised to address what he has long called the state’s “wall of debt” built up over years. And now that the nation’s most populous state is looking at a multibillion-dollar surplus, Mr. Brown, in a $155 billion state budget proposal submitted on Thursday, is pledging to make good on that promise.

headline: More U.S. Economists See Half-Full Glass
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Unemployment']
abstract: A smaller trade deficit, increased consumer spending and a surging stock market contributed to a revised outlook for United States growth.
lead_paragraph: Record exports and the smallest trade deficit in four years. Healthier consumer spending, including the strongest annual increase in automobile sales since 2007, spurred by a booming stock market and an improving housing sector. And a slow but steady pickup in job creation that has pushed unemployment to its lowest level since 2008.

lead_paragraph: Remember the Walloon Settlers? The contribution to New York’s history made by Eugene G. Putnam? Conrad Poppenhusen ring a bell?

headline: Rev. Vincent J. Termine, Pastor Who Fought Racism in His Parish, Dies at 93
abstract: Father Termine angered members of his predominantly white flock in Brooklyn when he let black youths participate in organized basketball at his parish in the mid-1970s.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Vincent J. Termine, a Roman Catholic priest who helped revive a dying parish in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, in the 1960s and ’70s, then angered members of his predominantly white flock when he let black youths from another neighborhood participate in organized basketball at the church, died on Dec. 26 in Johns Island, S.C., where he had lived since 2009. He was 93.

headline: Call to Honor Pakistani Boy in Fatal Tackle of a Bomber
abstract: Aitzaz Hasan, 15, stopped a suicide bomber whose target was believed to be a school in northwestern Pakistan, which has a history of sectarian violence.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Aitzaz Hasan, a 15-year-old ninth grader, was late for school and rushing with two friends to make the morning assembly when they were stopped by a stranger wearing the same uniform as theirs, who curiously asked for directions. Aitzaz grew suspicious, and tackled the stranger as he tried to flee. Then the stranger blew himself up, killing them both.

lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — A silver thief who has been called the “burglar to the stars” for breaking into the homes of the rich and sometimes famous has been charged with eight counts of burglary.

It was Jamie Moyer against Nolan Ryan. Finesse versus power. What a laboratory for an eager student of the craft of pitching.

headline: A Small, Versatile Way to Record Your Life
abstract: GoPro’s latest camera, the GoPro Hero 3+, has a longer battery life and higher-resolution camera than its predecessors.
lead_paragraph: Among all the vast booths at the International CES displaying 4K televisions and devices by big names like Sony and Panasonic was GoPro, a versatile digital-camera maker that was mostly unheard of just a few years ago.

headline: Government Owes 30,000 Indians Royalties for Land but Can’t Find Them
abstract: Rural life on sprawling reservations has complicated efforts to track down tens of thousands of Indians who are eligible for federal payments.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Ervin Chavez remembers hearing talk around the Navajo reservation when he was young of money owed to American Indian families by the federal government for land debts.

headline: Why Bankers Have Gotten a Pass
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Deferred Prosecution Agreements', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Ponzi and Pyramid Schemes', 'Editorials']
abstract: A federal judge asks why no one has been prosecuted when there is a widespread conclusion that fraud at every level permeated the bubble in mortgage-backed securities.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, it has become increasingly clear that no prominent banker would be prosecuted for fraud in the run-up to the financial crisis. In the current issue of The New York Review of Books, Judge Jed Rakoff of the Federal District Court in Manhattan asks why.

headline: Polio Vaccination Effort in Syria Appears to Have Some Effect
keywords: ['Poliomyelitis', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The outbreak of the disease appears to have been contained halfway through an emergency vaccination effort for millions of children in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: The first polio outbreak in Syria in 14 years, which caused alarm when detected last September in the war-ravaged country, appears to have been contained halfway through an emergency vaccination effort for millions of children in the Middle East, two top World Health Organization officials said Thursday.

headline: Syria Militants Said to Recruit Visiting Americans to Attack U.S.
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: American intelligence and counterterrorism officials said Islamic extremist groups were trying to identify, recruit and train Westerners to carry out attacks when they returned home.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Islamic extremist groups in Syria with ties to Al Qaeda are trying to identify, recruit and train Americans and other Westerners who have traveled there to get them to carry out attacks when they return home, according to senior American intelligence and counterterrorism officials.

headline: Knicks and Heat Offer a Contrast in Franchises and Stars
abstract: LeBron James learned from his experience signing with the Heat to focus on the present. Carmelo Anthony, by contrast, has taken the opposite approach, saying he wants to be a free agent.
lead_paragraph: LeBron James learned from his most publicized mistake; Carmelo Anthony ascertained next to nothing from James’s and his own.

headline: Buying Peace of Mind With a Pistol
abstract: After a violent mugging, a young New York woman moves to Austin, Tex., in search of peace and security in “Loves Her Gun.”
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: Fitful Progress in the Antismoking Wars
abstract: Despite big gains, the decades-long fight to control tobacco use is far from won.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago this Saturday, on Jan. 11, 1964, a myth-shattering surgeon general’s report on smoking and health brushed aside years of obfuscation by tobacco companies and asserted, based on 7,000 scientific articles, that smoking caused lung cancer and was linked to other serious diseases. Those findings expanded as more data was gathered.

headline: After Chris Christie’s Performance
abstract: If the governor wants to regain any credibility, he will have to admit that he set a tone of vindictiveness.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey issued repeated apologies Thursday for the abuse of office that now threatens to undermine his political future. Though he sounded remorseful — and clearly sorry that this scandal might sink his ambitions for national office — he blamed his staff for making him a victim. Unbeknown to him, he said, they shut down lanes to the George Washington Bridge to create a four-day traffic jam to punish a local mayor who failed to endorse him in last year’s election.

headline: Sexual Assault Case Yields a Plea Deal in Missouri
abstract: Under an agreement, a former high school football player pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor in a sexual assault case whose initial investigation ended with sexual assault charges being dropped.
lead_paragraph: MARYVILLE, Mo. — A former high school football player, under an agreement with a special prosecutor, pleaded guilty here on Thursday to a misdemeanor and was sentenced to two years’ probation in a sexual assault case that drew national outrage when an initial investigation two years ago ended with the sexual assault charges being dropped.

headline: Pretty, Yes, but for Boats, Ice Can Be a Menace
abstract: The below-freezing temperatures in the area this week filled New York City’s rivers with ice, posing challenges for ferries and tour boats.
lead_paragraph: It may not be the Akademik Shokalskiy, the Russian boat recently trapped by ice in Antarctica, but the Brooklyn, a 280-ton tour boat operated by the Circle Line, has had its own troubles with frozen water this week.

headline: Splitsville, a Land of Diabolical Lawyers
abstract: The documentary “Divorce Corp.” argues that lawyers and courts collude to make divorces as expensive and drawn-out as possible.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday.
