headline: Reid’s Uncompromising Power Play in Senate Rankles Republicans
abstract: Senator Harry Reid has engaged in the greatest consolidation of congressional power since Newt Gingrich led the House, unleashing a bitterness that may derail efforts to extend unemployment insurance.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With his strong-armed change to the filibuster rule and an iron-fisted control of the Senate floor, Senator Harry Reid has engaged in the greatest consolidation of congressional power since Newt Gingrich ruled the House, unleashing a bitterness that may derail efforts to extend unemployment insurance.

headline: U.S. Considers Resuming Nonlethal Aid to Syrian Opposition
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Foreign Aid']
abstract: Officials insisted that no nonlethal supplies would be given directly to Syria’s Islamist groups, but questions remained over how to keep it from ending up in the wrong hands.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is considering the resumption of nonlethal military aid to Syria’s moderate opposition, senior administration officials said on Thursday, even if some of it ends up going to the Islamist groups that are allied with the moderates.

headline: Christie’s Apology for the Sins of His Aides and Appointees Leaves Out His Own
abstract: Governor Christie noted that many federal investigations, like the one underway about the politically motivated traffic jams in Fort Lee, fizzle out.
lead_paragraph: Another 900 pages of documents on the George Washington Bridge Tollgate-Gate are due to be published as soon as Friday, and early word is what they lack in punchiness — after all, what could top “time for some traffic problems in Fort Lee”? — they make up for in venom.

headline: A Chilean Dictator’s Secret Book Collection: Heavy on Napoleon, Light on Fiction
abstract: General Augusto Pinochet Ugarte, known for his brutal 17-year rule, amassed about 50,000 volumes for his private library, using public money.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — The Augusto Pinochet Ugarte Library, on the manicured grounds of the military academy here, welcomes visitors with an oil portrait of the Chilean dictator himself in military regalia. The painting of General Pinochet, whose government killed or disappeared more than 3,000 people and tortured nearly 40,000 others, hangs above the librarian’s desk.

headline: Deals Show M.L.S. Is No Longer an Afterthought
abstract: The move of Michael Bradley from Roma, of Serie A in Italy, to Toronto F.C. is a promising sign for Major League Soccer.
lead_paragraph: CARSON, Calif. — When Omar Gonzalez left the University of Maryland and was taken by the Los Angeles Galaxy as the third pick in the 2009 Major League Soccer draft, he had a plan: Learn the ropes of being a professional, develop his craft and, when his contract was up, head to Europe, where a bigger stage and payday awaited.

headline: The Danish Prince and His Family Drama
abstract: Bruce Ramsay’s “Hamlet” is set in an upper-class, buttoned-down home in postwar London.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: Falluja’s Fall Stuns Marines Who Fought There
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Veterans']
abstract: The bloody mission to wrest Falluja from insurgents in November 2004 meant more to the Marines than almost any other battle in the 12 years of war in Iraq and Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Adam Banotai was a 21-year-old sergeant and squad leader in the Marine Corps during the 2004 invasion of Falluja, a restive insurgent-held city in Iraq. His unit — which had seven of 17 men wounded by shrapnel or bullets in the first days of the invasion — seized control of the government center early in the campaign.

headline: In a Rare Video, Fidel Castro Surfaces
abstract: The former Cuban president made a public appearance on the 55th anniversary of the Cuban revolution.
lead_paragraph: Fidel Castro, the former president of Cuba, made his first public appearance in nine months on Wednesday night at the opening of a nonprofit art studio in the Romerillo neighborhood of Havana.

headline: Promising Drug Trial Lifts Stock of Intercept
abstract: The trial, which was cut short, showed that Intercept Pharmaceuticals might have a treatment for a fatty liver disease.
lead_paragraph: Shares of a small biotechnology company nearly quadrupled Thursday after a clinical trial suggested the firm might have the first effective treatment for a fatty liver disease associated with the nation’s epidemic of obesity.

headline: If Opportunity Doesn’t Knock
abstract: A stunning Friday puzzle by Patrick Berry.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLES — Ah, a grid with lots of white space. There’s nothing better than a grid with lots of room to stretch out, except possibly a Patrick Berry grid with lots of room to stretch out.

headline: Wall Street Predicts $50 Billion Bill to Settle U.S. Mortgage Suits
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: Using an analysis based on a settlement paid in the residential mortgage crisis by JPMorgan Chase, the banking industry calculated what the rest of the banks might pay.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street could pay nearly $50 billion to buy peace from federal authorities who are taking aim at the banks over their role in the mortgage crisis, according to interviews and a confidential analysis of the industry’s potential legal exposure.

headline: Illinois: Chicago Wants Six Months to Revise Rules on Gun Sales
abstract: Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago said Thursday that he would ask a federal judge who declared the city’s ban on firearms sales unconstitutional to give lawmakers six months to adopt a new ordinance regulating gun shops.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago said Thursday that he would ask a federal judge who declared the city’s ban on firearms sales unconstitutional to give lawmakers six months to adopt a new ordinance regulating gun shops. The judge, Edmond E. Chang of the Northern District of Illinois, signaled in his decision on Monday that Chicago could still restrict gun transactions as long as they stopped short of a complete ban. “Though I fully disagree, the city has little option but to follow the ruling of the court,” Mr. Emanuel, who will not file an appeal, said in a statement. A status hearing is scheduled for next week.

headline: Christie Brings His Remorse to an Inconvenienced Borough
abstract: Traffic snarled again in Fort Lee, N.J., as the governor visited on Thursday afternoon to express his regrets.
lead_paragraph: FORT LEE, N.J. — Nobody had ever claimed that Mark Sokolich was one of the most powerful mayors in America. But on Thursday afternoon, Chris Christie, one of the most powerful governors in the country, flew to Mr. Sokolich’s borough to deliver a personal apology.

headline: Gmail Plans to Allow Google Plus Users to Send Anyone an Email
abstract: A change to Gmail that would allow people to use Google Plus to send emails even if they do not know the recipient’s email address provoked criticism from people who said they did not want their inboxes accessible by default.
lead_paragraph: Google will soon allow people to send anyone an email, even if they do not have the person’s email address, as long as both people have a Gmail and Google Plus account.

headline: Andrew Luck Is a Fan of Two Types of Football
abstract: Luck, the Colts’ quarterback, developed a passion for soccer during the 10 years he spent as a child in Germany and London, and he still follows it closely.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Andrew Luck has been preparing all week for Saturday’s A.F.C. divisional playoff game at New England against the Patriots. There have been game plans to dissect, film to study and practices to participate in to prepare for the wrinkles of a Bill Belichick defense. Then there was the football that had nothing to do with Tom Brady, Luck’s Indianapolis Colts or the game at all.

headline: More Naked Heathen Romps
abstract: “The Wicker Man” became a horror classic after enduring production troubles. A new Blu-ray version restores some footage.
lead_paragraph: You just can’t keep a good pagan cult down, although sometimes it seems as if everything colludes to do so. Take Robin Hardy’s 1973 horror classic “The Wicker Man,” now having its Blu-ray debut in a Lionsgate “Final Cut” edition. The film — about a prudish policeman’s encounters with pre-Christian Celtic practices in a remote Scottish community — has weathered numerous twists and turns in its 40-year existence, including a remake, a quasi-remake and at least three versions of varying length. But its journey concludes on a positive note, even if the film itself does not. On second thought, the film can be a little ambivalent in that department.

headline: Chemical Spill Fouls Water in West Virginia
abstract: More than 100,000 customers were without safe tap water on Thursday after a chemical used to clean coal leaked into the Elk River in Charleston, W.Va., officials said.
lead_paragraph: More than 100,000 customers were without safe tap water on Thursday after a chemical used to clean coal leaked into the Elk River in Charleston, W.Va., officials said.

headline: Christie’s Apology, Done His Way
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie said he was sorry in his characteristic style: It was excessive and vainglorious, with large, vivid and personal terms.
lead_paragraph: He was, he said, heartbroken. Embarrassed. Sad. Disappointed. Humiliated.

headline: Police Scrutinize Pensions; 6 More Arraigned in Fraud
keywords: ['Social Security (US)', 'Disability Insurance', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: Internal Affairs detectives will be reviewing claims of line-of-duty injuries by scores of retired officers accused in a scheme to bilk Social Security.
lead_paragraph: As six more New York police officers were arraigned in state court on Thursday on charges that they feigned mental illnesses to bilk Social Security out of disability benefits, a police commander said the Police Department was scrutinizing the city pensions being paid to scores of retired officers accused in the scheme.

headline: Delays in Bidding Help Put Focus on Masahiro Tanaka
abstract: Because an expected bidding war has been delayed by new rules, confusion, infighting and counterproposals, Tanaka has become a figure of intense interest in major league baseball.
lead_paragraph: It is not just that Major League Baseball changed its rules governing how Japanese players could join North American clubs. Masahiro Tanaka and his agent will be the beneficiaries of what is set to become an unprecedented bidding war because of delays, confusion, infighting, counterproposals and more delays.

keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']

lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s plan to create a tax credit for New York renters would only begin to address an imbalance in tax policy that historically has favored homeowners over tenants in the state, housing experts said.

lead_paragraph: Some 800 monuments — like busts and statues of people and animals; memorial benches; and historic plaques — are sprinkled throughout the five boroughs, memorializing the household names of the past. But their fame may have faded with time. Lisa W. Foderaro of The Times has written a guide to some of the more obscure historical markers that dot the city.

headline: Signs of Abuse in Toddler’s Death, but Few Warnings
abstract: The police said that Myls Dobson had been in the care of Kryzie King, a family friend he barely knew, who has been charged with assault and reckless endangerment.
lead_paragraph: By age 4, Myls Dobson knew the dislocation of family court hearings and custody fights. He also knew the love of grandparents and aunts. His smiling face beamed from Facebook, a healthy toddler full of promise, dressed up in ties or posing by a courthouse in Manhattan.

headline: Prokhorov Will See Different Nets Team in London Than in Brooklyn
abstract: With the owner Mikhail D. Prokhorov watching the Nets’ home opener in November, they beat the Heat. But changes have occurred leading to their game against the Hawks next week at O2 Arena.
lead_paragraph: Mikhail D. Prokhorov, the Nets’ owner, is planning to attend the team’s game against the Atlanta Hawks next Thursday at O2 Arena in London, a club spokesman said. It will be the first time Prokhorov has attended a Nets game since Nov. 1, when he watched his team’s home opener against the Miami Heat at Barclays Center. The Nets won that game, a misleading prelude given how the season has played out.

The contest underscores the diversity of the Houston district in a state where Asian-Americans are the fastest-growing race or ethnic group.

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13) RICHARD TUCKER AT 100: AN OPERA CELEBRATION Isabel Leonard, above, the winner of the 2013 Richard Tucker Award, and a roster including Stephanie Blythe, Stephen Costello, Joyce DiDonato, Renée Fleming, Susan Graham and Eric Owens perform works by Verdi, Rossini, Donizetti, Puccini and Offenbach, accompanied by the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra and the New York Choral Society. Writing in The New York Times about this gala, held Nov. 17 at Avery Fisher Hall and presented here by “Live From Lincoln Center,” Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim commended the “stellar lineup,” including the “exquisite” Ms. Leonard and the “silken soprano” of Ms. Fleming. She added, “It was perhaps revealing of the confidence of both these artists — at very different stages of their career — that their repertory choices lay outside the operatic mainstream.”

abstract: Called a “kung fu-Appalachian avant folk-rock” band, the Wu-Force combine musical traditions from East and West, pairing a banjo with a Chinese zither.
lead_paragraph: The beauty of being dubbed a “kung fu-Appalachian avant folk-rock” group is there’s little risk of feeling musically pigeonholed.

headline: As Indian Diplomat Exits After Arrest, a Culture Clash Lingers
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations', 'Domestic Service']
abstract: Devyani Khobragade’s return to India represented a possible resolution of a case that has harmed the United States’ ties with New Delhi.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Two dozen revved-up television crews were clustered outside a V.I.P. exit at Indira Gandhi International Airport on Friday, waiting for the flight from New York. They had been in place for two hours, and every time a trickle of passengers came into view, they all jumped up and pressed their cameras against the glass.

headline: Who Made That Dial Tone?
abstract: The replacement for Bell System’s corps of “hello girls.”
lead_paragraph: “Remove the Receiver from the hook,” read a notice in The Norfolk Ledger-Dispatch in 1919, “and listen for a steady humming sound, known as the ‘Dial Tone.’ If you hear the dial tone, place your finger in the hole containing the first figure of the number to be called and pull the dial as far as it will go. . . .” (An accompanying article described the noise as being “like the buzzing of a bumble bee or other large insect.”)

headline: Jared Diamond: ‘New Guinean Kids Are Not Brats’
abstract: The author of “The World Until Yesterday” on what we can learn from traditional societies.
lead_paragraph: Your latest book, “The World Until Yesterday,” is about traditional societies and your research in New Guinea. Why is the acronym Weird central to the book?  In Weird — Western, Educated, Industrialized, Rich and Democratic — societies we take these things for granted that just didn’t exist anywhere in the world until a few thousand years ago. We encounter strangers, and it’s normal, and we don’t freak out and try to kill them. We eat food that somebody else grew for us. We have a government with police and lawyers to settle disputes.

headline: Is Uber’s Surge-Pricing an Example of High-Tech Gouging?
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: Technological efficiency doesn’t necessarily mean lower fares.
lead_paragraph: At 10 p.m. on New Year’s Eve, I hailed a taxi outside my apartment in Adams Morgan and directed it to a friend’s apartment in Shaw, a nearby neighborhood, also in Northwest Washington. It took a mere minute to find an open car, and the traffic-clogged two-mile trip cost $13, including tip.

headline: The Flying Tomato Would Rather You Not Call Him That Anymore
abstract: Shaun White cut his hair, changed his clothes and became a businessman. Now if only he could master that pesky triple cork.
lead_paragraph: Shaun White sat in a lawn chair on the side of the mountain at Northstar California, a ski resort near Lake Tahoe, trying to think of a nice way to ask one of the young men grooming the hill to shovel some snow up onto the air bag, please. White was there in April to learn a triple cork 1440, a snowboarding trick that requires flipping three times in the air while moving through three different planes — horizontal, lateral and vertical — all while doing four 360-degree spins. Landing a triple cork is considered essential to winning slopestyle, a snowboarding event that will debut in the Olympic Games next month and that involves riding down a course filled with jumps and rails, sort of like those in a skateboard park. Because White had not yet mastered the triple cork, he needed to practice the trick by crash-landing into a giant yellow air bag. Judging from his emphatic cursing, the impact felt horrible.

headline: Care of: My Wife’s Lover’s Neighbor
abstract: Unwanted items: one precious, one lurid.
lead_paragraph: I received an envelope that was addressed to my home but did not include a name. I recognized the last name on the return-address label. I opened the envelope and realized it was intended for my neighbor, a woman I have known, along with her husband, for many years. The letter chronicled the dates and locations of an affair the sender claimed his wife was having with my neighbor’s husband. I regret reading the letter. Upon looking more closely at the envelope, I was able to discern my neighbor’s name (the wife) and the words “private and confidential,” but these were obscured by the postmark. It seems the sender intentionally sent the letter to my home to keep the husband from intercepting it, counting on me to deliver it to the wife. Now that the envelope is open, the neighbors will know that I have read the allegations. What is my obligation: To deliver the letter or to inform the sender that this plan didn’t go as intended? NAME WITHHELD

headline: We Didn’t Eat the Marshmallow. The Marshmallow Ate Us.
abstract: How a simple experiment about impulse control became a seductive gospel truth.
lead_paragraph: In a series of famous experiments in the 1960s and ’70s conducted by the Stanford psychologist Walter Mischel, preschoolers were invited to sit alone in a room furnished only with a small desk. On the desk sat two marshmallows (or equivalently tempting treats) and a bell. The researcher told each child that he had to leave, but that when he returned, she could eat both marshmallows. If she wanted one marshmallow before then, however, she could ring the bell and eat one, but not both. Then the researcher shut the door, leaving the child alone with the forbidden marshmallows.

headline: No Puff Piece
abstract: Sweet or savory, pâte à choux is easier than it looks. Really.
lead_paragraph: A friend who almost never cooks recently made gougères — baked puff pastries with cheese. “I could not believe how easy that was,” he told me. In fact, I can’t think of anything as impressive that needs so little work.

headline: The Murderer and the Manuscript
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: The winner of the novel-writing contest was a complete unknown, right down to the fact that he was serving a life sentence.
lead_paragraph: Just before Labor Day in 2011, Toni Kirkpatrick, an editor at Thomas Dunne Books, an imprint of St. Martin’s Press, picked up her phone and called an unfamiliar number with a Southern California area code. She was hoping to deliver good news to a man named Alaric Hunt, the newest winner of a debut-detective-novel writing contest, jointly sponsored by Minotaur Books (another St. Martin’s imprint) and the Private Eye Writers of America. The contest has a good track record — a past winner, Michael Koryta, a 21-year-old phenom, has since published 10 successful thrillers — and it also comes with a substantial prize: a $10,000 advance and a guaranteed publishing contract for the book that has been submitted.

headline: Fruits of the Loom
abstract: The nearly lost art of American textile manufacturing.
lead_paragraph: In 1776, America didn’t have a single textile mill. There were no spinning mules, no water-powered looms. There were only rumors of what such things might look like and a few nonfunctioning models built from those rumors. Nearly every American woman, except the wealthiest, knew how to spin her own yarn and weave her own cloth, even as across the Atlantic women were moving out of the home and into millwork as England — bent on protecting its export market by safeguarding its trade secrets — industrialized the manufacturing of textiles.

headline: Rosanne Cash Goes Home
abstract: She spent half a lifetime trying to escape the shadow of her famous father. But for her latest album, she went back to the South.
lead_paragraph: On an icy December morning, Rosanne Cash was making tea in the kitchen of the Chelsea brownstone she shares with her husband, the producer-songwriter-guitarist John Leventhal, and their 14-year-old son, Jakob. Her 25-year-old daughter Carrie, also a singer and the youngest of three children that Cash had with her ex-husband, the singer-songwriter Rodney Crowell, was also staying there for a while. It was a full house, and Cash seemed to like it that way. Carrie appeared from a downstairs bedroom to ask Cash to help her find the “save the date” cards she wanted to get in the mail for her May wedding to Dan Knobler, a guitarist and producer. Mother and daughter moved around a partly finished jigsaw puzzle on a nearby table, and Cash began looking through a cabinet, pausing to answer a phone call from a close friend, the former New Yorker TV critic Nancy Franklin. Soon the cards were found, and Carrie was off to address them.

headline: Big in Japan
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Here, I was just another writer. Over there, I was a star.
lead_paragraph: You might not know me, but I’m famous. Don’t feel bad. Until recently, I didn’t know I was famous either, and most days, even now, it’s hard to tell.

headline: Pictures of Men, Friends or Lovers
abstract: A collection of images of African-American men together, from the Civil War to the present, challenges modern discomfort with male intimacy, sexual or otherwise.
lead_paragraph: Trent Kelley wondered how he could study the history of African-American gay men when so many of them had lived their lives in relative secrecy. He found his answer in vintage photographs — which he began to collect on eBay, at flea markets and at estate sales — which depict everything from urban dandies and workers to athletes and soldiers.

headline: How Closely Do You Listen to Lyrics?
abstract: Do you often find meaning or inspiration in lyrics, or are you more interested in the music or beat?
lead_paragraph: Do you often find meaning or inspiration in lyrics, or are you more interested in the music or beat?

headline: Times Minute | Falluja Vets Watch Iraq
abstract: Also on the Minute, the poet Amiri Baraka dies and an influx of awards shows.
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, the poet Amiri Baraka dies and an influx of awards shows.

headline: Times Minute | Falluja Veterans Watch Iraq
abstract: Also on the Minute, the poet Amiri Baraka dies and an influx of awards shows.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Chinese Online Game Offers Chance to Blast Corruption
abstract: “Beat Corruption,” which lets players zap greedy officials, was released amid a push to eradicate government corruption and curb a culture of extravagant gift-giving among officials.
lead_paragraph: The website of People’s Daily, the mouthpiece of China’s Communist Party, has released “Beat Corruption,” an online game that allows players to fight graft by zapping greedy officials. Players win points by using their mouse to blast bad guys with a Taser and lose points by targeting virtuous police officers.

headline: New York Today: New at the Zoo
abstract: What you need to know for Friday and the weekend: a parade of animal oddities, soggy weather and the mayor goes to Staten Island.
lead_paragraph: Updated 11:07 a.m.

headline: N.F.L. Divisional Playoff Matchups
abstract: Seattle, which went 13-3 this season, is the favorite in Saturday’s game against New Orleans, especially after embarrassing the Saints in a 34-7 win in Week 13.
lead_paragraph: Saints at Seahawks

headline: The Well Smoking Quiz: Who Looks Older?
abstract: A new study provides photographic evidence for the claim that smoking ages a person prematurely.
lead_paragraph: We know that smoking is bad for you, and that it ages you prematurely. Now, a study provides photographic evidence for this claim.

headline: Striving to Be the Berkshire Hathaway of China
abstract: Fosun International is plain about its ambition to emulate Warren Buffett’s investment firm, buying companies at home and abroad. Its latest deal is for Portugal’s largest insurance company.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Fosun International aspires to be China’s answer to Warren E. Buffett’s investment firm, Berkshire Hathaway, and it wants to be sure everyone knows it.

headline: The Kugel Family: Big in Brazil
abstract: How did our Thanksgiving photo end up on a 15-foot ad in the Amazon?
lead_paragraph: IT’S not every day that your family photo appears on a 15-foot storefront sign in the Brazilian Amazon.

headline: London Looks
abstract: As the fashion show season moves on to Milan, some images from the autumn 2014 shows in the British capital.
lead_paragraph: As the fashion show season moves on to Milan, some images from the autumn 2014 shows in the British capital.

headline: A Tie That Binds Across Cultures
abstract: Chiyoko and Bob Bermant met as graduate students when he helped her with English. They married and have been inseparable ever since.
lead_paragraph: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more. Send us your story and photos through our submission form.

headline: Ireland's Rebound Is European Blarney
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Once the Celtic Tiger, the Irish economy has been severely chastened by austerity.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — I was talking just before Christmas to a young man who sells shoes in a department store in Dublin. He told me that a television news crew had filmed interviews in the store the previous day. They wanted to know if sales were picking up during the vital holiday period, indicating that the battered Irish economy was, after five grim years, on the rise at last.

headline: Daily Report: Seeking New Ways to Make Computer Chips
abstract: Scientists are looking for new ways to make computer chips and investigating materials that can self-assemble.
lead_paragraph: More than ever recently, industry pundits have been warning that the progress of the semiconductor industry is grinding to a halt — and that the theory of Gordon E. Moore, an Intel co-founder, has run its course, John Markoff reports.

headline: Top Tennis Players Join Forces With Former Champions
abstract: Former champions are flocking to coach today’s tennis stars like never before, including Boris Becker joining Novak Djokovic’s team and Roger Federer hiring Stefan Edberg.
lead_paragraph: Tennis royalty has coached tennis royalty before.

headline: IPad Is an Artist’s Canvas for David Hockney
abstract: A David Hockney exhibition at the de Young Museum in San Francisco includes iPad drawings made by the artist, who has long been interested in using new technology in art.
lead_paragraph: Stand before a huge image of Yosemite by David Hockney and see the artist’s rendition of wispy clouds hovering over midnight blue mountains. Look closer and see strokes drawn by a stylus on an iPad, and pixels from an inkjet printer.

headline: British Regulators Said to Prepare Charges Against Ex-Trader
keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Insider Trading', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Julian Rifat, a former trader arrested nearly four years ago in a crackdown on insider trading in London, is expected to face criminal charges in the coming weeks, according to a person familiar with the matter.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — British regulators are preparing to bring criminal charges against Julian Rifat, a former trader arrested nearly four years ago in what was then described as the largest crackdown on insider trading here, according to a person familiar with the matter.

headline: New Detail Emerges About Bo Xilai’s Downfall
abstract: A new article says John Garnaut, a prominent Australian reporter based in Beijing for the Sydney Morning Herald, was called in to act as the interpreter for Wang Lijun, the former Chongqing police chief who reported his suspicion that Bo Xilai’s wife had murdered the British businessman Neil Heywood.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Bo Xilai, the Communist Party aristocrat, was given a sentence of life in prison last September on charges of corruption, very little in the way of new details about his downfall have emerged. But this week, a Chinese magazine, Sanlian Life, published a 31­-page cover story on Mr. Bo’s youngest son, Bo Guagua, a favorite focus of gossip in China. He is currently a first-year student at Columbia Law School and has been spotted at social gatherings in Manhattan.

headline: The Zombie Confidence Fairy
abstract: Things serious people believe.
lead_paragraph: OK, and I’m more or less back on duty, although next week I’ll be busy in Ireland. But time to weigh in again on a few things.

headline: Mumbai’s International Airport Gets Modern Makeover
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Airport Security', 'AIRPORTS', 'Bridges and Tunnels', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Parking', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Stations and Terminals (Passenger)']
abstract: The addition of Terminal 2 is Chhatrapati Shivaji International Airport’s first major upgrade in nearly 30 years.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — For anyone who has traveled through the shiny airport hubs of Asia like Hong Kong and Singapore, flying into Chhatrapati Shivaji International Airport in Mumbai can deliver quite a shock.

headline: An Affair? France Shrugs, but Its Leader Calls for Privacy
abstract: President François Hollande condemned a glossy French tabloid, Closer, for publishing pictures it says show that he had met with a French actress.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The photographs show a stout man of middling height striding out of an ordinary-looking Parisian apartment house, a helmet and a dark visor obscuring his face. He gets on a motorized scooter and zooms away into the Eighth Arrondissement.

headline: The Medicaid Cure
abstract: It’s a really good program.
lead_paragraph: Something really interesting is happening on the health-care front: costs are rising much less rapidly than anyone expected. This is good news for the budget; it’s also good news for Obamacare. There was much skepticism about promises that health reform would “bend the curve”, reducing cost growth; well, the curve is bending, and it’s likely that the cost control measures that are part of Obamacare (and have been in effect for several years) are part of the reason.

headline: Changes in Windows 8.1, With Skype Replacing Messaging App
abstract: A summary of differences in the latest Windows upgrade, and how to share files between Apple devices.
lead_paragraph: Meeting the New Messenger in Windows 8.1

headline: Today in Small Business: Celebrity Business Failures
abstract: Super Bowl commercials are ineffective. Tough questions for job candidates. Why YouTube videos fail.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Central African Leader’s Exit Sets Off Rejoicing in the Streets
abstract: Michel Djotodia, the Central African Republic’s president, quit under pressure after regional leaders held him responsible for failing to halt continuing sectarian violence in the country.
lead_paragraph: BANGUI, Central African Republic — Joyful crowds poured onto the streets of this capital on Friday after the president of the strife-torn Central African Republic resigned under pressure from regional leaders.

headline: A Child’s Vote for New York
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A little girl’s happiness provided the perfect touch in a crowded intersection on a cold, busy Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Wong Kar-wai on ‘The Grandmaster’
abstract: The director discusses why he took on a martial arts film, why he shortened it for American audiences and what it’s like being a newcomer to the Oscar process at 55.
lead_paragraph: The Hong Kong director Wong Kar-wai is a global art-house favorite, best known for lushly photographed dramas about romantic loss or frustration, like “In the Mood for Love.” So there some oddity in the fact that when he finally made it onto the shortlist for the Oscar for best foreign-language film, it should be with a kung fu biopic called “The Grandmaster.”

headline: Growth in Jobs Slows Sharply to 3-Year Low
abstract: In December, employers added just 74,000 jobs, the slowest pace of growth in three years and far below the expectations of many economists who had grown convinced that the market was on a more solid footing.
lead_paragraph: Just when it seemed as if the economy was finally accelerating, the latest employment figures once again confounded expectations of better days ahead.

headline: Banks Brace for Reckoning
abstract: Fines for banks’ role in mortgage crisis could total nearly $50 billion, not including JPMorgan’s settlement. | Ex-SAC trader falsified grades at Harvard. | A storied Washington law firm looks to merge. | Snapchat says sorry.
lead_paragraph: When the dust has settled on investigations into the role of banks in the mortgage crisis, fines could total nearly $50 billion, and that does not include the $13 billion that JPMorgan Chase agreed to pay, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Peter Eavis report in DealBook. Put into context, the $50 billion would equal roughly half the total annual profit of large American banks in 2012.

headline: The Making Of | Folkert de Jong’s Synthetic, Sculptural Costumes for the Wooster Group
abstract: The Dutch artist crafted expressionistic, wearable art inspired by Native American tradition for the performance troupe’s new work, “Cry, Trojans!”
lead_paragraph: For the past decade, the Dutch artist Folkert de Jong has gained international recognition for eerily beautiful figurative sculptures made from materials like plastic, polyurethane and bronze. He’s shown at biennales in Sydney and Kiev, is in the permanent collection at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, has a show through early April at Antwerp’s Middelheim Museum and will have his work on exhibit this year at the Armory Show and at James Cohan Gallery. He also has upcoming solo shows in Paris, Milan and Wakefield, England.

headline: Thousands Without Water After Spill in West Virginia
abstract: As 300,000 people learned that their tap water was unsafe, residents and businesses expressed a mix of anger and anxiety in coping with the industrial accident.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — As 300,000 people awoke on Friday to learn that their tap water was unsafe for brushing teeth, brewing coffee or showering, residents and businesses expressed a mix of anger and anxiety in coping with an industrial accident with no clear end in sight.

headline: In Blow to Peace Effort, Israel Publishes Plans for New Housing in Settlements
abstract: A Palestinian negotiator called the plan for 1,400 units in East Jerusalem and the West Bank a “slap” to a peace deal.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli government on Friday published plans to build 1,400 housing units in Jewish settlements in East Jerusalem and the West Bank, a move the chief Palestinian negotiator condemned as a “slap” to Secretary of State John Kerry’s intense push for a Middle East peace deal.

headline: For Target, the Breach Numbers Grow
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Credit Cards', 'Debit Cards']
abstract: The retailer disclosed that the hackers stole a broader trove of data than originally reported, including mailing and email addresses, phone numbers and names.
lead_paragraph: Target on Friday revised the number of customers whose personal information was stolen in a widespread data breach during the holiday season, now reporting a range of 70 million to 110 million people.

headline: Carlyle Hires UBS Executive for Market Strategies Group
abstract: Boris Okuliar, recently a managing director at UBS, is joining Carlyle as head of capital markets in the firm’s global market strategies group. Carlyle is best known for private equity deals, but its market strategies business is also a major focus.
lead_paragraph: The Carlyle Group, the big alternative investment firm based in Washington, has hired a UBS executive to bolster its capital markets expertise.

headline: How Do You Motivate Your Teenager to Get Moving in the Cold?
abstract: Looking for experienced parents who know how to keep a sedentary teenager moving year round.
lead_paragraph: If the polar vortex had you hibernating, how has it affected your teenager? The open discussion on the New Parent, Old Parent collaboration between Motherlode and Booming is how to get a teen who is disinclined toward activity to get moving, especially in the winter when outdoor fun may be less appealing. I asked parents who have successfully nudged a less-than-enthusiastic teenager out of the house and into exercise to weigh in.

headline: The Employment Rate’s New Normal
abstract: Since a big drop after the recession, the share of American with jobs has failed to rebound, and was no higher in 2013 than the previous year.
lead_paragraph: The share of Americans with jobs did not increase in 2013. The economy added about 182,000 jobs a month, just enough to keep pace with population growth.

headline: Suzanne Vega Has Her Own Issues With ‘Llewyn Davis’
abstract: The musician says the film lacks the optimism that she recalls from the folk scene.
lead_paragraph: The irate folkies – a group that actually exists – will be paying close attention to how “Inside Llewyn Davis” fares at the Golden Globes on Sunday, and on the awards circuit beyond. “My hunch is that if the film gets a bunch of Oscar noms — especially if it gets a nom for best picture — the dust-up won’t go away,” wrote Christine Lavin, the singer-songwriter who has been on a mission to clarify some things about what she believes the Coen brothers’ portrait of the 1960s Greenwich Village folk scene got wrong. “Maybe it will become a haboob?” she added. “Love that word.”

headline: In Our Pages: January 11
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune
lead_paragraph: 1914: Bleak Week for Fleet Street

headline: New York Times Features Every Teacher Should Know About
abstract: Our list of lesser-known Times features that regularly yield rich material for teaching and learning, categorized by subject area. What would you add?
lead_paragraph: One example of the new Science Take video series.

headline: In Life and Business, Learning to Be Ethical
abstract: Most people, if pressed, would acknowledge that when it comes to ethics, they could use a tuneup.
lead_paragraph: LOTS of New Year’s resolutions are being made — and no doubt ignored — at this time of year. But there’s one that’s probably not even on many lists and should be: Act more ethically.

headline: ‘Paranoia Is the Mother-in-Law of Invention,’ Puppet Accused of Terror in Egypt Tells BBC
abstract: In an English-language interview with the British Broadcasting Corporation on Friday, the Egyptian puppet recently accused of acting as a terrorist mouthpiece protested her innocence.
lead_paragraph: In an English-language interview with the BBC on Friday, the Egyptian puppet recently accused of acting as a terrorist mouthpiece protested her innocence. The puppet, Abla Fahita, rejected allegations from a pro-military blogger that unseen hands had manipulated her into sending coded instructions to Islamist terrorists during an ad for a phone company.

headline: Debating Why the Work Force Is Shrinking
abstract: With the share of Americans in the labor force at a low, the challenge is sorting out how many are shuffling into retirement and how many have abandoned hope of finding jobs.
lead_paragraph: People keep leaving the labor force. The share of Americans either working or looking for work sank to 62.8 percent in December, tying October for the lowest level since 1977 – an era when women were much less likely to work.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: KURT VONNEGUT: Letters,  edited by Dan Wakefield. (Dial, $20.) Written over a 60-year period, these letters display all the hallmarks of Vonnegut’s fiction — smart, hilarious and heartbreaking. It includes chilling descriptions of the Allied firebombing of Dresden and Vonnegut’s time as a P.O.W.; wry dispatches from his years as a struggling writer; and words of commiseration and encouragement to contemporaries like Norman Mailer and Bernard Malamud.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: ON SUCH A FULL SEA,  by Chang-rae Lee. (Riverhead, $27.95.) Lee abandons realist fiction in this marvelous dystopian fantasy, set in an almost familiar future world. But he continues to grapple with themes of hope and betrayal.

headline: Image of the Day: January 10
abstract: The International Kite Festival in Dhordo, Gujarat.

headline: Hitting the Road
abstract: Punk rockers and a pair of misfits unite for cross-country trips in two young adult novels.
lead_paragraph: In Len Vlahos’s debut novel, the Scar Boys are a punk band from Yonkers that hits the road riding a rusty van and working out personal problems while playing gigs in college towns as far south as Georgia. “Music to the rescue,” muses Harry, the book’s narrator. Playing and touring demand creativity and commitment, forcing the Scar Boys — actually three guys and a girl — to come of age in this wry, stylish tale.

headline: The Making of the Presidents
abstract: In poetry and prose, these books shed light on the fascinating, complicated lives of our commanders in chief.
lead_paragraph: “Away back in my childhood, the earliest days of my being able to read,” Abraham Lincoln nostalgically remembered on the eve of his first inauguration, “I got hold of a small book. . . . Weems’ ‘Life of Washington.’ ” The future president never forgot its vivid accounts of the battles and heroes of the Revolutionary War, not to mention the causes for which the founders fought. “I recollect thinking then, boy even though I was,” he reminisced, “that there must have been something more than common that those men struggled for.” The book’s stories “fixed themselves on my memory,” he proudly added, acknowledging that “these early impressions last longer than any others.”

headline: Unbridled
abstract: In two middle-grade novels, horses possess fantastical abilities, including the power of speech.
lead_paragraph: The cherished bond between humans and horses is celebrated in many beloved children’s books, from “National Velvet” to “War Horse.” But when the real connection is already palpable, why do writers take their horse stories deeply into the realm of the imaginary? Two new books for middle-grade readers use different approaches to the equestrian genre to explore these fantasies.

headline: Line of Fire
abstract: The daughter of a traumatized war veteran must care for her father and survive senior year in Laurie Halse Anderson’s novel.
lead_paragraph: Beginning with the publication of her award-winning young adult novel “Speak” in 1999, Laurie Halse Anderson has written with honesty and grit, bravely shedding light on such once-taboo topics as rape, eating disorders, suicide and addiction. In doing so, she has helped build the current landscape of contemporary young adult literature. Anderson writes the hard truth, stirring debate and discussion among both fans and objectors, and ultimately creating long overdue conversations about the real issues teenagers face every day.

headline: Poems, Protests and Prayers
abstract: James Parker joins the list of Bookends contributors.
lead_paragraph: Over the next few weeks, we welcome three new writers to our roster of Bookends contributors: James Parker, Thomas Mallon and Leslie Jamison. Parker, who makes his initial appearance this week, is a contributing editor at The Atlantic, where he has written about everyone from Norman Rockwell and Martin Amis to Charlie Sheen and the lead singer of the 1980s hair-metal band Ratt. He was a staff writer at The Boston Phoenix and in 2008 won a Deems Taylor Award for music criticism from the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers.

headline: The ‘Wolf’ Is Still Bending the Truth, Prosecutors Say
abstract: Jordan Belfort, who is bathing in the publicity of “The Wolf of Wall Street,” says he is doing everything he can to make investors whole. The government is skeptical.
lead_paragraph: Jordan Belfort, the author of two books about his life as the rapacious “Wolf of Wall Street” and now a prominent motivational speaker, is sending mixed messages, federal prosecutors say.

headline: Global Warming
abstract: New books by William Nordhaus, Linda Marsa, Christopher White and J. B. MacKinnon.
lead_paragraph: THE CLIMATE CASINORisk, Uncertainty, and Economics for a Warming WorldBy William NordhausYale University, $30.

headline: A Southern Landscape
abstract: At 92, the novelist and short-story writer Elizabeth Spencer remains a distinguished regional voice.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Spencer published her first novel in 1948. Seven more followed, along with five volumes of short stories and the novella “The Light in the Piazza.” There would also be a play and an exquisite memoir. Now there is a new book of stories, “Starting Over.” Given that Spencer is 92, it’s tempting to call the title audacious, but since there seems to be nothing this extraordinary writer can’t do, maybe she’s just being realistic.

headline: The Music Gene
abstract: In Richard Powers’s novel, a composer’s experiment with sound and microbiology attracts the attention of Homeland Security.
lead_paragraph: Is it premature to talk of the “Powers Problem”? For the last three decades, Richard Powers has been bringing out hefty novels at the rate of one every 2.5 years: 11 in all. At his current age of 56, he is, as a novelist, midway on life’s path; presumably he has another 11 or so novels still in him. Powers has won a National Book Award and has been a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize; he has been the recipient of a MacArthur “genius grant”; he has elicited lavish praise from the critics — most of them, anyway. Two of the words most frequently employed in connection with his literary output are “cerebral” and “ambitious.” “Cerebral” refers to his tendency to lace his novels with scientific and scholarly themes, like artificial intelligence in “Galatea 2.2,” game theory in “Prisoner’s Dilemma” and musicology cum genetic recombination in “The Gold Bug Variations.” “Ambitious” refers to his penchant for fashioning narrative structures and symbolic networks on a heroic scale.

headline: The There There
abstract: Diane Johnson, who writes frequently about France, discovers the appeal of her native Midwest.
lead_paragraph: As a diminutive child growing up in the “landlocked Illinois” town of Moline, where John Deere built his plow-and-­tractor empire, Diane Johnson (author of the popular novel “Le Divorce,” among other books about Americans abroad) dreamed of a life of adventure, “preferably at sea, before the mast.” She fled the Flyover (as coastal sophisticates call the Midwest), first to New York, where she was part of the same cohort of aspiring college students at Mademoiselle magazine that Sylvia Plath recorded in “The Bell Jar,” then to her first marriage to a doctor in California and finally to France, where she now spends much of her time. “The one thing you, we, Americans, are not allowed to say is that there is somewhere better than America to live,” she writes, confidently having found “one of the better places.”

headline: Flying Through the Air
abstract: The snowboarder Shaun White practices at Northstar California, a ski resort near Lake Tahoe in preparation for the Olympic Games in Sochi, Russia in February.
lead_paragraph: The snowboarder Shaun White practices at Northstar California, a ski resort near Lake Tahoe in preparation for the Olympic Games in Sochi, Russia in February.

headline: Life in Transit
abstract: Elisabeth de Waal’s novel of betrayal and loss in postwar Vienna.
lead_paragraph: Elisabeth de Waal’s posthumously published novel takes place in the aftermath of some of the 20th century’s greatest calamities, as it follows Austrian exiles returning to their homeland to encounter a dramatically altered physical and psychological landscape. By 1954, when the action of the novel begins, Vienna has witnessed not only the dissolution of the Austro-Hungarian Empire but the Anschluss and Hitler’s reign of terror against the Jewish population, as well as repeated bombings during World War II and simultaneous occupation by four victorious foreign powers. Written during the late 1950s, “The Exiles Return” has an immediacy that makes de Waal’s readers feel the experiences of its characters in a visceral way.

headline: Islanders
abstract: An unexpected arrival stirs memories of war.
lead_paragraph: If there were a prize for ornery old men, the ornithologist Jim Kennoway in Alice Greenway’s novel “The Bird Skinner” would trounce every recluse in New England. Refusing help from his remarkably well-­adjusted son and incredibly patient neighbors, he’s drinking and smoking himself to death on an island in Maine. Trudging along in this Lear-like existence — “Wintertime, Jesus Christ, he lived like a bear” — he’s taken by surprise by the ebullient Cadillac, a remarkable young woman from the Solomon Islands who comes to stay with him before studying medicine at Yale. (Thirty years prior, stationed in the Solomons during the Second World War, Jim befriended Cadillac’s father, with whom he has since lost all contact.) If this premise sounds familiar — striking young woman brings hope to forsaken old man — the style with which Greenway weaves her tale of memory and loss is bracing in its restraint.

headline: A Vengeful Fury
abstract: Greg Grandin tells the story of the slave uprising that inspired Melville’s “Benito Cereno.”
lead_paragraph: Between the early 16th century and the middle of the 19th, more than 12 million human beings were shipped against their will from Africa to the New World and sold into slavery. An untold number died at different stages of the journey — overland in Africa, during the “middle passage” at sea or soon after arrival. Among those who perished, most died of disease, some by suicide and still others from wounds or execution following failed revolts.

headline: Mystical Pizza
abstract: In Rachel Cantor’s novel, rival fast-food factions pursue philosophical truths.
lead_paragraph: In a not-too-distant future, in a world much like our own, a young man sits in a white room, answering a white phone, listening. In his world, fast-food chains and political philosophies are one. Jack-o-Bites chefs and Whiggery Piggery employees brawl with kebab sticks in the public square, and neo-Baconians keep safe houses to protect themselves from the Cathars at the Strawberry Parfait. At the center of it all, Leonard, a customer-service rep for a Pythagorean pizza company, must save the world by time traveling and speaking to historical figures through the Neetsa Pizza support line.

headline: Dear Sasha, Dear Volodya
abstract: In a postmodern Russian epistolary novel, two lovers are separated both by distance and by time.
lead_paragraph: Contemporary Russia is short on pleasant surprises, but one is its formidable audience not only for the trashy novels prohibited by the Soviets but also for aggressively untraditional work. In the West, the phrase “Russian literature” typically conjures standard-bearers of ­realism — Tolstoy, Chekhov — but perhaps modern Russia is too real for realism. Imagine the madcap American fabulist Barry Yourgrau as an Oprah pick, and you have an inkling of the situation in Moscow, where bookstores are thick with nihilistic postmodern hallucinations by the likes of Vladimir Sorokin, perhaps best known for a sodomy scene between clones of Khrushchev and Stalin.

headline: Campfire Girl
abstract: Chasing love at a Soviet youth camp.
lead_paragraph: In her first published story for The New Yorker, “Love Lessons Mondays, 9 A.M.,” Lara Vapnyar wrote about a painfully shy 18-year-old in Moscow, teaching sex ed to 10th-grade girls who have more experience than she does. By the end the young narrator is dating the school ­Lothario and laughing uncontrollably when one of her students asks why it’s just as arousing to kiss a boy she doesn’t like as one she does. The narrator’s answer: “I don’t know!”

headline: How Arbitration Worked, and What Happens Next
abstract: Questions and answers about Alex Rodriguez’s arbitration case.
lead_paragraph: Questions and answers in connection with Alex Rodriguez’s arbitration case and the ruling, announced Saturday, that he would be suspended for the entire 2014 season.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Jack Higgins, whose novel “The Death Trade” is No. 11 on the hardcover fiction list, does much of his writing at a restaurant near his home in the Channel Islands.
lead_paragraph: Order Now: For the first time in three weeks, there are new names on the hardcover lists — although “new” may not be the best word to describe the thriller writers W. E. B. Griffin (“Hazardous Duty,” No. 3) and Jack Higgins (“The Death Trade,” No. 11). Higgins is well known for his audacious story lines: His 1975 breakthrough, “The Eagle Has Landed,” concerned a Nazi plot to kidnap Churchill, while his 1989 best seller “A Season in Hell” imagined smugglers transporting heroin in the corpses of drowning victims. By those lights, “The Death Trade” — about a nuclear scientist forced to work for the Iranian government — seems almost workaday. Higgins’s eating habits are less colorful. “I’m notorious for liking very simple food,” he told Virgin Media in 2000. “You can take me to some of the world’s top restaurants and I’ll leave half of it on the plate. Food is not hugely important to me.” That’s not to say Higgins never dines out — a restaurant near his home in the Channel Islands doubles as his office, he explained in the same interview. “I go in at lunchtime, do two hours’ work, and then I eat,” he said. “And then in the evening I’ll go in and do three hours and then I’ll eat. I’ll write by hand and I get so absorbed it doesn’t bother me if the place is full or the music’s playing. It’s very common, particularly at night, for the waiters to come up and say, ‘Look, it’s 10 o’clock and you haven’t had anything to eat yet.’ ”

headline: Teller on Penn’s Idea, Tim’s Hypothesis and Vermeer’s Painting
abstract: The silent half of the illusionist duo has a lot to say about making a film about a hypothesis that Vermeer used optical equipment for his paintings.
lead_paragraph: The “Tim” in “Tim’s Vermeer,” shortlisted for the Oscar for best feature documentary, is Tim Jenison, an inventor and friend of the illusionists Penn and Teller. The movie grew out of a conversation Mr. Jenison had with Penn Jillette in which he casually remarked that he thought he had figured out how the 17th-century Dutch painter Johannes Vermeer was able to produce canvases so lifelike that they still mystify painters and art historians alike.

headline: The Execution of David O. Dodd
abstract: Was the 17-year-old Arkansas boy a spy, or just unlucky?
lead_paragraph: On the afternoon of Jan. 8, 1864, a crowd of 6,000 soldiers and civilians gathered on the parade grounds in front of St. John’s Masonic College in Union-occupied Little Rock, Ark. Some of the onlookers perched in trees hoping for a better view of the day’s events: the public hanging of 17-year-old David O. Dodd, a convicted Confederate spy.

headline: Chrysler to Recall Fire-Prone Jeeps to Add Trailer Hitches
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Months after announcing a plan to recall Jeep S.U.V.’s, Chrysler said it would go ahead and install trailer hitches as a fix.
lead_paragraph: After announcing a recall last June over a rear-impact collision fire hazard, Chrysler is finally preparing to recall nearly 1.6 million 1993-98 Jeep Grand Cherokees and 2002-7 Jeep Liberty S.U.V.'s. The fix the automaker is using to correct the problem – the vehicles’ fuel tanks are exposed to rear impacts – is controversial: Chrysler will install trailer hitches to protect the fuel tanks and reduce the chance of fires caused by rear-impact collisions.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Austria; California; Amsterdam
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Mozart Week, Salzburg

headline: A Desperate Plot to Boost Google Plus
abstract: Google is trying to use its dominant position in one field to push a lesser service onto unsuspecting users.
lead_paragraph: When Google launched Gmail, Internet users quickly began using the service. Same with Google Maps. But the company has struggled to get people to try Google Plus, its answer to Facebook and Twitter.

headline: Bookshelf: Friends in Fur
abstract: New picture books about bears include “Cub’s Big World,” by Sarah L. Thomson.
lead_paragraph: New picture books about bears include “Cub’s Big World,” by Sarah L. Thomson.

headline: Obama to Nominate 3 to the Board of the Fed
abstract: The nominations would replenish the board of the Federal Reserve with officials who are seen as generally supportive of the Fed’s incoming chairwoman, Janet L. Yellen.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama plans to nominate three people to the Federal Reserve’s Board of Governors, including Stanley Fischer, former head of the Bank of Israel, as the Fed’s next vice chairman, the White House said on Friday.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Empire of Necessity’
abstract: This week, Greg Grandin talks about “Empire of Necessity: Slavery, Freedom, and Deception in the New World”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Coral Davenport discusses new books about global warming; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Greg Grandin talks about “Empire of Necessity: Slavery, Freedom, and Deception in the New World”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Coral Davenport discusses new books about global warming; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: When Tourists Rescue Scientists in Antarctica
abstract: A leader of Antarctic tourist voyages in Antarctica explores the rights and responsibilities of anyone plying those icy waters.
lead_paragraph: After I covered efforts to evacuate the participants in the ice-trapped Antarctic “Spirit of Mawson” expedition, an interesting comment was posted by Ted Cheeseman, the co-owner of Cheesemans’ Ecology Safaris, which runs frequent Antarctic tourist trips. He noted that tourist ships have come to the aid of scientists on occasion, and expressed concern that I was implying that tourists have no right to visit the region. I invited him to send a “Your Dot” piece building on his comment. Here it is (I added some contextual links):

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Empire of Necessity’
abstract: This week, Greg Grandin and Coral Davenport.
lead_paragraph: This week, Greg Grandin and Coral Davenport.

headline: Times Minute | Unfinished Art
abstract: Also on the Minute, a disappointing jobs report and Shaun White gets a makeover for Sochi.
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, a disappointing jobs report and Shaun White gets a makeover for Sochi.

headline: Times Minute | Unfinished Art
abstract: Also on the Minute, a disappointing jobs report, and Shaun White gets a makeover for Sochi.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Detecting a New Season
abstract: A bumper crop of new shows (“Broad City” and “Looking”), and some worthy veterans (“Sherlock” and “House of Cards”), awaits viewers huddled before the television this winter.
lead_paragraph: The winter television season brings more significant new shows than ever this year, starting this weekend with HBO’s “True Detective” and including that network’s “Looking”; Fox’s Greg Kinnear vehicle, “Rake”; Sundance’s “Red Road”; and USA’s “Sirens,” from Denis Leary. But the big news is likely to be made by the shows that are coming back: “The Following” on Fox, “The Americans” on FX, Netflix’s “House of Cards” and, perhaps best of all, the long-awaited third season of “Sherlock” on PBS.

headline: U.S. to Recognize 1,300 Marriages Disputed by Utah
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Federal-State Relations (US)']
abstract: The decision furthered President Obama’s self-described evolution on same-sex marriage rights as his administration appeared closer to confronting a state over its refusal to recognize such rights.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Friday made the latest contribution to a fast-moving legal battle over same-sex marriage rights as the Justice Department said that the federal government would recognize as lawful the marriages of some 1,300 same-sex couples in Utah even though the state government is largely refusing to do so.

headline: Now Starring as the Jerk You Can Feel For
abstract: Greg Kinnear reflects on his twisting career trajectory as he prepares for “Rake,” a new Fox series in which he plays a deeply flawed defense lawyer.
lead_paragraph: CULVER CITY, Calif — In an early episode of the new Fox series “Rake,” the down-and-out defense lawyer Keegan Deane, a middle-aged mess of a human being played by Greg Kinnear, is asked by his ex-wife how the man she once loved, a brilliant advocate and caring father, ended up this way.

headline: Air Rights: A Cash Bonanza?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Zoning']
abstract: Annoying foot traffic intended for a dentist next door, and rules governing rent-stabilized leases are also addressed.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a new weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: The Hangover: Cantilevered Buildings of New York
abstract: Cantilevers are extending buildings sideways all over New York, establishing a new frontier for developers and disconcerting preservationists.
lead_paragraph: Casting a glance skyward in Manhattan these days may include the risk of beholding not sky but horizontal appendages that curve and jut outward from the sides of residential towers and hover like geometric mutants above the roofs of vertically challenged neighbors, inhabiting space once occupied by open air.

headline: An Odd Couple, Separated by 55 Years, but Not by Much Else
abstract: Hector Castillo, 47, and Gene Bonagur, 102, are an improbable pair, but they’ve been celebrating twice-weekly boys’ night for five years running.
lead_paragraph: It was after midnight on a recent night at Sevilla, a Spanish restaurant in the West Village, and waiters wandered the aisles, watching the last two diners finish their second pitcher of sangria.

headline: ‘Idol’ Tries to Clean Up Its Act
abstract: Hoping to stabilize a sharp ratings decline for “American Idol,” Fox changes the judging panel, brings in a new director and promises stronger singing contestants.
lead_paragraph: Another season of “American Idol” begins Wednesday; perhaps you haven’t noticed.

headline: Weill Named Chairman of Hamilton Insurance
abstract: Sandy Weill, whose financial career has spanned five decades, could be a boon to Hamilton if it decides to pursue other acquisitions.
lead_paragraph: Sandford I. Weill, the former head of Citigroup, is preparing for his third act in the insurance industry.

headline: Ears for Opera, Eyes on the Future
abstract: The producer Beth Morrison’s work for emerging voices in opera has led to her involvement with festivals in New York and, now, the Los Angeles Opera.
lead_paragraph: On a bulletin board in her tiny, tidy Upper East Side apartment, Beth Morrison has displayed a quotation by the librettist and theatrical producer Oscar Hammerstein II since she first moved to New York City in 2005. Printed on a rumpled, coffee-stained scrap of paper, the note enumerates qualities that in Hammerstein’s view characterize the mysterious job of a theater producer: “a hopeful innocent in fair weather, a stern pilot in stormy weather, a mathematician who prefers to ignore the laws of mathematics and trust intuition, a realist, a practical dreamer, a sophisticated gambler, a stage-struck child.”

headline: Playing With Tracks
abstract: The song “When the Night Time Comes” by NightBus is recorded in an unusual way — with two completely different, complementary versions of the song on the left and right channels.
lead_paragraph: The song “When the Night Time Comes” by NightBus is recorded in an unusual way — with two completely different, complementary versions of the song on the left and right channels.

headline: A Window to Bone Disease in a ‘Shark’s’ Skeleton
abstract: The elephant shark’s skeleton is made up largely of cartilage, not bone, and a possible explanation could help in developing treatments for bone diseases like osteoporosis.
lead_paragraph: An elephant shark’s skeleton is made up largely of cartilage, not bone. Now, researchers have found a possible explanation that could help in the development of treatments for bone diseases like osteoporosis.

headline: Negotiators Move Closer on Iran Nuclear Pact
abstract: Iran asserts that all disagreements have been resolved, though its negotiating partners don’t go so far.
lead_paragraph: Iran and a group of six world powers moved closer on Friday to carrying out the nuclear agreement reached in November, with the Iranian side saying all outstanding issues have been resolved.

headline: Corporate Takeover? In 2013, a Lawsuit Almost Always Followed
abstract: In many cases, lawsuits challenging a merger are settled. And the vast majority of those are disclosure-only settlements, where shareholders don’t get any money, but the plaintiffs’ lawyers do.
lead_paragraph: These days, you can be sure that when a company announces it is being acquired, it will also be sued by a bevy of plaintiffs’ lawyers.

headline: Husband-and-Wife Architecture Firms Compete for Vancouver Commission
abstract: After being at odds of the Museum of Modern Art’s renovation plan, the firms of Diller Scofidio + Renfro and Tod Williams Billie Tsien Architects are finalists for the design of a new building for the Vancouver Art Gallery.
lead_paragraph: As they find themselves at odds over the Museum of Modern Art’s renovation announced this week, the architecture firms Diller Scofidio + Renfro and Tod Williams Billie Tsien Architects now also find themselves competing over a new commission. (Elizabeth Diller and Ricardo Scofidio are married to each other, as are Mr. Williams and Ms. Tsien.)

headline: On French TV, No Twerking Before 10
abstract: The French council that oversees broadcasting standards has decided that videos by Miley Cyrus and Britney Spears are too racy for daytime viewing.
lead_paragraph: Those French – they can be such prudes. The Conseil Superieur de l’Audiovisuel, the body that oversees French broadcasting standards, has decided that the promotional video clips for Miley Cyrus’s “Wrecking Ball” and Britney Spears’s “Work Bitch” should be effectively banished from daytime and early evening television in France.

headline: John Zorn to Present Latest Installment in His Masada Project
abstract: The work will be presented on March 19 at the Town Hall, in a concert involving roughly 20 ensembles.
lead_paragraph: John Zorn, the tirelessly prolific composer, organizer and genre-scrambler, will throw open the doors to yet another wing of his rambling musical estate this spring, with the premiere of “John Zorn’s Masada Book Three: The Book Beriah.” The work will be presented on March 19 at the Town Hall, in a concert involving roughly 20 ensembles, including the Masada String Trio, the Jamie Saft Trio, Fieldwork and Secret Chiefs 3. Mr. Zorn is scheduled to perform on alto saxophone with Aleph Trio, which includes Shanir Blumenkranz on bass and Ches Smith on drums. Tickets will be available on Monday through Ticketmaster and the Town Hall box office.

headline: Lobster Stirs Up the Sauce
abstract: An amalgam of recipes from two Italian restaurants results in a winter dish perfect after a day of skiing.
lead_paragraph: In Rome several years ago, at the all-fish restaurant Quinzi & Gabrieli, I was served a lobster pasta as a first course that haunts me still. Somehow the dish was simultaneously delicate and robust — wide, silky pappardelle noodles napped with a creamy yet intensely piquant sauce.

headline: Utah Gay Marriages to be Honored by U.S.
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. says the United States will recognize same-sex marriages officiated in Utah, despite a decision by the state not to do so.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. says the United States will recognize same-sex marriages officiated in Utah, despite a decision by the state not to do so.

headline: The Churchill War Rooms Greet Savile Row
abstract: Suzy Menkes visits the historic landmark where London's bespoke tailors displayed their finest.
lead_paragraph: Suzy Menkes visits the historic landmark where London's bespoke tailors displayed their finest.

headline: Shimmery Orchestrations, With a Tinge of Philip Glass
abstract: Jherek Bischoff, a Seattle songwriter and arranger, brought big names to St. Ann’s Warehouse on Wednesday night, including David Byrne and Zola Jesus.
lead_paragraph: Jherek Bischoff, a songwriter and arranger from Seattle, made his 2012 debut album, “Composed” (Brassland), with low-budget digital diligence. He built the album’s orchestral arrangements by recording one instrument at a time on his laptop. He then drew on some impressive contacts to add vocals, among them David Byrne, Caetano Veloso, Nika Danilova (better known as Zola Jesus), Zac Pennington of Parenthetical Girls and the indie-pop songwriter Mirah Zeitlyn, along with drumming from Greg Saunier of Deerhoof. They recognized a fellow pop experimenter.

headline: More Snow Days, Fewer Sick Days
abstract: The share of people who missed work in December because of bad weather was at its highest level since 1977, and the share who missed work because of illness was at a record low.
lead_paragraph: The nonfarm payroll numbers for December came in much worse than expected. One possible reason, economists speculate, could have to do with unusually bad winter weather.

headline: Google+ Hangout on Human Trafficking
abstract: Join Nick Kristof in a Google+ Hangout on how to solve one of the most pressing problems of our time: modern slavery.
lead_paragraph: Nick Kristof is doing a Google+ Hangout with leaders in the global fight against modern slavery. He will be talking with Rachel Lloyd, of Girls Educational & Mentoring Services, Gary Haugen, of the International Justice Mission, Dave Batstone, of Not For Sale, and Susan Bissell, of UNICEF about what 2014 holds for efforts to combat human trafficking worldwide. Tune in below, to what promises to be a thought provoking conversation.

headline: Hold Up, We’re Not Through With 2013
abstract: Before 2014 gets too far along, Jon Pareles looks at 2013 releases from Mum, Kuenta i Tambú, Tricky, James Holden and Tom McDermott.
lead_paragraph: Let’s postpone 2014 for the length of a Playlist — a handful of deserving 2013 albums that almost got away.

headline: Money Flows to the Biggest Buyout Funds
abstract: Half of all capital raised for private equity buyouts in 2013 went to the biggest funds, according to data released on Friday by Preqin, a research firm based in London. It was the first time since 2008 that megafunds have commanded half the market.
lead_paragraph: In the world of private equity, it may help to be big.

headline: All That Craft, and Now Some Abandon
abstract: Michele Wiles, a former principal with American Ballet Theater, says she’s given up safety by leading her own company, Ballet Next.
lead_paragraph: Almost three years ago, Michele Wiles performed her final “Swan Lake” with American Ballet Theater. She kept the occasion so private that her partner didn’t even realize what was going on. Driven by an urge to experience ballet in a new way, Ms. Wiles didn’t so much retire from the company as slip away.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘Empire of Necessity’
abstract: Greg Grandin discusses his new book about the endless sequence of human transactions connected through slavery.
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Andrew Delbanco reviews Greg Grandin’s “Empire of Necessity: Slavery, Freedom, and Deception in the New World.” Mr. Delbanco writes:

headline: The Collections | The Top Five Fall/Winter 2014 Men’s Wear Shows in London
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'London Fashion Week', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: Our men’s fashion director shares his favorites from the runways of London Collections: Men.
lead_paragraph: The first round of men’s fashion shows this year, London Collections: Men, have come to an end. From street-wear-inspired looks to the more refined and elegant clothing we expect from England’s capital, here are the five best shows from the Fall/Winter 2014 runways so far.

headline: Role Reversals Emerge in Dispute Over Obama’s Recess Appointments
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: As the battle over Senate confirmations during recesses moves to the Supreme Court, a tale is developing with a remarkable number of twists and turns.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — C. Boyden Gray, the former White House counsel and ambassador, is among the conservative lawyers urging the Supreme Court to severely constrain the Obama administration’s ability to fill executive branch vacancies during a Senate recess. Mr. Gray is exceptionally well versed in the subject, having received his own recess appointment in 2006.

headline: Jobs Data Gives Hope for Benefits Extension
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The Senate will consider legislation to revive expired benefits for 1.3 million out-of-work Americans on Monday, but it appears gridlock will continue.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The surprisingly weak December jobs report might have strengthened Democrats’ hand in the current fight over emergency jobless benefits for the long-term unemployed even as it weakened the party in the larger midterm election battle.

headline: House Votes to Increase Security Measures on Health Care Exchanges
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Computer Security', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The bill would require the health department to promptly notify consumers of any possible security breaches on the federal or state exchanges.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House voted on Friday to strengthen security protections on the HealthCare.gov website, requiring all security breaches of the health insurance exchanges to be reported in a timely fashion.

headline: W.V. Governor Issues Warning on Water
abstract: Gov. Earl Ray Tomblin urged affected residents to avoid using tap water after a chemical spill in West Virginia.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Earl Ray Tomblin urged affected residents to avoid using tap water after a chemical spill in West Virginia.

headline: Robert Gates Skewers the Ugliest Branch of Government
abstract: The former Defense Secretary says that most members of Congress are uncivil, incompetent and egotistical.
lead_paragraph: What are all those congressional hearing witnesses privately thinking as they face pompous inquisition from phalanxes of ambitious lawmakers tossing gotcha questions like grenades? “Congress is best viewed from a distance — the farther the better — because up close, it is truly ugly,” advises former Defense Secretary Robert Gates, in his new Washington tell-all, “Duty: Memoirs of a Secretary at War.”

headline: Tonics and Teas
abstract: A rare cold day in Los Angeles inspires tonics and teas made with ingredients on hand in the kitchen.
lead_paragraph: Last week, in the course of cleaning out my office and downsizing my cookbook library, I came across an interesting book called “Tonics” by Robert A. Barnett. The book is a collection of recipes, not just for liquid tonics, but for all sorts of dishes made with foods and herbs thought to improve well being.

headline: ‘12 Years’ Will Win, No, ‘Gravity,’ No ...
abstract: An Oscar season fever chart.
lead_paragraph: The Academy Award nominations will be announced Thursday, but Oscar pundits don’t like to wait until the field is narrowed down to make their predictions. In fact, they often don’t like to wait till the films have even been released. Nearly six months before the actual ceremony on March 2, predictions were already being made and second-guessed. Here’s a look at how the best picture race has already been won and lost several times over, following the fortunes of “12 Years a Slave.”

headline: A Collector’s Paradise
abstract: Rudy’s Hobby & Art in Astoria, Queens, has became a repository for many hard-to-find items, not just in Astoria but the entire city.
lead_paragraph: Rudy’s Hobby & Art in Astoria, Queens, has became a repository for many hard-to-find items, not just in Astoria but the entire city.

headline: A Hobby Shop Endures Despite Changes Around It
abstract: Rudy’s Hobby & Art in Astoria, Queens, sells an extensive selection of car kits, train sets and other knickknacks.
lead_paragraph: Planes, trains and automobiles — and a colorful assortment of rosary beads.

headline: Horror Thriller Has Major Bite in Israel
