abstract: The Israeli directors Aharon Keshales and Navot Papushado have been winning awards in their country for their thriller “Big Bad Wolves.”
lead_paragraph: During a screening of “Piranha 3D” last year in Tel Aviv, the filmmaker Navot Papushado found himself near two girls who were clearly under-age and squirming at the graphic imagery. He escorted them from the room.

headline: Big Ticket | A Photographer’s Refuge for $28.5 Million
abstract: A West Village compound served as home and work space for Annie Leibovitz and was the week’s most expensive residential sale in New York City.
lead_paragraph: The quaint collage of ivy-covered brick townhouses that the celebrity photographer Annie Leibovitz assembled in the West Village a decade ago and eventually transformed into a leafy compound where she lived, worked and entertained guests, sold for $28.5 million in two separate deals to the same buyer and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Blood Ties and Crossed Wires
abstract: Years after the fact, two children are found to have gone home from the maternity ward with the wrong parents.
lead_paragraph: Years after the fact, two children are found to have gone home from the maternity ward with the wrong parents. They have grown up in very different circumstances, and their biological parents now face difficult choices. The premise for the ABC Family drama “Switched at Birth”? Yes, but it also describes “Like Father, Like Son,” an affecting film from the Japanese director Hirokazu Kore-eda. In this story, the children are 6. One, Keita, has been raised in overprotective affluence, an only child. The other, Ryusei, grew up in humbler circumstances, with siblings and amid carefree chaos.

headline: Reaction to Resignation of Central African Republic President
abstract: Many hoped the resignation of President Michel Djotodia would signal an end to the violence in the Central African Republic between the Muslim rebel group, Seleka, and the Christian militia groups who oppose it.
lead_paragraph: Residents in the Central African Republic celebrated the resignation of their president, Michel Djotodia, as a potential turning point in the recent fighting in their country. Many hoped it would signal an end to the violence between Mr. Djotodia’s Muslim rebel group, Seleka, and the Christian militia groups who oppose it.

headline: Leaps and Bounds and Discoveries
abstract: You never know what you’re going to get at the American Realness Festival, running through next Sunday, which Ben Pryor started five years ago.
lead_paragraph: The American Realness Festival is the kind of event that has descriptions of performances that say things like “Taking inspiration from ballet, psychoanalysis, queer theory and Marxism ... ” (Jillian Peña’s “Polly Pocket”) or, “At a small-town tap studio, four dancers prepare for a competition” (Tina Satter’s “House of Dance”). You never know what you’re going to get at American Realness, running through next Sunday, which Ben Pryor started five years ago. If you are curious about the latest in contemporary dance, then wander through the scheduling madness of American Realness, dipping in and out at will. There are established names like Miguel Gutierrez, Ishmael Houston-Jones and Neal Medlyn; there are names less known to American audiences, like Marten Spangberg and Eszter Salamon; there are exhibitions (Sarah Maxfield, Ian Douglas, Mr. Medlyn and Fawn Krieger, Ann Liv Young); there are parties; there will be discoveries. (At the Abrons Arts Center and other New York City locations; americanrealness.com.)

headline: The Gun Report: January 10, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge has ruled that it is unconstitutional to prohibit licensed gun stores from operating in Chicago, the epicenter of the nation’s gun violence. The ruling would also make it legal for adults to transfer ownership of a firearm through a private sale as long as the recipient has a firearm owner’s identification card.

headline: Off the Charts: Japanese Economy Shows Life
abstract: In 2013, the Japanese stock market rose at the fastest rate since 1972 as deflation appeared to end.
lead_paragraph: In 2013, the Japanese stock market rose at the fastest rate since 1972 as deflation appeared to end.

headline: Back in the Pulpit After Losing His Church, and Still Supporting Gay Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Ministers (Protestant)', 'Homosexuality', 'Christians and Christianity']
abstract: The Rev. Oliver White threw his clerical life into disarray in 2005 with a single act of principle at the General Synod of the United Church of Christ.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH ST. PAUL, Minn. — Three below zero on a Minnesota morning, and the Rev. Oliver White stomps the snow off his boots as he enters the stucco edifice of Clark Memorial United Church of Christ to lead worship. He peels off an overcoat to reveal the kente-cloth vestments his wife made for him, which match the kufi hat he wears.

headline: Bulls to Angels in Spanish Drawing
abstract: The Morgan Library & Museum has long been known for its extraordinary collection of drawings.
lead_paragraph: The Morgan Library & Museum has long been known for its extraordinary collection of drawings — nearly 12,000 of them from the 14th through the 21st centuries — especially examples of Italian, Dutch and French old masters. Less known and rarely shown, however, is a small but outstanding group of Spanish drawings.

headline: High Culture, In the Basement
abstract: In town for concerts as part of his New York Philharmonic residency, the pianist Yefim Bronfman devotes Monday evening to Contact!, the orchestra’s new-music series.
lead_paragraph: In town for concerts as part of his New York Philharmonic residency, the pianist Yefim Bronfman devotes Monday evening to Contact!, the orchestra’s new-music series. At the lower-level Greenwich Village space SubCulture, he will give the premiere of “Passions, Reflected,” a Schumann-influenced work for solo piano by Marc Neikrug, who has a long relationship with the Philharmonic. Joined by two of the orchestra’s string players, Mr. Bronfman will also perform Marc-André Dalbavie’s Piano Trio No. 1 (2008); others in the string section will play Poul Ruders’s String Quartet No. 4 (2012). (7:30 p.m., 45 Bleecker Street, at Lafayette Street, 212-875-5030, nyphil.org.)

headline: Government Stimulus Lifts Japan
abstract: The nation’s era of deflation appeared to be on the wane as the Nikkei, Consumer Price Index and gross domestic product showed growth in 2013.
lead_paragraph: HAS Japan turned the economic corner?

headline: Exclusive | 995 Fifth Avenue
abstract: An eight-room simplex on the 6th-floor is about to enter the market at $13.5 million. The building occupies a prime spot opposite the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: An eight-room simplex on the 6th-floor is about to enter the market at $13.5 million. The building occupies a prime spot opposite the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Museum Mile Elegance
abstract: An eight-room condop in a 1926 Rosario Candela jewel box opposite the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: A svelte eight-room simplex that blends classic Museum Mile elegance, European élan and the open-ended entertainment flow of a luxury downtown loft is poised to enter the market at $13.5 million.

headline: Top Editor at People Magazine Leaving Time Inc.
abstract: Larry Hackett will leave Time Inc., the company said, and the editor of Entertainment Weekly, Jess Cagle, will succeed him.
lead_paragraph: Time Inc. shook up its management on Friday as it prepared itself to be spun off from the media conglomerate Time Warner into an independent company.

headline: Shakespeare Double-Bill to Be Treated as Two Shows for Tony Eligibility
abstract: The Broadway double-bill of Shakespeare’s “Twelfth Night” and “Richard III” will be treated as two separate shows for the purposes of the Tony Awards.
lead_paragraph: Contrary to the producers’ wishes, the Broadway double-bill of Shakespeare’s “Twelfth Night” and “Richard III” will be treated as two separate shows for the purposes of the Tony Awards, and not as a joint production, the committee that oversees Tony award eligibility ruled on Thursday.

headline: The Racecar Driver at Rest
abstract: Lucas Bize, 18, a high school senior and the youngest member of the Racers Edge Motorsports auto racing team, spends his Sundays before a race studying the track.
lead_paragraph: When Lucas Bize is not reading J. D. Salinger for his high school literature class, he is speeding around racetracks in his Mustang at up to 170 miles per hour. Mr. Bize, who lives on the Upper West Side, is a senior at the Professional Children’s School, also called P.C.S., and a professional racecar driver. At 18, he is the youngest driver on the Racers Edge Motorsports team. On Sundays before a race, besides sleeping in and then hanging out with friends, he will study as much as he can about a track. Occasionally he will go with his parents, Alex, 56, and Evelyne, 45, to their home in Montauk, N.Y., where he can practice using a racing simulator, a computer with a large monitor and a wheel attached. Mr. Bize learned to race by tagging along to tracks with his father, a former business partner of Jay Z in the clothing line Rocawear, and his brother, Dennis, 22; both race only for fun now. Mr. Bize’s mother works as his manager. His sister, Natasha, 20, recently moved to Charlotte, N.C., for college.

headline: 52 Places to Go in 2014
abstract: From No. 1 Cape Town all the way to No. 52 Niagara Falls, N.Y., explore the vibrant cities and spectacular coastlines, unexpected spots and new attractions that made our list this year.
lead_paragraph: From No. 1 Cape Town all the way to No. 52 Niagara Falls, N.Y., explore the vibrant cities and spectacular coastlines, unexpected spots and new attractions that made our list this year.

headline: Symphony Space Artistic Director Resigns
abstract: Laura Kaminsky had been the artistic director of Symphony Space since 2010, and the overseer of its music programming since 2006.
lead_paragraph: Laura Kaminsky, the artistic director of Symphony Space since 2010, and the overseer of its music programming since 2006, said on Friday that she had resigned her position. In a telephone interview, she described her departure as amicable, and said that she would stay on until March 30. But both she and a spokesman for the hall also said that they were parting ways because of “differences in artistic vision for the future” of the space. A press announcement said that the space would begin a search for Ms. Kaminsky’s successor immediately.

headline: Deft Hands Keep Figure Skaters Looking Sharp
abstract: Of the people working behind the scenes at the national figure skating championships, few provide a more urgent service than the seamstresses and technicians who repair costumes and skates.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The United States figure skating championships had not yet opened Thursday when a skater had a wardrobe malfunction at ice dance practice. Not to worry.

headline: American Man, After Jail Term in U.A.E., Says He Was Tried by ‘Kangaroo Court’
abstract: Shezanne Cassim told reporters when he returned to Minnesota that he did nothing wrong, adding that the United Arab Emirates authorities were “scared of democracy.”
lead_paragraph: An American man who was accused of endangering national security in the United Arab Emirates — after making a satirical video about a fictitious combat school — said on his return to the United States on Friday that he was given the one-year jail term by a “kangaroo court.”

headline: Pint-Size Players, Texas-Size Fervor
abstract: “Friday Night Tykes,” a reality show that has its premiere on Tuesday night at 9 on the Esquire Network, follows five San Antonio football teams of 8- and 9-year-olds.
lead_paragraph: There’s no quitting in football. But there’s plenty of blood, sweat and tears when you’re a baby linebacker exhausted in 99-degree heat, and the coach orders you to bear-crawl across the field. “I don’t care how much pain you’re in,” bellows Charles Chavarria, a former Marine, at his team, the Junior Broncos. “You don’t quit.”

headline: Harking Back to Country’s Roots
abstract: For 10 days in the summer of 1927, the Victor Talking Machine Company set up shop in Bristol, Tenn., recording a hodgepodge of hopefuls for possible release.
lead_paragraph: For 10 days in the summer of 1927, the Victor Talking Machine Company set up shop in Bristol, Tenn., recording a hodgepodge of hopefuls for possible release. The Bristol Sessions, as we now know them, included the first commercial recordings of Jimmie Rodgers and the Carter Family, which is one reason the sessions are often described as the big bang of country music.

headline: Can I Just Pick Your Brain?
abstract: Do you get a lot of people asking for advice on how to run a business? How do you handle those requests?
lead_paragraph: This week in SundayBusiness, the Workologist — a column by Rob Walker that addresses workplace conundrums — tackles a topic that many business owners will find familiar. How do you handle requests for advice from aspiring entrepreneurs?

headline: For the Couple That Loves Joe and Chai
abstract: Gifts for coffee and tea lovers.
lead_paragraph: Gifts for coffee and tea lovers.

headline: Fighting ‘Observation’ Status
abstract: There are steps to take when the hospital refuses to formally admit a Medicare patient.
lead_paragraph: Every year, thousands of Medicare patients who spend time in the hospital for observation but are not officially admitted find they are not eligible for nursing home coverage after discharge.

headline: Your Comments on Places to Go in 2014
abstract: Each year we compile a list of places to go in the coming year. And each year we hear from readers. Here is your chance to sound off.
lead_paragraph: Each year we compile a list of places to go in the coming year. And each year we hear from readers: agreements, disagreements, celebration, anger, bewilderment.

headline: How We Chose Our List of Places to Go in 2014
abstract: Here are some answers to common questions about how we selected our list of destinations to visit this year.
lead_paragraph: Each January, the editors of the Travel section publish our Places to Go issue. And each year after it runs, readers wonder why their favorite destination was overlooked or why their least favorite made the top 10. In order to add some clarity to the process, we’ve decided to answer some frequently asked questions about how we chose our list of 52 Places to Go in 2014.

headline: Bridge Scandal Papers Point to Cover-Up by Chris Christie Allies
abstract: Top officials loyal to Gov. Chris Christie went to great lengths to make it appear that the closing of several toll lanes was part of a traffic study, according to documents released Friday.
lead_paragraph: Officials loyal to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey went to elaborate lengths to make it appear that the September closing of lanes leading to the George Washington Bridge was part of a traffic study, even though their private communications suggest the move was purely political, according to documents released on Friday.

headline: Wheelies: The Ford Is Watching Edition
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'International Consumer Electronics Show']
abstract: Jim Farley, a Ford executive, pulled back from earlier remarks about Ford watching G.P.S. data; Tesla upgrades potentially faulty wall chargers.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: From Tweet to Ad to Mini Modern Scandal
abstract: A descent into the wormhole created by the collision of movie-awards campaigning and paracritical chirping.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve seen “Inside Llewyn Davis,” the latest movie by Joel and Ethan Coen, you know that it has an unusual narrative structure: The story unwinds along a loose, rambling path and then loops back on itself, catching hold of (if not quite swallowing) its own tail. The story I’m about to tell has a similar shape. It’s hard to say where it begins or ends and even more difficult to say what it all means.

headline: An Anxious Sally Hawkins, Onstage and in Auditions
abstract: Sally Hawkins, nervous as she presented an honor for her “Blue Jasmine” co-star Cate Blanchett, recalls her worries as she prepared to audition for Woody Allen.
lead_paragraph: Sally Hawkins was visibly and audibly nervous presenting an award to her “Blue Jasmine” co-star Cate Blanchett at the New York Film Critics Circle ceremony on Monday – her hands were shaking as she turned the pages of her speech, which praised Ms. Blanchett for operating “at a much higher vibration.” So just imagine how terrified she was auditioning for Woody Allen.

headline: A Scarcity of New One-Bedrooms
abstract: Developers of many new condominiums in Manhattan are phasing out one-bedroom apartments in favor of much more spacious units.
lead_paragraph: For decades, one-bedroom apartments have been a fixture of New York. But finding one going forward, at least in new developments, may become as hard as hailing a cab in a downpour.

headline: London Men’s Fashion Shows in Search of Direction
abstract: Designers tend to work feverishly in a single genre, instead of creating a broad vision.
lead_paragraph: I SORT OF LOST INTEREST in the London men’s collections once I had clicked through the first day or two of shows.

headline: Friday Night Music: Carolina Chocolate Drops, Jackson
abstract: A hot fiddle on a freezing night.
lead_paragraph: Yes, I know it’s only Friday afternoon in New York. But I’m in Stockholm, where it’s 11 degrees and dropping fast, and I wanted something to make me think of warmer climes. And Rhiannon Giddens is always a good thing, especially when she fiddles as well as sings:

headline: New York City F.C. Introduces a Philosophy Along With Its Coach
abstract: The club, Major League Soccer’s 20th, will not play until 2015, but Coach Jason Kreis said he welcomed the chance to immerse himself in the job.
lead_paragraph: There was much talk about soccer philosophy and very little about actual soccer players when New York City F.C. introduced Jason Kreis as its first head coach on Friday. But it will have to be that way for a while.

headline: Justices Take Case on Free TV Streaming
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Television']
abstract: Broadcasters contend Aereo’s service violates copyright laws. The company says it is not covered by the relevant provisions of those laws.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to resolve a dispute between television broadcasters and Aereo, an Internet start-up that the networks say threatens the economic viability of their businesses.

headline: Remembrance of News Past
abstract: Why do we remember some details about long-ago events, but not others?
lead_paragraph: WITHIN just over a year we’ve seen the Newtown shootings, the bombing at the Boston Marathon and the rescue of the kidnapped women in Cleveland. But which details of these events will you remember in a year? In five years? Will you remember the names of the perpetrators or the victims, the places where they happened, or the month and the year?

headline: Women of a Higher Calling
abstract: More women are becoming pastors as denominations proliferate and churches form in nontraditional spaces, such as storefronts.
lead_paragraph: More women are becoming pastors as denominations proliferate and churches form in nontraditional spaces, such as storefronts.

headline: All December Job Gains Went to Women
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Men and Boys', 'United States Economy', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Women’s gains have outpaced men’s in the last year, but they were concentrated in low-wage sectors.
lead_paragraph: American employers added 74,000 jobs in December on net. All of that employment increase was a result of new jobs filled by women.

headline: Underlining the Recovery’s Shortfall
keywords: ['Gross Domestic Product', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'United States Economy']
abstract: There may be more static than usual in the latest jobs report, but it’s still saying something worth hearing, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: In Brooklyn, Female Pastors on the Rise
abstract: Storefronts of Bedford-Stuyvesant and Bushwick have given rise to many Christian congregations. Over the years, these nontraditional church spaces have been a launch pad for female pastors.
lead_paragraph: Storefronts of Bedford-Stuyvesant and Bushwick have given rise to many Christian congregations. Over the years, these nontraditional church spaces have been a launch pad for female pastors.

headline: Video reviews of ‘The Rocket,’ ‘Cold Comes the Night’ and ‘In Bloom’
abstract: Times critics on “The Rocket,” “Cold Comes the Night” and “In Bloom.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “The Rocket,” “Cold Comes the Night” and “In Bloom.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: For Alex Prager, It’s Lonely in a Crowd
abstract: A new exhibition at Lehmann Maupin from the acclaimed photographer explores the fraught relationship between individuals and large groups. See a behind-the-scenes video about the making of the show, exclusively at T.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Alex Prager’s new solo exhibition, “A Face in the Crowd,” opened at the Chelsea and Lower East Side galleries of Lehmann Maupin last night. Using both still and moving images, the Los Angeles native riffs on the way individuals function in a large group: Physical proximity does not necessarily equate closeness, but there are a million stories in an anonymous mass.

headline: Something to Really Talk About
abstract: A same-sex couple, who met while working at a Costco, marry in Utah days after the state’s ban on gay marriage was found unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: Before they became lovers, Stephanie Segura and Becca Sicairos were nearly inseparable, friends with opposite outlooks and personalities, like Bert and Ernie from “Sesame Street,” Ms. Segura laughs, “but without the thick eyebrows.”

headline: Movie Review: 'The Rocket'
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "The Rocket."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "The Rocket."

headline: Newly Released Files in the New Jersey Bridge Scandal
abstract: Hundreds of pages of communications related to the scheme to close several lanes leading onto the George Washington Bridge in September were released Friday.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of pages of communications related to the scheme to close several lanes leading onto the George Washington Bridge in September were released Friday.

headline: Hugo Lindgren Named Acting Editor of Hollywood Reporter
abstract: Mr. Lindgren, former editor of The New York Times magazine, will take over for the next three months.
lead_paragraph: Hugo Lindgren, who stepped down as editor of The New York Times Magazine in November, will become acting editor of The Hollywood Reporter for the next three months, according to a Twitter post by Janice Min, who held that job before being promoted.

headline: Chicken Stew With Sweet Plantains
abstract: Melissa Clark transforms a traditional chicken stew into a dish hinting at the tropical with the addition of sweet plantains and citrus juices.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark transforms a traditional chicken stew into a dish hinting at the tropical with the addition of sweet plantains and citrus juices.

headline: It’s Bitesize Captain Kirk
abstract: The Coil theater festival show “An Evening With William Shatner Asterisk,” at the New Ohio Theater, makes an evening of clips of Mr. Shatner in his “Star Trek” role.
lead_paragraph: William Shatner managed to fit a lot more than just “Star Trek” anecdotes into his did-that-actually-happen? Broadway solo show in 2012. But the epistemological underpinnings of art, science and contemporary civilization were somehow left underdeveloped amid the talk of Ben Folds and “T. J. Hooker.”

headline: Women at the Pulpit
abstract: A growing number of women are becoming pastors and becoming leaders in their own churches.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 20 years ago, when the Rev. Susie Elliott, 83, preached her first sermon at Mt. Paran Baptist Church on the border of Bedford-Stuyvesant and Bushwick, she was an anomaly in Brooklyn’s male-dominated world of Christian pastors.

headline: Movie Review: 'In Bloom'
abstract: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews "In Bloom."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A.O. Scott reviews "In Bloom."

headline: This Bird’s Gone South
abstract: Plantains and spices with lime and orange juice take the winter out of a traditional chicken stew.
lead_paragraph: A bubbling pot of chicken stew with potatoes is a hearty, comforting thing. But substitute sweet plantains for the tubers, and suddenly your dinner leaps from familiar and predictable to unexpected and a whole lot more interesting — at least for someone who doesn’t eat plantains very regularly.

headline: Movie Review: 'Cold Comes the Night'
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis "Cold Comes the Night."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis "Cold Comes the Night."

headline: BlackBerry Chief Drops ‘Interim’ Label
abstract: John S. Chen became the company’s temporary chief executive and executive chairman of BlackBerry in November.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — With little fanfare, John S. Chen has dropped “interim” from his title as chief executive of BlackBerry, the struggling smartphone maker .

headline: A Musical and House of Scandal
abstract: The Stephen Ward Theater Break package includes tickets to the new Andrew Lloyd Webber musical about the Profumo scandal, as well as a stay at the estate where the war minister was introduced to Christine Keeler.
lead_paragraph: There’s nothing like a scandal to attract an audience. That’s good news for Andrew Lloyd Webber, whose latest musical, “Stephen Ward,” is based on a British scandal so licentious that it resulted in the resignation of two government officials and the suicide of the show’s title character.

headline: Premier Urges Award for Boy Who Halted Pakistan Attack
abstract: Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif issued his recommendation amid growing calls to honor the teenager, who was killed this week by a suicide bomber dressed in a school uniform.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif on Friday recommended that a high civil award for bravery be bestowed on a teenager who was killed this week while stopping a suicide bomber from attacking his school in northwestern Pakistan.

headline: SodaStream to Bring Some Heat to Super Bowl Ad With Scarlett Johansson
abstract: The ad for the home soda-making system is part of a multiyear, worldwide endorsement deal.
lead_paragraph: In the movie “Her,” Scarlett Johansson personifies new technology by providing the voice of an operating system. In a Super Bowl commercial, she will try something similar by providing a demonstration of a SodaStream home soda-making system.

headline: Actors’ Union to Discuss Pay for Touring Musicals
abstract: The Actors’ Equity union will hold a town hall meeting to discuss salaries and pay contracts for touring musicals.
lead_paragraph: In response to growing frustrations among some members, the Actors’ Equity union will hold a town hall meeting on Jan. 27 to discuss salaries and contracts for touring productions of musicals, an issue that also drew scores of actors to a regional Equity meeting in New York on Friday afternoon.

headline: Luke Steyn Gives Zimbabwe Someone to Cheer for in Winter Olympics
abstract: He grew up in Europe, but the skier says he has always kept a part of himself in his homeland.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s One-Page Magazine, I make note of Luke Steyn, an Alpine skier who will become the first athlete ever to represent the tropical African nation of Zimbabwe in the Winter Olympics next month in Sochi, Russia. In an email exchange over the holidays, Steyn said he knew that his nationality will make him something of a curiosity among competitors and the media.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: A Chelsea condo with full-time doormen; an Inwood postwar co-op; and a South Slope penthouse.
lead_paragraph: A Chelsea condo with full-time doormen; an Inwood postwar co-op; and a South Slope penthouse.

headline: On the Market in the Region
abstract: In Cranbury Village, a 1861 Victorian; and a Westchester contemporary on one acre.
lead_paragraph: In Cranbury Village, a 1861 Victorian; and a Westchester contemporary on one acre.

headline: Fleeing a Backwater to Lunge at Happiness
abstract: “Paul’s Case,” an operatic adaptation of a Willa Cather story by UrbanArias, focuses on a teenager who longs to escape his working class world in turn-of-the-century Pittsburgh.
lead_paragraph: There is something not quite normal about Paul, the teenager at the center of Willa Cather’s 1905 short story “Paul’s Case,” and everyone around him knows it. Cather memorably illuminates the outward manifestations of the boy’s dandyish disaffection: “His eyes were remarkable for a certain hysterical brilliancy, and he continually used them in a conscious, theatrical sort of way, peculiarly offensive in a boy.” Among his trespasses: a red carnation in his threadbare lapel.

headline: Yo, What’s Shaking? Not These Movers
abstract: Fox adds two series to its late-Saturday-night animation lineup, including “Lucas Bros. Moving Co.,” from the twin comedians Keith and Kenny Lucas.
lead_paragraph: The main characters of “Lucas Bros. Moving Co.,” a new addition to Fox’s late-Saturday-night collection of 15-minute animated series, have a lot in common with their creators. Kenny and Keef, like Keith and Kenny Lucas (who are also the show’s main writers and voice actors), are young black twins who live in a mythical place called Brooklyn.

headline: A Central Park Ice Hockey Referee Shares Some Secrets
abstract: Half the battle of officiating outdoor hockey is staying warm. Bill Marshall, a referee, has something of an edge on other officials.
lead_paragraph: By the third period, Bill Marshall really regretted not putting those heat packets in his skates.

headline: Is The Times Giving Proper Credit on the Christie-Bridge Story?
abstract: Readers wonder why The Times isn’t mentioning The Record in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: The explosive story surrounding Gov. Chris Christie this week is bringing well-deserved praise to The Record, the newspaper in northern New Jersey that has been chipping away at it for months.

headline: A Hybrid Pioneer Is Back in the Hunt
abstract: Honda was the first to market with a hybrid, the Insight, but the Toyota Prius went on to dominate the niche. Now Honda is trying again, and this time getting things right.
lead_paragraph: You might assume that Honda and hybrids go together like Bordeaux and a juicy steak. But despite a reputation for practical and fuel-efficient cars, Honda has largely whiffed on the hybrid front. That has to be vexing for a company that pioneered the hybrid in America, with the two-seat, podlike Insight that beat the Toyota Prius to market in 1999.

headline: Immigrants and Red Scare Case Studies
abstract: Essays on immigrants in New York and Amsterdam, a history of Italian-American food, and the human costs of McCarthyism.
lead_paragraph: Some years ago, Dr. Gabor Nagy, chairman of the Budapest City Council’s Committee on Human Rights and Minorities (the largest minority in his city was Gypsies), was shocked by what he viewed as the Balkanization of the New York City Council.

headline: White House, in Gates’s Telling, Restrained Clinton
abstract: In former Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates’s account, Hillary Rodham Clinton fares better than the president or vice president.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the early scorekeeping of winners and losers in “Duty,” Robert M. Gates’s unsparing account of his days as defense secretary, Hillary Rodham Clinton has fared better than either President Obama or Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Sudan and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from South Sudan, the West Bank, Bangladesh and Jordan.
lead_paragraph: Photos from South Sudan, the West Bank, Bangladesh and Jordan.

headline: Tea Party Delays Spending, Beats Dead Horse
abstract: Some Republicans are adding ridiculous, ideologically inflected riders to the appropriations bill.
lead_paragraph: It will only cover three days, but once again next week Congress will have to pass a continuing resolution to keep the government open. The current resolution expires on Wednesday, and even though a budget agreement was reached last month, appropriators in both chambers still haven’t nailed down a plan to tell various agencies what they can spend.

headline: Honda’s Hybrid Do-Over
abstract: Honda has returned to the hybrid front with better technology that is fitted to the latest, acclaimed redesign of the Accord sedan.
lead_paragraph: Honda has returned to the hybrid front with better technology that is fitted to the latest, acclaimed redesign of the Accord sedan.

headline: Court Returns Stolen Renoir Painting to Baltimore Museum of Art
abstract: Six decades after it was stolen, a Renoir painting is headed back to the Baltimore Museum of Art, according to a court ruling Friday.
lead_paragraph: A Renoir painting said to have been bought at a Virginia flea market will be returned to the Baltimore Museum of Art, from where it was stolen more than 60 years ago, a federal judge ruled Friday.

headline: Review: 2014 Chevrolet Traverse
abstract: Need practical wheels with room for the family? The spacious three-row Chevrolet Traverse is practically a family room on wheels.
lead_paragraph: Need practical wheels with room for the family? The spacious three-row Chevrolet Traverse is practically a family room on wheels.

headline: A Fork? De Blasio’s Way of Eating Pizza Is Mocked
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s use of a knife and fork at Goodfellas on Staten Island prompted a firestorm.
lead_paragraph: The pizza arrived, steaming and delectable, a smoked-mozzarella-and-sausage pie presented to Mayor Bill de Blasio like a gilded offering to a visiting caliph.

headline: Seven Days of Style | Miley Cyrus’s Latest Drama, The Row’s Seasoned Models and DVF’s 40th Anniversary
abstract: Martha Stewart shares her full beauty regimen, Jay Z rakes in a million dollars for charity and more, as we run the numbers from the last week in style and culture.
lead_paragraph: ALL THE NUMBERS THAT MATTER FROM THE WEEK IN STYLE AND CULTUREJan. 4 – 10

headline: Prada to Aid Restoration of Vasari’s ‘Last Supper’
abstract: The company has donated money to help pay salaries for conservators working to repair Giorgio Vasari’s wood-panel paintin, which was damaged in a flood in 1966.
lead_paragraph: Giorgio Vasari’s “The Last Supper,” an imposing wood-panel painting that was almost destroyed in a 1966 flood in Florence and has been undergoing restoration for more than four years, will be the beneficiary of a grant by the Prada company that conservators hope will allow them to bring the work back to public view.

headline: As Shop Owner, Woman Sees Troubling Sides of Herself
abstract: An angry essay by a middle-class woman in Park Slope, Brooklyn, reminds us that inequality is corrosive even when it isn’t extreme.
lead_paragraph: Living in New York can curiously and frequently feel like an exercise played out on a narrow emotional field, a continual toggle between envy and guilt. You wish for more; so many others seem to have it, after all — more space, nicer furniture, a greater number of things from Lululemon. But you also harbor a discomfort at possessing plenty while legions haven’t nearly enough. In any given hour you might veer from feeling unduly blessed to woefully disadvantaged. It is not the job of politics to solve the problem of this kind of split perspective, but it remains one of the chief psychological byproducts of inequality for those who occupy a place in the city’s vast and steeply tiered middle class.

headline: American Freed From Prison in United Arab Emirates
abstract: Shezanne Cassim, who was arrested in April after posting a video online that satirized Dubai youth culture, returned to the United States on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — An American who was detained and sentenced to a year in prison in the United Arab Emirates after posting a video online that satirized Dubai youth culture has returned to the United States after being released.

headline: Long-Eared Owls, Built for Stealth, Often Go Unnoticed
abstract: Long-eared owls have characteristics that allow them to disappear next to trees, fly quietly and hunt with precision.
lead_paragraph: The long-eared owl’s plumage is a tapestry of warm and cool grays, tawny browns and chestnut highlights. Some of nature’s most lavish camouflage, it is as close to bark as a bird can produce.

headline: A New Cultural Venue, Southampton Center, Hires Its First Director
abstract: A new cultural organization in the Hamptons has hired its first director as it moves through its first full season of programming.
lead_paragraph: The Southampton Center, a new cultural organization at the Parrish Art Museum’s former site, on Jobs Lane in Southampton Village, N.Y., has hired Michele Thompson as its first director.

headline: Twitter Gears Up for Second Fiction Festival
abstract: The social networking site’s festival will include the authors Megan Abbott, Benjamin Percy and Ransom Riggs.
lead_paragraph: Get ready for some #seriouslyshortstories. The second annual Twitter Fiction Festival is slated for March 12-16.

headline: A Mix That, Unabashedly, Doesn’t Really Mesh at All
abstract: The New York Philharmonic offers a concert of Shostakovich, Beethoven and Gershwin.
lead_paragraph: Listeners can discern links between eclectic works on a program in various ways, often by style or nationality, or perhaps the way one composer influences another. But no obvious aesthetic threads wove through the polyglot lineup on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall. In the New York Philharmonic’s program book, the music director, Alan Gilbert, described the offerings as a “bouquet of varied masterpieces.”

headline: Determining New York City’s Record Wind Chill
abstract: A reader asked, What was the lowest wind-chill temperature ever recorded in New York City?
lead_paragraph: Q. Tuesday’s freeze was hideous. What was the lowest wind-chill temperature ever recorded in New York City?

headline: Rethinking How Baseball's 'Greats' Are Chosen
abstract: Does the voting process for the Baseball Hall of Fame need to be changed?

headline: A Coupling as Bizarre as the Murder
abstract: The new HBO series “True Detective” pairs Matthew McConaughey and Woody Harrelson as a mismatched team of Louisiana state cops dealing with a reopened murder case.
lead_paragraph: The success of HBO’s new Sunday night crime drama, “True Detective,” depends on two pairs of men, a couple of veterans and a couple of relative rookies. Upfront, and drawing all the attention, are the movie stars Matthew McConaughey and Woody Harrelson, playing a mismatched team of Louisiana state cops.

headline: Actor-Doctor
abstract: Clancy O'Connor, the understudy for the play "Buyer & Cellar," talks about the demands of his job.
lead_paragraph: Clancy O'Connor, the understudy for the play "Buyer & Cellar," talks about the demands of his job.

headline: The Power of Imagination
abstract: Clancy O’Connor on his strategy for perfecting comedic timing while rehearsing on stage in front of an empty house.
lead_paragraph: Clancy O’Connor on his strategy for perfecting comedic timing while rehearsing on stage in front of an empty house.

headline: Americans Traveling to Winter Games Cautioned
abstract: The State Department issued a travel advisory cautioning Americans planning to travel next month to Sochi, Russia, that terrorists have threatened to attack the Games.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department issued a travel advisory on Friday cautioning Americans planning to attend the Winter Olympics next month in Sochi, Russia, that terrorists have threatened to attack the Games. The advisory also expressed concern about the quality of medical care in the region, noting that it could “differ substantially from Western standards.”

headline: Even Cheap Wine Can Work a Little Magic
abstract: Bartlett Sher’s “L’Elisir d’Amore,” at the Metropolitan Opera, features Andriana Chuchman in her Met debut.
lead_paragraph: It’s unusual for a tragedy-obsessed art form, but for the last month or so, the fare at the Metropolitan Opera has been dominated by works that end happily and without too many bodies piled up. There have been runs of Strauss’s elegant “Der Rosenkavalier” and Mozart’s sublime “The Magic Flute,” as well as new productions of Verdi’s merry “Falstaff” and Johann Strauss Jr.’s frothy “Die Fledermaus.” (If you really needed death, “Tosca” and “Eugene Onegin” were there, too.)

headline: Hope Under the Grip of Oppression
abstract: An exhibition of work by Paulo Bruscky displays the radical art that flourished under a violent and repressive government in Brazil.
lead_paragraph: Paulo Bruscky’s career as an artist began in a difficult time and place: Recife, Brazil, a few years after the 1964 coup that led to a dictatorship lasting nearly 20 years. Like other artists — and anyone who came under government suspicion — Mr. Bruscky was arrested (more than once), interrogated and tortured. But focusing only on the violent context of his work undermines what it set out to prove, which is that radical art can flourish even in repressive circumstances, and that it can be a form of communication, liberation and optimism, as the title “Paulo Bruscky: Art Is Our Last Hope” suggests. Installed at the Bronx Museum, the exhibition includes 140 works of sculpture, performance documentation, mail art and photography made between 1971 and 2011.

headline: Ethnic Segregation at a U.N. Camp in South Sudan
abstract: Reporting from South Sudan on Friday, the BBC correspondent Alastair Leithead discovered that civilians taking refuge from fighting at a U.N. base were being segregated along ethnic lines by the peacekeepers.
lead_paragraph: Reporting from South Sudan on Friday, the BBC correspondent Alastair Leithead discovered that civilians taking refuge from fighting at a United Nations base outside the town of Bentiu were being segregated along ethnic lines by the peacekeepers.

headline: A Rising Tide of Record Sales May Not Lift All Boats
abstract: Some segments of the classic-car market are flat, while others, like high-end cars, are strong.
lead_paragraph: The cluster of six collector-car auctions that get underway in the Phoenix area this week — and a 3,000-car sale by Mecum Auctions a week later in Florida — come five years after a major market correction, possibly providing clarity and insight on the state of the recovery.

headline: Measures of the Collectible-Car Market
abstract: Rob Sass looks at some of the cars to be offered in the Arizona auctions this week that may provide a gauge of value trends.
lead_paragraph: Rob Sass looks at some of the cars to be offered in the Arizona auctions this week that may provide a gauge of value trends.

headline: Tech Companies and White House Discuss Surveillance Reform
abstract: The gathering was part of a series of White House meetings before the president proposes reforms to national security surveillance.
lead_paragraph: Representatives from tech companies including Google, Twitter, Yahoo and Microsoft met on Friday with White House staff members to discuss Internet surveillance reforms.

headline: The F-150’s Aluminum Diet
abstract: Ford is taking a calculated risk by abandoning the traditional welded steel construction in the F-150 and switching to aluminum to reduce weight.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — When Ford rolls out its redesigned F-150 pickup truck here on Monday morning to kick off two days of press previews for the 2014 North American International Auto Show, the automaker will be making one of the boldest product gambles in its 111-year history.

headline: Ice Truck Starts, Moves and Melts, but No Heated Seats
abstract: To show that a battery could start a car in temperatures as low as minus 40 degrees, a company builds a truck out of ice.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — With no inkling that the polar vortex would freeze much of North America in January, executives at Canadian Tire, the country’s leading retailer of automotive and household goods, managed to hit on what proved a timely topic — ice — when they developed a winter advertising campaign for a new product.

headline: At CES, Wired Cars Reach Out
abstract: At the International CES, applications, systems and gadgets for automotive use were among the fastest-growing categories on display.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Not that long ago, a telephone meant a black two-piece unit with a handset and a rotary dial. Nowadays, the telephone has been completely redefined as a smartphone capable of performing an exponentially expanding array of tasks.

headline: Magical Crockery, Pop Music Parody, a Hula Hoop and Other Experiments
abstract: The American Realness festival has opened at the Abrons Arts Center with a mélange of performance art accented by music and choreography.
lead_paragraph: American Realness, a small-scale annual performance festival of the Abrons Arts Center, began just after 7 on Thursday evening with the audience seated onstage at the center’s playhouse. In a 45-minute solo show titled “Wonder,” a naked woman, Michelle Boulé, briskly paced a figure-eight pattern around the space with a fixed smile for several minutes, to some mild rock music. Later she donned dancewear and, at one point, a full-length blue gown and matching wig.

lead_paragraph: In May 1999, on the stately campus of Harvard Law School, Mathew Martoma was facing expulsion for doctoring his grades in the hopes of securing a coveted judicial clerkship.

headline: Playing Bridge Onboard the Silver Whisper
abstract: If ever a bridge game at sea was going to be fun and unpredictable, one on New Year’s Day fit the bill.
lead_paragraph: Slow down, you play too fast. You got to make the winners last. Just kickin’ down the trump tricks. Looking for fun and feelin’ groovy.

headline: In This Dance Performance, Love Takes a New Shape
abstract: A collaboration between Ishmael Houston-Jones and Emily Wexler, part of the American Realness festival on the Lower East Side, puts a highly physical spin on conventional notions of romance.
lead_paragraph: The vibrant, convivial and unfussy American Realness performance festival, now in its fifth year, is at Abrons Arts Center on the Lower East Side through January 19. Debuting last night was “13 Love Songs: dot dot dot”, the first evening-length collaboration between friends Ishmael Houston-Jones, a downtown dance pillar in his 60s who still fearlessly puts his body through brutal and manic paces, and Emily Wexler, a big-boned, flame-haired 30-something who matches his self-flagellating bravado.

headline: Moelis Is Said to Ready a Potential Public Offering
abstract: Moelis & Company, the boutique investment bank founded by Kenneth D. Moelis, has begun working with advisers on a potential initial public offering, people briefed on the matter said on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Moelis & Company, the boutique investment bank founded by Kenneth D. Moelis, has begun working with advisers on a potential initial public offering, people briefed on the matter said on Friday.

keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Credit Cards', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers']
abstract: If you can’t tell me how my personal information is going to be protected when you ask for it, don’t expect me to give it you. And you should do the same when someone asks you for that information.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard out there for a paranoid cybersecurity reporter.

lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — The contractor hired to build the computer enrollment system for President Obama’s health care law said Friday that it would stop working on the troubled insurance exchange when its contract expires at the end of February.

lead_paragraph: The French military captain (who will shortly thereafter become an English earl) is at a loss as to why everybody is so smitten with this peasant girl who’s suddenly shown up in their midst. It’s not as if she were particularly pretty or intelligent or, heaven forbid, sexy.

headline: Gender Politics Wiggles Into a World Guys Staked Out

lead_paragraph: Laura Jane Grace, the frontwoman of the punk band Against Me!, introduced all the new songs by name on Thursday night at the Music Hall of Williamsburg, as the singer of a band with a new album generally does, and should do.

headline: The Next Data Privacy Battle May Be Waged Inside Your Car
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Privacy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As cars increasingly come equipped with Internet connections, GPS and data recorders, concerns about what is being tracked and who has access to it.
lead_paragraph: Cars are becoming smarter than ever, with global positioning systems, Internet connections, data recorders and high-definition cameras. Drivers can barely make a left turn, put on their seatbelts or push 80 miles an hour without their actions somehow, somewhere being tracked or recorded.

headline: An Invitation to Geneva Two
abstract: The United Nations has sent out invitations to an international summit to address the conflict in Syria, called Geneva Two, which is scheduled to begin on Jan. 22 in Montreux, Switzerland.
lead_paragraph: An international summit to address the conflict in Syria, called Geneva Two, is scheduled to begin on Jan. 22 in Montreux, Switzerland. (Hotels in Geneva were fully booked by attendees to a watch convention.) The United Nations this week began sending out invitations, and Ayman Abdel Nour, a dissident Syrian exile who was once a friend of President Bashar al-Assad’s, posted one Thursday on his popular Arabic-language blog, All4Syria.

headline: Wrestlers in Leather: What More Is Required?
abstract: “The Legend of Hercules,” directed by Renny Harlin, has lots of abs and Kellan Lutz as the title demigod.
lead_paragraph: “The Legend of Hercules,” a new 3-D work of Classical beefcake scholarship, directed by Renny Harlin, is likely to be met with ridicule. At the crowded preview screening I attended on Thursday night in Manhattan, there were audible hoots of derision, which were, for the most part, well earned. But really, this movie, with its relatively modest running time and not-quite-household-name cast, is no more ridiculous than, let’s say, the “Thor” movies, and a lot less pretentious. It delivers what it promises, which is muscular guys in skimpy clothes fighting and howling, as well as some large-scale digitally enhanced battle sequences.

headline: Big Break? Well, Eyes Will Be on Him
abstract: A brief vacation for the actor Michael Urie is handing Clancy O’Connor the opportunity every understudy dreams of: proving himself to audiences and power brokers.
lead_paragraph: The Off Broadway hit “Buyer & Cellar” has delivered a 200 percent return to its investors in just six months, and everyone involved knows the main reason: The star, Michael Urie (television’s “Ugly Betty”), who has received phenomenal reviews in the one-man play. But with Mr. Urie on vacation this weekend, a perennial dream of New York actors is coming true. The understudy is going on.

headline: Video: An Updated Chevy Traverse That Can Fit the Family
abstract: The Chevrolet Traverse and its corporate siblings GMC Acadia and Buick Enclave have been substantially revised and are worth a look if you haul people or stuff.
lead_paragraph: Recently, I discovered that my older brother and his wife were interested in a Chevrolet Tahoe. Their reasoning was simple – its three rows of seating would be handy when chauffeuring my niece’s soccer teammates and gear. And they love the S.U.V. look.

headline: Two Power Options in One Small Package
abstract: The Powerdash r900 is a cylinder no wider than the your car’s charger but it also squeezes in an auxiliary battery.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Ventev, a company that makes battery and charger products, has an extra-compact car charger that manages to squeeze in an auxiliary battery.

abstract: The story of the woman who inspired the film “Philomena” is heartbreaking. But so is that of the man who was her real-life son.
lead_paragraph: In the early-to-mid 1980s, if you were a gay man in Washington working in politics, chances are you ended up on L Street near Capitol Hill, at a bar called Lost & Found.

lead_paragraph: After train accidents involving North Dakotan crude oil, the state’s political leaders are putting pressure on the Obama administration to improve railroad safety regulations, with some even urging a slowdown in drilling until safety solutions are found.

headline: They Want Her on Their Side

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In 2007, Brandee Barker and a colleague drove to a Nordstrom in Palo Alto, Calif., and bought Mark Zuckerberg a black suit. Mr. Zuckerberg, a founder of Facebook, was embarking on his first trip to Davos, Switzerland, for the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum, and Ms. Barker, then the head of public relations for his growing company, thought the occasion called for something more formal than his signature hooded sweatshirt.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama may have lost the power of persuasion with Congress, but he still has the underrated power of invitation to the White House. Since congressional Republicans remain hostile as ever to his agenda, next week Mr. Obama will begin hosting influential groups in the West Wing to try to spur specific action on national problems short of changes to federal law.

abstract: Alain Gauthier and his wife, Dafroza, have spent 13 years collecting evidence against Rwandans living in France whom they suspect of having participated in their country’s 1994 genocide.
lead_paragraph: REIMS, France — ABOVE his desk in a peaceful and tidy townhouse with pots of geraniums hanging from the windowsills and walls covered with photos of his children, Alain Gauthier keeps 24 files labeled with the names of some of the men and women accused in one of the most appalling crimes of the 20th century.

lead_paragraph: The Sri Lankan Ministry of Defense expressed shock and anger on Friday at what it called a “baseless allegation” against the nation’s military in a photo caption posted on the official Twitter feed of the United States Embassy the day before.

lead_paragraph: Mathew Martoma, a former SAC Capital Advisors hedge fund manager, “corrupted” doctors to get an “illegal edge” that helped him perpetrate the most lucrative insider trading scheme in history, a federal prosecutor said on Friday.

headline: In Rhino Horn Case, Judge Sees a Criminal Instead of a ‘Naïve Kid’
abstract: Michael Slattery Jr., who pleaded guilty last year to trafficking in the horns of an endangered species of rhinoceros, was sentenced to 14 months in prison.
lead_paragraph: Michael Slattery Jr. stood in court with his hands clenched behind him as if they were still in the shackles that had just been removed. It was time for his sentencing on Friday, in federal court in Brooklyn, an often surreal setting in which very different versions of the same human are described for the judge’s careful consideration.

headline: Thai Beer Loses Esteem After Heiress’s Remarks
abstract: Voters in rural Thailand have begun boycotting the popular Singha beer brand because of its affiliation to the leader of antigovernment protests.
lead_paragraph: UDON THANI, Thailand — It was probably inevitable in a country so obsessed with food and drink that Thailand’s political turmoil would spill over into beer.

abstract: Strange episodes have merely become part of the scenery for the Knicks as they have finally figured out how to play cohesive basketball.

headline: Lane Closings Scandal Shows Port Authority’s Status as 2 Warring Fiefs
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Bridges and Tunnels', 'George Washington Bridge']
abstract: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, controlled by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Gov. Chris Christie, appears to be wracked by politics.
lead_paragraph: After a top New Jersey official at the Port Authority, David Wildstein, ordered the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge that clogged Fort Lee, N.J., for four days in September, the authority’s New York-appointed executive director, Patrick J. Foye, exploded with anger and ordered the lanes reopened. But then the authority’s New Jersey-appointed chairman, David Samson, expressed outrage over Mr. Foye’s outrage, accusing him of leaking the story of the lane closings.

headline: It’s Time to Update Overtime
abstract: Obama should help workers by bringing the law up-to-date.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — PRESIDENT OBAMA has assured American workers that he won’t let Congress keep him from lending a hand during these tough economic times. “I will not allow gridlock, inaction or willful indifference to get in our way,” he said in a speech last year. “Whatever executive authority I have to help the middle class, I’ll use it.”

headline: To Regain Trust, Target Must Do More, Crisis Experts Say

headline: Nelson Ned, Florid Brazilian Balladeer, Dies at 66
abstract: Mr. Ned’s records and his sentimental style brought him a large following throughout Latin America.
lead_paragraph: Nelson Ned, a Brazilian singer of small stature and large voice who was hailed throughout Latin America as the “Little Giant of Song,” died on Sunday in São Paolo. He was 66.

lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Larry Speakes, Public Face of Reagan Era, Dies at 74
abstract: He became the press spokesman for President Reagan after his boss, the press secretary James Brady, was wounded in an attempt on the life of the president.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Larry Speakes, who became the public face of Ronald Reagan’s presidency when a would-be assassin’s bullet gravely wounded his boss, press secretary James Brady, died Friday in his native Mississippi. He was 74.

headline: Imagining President Christie

abstract: We have learned so much about how Chris Christie can handle a crisis this week.
lead_paragraph: Let us count the ways that this week’s traffic-jam scandal is actually good for Chris Christie’s presidential prospects.
