abstract: American officials say Iran has made no effort to use its influence to get the Syrian government to cease bombing and allow humanitarian aid.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Iran will not participate in peace talks on Syria that are to be held this month in Switzerland, a senior State Department official said Friday.

headline: Dale T. Mortensen, Labor Economist and Nobel Laureate, Dies at 74
abstract: Mr. Mortensen was one of three economists who shared the 2010 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences for their work on a line of economic thinking known as search theory.
lead_paragraph: Dale T. Mortensen, an economist whose pioneering work on labor markets won a Nobel and helped governments and policy makers better understand the stubborn complexities of unemployment, died on Thursday at his home in Wilmette, Ill. He was 74.

headline: Sex Is Not Our Problem
keywords: ['Sex', 'Sex Education', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: Dealing with the decline of the traditional family and high single-parent birthrates means addressing broader issues.
lead_paragraph: There is often a simplistic, black-or-white, conservative vs. progressive discussion around the dissolution of the traditional family and high single-parent birthrates in America and what these trends may portend for us as a country.

headline: Enrollees at Health Exchanges Face Struggle to Prove Coverage
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Many Americans who signed up through the federal marketplace for health care coverage have yet to receive an insurance card, policy number or bill.
lead_paragraph: FORT WORTH — Paul D. Donahue and his wife, Angela, are among more than a million Americans who have signed up for health coverage through the federal insurance exchange. Mr. Donahue has a card in his wallet from his insurer to prove it. But when he tried to use it to get a flu shot and fill prescriptions this week, local pharmacies could not confirm his coverage, so he left without his medications.

headline: Down to the Last Cigarette?
keywords: ['Smoking and Tobacco', 'Surgeon General (US)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Lung Cancer']
abstract: It might be time for another surgeon general’s report about the link between smoking and illness and death.
lead_paragraph: This is certainly turning out to be quite the year for 50th anniversaries. Fifty years ago next month, the Beatles made their U.S. debut on “The Ed Sullivan Show.” In 1964, President Lyndon Johnson started the War on Poverty. And 50 years ago Saturday, the surgeon general of the United States issued the single most important report that would ever come out of that office. It linked cigarette smoking to illness and death.

headline: Seeking Redemption, Sometimes With a Familiar Ring
abstract: See the ultimate political apology, culled from notable speeches and statements made in the aftermath of wrongdoing or other officeholder embarrassments.
lead_paragraph: See the ultimate political apology, culled from notable speeches and statements made in the aftermath of wrongdoing or other officeholder embarrassments.

headline: Florida’s Site Said to Delay Millions in Aid to Jobless
keywords: ['Unemployment Insurance', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Social Security (US)']
abstract: An analysis revealed that the botched rollout of Florida’s online system for unemployment claims may have kept jobless Floridians from receiving $20 million in benefits during October and November.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The botched rollout of Florida’s online system for unemployment claims may have kept jobless Floridians from receiving $20 million in benefits in October and November, according to an informal analysis by a workers’ rights group.

headline: Seahawks’ Punt Team Is Flashy With Play, Not Name
abstract: The unit, unlike other segments of one of the N.F.C.’s most dominant teams, lacks a nickname, but it shuts down return men.
lead_paragraph: RENTON, Wash. — In a locker room populated by the “Legion of Boom” and “Beast Mode” and even a “Fat Rabbit,” the most dominant unit on the most dominant team in the N.F.C. lacks a catchy nickname of its own. For this, Jeremy Lane, an integral member of that squad, apologizes.

headline: Booze, Revisited
abstract: At first, I couldn’t think of any alcoholics in my life — then they began to file into consciousness, coming into focus like ghosts in a story.
lead_paragraph: Dear Readers: Some of you had trouble finding my most recent column, on alcoholism. Since the latest entries are no longer part of Opinionator, the best way to locate my pieces is simply to search for my name in the Times’s search engine or go directly to my columnist page. I’ve always looked forward to reading your comments, even though the queue sometimes got so busy they had to be turned off — particularly unfortunate in this case since the 100 that were allowed were erudite and touching. Please keep your notes coming, as much as you can! I have a very busy year ahead, but I will be back to you as often as possible, even though it won’t be on a regular schedule. You can think of me as a little occasional surprise. Here’s to a productive and healthy 2014. — Dick

headline: Wall St. Shock: Take a Day Off, Even a Sunday
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Work-Life Balance']
abstract: After a review, Bank of America Merrill Lynch said its lowest-level employees should try to take four weekend days off each month.
lead_paragraph: For the ambitious college graduates who flock to Wall Street, working into the wee hours or even pulling all-nighters is an unwritten expectation of the job. Spending both Saturdays and Sundays at the office is the norm.

headline: World Bank Is Criticized for Honduran Loan
abstract: The bank’s ombudsman delivered a stinging review of a loan to a palm-oil company engaged in a violent conflict with poor farm workers over land in Honduras.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The World Bank ombudsman issued a stinging critique Friday of the bank’s private-sector arm over a loan to a Honduran palm-oil company engaged in a violent conflict with farm workers over land tenure.

headline: Arkansas: Lieutenant Governor Quitting Under Pressure
abstract: Lt. Gov. Mark Darr said Friday that he would leave office on Feb. 1, giving in to pressure from Democrats and fellow Republicans who said his impeachment was inevitable over ethics violations tied to his campaign and office spending.
lead_paragraph: Lt. Gov. Mark Darr, who was facing the threat of impeachment proceedings in the aftermath of a settlement with the state’s Ethics Commission, said on Friday that he would resign on Feb. 1. Although Mr. Darr, a Republican elected in 2010, had resisted bipartisan demands for his resignation, he agreed to quit as lawmakers openly discussed removing him from office. State investigators determined last month that Mr. Darr had repeatedly broken state law by using more than $31,000 in campaign money for personal reasons, accepting improper contributions and maintaining faulty records. Mr. Darr, who abandoned a bid for Congress after an Arkansas political blogger accused him of the misconduct, said his errors were unintentional but agreed to pay $11,000 in fines.

headline: U.S. Advisers Sent to Help Somalia Fight the Shabab
abstract: Three military advisers were deployed to Somalia last month to help provide logistics, planning and communication assistance to forces combating the Islamic militant group.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon has sent a small team of uniformed military advisers to Somalia, the first American troops assigned there since 1993, when 18 Americans were killed in the failed “Black Hawk Down” mission.

headline: An Assembly of Quietly Moving Parts
abstract: “The Record,” a dance-theater piece at the Public Theater, part of the Under the Radar Festival, calls reverent attention to the shared experience of the stage.
lead_paragraph: The stars of “The Record” — all 45 of them — do not really do much. They stand stock still on a bare stage, strike some funny poses then walk around a bit. They do a little running, too, and assemble in groups and sometimes stretch out on the floor. Just now and then, one will extend a hand to touch another, or a young woman will fall backward into a man’s arms, in a moment of connection that registers with soft surprise.

headline: No Jobs, No Benefits, and Lousy Pay
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Minimum Wage', 'Productivity', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Poverty', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'Editorials']
abstract: The latest jobs report is a sobering backdrop for the debate on poverty and inequality.
lead_paragraph: There is nothing good to say about the December employment report, which showed that only 74,000 jobs were added last month. But dismal as it was, the report came at an opportune political moment. The new numbers rebut the Republican arguments that jobless benefits need not be renewed, and that the current minimum wage is adequate. At the same time, they underscore the need, only recently raised to the top of the political agenda, to combat poverty and inequality.

headline: Bill Conlin, Sportswriter Who Quit After Molestation Claims, Dies at 79
abstract: Mr. Conlin was honored by Baseball’s Hall of Fame in 2011, the same year a newspaper article detailed several accounts of sexual abuse he was accused of committing.
lead_paragraph: Bill Conlin, a sports columnist for The Daily News in Philadelphia who was honored by the Baseball Hall of Fame in 2011 but who left his job later that year amid a storm of publicity over child-molestation accusations, died on Thursday in Largo, Fla. He was 79.

headline: Haiti, Unfinished and Forsaken
abstract: Four years after the earthquake, humanitarian aid seems to have run its course and development is lagging.
lead_paragraph: Four years after the earthquake, Haiti is a fragile, largely forgotten country. It’s possible that some natural or man-made crisis this year could push it back into the headlines. But sustained attention, with the kind of support from outside that Haiti still needs to rebuild and become more self-sufficient, is mostly gone.

headline: Weigh-In Section
abstract: Double quad stacks from Martin Ashwood-Smith.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Oh boy. I like Martin Ashwood-Smith’s puzzles, but this one really wasn’t in my wheelhouse. That doesn’t make it a bad puzzle, I just had a tough time solving it because I didn’t know much about the things in it. You know you’re in trouble when the clue at 1 Across — “It has a close ‘Kentucky’ cousin” — has you thinking about bourbon instead of flora.

headline: Increased Security for Nuclear Materials
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Editorials']
abstract: There has been progress, but at a nuclear summit meeting in March, world leaders can do more to make the world safer.
lead_paragraph: There is some rare good news on the issue of securing and containing deadly nuclear materials. In the last two years, seven countries have forsaken their uranium and plutonium stockpiles, bringing the number of nations still possessing appreciable quantities of nuclear fuel usable for bomb-making down to 25. In 1991, the number was 52.

headline: Yankees Sign Reliever (Matt Thornton) and Cut Outfielder (Vernon Wells)
abstract: Thornton, the former White Sox and Red Sox pitcher, will replace Boone Logan as the main left-hander in the bullpen.
lead_paragraph: With a glut of outfielders and a shortage of left-handed relief pitchers, the Yankees swapped out one for the other Friday, cutting Vernon Wells and signing Matt Thornton.

headline: A Mr. Feder, Once of Fort Lee, Chimes In
abstract: Richard Feder of Fort Lee, N.J., whose name was used on “Saturday Night Live” years ago as that of a letter writer to a news show, was stuck in the traffic caused by the lane closings.
lead_paragraph: A Mr. Richard Feder, famously from Fort Lee, N.J., has a question about the rather infamous closings of lanes to the George Washington Bridge.

headline: A Guillotine in Storage Bears Signs of a Role in Silencing Nazis’ Critics
abstract: The Bavarian National Museum has provisionally identified a guillotine as the one the Nazis used to execute Sophie and Hans Scholl, who led the White Rose resistance to Hitler.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A guillotine used to execute thousands of people during the Nazi era, including a brother and sister who led a group of Munich students known as the White Rose in resistance to Hitler, has been provisionally identified in a storage area belonging to the Bavarian National Museum, museum officials said Friday.

headline: Franklin McCain, Who Fought for Rights at All-White Lunch Counter, Dies at 73
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Segregation and Desegregation']
abstract: Mr. McCain helped fuel the civil rights movement in 1960 when he and three friends from their all-black college requested, and were refused, coffee and doughnuts at a whites-only lunch counter in Greensboro, N.C.
lead_paragraph: Franklin McCain, who helped fuel the civil rights movement in 1960 when he and three friends from their all-black college requested, and were refused, coffee and doughnuts at a whites-only lunch counter in Greensboro, N.C., died on Thursday in Greensboro. He was 73.

headline: Colts vs. Patriots: A Great Rivalry, Now Revised
abstract: Since Tom Brady’s first career start more than a dozen years ago, the rivalry between the New England Patriots and the Indianapolis Colts has been must-watch football.
lead_paragraph: Since Tom Brady’s first career start more than a dozen years ago, the rivalry between the New England Patriots and the Indianapolis Colts has been must-watch football. For years, Brady faced Peyton Manning in a duel of the top two quarterbacks in the N.F.L. With Manning playing in Denver for the Broncos, a second chapter of the rivalry is being established. Now it is Brady versus Andrew Luck, the Colts’ second-year quarterback and an emerging star.

headline: Dropbox Says Site Down After Maintenance Error, Not From Hackers
abstract: Dropbox blamed the shutdown on routine maintenance.
lead_paragraph: Updated January 11, 9:46 a.m. | A hacker claiming to be a member of the loose hacking collective Anonymous took credit for knocking offline the website of the cloud storage provider Dropbox late Friday. Attempts to reach the site were met with an error message.

headline: New Reality for Heat: From Rolling to Resting
abstract: Miami is not taking any chances with injured players this season, resting Dwyane Wade, Shane Battier and Mario Chalmers.
lead_paragraph: The Miami Heat appear to be learning from one of their few mistakes.

headline: Neiman Marcus Investigates Breach Involving Credit Card Data
abstract: Neiman Marcus confirmed that its systems had been compromised by hackers, after news that a similar breach at Target was much larger than previously thought.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Neiman Marcus is investigating a security breach involving credit card information stolen from its customers.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 11, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, January 11, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “We’re going to continue to file and act as if we’re married. Some people have said that’s an act of civil disobedience. If it is, so be it.”

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
abstract: A disappointing jobs report, thousands of airline flight cancellations and an aggressive move to attract cellphone customers.
lead_paragraph: A disappointing jobs report, thousands of airline flight cancellations and an aggressive move to attract cellphone customers.

headline: South Sudan: Army Says Its Soldiers Have Regained Control of Northern City
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: South Sudan’s military on Friday retook Bentiu, the capital of an oil-producing state, from rebels loyal to the former vice president, according to a military spokesman.
lead_paragraph: South Sudan’s military on Friday retook Bentiu, the capital of an oil-producing state, from rebels loyal to the former vice president, said a military spokesman, Col. Philip Aguer. Fighting in South Sudan began last month in the national capital, Juba, after President Salva Kiir, left, said that his former vice president, Riek Machar, had attempted a coup. Thousands are believed to have been killed and 200,000 displaced by the fighting, which has involved the country’s largest two ethnic groups, the Dinka and the Nuer. Peace talks are underway in Ethiopia. The military’s claim that it had regained control of Bentiu in the north could not immediately be confirmed. Colonel Aguer accused the rebels of looting the city and burning buildings. The medical aid group Doctors Without Borders also said that its facilities in Bentiu had been looted. “It is unacceptable that one of the only humanitarian organizations still providing assistance to the population in Bentiu has been looted,” said the group’s general director, Arjan Hehenkamp. The United Nations Security Council on Friday urged the warring parties to stop the fighting, continue negotiations and ensure the protection of the country’s oil fields. The Council also asked Mr. Kiir to release political prisoners and urged Mr. Machar to agree to a cessation of hostilities “without precondition.”

headline: St. John’s Pulls Together While Playing Through Grief
abstract: In the past two years, family members or friends of four Red Storm players have died, and through that shared sorrow, the team has drawn closer.
lead_paragraph: Steve Lavin, a son of an English professor, is philosophical about life and, in particular, his St. John’s men’s basketball team. He searches for themes, uses analogies as often as gestures and, as his father did, takes time to find the exact words to express his thoughts.

headline: Corrections: January 11, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on January 11, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Dreaming a Dream for a Daughter Talented in Art
abstract: Despite living under threat of homelessness, Alicia Guillén, 41, wants most to help her teenager pursue educational opportunities.
lead_paragraph: So far, Alicia Guillén’s dreams have come true.

headline: For Fund Investors, the Dangers of Rarefied Air
keywords: ['Mutual Funds', 'Exchange Traded Funds', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'United States Economy', 'Interest Rates', 'Quantitative Easing', 'Government Bonds', 'Junk Bonds']
abstract: In 2013, stock fund managers achieved their best year since 1991. But for various reasons, some strategists say investors should rein in their enthusiasm this year.
lead_paragraph: THE stock market ended 2013 at record highs and with indicators of investor optimism near best-ever levels. The enthusiasm is understandable after a year that was the strongest for stocks in well over a decade — but whether it is wise is another matter.

headline: From Ice Level, Rick Nash Helps Rangers Take Season to New Heights
abstract: Nash scored the game-winning goal from his back as the Rangers beat the Stars to move three games over .500 for the first time this season.
lead_paragraph: Coming off perhaps their most satisfying win of the season — in Chicago, over the defending Stanley Cup champions, the Blackhawks — the Rangers generated the same kind of success Friday at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Guru Funds, Mimicking the Smart Money
keywords: ['Mutual Funds', 'Exchange Traded Funds', 'Hedge Funds', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Some funds are trying to copy the investments of successful hedge fund managers and business leaders, but not everyone thinks the approach makes for canny investing.
lead_paragraph: SUCCESS breeds imitation, whether acknowledged or not. Now, two exchange-traded funds and a mutual fund are being open about their copying: They aim to replicate the investments of the most successful hedge funds and business people.

headline: In Search of Europe’s Growth Stories
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Mutual Funds', 'Exchange Traded Funds', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: As Europe finally starts to emerge from recession, some fund managers are sifting for those companies that have best resisted the undertow.
lead_paragraph: ALTHOUGH mutual and exchange-traded funds that invest in Europe recently posted strong results for the second consecutive year, the rally has largely been two-dimensional.

headline: A Surprising Surge for Industrial Stocks
keywords: ['Mutual Funds', 'Exchange Traded Funds', 'Natural Gas', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Hydraulic Fracturing']
abstract: Mutual funds concentrating in industrial shares outperformed the broader market, and some managers see continued good times in 2014.
lead_paragraph: IT may come as a surprise to those who have fretted over the hollowing of American industry, but in a year of big market gains, industrial stocks were among the strongest performers.

headline: In Fund Expenses, Tenths of a Point Mean a Lot
abstract: When mutual fund returns shrink, their annual costs start to stand out.
lead_paragraph: HOW much a fund costs to run may seem inconsequential, especially now. With the backdrop of a “go big or go home” stock market that frightens many small investors but can enrich those who take a chance, how could several tenths of a percentage point in operating expenses, one way or the other, really matter?

headline: Making the Most of Financial Resources at Hand
abstract: Those who have resolved to put their financial house on sounder footing this year may benefit from two new books.
lead_paragraph: IF improving your net worth made your list of New Year’s resolutions, two books — one about the personal investment ideas of John Maynard Keynes and the other from the creator of a relatively new financial website — could help.

headline: In a Stellar Quarter, Three Funds That Went Over the Top
abstract: Some of the best-performing mutual funds for the final three months of 2013 found gains in businesses as diverse as trucking, technology and automotive paint shops.
lead_paragraph: NEARLY every style of stock fund rose in the fourth quarter of 2013, and the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index continued its long sprint, returning 9.9 percent. But the stewards of three of the top-performing mutual funds beat even that heady return, finding gains in sectors as diverse as trucking, technology and automotive paint shops.

headline: In the Bond Market, Lower Expectations Became the Reality
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Interest Rates', 'Mutual Funds', 'Exchange Traded Funds', 'United States Economy', 'Junk Bonds', 'Government Bonds']
abstract: The math has changed for investors in the bond market — and not in a good way, as a leading bond index fell into negative territory in 2013.
lead_paragraph: BONDS lived down to expectations last year. The threat of rising interest rates, which had lurked in the ether for five years, finally materialized, pushing prices lower.

headline: Before His Death, Boy Faced Weeks of Abuse, Officials Say
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: As Mayor Bill de Blasio ordered an investigation into the death of Myls Dobson, 4, prosecutors said Kryzie King, a family friend, admitted to torturing Myls.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio ordered an investigation on Friday into the death of a 4-year-old boy who was beaten, tortured and starved for three weeks by his caregiver, as new details of the boy’s horrific ordeal emerged in court.

headline: In Performance: Eric Tucker
abstract: Eric Tucker plays the title character in Bedlam Theater’s production of Shakespeare’s “Hamlet.”
lead_paragraph: Eric Tucker plays the title character in Bedlam Theater’s production of Shakespeare’s “Hamlet.”

headline: New Clashes Erupt in Ukraine After Trial
abstract: At least a dozen protesters were injured in clashes with riot police after a Ukrainian court on Friday convicted three men of plotting to topple a statue of Vladimir Lenin in 2011.
lead_paragraph: At least a dozen protesters were injured in clashes with riot police in Kiev after a Ukrainian court on Friday convicted three men of plotting to topple a statue of Vladimir Lenin in 2011 in Boryspil, a city southeast of the capital. The protesters had denounced the prosecution of the three men as politically motivated and a “show trial” and pointed to evidence showing that the Boryspil City Council had voted to remove the Lenin statue even before the alleged plot was discovered. About 100 protesters had gathered at the courthouse in Kiev for the verdict. The clashes began after the three defendants were sentenced to six years in prison. Among the injured was Yuri V. Lutsenko, a former interior minister and an outspoken opposition leader who helped coordinate the recent mass demonstrations in central Kiev against the government of President Viktor F. Yanukovich. Local news agencies reported that Mr. Lutsenko had been knocked unconscious. Mr. Lutsenko, who was also an organizer of the 2004 Orange Revolution, is the leader of an opposition party called the Third Ukrainian Republic.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 10, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Week in Pictures for Jan. 10
abstract: Subjects include: Cold weather, visitors to Gracie Mansion and an emergency landing in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: Subjects include: Cold weather, visitors to Gracie Mansion and an emergency landing in the Bronx.

headline: If Couples Could Be Corporations
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Corporations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: In the same-sex marriage debate, why not take a page from the rights already granted to corporate America?
lead_paragraph: JUST before New Year’s, I attended a lovely wedding back in Texas, my home state. It couldn’t have been nicer: The couple exchanged vows out on a ranch under a perfect sky, and the barbecue and buffalo burgers served in the barn after the ceremony were mighty tasty.

headline: Retired Correction Officer’s Death May Have Stemmed From a Romantic Quarrel
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Assaults', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The police said an off-duty correction officer shot Jeffrey Ragland, 50, once in the chest, following a dispute involving a woman, who is also a correction officer.
lead_paragraph: In what may have been a romantic quarrel involving one former and two current New York City correction officers, a man was shot and killed early on Friday morning on a Queens street, officials said.

headline: LeBron James Seethes, and Nets Are Hotter, Winning 5th in Row
abstract: With Miami missing three regular starters, the pressure was on James, and his 36 points were not enough as he lost his composure.
lead_paragraph: LeBron James spent much of Friday night fuming. Almost as soon as he stepped on the court, he was jawing at the referees, shooting them incredulous glares. He slammed the ball to the floor early in the fourth quarter when his teammate Michael Beasley committed an offensive foul. He told a heckler along the baseline to sit down.

headline: For Once, Every Player Makes Name for Himself
abstract: In Friday’s game between the Nets and the Miami Heat, the players wore jerseys with nicknames on the back.
lead_paragraph: There was never any doubt that two of the N.B.A.’s new nickname jerseys would read Big Ticket and Truth, the monikers of Kevin Garnett and Paul Pierce of the Nets, but it is doubtful that anyone in the United States would have expected Andrei Kirilenko to go with Кириленко.

headline: In Bridge Scandal, a Slight Heard Around the World
abstract: An aide to Gov. Christie called Mayor Mark Sokolich of Fort Lee, N.J., a “little Serbian,” which was in poor taste and also untrue. He is of Croatian descent.
lead_paragraph: Amid the rivers of invective that Gov. Chris Christie’s allies spilled as they plotted to cripple traffic in Fort Lee, N.J., was one bitter drop of bile: The city’s mayor was referred to as a “little Serbian.”

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE PLACE BEYOND THE PINES  (2013) An itinerant motorcycle stunt rider (Ryan Gosling) tries to support a former lover (Eva Mendes, above with Mr. Gosling) and their son by robbing banks, leading to an encounter with a rookie cop (Bradley Cooper) that will have consequences neither can fathom at the time. “The most radical aspect of ‘The Place Beyond the Pines’ is its relentless linearity, the way it tells its story without foreshadowing or flashing back or resorting to other conventional shortcuts,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this three-part drama, directed by Derek Cianfrance (“Blue Valentine”). “Watching it is refreshing and absorbing partly because it is rare for a film to show this kind of confidence in its own narrative momentum, which is also a gesture of faith in the audience’s willingness to pay attention.” He added, “Your attention is especially rewarded by the work of Mr. Gosling and Mr. Cooper, who offer contrasting studies in tragic, shortsighted masculine intensity.”

headline: Cuomo Blocks Liquor License for Caterer in Upper East Side Church
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo vetoed the legislation regarding an Upper East Side catering hall who lost its previous liquor license because of a law banning sales within 200 feet of a church.
lead_paragraph: An Upper East Side catering hall that has waged a long-running campaign for a liquor license was dealt a major setback on Friday when Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo vetoed legislation tailor-made for the hall.

headline: Fire Ravages China District Said to Inspire Shangri-La
abstract: The fire broke out in Dukezong in Yunnan Province, which has cast itself as an inspiration for the mythic Shangri-la.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Fire blazed through an ancient Tibetan neighborhood in southwest China on Saturday, destroying hundreds of wooden homes and shops that have drawn tourists to an area casting itself as the inspiration for mythic Shangri-La.

headline: A Hammock In Kentucky?
abstract: Soda cans and bad analysis.
lead_paragraph: National Review has an actually interesting report by Kevin Williamson on the state of Appalachia, providing a valuable portrait of the region’s woes — plus an account of how people turn food stamps fungible by converting them into soda. But the piece also has a moral: the big problem, it argues, is the way government aid creates dependency. It’s the Paul Ryan notion of the safety net as a “hammock” that makes life too easy for the poor.

headline: From Today’s Paper: Whale Washes Up on a Florida Beach
abstract: A male sperm whale, said to weigh as much as 15 tons, came ashore on Friday in Boca Raton, Fla. Wildlife officials were unsure of the cause of death and said that a necropsy would be performed. Sperm whales are considered an endangered species.
lead_paragraph: A male sperm whale, said to weigh as much as 15 tons, came ashore on Friday in Boca Raton, Fla. Wildlife officials were unsure of the cause of death and said that a necropsy would be performed. Sperm whales are considered an endangered species.

headline: Ariel Sharon, Israeli Hawk Who Sought Peace on His Terms, Dies at 85

lead_paragraph: Ariel Sharon, one of the most influential figures in Israel’s history, a military commander and political leader who at the height of his power redrew the country’s electoral map, only to suffer a severe stroke from which he never recovered, died on Saturday in a hospital near Tel Aviv. He was 85.

Will suggests that consumer preferences are always going to win out over big government’s finger-wagging and incentives to do whatever it is liberals claim is the right thing. Prognosticating about the future of the Affordable Care Act, universal preschool and a possible minimum wage hike, he extrapolates from the auto market:

headline: Sharon, Through the Years
abstract: As a warrior and political leader whose reputation rose and fell with the times, Ariel Sharon left a profound imprint on Israel.
lead_paragraph: As a warrior and political leader whose reputation rose and fell with the times, Ariel Sharon left a profound imprint on Israel.

headline: Ariel Sharon, 1928-2014
abstract: A cunning general who went on to hold nearly every top Israeli government post, Mr. Sharon suffered a stroke in 2006 and fell into a coma from which he never awoke.
lead_paragraph: A cunning general who went on to hold nearly every top Israeli government post, Mr. Sharon suffered a stroke in 2006 and fell into a coma from which he never awoke.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s “Money Talking”: January 10, 2014
abstract: This week, Joe discusses Janet Yellen, the new Fed chair.
lead_paragraph: Janet Yellen will be the first woman to head the the Federal Reserve when she takes over for Ben Bernanke at the end of January. This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar from Time magazine discuss the woman who will soon steer the world’s largest economy. Ms. Foroohar said Yellen will focus on how to help ordinary families get back on their feet, while Joe said Yellen is an expert on unemployment who will apply her skills to the nation’s stubborn unemployment problem.

headline: The Raleigh Experiment
abstract: Much misery, no gains.
lead_paragraph: North Carolina is an interesting place these days, and I mean that in the worst possible way. It’s a southern state, but one with a major technology complex, growing foreign investment, and what seemed until recently to be a moderating, increasingly sophisticated political culture. But then came the Republican wave of 2010, and NC was taken over by right-wing radicals, who have — among other things — taken the nation’s hardest line in cutting benefits to the unemployed.

headline: A Last Look at the Media and the Dreaded Polar Vortex
abstract: A final look at media reactions to the dread polar vortex.
lead_paragraph: I was invited to explore the feeding frenzy surrounding the dreaded polar vortex on the NPR show On The Media. The segment, “Sucked Into the Polar Vortex,” is fun and brief. Give a listen here (I’ll add a transcript link when there is one):
