headline: Sharing Your Wisdom, Within Limits
keywords: ['Start-ups', 'Careers and Professions', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Mentors', 'Workplace Environment']
abstract: A start-up’s C.E.O. says aspiring entrepreneurs are constantly seeking his advice. He wants to help, but he also wants to have a life.
lead_paragraph: I am the C.E.O. of a technology start-up with a pretty major presence, especially in our home city. Every day I get a request for a meeting from an aspiring or early-stage entrepreneur. They all say, “Can I just pick your brain?” If I agreed to even a fraction of these requests, my head would become a colander. I’m already seriously slammed: We’re growing fast, I travel a lot and, most important, I have lots of young team members who need my time.

headline: Don’t Snow on His Parade
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Snow and Snowstorms']
abstract: A snowplow operator says that even in subzero temperatures, he “drives with the window open so I can hear if the truck makes a funny noise.”

headline: An Advantage Vanishes for Money Funds
keywords: ['Money Market Mutual Funds', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mutual Funds']
abstract: In a turnaround from decades past, money market bank deposits are paying more interest, on average, than money market mutual funds.
lead_paragraph: When money market mutual funds were invented back in 1971, they offered something new. Investors could earn higher yields than on bank deposits, with nearly the same liquidity and safety. But that has changed. Currently, a money market deposit at Citibank pays about five times as much interest as an investment in the Fidelity Cash Reserves fund — though, in today’s low-rate environment, the yields are minuscule.

headline: A Market Streak Has Ended, but the Echoes Haven’t
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', "Standard & Poor's 500-Stock Index", 'Interest Rates', 'Quantitative Easing']
abstract: A two-year pattern turned a bargain-basement stock market into a much more expensive one.
lead_paragraph: After two improbable, gravity-defying years, the streak is over.

headline: The Vicious Circle of Income Inequality
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Income', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: New forces are causing the American income gap to feed on itself, whether in the political process, education or the broader economy.
lead_paragraph: Almost every culture has some variation on the saying, “rags to rags in three generations.” Whether it’s “clogs to clogs” or “rice paddy to rice paddy,” the message is essentially the same: Starting with nothing, the first generation builds a successful enterprise, which its profligate offspring then manage poorly, so that by the time the grandchildren take over, little value remains.

headline: Michael Gregoire, on Diversity’s Importance
abstract: The chief executive of CA Technologies says that “if you’re dreaming bigger, you have to bring more diverse types of people into your organization.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Michael P. Gregoire, chief executive of CA Technologies, the software makers based in Islandia, N.Y., was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Syria’s Conflict Told Through a Caustic Wit
abstract: “You know, when you live with shelling all the time, you just let everything go,” said the Syrian activist Razan Ghazzawi. “You have to laugh.”
lead_paragraph: Raed Fares and Razan Ghazzawi are well-known Syrian activists who are wrapping up a speaking tour of North America. Ms. Ghazzawi, a prominent blogger who fled Damascus after facing government persecution and arrest, has traveled across Syria and the Middle East to raise awareness about the human cost of the Syria conflict. Mr. Fares runs an activist media center in the northern village of Kafranbel, which has gained a measure of international attention because of the witty banners and posters, many of them designed by Mr. Fares and his team, that protesters have displayed there.

headline: Ariel Sharon, the Ruthless Warrior Who Could Have Made Peace
abstract: He was the one Israeli leader who could have reached a settlement with the Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — POLITICS, to Ariel Sharon, was like a Ferris wheel. But he didn’t make do with just staying on the wheel; he did all he could to climb to the top and stay there.

headline: Bailout Risk, Far Beyond the Banks
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Hedge Funds', 'Mutual Funds', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: In the too-big-to-fail parade, what about a closer look at the asset management firms that oversee trillions of investor dollars?
lead_paragraph: Everyone knows that the largest of our nation’s banks would be destined for a taxpayer bailout if they ran into trouble anytime soon. But which nonbank financial institutions — say, asset management companies offering hedge funds or mutual funds — might also pose too-big-to-fail risks because of their size and interconnections?

headline: Light-Bulb Moments for a Nonprofit
keywords: ['Medicine and Health', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: A group that creates medical technology for developing countries has found that the job goes far beyond research and design.
lead_paragraph: No baby should die or be disabled because a light bulb can’t be replaced. Yet during visits to hospitals in India and other countries, Krista Donaldson often saw lifesaving phototherapy systems, used to treat infant jaundice, languishing in dusty corners because of burned-out bulbs and other seemingly simple problems.

headline: Eminent Domain: A Long Shot Against Blight
keywords: ['Eminent Domain', 'Foreclosures', 'Mortgages', 'Law and Legislation', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The mayor of Richmond, Calif., is pushing a novel use of eminent domain to prevent foreclosures. Financial firms are very, very unhappy.
lead_paragraph: You can’t fight city hall, the saying goes. But Gayle McLaughlin, the mayor of Richmond, Calif., a city of 100,000 souls, would tell you that fighting Wall Street is harder. Even for city hall.

headline: Dolce & Gabbana: Fall 2014 Menswear
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: In Scandal’s Wake, McKinsey Seeks Culture Shift
abstract: Touched by scandal, a firm that has long relied on a culture of trust has laid down some tougher rules to follow.
lead_paragraph: Dominic Barton is 51 years old, 6 feet 4 and silver-haired, yet he has the countenance of a choirboy. Born in Uganda, he is the son of a missionary and a nurse, both Canadians. But it could be said that the society to which he really belongs is that of McKinsey & Company.

headline: Panthers Out to Disprove Underdog Label in Rematch
abstract: After finishing with a 12-4 record and winning the N.F.C. South with a defense ranked second in the N.F.L. behind the Seattle Seahawks, the Panthers have wiped the smiles off skeptics’ faces.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Captain Munnerlyn has played for the Carolina Panthers long enough to know a bad defense. Remember 2011? Their defense was ranked 28th in the N.F.L.

headline: France Oil Giant Is Expected to Seek Shale Gas in Britain
abstract: It would be the first major oil company explore for natural gas and oil in shale rock in that country.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The French oil giant Total is on the verge of becoming the first major oil company to explore for natural gas and oil in shale rock in Britain.

headline: Variety: A Physical Acrostic
abstract: A geeky acrostic by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — I loved this one. My inner science geek stands right beside that of Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon (see their notes below), and today’s acrostic puzzle was right on my wavelength. That’s a lot funnier if you’ve studied physics.

headline: Arbitrator’s Ruling Banishes the Yankees’ Alex Rodriguez for a Season
abstract: The arbitrator hearing Alex Rodriguez’s appeal of his 211-game doping suspension upheld most of the punishment on Saturday, sidelining him for 162 games, all of next season and the postseason.
lead_paragraph: Yankees third baseman Alex Rodriguez was barred for 162 games and the 2014 postseason, the longest suspension for doping in baseball history, after an arbitrator upheld most of the punishment sought by Major League Baseball.

headline: Jil Sander: Fall 2014 Menswear
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Defying Japan, Rancher Saves Fukushima’s Radioactive Cows
keywords: ['Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Cattle', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Nuclear Energy']
abstract: Angered by what he considers Japan’s efforts to sweep away the inconvenient truths of a nuclear disaster, a rancher returns to the no-man’s land near the devastated plant.
lead_paragraph: NAMIE, Japan — His may be one of the world’s more quixotic protests.

headline: Banks Say No to Marijuana Money, Legal or Not
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Marijuana', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'States (US)']
abstract: Banks across the country are reluctant to provide services to marijuana businesses, fearing that federal regulators and law enforcement authorities might punish them.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — In his second-floor office above a hair salon in north Seattle, Ryan Kunkel is seated on a couch placing $1,000 bricks of cash — dozens of them — in a rumpled brown paper bag. When he finishes, he stashes the money in the trunk of his BMW and sets off on an adrenalized drive downtown, darting through traffic and nervously checking to see if anyone is following him.

headline: Unearthing Nuggets of Gold for NBC
abstract: Work performed by an army of researchers will backstop NBC’s 539 hours of live coverage of the Olympics from Sochi.
lead_paragraph: STAMFORD, Conn. — Nothing satisfies NBC’s crew of Olympic researchers more than discovering something unusual about an athlete heading to the Games. A little-known back story or a strange hobby. A name change or a shifted national affiliation. An injury or a medical condition overcome. And if an athlete is not a household name, all the better.

headline: Presidential Run Likely for Egypt’s Top General
abstract: General Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi all but explicitly linked his candidacy to this week’s referendum on a revised constitution.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s top military officer on Saturday offered the clearest indication yet that he sees this week’s referendum on a revised Constitution as a prelude to a bid for the presidency, moving to consolidate his power after his ouster of President Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood.

headline: Raging Fire in Ancient Tibetan Town
abstract: More than 2,000 firefighters tried over 10 hours to bring a fire under control in Dukezong, an ancient Tibetan town in China’s Yunnan Province.
lead_paragraph: More than 2,000 firefighters tried over 10 hours to bring a fire under control in Dukezong, an ancient Tibetan town in China’s Yunnan Province.

headline: A-Rod’s Suspension Reduced
abstract: The suspension of Alex Rodriguez of the New York Yankees was reduced from 211 to 162 games.
lead_paragraph: The suspension of Alex Rodriguez of the New York Yankees was reduced from 211 to 162 games.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Jan. 11
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey remains in hot water after his office was linked to lane closings causing gridlock in Fort Lee, N.J., as political punishment for the town’s mayor who did not endorse the governor. Sunday morning show guests dole out advice for the possible 2016 presidential candidate.
lead_paragraph: It was not Gov. Chris Christie’s week. The New Jersey Republican faced mounting criticism after emails and texts linked his office to lane closures on the George Washington Bridge from Fort Lee, N.J., in September. The closures were apparently retribution for the town’s mayor declining to endorse Mr. Christie for re-election. In a two-hour news conference on Thursday, Mr. Christie apologized, saying he was “blindsided” by the news. He fired Bridget Anne Kelly, his deputy chief of staff who wrote in one email, “time for some traffic problems in Fort Lee.”

headline: Israel and World Grapple With Sharon’s Mixed Legacy
abstract: A life and career paralleled Israel’s development, for better or worse.
lead_paragraph: SDEROT, Israel — When the Mark family heard the news about the death of Ariel Sharon on the radio on Saturday afternoon, they immediately turned their car around and headed to his sprawling sheep farm here in the Negev desert, where he is expected to be buried on a hill next to his wife, Lily.

headline: Emma Thompson, Bryan Cranston and Other Party Minglers
abstract: At the relaxed American Film Institute luncheon, stars turned into fans and took the opportunity to meet the performers they admired.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “I’m going to go tell Bryan Cranston that I worship the ground he walks on,” Emma Thompson said Friday at a luncheon for the American Film Institute. She made a beeline for Mr. Cranston, there as the star of “Breaking Bad,” and began complimenting. That means so much coming from you, Mr. Cranston murmured, as others (Tom Hanks among them) lined up to pay tribute.

headline: The Mixed Marriage
keywords: ['Marriages', 'Religion and Belief', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Photography', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Lise Funderburg speaks with Yael Ben-Zion, a photographer raised in Israel, about her new book, “Intermarried.
lead_paragraph: Lise Funderburg, a journalist, interviewed Yael Ben-Zion, a photographer raised in Israel, about her new book, “Intermarried,” published by Kehrer, which features families from the Washington Heights neighborhood where she lives with her French husband and 5-year-old twins.

headline: For Yanks, Some Payroll Relief Now but Questions Down the Road
abstract: The Yankees have been attempting to keep their payroll below $189 million in 2014. Alex Rodriguez’s suspension makes that possible and frees them to make a strong contract offer to Masahiro Tanaka
lead_paragraph: For more than two years, the Yankees have considered Alex Rodriguez’s record-setting contract a burden, a mistake and a hindrance to their planning. With so much money invested in a rapidly declining player, Rodriguez’s presence was a reminder of the team’s financial folly.

headline: Thunder Road
abstract: Chris Christie groveled like a champ, but the traffic jam scam is still unraveling.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — I HAVE learned two things covering politics.

headline: How Can We Help Men? By Helping Women
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Gender', 'Income Inequality', 'Child Care', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: The sinking floor, not the glass ceiling, is the urgent issue.
lead_paragraph: THIS week Maria Shriver brings together a star-studded cast of celebrities, from Hillary Rodham Clinton to Beyoncé, to call attention to the economic plight of American women and demand that women’s needs be put “at the center of policy making.”

headline: A Longer Life for the Space Station
abstract: Giving it an extra four years would provide more time for scientific and commercial experiments.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration’s decision to extend the international space station’s time in orbit by at least four years makes good sense. Some $100 billion has been invested to build the station, which was completed less than three years ago. The plan had been to allow the station to plunge into the ocean in 2020.

headline: Protect the President’s Appointments
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Editorials', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: The Supreme Court should reaffirm the longstanding practice of recess appointments that keeps government functioning.
lead_paragraph: Under the Constitution, the president nominates federal judges, cabinet members and officials for executive agencies, and the Senate votes on their confirmation. But what if the Senate isn’t in session? The answer has always seemed clear: The Constitution gives the president the power to fill “all vacancies that may happen during the recess of the Senate.”

headline: The Times, From the Top: Looking Ahead
abstract: After a year of great change, Executive Editor Jill Abramson discusses upcoming challenges.
lead_paragraph: THESE days, when Jill Abramson surveys the paper’s masthead, she does so with a certain amount of satisfaction. Half of the 10 top-ranking editors in the newsroom, including herself, are women. That’s a long way from a time when women had no presence on the Times masthead; the first on the news side was Carolyn Lee, in 1990 (though Charlotte Curtis preceded her, as an opinion editor, in 1974).

headline: End the Corporate Tax?
abstract: Readers respond to an Op-Ed essay that said abolition of the tax would benefit workers.
lead_paragraph: Readers respond to an Op-Ed essay that said abolition of the tax would benefit workers.

headline: The Civil Rights of Children
abstract: The Obama administration speaks out against zero tolerance disciplinary policies that disproportionately affect minorities.
lead_paragraph: Most school officials try to apply disciplinary policies fairly and in compliance with federal laws that forbid racial discrimination. Even so, a large and troubling body of data — some if it gathered by the federal government — shows that black and Hispanic students are disproportionately and unjustifiably subjected to suspension, expulsion or even arrest for nonviolent offenses that should be dealt with in the principal’s office.

headline: Anthony Mandler
abstract: The film director on disappearing into music and giving yourself over to film.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Mandler is a film director and photographer probably best known for the noir music videos he has created for pop artists such as Rihanna, Jay-Z, Beyoncé, Eminem and Lana Del Rey.

headline: The War on Women
keywords: ['Cyberharassment', 'Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', 'Men and Boys', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: What is behind all the threats, venom and misogyny that women face online?
lead_paragraph: THE year is new, but we already have a candidate for the most troubling magazine essay of 2014: Amanda Hess on “Why Women Aren’t Welcome on the Internet,” in the latest issue of Pacific Standard.

headline: If I Had a Hammer
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Science and Technology', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: In the Second Machine Age, it’s all about getting smarter, faster.
lead_paragraph: MY favorite story in Erik Brynjolfsson and Andrew McAfee’s fascinating new book, “The Second Machine Age,” is when the Dutch chess grandmaster Jan Hein Donner was asked how he’d prepare for a chess match against a computer, like I.B.M.’s Deep Blue. Donner replied: “I would bring a hammer.”

headline: The ‘I’ in Christie’s Storm
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'George Washington Bridge']
abstract: In politics, it’s best to work some “we” into the me, me me.
lead_paragraph: POLITICS boils down to three pronouns: I, you, we. The politician who has them in balance goes a long way.

headline: Goodnight. Sleep Clean.
abstract: Why do we have to rest? Meet your brain’s janitorial staff.
lead_paragraph: SLEEP seems like a perfectly fine waste of time. Why would our bodies evolve to spend close to one-third of our lives completely out of it, when we could instead be doing something useful or exciting? Something that would, as an added bonus, be less likely to get us killed back when we were sleeping on the savanna?

headline: A Week of Victories for Cold Weather and Al Qaeda
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Weather', 'Sunni Muslims', 'Floods', 'George Washington Bridge', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The first full week of the new year brought frigid weather, victories by Al Qaeda and a marathon apology from Chris Christie.
lead_paragraph: The first full week of the new year dutifully served up some of the themes likely to command attention in 2014.

headline: In This Rape Case, the Victim Was 4
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Women and Girls', 'Child Abuse and Neglect']
abstract: Doing a better job of imposing punishment has reduced sexual violence in the United States. It could work in other parts of the world, too.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — SHE’S a 4-year-old girl named Ida, fragile and shy, and when she was raped by a neighbor boy in September, her family tried to have the attacker arrested.

headline: When a Food Writer Can’t Taste
abstract: With my tongue impaired, I was like a deaf musician.
lead_paragraph: ON that early spring day in San Francisco, I walked out to buy local treats for my birthday party — country bread (sour, with walnuts) from Tartine bakery, tamales from the lady in front of my favorite produce shop, salted caramel ice cream from Bi-Rite and a tub of peanut curry ice cream from Humphry Slocombe’s.

headline: I Crashed the Wrong Shiva
abstract: The danger of deciding, too late, to be a good neighbor.
lead_paragraph: YOU get to know all the old people. This is what no one tells you when you live in New York City and decide to work from home, but it’s true. One generation’s “off-peak hours” is another’s “hours.” There they are, walking their rickety dogs at 10, doing their laundry at noon, checking their mail at 3, asking you if you know how to operate a VCR machine at 6.

headline: Matriarchs’ Duel for Power Threatens to Tilt Bangladesh Off Balance
abstract: A tumultuous election may mean the end of two rivals’ coexistence — and the beginning of a risky attempt at one-party rule.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh —  Two ladies eyed each other from their elegant residences in Dhaka, the Bangladeshi capital, last week, each waiting to see whether the other would blink.

headline: Sexual Violence and Impunity, from Kenya to America
abstract: Readers comment on strategies to tackle sexual violence worldwide
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column is from Nairobi, Kenya, about how police corruption and indifference create impunity that allows sexual violence to unchecked. This is a global problem, particularly in poor countries with dubious criminal justice systems but also of course in the United States. As you’ll see, I argue that we have to change attitudes but above all we have to end the impunity. The organization that I followed in Kenya, Shining Hope for Communities, is doing a terrific job trying to do just that.

headline: Chargers’ Rivers Wears Country Roots on Sleeve and Around His Neck
abstract: Philip Rivers’s distinctive choice of neckwear reflects his down-home roots, while his performance this season shows his capacity for remaining cool under pressure.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Gone are the days when a quarterback would stand at his locker after a game, freshly showered with a wet head or sweat soaked, grass stained and half undressed, and answer questions from reporters who crowded around. That ritual is now the domain of the proletariat — linemen, linebackers and the like.

headline: Cruel Bargain for A-Rod and Boys With Baseball Dreams
abstract: The affirmation of Alex Rodriguez’s suspension for doping may leave the next move up to the Yankees.
lead_paragraph: Before Alex Rodriguez was A-Rod, long before he became a symbol of all that’s wrong with baseball, he was simply Alex, a skinny little 8-year-old with dreams of being a pro ballplayer like his father.

headline: Heat Are Fine With Learning From Losses
abstract: Miami is 12-2 against teams with current records of .500 or better, and 16-8 against teams that now have losing records.
lead_paragraph: The Miami Heat arrived in New York last week in the midst of another marauding march through the regular season. They limped away with a training room full of banged-up players after losses on consecutive nights to the Knicks and the Nets.

headline: Tough Suspensions in Sports Don’t Always Stick
abstract: A look back at some notable suspensions shows that the penalty periods have often been shortened or vacated.
lead_paragraph: Through the decades, suspensions in sports have come in all sizes and for offenses that include attacking a coach and protesting a war. Often assumed to be career-enders, suspensions have often been shortened or vacated, allowing players to resume doing what they do best, which is to compete on a field, a court or a rink.

headline: With N.F.L. Concussion Deal, Two Tiers of Payouts
abstract: Former players who hired lawyers to sue the league are upset that the settlement could provide payments to players who did not file lawsuits and would not have to pay legal fees.
lead_paragraph: Court settlements are by nature compromises, and compromises are often messy. The proposed settlement of the lawsuits brought by more than 4,500 former N.F.L. players who contended that the league hid from them the dangers of concussions is no exception.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Ermenegildo Zegna Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: Setting a Hockey Team’s Direction Left and Right
abstract: The game’s complexities can obscure a player’s favored shooting hand, but players, coaches and general managers realize how crucial it can be.
lead_paragraph: Kurt Kehl has an unusual memory. Name just about any N.H.L. player in the last 40 years or so, and Kehl knows whether he shot from the left side or the right side.

headline: After Losing Gasol, Grizzlies Find Talent On the Bench
abstract: Jon Leuer and Ed Davis, relative unknowns at the start of the season, could be valuable players for Memphis in the years to come.
lead_paragraph: Marc Gasol, the Memphis Grizzlies’ starting center, is one of a number of high-profile N.B.A. stars who have missed a large chunk of this season because of an injury. But in the absence of Gasol, the Grizzlies discovered talent sitting on their bench.

headline: Rodriguez Barred From Baseball, but Not From the Public Eye
abstract: Alex Rodriguez may have to sit out a year, but his lifelong celebrity is assured.
lead_paragraph: Alex Rodriguez is not going away. An arbitrator has decided that Rodriguez cannot play in 2014, not in the regular season or the postseason, but we will see him again. Rodriguez will make sure of it.

headline: Panel Blocks Gas Pipeline in New Jersey Pinelands
abstract: The vote keeps the gas line, which Gov. Chris Christie’s government had lobbied for, out of the fragile area.
lead_paragraph: The New Jersey agency charged with protecting the Pinelands, a vast and fragile expanse of sand pines, gnarled oaks and river deltas, narrowly defeated a proposal on Friday to run a 22-mile natural gas pipeline through it.

headline: The 1890 Book I Had to Have
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Income Inequality', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Jacob Riis’s work detailing the squalor of New York tenements resonates today.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, while browsing in Second Story Books in Washington, D.C., I noticed a plain clothbound volume among the fine leather-bound tomes locked in a glass case. I had no business looking at any rare books, but that did not stop me from asking if I might see it. A moment later I was holding a copy of “How the Other Half Lives,” the 1890 classic on the squalor of New York’s tenements that pricked a nation’s conscience and became a template for generations of investigative reporters like myself.

headline: U.S. Figure Skating Team Awaits Difficult Winnowing
keywords: ['Figure Skating', 'United States Figure Skating Championships', 'Olympic Games (2014)']
abstract: Polina Edmunds, 15, finished second over all at the U.S. figure skating championships, but that does not guarantee she will be named to the American team for the Sochi Olympics.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Two hours before her long program on Saturday night, Polina Edmunds, 15, took a peek from backstage at the United States figure skating championships. This was her first competition at the senior level. Rarely, if ever, had she skated before an audience this large, with the stakes so high.

headline: Skating’s New Scoring System Adds to Challenge for American Men
keywords: ['Figure Skating', 'Olympic Games (2014)', 'United States Figure Skating Championships']
abstract: Two Olympic berths will be won when 19 men are scheduled to take the ice at TD Garden this weekend in the U.S. figure skating championships.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — As the sun set on the cavernous convention center Friday, five boyish-looking ice skaters laced up their footwear and took turns leaping, gliding and spinning their nerves away, making a chorus of satisfying crunches of skate blades on a fresh sheet of ice.

headline: Tennis Tries to Find Balance on Doping
abstract: While tennis has been criticized in the past for not being tough enough on performance-enhancing drugs, recent suspensions of players have been called unduly harsh.
lead_paragraph: Criticized in the past for not being tough enough, tennis’s antidoping program faced criticism in 2013 that it was too harsh as two prominent players, Viktor Troicki and Marin Cilic, received suspensions that were reduced on appeal.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Jil Sander Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

headline: Taking the Battle to the States
abstract: A look at the party splits in the states on different issues.
lead_paragraph: A look at the party splits in the states on different issues.

headline: A National Strategy Funds State Political Monopolies
keywords: ['States (US)', 'Campaign Finance', 'State Legislatures', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Series', 'Elections']
abstract: In some states, campaign cash from sophisticated donor networks has helped accelerate or arrest the natural drift toward one party or the other, defying national election trends and voter registration advantages.
lead_paragraph: By his third year as chairman of the Alabama Republican organization, Mike Hubbard believed his party had just about everything it needed to win control of the State Legislature.

headline: Six Who Could Challenge the Usual Suspects
abstract: These six players could challenge the more familiar names at the Australian Open.
lead_paragraph: These six players could challenge the more familiar names at the Australian Open.

headline: Versace: Fall 2014 Menswear
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: It’s Only “A” Game
abstract: Andrew Chaikin delivers a fun Sunday solve.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Well, that was A-one. I really enjoyed this puzzle by Andrew Chaikin, not just for the great fill and clever theme, but for the fabulous, cryptic-sounding clues that were not actually written to be cryptic. When I eventually realized what was going on.

headline: Alex Rodriguez’s Statement
abstract: Alex Rodriguez issued a statement in response to the arbitrator’s decision to suspend him for 162 games.
lead_paragraph: Alex Rodriguez issued the following statement in response to the arbitrator’s decision to suspend him for 162 games.

headline: This Time, Smith Avoids Sideshow and Just Puts On a Show
abstract: After drawing attention for antics and a benching, J. R. Smith sat out the first quarter before leading the Knicks on a 32-12 second-quarter run and finishing with 14 points in a win at Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The benching of J. R. Smith lasted 12 minutes into its second game. Knicks Coach Mike Woodson could not restrain the capricious and impulsive Smith any longer than that.

headline: Harvard-Yale Rivalry Echoes Through the Garden
abstract: The Bulldogs dominated the Crimson as the old rivals met in New York for the first time in more than 40 years.
lead_paragraph: The first Harvard-Yale hockey game was played in 1900 at St. Nicholas Rink off Columbus Avenue in Manhattan. It was so long ago that when the Elis won, 5-4, their fans celebrated with the Yale frog cheer, based on a passage from Aristophanes. “Brek-ek-ek-ex,” it began, mimicking the chorus of frogs on the banks of the River Styx.

headline: Seeking Nuclear-Power Workers of Tomorrow
abstract: In the next few years, about 40 percent of the employees at the state’s largest nuclear power plant will be eligible for retirement, so the company is working to recruit new specialists.
lead_paragraph: PALACIOS — At first glance, the large, framed photo hanging on a wall at the state’s largest nuclear power plant seems to tell a simple story. About 200 smiling men and women stand in block formation behind a long-stretching banner — shades of a high school class portrait, though one posed in front of the domes of two nuclear reactors.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Dolce & Gabbana Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Blogger’s Incarceration Raises First Amendment Questions
keywords: ['Libel and Slander', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Constitutional Amendments']
abstract: Roger Shuler’s accusatory posts have earned him many enemies. But even many of them are shocked by what has happened to him.
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — For over six years, Roger Shuler has hounded figures of the state legal and political establishment on his blog, Legal Schnauzer, a hothouse of furious but often fuzzily sourced allegations of deep corruption and wide-ranging conspiracy. Some of these allegations he has tested in court, having sued his neighbor, his neighbor’s lawyer, his former employer, the Police Department, the Sheriff’s Department, the Alabama State Bar and two county circuit judges, among others. Mostly, he has lost.

headline: In Scandal, Turkey’s Leaders May Be Losing Their Tight Grip on News Media
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media', 'Newspapers']
abstract: The Turkish government, which has frequently had journalists fired and even jailed, may be losing its grip on the news media, as a former ally turns and Internet influence abounds.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan has labeled an investigative reporter who has published a number of leaked documents related to a widening corruption scandal a traitor. Mr. Erdogan’s lawyers have also filed suit against a newspaper columnist, once a reliable supporter of the prime minister, for his critical Twitter messages.

headline: Kiss and Tell: Gene Simmons and Paul Stanley Talk Shop
abstract: Gene Simmons and Paul Stanley talk shop.
lead_paragraph: Even if you like the rock band Kiss, and the bratty superhero antics of its founders, Gene Simmons and Paul Stanley, their appearance at the end of John Varvatos’s show in Milan qualified as a cringe moment. With models standing around them, the rock legends fist-pumped the air — Mr. Simmons stuck his tongue out, of course — and Mr. Varvatos looked pleased to be with his new mates. His clothes this season have a sleek toughness, with scaly metallic finishes and feathered fabrics that made you think of animals. Maybe that’s a link to Kiss. Still, the group’s presence seemed out of context, like someone photo-bombing your wedding pictures. Well, someone with clown makeup and a cherry-red tongue.

headline: Keeping Public Buildings Free of Guns Proves Too Costly for Kansas Towns
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: A Kansas law requires towns to allow concealed weapons in public buildings but exempts them if they pay for additional security protections. Many are finding the measures to be prohibitively expensive.
lead_paragraph: WICHITA, Kan. — Reasoning that more guns mean greater safety, Kansas lawmakers voted last year to require cities and counties to make public buildings accessible to people legally carrying concealed weapons.

headline: A Cheerleader for Others, Virginia Governor Stands on His Own
abstract: At his inauguration, Terry McAuliffe, the governor of Virginia, seemed intent on showing that he was his own man, not a Washington wheeler-dealer that some have criticized him as being.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton toasted Terry McAuliffe, the incoming governor of Virginia, at a private dinner here Friday evening. Then they walked with him through the State Capitol on Saturday morning on the way to his inauguration and sat on the rain-soaked steps outside, smiling broadly under an umbrella as he took the oath not long after noon.

headline: Prepared for Seattle’s Noise, the Saints Can’t Overcome Seattle’s Players
abstract: The Saints, who pumped crowd noise at an earsplitting volume as they practiced outside, fell to the Seahawks, who advanced to the N.F.C. championship game.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — For their return to that caldron of cacophony called CenturyLink Field, the New Orleans Saints reconstructed the stadium’s atmosphere. Tried to, rather.

headline: Water Ban Continues
abstract: Residents in Charleston, West Virginia, and nearby communities have been warned to stay away from tap water for drinking and washing.
lead_paragraph: Residents in Charleston, West Virginia, and nearby communities have been warned to stay away from tap water for drinking and washing.

headline: 9-Year-Old Killed by Taxi Was ‘Spirited’ and ‘Wise’
abstract: Cooper Stock, a third-grader at The Calhoun School in the Upper West Side, was struck and killed on Friday night by a taxi making a left turn at West End Avenue and West 97th Street.
lead_paragraph: A 9-year-old boy who was one of two people struck and killed by separate vehicles on the Upper West Side on Friday night was described by his family on Saturday as a “spirited third grader” with a fanatical devotion to the New York Knicks.

headline: Wait Continues for Safe Tap Water in West Virginia
keywords: ['Water', 'Chemicals', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Water Pollution']
abstract: After a spill greater than previously estimated, hundreds of thousands of people may have to wait days before the water is declared safe again.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — As hundreds of thousands of residents faced a third day without water because of a chemical spill in a local river, a water company executive said on Saturday that it could be days before it was safe for them to drink tap water again.

headline: Staying Drug-Free, and Providing for His Son the ‘Right Way’
abstract: Justen Henderson had several run-ins with the law, but now he works two jobs and is considering a career as a nurse.
lead_paragraph: It has taken a while, but Justen Henderson, 25, has learned from his mistakes.

headline: Villanova Rediscovers 3-Point Touch, and St. John’s Loses Way
abstract: The Red Storm are still looking for their first Big East victory of the season after the Wildcats went on a 10-1 run late in the second half to break open a close game.
lead_paragraph: Eighth-ranked Villanova found the separation it needed to avoid an upset against St. John’s in the final six and a half minutes of a 74-67 victory Saturday at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Rising Tide Is a Mystery That Sinks Island Hopes
abstract: Lago Enriquillo in the Dominican Republic, the largest lake in the Caribbean, has been rising and rising, devouring tens of thousands of acres of farmland, ranches and whatever else stands in its way.
lead_paragraph: LAGO ENRIQUILLO, Dominican Republic — Steadily, mysteriously, like in an especially slow science fiction movie, the largest lake in the Caribbean has been rising and rising, devouring tens of thousands of acres of farmland, ranches and whatever else stands in its way.

headline: Delay in Plan to Drug Screen Applicants for Unemployment Aid
abstract: The state prepares for a drug screen procedure required of applicants for unemployment benefits, but the federal Labor Department has yet to set the required parameters.
lead_paragraph: Texans applying for unemployment benefits will be subject to a new drug screening procedure in a program scheduled to take effect Feb. 1. But the Texas Workforce Commission said it would not be able to start the program on the state’s timetable because the United States Labor Department had not set the required parameters.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 11, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Another Academic Group Considers Israel Censure
abstract: The Modern Language Association took a step toward approving a resolution to oppose what it called Israel’s discriminatory “denials of entry” to scholars trying to visit the West Bank.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A movement to pressure and isolate Israel gained further ground among American academics on Saturday, when the Modern Language Association took a step toward approving a resolution calling on the State Department to contest what it characterized as Israel’s discriminatory “denials of entry” to American scholars seeking to visit the West Bank to work at Palestinian universities.

headline: ‘A Coarse Pleasure’ in Stories of Impostors
abstract: James Magnuson, director of the Michener Center for Writers at the University of Texas, has written a new novel about a con man, a famous author and some elements his Austin students might find familiar.
lead_paragraph: In 1985, when the novelist and playwright James Magnuson first accepted a job teaching creative writing at the University of Texas at Austin, he harbored a fair amount of skepticism toward the academic world. In the past, he had taken what he called “an outsider’s pride” in being able to support himself as a writer without having to teach. He wondered too if both the teachers and the students in creative writing programs were prone to taking themselves too seriously.

headline: Goalie Gets Back on His Game in a Town Full of Tough Critics
abstract: Steve Mason fell out of favor after leading Columbus to its only postseason berth, but a trade to Philadelphia has helped him revitalize his career.
lead_paragraph: Over the last two decades, playing in Philadelphia has been a nightmare for Flyers goalies.

headline: Predicting the Future in 13 Races
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'State Legislatures', 'Elections, Governors', 'Elections, State Legislature']
abstract: In 2014 a handful of races, from Greg Abbott’s and Wendy Davis’s run for the governorship on down, will reveal whether Texas remains solidly red or whether Democrats are headed toward a renaissance.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for The Tribune.

headline: Violence Replaces Rejoicing After Central African Leaders Resign
keywords: ['Looting (Crime)', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: After thousands celebrated the resignations of two of the Central African Republic’s leaders, Christian militias renewed their fight with the Muslim rebels known as Seleka.
lead_paragraph: BANGUI, Central African Republic — Sporadic looting, gunfire and a handful of deadly clashes, including some with French soldiers, took the place of celebrations here after the forced resignation of President Michel Djotodia and Prime Minister Nicolas Tiangaye on Friday.

headline: 2 Far-Right Greek Lawmakers Are Accused of Criminal Activity
abstract: Giorgos Germenis and Panagiotis Iliopoulos, lawmakers from the Golden Dawn party, were ordered to be detained pending trial on charges of joining and directing a criminal organization.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Two lawmakers from Greece’s far-right party, Golden Dawn, were ordered to be taken into custody late on Saturday on charges of joining and directing a criminal organization. The decision was part of a government crackdown on the party, which has been condemned by European authorities as neo-Nazi and violent.

headline: Record-Setting Night for a Patriot (Not Brady) Eliminates the Colts
abstract: LeGarrette Blount had four rushing touchdowns, leading New England to the A.F.C. championship game, the team’s eighth in the Tom Brady era.
lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — The shootout between Tom Brady and Andrew Luck in Saturday night’s divisional playoff game was a riveting duel for three quarters. It had everything a postseason game should have, with Luck cast as the resolute heir apparent who played brilliantly as he tried to knock off Brady, the Patriots longtime king of playoff excellence.

headline: Judy Protas, Writer of Slogan for Levy’s Real Jewish Rye, Dies at 91
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Bread', 'Slogans and Mottoes', 'Bakeries and Baked Products']
abstract: Ms. Protas knew that a campaign spent selling rye bread to Jews would be a campaign squandered in preaching to the converted.
lead_paragraph: You don’t have to be Jewish to write an ad for rye bread that has endured in public memory for more than half a century, but in Judy Protas’s case it certainly didn’t hurt.

headline: GMC Canyon Is a Midsize Striver
abstract: Big pickups are showroom winners, but the midsize models are increasingly competitive.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — General Motors introduced its step-up entry in the midsize pickup market on Sunday, a day ahead of the opening of press previews for the Detroit auto show. The 2015 GMC Canyon takes its place in the G.M. lineup just a bit upstream of the 2015 Chevrolet Colorado, which was introduced at the Los Angeles auto show in November.

headline: Indonesia Announces Export Ban on Raw Ore
keywords: ['Metals and Minerals', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The ban on exports of unprocessed minerals has been criticized by miners who say a plan to build smelters in the country is not economically viable.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Indonesia, one of the world’s biggest producers of minerals including gold, nickel, copper, tin and thermal coal, implemented a new law Sunday banning the export of unprocessed ore.

abstract: Decades ago, families gathered around the only set in the house on Sunday nights because networks scheduled their best programming then. Today, even with DVRs and on-demand program selection, the phenomenon continues.

headline: After Surgery, Murray Lowers His Sights
abstract: There is no way to tell yet whether Andy Murray and his surgically repaired back can endure one grueling match, let alone win the Australian Open.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — For years, Andy Murray’s right hand shot so frequently to his back after arduous or even routine points that it sometimes seemed permanently attached. Murray looked, at times, like an old man, or at least a man far older than 26.

headline: When Divorce Magnifies Adoption’s Losses
abstract: My adopted child of divorced and remarried parents doesn’t feel like she fits in anywhere.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, en route to pick up my youngest daughter from a weeklong sleepaway camp in Connecticut designed specifically for adopted children, I was half-certain I would find her wailing about having been miserable, friendless and infected with Lyme’s disease. Would she run into my arms and dissolve into tears? This was her first time alone and away from home. That she might have enjoyed herself, made friends and been tick-free seemed like too much to wish for.

headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (NBC) THE 71ST ANNUAL GOLDEN GLOBE AWARDS Tina Fey and Amy Poehler (above right, with Ms. Fey) host these awards — often considered predictors of the Oscars — sponsored by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association and broadcast live. In the motion picture drama division, the nominees are “12 Years a Slave,” “Captain Phillips,” “Gravity,” “Philomena” and “Rush,” for best picture; Cate Blanchett, Sandra Bullock, Judi Dench, Emma Thompson and Kate Winslet, for best actress; and Chiwetel Ejiofor, Idris Elba, Tom Hanks, Matthew McConaughey and Robert Redford, for best actor. In the comedy or musical division, the nominees are “American Hustle,” “Her,” “Inside Llewyn Davis,” “Nebraska” and “The Wolf of Wall Street,” for best picture; Amy Adams, Julie Delpy, Greta Gerwig, Julia Louis-Dreyfus and Meryl Streep, for best actress; and Christian Bale, Bruce Dern, Leonardo DiCaprio, Oscar Isaac and Joaquin Phoenix, for best actor. Woody Allen will receive the Cecil B. DeMille Award, although he is not expected to attend. Awards will also be handed out for television work. A countdown to the ceremony begins at 4 on E!, which moves to red carpet coverage at 6. NBC will report on arrivals, starting at 7. And E! will visit after-parties at 11.

headline: What to Look for on the Globes Red Carpet
abstract: Lupita Nyong’o, Cate Blanchett and Greta Gerwig are among the actresses to look out for on the red carpet during tonight’s Golden Globes.
lead_paragraph: This much is clear about this year’s Golden Globes. Whether Lupita Nyong’o wins the award for best supporting actress at Sunday night’s ceremonies (an award for which she is the heavy favorite) or not, the young Kenyan actress will stride the red carpet beforehand as a bona fide star of the fashion world.

lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Marissa Mayer and 50 Cent. Budgee the robot and Parrot the drone. Smartwatches and curving TVs, all sprinkled with Hollywood stardust.

headline: Hungry? Buy This Billboard
abstract: An outdoor advertising company has been using short, catchy phrases with pictures of food on billboards to sell the billboards themselves.
lead_paragraph: Eric Justusson, a software engineer, was walking to work from Brooklyn across the Manhattan Bridge when he first saw the enigmatic billboard, the words “Easy As” in gigantic letters followed by a 12-foot-high picture of a slice of pie. For BJ Gruber, an actor who lives in Astoria, Queens, it was the words “Cool As A,” followed by a photo of a cucumber slice that he spotted while driving on the Brooklyn Queens Expressway. Soledad Tejada, a high school student from Brooklyn, noticed one with “The Big” and a tremendous hunk of cheese in her home borough.

lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Antigovernment protesters seeking to block next month’s elections in Thailand seized control of major roads in Bangkok on Monday as they began their campaign to shut down the city.

headline: ‘Lone Survivor’ a Surprise Hit at Box Office
abstract: “Lone Survivor” took in an estimated $38.9 million, surprising analysts.
lead_paragraph: Moviegoers have stubbornly refused to care about war movies set in Afghanistan, contributing to modest prerelease expectations for Peter Berg’s “Lone Survivor.” But ticket buyers, especially those in heartland states, surprised Hollywood over the weekend and powered “Lone Survivor” (Universal Pictures) to an estimated $38.9 million in sales, roughly double the total that most analysts expected and easily enough for first place at the North American box office.

abstract: Iran and a group of six world powers completed a deal on Sunday that will temporarily freeze much of Tehran’s nuclear program in exchange for limited relief from Western economic sanctions.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Iran and a group of six world powers completed a deal on Sunday that will temporarily freeze much of Tehran’s nuclear program starting next Monday, Jan. 20, in exchange for limited relief from Western economic sanctions.

lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. – Even to the most hedonistic Hollywood player, the party onslaught leading up the Golden Globes can seem a little, you know, excessive. Enter the Help Haiti Home benefit, now in its third year, which donated money to the J/P Haitian Relief Organization, as well as to typhoon relief efforts in the Philippines.

lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Her free skate was not yet complete, but Gracie Gold, 18, landed a double axel and smiled and pumped her fists.

headline: A Busy Doctor’s Right Hand, Ever Ready to Type
abstract: Scribes have entered the scene in clinics and operating rooms, liberating physicians from the constant note-taking that modern electronic health records systems demand.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Amid the controlled chaos that defines an average afternoon in an urban emergency department, Dr. Marian Bednar, an emergency room physician at Texas Health Presbyterian Hospital Dallas, entered the exam room of an older woman who had fallen while walking her dog. Like any doctor, she asked questions, conducted an exam and gave a diagnosis — in this case, a fractured hand — while also doing something many physicians in today’s computerized world are no longer free to do: She gave the patient her full attention.

headline: The Anti-Scientific Revolution in Macroeconomics

headline: Francis Looks to the Developing World in Appointing New Cardinals

headline: Q. & A.: Wu Wei Reflects on Reform, Now and in the 1980s
abstract: Wu Wei, a former Chinese official who in the 1980s was heavily involved in developing plans for measured political reform, says recently announced economic changes will stall without substantial changes to the political system.
lead_paragraph: Wu Wei is a former Chinese official who in the 1980s was heavily involved in developing the Communist Party chief Zhao Ziyang’s plans for measured political reform. Mr. Wu also served as a secretary to Bao Tong, the senior aide to Mr. Zhao. Those reforms collapsed in 1989, when the party patriarch, Deng Xiaoping, turned against Mr. Zhao and ordered troops to suppress student protests based in Tiananmen Square in Beijing. Mr. Wu was detained and investigated after the June 4, 1989, crackdown, and later went into publishing and business. He has remained a close observer of Chinese politics, and last year his book “On Stage and Backstage: China’s Political Reform in the 1980s” was published in Hong Kong.

headline: Visa Trims Slogan to Expand Meaning
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Olympic Games (2014)', 'Credit Cards']
abstract: “It’s everywhere you want to be,” has become “Everywhere you want to be” to highlight many options available under the Visa brand umbrella, including mobile and electronic payments.
lead_paragraph: IN a world where time-pressed people type “u 2” for “you too”; say “because” to introduce a noun or adjective rather than a full clause, as in “because doughnuts;” and use abbreviations like “ftw” (“for the win”), marketing and media phrases are also increasingly being compressed. For instance, commercials for Alka-Seltzer Plus keep the words “Oh, what a relief it is” from their vintage predecessors while eliminating the “Plop, plop, fizz, fizz.” The sequels to “The Fast and the Furious” go by titles like “Fast & Furious 6.” And “Masterpiece Theater” on PBS is now “Masterpiece.”

headline: ‘12 Years a Slave,’ ‘American Hustle’ Take Top Honors at the 2014 Golden Globes
abstract: The 71st annual Golden Globes spread the wealth on Sunday night, with many top contenders getting awards. Dave Itzkoff and Jon Caramanica live-blogged the telecast, with contributions from Melena Ryzik and others.
lead_paragraph: Dave Itzkoff and Jon Caramanica live-blogged the 71st annual Golden Globes on Sunday night, with contributions from Melena Ryzik and others.

headline: A Family Drama, and a Balancing Act
keywords: ['Television', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The creators of “The Fosters” have to weigh how much intimacy to include in their same-sex drama.
lead_paragraph: Peter Paige gets just a tiny bit agitated when asked about the amount of sex on his television show “The Fosters.” “We’re dealing with two women who are raising five kids!” he exclaims. Sometimes they can sneak away. But mostly they need to make lunches or monitor homework or drive someone to a piano lesson. Who has the time?

headline: If the Fur Doesn’t Drive You Crazy, the Virus Will
abstract: Two Syfy shows are variations on familiar premises: “Bitten” is about a modern-day female werewolf; “Helix” concerns a killer virus.
lead_paragraph: Syfy has been trying to step up its game lately, and two new shows make respectable additions to its lineup, even if they do work tried-and-true subject matter.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Jan. 13
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Not Just Another Ex-Con Hoping for Hip-Hop Glory
abstract: “Chozen,” an animated comedy on FX, follows the adventures of a gay white rapper after he leaves prison.
lead_paragraph: Animation is best suited for what might not be believable, even if seen. And our era of extreme progressivism notwithstanding, the idea of a gay white hip-hop thug still remains, for many, the stuff of fantasy.

headline: Now You See the Motorcycle, Now You Don’t
abstract: The illusionist Andrew Mayne combines small pranks with his tricks on this new A&E show.
lead_paragraph: Some skills aren’t particularly television friendly, and magic, especially the small-scale kind like the card trick, is one of them. If you’re not witnessing it live at fairly close range, you have to take it on faith that something magical happened, and that no camera manipulation was involved.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Jan. 13
abstract: JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo, set to report fourth-quarter results on Tuesday, will kick off a flurry of bank earnings, and Intel will post its fourth-quarter results.
lead_paragraph: BANK EARNINGS JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo, set to report fourth-quarter results on Tuesday, will kick off a flurry of bank earnings. The banking giants, analysts say, will most likely face sluggish demand from borrowers whose appetite for refinancing has been sapped by rising rates. For JPMorgan Chase, the nation’s largest bank, the quarterly report comes after a string of costly government settlements, prompting analysts to predict that high legal costs could hamper profit. All told, JPMorgan will have paid some $20 billion to resolve government investigations in the last 12 months alone.

headline: Talking About Their (Iron-Fisted) Generation
abstract: “El Año en Que Nací (The Year I Was Born)” examines Chile’s tumultuous history through the eyes of artists born during Augusto Pinochet’s rule.
lead_paragraph: Among indicators of an actor’s commitment, here’s an impressive one: sticks with a production despite a parent refusing contact as a result. Such (spoiler alert) has been the consequence for Viviana Hernández in “El Año en Que Nací (The Year I Was Born),” a play by the Argentine director Lola Arias playing at La MaMa as part of the Public Theater’s Under the Radar Festival. It makes sense that Ms. Hernández would stay; she is, after all, telling the story of her life in this production, in which nine Chileans, born between 1976 and 1984, knit together a history both sweeping and deeply intimate.

headline: A Personal Revolution Is Set Amid an Epic One
abstract: “Revolutionary,” by Alex Myers, is a novel based on the true story of a woman who fought as a man in the Revolutionary War.
lead_paragraph: Deborah Samson is 22 and free of indenture, but addicted to adventure. She has left the church, and yet she is a believer of sorts, in independence for the American colonies and for herself. She recoils at orders to serve at table, and yet she yearns to serve in arms.

headline: Playing Composer, of Course, to Impress
abstract: The Bronx Opera Company opened its 47th season on Saturday with “The Rivals,” a 2002 comic opera by Kirke Mechem.
lead_paragraph: At a time when opportunities for gifted emerging opera composers blazing all manner of new stylistic trails appear to be proliferating, there’s something to be said for a company willing to go to bat for fresh pieces by veteran creators working in conventional modes. Not long ago, that company likely would have been the Dicapo Opera, which performed an estimable service in championing composers like Thomas Pasatieri, Tobias Picker and Conrad Susa.

headline: In Baraka, Inspiration Came With Provocation
abstract: In an appreciation, Questlove, a founder of the Roots, talks about the influence Amiri Baraka had on him.
lead_paragraph: I’m not the right age for Amiri Baraka, not exactly. Or rather: I’m not the right age to have seen his changes as they happened. Mr. Baraka, who died last week at 79, passed through so many different phases, from middle-class kid in Newark to aspiring Beat poet to founder of the Black Arts movement to leftist activist to academic. For me, he arrived as an author looking back, already armed with his own self-reflection: He published his memoir, “The Autobiography of LeRoi Jones,” in 1984, when I was in high school, though the book didn’t make its way into my hands or my brain until a few years after that.

headline: Actors Jam Meeting to Seek Higher Pay for Tours
abstract: At an overflow membership meeting of the stage actors union, concerns were expressed about the pay — lower than past norms — to performers on coming tours.
lead_paragraph: More than 350 Actors’ Equity members packed a union hall and overflow room on Friday to demonstrate visibly their concern about lower salaries for musical theater performers on national tours, a source of intensifying frustration that has led Equity leaders to schedule a town hall meeting with members on Jan. 27.

headline: Networker
abstract: Is Roger Ailes’s management of Fox News driven by ideology, the profit motive or just plain rage?
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, my wife and I bought a weekend house in the town of Garrison, N.Y., in the lower Hudson Valley. We love the place for its scenic beauty, its peace and quiet, and its old-fashioned sense of community. For us, it’s a refuge from the pace of city life, a place with an easygoing mix of lifestyles and a widely shared ethos about preserving what makes it special.

headline: Everybody
abstract: Lynn Lempel offers us an inclusive puzzle.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — One of the things I like most about solving crossword puzzles is that it’s an ALL-inclusive pastime. Anyone can do it, if they are so inclined. And today, Lynn Lempel starts our solving week by inviting ONE AND ALL to solve her puzzle.

headline: With a Happy Refrain: MGM’s Magic Era
abstract: The 92nd Street Y’s Lyrics & Lyricists series celebrates Arthur Freed, the producer of classic MGM musicals.
lead_paragraph: Why is it that with few exceptions visionary film producers go largely unrecognized by the public while directors and movie stars become legends? That question informed “Going Hollywood: MGM Musicals,” the ebullient season-opening program of the 92nd Street Y’s Lyrics & Lyricists series on Saturday night, hosted by the director and choreographer Kathleen Marshall.

headline: Forget the Domestic. Try the Imported. It’s Less Fizzy.
abstract: Ute Lemper is singing at 54 Below, delivering the European repertoire to American cabaret audiences.
lead_paragraph: The narrowed cat eyes that suddenly widen into a maniacal blue-eyed stare, the pleated platinum hair of a ’40s femme fatale, the deployment of a voice that can rise to a furious yowl by an imperious diva sheathed in black satin: No expressionistic detail was overlooked in Ute Lemper’s new show, a kind of best-of concert, which began a run at 54 Below on Wednesday evening.

headline: A Victim Becomes Triumphant
abstract: The opera “Thumbprint” tells how a Pakistani rape victim defied convention by bringing her assailants to justice.
lead_paragraph: “Thumbprint,” an earnest new chamber opera, has going for it an inspiring true story. The work, which had its premiere on Friday at the Baruch Performing Arts Center as part of the festival Prototype: Opera/Theater/Now, is about Mukhtar Mai, a Pakistani woman who was gang-raped in 2002 as payback for an “honor crime” allegedly committed by her brother. While custom called for rape victims to kill themselves to avoid dishonor, Ms. Mukhtar spoke out, bringing her assailants to justice. She went on to become a human-rights activist, opening schools and running an ambulance service and a women’s aid group in her village.

headline: Editorial Cartoon
abstract: Dennis Rodman helps Kim Jong-un score propaganda points.
lead_paragraph: Dennis Rodman helps Kim Jong-un score propaganda points.

headline: Denver Art Museum Gets Impressionist Trove
abstract: The Denver Art Museum is announcing Monday that it has received the largest gift of paintings in its history, a group of 22 Impressionist works.
lead_paragraph: The Denver Art Museum is announcing Monday that it has received the largest gift of paintings in its history, a group of 22 Impressionist works — by artists including van Gogh, Monet, Cézanne, Manet and Renoir — from the collection of Frederic C. Hamilton, an oil and gas magnate who has been the museum’s chief benefactor for several decades. The works include van Gogh’s 1887 “Edge of a Wheat Field With Poppies,” which will be the first van Gogh in the museum’s collection. Besides European works the donation includes pieces by major American Impressionists like Childe Hassam and William Merritt Chase. The gift has “forever changed the museum’s ability to deliver world-class exhibitions and programs,” said Christoph Heinrich, the museum’s director, and it transforms Denver’s holdings of Impressionism into one of the most important in the Western states. The paintings, mostly landscapes and seascapes, will be given a dedicated home in the museum’s newest addition, by the architect Daniel Libeskind, which opened in 2006. Mr. Hamilton, who served as chairman of the museum’s board from 1994 until last year, led the fund-raising effort for that $110 million expansion, and the building now bears his name.

headline: Q. and A. With John Kerry
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry described his life in hockey, including the way he followed Yale’s run to a national championship.
lead_paragraph: If President Obama is the nation’s highest-ranking recreational basketball player, then Secretary of State John Kerry is probably the top hockey player. Kerry was awarded several medals for his Vietnam War service, served 28 years as a senator from Massachusetts and ran for president in 2004, but sometimes it seems that his proudest moments have taken place on a rink.

headline: U.S. Teams for the World Youth Teams Chosen at Atlanta Trials
abstract: This year’s World Youth Teams Championships will be in Istanbul from Aug. 13 to 23.
lead_paragraph: This year’s World Youth Teams Championships will be in Istanbul from Aug. 13 to 23. The United States Bridge Federation is sending five teams, and it recently organized trials in Atlanta to select them.

headline: Hollande’s Companion Is Hospitalized
abstract: Valérie Trierweiler, President François Hollande’s companion and the de facto first lady, was admitted to a hospital after a tabloid reported he was having an affair.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Valérie Trierweiler, the companion of President François Hollande and France’s de facto first lady, was admitted to a hospital on Friday after learning along with the rest of France that Mr. Hollande is apparently having an affair with another woman.

headline: Madeline Arakawa Gins, Visionary Architect, Is Dead at 72
abstract: Ms. Gins and her husband, the artist Arakawa, advanced theories of design they believed could make mortality a thing of the past.
lead_paragraph: Madeline Arakawa Gins, a poet-turned-painter-turned-architect who publicly forswore mortality — and whose buildings, by her own account, were designed to pre-empt death for those living in them — died on Jan. 8 in Manhattan. She was 72.

headline: Is the United States a ‘Racial Democracy’?
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Philosophy', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: The disparities in our criminal justice system threaten our core political values.
lead_paragraph: I.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Salvatore Ferragamo Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: Favorites and Discoveries Among a Superabundance of Jazz
abstract: The annual NYC Winter Jazzfest went gloriously big for its 10th anniversary, stretching to five days rather than the usual two, and reaching a total audience of 7,500.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you could have heard at around 6:45 on Saturday evening, during the earliest shift of that day’s programming for the 10th annual NYC Winter Jazzfest: Extravagantly detailed large-canvas compositions, courtesy of Darcy James Argue’s Secret Society. A deep meld of Afro-Cuban music and modern jazz by Michele Rosewoman’s New Yor-Uba. Acoustic folk singing emulsified into a satiny blend by Tillery. Complex rhythmic calculus refashioned into body blows, by the guitarist Miles Okazaki or by one of two dynamic young drummers, Mark Guiliana and Ted Poor.

headline: Interview: Kevin Spacey
abstract: The actor discusses "House of Cards" on the red carpet.
lead_paragraph: The actor discusses "House of Cards" on the red carpet.

headline: Afghan Police, Often Derided, Face Another Drawback: Missing Pay
abstract: The case exemplifies a glaring failure in the American-led nation-building effort here: weak government institutions are often staffed by unqualified officials.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Outgunned by the Taliban and often derided by some as little more than uniformed thieves, police officers in Afghanistan do not have an easy job. But in recent months, their lives have gotten even tougher: Afghanistan’s police officers have not been paid since November, and some have not seen a paycheck since October.

headline: The War on Poverty, Then and Now
keywords: ['Poverty', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Welfare (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: Readers respond to a Washington Memo about the campaign started by President Lyndon B. Johnson 50 years ago.
