abstract: Researchers at the Harvard School of Public Health respond to a Sunday Review article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Southwest’s Population
abstract: Prof. Stan Becker of the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health raises the question of what a sustainable population would be for the Southwest, given its water resources.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Next Frontier in Fertility Treatment
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexual', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Fertility Drugs', 'Discrimination', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Transgender men and women have the right to be parents, too.
lead_paragraph: ANDY INKSTER, a transgender man, had always wanted biological children. So when he embarked on the transition from female to male at age 18 — changing his name, taking testosterone and eventually undergoing surgery to remove his breasts — he left his female reproductive organs intact.

headline: Interview: Cast of 'Brooklyn Nine-Nine'
abstract: The cast discusses their sitcom.
lead_paragraph: The cast discusses their sitcom.

headline: Golden Globes Red Carpet Fashion
abstract: Established stars and newcomers made their entrances at the Golden Globes in Beverly Hills, Calif.
lead_paragraph: Established stars and newcomers made their entrances at the Golden Globes in Beverly Hills, Calif.

headline: More Movies at Sundance Are Sidestepping the Big Screen
abstract: Movies at the festival may take in even less at the domestic box office as digital-leaning distributors become the most active buyers.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — What will be the difference between this year’s Sundance and the Sundance of 2006, when independent film was last riding high?

headline: Steve McQueen & Bianca Stigter
abstract: A talk with the the director Steve McQueen and his partner Bianca Stigter.
lead_paragraph: A talk with the the director Steve McQueen and his partner Bianca Stigter.

headline: Texas Vote-Buying Case Casts Glare on Tradition of Election Day Goads
abstract: The arrests of three politiqueras, or campaign runners, who are often hired to gather votes in contested races, have become a tricky issue for elected officials in the Rio Grande Valley.
lead_paragraph: DONNA, Tex. — In this Rio Grande Valley town of trailer parks and weedy lots eight miles from the Mexico border, people call them runners or politiqueras — the campaign workers who use their network of relatives and friends to deliver votes for their candidates. They travel around town with binders stuffed with the names and addresses of registered voters, driving residents to and from the polls and urging those they bump into at the grocery store to support their candidates.

headline: Enemies of the Poor
keywords: ['Poverty', 'Welfare (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The reverse Robin-Hoodism of the Republicans runs deep.
lead_paragraph: Suddenly it’s O.K., even mandatory, for politicians with national ambitions to talk about helping the poor. This is easy for Democrats, who can go back to being the party of F.D.R. and L.B.J. It’s much more difficult for Republicans, who are having a hard time shaking their reputation for reverse Robin-Hoodism, for being the party that takes from the poor and gives to the rich.

headline: Dudes and Other Distractions in Milan
abstract: A look at the Milan men’s shows, including Bottega Veneta’s comfortable sweatpants and Donatella Versace’s cowboy-and-biker themed collection.
lead_paragraph: This morning I visited Antonio De Matteis, the chief executive of Kiton, in the company’s new offices in Milan — the former Palazzo Ferre — and he told me something that warmed my heart: you should be able to sleep in your clothes. When a garment feels good and is well made, as a Kiton suit or coat certainly is, you should be able to wear it without sense of care, even if your natural inclination is to baby a very expensive, handmade jacket. Mr. De Matteis, from years of experience, from generations of being Italian, wouldn’t dream of such fussiness. He removed his jacket and slipped it on backward, showing how he wears it to sleep on a plane.

headline: It’s Brooklyn, Basketball and Branding as Nets Head to London
abstract: The Nets will play Atlanta on Thursday at O2 Arena as the N.B.A. takes its game on the road.
lead_paragraph: After playing five games in eight days, the Nets find themselves with something of a holiday. They were headed to London on Sunday night, preparing to play the Atlanta Hawks at O2 Arena on Thursday night, the only game they are scheduled to play for the next eight days.

headline: Syria Rebels Turn Against Most Radical Group Tied to Al Qaeda
abstract: A broad array of factions have turned against the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, known as ISIS, in a showdown over tactics, power and ideology.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As a government warplane soared over the northern Syrian city of Raqqa recently, a fighter from the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, the country’s most radical group linked to Al Qaeda, watched from behind an antiaircraft gun mounted on a pickup truck. Fighters and activists from rival insurgent factions urged him to fire. He did not.

headline: Heroic Measures
abstract: The online writings of a woman who has been fighting cancer for seven years invite us to think about the different approaches people take.
lead_paragraph: LISA BONCHEK ADAMS has spent the last seven years in a fierce and very public cage fight with death. Since a mammogram detected the first toxic seeds of cancer in her left breast when she was 37, she has blogged and tweeted copiously about her contest with the advancing disease. She has tweeted through morphine haze and radiation burn. Even by contemporary standards of social-media self-disclosure, she is a phenomenon. (Last week she tweeted her 165,000th tweet.) A rapt audience of several thousand follows her unsparing narrative of mastectomy, chemotherapy, radiation, biopsies and scans, pumps and drains and catheters, grueling drug trials and grim side effects, along with her posts on how to tell the children, potshots at the breast cancer lobby, poetry and resolute calls to “persevere.”

headline: Interview: Jemima Kirke
abstract: The actress discusses “Girls.”
lead_paragraph: The actress discusses “Girls.”

headline: Dance Band Experiments With ‘Three-Way Stereo’
abstract: NightBus, a dance-pop band, has a single to be released on Tuesday by S-Curve Records with an audio innovation for the earbud age.
lead_paragraph: Pop musicians have been tinkering with the possibilities of stereo sound for decades. In the 1960s, for example, the Beatles sometimes separated individual instruments between left and right channel, and the Velvet Underground took that to an extreme on songs like “The Murder Mystery.”

headline: As Conjugal Visits Fade, a Lifeline to Inmates’ Spouses Is Lost
abstract: Mississippi, one of only a few states to allow conjugal visits, is putting an end to the hour that inmates and their spouses can spend alone together.
lead_paragraph: PARCHMAN, Miss. — To spend time alone with the man she married four months ago, Ebony Fisher, 25, drives nearly three hours through the flat cotton fields of the Mississippi Delta until she pulls into a gravel lot next to the state’s rural penitentiary.

headline: Clashes Between Militants and Army Spread in Iraq
abstract: A confrontation between insurgents and the army proved fatal in Baghdad and Anbar Provinces, and in Baghdad, two car bombs killed more than a dozen civilians.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — A confrontation between Iraqi insurgents and government forces in the western city of Falluja edged closer to the capital on Sunday, after clashes between militants and the army left at least 14 people dead in the Abu Ghraib district in Baghdad Province, according to security officials.

headline: Are Big Banks Out of Control?
abstract: Does the lack of legal compliance that have cost banks billions in fines show that some have gotten too big to manage properly?

headline: A Flashback to the Reign of J. Edgar Hoover
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Books and Literature', 'Editorials']
abstract: Four decades later, the Media, Pa., burglars come in from the cold.
lead_paragraph: I was a college sophomore in April 1971, still mourning the death of Jimi Hendrix, when I learned that a campus organization to which I belonged was being spied on by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The news landed in the mailbox of the Black Student Union — at what is now known as Widener University, not far from Philadelphia — in an envelope stuffed with documents that had been stolen from an F.B.I. office in nearby Media, Pa.

headline: Missing Executive Actions
abstract: There are some needed policy changes that could be made by presidential orders.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has often issued executive orders to get around recalcitrant Republicans in Congress or to clarify existing policy. Yet there are some areas where the president has been too reticent. The start of a new year is a good moment to point out some matters ripe for executive action.

headline: Where Free Speech Collides With Abortion Rights
abstract: The Supreme Court will hear challenges on Wednesday to a 2007 law limiting anti-abortion campaigners from communicating with women entering clinics, which they contend infringes on their rights.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — A couple of mornings a week, Eleanor McCullen stakes out a spot outside the Planned Parenthood clinic here and tries to persuade women on their way in to think twice before having an abortion.

headline: NBC’s News Unit Teams With Video Start-Up NowThis News
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Social Media', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: Working with the start-up is the latest part of NBC’s investment in keeping pace with the new ways that people consume news.
lead_paragraph: Broadcasting executives realize that viewers increasingly get their news by glancing on their smartphones instead of spending a half-hour in front of the television.

headline: The Basketball Player’s Guide to the (European) Galaxy
abstract: After competing for 25 years in Europe, changing clubs 15 times and living in five countries, Darryl Middleton has advice, a lot of it, to pass along to American players considering a tour abroad.
lead_paragraph: ALICANTE, Spain — You are a star high school basketball player, a whirlwind on the court. You score points, get rebounds and cover the ball on the defensive end. You get a scholarship and enjoy college. The N.B.A. draft is approaching and you can’t wait to cash in.

headline: Treading Water on Syria
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials']
abstract: It may be time to resume nonlethal aid to moderate rebels.
lead_paragraph: Nearly three years after the fighting began, many of the most dire predictions about Syria’s civil war have come true. The conflict has not only engulfed the country, killing more than 130,000 people and forcing more than nine million civilians out of their homes. Increasingly, it has metastasized across the region, destabilizing neighboring countries and serving as a magnet for militants, or would-be militants, including some from the United States.

headline: For Manning, Win Brings Big Relief and Bigger Rematch
abstract: Peyton Manning avoided another playoff upset, leading Denver past San Diego and setting up a showdown against Tom Brady and New England for the A.F.C. title.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — For exactly a year, Peyton Manning had lived with the duplicitous burden of being the N.F.L.’s best quarterback and an underachieving one. On Sunday, the anniversary of a stinging home loss to the underdog Baltimore Ravens, Manning and Broncos fans awoke to a full-page photograph of the quarterback under a dark cloud against a towering Denver Post headline: A Legacy Under a Cloud.

headline: Critics Say Spill Highlights Lax West Virginia Regulations
keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Water Pollution']
abstract: The chemical spill in West Virginia has brought renewed focus on the state’s troubled history of environmental disasters.
lead_paragraph: Last week’s major chemical spill into West Virginia’s Elk River, which cut off water to more than 300,000 people, came in a state with a long and troubled history of regulating the coal and chemical companies that form the heart of its economy.

headline: Saving Relics, Afghans Defy the Taliban
abstract: At the National Museum of Afghanistan, the most important objects smashed by the Taliban have been reassembled, and looted treasures have also been returned.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Every piece of antiquity that is restored to the halls of the bombed, pillaged and now rebuilt National Museum of Afghanistan sends a message of defiance and resilience.

headline: A Daunting Task
abstract: Mike Fisher, an archaeologist from the University of Chicago, is working with a team that is cataloging, classifying and restoring the National Museum of Afghanistan’s collection of artifacts.
lead_paragraph: Mike Fisher, an archaeologist from the University of Chicago, is working with a team that is cataloging, classifying and restoring the National Museum of Afghanistan’s collection of artifacts.

headline: The Heirs of Tarkenton Scramble, and Throw, to a New Era
abstract: A transformation at the quarterback position has arrived as a new generation of players skillfully combines throwing and scrambling.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Colin Kaepernick, the San Francisco 49ers third-year quarterback, stood outside a crowded interview room Sunday waiting his turn to face the news media.

headline: Big Changes for the Big 3
abstract: The Detroit auto show is ready to shine a light on developments for American automakers. As General Motors shed government ownership and Ford gambled on a redesign, Chrysler took on an Italian accent.
lead_paragraph: The Detroit auto show is ready to shine a light on developments for American automakers. As General Motors shed government ownership and Ford gambled on a redesign, Chrysler took on an Italian accent.

headline: Buffing a Battered City’s Image
abstract: City leaders in Detroit say they hope visitors will see a revival underway in a city lately known for bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Ever since Detroit filed for bankruptcy six months ago, political and business leaders here have insisted that the city’s long-awaited comeback has already begun.

headline: Struggle to Reach Olympics Is the Family’s, Too
abstract: For every triumphant Olympic story, a sea of athletes fall short of their dreams. Agnes Zawadzki, a figure skater, did not make the U.S. team, and even to try required huge sacrifices.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Watching Gracie Gold smile for the cameras after being named to the United States Olympic team on Sunday makes one forget that there is a heartbreaking downside to such thrilling moments.

headline: Bigger and Lighter, the Mercedes C-Class Will Flex Its Muscles
abstract: No longer the entry-level Mercedes, the C-Class has license to get a bit more edgy.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — With the aluminum diet all the rage in automaking capitals, Mercedes has dished up a lighter, yet more potent C-Class sedan to cement its status as the company’s best-selling model around the world.

headline: Clinic Director Says He Injected Rodriguez
abstract: Anthony Bosch, who ran the Biogenesis anti-aging clinic, told “60 Minutes” that a fear of needles had led Alex Rodriguez to ask him to administer injections.
lead_paragraph: A day after Yankees third baseman Alex Rodriguez received a season-long ban for doping, Anthony Bosch, the man who says he supplied Rodriguez’s performance-enhancing drugs, said in a taped interview Sunday that he had personally given him injections.

headline: Roger Ailes’s Permanent Pushback Campaign
abstract: Gabriel Sherman’s portrayal of the Fox News operation in his new book is hardly shocking, but it is not a pretty picture, and Mr. Ailes must know that.
lead_paragraph: Roger Ailes, the chairman of Fox News Channel, has little left to accomplish in a remarkable television career. He has made billions for his owners, created an entirely new genre of TV and, in doing so, he has changed the way politics is conducted. His business legacy is secure.

headline: Ian Barbour, Who Found a Balance Between Faith and Science, Dies at 90
abstract: Dr. Barbour embraced the notion of evolution and the Big Bang theory but was also a devoted churchgoer who in 1999 won the Templeton Prize for his progress in the field of religion.
lead_paragraph: Ian Barbour first studied science, then religion, but instead of concluding that the two are in eternal conflict, he helped create an academic realm where they share common ground.

headline: N.F.L. Explores New TV Deal
abstract: The N.F.L. is exploring with its existing broadcast and cable partners a proposal that would move some games from the NFL Network.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. is looking to sell six to eight of the 13 games it carries Thursday nights on NFL Network to one of its existing broadcast or cable partners — CBS, Fox, NBC or ESPN — or TNT, which once carried games.

headline: Watching ‘Downton Abbey': A Shocking Crime
abstract: This episode, if not this entire season of “Downton Abbey,” will be remembered for a single crime.
lead_paragraph: It was the “Downton Abbey” episode that shook Britain, and now it is America’s turn to react.

headline: A Songwriter Who Found Her Voice
abstract: This friendly, formulaic bio-musical traces the singer-songwriter’s bumpy road to stardom, song by song by song.
lead_paragraph: For purposes of transparency in advertising, “Beautiful: The Carole King Musical” should probably be titled “Brooklyn Girl.” This renaming would allow theatergoers to know exactly what to expect of the friendly, formulaic bio-musical that opened on Sunday night at the Stephen Sondheim Theater, starring an immensely likable Jessie Mueller.

headline: Cost of Cool in India? An iPhone
abstract: To draw young buyers and increase its market share in India, Apple has offered promotions like monthly payments and trade-ins.
lead_paragraph: BANGALORE, India — After deliberating for months, Abhilash Sathyendra, a 25-year-old equity adviser in Mysore, India, bought his first Apple phone. He paid 9,000 rupees, or $150, upfront for a black iPhone 4s and swiped his credit card for the remainder, six no-interest monthly payments of $62.50.

headline: At 28, Abbott Wins 4th U.S. Figure Skating Title
abstract: Jeremy Abbott conceded that he did not skate perfectly, but he finished first at the United States championships, earning a trip to Sochi with Jason Brown, 19, who came in second.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Jeremy Abbott said he knew his last United States Figure Skating Championships would end in tears, regardless of how his axels, spins and footwork played out on the ice.

headline: Twinned Cities Now Following Different Paths
keywords: ['Taxation', 'Labor and Jobs', 'State Legislatures', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Duluth, Minn., and Superior, Wis., are so close physically and culturally that they are known as the Twin Ports. But much began to change when Minnesota government went all Democratic and Wisconsin all Republican.
lead_paragraph: DULUTH, Minn. — The soaring Blatnik Bridge spans a modest body of water but a political gulf.

headline: Vugar Gashimov, a Bold Grandmaster of Chess, Dies at 27
abstract: Mr. Gashimov, an Azerbaijani, was renowned for his aggressive play and risky openings.
lead_paragraph: Vugar Gashimov, a chess grandmaster from Azerbaijan, who was one of the world’s top players for a decade and who helped lead his team to the gold medal in the European Team Chess Championship in 2009, died on Friday in Germany, where he had reportedly been receiving treatment for a brain tumor. He was 27.

headline: Litigation Finance Firm Raises $260 Million for New Fund
abstract: The firm, Gerchen Keller Capital, bankrolls plaintiffs and defendants in lawsuits, and has raised its new financing only a year after opening its doors.
lead_paragraph: An upstart investment firm that bets on lawsuits has raised hundreds of millions of dollars for its second fund.

headline: A Bridge to Scandal: Behind the Fort Lee Ruse
keywords: ['George Washington Bridge', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: A small borough’s colossal traffic backup was the face of a sloppily written farce featuring spiteful characters from Gov. Chris Christie staff and a patronage-laden Port Authority.
lead_paragraph: By his own account, Mark Sokolich rarely asks people for anything. “When you ask,” he said, “you usually have to give.”

headline: Upstate, Opposition to a Casino Is a Surprise
abstract: What was once considered a fait accompli is no longer a sure thing, and much of that is because of a coordinated local resistance.
lead_paragraph: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — With its rich history of horse racing and a 19th-century gambling parlor so opulent that it drew comparisons to Monte Carlo, this upstate enclave would seem to be a natural choice to receive one of the state’s new full-scale casinos.

headline: Heavy Hitters on Pariahs’ Row, Shunned by Hall of Fame
abstract: Five of the top 12 home run hitters in major league baseball history may never be enshrined in Cooperstown.
lead_paragraph: In 1999, Mark McGwire’s ostentatious power was worshiped by the actress Heather Locklear in a Nike commercial. Two envious pitchers, Greg Maddux and Tom Glavine, watched the scene and resolved to become more like McGwire.

headline: ‘Girls’ Returns, and a New Day Begins

lead_paragraph: Given the much remarked upon narcissism besetting the girls of “Girls,” what better way to open the new season than with a shot of each of them waking up?

headline: Fire at Manhattan Bank Burns for 30 Hours
abstract: A six-alarm fire raged at a Citibank branch in Morningside Heights on Saturday and Sunday, drawing over 200 firefighters before it was extinguished, fire officials said.
lead_paragraph: A six-alarm fire at a Citibank branch in Morningside Heights in Manhattan burned for more than 30 hours on Saturday and Sunday, drawing over 200 firefighters before it was extinguished, fire officials said.

headline: Assemblyman to Resign Over Harassment Claims
abstract: A state assemblyman representing part of Erie County, Dennis H. Gabryszak, who has been accused by seven women of sexual harassment, said he never intended to harass anyone.
lead_paragraph: A state assemblyman from western New York, Dennis H. Gabryszak, said on Sunday that he would step down amid mounting accusations that he sexually harassed women who worked in his office.

headline: Lundqvist Gives Little Yet Again, and the Flyers Pay a Familiar Price
abstract: Scoring three goals in the first period, the Rangers topped their longtime rivals at home for a seventh straight time.
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia Flyers made their first visit this season to Madison Square Garden, where the Rangers used three first-period goals and a smothering defense to top their longtime rivals at home for a seventh straight time.

keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Domestic Service', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Diplomatic Immunity']

lead_paragraph: It was 5:47 p.m. on Wednesday when the United States approved India’s request that Devyani Khobragade be accredited to that country’s United Nations mission, conferring on her “the privileges and immunities” accorded diplomatic envoys.

headline: An Unemployed Cook Grasps a Bit of Hope on One of Winter’s Coldest Days
abstract: On a frigid January morning, Gregory Brandon, who had been unemployed since August, nervously went on a job interview, hoping to call home with good news.
lead_paragraph: The night before his big interview, Gregory Brandon crawled into bed and prayed. “That I get the job,” he said quietly. “That everything will be all right.” Then he tossed and turned until he finally emerged from his blankets at about 6 a.m.

headline: A Mother Faces More Travails After the Loss of a Son
abstract: A Brooklyn mother’s grief at her son’s death during a family reunion in the Dominican Republic was compounded by funeral expenses and then a steep rent increase.
lead_paragraph: “Active” is the word Martha Rodriguez, 55, uses to describe her son, Alexander Espinal-Rodriguez.

headline: Need Cash? Own a Bentley? Take a Pawn Ticket
abstract: An increasing number of pawn businesses are catering to the wealthy, offering fast liquidity in exchange for high-end luxury items like Rolex watches and Bentley automobiles.
lead_paragraph: Walk into the Suttons & Robertsons showroom on the East Side of Manhattan and it looks like any high-end retailer or auction house: necklaces glittering with diamonds, sapphires and emeralds fill the display cases, and sterling silver knives, forks and spoons sit on a wooden table fit for a monarch. In the private room in back are bigger, shinier versions of the jewels out front.

headline: Quick Exit for Venus Williams at Australian Open
abstract: Williams started strongly, winning the first set, but errors cost her as her opponent rallied.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — For Venus Williams, a win in reach instead became another frustratingly early loss at a major tournament.

headline: CUNY Hopes to Dismiss Brooklyn College Official Over Financial Inquiry
keywords: ['Embezzlement', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: Prof. Joseph Wilson of Brooklyn College’s Graduate Center for Worker Education “unjustly enriched” himself, a City University investigation charged.
lead_paragraph: The Graduate Center for Worker Education, a tiny outpost of Brooklyn College in Lower Manhattan, has long been a busy place. For three decades, it has attracted students from across New York, minted hundreds of graduates of its master’s program in urban planning and administration, and housed the noted labor studies journal Working USA.

headline: The Week’s College Basketball Games to Watch
abstract: Now that a national champion has been crowned in college football, the spotlight shifts to basketball and a talented freshman class.
lead_paragraph: Now that Florida State has been crowned the national champion of college football, the spotlight shifts to basketball and a freshman class that includes the expected top N.B.A. draft picks Andrew Wiggins of Kansas and Jabari Parker of Duke. Here are some games to watch this week.

headline: Adding to Christie’s Troubles, a Rift With a Former Mentor Widens
abstract: Former Gov. Thomas H. Kean of New Jersey, who previously compared Gov. Chris Christie to Reagan, has begun calling his governing style dangerous.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie often dates his entry into politics to age 15, when, driven by his mother, he arrived at the doorstep of Thomas H. Kean, a state assemblyman who was pondering a run for governor, and asked for advice about getting involved.

headline: Denver Art Museum Gets a Trove of Impressionist Works
abstract: The museum will get 22 works by artists like van Gogh, Monet and Renoir, from the collection of Frederic C. Hamilton.
lead_paragraph: The Denver Art Museum announced that it had received the largest gift of paintings in its history, a group of 22 Impressionist works — by artists including van Gogh, Monet, Cezanne, Manet and Renoir — from the collection of Frederic C. Hamilton, an oil and gas magnate who has been the museum’s chief benefactor for several decades.

headline: The Empty-Diet-Claim Season
abstract: Pounds of quick-fix books invite a hasty return to bad eating and exercise habits. Effective weight loss and maintenance require a more serious commitment.
lead_paragraph: I don’t need a calendar to know that a new year has begun. I can tell by the deluge of new diet books that arrive in the office mail — more than two dozen since mid-December. On a whim, I weighed them all: over 25 pounds of mostly bad advice, about as much as many readers hope to lose before they have to shed the concealing garb of winter.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Kailyn Lowry, at age 17, decided to let MTV film her pregnancy and the birth of her first child in the hope of persuading other young men and women to wait to start a family.

abstract: As loyalty programs become more important for retailers, GE Capital Retail Bank will offer a product to help them track customers across online platforms and payment methods.
lead_paragraph: Its logo may not be prominent in stores, but GE Capital Retail Bank has a hand in the branded credit cards of tens of thousands of retailers, including J.C. Penney, Walmart and the Gap.

headline: Aiming to Push Genomics Forward in New Study
abstract: Regeneron Pharmaceuticals will sequence DNA from about 100,000 patients of Geisinger Health System in Pennsylvania, seeking genetic variants linked to diseases that may provide clues to developing new drugs.
lead_paragraph: Here comes genomics, Take 2.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (13) AT BERKELEY (2013) Without narration or identifying the people interviewed — from the humblest janitor to the most esteemed professor — Frederick Wiseman chronicles the history and teaching process of the University of California, Berkeley, while mulling the effect of capitalism on state-funded public education. “Mr. Wiseman has made his share of grim documentaries in which people are processed and oppressed by bureaucracy,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times of this four-hour film, presented here by “Independent Lens.” “ ‘At Berkeley’ is not one. Its cautiously upbeat attitude is expressed in a director’s note: ‘I think it is just as important for a filmmaker to show people of intelligence, character, tolerance and good will, hard at work, as it is to make movies about the failures, insensitivities and cruelties of others.’ Amen.”

headline: Blending Genders, for Some Laughs at the Golden Globes
abstract: Trying hard to top their job as hosts last year, Tina Fey and Amy Poehler fell short when aiming to be like the guys. But they were very funny on the subject of women and Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: The British actress Emma Thompson tossed her shoes across the stage and slurped a martini, Dean Martin-style. Jennifer Lawrence wore her hair almost West Point short, while the actor Jared Leto and the composer Alex Ebert put up their flowing locks in loose chignons.

headline: Bragging Rights to Share at the Golden Globes
abstract: “American Hustle” left a messy Golden Globes as the big winner on Sunday, winning three major awards, including best comedy. But voters stayed true to form and spread their love around.
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — “American Hustle” left a messy Golden Globes as the big winner on Sunday, capturing three major awards, including best comedy. But voters stayed true to form and spread their love around, handing best drama to an otherwise ignored “12 Years a Slave” and best director to Alfonso Cuarón, for “Gravity.”

headline: A Conversation With: Deepak Kapur, Chairman of India National PolioPlus Committee
abstract: Now that India has marked three years without a new polio case, Mr. Kapur spoke with India Ink about what is needed to ensure the disease doesn’t return.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, India completes three years without a single new polio case. India is finally on the brink of being polio-free, nearly 30 years after the Global Polio Eradication Initiative was established. Celebrations around the country will mark this feat in global health, with cities like Lucknow, Hyderabad and New Delhi lighting up their landmarks.

headline: From Today’s Paper: Breeches of Etiquette
abstract: A couple of riders on the London metro drew some sidelong glances as they took part in the “No Trousers Tube Ride” on Sunday, part of an international “No Pants Subway Ride” event.
lead_paragraph: A couple of riders on the London metro drew some sidelong glances as they took part in the “No Trousers Tube Ride” on Sunday, part of an international “No Pants Subway Ride” event. The annual happening was started in New York by a comedy group in 2002, and has since become a rite of winter in which pants-less people casually wait at stations along a subway line and hop onboard. Groups in dozens of cities across the world are said to be participating in the event.

headline: Bowed and Remorseful, Former Red Guard Recalls Teacher’s Death
abstract: A daughter of the Communist Party elite has offered public penance for her part in one of the most notorious killings of the Cultural Revolution.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:54 a.m. ET | Nearly half a century after Bian Zhongyun was beaten, kicked, tormented and left to die, bloody and alone, at the Beijing girls’ school where she was deputy principal, a daughter of the Communist Party elite has offered public penance — of a kind that instantly brought controversy — for her part in one of the most notorious killings of the Cultural Revolution.

headline: Forecast for Meteorologist’s Workweek: Busy
abstract: The Australian Open has its own official weather forecaster, who will be checking the heat index this week as the temperatures climb to over 100 degrees Fahrenheit.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — On the first two days of the Australian Open, players gulped water and applied ice packs to foreheads while on changeovers. Fans lathered on sunscreen, wore hats, sought shade. A heat wave has arrived, with temperatures expected to climb well over 100 degrees Fahrenheit.

abstract: Practice your prepositions with this edition of E.L.L. Practice.

abstract: Who took home awards at the Golden Globes ceremony?

headline: Plans for a Replica of Titanic Floated in China
abstract: The Titanic replica will be a tourist attraction moored at a riverbank and include features that recreate the experience of the ocean liner’s hitting an iceberg.
lead_paragraph: A company in southwestern China has announced plans to build a full-scale replica of the Titanic, the passenger ship that famously sank in 1912. The Seven Star Energy Investment Group, based in Sichuan Province, said it would spend spend 1 billion renminbi, or about $164 million, to build an ocean liner that would be moored on a river bank as a tourist attraction.

headline: Cops, Clowns and Cameras
abstract: The photographer Jill Freedman — at 74, “still like a rebellious adolescent” — may not be a household name, but her photography, and her life story, could fill volumes.
lead_paragraph: Jill Freedman was always attracted to closed societies, groups that didn’t much want her as a member. But her persistence always paid off.

lead_paragraph: Have you ever seen someone you know, or a celebrity you’ve read about, successfully transform a negative reputation or image?

headline: You’re All Losers
abstract: You’re rich or you’re nothing.
lead_paragraph: The other day someone — I don’t remember who or where — asked an interesting question: when did it become so common to disparage anyone who hasn’t made it big, hasn’t gotten rich, as a “loser”? Well, that’s actually a question we can answer, using Google Ngrams, which track the frequency with which words or phrases are used in books:

keywords: ['Engineering and Engineers', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: By acquiring Switzerland-based Foster Wheeler, the British engineering and project management firm would expand its footprint, including increasing its presence in Latin America.

headline: Israel Bids Farewell to Sharon, a ‘Complex Man’
abstract: The military and political elite, and foreign dignitaries including Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., were among those who gathered to honor former Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, who died Saturday.
lead_paragraph: SDEROT, Israel — Ariel Sharon, the fighter and farmer from Israel’s founding generation who became a prime minister both revered and reviled, was buried here Monday on a hill overlooking his family ranch, amid twin ceremonies in which he was eulogized as a courageous commander and pragmatic politician who relentlessly defended the land he loved.

headline: Swiss Teenager Beats Date-Krumm in a Battle of Generations
abstract: The 16-year-old Belinda Bencic, playing in her first Grand Slam main draw match, beat 43-year-old Kimiko Date-Krumm in three sets at the Australian Open.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Six months after winning the junior championship at Wimbledon, 16-year-old Belinda Bencic took the court Monday at the Australian Open against a woman old enough to be her mother.

headline: Tang Wei, Film Star, Reported Victim of Phone Scam
abstract: Tang Wei, celebrated yet also briefly blacklisted for her role in Ang Lee’s steamy 2007 film “Lust, Caution,” has been the victim of a telephone scam artist who persuaded her to wire about $34,500 from one of her accounts, according to Chinese news reports.
lead_paragraph: It was her graphic onscreen sex scenes with Tony Leung Chiu-Wai in “Lust, Caution,” under the direction of Ang Lee, that placed Tang Wei in the firmament of Chinese stars. She might have become an even bigger household name after the film was released in 2007 if prudish Chinese officials had not put her on an industry blacklist. Producers and directors avoided working with her for years, until at some point she was deemed to have been rehabilitated. She is now acting in films that are shown in mainland Chinese theaters.

headline: Protesters, Angry at Premier, Fill Bangkok’s Central Business District
abstract: In the boldest move in two months of protests against Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra’s government, crowds blocked traffic to Thailand’s costliest real estate.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Thousands of protesters who had spent the night on the streets of Bangkok’s central commercial district marched to government offices early Tuesday as part of a so-called shutdown of the city, a largely peaceful demonstration aimed at removing the government of Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra.

headline: Sanofi Unit to Buy $700 Million Stake in Rare Disease Company
abstract: Genzyme, the American biotechnology unit of the French drug maker Sanofi, is buying a 12 percent stake in Alnylam Pharmaceuticals for $700 million as part of an expanded alliance to develop treatments for rare genetic diseases.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The biotechnology unit of the French drug maker Sanofi  agreed on Monday to buy a 12 percent stake in Alnylam Pharmaceuticals for $700 million as part of an expanded alliance to develop treatments for rare genetic diseases.

headline: Matchmaker, Matchmaker, Find Me a Job
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Internships', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Collegefeed, a California startup, has developed a computerized job matching system that caters to the special needs of college students, recent graduates and employers looking for educated, entry-level workers.
lead_paragraph: It’s no coincidence that Sanjeev Agrawal, the co-founder and chief executive of Collegefeed, compares finding a job with dating. Finding The One (or at least The One That’s Good Enough) in both jobs and love is difficult under the best of circumstances, and it’s even harder if you don’t know where or how to start your search.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Jan. 13, 2014

headline: Would You Pay $698,000 for a Head Shop?
abstract: Many retail businesses would be thrilled with half of these profits.
lead_paragraph: In my posts I occasionally take a look at businesses for sale, which can offer interesting lessons for both buyers and sellers. This post looks at a specialty retail shop, what’s known as a head shop.

headline: My Old Osaka Home: Suntory of Japan to Buy Maker of Jim Beam
abstract: A privately held giant known for producing Japan’s first whiskey has agreed to acquire the maker of Jim Beam and Maker’s Mark bourbons, and Teacher’s and Laphroaig Scotch whiskies.
lead_paragraph: Few spirits are as American as bourbon. But the maker of some of whiskey’s most iconic brands, including Jim Beam and Maker’s Mark, will soon belong to an acquisitive Japanese beverage maker.

headline: Daily Report: Apple Makes Its Bid for Bigger Share of Indian Smartphone Market
abstract: To draw young buyers and increase its market share in India, Apple has offered promotions like monthly payments and trade-ins.
lead_paragraph: After deliberating for months, Abhilash Sathyendra, a 25-year-old equity adviser in Mysore, India, bought his first Apple phone. He paid 9,000 rupees, or $150, upfront for a black iPhone 4s and swiped his credit card for the remainder, six no-interest monthly payments of $62.50, Saritha Rai reports.

headline: 5 Chinese I.P.O.’s Shelved After Regulator Stiffens Rules
abstract: The China Securities Regulatory Commission announced that it would tighten restrictions on public offerings, shortly after the first new share sales since 2012 had been approved.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG – Five companies halted plans to sell shares on Monday after China’s securities regulator moved to tighten restrictions on new listings, the latest sign of challenges as the mainland seeks to reopen its stock markets to new offerings after a yearlong ban.

headline: Ranbaxy Says F.D.A. Lists Possible Violations at Punjab Drug Plant
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The latest warning from the American regulator comes four months after it announced a ban on any imports made by another Ranbaxy factory.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — Ranbaxy Laboratories, India’s largest drug maker, said Monday that the United States Food and Drug Administration had raised concerns about possible violations in manufacturing practices at a plant in the northern state of Punjab.

headline: Thank Ackman for the Beam Deal
abstract: It was William A. Ackman who pushed for the creation of Beam Inc. by calling for the breakup of its predecessor, Fortune Brands, a conglomerate that also sold golf equipment.
lead_paragraph: Monday ushered in the first big deal of 2014: Suntory’s takeover of Beam Inc. But the deal may not have been possible without William A. Ackman.

headline: Chevrolet Doubles Up for Car and Truck of the Year
abstract: In Detroit, Chevrolet swept the North American Car and Truck of the Year awards.
lead_paragraph: General Motors kicked off the 2014 North American International Auto Show in style Monday, sweeping the awards for the North American Car and Truck of the year with its new Chevrolet Corvette Stingray sports car and Silverado pickup.

headline: Why Barington Still Opposes Darden’s Plan to Spin Off Red Lobster
abstract: The activist hedge fund said on Monday that Darden’s plan to bolster its stock price did not go far enough in breaking apart the restaurant company.
lead_paragraph: The Barington Capital Group, the activist hedge fund pushing for change at Darden Restaurants, has already said that it is not happy with the company’s plans to spin off its Red Lobster chain.

headline: Suntory’s Deal for Jim Beam
abstract: Suntory of Japan is buying Jim Beam for $13.6 billion. | Bank of America tells its junior bankers to take a day off. | Sides trade harsh words at trial of former SAC trader. | Bank regulators back down on leverage ratio.
lead_paragraph: Suntory, known for producing Japan’s first whiskey, has agreed to acquire the maker of Jim Beam and Maker’s Mark bourbons, among other spirits, for $13.6 billion, DealBook reports. Including the assumption of debt, the deal is valued at $16 billion. Suntory is offering Jim Beam shareholders $83.50 a share in cash, 25 percent above the company’s closing price on Friday.

headline: Men’s Milan Fashion Week: Prada Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Gucci: Fall 2014 Menswear
abstract: Milan
lead_paragraph: Milan

headline: Utah, in Opposing Gay Marriage, Finds Three Arguments Are Better Than One
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: In the battle over Utah’s ban on same-sex marriage, the state has changed tack multiple times, refining its argument for the Supreme Court to include the benefits of “gender diversity” in parenting.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court’s order last week halting same-sex marriages in Utah was two sentences long. It was provisional and cryptic, and it added nothing to the available information on where the Supreme Court stands on the momentous question of whether there is a constitutional right to same-sex marriage.

headline: Hedge Fund Backs Men’s Wearhouse Bid for Jos. A. Bank
abstract: Eminence Capital, which owns a 9.8 percent stake in Men’s Wearhouse and a 4.9 percent stake in Jos. A. Bank, wrote a public letter to Jos. A. Bank’s board on Monday, urging the directors to accept the offer.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest investors in Men’s Wearhouse is officially on board with the retailer’s $1.6 billion hostile bid for Jos. A. Bank.

headline: Success, European Style
abstract: Things are slightly less awful. Hooray!
lead_paragraph: Since I’m in Ireland, I should give a belated plug to the very good piece by Fintan O’Toole debunking talk about Irish recovery.

headline: Elliott Turns Its Attention to Juniper Networks
abstract: The hedge fund Elliott Management wants Juniper Networks to cut costs, return money to shareholders and streamline its product offerings.
lead_paragraph: Days after throwing its weight around at Riverbed Technology and Celesio, the hedge fund Elliott Management has begun a campaign for change at Juniper Networks, the networking equipment company.

headline: Refreshing the Lunch Box for a New Season
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Lunch Boxes and Bags', 'Parenting']
abstract: Why waste your lunch-making efforts on September, when school is already exciting? If you pack school lunches, January’s a good time for a fresh start.
lead_paragraph: The fresh start that sparks in many of us in the new year can sputter out when the first day of school rolls around and those of us who send packed lunches with our children are faced with the gaping maws of empty insulated bags, waiting to be filled.

headline: Supreme Court Won’t Hear Arizona Appeal on Abortion Ban
abstract: The court declined to hear an appeal from Arizona officials seeking to reinstate a state law barring most abortions after 20 weeks of gestation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday declined to hear an appeal from Arizona officials seeking to revive a state law that barred most abortions after 20 weeks of pregnancy. The justices offered no reasons for turning down the appeal, as is their custom.

headline: Mediterranean Diet for Diabetes
abstract: A Mediterranean diet may help reduce the risk for Type 2 diabetes, even when people don’t lose weight or increase exercise levels.
lead_paragraph: More good news on the Mediterranean diet. Sticking to a Mediterranean-style diet may help reduce the risk for Type 2 diabetes, even when people don’t lose weight or increase exercise levels.

headline: Hudson River Club Forwards Chevron Grant to Group Fighting Oil’s Harms in Ecuador
abstract: A tiny Hudson River environmental group sends money it received from Chevron to a group helping Ecuadorian indigenous groups in challenges against big oil.
lead_paragraph: “The Mouse That Roared” comes to mind in pondering a move made in recent days by a tiny, barebones Hudson River environmental and sailing group, The Beacon Sloop Club. The club, which has a tree growing through the roof of its rickety headquarters on the waterfront 50 miles north of New York City, was one of two local groups receiving $1,000 checks from Chevron in November for help advising the oil giant in its cleanup efforts at the site of a former Texaco facility in the nearby community of Glenham, N.Y. (Chevron merged with Texaco in 2000.)

headline: Image of the Day: January 13
abstract: Devotees taking a holy dip at Sagar Island in the Bay of Bengal.

headline: Carrot, Squash and Potato Ragout With Thai Flavors
abstract: A colorful ragout that works on its own or over rice.
lead_paragraph: This is inspired by a recipe in Patricia Wells’s “Vegetable Harvest.” The flavors are both sweet and pungent. Serve it on its own or over rice; Thai purple sticky rice looks particularly pretty against the orange vegetables but any type of rice will do. I’m very happy serving this over brown rice.

headline: The Chrysler 200 Gets a Reboot
abstract: The company tries again with its midsize sedan, giving it a complete makeover for 2015.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 13: 2015 Chrysler 200

headline: Roasted Carrots With Turmeric and Cumin
abstract: A delicious way to enjoy carrots, as a side or on their own.
lead_paragraph: These are based on Suzanne Goin’s turmeric-spiced root vegetables from her wonderful new book “The A.O.C. Cookbook.” I use her technique for roasting the carrots, and use the same spices she uses, but I make the dish with a little less olive oil and butter to cut down on calories. Suzanne serves her mix of carrots, turnips, parsnips and rutabagas with Greek yogurt seasoned with kaffir lime juice and zest, and mint chutney. They are also delicious on their own.

headline: Roasted Sweet Potato Oven Fries
abstract: There are a lot of things to like about these delicious sweet wedges.
lead_paragraph: I don’t know what I like best about these sweet wedges – the way the sweet potato skins crisp and caramelize, the creamy texture of the sweet flesh, or the subtle flavors of the spices and infused oil.

headline: Grated Carrot Salad With Dates and Oranges
abstract: A fruity carrot salad, rich in vitamin C.
lead_paragraph: The influences here are Moroccan. The orange juice brings out the sweetness of the carrots. The juices combine in a delectable way, the salad sweetened all the more by the dates and cinnamon.

headline: Turkish Pumpkin Soup
abstract: An intriguingly sweet winter squash soup.
lead_paragraph: This is an intriguingly sweet winter squash soup, based on a recipe by Ghillie Basan from her wonderful book, “Classic Turkish Cooking.” The sweetness comes from the squash itself and the allspice and cinnamon, with the addition of only a teaspoon of honey or sugar. The sour and spicy yogurt and chile garnish make a great flavor contrast.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: More overexposure to commercials, and a familiar actor.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Bel Group names Y&R Midwest its agency of record for Bel Brands USA, and Burger King chooses Horizon Media as its media planning and buying agency for the United States.
lead_paragraph: Bel Group, Paris, expanded its relationship with Y&R, part of the Young & Rubicam Group division of WPP, by naming the agency’s Chicago office, known as Y&R Midwest, as agency of record for Bel Brands USA, Chicago, handling duties like brand strategy and social media for cheeses that include the Laughing Cow and Boursin. Spending was estimated at $15 million to $20 million. Y&R already handles Bel Group advertising in markets like Australia, Canada and Europe. The Bel Brands USA account had previously been handled by the Chicago office of Havas Worldwide, part of the Havas Creative unit of Havas.

headline: Airbus Led Rival Boeing in Jets Ordered Last Year
abstract: The orders reflect Airbus’s dominant position in the market for the most expensive aircraft: large wide-bodies with more than 400 seats.
lead_paragraph: TOULOUSE, France — In their rivalry as the world’s leading makers of passenger aircraft, Airbus captured the lead in jets ordered last year, but Boeing delivered more planes to customers.

headline: Another Mayor Felt Christie-Tied Reprisal
abstract: The administration of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey aggressively courted Mayor Steven Fulop of Jersey City, a Democrat, then abruptly cut ties after he told them he would not endorse the governor, emails show.
lead_paragraph: The night he was elected mayor of Jersey City in May, Steven Fulop got a call from Gov. Chris Christie congratulating him and offering whatever help he could — a pledge that was followed up by texts and emails from Mr. Christie’s campaign and State House aides, who set up a day’s worth of meetings with high-level commissioners in what they promised would be the beginning of a happy relationship.

headline: In Our Pages: January 14
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: 1889: Fake Francs Found in Paris

headline: Ford F-150 Is Now a Lighter Hauler
abstract: The aluminum-intensive 2015 F-150 pickup is a bold departure from conventional truck construction methods.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 13: 2015 Ford F-150

headline: The South’s Greatest Governor
abstract: Henry Watkins Allen belied the picture of Southern administrators as incompetent and inefficient.
lead_paragraph: Most prominent Civil War figures made a name for themselves through either a military or political career. A few, like Henry Watkins Allen, did both, first as a renowned colonel and later as governor of Louisiana. In fact, Allen’s term as governor undercuts the widespread assumption that Confederate administration was everywhere incompetent and inefficient. As the historian E. Merton Coulter wrote, “It was Henry W. Allen who showed the rest of the Confederate governors how good a Confederate state governor could be.”

headline: Fox Announces Return for ‘24’ and Start of an Updated ‘Cosmos’
abstract: The return of “24” will come in May, while the new version of the series that Carl Sagan made famous will arrive in March.
lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — The Fox network made a series of program announcements Monday, including the starting dates for two of its most anticipated projects: the return of the former hit “24” and an update of the famed “Cosmos” series.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: January 10-12, 2014
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Last March, after a night of drinking, Caleb Gordley, 16, sneaked into a house two doors down from his own and was shot and killed by its owner in Loudoun County, Va. Immediately after the shooting, Caleb’s parents said they forgave their neighbor, believing it to be accidental.

headline: Spalding Gray Prize Goes to Richard Maxwell
abstract: The award, named for the monologuist who died in 2004, includes a $20,000 commission to create a work.
lead_paragraph: The Spalding Gray Award, an annual prize named for the monologuist who died in 2004, will be given to the playwright and director Richard Maxwell, the consortium that oversees the prize announced on Monday. The prize includes a $20,000 commission to create a new work that will be given a full production at each of the organizations in the consortium. They are P.S. 122 in New York; the Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh; On the Boards in Seattle; and the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis.

headline: Suntory’s Deal for Beam Continues a Boom in Alcohol M.&A.
abstract: Suntory’s deal for the maker of Jim Beam is the third-largest acquisition by a Japanese company of a non-Japanese company, according to Thomson Reuters.
lead_paragraph: Suntory’s $13.6 billion deal for the maker of Jim Beam is the third-largest acquisition by a Japanese company of a non-Japanese company, according to Thomson Reuters, based on a $16 billion valuation that includes the assumption of debt.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Brit Hume Explains Christie
abstract: The governor of New Jersey, according to the Fox News host, is a “masculine and muscular” guy in a “feminized atmosphere.”
lead_paragraph: Via Media Matters

headline: Stern-Mackenzie One-Round War
abstract: From award-winning mathematics writer Dana Mackenzie: It’s war. What’s your strategy?
lead_paragraph: It’s war. You size up your warriors — all three of them. There’s strongest A, next-strongest B, and weakest C. Your opponent has three different-strength warriors as well. Warriors will fight in pairs (each warrior fights just one fight), and whichever side wins the most contests is the victor.

headline: Extremist Militant Group in Syria Retakes Ground Lost to Rival Rebels
keywords: ['Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The developments dampened hopes of the insurgents opposed to the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria that they could quickly subdue or co-opt the group.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Making good on threats to contest attacks by former allies on its power and claimed turf, the extremist militant group the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria has retaken significant parts of the territory in northern Syria that rival insurgent groups had wrested away last week, rebel representatives said on Monday.

headline: Foundations Aim to Save Pensions in Detroit Crisis
abstract: The money, from a group of philanthropic organizations, could also relieve the city-owned Detroit Institute of Arts from having to sell works to pay the city’s debts.
lead_paragraph: National and local philanthropic foundations have committed $330 million toward a deal to avoid cuts to Detroit retirees’ pensions and to save the Detroit Institute of Arts’ renowned collection, federal mediators involved in the city’s bankruptcy proceedings announced on Monday.

headline: Syrians May Allow the Delivery of Some Aid
keywords: ['Humanitarian Aid', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Diplomats have been discussing the delivery of humanitarian aid to some besieged areas, to set a positive tone for peace talks beginning Jan. 22.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Syrian government has told Russia that it is prepared to allow the delivery of humanitarian aid to some besieged areas in Syria, including East Ghouta, a suburb of Damascus where 160,000 people have been without assistance for a year, Russian and American diplomats said on Monday.

headline: Email Correspondence Regarding Steven Fulop, Mayor of Jersey City
abstract: Documents released Monday show that Gov. Chris Christie’s administration aggressively courted the mayor, then abruptly cut ties after he informed them that he would not endorse the governor for his re-election.
lead_paragraph: Documents released Monday show that Gov. Chris Christie’s administration aggressively courted the mayor, then abruptly cut ties after he informed them that he would not endorse the governor for his re-election.

headline: Today in Small Business: Learning From the Big Sites
abstract: How to tell your start-up story. How a bowling alley in New Jersey dealt with a competitor. And what you can learn from the big e-commerce sites.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Times Minute | Farewell to Ariel Sharon
abstract: Also on the Minute, Dennis Rodman returns to Beijing after his visit to North Korea and saving Afghan artifacts.
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, Dennis Rodman returns to Beijing after his visit to North Korea and saving Afghan artifacts.

abstract: Also on the Minute, Dennis Rodman’s visit to North Korea ends, and an effort to save Afghan artifacts.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Milady’s, a SoHo Stalwart, Shuts Its Doors
abstract: “It’s a dive bar,” said the owner, Frank Genovese. “I serve burgers; a beer is 5 bucks. I can no longer sustain that formula.’’
lead_paragraph: It was a safe bet that nobody at Milady’s on Sunday night cared much about the Golden Globes or the newest installment of “Downton Abbey.”

headline: Across Wall Street, Efforts to Revise a Hard-Charging Culture
abstract: As several major banks think hard about the workload of their junior employees, 2014 will probably be remembered as the year that Wall Street tried to offer some relief to the grunts.
lead_paragraph: The high-achieving college students bound for Wall Street jobs have heard the stories of long nights and weekends spent at the office, a grueling schedule etched into big bank culture.

headline: Europe Opens Inquiry Into Licensing of U.S. Films and TV
keywords: ['Television', 'Movies', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: Officials may seek to break down country-by-country partitions that keep pay TV from being a single market in the European Union.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The European Commission said on Monday that it had opened an investigation into the ways that major United States film and television studios license their content to European pay-TV providers — practices that the commission said might violate European antitrust rules.

headline: Taylor Swift or Sofia Vergara? Quick, Next Party!
abstract: The Golden Globes afterparties are an exercise in fear of missing out, whether it’s a lost opportunity to see a pop star or a television celebrity or two very cool Brits on the dance floor.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — There’s a complicated calculus to attending Golden Globes after-parties. Like the show, they’re all in the Beverly Hilton complex, but in far-flung corners. So there’s a scramble as guests and celebrities migrate from one to the other, running through the lobby, where fans congregate with cameras.

headline: Toyota Presents a Curvaceous Extrovert
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'North American International Auto Show', 'PlayStation (Video Game System)']
abstract: The FT-1 Concept can only be driven in the Gran Turismo 6 video game.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 13: Toyota FT-1 Concept.

headline: Biden Gives Eulogy at Sharon’s Funeral
abstract: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. spoke at Ariel Sharon’s funeral in Jerusalem.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. spoke at Ariel Sharon’s funeral in Jerusalem.

headline: For Prada and Gucci, a Similar View of Fall Fashion
abstract: Prada and Gucci are designed by women — Miuccia Prada and, at Gucci, Frida Giannini — but this scarcely accounts for their remarkable agreement this season at the men’s fall shows.
lead_paragraph: What do Prada and Gucci have in common? Milan, fleets of P.R. people. Both brands are also designed by women — Miuccia Prada and, at Gucci, Frida Giannini — but this scarcely accounts for their remarkable agreement this season at the men’s fall shows.

headline: Guggenheim Will Invite Architects to Imagine a Finnish Outpost
abstract: City officials in Helsinki voted to set aside a parcel of land that could be used for a new museum facility.
lead_paragraph: The on-again-off-again proposal to build an outpost of the Guggenheim Museum in Helsinki, Finland, appears to be on again. After city officials there shot down the idea of building the $185 million museum in May 2012, it voted on Monday to reserve a parcel of land on the city’s South Harbor waterfront for the prospective institution. This gives the Guggenheim the green light to start an open international architectural competition to determine who would build the museum.

headline: Justices Cite History as They Voice Doubts on Obama’s Recess Appointments
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Constitution (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: Justices across the ideological spectrum appeared prepared to rein in the ability of presidents to make appointments without the Senate’s consent.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an extended argument that contained large doses of constitutional history and practical politics, the Supreme Court on Monday seemed skeptical of the Obama administration’s contention that it could bypass the Senate to appoint officials during short breaks in the Senate’s work.

headline: Burton Lifland, Judge Who Oversaw Madoff Bankruptcy, Dies at 84
abstract: Burton R. Lifland, the judge who was overseeing the wind-down of Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme, died on Sunday, according to the clerk for the federal bankruptcy court in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Burton R. Lifland, the judge who was overseeing the winding down of Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme, died on Sunday, according to the clerk for the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan.

headline: Scenes of Protest in Bangkok
abstract: Demonstrators filled the city’s central commercial district Monday as part of an effort to overthrow Thailand’s prime minister, Yingluck Shinawatra.
lead_paragraph: Demonstrators filled the city’s central commercial district Monday as part of an effort to overthrow Thailand’s prime minister, Yingluck Shinawatra.

headline: One Woman’s Dying Wish: A Monthlong Farewell Party
abstract: When Marcy Glanz was told she had only weeks to live, she decided to say goodbye her way to her husband and their two sons, as well as to nearly everyone else she knew.
lead_paragraph: Marcy Glanz had been battling uterine cancer since early 2011, but in late November she was given grim news by her doctors — her cancer was so severe that she had only several weeks to live.

headline: Time’s Up for ‘Ticking’ as Wearability Supplants Reliability in Watch Pitches
abstract: A campaign for Timex Group USA will focus on style and authenticity to reach a new generation.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Timex has been promoted with the theme “It takes a licking and keeps on ticking” and variants like “Life is ticking” and, most recently, “Love what makes them tick.” Now, time has run out on the venerable slogan and its descendants as Timex takes a new tack that reflects the changing role of watches.

headline: So Long BMW 1 Series, Hello 2 Series
abstract: The company again tries to evoke its classic 2002 with a new sporty subcompact.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 13: BMW 2 Series Coupe

headline: Directors Guild Names Its 5 Documentary Nominees
abstract: Five documentary makers who also made the Academy’s shortlist are on the Directors Guild’s list.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 2:05 p.m. |  Last week, the Directors Guild of America released the five feature directors up for its top prize. Now comes the group’s documentary choices, all of which are also on the Academy’s shortlist:

headline: Alice Munro to Beam In for Night at Symphony Space
abstract: The Selected Shorts event honoring Ms. Munro will also feature Margaret Atwood, Holly Hunter and others.
lead_paragraph: The Canadian writer Alice Munro couldn’t make it to Stockholm in December for the ceremony commemorating her Nobel Prize because of health concerns, but Ms. Munro will visit New York — virtually, anyway — later this month.

headline: Armond White Expelled From Critics’ Group
abstract: After an awards ceremony marred by accusations that a member yelled abuse at the director of “12 Years a Slave,” the New York Film Critics Circle expelled a member, Armond White of City Arts. Another member, Lou Lumenick of The New York Post, was suspended for a year.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:25 p.m. |  The New York Film Critics Circle took the rare step Monday of expelling Armond White, the film critic for CityArts, and of suspending the New York Post film critic Lou Lumenick for a year. The group confirmed the moves in a statement.

headline: The Playlist | The Diverse, Influential Sounds Behind James Vincent McMorrow’s Sophomore Album
abstract: On “Post Tropical,” the Irish singer-songwriter throws out his acoustic sound in favor of hip-hop beats and ’90s soul. Here, he takes T on an audio tour of the making of his album.
lead_paragraph: James Vincent McMorrow’s debut album, 2011’s “Early in the Morning,” was a promising, if sometimes frustrating, collection of indie folk songs — the kind of tuneful music one is likely to hear during the more earnest moments of a hit TV drama, or in a dimly lit pub. The Irish singer-songwriter’s full-length follow up, “Post Tropical,” out tomorrow on Vagrant Records, takes McMorrow’s intimate lyrics and hushed vocals and soaks them in ’90s R&B and early 2000s hip hop, often with stunning results. (For proof, listen to the epic “Red Dust,” in which McMorrow bares his soul over a thumping hip-hop beat before the song gives way to lush synths and a falsetto that calls to mind Jeff Buckley’s best work on “Grace.”)

headline: Enhancements for Expedia
abstract: The travel site Expedia has added several feature for users, including one that recommends alternative itineraries.
lead_paragraph: Expedia, the travel booking website, has stepped up its search game in recent weeks, adding three features to help travelers find — and organize — the best flights possible.

headline: A Bold Move by Suntory
abstract: The strategic imperative for the Japanese corporation is clear, as it is for just about any consumer goods company in the incredibly shrinking Japan, notes Rob Cox of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: For a Japanese corporation, Suntory Holdings has an especially aggressive corporate slogan: “Yatte Minahare,” which roughly translates as “Go for it.”

headline: A Sort of Season for Ennio Morricone
abstract: The composer Ennio Morricone will conduct at concerts in Los Angeles and Brooklyn in March.
lead_paragraph: The first part of 2014 is slowly shaping up as a low-key Ennio Morricone festival. The Italian composer, who turns 85 in November, is best known for his film scores — some 450 of them, including “The Good, the Bad and the Ugly,” with its unmistakable, undulating ocarina figure; and “The Untouchables” and “The Mission,” both packed with gripping, dramatic string writing. And though he conducts rarely in the United States (his last visit to New York was a Radio City concert in 2007), he will be leading a freelance orchestra and choir in two concerts in March — his Los Angeles conducting debut, at the Nokia Theater in on March 20, and a performance at Barclays Center in Brooklyn on March 23.

headline: Recalling Past Threats, Afghans in Tranquil Valley Work to Keep It That Way
abstract: With American troops set to leave by the end of the year, worry is returning to the Panjshir Valley, a redoubt of Taliban opposition.
lead_paragraph: BAZARAK, Afghanistan — Even among Afghans, who are generally wary of outsiders, the members of the ethnic Tajik population of the Panjshir Valley are an unusually suspicious lot. So it is their good fortune to have been blessed with the closest thing to a naturally occurring “keep out” sign: a deep and narrow gorge at the valley’s mouth that seems tailor-made for obstruction and ambush.

headline: Christie Faces Audit Over Use of Hurricane Relief Money
abstract: The Department of Housing and Urban Development will investigate whether Gov. Chris Christie’s administration improperly spent federal money meant to encourage tourism after Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: Federal investigators have ordered an audit to determine whether Gov. Chris Christie’s administration improperly spent millions of dollars of relief meant to encourage tourists to visit New Jersey after the devastation of Hurricane Sandy.

headline: McKesson Comes Up Short on Celesio Tender Offer
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: A $8.3 billion deal for the German pharmaceutical wholesaler failed to receive the minimum shareholder support, but McKesson did not say whether it would continue to try to acquire the company.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The McKesson Corporation said on Monday that it had failed to receive the minimum shareholder support needed for its $8.3 billion acquisition of the German pharmaceutical wholesaler Celesio, despite a sweetened tender offer last week.

headline: After Beam Deal, Few Big Liquor Mergers Left
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Liquor', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Most of the big global liquor brands have been absorbed by Diageo, Pernod, Suntory or Brown-Forman, leaving little room for further consolidation.
lead_paragraph: A big whiskey acquisition is a shot in the arm for the global spirits industry, but there may not be many more substantial liquor deals to strike.

headline: BMW Introduces Its M&M Boys
abstract: Dropping the V8, BMW puts an in-line, turbocharged 6 cylinder into its new M3 and M4.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 13: 2015 BMW M3 and M4

headline: California Democrat to Retire From House
abstract: Representative George Miller of California was first elected in 1974, and he earned a reputation as a staunch liberal willing to work with Republican colleagues.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative George Miller, Democrat of California, announced Monday that he would retire at the end of his term, after 40 years in Congress.

headline: Poverty and Inequality, in Charts
abstract: An economist takes a closer look at the relationship between growing income inequality and the stubborn persistence of poverty, 50 years after Lyndon Johnson vowed to eradicate it.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Recalling a Poet’s Vigil for a Life-Extending Gift
abstract: In “Blessing the Boats: The Remix” at the Public, Will Power, Carl Hancock Rux and Mike Ladd inventively reprise Sekou Sundiata’s performance piece.
lead_paragraph: “According to the latest research, anything could be anything.” This is, to my ear, as crisp and withering a distillation of modern medical care as you’ll find, especially as experienced by a patient desperate for something a bit more concrete.

headline: Golden Globes Telecast Draws Nearly 21 Million Viewers
abstract: The broadcast, hosted by Tina Fey and Amy Poehler on NBC, had its biggest audience in 10 years, and was up 6 percent from last year.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The combination of hit movies like “Gravity” being honored, the return of Tina Fey and Amy Poehler as hosts and intense marketing on social media drove the 71st Golden Globes to a total audience of 20.9 million viewers, an increase of 6 percent from 2013.

headline: Ford Reveals 2015 F-150
abstract: Paul Stenquist describes the importance of the Ford 2015 F-150.
lead_paragraph: Paul Stenquist describes the importance of the Ford 2015 F-150.

headline: Chrysler 200 Is Redesigned
abstract: Jerry Garrett describes the new Chrysler 200.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Garrett describes the new Chrysler 200.

headline: DiCaprio Nabs Some Treats, and Coogan Assesses the Guest List
abstract: More scenes from the Globes afterparties, including snapshots of Diddy, Christoph Waltz and others.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Where were we in the Globes after-party shuffle? Oh, right: at 10:15, Andrew Dice Clay and Alyssa Milano were waiting patiently in the line to get into the Warner/InStyle party. Over at HBO, held atop and around the Beverly Hilton pool, Sofia Vergara was, indeed, taking selfies, and guests like Hayden Panettiere and Stephen Merchant milled around. Some cast members of “Girls” remained, but Lena Dunham was long gone.

headline: Push to Combat Insider Trading May Go Too Far
abstract: The latest crackdown by New York State’s attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, may end up blurring the already thin line between permissible securities analysis and illegal conduct, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: Last week, BlackRock, the asset management giant, agreed to a settlement with New York State to stop conducting surveys of investment analysts.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Jan. 7-13, 2014
abstract: A political scandal, a chemical spill, the Golden Globes and a same-sex marriage battle: how many of the 10 news stories in this quiz have you followed this week?
lead_paragraph: A political scandal, a chemical spill, the Golden Globes and a same-sex marriage battle: how many of the 10 news stories below have you followed this week?

headline: Calls for Oversight in West Virginia Went Unheeded
keywords: ['Water Pollution', 'Water', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances']
abstract: As chemical accidents continued in West Virginia, so did calls for increased oversight, but those recommendations went unheeded by lawmakers, federal regulators said.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — The accidents kept coming, and so did the calls for a plan to improve West Virginia’s chemical safety regulations.

headline: What Patients Don’t Tell Their Doctors
abstract: Personal demons can elude physicians, as patients try to save face in their offices. But a disclosure of substance abuse from a patient’s loved ones brings its own hurdles.
lead_paragraph: A patient’s wife was on the phone, her voice hesitant, unhappy. She didn’t bother with small talk. “I need to talk to you about Tom’s drinking,” she said.

headline: Skeptical of Facebook, Until the Checkbook Came Out
abstract: Josh Miller, who once wrote that Facebook has “an irreversibly bad brand,” has accepted its buyout offer for Branch and Potluck, his social network services.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, Josh Miller said that Facebook “may have an irreversibly bad brand.” Soon after, Mr. Miller, a co-founder of a start-up called Branch Media, was giving Facebook some unsolicited advice, suggesting that it “turn to Nike for strategic inspiration.”

keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Books and Literature', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In his memoir “Duty,” the former defense secretary Robert M. Gates provides revelations about major decisions made from late 2006 to 2011.
lead_paragraph: As I was reading “Duty,” probably one of the best Washington memoirs ever, I kept thinking that Robert M. Gates clearly has no desire to work in the federal government again in his life. That evidently is a fertile frame of mind in which to write a book like this one.
