headline: Sacrificing Gated Safety for a Lover and Herself
abstract: In Chang-rae Lee’s “On Such a Full Sea,” set in a future America divided into self-contained settlements, a 16-year-old goes in search of a missing boyfriend.
lead_paragraph: Chang-rae Lee’s new novel is part folk tale, part picaresque adventure, part dystopian satire. It signals a bold departure from both the carefully observed realism that distinguished Mr. Lee’s powerful earlier books “Aloft” (2004) and “A Gesture Life” (1999) — and the historical vistas of “The Surrendered” (2010). In eschewing one of his most potent gifts as a writer — his ability to map the inner lives of his characters with sympathy and precision — Mr. Lee has produced an ungainly and strangely inert novel. Instead of creating a palpably real flesh-and-blood heroine, he has chosen to center his book on an anime-like character named Fan; and instead of creating a fully imagined fictional realm (as Kazuo Ishiguro did in his bravura sci-fi-like novel, “Never Let Me Go,” from 2005), he’s dropped Fan into a futuristic world that seems at once overly familiar and unconvincing.

headline: Quail to Serve With Loire Valley Reds
abstract: You may not associate the Loire Valley with game, but the hunt, especially for birds, is important in this region of France.
lead_paragraph: You may not associate the Loire Valley with game, but the hunt, especially for birds, is important in this region of France. I had that in mind when I decided on a seasonal preparation for quail to serve with the deliciously sturdy cabernet francs we tasted.

headline: Revisiting the Reds of the Loire Valley
abstract: The region offers a reasonably priced chance to seek out easy drinking and soul-satisfying pleasures, sometimes in the same bottle.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a somewhat small region farmed primarily by myriad family grape growers, many of whom have made wine for generations. They work diverse soils, and because the reds are mostly from a single grape, comparing wines from a multitude of terroirs is fascinating.

headline: Printing the Windows 8 Calendar
abstract: The Windows 8 Calendar app takes a little extra work to print because it cannot do so from the Devices charm, which allows users to quickly send information to other devices.
lead_paragraph: Q. I use the Windows 8 Calendar app on my computer and would like to print out the monthly view of my schedule to have a paper copy. How do I do this? I press Control+P when I have the calendar page open and nothing happens.

lead_paragraph: An ancient human ancestor who lived in East Africa millions of years ago — nicknamed Nutcracker Man for his big, flat molars and powerful jaws — didn’t actually eat nuts, researchers say.

headline: Tent City in Central African Republic Swells as Violence Grips Capital
abstract: Most residents of Bangui, the capital city, have picked up and fled amid the nation’s low-boil civil war, including more than 100,000 who moved to one chaotic camp by the airport.
lead_paragraph: BANGUI, Central African Republic — The streets of this capital city’s center are nearly empty. A few citizens slowly walk the wide boulevards, outnumbered by French troops patrolling after recent deadly violence. The battered buildings remain, but much of the city’s population has disappeared.

headline: Why We Buy in a Marked-Up Market
abstract: Investors need to overcome the instincts that lead them to buy and sell stocks at precisely the wrong times.
lead_paragraph: When dividends are included, 2013 was the fifth consecutive year of positive performance in the stock market (as measured by the annualized Standard & Poor’s 500 return). The stock market is now up more than 200 percent from the bottom of the financial crisis in March 2009. Returns since those dark days have been unbelievable, including the market’s most recent performance in 2013 of around 30 percent.

headline: Has Christie Lost His Credibility?
abstract: Some Times readers think the scandal is an opportunity for the governor to prove his mettle.
lead_paragraph: New Jersey Governor Chris Christie’s troubles are not going away. Questions about whether the governor’s team was responsible for a giant traffic jam in Fort Lee, N.J., convulsed the national news shows over the weekend. More subpoenas are expected, probably for staff members Mr. Christie fired last week. Added to the pyre, federal investigators are now looking into whether the governor misused almost $5 million in Hurricane Sandy relief funds for his “Stronger than the Storm” ads featuring himself and his family in the months before his re-election.

headline: Rodriguez’s ‘Gummies’: Files Detail Doping, Down to Milligram
abstract: A report describes the complicated diet of a big-league doper who juggled four injections with two muscle treatments, two skin creams, two lozenges and six oral doses.
lead_paragraph: Alex Rodriguez took an energy cocktail on Mondays and a therapy cocktail on Fridays.

headline: Older Pool of Health Care Enrollees Stirs Fears on Costs
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Republicans seized on the latest insurance enrollment numbers under the Affordable Care Act as evidence that the law would not work.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — People signing up for health insurance through the Affordable Care Act’s federal and state marketplaces tend to be older and potentially less healthy, officials said Monday, a demographic mix that could threaten the law’s economic underpinnings and cause premiums to rise in the future if the pattern persists.

headline: Health Exchange Enrollment Ended With a Surge
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: More than eight million people signed up for private insurance in federal and state exchanges during the initial enrollment period, exceeding the administration’s original goal of seven million.
lead_paragraph: More than eight million people signed up for private insurance in federal and state exchanges during the initial enrollment period, exceeding the administration’s original goal of seven million.

headline: The Short, Exuberant Life of Sam Berns
abstract: A remembrance of Sam Berns, who died this past Friday from complications related to a rare genetic disorder, progeria.
lead_paragraph: Judging from media appearances last year that brought him a kind of celebrity — first as the subject of an HBO documentary, then as a speaker at a TEDx conference — Sam Berns seemed to be far healthier than anyone could have anticipated back in 2005, when I wrote about him for the magazine. My article focused on his mother’s search for a cure for his disease, progeria, a rare genetic disorder that makes children seem to age before your eyes, with damage to organ systems — particularly the heart, skin and bones — usually seen only in the very old.

headline: Hard-Liners in Iran Offer Mild Praise for Interim Nuclear Agreement
abstract: Conservatives cautiously welcomed the completion of an interim agreement that would provide Tehran with some relief from Western sanctions.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iranian hard-liners on Monday cautiously welcomed the completion of an interim nuclear agreement that will provide Tehran with some relief from Western economic sanctions in return for a suspension of certain nuclear activities for six months.

headline: Of New Atheists and Noble Lies
abstract: A response to Noah Millman on atheism, religion and morality.
lead_paragraph: I began last week by responding to Jerry Coyne’s broadside against my Christmas column, so I suppose it’s fitting to begin this one by responding to Noah Millman’s lament that I need to “argue with better atheists,” instead of “weak combatants” like Coyne. My facile response to that line is that I’ll argue with better atheists when America’s flagship journal of liberal opinion publishes better atheists attacking things I’ve written; my more serious response is that my quarrel with atheism grows cooler and more modest the more serious (in my admittedly-biased view) the atheist in question. I’ll elaborate on that a bit below, but first, here’s Millman’s more serious complaint about my response to Coyne:

headline: Readers Lash Out About Bill Keller’s Column on a Woman With Cancer
abstract: Many saw the column as insensitive to a woman who has communicated about every aspect of the disease.
lead_paragraph: Bill Keller’s column in The Times on Monday about Lisa Bonchek Adams has generated a great deal of negative response. Xeni Jardin, the well-known writer who blogs on Boing Boing, sometimes about her own experience with cancer, was outraged, calling it bullying.

headline: Globes Highlights and (of Course) Lowlights
abstract: Julia Louis-Dreyfus and Leonardo DiCaprio played along; Jacqueline Bisset confounded.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It used to be that the best part of awards shows, for those watching at home, was dissecting everyone’s outfits. Now that that happens on screen, too — and online, and often in real time — the best part is dissecting everything, the missteps and scripted and unscripted high points, all capturable and re-viewable in GIF form.

headline: Exploring Planetary Mass
abstract: A newly discovered planet weighs the same as Earth but is 60 percent larger in diameter. That means the planet, KOI-314c, has a very thick, gaseous atmosphere.
lead_paragraph: A newly discovered planet weighs the same as Earth but is 60 percent larger in diameter. That means the planet, KOI-314c — shown in an artist’s conception — has a very thick, gaseous atmosphere. To determine its weight, astronomers used a method called transit-timing variation: They measured how long it took the planet to orbit its star and how that time was affected by its gravitational pull toward another planet.

lead_paragraph: Last night, the annual Golden Globe Awards ceremony was preceded, as it always is, by an impressive parade of television and film stars going down the red carpet. The Twittersphere was abuzz with trends such as baby bumps and burly beards, and some of the most award-winning looks in front of the Beverly Hilton Hotel happened in groups of three.

headline: For Google, a Toehold Into Goods for a Home
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Home Appliances', 'Home Automation and Smart Homes']
abstract: The $3.2 billion deal for Nest Labs, which is led by former Apple engineers, will expand the technology giant’s portfolio of consumer goods.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google, which dominates much of life on the Internet, has been trying to expand beyond computers and telephones to living rooms, cars and bodies. It made its way a bit further into people’s homes on Monday when it agreed to pay $3.2 billion in cash for Nest Labs, which makes Internet-connected devices like thermostats and smoke alarms.

headline: An Ancient Fish’s Four-Wheel Drive
abstract: Based on fossils of Tiktaalik roseae, a transitional species that lived 375 million years ago, scientists have concluded that the modification of fins into four limbs began before vertebrates left the water.
lead_paragraph: Based on fossils found a decade ago, scientists had assumed that the earliest known species of fish to make the momentous transition to four-legged animals, capable of living and moving about on dry land, had developed a kind of front-wheel drive. They used enhanced forward fins to crawl out of shallow waters, and only later adapted their rear fins into limbs.

headline: As Christie Faces New Questions, State Lawmakers Expand Investigation
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie faces new questions about political retribution and Hurricane Sandy aid as Trenton lawmakers outline plans to create special investigative legislative committees.
lead_paragraph: As Gov. Chris Christie prepared to deliver his annual State of the State address on Tuesday, he faced new questions just days after he dismissed two aides, including his longtime political adviser Bill Stepien, in a political payback scandal that involved manufacturing a huge traffic jam last September at the George Washington Bridge.

But not the very first thing — that will be to make a beeline for the Michigan Hall in Cobo Center, where her grand prize-winning poster will be displayed when the show opens to the public on Jan. 18.

headline: A Solution That Now Looks Crazy
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists', 'Books and Literature']

lead_paragraph: “How the Federal Government Destroyed the Mental Illness Treatment System”: That subtitle is the opening shot across the bow in this jeremiad of a book by the psychiatrist Dr. E. Fuller Torrey. It could just as well have read: “How a group of well-intentioned, starry-eyed idealists made a hash of mental health care.”

headline: McConaughey Shimmies, Samberg Remembers

headline: Rebuilding Our Badly Broken Pets
abstract: In response to demand from owners, veterinary specialists are performing reconstructive operations as sophisticated as anything in human medicine.
lead_paragraph: DAVIS, CALIF. — Classical music played in the background as a team of surgeons leaned over Mischa, who lay anesthetized on the table, mouth wide open, tongue lolling to the side, all four legs in the air. The owners of the 7-year-old German shepherd had rushed her to the veterinary hospital at the University of California, Davis, after she ran in front of a small private plane and was clipped in the jaw by a propeller.

abstract: PBS’s “Frontline” goes inside the North Korea of Kim Jong-un.
lead_paragraph: PBS’s “Frontline” enjoys some morbid good timing on Tuesday night, presenting its report “Secret State of North Korea” in the wake of the execution last month of Jang Song-thaek, uncle of the North Korean dictator Kim Jong-un, and the return to the country this month of the former N.B.A. player and amateur diplomat Dennis Rodman.

headline: With Ruling, Funds to Aid Desegregation in Arkansas Are Ended
keywords: ['Segregation and Desegregation', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Education (K-12)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: Payments from Arkansas to help fund desegregation efforts in three school districts will be phased out under a settlement that was approved.
lead_paragraph: LITTLE ROCK, Ark. — A federal judge on Monday gave final approval to a legal settlement that would allow the state to phase out payments of millions of dollars to three school districts to fund desegregation efforts, bringing to a close a court battle that has lasted over three decades.

headline: A Mental Alarm Clock
abstract: A period of relative alertness, part of the body’s circadian rhythm, may explain why some wake up in the middle of the night.
lead_paragraph: Q. Why do I wake up at exactly the same time every night, without any stimulus? It has happened all my life, and it doesn’t even matter what time I went to bed.

headline: ‘Nine-Nine’ and Fox Enjoy Upset at Globes
abstract: The lightly watched Fox comedy “Brooklyn Nine-Nine” got a huge boost in knocking off network titans and much buzzed-about cable entries at the Golden Globes.
lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — This is what it has come to for broadcast television: When a new network show wins a major award, it’s the upset of the night.

headline: Keeping Their Eyes on the Score
abstract: Miami City Ballet’s program “See the Music” shows how closely the company’s new artistic director, Lourdes Lopez, is following the path of the old, Edward Villella.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Miami City Ballet, widely known as one of the world’s leading exponents of choreography by George Balanchine, also has a record of new choreography. Its current quadruple bill, labeled “See the Music,” opens with Balanchine’s “Concerto Barocco” (1941) and has Nacho Duato’s “Jardí Tancat” (1983), a new company acquisition, as a centerpiece. But it also features two works recently made for the troupe, Justin Peck’s “Chutes and Ladders” (2013, to the first movement of Benjamin Britten’s String Quartet No. 1) and Alexei Ratmansky’s “Symphonic Dances” (2012, to Rachmaninoff’s 1940 work of that name).

headline: Pictures of the Day: Central African Republic and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from South Sudan, Central African Republic, Israel and Thailand.
lead_paragraph: Photos from South Sudan, Central African Republic, Israel and Thailand.

headline: Like Solos, but Joined in a Slinky Procession
abstract: The new work by the choreographer Danah Katz, “Thousand Plateaus,” felt unfinished, like a conceptual shell waiting to be filled in.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Danah Katz waited until the end of her new work, “Thousand Plateaus,” to make a significant disclaimer. “This is an experiment for all of us,” she said on Sunday at the 92nd Street Y, surrounded by the four other members of her company, Danaka Dance; the piece, she added, is still in its “pilot period.”

headline: Proposed Metro-North Link Could Wake Up Sleepy Co-op City
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s revival of a plan for a Metro-North spur serving Co-op City, in the northeast Bronx, would put Midtown just a half-hour away.
lead_paragraph: It is quiet in Co-op City, the nation’s largest housing cooperative, even though some 50,000 people live there. So quiet that the sound of footsteps crunching on icy sidewalks was louder than the wail of distant police sirens on Friday afternoon. So calm that fewer than a dozen people boarded the express bus, the fastest link to Midtown Manhattan, for its hourlong 2 p.m. trip.

headline: Times Minute | Audit Over Sandy Funds
abstract: Also on the Minute, rising sea levels and a new owner for Jim Beam.
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, rising sea levels and a new owner for Jim Beam.

headline: The Whole World Gets Into the Groove
abstract: Globalfest 2014 was a 12-act world-music showcase that included dance music, gospel, African beats and many other genres.
lead_paragraph: “Are you ready to party with us?” asked Baloji, a Congolese singer, songwriter and rapper, as he kicked his band into a sunny, danceable three-chord soukous groove during Globalfest 2014 at Webster Hall on Sunday night. The song bounded along with lyrics in Lingala. Eventually, in English, Baloji gave instructions for a dance step: “Run for cover — protect yourself, because the army is shooting on you, you, you, you and your people,” he said. “So if you want to stay alive, stay down, down, down,” he continued, cuing the audience to crouch.

headline: Soloist and Conductor in One Pair of Shoes
abstract: Pinchas Zukerman played violin and led the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra in a Beethoven program at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center.
lead_paragraph: Like many top-tier violinists and pianists, Pinchas Zukerman has balanced a regular concert schedule of solo, chamber and concerto performances with his career as a conductor.

headline: The Museum With a Bulldozer’s Heart
abstract: It would be truly radical to save the former American Folk Art Museum building, but that’s not what MoMA has ever really been about.
lead_paragraph: Last year, the Museum of Modern Art caused a ruckus with a plan to raze its neighbor, the former American Folk Art Museum building, designed by Tod Williams and Billie Tsien. So MoMA trustees hired the architecture firm Diller Scofidio & Renfro to explore alternatives to demolition that would still permit expansion.

headline: Leno Holds His Feelings Tight as He Prepares to Exit ‘Tonight’
abstract: In an interview with his friend Jerry Seinfeld, Jay Leno seems to have reverted to the manic comic that won him many fans, including David Letterman.
lead_paragraph: In the months and weeks leading up to his departure from his long, successful run as host of the “Tonight” show, Jay Leno has steered clear of any interviews dealing with his feelings about the impending change in his career. He remains aloof from all that in a session with his longtime friend Jerry Seinfeld for Mr. Seinfeld’s web series “Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee.”

headline: Frozen Insects, Glowing Fish and a Futuristic Suit
keywords: ['International Space Station', 'Invasive Species', 'Batteries', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Insects', 'Weather']
abstract: NASA will keep the International Space Station in orbit through 2024, four years longer than planned, and Harvard researchers have developed an inexpensive carbon-based battery.
lead_paragraph: Winter tightened its grip last week, making life tough for New Yorkers and other invasive species. Fortunately, we should fare better than the hemlock woolly adelgid.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Man Skirts
abstract: A handful of menswear designers took a typically feminine silhouette through the gender blender.
lead_paragraph: In London, a trio of provocative men’s wear designers gave gender boundaries a nudge, sending out decidedly masculine interpretations of skirt and dress silhouettes. The kilt figured prominently in Sarah Burton’s latest collection for Alexander McQueen — no surprise, given her predecessor’s heritage and fondness for Scottish history and costume. Recent London College of Fashion graduate Sebastiaan Groenen debuted his line Sebastiaan Pieter in a small, provocative presentation that, in his words, explored “lengths unfamiliar in Western men’s wear,” such as a black crewneck sweater attached to a knit skirt with a mildly salacious slash at the midriff, revealing skin and a trouser waistband beneath. And Christopher Shannon showed a pair of heavy-gauge bi-layer sweaters that extended almost to the floor; their side slits bared taut, worked-out legs that looked anything but femme.

headline: Don’t Try Wooing Action Star Maggie Q with Shark Fin Soup
keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Fishing, Commercial', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Poaching (Wildlife)', 'Sharks', 'Soups']
abstract: A Chinese action star spills soup in a fresh effort to cut China’s appetite for shark fins.
lead_paragraph: A new video is making the rounds in the effort to blunt China’s appetite for shark fin soup and the resulting global decline in many shark species.

headline: Albums From Bruce Springsteen and Jennifer Nettles of Sugarland
abstract: In “High Hopes,” Bruce Springsteen goes back to unreleased material, and in “That Girl,” Jennifer Nettles of Sugarland goes solo.
lead_paragraph: BRUCE SPRINGSTEEN

headline: Kicking Back: Nature of Choreography Revised, With Beer Cans
abstract: “La Substance, but in English,” a four-and-a-half-hour work by Marten Spangberg performed at MoMA PS1, was part of the American Realness festival.
lead_paragraph: Debate swirling around the wave of dance presentation in museums hasn’t dissipated over the last couple of years. For one thing, economic inequality between the dance and art worlds isn’t likely to go away. Over the weekend at MoMA PS1, the Swedish choreographer Marten Spangberg added another layer to the conversation with “La Substance, but in English,” a four-and-a-half-hour work performed Sunday afternoon as part of the American Realness festival.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Uber’s Taxi Troubles in France, and Why ‘Her’ Might Offer a Glimpse of the Future
abstract: Monday’s highlights from around the web include protests against Uber in Paris, where a car was attacked on a freeway. Plus, an argument for why the technology in the movie “Her” might be more like what our future will look like compared to “Minority Report.”
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Three Former Rabobank Traders Charged in Libor Case
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Justice Department filed criminal charges on Monday against three former traders, the latest step in the investigation into the banking industry’s manipulation of interest rates.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department filed criminal charges on Monday against three former traders from the Dutch lender Rabobank, the latest step in the wide-ranging investigation into the banking industry’s manipulation of interest rates.

headline: Protecting a Source, James Risen Takes His Case to the Supreme Court
abstract: The Times reporter, who could face a jail sentence, makes a First Amendment case
lead_paragraph: The Times reporter James Risen took his case to the Supreme Court on Monday, asking that his effort to protect his confidential source be protected.

headline: Tide Gauges Needed for Research Are Often Victims of Storms
abstract: As Hurricanes Sandy, Katrina and Rita showed, equipment for accurate tidal readings, vital to understanding individual storms, may not withstand them.
lead_paragraph: As the waters of Hurricane Sandy rose higher and higher on Oct. 29, 2012, an instrument on a pier at Sandy Hook, N.J., recorded the ominous tidal surge. The reading hit eight feet above sea level, then nine, then 10 – and every few minutes, the gauge faithfully transmitted its readings to a satellite flying overhead.

headline: Fifth & Pacific Discloses Executive Compensation
abstract: Fifth & Pacific, which is adopting the name Kate Spade, disclosed compensation for its incoming executives.
lead_paragraph: The Fifth & Pacific Companies, which used to be known as Liz Claiborne and will now be known as Kate Spade & Company, announced several management changes last week. In a regulatory filing on Monday, the company provided details about compensation.

headline: Scene City: The Wrap Dress, Still Flirty at 40
abstract: A birthday party for Diane von Furstenberg’s emblematic wrap dress.
lead_paragraph: A birthday party for Diane von Furstenberg’s emblematic wrap dress.

headline: Overcoming Shyness to Inspire a Seatmate
abstract: Alison Levine, a mountaineer and leadership expert, encouraged another traveler by sharing her knowledge of and passion for climbing mountains.
lead_paragraph: OTHER than a couple of trips to Mexico, one of which involved sneaking a drive from Phoenix into Tijuana with my best friend when we were teenagers, I never really traveled out of the country until I was well into my 20s. Now, as a leadership consultant, author and someone who climbs mountains, I’m always flying. I try to put up with all of the hassles without making too much of a fuss.

headline: Intersection: Style Is Art in Miami
abstract: Isis Miller, a 27-year-old barista in the Wynwood neighborhood in Miami, looks to Katharine Hepburn’s style for her fashion inspiration.
lead_paragraph: Isis Miller, a 27-year-old barista in the Wynwood neighborhood in Miami, looks to Katharine Hepburn’s style for her fashion inspiration.

headline: Kate Young’s Golden Globes Look for Emilia Clarke
abstract: Go behind the scenes with the celebrity stylist as she created the stunning red carpet ensemble for the “Game of Thrones” star.
lead_paragraph: A red carpet isn’t a red carpet without a look created by the celebrity stylist Kate Young. For Sunday’s Golden Globes, Young traveled to Los Angeles to dress the “Game of Thrones” star Emilia Clarke, who landed on multiple best-dressed lists in a custom embroidered strapless peplum dress by Proenza Schouler. Here, Young recounts her whirlwind weekend.

headline: Google and Nest: Two Companies in the Business of Understanding You
abstract: This is not the usual start-up acquisition: The founders had money, recognition and momentum. What they needed was a like-minded giant with some muscle.
lead_paragraph: Google has announced it is buying Nest Labs, maker of smart thermostats and smoke alarms, for $3.2 billion in cash. At times like this, it’s normal to ask what is in it for each side.

keywords: ['Olympic Games (2018)', 'United States Figure Skating Championships', 'Figure Skating']
abstract: Many Olympic dreams start in the junior ranks, especially among talents like Nathan Chen, who dominated the short program and the free skate at the United States championships.

keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Extortion and Blackmail', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Informers', 'Politics and Government', 'State Legislatures']

lead_paragraph: Eric A. Stevenson, a New York assemblyman, was convicted on Monday of taking more than $20,000 in bribes in return for helping four businessmen build an adult day care center in his South Bronx district.

lead_paragraph: Matthew Kolodny, a consultant based in Chicago, used TripAdvisor to help choose a hotel for a recent yearlong assignment in Abu Dhabi.

headline: ‘Running on Fumes in North Dakota’
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Trucks and Trucking']
abstract: A female truck driver recounts her loneliness and disappointment working in the oil industry.
lead_paragraph: Since around 2006, North Dakota’s oil boom has been a beacon for recession-ravaged Americans. The oil towns in the western part of the state are a land of possibility and opportunity, a “Kuwait on the prairie,” where the American Dream is alive and well in the rural heartland. Or at least that’s the sales pitch that has lured thousands of job seekers.

headline: Europeans Struggle to Set Derivatives Rules
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Derivatives (Financial Instruments)', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The E.U. plans a last-ditch effort to reach agreement on one of the biggest issues highlighted by the financial crisis: how to rein in trading of derivatives and other complex instruments.
lead_paragraph: Faced with intense lobbying from the oil and commodity industries, the European Union plans what could be a last-ditch effort on Tuesday to reach agreement on one of the biggest issues to come out of the 2008 financial crisis: how to rein in trading of derivatives and other complex instruments.

headline: China: Village Blast Kills 14
abstract: An explosion on Monday afternoon in a village near Kaili in the southwestern province of Guizhou killed 14 people and injured seven, state media news reported.
lead_paragraph: An explosion on Monday afternoon in a village near Kaili in the southwestern province of Guizhou killed 14 people and injured seven, state news media reported. The news reports said that the authorities suspected that some people at the site had been engaging in illegal gambling, and that the police had begun a criminal investigation of the explosion.

headline: Rap Lyrics on Trial
keywords: ['Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Violence (Media and Entertainment)', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Music']
abstract: The work of amateur rappers is being used against them in court.
lead_paragraph: SHOULD rap lyrics be used in court as evidence of a crime?

headline: Nigerian President Signs Ban on Same-Sex Relationships
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Homosexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Discrimination']
abstract: The ban signed by President Goodluck Jonathan threatens violators with prison terms, and is considered the most significant setback to gay rights in Africa.
lead_paragraph: A tough ban on same-sex relationships that threatens violators with 14-year prison terms has been quietly signed into law by the president of Nigeria, Africa’s most populous nation, a step that rights advocates have long feared not only as a repression aimed at gays but as an affront to basic freedoms of speech and assembly.

headline: Seeking Bigger Role, Bradley Invests His Future in M.L.S.
abstract: Michael Bradley transferred from Roma, of Italy’s Serie A, to Toronto F.C., of Major League Soccer — a move that subverted the conventional definition of success for an American soccer player.
lead_paragraph: Over the last decade, Michael Bradley’s career path has seemed as pragmatic as one of his lateral passes, as persistently frontward as one of his box-to-box runs. It drove him along an ascendant path, to the top European leagues, to an indispensable role on the United States national team. But in recent days has come a dizzying improvisation.

headline: His Heart, My Sleeve: Writing About My Brother
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: With or without his approval, I was determined to write about my brother’s life as a mental patient.
lead_paragraph: On my 40th birthday, I began writing an essay about my brother, Robert, who, for the previous 16 years, had been in and out of mental hospitals. My intention was to write about his life as a patient, and also about the life he’d led before, when he was a bright, gifted young man who showed no signs, until his first breakdown at the age of 19, that any mental problems were likely or inevitable.

headline: The Leadership Revival
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: What should today’s aspiring leaders do to pursue careers that lead to meaningful change?
lead_paragraph: If you are in politics or public life, you probably had some moment of spine-tingling transcendence. Maybe you read the Declaration of Independence or watched the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s mountaintop sermon, or read Nelson Mandela’s 1964 speech from the dock.

headline: Iraq: Deadly Bombings Erupt in Baghdad
abstract: At least 29 people were killed as car bombs struck several Shiite neighborhoods in northern Baghdad on Monday.
lead_paragraph: At least 29 people were killed as car bombs struck several Shiite neighborhoods in northern Baghdad on Monday. The deadliest bombing, in a market in the working-class Shaab neighborhood, killed at least 11 people, according to witnesses and officials. More than 8,000 Iraqis were killed last year as security deteriorated, and hundreds more have died this month. In recent days Sunni militants, including some linked to Al Qaeda, seized control of the western city of Falluja, challenging the authority of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki. The violence on Monday coincided with a visit to Iraq by the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, who appeared to scold Iraq’s political elites for not working together to “stop the senseless deaths of Iraqi women, children and men,” according to a text of his remarks on the United Nations website. “The challenges facing Iraq require all political leaders to fulfill their responsibilities to ensure social cohesion, dialogue and progress over political obstacles,” Mr. Ban said.

headline: Despite Renovations After Hurricane, Unease Persists in the Rockaways
keywords: ['Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Floods', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Series']
abstract: It was called Ocean Village when Hurricane Sandy hit, leaving residents without heat or power. New owners made repairs, but some fear a new storm.
lead_paragraph: The buildings are offset by the Atlantic, a pastiche of warm tones and cool grays, jutting balconies overlooking tranquil landscaped gardens and million-dollar views. The apartment complex is in the Arverne section of the Rockaway Peninsula; it looks as if it could be Boca Raton, Fla.

headline: Secretive Apple Squirms in Gaze of U.S. Monitor
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Apple is campaigning aggressively against a court-appointed inspector, saying he is intruding on operations.
lead_paragraph: Most companies are reluctant to open themselves to outside inspection. Yet Apple is even resisting someone who was appointed by a court to do exactly that, leading to an unusual public feud between the world’s biggest technology company and the Justice Department.

headline: Dastardly, British and Brand New to the Super Bowl
abstract: Jaguar is using three British actors known for their roles as villains to give its F-Type coupe a sophisticated cool factor at the biggest ad event of the American calendar.
lead_paragraph: PAUL REVERE is recalled for shouting — whether or not he really did — “The British are coming! The British are coming!” Repeat that another time and you will summarize the plot of the first commercial that Jaguar will run during a Super Bowl.

headline: The Asbestos Scam, Part 2
abstract: A new decision from a federal bankruptcy judge is a potential game-changer in endless lawsuits.
lead_paragraph: Six weeks ago, I wrote a column about a ridiculous lawsuit being brought by Carolyn McCarthy, a congresswoman from Long Island. A smoker for most of her life, McCarthy has lung cancer. Yet her lawyers claimed that it was her “exposure” to asbestos, through the work clothes of her father and brother, both boilermakers, that triggered her cancer. Though McCarthy certainly deserves our sympathy as she fights cancer, it is hard to see her lawsuit as anything but an undeserved money grab — and the latest twist in asbestos litigation, the longest running tort in American history, with no end in sight.

headline: Inquiry Begins Into Airliner That Landed in Wrong Place
abstract: The flight landed at a general aviation field with no control tower — seven miles north of the Branson Airport where it was supposed to be.
lead_paragraph: Federal safety officials said on Monday that they were investigating why a Southwest Airlines plane landed at the wrong airport, a general aviation airfield near its destination with a shorter runway and no control tower.

headline: In All but the Name, a New Nissan Maxima
abstract: The company presents a sneak peek at a replacement for the Maxima sedan.

headline: Another Step Toward Nuclear Sanity in Iran
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Editorials']
abstract: An agreement reached over the weekend lays out a detailed plan for restraining Iran.
lead_paragraph: If all goes according to plan, Iran will begin freezing and then rolling back its most worrisome nuclear activities on Monday under an agreement reached over the weekend with the United States and other major powers. This would be the most significant restraint ever on a program that has threatened international stability since it was first disclosed in 2002 and an undeniably important step toward the peaceful resolution of a serious dispute. Even so, dangerously misguided forces, including leading Democrats and Republicans in Congress, are working to sabotage it.

headline: Obama Fights a Push to Add Iran Sanctions
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: With the United States and Iran set to embark on a critical phase of nuclear talks, President Obama is struggling to prevent Senate Democrats from backing a bill that could thwart his diplomatic efforts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the United States and Iran about to embark on a critical phase of nuclear talks, President Obama is waging an intense rear-guard action to prevent Senate Democrats from supporting strict new sanctions that could upend his diplomatic efforts.

headline: Abortion Rights: A Good Ruling Stands
abstract: The Supreme Court left a good ruling alone when it let stand the rejection of Arizona’s 20-week abortion ban.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court made a good call, announced on Monday, not to review a 2013 ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, which struck down Arizona’s 20-week abortion ban as unconstitutional. For women in Arizona, the appellate ruling is critically important in protecting their reproductive rights.

headline: Abortion Rights: Uphold Buffer Zones
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Supreme Court should uphold sensible buffer zones at health clinics.
lead_paragraph: Abortion is one of the most emotionally fraught issues in American society, and public discussion often turns into an attack on the women who choose to exercise their constitutionally protected rights.

headline: House and Senate Negotiators Agree on Spending Bill
abstract: The trillion-dollar spending plan finances the government through September, reverses some cuts to military veterans’ pensions and defeats efforts to curb President Obama’s health care law.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House and Senate negotiators reached accord on a trillion-dollar spending plan that will finance the government through September, reversing some cuts to military veterans’ pensions that were included in a broader budget agreement last month and defeating efforts to rein in President Obama’s health care law.

headline: The Man Behind Alibaba’s Eventual I.P.O.
abstract: Joe Tsai holds the keys to what will most likely be the largest initial public offering of this generation — Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce giant.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase has called. So has Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley. Joe Tsai’s phone is ringing off the hook these days, and you would be forgiven if you have never heard of him.

headline: Japan’s Leader Pledges Aid on Africa Tour
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe finished a three-nation visit to Africa during which he offered aid and development projects potentially worth billions of dollars.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan’s prime minister finished a three-nation tour of Africa on Monday in which he offered aid and development projects potentially worth billions of dollars to help his nation catch up with China’s enormous footprint on the continent.

headline: Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona Overhauls Child Welfare System
abstract: Ms. Brewer abolished the state’s beleaguered Child Protective Services, immediately transferring the task of safeguarding abused and neglected children to a new cabinet-level division.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Gov. Jan Brewer abolished Arizona’s beleaguered Child Protective Services on Monday, immediately transferring the task of safeguarding abused and neglected children to a new cabinet-level division over which she will have direct oversight.

headline: Aide Fired by Christie Is Called Loyal Team Player, Not Rogue Operative
abstract: At first glance, nothing about Bridget Anne Kelly’s life would suggest anything but a dutiful, behind-the-scenes role player.
lead_paragraph: Bridget Anne Kelly is devastated that Gov. Chris Christie denounced her as stupid and a liar — but she also is distraught over how much her actions have damaged him politically.

headline: Guardian Deletes Column About a Cancer Patient
abstract: The writer, Emma Gilbey Keller, had focused on the Twitter account and blog of Lisa Bonchek Adams, a mother of three who is being treated for stage four breast cancer.
lead_paragraph: The British newspaper The Guardian on Monday removed from its website a controversial column by one of its writers that discussed a woman’s use of Twitter to chronicle her struggle with cancer. In removing it, The Guardian cited an investigation into the column.

headline: Enemies of Mexican Drug Gangs Pose a Security Challenge
keywords: ['Drug Cartels', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: The armed men calling themselves self-defense forces may include members of the gangs themselves, officials said.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The scenes are incongruous. Inside the heavily guarded colonial state government building in Michoacán on Monday, a solemn lineup of officials vowed that the federal government would restore authority to a region that has descended into lawlessness.

headline: New Mexico Judge Affirms Right to ‘Aid in Dying’
keywords: ['Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The ruling could make New Mexico the fifth state to allow doctors to prescribe fatal drug doses that suffering patients can use to end their lives.
lead_paragraph: A state court in New Mexico said Monday that terminally ill residents have a constitutional right to obtain “aid in dying,” a ruling that could make New Mexico the fifth state to allow doctors to prescribe fatal drug doses that suffering patients can use to end their lives.

headline: Pope With the Humble Touch Is Firm in Reshaping the Vatican
abstract: Pope Francis has taken on a bureaucracy plagued by intrigue and inertia, steadily replacing traditionalists with moderates and upending the career ladder that many relied on.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — Less than a year into his papacy, Pope Francis has raised expectations among the world’s one billion Roman Catholics that change is coming. He has already transformed the tone of the papacy, confessing himself a sinner, declaring “Who am I to judge?” when asked about gays, and kneeling to wash the feet of inmates, including Muslims.

headline: Corrections: January 14, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on January 14, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Nonsense
abstract: A bunch of nonsense from Tim Croce.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Nice and smooth, but a whole lot of nonsense. Allow me to explain so you will GROK what I’m saying.

headline: In Court Fight, Rodriguez Comes Out Swinging Against Players Union
abstract: It was hardly a surprise that lawyers for Alex Rodriguez went to federal court to try to halt his suspension, but what was stunning was the degree to which the filing targets Rodriguez’s own union.
lead_paragraph: It was hardly a surprise that lawyers for Alex Rodriguez went to federal court in Manhattan on Monday to try to halt his season-long doping suspension. What was intriguing was the degree to which the lawsuit they filed to vacate the suspension ended up targeting Rodriguez’s own union, contending that it “abdicated its responsibility” to defend the Yankees’ third baseman as baseball moved to suspend him.

headline: Charges Seen as Unlikely in Scrutiny by the I.R.S.
abstract: F.B.I. investigators believe that officials with the tax-collecting agency did not break the law by giving special attention to conservative groups.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — F.B.I. investigators do not believe Internal Revenue Service officials committed crimes in the unusually heavy scrutiny of conservative groups that applied for tax-exempt status, a law enforcement official said Monday.

headline: Russia: American Journalist Is Barred
abstract: David Satter, an American journalist and the author of books on Russia and the Soviet Union, said he had been barred from the country by the Russian security services.
lead_paragraph: David Satter, an American journalist and the author of three books on Russia and the Soviet Union, said Monday that he had been barred from the country by the Russian security services. Mr. Satter had been working in Moscow as an adviser and a contributor to Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, which is financed by the American government. In a telephone interview from London, Mr. Satter said the Russian Foreign Ministry told him last month that he had been approved to receive a new visa, but that when he went to pick it up at the Russian Embassy in Ukraine he was told that he had been barred from Russia. An embassy official said the “competent organs” had declared his presence in Russia to be “undesirable,” Mr. Satter said. The American Embassy in Moscow has lodged a formal protest. Kevin Klose, the president of Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, called the visa denial a “fundamental violation of free speech and journalistic liberty.”

headline: Crowd-Pleasing Blasts, With Civil War Roots
abstract: The popularity of free products at sporting events has led to an arms race to develop the most entertaining and marketable T-shirt cannon.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The Philadelphia 76ers like to save their most impressive entertainment innovation for the fourth quarter. So with two minutes left in a recent game, and only after free T-shirts had wafted from the rafters in parachutes and acrobats had dunked off trampolines, did they finally bring out the big gun.

headline: Tepid U.S. Sales Are a Drag on Volkswagen’s Ambitions
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'North American International Auto Show', 'Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks']
abstract: The company said it would bring new models to the United States and invest $7 billion in North American production.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Volkswagen has outlined ambitious plans to become the world’s top-selling automaker within the next four years, but its lackluster sales in the United States have been a significant drag on meeting that goal.

headline: China: Doctor Is Sentenced in a Case of Baby Trafficking
abstract: Zhang Shuxia, an obstetrician in Shaanxi Province, received the death sentence but with two years’ reprieve for stealing seven babies and selling them.
lead_paragraph: A court on Tuesday sentenced Zhang Shuxia, an obstetrician in Shaanxi Province, to death but with two years’ reprieve for stealing seven babies and selling them. Death sentences with two years’ reprieve are almost always changed later to life sentences.

headline: New York’s Mortgage Bank Hunter May Not Be Able to Direct His Spoils
abstract: New York State attorney general Eric T. Schneiderman cannot hire so much as an extra secretary without approval from the Division of the Budget, which is controlled by the not so invariably helpful governor.
lead_paragraph: More than a year back, the New York State attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, came home bearing a legal pelt.

headline: With Fate of Safe Deposit Boxes Unknown, Bank Customers Fret After Blaze
abstract: A Citibank branch in Upper Manhattan burned for more than a day, leaving the fate of the bank’s 300 safe deposit boxes unknown.
lead_paragraph: For many people, a bank is a place to safeguard family heirlooms and vital documents from the unpredictable turns of life: theft, fire, flood. But over the weekend, a Citibank branch in Upper Manhattan burned for more than a day, leaving the building a burned-out husk and the fate of the bank’s 300 safe deposit boxes unknown.

headline: Four Talented Brothers, in the Devils’ Familiar Mold
abstract: The Devils’ center Travis Zajac has two younger brothers on the Devils’ American Hockey League team in Albany, while a fourth Zajac brother plays for the University of Denver.
lead_paragraph: Travis Zajac’s face brightens when he talks of long days with his three younger brothers at their favorite rink back home in Winnipeg.

headline: No-Tailgating Rule Spurs Events, but None Dare Call Them Super Bowl Parties
keywords: ['Football', 'Super Bowl', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Parking Garages and Lots', 'Series']
abstract: The Meadowlands Tailgate Party 2014 and the Secaucus Winter Blast will accommodate people who cannot get tickets to the game.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Tailgating will not be permitted in the parking lot at MetLife Stadium before the Super Bowl, so officials from this town — the very town in which the stadium is situated — called a news conference with officials from the neighboring town of Secaucus on Monday to announce alternatives.

headline: Man Killed During Argument Over Texting at Movie Theater
abstract: A retired Tampa police officer who became enraged at another man’s cellphone use has been charged with second-degree murder in the case.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — An argument over texting at the movies ended in a cellphone user’s death on Monday afternoon when a retired police officer in the audience shot him at a theater near Tampa, Fla., the authorities said.

headline: A Case of Amateurish Cloak-and-Dagger
abstract: In filing a lawsuit against Major League Baseball and the player’s union, Alex Rodriguez made some of the evidence against him public, and it suggests he deserved to be punished.
lead_paragraph: Proof that Alex Rodriguez has gone from defiant to desperate came Monday in the form of a federal lawsuit. In it, he sued not only Major League Baseball to overturn his 162-game ban but also his own players union, which has done its best — often successfully — to protect him for years.

headline: Texas: High School Is Evacuated
abstract: About 3,600 students were evacuated from Seven Lakes High School in the Houston suburb of Katy after the authorities there discovered a suspicious device in a backpack, officials said.
lead_paragraph: About 3,600 students were evacuated from Seven Lakes High School in the Houston suburb of Katy on Monday morning after the authorities there discovered a suspicious device in a backpack, officials said. Officials with the Katy Independent School District initially described it as a “potential explosive device,” but it was determined to be a homemade weapon known as a zip gun. An unidentified student was in custody, and a school spokesman said charges were pending. The fear of an explosive device prompted a large police response by the Harris County bomb squad, the F.B.I. and other agencies.

headline: Mixed Reports on State Health Exchange
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: New York is signing up enough young subscribers to make the insurance system viable, state senators were told at a hearing, but some enrollees have found problems in the program.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — New York is enrolling a significant number of young subscribers on its health insurance exchange, but many of those already enrolled have raised questions about rules that limit which doctors they can see, or are having problems finding out if their doctors are covered, according to testimony at a State Senate hearing on Monday.

headline: California: Octuplets’ Mother Charged
abstract: Natalie Suleman, who gave birth to octuplets in 2009, has been charged with welfare fraud, the Los Angeles district attorney’s office said.
lead_paragraph: Natalie Suleman, who gave birth to octuplets in 2009, has been charged with welfare fraud, the Los Angeles district attorney’s office said Monday. Ms. Suleman, 38, who is known as Nadya Suleman, is accused of failing to report nearly $30,000 earned from public appearances and video royalties since she applied for public assistance last year. A mother of 14, she illegally received more than $16,000 in welfare, the criminal complaint charges.

headline: F.B.I. Arrests Fund-Raiser for Congressman
abstract: The arrest of Diana Durand, a friend of Representative Michael G. Grimm of Staten Island, suggests that the two-year-old investigation into his campaign financing is active.
lead_paragraph: A Texas woman who was a friend of and fund-raiser for Representative Michael G. Grimm has been charged with illegally funneling more than $10,000 into his 2010 campaign, according to court papers and people with knowledge of the case. The charges suggest that a two-year-old federal investigation into his fund-raising is still active.

headline: Defense-Minded Knicks Win Their Fifth in a Row
abstract: The Knicks played stingy defense in overtime, when they held the Phoenix Suns to only four points, and extended their winning streak to five games.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks and the Phoenix Suns did not always play well Monday night. They played hard. They played it close. And eventually they played into overtime.

headline: Some West Virginia Residents Can Finally Use Water Again
abstract: A water ban was lifted for some West Virginia residents on Monday, but others were still waiting to use tap water again.
lead_paragraph: After officials in West Virginia announced on Monday that a ban on tap water was being lifted, many residents were excited to take a shower again.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 13, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Sam Berns, 17, Public Face of a Rare Illness, Is Dead
abstract: Sam’s life with progeria, a genetic disorder resulting in rapid premature aging, was the subject of a documentary film shortlisted for an Academy Award.
lead_paragraph: Sam Berns, a Massachusetts high school junior whose life with the illness progeria was the subject of a documentary film recently shortlisted for an Academy Award, died on Friday in Boston. He was 17.

headline: How the Courts Constrain Tax Reform
abstract: How and at what rate to tax capital gains has always been a contentious political issue, and resolving it is complicated by court rulings long ago, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform — Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Thai Leader Vows to Keep Job Amid Protests
abstract: Antigovernment demonstrators marched Tuesday to government offices as part of a so-called shutdown of the Thai capital.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — As antigovernment protesters continued their occupation of crucial parts of Bangkok’s main commercial and business districts, Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra on Tuesday said she was “protecting democracy” and would not resign.

headline: Over the Side With Old Scientific Tenets
abstract: Scientists, writers and other deep thinkers ponder a big question: What scientific idea is ready for retirement? (Hint: Watch yourselves, infinity and the universe.)
lead_paragraph: Here are some concepts you might consider tossing out with the Christmas wrappings as you get started on the new year: human nature, cause and effect, the theory of everything, free will and evidence-based medicine.

headline: After a Loss, Siblings Try to Reconnect
abstract: In September 2012, a family that was already marred by poverty and mental illness lost its beloved matriarch. Three siblings are now trying to mend their once-strong bond.
lead_paragraph: Silence has settled where animated banter and familial laughter were once the norm. The dynamic between Jasmine Morales, 25, and the two siblings who live with her has been thrown off kilter.

headline: Newsstand to Reopen, After de Blasio Helps
abstract: After 26 years, the not-by-the-book arrangement Jerry Delakas had for operating his newsstand in the East Village unraveled, but Mayor Bill de Blasio opened the door to a settlement.
lead_paragraph: A month after closing a newsstand on Astor Place that had been operated for 26 years without the proper license, New York City officials have reversed course, agreeing to let the stand reopen and to grant the longtime operator the necessary license.

headline: Injuries to Domestic Helper Cast Light on Abuses in Hong Kong
keywords: ['Employment Agencies', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: A human rights group says Indonesian domestic helpers are particularly subject to abuse in the territory because of lax enforcement of the rules.
lead_paragraph: An alleged beating of an Indonesian domestic helper by her Hong Kong employer has drawn new attention to the treatment of the hundreds of thousands of such workers in the territory, raising questions about whether the authorities are vigilant in preventing abuses in such cases.

headline: Robert Pastor, 66, Dies; Guided Panama Treaty for Carter
abstract: Mr. Pastor, an aide under President Jimmy Carter, shepherded the 1977 Panama Canal treaties and was punished for it years later, when conservatives defeated his nomination to be an ambassador.
lead_paragraph: Robert A. Pastor, a White House aide under President Jimmy Carter who shepherded the 1977 Panama Canal treaties to ratification — and was punished for it 17 years later, when conservatives defeated his nomination to be ambassador to Panama — died on Wednesday at his home in Washington. He was 66.

headline: Governor Hopes Speech Will Obscure a Scandal
keywords: ['State of the State Message (NJ)', 'George Washington Bridge']
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie’s State of the State address on Tuesday comes days after his last turn at the podium, when he accepted responsibility for his staff’s role in closing traffic lanes on the George Washington Bridge.
lead_paragraph: In a political high-wire act, Gov. Chris Christie will try on Tuesday to refocus attention from a controversy over a vindictive traffic jam to the day-to-day work of governing, by outlining plans to extend the school day, lower taxes for homeowners and reduce urban crime.

headline: What’s on Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Esquire) FRIDAY NIGHT TYKES There’s no quitting in football. But there’s plenty of blood, sweat and tears when you’re a baby linebacker exhausted in 99-degree heat, and the coach orders you to bear-crawl across the field. “I don’t care how much pain you’re in!” Charles Chavarria, a former Marine, bellows at his team, the Junior Broncos. “You don’t quit!” This new reality show follows five San Antonio teams of 8- and 9-year-olds as they try to pass, run and tackle their way to the top of the Texas Youth Football Association, where ranting coaches, obsessive parents and helmet-to-helmet hits are de rigueur. “Sometimes, parents say I may be crossing a little bit of a line,” Mr. Chavarria says. “They need to toughen up. If you don’t push your kids, you’re accepting failure.”

headline: Electrical Problem Blamed in Shangri-La Fire
abstract: The blaze in the Chinese province of Yunnan, in an area said to be the inspiration for the novel “Lost Horizon,” badly damaged or destroyed 343 structures and left about 2,600 people homeless, the local government said.
lead_paragraph: A fire that destroyed hundreds of structures in a Tibetan area in southwestern China was caused by an electrical problem that ignited a curtain, a county official said.

headline: A Dark Look at Modeling in China
abstract: An American writer details what it was like working for several months as a model in China, a job she describes as “the dregs of the modeling world, the bottom rung of the high­ fashion ladder.”
lead_paragraph: The insider essay on modeling in China opens with the American author, Meredith Hattam, sitting on a train from Chengdu to Beijing with a 16­-year­-old Ukrainian friend, Lana. The friend is eating a hard­-boiled egg. Ms. Hattam makes it clear that eggs are all Lana will eat for the next 10 days because the modeling agency in Beijing that employs the two of them has cut Lana’s weekly allowance due to her weight. Lana had violated the strict measurement standards laid out in her three­-month modeling contract.

headline: The Skate Escape
keywords: ['Indian Rupee (Currency)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Skateboarding', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Working Hours']
abstract: In Bangalore, skateboarding has become an unlikely refuge for stressed-out young professionals and street kids.
lead_paragraph: BANGALORE, Karnataka — On a warm December evening, one of the pioneers in India’s skateboarding scene was giving a private lesson to a 7-year-old girl on dropping in, a terrifying move for novices in which skaters prop their boards up on the edge of a ramp and plunge down the incline.

keywords: ['Meditation', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Colleges and Universities', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Creativity']

lead_paragraph: Two and a half millenniums ago, a prince named Siddhartha Gautama traveled to Bodh Gaya, India, and began to meditate beneath a tree. Forty-nine days of continuous meditation later, tradition tells us, he became the Buddha — the enlightened one.

lead_paragraph: Do TV shows like “16 and Pregnant” and “Teen Mom” glamorize being a teenage mother or present a cautionary tale?

headline: Generation Y-Me
abstract: In a study of heart failure patients, hints of a new generation gap.
lead_paragraph: We boomers haven’t heard much about the generation gap lately, although it was a big topic, the stuff of newsweekly covers, decades back. But I’m wondering if this phenomenon — fundamentally different perspectives on goals, behavior and values, based largely on one’s age cohort — resurfaces in later life.

headline: The New York Portfolio Review, Part II
abstract: Last year’s New York Portfolio Review, brought to you by the Lens Blog, was so successful that we couldn’t resist putting on another one this year — once again, for free.
lead_paragraph: What happens when you — O.K., we — put together 150 photographers with 75 top editors, curators, book publishers and gallerists for two days of photo critiques, networking and fun? Well, assignments, shows and sales, for starters. More important, popular demand that we do it again.

headline: Egyptians Vote on New Constitution in Referendum
abstract: Residents on Tuesday began two days of voting on a charter that the country’s top military officer has cast as a potential precursor to a bid for the presidency.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egyptians trundled to the polls on Tuesday for the third referendum in three years to approve a new constitution, this time to validate the military ouster of their first fairly elected president, Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood.

headline: Lowe’s Backs Recommendation Site for Home Projects

lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Anyone who has gone through a home improvement project knows what a hassle it can be to find a trusted professional to do electrical, plumbing and other work. The big retailer Lowe’s is backing a website that it believes can make the process better for its customers.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jonathan Jay Pollard liked to imagine his life was greater than it was. He told fanciful tales to peers while at Stanford in the 1970s, including that he was a Mossad officer and that he had once been captured and tortured by Arabs.

lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — It happened during a panic that has unfolded with frightening regularity in recent weeks. Fighters were advancing. Crowds of civilians fled to the river to escape the violence, rushing into barges to cross the White Nile. Amid the frenzy, officials said Tuesday, more than 200 people were killed when the ferry carrying them to safety went down.

headline: When My Son Flew Out of the Nest
abstract: This is uncharted territory for me — my son’s departure for the West Coast to study physics — and it’s as if a chunk of my heart is gone.
lead_paragraph: Physicists discover particles the way shop owners catch embezzlers: not by seeing them, but by noticing something is missing (in high-energy physics, particles are inventory, energy cash). They smash large particles, then tally up the energy and smaller particles produced. If the reckoning is incomplete, another tiny particle must have been there.

headline: From Hunger to Fame, With a Shoestring Menu
abstract: A single mother finds herself in the middle of a debate about poverty and the welfare state in Britain.
lead_paragraph: SOUTHEND-ON-SEA, England — First she stopped heating her apartment, putting furniture in front of the radiators to try to forget they were there. She unscrewed most of the light bulbs, turned off the hot water, and sold her iPhone, her watch, her television and even her curtains to feed herself and her 2-year-old son.

headline: French Leader Brushes Aside Questions Over Affair
abstract: Invoking his right to privacy, President François Hollande said at a news conference that everyone suffers “difficult moments.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It was arguably the most important speech of François Hollande’s presidency. His job approval remains at nearly the lowest level of any president in French history. His economic policies have failed to make major inroads in addressing chronic unemployment and persistent deficits. His Socialist Party is restive.

headline: Euro Zone Factory Output Rallied in November

lead_paragraph: PARIS — Factories in the euro zone ramped up output in November after two months of decline, according to data released Tuesday, the latest sign that economic growth in the region might be picking up steam.

lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase reported a 7.3 percent drop in fourth-quarter earnings on Tuesday, underscoring how expensive it has been for the bank to obtain peace with Washington, Jessica Silver-Greenberg reports in DealBook. The net earnings of $5.28 billion, or $1.30 a share, fell slightly below Wall Street analysts’ expectations of $1.35 a share.

headline: JPMorgan Continues to Tally Up Its Legal Headaches
abstract: JPMorgan Chase, the nation’s biggest bank, posted fourth-quarter earnings on Tuesday that were weighed down by $1.1 billion in legal expenses.
lead_paragraph: For JPMorgan Chase, legal costs continue to be a millstone.

headline: Activist Investor Takes Bob Evans Farms to Court
abstract: After two foiled attempts to pressure the board to make changes to its restaurant and packaged goods business, Sandell Asset Management filed a lawsuit on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The hedge fund Sandell Asset Management is bringing out the big guns.

headline: Eminence Plans Proxy Challenge at Jos. A. Bank
abstract: Eminence Capital, which owns a 4.9 percent stake in Jos. A. Bank, plans to add even more pressure on the menswear retailer by nominating two directors for its board.
lead_paragraph: Eminence Capital has already declared its support for Men’s Wearhouse and its $1.6 billion hostile takeover bid for Jos. A. Bank and taken the company to court.

headline: Citing Charging Concerns, Tesla Issues a Recall
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Overheating electrical adapters are being addressed in a recall related to the 2013 Model S.
lead_paragraph: Tesla is issuing a recall action concerning about 29,000 charging adapters for its 2013 Model S electric cars because of a potential fire hazard, the automaker has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration in a letter sent to the agency over the weekend.

headline: Ford Gambles on the F-150
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Trucks and Trucking', 'Aluminum', 'North American International Auto Show']
abstract: Ford has unveiled its new F-150 with an aluminum body. The truck may pose an interesting marketing challenge for a company with the slogan “Ford Tough.”
lead_paragraph: Ford has unveiled its new F-150 with an aluminum body. The truck may pose an interesting marketing challenge for a company with the slogan “Ford Tough.”

abstract: Cheryl Jensen analyzes the Honda 2015 Fit.
lead_paragraph: Cheryl Jensen analyzes the Honda 2015 Fit.

headline: How Have Tools Like Google and YouTube Changed the Way You Work?
abstract: Francine Prose and Rivka Galchen discuss how the Internet has changed the way they research and write.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Francine Prose and Rivka Galchen discuss how the Internet has changed the way they research and write.

headline: A Look at the Volvo Concept XC Coupe
abstract: Chris Jensen reveals the Volvo Concept XC Coupe.
lead_paragraph: Chris Jensen reveals the Volvo Concept XC Coupe.

lead_paragraph: Welcome Winter.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

lead_paragraph: 1889: Elephant Kills Boy

headline: A High-Tech Genesis Shows Hyundai’s Future Path
abstract: It’s a familiar-looking sedan that is full of gadgets, including a selectable all-wheel-drive system.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Monday, Jan. 13: 2015 Hyundai Genesis

headline: Conservative Group to Air Ads Attacking Health Law in Michigan and Iowa
abstract: One of the country’s most well-funded conservative groups is betting that public anger against President Obama’s signature health initiative is broad and deep enough to expand the field of competitive Senate races at stake this November.
lead_paragraph: One of the country’s most well-funded conservative groups is betting that public anger against President Obama’s signature health initiative is broad and deep enough to expand the field of competitive Senate races this November.

headline: Task Force Report Urges Municipalities to Stop Hiding Fiscal Troubles
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTANTS', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'States (US)', 'Local Government']
abstract: The State Budget Crisis Task Force’s final report called for an end to accounting practices that make sinking budgets appear balanced.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After years of painful service cuts and devastating bankruptcies, culminating in the financial collapse of Detroit, state and local governments are being urged to stop using budget gimmicks that obscure the true extent of their money problems.

headline: Sarah Paulson Learns to Withhold Judgment
abstract: The actress says she did not look forward to understanding the inner workings of her character, the sadistic Mistress Epps.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Accepting the award for best drama at the Golden Globes, the “12 Years a Slave” director Steve McQueen called Sarah Paulson “the Bette Davis of America.” Ms. Paulson is a theater, film and television veteran, most recently seen in the FX series “American Horror Story.” In “12 Years,” she plays the wife of Michael Fassbender’s sadistic plantation owner; her character, Mistress Epps, has some sadistic streaks of her own, which perhaps seem even crueler judged against her gender.

headline: Ex-SAC Capital Trader Found His Way to Stanford After Harvard Expulsion
abstract: Stanford’s application process would have required Mr. Martoma to disclose his expulsion from Harvard in 1999, but Mathew Martoma did graduate from the university with an M.B.A. in 2003.
lead_paragraph: It has been a bit of a mystery figuring out how Mathew Martoma, who is on trial on federal insider-trading charges, was accepted into Stanford Business School after being expelled from Harvard Law School for forging his transcript. Typically, universities do not look too kindly on academic violations when considering whether to admit applicants.

headline: ‘Satchmo at the Waldorf’ to Open Off Broadway
abstract: In Terry Teachout’s one-man play, John Douglas Thompson will play Louis Armstrong, reminiscing backstage after one of his last concerts.
lead_paragraph: “Satchmo at the Waldorf,” Terry Teachout’s one-man play about Louis Armstrong, will have its Off Broadway premiere at the Westside Theater. It begins previews on Feb. 15, and opens on March 4.

headline: Feigning Deafness, Giving Your Dog’s Email and Other Reader Tips to Thwart Privacy Grubbers
abstract: To avoid handing over their personal information, some readers said they feign deafness, act crazy, or hand over a fake email address belonging to their dog, or Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin.
lead_paragraph: After venting my frustrations with an (admittedly very sweet) cashier lady and the entire data mining industry last Friday, I was thrilled to hear from hundreds of simpatico readers who had experienced similar, frustrating encounters and a few who weren’t afraid to administer some digital justice of their own.

headline: After Cancer ‘Disruption,’ a Determined Comeback
abstract: Ross Hutchins lost a year to fighting Hodgkin’s lymphoma, but now he wants to make up for lost time and get his career back on track.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Ross Hutchins is a cancer survivor, but he does not, he will not, define himself that way. He is not happy just to be here, back on a tennis court, back in a Grand Slam. He appreciates the sympathy, but please, enough.

headline: Google Effect Stirs Several Stocks
abstract: A day after Google’s $3.2 billion deal for Nest Labs, the share prices of several companies with related technologies surged.
lead_paragraph: Google has raised the temperature in one small corner of the deal world.

headline: Red Tape Snarls Projects in India
abstract: The Mumbai Trans Harbor Link is one of numerous projects in India sorely needed to create economic growth but delayed because of government bureaucracy.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — The Mumbai Trans Harbor Link, a 14-mile series of pillars supporting an eight-lane highway and a rail line, was supposed to be an artery relieving pressure on India’s financial capital, while feeding a new city and fresh growth.

headline: Little Harm to Boy Who Fell Into Manhole
abstract: Moshe Altman, 10, came away with a few stitches and a bruised leg after tumbling down the unprotected opening at 13th Avenue and 49th Street in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: As every New Yorker knows, the city’s sidewalks and streets are poked through with innumerable openings — grates and holes and precarious metal doors that sometimes bend to heart-jumping angles under the weight of a passing pedestrian.

headline: Auto Loans Bring Growth, and Scrutiny, for Banks
abstract: Car loan origination jumped at JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo in the fourth quarter amid disappointing mortgage demand.
lead_paragraph: Car loans may be a boon to banks experiencing lackluster mortgage demand, but automobile lending has come with its own headaches recently.

headline: Times Minute | Christie's Address
abstract: Also on the Minute, Egypt goes to the polls and a new, lighter, Ford truck.
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, Egypt goes to the polls and a new, lighter, Ford truck.

abstract: Also on the Minute, Egypt goes to the polls and a new, lighter Ford truck.
