headline: Richard Ayoade Movie on the New Directors/New Films Slate
abstract: “The Double,” directed by Mr. Ayoade and starring Jesse Eisenberg, is one of seven selections announced for the March series.
lead_paragraph: Richard Ayoade’s follow-up to his feature-directing breakthrough, “Submarine,” is one of the seven selections for the annual New Directors/New Films series presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art, those organizations said Tuesday.

headline: Rebuffing F.C.C. in ‘Net Neutrality’ Case, Court Allows Streaming Deals
keywords: ['Net Neutrality', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The decision by a federal appeals court could pave the way for providers like Verizon and AT&T to charge content companies to deliver data at a faster speed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Internet service providers are free to make deals with services like Netflix or Amazon allowing those companies to pay to stream their products to online viewers through a faster, express lane on the web, a federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday.

headline: Google Fans the Flame of Connectivity
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Google’s decision to pay $3.2 billion for Nest Labs will stoke enthusiasm for a future when everyday products and simple gadgets can all be controlled remotely.
lead_paragraph: Google has turned up the temperature on the “Internet of things.” The company’s decision to pay $3.2 billion for Nest Labs, a maker of smart thermostats, signals a shift in Silicon Valley’s arc of disruption. Sending data to people on the go looks rather ho-hum next to a future where consumers communicate with, and control, their products remotely.

headline: Girl You Know It’s True! An Opera Inspired by Milli Vanilli Is Set for Brooklyn Run
abstract: “Wow,” an operatic work in progress, will run at BRIC House, a new performance space in Brooklyn, Jan. 23 throuh Feb. 1.
lead_paragraph: If Anna Nicole Smith and Jerry Springer can be opera subjects, why not Milli Vanilli?  Surely you remember Milli Vanilli, the pop vocal duo — Fab Morvan and Rob Pilatus — who left the record business in disgrace in 1990, after it was revealed that their live performances were lip-synced to recordings, which turned out to have been made not by Mr. Morvan and Mr. Pilatus, but by studio singers.

headline: 2 Injured in Shooting at New Mexico School
abstract: The boy suspected in the shooting at a middle school in Roswell was apprehended by a State Police lieutenant.
lead_paragraph: A 12-year-old boy opened fire with a shotgun on Tuesday at the middle school he attends in Roswell, N.M., striking two among the dozens of students who were gathered inside a gym waiting for the first bell to ring, the police and witnesses said.

headline: Subaru’s Pocket Rocket Gets a Distinct Look
abstract: Subaru’s most powerful vehicle will now be offered in a single body style.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan 14: 2015 Subaru WRX STI

headline: RC F Adds Hot Sauce to Lexus Line
abstract: The company introduces a blistering sport coupe meant to replace the outgoing IS F sedan.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan. 14: Lexus RC F Coupe

headline: The Moto X Heads to Europe
abstract: It is far from certain that the international expansion can reverse the phone’s lackluster sales, as the competition for top-of-the-line smartphones is becoming stiffer by the minute.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Motorola Mobility is bringing its struggling high-end smartphone to Europe.

headline: Men’s Milan Fashion Week: Giorgio Armani Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Ian McKellen and Nobel Winners Join Protests Against Russia’s Anti-Gay Laws
abstract: In an open letter, Mr. McKellen was joined by 27 Nobel Prize winners, including the South African writer J.M. Coetzee.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With the Sochi Winter Olympics three weeks away, the British actor Ian McKellen and 27 Nobel laureates have signed an open letter to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, demanding that he repeal recent legislation that is widely condemned for discrimination against gays.

headline: Big Fees for Advisers if Charter Wins Over Time Warner Cable
abstract: Should Charter succeed in its campaign, its advisers stand to reap a bounty of fees. And since analysts and investors appear to believe that any successful bid would end up being higher, those banks could make even more.
lead_paragraph: Charter Communications finally unveiled a takeover bid for Time Warner Cable on Monday, offering $37.8 billion for its much bigger rival.

headline: A Conversation With T-Mobile US Executives
abstract: In a brief interview last week, T-Mobile’s top executives shared their thoughts about the company’s future and its competitors.
lead_paragraph: T-Mobile US, the fourth largest carrier in the United States, started 2014 with an aggressive move: It offered to pay for customers’ termination fees to break up with a rival carrier and switch to T-Mobile.

headline: Flaws in Chemical Laws in the Context of the West Virginia Spill
abstract: A West Virginia chemical spill reveals a host of regulatory gaps.
lead_paragraph: Two staff scientists at the Environmental Defense Fund have helpfully asked and answered the following question in the context of the large and disruptive chemical spill in West Virginia:

headline: Image of the Day: January 14
abstract: The head priest of Hazratbal shrine in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir, displaying a relic of the Prophet Muhammad.

headline: As Parents Age, Asian-Americans Struggle to Obey a Cultural Code
abstract: Asian-Americans are struggling to abide by a strong tradition in which they are commonly expected to care for their parents at home, but few institutions are prepared to help.
lead_paragraph: SOUDERTON, Pa. — Two thick blankets wrapped in a cloth tie lay near a pillow on the red leather sofa in Phuong Lu’s living room. Doanh Nguyen, Ms. Lu’s 81-year-old mother, had prepared the blankets for a trip she wanted to take. “She’s ready to go to Vietnam,” Ms. Lu said.

headline: SAC’s Cohen Enjoys a Different Type of Court Scene
abstract: Steven A. Cohen, the billionaire founder of SAC Capital Advisors, took time to catch a Knicks game. Perhaps it was a distraction from the legal turmoil surrounding his firm.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, a former portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors, Mathew Martoma, sat stonefaced in a courtroom in Lower Manhattan, facing insider trading charges.

headline: Central African Republic Violence Ebbs, but U.N. Warns of Flare-Up
abstract: The United Nations human rights office released a report implicating Chadian members of the African peacekeeping mission in attacks on civilians.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — As a measure of calm returned to the capital of the Central African Republic on Tuesday after weeks of bloody turmoil, the United Nations human rights office warned that the violence could quickly reignite and released a report implicating Chadian members of the African peacekeeping mission in attacks on civilians.

headline: Guild Nominations That Could Skew Your Oscar Pool
abstract: Editing and sound mixing nominations from professional groups are worth examining, as longtime Oscar pool players know.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Awards-watchers pay close attention to editing guild prizes because a nod for best editing is considered a near-absolute necessity for a film to eventually win a best picture Oscar. As the guild notes, “No film has won best picture at the Oscars without also having received at least a best editing nomination since ‘Ordinary People’ in 1981.”

headline: As Gears Multiply, a Transmission Maker Prospers
abstract: The transmission supplier, ZF Friedrichshafen, is branching out in electric drive systems.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The proliferation of gear ratios in modern automatic transmissions — even 6-speeds are seeming slightly behind the times now — has been good to at least one company.

headline: Judge Rejects N.F.L. Settlement, for Now
abstract: A federal judge on Tuesday did not approve the proposed $765 million settlement of the N.F.L. concussion case, saying it might not be enough to cover all of the retirees’ claims.
lead_paragraph: The judge presiding over the proposed $765 million settlement between the N.F.L. and more than 4,500 retired players who sued the league and accused it of hiding the dangers of concussions has raised significant questions about whether there will be enough money for all of the payouts, medical tests and treatment.

headline: A Flawed Man as Lightning Rod and Empathetic Stumbler
abstract: In “Rodney King,” Roger Guenveur Smith pays a nuanced tribute to the man whose 1991 beating by police officers proved a seminal moment in contemporary race relations.
lead_paragraph: A quarter-century ago, Roger Guenveur Smith cajoled his friend Spike Lee into writing him into the script for “Do the Right Thing.” (He played Smiley, the mentally disabled man clutching a photograph of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X.) Now Mr. Smith, who has since constructed stage monologues around figures like Huey P. Newton and Frederick Douglass, has turned his wry attentions to an even more ferocious racial conflagration, this one all too real.

headline: Thailand Protests Are Captured in Social Media and Onstage
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Elections', 'News and News Media', 'Social Media']
abstract: In Bangkok in recent days, major intersections are choked with demonstrations, diverting the normal flow of business and traffic.
lead_paragraph: In the boldest move in two months of demonstrations against the government of Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra, Bangkok’s central commercial district has been swarmed by antigovernment protesters, and on Tuesday, the second day of the so-called “shutdown” of the city and its consequences were widely tracked on social media.

headline: Odds and Ends from the Detroit Auto Show
abstract: At the show, the spotlights are trained upon the next big things. But in the corners you can find oddities.
lead_paragraph: At the show, the spotlights are trained upon the next big things. But in the corners you can find oddities.

headline: Infiniti Mixes Formula One With Red Bull
abstract: The Q50 Eau Rouge is a go-fast concept based on the company’s sports car.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan. 14: Infiniti Q50 Eau Rouge concept

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: An Angry Republican
abstract: A lifelong Republican is distressed by his party’s candidates and behavior in recent years. Readers are invited to reply.

headline: Kerry Brushes Aside Israeli Official’s Reported Criticisms of Peace Effort
abstract: A news report that the Israeli defense minister thinks John Kerry’s efforts are naïve and messianic drew criticism from Washington and some Israeli leaders.
lead_paragraph: KUWAIT — Secretary of State John Kerry brushed aside reports Wednesday that Israel’s defense minister has dismissed his Middle East peace push as naïve and messianic, stressing that he was determined to continue his efforts to secure a peace treaty between Israel and the Palestinians.

headline: Herb Alpert’s Next Gig in Manhattan: An Art Show
abstract: Mr. Alpert, the musician and record industry executive, will show his sculptures in a pair of exhibitions.
lead_paragraph: Herb Alpert, the musician, composer and record industry executive, is bringing his other passion — art ­­— back to New York City. His giant totem sculptures are coming to New York’s Dante Park later this month, and Mr. Alpert will also have an exhibit of smaller bronze totems at ACA Galleries in Chelsea, beginning Jan. 16.

headline: What’s a ‘Recess’ Appointment?
abstract: There was a lot of talk about the meaning of words at the Supreme Court — like “the,” “recess,” and “happen”
lead_paragraph: There was a lot of talk about the meaning of words at the Supreme Court on Monday — not exciting words like “life,” “liberty,” or “equality,” but more pedestrian words, like “the,” “recess,” and “happen” — as the justices considered for the first time what, exactly, the recess-appointments clause of the Constitution actually allows.

headline: Voting Under Heavy Security in Egypt
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Egyptians lined up to vote on a new constitution under the watch of the security forces and military leadership of Gen. Abdel Fattah el-Sisi. A bomb exploded early in the day, but no one was injured.
lead_paragraph: Egyptians lined up to vote on a new constitution under the watch of the security forces and military leadership of Gen. Abdel Fattah el-Sisi. A bomb exploded early in the day, but no one was injured.

headline: Prototype Sets Stage for New TLX
abstract: It previews the design and performance characteristics of Acura’s coming midsize performance luxury sedan, which will replace the aging TL and TSX.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan. 14: 2015 Acura TLX Prototype

headline: Justices Raise Bar for Suing Foreign Companies
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: The justices unanimously ruled that residents of Argentina could not sue Daimler in California in connection with abuses during Argentina’s Dirty War.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday made it harder to sue foreign companies in American courts, prompting a justice in a concurrence to accuse the majority of creating “a new rule of constitutional law that is unmoored from decades of precedent.”

headline: The Gun Report: January 14, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Democratic Rep. Leslie Combs, a state representative from Kentucky, accidentally fired a gun in her Capitol Annex office. A House colleague, who was present at the time, said she was emptying a semi-automatic handgun and, thinking it was empty, pointed it away and down and pulled the trigger. No bullet fragments traveled outside the office.

headline: Protests Over Mississippi Plant Follow Nissan to Detroit
abstract: The use of temporary workers is a focus of labor activists.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Labor activists are using the larger stage of the North American International Auto Show to highlight complaints about conditions at Nissan’s plant in Canton, Miss. Before dawn on Monday, demonstrators from the United Automobile Workers stood in front of Cobo Center, where the show was being held, carrying yellow signs reading, “Tell Nissan: Labor rights are civil rights.”

headline: Video: Despite Growing Military Budget, an Undercurrent of Skepticism
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The continuing debate over military spending originated as a debate over whether America should have a military at all.
lead_paragraph: The continuing debate over military spending originated as a debate, at the time of the nation’s founding, over whether America should have a military at all. At the time even conservatives like John Adams and Alexander Hamilton, both partial to strong central government, had their doubts.

headline: Sotheby’s Report Defends Chinese Scroll It Sold as Authentic
abstract: In new report, Sotheby’s is defending the authenticity of an ancient calligraphy school that it sold to a Chinese collector in September.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Sotheby’s said Tuesday that an ancient calligraphy scroll the auction house sold in September for $8.2 million was authentic, despite recent claims by a group of Chinese art historians who insisted it was likely a 19th-century reproduction.

headline: Sled Dog Days
abstract: A look at sled dog racing, perhaps one of the first extreme sports, through the lens of the Times photography archive.
lead_paragraph: A look at sled dog racing, perhaps one of the first extreme sports, through the lens of the Times photography archive.

headline: New Michael Lewis Book on Financial World Will Be Published in March
abstract: Mr. Lewis’s new book is called “Flash Boys.’' He is the author of best sellers like “Moneyball,’' “Liar’s Poker’' and “The Big Short.’'
lead_paragraph: Michael Lewis, whose colorful reporting on money and excess on Wall Street has made him one of the country’s most popular business journalists, has written a new book on the financial world, his publisher said on Tuesday.

headline: Johnny Knoxville’s Makeup Passes the Street Test
abstract: The star of “Bad Grandpa” says the prosthetics he wore had to escape detection by the real people he interacted with in that hidden-camera comedy.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Johnny Knoxville is not a member of the Academy, nor is the “Jackass” star likely to be anytime soon. But he could be part of an Oscar-nominated movie: “Jackass Presents: Bad Grandpa,” his feature-length hidden-camera comedy, is on the shortlist for best makeup. And Mr. Knoxville is very invested in its chances.

headline: Sled Dog Days
abstract: A look at sled dog racing, perhaps one of the first extreme sports, through the lens of the Times photography archive.
lead_paragraph: Winter packed a punch last week. Most of the country hunkered down, taking shelter from the Arctic temperatures, but for dog sledding, the season has only just begun.

headline: Coffee as a Memory Booster
abstract: A shot of caffeine might improve your memory, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: In addition to its other well-known effects, a cup of coffee might improve your memory.

headline: Cocktails Under an 18th-Century Fresco in Milan to Fete a New Star at T
abstract: On the eve of the final day of men’s fashion week in Italy’s capital, fashion heavyweights converged to celebrate the appointment of Brendan Monaghan as the magazine’s new publisher.
lead_paragraph: WhoT’s editor in chief, Deborah Needleman, hosted a mix of style connoisseurs, ranging from the fashion arbiters Suzy Menkes, Jim Moore and Tim Blanks, to some of their most illustrious Italian subjects: Diego Della Valle of Tod’s, Frida Giannini of Gucci and three generations of Missonis, including Rosita, Luca and Margherita.

headline: Longtime Morgan Stanley Banker Said to Retire
abstract: Scott Matlock, a media and telecommunications banker, has decided to retire after 25 years with the investment bank, according to a person familiar with the matter.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – A longtime media and telecommunications banker at Morgan Stanley in London has decided to retire after 25 years with the investment bank, according to a person briefed on the matter.

headline: Are Potential Cable Mergers Good for Consumers?
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Cable Television', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Regulators are bound to look closely at the antitrust issues surrounding any potential cable industry merger, but operators argue that such tie-ups won’t hurt consumer choice.
lead_paragraph: With the specter of consolidation looming over the cable operator industry, eyes are already turning to Washington, where regulators are bound to look closely at the antitrust issues surrounding any potential merger.

headline: Federal Officials Return Looted Antiquities to India
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Indian-Americans', 'Smuggling', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Three looted, ancient sculptures, valued at $1.5 million, were returned to India on Tuesday by federal officials.
lead_paragraph: Relations between India and the United States thawed a bit Tuesday as federal officials returned three stolen antiquities worth about $1.5 million to the Indian Consulate in New York, among them a 350-pound sandstone sculpture snatched from an Indian temple in 2009 that had been among Interpol’s Top 10 stolen works of art.

headline: A Coupe for Cadillac’s BMW-Battling Line
abstract: A two-door ATS may help General Motors do battle with luxury compacts from Germany.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan. 14: 2015 Cadillac ATS coupe

headline: Tunisian Constitution, Praised for Balance, Nears Passage
keywords: ['Constitutions', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Legislators across the political spectrum and human rights groups hailed the charter, considered one of the most liberal in an Arab nation, as a triumph of consensus politics.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — Tunisia’s National Constituent Assembly is close to passing a new Constitution that legislators across the political spectrum, human rights organizations and constitutional experts are hailing as a triumph of consensus politics.

headline: Heroes, Just for One Day
abstract: Or at least one night: heroes are the theme of the Oscars telecast, the producers announced.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Three of the top five grossing movies of 2013 involved superheroes — men in tights or high-tech suits or women who know their way around weaponry. (That’s “Man of Steel,” “Iron Man 3” and the No. 1 grossing film, “The Hunger Games: Catching Fire.”) On Tuesday, the Academy announced that the theme for this year’s Oscars is movie heroes. Coincidence? Do you also believe bridges close for no reason?

headline: Springsteen and Clapton to Headline New Orleans Jazz Festival
abstract: This year’s New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival will run from April 25 through 27 and May 1 through 4.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band, Eric Clapton, Phish and Christina Aguilera are among the artists who will headline this year’s New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival, its organizers said on Tuesday. The festival, which is celebrating its 45th anniversary and will be held at the Fair Grounds Race Course from April 25 through 27 and May 1 through 4, will also feature the Canadian indie-rock ensemble Arcade Fire (which will be fresh off its earlier headlining slot at the Coachella festival in California), as well as performers like Robin Thicke, Vampire Weekend, Robert Plant, Trey Songz, Public Enemy and Chaka Khan.

headline: Bridgegate, Benghazi and the I.R.S. ‘Scandals,’ Compared
abstract: Republicans are trying to direct attention away from Christie.
lead_paragraph: Republicans with the unenviable task of defending Chris Christie seem to have been given talking points of the “yeah, but what about…” variety. Over the last few days, many have tried to downplay the politically motivated traffic jam by comparing it to Benghazi and the allegation that the Internal Revenue Service “targeted” conservative groups.

headline: Bobby Flay’s Next Course
abstract: With his new restaurant, the chef aims to regain a spot in New York’s pantheon.
lead_paragraph: Last month, on the day after he turned 49, Bobby Flay could be found where most of his fans expect him to be: racing around with a knife in a big room bathed in spotlights.

headline: No Bluster as Christie Moves From Scandal to His Agenda
keywords: ['State of the State Message (NJ)', 'George Washington Bridge']
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie, whose aides and appointees apparently engineered a traffic nightmare as political payback, sought to change the subject in his State of the State speech.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, scrambling to regain his political footing, delivered a high-stakes State of the State address on Tuesday that mixed arms-length expressions of contrition, a defiant assertion that his troubles are no excuse for inaction and a jarringly timed demand for bipartisanship.

headline: Appeals Court Opinion Rejecting F.C.C. Net Neutrality Rules
abstract: A federal appeals court threw out Federal Communications Commission rules that require Internet service providers to give all traffic equal access through their networks.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court threw out Federal Communications Commission rules that require Internet service providers to give all traffic equal access through their networks.

headline: Black Sabbath’s 1970s Albums to Be Sold on iTunes
abstract: On Tuesday the band and its label, Warner Brothers, announced that iTunes had started selling its first eight studio albums, along with three compilations.
lead_paragraph: The very short list of high-profile artists whose music is not on digital services just got a little shorter with the arrival of Black Sabbath’s classic 1970s albums on iTunes.

headline: Tours for the Younger Traveler
abstract: New trips offered by a company called Yomads strictly target travelers in their 20s and 30s.
lead_paragraph: As a traveler, I’m in a transition zone. I used to just show up in place with a backpack, a Rough Guide and not much else. The planning was always vague because anything else defeated the point: Tomorrow, who knew?

headline: ‘Always Journeying to Someplace New Gets Old Fast’
abstract: After darting around Europe in his younger years, the writer Daniel Klein, 74, talks about the pleasure he finds these days in slower travel.
lead_paragraph: In his early years, Daniel Klein darted through Europe like a bird of passage, moving from town to town under the same vagabond spell that draws so many young backpackers today.

headline: Text of Christie’s State of the State Address
abstract: Read the text of Gov. Chris Christie’s State of the State address, as prepared for delivery.
lead_paragraph: The following is the text of Gov. Chris Christie’s State of the State address, as prepared for delivery.

headline: Men’s Milan Fashion Week: DSquared2 Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Milan Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: Oddities From the Corners of the Detroit Auto Show
abstract: Not everything in Detroit this week was loud music and camera flashes. Just outside the limelight lived a host of automotive curiosities.
lead_paragraph: The press days of auto shows are well known for their bright lights, loud music and hordes of journalists scrambling for the position most advantageous for executive interviews and photos. But only during news conferences. Along the fringes, often in a corridor, visitors to any auto show can often find the strange and interesting.

headline: Nader, an Adversary of Capitalism, Now Fights as an Investor
abstract: The consumer advocate Ralph Nader has taken on a new fight: shareholder rights, which he sees as a natural extension of his work.
lead_paragraph: “The next step is to organize the shareholders.” Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, was on the phone, outlining to me his latest cause: plunging into capitalism’s muddy waters and fighting for shareholder rights.

headline: Snowden to Join Board of the Freedom of the Press Foundation
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Pentagon Papers', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: The foundation set up by Daniel Ellsberg, the Pentagon Papers leaker and a supporter of Edward J. Snowden, encourages publishing government secrets in the public interest.
lead_paragraph: Washington — Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor whose leaks of secret documents set off a national and global debate about government spying, is joining the board of a nonprofit organization co-founded by Daniel Ellsberg, the well-known leaker of the Pentagon Papers during the Vietnam War.

headline: A Warhol Show at a Dali Museum
abstract: An Andy Warhol show at the Dali Museum in St. Petersburg, Fla., includes the artist’s paintings, photographs and films.
lead_paragraph: The Pop artist and the Surrealist, who were once acquainted, meet again when the Dali Museum in St. Petersburg, Fla., stages “Warhol: Art. Fame. Mortality,” Jan. 18 through April 27.

headline: A Feverish Welcome for Indian Diplomat in Hometown of Mumbai
abstract: Several dozen supporters greeted the Indian diplomat Devyani Khobragade in Mumbai, in a gathering that was as much a show of support for Ms. Khobragade, who was indicted in the United States on charges of visa fraud, as it was a protest against Americans.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI – For the crowd of about 60 people waiting at the airport here on Tuesday for Devyani Khobragade, the Indian diplomat who was indicted in the United States on charges of visa fraud, the gathering was as much a show of support for Ms. Khobragade as it was a protest against the Americans who, in their view, had humiliated her and her country.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Egypt, South Sudan, Central African Republic and Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Egypt, South Sudan, Central African Republic and Pakistan.

headline: Bridging the Gap Between BlackBerry and iPhone
abstract: Typo is intended for people who want a touch-screen smartphone with a tactile keyboard.
lead_paragraph: Despite the popularity of touch-screen smartphones, some BlackBerry users have clung to their phones equipped with tactile keyboards. For those reluctant to let go of their BlackBerry, Typo Keyboard is here to help with the transition to a touch screen.

headline: Met’s Costume Institute to Be Renamed for Anna Wintour
abstract: The Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Costume Institute, which has undergone a nearly $40-million renovation, will be renamed in honor of Ms. Wintour, Vogue’s editor in chief.
lead_paragraph: When it reopens in May, the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s fabled Costume Institute will be renamed the Anna Wintour Costume Center.

headline: Listen to What Your Plants Have to Say
abstract: The Parrot Flower Power plant sensor can analyze the growing conditions of your plants and send you the results.
lead_paragraph: Some gardeners swear by talking to their plants to help them grow; now, those plants can talk back.

headline: Documents Spur British Inquiry Over 1984 Raid at Indian Shrine
abstract: Documents released after 30 years suggest that British special forces had helped draw up plans for the attack at the Golden Temple at Amritsar, India.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Thirty years after Indian troops stormed the Golden Temple at Amritsar, leaving hundreds dead, the British government said Tuesday that it would open an investigation after the release of documents suggesting that British special forces had helped to draw up a plan to attack the building.

headline: Is Marriage Promotion Possible?
abstract: A response to Matt Yglesias on the potential for a meaningful pro-marriage agenda.
lead_paragraph: Now that there’s actually some slight movement in the Republican Party in the direction suggested by “Grand New Party,”  the book I co-authored with Reihan Salam way back in the misty days of 2007-2008, I suppose I should be grateful to Slate’s Matt Yglesias for doing his part to make our ideas seem as reactionary as possible. In a post accusing conservatives of having a “phantom agenda” on marriage promotion, Yglesias raises the question of how, exactly, a movement usually suspicious of government’s effectiveness expects the state to somehow intervene effectively in people’s most intimate decisions, and then offers the following reading of our book:

headline: Life as a Jewish Ghost in Modern Germany
abstract: Yascha Mounk’s book about growing up Jewish in Germany is a help in trying to understand that country’s perverse, absurd love for its Jews.
lead_paragraph: Yascha Mounk’s book about growing up Jewish in Germany, “Stranger in My Own Country,” is rickety, not fully assembled, more the frame of a book than the sanded and stained product. Mr. Mounk is a young graduate student at Harvard, born in 1982, and his book is learned but at times not so wise.

headline: Another Democrat in Tight House District Won’t Run Again
abstract: The decision by Representative Bill Owens leaves his upstate New York district a tossup, and vulnerable to a Republican takeover in November.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Bill Owens, a Democrat who has clung to his seat in a politically divided district along New York State’s Canadian border by narrowly winning his last two re-election fights, said on Tuesday that he would not run for a third full term.

headline: The Politics of the Binding of Isaac
abstract: For Ariel Sharon, the lesson of the biblical story seemed to be: the Jewish state first, morality second.
lead_paragraph: Take now your son, your only son Isaac, whom you love, and go to the land of Moriah; and offer him there for a burnt offering on one of the mountains which I will tell you. — Genesis, 22:2.

lead_paragraph: Senator Kay Hagan of North Carolina is among the Democrats whom Americans for Prosperity is targeting, appealing to dissatisfaction with the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Mutual Funds in the Fourth Quarter of 2013
abstract: Highlights of mutual fund performance.
lead_paragraph: Highlights of mutual fund performance.

headline: Judge Reinstates Some Federal Oversight of Voting Practices for an Alabama City
keywords: ['Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Discrimination', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Election specialists said the move, involving Evergreen, was the first since the Supreme Court struck down part of the Voting Rights Act in June.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge in Alabama on Monday reinstated federal oversight over the voting practices of a city there, in what election law specialists said was the first such move since the Supreme Court struck down part of the Voting Rights Act in June.

headline: Motherlode Must-Read: ‘The Baby Chase: How Surrogacy Is Transforming the American Family’
abstract: Leslie Morgan Steiner’s book is a captivating exploration of the experience and ethics of surrogacy, and one of my favorite books about family from 2013.
lead_paragraph: “The Baby Chase: How Surrogacy Is Transforming the American Family,” by Leslie Morgan Steiner, was among the best books on family from 2013. I’ve been meaning to share it with you for some time, and Amy Klein’s post about donor eggs (“Would a Pregnancy Through a Donor Egg Feel Like ‘Mine’?”) and the resulting discussion of the medicine and ethics of egg donation, and in particular overseas egg donation, provided a perfect opportunity. If you’re at all curious about egg donation and surrogacy (in fact, if you’re just a curious reader at all), “The Baby Chase” makes a fascinating read.

headline: Behind the Olympics: Teaching About Russia in the Putin Era
abstract: In this lesson we offer a range of teaching ideas designed to help students understand the vast, multifaceted country behind the Sochi Olympics.
lead_paragraph: Overview | What is it about Russia and the Olympics? Back in 1980, some 65 nations including the United States boycotted the Summer Games in Moscow (PDF) over the invasion of Afghanistan by the communist-led Soviet Union, as Russia was then known. Thirty-four years later, the athletes are returning – this time to the Black Sea resort of Sochi for the 22nd Winter Olympics – and so is the controversy.

headline: Ad Hits Patrick Murphy on Health Care
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Political Advertising']
abstract: Representative Patrick Murphy of Florida is among the Democrats whom Americans for Prosperity is targeting, appealing to dissatisfaction with the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: Representative Patrick Murphy of Florida is among the Democrats whom Americans for Prosperity is targeting, appealing to dissatisfaction with the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Los Angeles Opera to Present ‘Figaro Trilogy’
abstract: The company will present “The Barber of Seville,” “The Marriage of Figaro” and John Corigliano’s 1991 opera “Ghosts of Versailles”
lead_paragraph: Opera fans will be able to trace the development of one its most famous characters, Figaro, from barber to bridegroom to older-but-still-wily servant next season when the Los Angeles Opera presents its “Figaro Trilogy.”

headline: A Visitor’s Luxury Room
abstract: Michel Richard checks into New York with a fancy bistro.
lead_paragraph: The first time I ate at Villard Michel Richard, the latest restaurant to dance among the frescoes and marble pilasters of the Villard mansion in Midtown, I strongly suspected that I was in an awful hotel restaurant.

headline: Living in Rowayton, Conn.
abstract: In this 1.4-square-mile coastal village in Norwalk, Conn., the most coveted homes are near the downtown, on the water, or in a beach association.
lead_paragraph: In this 1.4-square-mile coastal village in Norwalk, Conn., the most coveted homes are near the downtown, on the water, or in a beach association.

headline: Where Norwalk and Darien Collide
abstract: A 1.4-square-mile coastal village in Norwalk where the most coveted homes are near the village center, on the water, or in a beach association.
lead_paragraph: The coastal village of Rowayton, in Norwalk, is no place for anonymity. A 1.4-square-mile peninsula that hooks into Long Island Sound as if anchoring the entire city, it packs so much into so little space that running into neighbors on the narrow streets, in the compact parks, and along the single commercial strip is both inevitable and heartily encouraged by an energetic civic association.

headline: Ad Hits Joe Garcia on Health Care
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Political Advertising']
abstract: Representative Joe Garcia of Florida is among the Democrats whom Americans for Prosperity is targeting, appealing to dissatisfaction with the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: Representative Joe Garcia of Florida is among the Democrats whom Americans for Prosperity is targeting, appealing to dissatisfaction with the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Art Matters | Two Downtown Manhattan Gallerists Join Forces Upstate
abstract: Zach Feuer and Joel Mesler join a northward cultural migration with Retrospective, an intimate new gallery in tiny Hudson, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Retrospective, the newest art gallery in the hamlet of Hudson, N.Y., inaugurated its space this past Saturday night with “Gambler’s Choice,” a sold-out show of bright, cartoon-inflected paintings by the 27-year-old Brooklyn-based artist Jamian Juliano-Villani. Seemingly worlds away from the white-cube spaces of Chelsea two hours to the south, Retrospective features vintage checkerboard floors and a sculptural tree branch in the bathroom that serves as a toilet paper holder. The project is the brainchild of the art dealers Zach Feuer and Joel Mesler, fixtures of the New York and Los Angeles art worlds. Feuer, who moved upstate several years ago and commutes to his eponymous Chelsea gallery, says he wanted to try something “outside the pressure cooker.” Even Retrospective’s name alludes to what Mesler, the owner of Untitled Gallery on the Lower East Side, called the “speed of the art world” — in which younger and younger artists land exhibitions surveying their already oversize careers. “But ‘Retrospective’ also sounds like an ’80s rock band,” he adds.

headline: For 2 Wall Street Regulators, More Belt-Tightening
abstract: Under the new budget proposal, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission would receive less money this year than President Obama had requested.
lead_paragraph: Two primary regulators of Wall Street are preparing, once again, to make the most of scarce resources.

headline: Seeking Ways to Help the Poor and Childless
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Poverty', 'Single Persons']
abstract: A program similar to the earned-income tax credit acknowledges that the job market alone can’t provide for all workers’ needs.
lead_paragraph: Last Friday at the Food Bank for New York on 116th Street, I caught a glimpse of the many shapes of need.

headline: Unemployment Extension Is Stalled, With 2 Proposals Defeated in the Senate
abstract: The effort to extend long-term unemployment benefits suffered a setback in Washington when two separate proposals were voted down and the possibility of a bipartisan deal collapsed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Unemployment benefits for 1.3 million of the long-term unemployed — and millions more in the future — were imperiled on Tuesday after Senate efforts to reach accord on legislation to revive them collapsed in partisan finger-pointing.

headline: A Major Renovation on the Doorstep of Queens
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Building (Construction)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: Hotels, apartment complexes and parks are being built in Queens Plaza, but few offices are under construction.
lead_paragraph: Created in 1909, Queens Plaza in Long Island City was intended as an attractive gateway to the borough for which it was named. But in more recent decades it became known as a haven for drug-dealing and prostitution and as a filthy, noisy eyesore where pedestrians risked their lives as they tried to cope with multiple lanes of traffic.

headline: The Regency Bar & Grill, and More Restaurant Openings
abstract: The restaurant is aiming to become a destination for steaks and Caesar salads, not just bacon and eggs.
lead_paragraph: Headliners

headline: Obama to Place Some Restraints on Surveillance
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: President Obama plans to increase limits on access to phone data, call for privacy safeguards for foreigners and propose the creation of a public advocate post, according to people briefed on his thinking.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will issue new guidelines on Friday to curtail government surveillance, but will not embrace the most far-reaching proposals of his own advisers and will ask Congress to help decide some of the toughest issues, according to people briefed on his thinking.

headline: Unexpected Works, Familiar Composers
abstract: The Juilliard School’s ChamberFest opened with an obscure work by Gian Carlo Menotti, a difficult Schumann and a crowd-pleasing Brahms.
lead_paragraph: Some composers are so strongly associated with one genre that it’s easy to forget that they dallied in others. A lone string quartet is among the handful of nonvocal works in Verdi’s huge catalog. A Trio for Violin, Clarinet and Piano is one of only a few instrumental works by Gian Carlo Menotti, who composed dozens of operas and musical theater and choral works.

headline: SPX Reaches Accord With Relational Over Board Seats
abstract: The industrial equipment maker SPX Corporation said on Tuesday that it had reached an agreement with the activist investment fund Relational Investors that could give the firm up to two board seats over the next two years.
lead_paragraph: The SPX Corporation, an industrial equipment maker, said on Tuesday that it had struck an agreement with the activist investment fund Relational Investors that could give Relational up to two board seats over the next two years.

headline: Clip: 'Generation War'
abstract: A scene from the film, directed by Philipp Kadelbach.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film, directed by Philipp Kadelbach.

headline: Those Ripples in the Water of the Bayou
abstract: The fifth season of “Duck Dynasty” opens Wednesday night on A&E with a whiff of uneasiness over Phil Robertson’s comments about blacks and gays.
lead_paragraph: Phil Robertson has run his mouth; an endless number of commentators have fumed or crowed about what he said; and now comes the day of decision. The first new episodes of A&E’s “Duck Dynasty” since that controversy are being broadcast on Wednesday night, and people who were fans of the show before Mr. Robertson’s attention-getting remarks about gays and blacks have to decide whether they’re still fans.

headline: New Classical Notes From Underground
abstract: The classical pianist Yefim Bronfman, as part of the New York Philharmonic’s Contact! series of new music, played three works by contemporary composers at SubCulture on Monday night.
lead_paragraph: It used to be that the virtuoso pianist Yefim Bronfman was not someone you expected to encounter playing in a subterranean East Village club that houses all kinds of contemporary music. Mr. Bronfman has been known for brilliant accounts of mainstream Romantic piano concertos, like Tchaikovsky’s First, a work he played this September at Avery Fisher Hall with the New York Philharmonic.

headline: A History Lesson, Airbrushed
abstract: “Generation War,” a film about early-1940s Germany, is notable for what it includes and for what it leaves out.
lead_paragraph: “Generation War,” which was broadcast as a mini-series on German television last year, is perhaps more interesting as an artifact of the present than as a representation of the past. As the Second World War slips from living memory, as Germany asserts its dominant role in Europe with increasing confidence, and as long-suppressed information emerges from the archives of former Eastern bloc countries, the war’s cultural significance for Germans has shifted.

headline: The Echoes of War, From One Century to the Next
abstract: Shostakovich’s wartime Symphony No. 7 was performed Monday evening at a benefit concert for humanitarian aid to Syria at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Context may not be everything in music but it can count for a lot. And the context for a performance of Shostakovich’s imposing wartime Symphony No. 7 (“Leningrad”) at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening was cryptically hailed in its title: “Shostakovich for the Children of Syria.”

headline: How Much Time Warner May Be Worth to a Suitor
abstract: If Charter Communications hopes to get a deal done to buy Time Warner Cable, it will probably have to pay a higher price based on a crucial measure.
lead_paragraph: Charter Communications says it is offering a full price for Time Warner Cable. At $132.50 a share, its proposal amounts to a 40 percent premium above where Time Warner Cable’s stock was trading in June, before rumors of a deal surfaced. “We think a lot of the premium is already in the stock,” Charter’s chief executive, Thomas M. Rutledge, told DealBook on Monday.

headline: Oklahoma’s Ban on Gay Marriage Is Unconstitutional, Judge Rules
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The decision, the latest in a string of legal victories for gay rights, will not take effect immediately, and an appeal is almost certain.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Oklahoma ruled Tuesday that the state’s constitutional amendment barring same-sex marriage violated the federal Constitution, the latest in a string of legal victories for gay rights and one that occurred in the heart of the Bible Belt.

headline: The Joys of Rambling, as Artists and Raconteurs
abstract: Honorees at the National Endowment for the Arts’ Jazz Masters Awards ceremony reflected on the nature of improvisation and their distaste for boundaries.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps someone suggested to all the recipients of the National Endowment for the Arts Jazz Masters Awards that they should stretch things out during Monday night’s ceremony at Jazz at Lincoln Center’s Allen Room. Or perhaps the night’s first recipient, Jamey Aebersold, the pioneering developer of “Play-A-Long” books and recordings, did that simply because he felt compelled to, and the others — Anthony Braxton, Richard Davis and Keith Jarrett — played along, to some degree.

headline: A Confused Boy Wants to Play, Even When Others Want to Fight
abstract: In “When I Saw You,” a young Palestinian boy runs away from a refugee camp in 1967 and ends up with a band of volunteer soldiers preparing to fight Israelis.
lead_paragraph: Though licking around the edges of almost every scene, war is never allowed to intrude on the rose-tinted uplift of “When I Saw You,” a gauzy lament on displacement and disruption.

headline: Sea Salts Spiked With Chile, Italian Hot Chocolate and More
abstract: Recommendations for the week of Jan. 14.
lead_paragraph: To Savor: Old Favorites, New Neighborhood

headline: Hungers Unsatisfied: Mouths Full, but Only With Words
abstract: “Feast,” written and directed by Andrew Ondrejcak, re-enacts the final banquet of Babylon at the Public Theater as part of the Under the Radar festival.
lead_paragraph: I’m not sure if this is a spoiler, or simply stating the obvious, but there is no feast in “Feast.” The burnished table remains bare, the performers’ insatiable mouths empty, and wretchedly so.

headline: A Fan-Financed Game With a Retro Feel
abstract: The Banner Saga, developed with help from a Kickstarter campaign, has lavish artwork, a compelling score and Viking-like humans.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps because video games are often, and wrongly, viewed solely as technology, they are thought by many to be perpetually improving. And sure, the past few decades have brought changes. Visuals have shifted from ragged, chunky blocks to three-dimensional computer animation. Sounds have gone from either nonexistent — as in the text adventure games of the 1970s and ’80s — or blips and beeps to fully recorded voice performances and orchestral scores that sometimes rival the best productions for film and television.

lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, the French president brushes off questions about an affair and a review of Michel Richard's new restaurant.

headline: Republican Ideas on Immigration Could Legalize Up to 6.5 Million, Study Says
abstract: “Half a loaf” proposals may put many more on a so-called path to citizenship than immigrant advocates have previously thought.
lead_paragraph: Between 4.4 million and 6.5 million immigrants illegally in the United States could gain an eventual pathway to citizenship under proposals being discussed by Republicans in the House of Representatives, according to an estimate published Tuesday by the National Foundation for American Policy, a nonpartisan research group in Washington.

headline: Times Minute | Christie on New Jersey

headline: The Embodiment of an Idea, and Some Indelible Hits
abstract: Jay Z came home to Brooklyn on Monday on his Magna Carter Tour with a short, no-fills show that celebrated his origin story.
lead_paragraph: “The physical dies. Ideas are forever.”

headline: Low-Key Impresario at High Altitude
abstract: John Cooper directs the Sundance Film Festival, which opens its 30th installment on Thursday in Park City, Utah.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For a guy with one of the biggest jobs in movies, John Cooper keeps an extremely low profile. He is the director of the Sundance Film Festival, yet Robert Redford remains its public face. Mr. Cooper loathes red carpets, preferring a quiet life in suburban Los Angeles with his husband and three daughters.

headline: Music Teacher Pleads Guilty to Molesting Girl, 9
abstract: In exchange for a guilty plea, Ilya Lehman, who ran a music school for children in Manhattan, will receive a two-year sentence.
lead_paragraph: A 71-year-old music teacher who ran a music school for children in Manhattan admitted in court on Thursday that he had molested a 9-year-old girl under his tutelage, pleading guilty to forcible sexual conduct against a child in return for a two-year sentence, the Manhattan district attorney’s office said.

headline: Three Microphones to Filter Out Ambient Noise
abstract: Sennheiser is offering three headsets the company says better pick out voice from background sounds.
lead_paragraph: The German company Sennheiser has a long history of making headphones and microphones, and those two products have joined in a modernized twist: a Bluetooth ear piece that uses three microphones for noise cancellation.

headline: Sony Prepares for Widespread Use of 4K TVs With a 4K Camcorder
abstract: The FDR-AX100 is compact and lightweight, but expensive. In addition, most consumers don’t have a 4K TV yet.
lead_paragraph: The major TV manufacturers are making a line of new 4K televisions — sets with nearly four times the resolution of today’s best mass market sets.

headline: At Auto Show, Tesla Defends Safety Record
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobiles', 'North American International Auto Show', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: Tesla departed from the auto show pattern of announcing upbeat news and defended its reputation on safety after announcing a recall on wall chargers.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The North American International Auto Show has a familiar rhythm for automakers making a presentation — gather a crowd, announce new products and talk excitedly about the future.

headline: Order Chinese, and Not by the Numbers
abstract: Waygo, an iPhone app, translates Chinese characters, like those found in restaurant menus.
lead_paragraph: Here is one more thing the smartphone has now replaced: Your Chinese-reading friend you drag to restaurants to read the Chinese-only menus. Waygo, an app for the iPhone, is built to translate Chinese characters into English. (An Android version is being tested.)

headline: When Rosanne Cash Is Among Your Close-Knit Friends
abstract: The blog Mason-Dixon Knitting is run in part by Kay Gardiner, who counts Rosanne Cash among her knitting-and-sewing pals.
lead_paragraph: The blog Mason-Dixon Knitting exists as a series of letters between two friends, Kay Gardiner and Ann Shayne, who share stories about everything from sewing to denim yarn to their husbands and travels. Gardiner — who lives in Manhattan; Shayne is in Nashville — happens to belong to a sewing circle that includes Rosanne Cash, whose new album, “The River and the Thread,” was the occasion for an article about her in last weekend’s magazine.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Competing With North Korea on Credit Card Security
abstract: Tuesday’s highlights from around the web include an analysis of how Americans keep having problems with credit card security because the industry won’t buy the technology the rest of the world uses.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Listen Up | The Lofty Ambitions of Communion Records
abstract: Co-founded by Ben Lovett of Mumford & Sons, the London-New York label has become a global tastemaker, as evidenced by its popular new club nights in various U.S. cities. Check out Lovett’s exclusive playlist of his favorite Communion offerings.
lead_paragraph: Last Tuesday, Ben Lovett, the London-born, New York-based co-founder of the record label and events company Communion, pondered the soon-to-be-packed floor of the Rockwood Music Hall on the Lower East Side. “It makes me feel quite old,” the 27-year-old said. “When you’re 19, you just sort of have limitless energy.” That’s how old he was in 2006, when he launched Communion in its earliest form as a club night in Notting Hill, London. A year later, he also co-founded the folk-rock band Mumford & Sons, which soon became a Grammy-winning touring juggernaut. Meanwhile, Communion has evolved into a promotions giant and global musical tastemaker with a presence in both London and New York. It’s enough to make anyone feel stretched.

headline: Regulators Ease Volcker Rule Provision on Smaller Banks
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Collateralized Debt Obligations', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The revision would permit banks to continue to hold on to a special type of collateralized debt obligation.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:26 p.m. | Federal regulators on Tuesday bent to the will of the banking industry and some lawmakers and revised a rule that would have forced community banks to take write-downs on a security that many had invested in before the financial crisis.

headline: VL Automotive Destino Red Concept: A Convertible Pipe Dream?
abstract: The two-door hardtop convertible was at the show once before, wearing a Fisker badge.
lead_paragraph: Introduced on Tuesday, Jan. 14: VL Automotive Destino Red concept

headline: Dozens Reportedly Arrested in Nigeria Amid Antigay Crackdown
abstract: The government recently decided to crack down on gays harshly and in secret, arresting suspected gay men and signing into law a sweeping measure that punishes gay marriage
lead_paragraph: Homosexual sex is illegal in Nigeria, where in some states ruled by Islamic law gay people can be legally stoned to death. Still, the government in recent weeks has decided to crack down on gay Nigerians both harshly and in secret, arresting dozens of suspected gay men in the country’s north and signing into law a sweeping measure that punishes gay marriage and even the formation of gay associations or clubs with as many as 14 years in prison.

headline: Bailed-Out Bankia Is Symbol of Spain's Financial Revival
abstract: Operating under new management but still state-controlled, Bankia returned to the bond market and raised double its initial target.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Less than two years ago, Bankia looked like a Spanish version of Lehman Brothers: a big, troubled institution whose collapse threatened to take down a country’s financial system.

headline: Mundane, Meet Dramatic
abstract: In “Brand New Ancients,” part of the Under the Radar festival, Kate Tempest looks for majesty and mystery in ordinary lives.
lead_paragraph: The gold-plated cliché that a picture is worth a thousand words is flipped on its head in “Brand New Ancients,” the thrillingly good, genre-bending show from the young British writer and performer Kate Tempest, at St. Ann’s Warehouse through Sunday. As Ms. Tempest’s gorgeous streams of words flow out, they conjure a story so vivid it’s as if you had a state-of-the-art Blu-ray player stuffed into your brain, projecting image after image that sears itself into your consciousness. Both as writer and performer, Ms. Tempest stitches together words with such animate grace that language acquires an almost tactile quality, and the drama she unfolds — of betrayal, disappointment and violence among a handful of not especially special London dwellers — soars to operatic dimensions.

headline: Generations Blending: Better Dodge The Blades
abstract: John Hodgman, best known for this geeky “Daily Show” persona, brings a one-man show in the Under the Radar Festival.
lead_paragraph: The actor and comic John Hodgman removes the mask he regularly wears — of the complacently geeky, avuncular expert on everything who’s really an expert on nothing — to reveal some of his personal anxieties in “I Stole Your Dad,” his new solo show at the Public Theater. In this agreeable if not particularly substantial monologue, the Under the Radar Festival edges toward more populist terrain than it usually occupies. The show is essentially standard stand-up comedy featuring a familiar performer.

headline: How the Poor Get Washed Away
keywords: ['Land Use Policies', 'Squatters', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Evacuations and Evacuees', 'Typhoon Haiyan (2013)', 'Typhoon Bopha (2012)', 'Typhoons', 'Earthquakes']
abstract: Poor people who don’t own land routinely bear the brunt of natural disasters.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Typhoon Haiyan struck the Philippines in November, killing more than 6,000 people and leaving more than four million homeless, one group was particularly hard hit: the landless poor. More than a thousand of the dead lived in a single squatter camp.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — Eni, the Italian oil giant, is giving up on producing natural gas from shale rock in Poland, not long ago considered the most promising country in Europe for the new fuel source.

abstract: There should be a way for producers and processors of fruits and vegetables to make money without competing with subsidized junk food.
lead_paragraph: Let’s say your beliefs include the notion that hard work will bring good things to you, that the golden rule is a nice idea though it may occasionally have limits, and that it’s more or less every person for him or herself. Your overall guiding force is not altruism, but you’re not immoral; you’re a good citizen, and you don’t break any major laws. This could describe many of us; most, maybe.

headline: N.S.A. Devises Radio Pathway Into Computers
abstract: The agency has put software in thousands of computers that allows for surveillance and can also create a path for launching cyberattacks, according to documents, experts and officials.

headline: The Nuts and Bolts of Network Neutrality
abstract: A federal appeals court threw out F.C.C. rules requiring that all information be treated equally on the Internet; we explain what the decision means.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court on Tuesday rejected Federal Communications Commission rules that required Internet service providers to treat all traffic equally. The so-called network neutrality rules were championed by Internet companies worried that the carriers could start charging for preferential treatment to information carried on their networks.

headline: The Man on the Wall
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Sabra and Shatila Massacre, Lebanon (1982)', 'Israeli Settlements', 'International Relations']
abstract: Ariel Sharon was an enduring presence in Israeli political life.
lead_paragraph: I’ve always thought that the reason Ariel Sharon was such an enduring presence in Israeli political life is that he personally reflected three of the most important states of mind that the state of Israel has gone through since its founding. At key times, for better and for worse, Sharon expressed and embodied the feelings of the Israeli Everyman as much, if not more, than any Israeli leader.

headline: Training Fighters of Future Across Gaza
abstract: A Hamas program aims to prepare high school students for what some see as the next inevitable clash with Israel.
lead_paragraph: RAFAH, Gaza Strip — Dozens of high school students scrambled among the sand dunes here in recent days, learning how to shoot AK-47 rifles, crawl under barbed wire and jump over burning tires. Their bearded commanders barked at those who were too slow in hoisting iron bars overhead or those who hesitated around the thick flames.

headline: Joel S. Marcus
abstract: Mr. Marcus is the chairman and chief executive of Alexandria Real Estate Equities, a publicly traded real estate investment trust.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Marcus, 66, is the chairman and chief executive of Alexandria Real Estate Equities, a publicly traded real estate investment trust, or REIT, based in Pasadena, Calif. The company, which Mr. Marcus also co-founded in 1994, owns and operates properties in the life science industry, totaling around 17 million square feet, including the Alexandria Center for Life Science on Manhattan’s Far East Side.

headline: Nigeria: Rights Chief Assails Law as Roundup of Gays Begins
keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The United Nations human rights chief Navi Pillay condemned the Nigerian law, which gives anyone entering a same-sex union 14 years in jail.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations human rights chief Navi Pillay sharply condemned as “draconian” an antigay marriage law that took effect in Nigeria last week, saying Tuesday it violated fundamental rights and risked provoking a surge of antigay violence. Nigeria had already criminalized same-sex relationships, but the new law “makes an already bad situation even worse,” she said in a statement. The law provides for jail terms of 14 years for anyone entering a same-sex union and 10 years for anyone who aids or witnesses such a union or who supports the operation of gay groups. “Rarely have I seen a piece of legislation that in so few paragraphs directly violates so many basic, universal human rights,” Ms. Pillay said.

headline: Bulls, Built to Win Now, Decide to Disassemble
abstract: The Bulls, who traded the All-Star forward Luol Deng to the Cavaliers on Jan. 7, are a team filled with veterans still intent on winning, and a front office squarely committed to the future.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Joakim Noah politely declined to address the news media for five days (including three games) after the Bulls traded the All-Star forward Luol Deng to the Cleveland Cavaliers. Noah, a genial center and often the Bulls’ de facto spokesman, needed to sift through the wreckage of his feelings and process the loss of his friend, “my brother,” as he called Deng.

headline: Tines That Try Men’s Souls

lead_paragraph: LONDON — As his team acclimatized to London ahead of their game against the Atlanta Hawks on Thursday, the Nets’ Kevin Garnett tried another sports hot seat for size when he visited Chelsea F.C., long one of his sporting passions.

headline: As Refinancing Wanes, Banks Are Wary of New Loans
abstract: Many potential borrowers are shut out of the mortgage market, despite evidence in earnings reports that banks are strong enough to provide them with credit.
lead_paragraph: The stars seem to be aligning in the housing market. Home prices have been rising for many months, and the federal government is providing immense support to bolster the mortgage market. The big banks that make home loans are strong enough to provide credit to borrowers, as seen in the fourth-quarter results reported Tuesday by JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo.

headline: India-America Relations on Edge
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Domestic Service', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Editorials']
abstract: Devyani Khobragade’s case and the issues it raised are not resolved and will not likely dissipate soon.
lead_paragraph: The Indian diplomat charged with visa fraud and mistreating her domestic worker is back in Mumbai, and tensions between India and the United States have eased. But her case and the issues it raised are not resolved, and the damage to India-America relations is unlikely to dissipate soon. This unfortunate episode is a reminder that while both nations are democracies, neither can avoid the hard work necessary to make the relationship work.

headline: Giants Hire Packers Assistant to Reconstruct Offense
abstract: Ben McAdoo, who was considered an innovative quarterbacks coach for Green Bay, promises to take an “up-tempo, attacking” approach as the Giants new offensive coordinator.
lead_paragraph: The Giants on Tuesday named Ben McAdoo, an innovative Green Bay Packers assistant, as their new offensive coordinator, a move that signals the team’s desire to move away from the system of Kevin Gilbride, who retired Jan. 2.

headline: Arab Neighbors Take Split Paths in Constitutions
keywords: ['Constitutions', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Shariah (Islamic Law)']
abstract: Tunisia and Egypt, whose revolts ignited the Arab Spring, provide a dual lesson in the pitfalls and potentials for democracy in the region as they move toward new charters.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — One is setting a standard for dialogue and democracy that is the envy of the Arab world. The other has become a study in the risks of revolution, on a violent path that seems to lead only in circles.

keywords: ['State of the State Message (NJ)', 'George Washington Bridge', 'Editorials', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)']

lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey tried to change the subject on Tuesday with his annual State of the State speech, talking about longer school days and reducing urban crime. But there is no diverting attention from the unanswered questions about how Mr. Christie and his close advisers have used his office to mete out rewards or punishment for political reasons.

headline: Now Online, Diaries of British Soldiers Detail Horrors of World War I

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British obsession with the centennial of World War I, the war that did not end all wars, heightened on Tuesday as the National Archives announced that it was putting diaries from British soldiers in the conflict online.

headline: Finally, Congress Does Its Job
abstract: A spending bill for 2014 would end the worst of the sequester cuts.
lead_paragraph: The last time Congress approved a series of spending bills to pay for the government — its most basic job — was in 2011. Since then, Republican lawmakers, determined to thwart the Obama administration at every step, have forced the government to subsist on stopgap measures that simply carry over or cut previous spending, with no accounting for growth, inflation or changing priorities.

headline: Way Before Rodriguez, Another Yankee Gave Baseball Fits

lead_paragraph: In his written ruling on Alex Rodriguez’s appeal of his 211-game suspension, baseball’s impartial arbitrator raises the name and pathetic case of Steve Howe, the pitcher who was given more chances to play baseball than Billy Martin was given to manage the Yankees.

headline: On Camera, a Feminist Hero Gains Complexity
abstract: “She Is King” is a portrait of the tennis star Billie Jean King as a hero in an era of entrenched sexism and other inequalities in sports and life.
lead_paragraph: Are you an angry woman? That’s the first question James Day asks a smiling, ebullient Billie Jean King in “She Is King,” part of the Incubator Arts Project’s Other Forces festival. Sure, she says, she’s angry about certain things, but then, who isn’t?

headline: Location, Location, Location
abstract: Bernice Gordon becomes the first centenarian to have a puzzle published in The New York Times. That deserves a standing ovation.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — First, the big news: today’s constructor, Bernice Gordon of Philadelphia, turned 100 years young last Saturday. Let’s let that sink in for a bit, shall we? Not only has Ms. Gordon made it to her 100th birthday, but she is still constructing crossword puzzles, and really good ones at that.

headline: Mideast Strife Turns Trial on Beirut Assassination Into Another Fault Line
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The trial in the 2005 assassination of Rafik Hariri in Lebanon is about to begin, but it has become another friction point in the Middle East’s sectarian showdown.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Perhaps it was wishful thinking from the start. The huge car bomb that killed former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri of Lebanon nearly nine years ago led to an ambitious international investigation intended to bring about a new era of accountability to a country long splintered by political violence.

headline: Cuomo Saying Little on Bridge Scandal
abstract: When it comes to the case of the retaliatory lane closings at the George Washington Bridge, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and his aides keep repeating: It’s a New Jersey issue.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York is not one to shy away from a political fight. But in the case of the scandal engulfing Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey over retaliatory lane closings at the George Washington Bridge, Mr. Cuomo and his aides have kept to a simple mantra from the beginning: This was and remains a New Jersey issue.

headline: Even Supporters Question Cuomo’s Marijuana Plan

lead_paragraph: ALBANY — When Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced this month that he would allow medical marijuana in New York, the news was greeted with great enthusiasm by those who champion the drug for patients with cancer, AIDS and other serious illnesses.

headline: Bookstore May Have to Flee the Wrecking Ball, Again
keywords: ['Demolition', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The owners of the building housing Rizzoli Bookstore say they plan to demolish the six-story, 109-year-old building, as well as two small, adjoining buildings.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-nine years ago, Rizzoli Bookstore, whose Old World charm, hand-wrought chandeliers and big storefront windows make it a favorite of noted authors, book lovers and tourists, fled Fifth Avenue two steps ahead of the wrecking ball.

headline: France: Roma Evictions Increase
abstract: The eviction of migrant Roma squatters by French authorities doubled from the year prior in 2013, according to a report by rights groups.
lead_paragraph: French authorities sharply accelerated the eviction of migrant Roma squatters in 2013, razing the unauthorized encampments of nearly 20,000 Roma, according to a report by rights groups on Tuesday. The evictions were double those of 2012, according to the French Human Rights League and the European Roma Rights Center. President François Hollande took office in 2012 pledging to break with the strict policies of his predecessor, Nicolas Sarkozy. But Mr. Hollande has reinforced those policies, demolishing at least 165 Roma camps last year, according to the report. French officials did not respond to requests for comment.

headline: Congo: Fighters Quit, U.N. Says
abstract: The head of the United Nations peacekeeping mission said that 8,000 fighters affiliated with a variety of armed factions had surrendered since the M23 rebel group was routed.
lead_paragraph: The head of the United Nations peacekeeping mission in the Democratic Republic of Congo said Tuesday that 8,000 fighters affiliated with a variety of armed factions had surrendered since the M23 rebel group was routed in November. Among them are the Hutu militias that Rwanda holds responsible for the genocide 20 years ago. Martin Kobler, the United Nations’ special representative for Congo, said about 50 members of a Hutu group, Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda, had surrendered in each of the last two months alone, steadily diminishing what he said was a 1,800-strong force. He said his peacekeepers were focused on rooting out the rest, but warned that the group was not likely to be eliminated by military means alone.

headline: American Weight Lifter Is Suspended
abstract: Sarah Robles, an American weight lifter who became a crowd favorite at the 2012 Summer Games in London, received a two-year suspension after testing positive for a banned substance, Usada announced.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Robles, an American weight lifter who became a crowd favorite at the 2012 Summer Games in London, received a two-year suspension after testing positive for a banned substance, Usada announced.

headline: Court Weighs Police Role in Coercing Confessions
keywords: ['Interrogations', 'Confessions', 'Police', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The New York Court of Appeals heard arguments in two murder cases on Tuesday that examined how far police can go in lying to suspects during interrogations.
lead_paragraph: New York State’s highest court heard arguments in two murder cases on Tuesday that plumbed the question of how far the police can go in lying to suspects during interrogations — even to the point of telling suspects a dead victim is still alive, but might survive if they confess to precise details of the crime.

headline: In 9 Seconds, Rangers Watch Lead, Tie and Game Vanish
abstract: The Lightning scored nine seconds apart in the second period, the quickest two goals in their history, to end the Rangers’ winning streak at three games.
lead_paragraph: Nine costly seconds was all it took to scuttle the Rangers on Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden. In that lightning-quick stretch Tampa Bay scored twice for a 2-1 win.

abstract: As a teacher and principal, Carmen Fariña became known for her hands-on approach, which propelled her rise in the Education Department of New York City and ultimately contributed to her departure.
lead_paragraph: Carmen Fariña was known for her meticulous demands.

lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The Knicks, making their way back to relevance in the Eastern Conference’s Atlantic Division, arrived here on a five-game winning streak and facing a Bobcats team that had lost eight of its last nine games.

headline: After Family Turmoil, a Commitment to Her Two Siblings
abstract: Life for Krystine Dykes, 25, has been a progression from neglect and abuse to foster care and depression, and last year she became the foster guardian of her younger brothers.
lead_paragraph: Never had the sound of snoring been such a comfort.
