keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Lunar New Year', 'Rana Plaza Building Collapse, Bangladesh (2013)', 'Shoes and Boots']
abstract: The fire at the plant comes as Western retailers have faced scrutiny for workplace conditions at Asian plants that supply them.
lead_paragraph: A fire tore through a shoe factory in eastern China, killing at least 16 people, and the state media said that the police on Wednesday took into custody the owners of the plant, which makes shoes for export around the world.

headline: Teenager Is One of Australia’s Remaining Hopes
abstract: The burden of the home country’s expectations in the men’s draw at the Australian Open has shifted to 18-year-old Nick Kyrgios.
lead_paragraph: With a serve that can reach nearly 137 miles per hour and a powerful all-court game, Nick Kyrgios has been gaining attention for some time.

headline: Burton R. Lifland, Bankruptcy Judge in Big Cases, Dies at 84
abstract: One of Judge Lifland’s biggest challenges was sifting through the wreckage of Bernard L. Madoff’s multibillion-dollar Ponzi scheme.
lead_paragraph: Burton R. Lifland, a pre-eminent federal bankruptcy judge who for three decades rode herd on some of the nation’s biggest corporate rescue efforts and presided over the financial chaos left by the swindler Bernard L. Madoff, died on Sunday in New Haven. He was 84.

headline: Port Authority’s Chairman May Be the Next to Topple
abstract: David Samson, one of the closest advisers to Gov. Chris Christie, has raised the issue of stepping down, according to government officials.
lead_paragraph: It is starting to look as if this could be the traffic jam that ate New Jersey.

headline: Thomas L. Chrystie, Bank Services Innovator on Wall St., Dies at 80
abstract: Mr. Chrystie created the cash management account, a one-stop-shopping convenience for the brokerage business.
lead_paragraph: When Thomas L. Chrystie became a top executive in the early 1970s at Merrill Lynch & Company, it was a rocky time for Wall Street brokerage firms. A recession, a bear market, high inflation and “stagflation,” the fusion of rising prices and rising unemployment, had stock investors fleeing and taking with them the commissions and fees that brokerage houses lived on.

headline: Return to Normal in Parts of West Virginia Is Marred by Distrust
abstract: Even as some 39,000 customers had received the all-clear signal by Tuesday, after a chemical spill last week contaminated tap water, many feared drinking and cooking with it.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — The water was back on, but the anxiety had not shut off.

headline: Ideas, Costs and the All-Volunteer Army
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Draft and Recruitment (Military)', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: In the end, cost-benefit analysis drives policy change more than economic research does, and the change from conscription to an army of enlistees is an example, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: What Ultra-Marathons Do to Our Bodies
abstract: Those who race 50 to 100 miles at a time or longer tend to be older and have different health concerns than most of us might expect, new research shows.
lead_paragraph: Ultra-runners are different from you and me. They run more. But a new study of these racers, who compete in events longer than marathons, joins other recent science in finding that they also tend to be older and have some different health concerns than most of us might expect, suggesting that some beliefs about how much activity the human body can manage, especially in middle age, may be too narrow.

headline: Retired Police Captain Feared Attack Before Shooting in Theater, Officials Say
abstract: The case of Curtis J. Reeves Jr., charged with second-degree murder for shooting a man who was texting in a theater, is likely to revolve around Florida’s much-debated self-defense laws.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — A retired police captain who killed a man after an argument over texting in a movie theater told detectives that he feared he was under attack when the victim hit him in the face with an unknown object, police records show.

headline: Christie's State of the State Address
abstract: The full remarks from Gov. Chris Christie’s speech.
lead_paragraph: The full remarks from Gov. Chris Christie’s speech.

headline: Aide to Late Lawmaker Wins a House Primary in Florida
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In a March 11 special election, David Jolly will now face Alex Sink, a well-known Democrat who narrowly lost to Gov. Rick Scott and is considered the front-runner.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The first race in the 2014 battle for Congress took shape on Tuesday in one of the country’s quintessential swing districts as David Jolly, a former general counsel to the district’s longtime Republican representative, the late C. W. Bill Young, defeated two opponents to win the Republican primary.

headline: For Super Bowl, It’s Back to Basics for Anheuser-Busch
abstract: The Anheuser-Busch division of Anheuser-Busch InBev has a game plan for Super Bowl XLVIII that focuses on Bud Light and Budweiser.
lead_paragraph: The Anheuser-Busch division of Anheuser-Busch InBev, which typically buys the most commercial time during the Super Bowl each year, has a game plan for Super Bowl XLVIII on Feb. 2 that is focused on its two core brands, Bud Light and Budweiser.

headline: In Rare Video, Wife of Jailed Nobel Laureate Reads Poems While Under House Arrest
abstract: The poet Liu Xia has been held in extralegal detention in her apartment since the imprisonment of her husband, Liu Xiaobo, after his conviction on charges of inciting subversion of state power.
lead_paragraph: Liu Xia, the wife of the imprisoned Nobel Peace laureate Liu Xiaobo, was shown reading two of her poems in a short video aired at an event on Tuesday in New York. The two-minute video was filmed in December and obtained by the Friends of Liu Xiaobo and the Independent Chinese PEN Center, a free-speech advocacy group that Ms. Liu helped establish.

headline: Suing to End Life Support for Woman and Fetus
keywords: ['Life-Sustaining Support Systems, Withdrawal Of', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'ABORTION']
abstract: Lawyers for the husband of Marlise Muñoz, a pregnant woman said to have been brain-dead since November, have sued the Texas hospital that is keeping her on life support.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Lawyers for the husband of a pregnant woman being kept on life support at a Fort Worth hospital against her family’s wishes sued hospital officials on Tuesday, asking a judge to order the doctors to remove her from the machines and declare the Texas law at the center of her case unconstitutional.

headline: Ads Attacking Health Law Stagger Outspent Democrats
keywords: ['Political Advertising', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Elections, Senate', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: A group financed in part by the Koch brothers is spending millions on ads aimed at vulnerable Democrats who supported the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democrats are increasingly anxious about an onslaught of television ads hitting vulnerable Senate and House candidates for their support of the new health law, since many lack the resources to fight back in the early stages of the midterm campaign.

headline: Thousands March Against Thai Leader in 3rd Day of Protests
abstract: A protester was shot and the compound of a former prime minister, Abhisit Vejjajiva, was damaged by a small explosion during the unrest.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — With no sign of resolution to Thailand’s debilitating political power struggle, antigovernment protesters marched through Bangkok on Wednesday pledging to stop elections next month while the government vowed that they would take place.

headline: Program to Cover Major Illnesses Is Extended
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Cancer', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The Pre-Existing Condition Insurance Plan will be extended through March so patients can continue treatment while they find other coverage, the Obama administration said.
lead_paragraph: A special health insurance program for people with cancer, heart disease and other serious illnesses will be extended for two additional months, through March, so patients can continue treatment while they search for other coverage, the Obama administration said Tuesday.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (FXX) HOW TO TRAIN YOUR DRAGON (2010) In this feature from DreamWorks Animation, a teenage Viking named Hiccup (voiced by Jay Baruchel) befriends Toothless, an injured dragon, on a windswept island; pleases his demanding father (Gerard Butler); and saves the world in the process. The airborne sequences, like the one above, are particularly compelling, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “When Hiccup first climbs on Toothless’s back and urges the dragon to take wing, the hearts of the audience soar with a primitive and durable delight,” he said. “The techniques that enabled this feeling may be dauntingly complicated, but the feeling could not be simpler.” At the beginning and the end, “ ‘How to Train Your Dragon’ is noisy and action-packed in the usual way,” Mr. Scott added, with “eye-straining, ear-popping large-scale effects.” But they are worth sitting through, he wrote, “for the tenderness, beauty and exhilaration that are the movie’s great strengths.”

headline: After Flurry of Changes, Some States Ease Up
abstract: In many states under single-party control, lawmakers are steering away from the divisive battles on abortion, gun control, collective bargaining and large tax cuts that have marked recent sessions in state capitols.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — One year ago, Gov. John W. Hickenlooper, a Colorado Democrat, stood before a state legislature controlled by his party and laid out an aggressive agenda that included a sweeping expansion of gun-control laws after the mass shooting at an Aurora movie house. “Why not have universal background checks for all gun sales?” he asked.

headline: Tussling Over a Name for Beijing’s New Airport
abstract: Expected to have half a dozen runways and to handle more passengers than Heathrow, Beijing’s planned new international airport is the center of a naming debate that speaks of the country’s image, commerce and history.
lead_paragraph: What’s in an airport name? In Beijing, a debate has begun over the name of a planned new international airport, the capital’s second. The front-runners are Daxing, Jingji, Lixian, Yongding, Yufa and Zhuque, with the struggle between the two favorites, Daxing and Lixian, seeming to rest on this: What image does China want to present to the world? Money or virtue?

headline: Danish Tourist Says She Was Gang-Raped in India
abstract: The woman said she was assaulted after approaching a group of men Tuesday to ask for directions to her hotel, according to the police.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A 51-year-old Danish woman said she was gang-raped at knife point by seven or eight men in central New Delhi after she approached them to ask for directions to her hotel, the Delhi police reported on Wednesday.

headline: Washington: More Money Sought for Schools and Wages
abstract: Gov. Jay Inslee asked lawmakers to increase spending on K-12 education and raise the state minimum wage as the Legislature began work on the first state budget in six years without a major financial shortfall.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Jay Inslee asked lawmakers to increase spending on K-12 education and raise the state minimum wage as the Legislature began work on the first state budget in six years without a major financial shortfall. Mr. Inslee, a Democrat, said in his State of the State speech on Tuesday that improving finances made education spending a priority. The Washington Supreme Court has ruled that education spending does not meet constitutional requirements. Washington already has the nation’s highest statewide minimum wage, $9.32, and Mr. Inslee said there was “ample evidence” that an increase in the $1.50 to $2.50 range “does not kill jobs.”

headline: Florida Governor Chooses Running Mate
abstract: Gov. Rick Scott named Carlos Lopez-Cantera to fill the lieutenant governor’s job and to join him in his re-election bid this year.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Gov. Rick Scott named a South Florida property appraiser and former Republican legislator to be his running mate and lieutenant governor, filling a position that had been vacant for nearly a year.

headline: Administration Is Seen as Retreating on Environment in Talks on Pacific Trade
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Environment', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Documents obtained by WikiLeaks show that the Obama administration is pulling back on environmental protections to reach a trade deal that is a pillar of the president’s strategic shift to Asia.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is retreating from previous demands of strong international environmental protections in order to reach agreement on a sweeping Pacific trade deal that is a pillar of President Obama’s strategic shift to Asia, according to documents obtained by WikiLeaks, environmentalists and people close to the contentious trade talks.

headline: With China Awash in Money, Leaders Start to Weigh Raising the Floodgates
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renminbi (Currency)']
abstract: The amount of money sloshing the economy, according to a broad measure, has tripled since 2006 and has driven asset prices through the roof.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Move over, Janet Yellen and Ben Bernanke. Step aside, Mario Draghi and Haruhiko Kuroda. When it comes to monetary stimulus, Zhou Xiaochuan, the longtime governor of the People’s Bank of China, has no rivals.

headline: Ambitious Art on Display at Mumbai’s New Airport Terminal
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'AIRPORTS', 'Art', 'Buddhism', 'Collectors and Collections', 'Museums', 'Stations and Terminals (Passenger)']
abstract: Chhatrapati Shivaji International Airport’s Terminal 2 will eventually showcase 7,000 art objects, including antiquities procured from 27 states within India.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI — Airports are normally places people want to rush in and out of, but the developers of the new Terminal 2 at Chhatrapati Shivaji International Airport in Mumbai hope to change that. Among the many benefits for flyers coming through Terminal 2 is the opportunity to take in a vast amount of traditional and contemporary Indian art via an ambitious public arts program.

headline: Hong Kong Leader’s Speech Skirts Appeals for Democracy
abstract: The comments by Leung Chun-ying, the territory’s chief executive, did little to clarify whether Hong Kong would allow all adults to vote in the next election.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The chief executive of Hong Kong, in his annual policy address on Wednesday, called for greater government spending on education from kindergarten through college, but said little in response to appeals here for greater democracy.

headline: Test Yourself, Math | Jan. 15, 2014
abstract: Can you calculate the snowfall in a recent storm needed to yield of an average of one foot in the New York City area?
lead_paragraph: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | ‘The New Face of Polygamy’?
abstract: How has one polygamist family managed to “anger both the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, which abandoned polygamy in 1890, and to some extent their own Mormon fundamentalist offshoot, the Apostolic United Brethren”?
lead_paragraph: In “Polygamy as Lifestyle Choice, and a Reality TV Brand,” John Schwartz reports on the Brown family of the reality show “Sister Wives.”

headline: Spring Festival Gala Performance by Chinese Rock Icon in Doubt
abstract: The invitation to Cui Jian, whose songs became anthems of the 1989 pro-democracy student movement, was seen as an attempt to enliven one of the world’s most watched programs. But his agent cited concerns about censorship.
lead_paragraph: An iconic Chinese rocker whose music is closely associated with the 1989 pro-democracy movement is unlikely to appear on this year’s Spring Festival gala on Chinese state television because of censorship concerns, his agent said.

headline: Choosing Sides and a Camera
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Mines and Mining', 'Organized Labor', 'Photography']
abstract: In his quest for social justice, Builder Levy has spent his life as a New York City schoolteacher. But when he could, he ventured to Appalachia to document mine workers.
lead_paragraph: Builder Levy grew up thinking the world could be — had to be — a better place. How he would do his part was almost predetermined. He grew up in a family of what would now be called progressives. He called them Mom, Dad and Aunt Dolly. One day, bored, he put on one of his father’s records, “Which Side Are You On?” It entranced him.

headline: Donors Offer $2.4 Billion to Aid Syrian Civilians, but U.N. Says More Is Needed
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Western nations, Arab states and others pledged the aid as Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, said that $6.5 billion was needed to help Syrian civilians this year.
lead_paragraph: KUWAIT — Western nations, Arab states and others pledged more than $2.4 billion on Wednesday to help civilians who are suffering because of the civil war in Syria.

headline: American Life Turns Off One Chinese Student
abstract: A news agency employee who went to the United States to study film editing says now all he wants to do is return to the land of the Chinese Dream.
lead_paragraph: Disillusioned by rampant partying, illicit drugs and racial discrimination, one Chinese student in the United States has held nothing back in telling a Chinese news outlet why he is eager to return home.

headline: Where in the World Would You Travel If You Could?
abstract: What places from The Times’s annual Places to Go list interest you most? Where else in the world would you like to go? What kind of traveler are you?
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of each year, the Times Travel section suggests the best places on the globe to visit. The 2014 edition includes photographs and short descriptions of 52 places.

headline: State Television Airs Footage of Major Drug Raid
abstract: The assault on a Guangdong village in December by 3,000 officers ended in 182 arrests for suspected manufacture of methamphetamine.
lead_paragraph: Chinese state television broadcast video on Tuesday of last month’s raid by 3,000 police officers on a village described as a center of methamphetamine production.

abstract: What you need to know for Wednesday: flooded subways and streets, foggy weather, and a look at the bridge behind Bridgegate.

headline: Obama Announces Institute to Create Manufacturing Jobs
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Making good on a pledge from last year, the president announced the establishment of an institute in North Carolina that he said would reinvigorate the nation’s manufacturing economy.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — It was President Obama’s first policy-related trip of 2014, but he used it to take care of some unfinished business from 2013.

headline: Better Hearing Through Bluetooth
abstract: A new generation of products that utilize the latest wireless technology are offering promising alternatives for some people with hearing loss.
lead_paragraph: Like many men of his generation, Larry Faust, 61, of Seattle, went to a lot of rock concerts in his youth. And like many men of his generation, his hearing isn’t what it used to be.

headline: German Economy Grows at Modest Pace
abstract: Compared to the rest of the euro zone, Germany is still deemed a success story because unemployment remains low at just 5.2 percent.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The German economy registered only meager growth in the fourth quarter of 2013, according to early estimates released on Wednesday, as an improvement in consumption was not strong enough to compensate for a decline in investment by business and government and the effects of recession elsewhere in Europe.

headline: Deutsche Bank Suspends Traders Amid Foreign Exchange Investigations
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Currency', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The German bank has suspended several traders in New York amid investigations into potential manipulation of the $5-trillion-a-day foreign exchange market, according to a person briefed on the matter.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Deutsche Bank has suspended several traders amid a series of investigations into potential manipulation of the $5-trillion-a-day foreign exchange market, according to a person briefed on the matter.

headline: Daily Report: Court Rejects F.C.C. Rules Barring Deals on Faster Streaming
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Net Neutrality', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Telephones and Telecommunications']
abstract: The decision by a federal appeals court against so-called net neutrality could pave the way for Internet service providers to charge content companies to deliver data at a faster speed.
lead_paragraph: Internet service providers are free to make deals with services like Netflix or Amazon allowing those companies to pay to stream their products to online viewers through a faster, express lane on the web, a federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday, Edward Wyatt reports.

headline: Negotiating Conflicts, Part 4: Parents at a Wedding
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Emotions', 'Baby Boomers', 'Inheritance and Estate Taxes', 'Wills and Estates', 'Elder Care']
abstract: The wedding is a time to set the parameters for how a couple will deal with family conflicts in marriage.
lead_paragraph: Sheila Heen, an expert in negotiation and difficult conversations, is answering reader questions about how to resolve disputes within families and in other parts of life.

headline: Bank of America’s Profit Exceeds Estimates
abstract: The big bank, which has been trying for five years to recover from the financial crisis, saw its fourth-quarter revenue and net income surge.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:18 a.m. | Bank of America has spent the last five years digging out from its mortgage problems, shoring up its capital levels and laying off employees.

headline: For Some Ski Racers, an Advantage Before the Season Even Starts
abstract: In an age where ski racing has become increasingly specialized, technical racers have more chances to win points for the overall title.
lead_paragraph: LA GRAVE, France — In the fight for the World Cup overall title, Marcel Hirscher of Austria already has a 23-point lead over Aksel Lund Svindal of Norway. Unfortunately for Svindal, there might be an even bigger obstacle that he has no control over as he tries to close the gap before the season ends in March.

headline: Militants Unleash Wave of Violence in Iraq, Killing Dozens
abstract: At least 64 people were killed, including residents who had been shopping in markets, soldiers on patrol and seven truck drivers who were found dead from gunshot wounds.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Militants launched lethal and coordinated car bombings in Baghdad on Wednesday, killed truck drivers outside the city and detonated explosives at a funeral tent in a village during one of the deadliest outbreaks of violence in Iraq so far this year, according to health and security officials.

headline: A Pocket Guide to the 2014 Jaipur Literature Festival
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', 'Indian-Americans', 'News and News Media', 'Nobel Prizes', 'Pulitzer Prizes', 'United States Economy', "Women's Rights", 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: From Friday through Tuesday, celebrated writers from India and abroad will talk about not just their books but also about the two World Wars, Afghanistan after the withdrawal of American troops, Himalayan languages and the making of modern China.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 Jaipur Literature Festival, now in its ninth edition, kicks off in the state capital of Rajasthan on Friday. Over the course of five days, celebrated writers from India and abroad will talk about not just their books but also about the two World Wars, Afghanistan after the withdrawal of American troops, Himalayan languages and the making of modern China.

headline: Carson, Set Up the Universal Remote
abstract: The real reasons we watch “Downton Abbey.”
lead_paragraph: There have been a lot of theories lately about why Americans like to watch “Downton Abbey,” but in my case it’s very simple: I like the stuff. I like the drawing room stuff, I like the bed linen stuff, I like the wine glass stuff. It’s better than Pottery Barn.  I especially like the idea that if you dribble something on the stuff you have somebody to clean it up. Like this morning, at the gym, when I dribbled some coffee on my workout top, no one came over with a linen handkerchief, dabbing or even daubing. I had to, if you can believe it, do the elliptical trainer with a stain.

headline: On Wall Street, a Generation Gap on Work-Life Issues
abstract: Wall Street firms are making a show of re-evaluating the grueling hours endured by their junior employees as a younger generation increasingly wants meaningful work and the flexibility afforded by technology.
lead_paragraph: “If you love what you do, it’s not ‘work,’” David M. Rubenstein, co-founder and co-chief executive of the private equity giant Carlyle Group, told CNBC’s Squawk Box on Tuesday.

headline: Misunderstood Aboard the Intrepid
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A former aircraft carrier crewman visiting the Intrepid museum was asked two odd questions about his identity.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Sebastian Junger and the Complicated Obligations of Friendship
abstract: Sebastian Junger talks about making the film “Which Way to the Front Line From Here?,” about the life and death of his friend Tim Hetherington.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, “Restrepo,” a documentary about American soldiers in Afghanistan directed by the American writer Sebastian Junger and the British photojournalist Tim Hetherington, was an Oscar nominee in the best feature documentary category. This year Mr. Junger is back, with another film shortlisted in the same category, but in extremely painful circumstances: “Which Way Is the Front Line From Here? The Life and Time of Tim Hetherington” addresses the death of Mr. Hetherington in 2012, at the age of 40, while covering the uprising in Libya that overthrew Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: Today in Small Business: ‘Economic Freedom’
abstract: Small-business optimism rises. How to assess the health of your business. A reason to use Google Plus.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Good News for Bank of America
abstract: Bank of America’s fourth-quarter results exceeded Wall Street expectations. | Doctor admits sharing data with former SAC trader accused of insider trading. | Regulators revise Volcker Rule. | Michael Lewis has a new book.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America posted fourth-quarter results on Wednesday that exceeded Wall Street expectations, driven by decreasing expenses in its mortgage business. Earnings rose to $3.4 billion, or 29 cents a share, from $732 million, or 3 cents a share, in the period a year earlier, Michael Corkery reports in DealBook. Earnings exceeded the 26 cents a share that analysts had expected. Net revenue rose 15 percent, to $21.7 billion.

headline: HarperCollins to Publish New Novels by James Frey
abstract: Mr. Frey, whose 2003 memoir was excoriated for embellishing the truth, will write three novels in a series that will include other written and digital material.
lead_paragraph: James Frey is once again venturing into young-adult literature with a new series, “Endgame,” that has been acquired by HarperCollins, the publisher said on Tuesday.

headline: Fukushima Radiation (Still) Poses No California Risk
keywords: ['Fear (Emotion)', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Social Media']
abstract: Fresh coverage of the lack of radiation risk in California from the Fukushima disaster.
lead_paragraph: I’m catching up with an incredibly helpful, and sadly necessary, article by Tony Barboza in the Los Angeles Times explaining why there’s no scientific basis for the persistent stream of fear mongering about a radiation threat in American seafood and along California coasts from the 2011 Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant calamity.

headline: Riverbed Rejects Elliott’s $3.2 Billion Takeover Bid
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: Riverbed Technology described Elliott Management’s offer of $19 a share inadequate, but did not say whether it would take the activist hedge fund up on its other demand: setting up a process to sell itself.
lead_paragraph: The networking equipment maker Riverbed Technology announced on Wednesday that it had rejected a $3.2 billion takeover bid by the activist hedge fund Elliott Management and reported preliminary fourth-quarter results that were better than expected.

headline: Crafting the World of ‘Saving Mr. Banks’
abstract: The costume designer Daniel Orlandi and his staff sifted through hundreds of archival photos and online candids to recreate the 1961 world of Walt Disney and P. L. Travers for “Saving Mr. Banks.”
lead_paragraph: The costume designer Daniel Orlandi and his staff sifted through hundreds of archival photos and online candids to recreate the 1961 world of Walt Disney and P. L. Travers for “Saving Mr. Banks.”
