lead_paragraph: 1964: Germany Wants United Europe

headline: Living In a Gun Lobby Dystopia
abstract: An angry patron at a showing of “Lone Survivor” shot a fellow audience-member because he was texting.
lead_paragraph: The gun lobby says Americans would be safer if more “good guys” carried loaded guns in public places, and extols the benefits of an armed citizenry.

headline: Art Installation at J.F.K. Faces Possible Destruction
abstract: The work of art, welcoming arriving international passengers at Terminal 4 since 2001, is scheduled to be removed by this spring and could be destroyed if a new home is not found.
lead_paragraph: Every year, more than seven million international air passengers are greeted gladly on their arrival in the United States — not by forbidding blank corridors or a blizzard of oversize advertising, but by billowing, cloudlike, buttercream-colored curtains stretching hundreds of feet along a periwinkle sky.

headline: A Revival of Key West-to-Cuba Travel
abstract: In late December, a commercial flight traveled from Key West, Fla., to Cuba for the first time in more than 50 years.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in more than 50 years, a commercial passenger aircraft has flown from the island of Key West, Fla., to Havana, Cuba, reestablishing the direct connection the two cities shared in the early 1950s.

headline: Want Better Hedge Fund Returns? Try One Led by a Woman
abstract: In the years since the financial crisis, hedge funds managed by women performed better than a broader index reflecting the performance of the industry, a report found.
lead_paragraph: In the world of hedge funds, a relative few have a woman at the helm. And yet, these funds may be the standouts from the bunch, a new report argues.

headline: Richard Parsons’s New Restaurant Receives Accolades
abstract: The New York Times on Wednesday gave high marks to the Cecil, a restaurant that counts Richard Parsons, Citigroup’s former chairman, and Alexander Smalls, a former opera singer, as owners.
lead_paragraph: Richard D. Parsons has held many titles during his career: media conglomerate chief, chairman of Citigroup, wearer of leather jackets.

headline: Clothes and Character: ‘Saving Mr. Banks’
abstract: The costume designer for “Saving Mr. Banks” explains how the initial looks for Emma Thompson’s characters didn’t work because the actress was too glamorous.
lead_paragraph: The movie business has its perks, and spending time at Disneyland is one of them.

headline: Giving Vaccines Together Increases Fever Risk
abstract: When shots for flu and pneumococcal disease were given together, children were more likely to develop a fever within a day.
lead_paragraph: Some children get a moderate fever after a vaccination for flu or pneumococcal disease. But when the vaccinations are given together, the risk of fever increases significantly.

headline: Playing the Odds on Saving
abstract: Lotteries, usually considered part of the problem, could in fact be part of the solution.
lead_paragraph: Americans’ lack of savings has become a crisis. Our confidence that we’ve got enough saved for retirement is at historically low levels, according to the Employee Benefit Research Institute’s annual Retirement Confidence Survey. More than a quarter of Americans have saved less than $1,000 for retirement. Only half of those surveyed say they could definitely find $2,000 if an emergency arose in the next month.

headline: ScienceTake: Flying Jellyfish
abstract: Researchers have designed a flying machine that can stay aloft without fancy sensors or control mechanisms.
lead_paragraph: Researchers have designed a flying machine that can stay aloft without fancy sensors or control mechanisms.

headline: With Math as Inspiration, a New Form of Flyer
abstract: Two scientists have developed a small, hovering, flapping-wing flying machine that looks for all the world like a flying jellyfish.
lead_paragraph: When the Wright brothers pioneered powered flight, said Leif Ristroph, they “didn’t solve a lift problem; they solved a stability problem.”

headline: Arbitrator’s Ruling on Rodriguez Gives Baseball a Disciplinary ‘Hammer’
abstract: In upholding most of Alex Rodriguez’s suspension, labor lawyers say, an arbitrator established a broad standard on penalties available to the commissioner.
lead_paragraph: Alex Rodriguez incurred the anger of many of his fellow players when he sued the players union on Monday, but over time, they may come to despise him even more for confirming Major League Baseball’s sweeping powers of punishment.

headline: Outside the Fall/Winter 2014 Milan Men’s Shows
abstract: A glimpse at what guys are wearing this season.
lead_paragraph: A glimpse at what guys are wearing this season.

headline: Image of the Day: January 15
abstract: Jallikattu, a bull-taming sporting event, was held in Palamedu, Tamil Nadu.

headline: Sports 2.0: Upgrade Your Game
abstract: App-enabled sports technology promises to put a coach in your pocket and help you improve your game in baseball, golf and basketball. Does it work?
lead_paragraph: App-enabled sports technology promises to put a coach in your pocket and help you improve your game in baseball, golf and basketball. Does it work?

headline: Digital Coach Perched Right in Your Pocket
abstract: Companies have started to introduce some intriguing sports devices that analyze movement using sensors.
lead_paragraph: The tech world’s current obsession is with wearables — the idea being that you can stuff all manner of technology into increasingly tiny packages. So far, much of the attention has been on watches and glasses. But the same teeny sensors and smartphone brains that power those devices have other applications, too — for instance, in a new wave of smart sports equipment.

headline: Benghazi Attack Called Avoidable in Senate Report
abstract: A stinging report by the Senate Intelligence Committee blames both American diplomats and spies for poor communication and lax security before the deadly 2012 episode in Libya.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A stinging report by the Senate Intelligence Committee released Wednesday concluded that the attack 16 months ago that killed four Americans in Benghazi, Libya, could have been prevented, singling out the State Department for criticism for its failure to bolster security in response to intelligence warnings about a growing security crisis around the city.

headline: Location, Location, Impersonation
abstract: In “The Tribute Artist,” Charles Busch plays a female impersonator whose landlady dies, leaving an opportunity to take on her identity — and her townhouse.
lead_paragraph: Alongside winning the lottery and buying a gorgeous full-floor penthouse perched alongside Central Park, acquiring a Greenwich Village townhouse at a steal must rank among a New Yorker’s real-estate fantasies. In “The Tribute Artist,” a new comedy by Charles Busch, known for his riotous, gender-bending farces, like “Vampire Lesbians of Sodom” and “The Divine Sister,” he plays a female impersonator whose landlady dies, leaving an opportunity to take on her identity — and her townhouse. The plan naturally hits some snags and leads to further nutty scheming.

headline: G.M.’s Dividend Hits the Right Spot
abstract: It is notable that the board of General Motors is reinstating the dividend before sorting out new pay levels for its top executives, Antony Currie writes for Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: General Motors is hitting the right spot on several levels with its return to paying a common stock dividend.

headline: Classical Playlist: Louis Lortie, Daniel Barenboim, the Hilliard Ensemble and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: ‘LISZT AT THE OPERA’Louis Lortie, pianist(Chandos)Liszt’s transcriptions of, and fantasias on, excerpts from operas like “Rigoletto” and “Faust” — not to mention the works of his future son-in-law, Richard Wagner — are some of the most dazzling and complex piano works of the 19th century. Louis Lortie, a fantastic Lisztian, performs them with confidence and clarity. And his new version of the prelude to Wagner’s “Tristan und Isolde,” a companion to Liszt’s transcription of the “Liebestod,” stands comparison with the master. (Zachary Woolfe)

headline: Handybook Buys Exec in a Deal for the On-Demand World
abstract: Handybook’s acquisition of Exec, a San Francisco house cleaner-booking service, reinforces the advent of the on-demand world, where anything you want can be bought with the tap of a button on your smartphone.
lead_paragraph: The rise of services like Uber, TaskRabbit, Seamless, Postmates and Shyp signals the beginnings of an on-demand world, where practically anything you want is available — and fast — with the tap of a button on your smartphone.

headline: Flow of Westerners to Syria Prompts Security Concerns
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Western officials say they are worried that the civil war in Syria could create a cohort of radicalized young people, experienced with warfare, who hold European or American passports.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — A week before international peace talks on Syria are to begin in Switzerland, Western leaders and intelligence officials are reacting with alarm to what they say are the rising numbers of young people leaving Europe and the United States to wage jihad against President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Times Minute | Lawmakers' Pet Projects
abstract: Also on the Minute, American Idol premieres and a device that lets users hit like a pro.
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, American Idol premieres and a device that lets users hit like a pro.

headline: Times Minute | Lawmakers’ Pet Projects
abstract: Also on the Minute, American Idol premieres and a device that lets users hit like a pro.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Wheelies: The 2015 F-150 in a 2014 F-150’s Clothing Edition
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'North American International Auto Show', 'Automobile Insurance and Liability']
abstract: Ford sneaked a 2015 F-150 into the 2013 Baja 1000 by dressing it up as a 2014 model; Ford chief says lawmakers should protect consumer privacy.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Life of Pie
abstract: On the Greek island of Ikaria, what you find on the hills is what you bake in the phyllo.
lead_paragraph: When Diane Kochilas said we were making phyllo, I confess I was intimidated. But as Kochilas taught me, although “phyllo” means “leaf,” that leaf need not be the paper-thin type we’re accustomed to seeing in flaky Middle Eastern pastries. It may be, as it is here, a thin but readily made dough, rich in olive oil, smooth to the touch and easy to handle.

headline: The Rollout: An Ikarian Greens Pie
abstract: Greek chef Diane Kochilas shows Mark Bittman how to prepare a traditional pie loaded with fresh greens. And in Greece, that means preparing a hand-rolled phyllo dough laced with olive oil.
lead_paragraph: Greek chef Diane Kochilas shows Mark Bittman how to prepare a traditional pie loaded with fresh greens. And in Greece, that means preparing a hand-rolled phyllo dough laced with olive oil.

headline: New York Festival to Celebrate the Work of James Baldwin
abstract: This year’s Live Ideas Festival in Chelsea will present readings and multi-disciplinary performances inspired by the life and work of James Baldwin.
lead_paragraph: New York Live Arts, the performance group based in Chelsea, describes its specialty as “movement-based artistry.” Given the group’s history — it was founded after a merger between the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company and Dance Theater Workshop, and Mr. Jones is its executive artistic director — “movement-based artistry” is usually taken to mean dance. But last year, Live Arts expanded into multidisciplinary performance with its first Live Ideas Festival, built around the work of Dr. Oliver Sacks, the neurologist and author.

headline: Memorable Oscar Moments
abstract: What is it really like to go the Academy Awards show? Melena Ryzik asked some annual Oscar attendees about their most memorable moments.
lead_paragraph: What is it really like to go the Academy Awards show? Melena Ryzik asked some annual Oscar attendees about their most memorable moments.

headline: A Procrastinator’s Guide to the Super Bowl
abstract: If you’ve put off making plans for the big game, here’s a look at some of the ways you can join the fun.
lead_paragraph: Attending a Super Bowl is almost always a pricey proposition, and this year’s game, scheduled for Feb. 2 at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., definitely will be no exception. Still, there are plenty of ways to go to Super Bowl XLVIII, and not all of them are as costly as might be expected.

headline: Telling the Olympic Story, Far From Sochi
abstract: With the Winter Olympics set to open next month in Sochi, Russia, the Olympic Museum has reopened in Switzerland after a renovation that almost doubled its size.
lead_paragraph: As the world’s top athletes prepare to compete in Sochi, Russia, a revamped modern-day shrine to athleticism more than 2,000 miles away pays homage to the competitors, creators and engineers who came before.

headline: Apple to Refund App Store Purchases Made Without Parental Consent
abstract: The chairwoman said the F.T.C. settlement was “more robust” and more thorough than an earlier lawsuit settlement.
lead_paragraph: An agreement between federal regulators and Apple may make parents wince a little less at the sight of their children staring at an iPhone.

headline: Facebook Revamps Ads to Compete With Google
abstract: Small businesses can use tools on Facebook to track customers from ad to website, and target audiences more precisely.
lead_paragraph: Last June, Facebook released a tracking pixel, a snippet of code that allows advertisers to track customers who come to their websites from Facebook ads. For Amy Norman, co-chief executive officer of Little Passports, the pixel was a game-changer.

headline: A Social Media Marketer Assesses Facebook’s Advertising Platform
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Online Advertising', 'Restaurants', 'Small Business', 'Social Media']
abstract: There may be a billion people on Facebook, says Jeff Gibbard, but no business needs to reach a billion people.
lead_paragraph: A guide we just published discusses ways small businesses can make the most of Facebook’s revamped advertising programs. In a conversation that has been condensed and edited, we asked Jeff Gibbard, a social media marketer, to talk about whether small-business owners are likely to get the best return on investment on Facebook or on one of the many other options available. Mr. Gibbard is president of True Voice Media in Philadelphia, an agency that devises social media strategies for small and medium-size businesses. He is also the creator of Social Media Philanthropy, a social media marketing blog that, among other things, attempts to simplify social media concepts.

headline: Rethinking an ‘End-All, Be-All’
abstract: Julia Noran Johnston and her husband, Ben Johnston, were die-hard Upper West Siders, but their rent rose steeply.
lead_paragraph: Julia Noran Johnston and her husband, Ben Johnston, were die-hard Upper West Siders. Both had been living in rentals there when they met three years ago, and she later moved into his one-bedroom in the West 70s.

headline: Songs From Home Greet Young Bosnian as He Faces Croatian on Foreign Court
abstract: An enthusiastic group of supporters greeted Damir Dzumhur, the first man representing Bosnia and Herzegovina to play in the main draw of a Grand Slam.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — The shouts of delight on Court 13 at the Australian Open were never louder Wednesday than when an old man began to play his accordion.

headline: Virginia’s Moran to Retire From House After 23 Years
abstract: Representative James P. Moran, Democrat of Virginia, announced on Wednesday that he would not seek re-election in November, making him the latest in a string of recent retirements in the House.
lead_paragraph: Representative James P. Moran of Virginia announced on Wednesday that he would not seek re-election in November in the deeply Democratic district in Northern Virginia that he has represented for 23 years. His is the latest in a string of recent retirements in the House.

headline: Memories of the Way They Were With Oscar
abstract: Robert Redford’s lifetime achievement award was “a little early,” Abigail Breslin came prepared, and Leonardo DiCaprio was “uncomfortable” in a suit.
lead_paragraph: Early Thursday morning, the Oscar nominations will be announced, clarifying a race with a surfeit of contenders. The stars and filmmakers behind hopefuls like “12 Years a Slave,” “American Hustle” and “Gravity” will know whether they are indeed front-runners or sudden underdogs; others will abruptly find themselves in the position of also-rans and step off the red-carpet circuit.

headline: F.C.C. Chairman Adds More Ambiguity to His Position on Network Neutrality
abstract: In a blog post on the Federal Communication Commission’s website, Tom Wheeler sought to calm the nerves of both backers of Internet regulation and the people fighting against it.
lead_paragraph: Tom Wheeler, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, added further nuance to his already ambiguous position on network neutrality with a blog post late Tuesday, saying again that the F.C.C. will vigorously — but cautiously — exercise its authority to make sure broadband providers operate their networks in the public interest.

headline: Testing the Waters: Investigating Questions About the West Virginia Chemical Spill
abstract: Ideas for teaching about the West Virginia chemical spill, either by focusing on West Virginia alone, or widening the lens to include other industrial spills, inquiries into the water supply or regulation in general.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the spill of an industrial chemical into a West Virginia river contaminated the water supply for 300,000 people, setting off renewed debate over regulating the chemical industry.

headline: Justices Seem Split on Abortion Clinic Buffer Zones, but Crucial Voice Is Silent
abstract: The Supreme Court heard arguments in a challenge to a Massachusetts law, but Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr., who almost certainly holds the crucial vote, asked no questions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court appeared evenly divided on Wednesday as it heard arguments in a First Amendment challenge to a Massachusetts law that created buffer zones around abortion clinics in the state.

headline: A Harder Look at Welfare Rules as Europeans Flood Countries in Search of Jobs
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Foreign Workers', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: At a time when government austerity policies have led to cuts, Europe’s debate over immigration has become intertwined with a thorny discussion of the costs of welfare.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When she arrived in Britain a decade ago from Poland, Justyna Mikler worked hard to find cleaning jobs, studied English and, she says, never even thought of applying for welfare.

headline: Bolshoi Names Cast for First Part of American Tour
abstract: A week of performances at the Kennedy Center will include the Bolshoi’s prima, Svetlana Zakharova, dancing with David Hallberg, in his first American appearance since joining the Bolshoi.
lead_paragraph: The Bolshoi Ballet has announced principal casting for the first leg of its spring tour of North America, a week of performances of “Giselle” at the Kennedy Center (May 20 through 25). First cast (May 20 and 22) are the Bolshoi’s prima, Svetlana Zakharova, and David Hallberg, the American star who joined the Bolshoi in 2011. Mr. Hallberg’s debut performance then, broadcast live internationally, was as Ms. Zakharova’s partner in “The Sleeping Beauty.” The April 20 performance will be his first performance on American soil as a member of the celebrated Russian company.

headline: Snowboarder Danny Davis’s Ambivalent Comeback
abstract: Davis, who was virtually assured an Olympic spot in 2010 before he crashed an A.T.V., hopes to reach the Games on his third try.
lead_paragraph: COPPER MOUNTAIN, Colo. — Danny Davis has been through it all before, and before that, too. As the top American snowboarders converge on the Mammoth Mountain ski area in California this week to decide who will compete next month in Sochi, Russia, the Winter Olympics are within Davis’s reach for the third time.

headline: Jo Nesbo to Write Updated ‘Macbeth’
abstract: Mr. Nesbo’s retelling will be part of the Hogarth Shakespeare series.
lead_paragraph: Jo Nesbo’s best-selling series of thrillers has made the detective Harry Hole a famous name. Now Mr. Nesbo will turn his attention to a name with 400 years of history behind it: He will write a new version of “Macbeth” for Hogarth Shakespeare, a series that will feature contemporary authors retelling Shakespeare plays, beginning in 2016.

headline: In a Gagosian Gallerist’s Personal Work, Cultures Collide
abstract: The Iranian-American artist Andisheh Avini layers references to his heritage with Pop Art influences and bold swaths of color.
lead_paragraph: Every so often, boxes bedecked with Iranian postage and customs stamps arrive at Andisheh Avini’s doorstep. He can instantly recognize the packages as containing handcrafted marquetry panels from a traditional woodworker in Iran, but, though he ordered them himself, couldn’t tell you what they look like. That’s because when he commissions the works a month before they arrive, his only instructions are their dimensions. The rest — the size and pattern of the decorative inlay on the lacquered wood boards, which are typically used for interior decor — is left to the maker, whom Avini has never met in person. This inscrutability is an essential part of the artist’s process.

headline: Who Moved My Cones?
keywords: ['Bridges and Tunnels', 'George Washington Bridge', 'Trans-Hudson Passenger Rail Tunnel (ARC Tunnel)', 'Transit Systems']
abstract: Brooks and Collins on Chris Christie, Fort Lee and the road to the White House.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: David, I have to ask you what you think about Chris Christie and the George Washington Bridge.

headline: A Case of Mistaken Identity Sends a Worthless Stock Soaring
abstract: After Google announced it was buying Nest Labs on Monday, shares jumped for a stock with the ticker symbol NEST — a different, and defunct, company.
lead_paragraph: Nestor Inc. is a defunct shell of a company that once sold automated traffic enforcement equipment to state and local governments. Based in Providence, R.I., the company went into receivership in 2009, and all of its assets have been sold.

headline: L’Affaire Hollande
abstract: The frenzy of interest in the French press over the reported liaison between President François Hollande and an actress, Julie Gayet, has laid bare that the vaunted privacy of a French president is an illusion.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The famously libertine French have long professed Gallic indifference over the sexual peccadilloes of their elected officials.

headline: Sarasota Ballet Signs Artistic Director to 10-Year Contract
abstract: Iain Webb, a former dancer with The Royal Ballet, was first appointed to the position in 2007 on a four-year contract.
lead_paragraph: Iain Webb, the artistic director of the Sarasota Ballet, has signed a contract extending his appointment for 10 more years, the company announced on Tuesday.

headline: Reforming a Picky Eater, Step One: Children Don’t Control the Family Meal
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Parenting']
abstract: If picky eaters are made, not born, then a few resolute adults ought to be able to help one change.
lead_paragraph: What is a picky eater? Is it someone who won’t taste new things? Someone who knows exactly what they like? Someone who loves the spotlight? Are picky eaters made, not born? I believe they are mostly, but not entirely, made. And if adults can make a picky eater, then it ought to be possible for them to help one change.

headline: Program to End Homelessness Among Veterans Reaches a Milestone in Arizona
abstract: Phoenix has become the first American city to end homelessness among veterans with long or recurrent histories of living on the street.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Their descent into homelessness began almost as soon as they had closed a dignified chapter in their lives: their military service.

headline: O.E.C.D. Encourages Labor Changes in Russia
abstract: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development offered several proposals that could help lift the country from its slump.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia will have to remake its labor practices for the country’s economy to pull out of its current doldrums.

headline: Researcher Footage of Flying Ibises
abstract: Scientists have found that a V-formation helps birds conserve energy during flight and report their findings in this week’s Nature.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have found that a V-formation helps birds conserve energy during flight and report their findings in this week’s Nature.

headline: The Power of V: Conserving Energy
abstract: Information collected from 14 flying bald ibises supports the explanation that birds fly in V formations to conserve energy.
lead_paragraph: Birds of a feather may flock together, but why they fly together in V formations has never been known for certain.

headline: Christie and Springsteen: A Tale of Devotion, and a Very Public Snub
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie has loved Bruce Springsteen for years, but in his hour of need, he was scorned by the singer on national television.
lead_paragraph: This is a love story.

headline: M.L.S. Set to Change Channels
abstract: Major League Soccer is pushing for a lucrative eight-year deal with ESPN and Fox to carry its games and those of the U.S. national team.
lead_paragraph: Major League Soccer is expected to announce a new long-term television deal with ESPN and Fox this week, leaving NBC Sports Network after the 2014 season.

headline: The Online Avengers
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Sex Crimes', 'Cyberharassment', 'Bullies', 'Vigilantes', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Are antibullying activists the saviors of the Internet — or just a different kind of curse?
lead_paragraph: One day last April, a 25-year-old named Ash smoked a cigarette in the garden of his London workplace and scrolled through the Twitter feed on his phone. He stopped at the headline “Who Failed Rehtaeh Parsons?” and clicked on the link, which took him to the website of The Chronicle Herald, a Canadian newspaper. The article was an example of the kind of story, about a mistreated and suffering teenager, that Ash spends a considerable portion of his life searching for online, the kind that makes him feel, as he puts it, “very rustled up.”

headline: Snowboarders Prepare for the Worst
abstract: Jeremy Jones has been exploring and snowboarding remote mountain ranges for over two decades. To minimize risk, Jones and his fellow athletes continually refine their mountaineering and rescue skills.
lead_paragraph: Jeremy Jones has been exploring and snowboarding remote mountain ranges for over two decades. To minimize risk, Jones and his fellow athletes continually refine their mountaineering and rescue skills.

headline: In Vermont, a Quick Course on Winter Sports
abstract: Lake Morey Resort in Vermont will offer instruction in winter sports like curling and hockey, complete with Olympics-themed movies.
lead_paragraph: For those with Olympic fever — but not the foggiest notion of how to curl — Lake Morey Resort in Fairlee, Vt., will introduce its first Ice Sports University weekend, Jan. 24 to 26.

headline: The Insider | Mark Duplass on Navigating the Sundance Film Festival
abstract: If you’re going to Park City, the mumblecore filmmaker and Sundance veteran Mark Duplass has tips for beating the lines, scoring free food, getting away and more.
lead_paragraph: Those looking for a personal guide to the Sundance Film Festival, which begins tomorrow in Park City, Utah and runs through Jan. 26, could do a lot worse than Mark Duplass. The veteran actor and filmmaker, who is known for his roles in such films as “Your Sister’s Sister” and “Safety Not Guaranteed” and is a founding father of the mumblecore genre with his brother, Jay, has been to the festival every year since 2003. This year, he returns to Park City with a pair of films he produced: the comedic drama “The Skeleton Twins,” starring Bill Hader and Kristen Wiig, and “The One I Love,” the debut film by the writer Charlie McDowell, in which Duplass also stars alongside the “Mad Men” actress Elisabeth Moss. Here, Duplass shares his tips for navigating the festival.

headline: Norman Foster to Design Comcast Tower in Philadelphia
abstract: The 59-story, 1,121-foot tower in Philadelphia’s Center City neighborhood is being jointly developed by Comcast and Liberty Property Trust.
lead_paragraph: The British architect Norman Foster will design a $1.2 billion tower in Philadelphia’s Center City for the Comcast Corporation, the corporation announced Wednesday.

headline: Robert Redford Would Like a Visitor or Two at Sundance
abstract: As he awaits word of whether he will get an acting nomination for “All Is Lost,” he talks about challenges — with the role and with the festival he started 30 years ago.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Somehow, Robert Redford is a dark horse as a best actor candidate this season. Though his performance in “All Is Lost” drew some of the best reviews of his career, Mr. Redford was passed over for a nomination by his colleagues in the Screen Actors Guild (whose winners will be announced on Saturday), and lost the prize at the Golden Globes to Matthew McConaughey earlier this week. Whether he will get an Oscar nomination on Thursday is an open question among awards-watchers.

headline: A Masterly Menagerie
abstract: In “What’s Your Favorite Animal?,” 14 renowned children’s book illustrators give the question the attention it deserves.
lead_paragraph: Children ask illustrators to name their favorite animals at virtually every school and library visit. In some cases, the artists probably come up with something on the spot and then sketch the rabbit or dromedary in question. But the urge to answer more thoughtfully must weigh on them with a little bit of l’esprit de l’escalier.

headline: Outkast to Headline Governors Ball Music Festival
abstract: Outkast tops a bill of nearly 70 performers for the three-day festival, including Jack White, Vampire Weekend, the Strokes, Neko Case and Skrillex.
lead_paragraph: Outkast is topping the bill at the fourth Governors Ball Music Festival, to be held at Randalls Island Park, June 6 through 8. The festival, which started as a single-day concert on Governors Island in 2011, then moved to Randalls Island Park, where it grew to two days in 2012 and three last year, has become an important event on the summertime popular music calendar. Among the nearly 70 bands and solo performers on this year’s roster are Jack White, Vampire Weekend, the Strokes, Neko Case, Phoenix, Skrillex, Jenny Lewis, TV on the Radio and Foster the People. Tickets go on sale Wednesday at 3 p.m. at govball.com.

headline: Lawmakers Seek Curbs on Trading Commodities
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Commodities', 'Law and Legislation', 'Futures and Options Trading']
abstract: A Senate hearing comes as concerns grow that the huge commodities holdings of investment banks allow them to manipulate prices for essentials like oil and electricity.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lawmakers pressed the Federal Reserve on Wednesday to act more forcefully, and quickly, to limit banks’ involvement in the commodities business, which has been blamed for inflating prices on everyday items like electricity and canned beverages.

headline: Tensions Between Afghanistan and U.S. Increase as Airstrike Kills Civilians
abstract: A coalition airstrike in a province north of Kabul killed at least two villagers, prompting President Hamid Karzai to order an inquiry.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A coalition airstrike in a province north of Kabul killed at least two Afghan villagers on Wednesday morning, prompting President Hamid Karzai to order an official inquiry and escalating tensions yet again between the allies over civilian deaths.

headline: Video: Blending Into Her Scenery
abstract: “Your style is your art, so I definitely want to complement the area in which I live,” Isis Miller said of the Wynwood neighborhood of Miami.
lead_paragraph: For Isis Miller, style is not just self-expression. It’s her contribution to Wynwood. The Miami neighborhood is an area of concentrated creativity, where nearly every cafe, gallery and auto body shop displays elaborate and vivid street art.

headline: Pope Names Cardinals to Oversee Vatican Bank
abstract: Pope Francis replaced all but one of the appointees made by his predecessor, Benedict XVI, in another example of how the new pope is consolidating power.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Pope Francis continued shaking up the Vatican on Wednesday as he named new cardinals to an oversight commission for the troubled Vatican Bank, replacing all but one of the appointees made by his predecessor, Benedict XVI, in another example of how the new pope is consolidating power.

headline: The Gun Report: January 15, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning, a seventh-grader at Berrendo Middle School in Roswell, N.M., opened fire with a sawed-off shotgun, gravely injuring a 11-year-old boy and a 13-year-old girl.

headline: Consumers Can Check on Data Beyond Their Credit Reports
abstract: Specialty consumer reporting agencies that gather information for purposes like insurance underwriting must make it available to individuals.
lead_paragraph: You most likely know the drill when it comes to the importance of checking the accuracy of your credit report, which lenders review before deciding to make a loan or issue a credit card. Federal law allows you to get a free copy of it once a year.

headline: A Home in the Spanish Pyrenees
abstract: A property in the Val d’Aran, consisting of three traditional Pyrenean farm buildings, is on the market for $4.1 million.
lead_paragraph: A property in the Val d’Aran, consisting of three traditional Pyrenean farm buildings, is on the market for $4.1 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... the Spanish Pyrenees
abstract: Spain’s housing-market collapse hit the valley hard, with prices returning to 2003 levels, but also opened up a market once exclusive to the very rich.
lead_paragraph: A RENOVATED FARM COMPOUND IN THE VAL D’ARAN

headline: If Old Humans Grew Like Old Trees, Stand Back
keywords: ['Biology and Biochemistry', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Environment', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Trees and Shrubs']
abstract: A comprehensive tree survey finds that big old trees continue to grow at a rapid pace.
lead_paragraph: There’s a fascinating paper in Nature finding that big trees continue to grow fast even as they grow old. This makes them particularly valuable as carbon sinks, but it also leads to some fun “what if” thoughts, as summarized nicely by a United States Geological Survey news release, excerpted below.

headline: On Abortion-Free Speech Case, Justices Pull Out Tape Measure
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: A law setting a 35-foot buffer zone around reproductive-health clinics is under review.
lead_paragraph: The First Amendment protects the speech of short, elderly women and large and intimidating men equally, but you would be forgiven for thinking otherwise after oral arguments before the Supreme Court Wednesday morning. The case was McCullen v. Coakley, a challenge to a Massachusetts law setting a 35-foot buffer zone around reproductive-health clinics where abortions are performed.

headline: Governors Criticize Gridlock in Congress
abstract: The National Governors Association blamed political gridlock for the stymieing of numerous federal initiatives needed by the states, noting that its requests for 2013 and 2014 were nearly identical.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The nation’s governors criticized Congress on Wednesday for the political gridlock that they said had stymied passage of almost every federal initiative most needed by the states, and reiterated their calls for help from Washington.

headline: Video: Backcountry Snowboarders Prepare for the Worst
abstract: Jeremy Jones has been exploring and snowboarding remote mountain ranges for over two decades. To minimize risk, Jones and his fellow athletes continually refine their rescue skills.
lead_paragraph: “Higher Unplugged” looks at the making of the film “Higher,” which follows the snowboarder Jeremy Jones and the TGR crew as they ascend and ride peaks in Alaska, Wyoming, California and Nepal. Jones is a professional snowboarder who has been named big mountain rider of the year 10 times by Snowboarder magazine.

headline: App Smart: Journals
abstract: Keep track of your doings in 2014 with a suite of iOS and Android apps, including My Wonderful Days, Moleskine Journal and 1 Second Everyday.
lead_paragraph: Keep track of your doings in 2014 with a suite of iOS and Android apps, including My Wonderful Days, Moleskine Journal and 1 Second Everyday.

headline: Take 2014 a Day at a Time, Chronicling Each One
abstract: Apps let a user create an electronic journal, or just capture a highlight for each day.
lead_paragraph: After years of letting life fly by undocumented, I’ve resolved to keep better track of my doings in 2014. The idea is to use an app to record what I did, how it felt, where I was and so on — more reminders than diary. If you like the idea, there are many apps that can help.

headline: Skeptics Question Banks’ Bottom Lines
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: While Bank of America and Wells Fargo reported healthy profits in the last quarter, some observers are concerned that the banks are quickly depleting their rainy day funds.
lead_paragraph: Some banks cheer an improvement to their bottom lines, but a debate is brewing over the calculations used to get there.

headline: Another Florida Couple’s Possible Encounter With Movie-Theater Gunman
abstract: A Florida couple describes an eerily similar encounter in December at the same movie theater where a retired police officer was arrested on Monday for shooting and killing a man during an argument over texting.
lead_paragraph: A Florida couple said they believe they encountered a 71-year-old retired police captain in December at the same movie theater where police said he shot and killed a man and injured the man’s wife during an argument that began over texting.

headline: Catholicism and Cognitive Dissonance
abstract: Thinking through the liberal Catholic response to Pope Francis.
lead_paragraph: I’m written a bit about the question of what kind of reforms liberal Catholics should be actually be hoping for from Pope Francis, besides the good feelings that the pope’s rhetorical focus on social justice has inspired. In a deliberate provocation, Damon Linker raises the possibility that the good feelings are really all that the church’s liberal dissenters really want, because many of them just don’t think church teaching (or, for that matter, any kind of religious doctrine) matters anymore:

headline: Video Shows U.S. Soldier Long Held by Afghans
keywords: ['Prisoners of War', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A video of an American held captive for four and a half years has been obtained by the U.S. government, and officials said that it showed him in declining health.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A video of an American soldier held captive by Afghan insurgents for the past four and a half years is in the possession of the United States government, and officials said Wednesday that it showed the soldier, Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, alive but in declining health.

headline: The Dress Heard Round the World
abstract: An exhibition pays tribute to Diane von Furstenberg’s wrap, which introduced a new way to dress.
lead_paragraph: Edward Norton was just one in a throng of A-listers who arrived at the May Company Wilshire Building in Los Angeles last Friday, the scene of a party and exhibition celebrating the 40th birthday of Diane von Furstenberg’s emblematic wrap dress.

headline: Financier Says He’s Guilty of Everything but a Crime
abstract: Florian Homm, a former fund manager from Germany who faces extradition to the United States on security fraud, has willfully documented his rise and fall.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Defense lawyers almost always give the same advice to clients facing charges: Don’t say a word in public. That admonishment comes too late for Florian Homm.

headline: The Collections | The Top Five Fall/Winter 2014 Men’s Wear Shows in Milan
abstract: Our men’s fashion director shares his favorites from the runways in Milan.
lead_paragraph: At the fall/winter 2014 men’s shows in Milan, Italian tailoring continued to explore its softer side. Designers kept trousers trim and continued to show more casual wear, like the ones we saw in London last week. Here are the five best collections from the set.

headline: At JPMorgan’s Health Care Conference, Deal Talk Abounds
abstract: Few events are bigger in the world of corporate health care than JPMorgan Chase’s annual conference in San Francisco. And this year, much of the buzz seems to surround the prospect of more deals.
lead_paragraph: Few events are bigger in the world of corporate health care than JPMorgan Chase’s annual conference in San Francisco. And this year, much of the buzz seems to surround the prospect of more deals.

headline: Global Piracy Hits Lowest Level Since 2007, Report Says
abstract: The International Maritime Bureau attributed the drop mostly to a sharp decline in piracy off Somalia’s coast.
lead_paragraph: Global piracy at sea fell to the lowest level in six years in 2013, largely because of an international crackdown on pirate gangs that once operated with impunity off the coast of Somalia, a maritime monitoring organization reported on Wednesday.

headline: ‘Frozen’ Soundtrack Is No. 1 as Album Sales Continue to Fall
abstract: The soundtrack to Disney’s animated film “Frozen,” sold 86,000 copies, as the industry faced a grim sales tally from 2013.
lead_paragraph: The surprise and success of Beyoncé’s new album last month gave the music industry a feel-good story around the holidays. But now that the dust has settled, the hard reality of the state of music sales is clear once again.

headline: Below the Line: Shooting ‘Nebraska’
abstract: The cinematographer Phedon Papamichael discusses his work on “Nebraska.”
lead_paragraph: From “Sideways” to “The Descendants,” Alexander Payne’s movies have long created a strong sense of place. That trend continues in Mr. Payne’s latest film, “Nebraska.” Nebraska is Mr. Payne’s home state, and he has set four of his movies there.

headline: Ex-SAC Trader’s Drug Data a Surprise, Doctor Testifies
abstract: On the witness stand for a second day on Wednesday, Dr. Joel S. Ross told the jury that a former SAC Capital Advisors hedge fund manager, Mathew Martoma, knew the specific results of a clinical drug trial before they were publicly known.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors may not have any recorded conversations showing how a former SAC Capital Advisors trader, Mathew Martoma, engineered what they have called the biggest insider trading scheme in history. But testimony from one doctor indicates that Mr. Martoma knew the specific results of a clinical drug trial before they were known publicly.

headline: Cleaning Up Our E-Waste Mess
abstract: Traci Phillips of Tulsa, Okla., is in the business of recycling old cellphones, discarded laptops and other electronic waste, a fast-growing environmental problem.
lead_paragraph: Traci Phillips of Tulsa, Okla., is in the business of recycling old cellphones, discarded laptops and other electronic waste, a fast-growing environmental problem.

headline: Homes for $900,000
abstract: This week’s homes include a midcentury modern in Oregon, a cabin in Montana and a house on the Jersey Shore.
lead_paragraph: This week’s homes include a midcentury modern in Oregon, a cabin in Montana and a house on the Jersey Shore.

headline: What You Get for... $900,000
abstract: A midcentury modern in Oregon, a cabin in Montana and a house on the Jersey Shore.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, ORE.

headline: Shoring Up Those Fitness Resolutions
abstract: Why do so many New Year’s promises to exercise go pear-shaped?
lead_paragraph: January is the cruelest month, at least for those with good intentions to get fit. According to recent analyses of decades’ worth of exercise studies, many new exercise “intenders” will abandon their workout routines within two weeks of their New Year’s resolutions, and about half will quit by June. Even longtime exercisers feel the pull of physical entropy. In any given year, around a quarter of the people who had been working out dutifully will stop. (And about 2 percent of those who claim to have no intention of exercising actually start and continue, baffling researchers and possibly the exercisers themselves.)

headline: AOL Finds a Partner to Run Its Troubled Patch Division
abstract: The local news network has been a personal passion of AOL’s chief executive, Tim Armstrong, but also something of an albatross.
lead_paragraph: In May 2012, Tim Armstrong, the chief executive of AOL, promised restive investors that he would make Patch, the company’s local news division, profitable by the end of 2013. When the deadline arrived and Patch was still losing money, Mr. Armstrong promised to take on partners to share the cost.

headline: Should Mayor de Blasio Unravel Bloomberg's Reforms?
abstract: New York City's new schools chancellor, Carmen Fariña, is no Michael Bloomberg fan. Does this mean city schools are about to be overhauled again?

headline: The Stars’ Quirks Come Out
abstract: At the Golden Globes after-party at the Beverly Hilton hotel in Beverly Hills, Calif., stars displayed an assortment of personal quirks and others managed to party without incident.
lead_paragraph: Beverly Hills, Calif. — Security was viselike along the red carpet to the Beverly Hilton hotel last Sunday night, the setting of the Warner Brothers and InStyle Golden Globes after-party, which sped on at full throttle inside.

headline: Walking on a Bigger Runway
abstract: The Czech fashion model and former Victoria’s Secret Angel Karolina Kurkova is polishing her image as a celebrity.
lead_paragraph: The crowd in Central Park had swelled to 60,000 as Karolina Kurkova, the Czech fashion model and former Victoria’s Secret Angel, waited backstage at the second Global Citizens Festival, a star-studded concert last September. Scheduled to go on after Alicia Keys and her performance of “Girl on Fire,” Ms. Kurkova sang along with gusto from the wings.

headline: Harnessing Celebrity to Civil Rights Cause
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Books and Literature', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: In “How It Feels to Be Free,” Ruth Feldstein traces the impact of black female singers and actors in the civil rights movement.
lead_paragraph: Ruth Feldstein’s important new book, “How It Feels to Be Free: Black Women Entertainers and the Civil Rights Movement,” is an original exploration of the little-known but central role that black entertainers, especially black women, played in helping communicate and forward the movement’s goals. Lena Horne, Miriam Makeba, Nina Simone, Abbey Lincoln, Diahann Carroll and Cicely Tyson — the black women entertainers in this book — were popular at the height of an organized global struggle for black freedom, from around 1959 till the mid-1970s. They were influenced by this movement, even as they helped shape it.

headline: Cheating Accusations Among Officers Overseeing Nuclear Arms
keywords: ['Cheating', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Air Force officials said an investigation has revealed instances of cheating on proficiency tests by officers with the responsibility to launch nuclear weapons.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Air Force said on Wednesday that 34 officers responsible for launching the nation’s nuclear missiles had been suspended, and their security clearances revoked, for cheating on monthly proficiency tests that assess their knowledge of how to operate the warheads.

headline: City Opera Musicians and Singers to Play a Benefit Concert
abstract: The orchestra musicians and several of the principal singers of the New York City Opera will perform to commemorate the now-defunct company’s 70th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: The orchestra musicians and several of the principal singers of the New York City Opera have decided that the company’s 70th anniversary should be commemorated, bankruptcy and closing notwithstanding. And besides, the company’s demise has put its musicians out of work, and a concert honoring the anniversary seemed to them the proper way to address that.

headline: Federal Judge Upholds Health Care Subsidies
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: A judge’s ruling means that millions will be able to obtain health insurance subsidies, whether they buy coverage through the federal insurance exchange or one of the marketplaces run by the states.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge rejected a legal challenge on Wednesday to a central part of President Obama’s health care law, ruling that millions of low- and moderate-income people could obtain health insurance subsidies regardless of whether they bought coverage through the federal insurance exchange or in marketplaces run by the states.

headline: J.C. Penney to Close 33 Stores and Cut 2,000 Jobs
abstract: The retailer, one of America’s oldest, said the shuttering of the “underperforming” stores would save about $65 million a year.
lead_paragraph: In yet another sign of its deep slump, J. C. Penney Company said on Wednesday that it would close 33 stores across the country and shed about 2,000 jobs.

headline: In Advance of Oscar Nominations, What the Pundits Are Saying
abstract: Most are predicting the best-picture field will include “12 Years a Slave,” “American Hustle,” “Gravity” and “Captain Phillips,” but after that it gets interesting.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – There are mere hours to go before the Oscar nominations are at last revealed, which means that the hopefuls are beginning to sweat and the punditocracy is in a tizzy, revising and refining predictions.

headline: D.C. Lawmakers Advance Measure to Loosen Marijuana Law
abstract: A City Council committee sent the full Council a measure that would make possessing marijuana a civil, not criminal, violation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The District of Columbia on Wednesday moved closer to easing restrictions on marijuana, as city lawmakers advanced a measure that would decriminalize possession of up to one ounce of the drug.

headline: The Rube Goldberg Approach to Campaign Transparency
abstract: Print, scan, email, repeat. How senators file their campaign finance reports.
lead_paragraph: Myriad causes and crusades pursued by special interests on Capitol Hill are at stake in the fine print of the $1 trillion appropriations bill that Congress is finally managing to complete. Lobbyists are heartbroken — or not. Lisa Rosenberg falls into the former camp. She’s the government affairs consultant for the Sunlight Foundation in its long struggle to make the Senate abandon Dickensian ways of print and join the computer age, allowing constituents a far timelier look at campaign finance reports.

headline: The Wrong Guidepost on Unemployment
abstract: The official jobless rate does not represent the true slack in the labor market and should not be the basis of a decision on extending unemployment benefits, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Poetry Profiles: Coffee House Press
abstract: The publisher Chris Fischbach talks about poetry and his favorite books.
lead_paragraph: The latest in a series of occasional profiles of poetry publishers. These questions were answered by Chris Fischbach, a longtime editor at Coffee House Press who became publisher in 2011.

headline: How Banks Work, as Told by ABN Amro’s Chairman in Drag
abstract: To help explain ABN Amro’s core values this week, Gerrit Zalm dressed up as his “sister,” Priscilla, wearing a bright blue dress and a vivid red wig. Oh, and his fake sibling just happens to be a brothel owner.
lead_paragraph: In his former life as the finance minister for the Netherlands, Gerrit Zalm was known for his serious demeanor. But as chairman of ABN Amro, he has taken on a decidedly lighter tone on occasion.

headline: Westminster’s New Agility Trial to Include Mixed Breeds
abstract: The Westminster Kennel Club will stage its first agility championship on Feb. 8, at Pier 94, two days before its dog show begins at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: Alfie is an athletic, charming 7-year-old poodle-terrier who, because of his mixed heritage, cannot compete in the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show, which is for purebred dogs.

headline: In Defeat for Tea Party, House Passes $1.1 Trillion Spending Bill
keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: The 359-to-67 vote came as members shrugged off the angry threats of Tea Party activists and conservative groups.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House voted overwhelmingly on Wednesday, 359 to 67, to approve a $1.1 trillion spending bill for the current fiscal year, shrugging off the angry threats of Tea Party activists and conservative groups whose power has ebbed as Congress has moved toward fiscal cooperation.

headline: CUNY Picks James Milliken as New Chancellor
abstract: Mr. Milliken, the president of the University of Nebraska since 2004, will take over a system that is expanding but is troubled by large pockets of impoverished students.
lead_paragraph: The City University of New York, the country’s third largest public university system, turned to Nebraska for its next leader on Wednesday, choosing James B. Milliken, a onetime New York lawyer and longtime college administrator, as its chancellor.

headline: How to Choose an Air Travel Search Site
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Budget Travel', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Finding the best site to suit your specific budget, needs and preferences can be tricky. Here’s the Frugal Traveler’s guide to selecting the right site at the right time.
lead_paragraph: Which airline booking sites offer the cheapest airfares?

headline: With Dodgers, Clayton Kershaw Becomes First $200 Million Pitcher
abstract: Kershaw, who won two National League Cy Young Awards before turning 26 years old, becomes the first player ever with a contract averaging at least $30 million per season.
lead_paragraph: Clayton Kershaw won two National League Cy Young Awards, three earned run average titles and two strikeout titles and made three trips to the playoffs before turning 26 years old. Now he has another distinction: Kershaw is baseball’s first $200 million pitcher.

headline: Some Girls Just Know Things
abstract: In her solo show, “Bronx Gothic,” Okwui Okpokwasili shares a story of innocence and experience about two 11-year-old girls.
lead_paragraph: Before people are even seated for “Bronx Gothic” at Danspace Project, Okwui Okpokwasili is moving. Her back to the audience, she does a shimmying, herky-jerky kind of dance. It seems like a private ritual, a gathering of forces or, maybe, a summoning of the muse. And it goes on so long, 20 minutes or so, that you worry she’ll knock herself out. Or exhaust your patience.

headline: Romance Novelist Wins Big Valentine
abstract: Sylvia Day, the author of the “Crossfire” series of romance novels, will receive a substantial sum from St. Martin’s Press for her next two books.
lead_paragraph: St. Martin’s Press is making a very big bet that Americans are still hot and heavy for romance novels.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Haider Ackermann Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Virtuoso Poignancy Unfettered by Concepts
abstract: “La Bohème” returns to the Met and proves not much has changed in audience response to a Franco Zeffirelli staging from 1981.
lead_paragraph: For more than 30 years, the known quantity of attending Puccini’s “La Bohème” at the Metropolitan Opera has been Franco Zeffirelli’s colorful, minutely detailed and popular production. Audiences erupted with amazed ahs and applause when the curtain first went up in 1981 on the Act II scene depicting the Café Momus and the milling crowds (with some 240 choristers and extras) on a hilly street in the Latin Quarter of Paris. The audience did so again when “La Bohème” returned to the Met stage on Tuesday night.

headline: Tenement Museum to Expand Its Space and Programming in Nearby Building
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Museums', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Tenement Museum has announced a plan to expand its programming and space in new building a few doors down.
lead_paragraph: Visitors who enter 97 Orchard Street on the Lower East Side walk into a different century.

headline: Pictures of the Day: India and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Syria, Indonesia, Israel and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Indonesia, Israel and India.

headline: Carlyle Said to Strike Deal for Johnson & Johnson Testing Division
abstract: The Carlyle Group is near a deal to buy Johnson & Johnson’s clinical testing arm for about $4.1 billion, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The Carlyle Group has all but clinched a deal to buy Johnson & Johnson’s clinical testing arm for about $4.1 billion after several weeks of negotiations, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Dorsey on Disrupting Receipts, and Implications of the Net Neutrality Ruling
abstract: Wednesday’s highlights from around the web include Jack Dorsey, while pitching his payments start-up, Square, arguing that the receipt is an untapped “canvas” and “publishing medium.” Plus, why the network neutrality ruling on Tuesday could matter to start-ups.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Unkempt Yet Profound, a Cult Band Returns for More Interpretation
abstract: Touring again after a 15-year hiatus, Neutral Milk Hotel drew a crowd in Jersey City more than willing to be baffled all over again.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — After a 15-year absence, the reunited Neutral Milk Hotel could have satisfied its fans at the Loew’s Jersey Theater here on Tuesday night with a rote run-through of the music it recorded in the 1990s. But the band did more than that: It revved up and magnified all the impulses that collide in Jeff Mangum’s songs, which have continued to collect and baffle fans since Neutral Milk Hotel released its last studio album, “In the Aeroplane Over the Sea,” in 1998. The band used to play clubs; now it is headlining sold-out theaters.

headline: Woodson Offers Clues to Most Recent Benching of Smith
abstract: In a radio appearance on Wednesday, Coach Mike Woodson said J. R. Smith, whom he benched in Tuesday’s game, needed to “grow up” and “be more of a pro.”
lead_paragraph: The big mistake was to assume that there had been some resolution to the J. R. Smith soap opera. Instead, it continued after Coach Mike Woodson benched Smith in the Knicks’ loss to the Charlotte Bobcats on Tuesday night.

headline: 5 Years Later, Still Feeling Impact of Plane Down in the Hudson
abstract: A reporter remembers fearing the worst as he ran through the streets after a jetliner went down in frigid water.
lead_paragraph: Plane down in the Hudson. No sign of it at 42nd and 12th Avenue. Where was it? Moving downstream, or downtown, fast.

headline: Can Heavier People Really Be Healthier?
abstract: A new study questions the notion that being overweight or moderately obese lowers the risk of an early death, at least among patients with Type 2 diabetes.
lead_paragraph: Scientists call it the obesity paradox, the notion that being overweight or moderately obese lowers the risk of an early death. They have documented the phenomenon in large population studies and in groups of patients with chronic diseases like hypertension and Type 2 diabetes.

headline: Twenty Years On, an Icy Rivalry Still Has Heat
abstract: “The Price of Gold,” part of ESPN’s documentary series “30 for 30,” chronicles the figure-skating rivalry between Tonya Harding and Nancy Kerrigan.
lead_paragraph: “The Price of Gold,” making its debut on Thursday in ESPN’s “30 for 30” series, is a serious documentary about the 1994 kneecapping (to use President Obama’s word) of the figure skater Nancy Kerrigan by thugs who later said they were in league with her great rival, Tonya Harding.

headline: Lockout Over, Minnesota Orchestra Faces Challenges as It Salvages Its Season
abstract: A new contract agreement ended a long-running labor battle, but Minnesota Orchestra musicians will return to a leaderless ensemble.
lead_paragraph: The end of the corrosive 15-month lockout of the Minnesota Orchestra on Tuesday was greeted with relief by musicians, management and fans, who took to the “Save Our Symphony Minnesota” Facebook page and other websites to praise the impending return of music to Orchestra Hall.

headline: Times Minute | Why Birds Fly in V's
abstract: Also on the Minute, more relief aid for Syria and the model Karolina Kurkova's career beyond the runway.
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, more relief aid for Syria and the model Karolina Kurkova's career beyond the runway.

headline: Go Big and Tell the Truth
keywords: ["Men's Fashion Week", 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Men and Boys', 'Milan Fashion Week']
abstract: Those are the messages from the men’s shows in Milan.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — A woman, looking at the fall men’s shows here, feels cheated. Pullovers are big this season, but a woman would be lucky to find one in the vegetable-tone colors that Massimo Piombo offered, and with the nice touch of extra-wide ribbing, a detail that transformed his Shetlands into something special.

headline: What Do Students Need Most? More Sleep
abstract: I’m convinced that sleep is the single most important factor in ensuring my children’s health and academic success.
lead_paragraph: When I travel around to schools to speak to students, I deliver one line in my talk that kills, each and every time. The students do not simply laugh, they whoop and holler, throw their heads back in open-mouthed guffaws and shake their heads in disbelief. I would love to lay claim to the funniest educator joke of all time, but sadly, I don’t have that kind of comic game. I’m not even aiming for their funny bone when I proclaim, “In order to function at your mental and physical best, adolescents should be getting at least nine hours of sleep a night.”

headline: Detroit Symphony Agrees to New Contract With Musicians
abstract: The three-year agreement, settled eight months before the old contract expires, will give musicians modest raises each year.
lead_paragraph: The Detroit Symphony Orchestra, which endured a bitter six-month strike a few years ago, settled its latest contract eight months early, orchestra officials announced Wednesday.

headline: Not So Golden
abstract: Tweeters weighed in on the show.
lead_paragraph: It was not a particularly good night for women over 60 at the Golden Globes on Sunday, and not just because Meryl Streep (64) lost to Amy Adams (39), Judi Dench (79) lost to Cate Blanchett (44), and June Squibb (84) lost to Jennifer Lawrence (23).

headline: ‘Hustle,’ ‘Gravity’ and ‘Slave’ Jump to Fore in Oscar Race
abstract: The most Academy Award nominations went to three very different best picture possibilities: “Gravity” and “American Hustle,” with 10 in all, and “12 Years a Slave,” with nine.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Oscar voters set up a three-way slugfest on Thursday, with the visual wizardry and box office might of “Gravity” going up against the historical heft of “12 Years a Slave” and the 1970s-era hairdos and cleavage of “American Hustle.”

headline: The (Auction) House Doesn’t Always Win
abstract: As Christie’s, Sotheby’s and others vie to lure sellers of big-name artworks, analysts wonder if the houses are running oversize risks.
lead_paragraph: When Christie’s sold Jeff Koons’s “Balloon Dog (Orange)” for $58.4 million in November, it seemed as if the auction house had just earned a pretty penny.

headline: Raf Simons: Fall 2014 Menswear
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Even Jeans Need a Break Once in a While
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Handbags and Purses', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Jewels and Jewelry']
abstract: Six essentials to help give your denim a rest; Longchamp celebrates the Year of the Horse; the jeweler Melissa Joy Manning opens a New York store; minimalist sneakers at Dover Street Market.
lead_paragraph: So, jeans are over? It was announced last week that Gwen Stefani was collaborating with Michael Glasser, the man behind 7 for All Mankind and other denim labels, on a line of nondenim pants, the aim being to replace the jeans in our closets with casual, sort-of-slouchy trousers. Unlikely as it is that we’ll be jettisoning our jeans anytime soon, it could be said that, in 2014, they do look a little ... safe. Should you want to give your precious denim a break, here are our six style essentials: 1. black trousers with a bit of souped-up detail, like this Acne pair with knee patches, to wear interchangeably with black jeans; 2. prints that could be crazy vacation pants but also cool with a big sweater and parka on the weekend; 3. leather in a new relaxed shape; 4. pants in an unexpected color, for work and beyond; 5. cropped pants to wear with heels (a little ankle is always sexy); and 6. a chic pair of white pants, for evening.

headline: Buyer of $142.4 Million Bacon Triptych Identified as Elaine Wynn
abstract: Art world sources say the buyer was Ms. Wynn, the ex-wife of Stephen A. Wynn, the Las Vegas casino owner.
lead_paragraph: The mystery began the moment a telephone bidder bought Francis Bacon’s triptych “Three Studies of Lucian Freud” for $142.4 million at Christie’s New York in November.

headline: Trials for U.S. World Youth Team
abstract: Jimmy Wang, Erli Zhou, Edmund Wu and William Zhu had two chances to qualify for the under-26 open event.
lead_paragraph: At the trials to select the United States entries for this year’s World Youth Teams Championships in Istanbul, Jimmy Wang, Erli Zhou, Edmund Wu and William Zhu had two chances to qualify for the under-26 open event. After losing the USA-1 final to Adam Kaplan, Zach Brescoll, Marius Agica, Owen Lien, and the brothers Adam and Zach Grossack, they played 48 boards against the winners of the match between the losing semifinalists: Greg Herman, Anam Tebha, Drew Cavalier and Alex Hudson.

headline: Walking in Paint-Spattered Footsteps
abstract: Lisa Cooley, a young gallery owner views the exhibition on Ileana Sonnabend at the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Cooley stood for a moment, a crowd of museumgoers swarming around her, looking at a black-and-white photograph of Jasper Johns paintings installed at the Galerie Ileana Sonnabend in Paris in 1962. But when she spoke, it was not about the quality of the work displayed, the era in which it was made or even about the artist who created it.

headline: Emails Raising Questions About the Polanski Case
abstract: Los Angeles County Superior Court emails show some judges’ fears and some thoughts behind decision making.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Internal court emails have raised new questions about the conduct of the judges in the statutory rape case against the film director Roman Polanski.

headline: Public Hospitals Hope to Attract More Upscale Patients Under Affordable Care Act
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hospitals']
abstract: The health exchanges created under the Affordable Care Act have given public health systems an opportunity to attract more upscale patients.
lead_paragraph: Todd Obolsky lives in a studio apartment in Manhattan, drives a leased Toyota Corolla and occasionally splurges on experimental cuisine in the East Village. When the Affordable Care Act allowed him to buy insurance for the first time in years, he was so price-sensitive that $30 a month made a difference in which plan he picked.

headline: After Hours | A Bronx Schoolyard Rivalry, Told Through Dance
abstract: “Bronx Gothic,” a one-woman show by the performance artist Okwui Okpokwasili at COIL 2014, is a fraught, semi-autobiographical tale.
lead_paragraph: The new year is kicking off with a host of dance and performance festivals, including Abrons Arts Center’s American Realness, the Public Theater’s Under the Radar and P.S. 122’s Coil. Last night, at Danspace Project, Coil debuted “Bronx Gothic,” a mesmerizing and sometimes harrowing solo piece, long in the making, by the writer and dance artist Okwui Okpokwasili. Raised in the Bronx by Nigerian immigrant parents, Okpokwasili has collaborated with the conceptual artist and choreographer Ralph Lemon and appeared in films including “I Am Legend.” She begins this show even before the audience has settled in, quaking in a corner, her back to the crowd.

headline: Pointing a Finger on Facebook
abstract: A journalist lands in the hot seat after he outs a congressman in a blind Facebook post.
lead_paragraph: Itay Hod has been a journalist for more than 15 years. He has reported on health issues for NY1, done segments for CBS News on gay rights, covered the Oscars for Logo, and written articles for The Daily Beast about lesbian pornographers and “American Idol” winners.

headline: Baryshnikov Plans Fund-Raising to Give Artists Space
abstract: Mikhail Baryshnikov is opening a fund-raising effort to give artists a space to work in Manhattan, through fellowships named for Merce Cunningham and John Cage.
lead_paragraph: Mikhail Baryshnikov, the founder and artistic director of the Baryshnikov Arts Center, is opening a campaign to raise $1 million for artistic fellowships named for the composer John Cage (1912-92) and the choreographer Merce Cunningham (1919-2009). The effort, to be announced on Thursday, is intended to give artists a place to work, specifically in Studio 6A, a 43-foot-by-43-foot top-floor space at the Baryshnikov Center in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: After Crisis, Iceland Holds a Tight Grip on Its Banks
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Iceland is a living experiment in what can happen when a country forces its financial firms to go under, rather than bailing them out.
lead_paragraph: REYKJAVIK, Iceland — An angular glass building on the waterfront here used to be the headquarters of a banking giant with operations in Europe, North America and the Middle East.

headline: Obama's Remarks in North Carolina
abstract: During a visit to Raleigh, President Obama spoke about manufacturing.
lead_paragraph: During a visit to Raleigh, President Obama spoke about manufacturing.

headline: How to Make Smart Televisions a Little Less Dumb
abstract: Television makers still don’t understand that consumers don’t want a larger, thinner TV, but rather better software to help them manage the deluge of content now available on screens.
lead_paragraph: They all looked the same. Rectangular, thin, bright and blaring.

headline: That Nose, That Chin, Those Lips
abstract: Some people take their admiration for a celebrity’s looks straight to the operating room.
lead_paragraph: When Nino Dean looks in the mirror, the face staring back at him is eerily evocative of Vanessa Paradis, the French chanteuse and former paramour of Johnny Depp.

headline: Beauty News
abstract: A new nail boutique opens, as does a spa; for some gym members, there is now a blow-dry bar.
lead_paragraph: With the new year comes a number of new ways to pamper yourself.

headline: A.P. Cameraman Detained in Egypt After His Images Appear on Al Jazeera
abstract: A cameraman covering the constitutional referendum in Egypt for The Associated Press was arrested on Wednesday while transmitting live video from a polling place in Cairo.
lead_paragraph: A cameraman covering the constitutional referendum in Egypt for The Associated Press was arrested on Wednesday while transmitting live video from a polling place in Cairo.

headline: Police Chief Says 12-Year-Old Gunman Planned Attack in New Mexico
abstract: An eighth-grade social studies teacher is being lauded as a hero for approaching the 12-year-old gunman and telling him to drop the gun. The suspect did.
lead_paragraph: The head of the state police in New Mexico said Wednesday that the 12-year-old suspect in the shooting at a Roswell middle school had planned the attack but chose his victims at random. Two students, an 11-year-old boy and a 13-year-old girl, were seriously wounded after they were shot inside the school’s gym around 8 a.m. Tuesday.

headline: Openings and Events for the Week of Jan. 16
abstract: The Manhattan Vintage Show returns with “Almost Dior: America’s Stamp on the New Look.”
lead_paragraph: Openings and Events

headline: H.I.V.-Positive Person, Told Otherwise, Is Being Sought
abstract: Walter Reed National Military Medical Center made a false H.I.V.-negative finding after a mix-up of blood samples.
lead_paragraph: For the last six weeks, Walter Reed National Military Medical Center has been engaged in a highly unusual effort to identify an individual who is H.I.V. positive but was wrongly informed that he or she was H.I.V. negative after a mix-up of blood samples taken at the hospital.

abstract: Top editors discussed columns by The Post’s media critic that criticize a reporter at Politico.
lead_paragraph: Top editors at The Washington Post and Politico tried on Wednesday to mend a rift between the two news organizations.
