headline: The Global Village Rolled Up in a Carpet
abstract: Lucky, a rug by a Dutch designer in Shanghai inspired by the culture of northern Brazil, was recently introduced in Germany.
lead_paragraph: This week at the International Furniture Fair in Cologne, Germany, Danskina, the Dutch rug company, is presenting its first collection under its new design director, Hella Jongerius.

headline: Look Before You Climb
abstract: Maison Martin Margiela’s latest trompe l’oeil wallcovering looks very much like a staircase.
lead_paragraph: Maison Martin Margiela, the Paris-based fashion house founded by the reclusive Belgian designer, who parted ways with the business in 2009, has an idiosyncratic, avant-garde style that can go anywhere. Collaborating with L’Atelier d’Exercices, a French company, the design team is producing objects for the home that mix irony, mystery and humor, such as eggs filled with fortune-cookie-type messages and a melted wax candleholder. One of the group’s favored memes is trompe l’oeil, and it has created a series of black-and-white photographs of architectural details, which are printed on an easily repositioned adhesive fabric. The latest, an atmospheric staircase, would add wit and misdirection to any room and bring a new dimension to a cramped studio apartment. The mural measures 7.4 feet by 3.9 feet and is $320. Information: 888-266-1737 or sweetbellausa.com. or at Top Hat, 245 Broome Street, 212-677-4240.

headline: Where Are the Jellyfish, Exactly?
abstract: A rooftop swimming pool gives a Spanish vacation home its name.
lead_paragraph: How to add a swimming pool with an ocean view to an inland suburban retreat? Put it on the roof. When designing the Jellyfish House, a summer home for a Dutch family in the coastal town of Marbella, Spain, Wiel Arets, an architect with offices in the Netherlands and Switzerland, turned the pool into a central feature of the three-story building by elevating it.

headline: Perfection By the Book
abstract: “Promise Land,” by Jessica Lamb-Shapiro tries to make sense of self-help, from the dawn of religion to modern home management.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Lamb-Shapiro began writing her new book, “Promise Land” (Simon & Schuster; $25), as a way to make sense of the immense body of self-help literature, from the dawn of religion to modern home management. Wildly funny, it takes a few dark turns as well.

headline: Pro-Progressive Is Better Than Anti-Christie
abstract: Instead of rooting for a bridge to drag the governor under, people should focus on the issues that will matter in the 2016 elections.
lead_paragraph: We’re a week into Chris Christie Bridgegate and I’m already bored, not because I don’t think the truth should be ferreted out in the bright light of day, but because the political discussion about it appears to be devolving into pettiness.

headline: The Power Behind the Throne
abstract: What you’ll need to replace your toilet.
lead_paragraph: What you’ll need to replace your toilet.

headline: Whose Mall Is It?
keywords: ['Youth', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Shopping Centers and Malls']
abstract: The Brazilian elite see favela-dwelling vagrants. I see ordinary teenagers.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — LAST Saturday, security officers stopped two tall young black men at the entrance of JK Iguatemi, a luxury shopping mall in São Paulo. The young men were wearing flashy tennis shoes and brand-new soccer jerseys. “What are you doing here?” I heard the guards ask. “We came to buy something,” explained one. “My cousin here is a soccer player. From Bragantino.”

headline: Seizing the Throne
abstract: Fixing a toilet is not hard when you know all the dos and don’ts. Just ask Oprah.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago the strangest thing happened with two of our toilets. The water level on both lagged well below normal, even though the pipes were clear. We assumed that the problem was in our septic system. Our plumber suspected otherwise.

headline: Walmart Is Facing Claims That It Fired Protesters
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Organized Labor', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: A complaint filed by the National Labor Relations Board says employees in several states were disciplined or fired after striking for better pay.
lead_paragraph: The National Labor Relations Board, in a sweeping complaint filed on Wednesday, said that Walmart illegally disciplined and fired employees after strikes and protests for better pay.

headline: Cultivating Hudson: Enter the Tastemakers
abstract: The New York river town has always been on the verge of something. It’s now rising again, betting on new arrivals and the “Marina” effect.
lead_paragraph: HUDSON, N.Y. — Ann Marie Gardner has a buzzword for the “urban-rural confluence” she sees fueling this town’s most recent boomlet as a cultural hub. “Rurbanism,” as she describes it, is when urban expats bring their cultural touchstones and appetites with them when they move to a place like Hudson.

headline: Puzzle of Super Bowl Security Has to Include New Pieces
keywords: ['Football', 'Super Bowl', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Police', 'Security and Warning Systems']
abstract: This year, the challenges of securing the Super Bowl will extend far beyond the game site in East Rutherford, N.J., across state lines and multiple jurisdictions.
lead_paragraph: As is the case for other major sporting events, securing the Super Bowl is a complex and nerve-racking task that involves the coordination of many law enforcement agencies, the use of technologies like cameras and radiation detectors, and the identification of potential troublemakers.

headline: The Coldest Yard
abstract: Why football fans should root for a frigid and snowy Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — IF I were to attack you and slam you to the ground as you stood in line for your morning coffee, you might not get up. But if I put a helmet on you and put you on a football field, then did the exact same thing, you’d pop up and ask for another. There is something powerful about football, something that grants men temporary invincibility, makes them immune to pain and anguish.

headline: Sheila Guyse, Singer and Star in ‘Race Movies,’ Dies at 88
abstract: Ms. Guyse appeared on Broadway and in so-called race movies of the 1940s and ’50s. She also recorded an album of standards for MGM.
lead_paragraph: Sheila Guyse, a popular actress and singer who appeared on Broadway and in so-called race movies in the 1940s and ’50s, and who for a time, despite limited opportunities in the entertainment industry, appeared headed for broader fame, died on Dec. 28 in Honolulu. She was 88.

headline: Have Your Job and Moonlight, Too
abstract: Ad agencies add side projects to tap the entrepreneurial spirit of employees who have creative energy to spare.
lead_paragraph: ALMOST a century ago, a hit song lamented the difficulty in persuading American soldiers who saw the world during the Great War to return to their rural homes. The title said it all: “How Ya Gonna Keep ’Em Down on the Farm? (After They’ve Seen Paree).”

headline: Weighing In at the End
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Design', 'Rock and Stone', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Ted Muehling’s polished quartz stones are part of a new collection of memorial objects from Three-Fourths of an Ounce.
lead_paragraph: Three-Fourths of an Ounce, a new line of condolence products including memorial candles and jewelry, is named after measurements taken by the early 1900s Massachusetts doctor Duncan MacDougall. After studying terminally ill people and euthanized dogs, he concluded that a body lost three-quarters of an ounce at the moment of death, so a soul must weigh that much. (Scientists, however, have since discredited his methods and data.) The designer Ted Muehling has contributed polished quartz ovals ($200 each) that weigh, yes, 0.75 ounces. His staff grinds the stones at a workshop behind his Manhattan boutique, on machines with wet sandpaper wheels that emit mournful sounds as they spin. Mr. Muehling, who was brought up Catholic, said the translucent stones remind him of his childhood image of the soul as an internal vapor that grows cloudier with every sin. The polished talismans are also ecumenically reminiscent of crystal orbs that Buddhist temple statues carry and pebbles that Jews place on gravestones. Information: 3-4oz.com.

headline: Theft at Target Leads Citi to Replace Debit Cards
abstract: Citibank is the second major bank to replace cards since the data breach was disclosed last month.
lead_paragraph: Citibank plans to reissue all customer debit cards involved in the data breach at Target, making it the second major bank to do so since the attack was disclosed last month.

headline: Sales at Ralo Tibet Carpet, Jayson Home and Others
keywords: ['Discount Selling', 'Carpets and Rugs', 'Furniture', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Bargains on rugs, furniture and more.
lead_paragraph: During Ralo Tibet Carpet’s warehouse sale, through Sunday, many rugs are up to 70 percent off (a 6-by-9-foot Trellis Red rug, regularly $7,130, is $3,565); 29 Howard Street (Broadway), 212-966-7661, tibetcarpet.com.

headline: Pendant Lamps: Theater of Suspension
abstract: How to create drama in a room without adding clutter.
lead_paragraph: Will Meyer and Gray Davis consider themselves “maniacs” about the lighting in the spaces they design. If nothing else, Mr. Meyer, 45, said, “It needs to make people look attractive.”

headline: Should We Install Underfloor Heat in the Bathroom?
abstract: It’s a selling feature, but there are less expensive ways to take off the chill.
lead_paragraph: Q. Our bathroom is always colder than the rest of our house. Should we install underfloor radiant heating when we remodel?

headline: Giants Fire Two Longtime Assistants
abstract: The Giants’ offensive shake-up continued as their tight ends coach, Mike Pope, and their running backs coach, Jerald Ingram, were let go.
lead_paragraph: The sweeping shake-up of the Giants’ offensive brain trust continued Wednesday when the longtime assistants Mike Pope and Jerald Ingram were fired.

headline: Yahoo Parts Ways With Its No. 2 Executive
abstract: Yahoo, which has lost ground to competitors in recent years, tersely announced that Henrique de Castro would step down as chief operating officer.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Yahoo’s No. 2 executive, Henrique de Castro, has been fired by his boss, Marissa Mayer, a little more than a year after she wooed him away from Google to help her turn around the struggling Internet company.

headline: Federal Contracts Plunge, Squeezing Private Companies
abstract: In the 2013 fiscal year, total federal contracts fell by $58 billion, or roughly 11 percent, the steepest decline in at least a decade.
lead_paragraph: The big business of Washington — federal contract work — is losing some steam.

headline: Phones in Subway: On Elevated Lines, Hear the Future
abstract: New York City subway officials hope to expand cellphone reception to all underground trains, but the practice has persisted for years on the city’s elevated lines.
lead_paragraph: Slang and Mandarin commingle on the No. 7 line during the evening rush, and teenagers arrange their meeting spots by text on the N at Coney Island, the Wonder Wheel rising through train car windows at sunset.

headline: Far West Got Drier Last Year, Data Shows
abstract: Although 2013 was a wetter than average year for the contiguous 48 states, scientists said, that statistic masked sharp regional differences.
lead_paragraph: Drought conditions in California and elsewhere in the Far West intensified last year, government scientists said Wednesday, adding to concerns about water supplies in the region.

headline: Lebanese Bomber’s Death, and Life, Leave Questions
abstract: Qutaiba al-Satem, implicated in a bombing, has become the face of what many Lebanese fear: citizens radicalized by the Syrian conflict. But in the village where he grew up, the picture is murkier.
lead_paragraph: HNAIDER, Lebanon — The last time his mother saw him, he joined the family for dawn prayers as usual. A few hours later, the 19-year-old engineering student had vanished. No one saw him leave, his cellphone was off and text messages went unanswered.

headline: Ken Landwehr, Who Played Key Role in Capture of Serial Killer, Dies at 59
abstract: Lieutenant Landwehr, a homicide detective in Wichita, Kan., played a pivotal role in the capture of the serial killer known as B.T.K.
lead_paragraph: Lt. Ken Landwehr, a homicide detective in Wichita, Kan., who played a pivotal role in the capture of the serial killer known as B.T.K., whose terrorizing spree went unredressed for more than 30 years, died at his home on Monday in Wichita. He was 59.

headline: In N.F.L. Suit, Judge Flags Provision Protecting N.C.A.A.
abstract: The judge in the concussion settlement case took exception to a clause that would keep players who receive a cash payout from suing the N.C.A.A.
lead_paragraph: The federal judge who rejected the N.F.L.’s concussion lawsuit settlement Tuesday raised a fundamental concern about the deal: whether the $765 million set aside for payouts and medical testing would be enough over the suit’s 65-year life.

headline: The State of the Speeches
keywords: ['States (US)', 'Governors (US)', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Heroin', 'State of the State Message (NJ)']
abstract: It’s that time of year when one governor after another takes to the podium. Listen up, people!
lead_paragraph: Let’s discuss state of the state speeches.

headline: New York City to Pay $18 Million Over Convention Arrests
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Republican National Convention', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: The settlement resolves civil rights lawsuits filed on behalf of roughly 1,600 people who were arrested during the 2004 Republican National Convention.
lead_paragraph: New York City will pay nearly $18 million to settle civil rights lawsuits filed on behalf of roughly 1,600 people who claimed they were wrongfully swept up in mass arrests during the 2004 Republican National Convention, lawyers for the city and plaintiffs said on Wednesday.

headline: U.S. to Expand Rules Limiting Use of Profiling by Federal Agents
abstract: The new rules will prohibit federal agents from considering religion, national origin, gender and sexual orientation in their investigations, a government official said.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department will significantly expand its definition of racial profiling to prohibit federal agents from considering religion, national origin, gender and sexual orientation in their investigations, a government official said Wednesday.

headline: Dissent, Guns & Ammo
abstract: A respected columnist was dismissed from the magazine after he wrote that the right to bear arms needs to be subjected to legitimate regulation.
lead_paragraph: It was a rare peek behind the Oz-like curtain of gun journalism in its role as the gun industry’s mouthpiece: A respected columnist was dismissed from Guns & Ammo magazine in October after he dared to write the obvious — that all constitutional rights, including the right to bear arms, are and “need to be” subject to legitimate regulation. This was heresy for Second Amendment absolutists.

headline: False Reasons for Filibustering Jobless Aid
abstract: Republicans do not believe that job-seekers who have been out of work for six months or longer deserve government assistance.
lead_paragraph: Republican senators are pulling out every fake excuse they can think of for filibustering an extension of jobless benefits for the long-term unemployed on Tuesday. The majority leader, Harry Reid, was mean to us and wouldn’t let us offer amendments, they say. Democrats refused to pay for the benefits. It’s President Obama’s fault people can’t find work because he won’t approve the Keystone XL oil pipeline.

headline: Hauling Bags and Cleaning Planes for Little Pay and No Vacations of Their Own
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs', 'AIRPORTS']
abstract: Workers at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey’s three airports, who used to work directly for the airlines, toil for little pay, and have no unions, vacation days or pensions.
lead_paragraph: Norman Echeverri’s life once glowed with promise. He held a job at a company in Medellín, Colombia, had a car, laughed, played cards with friends.

headline: Chinese Activists Test New Leader and Are Crushed
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: An anti-corruption group was heartened when China’s new president, Xi Jinping, came to power in 2012. Since then, their ideals have collided with a harsh reality.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The 20 or so activists gathered at an isolated guesthouse on the outskirts of the capital, leaving their cellphones behind to avoid detection by the police. China’s first leadership change in a decade was fast approaching, and the group saw an opening for a movement to fight injustice and official corruption.

headline: A Disappointing Internet Decision
abstract: Regulators should rewrite rules to keep broadband networks impartial on content.
lead_paragraph: In a discouraging ruling, a federal appeals court on Tuesday struck down regulations that prohibited phone and cable companies from charging different rates for delivering different types of content to consumers or even blocking certain content.

headline: A Culture of Violence
abstract: In the South Pacific island nation of Papua New Guinea, one of the world’s most violent places, nearly every woman has experienced some form of domestic abuse.
lead_paragraph: In the South Pacific island nation of Papua New Guinea, one of the world’s most violent places, nearly every woman has experienced some form of domestic abuse.

headline: Mixed Results for Mideast Democracy
abstract: Two Arab countries, Egypt and Tunisia, are moving in radically different directions.
lead_paragraph: A constitution is supposed to be a set of governing principles around which citizens can unite and peacefully build a democratic state. Tunisia is providing a constructive path to this goal. Egypt is not. Sadly, Egypt is on the verge of enacting a Constitution that would effectively legitimize last year’s coup and further enable the kind of authoritarian system that the 2011 revolution was intended to displace.

headline: Long-Running D.C. Show Faces a Major Plot Twist
abstract: The landlord and congressman who owns the house that inspired the series “Alpha House” is retiring, and the future of the arrangement is unknown.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — This week’s news that Representative George Miller, Democrat of California, is planning to retire at the end of the year reverberated around the House of Representatives, where Mr. Miller has served since 1975.

headline: Fuchsia Would Have Killed Her
abstract: To please a friend, a designer with an aversion to color decided she could stomach turquoise.
lead_paragraph: To please a friend, a designer with an aversion to color decided she could stomach turquoise.

headline: Just for You, Blue
abstract: To please a friend, a designer with an aversion to color decided she could stomach turquoise.
lead_paragraph: What do you do when you love bright color but don’t want to be overwhelmed by it? Hire a designer who works almost entirely in white.

headline: A Fine Line Between Summer Sizzle and Too Darn Hot
keywords: ['Weather', 'World Cup 2014 (Soccer)', 'Australian Open (Tennis)', 'Temperature', 'Olympic Games', 'World Cup 2022 (Soccer)', 'Seasons and Months', 'Tennis', 'Athletics and Sports']
abstract: The Australian Open is not the first event held in extreme heat: sports organizations have been ignoring high temperatures for years, paying little regard to athletes.
lead_paragraph: As the soccer world sweats and frets at the prospect of a summer World Cup in Qatar, the rest of the sports world gets on with business at usual: making elite athletes perform in extreme heat.

headline: Illinois: Diocese Releases Papers on Abuse by Priests
abstract: The Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago released 6,000 pages of documents on sexually abusive priests on Wednesday to victims’ lawyers.
lead_paragraph: The Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago released 6,000 pages of documents on sexually abusive priests on Wednesday to victims’ lawyers. The files pertain to 30 priests, 14 of whom are dead and all removed from ministry. Most of the abuse occurred before the mid-1990s. The archdiocese said in a statement that it “did not hide abuse or protect abusers,” and that it reported all the cases to the civil authorities. But victims’ lawyers said the documents showed a pattern of covering up. The archdiocese agreed to release the documents in 2006 during settlements with victims, but it took eight years to negotiate thedetails. The lawyers plan to release the documents next week.

headline: Obama on Surveillance Through the Years
abstract: Throughout his political career, President Obama has expressed a range of views on balancing national security needs with personal rights and freedoms.
lead_paragraph: Throughout his political career, President Obama has expressed a range of views on balancing national security needs with personal rights and freedoms.

headline: As Inquiry Widens, Port Authority Chief May Lose His Low Profile
abstract: David Samson’s role in the aftermath of the bridge scandal and his ties to Gov. Chris Christie, who appointed him, are expected to receive close scrutiny by a new investigative panel.
lead_paragraph: He has been a close adviser to three New Jersey governors and was appointed state attorney general by a fourth. He was a co-founder of one of the state’s largest law firms. And for two years he has led the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Yet outside of New Jersey political and legal circles, David Samson, 74, has steadfastly maintained a low profile.

headline: How Brave Girls Helped Crack a Taboo
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Domestic Violence', "Women's Rights", 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: This 11-year-old was raped by her grandfather for years. Now, with some help from advocates, she is turning the table on her abuser.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — For a window into rape culture, consider an 11-year-old girl named Flevian, who says that her grandfather has been raping her almost daily since she was in the first grade.

headline: Obama’s Path From Critic to Overseer of Spying
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: In 2007, Barack Obama described a surveillance state run amok. He is now the leader of a surveillance state that some of his own advisers think has gotten out of control.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As a young lawmaker defining himself as a presidential candidate, Barack Obama visited a center for scholars in August 2007 to give a speech on terrorism. He described a surveillance state run amok and vowed to rein it in. “That means no more illegal wiretapping of American citizens,” he declared. “No more national security letters to spy on citizens who are not suspected of a crime.”

headline: What Some Waiters Never See
abstract: In which Elizabeth A, Long is very careful with her construction.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Solving crossword puzzles sometimes feels to me like I’m watching a magic trick being performed. If it’s a particularly clever idea, like the one we have today by Elizabeth A. Long, you might even want to applaud when you tumble to the trick or get to the reveal.

headline: School in India Ensnared in U.S. Diplomatic Spat
keywords: ['Americans Abroad', 'United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Private and Sectarian Schools']
abstract: The American Embassy School, popular with expatriates in New Delhi, is facing questions from the Indian government in the latest volley in its diplomatic spat with the United States.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A handout for new teachers at this city’s exclusive American Embassy School, an academic oasis for children of American diplomats and other expatriates, offers some unusual guidance to female teachers whose husbands will also be teaching at the school.

headline: Israel’s Efforts to Limit Use of Holocaust Terms Raise Free-Speech Questions
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'ANTI-SEMITISM']
abstract: A measure making it a crime to call someone a Nazi battles the trivialization of an atrocity, but not everyone agrees that this is the way to proceed.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel is on the brink of banning the N-word. N as in Nazi, that is.

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on January 16, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Van Is Found; Ties to Killing Are Sought
abstract: A minivan found in Brooklyn fit the description of the one used in the kidnapping and murder of Menachem Stark, a developer.
lead_paragraph: Investigators have located a minivan they believe may have been used to abduct a Brooklyn real estate developer who was killed this month, the police said on Wednesday.

headline: Winning Powerball and Lottery Numbers for Jan. 15, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Los Angeles Museum Names a New Director
abstract: The Museum of Contemporary Art ended weeks of intense speculation by confirming that Philippe Vergne, of the Dia Art Foundation, has been chosen as its new director to replace Jeffrey Deitch.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After a six-month search that fueled intense speculation, the Museum of Contemporary Art here has confirmed that Philippe Vergne, director of the Dia Art Foundation in New York, has been chosen as its new director.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, January 16, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Thursday, January 16, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve kept them warm when it’s cold, I’ve kept them dry when it’s wet, and I’ve fed them when they’re hungry.”

headline: A Quandary for Mexico as Vigilantes Rise
keywords: ['Vigilantes', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Drug Cartels']
abstract: In Michoacán State, where vigilantes battle drug cartel gunmen, Mexican officials face a decision on whether to disarm the loosely organized groups or allow them to continue fighting.
lead_paragraph: ANTÚNEZ, Mexico — Word spread quickly: The army was coming to disarm the vigilante fighters whom residents viewed as conquering heroes after they swept in and drove out a drug gang that had stolen property, extorted money and threatened to kill them. They even had to leave flowers and other offerings at a shrine to the gang’s messianic leader.

headline: Cuomo Has Raised Over $33 Million for Re-election Bid
abstract: The size of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s war chest exceeds what he spent on his entire 2010 campaign, and it highlights the challenge that a Republican opponent would face.
lead_paragraph: As he prepares to seek re-election in November, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has already amassed more than $33 million to finance his bid for a second term, his campaign team said on Wednesday.

headline: Early Tallies Show Revised Charter Passing in Egypt
abstract: A revised Constitution validating the military takeover in Egypt appeared headed for approval, according to early tabulations, as international monitors questioned the fairness of the vote.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A revised Constitution validating the military takeover in Egypt this past summer appeared headed for lopsided approval by more than 90 percent of the votes cast, according to early tabulations in the official and private news media on Thursday, as international monitors raised alarms about the fairness of the plebiscite.

headline: Workers at an Amazon Warehouse Reject Forming a Union
abstract: A small group of technical workers at the Amazon warehouse in Middletown, Del., voted overwhelmingly against joining the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers.
lead_paragraph: In the first unionization vote ever held at an Amazon facility in the United States, a small group of technical workers at the company’s warehouse in Middletown, Del., voted overwhelmingly on Wednesday against forming a union.

headline: De Blasio Announces Steps to Reduce Traffic Deaths
abstract: In a major victory for pedestrian and cycling advocates, Mayor Bill de Blasio set a goal of bringing the number of traffic deaths “literally” to zero.
lead_paragraph: Along a Queens corridor busy with traffic, Mayor Bill de Blasio took a moment on Wednesday to stand at the memorial of an 8-year-old boy killed by a turning truck steps from his school.

headline: French Leader’s Policy Proposals Seek Centrist Path
abstract: Europe’s Socialist standard-bearer, President François Hollande, who campaigned against austerity policies, has received praise from the European Union and Germany for his plan to reduce spending.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President François Hollande startled the usually staid world of European economic policy with proposals to take France in a centrist direction with tax cuts for companies, reductions in public spending and a business-friendly tone.

headline: For an Immigrant, a New Home Brings Comfort but Also Isolation
abstract: Yefim Zadov, a 79-year-old immigrant from Ukraine, likes his newly built apartment in Manhattan, but he misses his friends — fellow Russian speakers he left behind in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: In 2002, Yefim Zadov, then 68, came to the United States from Ukraine, looking to change a life that had deteriorated into loneliness and poor health.

headline: A 5-Foot-7 Ranger Makes Tremendous Strides
abstract: Since being benched on Oct. 24, Mats Zuccarello has given the Rangers an offensive spark with 11 goals and 22 assists.
lead_paragraph: When Mats Zuccarello started this season with no points in seven games, there was enough consternation among Rangers coaches that he was a healthy scratch against the Philadelphia Flyers on Oct. 24.

headline: China: Success Claimed in Test of Weapons-Delivery System
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Aircraft', 'Gliders, Hang Gliding and Paragliding']
abstract: China’s Defense Ministry said that it had successfully tested a glider that can travel many times the speed of sound, following a report in the online Washington Free Beacon.
lead_paragraph: China’s Defense Ministry said that it had successfully tested a glider that can travel many times the speed of sound, following a report in the online Washington Free Beacon. Such systems, lobbed high into the atmosphere and then guided down to a distant target, can be used to carry conventional or nuclear weapons past missile defense systems, which are designed to intercept slower missiles at lower altitudes or intercontinental ballistic missiles in space. The ministry said the system was not aimed at any specific country and gave no indication of whether China would deploy armed gliders.

headline: Notes on Blindness (Audio Description)
abstract: After the writer John Hull became completely blind in 1983, he kept an audio diary of his experience. A short film by Peter Middleton and James Spinney is a dramatization using those recordings.
lead_paragraph: After the writer John Hull became completely blind in 1983, he kept an audio diary of his experience. A short film by Peter Middleton and James Spinney is a dramatization using those recordings.

abstract: After the writer John Hull became completely blind in 1983, he kept an audio diary of his experience. A short film by Peter Middleton and James Spinney is a dramatization using those recordings.
lead_paragraph: After the writer John Hull became completely blind in 1983, he kept an audio diary of his experience. A short film by Peter Middleton and James Spinney is a dramatization using those recordings.

lead_paragraph: In his first public comments since Alex Rodriguez’s drug-related suspension was reduced to 162 games, Hal Steinbrenner called Rodriguez an asset and did not rule out his return to the Yankees in 2015, when his suspension is supposed to end.

headline: U.S. Olympian Explains Positive Test
abstract: Sarah Robles, an American Olympian who received a two-year suspension after testing positive for a banned substance, said the test result was because of a hormonal precursor supplement.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Robles, an American Olympian who received a two-year suspension after testing positive for a banned substance, said the test result was because of a hormonal precursor supplement sometimes used in the course of medical treatment for polycystic ovary syndrome. “I accept the conditions of my suspension,” Robles said.  I made a choice to take care of my health as advised by my doctor.” She said she hoped to compete for a weight-lifting spot at the 2016 Summer Games in Rio de Janeiro.

headline: Conference Championship Probabilities, and How the Patriots Run
abstract: New England’s consistently effective running game is a marvel, but Denver is the pick in the A.F.C. title game.
lead_paragraph: The Patriots’ running game is finally getting its due. After a 234-yard, 6-touchdown explosion to defeat the Colts in the divisional round, the New England rushing attack is suddenly in the spotlight.

headline: A Christie’s Auction Honors the Passing of a British Design Giant
abstract: “Michael Inchbald: A Legacy of Design” is a sale of the talented designer, whose work on the Queen’s Room on the Queen Elizabeth 2 is said to have inspired the sets of “2001: A Space Odyssey.”
lead_paragraph: Every now and then an auction comes along which throws light upon hidden secrets of the design world. On Jan. 22, Christie’s London will offer Michael Inchbald: A Legacy of Design, an auction of the varied estate of the talented (but in America, underappreciated) British designer who died last year at the age of 92. His career spanned nearly five decades and included many public and private commissions in the U.K. Among the most notable were the interiors of the Berkeley and Savoy Hotels and projects for the Duke of St. Albans and the filmmaker John Schlesinger (“Darling,” “Marathon Man”). Inchbald executed his interiors in diverse styles, ranging from ’60s groovy to richly baronial. Throughout all of his work, however, there are unexpected juxtapositions of objects and a deep understanding of the role of lighting to create atmosphere.

headline: Matching Jewelry Is Anything but Stuffy
abstract: The traditional demi-parure jewelry set made a chic comeback at the resort collections.
lead_paragraph: Matching your bracelet to your necklace may sound old-fashioned. But the demi-parure — the classic coordinating jewelry set, favored by style icons like Diana Vreeland and Grace Kelly in their heyday — is making a comeback. Not long after Kate Middleton was spotted wearing the style, a host of modern collar-cuff pairings are popping up in designers’ resort collections. Saint Laurent and St. John offer subdued takes on the trend in gold and clear crystals, while Balenciaga’s stone-embroidered padded tubes feel at once organic and futuristic. Other versions look downright rock ‘n’ roll, such as Ca & Lou’s geometric shapes in rose-gold and Givenchy’s black and white stones dangling from oxidized metal chains. Whether worn with a cocktail dress or thrown atop a T-shirt for a touch of sparkle, each pair is an instant outfit-maker.

headline: An Occupy Wall Street Offshoot Has Its Day
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Outside expertise brought to bear on policy makers can be a formidable ally, and that has been the case in the promulgation of the Volcker Rule, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz professor of entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Officer Is Arrested in Bronx Crash
abstract: Carlos Sierra, 36, a detective who was off duty when the hit-and-run occurred in 2012, faces four misdemeanor charges.
lead_paragraph: An off-duty police detective has been arrested in a hit-and-run crash that occurred in the western Bronx more than a year ago, the police said Wednesday.

lead_paragraph: The United States military said it had begun an inquiry after photographs that appeared to show Marines burning the dead bodies of Iraqi militants appeared on a gossip website.

headline: What’s on Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Lifetime) UNDER THE GUNN Auf Wiedersehen, Heidi Klum. Tim Gunn steps into hosting mode in this new competition series, in which the “Project Runway” alumni Mondo Guerra, Anya Ayoung-Chee and Nick Verreos must show off their artistic vision and business savvy — while proving themselves as mentors — as they oversee their own fashion empires with teams selected from 15 burgeoning designers. The designer Rachel Roy, the stylist Jen Rade, and Zanna Roberts Rassi, the senior fashion editor of Marie Claire, are the judges.

headline: In a Confrontation, a Secret Is Revealed
abstract: Deborah Wells-Clinton and Phil Clinton divorced after more than 30 years once he divulged a painful truth.

headline: Thailand Protests Wane Despite Calls to Shut Down Bangkok
abstract: Thailand appears no closer to resolving its debilitating political power struggle and protesters say they will not give up.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Antigovernment demonstrators marched to government offices on Thursday, but their numbers were far lower than they were earlier in the week, when they started their campaign to shut down Bangkok.

headline: World’s Biggest Annual Human Migration Begins in China
keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Lunar New Year', 'New Year', 'Railroads', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: For 40 days, hundreds of millions of Chinese will hit the roads, rails and airways to get home and back over the Lunar New Year festival.
lead_paragraph: With a military-style precision that framed something very human and messy, the world’s biggest annual human migration – the Chinese Lunar New Year festival, known as Spring Festival – officially got under way in the first second of Thursday, Jan. 16, and will last 40 days, Chinese officials said.

headline: With $613 Million at Stake, an Albany Rivalry Is Said to Escalate
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman have long been at odds, but the huge settlement from JPMorgan Chase has brought new bitterness to their conflict.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has asked people if they think Eric T. Schneiderman, the attorney general of New York State, wears eyeliner.

headline: Party Issues Rules to Curb ‘Naked’ Corruption
abstract: The Communist Party has barred the advancement of wayward cadres in its ranks.
lead_paragraph: It’s official: No more “naked officials” rising in the ranks, the Chinese Communist Party has decreed.

headline: Egypt’s Crackdown Belies Constitution as It Nears Approval
abstract: Rights groups said the juxtaposition underscored the persistent doubts about the government’s pledges to steer Egypt toward a new era of freedom and democracy after the military’s ouster of Mohamed Morsi.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A new constitution revised after the military takeover was headed to ratification by more than 95 percent of the votes cast, official Egyptian news media said Thursday, even as the authorities stepped up a crackdown on journalists and dissenters that human rights advocates said belied the charter’s promises of free speech.

headline: In Wilting Heat, Sharapova Escapes 2nd Round
abstract: In a match where the temperature climbed to 111 degrees, it took Maria Sharapova 3 hours 28 minutes to beat Karin Knapp of Italy, 6-3, 4-6, 10-8, and advance to the third round of the Australian Open.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — As her match dragged more than three hours, Maria Sharapova stomped and grunted and stole glances at her box. Her face twisted into grimaces. She seemed happiest on changeovers, underneath the shade of an umbrella, an ice vest draped over the back of her neck.

headline: A Village Takes Small Steps Toward Reconciliation After Muzaffarnagar Riots
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Hinduism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: Economic necessity has prompted talks in Fugana, Uttar Pradesh, between the Hindu Jats and the Muslim residents who fled after the violence that erupted in September.
lead_paragraph: FUGANA, Uttar Pradesh– Four months after religious violence shattered generations of coexistence in the rural hinterland of western Uttar Pradesh, community leaders are trying to get Hindus and Muslims to talk to each other again as the first step to removing the fear and bitterness that divides villages in the Muzaffarnagar district.

headline: E-Commerce Competition Intensifies in China
abstract: Tencent, one of the country’s online powers, is moving further into the mainstay of another titan, Alibaba.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — An arms race between the two most powerful Internet companies in China has escalated again, with one of them, Tencent, announcing an investment that pushes it further into e-commerce — territory long controlled by its rival, Alibaba.

headline: Outspoken Uighur Scholar Detained in Beijing
abstract: Ilham Tohti, an economist, has been critical of Chinese policies in the northwestern region of Xinjiang, and said economic discrimination fueled dissatisfaction among Uighurs, a Turkic-speaking minority group.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:35 a.m. | A prominent Uighur economist known for his criticism of the discrimination the predominantly Muslim ethnic group faces in China has been detained by the police, his wife said.

headline: European Car Sales Ended Year on High Note, Sort Of
abstract: New car registrations, a proxy for sales, fell over the year as a whole but rose 13.3 percent year-on-year in December, the fastest growth since 2009.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — European car sales ended 2013 on a strong note, raising hopes of a market rebound, despite another year of contraction.

headline: U.N. Panel Questions Vatican on Handling of Clergy Sexual Abuse
abstract: It was the first prolonged interrogation by an international body and a moment long awaited by abuse victims in many countries.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The Vatican faced a barrage of pointed questions from a United Nations panel on Thursday about how it had handled decades of reports of clergy sexual abuse, the first such prolonged interrogation by an international body and a moment long awaited by abuse victims in many countries.

headline: ‘Airpocalypse’ Smog Hits Beijing at Dangerous Levels
abstract: Pollution levels in China’s capital hit the upper level of the measurement scale, a dangerous development for Beijing residents.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, some residents of Beijing woke up with splitting headaches. A curtain of haze had fallen across the city of more than 20 million. It was the first “airpocalypse” of the year in the Chinese capital and nearby provinces, and it had come appropriately enough one year after a similar event had led to widespread anxiety.“How does the smog differ from the apocalypse?” Joe Wong, a comedian from northeast China, wrote on his microblog on Wednesday night, when the pollution levels had begun surging. “After the apocalypse, you no longer worry about the smog.”

headline: Blast in Lebanon Kills at Least 3
keywords: ['Bombs and Explosives', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The car bombing, which wounded more than 20, was the latest in a string of attacks that many believe are aimed at groups backing opposite sides in Syria’s civil war.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A suicide bomber detonated an explosives-laden car in a town in northeastern Lebanon on Thursday, killing at least three people and wounding more than 20, Lebanon’s National News Agency reported.

headline: Jeffrey Wright’s Gold Mine
abstract: The actor in his most morally complicated role yet: Prospector in Sierra Leone.
lead_paragraph: “This is a relationship that could bring us all the things we desire,” Jeffrey Wright said. He was sitting with Samuel Jibila under an awning rigged from rusty metal sheets in front of Jibila’s decrepit house in Sierra Leone. Jibila is the traditional ruler — the paramount chief — of Penguia, a little domain of jungly hills and dusty villages 250 miles from the capital. Wright is an actor who lives in Brooklyn. He has won a Tony, an Emmy and a Golden Globe and most recently appeared as Beetee in “The Hunger Games: Catching Fire.” And for the last decade, he has been traveling to this isolated area near the Guinea border to run his small gold-exploration company, Taia Lion Resources. He wanted to maintain Jibila’s faith in his company, in his plans, but Jibila, who was surrounded by lesser chiefs in glossy robes, wasn’t feeling faithful.

headline: Youth in Iran: Inside and Out
abstract: The photographer Hossein Fatemi explores the contrast between how young Iranians present themselves in public and in private, when they are beyond the watchful eye of the Islamic republic’s authorities.
lead_paragraph: If Iranian youth culture was portrayed in a BBC drama, it might be called “Inside, Outside,” or even “Righteous, Raucous.” That is the duality present in Hossein Fatemi’s “An Iranian Journey,” a series that shows young people’s public modesty and piety vanishing once they escape the wary gaze of authority. These youths play music, drink, smoke, commingle and enjoy other intemperate — i.e., regular — Western activities. They are online, on Facebook, and are politically engaged and simmering, craving freer speech but stifled by the ayatollah’s rules.

headline: France by the Numbers
abstract: Why the panic?
lead_paragraph: “You shall not crucify mankind upon a croissant d’or.” That was Alan Taylor’s response (in correspondence) to François Hollande’s embrace of Say’s law — he literally said that “supply actually creates demand” — together with a shift to, again in his own words, supply-side policies. Kevin O’Rourke also weighs in, as did Ambrose Evans-Pritchard . Mark Thoma is your go-to site for the rapidly growing avalanche of horrified snark.

headline: How Much of a Priority Do You Make Sleep?
abstract: What are your sleep habits? Do you feel that you generally get enough sleep every night?
lead_paragraph: You may feel as if there just isn’t enough time in the day to get a good night’s sleep. To get everything done that you need and want to do, you end up going to bed too late and then waking up too early. Or you may think sleep is something you don’t mess around with, and no matter what, you make sure to get your eight hours or more every night.

headline: Trial Opens Into Killing of Lebanese Premier, Absent the Accused
abstract: At a special tribunal in The Hague, the prosecution said a suicide bomber created a “man-made hell” in the 2005 assassination in the Lebanese capital.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Almost nine years after Rafik Hariri, the former Lebanese prime minister, was killed by a truck bomb, an international tribunal opened hearings into the case on Thursday in a courtroom in the Netherlands with lawyers and judges clustered around a mock-up of the crime scene on the Beirut waterfront.

lead_paragraph: GARDEZ, Afghanistan — “The Taliban are still here,” a pharmacist who sells medicine to remote villages in the southeast told me last month in this shabby frontier town. “People are anxious about 2014 because the troops are leaving.”

lead_paragraph: It’s where “a kid can be a kid.” Can it also be where a private equity firm reaps a big return?

headline: Finding Rewards, Financial and Spiritual, in E-Waste
keywords: ['Electronics', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Small Business', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: Discarded consumer electronics are clogging landfills, fast-becoming a worldwide environmental calamity. One woman in Tulsa, Okla., is trying to make a dent.
lead_paragraph: Traci Phillips, 42, started a recycling company, Natural Evolution, more than a decade ago, after realizing the hazards associated with electronic waste. Dead cellphones, dilapidated computers, broken video-game consoles and other thrown-away gadgets are laden with toxins like lead, mercury and arsenic. The United States alone produces three million tons of e-waste a year, a figure that’s expected to rise as tech companies churn out new products and consumers snap them up.

headline: Investors Turning to Riskier Investments for Returns, BlackRock Survey Finds
abstract: Investors seeking higher yields are increasingly turning to riskier sectors like real estate and hedge funds, BlackRock found in a survey of 100 institutions released on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Investors looking for bigger returns are increasingly turning to riskier but potentially more rewarding opportunities like real estate and hedge funds, according to BlackRock.

headline: Carpet Bombing: How One Business Is Trying to Get Rid of Bad Reviews
abstract: Anonymous reviews are protected by the First Amendment. But if they are anonymous, how can they be determined to be fake?
lead_paragraph: Businesses have always lived by word of mouth, but in the old days the process was diffuse, hidden, incremental. Then Yelp kicked things up a few notches. It was bad news for bad businesses.

lead_paragraph: Yahoo’s chief operating officer, Henrique de Castro, has been fired by his boss, Marissa Mayer, a little more than a year after she wooed him away from Google to help her turn around the struggling Internet company, Vindu Goel reports.

headline: Carlyle Buys Johnson & Johnson Testing Division for $4.15 Billion
abstract: The deal for the unit, Ortho-Clinical Diagnostics, is the Carlyle Group’s first big buyout of the year.
lead_paragraph: The private equity firm Carlyle Group said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire the clinical testing division of Johnson & Johnson for $4.15 billion, its first big buyout of the year.

headline: One Good Man to Save the World
abstract: Paramount reboots an action franchise, casting Chris Pine in a role previously played by Alec Baldwin, Harrison Ford and Ben Affleck.
lead_paragraph: Say what you will about Vladimir V. Putin, but he seems to have been very, very good for screen villainy. Despite the collapse of the Soviet Union, Soviet-style skulduggery has remained a durable narrative cliché in recent movies that feature Russian bad guys doing their dastardly worst at home or abroad, from “Iron Man 2” to “Jack Reacher,” “Safe,” “A Good Day to Die Hard.” In “Kick-Ass 2,” one sadistic sicko, a former K.G.B. agent, is even called Mother Russia and wears a red bikini top with a hammer and sickle over each breast. The Ruskie heavy in “Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit” played by Kenneth Branagh may be less stacked, but he’s scarcely subtler.

headline: At SAC Trial, Doctor Tells of Surprise at Ex-Trader’s Drug Trial Knowledge
abstract: Doctor at SAC insider trading trial says trader knew so much detail about a drug trial, it was like “he was in the room.” | Goldman Sachs reports earnings after strong results from Bank of America and Wells Fargo. | Yahoo fires its No. 2 executive. | Let’s play the M.&A. Game.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Joel S. Ross took the witness stand for a second day at the insider trading trial of Mathew Martoma, a former hedge fund manager at SAC Capital Advisors. During his testimony, Dr. Ross told the jury of seven men and five women how Mr. Martoma knew so much detail about a confidential presentation on a clinical drug trial that Dr. Ross had attended, “it was like he was in the room with me,” Alexandra Stevenson reports in DealBook.

lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Temperatures spiked to incredible heights again at the Australian Open on Thursday, so high that play was suspended for four hours. When the day’s matches were completed early Friday, the temperature had not fallen significantly, but a title contender had.

headline: In Assam, an Idea Whose Time Has Not Yet Come
abstract: The state’s chief minister made headlines earlier this month when he said his constituents would move their clocks ahead of the rest of the country, but it looks like he spoke too soon.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — In Mumbai, where Jahnu Barua makes documentary films, a normal Indian lunchtime of 2 p.m. more or less corresponds to midday, when the sun is highest overhead. But when Mr. Barua goes back to his home state of Assam, especially during the winter months, the afternoon light is waning by the time lunch rolls around, and is completely gone by the time most people get out of work around 5.

abstract: The money manager reported that fourth-quarter profit rose to $841 million, from $690 million in the same period a year ago, helped by the popularity of its exchange-traded funds.
lead_paragraph: The giant money manager BlackRock reported strong fourth-quarter profit on Thursday, as new money flowed into a wide range of its investment products.

headline: Seeking Bigger Sweet Spot, Roger Federer Hopes His Racket Will Grow on Him
abstract: Federer long dominated tennis with a smaller racket, but he is now using a bigger one after failing to reach a Grand Slam final last year.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — In the obsessive, superstitious, fine-tuned realm of tennis equipment, the best players hope to fiddle least with two main pieces: their shoes and their rackets.

headline: American Home Owners, Living Larger Again
abstract: After a brief pause, the American home is continuing its historical march to massiveness.
lead_paragraph: That rattling noise you hear is the average American family moving about in the average American house, which — after a brief pause, due to the downturn — is continuing its historical march to massiveness.

headline: When Slavery and Its Foes Thrived in Brooklyn
abstract: “Brooklyn Abolitionists/In Pursuit of Freedom,” at the Brooklyn Historical Society, spotlights extraordinary figures in the history of slavery and abolition in New York, and James W. C. Pennington, a preacher and abolitionist.
lead_paragraph: Heroic terra-cotta busts of Columbus, Franklin, Shakespeare, Gutenberg, Beethoven and Michelangelo gaze down from the lovingly restored 1881 facade of the Brooklyn Historical Society, reminding the approaching visitor of what the place was once meant to represent. The founders of the society — which is now celebrating its 150th anniversary — conceived of its building in Brooklyn Heights as a repository of history that would aspire to the greatest achievements of European civilization. And why not? Brooklyn was the third-largest city in the United States, the architect was George B. Post (who later designed the New York Stock Exchange), and the society’s founders were among the elite.

headline: E. L. Doctorow: By the Book
abstract: The author of “Andrew’s Brain” and “Ragtime” sometimes puts down a book because he can see where the story’s going. “As you practice your craft, you lose your innocence as a reader.”
lead_paragraph: The author of “Andrew’s Brain” and “Ragtime” sometimes puts down a book because he can see where the story’s going. “As you practice your craft, you lose your innocence as a reader.”

headline: Victoria & Albert Museum to Overhaul Baroque and Rococo Galleries
abstract: The renovation is expected to be completed in December and cost $20.4 million.
lead_paragraph: London’s Victoria and Albert Museum has announced that it will overhaul its Baroque and Rococo galleries to let in more light and better install 1,100 gems from its collection — including items designed for Marie Antoinette, Catherine the Great and Napoleon.

headline: Surprises and Snubs:  Bold Choices Like ‘Wolf’ Rewarded; Veterans Like Hanks Ignored
abstract: The Academy has long been considered stodgy, but this year’s nominations suggest that reputation may be outdated.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Academy may not be as stodgy as people thought. In its nominations it overlooked films and performances that many considered classic Oscar bait, choosing instead to reward indie films and those with bold acting and filmmaking choices.

headline: Raf Simons and the Heart of Art
abstract: The designer, in collaboration with a Los Angeles artist, sent out a winter 2014 men’s collection that was as colorful as it was desirable.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Color! Craft! The American flag rolled into soft sculptures framing the runway. Embroidered hands clutching the hem of a jacket. Stripes at the collar, wrists and hem of a tailored coat. And the word “Father” appearing clearly between the splatters of paint.

headline: Hurt by Slower Sales of Smartphones, Best Buy Has Bleak Holiday Results
abstract: The electronics retailer’s results were weighing on its stock, which recovered a bit in after-hours trading.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A slowing smartphone market and aggressive price-cutting by competitors have struck at the heart of Best Buy, the large electronics retailer.

headline: This Week’s Forecast: What Flu Season May Look Like
abstract: Scientists are developing computer models that make predictions about the flu season in the United States in real time.
lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Shaman, an environmental health scientist at Columbia University, hopes that he and his colleagues will someday change the nightly news. “The way you get pollution reports and pollen counts on the local weather report, you could also have a flu forecast on there,” said Dr. Shaman.

headline: Formula One Chief Faces Bribery Trial
abstract: Bernie Ecclestone, 83, is accused of bribing a German businessman involved in the sale of the auto racing circuit.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A court in Munich said on Thursday that it would proceed this spring with a trial on bribery charges against Bernie Ecclestone, the 83-year-old Englishman who has been Formula One’s all-powerful overseer for more than 35 years.

headline: New Ratings Agency Hopes to Compete With Big 3 Outside U.S.
abstract: A group of smaller credit rating agencies outside the United States has formed Arc Ratings, a new company that the group hopes will provide a viable alternative to the so-called Big 3 credit rating agencies when it comes to international debt financing.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Challengers have come and gone, but no viable alternative has emerged to supplant the so-called Big 3 credit rating agencies when it comes to international debt financing.

headline: Divisions in the Foreign-Language Category
abstract: The Academy split the category between European films with strong performances, and Asian films that rely more on plot than cast.
lead_paragraph: The nominations in the best foreign language film category contain no big surprises, but have produced a divided field. Three of the nominations are from Europe, and are powered by strong individual performances from their leading actors. The remaining two are the Cambodian and Palestinian submissions and depend more on the strength of the story they tell than their cast.

headline: Probiotics May Ease Stomach Upset in Babies
abstract: In a new clinical trial, babies who got took a probiotic showed a decrease in crying time and an increase in frequency of bowel movements after one month.
lead_paragraph: A new clinical trial suggests that a daily dose of a probiotic may ease digestive upset in babies.

headline: Matthew McConaughey, a Nominee Who Writes His Congressman
abstract: The actor, nominated on Thursday for his role in “Dallas Buyers Club,” said his character’s anti-authoritarian bent has stayed with him.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — You know it’s coming: “All right, all right, all right,” Matthew McConaughey said, on the phone from Malibu moments after receiving an Oscar nomination for his performance as Ron Woodroof, the cowboy-turned-activist stricken with AIDS in “Dallas Buyers Club.”

headline: Maupin Takes Final ‘Tales’ on the Road
abstract: Armistead Maupin will make multiple stops to promote the last novel in his “Tales of the City” series.
lead_paragraph: The author Armistead Maupin begins a tour this month to promote “The Days of Anna Madrigal,” the last novel in his “Tales of the City” series. First published in 1976 as a serial in The San Francisco Chronicle, the stories were praised for bringing the gay, lesbian and transgender subjects and story lines of San Francisco to the general public.

headline: Goldman Sachs Keeps a Lid on Pay
abstract: The value of the bank’s compensation and benefits for 2013 is the lowest it has been since 2009, measured as a proportion of net revenue, according to results released on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs, a bank once famous for its rich bonuses, is clamping down on pay.

headline: Political Conflict and Art Dominate Documentary Field
abstract: The stark split will mean the Academy has a clear-cut choice.
lead_paragraph: The nominations in the best feature documentary category set up an almost Manichaean split in the field. Three of the films address various forms of political conflict, while the other two, “20 Feet From Stardom” and “Cutie and the Boxer,” take a look at overlooked artists and their relationship to the artistic process.

headline: A Hiring by Christie Raises Questions Over Cooperation
abstract: As lawmakers prepared to serve 20 subpoenas, Gov. Chris Christie hired a lawyer to conduct an internal investigation of his office following the orchestrated lane closings on the George Washington Bridge.
lead_paragraph: TRENTON — As the New Jersey Assembly voted unanimously on Thursday to authorize an investigation into abuses of power by Gov. Chris Christie’s administration, Mr. Christie seemed to be maneuvering against the inquiry, hiring a high-powered defense lawyer and resisting questions about whether he would cooperate with the Legislature’s efforts.

headline: What’s in a Name? The Equus Bass770
abstract: It’s not a Hyundai, has nothing to do with fish and does not have 770 of anything. But for $250,000, it provides a cross-section of ’60s muscle cars.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Equus is Latin for horse. It’s also English for a certain Hyundai model, but don’t tell that to Equus Automotive. Michael Qualid, a spokesman for the company, said that Equus didn’t know the name had been in use on Hyundai’s premier luxury model when Equus opened in 2006, but he expressed hope that the Korean automaker would not come after a niche marque over its name.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Sarabande’
abstract: “Sarabande” by Lucie Thésée is paired with the article “Beneath Martinique’s Beauty, Guided by a Poet” by Sylvie Bigar in this Poetry Pairing.
lead_paragraph: This Poetry Pairing features “Sarabande” by Lucie Thésée and the article “Beneath Martinique’s Beauty, Guided by a Poet” by Sylvie Bigar.

headline: Alex Rodriguez Seems to Accept That Suspension Will Stand
abstract: Commenting on his 2014 suspension for the first time, Alex Rodriguez told reporters in Mexico City that “2014 will be a good year to rest physically, mentally and to prepare for the future.”
lead_paragraph: Alex Rodriguez appears a step closer to accepting the likelihood that he will not be playing major league baseball in 2014. But he is also confident he will be back.

headline: Image of the Day: January 16
abstract: Motorists driving through thick fog on the outskirts of Jammu city, Jammu and Kashmir.

headline: Index of Millions of New York History Records Available Free Online
abstract: With a collaboration between the city’s Department of Records and Ancestry.com, an index to more than 10 million birth, marriage and death records from 1866 to 1948 is accessible to those who create a free account at ancestry.com.
lead_paragraph: Updated, Jan. 21

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Valentino Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: U.N. Says Lag in Confronting Climate Woes Will Be Costly
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Coal', 'International Relations']
abstract: Another 15 years of failure by nations to limit carbon emissions could make the situation virtually impossible to solve with current technologies, according to a draft United Nations report.
lead_paragraph: Nations have so dragged their feet in battling climate change that the situation has grown critical and the risk of severe economic disruption is rising, according to a draft United Nations report. Another 15 years of failure to limit carbon emissions could make the problem virtually impossible to solve with current technologies, experts found.

headline: David O. Russell Has Said His Thank-Yous
abstract: The director spoke with his cast well before the nominations were announced.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “I told everybody thank you already last night,” said the director David O. Russell, whose four stars in “American Hustle” all became Oscar nominees this morning.

headline: Louis Vuitton’s Satellite View
abstract: Kim Jones’s autumn 2014 collection celebrated outer space, but had streamlined pieces for planet earth.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “It was digital travel — online, via satellites — NASA’s maps from outer space,” said Kim Jones, the designer of the sky blue, all-embracing runway that was the backdrop for the Louis Vuitton show on Thursday.

headline: Harvey Weinstein vs. the National Rifle Association
abstract: The producer announces plans for a film that takes on the organization.
lead_paragraph: “Philomena” and “August: Osage County” did well for the Weinstein Company in the nominations, even if another of its hopefuls, “Lee Daniels’ The Butler” came away empty-handed. But Harvey Weinstein still managed to grab attention in a different way by announcing on Howard Stern’s radio show that he was joining Meryl Streep – picking up her 18th nomination, for best actress for “August” — in a secret anti-gun movie project.

headline: Louis Vuitton: Fall 2014 Menswear
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Lots of New Patients, Too Few Doctors
abstract: It is increasingly difficult for patients to find doctors and to get appointments with primary care physicians like myself, and it is likely to get worse, not better, as millions more gain health insurance under the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: The first thing my new patient did when she walked into my office was breathe an enormous sigh of relief. “It was so hard to get this appointment with you,” she said. “It took weeks!”

headline: ‘Gravity’s’ Special Effects Flashback
abstract: The effects supervisor says the job recalled his visit to the set of “Superman” in the ’70s, when his uncle took on the challenge of making Christopher Reeve look like he could fly.
lead_paragraph: Flashback: Britain, the mid-’70s. A teenage lad goes to visit his uncle at work and beholds before him a veritable magic shop.

headline: Facebook Rolls Out Its Version of Trending Topics
abstract: The social network is adding a module to its news feed that will suggest popular topics of conversation on the service, customized for each user.
lead_paragraph: Facebook is finally rolling out its version of trending topics on a widespread basis — and it’s not using Twitter-style hashtags to organize them.

headline: A Game for Would-Be Deal Makers
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Names, Organizational']
abstract: On Thursday, Ansarada, which provides virtual data rooms for merger and acquisition transactions, released the M&A Game, aimed at bringing some levity to the soul-crushing work of investment banking.
lead_paragraph: For young finance professionals, an investment banking deal usually conjures up images of spreadsheets, weekend work and late-night emails from managers.

headline: Times Minute | Oscar Nominations
abstract: Also on the Minute, a grim climate study and a sampling of a sitzprobe.
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, a grim climate study and a sampling of a sitzprobe.

headline: Times Minute | Oscar Nominations
abstract: Also on the Minute, a new climate study and a sampling of the Sitzprobe.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: ‘The Wolf of Wall Street,’ in the Hunt for Oscars
abstract: Martin Scorsese’s movie based on the debauched tale of Jordan Belfort’s first memoir has garnered five Academy Award nominations, including for best picture.
lead_paragraph: The debauched tale of Jordan Belfort’s rise and fall has prompted a lot of controversy.

headline: Sabine Heller of A Small World, on Teaching Yourself
abstract: The chief executive of A Small World, the online travel and lifestyle community, says she has learned the importance of self-education throughout a career.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Sabine Heller, chief executive of A Small World, an online travel and lifestyle community, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: How Jared Leto Did Not Get the News
abstract: The actor was not awakened by the police telling him he had been nominated, no matter what he says
lead_paragraph: With Los Angeles shrouded in darkness as the Oscar nominations were being announced early Thursday, Jared Leto was doing his best to pretend to sleep and wondering if perhaps his performance as the transgendered Rayon in “Dallas Buyers Club” had been overlooked.

headline: Motherlode in The Times’s Redesign
abstract: Motherlode has joined the Times redesign. Here’s what’s new, for now.
lead_paragraph: As I’m sure you’ve noticed, Motherlode (along with all of the other blogs at The Times) has joined the redesign, with a streamlined appearance and new navigation tools. For starters, and most importantly on a blog where reader interaction is a big part of the experience, you can pop up the comments as you read the post by clicking on the number of comments at the top of the post next to the headline. Comments still aren’t available for readers on mobile apps. (For this reason, I am considering a weekly post highlighting the best commentary.)

headline: A Veteran Returns to Gettysburg
abstract: Jessica Dickey, who grew up near Gettysburg, Pa., explores the Civil War in her new play, “Row After Row,” at City Center.
lead_paragraph: Growing up just outside Gettysburg, Pa., Jessica Dickey knew from an early age that she was surrounded by a complicated history. On the roads outside her home were signs marking where the Union and Confederate troops had marched. Downtown were buildings flecked with bullet holes. “I was always so intrigued by the idea of the presence of the past, the ghosts of the past,” Ms. Dickey said.

headline: Treasury Sells $3 Billion Stake in Ally Financial
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The sale, conducted as a private placement, helps resolve questions about how the government would dispose of its Ally stake.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department said on Thursday that it had sold $3 billion worth of its shares in Ally Financial, bringing taxpayers’ stake in the auto lender below 50 percent.

headline: On Spying, Woes of Obama Echo Those of Past Presidents
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: History shows that the reality of governing nearly always gives the lie to the I-can-square-the-circle formulations that winning candidates take to the White House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In his first Inaugural Address, President Obama stirred liberals by proclaiming that “we reject as false the choice between our safety and our ideals.”

headline: A Death-Squad Leader Feels Honored
abstract: The main character in “The Act of Killing” tells the director an Oscar nomination would be an honor for both him and his country.
lead_paragraph: The director Joshua Oppenheimer was at his father’s home outside Washington, D.C., when he got the news that his documentary, “The Act of Killing,” had received an Oscar nomination in the best feature documentary category. But he wasn’t just with his family when the announcement was made: watching with him on Skype from the other side of the world were members of the Indonesian crew that at some personal risk, helped him make his ground-breaking film about the mass killings carried out by the Indonesian armed forces and paramilitary death squads in the 1960s.

headline: Amy Adams, Still a Newbie Even 5 Nominations Later
abstract: The actress, nominated for “American Hustle,” hasn’t won yet but says she doesn’t feel disappointed or cynical.
lead_paragraph: First of all, this is Amy Adams’s fifth Oscar nomination, and she has yet to win. Doesn’t she feel the Academy is being a little sadistic by putting her through this cycle of hype all over again?

headline: Snubs and Favorites of the Oscars Field
abstract: The Academy Award nominations for 2014 included a few surprises, but “American Hustle” and “Gravity” lead the field.
lead_paragraph: The Academy Award nominations for 2014 included a few surprises, but “American Hustle” and “Gravity” lead the field.

headline: 36 Hours in Sydney
abstract: Hit golden beaches, soak up contemporary culture, explore atmospheric bars and, sure, catch a glimpse of that opera house during a weekend in Australia’s most populous city.
lead_paragraph: In ever-sunny, easygoing Sydney, don’t let the famous attractions circling the handsome harbor consume all your attention. Focus instead on the evolving neighborhoods where art spaces are cropping up beside train tracks, and innovative, chef-driven restaurants are opening at a rapid clip. If you’re searching for flash, look to Darling Harbour, where celebrity chefs like David Chang and Luke Nguyen have opened outposts in the Star, a ritzy casino and entertainment complex that reopened in 2011 after a renovation costing around $800 million. For more discreet indulgences, seek out the diminutive drinking dens that now pepper the city, the result of a change in local liquor licensing laws that finally made business viable for small bars. Then when it’s time to dry out, the natural beauty of Australia’s most populous city will be waiting along the sandy beaches that lie just minutes from downtown. And don’t worry, you’re bound to pass a certain opera house along the way.

headline: Let’s Cease the Insults, North Korea Says to South
abstract: A proposal by North Korea calls for an end to all the cross-border invective both sides have hurled at each other for decades.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — For years, North and South Korea have hurled invective at each other that would do Shakespearean characters proud.

headline: Leonardo DiCaprio Didn’t Exercise His Producer’s Prerogative
abstract: As producer of “The Wolf of Wall Street,” he could have cut scenes of his character’s drug-induced breakdown, but he opted not to.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Leonardo DiCaprio was at home having breakfast — coffee and eggs, with tomatoes — as he discussed his multiple Oscar nominations for “The Wolf of Wall Street.”

headline: Time Warner Is Planning a Move to Hudson Yards
abstract: Time Warner Inc. announced on Thursday that it plans to move its headquarters to a new, 80-story skyscraper on the Far West Side of Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Time Warner Inc. announced on Thursday that it plans to move its headquarters from Columbus Circle to a new, 80-story skyscraper on the Far West Side of Manhattan, ensuring the development of a vast neighborhood made up of office towers, residential buildings, a shopping mall and a park, all built over a 13-acre railyard.

headline: Ford Mustang and Volvo Concept Win Design Awards
abstract: At the Detroit auto show, the Mustang won for best production vehicle and the Volvo won two awards, including one for best concept.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The Ford Mustang and Volvo Concept XC Coupe won the annual Eyes on Design awards presented at the Detroit auto show on Tuesday.

headline: Why It May Take More Than Former Google Stars to Turn Yahoo Around
abstract: Marissa Mayer has done much to revive Yahoo, Richard Beales and Robert Cyran of Reuters Breakingviews write, but the Internet company still has a fundamental problem: Its sites are a hodgepodge.
lead_paragraph: The Googleization of Yahoo has hit an expensive speed bump.

headline: Free Markets, Infidelity and the President of France
abstract: Among President François Hollande’s proposed changes – while dealing with revelations of his supposed infidelity with an actress – was a pledge to cut public spending and slash the payroll taxes for business.
lead_paragraph: PARIS – Is it worse to be an ardent advocate of the free market than a suspected adulterer?

headline: A Reader Behind Bars
abstract: I daydreamed that my book would end up in the White House library. But its real path was humbler, and more meaningful.
lead_paragraph: I am not proud of it, but I will admit to having felt a twinge of envy when I read, over the holidays, of President Obama’s latest book purchases. How amazing would it be to have the president buy, and read, your novel?

headline: New Foundation to Focus on Publishing Art Books
abstract: The Artist Book Foundation plans to document and distribute a visual record of work that would otherwise hardly be seen.
lead_paragraph: Art books, monographs and catalogs are essential for historians, collectors and artists, but they rarely make money. Often oversized and lavishly illustrated on high-quality glossy paper, they are expensive to produce for the relatively tiny number of institutions and individuals who buy them. Enter the Artist Book Foundation, a new nonprofit organization dedicated to publishing fine-art references that otherwise would not be seen. Next month, it will release “Trucks: Recent Works by John Himmelfarb,” to accompany a new traveling exhibition of that Chicago artist’s work that opened last week at the Brauer Museum of Art at Valparaiso University in Valparaiso, Indiana.

headline: Steve Coogan Shares His Victory March
abstract: The co-star, co-writer and producer of “Philomena” received several nominations but says whooping over good news is not a British thing to do. He did however celebrate in his own way.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Steve Coogan is playing catch-up.

headline: Today in Small Business: Name Your Own Price
abstract: A new chief of the S.B.A. Federal contracts going to private companies plunge. What business owners wish they had known when they started.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: An Osteoarthritis Primer
abstract: Osteoarthritis is the leading cause of disability in the United States. A Q & A with Dr. C. Thomas Vangsness Jr., co-author of “The New Science of Overcoming Arthritis.”
lead_paragraph: Maybe we should rewrite that quote usually attributed to Benjamin Franklin. Nothing is certain except death, taxes — and arthritis, the leading cause of disability in the United States.
