headline: Deep Emotions Explored in Song
abstract: The Riverside Symphony, founded in 1981, has been offering adventurous programming for decades.
lead_paragraph: Many orchestras talk up the idea of adventurous programming. The Riverside Symphony, founded in 1981 by the conductor George Rothman and the composer Anthony Korf, has been putting the concept into practice for decades. This accomplished ensemble’s next program, on Saturday at Alice Tully Hall, is titled “Shadow and Light” and is typically intriguing.

headline: Sally Hawkins’s Jet-Lagged Euphoria
abstract: The actress received the news of her supporting actress nomination after flying from Los Angeles to London, and wasn’t sure if she dreamed it all up.
lead_paragraph: The little golden man is, at this point, rather immaterial. To hear Sally Hawkins tell it, she has already won.

headline: Authorities Comb New Jersey Woodland in Hunt for Missing Reporter
abstract: David Bird, 55, was last seen Saturday when he told his wife that he planned to go on a walk through the wooded trails near their home in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: LONG HILL TOWNSHIP, N.J. — Using all-terrain vehicles, rubber rafts and aluminum motorboats, hundreds of law enforcement officers and volunteers scoured a dense, swampy woodland in central New Jersey on Thursday in search of a Wall Street Journal reporter who went out for a walk last weekend and never returned.

headline: Clothes Inspired on Demand
abstract: The resourceful American Folk Art Museum continues to explore new ways of using its collection.
lead_paragraph: The resourceful American Folk Art Museum continues to explore new ways of using its collection, and in particular to involve living artists in its exhibitions. Its previous attempt, last fall’s “alt_quilts,” presented quilts from its collection and the quiltlike works of three contemporary artists, with weak results. Now, the museum has turned to the fashion world in “Folk Couture: Fashion and Folk Art,” which opens on Tuesday. To explore the idea of fashion designers finding inspiration in all sorts of unexpected places, 13 New York-based designers have been invited to create garments inspired by works they select from the museum’s collection.

headline: Endurance as Art Form
abstract: It’s been almost two years since Sarah Michelson commandeered the fourth floor of the Whitney Museum of American Art.
lead_paragraph: It’s been almost two years since Sarah Michelson commandeered the fourth floor of the Whitney Museum of American Art, transforming several thousand square feet into the gleaming terrain for “Devotion Study #1 — The American Dancer.” Some audience members walked out. Others sat transfixed as Ms. Michelson’s dancers rose to the punishing task of walking backward, in circles, for a spectacularly long time, never doubting (or so it seemed) that their bodies would carry them through.

headline: Back Together After a Breakup
abstract: Jeff Mangum returns with the rest of Neutral Milk Hotel.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Mangum, the songwriter who leads Neutral Milk Hotel, defused some suspense with his 2011-12 solo tours. Those were his first consistent reappearances since the group quietly disbanded after touring for its beloved 1998 album, “In the Aeroplane Over the Sea,” an oblique yet impassioned set of songs inspired by thoughts of Anne Frank, with Mr. Mangum’s ceaseless strumming punctuated by jaunty trombone tunes and outbursts of distortion. Mr. Mangum stayed largely out of sight as the album’s reputation spread and solidified, but his solo concerts showed him fully in command. Now, with the band, patient fans should hear the trombone, too. Elf Power shares the bill.

headline: Guinea Worm Said to Infect Few in 2013
abstract: Only 148 cases of Guinea worm disease, which is on the brink of extinction, were found in the world in 2013, the Carter Center announced.
lead_paragraph: Only 148 cases of Guinea worm disease were found in the world in 2013, a 73 percent drop from the 542 cases found one year earlier, the Carter Center announced Thursday.

headline: What Was Behind All Those Whacks?
abstract: Christina Ricci showed early that she could play creepy: One of her first film credits is as Wednesday Addams.
lead_paragraph: Christina Ricci showed early that she could play creepy: One of her first film credits is as Wednesday Addams in the 1991 movie “The Addams Family.” So the role of Lizzie Borden, the odd Massachusetts woman accused of killing her father and stepmother with an ax in 1892, seems a logical fit. “Lizzie Borden Took an Ax,” a telling of the real-life story being shown on Saturday at 8 p.m. on Lifetime, isn’t shy about speculating on what actually happened in the Borden household in Fall River that bloody August day, though that has remained in dispute for more than a century. The movie also presents the record of Lizzie’s arrest and trial, whose conclusion won’t be spoiled here for the sake of those not up on their murder history. The cast includes Billy Campbell as Lizzie’s lawyer and Clea DuVall as her sister, Emma. Also listed are credits for three “Jump Rope Girls.” You can probably guess why, though the film reminds us that the oft-chanted rhyme is inaccurate. The figures of 40 and 41 whacks are greatly inflated.

headline: Mets’ Parnell Says He’ll Be Ready for Opening Day
abstract: Bobby Parnell, the Mets’ closer, who had surgery to repair a herniated disk in his neck in September, said on Thursday that he had been throwing for several weeks.
lead_paragraph: In September, as the Mets’ 2013 season was coming to a close, Bobby Parnell, the team’s closer, made a rare appearance in the clubhouse. He had been out since July with a herniated disk in his neck, and recently had surgery on it. As he visited with his teammates, he wore a big neck brace and looked thinner. Manager Terry Collins, for one, seemed worried about his appearance.

headline: Unknown No Longer
abstract: The Film Society of Lincoln Center begins a retrospective of work by the French director Alain Guiraudie.
lead_paragraph: Until his eerie gay murder mystery, “Stranger by the Lake,” was shown last fall at the New York Film Festival, the work of the French director Alain Guiraudie was almost unknown in the United States. Concurrent with the theatrical opening of that movie, the Film Society of Lincoln Center will begin a weeklong retrospective of his work, running Friday through Jan. 30, that spans two decades.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Louis Vuitton Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Wheelies: The Better Efficiency Now Edition
abstract: An automotive panel in Detroit says 54.5 m.p.g. is possible with current technology; Subaru expects to sell 500,000 vehicles a year in the United States by 2016.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Ethan Hawke, Adapted Screenplay Nominee for Original Characters
abstract: The actor, who was nominated alongside his co-star, Julie Delpy, and director, Richard Linklater, says he kinda, sorta understands the reasoning.
lead_paragraph: Question to Ethan Hawke (currently on a layover in Houston, after leaving his family on a beach in Tulum, Mexico, because he had to fly to Los Angeles to collect another movie award):

headline: Turning the Mini-Series Inside Out
abstract: “The Spoils of Babylon” injects a bit of the farcical into a mini-series reminiscent of “The Thorn Birds” or “The Winds of War.”
lead_paragraph: It doesn’t get much better, in mini-series land, than the consummation of a forbidden love. The writers of “The Spoils of Babylon” liked the idea so much, they did it twice: first, in a steamy scene in a trashy San Francisco hotel room; then, with an encounter on the beach, straight out of “The Thorn Birds.”

headline: Jonah Hill Would Like to Thank Those Teeth
abstract: He said his “Wolf of Wall Street” character’s gleaming choppers deserve some credit for securing his Oscar nomination.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Before he talked to the press, Jonah Hill got on the phone with his director, Martin Scorsese, and his co-star, Leonardo DiCaprio, to congratulate one another on the five nominations that their film, “The Wolf of Wall Street,” received. “It took Leo about 45 minutes to figure out how to conference us all together,” Mr. Hill said, perhaps exaggerating just a tad. “It was very sweet.”

headline: Soderbergh to Direct New Play at Public Theater
abstract: Steven Soderbergh is set to direct “The Library,” a new drama about the effects of gun violence on a high school student, written by his frequent collaborator Scott Z. Burns. Chloe Grace Moretz is to star.
lead_paragraph: The Oscar-winning film director Steven Soderbergh (“Traffic”) will make his New York theater debut this spring staging the Off Broadway world premiere of a new drama, “The Library,” about the effects of gun violence on a high school student, played by the movie actress Chloe Grace Moretz (“Kick-Ass,” the 2013 remake of “Carrie”). The Public Theater, which will produce “The Library,” made the show announcement on Thursday.

headline: Letters: ‘The Trip to Echo Spring’
abstract: Readers respond to a review of Olivia Laing’s “The Trip to Echo Spring” and more.
lead_paragraph: ‘Intoxicating Prose’

headline: To Sit and Sing: A Musical Tradition
abstract: A behind-the-scenes look at the sitzprobe for the musical “The Bridges of Madison County.” This theater tradition is the first time a show’s cast and full orchestra practice face-to-face.
lead_paragraph: A behind-the-scenes look at the sitzprobe for the musical “The Bridges of Madison County.” This theater tradition is the first time a show’s cast and full orchestra practice face-to-face.

headline: You’ve Got Another Chance, Broadway
abstract: Jason Robert Brown’s moment could very well be 2014: His “Bridges of Madison County” opens on Broadway next month; his “Honeymoon in Vegas” is up next; and a film of his show “The Last Five Years” is being made.
lead_paragraph: The composer Jason Robert Brown is never happier than when surrounded by musicians. Kibitzing with the string section, directing the percussionist to feather in the high-hat more softly, poking fun at his own orchestrations, Mr. Brown, 43, was in his element on a recent Thursday at a musical theater ritual known as the sitzprobe, an evocative German term for the first time the full orchestra plays with the cast.

headline: Redefining Gender Blueprints
abstract: Russell Tovey discusses sexuality and the movies that inspired his career choice.
lead_paragraph: For much of his adult career, Russell Tovey has been rather famously out. But he’s built his reputation on playing it straight in British television roles like the werewolf George in “Being Human” and the slacker Steve in “Him & Her,” and as the jock Rudge in “The History Boys,” onstage in New York and London and on film.

headline: One Part Rigor, Two Parts Whimsy
abstract: The postmodern dancer and choreographer Douglas Dunn reconnects with his younger, free-spirit self in his new work, “Aubade,” at Montclair State University.
lead_paragraph: It started with a mountain.

headline: Spreading Their Wings and Moving On
abstract: New music from Sharon Jones & the Dap-Kings, Alcest, Matt Wilson Quartet, Frank Fairfield and Nir Felder.
lead_paragraph: Stan Douglas

headline: Veggies for the Blazer Set
abstract: On the Upper East Side, cauliflower, beets and broccoli steal the limelight.
lead_paragraph: It was midweek on the Upper East Side, and the maître d’ wore a calla lily speared through a tiny braid behind his head and garlands of amulets, including one draped across his brow.

headline: Along Milan’s Streets, Color at Play
abstract: In Milan, men battled the chill in everything from bright long coats to plaid vests and patterned wraps.
lead_paragraph: PHOTOS: In Milan, men battled the chill in everything from bright long coats to plaid vests and patterned wraps. For more images from street style during the Milan men’s collections.

headline: Corvex Turns Down CommonWealth Board Seat
abstract: Keith Meister, the founder of the activist hedge fund Corvex, pledged to continue his campaign to replace the existing slate of directors at the real estate investment trust.
lead_paragraph: A long, contentious spat between the activist hedge fund Corvex Management and CommonWealth REIT, a real estate investment trust, took another twist on Thursday, as the founder of Corvex, Keith Meister, declined an invitation to join the CommonWealth board.

headline: A Sensor Guided by Voice or Gestures
abstract: Microsoft wants the Xbox One to be the center of a home’s entertainment universe, providing Skype video calls and playing television shows, music and more.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft wants the Xbox One to be the center of a home’s entertainment universe, providing Skype video calls and playing television shows, music and more.

headline: Musical ‘Titanic’ Headed Back to New York
abstract: The Maury Yeston musical, which won five Tony Awards in 1999, including Best Musical, will play in Toronto this summer before coming to Broadway in the fall.
lead_paragraph: “Titanic,” the grandly scaled Maury Yeston musical about the ill-fated luxury liner, had a rocky Broadway run in the late 1990s, finally sinking in 1999, despite having won five Tony Awards, including best musical. But the show is getting what its namesake never had: a second voyage. It is steaming back to Broadway in a new production, to be directed by Thom Southerland (who directed the show in London last year) in the fall. The casting, and production details have not been announced, but a six-week out-of-town run has been booked: the show will be staged at the Royal Alexandra Theater in Toronto from July 22 to Aug. 31.

headline: Czech Police Reveal Discovery of More Explosives in Envoy’s Residence
abstract: The police said the explosives, found in the residence of the Palestinian ambassador after a safe there exploded, killing him, were undergoing ballistic tests.
lead_paragraph: PRAGUE, Czech Republic — The police disclosed on Thursday that they had found additional explosives on Jan. 1 while investigating the explosion of a safe at a residence in Prague that  killed the Palestinian ambassador to the Czech Republic.

headline: You Sleep More Than You Claim You Do
abstract: When asked how much sleep they “usually” get, Americans estimate just 6.8 hours. When asked to document their sleep the night before, slumber time jumps to 8.7 hours.
lead_paragraph: A couple years ago I wrote about how people don’t work nearly as many hours as they claim they do. That is, there’s a big gap between how many hours people estimate they “usually” work versus how many hours they log when asked to keep a time diary, especially for people who already keep long hours. (The typical person who reported having worked 40 hours, for example, actually worked about 37; people who claimed a usual week of 75 hours worked 50.) This discrepancy could be due to fuzzy memories, or a desire to sound more industrious, or both.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: the obesity paradox, vaccines and probiotics. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: the obesity paradox, vaccines and probiotics. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: The Gun Report: January 16, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Gun advocates argue that more guns means a safer society. Though successful defensive gun use is rare, we reported yesterday that a Good Samaritan intervened in a stabbing at an auto parts store and shot the perpetrator.

headline: Hariri Son Discusses Assassination at Lebanon Tribunal
abstract: A suicide car bomb in a Lebanese town was a bloody backdrop on the opening day of the Special Tribunal for Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Ben Hubbard reported, a suicide car bomber killed at least 3 people in a northeastern town in Lebanon, the latest in a string of attacks that many have interpreted as targeting groups backing opposite sides in the civil war in neighboring Syria.

headline: Judge Disallows Plan by  Detroit to Pay Off Banks
abstract: In a decision that surprised many, a bankruptcy judge said it was “reasonably likely” that Detroit could free itself of costly swap contracts if it sued the two banks holding them.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Thursday rejected a deal that Detroit had negotiated to help it move forward in bankruptcy, but he did offer some hope, saying the city could borrow $120 million it says it urgently needs to provide services to its residents.

headline: Apple and Samsung Widen Lead in U.S. Phone Market
abstract: Apple and Samsung Electronics, the two technology companies that make almost all the profit in the smartphone market, have grown even stronger in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Apple and Samsung Electronics, the two technology companies that make almost all the profit in the smartphone market, have grown even stronger in the United States.

headline: For Goldman in Europe, a 3rd Way to Get Paid
abstract: To skirt caps placed on bonuses in Europe, the company will pay some employees a salary, a bonus and what it calls “role-based pay.”
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:44 p.m. | To navigate bonus caps in Europe, Goldman Sachs will offer a new kind of pay class for bankers in Britain and on the Continent, a person briefed on the company’s plans said.

headline: What I Miss When I’m in China (and Arizona)
abstract: My dog is always ready to move on and look for something new. I can relate.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I have a German shepherd mix named Raz that we rescued when he was a 9-month-old puppy. Today, Raz is always thrilled to go anywhere, whether it’s to the park or to visit the vet. I joke with my managers that I wish our employees jumped up and down and yodeled with joy upon arriving at our company’s office the way Raz does.

headline: Roundabout Theater Will Revive ‘Noises Off’ on Broadway
abstract: The company announced plans to mount a new Broadway revival of “Noises Off,” Michael Frayn’s backstage farce, as well as the Off Broadway premiere of Tom Stoppard’s 1995 play “Indian Ink.”
lead_paragraph: Roundabout Theater Company announced plans on Thursday to mount a new Broadway revival of “Noises Off,” Michael Frayn’s backstage farce about blundering British actors, as well as the Off Broadway premiere of Tom Stoppard’s 1995 play “Indian Ink.”

headline: ‘American Idol’ Keeps Sliding; Ratings Fall 22 Percent for Premiere
abstract: Despite the falloff, the singing show is still a formidable competition, beating all comers Wednesday night, including the premiere of “Duck Dynasty.”
lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — Fox executives were candid about their expectations for the ratings for the premiere of the new season of “American Idol.” Several of them said the same thing here this week: We expect to be down about 20 percent.

headline: Obama Lauds Pledges to Expand College Opportunities
abstract: Scores of college presidents and corporate and nonprofit leaders promised initiatives toward enrolling and graduating low-income minority students.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Mobilized by the Obama administration, and egged on by both the president and the first lady, scores of college presidents along with corporate and nonprofit leaders on Thursday promised initiatives and grants toward enrolling and graduating more low-income minority students.

headline: Great Music for the Great War
abstract: The 100th anniversary of the start of World War I, this summer, will be heard around the world, with concerts in Sarajevo and California, among many others.
lead_paragraph: If 2013 brought the music world bicentennial celebrations of Verdi and Wagner and the centenaries of Benjamin Britten’s birth and the premiere of Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring,” 2014 brings with it a far grimmer milestone: the 100th anniversary of the start of World War I.

headline: Raf Simons’s Colorful Collaboration With Sterling Ruby for Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: The Belgian designer teamed up with the American artist, an old friend, to design a one-off collection under a new label.
lead_paragraph: Last night, the Belgian designer Raf Simons and the Los Angeles artist Sterling Ruby presented their collaborative fall/winter 2014 collection in a gutted raw space just off the Place Vendome in Paris. “We have done the whole thing together,” Simons said backstage about creating the label Raf Simons/Sterling Ruby with his friend of nine years. The two met through a gallerist when Simons first purchased a piece of Ruby’s art, and collaborated several years ago on a capsule collection of denim jeans and jackets. For this one-off set of designs for the label, which was presented in place of Simons’s eponymous line, Ruby decked out the runway with his signature large-scale sculptures. Shaped like red-white-and-blue fangs dripping from the ceilings, the artwork set the scene for the colorful clothes: khaki trench coats artfully appliquéd with brightly colored fabric strips and various articles emblazoned with words like “father” and “Abu Lang,” which Ruby explained stood for the phrase “abusive language.” “We loaded a lot of things into the clothing, both in terms of iconography and also our own path,” Ruby added. The pieces spattered with color were the most literal references to their craft — a real artist’s wardrobe.

headline: A Tire That Evolves as It Wears
abstract: Michelin has developed a tire for wet roads with channels that grow wider and hidden rain grooves that emerge as the tire is used.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — As your tires wear, their ability to maintain grip on wet roads diminishes with reduced tread depth. Michelin has developed a tire that counters the effects of wear with channels that grow wider, and hidden rain grooves that emerge as the tire is used, along with a special rubber compound for wet conditions.

headline: In Age of School Shootings, Lockdown Is the New Fire Drill
keywords: ['School Shootings', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Education (K-12)', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: At the whiff of a threat, a generation growing up in the shadow of Columbine and Sandy Hook is trained to snap off the lights, lock the doors and take refuge in corners and closets.
lead_paragraph: The bomb threat was just a hoax, but officials at Hebron High School near Dallas took no chances: School officials called the police and locked down the school this week. Separately, a middle school 2,000 miles away in Washington State went on lockdown after a student brought a toy gun to class.

headline: Sluggish Economy Prompts Europe to Reconsider Its Intentions on Climate Change
keywords: ['Energy and Power', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming']
abstract: European Union officials are having second thoughts about how aggressively to remake the Continent’s energy-producing sector.
lead_paragraph: The European Union, which for years has sought to lead the world in addressing climate change, is tempering its ambitions and considering turning mandatory targets for renewable energy into just goals.

headline: With New Contract, Rex Ryan Has Security With Jets, to an Extent
abstract: Ryan received a multiyear extension, but if the Jets fail to return to the postseason, the team will be able to escape without much financial penalty after 2015.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the most interesting aspect of Rex Ryan’s new contract with the Jets is not the extension, which was expected after management assured his return nearly three weeks ago, but rather its implications. The deal he signed on Thursday protects Ryan through at least the 2016 season. By then, the Jets will have not only made the playoffs again but won a few games there, too.

headline: A Personal Pleasure, and Eager to Share It
abstract: Toni Bentley’s erotic memoir, “The Surrender,” is now a one-woman play at the Clurman Theater.
lead_paragraph: It is tempting to open a review of “The Surrender,” the staged version of Toni Bentley’s erotic memoir, with a bad joke.

headline: Remembering Amiri Baraka
abstract: Ben Ratliff and Harmony Holiday discuss the poet, playwright, critic and polemicist.
lead_paragraph: Ben Ratliff and Harmony Holiday discuss the poet, playwright, critic and polemicist.

headline: Trips for Bikers — and Those Who Aren’t
keywords: ['Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The outfitter Sacred Rides has introduced trips for mountain bikers and their non-biking companions.
lead_paragraph: Sacred Rides, a Canadian-based outfitter that focuses on single-track mountain bike tours for experienced riders, has introduced a line of Bring-Your-Partner trips that mountain bikers and their non-biking companions can enjoy together.

headline: Dries Van Noten: Fall 2014 Menswear
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Events in Connecticut for Jan. 19-25
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Lawmakers Weigh Aid for Detroit on Pensions
abstract: State leaders are considering whether to devote hundreds of millions of dollars to help spare the pensions of retirees, while also saving the city’s prized art collection from the risk of sale.
lead_paragraph: Opening up the delicate question of how much help the State of Michigan ought to provide its ailing largest city, state leaders are weighing whether to devote hundreds of millions of dollars to help spare the pensions of Detroit retirees, while also saving the city’s prized art collection from the risk of sale in bankruptcy.

headline: Reader Comments in the New Design
abstract: How to find and submit comments in our new design.
lead_paragraph: As you’ve no doubt noticed, The Times has redesigned its blogs, including The New Old Age. Readers accustomed to finding comments at the end of the post will discover that they have moved. You can find them now by clicking the icon above the headline of the post, next to the date and time. Alternatively, scroll down from the top of the post and click on the squarish balloon that appears at the top right corner of your browser next to the “Share” button.

headline: Beach Weekend as Drill for a Double Root Canal
abstract: In “I Could Say More,” a play written by and starring Chuck Blasius at the Hudson Guild Theater, a writer’s beach house party devolves into tumult.
lead_paragraph: There’s nothing quite like the romance of a summer squall at the beach. An emotional hailstorm that erupts indoors is a different matter entirely.

headline: On Times Language Use: Dwarfs, Indians and More
abstract: Readers challenge the use of words and accent marks
lead_paragraph: The Times is made up mostly of words (although video is coming on strong), so it’s not surprising that many of the complaints and questions that come to my office are about language use.

headline: Milestones in Marissa Mayer’s Tenure as Yahoo’s C.E.O.
abstract: As Yahoo’s chief executive, Ms. Mayer acquired more than 20 companies, but ultimately struggled to turn around the web pioneer.
lead_paragraph: As Yahoo’s chief executive, Ms. Mayer acquired more than 20 companies, but ultimately struggled to turn around the web pioneer.

headline: Disputing the Origins of Four-Legged Treasures
abstract: Are they Bostonians or New Yorkers? Cherished chairs from colonial days go on display at the Bernard & S. Dean Levy gallery in New York, but their history is anything but clear.
lead_paragraph: New York and Boston butt heads over more than sports teams: Try 18th-century walnut chairs whose origins are at the center of a controversy.

headline: Monumental Cast, but Not Much Plot
abstract: Andy Warhol’s 1964 film “Empire” is seven hours of the Empire State Building doing nothing. What’s it like to watch the whole thing?
lead_paragraph: ANDY WARHOL was a genius, but he could be mean. He loved to make his acolytes squabble. He’d torture visitors by blaring the same pop song over and over.

headline: Baseball’s Expanded Replay Adds to Managerial Strategy
abstract: Major League Baseball announced that its teams had unanimously approved the expanded use of replay for 2014, and that the players’ and umpires’ unions had also agreed.
lead_paragraph: Tony La Russa watched about 130 games last season in his role as a special assistant to Commissioner Bud Selig. With the sharp eyes of a Hall of Fame manager, he paid close attention to plays that would need to be reviewed by video.

headline: Events in Westchester for Jan. 19-25
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: A Younger Christie and a Bridge He Wanted Kept Open
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie, as head of the University of Delaware’s student congress in 1983, gave assurances that there would be no gridlock at graduation time.
lead_paragraph: A crucial bridge. An anxious public. And Chris Christie at the center of it all.

headline: The Mostly Mindful Parent
abstract: I don’t see the mindful parenting movement as creating more goals for parents. I see it as putting a name to a goal most of us already have.
lead_paragraph: Mindful Parenting is having a moment.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Gaza Strip and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Gaza City, Indonesia, California and Nepal.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Gaza City, Indonesia, California and Nepal.

headline: Tortuous Trek to Something Like Normal
abstract: In his first novel, “Radiance of Tomorrow,” the best-selling memoirist Ishmael Beah writes of people trying to start new lives amid the ruins of war in Sierra Leone.
lead_paragraph: “A Long Way Gone,” Ishmael Beah’s harrowing 2007 memoir of his years as a child soldier in Sierra Leone’s brutal civil war, turned him into not just a best-selling author but also, for many, a potent symbol of hope. Here was someone who had emerged from years of murderous frenzy to write a memoir of not just uncommon horror but uncommon tenderness, topped by a smiling, open-faced author photo one reviewer called “welcome and timely reassurance” of the enduring power of humanity.

headline: Curtain Call | Men's Milan Fashion Week
abstract: We say goodbye to the fall/winter runway collections with this video that compiles the post-show farewells of 14 designers.
lead_paragraph: We say goodbye to the fall/winter runway collections with this video that compiles the post-show farewells of 14 designers.

headline: Daniel Radcliffe Returning to Broadway in ‘Cripple of Inishmaan’
abstract: Daniel Radcliffe will return to Broadway in April in the title role of “The Cripple of Inishmaan,” Martin McDonagh’s black comedy about a young man with a sea of troubles who tries to become a movie star.
lead_paragraph: In a last-minute arrival that will qualify for this year’s Tony Awards, Daniel Radcliffe will return to Broadway in April in the title role of “The Cripple of Inishmaan,” Martin McDonagh’s black comedy about a young man with a sea of troubles who tries to become a movie star. The production, which was mounted in London last summer by the Tony Award-winning director Michael Grandage (“Red”), will begin running at the Cort Theater on April 12, less than two weeks after the closing performance of the Cort’s current double-bill, “Waiting for Godot” and “No Man’s Land.”

headline: Lingenfelter’s Custom Corvettes Blend Eras
abstract: A company grafts ’67 Corvette body parts onto a sixth-generation Corvette.
lead_paragraph: Lingenfelter Performance Engineering is known for building General Motors vehicles — and occasionally some from Chrysler — that seem capable of breathing fire. The company also sells performance parts and upgrade packages.

headline: ‘Frozen’ Directors Take Divide-and-Conquer Approach
abstract: The two get the big news on an otherwise routine day.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 4:39 p.m. | Disney heroines don’t always ride off into the sunset on a silver steed with Prince Charming. Sometimes they actually come down with …

headline: ‘Lounge’ Acts You Can Dance To
abstract: Four New York festivals are presenting free late-night performances by offbeat artists at the Public Theater’s LuEsther Lounge this weekend.
lead_paragraph: They may have started as homespun outfits operating off Off Broadway against long odds, but it’s now clear that institutions like Performance Space 122, Here and the Abrons Arts Center have secured their rightful place in New York’s artistic firmament, staging high-profile festivals across Manhattan.

headline: From Easy Mark to Street Fighter
abstract: Some New Yorkers are turning to krav maga, a self-defense technique, as a safety measure and a good workout.
lead_paragraph: “MOVE slowly,” the instructor cautioned as students of the Krav Maga Institute, grouped in twos, moved menacingly toward each other. “We don’t want to hit our partner.”

headline: Curtain Call | The Designers of Milan Men’s Fashion Week Take Their Bows
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', "Men's Fashion Week", 'Milan Fashion Week']
abstract: We say goodbye to the fall/winter runway collections with this video that compiles the post-show farewells of 14 designers.
lead_paragraph: Designers project their personalities not only through their collections but also in their appearances at the end of their runway shows. To mark the conclusion of Milan Men’s Fashion Week, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 14 fashion visionaries.

headline: Facts & Figures: Paper Books, Vinyl Records
abstract: Print is still American’s preferred medium for reading books. And vinyl record sales are up.
lead_paragraph: Via Pew Internet: Only 4 percent of readers are “e-book only.” Print is still Americans’ preferred medium for reading books.

headline: The Scramble: A Simple Greek Lunch
abstract: Mark Bittman and the Greek chef Diane Kochilas make strapatsada, an easy shredded-tomato-and-egg scramble.
lead_paragraph: Mark Bittman and the Greek chef Diane Kochilas make strapatsada, an easy shredded-tomato-and-egg scramble.

headline: 3 Campers Linked to Fire Are Arrested in California
abstract: A fast-moving brush fire quickly burned at least 1,700 acres of land northeast of downtown Los Angeles, and the police said three campers in Angeles National Forest had been arrested.
lead_paragraph: GLENDORA, Calif. — A fast-moving brush fire that erupted Thursday morning has quickly burned at least 1,700 acres of land northeast of downtown Los Angeles, county fire officials said, and fire crews worked throughout the day to contain the blaze.

headline: The Set and Its Designer, Ming Cho Lee, Take Center Stage
abstract: More than 90 models, sketches and images on display at the Yale School of Architecture in New Haven show how Ming Cho Lee sets up new worlds for actors.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to overstate the impact Ming Cho Lee has had on the world of theater design.

headline: Reader Comments in the New Design
abstract: They no longer appear where you are used to finding them.
lead_paragraph: As you may have noticed, The Times has redesigned its blogs, including You’re the Boss. Readers accustomed to finding comments at the end of a post will discover that they have moved.

headline: After Tina Brown’s Exit, Daily Beast Brings In Editing Help
abstract: Noah Shachtman, a former editor at Foreign Policy and Wired, will be the site’s executive editor, and John Avlon becomes editor in chief.
lead_paragraph: The Daily Beast has hired Noah Shachtman, a former editor at Foreign Policy and Wired, as its new executive editor and has formally elevated John Avlon to editor in chief, according to a memo Mr. Avlon wrote to the website’s staff on Thursday.

headline: Russell Johnson, the Professor on ‘Gilligan’s Island,’ Dies at 89
abstract: After a busy career playing villains in westerns, Mr. Johnson was the brains of an otherwise clueless band of castaways that remains lost in reruns.
lead_paragraph: Russell Johnson, an actor who made a living by often playing villains in westerns until he was cast as the Professor, the brains of a bunch of sweetly clueless, self-involved, hopelessly naïve island castaways, on the hit sitcom “Gilligan’s Island,” died on Thursday at his home in Bainbridge Island, Wash. He was 89.

headline: Who Will Win the Foreign Language Oscar?
abstract: The Academy Award winners for the best foreign language film category have seemed preordained in past years, but the 2014 field has five strong nominees led by the Italian film “The Great Beauty.”
lead_paragraph: The Academy Award winners for the best foreign language film category have seemed preordained in past years, but the 2014 field has five strong nominees led by the Italian film “The Great Beauty.”

headline: Oscar Snub Is Applauded by SeaWorld Investors
abstract: After “Blackfish,” a documentary critical of SeaWorld, was denied an Academy Award nomination on Thursday, the company’s shares surged.
lead_paragraph: Fans of “Blackfish,” a documentary that casts SeaWorld in a harsh light, were dismayed to learn Thursday morning that the film had not been nominated for an Academy Award.

headline: Target Tests Small Store for Urban Shoppers as Young People Pick Cities Over Suburbs
abstract: The discount retailer known for big suburban stores will open a 20,000-square-foot outlet in Minneapolis to test a new format called TargetExpress.
lead_paragraph: Target wants to be a bigger part of city living, by experimenting with going smaller.

headline: Owen Pallett in the Moment
abstract: Photographs of Owen Pallett, who composed the score for The Times Magazine’s 2010 Hollywood feature, on the film set.
lead_paragraph: When Owen Pallett was working on the musical score to accompany The Times Magazine’s Hollywood feature “Fourteen Actors Acting” in 2010, I got to see him compose right on the spot. He was on set as Solve Sundsbo filmed Matt Damon, and in the interim until Michael Douglas’s shoot later that day, Pallett watched some of the other films that had already been shot and quickly began making notes. He played some short clips of music from the Internet to give us an idea of the kinds of melodies he was thinking of. I have this memory of Pallett pacing about in the dark, cavernous studio, his pad in hand as he came up with ideas for each of the shorts. That fast-working style was partly what inspired Miki Meek, former online editor of the magazine, to suggest we work with him (indeed, he wrote all 14 scores, which were subsequently recorded by the Czech FILMharmonic Orchestra, in less than two weeks).

headline: Uptown Mingles With Downtown
abstract: Anna Netrebko performed at Le Poisson Rouge on Wednesday, in a rare chance to hear her in the song repertory.
lead_paragraph: They say the old culture-world distinction between uptown and downtown New York has vanished, but on Wednesday evening at Le Poisson Rouge, the Greenwich Village basement club, it still felt like a meeting of two disparate domains. There was delicious incongruence between the sight of Mercedes Bass, the Metropolitan Opera’s elegantly coifed vice chairwoman, and the unmistakable scent of marijuana just a few feet away.

headline: Clip: 'Visitors'
abstract: A scene from Godfrey Reggio’s film featuring a gorilla from the Bronx Zoo named Triska.
lead_paragraph: A scene from Godfrey Reggio’s film featuring a gorilla from the Bronx Zoo named Triska.

headline: The Source | Doug Aitken
abstract: Doug Aitken interviews several dozen noteworthy figures about their creative process.
lead_paragraph: Doug Aitken interviews several dozen noteworthy figures about their creative process.

headline: Dutch Bonanza for the Frick
abstract: The Frick Collection has decided to keep its three Vermeers hanging side by side to capitalize on interest in a record-breaking show of Dutch paintings that closes there on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: As soon as “Vermeer, Rembrandt, and Hals: Masterpieces of Dutch Painting From Mauritshuis” opened at the Frick Collection in October, lines began stretching around the corner to Fifth Avenue from the museum’s entrance on 70th Street.

headline: A Salty, Sweet, Buttery Taste of Brittany
abstract: There are many reasons to visit this region of France. For the author, however, there was just one: caramel candies.
lead_paragraph: We didn’t come for the miles of shoreline, the promise of seafood feasts or the many history-rich towns. Even the dramatic views and craggy cliffs weren’t a draw. There was only one thing that lured my husband, Mahir, and me to Brittany in northwestern France: salted butter caramel candies.

headline: 1 Choreographer, 3 Works, 2 Premieres, 14 Feet and 2 Pianos (but 1 Pianist)
abstract: Ballet Next unveiled a program of three works by one choreographer on Tuesday at New York Live Arts.
lead_paragraph: Ballet Next, the three-year-old company directed by the former American Ballet Theater principal Michele Wiles, is dedicated to presenting new choreography with live music. That’s a worthy goal, but whose choreography? The group’s New York performances have been undermined by poor choices. But on Tuesday at New York Live Arts, the company unveiled a program of three works by one choreographer: Brian Reeder. This choice was good.

headline: THE SOURCE
abstract: Doug Aitken’s ongoing series of conversations with the creative individuals shaping contemporary culture.
lead_paragraph: Doug Aitken’s ongoing series of conversations with the creative individuals shaping contemporary culture.

headline: A Few Pearls of the Grisly and the Mundane
abstract: The Morgan Library & Museum’s first show of Spanish drawings covers four centuries with just 25 objects.
lead_paragraph: Although it’s well-stocked with French, Dutch and Italian drawings, the Morgan Library & Museum does not have many from Spain, in part because some of the great Spanish painters, Velázquez included, worked out their ideas directly on canvas. So while the Morgan mounted a 100-piece exhibition last fall on the topic of Venetian drawings from the 18th century, its first-ever show of Spanish drawings whips through four centuries in just 25 objects.

headline: Attention, Shoppers: We’re Singing
abstract: If store cashiers would sing, “Have a Good Day!,” at Here Arts Center, has the lyrics.
lead_paragraph: The first thing you noticed was the smell. Lingering fumes attested to a black box theater at the Here Arts Center in the South Village freshly repainted white for the American premiere of “Have a Good Day!” The hourlong musical-theater work, presented on Wednesday evening as part of the Prototype: Opera/Theater/Now festival, was mounted by the Lithuanian company Operomanija, making its United States debut.

headline: ‘Brooklyn Abolitionists’
abstract: Images from a new show at the Brooklyn Historical Society.
lead_paragraph: Images from a new show at the Brooklyn Historical Society.

headline: Painting With Words, Writing With Color
abstract: Dahlia Elsayed’s exhibition culled a decade’s worth of work, expressing the beauty she experienced in her everyday life.
lead_paragraph: Dahlia Elsayed thinks of the current exhibition of her paintings at the New Jersey State Museum in Trenton as similar to a short-story collection. Titled “Dahlia Elsayed: Hither and Yon,” it culls a decade’s worth of work, “and each has its own beginning, middle and end,” she said, describing them as “distinct narratives.”

headline: Clip: ‘Like Father, Like Son’
abstract: A scene from Hirokazu Kore-eda’s film.
lead_paragraph: A scene from Hirokazu Kore-eda’s film.

headline: Faith in the Early Age of Reason
abstract: “Piero della Francesca: Personal Encounters,” at the Metropolitan Museum, puts together Piero’s four devotional paintings in his 30-year career.
lead_paragraph: Narrow windows sometimes afford expansive views. Consider, for example, “Piero della Francesca: Personal Encounters” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, an exhibition of four small paintings made for private devotion by one of the foundational artists of the Italian Renaissance.

headline: New Snags for the Self-Employed
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)']
abstract: New federal regulations, created as part of the Dodd-Frank lending reforms, stiffen requirements for verifying applicants’ ability to repay.
lead_paragraph: Borrowers who are self-employed may have a tougher time obtaining a mortgage under new federal regulations requiring lenders to verify applicants’ ability to repay.

headline: Moira Dryer Project
abstract: This excellent exhibition is the first in New York in 20 years for the obdurate yet romantic wood-panel paintings of Moira Dryer.
lead_paragraph: Eleven Rivington

headline: Julien Bismuth: ‘An image as the _______ of a surface’
abstract: In the 1950s and ’60s, artists used silk-screened images in their canvases. Mr. Bismuth is showing the silk screen itself.
lead_paragraph: Simone Subal

headline: ‘Stay in Love’
abstract: This expertly packaged two-part group show is a sign of the Lower East Side’s maturation.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Cooley

headline: A Dealer’s Eye, and Life
abstract: “Hooray for Hollywood!” celebrates the life and artistic eye of Holly Solomon, an art dealer with an outsize personality who often became the subject of artists’ portraits.
lead_paragraph: When the history of galleries in postwar New York is written, there will most likely be a chapter devoted to Holly Solomon (1934-2002), the petite and feisty blonde who was a vivid art-world presence for nearly 40 years. In the meantime, her gallery is being revisited in “Hooray for Hollywood!,” a big, sumptuous exhibition spread between adjacent Chelsea galleries, Mixed Greens and Pavel Zoubok. The show has the added advantage of offering a relatively wide-angle view of the 1970s and the ’80s, a period that recent curatorial habit — most prominently at the Museum of Modern Art — has reduced to a depressingly thin gruel of Post-Minimalism, Conceptual art and appropriation art.

headline: After Old Mistakes, Hard Choices Must Be Made
abstract: Hirokazu Kore-eda’s “Like Father, Like Son” deals with two families who learn that their sons were switched at birth.
lead_paragraph: The Japanese melodrama “Like Father, Like Son” turns on the kind of cruel twist — children switched at birth — that’s the stuff of tear-wringing headlines and fiction. It begins with the revelation that two 6-year-old boys were given at birth to the wrong families, which now need to decide on the best thing to do. For one set of parents, Ryota (Masaharu Fukuyama) and Midorino (Machiko Ono), a comfortably middle-class couple nestled high in a glass tower, the revelation that their only son, Keita (Keita Ninomiya), isn’t a blood relation is a blow to their tiny family. It’s also a wedge that — day by day, hurt by hurt — transforms these loving parents into sparring partners.

headline: ‘Selling the Dwelling’: ‘The Books That Built America’s Houses, 1775-2000’
abstract: There are more than 200 books, prints and objects in the Grolier Club’s captivating exhibition.
lead_paragraph: Grolier Club

headline: Nasreen Mohamedi: ‘Becoming One’
abstract: Mohamedi is now recognized as a key figure of South Asian Modernism.
lead_paragraph: Talwar Gallery

headline: Josephine Meckseper
abstract: In the three years since Ms. Meckseper’s last gallery show in New York, her work has undergone a serious upgrade.
lead_paragraph: Andrea Rosen Gallery

headline: Most New York Voters Are Optimistic About the Mayor, a Poll Finds
abstract: Two-thirds of those polled said they were hopeful about the next four years with Bill de Blasio as mayor, and most endorsed a plan to tax wealthy New Yorkers to pay for prekindergarten.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks into a new administration at City Hall, New York City voters are highly optimistic about Mayor Bill de Blasio and overwhelmingly endorse his plan to raise taxes on the wealthy to pay for prekindergarten, according to a new Quinnipiac University poll.

headline: No Is All You Need
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners']
abstract: Addressing matters of a pushy friend, a reluctant aunt, an absent skullcap and a boyfriend on autocorrect.
lead_paragraph: I made a reservation for my wife and me at our favorite restaurant. We were really looking forward to it. I casually mentioned our plans to an acquaintance, and the next day, he told me he had called the restaurant, changed our reservation from two people to four. He then asked, “Would it be O.K. if we joined you?” I didn’t know what to say. I was so astonished that I agreed. But we don’t know this couple very well and soon began dreading a long night of stilted conversation. Was there any way around his maneuver? Anonymous, Louisville, Ky.

headline: Adrift Too Long, Searching for a Navigator
abstract: Having rejected God and a confining faith, I was alone and making up for lost time.
lead_paragraph: I was hurtling toward Brooklyn on the Q train, wearing cherry-red pants that hugged my hips. He was tall, bald, in his early 30s, with pale skin, tired eyes and a thin nose over a goatee. His smile was bashful, but his legs, in baggy track pants, were spread confidently on the orange seat.

headline: The Company They Kept
abstract: “An Opening of the Field” focuses on the San Francisco poet Robert Duncan and his life partner, the artist Jess, and the assorted band of offbeat artists and writers who found a common link in their friendship.
lead_paragraph: If you were young, gifted and odd, San Francisco was a good place to be in the years after World War II, when big changes were brewing in American art and culture. And that city is the setting for “An Opening of the Field: Jess, Robert Duncan, and Their Circle,” an exhibition that feels like a chunk of Bay Area turf lifted from the past and set down, untrimmed and buzzing, in New York University’s Grey Art Gallery.

headline: What the Writer Had to Edit From ‘12 Years a Slave’
abstract: John Ridley, nominated for his adaptation of Solomon Northup’s memoir, included details like how violin strings were made in the 19th century. That four-page description had to go.
lead_paragraph: To celebrate his Oscar nod for “12 Years a Slave,” the screenwriter John Ridley was visiting the White House on Thursday afternoon — not in a special capacity as, say, an honored guest who had penned a major film but rather as a tourist.

headline: A Performer’s Life Story Leaps ‘Over the Rainbow’
abstract: A singer and actor, Sam Harris wrote the recently published “Ham: Slices of a Life,” and used it as the meat of his cabaret show at 54 Below.
lead_paragraph: The singer Sam Harris, who attracted the world’s attention 31 years ago when he won the television talent contest “Star Search,” belongs to a breed of hyperkinetic entertainer and vaudevillian who has been “on” since early childhood. He is still best known for his extravagantly flowery and emotional rendition of “Over the Rainbow,” the song that capped Wednesday’s opening-night performance of his show “Ham: Slices of a Life,” at 54 Below. The show’s title is also the name of Mr. Harris’s just-published book of essays and stories.

headline: A Spectral Compound of Strange and Familiar
abstract: Steve Lehman tried out some new material with his octet at the Stone.
lead_paragraph: Steve Lehman got a knowing laugh Wednesday night while introducing the last piece in his first set at the Stone, a stutter-stepping workout called “Beyond All Limits.” He began by pointing out that it shared a title with a tune by the post-bop trumpeter Woody Shaw. (Perhaps you know it from the classic 1965 album “Unity,” by Larry Young.) And so, Mr. Lehman suggested, this would be a tribute of sorts to Shaw, “even though it sounds completely different.” Ha-ha, replied the crowd, conspiratorially.

headline: Model Casting Is as Distinctive to a House as Its Designs
abstract: In Milan, it became especially evident that the men wearing the clothes down the runway were as meticulously curated as the fabrics and embellishments that went into making the collections.
lead_paragraph: It goes without saying that when putting together a fashion show, designers are as careful with casting as they are in designing their clothes. Nowhere is this more true than in Milan, where the models’ looks are as distinct as the Italian labels they’re representing.

headline: Times Minute | The New Duck-and-Cover
abstract: Also on the Minute, police officers sleeping on the job and playing tennis through the heat in Australia.
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, police officers sleeping on the job and playing tennis through the heat in Australia.

headline: Times Minute | The New Duck-and-Cover
abstract: Also on the Minute, police officers sleeping on the job and playing tennis through the heat in Australia.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Adding Penthouses for Profit
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Condominiums']
abstract: Designing penthouse additions to affix atop buildings helps conversion make economic sense.
lead_paragraph: In today’s luxury real estate market, where more is more, and consequently better, developers and their architects have been busy designing penthouse additions to affix atop buildings that they are already converting into condos.

headline: You’d Never Know the Kids Are Upstairs
abstract: “Flowers in the Attic,” on Lifetime, is an incest story about children hidden away from a clan patriarch in his own home.
lead_paragraph: If you’re going to make a movie about four children who are locked in their room for years because their grandfather can’t know they’re alive, the last thing you want to do is play it straight. Unfortunately, that’s the only way Lifetime knows how to play it.

headline: Comedy Listings for Jan. 17-23
abstract: A guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Theater Listings for Jan. 17-23
abstract: A guide to productions in New York City, with a special note of shows in previews or about to open.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Movie Listings for Jan. 17-23
abstract: A critical guide to movies playing in New York, including film series.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Tripped Up by Crises on the Path to His Opus
abstract: “The Angola Project,” a multimedia performance piece narrated by Jeremy Xido, charts his artistic and personal detours and setbacks.
lead_paragraph: “The Angola Project,” a trilogy that unfolded on Tuesday and Wednesday at the Invisible Dog Art Center, is an intersection of places and cultures: a modern-day travelogue with stops in Lisbon, Vienna, Detroit, China, New York and, of course, Angola. Picture a tree, its leaves fallen away, to reveal a tangle of curling branches, each leading to a different story, or, in the cast of this trilogy, different sides to many stories.

headline: Window Is Opening for Change in Tax Code
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Taxation']
abstract: Enacting a plan that would close tax loopholes and lower rates, while raising needed federal revenue, would not be easy. But recent work by congressional committees raises some tantalizing possibilities.
lead_paragraph: Could this be the year that a comprehensive tax reform law is passed by Congress and signed by President Obama?

headline: Al Jazeera Denies That Journalists Detained in Egypt Confessed to Terror Charges
abstract: Egypt said journalists from Al Jazeera English detained on Dec. 29 had “confessed” to being members of the Muslim Brotherhood, but their network denied the claim.
lead_paragraph: Egyptian officials said on Thursday that journalists from the Al Jazeera English network detained on Dec. 29 had confessed to being members of the Muslim Brotherhood, which has been declared a terrorist organization by the military-backed government that took power after the ouster in July of President Mohamed Morsi, a member of the group.

headline: A Place Where Kitsch Gets All Dressed Up in Avant-Garde Clothing
abstract: Despite remarkable pieces by Dana Michel and Juliana F. May, the American Realness festival mostly descends into banality.
lead_paragraph: Seventy-five years ago, the art critic Clement Greenberg wrote the lastingly celebrated essay “Avant-Garde and Kitsch,” defining them as two opposite poles in art. Although they have always overlapped, it’s depressing how far kitsch (mass-produced or widely popular art) now masquerades as avant-garde (challenging experimentalism in art). As proof, just check out the current American Realness festival.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for Jan. 17-23
abstract: A selected guide to performances of indie rock, electronic dance music, hip-hop, neo-psych rock, folk-pop and more in the New York.
lead_paragraph: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Taking Brazil’s Rhythms and Stretching Them Out
abstract: The concert “Brazilian Explorative Music,” on Monday, featured players who put fresh spins on the region’s art forms.
lead_paragraph: Brazilian popular music has few rivals anywhere for structural sophistication. That hasn’t prevented at least one cabal of experimenters from setting out to add even more intricacies. On Monday night, the third annual “Brazilian Explorative Music,” a concert organized and headlined by the songwriter Pedro Sá Moraes, brought all the members of Coletivo Chama (the Flame Collective) to S.O.B.’s. They brandished advanced ways to construct, dismantle and sometimes disrupt a piece.

headline: Advocates for Workers Raise the Ire of Business
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Organized Labor', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Restaurants']
abstract: Business officials say advocacy groups often demonize companies unfairly and inaccurately, while the groups question why corporations have attacked such fledgling organizations.
lead_paragraph: As America’s labor unions have lost members and clout, new types of worker advocacy groups have sprouted nationwide, and they have started to get on businesses’ nerves — protesting low wages at Capital Grille restaurants, for instance, and demonstrating outside Austin City Hall in Texas against giving Apple tax breaks.

headline: Jazz Listings for Jan. 17-23
abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: On the Trail of a Vicious Killer, Eagerly Licking Their Chops
abstract: In “Big Bad Wolves,” three vigilantes hunt for a child-killer and rapist.
lead_paragraph: A foul tale foully told, the Israeli horror flick “Big Bad Wolves” begins on a dreamy, once-upon-a-time note with three children playing hide-and-seek. As a boy counts down, two girls, one dressed in red and the other in blue, enter a derelict building. One stays, the other leaves; one dies; the other, well, who knows, much less cares, what happens to her? Certainly not the writers and directors, Aharon Keshales and Navot Papushado, for whom murdered children are just an easy, conveniently blunt and effectively faceless (and headless) means to a self-satisfied, jokey and blood-slicked end.

headline: An Exploratory Stroll Up Park Avenue
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: The historic district proposed between 79th and 96th Streets has some people yawning.
lead_paragraph: The proposed Park Avenue Historic District, running from 79th to 96th Street, breaks new ground in landmarks preservation. Instead of sweeping up all the little brownstones and townhouses on the side streets, the district ignores them entirely; this district is all about the multiple-family dwelling. These are the comfortable residences of the rich, just as the brownstones and townhouses were a century ago, but is that alone enough for landmark designation?

headline: Small Plates Redolent of Both Sides of the Pyrenees
abstract: Opened about six months ago, Alain’s Wine & Tapas offers small plates of Spanish food, many of which have a French influence.
lead_paragraph: Walk into Alain’s Wine & Tapas in Nyack and you are likely to hear Spanish guitar music playing in the background. Yet the prominent piece of art in the room is an old map not of Madrid, but of Paris (oddly, with the northern part of the city on the bottom).

headline: Exploring Emotions, Painful and Sincere
abstract: The British pop band London Grammar performed on Wednesday at Baby’s All Right, a club in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Longing, loving, leaving: Those are the boundaries of the melancholy, impeccable pop universe that London Grammar has built for itself. It’s a realm of quietly tolling piano chords, modestly picked guitar parts and reticent drums, all deferring to Hannah Reid’s velvety, sustained voice. “This one always makes me cry,” Ms. Reid told the audience at Baby’s All Right, a club in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on Wednesday night as the band started “Stay Awake.” But it was just one of the many lovelorn wishes she would sing during a set that never budged above midtempo and never had to.

headline: Opera and Classical Music Listings for Jan. 17-23
abstract: A selected guide to performances of classical music in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Sea, Sky, Spray and a Love Triangle
abstract: “Summer in February,” directed by Christopher Menaul, focuses on a love triangle involving the painter A. J. Munnings at an artists’ colony in Edwardian England.
lead_paragraph: “Summer in February” probably deserves some sort of award for its churning romantic atmosphere. This Edwardian period piece is set in the Lamorna artists’ colony in the southwest corner of Cornwall, England, in 1913. The painter Winslow Homer would have been hard put to match the majestic images of spindrift flying from crashing waves in a movie that might facetiously be subtitled “Early ‘Downton Abbey’ by the Sea, Manqué.”

headline: Dance Listings for Jan. 17-23
abstract: A guide to dance performances in New York.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Wiki-Validation
abstract: Judith Newman’s hard-sought Wikipedia page went live at about 9:15 Pacific Standard Time. About 20 minutes later she got an email, “It was just vandalized, but don’t worry, I flagged it.”
lead_paragraph: Last week I wrote a piece for this section about trying to make it into Wikipedia. When I was rejected (for lacking references and, O.K., notability) there was an outpouring of outrage and emoticon frownie faces from friends. I also received many emails from people, several well-known, about their own Wiki trials. “I have been at war with my P.R. agency over the fact that I don’t have a Wikipedia page while it feels to me that every Tom, Dick and Harry does,” said the designer Liz Lange.

headline: Deception and Uncertainty Feed a Murky Justice
abstract: In “Reasonable Doubt,” a prosecutor thinks he has committed a fatal hit-and-run and then tries to derail the prosecution of a man fingered for the death.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for Jan. 17-23
abstract: A critical guide to the visual arts in New York and the region.
lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Events on Long Island for Jan. 19-25
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Q. and A. | Doug Aitken Unveils the Source, a Collective Meditation on the Nature of Creativity
abstract: The project, which takes physical form this week at an interactive pavilion at Sundance, consists of video interviews with dozens of high-achieving creatives. Over the next two weeks, T will exclusively present samples of Aitken’s conversations for the Source with people like Tilda Swinton, James Turrell, Alice Waters and more.
lead_paragraph: The last time we heard from the multidisciplinary artist Doug Aitken, he was hosting Station to Station, a “nomadic happening” aboard a passenger train traveling from New York to San Francisco, which saw a diverse group of artists, musicians, writers and thinkers stage events in cities across the country. At this year’s Sundance Film Festival, he’s presenting the North American premiere of another group project that explores the nature of creativity, the Source. Several years in the making (an early version appeared in 2012 at the Tate Liverpool), it’s a series of candid four-minute video conversations with several dozen noteworthy figures about their creative process.

headline: Italian Port Chosen as Transfer Point for Syrian Chemicals
abstract: The port of Gioia Tauro, one of the busiest in Europe, was picked because of its facilities for transferring cargo ship-to-ship.
lead_paragraph: The southern Italian port of Gioia Tauro, one of the busiest in Europe, will be the transfer point for hundreds of tons of the most deadly Syrian chemical weapon compounds en route to their neutralization at sea, the organization responsible for helping oversee the destruction of the arsenal announced on Thursday.

headline: Actions as Well as Prayers
abstract: The documentary “Band of Sisters” explores the evolution of nuns in the United States since the Second Vatican Council in the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: Fixed Income Drops at Some Big Banks, but Who’s to Blame?
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Company Reports', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Citigroup and Goldman both reported significant slides in fixed-income revenue, and banks tried to blame many factors for that drop-off.
lead_paragraph: Bank executives may want to blame an uncertain economic climate for steep drops in fixed income, but some analysts are questioning that rationale.

headline: Events in New Jersey for Jan. 19-25
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Both Ends of a Sculpture Spectrum
abstract: A sculpture exhibition, at the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington, displays traditional statues and busts in one room and abstract forms and assemblages in another.
lead_paragraph: The sculpture exhibition at the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington starts with two 19th-century marble figures, each about two feet high, flanking the entranceway like sentinels. One, titled “Industry,” shows a man wearing a miner’s helmet and balancing an ax on his shoulder. The other, called “Commerce,” depicts a sailor leaning casually on a post. Both were made by Emma Stebbins, an American artist who also created the angel that stands atop Bethesda Fountain in Central Park.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Jan. 17-23
abstract: A listing of cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: ‘Still Awake Still!’

headline: Spare Times for Jan. 17-23
abstract: A listing of walking tours, speaking engagements, cultural activities and Martin Luther King’s Birthday celebrations in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Second annual Black Comic Book Festival (Friday and Saturday) Commentary will be as abundant as illustrations when scholars, artists and collectors gather for this free symposium at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, 515 Lenox Avenue, at 135th Street, Hamilton Heights. One of the earliest black superheroes to appear in mainstream comics is thought to be the Black Panther, who made his debut in Marvel’s Fantastic Four in 1966. At last year’s festival, a costumed Black Panther and Superman mingled with Khalil Gibran Muhammad, the center’s director.

headline: These Criminals Are Throwbacks
abstract: The animated feature “The Nut Job” centers on a gang of humans trying to rob a bank, and a group of squirrels attempting a heist of a nut store.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday.

headline: You Have the Right to Remain Funny
abstract: Kevin Hart plays a man aspiring to be a police officer, and Ice Cube plays a veteran on the force in this buddy cop comedy.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday.

headline: It’s His Move, This Time on the Right Side of the Law
abstract: “Life of a King” stars Cuba Gooding Jr. as a chess-loving ex-con struggling to rebuild his life.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday.

headline: The 20th High School Reunion Rears Its Head
abstract: “Back in the Day,” directed by and starring Michael Rosenbaum, is full of crass bathroom humor and references to retardation that are in questionable taste.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: Drifting Closer but Never Enough
abstract: “Indigo Children” centers on the summer idyll of two adolescents.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: A Teenager Finds Freedom on the Seas
abstract: “Maidentrip” documents Laura Dekker’s journey around the world, sailing alone, at the age of 14.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: Back to the Digital Drawing Board
keywords: ['Net Neutrality', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The F.C.C.’s approach to net neutrality is dead, and that’s a good thing.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — IN less than 20 years, ubiquitous, reliable high-speed Internet access has gone from a vision to a novelty to a fundamental part of the American economy — not to mention our civic, social and personal lives.

headline: The New Midlife Crisis
abstract: Arvin Chen’s “Will You Still Love Me Tomorrow?” is a mature story of a married man struggling to stay closeted.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in New York and Los Angeles.

headline: Los Angeles Wildfire
abstract: Firefighters battled the Colby fire in Glendora, Calif., which broke out just before 6 a.m. in the Angeles National Forest, about 25 miles northeast of downtown Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Firefighters battled the Colby fire in Glendora, Calif., which broke out just before 6 a.m. in the Angeles National Forest, about 25 miles northeast of downtown Los Angeles.

headline: Video From U.N. Panel Grilling Vatican Officials on Abuse of Children
abstract: At a United Nations meeting in Geneva, committee members questioned Vatican officials about sexual abuse cases by the clergy involving children.
lead_paragraph: The Vatican’s former top sex crimes prosecutor told a United Nations committee on Thursday that “the Holy See gets it” when he was sharply questioned about the Roman Catholic Church’s slow response to handling cases involving clergy members’ sexual abuse of children.

headline: Domestic Workers, Foreign Tensions
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Domestic Service', 'Visas', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Editorials']
abstract: Readers react to an editorial about an Indian diplomat accused of mistreating her household help.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: De Blasio, a Critic of Charter Schools, May Need Them for His Pre-K Agenda
abstract: Mayor de Blasio is looking for classroom space and qualified teachers to accommodate 50,000 prekindergartners. Charter schools are willing, but not allowed to provide prekindergarten.
lead_paragraph: As a candidate for mayor, Bill de Blasio positioned himself as a nemesis of New York’s charter schools, arguing that they had a “destructive impact” on traditional schools and should have to pay to use public classrooms.

headline: Israel and Holocaust Terms
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: Abraham H. Foxman of the Anti-Defamation League responds to a news article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Talk of Tighter Restrictions on Fishing Raises Questions
abstract: The Parks and Wildlife Department last week discussed the possibility of imposing additional restrictions to some of the most sought-after fish in the state.
lead_paragraph: Catching spotted sea trout and flounder along the Gulf Coast is more than just a point of pride for outdoorsmen in Texas. The pastime attracts sporting fishermen from around the world, part of a renowned saltwater recreational fishing industry that adds $2 billion to the Texas economy each year.

headline: An Abused Child’s Death
abstract: A reader warns against indiscriminate foster care placements.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Shout-Out to Family on the Menu
abstract: It is clear at Eric’s Italian Bistro that George Echeverria has a following; many of the diners he greets are apparently regulars.
lead_paragraph: George Echeverria is a chef and restaurateur with a track record that includes Soigné in Woodmere and Amicale in Huntington Station (both now closed); his latest venture, Eric’s Italian Bistro in Mineola, made its debut in May.

headline: Asbestos Litigation
abstract: A lawyer reacts to columns by Joe Nocera about fraudulent asbestos claims.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Hanging Out at McDonald’s
abstract: A reader writes that the elderly want to be a part of society.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Leadership of Citizens
abstract: A reader responding to a column by David Brooks writes that leadership is not just about winning elections.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: India: 3rd Arrest in Rape of Danish Tourist
abstract: The police in New Delhi arrested a third man on Thursday in connection with the gang-rape of a Danish tourist and said they were still seeking five other men.
lead_paragraph: The police in New Delhi arrested a third man on Thursday in connection with the gang-rape of a 51-year-old Danish tourist, who was allegedly held at knife point for three hours by a group of men after she approached them to ask directions to her hotel in the city’s downtown. The police described the man, Bhagat Singh, 23, as a “vagabond” and said that they were still seeking five other men implicated in the attack. The woman refused to submit to a medical examination before she left India on Wednesday, but two of the suspects were carrying property they had stolen from her, the police said.

headline: Scandal in France
keywords: ['Recession and Depression', "Great Depression (1930's)", 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: President François Hollande does a bad, bad thing. And this has nothing to do with his personal life.
lead_paragraph: I haven’t paid much attention to François Hollande, the president of France, since it became clear that he wasn’t going to break with Europe’s destructive, austerity-minded policy orthodoxy. But now he has done something truly scandalous.

headline: Promoting Its Own Products, a Magazine Labels an Ad as News
abstract: Shape magazine has drawn a rebuke for an unusual case in which it served as both publisher and advertiser.
lead_paragraph: CONTENT from advertisers that resembles editorial coverage, commonly called native advertising, is drawing heightened scrutiny from the Federal Trade Commission, which wants to establish guidelines for labeling it clearly. Now Shape magazine has drawn a rebuke for such content from advertising regulators for an unusual case in which it served as both publisher and advertiser.

headline: Sheriff and Judge Battle Over Medical Care in Jail
abstract: In Henderson County, when a judge sent a diabetic inmate to a clinic for medical treatment and ordered the county jail to follow doctor’s orders, an argument erupted over who was accountable for inmates’ health care.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — In November, David Conis Jr. sat in a Henderson County courtroom, vomiting repeatedly because of his vacillating blood-sugar levels, terrified that he was facing a diabetic coma.

headline: Guy’s Guys
abstract: Christie’s Jersey edge is his greatest commodity, but a truly muscular politician can govern without acting like a thug or a Neanderthal.
lead_paragraph: People love a man who tells it straight, the authentic stand-up guy who doesn’t have to let you know he’s that guy. Harry Truman, despite looking like the bank auditor from Bedford Falls, was that guy, and earned his nickname — Give ‘Em Hell, Harry.

headline: A Bistro Sparing Few Details
abstract: À Vert, whose owners visited restaurants in France for inspiration on design, emphasizes standard French dishes that are deceptively-labor intensive.
lead_paragraph: The name of West Hartford’s shiny new brasserie, À Vert (rough translation: “here’s to green!”), celebrates the freshness of locally sourced ingredients while wittily mirroring the name of Treva, the co-owner Dorjan Puka’s superb Italian restaurant just around the corner. A restaurant that’s half a palindrome — how cool is that?

headline: You Can Look, but to Read, You Must Write
keywords: ['Archives and Records', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Data Storage']
abstract: The University of Texas System includes a database of requests for information, but it does not include the actual records that reporters and other curious Texans sought.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for The Tribune.

headline: In South Sudan, Some Lessons of Rwanda Learned, Others Revisited
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The United Nations has taken greater steps to protect civilians from the conflict, and while approval for reinforcements has come quickly, the troops and equipment have not.
