lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Twenty years after Rwanda, is the United Nations any better at preventing mass atrocities?

headline: GTT ★
abstract: The coming week’s events include a Martin Luther King Day observance at the Rothko Chapel in Houston, a Leon Russell concert in Dallas and a photo exhibition from the authors of “Historic Texas Courthouses” in Beeville.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: In Rare Visit, Nets’ Owner Offers His Support
abstract: Mikhail D. Prokhorov attended the Nets’ game against the Hawks in London, the second game he has seen in person this season.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It took several weeks for him to break his silence, and when he did, it was in London, not New York or Moscow, where he makes his home for much of the year.

headline: Reflections by America’s Buddha of Banking
abstract: As he prepares to step down this month, Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, discussed the financial crisis and policies adopted by the central bank.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, seemed so calm during the worst hours of the 2008 financial crisis that Timothy F. Geithner, then the Treasury secretary, once described him as a central banking Buddha.

headline: Climate Aids in Study Face Big Obstacles
keywords: ['Carbon Capture and Sequestration', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming']
abstract: The latest draft report by United Nations climate experts cites technologies that are still in their infancy, with few projects operating around the world.
lead_paragraph: Some of the technologies cited in the latest draft report by United Nations climate experts face significant obstacles before they can be widely put in effect to limit the impact of climate change.

headline: Spending Plan Ignores Overhaul for I.M.F.
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The bill that won final approval in the Senate left behind what might have been the best chance the Obama administration had to meet its obligations to the world’s other economic powers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday gave final approval to a $1.1 trillion spending bill for the current fiscal year, leaving behind what might have been the Obama administration’s best chance to overhaul the International Monetary Fund and meet its obligations to the world’s other economic powers.

headline: Under Gang’s Rule, a Mexican City Loses Hope in the State
keywords: ['Gangs', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Apatzingán has been under the control of a gang called the Knights Templar, with little interference from state or federal authority.
lead_paragraph: APATZINGÁN, Mexico — Like the shutters closing in an old Western, the metal gates on storefronts in this town slammed shut and their owners fled as first a powerful drug gang took hold and then the federal police and soldiers arrived to restore order, stirring fears of a bloody showdown.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Thick Soles for Sleek Silhouettes
abstract: Simple lace-up shoes get a lift with the addition of a modest platform.
lead_paragraph: The recent rise of the straightforward, unadorned black lace-up shoe has accompanied the growing turn toward minimalism in men’s wear, helping to balance the proportions of an outfit. But it’s the simple shoes with a heavier, thicker sole — less a ’70s revival and more a new platform style this season — that stand out this season. In Paris, Pierre Hardy presented a beautifully refined pair of double-soled shoes in two contrasting black leathers. He explained that they weren’t quite high enough during the first round of sampling, so he had to go back to the factory for a little retooling. “We can all use a little bit of height,” he said, smiling. In Milan, the platform lace-ups at Marni were a bit chunkier, giving a little extra lift. And monochromatic polka dots were applied to some of the thick soles at Jil Sander, adding some nice surface interest and texture.

headline: Korean Community Leaders Urge McDonald’s Boycott
abstract: Many in the Korean-American community in Queens voiced outrage that the restaurant had appeared to disrespect several older Korean people who treat a neighborhood branch like their living room.
lead_paragraph: Word ricocheted around the Korean enclaves of Queens, then onto the Internet, where it was picked up by Korean news media and sent in translation to the homeland. The situation inspired television news reports, an animated parody and on Thursday culminated in a summit on a Flushing street corner calling for a boycott: all because a McDonald’s had appeared to disrespect several older Korean people who treat a neighborhood branch of the fast-food chain like their living room.

headline: Ohio Execution Using Untested Drug Cocktail Renews the Debate Over Lethal Injections
abstract: The inmate, convicted of rape and murder, gasped and struggled, taking 15 minutes to die.
lead_paragraph: Dennis McGuire took 15 minutes to die by lethal injection Thursday morning at the Southern Ohio Correctional Facility in Lucasville for the 1989 rape and murder of a 22-year-old pregnant woman named Joy Stewart.

headline: U.S. Steps Up Scrutiny of Freight Train Safety
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Railroad Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Officials from the rail and petroleum industries agreed to examine quick ways to improve the safety of freight trains carrying crude oil after recent series of fiery accidents.
lead_paragraph: After meeting with federal regulators on Thursday, officials from the rail and petroleum industries agreed to examine quick ways to improve the safety of freight trains carrying crude oil following a spate of fiery accidents in recent months.

headline: Once Known for a Punch, Now for Smash-Mouth Running
abstract: Over the past few weeks, running back LeGarrette Blount has burst into the national spotlight for the Patriots as they prepare to face the Broncos in the A.F.C. championship game.
lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — The coaches at East Mississippi Community College were not quite sure what to make of LeGarrette Blount when he showed up for football practice in 2006.

headline: M.L.S. Draft: Red Bulls Select Two
abstract: The Red Bulls did not have a pick in the first round of Thursday’s draft in Major League Soccer.
lead_paragraph: Chris Duvall was at home in Duluth, Ga., sitting on the couch with his mother, father and grandmother when his name was called on Thursday during the second round of Major League Soccer’s draft in Philadelphia.

headline: Banks Keep Their Mortgage Litigation Reserves a Secret
abstract: Some investors are upset that banks will not divulge the amount of money set aside, but some banks say they don’t want regulators to know the number lest the authorities increase settlement totals.
lead_paragraph: From JPMorgan Chase’s $13 billion settlement over mortgage securities to lawsuits brought by bondholders, a barrage of litigation has been raining down on Wall Street banks. Yet the banks are not disclosing a number that is crucial for assessing their ability to deal those legal costs. And, curiously, the regulator that has sway over companies’ disclosure practices has not called on the industry to reveal this important figure so that investors can weigh the institutions’ health.

headline: Bumps on a Road to Revival for Yahoo
abstract: Marissa Mayer’s firing of her top lieutenant, Henrique de Castro, was her first public signal that turning around Yahoo would be far more difficult than some had suggested.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It looks as if the Google pixie dust isn’t so easy to spread around.

headline: IBM Plans Big Spending for the Cloud
abstract: IBM is planning to spend $1.2 billion this year on increasing the number and quality of computing centers it has worldwide, partly to keep pace with the competition.
lead_paragraph: IBM is moving rapidly on its plans to spend heavily on cloud computing. It expects to spend $1.2 billion this year on increasing the number and quality of computing centers it has worldwide.

headline: Converse All You Want, but Don’t Expect Connection
abstract: Jon Fosse’s “I Am the Wind,” at 59E59 Theaters, finds two men in a boat, lost on the ocean.
lead_paragraph: It can get pretty lonely for a guy in the middle of an ocean. That proposition — being pursued with intensity on screen by Robert Redford in “All Is Lost” — is also under consideration in the American premiere of “I Am the Wind,” by the Norwegian playwright Jon Fosse, at 59E59 Theaters.

headline: Goalkeeper Is Top Pick in M.L.S. Draft
abstract: Philadelphia, which had four picks in the first two rounds, swapped places with D.C. United to acquire the No. 1 selection over all in the M.L.S. draft and chose Andre Blake, Connecticut’s goalkeeper.
lead_paragraph: Philadelphia, which had four picks in the first two rounds, swapped places with D.C. United to acquire the No. 1 selection over all in the M.L.S. draft and chose Andre Blake, Connecticut’s goalkeeper. Blake is the first goalkeeper to be picked No. 1 in an M.L.S. draft. Chris Duvall, a defender from Wake Forest, was the top pick of the Red Bulls and the No. 22 pick over all. “We like how he gets up and down the flank,” Coach Mike Petke said.

headline: Congress Restricts Drones Program Shift
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Congress is placing restrictions on the Obama administration’s plan to shift responsibility for armed drones toward the military and away from the C.I.A.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an unusual move, Congress is placing restrictions on the Obama administration’s plan to shift responsibility for armed drones more toward the military and away from the C.I.A., congressional and administration officials said Thursday.

headline: The Convention and the Damage Done
keywords: ['Republican National Convention', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Editorials']
abstract: New York City agreed to pay $18 million to settle a lawsuit over the wrongful arrests of hundreds of people during a 2004 convention.
lead_paragraph: The Republican National Convention came to New York City in 2004. The event was mostly unmarred by chaos or violence, unless you count the damage inflicted by the New York Police Department to the constitutional rights of innocent people swept up in mass arrests.

headline: Arizona Hopes New Charter Schools Can Lift Poor Phoenix Area
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Charter Schools', 'Urban Areas', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Mathematics', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'Poverty']
abstract: A movement in Phoenix to open 25 high-performing schools in the next five years is focused on test scores in the growing Latino population.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — In Arizona, the charter school movement has sold itself as a safe alternative for middle-class families looking to avoid the maze of underfunded neighborhood schools. The movement is now expanding into this city’s most impoverished area for the first time, starting, in effect, an experiment in urban education.

headline: Mae Young, Unladylike Wrestler Who Loved to Be Hated, Dies at 90
abstract: Ms. Young, who pulled hair and took cheap shots, was a Hall of Famer who rose to prominence in the 1940s and fought her last round in 2010.
lead_paragraph: Mae Young — make that the Great Mae Young — who pulled hair and took cheap shots, who preferred actually fighting to pretending, who was, by her own account and that of many other female wrestlers, the greatest and dirtiest of them all, died on Tuesday in Columbia, S.C. She was 90, and her last round in the ring was in 2010.

headline: Breach at Neiman Marcus Went Undetected From July to December
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Computer Security', 'Credit Cards', 'Identity Theft', 'Customer Relations']
abstract: The company, which disclosed the data theft of customer information late last week, said it did not believe Social Security numbers or birth dates had been compromised.
lead_paragraph: The computer network at Neiman Marcus was penetrated by hackers as far back as July, and the breach was not fully contained until Sunday, according to people briefed on the investigation.

headline: Kerry Offers Assurances as Syria Talks Draw Near
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'International Relations']
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry urged “a positive vote” as the Syrian opposition weighed whether to join a peace conference scheduled for next week.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Syrian opposition neared a decision on whether to attend an international peace conference next week, Secretary of State John Kerry offered a public assurance on Thursday that the Obama administration had not pulled back from its goal of establishing a transitional government that would not include President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Health Care Reform Survives a Lawsuit
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Editorials']
abstract: A federal district judge reinforces that the health reform law was designed to provide quality, affordable health care for “all” Americans.
lead_paragraph: A long-shot lawsuit that could have damaged the effectiveness of health care reform got a well-deserved brushoff from a federal district judge on Wednesday. The suit was brought with the help of conservative legal groups and cheered on by Congressional Republicans eager to disable the Affordable Care Act.

headline: This Week’s Movies: Jan. 17, 2014
abstract: The New York Times movie critics on “Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit,” “Generation War” and “Big Bad Wolves.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times movie critics on “Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit,” “Generation War” and “Big Bad Wolves.”

headline: All That Remained of 100 Elephants: A Ton of Ivory, Turned Into Trinkets
abstract: New York City has the largest market for illegal ivory sales in the country. While it is against the law, the crime rarely results in prison time for poachers or sellers.
lead_paragraph: On a winter day in 2012, a man named John C. Fitzpatrick made his way to the fourth floor of 7 West 45th Street, to the offices of Raja’s Jewels, where he expected that he would find a cache of ivory.

headline: Contaminated Water in West Virginia
keywords: ['Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Law and Legislation', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Water Pollution', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Chemicals', 'Editorials', 'Water']
abstract: State and federal officials need to strengthen laws to reduce the risk of chemical spills.
lead_paragraph: The chemical spill that cut off water to more than 300,000 people in West Virginia for several days has exposed serious defects in state and federal environmental protections that allow many facilities and chemicals to escape scrutiny.

headline: Blue and Gray Still in Conflict at a Battle Site
keywords: ['Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)']
abstract: A proposed monument to Union soldiers at Olustee Battlefield Historic State Park has enraged the area’s Confederate descendants.
lead_paragraph: OLUSTEE, Fla. — There is an old saying in this state of seesawing sensibilities: The farther north you go, the farther south you get.

headline: A ‘Preventable’ Tragedy
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations', 'Editorials', 'Benghazi Attack (2012)']
abstract: Damning details emerge in a Senate report on the Benghazi attacks.
lead_paragraph: The latest report on the 2012 debacle in Benghazi, Libya, where Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens and three others were killed in an attack on an American diplomatic mission, offers new detail and a chilling bottom line: the tragedy was “preventable.” Released in unclassified form by the Senate Intelligence Committee, the report reflects a bipartisan consensus about the tragedy that is broadly consistent with the findings of previous inquiries. Even so, it contributes to a better understanding of what happened and why and what must be done to mitigate the chances of its happening again.

headline: The Inequality Problem
abstract: The current income inequality debate misses the point and prevents a nuanced, bipartisan discussion of our economic and social ills.
lead_paragraph: Suddenly the whole world is talking about income inequality. But, as this debate goes on, it is beginning to look as though the thing is being misconceived. The income inequality debate is confusing matters more than clarifying them, and it is leading us off in unhelpful directions.

headline: Syrian Rebels Say Cease-Fire Deals Prove Deceptive
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'International Relations']
abstract: Officials from the United States and Russia have urged localized cease-fires to jump-start peace talks, but some rebels have regretted making deals with the state.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — To the starving residents and rebel fighters in the bitterly contested suburbs of Damascus, the offer from the Syrian government can be tempting enough to overcome their deep mistrust: a cease-fire accompanied by the delivery of food supplies, if they agree to give up their heavy weapons and let state-run news media show the government’s flag flying over their town.

headline: Why We Like to Watch Rich People
abstract: Why do American television and movie audiences like to watch the antics and questionable behavior of the 1 percent?

headline: Forbidden Zone for the Police: Places Ready-Made for a Nap
abstract: Each precinct has a list of places where officers on patrol are prohibited from going because they are too inviting for those seeking a bit of sleep.
lead_paragraph: On a police station bulletin board in Queens, the officers of the 108th Precinct can see where their bosses do not want them to go. The auto body shop and the doughnut store, for example, because of suspicions that they offered police discounts. The Irish bar around the corner is forbidden as well, because the commanding officer was wary of drunken trouble.

headline: A First Lady at 50, Finding Her Own Path
abstract: In many ways she is the embodiment of the contemporary, urban, well-heeled middle-aged American woman. Except she is also Michelle Obama.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — She has perfected a mean forehand, is working on her yoga poses, dishes with girlfriends over brussels sprouts and dirty martinis (one olive) at the Mediterranean hotspot Zaytinya, pushes her two daughters to play two sports — one of her choosing and one of theirs — and said this week that the wonders of modern dermatology, like Botox, are in the realm of possibility for her.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, January 17, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, January 17, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “Old grudges die hard.”

headline: Unspent MetroCard Money Means Millions for M.T.A.
abstract: Some attribute the phantom fare influx of about $50 million a year to visitors, but many people simply lose their MetroCards or forget about them.
lead_paragraph: Think of it as New York’s biggest sock drawer, except that instead of nickels, dimes and quarters, what is squirreled away in its dark recesses are millions of lapsed yellow-and-blue MetroCards with digital loose change still dangling from their magnetic strips.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 16
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: De Blasio Names Ex-Bloomberg Official as Health Chief, but Vows New Approach
abstract: While praising Bloomberg administration efforts to reduce smoking and obesity, Mayor Bill de Blasio said he would seek more community advice.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio, who supported many of his predecessor’s health policies, from smoking bans to restrictions on the sale of large sugary drinks, on Thursday named a former top Bloomberg administration health official, Dr. Mary T. Bassett, as his health commissioner.

headline: A Finale of Sorts for David Stern, Who Predicts a More Global N.B.A.
abstract: In what he said would be his final news conference as N.B.A. commissioner, Stern said the ultimate aim was to have a European division with perhaps five teams in major cities like London, Berlin and Paris.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Nets-Hawks game here on Thursday was also the occasion for another N.B.A. landmark, the last news conference, as he pronounced it, of David Stern’s 30-year tenure as commissioner, which will end with the 71-year-old Stern’s retirement on Feb. 1.

headline: A Bill Stokes Debate, and Doubt, on Iran Deal
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: A Senate bill that lays down the contours of an acceptable final nuclear agreement with Iran is condemned by the White House as a deal-killer.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Its Senate sponsors describe it as a “diplomatic insurance policy” that will help President Obama cut a better nuclear deal with Iran. The White House condemns it as a deal-killer that could put the United States on a path to war.

headline: Corrections: January 17, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on January 17, 2014.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: With Rage, He Flails in a World Gone Deaf
abstract: In “King Lear” at the BAM Harvey Theater, Frank Langella manifests a tyrant’s reflexes in a multitude of keys.
lead_paragraph: Hey, who shut off the power?

headline: Woman Trapped in Modern Times (1920s Edition)
abstract: A desperate life blazes amid devouring shadows in the Roundabout Theater Company’s intensely stylish revival of “Machinal.”
lead_paragraph: A desperate life blazes amid devouring shadows in the Roundabout Theater Company’s intensely stylish revival of “Machinal,” Sophie Treadwell’s fascinating play from 1928 about one woman’s captivity in a hell called New York City. That life is embodied by the charismatic British stage and film star Rebecca Hall, in her Broadway debut, so you can bet that it’s going to burn bright.

headline: Now, Look Here
abstract: Friday fun with Kevin Der.
lead_paragraph: Because of a production error, the crossword puzzle that was published in Friday’s print issue, by Ian Livengood, was published in error. The correct puzzle for this date, by Kevin G. Der, appeared online on Friday. The Livengood puzzle will be published online next Friday and the Der puzzle will appear in print that day.

headline: Professors Detail Brutal Tangle With Police
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: A call to 911 for medical assistance in April led to handcuffs and a violent arrest on the Upper West Side.
lead_paragraph: The call was a routine medical emergency, a sick man having a bad reaction to medication. But before it was over, it involved the police and led to the wrongful arrest of a City University of New York professor on the Upper West Side. And it all started with a glass of wine.

headline: Galloping Once Again Into a Rainbow Sunset
abstract: Shout! Factory’s “My Little Pony: Classic Movie Collection” reissues four straight-to-video cartoons. Criterion’s Eclipse set “Late Ray” includes three films by Satyajit Ray.
lead_paragraph: ‘My Little Pony’

headline: Emerging From Dark Past, and Forgiving
abstract: After being released from prison, Leché Cornish is taking steps to rebuild her life after years of drugs and prostitution, and the loss of her children.
lead_paragraph: She was just 12 when she was kicked out of her mother’s house in the Bronx. She developed survival instincts, a brittle attitude and a willingness to engage in unsavory activities, for a price.

headline: Despite a Guilty Plea, a Ruling Allows a Man to Sue New York City
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Michael Poventud’s conviction for the attempted murder and attempted robbery of a Bronx cabdriver was reversed after he spent nine years in prison, but he pleaded guilty to a lesser charge.
lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court ruled on Thursday that a man whose 1998 conviction for the attempted murder and attempted robbery of a Bronx livery cab driver was reversed but who later pleaded guilty to a lesser charge could still sue the city for violating his rights.

headline: British Police Arrest 2 Women in Terror Inquiry
abstract: British police officers, acting on intelligence information, arrested two women in London on Thursday on suspicion of terrorism offenses.
lead_paragraph: British police officers, acting on intelligence information, arrested two women in London on Thursday on suspicion of terrorism offenses. One was arrested at Heathrow Airport as she was preparing to fly to Istanbul, carrying a “large quantity of cash,” the police said. The second was arrested in northwest London on charges of “suspicion of being involved in the commission, preparation and instigation of acts of terrorism.” The British are carefully monitoring citizens who are trying to travel to Syria to fight or get training with radical Islamic groups or who return from there, usually through Turkey.

headline: China: Uighur Scholar Detained
abstract: A scholar known for his criticism of the discrimination against Uighurs, a predominantly Muslim ethnic group, has been detained by the police, his wife said.
lead_paragraph: A Uighur scholar known for his criticism of the discrimination against Uighurs, a predominantly Muslim ethnic group, has been detained by the police, his wife said Thursday. The scholar, Ilham Tohti, a professor at Minzu University of China, was taken into custody when 30 to 40 police officers raided his Beijing apartment on Wednesday, said his wife, Guzaili Nu’er. Mr. Tohti, 44, has been one of a few intellectuals willing to speak publicly about what critics call shortcomings in the Communist Party’s management of the Uighur homeland in northwest China. A Foreign Ministry spokesman, Hong Lei, said at a regular news briefing on Thursday that Mr. Tohti had been “suspected of breaking the law,” Reuters reported.

headline: Turkey: Prosecutors in Corruption Inquiry Reassigned
abstract: Turkish officials on Thursday reassigned 20 prosecutors working on a corruption inquiry that has targeted the inner circle of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
lead_paragraph: The Turkish Supreme Board of Judges and Prosecutors on Thursday reassigned 20 high-ranking prosecutors working on a corruption inquiry that has targeted the inner circle of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan. The reassignments included the chief prosecutor of Istanbul, who has led the inquiry, the biggest threat to Mr. Erdogan since he came to power a decade ago. It was the latest move in Mr. Erdogan’s attempt to quash the inquiry. He has called the investigation a plot against him and his party, which faces three elections in the next 18 months.

headline: Emptying a Building Long Home to Activists
abstract: The residents of 9 Bleecker Street in Manhattan, a bastion of social activism for 40 years, are being forced to move because of foreclosure proceedings.
lead_paragraph: The three-story brick building at 9 Bleecker Street in Lower Manhattan, long a celebrated bastion of countercultural activity, was in a state of transitional disarray.

headline: Christie Lawyer Is Known for His Aggressive Tactics
abstract: Randy Mastro, chosen by Gov. Chris Christie’s office to aid the internal review of the George Washington Bridge lane closings, is an accomplished litigator with a reputation for aggressiveness.
lead_paragraph: The announcement on Thursday by Gov. Chris Christie’s office that it had hired a former veteran prosecutor to help conduct its own internal review into the George Washington Bridge lane closings raised more questions than it answered about how Mr. Christie and his staff will respond to the federal and legislative inquiries into the matter.

headline: Zuccarello Provides the Difference in Another Tight Game vs. Detroit
abstract: The Rangers improved their record in their last 13 games to 9-3-1 with a victory over the Red Wings on a third-period goal by Mats Zuccarello.
lead_paragraph: The Detroit Red Wings have been rare guests at Madison Square Garden the past two decades. Now, with the Red Wings part of a revamped Eastern Conference, their red and white sweaters will appear at the Garden more often, pleasing hockey purists who relish games between Original Six opponents.

headline: Unbending at Home, Pacers Rout the Knicks
abstract: Indiana improved to a league-best 20-1 at home in a victory over the Knicks on Thursday that featured the return of J. R. Smith to the rotation.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Coach Mike Woodson expected that the Knicks would need to play what he called a “perfect” game to compete with the Indiana Pacers on Thursday night. What Woodson got from his team was not the dream scenario. Far from it, in fact.

headline: Deflating End to Last Season Inspires Ducks in Hot Start
abstract: The Anaheim Ducks, with an N.H.L.-best record of 36-8-5, have been amassing victories at an extraordinary rate this season.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — The roots of the Anaheim Ducks’ excellence this season penetrate deep into the soil of last year’s frustration.

headline: Coburn to Leave Senate at Year’s End
abstract: Senator Tom Coburn, who has had repeated treatments for prostate cancer, said his decision was not about his health or prognosis.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Tom Coburn, the Oklahoma Republican known for his blunt personality and distaste for government spending, will leave office at the end of the year as he battles cancer.

headline: The Times Hires a Technology Columnist
abstract: Farhad Manjoo, a technology columnist at The Wall Street Journal, will write the “State of the Art” column.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times has hired Farhad Manjoo, a technology columnist at The Wall Street Journal, to write the “State of the Art” technology column that reviews new software and devices.

headline: The Real Health Care ‘War’ on the Young
keywords: ['Gender', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Those who criticize Obamacare as discriminatory against young men have turned a blind eye to how health insurance premiums are traditionally established, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: Landscapes Tainted by Asbestos
abstract: Deposits of naturally occurring asbestos have been discovered across a wide swath of the country, from Staten Island to the mountains of California.
lead_paragraph: For the past few years, Brenda Buck has been sampling the dust blowing across southern Nevada. Until recently, she focused on the risks of airborne elements such as arsenic. But then she started noticing an oddity in her samples, a sprinkling of tiny, hairlike mineral fibers.

headline: Word of the Day | incorrigible
abstract: This word has appeared in 28 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: incorrigible •\(ˌ)in-ˈkȯr-ə-jə-bəl,\• adjective

headline: Sabathia and Cano Reunite, via Jay Z
abstract: Pitcher C. C. Sabathia became the latest professional athlete to join Roc Nation Sports, the agency that represents Robinson Cano, Sabathia’s former teammate on the Yankees.
lead_paragraph: Pitcher C. C. Sabathia became the latest professional athlete to join Roc Nation Sports, the agency that represents Robinson Cano, Sabathia’s former teammate on the Yankees. Roc Nation announced the deal Thursday and sent out a photograph of Sabathia signing his contract with Jay Z, the head of the company, which negotiated a 10-year, $240 million contract for Cano with the Seattle Mariners in free agency last month. Sabathia, a left-hander who was 14-13 last season, is signed through 2016 with a vesting option for 2017 based on the health of his left shoulder.

headline: Mayor and Speaker to Seek Further Expansion of Sick Pay
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio and Melissa Mark-Viverito, the speaker of the City Council, are set to outline plans on Friday to significantly expand the number of city businesses required to provide paid time off for sick employees, according to three people told directly of the plans.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio and Melissa Mark-Viverito, the speaker of the City Council, are set to outline plans on Friday to significantly expand the number of city businesses required to provide paid time off for sick employees, according to three people told directly of the plans.

headline: Reid Indicates His Support for Medical Marijuana
abstract: The Senate majority leader said he began changing his mind after seeing the struggles of people who would have been helped by the drug.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate’s majority leader, Harry Reid, said Thursday that lawmakers should ease their opposition to medical marijuana, telling The Las Vegas Sun, “I think we need to take a real close look at this.”

headline: List of Smoking-Related Illnesses Grows Significantly in U.S. Report
keywords: ['Smoking and Tobacco', 'Liver Cancer', 'Death and Dying', 'Lung Cancer', 'Respiratory System', 'Research', 'Colon and Colorectal Cancer', 'Diabetes']
abstract: Long known to cause lung cancer and heart disease, smoking also causes diabetes, colorectal and liver cancers and erectile dysfunction, a new report from the United States surgeon general says.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a broad review of scientific literature, the nation’s top doctor has concluded that cigarette smoking — long known to cause lung cancer and heart disease — also causes diabetes, colorectal and liver cancers, erectile dysfunction and ectopic pregnancy.

headline: Super Bowl Ads Get Their Own Pregame Show (and It’s an Early One)
abstract: YouTube and Hulu are promoting teaser commercials for ads that will appear during the game on Feb. 2.
lead_paragraph: For the last couple of years, Super Bowl advertisers have been drastically changing their decades-old strategy of keeping mum about their commercials until the spots are broadcast during the game. Instead of trying to surprise viewers, many sponsors are filling social-media platforms with previews, teasers and coming attractions in hopes of stimulating additional interest.

headline: Sweeping New Restrictions Take Aim at Protesters Camped Out in Kiev
abstract: The Ukrainian Parliament outlawed tents in public spaces and imposed other restrictions aimed at clearing out hundreds of demonstrators from Independence Square in the capital.
lead_paragraph: The Ukrainian Parliament on Thursday pushed through sweeping legislation outlawing the installation of unauthorized tents in public spaces and imposing other new restrictions on protests that seemed aimed at authorizing the government to clear hundreds of demonstrators occupying Independence Square in Kiev, the capital.

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Disney) CLOUD 9 (2014) Two ace snowboarders — Kayla Morgan (Dove Cameron), who was dropped from her competition team, and Will Cloud (Luke Benward), a former champion trying to recover after the wipeout that ended his career — become unlikely friends and training partners when Kayla is forced to work at the dog grooming shop owned by Will’s mother. Their mission: for Kayla to learn the Cloud 9, the maneuver that ended Will’s reign. In “I Didn’t Do It,” at 9:40, five teenagers — the supercompetitive twins Lindy (Olivia Holt) and Logan (Austin North, above with Ms. Holt), and their three best friends, Jasmine (Piper Curda), Garrett (Peyton Clark) and Delia (Sarah Gilman) — try to explain through flashbacks just how they wound up in weekly predicaments. The mayhem starts as the twins’ parents return from a night out to find their home covered in foam, with pizza falling from the ceiling, a goat in the living room and a missing 91-year-old babysitter.

headline: A Woman’s Liberation, a Nation’s Past
abstract: Sebastián Lelio, the director of the Chilean film “Gloria,” talks about the film’s possible role as a historical parable.
lead_paragraph: The story line of “Gloria,” a drama from Chile directed by Sebastián Lelio that opens Friday, is straightforward enough: The title character, divorced and lonely, with self-absorbed adult children, yearns for a companion and frequents singles events looking for one. Gingerly, she begins a romance with Rodolfo, a retired Navy officer who turns out to be a jerk, and so she is forced to decide whether she is better off alone.

headline: Cut Here, Cut There, but It’s Still 3 Hours
abstract: Thelma Schoonmaker, Martin Scorsese’s longtime editor, and the filmmakers Frederick Wiseman and Joshua Oppenheimer talk about the art of editing movies — long movies.
lead_paragraph: What makes a movie long?

headline: Marilyn Horne at 80, Celebrated by Fellow Stars
abstract: To honor Ms. Horne on her birthday, the soprano Renée Fleming and the ageless songstress Barbara Cook turned out at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: The formidable American mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne turned 80 on Thursday, and to honor her, Carnegie Hall presented a song celebration at Zankel Hall. During the prolonged ovation at the end of this sold-out event, Ms. Horne hugged and kissed all 13 artists who participated, an impressive group that featured both emerging and renowned singers, including the superstar soprano Renée  Fleming and the ageless songstress Barbara Cook.

headline: Reluctant Action Hero, Reborn
abstract: As “Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit” hits theaters on Friday, the first four films in the series are out in a new DVD collection.
lead_paragraph: Someone once said, “Never trust a man with two first names,” but that wit obviously was not referring to Jack Ryan, the C.I.A. analyst and reluctant action hero of Tom Clancy’s series of spy novels. The closest thing pop culture may have to an American James Bond, the character has appeared in four films, which were collectively rereleased in December by Paramount Home Video as “The Jack Ryan Collection.” And now he is the focus of a fifth, “Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit,” which arrived in theaters on Friday. It turns out that every era gets a Jack Ryan to fit the times.

headline: Use of Microblogs Drops Sharply Amid Crackdown
abstract: A crackdown on online speech and competition from smartphone messaging apps curtailed the popularity of services like Sina Weibo.
lead_paragraph: The number of users of Chinese microblogs saw a sharp drop last year, as a crackdown on online speech and competition from smartphone messaging apps curtailed the popularity of services like Sina Weibo.

headline: A Conversation With: Summersalt, Band from Meghalaya
abstract: The musicians, who play Khasi folk music fused with reggae, progressive rock, gospel and blues, talked about the music scene in Shillong, known as India’s rock capital.
lead_paragraph: SHILLONG, Meghalaya — There’s no definitive theory on how Shillong, the capital of the northeastern state of Meghalaya, became known as the rock capital of India. Some say the Khasi culture of most Meghalayans has always celebrated music and is simply continuing to do so. Others cite the hymns brought by Welsh missionaries, while some point to the void created by the lack of Hindi cinema in this mostly Khasi-speaking state.

headline: Facing Tough Race, a Gandhi Isn’t Nominated for Premier
abstract: The decision not to seek the nomination is a tactic by a member of the family that has dominated India’s politics for decades.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — At a major gathering of the Indian National Congress party on Friday, Sonia Gandhi, the party’s president, announced that her son, Rahul, would not be formally nominated for the post of prime minister ahead of general elections, a decision made after prolonged deliberation within a party braced for a punishing race.

headline: Hiroo Onoda, Soldier Who Hid in Jungle for Decades, Dies at 91
abstract: Mr. Onoda was one of World War II’s last holdouts, a Japanese Imperial Army officer who guarded his post for 29 years, returning home in 1974.
lead_paragraph: Hiroo Onoda, an Imperial Japanese Army officer who remained at his jungle post on an island in the Philippines for 29 years, refusing to believe that World War II was over, and returned to a hero’s welcome in the all but unrecognizable Japan of 1974, died on Thursday in Tokyo. He was 91.

headline: In Mumbai, One Day at the Stadium, Two Strains of Cricket
abstract: The author, a fan of long-form cricket, laments the big divide between the city’s much-ballyhooed Indian Premier League team and the scrappy, homegrown Ranji Trophy players.
lead_paragraph: Last Saturday, Jan. 11, Mumbai’s cricket team lost its final match of the season. The 40,000-seat Wankhede Stadium had several hundred fans in attendance. I imagine that reading this news might befuddle a foreign visitor with an interest in cricket. After all, she might remember, Mumbai’s cricket team won it all last May, in a glitzy final watched by many thousands of screaming fans. What, they’ve already run the course of another season?

headline: Test Yourself | English, Jan. 17, 2014
abstract: Can you choose the best adjective and verb to complete some sentences from the article?
lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Crowd-Pleasing Blasts, With Civil War Roots
abstract: Why are T-shirt cannons so popular?
lead_paragraph: In “Crowd-Pleasing Blasts, With Civil War Roots,” Zach Schonbrun writes about the growing firepower of the ever-popular T-shirt cannon.

headline: China Unveils New Native Operating System
abstract: The Chinese Academy of Sciences called COS, designed for use on many devices including smartphones and personal computers, a strategic product for national security.
lead_paragraph: Chinese researchers have developed a new mobile operating system intended to break the dominance in China of systems produced by Google, Apple and Microsoft.

headline: Technology Is Not Driving Us Apart After All
keywords: ['Sociology', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Urban Areas']
abstract: It turns out, we may be more social than we were 30 years ago — at least in public spaces.
lead_paragraph: In September 2008, two graduate students working for Keith Hampton, a professor at Rutgers, raised a camera atop a 16-foot tripod to film down into Bryant Park, the sprawling green space behind the main branch of the New York Public Library. They hit record, then milled about nearby pretending they had nothing to do with the rig, as it semi-surreptitiously filmed the comings and goings of hundreds of New Yorkers. The charade didn’t last. After an hour, Lauren Sessions Goulet, the more senior of the pair, found herself talking to the park’s private security force, which sent her to see their bosses, the Bryant Park Corporation. She was nervous.

headline: Welcome to Watchington
abstract: Since the N.S.A. detained Jim Lo Scalzo for trying to photograph its headquarters, he has been noticing all types of surveillance devices all over his hometown, Washington.
lead_paragraph: We highly recommend viewing this slideshow in “full-screen” mode.

headline: What Were the Best Movies You Saw in the Past Year?
abstract: What do you think about the Oscar nominees this year? Did you see any of the films nominated?
lead_paragraph: The nominations for this year’s Academy Awards were announced on Thursday, and the three films with the most nominations are “American Hustle,” “Gravity” and “12 Years a Slave.”

headline: Times Minute | Kerry on Syria
abstract: Also on the Minute, smoking even worse than you thought and Michelle Obama's 50th birthday.
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, smoking even worse than you thought and Michelle Obama's 50th birthday.

headline: Shell Says Quarterly Earnings Will Fall 48%
abstract: Shares of Royal Dutch Shell fell on the news that adjusted quarterly earnings would be $2.9 billion, a significant decline from the previous year.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Roughly two weeks into his job, the chief executive of Royal Dutch Shell warned on Friday that the oil company’s fourth-quarter results would be lower than financial markets had anticipated.

headline: Times Minute | Kerry on Syria
abstract: Also on the Minute, smoking even worse than you thought and Michelle Obama’s 50th birthday.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: A Muted Beginning to Sales of Apple’s iPhone Through China Mobile
abstract: Customers were finally able to buy iPhones from China Mobile on Friday, but the turnout was underwhelming in Beijing, even with Apple’s chief on hand.
lead_paragraph: Apple is counting on a long-awaited agreement with China Mobile, the world’s largest cellular operator, to make major headway in China. But before Apple declares any major degree of success, the technology giant may need to overcome some significant hurdles.

headline: Rise in Bird Flu Cases in China Stokes Worry Before Peak Travel Time
abstract: The growing number of cases could pose a health threat as the world’s largest annual human migration begins ahead of Chinese New Year.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China is disclosing a steadily growing number of cases of H7N9 bird flu, including four more cases announced on Friday, reviving concerns among health experts that the disease may be spreading and could pose a further threat as the world’s largest annual human migration begins ahead of Chinese New Year.

headline: New York Today: Skate City
abstract: What you need to know for Friday and the weekend: rinks galore, more fair weather, and how to celebrate Martin Luther King’s Birthday.
lead_paragraph: Updated 10:18 a.m.

headline: Between China and Japan, a Tug-of-War Over Africa
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: On Africa, China is “sincere, unlike some countries” driven by self-interest and politics, said a top Chinese official making remarks after Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan wrapped up a tour of the continent.
lead_paragraph: Diplomatic tensions between China and Japan showed no signs of abating this past week as the two countries traded barbs over Africa.

headline: N.F.L. Conference Championship Matchups
abstract: Peyton Manning and the Broncos are favored because their offense has been loaded since Day 1 and the Patriots have had to cobble one together, but Tom Brady has a 10-4 record against Manning.
lead_paragraph: Patriots at Broncos

headline: Suchitra Sen, Star of Bengali Cinema, Dies at 82
abstract: The actor became known as India’s Greta Garbo for her iconic performances and her reclusive ways after she quit acting over three decades ago.
lead_paragraph: KOLKATA, West Bengal — The Bengali actor Suchitra Sen, who was often called India’s Greta Garbo because of her iconic performances and her reclusive ways, died Friday morning at a Kolkata nursing home after a heart attack. She was 82.

headline: Tension Rises Between Australia and Indonesia Over Migrant Patrols
abstract: The dispute follows Australia’s admission that its naval vessels inadvertently entered Indonesian waters while seeking to intercept boat people.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — An Indonesian government official said Friday that the country would increase maritime security patrols following an admission by Australia of breaching Indonesia’s territorial waters this week during operations to repel boats carrying migrants. The announcement is the latest diplomatic row between the two countries over asylum seekers.

headline: British Regulator Steps Up Review of R.B.S. Loans
keywords: ['ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTANTS', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Bonuses', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Financial Conduct Authority has hired Promontory Financial and an accounting firm to assist in its review of the Royal Bank of Scotland’s lending practices.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – A British financial regulator said on Friday that it had hired a consultant and an accounting firm to assist in its review of the Royal Bank of Scotland‘s lending practices, including claims that the bank pushed some business clients into serious financial difficulties.

headline: Laughing 'Til Death Do You Part
abstract: A comedy writer, Lew Schneider, and his wife, Liz Abbe, talk about how they’ve kept laughing over decades together in an interview with Dani Klein Modisett for her 2015 book “Take My Spouse, Please.”
lead_paragraph: A comedy writer, Lew Schneider, and his wife, Liz Abbe, talk about how they’ve kept laughing over decades together in an interview with Dani Klein Modisett for her 2015 book “Take My Spouse, Please.”

headline: Colorful Dries Van Noten
abstract: The designer’s autumn 2014 collection matched shades and styles in men’s wear.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “How can we bring back color in men’s wear?” Dries Van Noten mused backstage, before sending out groups of men, tough, rough and street smart, wearing blocks of color. There were shades of pink from peony to purple; an Yves Klein blue, with inky shades; and absinthe and neon green trailing to a darker shade of moss.

headline: Take My Spouse, Please
abstract: Thirty-three years after they met, Liz and Lew Schneider (an Emmy-winning comedy writer) talk on camera about how they still make each other laugh.
lead_paragraph: After a particularly bad fight with my husband that ended with me curled up in bed in the fetal position, I thought of something people used to say during my 10 years working as a stand-up comic: “Honey, I could never do comedy. That’s the hardest thing in the world.” Burying my head deeper in the pillow, I thought: Even the worst set is over in an hour; this marriage could last a lifetime.

headline: Workers of the World, Faint!
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Women and Girls', 'Occult Sciences', 'Fainting']
abstract: In history, magical events have been reported when indigenous peoples confront industrial capitalism.
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — Just over two years ago, at the Anful Garments Factory in Kompong Speu Province, a young worker named Chanthul and 250 of her colleagues collapsed in a collective spell of fainting. They had to be hospitalized; the production line shut down.

headline: Obama Outlines Calibrated Curbs on Phone Spying
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Privacy']
abstract: In a speech that seemed more calculated to reassure audiences at home and abroad than to force radical change, President Obama announced significant changes to the way the government collects and uses telephone records.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, acknowledging that high-tech surveillance poses a threat to civil liberties, announced significant changes on Friday to the way the government collects and uses telephone records, but left in place many other pillars of the nation’s intelligence programs.

headline: Junya Watanabe: Fall 2014 Menswear
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Meet Maria Contreras-Sweet: An S.B.A. Nominee With Lending Experience
abstract: In 2006, Ms. Contreras-Sweet helped organize what is now called ProAmérica Bank in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Maria Contreras-Sweet, the woman chosen by President Obama to lead the Small Business Administration, has a long and varied résumé: corporate executive, public servant, ambassador for a host of causes.

headline: Shire to Take Loss on Dermagraft Sale
abstract: The Irish biopharmaceutical company has sold its skin substitute Dermagraft to Organogenesis and will record a $650 million loss on the sale.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Irish biopharmaceutical company Shire has sold its skin substitute Dermagraft to Organogenesis and will record a $650 million loss on the sale.

headline: Phillip Lim Draws Inspiration From America’s West
abstract: The designer’s collection included all the elements: big coats, a full riding cloak, cowhide bags and big easy shapes with the focus on square cuts.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A scarf at the neck, a dashing checked jacket and a horse’s-head print on a sweater. It looked like cowboy country.

headline: Lady Gaga to Sing Again in China with ‘Artpop’
abstract: More than two years after several of Lady Gaga’s songs were banned in China, the authorities are permitting her new album, “Artpop,” to go on sale.
lead_paragraph: Lady Gaga can sing legally in China again, more than two years after her provocative lyrics and persona landed her on a government blacklist. The change of heart by the censors means her new album, “Artpop,” can be released in China.

headline: Banks Keep Mouths Shut on Litigation Reserves
abstract: Banks are setting aside cash to settle impending legal settlements, but they are not sharing their litigation reserve levels. | Goldman’s profit falls 19 percent. | A judge rejected Detroit’s plan to free itself from interest-rate swaps. | The Sacramento Kings will start accepting Bitcoin.
lead_paragraph: BANKS’ LITIGATION RESERVES KEPT SECRET  |  Bracing for a barrage of legal settlements for their roles in mortgage practices leading up to the financial crisis, banks have been setting aside cash to fund impending payouts. But while understanding the size of these funds, called litigation reserves, is necessary for weighing the banks’ financial strength, many banks are continuing to keep this figure secret, Peter Eavis writes in DealBook.

headline: At the Australian Open, It’s Not the Heat, It’s the Stupidity
abstract: There is a widening gulf between the way officials have attempted to portray the impact of the heat wave and what has actually happened with the players.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — The Australian Sauna Championships, disguised as a Grand Slam tennis tournament, finally ended Saturday. Advancement had depended on survival, on remaining upright, on shade and hydration and on the coolest accessory in sports, something called an ice vest.

headline: General Electric’s Industrial Segments Lift Earnings
abstract: The fourth-quarter earnings of 53 cents a share, bolstered by growth in G.E.’s industrial businesses and an improving United States economy, were in line with expectations.
lead_paragraph: General Electric is getting back to its industrial roots.

headline: U.N. Says Climate Situation Is Critical
abstract: And nations are dragging their feet.
lead_paragraph: And nations are dragging their feet.

headline: You Watch This Film as It Watches You
abstract: For his wordless black-and-white film “Visitors,” Godfrey Reggio had a tough time shooting some of the images.
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of the new film “Visitors,” opening on Friday, an image fades up slowly from black. As Philip Glass’s anticipatory strings play on the soundtrack, the figure dominating the screen is gradually revealed to be a gorilla. But shown in slow motion against a black background, the magnificent animal looks as if she is solemnly posing. Barely moving, she stares right into the lens, and seemingly right into the viewer’s eyes for moments on end.

headline: Easy, Breezy, Trending
abstract: On the eve of hosting the Academy Awards ceremony, Ellen DeGeneres took a reporter behind the scenes on her talk show.
lead_paragraph: BURBANK, Calif. — Since 2011, when “The Oprah Winfrey Show” ended its stunning run, daytime TV has been on a desperate search for a new supreme ruler, a star capable of delivering more than enormous ratings (Dr. Phil can do that) and acting as more than a moral compass (bless you, Judge Judy). The job requires a person who can do those things while also serving as an arbiter of American pop culture.

headline: A Debt-Related Charge of $1.2 Billion Puts a Dent in the Profit of Morgan Stanley
abstract: The bank disclosed it had set aside an unusually large $1.2 billion for litigation costs associated with its mortgage lending businesses and other credit crisis headaches.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:38 p.m. |

headline: Syria Proposes Aleppo Cease-Fire as Opposition Weighs Attending Peace Talks
abstract: The proposal appeared to be an effort by the government to show good faith before a peace conference next week aimed at ending Syria’s civil war.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian government on Friday proposed a cease-fire with rebel forces in the city of Aleppo and said it was willing to exchange detainee lists with the opposition to pave the way for a possible prisoner exchange.

headline: Daily Report: Apple’s China Mobile Deal Gets Off to a Weak Start
abstract: Instead of the round-the-block lines that have greeted Apple product introductions in China and other countries in the past, only about a dozen customers showed up to buy iPhones at the opening of a store in Beijing on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Apple has been counting on a long-awaited agreement with China Mobile, the world’s largest cellular operator, to reverse its fortunes in China. If the muted reception Friday, when customers were finally able to buy iPhones from China Mobile, is any indication, the companies may have to work harder to whip up enthusiasm, Eric Pfanner reports.

headline: A Missing Comb-Over, a Miffed Actor and Other Surprises
abstract: Beyond the snubs of the Oscar nominations, there were mysteries like how “American Hustle” was overlooked for makeup and hairstyling. Meanwhile. Robert Redford had some gripes with how the distribution of his film “All Is Lost” was handled.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the wake of the Oscar nominations on Thursday, there are snubs and then there are head-scratchers, like how, exactly, did “American Hustle” miss its chance for makeup and hairstyling? The opening minutes of the film are a long paean to the artifice and artfulness of Christian Bale’s comb-over.

headline: Please Be Alert and Aware of Your Surroundings
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: Despite the recorded warning to be alert, a commuter finds the soldiers at Pennsylvania Station to be rather laid-back.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: The Case for a Better U
abstract: It’s a lot worse than the usual number suggests.
lead_paragraph: Unemployment has fallen a lot recently, but for a peculiar reason: not so much rising employment as a falling share of the population actively looking for work. This has sparked a debate over how much of the decline in labor force participation reflects a weak job market — why bother looking? — and how much demography, changing culture, and all that. And it looks like one of those debates that will go on, unresolved, for a long time — certainly past the point where a decisive win for one side or the other can inform policy.

headline: Givenchy: Fall 2014 Menswear
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Men’s Paris Fashion Week: Kolor Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Luise Damgaard.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

headline: Skills Practice | Persuading an Audience Using Logos, Pathos and Ethos
abstract: In this edition of Skills Practice, students explore how writers use the rhetorical devices logos, pathos and ethos to appeal to an audience. They then try out their own use of rhetoric to make a persuasive argument.
lead_paragraph: Update: Jan. 22, 2014

headline: The Glittering Crises
abstract: Even under the gold standard, inflation was essential.
lead_paragraph: Many people have pointed out that the euro has ended up functioning a lot like the gold standard — and in so doing has replicated the “gold fetters” that many economic historians say played a big role in the propagation of the Great Depression.

headline: Remains Examined for Link to Missing Boy With Autism
abstract: The authorities were working to determine if human remains that washed ashore are those of Avonte Oquendo, 14, who disappeared more than three months ago.
lead_paragraph: Nearly every morning for the past 104 mornings, Avonte Oquendo’s mother, Vanessa Fontaine, has woken up to the same nightmare. But each day, she wiped away tears and pressed on in the search for her missing son, a boy with severe autism who was last seen in early October. Surveillance video showed the 14-year-old darting out of his school in Long Island City, Queens, in the middle of the day.

headline: In Our Pages: January 18
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: 1939: 25 Million Nickels Stolen

headline: Why We Talk About the One Percent
abstract: Don’t dilute the wolves.
lead_paragraph: Many people in Washington, even those willing to concede that inequality has been rising rapidly, are uncomfortable talking about the famous 1 percent — perhaps because it sounds too populist, too much like an invitation to crowds with pitchforks. For a long time respectable discussion focused on the top 20 percent; today I see my colleague David Brooks talking about the top 5 percent.

headline: Givenchy: Basketball and Bauhaus
abstract: Riccardo Tisci sent out a collection that melded street wise and office smart.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The basketball court was framed by crisscross mesh; the lines were red neon strips. And from the first moment that a model in a tailored outfit stalked the court, followed by outfits with fiery colors licking across the chest, the result was clear: game to Givenchy.

headline: Lost in the Gallery-Industrial Complex
abstract: Most every aspect of the art world has been affected by high-priced galleries and collectors with deep pockets.
lead_paragraph: A new year. A new New York mayor. Old problems with art in New York. I have a collection of complaints and a few (very few) ideas for change.

headline: Pennsylvania Voter ID Law Struck Down as Judge Cites Burden on Citizens
abstract: A judge said the law placed an unreasonable burden on people trying to exercise their fundamental right to vote.
lead_paragraph: In a strongly worded decision, a state judge on Friday struck down Pennsylvania’s 2012 law requiring voters to produce a state-approved photo ID at the polls, setting up a potential Supreme Court confrontation that could have implications for other such laws across the country.

headline: What They Said: Rahul Gandhi’s Speech at Congress Executive Meeting
abstract: In an unusually passionate address on Friday, Rahul Gandhi praised the governing party as the defenders of the people’s will and criticized the main opposition as being undemocratic.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI – In an unusually passionate speech at the Indian National Congress’s national meeting on Friday, Rahul Gandhi praised the governing party as the defenders of the people’s will and criticized the main opposition as being undemocratic.

headline: Barkhad Abdi Breaks the Cool Rule
abstract: The actor who plays the lead Somali pirate in “Captain Phillips” wasn’t fazed by invitations from Amy Poehler and Tina Fey. An Oscar nomination is a different story.
lead_paragraph: Few veteran actors might know how to react to Amy Poehler’s admonition that “there’s such a beautiful life lesson here, everyone. Sleep with your limo driver tonight — before he gets famous.” Or Tina Fey’s offer to come to her room: “I’m talking to you, Somali pirates. I am de captain now.”

headline: Citigroup Report Urges Deal-Making, Activist Thinking
abstract: Many companies are enjoying record high valuations not because of strong results but because of investor optimism, Citigroup says in a new report. It has suggestions for bolstering earnings so that valuations are based not on wishful thinking but on the bottom line.
lead_paragraph: Citigroup has a stark message for its corporate clients: They are going to have to justify those lofty valuations.

headline: Where to Turn if You’re Shunning Sugar
abstract: Readers offered their own advice about how to satisfy a sweet tooth on fewer calories.
lead_paragraph: Inspired by Daniel Engber’s recent magazine article about the challenge of creating a natural sugar substitute, readers in the comments section swapped advice about how to satisfy a sweet tooth with fewer calories, including:

headline: Reacting to a Clash Under the Golden Arches
abstract: Some readers sided with a group of older Korean patrons who gather at a McDonald’s in Queens for hours, others sided with the fast-food franchise that wants them out, and still more offered suggestions.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Maslin Nir and Jiha Ham reported this week on a McDonald’s in Flushing, Queens, that for months has been clashing with a group of older Korean patrons.

headline: Hertz’s New Model: Revamped Rental Offices
abstract: Hertz is redesigning many of its branches, which will include self-service as well as staffed kiosks and retail shops selling food.
lead_paragraph: The car rental company Hertz, which has 8,800 worldwide locations, is in the process of revamping several hundred of its branches to make them more user-friendly.

headline: Analysis of Obama’s N.S.A. Speech
abstract: President Obama delivered a much-anticipated speech Friday morning in which he announced that he is pulling back the government’s wide net of surveillance at home and abroad.
lead_paragraph: President Obama delivered a much-anticipated speech Friday morning in which he announced that he is pulling back the government’s wide net of surveillance at home and abroad. Times reporters provided live analysis of the speech.

headline: James Earl Jones on Darth Vader, Mufasa and, natch, Totes McGotes
abstract: Also, the secret to longevity and how to freak out truck drivers.
lead_paragraph: Your new film, “Gimme Shelter,” is the latest of more than 65 features that you’ve acted in. What’s the secret to longevity? The secret is never forgetting that you’re a journeyman actor and that nothing is your final thing, nothing is your greatest thing, nothing is your worst thing. I still consider myself a novice.

headline: Who Made That Captcha?
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Computer Security', 'Inventions and Patents']
abstract: A Turing test in reverse.
lead_paragraph: Before the presidential election in 1996, a computer company called Digital Equipment Corporation set up a website for opinion polls. There was one problem, though: Partisan hackers could use bots to fill the site with useless spam. So D.E.C. put a pixelated image of the U.S. flag at a random spot on the screen that users had to click before they registered their votes.

headline: Tough Sledding
abstract: New Yorkers take snowy rides on skateboards, lunch trays, sheet metal and more.
lead_paragraph: There was plenty of snow in New York City for the first weekend of the year after a huge storm hit the Northeast, but sleds appear to have been in shorter supply. The best alternatives, according to the photographer Nolan Conway, who visited several parks in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens to capture the resourceful at play, were made of glossy things and included corrugated plastic and skateboards with their wheels removed. Laundry baskets, broken sleds and mats were O.K.; brown cardboard boxes, lunch trays and trash-can lids didn’t work. And in the dangerous category: sheet metal. Some with real sleds, like Anyssa Mundle, 11, seemed to enjoy using found objects just as much. “This is a check off my Christmas list,” Anyssa said. “Sledding and going in a magazine.” Julie Bosman

headline: The Mistress at the Funeral
abstract: A guest list from beyond the grave.
lead_paragraph: My good friend just died. In the last weeks of his lucidity, he told me he absolutely wanted his mistress of many years to attend his memorial service. He relayed a few messages through me to her, as he lay dying. His wife did well in her role as caregiver, running an in-house hospice for him. But their marriage was — by his account and all available evidence — in shambles for years. His wife knew the mistress existed, and only in the waning months of his life did my friend sever the extramarital relationship (in order to die with less complexity at home). There will be a funeral, hosted by his family. The dilemma: Enact the expressed will of my friend and ensure the mistress is present or — given the wife’s emotional fragility and proneness to angry outbursts — enact my friend’s constant goal of peace and simplicity for his child. NAME WITHHELD, NEW YORK CITY

headline: Reply All: The 1.5.14 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: A SPECK IN THE SEA

headline: Members of a Very Small Club
keywords: ['Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Two strangers gave me the self-help I’d been waiting a lifetime for.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, I rented a house from a stranger. Her name was Robin, and when I arrived to collect the keys, she gave me a quick tutorial on the washer-dryer and showed me how to restart the router. There was an uncomfortable intimacy in seeing her space, her cats, her belongings, which I’d been hoping to avoid so I could more easily pretend the house was mine. But when she offered me a cup of tea, I accepted, mostly because I didn’t want her to change her mind about renting the house to me.

headline: Popcast: Hearing Amiri Baraka
abstract: Ben Ratliff and Harmony Holiday discuss the poet, playwright, critic and polemicist.
lead_paragraph: Most would agree that the essence of the poet, playwright, critic and polemicist Amiri Baraka, who died last week at the age of 79, is words on paper, and the ideas resounding from the words about black art, memory, racism, class struggle and political power relationships. There’s more to it, though.

headline: Hands and Mind: Raf Simons and Sterling Ruby
abstract: Raf Simons has good taste in art. That he proposed doing a complete line with Sterling Ruby is not surprising.
lead_paragraph: Raf Simons has good taste in art. Mike Kelley, Paul McCarthy, Cindy Sherman, Christopher Wool and Brian Calvin are among the artists whose work he admires and in some cases owns. About 15 years ago, Mr. Simons took a break from fashion to help a Belgian businessman expand his art collection. In more recent years, art has been a keystone of his fashion. He collaborated with Mr. Calvin on some T-shirts for his Antwerp-based Raf Simons men’s label, and in February 2013, he paid brilliant homage to Surrealism in a collection for Dior, where he is creative director.

headline: Why Renters Renovate
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: As the market softens in Manhattan, some landlords will negotiate with renters who want to make changes.
lead_paragraph: After finding a two-bedroom one-bath fixer-upper in the financial district last fall, Kelly and Brandon Michon went to work ripping out musty old carpets, dated kitchen appliances and damaged flooring; they scraped away layer upon layer of paint, wallpaper and plaster that had been slapped up over the years.

headline: A Tabloid Bashing, and a Lost Job With the Mayor
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Elections, State Legislature', 'Public Relations and Publicity']
abstract: Lis Smith, a young political operative, seemed to be an obvious choice for a post in City Hall — until the news media learned about her relationship with Eliot Spitzer.
lead_paragraph: To those following prospective appointments in City Hall, Lis Smith, a well-respected young political operative who had run Bill de Blasio’s communications effort for the last stretch of his mayoral campaign and throughout his transition, was the obvious choice to lead press operations in the new administration. In the days preceding Christmas, though, the tabloids revealed that Ms. Smith was dating Eliot Spitzer.

headline: Yohji Yamamoto Embraces Pattern
abstract: Florals and other motifs are mixed with the designer’s traditional black palette for autumn 2014 men’s wear.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A splash of orchids brightening a coat, daffodils on an orange suit, blood-red roses enmeshed with snakes and flowers mingled with skulls.

headline: Presidential Policy Directive on Signals Intelligence Activities
abstract: President Obama released a plan for overhauling the National Security Agency’s bulk data collection program.
lead_paragraph: President Obama released a plan for overhauling the National Security Agency’s bulk data collection program.

headline: Remapping the Territory
abstract: Felipe Fernández-Armesto’s revisionist history of America pays tribute to its Hispanic past, present and future.
lead_paragraph: In “Our America,” Felipe Fernández-­Armesto, a British historian of Spanish heritage at the University of Notre Dame, recasts the pilgrimage of Hispanics in the United States as a rich and moving chronicle for our very present. His book navigates five centuries of painful documents, atrocious statements and dubious literature to argue that the United States was, from its beginning, as much a Spanish colonial southern enterprise as an unending march westward. After long periods of migration, deportation and accommodation, the next United States could well be a pluricultural bilingual power, updating the American dream. “Our America” is perhaps the first history to make the case for this nation’s becoming a bright Latin American country.

headline: An Evolving Field
abstract: Jonathan Weiner talks about his Pulitzer Prize-winning book about evolution, “The Beak of the Finch,” which was published 20 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, Jonathan Weiner published “The Beak of the Finch,” his Pulitzer Prize-winning book about two biologists studying rapid changes in the birds on the Galápagos Islands, where Darwin observed the same creatures in the 1830s. In the Book Review, Douglas H. Chadwick called it an “admirable and much-needed treatise” that explains “very complex scientific and philosophical concepts in lucid prose.”

headline: Darwin’s Arks
abstract: An evolutionary biologist discusses how related species came to inhabit far-flung regions.
lead_paragraph: This book begins with a small struggle in an arroyo near the southern tip of Baja California. It’s June 2000, and the author and his girlfriend, Tara, are trying to pull a snake from a hole. She’s gripping it by the neck. He’s reaching down the snake’s body trying to gain purchase. “The process is exhausting,” Alan de Queiroz writes, “not because it’s physically difficult, but because we’re fighting against the will of another being; with each pull I feel the snake resisting.”

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Christine Feehan, whose paranormal romance novel “Dark Wolf” is No. 3 on the hardcover fiction list, wrote her first steamy love scene during a middle school math class.
lead_paragraph: In the Mood: Christine Feehan’s new ­novel, “Dark Wolf,” enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 3. It’s the 25th book in her “Dark” series of paranormal romances, about a race of shape-shifters called the Carpathians — basically, kindhearted vampires who refuse to kill humans and often have energetic, soul-trembling sex with them. Feehan discovered her calling while she was still in middle school; speaking with the romance website RBL Romantica early in her career, she remembered sitting in math class and working on her first steamy love scene until the teacher confiscated her notebook. “You should have seen his face,” she said. “I was about 13 at the time. I don’t know which of us was more mortified.” But despite her early start she delayed publishing for a long time, working more than 20 years as a martial arts instructor (she has a third-degree black belt in karate) and writing for herself while she and her husband raised 11 children. “I can write with the entire household around me most of the time,” she told another website in 2002. “My husband reads all my books and had better love them — and if he doesn’t, he’d better lie like crazy with a smile on his face. The only thing I avoid while writing a love scene is my children. Children and writing love scenes don’t mix; they get you out of the mood very, very fast.”

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE POWER OF HABIT: Why We Do What We Do in Life and Business,  by Charles Duhigg. (Random House, $16.) Duhigg, a Pulitzer-­winning reporter for The New York Times, looks at the science behind how we form, and break, habits. In engrossing narratives that take us from corporate boardrooms to N.F.L. sidelines and the civil rights movement, he distills research from the fields of social psychology, clinical psychology and neuroscience.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: ANDREW’S BRAIN,  by E. L. Doctorow. (Random House, $26.) A neuroscientist frustrated in his research, and with a messy personal life, explores his own oppressive consciousness in Doctorow’s cunning but serious novel.

headline: No Resistance
abstract: Nicholas Shakespeare investigates his aunt’s complicated experience in occupied France.
lead_paragraph: What did you do in the war, Auntie?

headline: Lupita Nyong’o’s Elegant Silhouette
abstract: Last night, the actress won a Critic’s Choice Movie Award for Best Supporting Actress in “12 Years a Slave.”
lead_paragraph: The Girl: The actress, who is nominated for an Academy Award for best supporting actress in “12 Years a Slave,” wore an ivory silk crepe bandeau dress to accept a Critics’ Choice Movie Award in the same category at last night’s ceremony in Santa Monica.

headline: Fabled Lands
abstract: Simon Winder traces the history and influence of the Hapsburgs and their far-reaching empire.
lead_paragraph: The River Danube, like a siren, has seduced at least three authors over the centuries. The first was Count Luigi Ferdinando Marsigli from Bologna, in the 17th century. His work grew into six wonderfully illustrated volumes, published in ­Latin in 1726. The second was Claudio Magris, from Trieste, in the 20th century. A professor, scholar and novelist, he completed a journey to the Black Sea in 1986, just before the fall of the old Communist regimes in Eastern Europe. Like Marsigli, he had no very clear idea of what kind of book he wanted to write, yet in the end, Magris produced “Danube,” a masterpiece.

headline: Austin City Limits
abstract: A con man hides out at a famous writing program in this satiric novel.
lead_paragraph: Feeling like a fraud or a con artist can be a hazard of the writing profession; there’s a fine line, Balzac wrote, between the artist and the criminal. That’s certainly true of Frankie Abandonato — a New York grifter who makes the critical error of pulling a lottery scam on a mobster. Abandonato, the hero of James Magnuson’s novel “Famous Writers I Have Known,” slips town for Texas, holing up at a creative writing institute where he’s mistaken for a J. D. Salingeresque recluse named V. S. Mohle.
