(The real Mohle was expected on campus to teach a seminar while either reconciling or settling an old score — it’s complicated — with the institute’s fabulously successful founder, Rex Schoeninger, whose sprawling social novels are reminiscent of James Michener’s; their feud culminated years ago in a brawl on “The Dick Cavett Show,” after which Mohle dropped out of society and never published again.)

headline: Tales’ End
abstract: Armistead Maupin concludes his series with a reunion of the tribe.
lead_paragraph: In the mid-1970s, the managing editor of The San Francisco Chronicle kept a chart in his office with two columns: “heterosexual” and “homosexual.” Whenever a new character appeared in “Tales of the City” — the newspaper’s fiction serial by Armistead Maupin, which begat a stack of popular novels — the name was slotted accordingly.

headline: The Enemy Within
abstract: Jennifer Percy follows a tortured Army veteran who searches for salvation in a Christian exorcism camp.
lead_paragraph: The subtitle of Jennifer Percy’s first book, “Demon Camp,” is “A Soldier’s Exorcism,” and four of its five chapter titles contain the words “kill” or “war.” Despite appearances, though, this isn’t really a book about soldiers or killing or war; it’s about a certain strain of American religious belief, and one writer’s transformation as she documents its effects on its adherents, several of them veterans, and on herself.

headline: Ask Well: How Long Does a Flu Shot Last?
abstract: A flu shot’s ability to last depends on how powerfully an immune system reacts to it, experts say.
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: Hugh Jackman Returning to Broadway in ‘The River’
abstract: Mr. Jackman will star in Jez Butterworth’s play “The River” next season.
lead_paragraph: Hugh Jackman, who has become one of the theater world’s most lucrative draws, will return to Broadway next season starring in Jez Butterworth’s play “The River,” the producers and Mr. Jackman said on Friday.

headline: In Sickness and in Health
abstract: Nancy Horan’s second historical novel reimagines another tempestuous love story.
lead_paragraph: Nancy Horan’s first novel, “Loving Frank,” explored the tangled personal life of Frank Lloyd Wright. Now, in her second, she takes a deep, long look at the intimate history of yet another creative man. This time, the action is viewed from two perspectives — those of Robert Louis Stevenson and (even more so) of his American wife, Fanny Van de Grift Osbourne, who hopes to be a painter or a writer herself. “Under the Wide and Starry Sky” is at once a classic artistic bildungsroman and a retort to the genre, a novel that shows how love and marriage can simultaneously offer inspiration and encumbrance, especially when the more successful partner believes that, as far as artists go, “a family could tolerate only one.” The Stevensons’ story is full of morbidity and sacrifice, chronicling losses and gains — and, of course, the writing of classics like “Treasure Island,” “Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde” and “Kidnapped,” none of which, Horan suggests, would have been possible without Fanny Stevenson’s careful nurturing of her husband.

headline: Not Long for This World
abstract: The Edinburgh homicide detective John Rebus is back on the job in Ian Rankin’s “Saints of the Shadow Bible.”
lead_paragraph: John Rebus is the kind of cop who isn’t afraid to think, and what he’s thinking in Ian Rankin’s terrific new procedural, SAINTS OF THE SHADOW BIBLE (Little, Brown, $26), is that he and his ilk aren’t long for this brave new world. Having decided that retirement wasn’t such a hot idea after all, the Edinburgh homicide detective is back on the job, but feeling increasingly out of step with his younger, more tech-­savvy and ethics-bound ­colleagues.

abstract: Super-8 footage shot of the northwest corner of Bryant Park by Project for Public Spaces in 1980.

headline: Era of Cheap Apparel May Be Ending for U.S.
keywords: ['Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Prices rose in 2013 for the third consecutive year after lagging inflation for more than 20 years.
lead_paragraph: FOR decades, declining prices have helped American consumers spend less on one critical part of every family’s budget: clothing. But those days may be ending.

headline: Trial Begins Next Week for Human Rights Activist in China
abstract: Although the defendant, Xu Zhiyong, believes the outcome is a foregone conclusion, he will still fight the accusations in court, his lawyers said.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — One of China’s most prominent human rights activists, Xu Zhiyong, will stand trial next week and believes that his conviction is all but certain, although he will fight the charges, his lawyer said Friday.

abstract: This week, Felipe Fernández-Armesto talks about “Our America: A Hispanic History of the United States”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Gabriel Sherman discusses his new book about Roger Ailes; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Felipe Fernández-Armesto talks about “Our America: A Hispanic History of the United States”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Gabriel Sherman discusses his new book about Roger Ailes; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Rutgers to Test Its Spirit vs. No. 1 UConn
abstract: The Rutgers women’s basketball team, in the top 25 again after an off year under Coach C. Vivian Stringer, hosts No. 1 Connecticut on Sunday, and she welcomes the test.
lead_paragraph: PISCATAWAY, N.J. — Ariel Butts, a sophomore forward-center, worked to improve her conditioning by repeatedly running the length of the court after a recent practice at Rutgers Athletic Center. When the laps began to take their toll and the grimace on her face flashed fatigue bordering on exhaustion, her teammate Betnijah Laney helped talk her through the rest of the regimen.

headline: Annoying Trends in Baby Names
abstract: Washington’s new culture war; Liz Cheney versus Lon Chaney Jr.; Matthew Crawley in context.
lead_paragraph: Washington’s new culture war; Liz Cheney versus Lon Chaney Jr.; Matthew Crawley in context.

headline: Concert to Re-Create Debut of Gershwin’s ‘Rhapsody in Blue’ on 90th Anniversary
abstract: Maurice Peress will re-create the debut performance of George Gershwin’s jazz-tinged work at Town Hall on Feb. 12.
lead_paragraph: “The stage setting was unconventional as the program,” the New York Times music critic Olin Downes wrote of a concert he attended at Aeolian Hall, on West 43rd Street, on Feb. 12, 1924. He went on to describe “a scene that would have curdled the blood of a Stokowski or a Mengelberg,” two of the most revered conductors of the day, not least because the musicians drew on an instrumental arsenal that included pianos in various states of disassembly, an array of wind, brass and percussion, and “frying pans, large tin utensils and a speaking trumpet, later stuck into the end of a trombone.”

headline: Critics’ Choice Movie Awards Red Carpet
abstract: Lupita Nyong’o in Calvin Klein, and Cate Blanchett in Lanvin on Thursday in Santa Monica, Calif.
lead_paragraph: Lupita Nyong’o in Calvin Klein, and Cate Blanchett in Lanvin on Thursday in Santa Monica, Calif.

headline: Orange Is the New Green
abstract: Orange is the color of the week in my kitchen, as it has been since the fall and will be throughout the winter at my farmer’s market.
lead_paragraph: Orange is the color of the week in my kitchen, as it has been since the fall and will be throughout the winter at my farmers’ market. I’m making oven fries with sweet potatoes, roasting and simmering carrots and winter squash with seasonings I haven’t used before with these vegetables and finding new ways to enjoy grated carrot salads, which have always been a weakness of mine. Sometimes markets can look bleak in winter, but there’s nothing drab about carrots, sweet potatoes and winter squash; I’m finding that there is a lot I can do with these nutrient-dense vegetables.

headline: From Street Smart to Safari Savvy
abstract: Alexander Wang and Olivier Rousteing, for Balmain, offered collections that were very different but had the same spirit of sport.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Alexander Wang, 30, and Olivier Rousteing, 27, the designer of Balmain, are of the same generation. But the collections they offered for the winter 2014 men’s season could not have looked more different.

abstract: Tribal fishermen taking part in the Jonbeel festival near Jagiroad, Assam.

headline: Spike Jonze Is Part of More Nominated Films Than You May Know
abstract: Spike Jonze was only nominated for “Her,” but he had a hand in a number of films that got nods on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It’s a Spike Jonze world, and we’re just living in it. That’s true for any fan of the writer-director, whose films, like “Being John Malkovich,” “Where the Wild Things Are” and especially his latest, “Her,” conjure up their own, slightly-left-of-center universe.

headline: Israel Summons 4 Envoys With Complaints About Bias
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Israeli Settlements', 'Palestinians', 'International Relations']
abstract: The Foreign Ministry told ambassadors from France, Britain, Italy and Spain that their countries had shown bias in favor of the Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — In the latest diplomatic confrontation over Israeli settlement building, Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman of Israel took the unusual step of summoning four European ambassadors on Friday to complain about what he called their countries’ “perpetual one-sided stance against Israel and in favor of the Palestinians.”

headline: Disney’s Troubled Gaming Unit Finds Success With Infinity
abstract: The console game that lets players mix and match Disney characters has sold 3 million starter packs worldwide, the company said.
lead_paragraph: Disney’s new Infinity video game is a certified hit, an important win for what has been one of the entertainment conglomerate’s most troubled businesses.

headline: In Praise of Depth
abstract: What we chase through our digital devices is instant connection and information. What we get is no more nutritious or enduringly satisfying than a sugary dessert. We need instead more wisdom, insight and understanding.
lead_paragraph: Many years ago, I realized that New Year’s resolutions don’t work. This year, instead, I created a ritual. A resolution is a hope and a prayer. A ritual is a highly specific behavior done at a precise time, so that it becomes automatic over time.

headline: Congress Moves Mountains
abstract: House Republicans make sure “mountaintop removal” can continue unabated.
lead_paragraph: Even as an alarming chemical spill from coal-industry storage tanks cut off the water supply for Charleston, West Virginia, Congress moved blithely ahead this week to protect one of the industry’s most toxic excesses — the massive dumping of rubble into valleys and streams from a strip-mine process euphemistically termed “mountaintop removal.”

headline: Taliban Attack Kills 16 at Restaurant Favored by Westerners
abstract: The Taliban claimed responsibility for an attack in which a suicide bomber cleared a path for two gunmen, who ran in and fired on diners.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban struck a restaurant popular with Westerners in downtown Kabul on Friday in what appeared to be a well-coordinated assault, with a suicide bomber clearing a path for two gunmen, who rushed in and fired on diners, the police said. At least 16 people were killed, most of them foreigners.

headline: Time for Doggy Daycare
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Landlords', 'Noise']
abstract: This week’s questions address barking dogs; inadequate heat; and hallway traffic to and from a neighboring therapist’s office.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a new weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: A.P. Cameraman Released on Bail in Egypt
abstract: An Egyptian cameraman who was arrested this week while covering the constitutional referendum in Egypt for The Associated Press was released on bail on Friday.
lead_paragraph: An Egyptian cameraman who was arrested this week while covering the constitutional referendum in Egypt for The Associated Press was released on bail on Friday, the news agency reported.

headline: Today in Small Business: Target Goes Small
abstract: Fifty ways to get customers. Hershey plans to print chocolate. And the dark side of the truffle trade.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

abstract: This week, Felipe Fernández-Armesto and Gabriel Sherman.
lead_paragraph: This week, Felipe Fernández-Armesto and Gabriel Sherman.

headline: Food Matters | Maison Kitsuné’s Quaint New Parisian Cafe
abstract: The music and fashion company opened the doors to its second coffee shop today in the Palais Royal.
lead_paragraph: Maison Kitsuné, the French cool-kid company for turned-out fashion and electronic music, is adding an eponymous Parisian cafe to its stable. The label was founded in 2002 by Gildas Loaëc, former art-director and manager for Daft Punk, and Masaya Kuroki, an architecture student turned fashion designer. This is the duo’s second Café Kitsuné; the popular original opened in Tokyo last February.

headline: Britain Scrambles to Fill Skills Gap
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'Welding and Welders', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: Faced with a shortage of skilled manufacturing workers, the government and industry are behind a push to get teenagers into apprenticeships.
lead_paragraph: STAFFORD, England — For the last two years, Josh Younger, 19, has been learning how to fuse heavy steel pipes used in nuclear power plants, spending hours each day behind a welding helmet and surrounded by the acrid smell of burned metal.

headline: A Long Way Home
abstract: In Ishmael Beah’s novel, a Sierra Leone village adapting to life after war faces a new invasion, this time from a mining company.
lead_paragraph: What you fall for first, reading ­Ishmael Beah’s new novel, is its setting — the small village of Imperi, in the rural grasslands of Sierra Leone. The sky above it is wide and colorful. A giant mango tree sits at its center. A river flows nearby. In better times, villagers farmed coffee behind their homes. In the evenings, schoolchildren shucked their uniforms on the riverbank and noisily splashed around.

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘Our America: A Hispanic History of the United States’
abstract: Felipe Fernández-Armesto discusses “Our America,” and Gabriel Sherman talks about his new biography of Roger Ailes.
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Julio Ortega reviews Felipe Fernández-Armesto’s “Our America: A Hispanic History of the United States.” Mr. Ortega writes:

headline: Civil War in the Senate
abstract: Even within Congress, battles over loyalty to the Union — and the Constitution — raged.
lead_paragraph: No word was more hotly contested during the Civil War than “loyalty.” Republicans persistently accused Democrats of disloyalty and treason for opposing Republican war measures, and no Democrat was immune from accusations of disloyalty, even at the highest levels of the government.

headline: A Conversation With Steven Moffat, a ‘Sherlock’ Co-Creator
abstract: The new season of “Sherlock,” which already aired in Britain, makes its American debut this Sunday on PBS.
lead_paragraph: Steven Moffat is the co-creator of the BBC hit “Sherlock” and the lead writer and executive producer of “Doctor Who,” the classic sci-fi series about a time-traveling alien that celebrated its 50th anniversary in November. He also created, in 2000, “Coupling,” a saucy sitcom about the sexual misadventures of 30-something Londoners that was based loosely on his marriage to the television producer Sue Vertue. All this makes the 52-year-old Scotsman one of the most influential figures in British television, and also a target for legions of fans who bombard the Internet with theories about how Holmes could have possibly faked his suicide or whether a woman should play the next Doctor. “It’s very dangerous for me to venture onto social media,” Mr. Moffat said by phone from London.

headline: Burke in America
keywords: ['Articles of Confederation (1781-89)', 'Constitution (US)', 'Declaration of Independence (US)', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Magna Carta (1215)', 'Revolutionary War, American (1775-83)']
abstract: Can American conservatives legitimately lay claim to the ideas of Edmund Burke?
lead_paragraph: I’ve been following with great interest the discussion surrounding Yuval Levin’s new book, “The Great Debate,” which offers an overview of the competing worldviews of Thomas Paine and Edmund Burke in an effort to explain what the subtitle calls “the birth of right and left.” And I’ve been particularly interested in the liberal critiques of Levin’s argument, which have taken an interesting (if perhaps unsurprising) form: Very few reviewers have questioned his interpretation of his subjects’ long-running late-18th century argument, but I’ve noticed repeated attempts to deny their relevance to present-day American conservatism, which a number of left-of-center reviewers have argued owes little-or-nothing to any kind of Burkean worldview. In a later post I want to take up Sheri Berman’s version of this argument, in the liberal journal Democracy, but here let me say something about William Galston’s response to Levin, in his Wall Street Journal column, which I’ll quote at length:

headline: Comme des Garçons’s ‘Holey Suit’
abstract: Rei Kawakubo’s autumn 2014 men’s collection opened rounded windows in the fabric to reveal the shirts beneath.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “Holy suit” were the two mysterious words spoken by Rei Kawakubo before her Comme des Garçons show kicked off Friday with smart tailoring.

headline: Helping Catholics by Teaching Priests How to Be the Boss
abstract: Management experts offer retreats focusing on the nonspiritual part of leading a parish.
lead_paragraph: ST. JOHNS, Fla. — They came for prayer and fellowship, naturally. They gave confession to other priests, too. But mostly they came for lectures. Lectures on employment law. And on best practices in hiring and firing. And accounting and auditing. It was five days with hardly any theology.

headline: Sundance: The Politics of Picking an Opening-Night Film
abstract: How “Whiplash” came to agree to take the early spot at the festival.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah – Opening night at the Sundance Film Festival, always on a Thursday, has recently been reserved for the premiere of an extra-arty film. One longtime attendee calls it the “gay Eskimo” slot: a picture that tries so hard to be original that it ends up being completely uncommercial.

headline: Victoria and Albert Museum to Publish Nazi-Era ‘Degenerate Art’ Inventory Online
keywords: ['Art', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Museums', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Victoria & Albert Museum will make a copy of a list of “degenerate art” seized by the Nazis available online to the public starting at the end of January.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Britain’s Victoria and Albert Museum, the holder of the only known complete inventory of modern works reviled by the Nazis and confiscated from German museums in 1937 to 1938, will make a copy of the list available online starting at the end of January.

headline: A Reunion That Was a Long Time Coming
abstract: The couple dated for five years, starting in college, then were apart for six before reconnecting.
lead_paragraph: Sundays were the hardest day of the week for Peter Tiboris.

headline: Hilary Mantel’s Next Book Is a Story Collection
abstract: Ms. Mantel, the author of the bestselling historical novels “Wolf Hall” and “Bring Up the Bodies,” will release a collection of short stories called “The Assassination of Margaret Thatcher.”
lead_paragraph: Hilary Mantel, the author of the bestselling historical novels “Wolf Hall” and “Bring Up the Bodies,” has written a collection of short stories that will be released in September, her publisher said. The book, “The Assassination of Margaret Thatcher,” was acquired by Henry Holt in the United States and 4th Estate in Britain. Nicholas Pearson, the publishing director of 4th Estate, said in a statement: “A new book from Hilary Mantel is a treat. Where her last two novels explore how modern England was forged, ‘The Assassination of Margaret Thatcher’ shows us the country we have become.'” Ms. Mantel won the Man Booker Prize in both 2012 and 2009.

headline: Exclusive | 165 East 73rd Street
abstract: The Upper East Side building, priced at $14.5 million, features arched doorways and an oak balustrade, carry-overs from the its era as a stable.
lead_paragraph: The Upper East Side building, priced at $14.5 million, features arched doorways and an oak balustrade, carry-overs from the its era as a stable.

headline: Long on Horsepower
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A two-story carriage house has remained in the same family for 110 years, once serving as a stable.
lead_paragraph: A historic Beaux-Arts-style Upper East Side carriage house that has remained in the same family for its entire 110-year existence — morphing from a repository for horses and carriages belonging to the owner of a Fifth Avenue mansion, to a garage and chauffeur’s digs, to a single-family home, to a quaint rental — is about to enter the market at $14.5 million.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Saving Mr. Banks'
abstract: John Lee Hancock narrates a scene from his film about the making of “Mary Poppins.”
lead_paragraph: John Lee Hancock narrates a scene from his film about the making of “Mary Poppins.”

headline: Does the P.&G. Olympics Ad Have You Dreaming of Glory by Proxy? Don’t.
abstract: Proctor & Gamble’s big 2014 Winter Olympics ad glorifies the sacrifices moms and children make in the name of athletic glory (once again, dads aren’t in the picture). I say Thanks, Mom and Dad, for letting me enjoy the sport without the sacrifice.
lead_paragraph: Has Procter & Gamble’s “Pick Them Back Up campaign brought a tear to your eye yet? It’s a powerful combination of exhilarating sports imagery, dramatic music and tender moments between mothers and kids. Moms encourage their kids to get back up after various athletic setbacks, from faceplanting on the ice rink as tots to recovering from injuries as teens, then finally sharing the sweet taste of victory with their adult daughters and sons.

headline: HSBC and Citigroup Suspend Currency Traders
abstract: The suspensions by the two banks on Friday came amid questions about whether the traders colluded to fix benchmark currency rates.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — HSBC and Citigroup each suspended currency traders on Friday amid ongoing investigations into potential manipulation of the $5-trillion-a-day foreign exchange market.

headline: Blast at Antigovernment March Raises Tensions in Bangkok
abstract: The attack intensified tensions in the city as a dwindling but dedicated core of protesters continues to block access to a number of major intersections and government buildings.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — An attack on antigovernment protesters in Bangkok on Friday, most likely with a grenade, killed one person and injured more than 30, intensifying tensions in the city as a dwindling but dedicated core of protesters continues to block access to a number of government buildings and major intersections.

headline: The ‘No More Tears’ Shampoo, Now With No Formaldehyde
keywords: ['Formaldehyde', 'Shampoos and Hair Products', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances']
abstract: Johnson & Johnson’s Baby Shampoo no longer contains two potentially harmful chemicals, formaldehyde and 1,4-dioxane, that have come under increasing scrutiny by consumers.
lead_paragraph: SKILLMAN, N.J. — The only hint that something is different inside millions of bottles of Johnson’s Baby Shampoo arriving on store shelves are two words: “Improved Formula.”

headline: A Top U.N. Rights Official Describes ‘Horror’ in South Sudan
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: At the end of a four-day visit, a human rights official said “mass atrocities” had been committed, with reports of killings and sexual violence.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — A top United Nations human rights official visiting South Sudan described “horror” on Friday, with bodies on the streets and reports of mass killings, sexual violence and the recruitment of children into battle.

headline: Obama Signals Change to N.S.A. Practices
abstract: The president, in response to months of debate set off by the disclosures of Edward J. Snowden, highlighted changes to the National Security Administration’s practices.
lead_paragraph: The president, in response to months of debate set off by the disclosures of Edward J. Snowden, highlighted changes to the National Security Administration’s practices.

headline: Apollo’s Rush to Get the Chuck E. Cheese Deal Done
abstract: The deal to buy out the parent company of Chuck E. Cheese contains a number of provisions which seem to suggest that Apollo is concerned about a competing bid or a challenge, Steven M. Davidoff writes in the Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: Apollo Global Management is sprinting to acquire Chuck E. Cheese.

headline: Comme des Garçons: Fall 2014 Menswear
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Sex, Scandal and Soccer, the Italian Way
abstract: At Sundance, the exhibition “The Art of Black and White Stripes,” co-curated by the Fiat heir Lapo Elkann, offers a preview of a salacious forthcoming documentary about the Italian football club Juventus.
lead_paragraph: The filmmakers Marco and Mauro La Villa conceived of their forthcoming documentary, “Black and White Stripes: the Juventus Story,” shortly after their father, Giovanni, died in 2001. He had rooted for Juventus, Italy’s most storied soccer club, his entire life. In Pietramilar, the tiny village were Giovanni was born and raised, priests moonlighted as scouts for professional soccer clubs, and at a young age Giovanni was offered a scholarship to go to school in Turin to play for Juventus’s junior squad. His mother disapproved, though, and forced him into the family’s gravestone-painting business. “His life’s great regret was that he didn’t get to chase his dream,” Marco says. The brothers, however, chased theirs, and are currently at Sundance, not screening their movie but rather promoting it with “The Art of Black and White Stripes,” a traveling art exhibition they co-curated with Lapo Elkann, a scion of the Agnelli family, which has owned the team since 1923.

headline: Dangers of Giving In to Impulse for Revenge
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Bridges and Tunnels', 'George Washington Bridge']
abstract: The New Jersey traffic jam scandal offers lessons on seeking retaliation for perceived slights.
lead_paragraph: I found the machinations in the Netflix political series “House of Cards” to be immensely entertaining but a little over the top — until, that is, the traffic jam scandal in New Jersey.

headline: Marine Corps Apologizes for Gunman Reference in Martin Luther King Jr. Holiday Tweet
abstract: The Marine Corps Special Operations Command apologized on Friday for a Tweet that appeared to make light of the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., urging its followers not to be a “lone shooter” over the holiday weekend. Dr. King was assassinated by a gunman in 1968.
lead_paragraph: On Friday the official Twitter account of the Marine Corps Special Operations Command posted a picture and message that appeared to make light of the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. at the start of the long holiday weekend to commemorate his birth.

headline: Time for More Competitiveness at Citigroup
abstract: The bank was not alone in its struggles at the end of 2013, but Citigroup’s rivals managed to keep on the right side of Wall Street guesstimates.
lead_paragraph: Citigroup’s boss, Michael L. Corbat, needs to channel some of the aggression from his boardroom.

headline: Gays Can Be ‘Relaxed and Calm’ at the Olympics, Putin Says
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin said visitors to Sochi for the Olympic Games, including gay men and lesbians, could be “relaxed and calm,” but he defended a ban on “homosexual propaganda.”
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Seeking to head off one of several simmering controversies ahead of next month’s Winter Olympics, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said on Friday that no one would be targeted at the Games under a federal law banning “homosexual propaganda” among minors, even as he defended the law as a way to protect children from exposure to nontraditional relationships.

headline: Obama’s Changes to Government Surveillance
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: President Obama announced that he would place new limits on intelligence agencies’ bulk collection of phone call records. But he rejected some other recommendations to rein in surveillance made by a panel of outside advisers.
lead_paragraph: President Obama announced that he would place new limits on intelligence agencies’ bulk collection of phone call records. But he rejected some other recommendations to rein in surveillance made by a panel of outside advisers.

headline: Why Are the Intelligence Budgets a State Secret?
abstract: There is no public debate about the budgets, and no opportunity for outside groups or experts to weigh in.
lead_paragraph: You can dig all you want through the trillion-dollar spending bill just approved by Congress and still not learn how much the country is spending on each of the intelligence agencies. That’s because those amounts are a state secret, and nowhere in President Obama’s call for greater oversight and transparency on Friday did he propose changing that status.

headline: A Continent on Her Musical Map
abstract: Angélique Kidjo, the songwriter and singer from Benin, has kept African languages and an African sensibility at the core of her music.
lead_paragraph: Angélique Kidjo, the songwriter and singer from Benin, was in Kenya being a do-gooder when the concept of her new album, “Eve,” came to her, she said, “like a light bulb blowing up in your head.”

headline: Severe Drought Grows Worse in California
abstract: The problem is visible from the Sierra Nevada to the farmlands in the southern part of the state, and it threatens to cause major hardship.
lead_paragraph: NORDEN, Calif. — Cattle ranchers have had to sell portions of their herd for lack of water. Sacramento and other municipalities have imposed severe water restrictions. Wildfires broke out this week in forests that are usually too wet to ignite. Ski resorts that normally open in December are still closed; at one here in the Sierra Nevada that is open, a bear wandered onto a slope full of skiers last week, apparently not hibernating because of the balmy weather.

headline: At the Critics’ Choice Awards, Fine-Tuning Stump Speeches
abstract: At the Critics’ Choice Awards, “12 Years a Slave” takes the top award, while other winners take the opportunity to work on their acceptance language.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – Held on the same day that many of the Oscar hopefuls became nominees, and anointing largely the same bunch, the Critics’ Choice Awards – given by the Broadcast Film Critics Association and televised on the CW – are as relaxed and joyful as an awards show gets.

headline: On the Market in Scottsdale, Ariz.
abstract: Contemporary and traditional homes with southwestern flair. Prices range from $729,000 to $6.975 million.
lead_paragraph: Contemporary and traditional homes with southwestern flair. Prices range from $729,000 to $6.975 million.

headline: Twitter Suspends Hamas Accounts
abstract: The accounts were used by the militant wing of the Palestinian government to directly communicate with the Israel Defense Forces during at 2012 bombing campaign.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, Sunday, Jan. 19 | Several Twitter accounts used by the military wing of Hamas have been suspended by the social network in recent days, angering the Islamist militants and delighting Israel’s military.

headline: Doctor Tells of Leaking Data to ‘Friend’ at SAC
abstract: Sidney Gilman, an 81-year-old doctor, took the stand for the first time as the central witness for prosecutors in the trial of Mathew Martoma, a former portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors.
lead_paragraph: The largest insider trading scheme on record started with an attempt at friendship.

headline: Ford Recalls Edge, Explorer and Vans; N.H.T.S.A. Upgrades Jeep Investigation
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks']
abstract: Ford recalls 28,000 Edge S.U.V.’s for fuel-system problem, 4,500 vans for windshield defect and 300 Explorers for steering issue.
lead_paragraph: Ford recalled about 28,000 of its 2012-13 Edge crossover utility vehicles for possible fuel leaks on models equipped with the 2-liter 4-cylinder EcoBoost engine, according to a report posted on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website. The automaker said the fuel line pulse damper was not manufactured properly by a Michigan supplier, which could allow “fuel odor, seepage or a small fuel leak.”

headline: Calling It Art, Not ‘Native American Art’
abstract: In “Decolonizing the Exhibition,” it is almost impossible to tell who made some of the artworks from either the style or the content.
lead_paragraph: One is a picture of a jaunty red bra — just a bra — distilled to its basic geometric elements, including the little white tag peeking out from behind one strap. The other still life, by the same artist, depicts the simplified form of a pair of thick-rimmed eyeglasses.

abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit.”

lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Big Bad Wolves.”

abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Generation War.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “Generation War.”

headline: Having Enough, but Hungry for More
abstract: Parables from the financial world give insight into a culture that compels young people to take risks in pursuit of wealth and prestige.
lead_paragraph: THREE recent stories got me thinking about a concept that is central to money, wealth and ultimately contentment but that is overlooked this time of year: knowing how much is enough.

headline: Men’s Paris Fashion Week: Dries Van Noten Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.

headline: Hotel Spa Treatments, Day and, Now, Night
abstract: Hotel spas are usually open only during the day, but some properties around the world are breaking from tradition by offering nighttime treatments.
lead_paragraph: Hotel spas are usually open only during the day, but some properties around the world are breaking from tradition by offering nighttime treatments. Chi, the spa at Shangri-La’s Fijian Resort and Spa, has a Dusk Till Dawn experience ($514) for couples where they actually sleep in the spa treatment villa. The service begins with an outdoor bath followed by a body polish, massage and dinner and ends in the morning with a facial and breakfast.

headline: Stop Trusting Yourself
abstract: Why we struggle to keep the promises we make, even to ourselves.
lead_paragraph: TRUST is a double-edged sword. Though you can accomplish more in life if you put your faith in others, doing so also leaves you vulnerable. If your friend, business partner or political ally betrays you, he benefits — in terms of money, power or some other resource — at your expense. This risk is the drawback of trust, and it leads many people to prefer self-reliance, an arrangement that seems more secure because the only person you have to count on is yourself.

headline: Artkick Wants to Be the Spotify of Art
abstract: A startup called Artkick has secured 50,000 digital representations of paintings and photographs from 2,000 museums around the world. It places them on Internet-connected televisions and computer screens.
lead_paragraph: Pandora and Spotify are businesses that sort through digital music and figure out your likes. Netflix does the same for movies. There’s even Yelp, doing something like that for food. Meantime, fine art just hangs there on the wall.

headline: Navigating a New Health Plan, After the Surge
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: A backlog of applications for coverage under the Affordable Care Act has resulted in delays for many people awaiting insurance cards or authorization for treatment.
lead_paragraph: YOU’VE no doubt heard about problems some people are encountering when they try to use the health insurance they’ve bought through the federal and state exchanges. A backlog of applications, the result of a surge in enrollments at year’s end for coverage starting this month, has resulted in many people experiencing delays in getting insurance cards, policy numbers or authorization for treatment.

headline: Sex? Yes. The City? Yes. But Things Have Changed.
abstract: Cynthia Nixon of “Sex and the City” and Allison Williams of “Girls” discussed their groundbreaking roles and their respective generations.
lead_paragraph: Fourteen years apart, Cynthia Nixon and Allison Williams created roles in two groundbreaking series, both on HBO, that captured for their respective generations the confounding experience of being a young single woman in New York: Miranda Hobbes on “Sex and the City,” which aired from 1998 to 2004, and Marnie Michaels on “Girls,” which had its debut in 2012 and began its third season last week.

headline: Big Ticket: 7 Fireplaces and a Hot View for $27.5 Million
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A nine-room restored and renovated apartment in the Dakota that enjoys 100 feet of unobstructed park views was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.
lead_paragraph: An exquisitely restored and renovated co-op at the Dakota that enjoys 100 feet of unobstructed Central Park vistas just above the tree canopy sold for $27.5 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Two Broncos Quarterbacks, Sparkling in the Twilight
abstract: Peyton Manning’s late-career Super Bowl bid and his rivalry with the Patriots’ Tom Brady are thrilling to John Elway, who can relate.
lead_paragraph: ENGLEWOOD, Colo. — In an upstairs conference room at the Denver Broncos’ practice complex, John Elway rocked back and forth in his black leather seat and swiveled from side to side. Three days before his Broncos were to play for a berth in Super Bowl XLVIII, Elway was like a big kid in a darkened theater waiting for an absorbing double feature to light up the giant screen.

headline: The Source | Tilda Swinton
abstract: Doug Aitken interviews the actress Tilda Swinton.
lead_paragraph: Doug Aitken interviews the actress Tilda Swinton.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Red Herrings Solved!
abstract: Readers solve the case of a 29-year-old woman with an injured groin, a swollen foot and long list of other abnormalities.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday we challenged Well readers to take the case of a 29-year-old woman with an injured groin, a swollen foot and other abnormalities. Many of you found it as challenging as the doctors who saw her. I asked for the right test as well as the right diagnosis. More than 200 answers were posted.

headline: Rapture for Valentine’s: Blondie in Miami Beach
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Travel and Vacations', "Valentine's Day"]
abstract: The band Blondie, celebrating its 40th anniversary, begins a tour on Valentine’s Day weekend at the Fontainebleau hotel in Miami Beach.
lead_paragraph: Blondie, the new wave rock group started by Debbie Harry and Chris Stein on the Lower East Side of New York in the mid-70s, is celebrating its 40th anniversary this year (that’s right, 40th). But they’re far from being over the hill.

headline: The Gun Report: January 17, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Today marks the final day of the world’s largest gun exhibition, the SHOT Show in Las Vegas, which features 12 miles of guns and outdoor gear offered by 1,600 exhibitors. Sponsored by the National Shooting Sports Foundation, the show, which hosted 60,000 commercial buyers and sellers of military, law enforcement and tactical products, is the primary marketing opportunity for firearms companies to hawk their new products to gun dealers—products like assault rifles, high-capacity ammunition magazines and silencers.

headline: Years Before His Bipartisan Luster, a Rough Reception for Gates
abstract: Strong criticism of Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. by former Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates recalls his tough battles with Congress in 1987 and 1991 over his nomination as C.I.A. director.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Former Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates startled Washington with a withering critique of Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. when he said in his new memoir that Mr. Biden had “been wrong on nearly every major foreign policy and national security issue over the past four decades.”

headline: Weekend Reading: Bank Earnings Quiz
abstract: How well do you know your earnings reports? Match the financial company with the quote about its latest earnings report.
lead_paragraph: How well do you know your earnings reports? Most of the Wall Street giants released fourth quarter results this week, including Bank of America, BlackRock, Citigroup, Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase, Morgan Stanley and Wells Fargo. Match the financial company with the quote about its latest earnings report. Answers below.

headline: What I Love | Gwynne Duncan
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Art', 'Public and Subsidized Housing']
abstract: A child of Westbeth the first subsidized artists’ housing complex of its type in the United States, returns.
lead_paragraph: A child of Westbeth the first subsidized artists’ housing complex of its type in the United States, returns.

headline: A Kinship With Westbeth
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Art', 'Public and Subsidized Housing']
abstract: A daughter returns, so her own daughter can grow up among artists and their families.
lead_paragraph: Decades before the elevated train tracks on the Lower West Side of Manhattan were transformed into a global tourist attraction called the High Line, they were Gwynne Duncan’s playground.

headline: Supreme Court Will Consider Whether Police Need Warrants to Search Cellphones
keywords: ['Search and Seizure', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Fourth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)']
abstract: The case centers on the wide variety and personal nature of information on today’s smartphones.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to hear a pair of cases about whether the police need a warrant to search the cellphones of people they arrest, presenting a major test of the meaning of the Fourth Amendment in the digital age.

headline: In the Future, Your Fridge Could Get Hacked
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Home Automation and Smart Homes']
abstract: While the Internet of things could make our lives more convenient, it could also serve to compromise our privacy.
lead_paragraph: The next great advance in technology may well be the “Internet of Things.” Simply put, many more devices and appliances that you use every day, like refrigerators, thermostats, garage doors and so on will be connected to the Internet, will adapt to your behavior and will be available to do your bidding even when you are not near them.

headline: Where a Storied Classical Label Embraces Rockers
abstract: Deutsche Grammophon will release “St. Carolyn by the Sea,” a collection of works by Bryce Dessner (of the National) and Jonny Greenwood (of Radiohead), performed by the Copenhagen Philharmonic.
lead_paragraph: More evidence, if any were needed, that the boundary between classical music and rock continues to erode: Deutsche Grammophon, once the most staid of the world’s classical music labels, is releasing “St. Carolyn by the Sea,” a collection of works by Bryce Dessner, best known as a guitarist in the National, and Jonny Greenwood, the lead guitarist in Radiohead. The album, recorded by the Copenhagen Philharmonic, led by André de Ridder, is due out March 3.

headline: Minnesota Orchestra Announces First Concert After Lockout
abstract: The orchestra announced Friday that its first concert back in Orchestra Hall would be given Feb. 7 and conducted by Stanislaw Skrowaczewski.
lead_paragraph: With the 15-month lockout of its musicians now behind it, the Minnesota Orchestra announced Friday that its first concert back in Orchestra Hall would be given Feb. 7 and would be conducted by Stanislaw Skrowaczewski, its music director from 1960 to 1979.

headline: Russians: Still the Go-To Bad Guys
abstract: In the post-Cold-War era, Boris Badenov remains a model villain.
lead_paragraph: THE movie “Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit,” which opens in theaters this weekend, revolves around an American C.I.A. analyst first introduced in Tom Clancy’s 1984 novel “The Hunt for Red October.” The source material isn’t the only thing that’s a little creaky. Ryan’s destination is Moscow, his target a Russian businessman plotting to crash the American economy through a terrorist attack. In portraying the diabolical oligarch Viktor Cherevin, Kenneth Branagh delivers his lines in the thick, menacingly slow accent that defines Eastern European baddies on screen: “You think this is game, Jack?”

headline: A.P.C. and Bonton Design Children’s Wear That’s Too Cool for School
abstract: Brought together by a classroom friendship at Paris’s hippest primary school, the French clothier and children’s retailer team up for a pint-sized capsule collection.
lead_paragraph: The A.P.C. founder Jean Touitou believes that children are never too young to be exposed to good design. He founded a creativity-centered Paris school, Atelier de la Petite Enfance (A.P.E. for short), to educate his now-9-year-old daughter Lily; the space, designed by the architect and frequent A.P.C. collaborator Laurent Deroo, features tiny Alvar Aalto chairs and building blocks created by the art director Mathias Augustyniak of M/M Paris. When the school’s art department needed uniforms for the children to wear while painting, Touitou turned to Bonton, the hip French children’s clothier — whose founders, Thomas and Irène Cohen, are the son and daughter-in-law of the owners of Bonpoint and have a daughter in Lily’s class. The uniforms also ended up in Bonton’s five retail outlets, where they became a best seller. “The design was the right balance between playful and straight,” Touitou says. “I sort of knew that we’d have kids together one day, so to speak.”

headline: Review: Jeep Grand Cherokee EcoDiesel
abstract: If your commute includes mud, boulders and steep grades, the Jeep Grand Cherokee can tame it. The 2014 model is available with a clean diesel engine for an extra $4,500. Torque lovers will rejoice.
lead_paragraph: If your commute includes mud, boulders and steep grades, the Jeep Grand Cherokee can tame it. The 2014 model is available with a clean diesel engine for an extra $4,500. Torque lovers will rejoice.

headline: From Classical Giant to Clearance Bins
abstract: J&R, the last store in Manhattan to maintain a substantial inventory of classical recordings, now has only a small amount in close-out bins.
lead_paragraph: For classical music lovers with old-fashioned ideas about buying recordings in Manhattan — in stores, on compact discs — the choices have dwindled. Tower Records near Lincoln Center closed in 2006. The Virgin Megastore in Times Square shut down in 2009. And in 2011, Barnes & Noble, which had devoted one level to CDs and videos in a large store across the street from the former Tower space, moved out.

headline: The Source | Paolo Soleri
abstract: Doug Aitken interviews the architect Paolo Soleri.
lead_paragraph: Doug Aitken interviews the architect Paolo Soleri.

headline: An App for Cultural Goings-On in New York City
abstract: CultureCraver lists cultural offerings in a way that feels familiar and knowledgeable.
lead_paragraph: Listings apps have proliferated ever since developers realized how desperate users were for suggestions about what to do. Apps like YPlan and Sosh have muscled into that space, with dazzling displays and a huge number of events available. Those apps, while functional, can seem faux local, the app version of your corner Starbucks, a global chain that tries its best to feel homey.

headline: Upbeat Again, but Not Overconfident
abstract: The auto industry has been bouncing back, and at the Detroit auto show carmakers are showing off, presenting their new models and forward-looking concepts.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Twenty-five years ago, the Detroit Lions’ biblical trials of football futility coincided with a familiar economic slump — the kind that often seemed to save its worst for Detroit.

headline: If Your Car Could Talk, Would It Speak ‘Sensual Clarity’?
abstract: At the Detroit auto show, many companies restated or reset their design language, which distills and defines the shapes and forms that make car families recognizable.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The native languages of automobile designers ceased to matter years ago. In studios around the world, Germans work for Americans, Japanese for Germans, and so on.

headline: In Search of an Uncommon Language
abstract: Examples of the interplay between design and phraseology abound at the North American International Auto Show this year.
lead_paragraph: Examples of the interplay between design and phraseology abound at the North American International Auto Show this year.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Sudan and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from South Sudan, Egypt, Bahrain and Britain.
lead_paragraph: Photos from South Sudan, Egypt, Bahrain and Britain.

headline: A Met Debut as That Besotted Geisha, Adamant That He Will Be True
abstract: Anthony Minghella’s “Madama Butterfly” has returned to the Metropolitan Opera with the South African soprano Amanda Echalaz in the title role.
lead_paragraph: In many ways, Anthony Minghella’s production of Puccini’s “Madama Butterfly,” which returned to the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday, resembles an insect collection in which colorful, exotic specimens are fixed on a neutral background and bathed in a sharp, bright light. It’s a fitting way to present this ever-popular opera about a caddish American naval officer who enters into a nonbinding marriage with a teenage Japanese geisha and then abandons her, pregnant, lovesick and cast out from her community. Featuring innovative puppetry by Blind Summit Theater, it’s also an uncomfortable production that introduces multiple perspectives in ways that illuminate and alienate in equal measure.

keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Dresses', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Academy Awards (Oscars)', 'Golden Globes (Awards)', 'Movies']
abstract: Julia Roberts’s personal style can run counter to the norm for awards shows and benefits.
