headline: Red Carpet Watch: Julia Roberts’s Style
abstract: Ms. Roberts’s style on the red carpet is very easy and low-key.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Roberts’s style on the red carpet is very easy and low-key.

headline: Jeep Thirst Quenched by Diesel
abstract: The Grand Cherokee EcoDiesel proves that an off-road-capable S.U.V. can be remarkably fuel-efficient without sacrificing toughness.
lead_paragraph: TESTED 2014 Jeep Grand Cherokee EcoDiesel

headline: A Stew Greater Than the Sum of Its Parts
abstract: Creating a sort of curry, colorful and highly seasoned, from a humble collection of vegetables.
lead_paragraph: IT HAD BEEN DARK and dismal all day. Bitter cold. Snowing. I would not be going to the store to fetch groceries; the weather in New York was far too brutal for any kind of shopping. Just getting home from the subway stop was a slippery, treacherous ordeal.

headline: A Crucial Caveat in Obama’s Vow on Phone Data
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Telephones and Telecommunications']
abstract: President Obama left the “end” of the bulk telephone data program to another day in a speech partly intended to convince the public that spy programs are being run appropriately.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In overhauling the nation’s spy programs, President Obama vowed on Friday that he “will end” the bulk telephone data program that has caused so much consternation — “as it currently exists.”

headline: Underground London
abstract: A descent into the city’s subterranean spaces can lead urban explorers to everything from culture to cocktails to cuisine.
lead_paragraph: The British capital’s evolving skyline is as impressive as it is unusual. Consider the Shard, the 1,016-foot “vertical city” that topped out as Western Europe’s tallest building when it was completed in 2012, and 20 Fenchurch Street (a.k.a the Walkie-Talkie), which made headlines last summer when the glare from its cartoonishly flaring facade warped the panels of a Jaguar parked outside.

headline: James Baldwin’s Paris
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Americans Abroad', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: How has the city changed since Baldwin arrived more than 60 years ago? A trip in his footsteps reveals some answers.
lead_paragraph: One bright afternoon in Paris, on the terrace of the cafe Deux Magots, in St.-Germain-des-Prés, I found myself engaged in an increasingly animated conversation about the writer James Baldwin and the notorious feud that broke out between him and his fellow African-American expatriate Richard Wright.

headline: The Overlooked Travel Agent, Now Starring Off Broadway
abstract: A new play, largely backed by sponsors in the hospitality industry, does its best to romanticize the work of booking hotel rooms and scheduling flights.
lead_paragraph: Consider the hapless travel agent. Undercut by Expedia. Ignored by app-reliant consumers. Overlooked, thanks to the digital revolution.

headline: Hotel Review: The Thief in Oslo
abstract: This nine-story, 118-room property may be the most opulent hotel in Norway, and arguably all of Scandinavia.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: Restaurant Report: Oaxen Krog & Slip in Stockholm
abstract: A trip to these sister restaurants, set on an island in central Stockholm, can lead you either to tasting menus (at Krog) or a casual-dining experience (Slip).
lead_paragraph: Though Copenhagen gets most of the regional limelight, Stockholm has quietly emerged as a gastronomic destination on par with the Danish capital. One of the strongest sets of players in that mix is the chef Magnus Ek and his wife, Agneta Green, who closed Oaxen, the restaurant they’d founded in 1994 on its namesake island in the southern part of the Stockholm archipelago, and moved to a striking new water’s-edge location on Djurgarden, an island in central Stockholm, last May.

headline: A Humble Meal to Pair With Pinot Grigios
abstract: A tin of anchovies, some fennel and bread crumbs are all it takes to ramp up cacio e pepe for bucatini.
lead_paragraph: Before we tasted these pinot grigios, I anticipated pairing them with local bay scallops. But wines that are not profound, yet pleasant enough and reasonably priced, call for a sense of proportion. I’ll save the scallops, at $30 a pound, for more impressive bottles and opt instead for humbler satisfaction.

headline: The Enemy Is Not Pinot Grigio
abstract: Is it so hard to make good pinot grigio? Are producers simply taking the easy way out to make vast quantities of a wine they know will sell?
lead_paragraph: Can a wine be too popular for its own good? Apparently so. Exhibit A: pinot grigio from Italy.

headline: Submit Your Summer Vacation Rental Questions
abstract: Ever wonder how to go about renting a summer vacation home on the East Coast? We’d like to hear your questions and insights.
lead_paragraph: It may be in the 40s in New York City, but it’s nonetheless prime season for solidifying summer plans if yours include renting a vacation home. Do you have questions about East Coast summer vacation rentals? What’s the best way to find a house? What should you expect to pay? What’s the etiquette in a share house? Whether you’re dreaming of sunbathing in the Hamptons or on Martha’s Vineyard, now’s the time to get real about what that might entail.

headline: Men’s Paris Fashion Week: Givenchy Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: As Smooth as a Martini
abstract: Devin Bing and his band, the Secret Service, mix old tunes and new in a show at the Metropolitan Room.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve got more style than a Rolex watch/I’ve got more style than a Rolls-Royce car,” Devin Bing, a Long Island blue-eyed soul crooner declared in his original ballad “Smooth” in the opening of his show on Thursday evening at the Metropolitan Room. Accompanying Mr. Bing, who played piano, was his four-member band, the Secret Service (Michael Feinberg on bass, Blaise Lanzetta on drums, Gavi Grodsky on guitar and Mark Bader on percussion), who churned out the kind of sleek, generic pop-soul grooves with jazz flavoring that are associated with hits by the likes of Robin Thicke.

headline: Oatmeal Sandwich Cookies
abstract: In a twist on an old classic, Melissa Clark adds soft dates and toasted coconut to oatmeal cookies, then sandwiches a thin layer of sweetened mascarpone between them.
lead_paragraph: In a twist on an old classic, Melissa Clark adds soft dates and toasted coconut to oatmeal cookies, then sandwiches a thin layer of sweetened mascarpone between them.

headline: A Fight Over Horses
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio has vowed to banish Central Park carriage horses, but the drivers reject the charge of animal cruelty and say the horses’ health is their biggest concern.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio has vowed to banish Central Park carriage horses, but the drivers reject the charge of animal cruelty and say the horses’ health is their biggest concern.

headline: If You Give A Cookie Some Stuffing
abstract: These oatmeal sandwich cookies woo the kinds of cookie eaters who never seem to look beyond chocolate chips.
lead_paragraph: Forget all the bad, soggy oatmeal cookies you’ve ever had.

headline: Who Speaks for the Carriage Horses?
abstract: In the fight over the future of New York City’s carriage horse trade, both sides say they want what is best for the animals.
lead_paragraph: If only Teddy could talk. Then we would know what he thinks of the politicians and activists and drivers who argue about his future. He could expound on Manhattan traffic, its pollution, the cold, the heat, the hay and the shrieking girls clutching dolls who pet his nose on Grand Army Plaza.

headline: A Bit of Bush and bin Laden
abstract: “BigMouth,” from the Belgian actor-writer-director Valentijn Dhaenens, jostles together the words of speechmakers throughout history.
lead_paragraph: In “BigMouth,” his one-man show in the Under the Radar Festival, the Belgian stage veteran Valentijn Dhaenens takes the long view. Centuries long: In this spare, thought-provoking production, which he directed, Mr. Dhaenens quotes speeches from luminaries across millenniums. Some, like Pericles and George S. Patton, were military commanders; others, like Ronald Reagan and  King Baudouin I of Belgium, national rulers; and still others, like Socrates and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., philosophical leaders. Several, like Nicola Sacco and Ann Coulter, could be called political radicals.

headline: Sharing Web Links Without Cutting and Pasting
abstract: There is an easier way to email a web page link on the Nexus 7 without copying it from the browser and pasting into a message.
lead_paragraph: Q. Is there an easier way to email a web page link on the Nexus 7 than copying and pasting the link from the browser into the mail app?

headline: Bloomberg to Press Republicans on Immigration Overhaul
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Former Mayor Michael Bloomberg will be in Washington next Friday to pressure Republican lawmakers to take up broad reform of immigration laws before the end of the current Congress.
lead_paragraph: Former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York will be in Washington next Friday, along with members of the United States Chamber of Commerce and several prominent Republicans, to pressure Republican lawmakers to take up an overhaul of the nation’s immigration laws before the end of the current Congress.

headline: She’s Having My Baby, Satan Croons
abstract: “Devil’s Due” centers on a couple who discover they’re expecting a baby after a honeymoon outing that they can’t fully recall. Hmm.
lead_paragraph: From “Rosemary’s Baby” (1968) to The Brood” (1979), demon spawn has been erupting from innocent wombs, to the surprise of mothers who unaccountably fail to greet this vile emission with a pillow to the face — presuming it has one, of course.

headline: Pop on Those Prada Shades, Puff Out Your Lips and Say, ‘Puh-leeeze!’
abstract: In “#Rich Kids of Beverly Hills,” a reality show on E!, young, well-off narcissists gleefully document their doings and themselves.
lead_paragraph: The Statler and Waldorf of 90210 are Dorothy Wang and Morgan Stewart, longtime friends with shared passions — expensive nights out, expensive clothes and shoes — paid for with Mommy and Daddy’s money.

headline: ‘Let’s Put On a Show! I’ll Make ...’
abstract: “HitRECord on TV,” making its debut on Pivot, is a television version of a website where various artists collaborate on short films, songs and other creations.
lead_paragraph: The deeply inessential “HitRECord on TV,” which begins Saturday on Pivot, is a variety-show outgrowth of a website started by the actor Joseph Gordon-Levitt and his brother in which contributions from various creative types are crowdsourced to make short films and songs and other things. On the show, all of the contributors are identified by the screen names they use at hitrecord.org. Mr. Gordon-Levitt’s is RegularJoe.

headline: Clothier Outfits New York’s Clergy and Judges in Robes
abstract: Marvin Goldman, 85, has been dressing clergy members and judges most of his life. One nice thing about his clientele, he said, was “getting paid is no problem.”
lead_paragraph: That measuring tape dangling from Marvin Goldman’s neck is almost a formality: Even at 85, he can size you up at 10 paces for your height, weight and sleeve length.

headline: A Photographer’s Artful Images of African Agriculture
abstract: For her latest body of work, “Terrain,” Jackie Nickerson spent about two years visiting and documenting sub-Saharan farmland.
lead_paragraph: In 1997, Jackie Nickerson set out for a farm in Zimbabwe to visit a friend, intending to stay for just a few weeks. But the landscapes, people and agricultural practices of sub-Saharan Africa captivated her, so she ended up staying for four years. At the beginning of her time in Africa, the former fashion photographer documented the rural scenes around the southern part of the continent. The more she traveled, the more her portfolio of alluring portraits and landscapes grew, photographs which she eventually compiled into “Farm,” her first body of work outside of fashion, which was released as a book in 2002.

headline: Met’s General Manager to Take Over Labor Talks
abstract: Peter Gelb, the Metropolitan Opera’s general manager, said he would replace Joseph Volpe as lead negotiator with the Met’s 16 unions.
lead_paragraph: One of the more unusual duo acts in opera is breaking up.

headline: Times Minute | Turmoil in Thailand
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Explosions', 'Law and Legislation', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Also on the Minute, Pennsylvania's voter identification law is struck down and the quarterback matchup of the season takes place on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, Pennsylvania's voter identification law is struck down and the quarterback matchup of the season takes place on Sunday.

headline: If You See Something, Say Something
keywords: ['Science and Technology', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Climate scientists can no longer stay on the sidelines of the global warming debate.
lead_paragraph: STATE COLLEGE, Pa. — THE overwhelming consensus among climate scientists is that human-caused climate change is happening. Yet a fringe minority of our populace clings to an irrational rejection of well-established science. This virulent strain of anti-science infects the halls of Congress, the pages of leading newspapers and what we see on TV, leading to the appearance of a debate where none should exist.

headline: Pulled Down From the Sky, Still Lethal
abstract: In “Grounded,” a one-woman show starring Hannah Cabell at Walkerspace, a military pilot is reassigned to drone duty, operating deadly missions from a base outside Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: The heroine of “Grounded,” a solo play by George Brant, feels most alive when she’s up in the air. A fighter pilot in the Air Force, she loves everything about her job — the suit, the speed, the danger, the respect — but most of all the “blue,” as she calls the wide expanses of sky through which she steers her plane, searching out the bad guys in sorties over Iraq.

headline: Kurt Masur Conducting Seminar Is Postponed
abstract: Mr. Masur, the former music director of the New York Philharmonic, was hospitalized for anemia, and a conducting seminar at the Manhattan School of Music was postponed until next year.
lead_paragraph: Kurt Masur, the former music director of the New York Philharmonic (he now holds an emeritus title) was to have spent next week leading what has become an annual conducting seminar at the Manhattan School of Music. But late Friday afternoon the school announced that Mr. Masur, 86, was hospitalized to be treated for anemia, and that the seminar would be postponed until next year.

headline: Times Minute | Turmoil in Thailand
abstract: Also on the Minute, Pennsylvania’s voter identification law is struck down and the quarterback matchup of the season takes place on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: An Aromatic Experience
abstract: McNulty’s Tea & Coffee, on Christopher Street, has been selling bags of coffee and tea since 1895.
lead_paragraph: McNulty’s Tea & Coffee, on Christopher Street, has been selling bags of coffee and tea since 1895.

headline: Stalking Heritage Far From Home
abstract: About 80 Maya artifacts are on view in Los Angeles, home to many Guatemalans, to drum up support for a national heritage museum.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It is odd to see an eight-foot-long stucco statue of a man in a jaguar mask slinking along the floor of the Convention Center here, as if stalking unsuspecting prey. Over 1,400 years ago, royal accouterments would have accompanied him: The yellow and black discolorations we see on his carved skirt, now faded, would have been potently vivid — evoking animal pelts worn by the Maya elite. Jaguars, in some respects, were Maya lords of the underworld; this representation — formal and monumental — is coiled with menace, threatening death.

headline: The Sweet Smell of Longevity at McNulty’s
abstract: McNulty’s Tea & Coffee, founded in 1895, has lured customers with its wafting scents, a cheap, nearly irresistible advertising strategy.
lead_paragraph: You can smell the store from the sidewalk: the warm, dark aroma of coffee beans.

headline: Intel Plans to Cut 5,000 Jobs in 2014
abstract: Intel, the big chip maker, is cutting positions as it shifts its sights to more profitable lines after failing to recognize the rise of tablets and smartphones and the decline of the PC.
lead_paragraph: Intel expects to shed about 5 percent of its work force, or 5,000 jobs, in 2014, as it tries to change the company with the times, according to a company official.

headline: Not Just a Ride in the Park
abstract: Are horse carriages abusive to animals? Should they be banned?

headline: Armond White, Ousted Critic, Has Words on Expulsion
abstract: Mr. White comments on being voted out of the New York Film Critics Circle after he was attributed with making disparaging remarks about the director Steve McQueen at the circle’s annual awards dinner.
lead_paragraph: “Black Swan” was called “a ridiculous psychological thriller.”

headline: Friday Night Music: San Fermin, The Count
abstract: Powerful stuff.
lead_paragraph: I’m trying to fight back a cold, plus make good on promises to editors, so not much of substance since early today. But I did promise San Fermin to more or less premiere their latest live video — another really striking performance that won’t be to everyone’s taste but which has been rattling around in my head, growing on me, since I first listened to it. I’d recommend their Feb. 7 show at the Bowery Ballroom, but it’s sold out. Here’s what you’ll be missing:

headline: Anheuser-Busch InBev Said to Be Near $4.5 Billion Deal for Korean Brewer
abstract: To regain the asset it had sold off, Anheuser-Busch InBev appears poised to pay a price that will allow Oriental Brewery’s current owners, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Affinity Equity Partners, to more than double their money.
lead_paragraph: Anheuser-Busch InBev is closing in on a deal to reacquire Oriental Brewery from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Affinity Equity Partners for more than $4.5 billion, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: The Scenic Route to ‘Nebraska’
abstract: For the actress June Squibb, nominated for an Oscar at age 84 for her role in “Nebraska,” “plugging away” is a way of life.
lead_paragraph: SHERMAN OAKS, Calif. — June Squibb, 84, was nominated for an Oscar on Thursday for playing a way-past-giving-a-hoot Montanan in “Nebraska.” What does her character think of her dead sister-in-law? While standing over the woman’s grave, Ms. Squibb’s foul-mouthed Kate gives her hilariously matter-of-fact answer: “What a whore.”

headline: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 17
abstract: Subjects include Gov. Chris Christie at the State of the State address, a water main break on Fifth Avenue, and a vaporium in Lower Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Subjects include Gov. Chris Christie at the State of the State address, a water main break on Fifth Avenue, and a vaporium in Lower Manhattan.

headline: De Blasio, Citing ‘Horrible’ Death of Abused Boy, Unveils Plans for Reforms
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio said there had been “more than one opportunity to save” the life of Myls Dobson.
lead_paragraph: After an inquiry into the death of a 4-year-old boy uncovered several holes in New York City’s safety net, Mayor Bill de Blasio on Friday proposed a raft of changes to close some of the gaps and improve communication between the criminal justice system and the agency charged with preventing child abuse.

headline: Filmmaker Ira Sachs’s Sundance Stories
abstract: The director — who shows his sixth film at the festival this month — traces his personal and professional history in Park City.
lead_paragraph: The director Ira Sachs has shown five of his films at the Sundance Film Festival since 1994. This week, he returns with his sixth, the much-anticipated “Love Is Strange,” with a cast including John Lithgow, Alfred Molina and Marisa Tomei. Sachs, whose childhood was partly spent in Park City, Utah, has been attending the festival since its earliest days – even before it was called Sundance — and was present at many of its most famous premieres. Here, he recounts his pivotal festival memories and the lessons he’s learned about the industry along the way.

headline: Company in West Virginia Spill Files for Bankruptcy
keywords: ['Water Pollution', 'Bankruptcies', 'Water', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Freedom Industries, whose chemical spill last week in West Virginia tainted the drinking water of more than 300,000 residents in and around Charleston, is seeking Chapter 11 protection.
lead_paragraph: Freedom Industries, the West Virginia company whose chemical spill last week tainted the drinking water of more than 300,000 residents in and around Charleston, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy on Friday.

headline: The Scene After a Bombing in Kabul
abstract: Three Taliban suicide bombers struck a restaurant popular with Westerners in downtown Kabul, setting off a blast that killed more than 20 people.
lead_paragraph: Three Taliban suicide bombers struck a restaurant popular with Westerners in downtown Kabul, setting off a blast that killed more than 20 people.

headline: Industry City, the SoHo of Sunset Park
abstract: A 30-acre complex in Brooklyn had been a hub for artists, but change in the form of gentrification and high rents is forcing out dozens of them.
lead_paragraph: In October, more than 200 artists combined forces in a former warehouse in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, to create “Come Together: Surviving Sandy, Year 1,” a sprawling exhibition of painting, sculpture and photography. Critics raved about the show, a mix of established names and relative unknowns that “verified that New York is as alive and brilliant as ever,” according to New York magazine, “with artists spread out into all the boroughs.”

headline: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 17
abstract: A slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include Gov. Chris Christie at the State of the State address, a water main break on Fifth Avenue, and a vaporium in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Trials for World Youth Teams Championships in Bridge
abstract: At the trials to select the United States entries for the World Youth Teams Championships in August in Istanbul, six teams entered the under-21 open division.
lead_paragraph: At the trials to select the United States entries for the World Youth Teams Championships in August in Istanbul, six teams entered the under-21 open division. After a round robin and semifinals, two teams played 48 boards to select USA-1.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Check Mates
abstract: The silhouette is familiar, but the mix of three fabrics and patterns on one coat is a winter highlight.
lead_paragraph: The silhouette is familiar, but the mix of three fabrics and patterns on one coat is a winter highlight.

headline: The Logical Sherlock for Our Time
abstract: The hero of PBS’s “Sherlock” is lissome, spirited and briskly energetic, but he isn’t turned inside out to suit current, navel-gazing fashions.
lead_paragraph: It’s not too late.

headline: Jos. A. Bank Rejects Men’s Wearhouse Bid, Again
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: In the latest chapter of the seemingly never-ending takeover war between two of the country’s largest men’s suit retailers, Jos. A. Bank on Friday called its suitor’s offer of $57.50 a share “inadequate and opportunistic.”
lead_paragraph: In the seemingly never-ending takeover war between two of the country’s largest men’s suit retailers, Jos. A. Bank on Friday rejected the latest unsolicited bid from Men’s Wearhouse.

headline: Detroit Officials Scramble on Financing
abstract: Detroit officials spent Friday reshuffling legal and financial plans, a day after a federal bankruptcy judge barred the city from paying $165 million to end some troublesome interest-rate swaps that have been tying up money the city needs.
lead_paragraph: Detroit officials spent Friday reshuffling legal and financial plans, a day after a federal bankruptcy judge barred the city from paying $165 million to end some troublesome interest-rate swaps that have been tying up money the city needs.

headline: Let Curators Be Curators, MOCA’s New Chief Says
abstract: Philippe Vergne said his first priority in rebuilding the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles is to find a chief curator.
lead_paragraph: The New York office of Philippe Vergne, the Dia Art Foundation director, who was named on Wednesday to lead the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, looks out onto a brick vista of Chelsea art galleries. But hanging on the wall next to the windows is a photograph of Walter De Maria’s New Mexico land-art work “The Lightning Field,” showing a vast sweep of Western plateau.

headline: Secret Histories
abstract: In an age in which privacy seems a myth, in which nearly everything about everyone can be gleaned from social media, mysteries do persist, especially in families, to be revealed only after death.
lead_paragraph: After Itzhak Goldberg’s father died in 1995, at age 86, his mother gave him a watch in a red case. The 18-karat gold Patek Philippe was a rare indulgence for his father, a Polish Holocaust survivor who married, moved to Israel and ran a produce business.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Check Mates
abstract: The silhouette is familiar, but the mix of three fabrics and patterns on one coat are a winter highlight.
lead_paragraph: The silhouette is familiar, but the mix of three fabrics and patterns on one coat are a winter highlight. Above, houndstooth check, a gray flannel back and a leather accent on the sleeve for women, and a similar mix of fabrics on men’s coats, bottom left. And for some people, shades of gray were an alternative to black.

headline: Shepherding the Coney Island Polar Bear Club
abstract: Dennis Thomas, the president of the Coney Island Polar Bear Club, goes for a frigid swim in the morning and spends the rest of the day trying to warm up.
lead_paragraph: After three decades, Dennis Thomas’s winter Sundays are no longer shocking. They are just cold. From November to April, Mr. Thomas, 59, charges into the Atlantic Ocean, along with other members of the Coney Island Polar Bear Club; he has been the group’s president for five years. This year, the club’s premier event on New Year’s Day drew 2,000 swimmers and 6,000 spectators and raised $65,000 for children with serious illnesses. On any given Sunday, 80 to 100 members show up at the New York Aquarium for the frosty frolic — neoprene bootees allowed. The lowest water temperature recorded for a swim was 32 degrees one February. Mr. Thomas, the director of global branding for the technology company SAP, lives alone in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. He suspects that his 25-year-old daughter thinks he is crazy.

headline: Evening Hours
abstract: Events for young artists, an old dynasty, finance, football and ice skating.
lead_paragraph: Events for young artists, an old dynasty, finance, football and ice skating.

headline: Weighing the Need for a Landline in a Cellphone World
abstract: Questions to consider include the state of wireless 911 service, what happens when the power goes out and consumer protections.
lead_paragraph: As I was hooking up a new phone in my living room, the kind where you plug a jack into the wall, I wondered why I was holding onto what had largely become a relic. It rarely rings, and even when it does, it’s usually the dentist or a robocaller.

headline: Seven Days of Style | Anna Wintour Gets a Building Named After Her, Victoria Beckham Opens a Store and Amy Adams Wears Some Pricey Bling
abstract: Plus, Prada’s back taxes, a victory for unpaid fashion interns and more, as we run the numbers from the last week in style and culture.
lead_paragraph: ALL THE NUMBERS THAT MATTER FROM THE WEEK IN STYLE AND CULTUREJan. 11 – 17

headline: A Superintendent’s Personal Space
abstract: Gesche Wurfel has been documenting basements in Upper Manhattan that have been decorated by the building superintendents, often with items discarded by tenants.
lead_paragraph: Gesche Wurfel has been documenting basements in Upper Manhattan that have been decorated by the building superintendents, often with items discarded by tenants.

headline: Live-In Superintendents Create Basement Sanctuaries
abstract: Some live-in superintendents have taken to decorating the basements of their buildings with knickknacks, some of which were left behind by departing tenants.
lead_paragraph: As many New York City apartment dwellers know, some live-in superintendents love to decorate the basements of their buildings. Whether this urge to adorn stems from a proprietary sensibility — what’s near the boiler room is mine! — or is simply the result of too many personal knickknacks spilling out of tiny living spaces, the “super cave,” with its birds, potted plants and blinking religious icons, is a phenomenon you have surely seen before.

headline: Standstill on Farm Bill May Revive 1949 Rules
abstract: Lawmakers have until the end of the month to reach agreement on a new farm bill and halt 1949 policies that could cause the cost of milk double.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Pressure is mounting on lawmakers working on a farm bill to come up with a deal before the end of the month, when the Agriculture Department is to begin enforcing a series of decades-old laws that could cause the price of milk and other agricultural products to double.

headline: Eating Pig’s Head (Terrine), Talking Nascar
abstract: Colleagues at Ogilvy & Mather tucked into lunch at a meat-and-beer place at the new Gotham West Market, happy to have new options near the office.
lead_paragraph: If you are ever looking for the world’s best airport food court, you could do worse than to visit the Gotham West Market, the blocklong complex that opened on 11th Avenue by 44th Street in November. There you’ll find high-end branded ramen, upmarket coffee, a kiosk named for the borough of Brooklyn and another named for one of the borough’s streets, where workers and other slurpers from the Far West Side circulate in predatory patterns through the cavernous, music-filled mall or take their places at counters or communal tables. The market joins Eataly and the Todd English Food Hall at the Plaza Hotel in making culinary New York more amenable to people who — no names, please — can’t make up their minds about where to eat. Next up are food courts in Battery Park City and Hudson Yards, and a proposed food mall by Anthony Bourdain.

headline: Video: Papua New Guinea, Where Violence Can Seem Like the Norm for Women
abstract: The Australian government found that nearly every woman has experienced some form of physical violence, sexual violence or both.
lead_paragraph: Papua New Guinea, a developing country of seven million people with a growing market in the mining of natural resources, is one of the most violent places in the world for women, according to the United Nations. In the country’s remote Highlands, the Australian government found that nearly every woman has experienced some form of physical violence, including sexual violence. After decades of abuse from her husband, Agnes, who is now living in a safe house said: “I thought that that was normal for a woman to be beaten by her husband. I never thought it wasn’t right.”

headline: Unusual Chrysler Fix for Jeep Fires Wins Approval
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The automaker will add tow hitches on some Liberty S.U.V.’s and Grand Cherokees in an effort to lower danger from fire in rear-impact collisions.
lead_paragraph: Chrysler can go ahead with an unusual recall plan affecting 1.6 million Jeeps, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said late Friday. The plan involves the use of a trailer hitch intended for towing to reduce the danger of gas tank fires in rear-impact crashes.

headline: Child Rape in Kenya
abstract: L. Susan Slavin, a lawyer representing child rape victims in Kenya, responds to a column by Nicholas Kristof.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: More Details in Mistaken Landing of a Plane
abstract: The National Transportation Safety Board said it had interviewed the pilots of a Southwest Airlines flight that landed at the wrong airport this week.
lead_paragraph: Federal investigators said that the pilots of a Southwest Airlines flight that landed at the wrong airport this week realized their mistake only after they were on the runway, forcing them to brake heavily to bring the plane to a stop.

headline: Defendant Admits Sending Letter With Ricin to Obama
abstract: J. Everett Dutschke, who mailed poison-tainted letters to public officials including President Obama, pleaded guilty to four counts in Oxford, Miss.
lead_paragraph: More than nine months after he mailed ricin-laced letters to public officials as part of a brazen and unconventional plot to incriminate a longtime adversary, a Mississippi man pleaded guilty on Friday to charges that were likely to send him to prison for decades.

headline: Yahoo’s No. 2 Executive Made More Than His Boss (and Virtually Everyone Else)
abstract: Henrique de Castro, who was fired this week as Yahoo’s No. 2 executive, will walk away with as much as $109 million for 15 months of work. His pay for 2012 was higher than that of most Silicon Valley chief executives.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:57 p.m. | Clarified that Mr. de Castro has not responded to requests for comment on his departure.

headline: Sanctions Eased, Iran Gets Feelers From Old Trading Partners
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Excitement over the interim agreement, which will ease some provisions of the American-led sanctions on Iran but essentially leave all of them in place, has not extended to American companies.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — For critics of the interim nuclear agreement with Iran, Hossein Sheikholeslami might seem to embody their worst fears.

headline: Typography Partners Part Ways in Money Fight
abstract: Tobias Frere-Jones, in a lawsuit filed late, accused Jonathan Hoefler of luring him to the company in 1999 with the false promise that they would be 50-50 partners.
lead_paragraph: Tobias Frere-Jones and Jonathan Hoefler are the closest thing to superstars in the arcane world of typography. Their renowned studio has created fonts for Fortune 500 companies and reaped numerous design honors. A signature typeface, Gotham, originally created for GQ Magazine, gave Barack Obama’s “hope” and “change” presidential campaign its distinctive look.

headline: The Source | Tilda Swinton in Conversation With Doug Aitken
abstract: In the latest installment of the Source, a series of conversations on the roots of creativity, the artist Doug Aitken interviews the actress Tilda Swinton, who talks about identity, language and performance.
lead_paragraph: “The thing that keeps me being a performer,” Tilda Swinton says, “is my interest in society’s obsession with identity.” Swinton, who will appear in the upcoming Wes Anderson film, “The Grand Budapest Hotel,” and is known for her roles in “I Am Love,” “Michael Clayton” and “Adaptation,” talks to the artist Doug Aitken about what drives her as an actress. (She appeared in the 2007 Aitken film installation “Sleepwalkers.”) The interview is part of the Source, a series of candid video conversations with several dozen noteworthy figures about their creative process, currently on view in a custom pavilion at the Sundance Film Festival.

headline: The Forgotten Virtues of Tammany Hall
abstract: Political machines served the people when the government didn’t.
lead_paragraph: DURING last summer’s contentious primary campaign, Bill de Blasio managed to get himself selected as his party’s candidate for mayor of New York without the support of the Democratic Party’s once-powerful county organizations. Historically, that’s quite an achievement. Even Ed Koch, the man who helped put a stake in the heart of Tammany Hall in the early 1960s, had the tacit backing of machines in Brooklyn and the Bronx when he captured the mayoralty in 1977.

headline: Ways to Look at Income Inequality

headline: Last-Ditch Effort Emerges to Restore Order in Central African Republic
keywords: ['Elections', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: An unlikely experiment is underway in the Central African Republic as a council of 135 rebels, rivals, politicians and others is trying to choose an interim president.
lead_paragraph: BANGUI, Central African Republic — By midafternoon, a hot breeze blows down empty corridors of the mostly vacant national assembly building here. Hundreds of grim soldiers, their uniforms looted or hidden away, mass in civilian clothes after going AWOL for months. Around abandoned university buildings, idle students loiter, their classes long canceled.

headline: After Slow Execution, Renewed Death Penalty Debate and Threat of Lawsuit
abstract: Ohio corrections officials used a new combination of untested drugs during an execution of a man convicted of murdering and raping a 22-year-old pregnant woman.
lead_paragraph: A 53-year-old convicted killer’s unusually slow death while being executed with an untested combination of drugs in Ohio on Thursday has renewed the debate over lethal injection and the death penalty.

lead_paragraph: Many Atlantic Coast Conference basketball fans expected the newcomers from the Big East — Syracuse, Pittsburgh and Notre Dame — to introduce a rough-and-tumble style that would be irritating to watch.

abstract: Readers react to the continuing fallout over the George Washington Bridge lane closings.

lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Uganda’s president has refused to sign a bill that would impose harsh sentences for gay people, including life imprisonment, temporarily sidestepping a clash with foreign donors who have condemned the legislative push for years.

headline: Traffic Jam Investigator Offers Ulterior Motive
keywords: ['George Washington Bridge', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: For some who doubt that gridlock on the George Washington Bridge was simply a matter of political punishment, a construction site near the bridge has spurred a collective “Aha!”
lead_paragraph: Four months after the streets of Fort Lee, N.J., were suddenly gridlocked, speculation continues to swirl about what really motivated allies of Gov. Chris Christie to engineer the mess. For some clue-seekers, a construction site at the west end of the George Washington Bridge has spurred a collective “Aha!”

headline: Unto the Breach
abstract: Target, Neiman Marcus and other retailers need to do more to protect customer data.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, a letter landed in my email inbox from Gregg Steinhafel, the chief executive of Target. He wanted me to know that there was a decent likelihood that some of my personal information had been stolen by criminals who had “forced their way into our systems,” as Steinhafel put it, and pulled off one of the biggest data breaches in history.

headline: Two Senators Have Little but a State in Common
abstract: Tammy Baldwin, a Democrat, and Ron Johnson, a Republican, of Wisconsin personify the polarized Congress, voting against each other more than any other state’s senators.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He offered to explain the intricacies of the federal budget. She reminded him that she had majored in math.

headline: Yankees Sign Five Players, Flirting With Payroll Threshold
abstract: The Yankees came to terms with Brett Gardner and four others, but should the team sign Masahiro Tanaka, the Japanese pitching star, it could trigger the payroll luxury tax.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees settled all of their arbitration-eligible cases on Friday as their payroll crept closer to the $189 million threshold for luxury-tax purposes. If the Yankees were to sign the coveted Japanese pitcher Masahiro Tanaka before the Jan. 24 deadline, they would almost certainly surge past the mark.

headline: 384 Priests Defrocked Over Abuse in 2 Years
abstract: After the child sexual abuse scandal exploded in Europe and beyond, the Vatican defrocked 260 priests in 2011 and 124 more in 2012, according to statistics compiled by The Associated Press.
lead_paragraph: The Vatican defrocked 260 priests for the sexual abuse of children in 2011 and 124 more in 2012 after the scandal exploded in Europe and beyond and bishops forwarded hundreds of cases to the Vatican, according to statistics compiled by The Associated Press.

headline: Sometimes ‘Nazi’ Is the Right Word
abstract: If Israel bans the word “Nazi,” “Seinfeld” will be verboten, too.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — “NAZI” is a short word. It has only two syllables, like “rac-ist” or “kill-er.” “Democracy,” on the other hand, is a long word with lots of syllables that is very tiring to say. It may not be as tiring as saying “freedom of expression” or “social justice,” but still, there is something really exhausting about it.

headline: Leaders Begin City’s Left Turn With Sick Pay Proposal
abstract: The plan is the first in a series of labor- and immigrant-friendly laws that Mayor Bill de Blasio is expected to champion, including higher pay for employees on many city-sponsored projects.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s top elected officials said on Friday that they would greatly expand the reach of a measure mandating paid time off for sick workers, a cherished cause of the national left that had long been resisted by local business leaders.

headline: Twitter’s Product Chief Leaves the Nest

lead_paragraph: Michael Sippey, the vice president of product at Twitter, announced on Friday that he would step down from his position — the first high-level departure from the social network company since it went public in November.

headline: The President on Mass Surveillance
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Privacy', 'Speeches and Statements', 'Editorials']
abstract: Restoring trust in government agencies requires more than a few good restrictions on collecting personal data.
lead_paragraph: In the days after Edward Snowden revealed that the United States government was collecting vast amounts of Americans’ data — phone records and other personal information — in the name of national security, President Obama defended the data sweep and said the American people should feel comfortable with its collection. On Friday, after seven months of increasingly uncomfortable revelations and growing public outcry, Mr. Obama gave a speech that was in large part an admission that he had been wrong.

headline: A Good Start for Health Care Sign-Ups
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Youth', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Editorials']
abstract: Young adults are surging into the state and federal exchanges now that website glitches have been fixed.
lead_paragraph: Enrollments in health insurance plans through state and federal exchanges are rising rapidly, especially among young adults, making it likely that the Affordable Care Act will achieve a large and stabilizing mix of enrollees by the end of the open enrollment period on March 31. Some 2.2 million people signed up in the first three months, from Oct. 1 through Dec. 28.

headline: City Newcomer Is Let Down by a Stranger, Then the Police
keywords: ['Robberies and Thefts', 'Disabilities', 'Snow and Snowstorms', 'Port Authority Bus Terminal (NYC)', 'Police']
abstract: Over two days Fredrick Brennan, 19, who uses a wheelchair, had nearly $5,000 stolen from him, helped the police identify the thief, and was left to get home on his own during a winter storm.
lead_paragraph: Fredrick Brennan, 19, moved out of his mother’s home in New Jersey in August and into an apartment in Brooklyn that his boss helped him find. This leap was far greater than the 120 miles or so on a map.

keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Sex Crimes', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: At a time when the drugs used in executions are in short supply, an execution in Ohio has raised questions about the obligations of the state toward those it kills.
lead_paragraph: As the lethal drugs flowed into his veins in the Ohio death chamber, Dennis B. McGuire at first “went unconscious” and his body was still, his daughter, Amber McGuire, said Friday.

headline: North Carolina: Judge Blocks Ultrasound Requirement
abstract: A federal judge on Friday declared unconstitutional the state’s ultrasound requirement for women seeking abortions, saying it violated the First Amendment by requiring doctors to display a fetal image and describe it even to women who covered their eyes and ears.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on  Friday declared unconstitutional the state’s ultrasound requirement for women seeking abortions, saying it violated the First Amendment by requiring doctors to display a fetal image and describe it even to women who covered their eyes and ears. Judge Catherine C. Eagles of the Middle District of North Carolina called the law, passed in 2011, an impermissible attempt to compel doctors “to deliver the state’s message in favor of childbirth and against abortion.” The state has not said whether it will appeal to the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, Va. A similar law in Texas was upheld by the Fifth Circuit, in New Orleans, and is in effect.

headline: After Leaving Office, Bloomberg Is More Hands-On at Old Company
abstract: Michael R. Bloomberg’s dive back into the news side of Bloomberg L.P. has worried some that the division’s editorial independence could be called into question.
lead_paragraph: At editorial meetings in Bloomberg L.P.’s headquarters this week, Michael R. Bloomberg gave clear signs that he would not be taking a hands-off approach as he returned to his old company.

headline: Shaun White Reasserts Snowboard Dominance, in Just a Day
abstract: White moved a step closer to his goal of pursuing two Olympic gold medals in Sochi by capturing the halfpipe event Friday in qualifying competition for the American team.
lead_paragraph: MAMMOTH LAKES, Calif. — In just over 24 hours, Shaun White went from being violently splayed on the snow to looking positively ready for his quest for dual gold medals in Sochi.

headline: Bloomberg to Push G.O.P. for Immigration Action
abstract: Former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York will be in Washington on Friday to pressure Republican lawmakers to take up an overhaul of immigration laws.
lead_paragraph: Former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York will be in Washington on Friday to pressure Republican lawmakers to take up an overhaul of immigration laws. The meeting, his first major public policy event since his term ended, is pegged to President Obama’s State of the Union address on Jan. 28. The meeting will include prominent Republicans and U.S. Chamber of Commerce representatives. Speaker John A. Boehner and his leadership team are preparing a policy blueprint that is likely to include at least some path to legal status for 11 million undocumented immigrants in the country.

headline: Exchange Some Words

lead_paragraph: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I’ve come to the conclusion that there are two people inside David Steinberg. I’ve met him, and they’re both lovely people. But it has become increasingly clear that while he is chronologically a teenager, there is also an old soul inside him struggling to get out.

headline: Skeleton’s Predecessor Is Still Alive at Cresta Run
abstract: Alexandros Kefalas was introduced to the sport at the Cresta Run, a unique course where competitors use equipment that is different from what is used at the Winter Olympics.
lead_paragraph: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland — Alexandros Kefalas had just plunged down a bobsled run more than a mile long at almost 80 miles an hour. His time was 1 minute 11.93 seconds, only a second slower than that of the fastest rider during a recent practice here. But in skeleton a race is often decided by hundredths of a second.

lead_paragraph: Many are calling on Alex Rodriguez to drop his lawsuits against baseball and ride off into oblivion. His critics are clamoring for A-Rod to take his medicine.

headline: In Keeping Grip on Data Pipeline, Obama Does Little to Reassure Industry
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Corporations', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Google, which briefly considered moving all of its computer servers out of the United States last year after learning how they had been penetrated by the National Security Agency, was looking for a public assurance from President Obama that the government would no longer secretly suck data from the company’s corner of the Internet cloud.

headline: Egypt: Clashes Erupt During Protests
abstract: Egypt’s security forces killed at least two protesters and arrested more than a hundred on Friday during demonstrations around the country.
lead_paragraph: Egypt’s security forces killed at least two protesters and arrested more than a hundred on Friday during demonstrations around the country against the military government, the state news media reported. In recent days millions voted to approve a new constitution validating the military takeover last summer. Friday’s clashes are the first evidence that the new charter is unlikely to resolve the complaints of the protest movement, the terrorist threat from a budding insurgency or Egypt’s deep divisions. At least one protester was killed in Fayoum, south of Cairo, and another on the outskirts of Cairo. Separately, a report from Democracy International, an election-monitoring group that sent 80 observers to track the constitutional referendum, said it had “serious concerns” about the political environment of the voting, with “arrests and detention of dissenting voices” and “no real opportunity for those opposed to the government’s road map of the proposed constitution to dissent.”

headline: Fighting to Keep a Life Built in the United States
abstract: When Beatriz Rivera was a child, her family moved from Mexico to Yonkers. But the possibility of deportation limited her job opportunities.
lead_paragraph: Things have not gone according to the plan hatched long ago by Beatriz Rivera’s family.

headline: South Africa: Rhino Killings Increase
abstract: The South African government reported Friday that poachers killed 1,004 rhinos in South Africa last year, up from 668 in 2012.
lead_paragraph: Poachers killed 1,004 rhinos in South Africa last year, up from 668 in 2012, as they continue to hunt the animals for their valuable horns, the South African government reported Friday. The Department of Environmental Affairs blamed poachers who cross the border from Mozambique to South Africa, then sell the horns to places like Vietnam and China, where they are symbols of wealth and are used in potions. The number of rhinos illegally killed in South Africa has been climbing since at least 2010, when 333 deaths were reported. Susie Ellis, of the global nonprofit group International Rhino Foundation, said the latest figure was almost certainly an undercount. “Those are only the deaths that we know about,” she said. Traffic, an international wildlife watchdog group, said Mozambique treated rhino-related crimes as misdemeanors.

headline: Turkey: Contentious Medical Bill Signed
keywords: ['First Aid', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Emergency Medical Treatment']
abstract: President Abdullah Gul signed a measure into law on Friday that makes it a crime to administer emergency first aid without government authorization.
lead_paragraph: Over the objections of human rights and medical groups, President Abdullah Gul signed a measure into law on Friday that makes it a crime to administer emergency first aid without government authorization. Critics contend that the law could be used by the police and prosecutors to intimidate and punish doctors and other medical workers for treating protesters wounded in demonstrations against the government, like those in Turkey last year. “Passing a bill that criminalizes emergency care and punishes those who care for injured protesters is part of the Turkish government’s relentless effort to silence any opposing voices,” said Dr. Vincent Iacopino, senior medical adviser at Physicians for Human Rights, one of the groups that had campaigned against the legislation. If convicted, violators could be imprisoned for up to three years and face fines of nearly $1 million.

headline: To ‘Rambo’ Hit-Man Case, Add an Element of Houdini
abstract: A former soldier charged with conspiring to kill a federal agent and a federal informer had gotten out of his handcuffs on his own, a federal prosecutor said.
lead_paragraph: When charges were announced last fall against Joseph Hunter, a former Army sergeant accused of being a contract killer, the authorities revealed that one of his nicknames was Rambo.

headline: Japan: Lawmaker Defends Shrine Visit
abstract: A top Japanese lawmaker on Friday denounced American criticism of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s visit last month to a Tokyo war shrine.
lead_paragraph: A top Japanese lawmaker on Friday denounced American criticism of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s visit last month to a Tokyo war shrine, comparing it to American politicians’ paying their respects at Arlington National Cemetery. The lawmaker, Koichi Hagiuda of Mr. Abe’s governing Liberal Democratic Party, said it was unfair for the United States to expect Japanese leaders to refrain from visiting the Yasukuni shrine, which honors the nation’s war dead, when American politicians can freely honor their fallen soldiers. “If Japan says, ‘It’s unfavorable to pay a visit to Arlington National Cemetery,’ do they refrain from going there?” Mr. Hagiuda, a special adviser to Mr. Abe, was quoted as saying by the Kyodo News Agency. “I assume the United States will say, ‘It’s none of a foreign country’s business.’ ” Mr. Hagiuda was responding to an American government statement expressing disappointment with Mr. Abe’s visit to the controversial Shinto shrine on Dec. 26. Washington feared such a visit could anger other Asian nations, where Yasukuni is viewed as a symbol of Japan’s refusal to come to terms with its brutal 20th-century militarism because it honors all war dead, including convicted war criminals. The shrine also houses a museum that views World War II as a noble struggle by Japan to liberate Asia from white imperialism.

abstract: Lottery numbers for Jan. 17, 2014, in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: In Small Town in Canada, Celebrating Hockey With Songs

lead_paragraph: LLOYDMINSTER, Alberta — Thousands of miles wide, Canada is girded by a narrow belt of population stretched thin across its vast landscape. Hockey is the common experience shared in every large city and small town along the way.

headline: Outside Convention Hall, New Cars Often Aren’t on the Mind
abstract: In Detroit, a struggling but often upbeat city, just getting by is the main focus.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Inside the North American International Auto Show, the cars are the stars and the razzle-dazzle is nonstop. But outside Cobo Center, where the exhibition opens to the public on Jan. 18, a bankrupt but sometimes surprisingly optimistic city goes about its business. Here are a few scenes from outside the show:

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Showtime) SILVER LININGS PLAYBOOK (2012) Pat Solatano (Bradley Cooper, above), who has returned to the home of his parents (Jacki Weaver and Robert De Niro) after eight months in a mental institution, following a violent crime, tries to tackle the world — and reclaim his estranged wife, Nikki, who took out a restraining order against him — through a physical and psychological regimen he created while locked away. Then he meets Tiffany (Jennifer Lawrence), a heartbreaker who persuades Pat that she can circumvent the law by passing a letter from him to Nikki — if only he’ll enter a dance contest with her. Soon, she is leading, and he is following. “For all its high-flying zaniness, the movie has the sting of life, and its humor feels dredged up from the same dark, boggy place from which Samuel Beckett extracted his yuks,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this best picture Oscar nominee directed by David O. Russell, which also earned nominations for Mr. Cooper, Ms. Weaver and Mr. De Niro, and a win for Ms. Lawrence. “ ‘Silver Linings Playbook’ is crammed with people talking and shouting and weeping and also yielding to what are sometimes called boundary issues but which here turn out to be the mad, loving scrambling of people finding and saving one another,” Ms. Dargis added. “These are characters who get in one another’s faces and occasionally punch a loved one right in the kisser. They must go on, they can’t go on, but together they do.”

headline: Deadly Attack at Kabul Restaurant Hints at Changing Climate for Foreigners
abstract: Kabul during the Afghan war was never violent as Baghdad during the Iraq war. But as coalition forces leave, international workers here feel more vulnerable.

Vadim Nazarov, a top political officer at the United Nations, dedicated himself over the past nine years to looking for a peaceful solution to the Afghan war. Dhamender Singh Phangurha, a British candidate in the coming elections for the European Parliament, was here on a consulting contract.
