headline: A Philandering French President, a Complex Election in Egypt
keywords: ['Elections', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Constitutions']
abstract: A week dominated by the Middle East’s maddening ambiguities and conflicts.
lead_paragraph: The Middle East was much in the news these past days, with all its maddening ambiguities and conflicts on full display.

headline: Men’s Paris Fashion Week: Berluti Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: The Rationality Debate, Simmering in Stockholm
abstract: Three Nobel lectures continue a discussion that divides economists, and those in other social sciences as well.
lead_paragraph: Are people really rational in their economic decision making? That question divides the economics profession today, and the divisions were evident at the Nobel Week events in Stockholm last month.

headline: Girish Navani, on Why Titles Don’t Matter
abstract: The chief executive of eClinicalWorks says he guards against “title warfare” at his company, saying that new job titles “get old within the first day of having them.”
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Girish Navani, C.E.O. of eClinicalWorks, a provider of clinical information systems, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Inspecting a Student Loan Spigot
keywords: ['For-Profit Schools', 'Student Loans', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: ITT Educational Services, which operates for-profit technical schools, has drawn the attention of regulators over a private lending trust.
lead_paragraph: A few days after Christmas, ITT Educational Services, one of the nation’s largest operators of for-profit technical schools, reported some unwelcome news. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau had warned the company that it might seek penalties and remedies against it for possible student loan violations.

headline: Tackling Inequality
abstract: Readers respond to “The Vicious Circle of Income Inequality” (Economic View, Jan. 12).
lead_paragraph: Tackling Inequality

headline: Film Gives a Peek at the Romney Who Never Quite Won Over Voters
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)', 'Movies']
abstract: A film offers a behind-the-scenes look at Mitt Romney and his quest for the presidency.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — “Mitt,” the documentary about Mitt Romney’s failed quest for the presidency, begins on Christmas Eve 2006, with Mr. Romney, his wife, Ann, and their five sons sitting in their Park City house, weighing the pros and cons of a Romney candidacy.

headline: Rivalry Between Seattle and San Francisco Heats Up the West Coast
abstract: The N.F.C. championship game between Seattle and San Francisco is the latest event in a long-running debate over football and cultural superiority in the West Coast cities.
lead_paragraph: The Seattle Seahawks and the San Francisco 49ers act like the N.F.L.’s fiercest rivals, which might seem strange for teams that have never met in the playoffs. Stranger still, the tension’s origins trace to five years ago, when both teams were bad and their current coaches led college programs.

headline: Yahoo’s Asian Lifeline
abstract: Despite the company’s recent shake-up, Wall Street still likes its valuable holdings in China and Japan.
lead_paragraph: Yahoo’s core business has been eroding. It’s lost ground in display advertising and in online search, and the Wall Street consensus is that its revenue declined last year.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines.
lead_paragraph: Rodriguez Ban Teaches Lessons, Albeit Late

headline: Joe on WNYC’s “Money Talking”: January 17, 2014
abstract: This week, Joe discusses the World Economic Forum and the N.S.A.
lead_paragraph: This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine discuss the connection between the upcoming World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, and the idea of privacy that’s been put front and center by the N.S.A. leaks and the President’s new reforms. Joe also discusses the data breach at Target, which is the subject of his column today.

headline: The Source | Paolo Soleri in Conversation With Doug Aitken
abstract: In the latest installment of the Source, a series of conversations on the roots of creativity, the artist Doug Aitken interviews the late architect Paolo Soleri, who talks about the importance of the unknowable.
lead_paragraph: “Reality is a process,” says the Italian-American architect Paolo Soleri, who passed away last year at the age of 93. “So we are a tiny, tiny, tiny, tiny, little processing plant.” Soleri, who is best known for Arcosanti, his experimental planned community in the Arizona desert, talks to the artist Doug Aitken about the importance of the unknowable. The interview is part of the Source, a series of candid video conversations with several dozen noteworthy figures about their creative process, currently on view in a custom pavilion at the Sundance Film Festival.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
abstract: Dani Raymon talks to us, cryptically.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — I believe this is Daniel Raymon’s first cryptic crossword puzzle published in The New York Times, and if this one is any indication, he’s got a nice cryptic career ahead of him. This was a fun one.

headline: The Myth of the Deserving Rich
abstract: Why the sociologizers are wrong.
lead_paragraph: Many influential people have a hard time thinking straight about inequality. Partly, of course, this is because of Upton Sinclair’s dictum: it’s hard for a man to understand something when his salary depends on his not understanding it. Part of it is because even acknowledging that inequality is a real problem implicitly opens the door to taking progressive policies seriously.

headline: Army’s New Rhythm
abstract: American soldiers are struggling to find relevance in the face of an uncertain future.
lead_paragraph: American soldiers are struggling to find relevance in the face of an uncertain future.

headline: In Denver, Fans Are Bullish on the Broncos, but Wary of the Patriots
abstract: Broncos fans are rabid in support of their team, but ever-wary of Tom Brady and the Patriots in Sunday’s A.F.C. title game.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — On a sun-splashed Friday afternoon that felt more like spring than the prelude to an A.F.C. championship game, this football-crazed city showed a self-assured calm before the storm blowing west out of New England.

headline: Eagle Scout. Idealist. Drug Trafficker?
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Bitcoin (Currency)', 'Black Markets']
abstract: Friends call Ross Ulbricht sensitive and soulful. Prosecutors contend that he ran a global, illicit online bazaar.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ulbricht’s last moments as a free man were noisy enough to draw a crowd. Employees at the Glen Park branch of the San Francisco library heard a crashing sound and rushed to the science fiction section, expecting to find a patron had hit the floor. Instead, they found a handful of federal agents surrounding a slender 29-year-old man with light brown hair and wearing a T-shirt and jeans.

headline: Dizzying Heights, With Risks
abstract: The X Games drive revenue while showcasing sports like motocross and freestyle snowmobiling, but last year came a first: a death in competition, of Caleb Moore.
lead_paragraph: KEMP, Tex. — The life of an all-terrain vehicle racer is a peripatetic one, big on low-budget adventures but small when it comes to paychecks. The best racers in the nation were here in October for the ATV Pro Challenge in Memory of Caleb Moore, which offered $30,000 in total prize money, a record for the sport. As on most weekends on the ATV tour, however, it meant that competitors shared recreational vehicles and campers as well as fuel pumps and any other part that failed.

headline: Defying Gravity
abstract: Extreme sports have grown in popularity, but as athletes scale the heights to became stars, debilitating injuries or death can result.
lead_paragraph: Extreme sports have grown in popularity, but as athletes scale the heights to became stars, debilitating injuries or death can result.

headline: Still Waiting for New Royalty in Men’s Game
abstract: The same four players have had a hold on men’s tennis for the better part of nine seasons, but Grigor Dimitrov and Milos Raonic could be capable of breaking through.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — One court on Saturday at the Australian Open provided a window into the future of men’s tennis, the possibilities and pitfalls on display.

headline: Patients’ Costs Skyrocket; Specialists’ Incomes Soar
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Skin Cancer', 'Surgery and Surgeons', 'Series', 'Doctors', 'Medicine and Health', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: Patient costs have risen as doctors have become more entrepreneurial, protecting their turf through lobbying by medical societies and increasing revenues by offering new and more lucrative procedures.
lead_paragraph: CONWAY, Ark. — Kim Little had not thought much about the tiny white spot on the side of her cheek until a physician’s assistant at her dermatologist’s office warned that it might be cancerous. He took a biopsy, returning 15 minutes later to confirm the diagnosis and schedule her for an outpatient procedure at the Arkansas Skin Cancer Center in Little Rock, 30 miles away.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Clutching Men’s Bags, Big or Small
abstract: At men’s wear shows, the Victoria Beckham way of holding a large bag as though it were a tiny clutch infused runway style.
lead_paragraph: It’s a source of mild debate in the style-obsessed sphere whether Victoria Beckham truly originated, or at the very least popularized, the style of clutching — as opposed to toting or carrying — a leather handbag as one would a more diminutive evening style. This manner of wearing a large bag — with an arm slipped through both handles, the one hand supporting the bottom while the straps fall to the side — was surprisingly adopted by some major fashion houses for their men’s wear runway presentations. The slick dudes at Gucci looked no less manly carrying soft pastel leather bags in this fashion, nor did Tomas Maier’s athletic guys wearing the house‘s signature leather bags. At Valentino, an actual clutch replaced the large bag style, but the stylistic technique remained the same. And aside from the aesthetic affectation, this method also provides an added amount of security. It would certainly require a skilled purse snatcher to disentangle the bag from its owner.

headline: At Center Stage Again, Stephens Looks to Rise
abstract: Sloane Stephens has been a difficult player to assess, but she is her most consistent at big tournaments.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Sloane Stephens, one of the fastest players on the WTA Tour, is a slow starter. She has fallen behind in the first set of her first three matches at the Australian Open and won two of those sets.

headline: G.O.P. Advice for Christie: Pick a Better Team
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'George Washington Bridge']
abstract: Republicans around the country are offering pointed advice, sobering in its candor, for Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, after his top aides were linked to the Fort Lee scandal.
lead_paragraph: On a conference call with Gov. Chris Christie’s most loyal donors a few nights ago, his brother, Todd, pressed for last-minute cash to pay for the governor’s inauguration, a daylong fete ending on Ellis Island.

headline: Rules for Equal Coverage by Employers Remain Elusive Under Health Law
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Executive Compensation', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: The administration is delaying enforcement of the health law provision that prohibits employers from providing better benefits to top executives than to other employees.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is delaying enforcement of another provision of the new health care law, one that prohibits employers from providing better health benefits to top executives than to other employees.

headline: Dior Homme: Fall 2014 Menswear
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu: Jan. 19
abstract: After President Obama’s speech on changes to N.S.A. surveillance practices, national security and civil liberties debates will dominate the Sunday morning shows this week.
lead_paragraph: In a speech Friday, President Obama vowed to make significant changes to the surveillance programs, run by the National Security Agency, but included important qualifiers to his promises. The president accepted some of the recommendations from an independent panel that argued late last year for significant curbing of N.S.A. power and the imposition of more oversight. But  he left some grumbling that the overhaul will not do enough to protect civil liberties.

headline: Jersey Sponsor Threatens to Bolt Over Anelka
abstract: Zoopla, West Bromwich Albion’s jersey sponsor, could cancel its deal if the Premier League club allows Nicolas Anelka to play Monday.
lead_paragraph: Pepe Mel, the new manager of West Bromwich Albion, is looking forward to his first match in charge when his club hosts Everton on Monday in England’s Premier League.

headline: With Plan to Overhaul Spying, the Divisiveness Is in the Details
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Now that President Obama has announced an overhaul of surveillance practices, the real work begins for intelligence agencies and a divided Congress to create new policies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The roiling debate over security and liberty did not end with President Obama’s newly announced overhaul of surveillance practices. Rather, it now enters a volatile next phase as intelligence agencies and a divided Congress try to turn principles into policy.

headline: Syrian Opposition Votes to Attend Peace Talks
abstract: The vote was boycotted by a third of the members of the main rebel coalition, a reflection of the intense divisions among those seeking to overthrow President Bashar al-Assad.
lead_paragraph: SILIVRI, Turkey — Under intense international pressure and facing a boycott from a third of its members, the National Coalition for Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces voted Saturday to send a delegation to an international peace conference aimed at ending Syria’s civil war.

headline: An Interview With Mitt Romney
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: The former presidential candidate gives his thoughts on another run (“No, no, no”) and on the future for him and his party.
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY —  Mitt Romney’s long journey in search of the presidency began on Christmas Eve in 2006, in Park City, Utah, as he and his family considered the burdens of a presidential bid. On Friday, Mr. Romney returned to where it all started, attending the Sundance Film Festival for the premiere of “Mitt,” a 94-minute documentary chronicling both his 2008 and 2012 campaigns.

headline: Among the Best, but Having to Wait
abstract: Chloe Kim, 13, routinely outscores veteran champions and past Olympians, but she will not compete in the Sochi Olympics because she is too young.
lead_paragraph: MAMMOTH LAKES, Calif. — The goal of this winter’s Olympic qualifying events in snowboarding is to find the Americans most likely to win a medal in Russia next month.

headline: Trade and the Environment
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Environment', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Treaties']
abstract: American officials must insist on enforceable standards in any deal with Pacific Rim countries.
lead_paragraph: One of the most laudable American goals in negotiating the trade agreement known as the Trans-Pacific Partnership with 11 other countries was to strengthen environmental protections around the world. But a draft chapter of the agreement made public last week by WikiLeaks shows that many of the countries involved in the talks are trying to undermine that goal.

headline: Ann Cavoukian
abstract: An online confidentiality expert whose grandmothers escaped the Armenian genocide talks about freedom and privacy.
lead_paragraph: Ann Cavoukian is the information and privacy commissioner in Ontario, Canada, and a longtime advocate of default online confidentiality. Her concept of “privacy by design,” which was developed in the 1990s and encourages embedding privacy protections in information technology and business practices, has recently gained renewed attention and proclamations of support from regulatory agencies worldwide.

headline: Peeling Away the Plastic
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2012', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Movies']
abstract: Despite the brutal endurance tests of campaigns, do we ever really know the people we put in the Oval Office?
lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — IT’S hard to imagine anything more painful than going through the presidential campaign all over again with Mitt Romney.

headline: A Step Toward Restoring Voting Rights
keywords: ['Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Editorials']
abstract: Though flawed, a bipartisan bill would begin to undo the Supreme Court’s damage.
lead_paragraph: Only seven months after the Supreme Court shattered the Voting Rights Act, a bipartisan group of lawmakers has come up with a bill that would go a long way toward putting it back together. If they can persuade Republicans in Congress to set aside partisanship and allow it to pass, they would begin to restore justice to a deeply damaged electoral process. It would be an ideal way to observe the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr.’s birthday this week.

headline: At Last, Conservative Reform
abstract: It’s not just that new ideas are popping up. There are also some real live politicians to go with them.
lead_paragraph: IN American life, political ideas that lack partisan champions are regarded suspiciously, like an attempt to cheat at cards or pay for dinner with counterfeit cash. Because we have only two parties, because those parties are ideologically disciplined, and because everyone is obsessed with the other side’s unrighteousness, there’s a sense that if you aren’t fully on board with an existing partisan agenda, you don’t have any business getting mixed up in the debate.

headline: ‘Neglected Topic’ Winner: Climate Change
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Temperature', 'News and News Media', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The winner of my neglected topic contest is climate change. And there is a lot to discuss!
lead_paragraph: HERE’S a scary fact about America: We’re much more likely to believe that there are signs that aliens have visited Earth (77 percent) than that humans are causing climate change (44 percent).

headline: Obama’s Homework Assignment
abstract: As he prepares his State of the Union address, he might get some inspiration from his secretary of education.
lead_paragraph: PRESIDENT OBAMA will deliver his State of the Union address on Jan. 28, but, for my money, his secretary of education, Arne Duncan, already gave it. Just not enough people heard it.

headline: For the Love of Money
keywords: ['Addiction (Psychology)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Derivatives (Financial Instruments)', 'Bonuses', 'Financial Brokers', 'Executive Compensation', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: We are letting money addiction drive too much of our society.
lead_paragraph: IN my last year on Wall Street my bonus was $3.6 million — and I was angry because it wasn’t big enough. I was 30 years old, had no children to raise, no debts to pay, no philanthropic goal in mind. I wanted more money for exactly the same reason an alcoholic needs another drink: I was addicted.

headline: Disaffected Republicans
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: Readers respond to a Jan. 15 letter in which Robert L. Bryant, a lifelong Republican, decried “the choices my party has presented to me.”
lead_paragraph: Readers respond to a Jan. 15 letter in which Robert L. Bryant, a lifelong Republican, decried “the choices my party has presented to me.”

headline: Thanks, Mom and Dad, for All Your Support
abstract: Parents’ web searches show that gender roles continue.
lead_paragraph: Parents’ web searches show that gender roles continue.

headline: Smoking Is Worse Than You Imagined
abstract: The latest surgeon general’s report offers astonishing new evidence of just how much harm tobacco is causing.
lead_paragraph: The latest surgeon general’s report on the health effects of smoking — issued at the 50th anniversary of the pathbreaking 1964 report — offers astonishing new evidence of just how much harm tobacco is causing. Despite the many gains in reducing risks over the past half-century, researchers keep finding new and insidious ways in which smoking is harming the smokers themselves and nonsmokers who breathe in toxic fumes.

headline: Google, Tell Me. Is My Son a Genius?
abstract: Parents wonder far more often if their boys are gifted than if their girls are.
lead_paragraph: MORE than a decade into the 21st century, we would like to think that American parents have similar standards and similar dreams for their sons and daughters. But my study of anonymous, aggregate data from Google searches suggests that contemporary American parents are far more likely to want their boys smart and their girls skinny.

headline: The Cruelest Pregnancy
abstract: A Texas law has turned a brain-dead woman into an incubator. How does that honor life?
lead_paragraph: WHAT would Marlise Munoz have made of all of this?

headline: Sex and the Single Senior
keywords: ['Sexually Transmitted Diseases', 'Elderly', 'Retirement Communities and Assisted Living']
abstract: Older people, with little interest in protection, have more S.T.D’s.
lead_paragraph: WHAT is happening in retirement communities, assisted living facilities and nursing homes? You might imagine quiet reading, crossword puzzles, bingo, maybe some shuffleboard. Think again. Think about sex — unsafe sex.

headline: Obama, Melville and the Tea Party
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: A Melville novella explains today’s racial politics.
lead_paragraph: IN 2009, shortly after Barack Obama’s successful campaign for the White House, the McNally Jackson bookstore in Manhattan organized a display of about 50 books that Mr. Obama had read as a young man. The titles were eclectic, with a good number by African-American authors, including Ralph Ellison, James Baldwin and Toni Morrison.

headline: South Sudan Recaptures Town From Rebels
abstract: The government said it had won a significant military victory by seizing the city of Bor in Jonglei State.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Amid signs that a cease-fire agreement could be close, the government of South Sudan said Saturday that it had won a significant military victory, recapturing the strategic town of Bor from rebel forces.

headline: You Can Tell Everybody This Is Your Song
abstract: Life is performed on a million tiny stages. The one-man show never quite ends.
lead_paragraph: FOR most of my 20s I played in the indie rock band Sleater-Kinney. We wrote songs, we recorded them, we toured. In my 30s, though, things changed. I started spending most of my time writing or working on the TV show “Portlandia.” I haven’t played many live shows in the past decade, but somehow I feel as if I’m still on tour — not just with my bandmates, but with everyone. So I thought I’d try writing a song again, so I’d have something to play.

headline: Is the Fifth Republic Burning?
abstract: The Hollande affair may mark the end of the Fifth Republic.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — FUTURE historians of France may well decide that the Fifth Republic died as it was born: in a traffic incident.

headline: Reaching the Top at Every Rung
abstract: Since taking over as coach of the Tampa Bay Lightning, Jon Cooper has led the team to its best first half in franchise history, securing 54 of a possible 84 points.
lead_paragraph: Jon Cooper has yet to coach a full season in the N.H.L., yet his Tampa Bay team is among the best turnaround stories in the league. The Lightning entered Friday in third place in the Eastern Conference after finishing last season 28th in the 30-team league.

headline: Madison’s Privacy Blind Spot
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Search and Seizure', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Corporations']
abstract: His brand of libertarianism is inadequate in an age of corporate surveillance.
lead_paragraph: IN his opinion last month regarding the constitutionality of the National Security Agency’s phone-data collection program, Judge Richard Leon wrote that “James Madison, who cautioned us to beware of ‘the abridgment of freedom of the people by gradual and silent encroachments by those in power,’ would be aghast.”

headline: Lean Times for the Lakers
abstract: The Lakers are on a pace to finish with a losing record for the seventh time since the franchise moved from Minneapolis after the 1959-60 season.
lead_paragraph: The two most decorated teams in N.B.A. history squared off Friday, but the game hardly brought back memories of Bill Russell facing Wilt Chamberlain or Larry Bird battling Magic Johnson.

headline: How I Stopped Procrastinating
abstract: It took a broken hip and no access to coffee or a morning newspaper.
lead_paragraph: I learned something about a year ago that I wish I’d learned much sooner. And it happened only after I woke up one morning and couldn’t walk. An X-ray revealed that my hip cartilage had made a unilateral decision to jump ship. I liked my hip cartilage. I thought we’d be together forever.

headline: A Monster of the Dunk Shows Finesse as a Playmaker
abstract: The Los Angeles Clippers are 5-2 since losing point guard Chris Paul, and Blake Griffin, a 6-foot-10 power forward, has assumed a big part of Paul’s playmaking duties.
lead_paragraph: After the Los Angeles Clippers’ 109-95 destruction of the Knicks on Friday night, a reporter was moving through the visiting locker room, asking each Clippers player for his favorite Blake Griffin dunk.

headline: What Happens When the Poor Receive a Stipend?
abstract: A study of what happened with a Native American tribe shows a big effect on children.
lead_paragraph: Growing up poor has long been associated with reduced educational attainment and lower lifetime earnings. Some evidence also suggests a higher risk of depression, substance abuse and other diseases in adulthood. Even for those who manage to overcome humble beginnings, early-life poverty may leave a lasting mark, accelerating aging and increasing the risk of degenerative disease in adulthood.

headline: Celtics Banking on Rondo, for Now
abstract: The Celtics’ Rajon Rondo returned to the lineup for the first time in a year against the Lakers on Friday.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — In the summer of 2007, Wyc Grousbeck, a co-owner of the Boston Celtics, went for a quiet, solitary walk along a beach on Cape Cod. He had his cellphone, and when it rang, he was ready for the call and even readier for his response.

headline: Bankability Can Desert Tainted Athletes
abstract: There was a time when Alex Rodriguez was an easy-to-market athlete, regionally and nationally.
lead_paragraph: In the 1990s, Alex Rodriguez starred in a commercial for Nike that looked like yet another creative campaign by the sports apparel giant. It was amusing and effective and reflected positively on Rodriguez.

headline: Iowa State’s Legacy of Fervor and Success Is Handed Down
abstract: The magic of the golden era of Cyclones basketball, when Johnny Orr was the men’s coach from 1980 to 1994, has returned to Ames, Iowa, with Fred Hoiberg.
lead_paragraph: AMES, Iowa — Forty-five minutes before Iowa State and Kansas tipped off last Monday, members of the Eby family, all in gold I.S.U. shirts, settled into their seats at Hilton Coliseum. Jeff Eby, who raises corn and soybeans on his 1,000-acre farm in Adel, about 40 miles southwest of here, has been coming to Cyclones men’s basketball games since he was a boy. For 2012-13, he eagerly bought season tickets.

headline: After Love Unravels in Media, Indian Politician’s Wife Is Found Dead
abstract: The death of Sunanda Pushkar stunned many in Delhi’s journalistic and political circles, many of whom had followed the twists in her life since she met Shashi Tharoor.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — He was a smooth-talking politician from South India with an international reputation from his time at the United Nations. She was a beautiful Kashmiri from the north when they met in 2009 in middle age and began a relationship partly played out in the media, and social media, glare.

headline: Eddie the Eagle Soars With His Feet Mostly on the Ground
abstract: Michael Edwards, better known as the Olympic ski jumper Eddie the Eagle, remains a synonym for fun-loving underdogs.
lead_paragraph: WOODCHESTER, England — It is perhaps a mild indictment of ski jumping that outside of a few countries in Europe and Asia, the two most famous jumpers are a Slovene who careened off a slope in the 1970s and a jolly Briton who finished last in the Calgary Olympic Games a quarter-century ago.

headline: Mayor of Hoboken Says Hurricane Relief Was Threatened
abstract: A swing through Florida was no escape for Gov. Chris Christie as protesters hounded him, a State House ally rebuked his office and a mayor accused his administration of intimidation.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — A swing through Florida proved no sunny retreat for Gov. Chris Christie on Saturday, as well-organized protesters hounded him outside a Republican fund-raiser here, a powerful ally in the New Jersey State House rebuked the governor’s office and new allegations emerged that his administration tried to intimidate a New Jersey elected official.

headline: Greek Prosecutors Focus on Corruption at the Top
abstract: Corruption cases are being pursued against a widening pool of current and former high-ranking government officials and members of the business gentry once deemed untouchable.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Since the country’s financial meltdown, Greeks have protested what many here consider the unfairness of the austerity measures that have raised taxes and trimmed salaries and benefits for average Greeks, while the elite escaped similar burdens or being held accountable for their part in creating the mess in the first place.

headline: Readers and Climate Change
abstract: The winner of my neglected topic contest, and a reminder to apply for the 2014 win a trip contest.
lead_paragraph: Thanks so much to all of you for responding to my request two weeks ago for “neglected topics” for me to weigh in on this year. There were 1,300 comments that came pouring in, many with multiple ideas, and I’m still thinking them through. Today’s column takes off on one of the suggestions that came up regularly: climate change. It’s not 100 percent neglected of course, but I think it’s vastly undercovered considering the scale of the issues. So read the column and share your thoughts below.

headline: Olden Goldies
abstract: Dan Schoenholz takes us back.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Hands up if you like spoonerisms. For those of you just joining us, a spoonerism is a word or phrase in which letters or syllables are swapped. That can happen with tips of the slung, sorry, slips of the tongue, and today Dan Schoenholz has spoonerized a set of seven oldies songs.

headline: Overwhelming Vote for Egypt’s Constitution Raises Concern
abstract: The voters approved a revised constitution validating last summer’s military takeover and paving the way for Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi, the country’s top military leader, to seek the presidency.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Secretary of State John Kerry on Saturday raised concerns about the fairness of a referendum on Egypt’s revised Constitution after the military-led government announced that it had passed with an extraordinary 98.1 percent of the vote.

headline: Chemical Spill Muddies Picture in a State Wary of Regulations
keywords: ['Water Pollution', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Coal', 'Law and Legislation', 'Mines and Mining', 'Water', 'Chemicals', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Energy and Power']
abstract: West Virginia, with its strong ties to coal and chemicals, has long had a fierce opposition to environmental regulations.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — Here in West Virginia, residents were still reeling from the chemical spill that left more than 300,000 people without usable water for days, many of them still frightened and unsure whether official assurances that they could once again drink tap water or bathe their children were true.

headline: Region Boiling, Israel Takes Up Castle Strategy
abstract: As Israel faces threats both from traditional Shiite adversaries like Iran and from extremist Sunni cells in Syria, Iraq and beyond, officials insist they have no inclination to intervene.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — After a Katyusha rocket fired from Lebanon landed in Israel last month, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu blamed Hezbollah, the Shiite militia, and its Iranian backers. But Israeli security officials attributed the attack, as well as a similar one in August, to a Sunni jihadist group linked to Al Qaeda.

headline: After Years at War, the Army Adapts to Garrison Life
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Army sent 1.3 million troops to war after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, creating the most combat-tested force in the nation’s history. But now it must sustain morale on its bases.
lead_paragraph: FORT DRUM, N.Y. — Spec. Perez Brown Jr. spent three years in the Army and two tours in Afghanistan, where on his 23rd birthday a homemade bomb blew up a vehicle in his convoy and he came close to driving over another one just down the road. “That second one might have been for me,” he said.

headline: ‘Bachelor’ Star’s Comments on Gays Spark Uproar
abstract: Juan Pablo Galavis, the current star of ABC’s long-running reality show, told a journalist he opposed putting a gay man at the center of the program.
lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — ABC faced a potential crisis on Saturday over one of its longest-running hits when a storm erupted here over homophobic comments made by the star of the reality series “The Bachelor.”

headline: De Blasio Picks Mark Peters, a Former Prosecutor, to Oversee Investigations
abstract: Bill de Blasio nominated Mark G. Peters, a respected former civil rights lawyer who worked as his campaign treasurer, for the top position at the city’s Department of Investigation.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Saturday that he had picked a respected former prosecutor and civil rights lawyer to fill the top position at the city’s Department of Investigation, an anticorruption agency that will soon take on an expanded role in overseeing the New York Police Department.

headline: Jamaican Bobsledders Seek Money for Sochi Trip
abstract: The team has qualified for the Olympics, but with little support from the Jamaica Olympic Association, it is trying to raise funds through donations.
lead_paragraph: With a little bit of perseverance, Jamaica’s Winston Watts has appeared to qualify as a bobsled pilot at next month’s Olympics. Without a little bit of money, though, the latest edition of the Jamaican bobsled team might not actually appear in the Sochi Games.

headline: Torn Between Higher Taxes and Border Hassles
abstract: A tax increase for Mexican towns near the United States border could mean an economic boost for South Texas, with Mexican shoppers bargain-hunting here, but there are concerns.
lead_paragraph: LAREDO —  Braving the unusually cold temperatures one recent afternoon, Aurelia Alcantar crossed the Puente de las Américas international bridge from Mexico into this South Texas town. She was going shopping, and crossing the border let her avoid a recent tax increase in her hometown, Nuevo Laredo, Tamaulipas.

headline: It’s Here: A Library With Nary a Book
abstract: The paperless office never happened (at least not yet), but the bookless library is now a reality in San Antonio, complete with e-readers that can be checked out along with the digital fiction and nonfiction.

headline: For Cubs Fans, Everlasting Hope With Dread to Match
abstract: At a convention in Chicago, fans had conflicting emotions about a losing team with one of the best farm systems in baseball.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A legion of die-hard Cubs fans converged here at a downtown hotel this weekend for the team’s annual fan convention. They were children and adults, wearing blue-and-red jerseys, hats and face paint, armed with baseball cards, pennants and posters to be autographed.

headline: Run for Speaker as a Marker for Republicans
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A state representative’s announcement that he will run for speaker of the House in 2015 may force candidates in primaries this year to declare their preferences.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for The Tribune.

headline: A Consultant Who Stumped for Cruz Makes a Bid for Congress
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, State Legislature']
abstract: Katrina Pierson, a media consultant who supported Ted Cruz in his successful bid for senator, is using her conservative ties to try to unseat a House incumbent.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, Katrina Pierson was crisscrossing Texas in her spare time to help Ted Cruz become the state’s next United States senator. At Republican club meetings, public rallies and on Twitter, she praised Mr. Cruz’s tenacity and commitment to repealing the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Determined to Miss Nothing, Russia Trains All Eyes on Sochi
keywords: ['Olympic Games (2014)', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: As the Winter Games approach, tens of thousands of personnel and surveillance cameras have been deployed to Sochi. Critics say the measures threaten to temper the Olympic spirit.
lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — This may now be the safest city in Russia.

headline: Strong Showing for U.S. at Youth Championships
abstract: Awonder Liang of Wisconsin won first place in the under-10 open division, and four other Americans either won medals or came close.
lead_paragraph: The vitality of the United States’ scholastic chess programs was on display last month at the World Youth Chess Championships in the United Arab Emirates, where 94 Americans took to the boards.

headline: The Surprise Wedding
abstract: When guests arrived at what they were told was Rebecca Garcia and Andrew Spiegel’s engagement party, they found the space decorated for a wedding.
lead_paragraph: When guests arrived at what they were told was Rebecca Garcia and Andrew Spiegel’s engagement party, they found the space decorated for a wedding.

headline: Remembering Amiri Baraka With Politics and Poetry
abstract: Thousands of people attended funeral services for Mr. Baraka, the poet and playwright who helped forge the Black Arts Movement of the 1960s and 1970s and who died Jan. 9.
lead_paragraph: Amiri Baraka’s funeral began with a wordless tribute on Saturday morning: A procession of African drums and jazz trumpets followed the writer’s coffin through Newark Symphony Hall.

headline: After Cancer, Tour Guide Plans Next Destination
abstract: Edicson Valderrama, who has traveled the world chaperoning fellow sojourners, fell behind on his bills when he was sidelined by cancer. He now hopes to start a school for aspiring guides.
lead_paragraph: Name a place, and Edicson Valderrama, international tour guide, will give you the story.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 18, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Building Faces Wrecking Ball. So Does Couples’ Friendship.
abstract: A long friendship between two couples, all four of whom are well-known architects, is under stress after one couple recommended tearing down a Manhattan museum designed by the other pair.
lead_paragraph: As in any fight between longtime friends, there are raw emotions, tarnished memories, tears.

headline: Ex-Official Claims to Speak for Sidelined Syrians
abstract: Jihad Makdissi, the former Foreign Ministry spokesman, has resurfaced, a rare high-profile dissenter seeking to position himself as a voice for many Syrians who remain on the sidelines.
lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — For years, Jihad Makdissi was the urbane, outward-looking face of the Syrian government, proclaiming its views in perfect English as the Foreign Ministry’s spokesman. Then, about a year ago, he resigned and fled here, withdrawing his support from President Bashar al-Assad without throwing it to the opposition, quietly waiting, he said, for his chance to be of use.

headline: In Syria, Former Official Says, ‘Nobody Is Winning’
abstract: Excerpts from an interview with Jihad Makdissi, a former Foreign Ministry spokesman in Syria who fled in 2012 as the government cracked down on protesters.
lead_paragraph: The following are excerpts from an interview with Jihad Makdissi, a former Foreign Ministry spokesman in Syria who fled in 2012 as the government of President Bashar al-Assad cracked down on antigovernment protesters. Mr. Makdissi, however, has not supported the rebels. He casts himself as a voice for the Syrians who remain on the sidelines, skeptical of the armed uprising but still wanting change.

headline: Arnold R. Pinkney Dies at 83; Steered 1984 Jesse Jackson Run
abstract: Mr. Pinkney, a strategist who ran the campaigns in landmark races for black politicians, also advised Hubert H. Humphrey in his second bid for the Democratic presidential nomination.
lead_paragraph: “There are always more slaves than slave masters,” the Rev. Jesse Jackson roared in a speech in Selma, Ala., early in his 1984 presidential campaign. “We can win! We got master’s degrees in disappointment and Ph.D.s in how to overcome!”

headline: Chryssa, Artist Who Saw Neon’s Potential as a Medium, Dies at 79
abstract: Chryssa, a Greek-born sculptor, began incorporating neon into her constructions in America in the 1960s, in time mastering the technical difficulties of the medium.
lead_paragraph: Chryssa, a Greek-born American sculptor who in the 1960s was one of the first people to transform neon lighting from an advertising vehicle into a fine art medium, died on Dec. 23. She was 79.

headline: Roy Campbell Jr., Avant-Garde Jazz Trumpeter, Dies at 61
abstract: Mr. Campbell combined a pugnacious, hard-bop sound with an open-minded approach, working with a variety of free jazz musicians and becoming a fixture at avant-garde events like the Vision Festival.
lead_paragraph: Roy Campbell Jr., who carried the soulful swagger of hard-bop trumpet into the jazz avant-garde, of which he became a pillar, died on Jan. 9 at his home in the Bronx. He was 61.

headline: Corrections: January 19, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on January 19, 2014.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL

headline: ‘American Hustle’ Wins SAG Award for Top Film
abstract: The Screen Actors Guild spread the honors around, also giving trophies to actors from “Blue Jasmine,” “Dallas Buyers Club” and “12 Years a Slave.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “American Hustle,” the 1970s caper comedy from the director David O. Russell, took the top prize, for best ensemble, at the Screen Actors Guild Awards here Saturday.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, January 19, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Sunday, January 19, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “It may be better to wait and see, but waiting doesn’t make you money. It’s ‘Let me do a little snip of tissue’ and then they get professional, lab and facility fees. Each patient is like an ATM machine.”

headline: Caitlin Homberger, Nicholas Green
abstract: The bride is a doctor; the groom is a lawyer.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Caitlin Healy Homberger and Nicholas Glenn Green were married Saturday at McCrady’s, a restaurant in Charleston, S.C. Judge David C. Norton of the United States District Court in Charleston, for whom the groom was a law clerk, officiated.

headline: Alicia Susser, Adam Epstein
abstract: The bride works in education; the groom is a lawyer.
lead_paragraph: Alicia Caryn Susser, a daughter of Andrea Susser and Allen Susser of Wayne, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Adam Mark Epstein, the son of Carol Epstein and Gary Epstein of Henderson, Nev. Rabbi Stephen Wylen officiated at the Tribeca Rooftop, an event space in Manhattan.

abstract: The couple met at Cornell, where they received law degrees.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Elizabeth Yetter, the daughter of Connie F. Glang of Riverside, Calif., and Gary A. Yetter of Moreno Valley, Calif., was married Saturday to Jeremy Waters Cline, a son of C. Rebecca Cline and Gary W. Cline of New Haven. The Rev. Maria LaSala, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Dwight Hall Chapel at Yale University in New Haven.

headline: A Thousand Violins Fill the Air
abstract: A viola and a violin, the perfect duet.
lead_paragraph: Janet Yichieh Lee and James Hong Shin are to be married Sunday at the Parker, a hotel in Palm Springs, Calif. Eliot Davidoff, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, is to officiate.

headline: Daira Avila and Charbel Barakat
abstract: The bride is a dentist; the groom is an associate regional counsel for a homebuilder.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Daira Maria Avila and Charbel J. Barakat were married by the Rev. Elie Saade on Saturday at the St. Jude Melkite Catholic Church in Miami, with Msgr. Pablo Navarro taking part.

headline: Jacqueline Kelly and Nicholas Moscow
abstract: The couple met at Columbia, from which each received a law degree.
lead_paragraph: Jacqueline Christine Kelly, a daughter of Linda Kelly and Stephen C. Kelly of New Windsor, N.Y., is to be married Sunday to Nicholas John Moscow, a son of Melinda L. Moscow and John W. Moscow of New York. The Rev. William Scafidi, a Roman Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Newburgh, N.Y.

headline: Nicole Blank and Brian Koles
abstract: The bride is a clinical psychologist; the groom is the head of business development at a technology company.
lead_paragraph: Nicole Blank, a daughter of Bonnie K. Blank and Mark B. Blank, both of Miami, was married Saturday evening to Brian Wayne Koles, the son of Judy F. Koles of Melville, N.Y., and Martin N. Koles of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Edwin Goldberg performed the ceremony at the Bath Club, an event space in Miami Beach.

headline: Sari Abraham and Matthew Imberman
abstract: The bride is studying for a degree in nutrition; the groom works for a hedge fund.
lead_paragraph: Sari Lisa Abraham, the daughter of Lynn Abraham and Seth G. Abraham of Manhattan, was married Saturday evening to Matthew Todd Imberman, a son of Susan Imberman and Dr. Steven Imberman of Manalapan, N.J. Rabbi Daniel Alder officiated at Gotham Hall, a Manhattan event space.

headline: Amanda Echalaz and Robert Meya
abstract: The bride is an operatic soprano, and the groom oversees fund-raising for the Santa Fe Opera.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Echalaz and Robert Kruedener Meya were married Saturday evening at the New Leaf Restaurant in Fort Tryon Park in Manhattan. Sabrina R. Martin, a friend of the couple who was ordained by the American Marriage Ministries for the occasion, officiated at a ceremony that was led by Francis J. Foley III, a senior judge on the Windham District Superior Court in Willimantic, Conn.

headline: Serena Williams Tumbles in Australian Open’s Fourth Round
abstract: In the biggest upset so far at the tournament, Ana Ivanovic defeated Serena Williams for the first time as Williams suffered from back pain and a flurry of errors.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — For almost a year, Serena Williams won professional tennis matches at an improbable 96 percent clip. Since her exit from the 2013 Australian Open, she had played 80 matches and had won 77 of them.

headline: Deadly Bomb Blast Rocks Pakistan Military Compound
abstract: Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan, an umbrella group for militants, has taken responsibility for a bomb planted inside a vehicle that killed at least 20 people.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — A bomb exploded inside a vehicle at a Pakistani military compound in the country’s northwest on Sunday, killing at least 20 members of a paramilitary unit and wounding 30 more, a security official said.

headline: What’s On Today?
abstract: Television highlights
lead_paragraph: 1:30 P.M. (Showtime2) AMÉLIE (2001) Audrey Tautou, above, in her breakthrough role, plays a French sprite working as a waitress who lays out elaborate practical jokes as payback for those who offend her friends. When she falls in love with Nino (Mathieu Kassovitz), Amélie finds herself incapable of revealing her feelings and instead turns Paris, recreated through sets and computer-generated imagery, into a kind of treasure hunt as she leaves clues about her identity, and he trails after her. Writing in The New York Times, Elvis Mitchell called this comedy from Jean-Pierre Jeunet, whose original title was “Le Fabuleux Destin d’Amélie Poulain,” “a sugar-rush of a movie.” It has, he said, “a hypnotic sense of romance; it’s a fable filled with longing, with a heroine who constantly flirts with failure.” The film’s “fastidious complex of flesh and fantasy is a dazzling achievement,” he added. There is no denying, he said “that ‘Amélie’ is, to paraphrase its title, fabulous.”

keywords: ['ARCHITECTURE', 'Hunting and Trapping', 'Travel and Vacations', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)']

headline: Europe’s Dominance Faces a Challenge in a FIFA Bid
abstract: Jérôme Champagne, a former official of FIFA, the sport’s governing body, plans to challenge Sepp Blatter, the longtime president.
lead_paragraph: ZURICH — Jérôme Champagne has spent most of his career in soccer behind the scenes, quietly operating in the shadows with little fanfare or credit. But on Monday, Champagne, a Frenchman who once served as FIFA’s deputy general secretary, is set to become front-page news in Switzerland and beyond.

headline: Lanvin: Fall 2014 Menswear
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: At Kenzo, a Techno Take on Sportswear
abstract: Carol Lim and Humberto Leon photographed their designs and then played with them digitally.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Designing men’s wear with techno-conscious eyes produces regular clothes with a digital spin, and can even bring subtle changes to apparently simple sportswear.

headline: When Elite Parents Dominate Volunteers, Children Lose
abstract: I grew up poor, and I’ve tried to speak up for the students in my daughter’s schools who don’t eat sushi and can’t afford cheerleading. Mostly, I’ve failed.
lead_paragraph: One long-ago day my mother took cupcakes to school wearing a pale yellow coat — not warm enough for the winter day, but she wanted to look nice. A classmate admired her. I was a little proud. I hoped to impress this classmate, or anyone. My dad was an alcoholic. A friend with a similar childhood calls it “impoverished.” I lacked currency: cash or social sway.

headline: Punk Hangs In There
abstract: After 40 years, the rebellion still inspires designers like Junya Watanabe.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — How can a 40-year-old rebellion, triggered by young men now well into their 60s, keep hanging in there for male fashion?

headline: Bangkok Protests Hit by Two Explosions
abstract: More than two dozen people were injured in the blasts that hit an antigovernment demonstration in Bangkok, a further escalation of violence in Thailand’s political crisis.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — More than two dozen people were injured in twin explosions at an antigovernment demonstration in Bangkok on Sunday, a further escalation of violence in Thailand’s protracted political crisis.

headline: UI, the NAIRU, and the ZLB
abstract: Depression economics: still different.
lead_paragraph: I see from Mark Thoma that Chris Dillow is doing battle with the usual idiots suspects, who are once again accusing me of hypocrisy or something for saying that increased unemployment benefits would, under current conditions, reduce unemployment. “But your textbook says that UI raises unemployment!”

headline: The Pope and Chris Christie
abstract: The man from Home Depot weighs in.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, when you read a news report, you remember connections that, while not invalidating the reporting at all, nonethless shed a different light on some aspects of the story. So it was with today’s Times report on the internal recommendations Chris Christie has been getting within the GOP. Quoted at some length was a guy named Ken Langone:

headline: Familiar Rivals Meet Again, With the Same Result
abstract: When Kevin Anderson faced Tomas Berdych in their fourth-round match Sunday at the Australian Open, it was their 10th meeting since the same tournament in 2012, and once again, Berdych walked away triumphant.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — For Kevin Anderson, running into an old familiar face just doesn’t have the same appeal it once did.

headline: Sumptuous and Ubiquitous: Berluti and Will Smith
abstract: Will Smith is seen at various Paris men’s fashion shows.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — As I settled into my seat a few minutes before the start of Berluti’s fall men’s show here Friday night, another reporter asked me if I had just arrived that day.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Sundance: A Gay-Wedding Reception While the Litigation Continues
abstract: The Sundance Film Festival celebrates gay unions — via a documentary — in Utah, where they were effectively halted by a Supreme Court stay.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — Same-sex marriage, or at least a big celebration of it, came sweeping back to this state over the weekend courtesy of Hollywood occupiers.

headline: Disruptions: Looking for Relief From a Flood of Email
abstract: Email is probably one of the most invasive forms of communication yet devised. For those who can’t seem to handle the onslaught, there is always the extreme option: select all, hit delete and declare email bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 31, I had 46,315 unread emails in my inbox. On my first day back to work in the new year, I had zero.

keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']

Mann, the Penn State climate scientist who, after years of attacks from groups fighting restrictions on greenhouse gases, has become a prominent climate and political campaigner, as well.

headline: Two Are Wounded After Israel Orders Airstrike in Gaza
abstract: A Palestinian man and a boy were hurt after the Israeli military targeted an Islamic Jihad operative it said had been responsible for recent rocket fire in southern Israel.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli military said it carried out an airstrike in Gaza on Sunday aimed at eliminating an Islamic Jihad operative responsible for recent rocket fire against southern Israel, part of a growing cycle of border clashes in recent weeks that reflect the fragility of the 14-month cease-fire between Israel and the Palestinian coastal enclave.

headline: 1914: A Map of Tango
abstract: 100 years ago, The New York Herald shared with its readers a map of Tango from the French press.
lead_paragraph: “This is the map of the kingdom of king Tango. The white parts indicate countries it has subjected to his law. The black parts show those who do not recognize his sovereignty yet. We have, otherwise, marked with a black spot the French cities where bishops have forbidden the faithful to dance tango in their diocese.” — The New York Herald, Paris Edition, Jan. 20, 1914 (From Le Matin)

headline: Lanvin: The Sum of All Looks
abstract: At their Paris Fashion Week show on Sunday, Alber Elbaz and Lucas Ossendrijver produced tailored suits, slim trousers and silhouette prints that could not be forgotten.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — How rare it is to find a show that has everything: slim tailoring, high tech fabrics, colorful accessories, arty drawings, covetable sneakers — and an overall look that sums up men’s wear today.

headline: At Umit Benan, an Homage to Jackie Robinson
abstract: As the models came out in a murky darkness, their faces were covered by baseball mitts and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s “I Have a Dream” speech played on the sound system.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Walking into the Turkish designer Umit Benan’s show here, his first in Paris after several seasons in Milan, you noticed that the set resembled a soccer pitch in slight disrepair, an effect accentuated by the chain link fence separating the audience from the runway, parts of it torn away, as if by age or neglect.

headline: Men’s Paris Fashion Week: Officine Generale Fall/Winter 2014

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

headline: Four Traffic Fatalities in Two Days As Mayor Vows to Make Streets Safer
abstract: Four people were struck and killed in crashes over the weekend, coinciding with Mayor Bill de Blasio’s call on Friday to end the “epidemic” of traffic violence in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A large highway sign flashed orange warnings to pedestrians. Patrol officers in neon vests directed traffic; others gave tickets to drivers and nearly a dozen jaywalkers. And at each corner of West 96th Street and Broadway on the Upper West Side of Manhattan on Sunday, residents warned one another to use caution: The traffic here can be deadly.

headline: A Fast Start for ‘Ride Along’ at the Box Office
abstract: “Ride Along,” featuring Ice Cube and Kevin Hart, continues a winning streak at the box office for movies with predominantly black casts.
lead_paragraph: The action comedy “Ride Along” burned rubber at North American theaters, taking in a projected $47.8 million for the four-day Martin Luther King Jr. holiday and leaving another new film, “Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit,” choking on its fumes. “Ride Along” (Universal Pictures), featuring Ice Cube and the increasingly popular Kevin Hart, cost about $25 million to make and continues a winning streak at the box office for movies with predominantly black casts. About 50 percent of opening-weekend ticket buyers were black, with Hispanic moviegoers making up 30 percent, according to Universal.

headline: Chris Chataway, British Runner and Politician, Dies at 82
abstract: Chataway helped Roger Bannister, a fellow Oxford graduate, achieve the first sub-four-minute mile in 1954, and he later became a member of Parliament and a Cabinet minister.
lead_paragraph: Chris Chataway, a British runner who helped Roger Bannister achieve the first sub-four-minute mile, then broke world records himself before becoming a member of Parliament and a cabinet minister, died on Sunday in London. He was 82.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Olympics Security Worries U.S. Officials
abstract: Several congressional leaders said Russia was not sharing information about potential terrorist threats to the Games to be held in Sochi next month.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Tensions rose Sunday over security preparations ahead of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, as several congressional leaders expressed concern about Russia’s willingness to share information about terrorist threats, while President Vladimir V. Putin asserted that he would “do whatever it takes” to protect the thousands of visitors arriving soon for the Games.

headline: A Tiny Antenna Threatens the TV Networks’ Airspace
abstract: Chet Kanojia’s company, Aereo, has figured out how to grab over-the-air television signals and stream them to subscribers on the Internet. It is an invention that could topple TV titans.
lead_paragraph: When the case of American Broadcasting Companies v. Aereo comes before the Supreme Court in April, it will feature two American archetypes in a battle that could upend the television industry.

headline: Derp Pirate Roberts
abstract: And now, homicidal libertarians.
lead_paragraph: We finally saw American Hustle last night; it was a lot of fun, although heavy-handed in parts (I would have lost the microwave scene). But if this story on the arrest of the man accused of being Dread Pirate Roberts is any indication, being in the FBI these days is a lot more fun (unless you’re really into Amy Adams’s cleavage, which I can understand) than it was in the Abscam days.

headline: In Ukraine Protests Over New Laws, Sticks and Stones Are Met With Tear Gas
abstract: In the worst violence in at least a month for the continuing protest movement in Ukraine, men in masks clashed with the police over new laws cracking down on public assembly.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A large rally in Kiev, Ukraine, that was called in part to protest a new set of laws cracking down on public protests turned violent on Sunday when men in balaclavas attacked the police with sticks and threw firecrackers and cobblestones at them.

headline: Congressional Leaders Suggest Earlier Snowden Link to Russia
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']

Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor, might have been working for Russian spy services while he was employed at an agency facility in Hawaii last year and before he disclosed hundreds of thousands of classified government documents.

headline: A Real-Life Mother and Son Share Memories and Grief
abstract: “Have I No Mouth,” part of P.S. 122’s Coil Festival, puts a mother, a son and their psychotherapist on stage in an exploration of loss.
lead_paragraph: Feidlim Cannon got drunk over dinner the night he asked his mother, Ann, to make a theater piece with him. He needed the courage, he says.

headline: Seahawks Fans Act as Extra Player, Tormenting Opponents and Eardrums
abstract: Seattle’s so-called 12th Man creates the loudest setting in the N.F.L., and the crowd lived up to its reputation again on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Is the 12th Man a man or a myth? Fans in this football-mad city talk about “him” like a trusted uncle or a fabled warrior. Flags flap in his honor. Placards with his telltale number are plastered in shop windows like totems.

abstract: See a selection of programs in the spending bill (and a couple of others), expressed in cost per U.S. resident.
lead_paragraph: See a selection of programs in the spending bill (and a couple of others), expressed in cost per U.S. resident.

headline: Central African Town Is Left Charred, Empty and Hopeless Amid Violence
abstract: The buildings in Bossangoa are charred and abandoned, with most of the population of 50,000 now in refugee camps, one for Muslims and another for Christians.
lead_paragraph: BOSSANGOA, Central African Republic — The rutted roads through this regional capital are strangely empty.

headline: Iran Welcomes Start of Nuclear Deal
abstract: Iranian leaders said they were encouraged not only by the prospect of economic relief with the lifting of some sanctions, but also by a possible end to the country’s political isolation.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iranian officials said they expected positive economic changes with the lifting of some sanctions against the country as part of a deal struck with world powers, which begins on Monday.

headline: Back in China, Watching My Words
abstract: A writer returns to China after spending years in the United States, to find herself in tricky conversations with Chinese relatives and friends.
lead_paragraph: Helen Gao writes an occasional column on overseas education for cn.nytimes.com, the Chinese-language website of The New York Times. This piece is adapted from a column published shortly after the Lunar New Year in 2013.

headline: NBC Plans Live ‘Peter Pan’ for Next Holiday Season
abstract: The chairman of NBC Entertainment also gave a guest list for the final “Tonight” show with Jay Leno as host.
lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — NBC will go back into its past for its next attempt at live musical theater on television, bringing back the classic “Peter Pan” for a holiday season viewing next Dec. 4.

headline: Protests in Kiev Turn Violent
abstract: Protesters attacked the police with sticks and threw firecrackers at them, while the officers responded with tear gas during a rally in Kiev, Ukraine, on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Protesters attacked the police with sticks and threw firecrackers at them, while the officers responded with tear gas during a rally in Kiev, Ukraine, on Sunday.

headline: Poor Mummy, Tossed Around and Then Stashed in a Closet
abstract: Lunacy is presented with a poker face in a revival of “Loot,” Joe Orton’s farce directed by Jesse Berger at the Lucille Lortel.
lead_paragraph: The comic payoffs arrive only sporadically in the new production of Joe Orton’s “Loot” at the Lucille Lortel Theater. Those deliciously perverse epigrams whiz through the air, and the corpse of a beloved wife is frantically hauled about a parlor like a medicine ball being flung around at a gym. But the deadpan style that best serves these antics often slips into a kind of winking archness that announces an awareness of the inspired lunacy of it all. The production, directed by Jesse Berger for the Red Bull Theater, hits its marks with an air of studied effort that tends to put the brakes on the mayhem.

headline: Gold and Survival, Yes, but Scripts and Stars, Too
abstract: Discovery Channel returns to a familiar well with “Klondike,” which follows two men as they head from the East Coast to the Yukon Territory as part of the Klondike gold rush of the 1890s.
lead_paragraph: Scan the “our shows” section of Discovery Channel’s website, and it becomes clear that someone in the executive department is obsessed with cold weather, survival and gold. “Frozen Planet,” “Yukon Men,” “Alaska: The Last Frontier,” “Gold Rush,” “Bering Sea Gold” and more are there.

headline: A Little Help From a Friend of Buttercup
abstract: Ringo Starr is part of “Dance Pantsed,” a new animated special featuring the Powerpuff Girls on the Cartoon Network.
lead_paragraph: Very soon now, the airwaves will be jammed with remembrances of the Beatles’ first appearance on “The Ed Sullivan Show,” because there’s nothing the baby-boom generation likes better than commemorating 50th anniversaries. If you stare hard enough at the clips of those screaming young female fans from February 1964, you can see an unspoken question in their eyes: “Will one of these guys, in 2014, be singing a song aimed at my grandchildren or even my great-grandchildren about dressing up as a superpower-endowed little girl?”

headline: Tunefully Purveyed Snake Oil, Anyone?
abstract: The soprano Anna Netrebko, absent from the first two performances of “L’Elisir d’Amore” at the Met, arrived to inhabit the leading role fully on Friday.
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 7, two days before the Metropolitan Opera’s revival of Bartlett Sher’s 2012 production of Donizetti’s “L’Elisir d’Amore” was scheduled to open, the company announced that the soprano Anna Netrebko had the flu and would not perform the role of Adina. Curiously, the announcement specified that Ms. Netrebko, probably the most celebrated soprano in opera right now, would miss the first two performances but planned to return for the third. Singers grappling with an illness usually cannot anticipate how long their incapacity will last.

headline: Tipping a Hat to Country Music Pioneers
abstract: The guitarist Bill Frisell was joined by Buddy Miller and Carrie Rodriguez in playing songs from a historic 1927 recording session in Tennessee.
lead_paragraph: If there were an appropriate emoji ideogram for the Bristol Sessions, the 1927 recordings that helped start the framing of what we now know as country music, it wouldn’t be a cartoon face conveying anger, sadness or gratitude — nothing that simple. It might be one of the lesser-known ones: the image of Japanese-carp wind socks on a flagpole, the flags flown on Children’s Day in Japan representing high hopes to navigate the currents of an uncertain life and grow up with health and courage.

headline: Repertory of Mandolin Is in Motion
abstract: The mandolinist Avi Avital was joined by the Enso String Quartet and others in Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Pianists can spend a lifetime learning a vast established repertory, but a greater degree of creativity is essential for double bassists, trumpeters or mandolinists hoping for careers in the spotlight.

headline: Where Guitars Sound Like Orchestras or Brawling Geese
abstract: Fred Frith and Nels Cline, virtuosos with conventional guitar techniques, performed their first public duet at the Alternative Guitar Summit at Subculture.
lead_paragraph: When the guitarists Fred Frith and Nels Cline played their first public duet on Saturday night at Subculture, it didn’t always sound like guitar music. It sounded, at times, like a sanitation truck’s trash compactor, like an orchestra tuning up, like a brawl between flocks of geese, like a creaky water pump, like a collapsing carillon and like a slowed-down train wreck.

headline: Bulgarian Architects’ State-Sponsored Whimsy
abstract: An architect who studied abroad came home to Bulgaria, where he joined with others to enliven the city of Sofia with whimsical, low-cost public art projects.
lead_paragraph: SOFIA, Bulgaria — Delcho Delchev came back.

headline: Leaping and Twirling, but Emphasizing Much More
abstract: Parsons Dance is celebrating its 30th anniversary with works by its director and others with ties to the company.
lead_paragraph: If dance is a form of wordless communication, what are the members of Parsons Dance trying to tell us? That they’re happy to be onstage? That they feel really good? That they think they look great and hope we agree?

headline: A Comic’s Fifth Second Chance
abstract: The comedian Katt Williams’s past includes arrests, a lien from the I.R.S. and physical altercations. But he is determined to complete his current tour.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Deep into a raucous comedy set at Symphony Hall here on Friday night, Katt Williams briefly halted his mockery of the Boston Marathon bombers, the Roman Catholic Church and racially inclusive cereal commercials for a moment of sincerity.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Jan. 20
abstract: The World Economic Forum will take place in Davos, Switzerland; the European Commission will publish its proposals on climate change policy; and Microsoft will release its earnings.
lead_paragraph: GATHERING IN DAVOS The World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, will begin with a ceremony on Tuesday evening. World leaders scheduled to attend the forum include Shinzo Abe, prime minister of Japan; David Cameron, prime minister of Britain; Benjamin Netanyahu, prime minister of Israel; and Hassan Rouhani, president of Iran. The United States will be represented by Jacob J. Lew, the Treasury secretary; Penny Pritzker, secretary of commerce; and Gina McCarthy, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, who will discuss President Obama’s climate action plan. This year’s celebrity in residence is Matt Damon, who will receive an award for his charitable work. Some of the speeches and panels will be posted on the forum’s website, weforum.org.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Jan. 20
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes the regular weekly auction on Tuesday of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

headline: Hearing Genuine Voices of Midcentury Fiction
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Audio Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: A half-century ago, Calliope Records issued recordings by John Updike, Philip Roth and others. Those readings have been reissued, allowing listeners to time-travel back to a ripe moment in American fiction.
lead_paragraph: Just over half a century ago, Harry Schwartz, a city planner, and his wife, Lynne Sharon Schwartz, an editor at The Writer magazine, were sitting in their Boston apartment with friends and talking about American fiction.

headline: He’s Hard as Nails, Hard to Nail Down, Too
abstract: “The Loudest Voice in the Room” is Gabriel Sherman’s biography of Roger Ailes, the president of Fox News.
lead_paragraph: Tucked away at the end of Gabriel Sherman’s disingenuous Roger Ailes biography, there is a note on sources that should have opened the book. Mr. Sherman has done a lot of interviewing, but there are so many citations of “author interview with a person familiar with the matter” that “The Loudest Voice in the Room” may set a record for blind items and the untrustworthiness they engender. It would have helped to know right from the get-go why Mr. Sherman found this kind of journalism necessary.

headline: Thai Democracy in a Nutshell
abstract: Ultimately, the Thai military will determine the winner.
lead_paragraph: Ultimately, the Thai military will determine the winner.

headline: Saint Laurent: Fall 2014 Menswear
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Paramount Takes Step With Digital Film
abstract: Paramount Pictures became the first major Hollywood studio to stop delivering movies on 35-millimeter film in the United States, offering them only in digital format, The Los Angeles Times reported.
lead_paragraph: Paramount Pictures became the first major Hollywood studio to stop delivering movies on 35-millimeter film in the United States, offering them only in digital format, The Los Angeles Times reported. The change reflects a shift toward use of digital projection. Only about 8 percent of about 40,045 United States theaters screens are equipped to show movies only in a film format, according to the National Association of Theater Owners, The Los Angeles Times said. Statistics compiled by the Motion Picture Association of America showed that the number of nondigital screens in the United States dropped to 6,387 by the end of 2012, from 33,319 in 2008. The last Paramount picture delivered to some theater owners in a film format was “Anchorman 2: The Legend Continues,” The Times reported. Many of the remaining film-only screens are in small towns, where owners have been hard pressed to afford a conversion.

headline: Finals for U.S. World Youth Teams
abstract: At the junior trials at the beginning of this month, in the under-21 open division, Oren Kriegel, Christopher Huber, Benjamin Kristensen and Kevin Rosenberg won the first final to become USA-1 in the World Youth Teams Championships.

headline: Moral Support Is Family Tradition for Seahawks’ Wilson
abstract: The Seahawks quarterback has not lacked for encouragement since his father died four years ago, particularly from his uncle.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Benjamin Wilson arrived in Seattle near midnight Saturday.

headline: Repeated Phrase
abstract: Elizabeth C. Gorski helps us celebrate some special words.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Every year, on the third Monday in January, we as a nation pause — hopefully — to remember a fallen leader who died as a result of his quest for peace and equality, not as a result of being a warmonger. I can’t think of a better reason for a holiday.

headline: N.F.L. Conference Championship Sunday
abstract: The Broncos defeated the Patriots for the A.F.C. title, while the Seahawks got past the 49ers in the N.F.C.game.
lead_paragraph: The Broncos defeated the Patriots for the A.F.C. title, while the Seahawks got past the 49ers in the N.F.C.game.

headline: Michael Kinsley to Join Vanity Fair and Write a Monthly Column
abstract: Mr. Kinsley will write a monthly column for Vanity Fair, which is likely to cover “what I’ve written about most of the time: politics, in one form or another,” he said.
lead_paragraph: Michael Kinsley will join Vanity Fair as a contributing editor, stepping down as editor at large of The New Republic, and leaving its masthead for the first time since 1976.

headline: Manning Reclaims the Biggest Stage
abstract: Peyton Manning, at 37, passed for 400 yards in the A.F.C. championship game and will play in the N.F.L.’s finale for the first time in four years.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — The family reunion was at Peyton Manning’s corner locker. It might have otherwise looked like an afternoon barbecue with a father, Archie Manning, and his three sons, Cooper, Peyton and Eli, smiling and talking football.

headline: Fifty States of Fear
abstract: Is our government trying to minimize our worries about terrorism, or manipulating them to consolidate its power?
lead_paragraph: The British philosopher Bertrand Russell, writing as World War II was drawing to a close in Europe, observed that “neither a man nor a crowd nor a nation can be trusted to act humanely or to think sanely under the influence of a great fear.” Russell’s point was that irrational fear can propel us into counterproductive activities, ranging from unjust wars and the inhumane treatment of others to more mundane cases like our failure to seize opportunities to improve our everyday lives.

headline: MoMA’s Plan to Raze Its Neighbor
abstract: Readers react to news that the Museum of Modern Art will not reverse its decision to demolish a former folk art museum.

keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Men and Boys', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment']
abstract: Readers respond to a Sunday Review essay by Stephanie Coontz.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
