headline: In a City on Okinawa, Mayor’s Re-election Deals a Blow to Marine Base Relocation Plan
keywords: ['Military Bases and Installations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Voters in an Okinawan city re-elected a mayor who promised to block construction of a replacement site for the United States base.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Efforts to relocate a Marine air base that has been a longstanding irritant in ties between Japan and the United States suffered a new setback on Sunday when voters in a small Okinawan city re-elected a leftist mayor who promised to block construction of a replacement site.

headline: China’s Web Junkies
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Addiction (Psychology)', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: A short documentary about a Chinese boot-camp-style treatment center for young men “addicted” to the Internet.
lead_paragraph: A short documentary about a Chinese boot-camp-style treatment center for young men “addicted” to the Internet.

headline: Reviving a Life Saver, the Tourniquet
abstract: Law enforcement agencies across the country have placed a new emphasis on training and equipping officers to treat serious wounds by reviving the use of tourniquets.
lead_paragraph: As far back as Alexander the Great’s campaigns, tourniquets were wartime staples, used to stanch the bleeding of wounded soldiers. But they became a last resort for both military and civilian emergency personnel after World War II, when medical experts blamed the prolonged cutoff of blood for frequent amputations.

headline: ‘China’s Web Junkies’
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Addiction (Psychology)', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: A short documentary about a Chinese boot-camp-style treatment center for young men “addicted” to the Internet.
lead_paragraph: Compulsive Internet use has been categorized as a mental health issue in many countries, including the United States, but China was among the first to label “Internet addiction” a clinical disorder.

headline: Brazil’s Latest Clash With Its Urban Youth Takes Place at the Mall
keywords: ['Racial Profiling', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Shopping Centers and Malls', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Authorities are struggling to decide how to handle rolezinhos — rowdy gatherings of young people at shopping malls — as questions abound about the racial, social and class implications.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The images have already been so jolting to Brazil’s elites that President Dilma Rousseff has convened a meeting of top aides to form a response and business owners have obtained injunctions to shut them down: thousands of teenagers, largely from the gritty urban periphery and organizing on social media, going on raucous excursions through shopping malls.

headline: Confident Nets Spoiling for Rematch With Knicks
abstract: Heading into Monday’s game at Madison Square Garden, the Nets have gone 11-8 since an ugly 113-83 loss to the visiting Knicks on Dec. 5.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Their rivalry is still just budding, but the Nets are hoping to use an embarrassing loss to the Knicks last month as fuel when the teams meet for the second time this season, Monday at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Proposed Abortion Restrictions in Spain Face Backlash
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The proposal would allow the termination of a pregnancy only if it was the result of rape or if having the baby would endanger the mother’s health.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy’s proposal to enact some of the toughest abortion restrictions in Europe has exposed his already unpopular government to a building political backlash and criticism from the European Parliament, while reinvigorating his Socialist opponents and opening divisions in his own conservative Popular Party.

headline: Hasbro Gives Its Transformers Toys a New Look
abstract: The maker of the line of toy robots, which have spawned $3 billion in movie revenue, has streamlined both the figures and their marketing.
lead_paragraph: When Hasbro conceived its Transformers toy line 30 years ago, the concept was simple: robots that turned into vehicles faster than you could say “more than meets the eye.”

headline: Life as a Female Journalist: Hot or Not?
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Writing and Writers', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Discrimination', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Men are also attacked, but their bodies aren’t the target.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — IN 2009, I wrote a cover story for Wired magazine about the anti-vaccine movement and profiled Paul Offit, a leading proponent of vaccines for children. Dr. Offit is a man. I am a woman. That was sufficient grounds for things to get ugly.

headline: Many Choices for Tanaka With Deadline Approaching
abstract: Although there is a feeling that the Yankees will make the highest bid among the many teams pursuing the Japanese pitcher Masahiro Tanaka, he does not have to take the most lucrative offer.
lead_paragraph: Masahiro Tanaka’s baseball fate will be decided by Friday afternoon, and it appears that more than a half-dozen teams have made bids for him or are prepared to. The Yankees, the Los Angeles Dodgers, the Arizona Diamondbacks, the Chicago White Sox and the Chicago Cubs are said to be among the teams in hot pursuit of Tanaka, a Japanese right-handed pitcher.

headline: Fixing Disability Courts
abstract: In my courtroom, it is far too easy for claimants to cheat.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — IT’S hard to imagine a more cynical fraud. According to an indictment unsealed last week by the Manhattan district attorney’s office, post-9/11 phobias of airplanes and skyscrapers were among the fictitious ailments described by retired New York City police officers and firefighters who, in a scheme involving as many as 1,000 people, are accused of ripping off the Social Security disability system by filing false claims.

headline: Trying to Salvage Garbage Time
abstract: The Knicks are no strangers to the waste of minutes at the end of blowouts — unfortunately for them, they are the ones being trashed.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — When the Knicks played the Nets on Dec. 5 at Barclays Center, the game presented the rare opportunity for Carmelo Anthony to watch the final minutes of a blowout win from the bench. He enjoyed the experience.

headline: The ‘How Are You?’ Culture Clash
abstract: Americans are “fine.” Ask a Russian, and you’ll get much more: the truth.
lead_paragraph: “WHEN an American asks me this question, it’s like a wall of ice crashing down between us.”

headline: The Undeserving Rich
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Why you can’t lump the plutocrats in with the upper middle class.
lead_paragraph: The reality of rising American inequality is stark. Since the late 1970s real wages for the bottom half of the work force have stagnated or fallen, while the incomes of the top 1 percent have nearly quadrupled (and the incomes of the top 0.1 percent have risen even more). While we can and should have a serious debate about what to do about this situation, the simple fact — American capitalism as currently constituted is undermining the foundations of middle-class society — shouldn’t be up for argument.

headline: Crowded Out of Ivory Tower, Adjuncts See a Life Less Lofty
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Part-Time Employment', 'Tenure', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: The position of adjunct faculty member, though increasingly common, offers no job security, no health benefits and no assured pathway to full-time university employment.
lead_paragraph: His students call him “Prof,” and in the classroom James D. Hoff looks like any other English professor, circulating among the undergraduates and urging them to recite, savor and interrogate the texts of writers as varied as James Baldwin, Stephen Crane and the Beat poets.

headline: Egypt Says Twitter Post by Liberal Was Crime
abstract: One of Egypt’s most prominent liberal intellectuals was charged with insulting the judiciary because he criticized a court ruling against three American nonprofits that promote democracy.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A prosecutor on Sunday charged one of Egypt’s most prominent liberal intellectuals with insulting the judiciary because he posted a message on Twitter criticizing a court ruling against three American nonprofits that promote democracy.

headline: Tortorella’s Temper Lands Him in Trouble Again
abstract: John Tortorella had a history of blowups during his career, including one when he led the Rangers.
lead_paragraph: John Tortorella had kept his temper in check remarkably well this season, but in an explosion of fury Saturday night, his inability to ignore provocation got the better of him. Now Tortorella, the Vancouver coach, almost certainly faces a substantial fine and may be suspended.

headline: When Children Become Criminals
abstract: Sixteen-year-olds in New York belong in the juvenile system, not in adult courts or prisons.
lead_paragraph: New York is one of two states, the other being North Carolina, in which 16-year-olds are automatically tried as adults. This is the case despite overwhelming evidence that sending children into adult courts, rather than the juvenile justice system, needlessly destroys lives and further endangers the public by turning nonviolent youngsters into hardened criminals.

headline: Dangerous Inaction by the Election Commission
abstract: When the F.E.C. staff did its job and sought an investigation of Crossroads GPS, it was blocked by the usual deadlock vote.
lead_paragraph: For all its signature dysfunction, the Federal Election Commission has a staff of professionals working to track big money and shady behavior in the nation’s congressional and presidential campaigns.

headline: Undefeated Connecticut Leaves No Doubts at Rutgers
abstract: The top-ranked Huskies overwhelmed the Scarlet Knights for their 25th straight victory and their 19th this season.
lead_paragraph: PISCATAWAY, N.J. — C. Vivian Stringer, the women’s basketball coach at Rutgers, appeared on the video scoreboard before Sunday’s game against Connecticut in a film clip intended to stoke her players and the announced 6,480 fans at Rutgers Athletic Center.

headline: A-Rod’s Drug Testing
abstract: Alex Rodriguez wasn’t the only player to use drugs and evade detection in Major League Baseball’s testing system.
lead_paragraph: Yankees third baseman Alex Rodriguez took testosterone lozenges before games. He applied testosterone cream every evening and injected H.G.H. regularly. And yet he never failed a drug test. Evidence that he broke antidoping rules surfaced through other channels. In January 2013, The Miami New Times linked a “rejuvenation” clinic — Biogenesis of America — to Rodriguez and other players, putting in motion an investigation by Major League Baseball, which culminated in a 162-game suspension for Rodriguez and an official report, released last week, detailing his regimen.

headline: Arkansas Town’s New Owner Has Visions of Its Renaissance
abstract: For 125 years, the Lee Wilson family owned Wilson, Ark., building a fortune from farming. Its new owner, however, seeks to transform the town into a beacon of art, culture and education.
lead_paragraph: WILSON, Ark. — The little farm towns here in Delta cotton country spin by, each rusting grain silo and boarded-up discount store fading into the next.

headline: What’s Happening With the Air Force?
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Cheating', 'Editorials']
abstract: Cheating on tests is the latest in a growing list of alarming behavior by Air Force officers.
lead_paragraph: If the Air Force cheating scandal disclosed last week were a singular event, it would be easier to accept Pentagon assurances that America’s nuclear deterrence and military readiness have not been compromised. But it is the latest in a series of breaches that have raised alarms about discipline and competency in the Air Force.

headline: An Attack on Westerners Helps Bridge a Divide in Kabul
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: The attack by the Taliban at a restaurant in Kabul narrowed a gap between the Westerners who live an often cosseted existence, and ordinary Afghans, who have borne the brunt of the war’s violence.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — His suicide vest packed with steel pellets the size of musket balls, the Taliban bomber walked down the potholed street to the entrance of the Taverna du Liban. Behind the thin steel door, in a small guardroom, three men huddled for warmth from the cold Kabul winter.

headline: U.S. Snowboarding Olympians Include Siblings
abstract: Arielle and Taylor Gold were part of an eight-member American halfpipe team announced Sunday that is expected to dominate at the Sochi Olympics.
lead_paragraph: MAMMOTH LAKES, Calif. — Arielle Gold began snowboarding at age 7 to be more like Taylor, her older brother. These days, Arielle, 17, and Taylor, 20, spend much of their summers training together in the gym and their winters riding together, pushing each other to be better.

headline: Publisher Struggles in Chase for Growth
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Newspapers', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Aaron Kushner, publisher of The Orange County Register, has been playing hardball against distressed competitors and lustily grabbing for a bigger footprint.
lead_paragraph: Timing matters when it comes to news. I had been reading about Aaron Kushner’s audacious strategy to invest in journalism ever since he bought The Orange County Register in 2012 for about $50 million and the assumption of $110 million in pension obligations. After years of covering layoffs, I wanted to write a different kind of tale about newspapers.

headline: Juveniles Facing Lifelong Terms Despite Rulings
keywords: ['Juvenile Delinquency', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'States (US)', 'Mandatory Sentencing']
abstract: The Supreme Court acted in 2010 and 2012 to curtail the use of mandatory life sentences for juveniles, but experts say most states have taken half-measures to carry out the rulings.
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — In decisions widely hailed as milestones, the United States Supreme Court in 2010 and 2012 acted to curtail the use of mandatory life sentences for juveniles, accepting the argument that children, even those who are convicted of murder, are less culpable than adults and usually deserve a chance at redemption.

headline: For Super Bowl Jet-and-Helicopter Set, Urging Buses and Rail
keywords: ['Super Bowl', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Transit Systems', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Football', 'Series']
abstract: For many of the expected 400,000 visitors to New York City, the transportation options for getting to their stadium seats on Feb. 2 are not their usual ones.
lead_paragraph: It can seem like an impossible math problem, packed with variables that include the reliability of famously fussy rail systems, conditions at the region’s oldest operating airport and the whims of Mother Nature in the dead of winter.

headline: U.N. Invites Iran to Syria Talks, Raising Objections From the U.S.
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: American officials appeared to be caught off guard by the announcement and suggested that Iran had not met all the conditions for attending the conference to end the war in Syria.
lead_paragraph: The announcement by Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, that he had invited Iran to a peace conference to end the war in Syria drew strong objections on Sunday from American officials, who suggested that Iran had not met all the conditions for attending and that the invitation might need to be withdrawn.

headline: Nonprofit Clinic Offers ‘Bridges of Health’ to Philadelphia’s Illegal Immigrants
abstract: Puentes de Salud is a nonprofit group that provides primary care to Philadelphia’s undocumented and uninsured immigrants.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Like many other immigrants, Mery Martinez has no legal status in the United States, no health insurance and no money.

headline: Influence in Paradise: An Annotated Tour
abstract: Lawmakers from Washington travel to resorts across the United States for multiday fund-raising events that often mix business and pleasure.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers from Washington travel to resorts across the United States for multiday fund-raising events that often mix business and pleasure.

headline: On ‘Downton Abbey': the First Black Character Makes an Appearance
abstract: Gary Carr is the first black actor to play a regular role on the series.
lead_paragraph: “While it was shocking and sad to see such a likable character as Anna suffer, the fact is that women – in those days and even today in many parts of the world – were subjected to this horrible crime as well as the shame and long-term damage in its aftermath. … The show took a unique opportunity to portray an important reality and I thought it was done appropriately.” – Steven Feinstein, Massachusetts

headline: An Unsung Hero of Civil Rights
keywords: ['Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Law and Legislation', 'Segregation and Desegregation']
abstract: Celebrate Martin Luther King Jr. and lift a glass to Bill McCulloch. (Who?)
lead_paragraph: This year America will celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Civil Rights Act, a candidate for the greatest legislative accomplishment of the last century. We will recall the presidents who launched (J.F.K.) and landed (L.B.J.) this profound if incomplete attempt to repair the damage racism had done to our democracy and our humanity. We will esteem the leaders and martyrs of the movement that forced the issue onto our national conscience, including the man we honor on this holiday. We will recall, too, the Southern Democrats who stood — and stalled — in defense of segregation, and the Republicans who later capitalized on the outcome with a cynical appeal to white resentment. We will lament the current attempts by several states, with the Supreme Court’s blessing, to roll back the basic franchise promised in the Civil Rights Act (and reinforced by the Voting Rights Act the following year). And we will probably invoke the legacy of this great law many times as we debate the status of millions of undocumented residents and the rights of gay Americans.

headline: A Loophole Allows Lawmakers to Reel In Trips and Donations
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Campaign Finance', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Political Action Committees']
abstract: Weekend fund-raisers at high-end resorts prove well worth the trip for the members of Congress who host the events, and those seeking influence in Washington.
lead_paragraph: VAIL, Colo. — After some time in the hot tub, an evening cocktail reception and a two-and-a-half-hour dinner in a private dining room named Out of Bounds, Representative Adrian Smith, Republican of Nebraska, made one last stop, visiting the lounge at the Four Seasons Resort hotel here to spend more time with the lobbyists and other donors who had jetted in from Washington, D.C., to join him for the weekend getaway.

headline: Iraq Again Uses Sunni Tribesmen in Militant War
abstract: As the prime minister struggles to put down an insurgency led by Qaeda-affiliated militants, he has taken to paying tribal militias to fight as proxies, as the Americans did in 2007.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — At a command center in western Anbar Province, Iraqi military officials are handing out guns and cash to local Sunni tribal fighters who are battling militants for control of Iraq’s largest province.

headline: Lucrative Getaways
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Campaign Finance', 'Political Action Committees', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: Here is a look at some fund-raising events that lawmakers hosted, often far from their home states. The charges represent the hotel and meal costs that lawmakers or their leadership PACs paid.
lead_paragraph: Here is a look at some fund-raising events that lawmakers hosted, often far from their home states. The charges represent the hotel and meal costs that lawmakers or their leadership PACs paid.

headline: Tijuana Airport Parking, Just Over the Border
abstract: Next year, if all goes according to plan, air travelers will be able to park their cars in the United States and walk across an enclosed 325-foot passageway directly to Tijuana International.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — In the barren Southwest, a good portion of the 1,900-mile border between the United States and Mexico is being fortified with walls, electronic surveillance and trenches.

headline: A New Character, and a New Crazy,  on ‘Girls’
abstract: Is she just too annoying and crazy?
lead_paragraph: All right! There’s a new girl on the block!

headline: Common Gripes Greet Common Man Party, Now Running Delhi
abstract: Barely 20 days after the party upended Indian politics and took control in one of the world’s most populous cities, it is being criticized from many directions.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — You could hardly blame Arvind Kejriwal, Delhi’s new chief executive, for looking dour as he drove to work this week, barely 20 days after his anticorruption Aam Aadmi, or Common Man, party upended Indian politics and took control of one of the world’s most populous cities.

headline: The Significance of Winning One for Welker
abstract: The Broncos’ Wes Welker gave an inspirational speech to his teammates before Sunday’s game against the Patriots, his former team.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Wes Welker gave a speech. Then he sent a message, the contents of which were unavoidably mixed.

headline: For Christie and MSNBC, a Messy Divorce Plays Out in Public View
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'George Washington Bridge']
abstract: The improbable relationship between a governor with his eyes on the White House and a network determined to break into the top tier has curdled in a spectacularly public fashion.
lead_paragraph: It was a match made in moderately minded Northeast Corridor heaven.

headline: Corrections: January 20, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on January 20, 2014.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: A Community Center Honoring 2 Slain Nuns, Forced Out of Its Home
abstract: The Maura Clarke-Ita Ford Center must vacate its rooms at St. John the Baptist Parish in Bedford-Stuyvesant since the property is being leased to a developer for housing.
lead_paragraph: Faith demands sacrifice. Maura Clarke and Ita Ford, two Maryknoll nuns, understood that when they went to work among the poor in Central America. The Cold War turned white-hot in El Salvador when they, along with Jean Donovan and Sister Dorothy Kazel, were raped, tortured and murdered by the Salvadoran military on December 2, 1980.

headline: Thunderous Defense and Crowd Lift Seahawks to Super Bowl
abstract: For the first time in eight years, Seattle advanced to the Super Bowl, where its top-ranked defense will match up with the top-ranked offense of the Denver Broncos.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — It was loud, so, so loud at CenturyLink Field on Sunday. The press box shook and the crowd rumbled and heaved and Pete Carroll, the Seahawks’ coach, paced the sideline raising his arms, pleading the crowd for more, more, more.

headline: Building Toward the Home of Tomorrow
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Home Appliances', 'Home Automation and Smart Homes']
abstract: The announcement last week that Google was paying $3 billion to acquire Nest, a maker of Internet-connected home products, put a sort of Good Housekeeping seal of approval on this nascent market.
lead_paragraph: The home of the future — complete with helper bots and automated appliances — has long been the stuff of science fiction. The tech world is determined to make it a reality.

headline: Surging Rangers Overwhelm Capitals
abstract: Henrik Lundqvist looked sharp and Rick Nash had multiple goals as the Rangers turned in another strong home performance.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers are on a roll. With Henrik Lundqvist stopping pucks with aplomb and multiple goals from Rick Nash, the team is skating with as much confidence as it has displayed all season.

headline: China Reports Cooling Down of Economy
abstract: China’s economy expanded 7.7 percent in the final three months of 2013, compared with a year earlier, underlining that the world’s second-largest economy has continued to lose the supercharged momentum of recent decades.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s economy expanded 7.7 percent in the final three months of 2013, compared with a year earlier, underlining that the world’s second-largest economy has continued to lose the supercharged momentum of recent decades.

headline: A Colossal Bridge Will Rise Across the Hudson
keywords: ['Bridges and Tunnels', 'Tappan Zee Bridge', 'Roads and Traffic']
abstract: A replacement for the Tappan Zee, the longest bridge in New York, will carry eight lanes of traffic 3.1 miles between Rockland and Westchester Counties.
lead_paragraph: David Capobianco was a toddler in 1964 when the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge slowly soared over his neighborhood of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, and tethered it to Staten Island. As he grew up, the improbable notion of assembling something so big and of such gossamer design propelled him to become a civil engineer.

abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A woman who was giving directions to a new arrival discovered that he was also looking for a friend.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Governor Tells Donors: ‘Come See Me Next Year’
abstract: Over the weekend Gov. Chris Christie said his presidential ambitions were on hold until 2015.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey told top Republican donors on Sunday that his presidential ambitions were on hold until next year, amid a widening state investigation into a bridge closing ordered by his aides, and further allegations that he has bullied local officials.

headline: Photo Replay: Jan. 12-18
abstract: Often at sports events, the mix of action, location, light and “atmospherics” can create hypnotic visuals that complement the lure of competition.
lead_paragraph: Often at sports events, the mix of action, location, light and “atmospherics” can create hypnotic visuals that complement the lure of competition.

headline: Debate on Photo Retouching Flares Online, With Roles Reversed
abstract: A call for untouched photos of Lena Dunham from the new issue of Vogue had some wondering about the target and the far different terrain women’s magazines cover nowadays.
lead_paragraph: Last week, two publications that consider themselves champions of women faced off — with an unexpected outcome.

headline: Tappan Zee Bridge Opens for Business in 1955
abstract: A December 1955 article in The New York Times on the opening of the Tappan Zee bridge.
lead_paragraph: A December 1955 article in The New York Times on the opening of the Tappan Zee bridge.

headline: Bryan Brothers Upset in Australian Open
abstract: Top-seeded Bob and Mike Bryan made their earliest exit in Melbourne in 11 years, losing in the third round in doubles.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — The top-seeded American team of Bob and Mike Bryan fell with surprising speed, 7-6 (9), 6-4 in 78 minutes, in the third round of men’s doubles to an unheralded pair, Eric Butorac of Boston and Raven Klaasen of Cape Town.

headline: The Week’s Men’s College Basketball Games to Watch
abstract: Kentucky, which faces Texas A&M on Tuesday night, is led by the freshman forward Julius Randle, but the freshman guard Andrew Harrison is also making a name for himself.
lead_paragraph: TEXAS A&M at No. 14 KENTUCKY

headline: The Limits of Marriage as a Path Out of Poverty
abstract: Emphasis on marriage as a solution to poverty fights against demographic trends, the track record of policy interventions, and gains made by single mothers, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Coming a Long Way on Smoking, With a Way to Go
abstract: Since 1964, when the first “Surgeon General’s Report on Smoking and Health” was released, rates have fallen by more than half, but it remains a killer.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago this month, Dr. Luther L. Terry issued the first “Surgeon General’s Report on Smoking and Health,” which cited smoking as a cause of lung cancer in men. The hefty report landed like a bombshell on a complacent public, bombarded daily by tobacco advertising and surrounded at work, home and play by people who smoked.

headline: U.S. Attorney Said to Meet With Hoboken Mayor
abstract: Mayor Dawn Zimmer said that she met with federal investigators who are looking into her allegation that Lt. Gov. Kim Guadagno threatened to withhold federal storm aid.
lead_paragraph: The mayor of Hoboken, N.J., Dawn Zimmer, said that she met on Sunday afternoon with federal prosecutors who are investigating her allegation that Lt. Gov. Kim Guadagno threatened to withhold federal funds that could have helped her city recover from Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Cuomo’s Budget Is Said to Include Ethics and Campaign Finance Reforms
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo plans to use his budget proposal this week to push for approval of new ethics laws and a public campaign financing system, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, seeking to prod recalcitrant lawmakers to take action after a rash of embarrassing corruption scandals in Albany, plans to use his budget proposal this week to push for approval of new ethics laws and a public financing system for state political campaigns, administration officials said.

headline: Swindlers Use Telephones, With Internet’s Tactics
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Identity Theft', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: Online phone-call tools have made it easy for swindlers to dupe victims out of valuable personal information or to overwhelm phone systems for essential public services like hospitals.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Phone swindles are practically as old as the telephone itself. But new technology has led to an onslaught of Internet-inspired fraud tactics that try to use telephone calls to dupe millions of people or to overwhelm switchboards for essential public services, causing deep concern among law enforcement and other groups.

headline: Lynch’s Third-Quarter Blast Breaks Pacific Northwest Logjam
abstract: The showdown between Seattle and San Francisco backs found little traction until Marshawn Lynch ripped off a 40-yard touchdown in the third quarter.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The showdown between Beast Mode and the Inconvenient Truth, the nicknames for Marshawn Lynch and Frank Gore, the star running backs of the Seattle Seahawks and the San Francisco 49ers, was one of many subplots expected to emerge from the N.F.C. championship game.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, January 20, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Monday, January 20, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “Fake emails are usually pretty easy to spot because you can look and see if it came from Bank of America or from FreeEmailAddressInEgypt.com. With the phone, you don’t have that option of researching.”

headline: In New Country, Mother Sacrifices Precious Family Time to Pay Bills
abstract: Antonia Caba moved to New York from the Dominican Republic in 2007. She struggled to pay her bills and worked a night shift that left her precious little time to spend with her four children.
lead_paragraph: Antonia Caba did not have any tissues so she used a paper towel to dab away her tears, taking care not to smudge her meticulously applied makeup as she described how she had tried to provide for her children in this new country.

headline: Woman and 2 Daughters in Queens Are Found Stabbed to Death at Home
abstract: Emergency responders answering a call on Sunday found the family dead in their apartment, a Fire Department spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: The police are investigating the stabbing deaths on Sunday of a Queens woman and her two daughters, police and fire officials said.

headline: Sharapova Follows Williams Out the Door
abstract: The No. 3 seed Maria Sharapova of Russia fell to No. 20 Dominika Cibulkova of Slovakia in the fourth round after winning the first set.
lead_paragraph: One day after the heavy favorite Serena Williams lost to Ana Ivanovic, another multiple Grand Slam champion crashed out in the fourth round at the Australian Open.

headline: With University’s Help, New Park on Harlem River Is a Marshland Sanctuary
keywords: ['Wetlands', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Muscota Marsh, built by Columbia University, features a wooden boardwalk and gravel paths that extend river access to Inwood residents.
lead_paragraph: Muscota means “place in the reeds” in the language of the Lenape, Manhattan’s original Native American inhabitants, and a new park that opened quietly in mid-January at the northern tip of the island appropriately bears the name.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 19, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Citing Costs, N.H.L. Injury Study Urges More Safety
abstract: Researchers estimated that N.H.L. teams and their insurers paid about $653 million in salary to players sidelined by concussions and other injuries over three recent seasons.
lead_paragraph: An author of a new medical study said the high cost of paying injured N.H.L. players should push the league to stiffen what he described as inadequate measures to prevent brain trauma, including rules that still allow fighting.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8:10 A.M. (Starz) CHARLIE BARTLETT (2008) After being kicked out of private school for making fake IDs, Charlie (Anton Yelchin, above) goes the public route, arriving at a high school in a chauffeured limousine, wearing a navy blazer with a Latin insignia and toting a briefcase. An instant pariah, he discovers a road to popularity paved with prescription drugs. Soon, he has become a sort of therapist, dispensing advice and medication to classmates. Hope Davis plays his flaky, depressed mother; Robert Downey Jr. is the high school’s alcoholic principal, whose relationship with Charlie turns into warfare, once he learns that Charlie is dating his rebellious daughter (Kat Dennings). “In the movie’s funniest scene, Charlie and his business partner, Murphy, the school bully who beat him up and dunked his head in the toilet when he first arrived, dispense Ritalin to the students and turn a dance into a frenzied free-for-all with bare-breasted girls running down the halls,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. “The movie, directed by Jon Poll from a screenplay by Gustin Nash, is never more amusingly subversive than in this scene, which suggests the hypocrisy of American attitudes toward drugs without putting it in words.” Still, he said, “as the movie dashes from one base to the next, it never coalesces into the character-driven, serious comedy with heart that you want it be.”

headline: Parking Rules
abstract: Because of Martin Luther King’s Birthday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Because of Martin Luther King’s Birthday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Monday. Other regulations remain in effect.

headline: Juan Gelman, Argentine Poet Who Challenged Junta, Dies at 83
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'Language and Languages', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Books and Literature', 'Spanish Language']
abstract: Social commentary, some of it born of personal tragedy, was just one hallmark of Mr. Gelman’s work.
lead_paragraph: Juan Gelman, an Argentine poet who challenged the petty and profound tyrannies of his country’s military junta — including those directed against his family — in works that established him as a formidable presence in the Spanish-language literary canon, died on Tuesday at his home in Mexico City, where he had lived for many years. He was 83.

headline: Dr. Donald Morton Dies at 79; Melanoma Expert Pioneered a Cancer Technique
keywords: ['Melanomas', 'Cancer', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Lymph Nodes and Lymphatic System', 'Surgery and Surgeons']
abstract: Dr. Morton, who was known as one of the last physicians to treat the actor John Wayne, was at the forefront of cancer research and treatment.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Donald L. Morton, a son of an Appalachian coal miner who gained renown as a surgeon for helping to develop a widely used technique for detecting and treating certain kinds of cancer, died on Jan. 10 in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 79.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Defense Becomes Issue as Warriors Try to Keep Pace
abstract: Golden State’s schedule does not have much of a letup, and Andre Iguodala’s hamstring injury and Andrew Bogut’s reduced playing time are reasons for concern.
lead_paragraph: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks, and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: Popular Demand
abstract: Album sales declined again this year. Total sales, a figure that includes CDs, cassettes, digital albums and LPs, fell 8 percent from 2012 to 2013, to 289 million.
lead_paragraph: Album sales declined again this year. Total sales, a figure that includes CDs, cassettes, digital albums and LPs, fell 8 percent from 2012 to 2013, to 289 million.

headline: ‘Gravity’ and ‘12 Years’ in Unprecedented Tie for Producers Guild Award
abstract: The tie is a first for the guild. Until now, the honor has been considered a good indicator of which film would win the best-picture Oscar.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In an indication of how highly competitive this year is for film, the Producers Guild of America announced a tie for its best feature award on Sunday. “Gravity” and “12 Years a Slave” both took the top honors, the first time there has been a tie for the award. The producers prize is considered a good forecaster for the eventual Oscar best picture winner; the two prizes have matched up for the last six years.

headline: China Growth Figures Show Rapidly Narrowing Gap With U.S. Economy
abstract: Factors like rising prices that are fueling China’s growth have pushed the economy to expand at a rate almost four times that of the United States economy.
lead_paragraph: China’s economic growth figures released Monday morning may show a slowdown, but they still indicate that China is growing almost four times as fast as the United States in dollar terms, rapidly closing the gap in the size of the two countries’ economies.

headline: Work on New Chinese Aircraft Carrier Reportedly Underway
abstract: A Hong Kong newspaper reported a senior Communist Party official as saying that China now had plans to operate a fleet of at least four aircraft carriers.
lead_paragraph: A senior Communist Party official in northeastern China said that China was at work on a home-built aircraft carrier and had plans to operate a fleet of at least four of the vessels, a Hong Kong newspaper reported.

headline: A Conversation With: Anthropologist Mukulika Banerjee
abstract: At the Jaipur Literature Festival, Mukulika Banerjee, who wrote “Why India Votes,” spoke with India Ink about why the act of voting is so meaningful for the majority of Indians.
lead_paragraph: “Voting in elections is considered sacrosanct by a large majority of Indians,” Mukulika Banerjee writes in the introduction to her new book, “Why India Votes.” That observation forms the backbone of the anthropology professor’s work, an ethnographic study of 12 sites in India during the 2009 general elections, which explores the motivations and opinions of Indian voters on a range of issues related to the electoral process.

headline: Deutsche Loss Underlines European Economy’s Dependence on Banks
abstract: The state Deutsche Bank and other financial institutions in Europe is crucial for the economy because European companies are more dependent on bank credit than American businesses.
lead_paragraph: With its surprise report of a billion-euro fourth-quarter loss, Deutsche Bank has provided another reminder that the financial crisis has never really ended for European banks — raising questions about whether the Continental economy can recover before they do.

headline: Woman and 2 Daughters in Queens Are Found Stabbed to Death at Home
abstract: Emergency responders answering a call on Sunday found the family dead in their apartment, a Fire Department spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: The police are investigating the stabbing deaths on Sunday of a Queens woman and her two daughters, police and fire officials said.

headline: Anheuser-Busch InBev Buying Back Oriental Brewery
abstract: dealbook
lead_paragraph: Anheuser-Busch InBev said on Monday that it would repurchase Oriental Brewery, the South Korean brewer, in a deal valued at $5.8 billion, nearly five years after it sold the company to the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

headline: Nintendo Shares Recover Slightly After Plunge
abstract: The sharp swing in the stock on Monday came after an announcement that sales of the company’s Wii U console were smaller than expected.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Nintendo shares plunged on Monday, then recovered much of their losses as investors focused on indications that the company was softening its resistance to mobile video gaming.

headline: South Korean Trade Official Abducted in Libyan Capital
abstract: Han Seok-woo of the Korea Trade-Investment Promotion Agency was kidnapped on Sunday by four gunmen, officials at the South Korean Foreign Ministry said.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Gunmen have kidnapped a South Korean trade official in the Libyan capital of Tripoli, according to the South Korean government, which advised its citizens Monday to leave the country.

headline: From Chinese Students in Germany, a Technology Promise to the Motherland
abstract: A letter exchange between President Xi Jinping of China and overseas Chinese students in Germany highlights what one Western intelligence analyst called a well-honed system to bring technology from the West to China by appealing to patriotism.
lead_paragraph: Illustrating the grip the Communist Party and government try to maintain on overseas Chinese students, researchers and businesspeople, an exchange of letters between President Xi Jinping and Chinese students in Germany has produced passionate promises from the students to serve the motherland — and deliver “advanced technology” back to China, the state news media reported.

headline: The Photographer and His Printer, Partners in Art and Love
abstract: While Leonard Freed made historic images of the civil rights era, they would not have been seen if not for his loyal master printer — his wife, Brigitte Freed.
lead_paragraph: Leonard Freed’s photos from Harlem, Brooklyn and the historic 1963 March on Washington lay on a workroom table in the home he shared with his wife, Brigitte. She stood over the images — as she has over his reputation — with a slight smile of pride.

headline: Celebrating Martin Luther King’s Birthday
abstract: We’re off for to celebrate the life and legacy of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. But please visit our collection of Dr. King resources that was updated after last August’s 50th anniversary of the March on Washington.
lead_paragraph: Like most schools across the United States, we’re off today in observance of the life and legacy of Martin Luther King. The weekly News Quiz will be published on Tuesday, and a new edition of What’s Going On in This Picture? will be available early next Monday.

headline: A Conversation With: Jonathan Shainin, Newyorker.com News Editor
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Magazines', 'News and News Media', 'Newspapers']
abstract: Mr. Shainin, a former editor at The Caravan, spoke to India Ink at the Jaipur Literature Festival, where he discussed foreign correspondence in India and India’s evolving media landscape.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Shainin was the senior editor at The Caravan, an English-language long-form journalism magazine, for three years before leaving India in October to become the news editor at The New Yorker’s website, where he commissions and edits both domestic and international news stories. He sat with India Ink at the Jaipur Literature Festival over the weekend to discuss the possibilities and pitfalls of foreign correspondence in India and India’s evolving media landscape.

headline: At Versace, Grace Jones Meets Lady Gaga
abstract: The house’s couture collection used a strong 1980s look but with a bit of soft and sweet.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It was Lady Gaga’s ode to Donatella Versace from her “Artpop” album come to life. The performing artist sat front row, her waterfall of blond hair looking so like her designer mentor’s that the two might have been soul sisters.

headline: Claudio Abbado, an Italian Conductor With a Global Reach, Is Dead at 80
abstract: Mr. Abbado led some of the world’s most revered musical institutions, including La Scala, the Vienna State Opera and the Berlin Philharmonic.
lead_paragraph: Claudio Abbado, a conductor whose refined interpretations of a large symphonic and operatic repertory won him the directorships of several of the world’s most revered musical institutions — including La Scala, the London Symphony Orchestra, the Vienna State Opera and the Berlin Philharmonic — died on Monday at his home in Bologna, Italy. He was 80.

headline: Saint Laurent’s Rock Kids Grow Up
abstract: Hedi Slimane puts more tailoring into his autumn 2014 collection.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — As Salma Hayek walked into the Saint Laurent men’s show wearing a feminized black tuxedo that traced her curves, she looked like a poster girl for the company’s rebirth.

headline: Majority of New York Voters Say They Would Re-elect Cuomo, Poll Finds
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Medical Marijuana', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: With his re-election campaign looming, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has enviable voter approval ratings and general support for many of his newest proposals, according to a new poll.
lead_paragraph: With his re-election campaign looming, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has enviable approval ratings from New York voters and general support for many of his newest proposals, including legalizing medical marijuana, according to a new poll released on Monday. But his specific plan for the drug — to use an obscure law, and not new action by the State Legislature, to provide it to patients — is much less popular.

headline: Suicide Blast in Pakistan Kills at Least 13
abstract: The Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility for the blast in Rawalpindi, which came a day after an attack on a military compound in the northwest.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A suicide bomber struck Monday morning near the Pakistani military’s general headquarters in Rawalpindi, killing at least 13 people, including six soldiers, officials said.

headline: Anheuser-Busch InBev Buying Back Oriental Brewery for $5.8 Billion
abstract: Anheuser-Busch InBev had sold Oriental Brewery to the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts for $1.8 billion nearly five years ago.
lead_paragraph: Anheuser-Busch InBev said on Monday that it would repurchase Oriental Brewery, the South Korean brewer, in a deal valued at $5.8 billion, nearly five years after it sold the company to the private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

headline: Blinkx Founder to Join Venture Firm Balderton Capital
abstract: Suranga Chandratillake will return to London from Silicon Valley and lead Balderton Capital’s early stage investments in technology and online media.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Suranga Chandratillake, the founder of the British Internet media company Blinkx, is joining the European venture capital firm Balderton Capital.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Emily Bazelon on Anonymous’s Brand of Vigilante Justice
abstract: Our contributing writer explains what happens when online bullies get bullied themselves.
lead_paragraph: Emily Bazelon, a contributing writer for the magazine, wrote this week’s cover story about efforts by Anonymous, the online collective, to push law enforcement to reopen rape cases that they believe have been mishandled. Bazelon, who is the Truman Capote Fellow for Creative Writing and Law at Yale Law School, is the author of “Sticks and Stones: Defeating the Culture of Bullying and Rediscovering the Power of Character and Empathy.”

headline: Temporary Nuclear Deal With Iran Takes Effect
keywords: ['Nuclear Energy', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: In return for curbing its enrichment of uranium, Iran is hoping that the economic benefits flow in after international sanctions are eased.
lead_paragraph: The first orchestrated rollback in Western antinuclear economic sanctions against Iran took effect on Monday under Tehran’s temporary agreement with world powers, as all sides reported that the steps initially promised had been fulfilled.

headline: In Letter, Former Premier Denies Using Office for Personal Gain
abstract: In a letter to a Hong Kong newspaper columnist, former Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China said he had a clean conscience about his time in office.
lead_paragraph: In a letter to a Hong Kong newspaper columnist, former Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China said he had a clean conscience about his time in office.

headline: British Financial Services Sector Optimistic, Survey Finds
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Of the 87 banks, asset managers and insurance companies surveyed, 69 percent said they felt more optimistic about the business environment, the highest level since 1989.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Financial services firms in Britain are increasingly optimistic about the business environment heading into the first quarter and are prepared to add as many as 15,000 new jobs in the quarter, according to a survey released on Monday.

headline: A Trophy Hunt That’s Good for Rhinos
abstract: Calm down, protesters. Namibia’s conservation policy is working.
lead_paragraph: Let’s stipulate up front that there is no great sport in hunting a black rhinoceros, especially not in Namibia’s open countryside. The first morning we went out tracking in the northern desert there, we nosed around in vehicles for several hours until our guides spotted a rhino a half mile off. Then we hiked quietly up into a high valley. There, a rhino mom with two huge horns stood calmly in front of us next to her calf, as if triceratops had come back to life, at a distance of 200 yards. We shot them, relentlessly, with our cameras.

headline: Venezuela May Meet New Reality, and New Price, at the Pump
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: In the country with the world’s cheapest gasoline, a beleaguered economy may force the government of President Nicolás Maduro to raise prices.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Venezuela has the world’s cheapest gasoline, about 6 cents a gallon, a price so low that drivers often fill their tanks for less than a dollar and tip the gas station attendant more than the cost of the fuel pumped into their cars.

headline: Police and Protesters in Ukraine Escalate Use of Force
abstract: Protests in Kiev took a darker turn as the riot police unleashed stun grenades and rubber bullets, and protesters built a catapult and threw firebombs.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — The catapult that went up on a central street of this city on Monday was a clear sign that the protests that have been going on here for more than two months were taking a darker turn.

headline: 3-D Printing Moves Closer to the Mainstream
abstract: Yes, 3-D printers are quickly adding the features that could take them past the bleeding edge of tech buyers.
lead_paragraph: You know that inkjet printer sitting under your desk? The one with the old, crusty ink cartridges that are collecting dust because you no longer use it? Well, you can move it aside now and buy a fancy, new 3-D printer.

headline: Talks Over Syria Are Set to Begin, but Iran Is Not Invited
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Under pressure from the United States, Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, rescinded Iran’s invitation to the meeting a day after he offered it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American and other Western diplomats on Monday managed to salvage the long-awaited peace conference on Syria, which had seemed on the verge of unraveling before it even began when Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, issued an unexpected invitation to Iran to attend.

headline: Daily Report: Closing In on the Internet-Enabled Home
abstract: The announcement last week that Google was paying $3 billion to acquire Nest, a maker of Internet-connected home products, put a sort of Good Housekeeping seal of approval on this nascent market.
lead_paragraph: The concept of outfitting everyday objects — from garden products to bathroom fixtures — with sensors and connecting them to the web, often called the Internet of Things, has been brewing for several years. But the announcement last week that Google was paying $3 billion to acquire Nest, a maker of Internet-connected home products, put a sort of Good Housekeeping seal of approval on this nascent market, Jenna Wortham reports.

headline: Federer’s Revival Faces Crucible, Starting With Murray in Quarterfinals
abstract: Roger Federer and Andy Murray all but skated into their quarterfinal confrontation, winning easily despite real concerns for both early in the 2014 season.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — New racket, new coach, old Federer.

headline: Pelé Backs Frenchman for FIFA Presidency
abstract: In a letter, the Brazilian soccer great gave a strong endorsement for Jérôme Champagne’s bid to replace Sepp Blatter.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Jérôme Champagne announced Monday that he would run for the presidency of FIFA, the world governing body of soccer, few outside the world of soccer administration had heard his name before. But Champagne, a former diplomat and FIFA adviser, can count on the backing of someone with a much more recognized name: Pelé.

headline: A Conversation With: Author Antony Beevor
abstract: The British military historian spoke with India Ink at the Jaipur Literature Festival about why the Second World War still interests readers.
lead_paragraph: Since 1998, the British military historian Antony Beevor has written six books on the Second World War –“Crete,” “Berlin,” “Stalingrad,” “D-Day,” “Paris” and “The Second World War,” — in which he re-creates the military strategies and the on-the-ground military conflict. At the Jaipur Literature Festival over the weekend, Mr. Beevor talked to India Ink about how he wrote his 2012 book, “The Second World War,” the treatment of the conflict’s gruesome aspects and why the war still interests readers.

headline: Electra Partners to Take Majority Stake in British Shoemaker
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Shoes and Boots']
abstract: The British private equity firm Electra Partners says its funds will buy a stake in Hotter Shoes held by another private equity shop, Gresham, in a deal worth as much as 200 million pounds, according to a person familiar with the matter.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The British private equity firm Electra Partners said on Monday that its funds would take a majority stake in the British shoemaker Hotter Shoes.

headline: After the Times Redesign, Complaints and Changes
abstract: The five top complaints and what’s being done about them
lead_paragraph: I’ve seldom had as much response to any post as to one earlier this month – from the first day of the redesign of The Times’s website: about 1,000 comments on this blog, in addition to hundreds of emails to my office.

headline: Missionary Jailed in North Korea Asks U.S. to Help Free Him
abstract: Kenneth Bae, a Korean-American missionary serving a 15-year sentence, asked Washington to send a high-ranking official to Pyongyang to “apologize” for his crime.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — A Korean-American missionary who has been jailed in North Korea for more than a year appeared at a news conference in Pyongyang on Monday and appealed to the United States government to negotiate with Pyongyang to secure his release.

headline: In Paris, Schiaparelli Returns to Couture
abstract: After a 60-year hiatus, the legendary fashion house offers a new collection by Marco Zanini.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “I loved the trousers,” Carla Bruni said in her seductive whisper as she hitched up her jeans, referring to pajamas patterned with miniature tribal warriors. It was an outfit from Schiaparelli, reintroduced as a couture house on Monday after a 60-year hiatus.

headline: Woman Chosen to Lead Central African Republic Out of Mayhem
abstract: Catherine Samba-Panza, the mayor of Bangui, the capital, was elected by the makeshift Parliament to help end the bloodshed and hold elections.
lead_paragraph: BANGUI, Central African Republic — Cheers broke out in the National Assembly building here on Monday as representatives chose the mayor of this beleaguered capital to serve as the interim president of the Central African Republic, a country in the grip of a sectarian civil war.

headline: Bike Trips With a Boost
abstract: Electronic bikes offered by the outfitter Inntravel can assist riders on their uphill climbs on European tours.
lead_paragraph: If the thought of cycling in the Alps or even keeping up with your more buff partner in the rolling hills of Tuscany exhausts you, consider taking an electric bike, newly offered by the Britain-based outfitter Inntravel.

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Dior Homme Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Men’s Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Fashion Week photo diary of Schohaja.

headline: Roasted Cauliflower Gratin With Tomatoes and Goat Cheese
abstract: A beautiful, light gratin with Middle Eastern spices.
lead_paragraph: Roasting is one of my favorite ways to prepare cauliflower, and I have always loved preparations that pair the vegetable with coriander seeds. I use coriander seeds and cinnamon to season the tomato sauce that I toss with the roasted cauliflower and sautéed red onions, then add a couple of eggs beaten with goat cheese.

headline: Potato and Sorrel Gratin
abstract: A gratin that is not a typical creamy sliced potato gratin but more like a potato pie.
lead_paragraph: When a friend offered me sorrel from her garden I accepted gladly. I love the tangy flavor of this green leafy vegetable and will always buy it if I see it in my farmers’ market. You don’t need much to contribute lots of lemony flavor and vitamins C, A, iron, calcium and magnesium. The gratin is not a typical creamy sliced potato gratin; it’s more like a potato pie. I cook the potatoes first, then slice or dice and toss with the wilted sorrel, eggs, milk and cheese.

headline: Roasted Eggplant and Red Pepper Gratin
abstract: A Mediterranean gratin seasoned with cumin and thyme.
lead_paragraph: Roasting eggplant requires less oil than frying. It is important to let the roasted eggplant and roasted peppers drain in a strainer, otherwise the gratin will be watery. I recommend roasting the vegetables several hours or a day before you wish to make this. Adding cooked rice to the mixture will result in a firmer gratin.

headline: Fennel, Kale and Rice Gratin
abstract: Two different greens provide contrast in this casserole.
lead_paragraph: I like the contrast of pale and dark green in this gratin, and the sweet anisy fennel flavor against the more intense cruciferous flavor of the kale.

headline: Roasted Squash and Red Onion Gratin With Quinoa
abstract: Roasting the squash results in a sweet layer of flavor in this beautiful gratin.
lead_paragraph: I have given you several winter squash gratins over the years; this is my favorite to date, because of the sweet layer of flavor of the roasted squash and the texture of the black quinoa.

headline: A Queen Bee’s Secret, Pinpointed
abstract: An international team of researchers has identified pheromones that are specific to queen wasps, bumblebees and desert ants that keep workers sterile while in their presence.
lead_paragraph: In the highly organized colonies of bees, wasps and ants, the queen has a monopoly on breeding; workers do not reproduce when a fertile queen is present. Just how she accomplishes that has been something of a mystery. Previous studies have shown that queens use chemical signals to keep workers sterile, but the few chemicals identified so far did not appear to be related to one another.

headline: Screen Actors Guild Awards Red Carpet
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Movies', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: Stars including Lupita Nyong’o in Gucci and Jennifer Lawrence in Dior attended the SAG awards.
lead_paragraph: Stars including Lupita Nyong’o in Gucci and Jennifer Lawrence in Dior attended the SAG awards.

headline: Three-Piece Suits, Breakfast Meetings, and Overwork
abstract: The destructiveness isn’t a bug, it’s a feature.
lead_paragraph: No, this isn’t more about “American Hustle”; it’s a commentary on James Surowiecki’s interesting piece on the cult of long hours. I don’t exactly disagree with his argument, but I’d place the emphasis a bit differently.

headline: Objectively Pro-Unemployment
abstract: The truth about deficit scolds.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Chait makes a good point about the deficit scolds: whatever they may say, they have in practice played a key role in promoting short-run fiscal austerity and therefore in keeping unemployment high.

headline: Interview: June Squibb
abstract: At the Critics’ Choice awards, June Squibb speaks with Melena Ryzik about her role in Alexander Payne’s black and white film “Nebraska.”
lead_paragraph: At the Critics’ Choice awards, June Squibb speaks with Melena Ryzik about her role in Alexander Payne’s black and white film “Nebraska.”

headline: Thom Browne and Donatella Versace Both Put on a Show
abstract: Both designers take seriously the notion that fashion shows are, more than anything else, a “show,” and they did not disappoint at Paris Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It’s somehow fitting that Sunday marked the end of the fall men’s shows here in Paris, with Thom Browne among the last to show his collection, as well as the beginning of couture week, with Donatella Versace getting a jump on her fellow designers with a show on Sunday night.

headline: Image of the Day: Jan. 20
abstract: A Republic Day parade rehearsal in New Delhi.

headline: Video: The Roots of ‘Nebraska’s’ Feisty Wife
abstract: June Squibb explains how she recognized her own mother in the foul-mouthed character.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – At 84, June Squibb is one of the unlikely ingénues of this Oscar season, lauded for her feisty performance in Alexander Payne’s “Nebraska.” Of course, Ms. Squibb has put the work in, starting with her big break, onstage in Ethel Merman’s “Gypsy” in 1959. Since then, as the Bagger’s colleague Brooks Barnes writes, Ms. Squibb “has kept plugging away and plugging away and plugging away,” taking acting classes and auditioning. Though she had worked with Mr. Payne before, she still put herself on tape to play the foul-mouthed Kate, the wife of Bruce Dern’s sullen patriarch in “Nebraska.”

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Lanvin Fall/Winter 2014

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Men’s Fashion Week photo diary of Sarah Aubel.

headline: In the Matter of Kim Guadagno
abstract: Some news from the neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: One of the interesting and bittersweet aspects of the burgeoning Bridgegate-plus scandal in New Jersey has been the centrality of local newspapers. The original story wasn’t broken by the crack investigative reporters at the New York Times, or the fake-scandal-chasers at 60 Minutes. It was broken by the transportation reporter of the Bergen Record.

headline: The Source | Liz Diller

lead_paragraph: Doug Aitken interviews the architect Liz Diller of Diller Scofidio + Renfro.

headline: More Monster and Hats
abstract: Two people are stuck on a remote island with a horrible monster. What should they do to maximize their chance of survival?
lead_paragraph: Our challenge this week was suggested by Chris Roat, who calls it “one of my favorite puzzles of the year.” And Dr. Roat sees a lot of puzzles — he’s an active participant in Bay Area puzzle competitions and a longtime Google employee currently up to something top-secret at Google X. His suggestion for this week is a continuation of our recent Andrew Luck Monster Problem. Put on your headgear and get ready for —

headline: Hyundai to Sponsor Artworks in Turbine Hall at Tate Modern
abstract: Turbine Hall at the Tate Modern in London gains a new sponsor, Hyundai.
lead_paragraph: Since 2012, when Unilever stopped funding art installations at Turbine Hall, the cavernous entrance to the Tate Modern in

headline: Lieutenant Governor Calls Hoboken Mayor’s Claims ‘Illogical’
abstract: Lt. Gov. Kim Guadagno pushed back against an accusation that she had threatened to deny Hurricane Sandy relief to Hoboken, N.J., if the city’s mayor, Dawn Zimmer, failed to support a redevelopment project.
lead_paragraph: HOBOKEN, N.J. — The fenced-off piles of rubble at the northern end of this city bear no resemblance to the limestone towers of Rockefeller Center in Manhattan. But the connection between the two plots on opposite sides of the Hudson River is at the core of Gov. Chris Christie’s latest political headache.

headline: Taliban Attack Kills G.I. at an Afghan-U.S. Base
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: Behind a truck bomb, gunmen raided the base in the first major Taliban attack since insurgents killed 21 civilians at a Kabul restaurant on Friday.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Behind a truck bomb, Taliban gunmen in military fatigues staged a brazen raid on Monday against a sprawling base shared by American and Afghan forces in southern Afghanistan. Afghan officials said an American soldier was killed in the attack, which took place a few miles from where the Taliban movement was founded nearly 20 years ago.

headline: Casting ‘Nebraska’ Via Radio and Other Producing Secrets
abstract: The “Nebraska” production sought nonprofessionals via announcements on rural radio, it was revealed at a Producers Guild panel. At the same session, Woody Allen’s longtime producer explained how he figures out where to set his films: where he can stand to live for the 10 weeks of filming.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — June Squibb, an actress for more than 50 years, had to audition on tape to play Bruce Dern’s feisty wife in “Nebraska,” but much of the rest of the cast came from wide open calls in the Midwest.

headline: Failed Talks With Militants Prompt Many to Flee in Iraq
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: A tentative agreement to allow officials to return to Falluja fell apart after jihadist militants kidnapped local negotiators, those involved in the talks said.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Thousands of residents have fled Falluja in recent days, fearing worsening violence after the failure of negotiations between local leaders and jihadist militants to end a standoff that has lasted weeks, leaders from the city said Monday.

lead_paragraph: Paris
