lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Men’s Fashion Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Oil Industry Nears a Big Asset Sell-Off
abstract: The deal may be one of many this year, as energy companies seek cash for other projects or to finance share buybacks and higher dividends.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Royal Dutch Shell said on Monday that it would sell its minority interest in an Australian liquefied natural gas project to the Kuwait Foreign Petroleum Exploration Company for about $1.1 billion.

headline: Peugeot Shares Tumble as Capital Plan Comes into Focus
abstract: Investors fear their stakes in the French automaker will be diluted under terms of a capital injection by a Chinese car company and the French government.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Shares of PSA Peugeot Citroën, the largest French automaker, fell sharply on Monday as the outline of a proposed tie-up with a Chinese partner became clearer.

headline: Aam Aadmi Protest Shuts Down Central Delhi
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Human Trafficking', 'Law and Legislation', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: Arvind Kejriwal, Delhi’s chief minister, and his party demanded that the central government hand over control of the city’s police force to the state government.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The heart of India’s capital came to a standstill on Monday after Arvind Kejriwal, the Delhi chief minister, and members of his Aam Aadmi Party squared off with the central government in a public demonstration to demand that the Delhi police should be under state, not federal, control.

headline: Some Alluring Sex Ideas For Dolphins in Your Life
abstract: Isabella Rossellini talks about the sex lives found in the natural world in “Green Porno,” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: Isabella Rossellini’s fascination with sex makes for an odd, occasionally endearing evening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Fishman Space, one that suggests a class by a high school biology teacher who is angling for a suspension. And lecherous types take note: Although the show is about sex, it’s not at all sexy. If anything, it is likely to cause you to be creeped out by the very thought of such activity any time soon.

headline: In Paris, The Start of Summer Couture
abstract: The couture season opened with drape from Versace, cutouts from Dior and a splash of color from the newly revived house of Schiaparelli.
lead_paragraph: The couture season opened with drape from Versace, cutouts from Dior and a splash of color from the newly revived house of Schiaparelli.

headline: Carnal Carnivals of Song and Dance
abstract: Two dark new London musicals, “Stephen Ward,” about the early-1960s Profumo scandal, and “American Psycho,” show men and their libidos behaving badly.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — There’s no accounting, it seems, for the unspeakable places a man might be driven by a wayward libido. On my first morning on British soil this month, I opened the newspaper to discover not one but three accounts of eminent entertainment personalities — a soap opera star, a disc jockey, a broadcaster — charged with molesting girls and women. (“Roache assaulted me in ‘Coronation Street’ toilets when I was 14, woman tells court,” one headline read.)

headline: Sundance: A Food Documentary That Hopes to Start a Movement
abstract: “Fed Up,” whose backers include Katie Couric and Laurie David, hopes to organize town hall meetings as part of its argument that food companies have misled consumers.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — Stephanie Soechtig’s “Fed Up,” as one might guess from the title, is not a cheery little documentary. While not quite delivering a Michael Moore-style vituperation, Ms. Soechtig and her executive producers — among them Katie Couric and Laurie David — make their exasperation extremely clear.

headline: Video of New Jersey Lt. Governor Denying Hoboken Mayor’s Allegation
abstract: Lt. Gov. Kim Guadagno denies that she linked a redevelopment project to federal assistance for projects in the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: Lt. Gov. Kim Guadagno of New Jersey flatly denied allegations made over the weekend that she linked federal aid to support of the Christie administration, as my colleague Alan Feuer reports.

headline: Department of Corrections, and Not
abstract: I do not think that word means what Bret Stephens thinks it means.
lead_paragraph: So Bret Stephens of the WSJ has contacted the Times to protest my remark, in today’s column, that his error in using nominal incomes has not been corrected on the WSJ’s website. I actually anticipated something like this, and saved a copy of his original column as it appeared yesterday, just in case a correction suddenly appeared.

headline: Crystal Bridges Museum Buys a Frank Lloyd Wright House
abstract: A Frank Lloyd Wright House in New Jersey will be sent to the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art in Arkansas and reconstructed there.
lead_paragraph: The Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art is fast becoming more than a place to see a historic sweep of paintings by masters like Gilbert Stuart, Asher B. Durand, Norman Rockwell and Andy Warhol.  An architecturally historic house will soon be relocated to the museum’s 120-acre campus in Bentonville, Ark.

headline: Delhi’s Leader Holds Protest Over Police
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Police', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Sex Crimes', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: To protest police corruption, Arvind Kejriwal, Delhi’s chief minister, and supporters held a demonstration that shut down the heart of downtown.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — This city’s most vocal protest leader once again shut down the heart of downtown, snarling traffic for tens of thousands while he and his supporters shouted slogans denouncing police corruption.

headline: W.H.O. May Begin Webcast of Health Ministers’ Meeting
keywords: ['Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows', 'Medicine and Health', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: A move would allow health campaigners and journalists from many poor countries to at least watch the annual meeting, which considers questions of life and death.
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization, responding to an angry letter to a British medical journal, says it may soon start streaming its annual meeting of the world’s health ministers on the web.

headline: The Source | Liz Diller in Conversation With Doug Aitken
abstract: In our latest installment of this exclusive series of interviews by Doug Aitken, the artist interviews the architect Liz Diller, a founding member of Diller Scofidio + Renfro.
lead_paragraph: “We like to take impossible things and actually make them happen,” Liz Diller says. A partner at the multidisciplinary architecture firm of Diller Scofidio + Renfro, which has been celebrated for its recent work on the High Line and Lincoln Center, as well as on numerous other projects in New York City and beyond, Diller also discusses being a “problem maker” and the unique opportunity she’s had as an architect to build in her own city. The interview is part of the Source, a series of candid video conversations with several dozen noteworthy figures about their creative process, currently on view in a custom pavilion at the Sundance Film Festival.

headline: The Problem With Science, Civil War Medicine, Inside Thyroid Supplements
keywords: ['Falsification of Data', 'Science and Technology', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Thyroid Gland', 'Dietary Supplements and Herbal Remedies']
abstract: A new column on science in the raw — data, that is; a historical view of battlefield fallout, as seen through a new collection at the Mütter Museum in Philadelphia; that supplement for your thyroid may be doing you more harm than good.
lead_paragraph: A new column on science in the raw — data, that is; a historical view of battlefield fallout, as seen through a new collection at the Mütter Museum in Philadelphia; that supplement for your thyroid may be doing you more harm than good.

headline: Inside Thyroid Supplements
abstract: That supplement for your thyroid may be doing you more harm than good.
lead_paragraph: That supplement for your thyroid may be doing you more harm than good.

headline: Law’s Expanded Medicaid Coverage Brings a Surge in Sign-Ups
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicaid', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The men and women getting coverage in West Virginia, one of the poorest states in the country, say the mere fact of having it has drastically improved their mental health.
lead_paragraph: WELCH, W.Va. — Sharon Mills, a disabled nurse, long depended on other people’s kindness to manage her diabetes. She scrounged free samples from doctors’ offices, signed up for drug company discounts and asked for money from her parents and friends. Her church often helped, but last month used its charitable funds to help repair other members’ furnaces.

headline: Thyroid Supplements With a Kick
abstract: Researchers have found that nine of 10 popular thyroid-boosting products sold online contained hormones that should only be dispensed by prescription.
lead_paragraph: Feeling sluggish? Having a hard time getting out of bed in the morning? Gaining weight?

headline: Paris Men’s Fashion Week: Saint Laurent Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Men’s Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Men’s Fashion Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: A Risk in Caring for Abusive Parents
abstract: Perhaps unsurprisingly, people caring for abusive parents are more likely to have symptoms of depression, a new study finds.
lead_paragraph: Who could condemn someone for staying far away from a parent, even an ailing or dying parent, who mistreated him or her as a child? The last time I wrote about this emotional subject, most readers understood that response. Many who had suffered through similar experiences said they had taken the same stance.

headline: He’s Traveling in First Class, but He’ll Still Look at Your Recipe
abstract: Alton Brown, a cookbook author and television host, flies commercial when he is not in his Cessna, and sometimes other fliers recognize him.
lead_paragraph: SINCE I’m in the food and entertainment business, practically all my flights are business-related, flying from Atlanta to either New York City or Los Angeles. I am a pilot and have my own eight-seater Cessna, and when I fly my own plane it’s spectacular. But there are positives when flying commercial.

headline: A Taste of My Own Manners
abstract: In past doctor-patient relationships, there was no question whose time took precedence and who was kept waiting. Thanks to technology, physicians are finding out what it feels like.
lead_paragraph: When I started my internship, in 1986, I was given a beeper, which was handed over with a certain sense of ceremony and a certain yoke of obligation. Before cellphones were omnipresent, the beeper was a badge of professional importance: I’m a doctor — life and death depend on my instant availability.

headline: Airline Hits Sour Notes With the Wait Times on Customer Calls
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Travel Agencies and Agents', 'Music', 'Business Travel', 'Customer Relations']
abstract: Listening to a tiny snippet of “Rhapsody in Blue” for hours on United’s customer service line is enough to drive a passenger to a travel agent.
lead_paragraph: AFTER George Gershwin’s “Rhapsody in Blue” was born, it became a classic of the Jazz Age. But if you ask me, it died this month. The cause was overwork. “Rhapsody” would have been 90 years old on Feb. 12, the anniversary of its first performance in 1924.

headline: China Exports Pollution to U.S., Study Finds
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Emissions from China’s export industries are carried across the Pacific and contribute to air pollution in the Western United States, according to a paper.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Filthy emissions from China’s export industries are carried across the Pacific Ocean and contribute to air pollution in the Western United States, according to a paper published Monday by a prominent American science journal.

headline: $28,000 a Night: Hotels Race to Attract Superrich Clientele
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Travel and Vacations', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: Hotels are competing with one another to create luxury suites for the extremely wealthy, who are willing to pay five-figure nightly rates.
lead_paragraph: In most hotels, luxury is measured by the thread count of the linens (minimum 400, please) or the brand of the bathroom toiletries. But for those at the highest end of the market, where the only restraint on consumption is how conspicuous they want to be, a race to the top has broken out, with hotels outdoing one another to serve this tiny, if highly visible, niche.

headline: Fighting a Cold
abstract: Effective prevention is the best remedy for the common cold, experts say, but failing that, symptoms can always be treated with rest and fluids.
lead_paragraph: Q. What’s the best remedy for a cold?

headline: What Does the Producers’ Tie Mean for the Season?
abstract: It’s clearer now that “Gravity,” “12 Years a Slave” and “American Hustle” lead the race for best picture. Perhaps the Directors Guild Awards next weekend will narrow the options.
lead_paragraph: “TIE AT THE PGA AWARDS!” went the alarm-bell tweet from Kris Tapley, a chronicler of the Oscar race at Hitfix’s In Contention blog. Since the news Sunday that “12 Years a Slave” and “Gravity” took home the Producers Guild top prize, awards prognosticators have been busy dissecting what it means for the season.

headline: Sundance Q. and A. | Astrid Bergès-Frisbey
abstract: This series introduces some of the standout, rising stars from the 2014 Sundance Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: This series introduces some of the standout, rising stars from the 2014 Sundance Film Festival.

headline: Canada Chooses Three Sisters for Its Olympic Skiing Team
abstract: The Dufour-Lapointes, who include Justine, 19, Chloé, 22, and Maxime, 24, are believed to be at least the fifth family to send at least three siblings to the Games.
lead_paragraph: The Dufour-Lapointe sisters grew up chasing one another down the ski slopes near Montreal, their hometown. But next month they will be chasing one another down the slopes at the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, as the three sisters — Maxime, Chloé and Justine — will all be members of Canada’s freestyle ski team.

headline: Yogurt Joins Super Bowl Snack Parade
abstract: Two brands of Greek-style yogurt, Chobani and Dannon Oikos, have bought commercial time during the game.
lead_paragraph: WHO would have thought X Super Bowls ago, or even V, that there could be as many commercials for yogurt during a game as for candy?

headline: ‘She. Herself. Naked.': The Art of He Chengyao
keywords: ['ACUPUNCTURE', 'Age, Chronological', 'Art', 'Buddhism', 'Elderly', 'Families and Family Life', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Parenting', 'Performance Art', 'Photography', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Her birth brought her mother punishment. Since then He Chengyao has spoken out artististically for a woman whose life was haunted by mental illness, in mother-daughter inspired works that involve a lot of nudity. For a reason.
lead_paragraph: Wearing only underpants, He Chengyao faces the camera, the long acupuncture needles sticking out of her body making her look somewhat like a human porcupine. The performance art piece, now a video and a photograph, is titled “99 Needles.”

headline: Texas Company, Alone in U.S., Cashes In on Nuclear Waste
abstract: Waste Control Specialists is the only company that will dispose of some categories of low-level waste for 95 nuclear reactors in 29 states.
lead_paragraph: ANDREWS, Tex. — Standing at the lip of what might be America’s most valuable hole in the ground, Rodney A. Baltzer cataloged the features that he said would isolate the radioactive waste to be buried here for thousands of years.

headline: Paris Couture Week: Atelier Versace Spring/Summer 2014

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

headline: For Spot in Artists’ Loft, Impress a Critic: The City
abstract: Those seeking lofts in SoHo and NoHo, two downtown Manhattan neighborhoods, must first persuade the city that they qualify as an artist.
lead_paragraph: About every other month, an obscure mini-committee of two artists meets behind closed doors at New York’s Department of Cultural Affairs on Chambers Street. In their hands are stacks of applications from self-described artists seeking formal certification from the city, giving the panel influence over millions of dollars in lucrative real estate deals.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Pakistan, China and the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Pakistan, China and the Philippines.

headline: Familiar Silhouette Is Quick to Dispel Shadow of Doubt
abstract: After missing most of the 2013 baseball season because of various injuries, the Yankees’ Derek Jeter said all was well after his first workout at the team’s training complex.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — On the back fields of the Yankees’ minor league complex Monday, the familiar silhouette of Derek Jeter was suddenly apparent, a sign that spring training could not be far away.

headline: The Final Frontier’s Financial Limits
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Space and Astronomy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As NASA waits on the coming year’s federal allotment, present and future missions hang in the budgetary balance.
lead_paragraph: A decade after swinging into orbit around Saturn, NASA’s venerable Cassini spacecraft is still working, well beyond the four years of science the space agency had hoped to get. But the spacecraft is running low on maneuvering fuel, and its managers want to end with a scientific bang — an ambitious agenda that includes 22 orbits through a gap between the planet and its innermost ring before sending the craft on a death plunge into Saturn in 2017.

headline: Art Matters | “The Mothership” Lands in Downtown Los Angeles
abstract: An all-female group show surveys L.A.’s burgeoning metaphysical-art movement.
lead_paragraph: Currently eight and a half months pregnant with her first child, the artist and curator Carly Jo Morgan has been exploring themes of motherhood since long before her own was imminent. Years ago, she designed a tribal-futurist “Mothership” collection for her jewelry line, All for the Mountain, that led to a commission from Sonia Rykiel. And recently, she became a certified birth doula. Now Morgan is co-curating a women’s art show, called “The Mothership,” which opened last Thursday at Dilettante, a creative incubator and event space at the edge of the Arts District in Downtown L.A. “I started thinking about the idea of a force that is guiding these vessels — these women and artists,” explains Morgan, who lives in a cabin in Topanga Canyon, of the show’s concept. “Being pregnant, I do feel very connected to the divine feminine. But growing a baby is also very sci-fi.”

headline: Longer Life Span Tied to Energy Use in Primates
abstract: According to a new study, primates burn about half as many calories per day as mammals of comparable size — and not simply because the other mammals are more active.
lead_paragraph: Most mammals reach adulthood within months and die in their teens or 20s. Not so with humans and other primates, which take years to become adults, then live for decades and reproduce infrequently.

headline: Manning Fans Swing Early Betting Line to Favor Broncos
abstract: Las Vegas sports books made Seattle the opening favorite, by up to 2 ½ points, but by Monday money was pouring in for Denver and its quarterback, Peyton Manning.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Who will win Super Bowl XLVIII? We will know in less than two weeks. Who should be the betting favorite? The oddsmakers and early bettors have differing opinions. Soon after the Seattle Seahawks dispatched the San Francisco 49ers in the N.F.C. championship game, they were made the favorites, by up to 2 ½ points, by a majority of sports books here.

headline: Giambattista Valli: Spring 2014 Couture
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: New Truths That Only One Can See
abstract: Replication, the gold standard of science, can help affirm the truth of a discovery, but it is getting harder all the time, raising questions about findings and unconscious bias.
lead_paragraph: Since 1955, The Journal of Irreproducible Results has offered “spoofs, parodies, whimsies, burlesques, lampoons and satires” about life in the laboratory. Among its greatest hits: “Acoustic Oscillations in Jell-O, With and Without Fruit, Subjected to Varying Levels of Stress” and “Utilizing Infinite Loops to Compute an Approximate Value of Infinity.” The good-natured jibes are a backhanded celebration of science. What really goes on in the lab is, by implication, of a loftier, more serious nature.

headline: Betting on the Handicappers, Not the Horses
abstract: Esquire Network begins the series “Horseplayers,” a reality show examining the same turf covered by the ill-fated HBO scripted series “Luck.”
lead_paragraph: Could it be that where mighty HBO failed, the fledgling Esquire Network has succeeded?

headline: For Revered Concertmaster, the Start of a Long Goodbye
abstract: Glenn Dicterow’s chamber music recital on Sunday at Alice Tully Hall revealed facets of his playing that don’t always come to the fore in an orchestral setting.
lead_paragraph: When you have served as concertmaster of the New York Philharmonic for 34 years, it is only appropriate that your farewell should be a drawn-out affair. Glenn Dicterow, who will retire from this post in June to take up a teaching position at the University of Southern California, is being celebrated with star billing throughout the Philharmonic’s season.

headline: ‘Extinct’ Shark Reappears, and Sochi Awaits Snow
keywords: ['Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Water Pollution', 'Sharks', 'Olympic Games (2014)', 'Drought', 'Trees and Shrubs']
abstract: Water was the watch word this week, with a drought tormenting California and residents of West Virginia still wary of the state’s drinking supply after a chemical spill.
lead_paragraph: There is no certainty in science, only knowns and unknowns. Last week, researchers reversed some conventional wisdom about trees. A shark species thought to be extinct turned up in a fish market — 48 times. And no one seemed sure how much to fear the chemical spilled into West Virginia drinking water. Just imagine what we won’t know next week.

headline: Knicks Are Baffled in Blowout Loss to Nets
abstract: Joe Johnson scored 25 points for the Nets, who have won seven of their last eight, and the Knicks, meanwhile, lost their fourth in a row.
lead_paragraph: The Nets began to set screens in the game’s opening minutes, and they never stopped. They set screens at the top of the key. They set screens near the left elbow. They set screens on Raymond Felton and Iman Shumpert, and the Knicks switched and scrambled. They could never figure it out.

headline: Bolshoi’s Balanchine, From Stage to Screen
abstract: The Bolshoi Ballet broadcast its take on Balanchine’s “Jewels” on Sunday in HD.
lead_paragraph: Sunday’s HD broadcast of George Balanchine’s pure-dance and full-length “Jewels,” live from the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow, was — though by no means without drawbacks — both newsworthy and artistically noteworthy. One historic aspect occurred not in the dancing but at intermission.

headline: A Five-Band Countdown to Goodbye
abstract: The Brooklyn music club 285 Kent has shut down, having left its mark on a scene that’s ever mutating.
lead_paragraph: “Hold on, I just want to Instagram this,” a young woman said to her friend as they stepped outside of 285 Kent on Sunday night for some fresh air, then stopped to regard the nondescript exterior of the building.

headline: Stark Reminders of How Uncivil a War It Was
abstract: A new exhibition in Philadelphia, with its ball forceps and Minié balls, offers visitors “a kick in the gut.”
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — More than 40 years after losing his right arm in the Civil War, Henry S. Huidekoper, a lieutenant colonel in the Union Army, had long since adjusted, and no longer found himself trying to reach for things or write with his missing hand.

headline: Guggenheim Is to Show Rare Murals by a Futurist
abstract: The Guggenheim’s Italian Futurism retrospective, opening next month, will be capped by rarely seen murals on loan from a post office in Sicily.
lead_paragraph: As a capstone to its coming show “Italian Futurism, 1909-1944: Reconstructing the Universe,” the Guggenheim Museum has managed a rare coup: securing the first loan of five major Futurist murals from the central post office in Palermo, Sicily, where they have hung since being commissioned for the space in the 1930s.

headline: Trying On the Ties That Bind
abstract: “Are You the One?” and “90 Day Fiancé” are among the new dating shows that, at a minimum, make a great setup for television.
lead_paragraph: Nothing better than being trapped in a house with your love, right? The extreme intimacy, the disintegration of private space, the presumption of omnipresence — those are the building blocks of a lasting relationship, no?

headline: An Attempt to Outdream a Surrealist
abstract: In “Forgiving the Angel,” the novelist Jay Cantor proffers four Kafkaesque stories based on real people in Kafka’s life.
lead_paragraph: “Kafkaesque” has become a strangely fuzzy and elastic adjective. It can be taken to mean anything from the vaguely surreal to the deeply anxiety-inducing, from the psychologically disorienting to the bureaucratically complex — anything that summons any sort of association with such classic Kafka works as “The Trial,” “The Castle” or “The Metamorphosis.”

headline: A Great Big World and Linnea Olsson Release Albums
abstract: New CDs include those from A Great Big World, Linnea Olsson and the Matt Wilson Quartet.
lead_paragraph: A GREAT BIG WORLD

headline: Seeing X Chromosomes in a New Light
keywords: ['DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Chromosomes', 'Women and Girls', 'Research', 'Biology and Biochemistry']
abstract: Scientists have enlisted color coding in the effort to better understand X chromosomes, how they are shut down in certain cells and what it all means for men and women.
lead_paragraph: The term “X chromosome” has an air of mystery to it, and rightly so. It got its name in 1891 from a baffled biologist named Hermann Henking. To investigate the nature of chromosomes, Henking examined cells under a simple microscope. All the chromosomes in the cells came in pairs.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,292 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 2,292 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: IBM Restarts Talks on Low-End Server Business
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: A sale would be the latest step in IBM’s evolution from a dominant producer of hardware like computers and servers into a company focused on providing services to governments and businesses.
lead_paragraph: IBM has restarted efforts to sell its low-end server business and is in talks with companies including Dell and Lenovo, two people briefed on the process said Monday.

headline: Poet’s Archive Goes to University of Texas
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'Archives and Records', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Billy Collins, a former United States poet laureate, can now claim another feather in his cap: a sale of his archive to the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas at Austin.
lead_paragraph: Billy Collins, a former United States poet laureate and the rare poet to send books onto the best-seller list, can now claim another feather in his cap: a sale of his archive to the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas at Austin, where his papers will sit beside collections of such greats as E. E. Cummings and T. S. Eliot. They include dozens of notebooks containing observations, notes, doodles, clippings and extensive drafts of poems, published and unpublished. There is also wide correspondence, audio and video recordings, childhood writings and diaries. Mr. Collins, 72, said by email that he had decided to sell his papers when he “started making a mental pile” and realized just how much material there was, including more than a few jottings on cocktail napkins, envelopes and other scraps. “I remember one occasion when the lines of a poem occurred to me while I was walking around the city with no pen and nothing to write on,” he said. “So I ducked into a bank and started writing the poem, standing up, on the backs of deposit slips. I used the bank pen that was attached to a desk with a chain, all of which made for a rather short poem. I tried to look very serious as if I were making a monster deposit.”

headline: In Performance: Peggy Shaw
abstract: The Obie-winning performer and writer Peggy Shaw performs a scene from her solo piece “Ruff,” about her life before and after a stroke. The show is at La MaMa.
lead_paragraph: The Obie-winning performer and writer Peggy Shaw performs a scene from her solo piece “Ruff,” about her life before and after a stroke. The show is at La MaMa.

headline: U.N. Dispute Brings West Bank Differences to the Fore
abstract: Amid a United Nations strike that has brought food aid and education to a standstill, West Bank refugees are calling on the Palestinian Authority to take responsibility for their welfare.
lead_paragraph: JALAZOUN REFUGEE CAMP, West Bank — The children roaming the alleys of this Palestinian refugee camp north of Ramallah have been out of school for seven weeks. Food distribution is at a standstill, as are the camp’s regular health services. This crowded, concrete warren of roughly 15,000 residents is seething with anger.

headline: War Crimes Experts Call Syrian Defector’s Photographs ‘Direct Evidence’ of Assad’s ‘Killing Machine’
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: A team of legal and forensic experts concluded that post-mortem photographs, provided to the Syrian opposition by a man who describes himself as a defector from President Bashar al-Assad’s security forces, offer “direct evidence” of torture and execution.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, Wednesday, Jan. 22 | Thousands of post-mortem photographs of scarred, emaciated corpses, provided to the Syrian opposition by a man who describes himself as a defector from the security forces of President Bashar al-Assad, appear to offer “direct evidence” of torture and execution on a mass scale, a team of legal and forensic experts concluded in a report made public on Monday.

headline: At Least 2 Die in Omaha After Explosion and Fire
keywords: ['Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Fires and Firefighters', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: Ten people were taken to local hospitals, four of them in critical condition, according to Bernard J. Kanger Jr., Omaha’s interim fire chief. Seven others were injured but did not go to the hospital, he said.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA — At least two people were killed and more than a dozen injured here on Monday after part of a plant that manufactures food supplements for animals collapsed, burst into flames and set off a struggle for survival for those trying to escape the crushing debris.

headline: A Popular Chinese Social Networking App Blazes Its Own Path
abstract: Weixin, a fast-growing app from the Chinese Internet company Tencent, is no mere copy of any existing service, and its success may thwart Facebook’s ambitions in China.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Every half-hour or so, Jenny Zhao, young and wired, unlocks her iPhone 5 to connect with friends using Weixin, China’s wildly popular social messaging app.

headline: Deutsche Bank Loss Underlines European Economy’s Dependence on Banks
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Company Reports', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Government Bonds', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The state Deutsche Bank and other financial institutions in Europe is crucial for the economy because European companies are more dependent on bank credit than American businesses.
lead_paragraph: With its surprise report of a billion-euro fourth-quarter loss, Deutsche Bank has provided another reminder that the financial crisis has never really ended for European banks — raising questions about whether the Continental economy can recover before they do.

headline: At Midway Point, Sundance Lacks Bidding Wars
abstract: By the fifth day of the 10-day Sundance Film Festival, with distributors having sampled about 50 films, movies have been selling on the cheap.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah – By Monday, the fifth day of the 10-day Sundance Film Festival here, distributors had sampled about 50 films and decided – so far, at least — that none required an instant bidding war and a Brink’s truck.

headline: Theft of Data Fuels Worries in South Korea
abstract: A string of senior executives at three credit card companies offered to resign on Monday after a huge theft of client data may have affected 20 million people.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — A string of senior executives at three credit card companies in South Korea offered to resign on Monday after a huge theft of client data that may have affected 20 million people in this nation of 50 million.

headline: Syria: 14 Companies Bid to Destroy Chemical Weapons
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The companies, including four from the United States, have bid for contracts to eradicate 500 tons of chemicals in Syria’s munitions stockpile.
lead_paragraph: Fourteen private companies, including four from the United States, have bid for contracts to eradicate 500 tons of chemicals in Syria’s munitions stockpile, as well as to destroy the residue from the most dangerous poisons that are to be neutralized at sea, the organization responsible for helping to oversee the elimination of the arsenal said Monday.

headline: Boston Fed’s Latest Role: Community Organizer
abstract: The Federal Reserve Bank of Boston funneled $1.8 million from outside donors to help turn around some of the Massachusetts’ most depressed midsize cities.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Economists do not tend to be social activists. And that is especially true if they work for the Federal Reserve, let alone run one of its 12 regional banks.

headline: Japan: New Leak Detected at Crippled Reactor
keywords: ['Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Radiation', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Water Pollution', 'Nuclear Energy']
abstract: Highly radioactive water found in a reactor building at the Fukushima nuclear plant indicates that the reactor’s containment vessel was breached during the accident, the plant’s operator said Monday.
lead_paragraph: Highly radioactive water found in a reactor building at the destroyed Fukushima nuclear plant offers new evidence that the reactor’s containment vessel was breached during the accident, the plant’s operator said Monday. The operator, the Tokyo Electric Power Company, said a remote-controlled robot had found water on the floor of the heavily contaminated No. 3 reactor building that was even more radioactive than expected. The high radiation level suggests that the water had leaked from inside the reactor itself, where it would have come in contact with the melted-down fuel core. Nearly three years after the accident, the exact condition of the plant’s three damaged reactors remains unclear since high radiation levels and flooding make it impossible for workers to inspect them.

headline: When One Party Controls the Day
abstract: Readers respond to the “One-Party Rule” series.

headline: A Globe-Trotting Serial Entrepreneur Finds Roots in China’s Start-Up Scene
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Mobile Applications', 'Start-ups']
abstract: Richard Robinson has spent more than a dozen years in Beijing, where he has mainly focused on mobile Internet and gaming.
lead_paragraph: Richard Robinson tended bar in the Virgin Islands, taught English in Prague, picked grapes in France, painted houses in Norway and toiled at a BMW factory in Munich. But little prepared him for the adventure that awaited him in Hong Kong.

headline: Obstacles on the Road to Mideast Democracy
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Constitutions', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat"]
abstract: Readers including Jacob Bender of the Council on American Islamic Relations respond to an editorial.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Greece: Prison Escapee Vows to Fight Again
abstract: Christodoulos Xiros, a leftist guerrilla who walked away from prison while on furlough this month, on Monday announced his return to terrorism.
lead_paragraph: A leftist Greek guerrilla who walked away from a prison while on furlough this month announced his return to terrorism on Monday. The fugitive, Christodoulos Xiros, did so in an online video and letter, in which he called on “comrades of armed action” to unite to protest the repercussions of three years of economic austerity in Greece. “Once again I have taken the decision to thunder the guerrilla rifle against those who stole our lives and sold our dreams for a profit,” the letter said. It was dated Jan. 14 and signed by Mr. Xiros, who described himself as “a free member of November 17,” once considered Greece’s deadliest terrorist organization. Mr. Xiros, 55, was serving multiple life terms at the Korydallos Prison near Athens for a series of attacks carried out by the group, chiefly against Greek, British and American business and political targets over nearly three decades. He has been at large since failing to return from a nine-day furlough that began on Jan. 1.

headline: U.S. Plans Naval Backup for Olympics
keywords: ['Olympic Games (2014)', 'Terrorism', 'Evacuations and Evacuees', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Two Navy warships will be in the Black Sea during the Olympics in Sochi, Russia, next month, should they be needed to evacuate Americans, a Pentagon official said.
lead_paragraph: The American military’s European Command is drawing up plans to have two Navy warships in the Black Sea at the time of the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, next month, should they be needed to evacuate Americans in the event of a terrorist attack or any other emergency, a Pentagon official said Monday. American transport planes would also be on the call in the region. So far, the Pentagon has not put the plans into effect, although that order could come in a matter of days, the official said. The ships are to be passing through the region as part of a regularly scheduled deployment, and the planes would remain at their bases, probably in Europe, until ordered to help. The planning was first reported by CNN on Monday. The State Department would coordinate any evacuation of Americans. Any plans to use the American ships or planes would be done in coordination with and with permission from Russia, American officials said.

headline: Cuomo and Attorney General Agree on Division of JPMorgan Funds
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Eric T. Schneiderman, New York State’s attorney general, will split $163 million of the $613 million settlement the state received over JPMorgan Chase’s mortgage-lending practices.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Eric T. Schneiderman, New York State’s attorney general, have reached an agreement on how to divide a big piece of the $613 million the state received as part of a securities settlement with JPMorgan Chase.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Racers Unhappy With a 1-2-3 Finish by Mini at the Dakar Rally
abstract: Mini issues team orders and stirs up a dispute, and Bryan Clauson takes a midget car win at Tulsa.
lead_paragraph: Nani Roma of Spain celebrated an anticlimactic and controversial victory in the two-week-long Dakar Rally, which ended Saturday near Valparaíso, Chile. Roma had taken the lead in the rally during the first week, but his teammate, Stephane Peterhansel, the 11-time Dakar winner and defending champion, gradually cut Roma’s lead from 39 minutes to just two minutes by Wednesday. Another teammate, Nassar Al-Attiyah, ran in third place.

headline: Treatment for Addiction
abstract: Dr. Thomas Farley, the departing New York City health commissioner, responds to a news article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Michigan: Study Disputes Stray Dog Numbers
abstract: Preliminary findings from a survey of Detroit’s stray dog population estimated that the city has fewer than 3,000 loose dogs on its streets on any given day.
lead_paragraph: Preliminary findings from a survey of Detroit’s stray dog population estimated that the city has fewer than 3,000 loose dogs on its streets on any given day. The count was made public on Monday by the World Animal Awareness Society, which used volunteers to collect data from around the city last year. It challenges previous reports that as many as 50,000 abandoned dogs live in vacant homes in Detroit. Tom McPhee, the executive director of the survey group, said more attention should be focused on responsible pet ownership.

headline: Still Committed to Haiti
abstract: The United States ambassador to Haiti disagrees with an editorial suggesting that other countries have forsaken it.

headline: School Lockdown Drills
abstract: A reader recalls the school drills of the Cold War era.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Make Legal Memos Public
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Marc Rotenberg and Julia Horwitz of the Electronic Privacy Information Center respond to an editorial.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Demand Grows for Hogs That Are Raised Humanely Outdoors
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Pigs', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Restaurants']
abstract: Some farmers are raising their pigs more humanely in wide open spaces, instead of tight quarters, and selling them to restaurants and grocers increasingly interested in how animals are treated.
lead_paragraph: SHUSHAN, N.Y. — Turn down the road to Flying Pigs Farm here, and two or three of Michael Yezzi’s pigs are probably standing in the middle of it.

headline: The Obama-Bush Nexus
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: Our last two presidents entered a profession of crowds and commotion without a robust appetite for either.
lead_paragraph: Our current president and his predecessor in the Oval Office are typically cast as opposites, antonyms, not just far apart on an ideological spectrum but cats of wholly different stripes.

headline: Notable in Their Absence From Davos
abstract: The leaders of some of the largest and most transformative companies are demonstrating, with their absence, the difficulty of convening a global conversation with all the main stakeholders, writes Andrew Ross Sorkin.
lead_paragraph: The annual parade of boldface names at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, is always striking. This year’s attendees at the meeting, which begins Wednesday, will include Japan’s prime minister, Shinzo Abe; the billionaire Bill Gates; JPMorgan Chase’s chief executive, Jamie Dimon; and the movie star-philanthropist Matt Damon.

headline: Burke and Hardaway Gone, Yet Michigan Rolls On
abstract: Missing two of the stars who carried them to the N.C.A.A. championship game last season, the Wolverines put their trust in a pair of young players: Glenn Robinson III and Nik Stauskas.
lead_paragraph: AUBURN HILLS, Mich. — Trey Burke’s Michigan homecoming Friday night began with pregame jitters, followed by a lonely walk onto the court and then an early exit to the bench.

headline: Scottsdale Classic Car Auctions Total $249 Million, Improving on 2013 Results
abstract: The top two sales in Arizona last week were 1958 Ferrari 250 GT models.
lead_paragraph: Scottsdale, Ariz. — The opening sales of the 2014 classic-car auction season, which took place here last week, often set the market direction for the year. This year’s sales, according to a tally compiled by Hagerty, an insurer of vintage vehicles, totalled $249 million, up from $224 million in 2013 (2,815 lots sold, compared with 2,699 last year). The average sale was $107,096, up from $100,176 a year ago.

headline: Canadian Company Behind Bike-Sharing Programs Seeks Bankruptcy Protection
abstract: Bixi, which designs and builds bike-sharing systems used around the world, owes the city of Montreal millions of dollars.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — The Canadian company that designs and builds the bicycles and supporting technology for bike-sharing systems around the world, including those in New York and London, sought bankruptcy protection on Monday.

headline: Does Brazil Have the Answer?
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Income Inequality', 'Poverty', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy']
abstract: As income inequality gets worse in the United States, it is falling in Brazil.
lead_paragraph: Not long after I got back from my recent trip to Brazil, I called some economists to gain a better understanding of where the country stood economically. To me, Rio de Janeiro felt a little like Shanghai: there was plenty of high-end shopping in neighborhoods like Ipanema — and plenty of poverty in the favelas, or slums. There was also a lot in between. What is most striking to a visitor is how many middle-class citizens there seem to be. Cars were everywhere; traffic jams, I’ve come to believe, are a sign of a growing middle class. It means people have enough money to buy automobiles.

headline: A Tragedy on 10th Avenue
abstract: Firefighters, coming up the same stairwell the victims were using to descend from above, entered the fire floor, and opened the stair doors and the apartment door, sending the smoke up as if through a chimney.
lead_paragraph: Firefighters, coming up the same stairwell the victims were using to descend from above, entered the fire floor, and opened the stair doors and the apartment door, sending the smoke up as if through a chimney.

headline: Pre-K on the Starting Blocks
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s ambitious plan to provide preschool education to every 4-year-old brings high expectations.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s plan to offer full-day preschool to every New York City 4-year-old hasn’t yet rounded the corner from election slogan to classroom reality. But it’s moving: a public-relations campaign on Friday started blitzing the city with leaflets and emails to drum up support for the tax to pay for it.

headline: Manning Is on the Verge of the Sublime
abstract: If the Broncos win the Super Bowl, Peyton Manning could be granted iconic status in two cities, something rarely achieved in the N.F.L.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Peyton Manning may not need another Super Bowl victory to solidify his place in football history, although his lingering detractors might suggest otherwise. But if there is debate about whether Manning’s legacy could use a boost, there is no doubt that a defeat of the Seattle Seahawks in Super Bowl XLVIII will elevate him to an unparalleled position in the game.

headline: Counterintuitive Advice When You Hear ‘Fire!’ in a High-Rise: Stay Put
keywords: ['Fires and Firefighters', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Fire experts say residents of buildings made of fire-retardant materials should stay put when there is a fire, because the fire will probably not spread.
lead_paragraph: The first clang of the alarm came as many residents of the modern high-rise in Hell’s Kitchen, Manhattan, were sitting down to brunch or opening the Sunday paper. Quickly came the screams — “Fire!”— and an acrid smoke that blackened windows and seeped under doors and through air vents. Few knew exactly where in the 42-story building the fire was. Some tried and failed to reach 911 operators, who were overwhelmed by calls. Many decided to flee.

headline: A Potentially Harmful Merger
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Editorials', 'Food', 'Restaurants']
abstract: Sysco’s proposed acquisition of US Foods could lead to higher prices for restaurant meals and significantly reduce competition among suppliers.
lead_paragraph: A proposed merger between two of the largest suppliers of food to restaurants, hotels and school cafeterias could significantly reduce competition and drive up prices of the meals Americans eat outside their homes. Of all the money consumers spend on food, nearly half is spent at restaurants.

headline: The Art of Presence
abstract: One family’s trauma offers valuable lessons on how to comfort those in pain.
lead_paragraph: Tragedy has twice visited the Woodiwiss family. In 2008, Anna Woodiwiss, then 27, was working for a service organization in Afghanistan. On April 1, she went horseback riding and was thrown, dying from her injuries. In 2013, her younger sister Catherine, then 26, was biking to work from her home in Washington. She was hit by a car and her face was severely smashed up. She has endured and will continue to endure a series of operations. For a time, she breathed and ate through a tube, unable to speak. The recovery is slow.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 20, 2014
abstract: Winning Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Detention Must Be Paid
keywords: ['Immigration Detention', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Unemployment Insurance']
abstract: Congress won’t pay to extend unemployment insurance, but it can find billions of dollars to hunt down illegal immigrants.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans can’t find work and have lost their unemployment benefits because Congressional Republicans insist the government can’t afford to help them. But there is no shortage of money when it comes to hunting down unauthorized immigrants.

headline: Saratoga Springs Doesn’t Need a Casino
abstract: Though voters in New York approved a constitutional amendment to allow casinos, local residents should have the right to say: not in our town.
lead_paragraph: Early this summer, New Yorkers can expect to see proposals for four new casinos upstate. Some communities in the Catskills and Western New York are ready to welcome these gambling meccas, especially if they come with good jobs, as promised.

headline: Otis G. Pike, 92, Dies; Long Island Congressman Took On C.I.A.
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Mr. Pike was a long-term congressman from Long Island who spearheaded an inquiry in the 1970s into accusations that the intelligence establishment had abused its power.
lead_paragraph: Otis G. Pike, a longtime congressman from New York who spearheaded an inquiry in the 1970s into accusations that the intelligence establishment had abused its power, died on Monday in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 92.

headline: How to Compensate Victims of Terrorism
abstract: Sometimes the U.S. government sets aside money for victims of mass violence. More often, survivors and families pursue lawsuits and receive private donations. Which is more fair?

headline: Hollande’s Romances Turn Into a Political Spectacle in France
abstract: François Hollande once vowed to be on his most exemplary behavior as president of France. But an affair has exposed a more politically calculating side and threatens to undercut his economic agenda.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — As a candidate for the French presidency in 2012, François Hollande promised to be more boring spouse than flamboyant seducer.

headline: An Athlete for Two Seasons Can Double Up on Games
abstract: Lolo Jones and Lauryn Williams are part of a group of athletes pulling the Summer Olympic-Winter Olympic double, a feat that lies recorded deep in the history books.
lead_paragraph: With the Winter Games in Sochi, Russia, set to begin in less than three weeks, Olympic human interest tales are beginning to pile up almost as fast as security concerns.

headline: A Widow Finds Solace in Rescuing Kittens
abstract: After losing two husbands to illness, Maureen Brown, 61, began fostering abandoned kittens.
lead_paragraph: Maureen Brown can tell stories about kittens. Happy stories, sad stories, funny stories.

headline: Carroll Addresses the Tension Over Sherman’s Postgame Actions
abstract: Seattle Seahawks Coach Pete Carroll said he spoke to Richard Sherman about his emotional outburst, and Sherman later apologized for funneling attention toward him instead of his team.
lead_paragraph: RENTON, Wash. — Before their game against the Giants on Dec. 15, the Seattle Seahawks stayed at a Westin hotel in Jersey City. That is where the N.F.C. representative will be staying for the Super Bowl, and Coach Pete Carroll wanted his players to get acclimated for their return.

headline: In New Jersey, Leader of an Agency Under Investigation Is Given a Judge’s Robe
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie recently paused in his war over traffic cones, traffic jams and accusations of political retribution to nominate a few men as judges on the state’s Superior Court.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie recently paused in his war over traffic cones, gargantuan traffic jams and accusations of political retribution to nominate a few men as judges on the state’s Superior Court.

headline: 2 Birthdays and 2 Ends of the Income Spectrum
abstract: On Monday’s holiday, the Obama family prepared food for the homeless, and two nights before, they celebrated the first lady’s birthday with a star-studded party.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama has pledged to use the remainder of his presidency to address income inequality, which he calls “the defining challenge of our time.” This holiday weekend, Mr. Obama had an intimate look at how vast wealth disparities in America have become.

headline: Elderly Patrons End Dispute With a McDonald’s in Queens
abstract: A group of older Koreans, who the restaurant in Flushing said spent too much time seated there, can now stay there for as long as they want, except from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m.
lead_paragraph: A group of elderly Korean patrons has reached an agreement with the owner of a McDonald’s in Queens to avoid the restaurant during busy lunch hours, ending a dispute over whether they were spending too much time seated at tables drinking coffee.

headline: Old Job Is Hurdle for Napolitano on Campuses
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Deportation', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: On campuses filled with foreign-born students, Janet Napolitano, who was named president of the University of California last summer, faces anger over her role in the Obama administration’s deportation of 1.9 million unauthorized immigrants.
lead_paragraph: SANTA BARBARA, Calif. — The choice sounded ingenious: Take a high-profile political figure — a former governor and cabinet member — and have her apply her acumen to the task of rebuilding one of the great public university systems ravaged by decades of eroding state support.

headline: Schools Deputy to Run Bank Street College
abstract: Shael Polakow-Suransky was once considered a candidate to be schools chancellor, but his strong ties to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg made that unlikely.
lead_paragraph: Shael Polakow-Suransky, who helped lead an overhaul of city schools under former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and became an advocate of more rigorous and routine testing, will become the next president of Bank Street College of Education, the school will announce on Tuesday.

headline: Super Sunday, and the Crowd Goes, Um, Silent
abstract: When the Seattle Seahawks and the Denver Broncos meet in the Super Bowl on Feb. 2 at MetLife Stadium, the high-decibel help of their hometown crowds will be missing.
lead_paragraph: Fans of the Seattle Seahawks collectively call themselves the 12th Man, an extra player with a noise level so pounding at their home stadium that seismologists have recorded minor earthquakes during big plays.

headline: Johnson’s Versatility Is Driving the Nets
abstract: As the Nets have surged to a 7-1 record since the start of 2014, this has been the blueprint that Coach Jason Kidd has followed: Get the ball into Joe Johnson’s hands and let him get to work.
lead_paragraph: The last basket that Joe Johnson sank on Monday afternoon — a wide-open, 27-foot 3-pointer — spurred the first faint “Brooklyn” chants inside Madison Square Garden as the Nets flagellated the Knicks, 103-80.

headline: Parties Seize on Abortion Issues in Midterm Race
abstract: Abortion is becoming an unexpectedly animating issue in the 2014 midterm races, with Republicans using it to stoke enthusiasm among core supporters and Democrats looking to rally female voters.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Republican National Committee gathers for its winter meeting here on Wednesday, the action will start a few hours late to accommodate anyone who wants to stop first at the March for Life, the annual anti-abortion demonstration on the National Mall. And if they need a lift to the meeting afterward, they can hop on a free shuttle, courtesy of the Republican Party.

headline: As Community Mourns, Police Search for Father of 2 Dead Toddlers
keywords: ['Domestic Violence', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The police said two children were found dead from multiple stab wounds on Sunday night at their home in Jamaica, Queens; officers found their mother on the floor of a separate bedroom.
lead_paragraph: Deisy Garcia was not just a member of her church, Iglesia Naciones Unidas en Cristo. She was one of its pearls — one of 11 dancers in the group Rosas de Sarón, a team of women who performed five dances each Sunday.

headline: For New York City’s First Lady, a Chief of Staff but Still No Defined Role
abstract: A top aide to the Rev. Al Sharpton will be the chief of staff to Chirlane McCray, wife of Mayor Bill de Blasio, a signal of the scope of Ms. McCray’s yet-to-be-announced position.
lead_paragraph: A top aide to the Rev. Al Sharpton will serve as the chief of staff to Mayor Bill de Blasio’s wife, Chirlane McCray, as the couple finalizes plans for Ms. McCray to take an unusually active role in her husband’s administration.

headline: Accused of Blurring Facts of Stirring Life Story, Texas Lawmaker Offers Chronology
abstract: Wendy Davis, a Texas state senator, released a chronology of her life after a Dallas newspaper said that she had blurred some details about her past.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Wendy Davis, the Texas state senator who has shaped her campaign for governor largely around her story of rising from a teenage single mother to a Harvard law graduate, released a chronology of her life on Monday after a Dallas newspaper said that she had blurred some details about her past.

keywords: ['Dolphins and Porpoises', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The new American ambassador, Caroline Kennedy, had pointedly criticized the “drive hunt,” in which dolphins are herded into an area from where they cannot escape.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Japanese government Monday defended the practice of dolphin hunting off its coastline, taking issue with the new American ambassador, Caroline Kennedy, who pointedly criticized its “inhumaneness” in a recent Twitter post.

headline: You Don’t Have to Be Jewish to Love a Kosher Prison Meal
keywords: ['Kosher Foods and Products', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']

lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Captive diners know that a good meal is hard to find.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, January 21, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, January 21, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “Is bread and water considered kosher? Just a thought. Just a thought.”

headline: The Roots of the Tax Reform Act of 1986, Part I
abstract: Tax reform is long overdue, and lessons on how to go about it can be learned from the Tax Reform Act of 1986, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform — Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Truck Hits Bronx House, Killing Driver
abstract: A three-story house on Cedar Avenue was destroyed in the crash Monday evening and nearby buildings were evacuated; five people were injured, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A concrete pump truck crashed into a home in the Bronx on Monday evening, killing the driver and destroying the front of the building.

headline: What’s on Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13, 49) SALINGER (2013) With Paul Alexander’s book “Salinger” as his starting point, Shane Salerno layers biographical material with archival photographs, re-enactments and interviews with high school students, celebrities and even murderers to shed light on J. D. Salinger, above — from his World War II experiences and relationships with younger women to his decision to live in a fortress of privacy. Philip Seymour Hoffman, Edward Norton, John Cusack, Martin Sheen, Tom Wolfe and Gore Vidal offer perspective. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called the film, presented here by “American Masters,” “less a work of cinema than the byproduct of its own publicity campaign.” He added: “It does not so much explore the life and times of J. D. Salinger as run his memory and legacy through a spin cycle of hype. Salinger moved to the woods of New Hampshire partly to escape the intrusions and indignities of American celebrity culture. ‘Salinger’ is that culture’s revenge.”

headline: Shanghai Doctor Dies of Bird Flu
abstract: Investigators are trying to determine if the doctor had contact with poultry or live birds, as in most previous H7N9 cases, or if he might have contracted the disease from a patient.
lead_paragraph: Shanghai health officials say that a doctor has died of H7N9 bird flu, adding to concerns about a recent upturn in the disease’s spread in China.

headline: For Aam Aadmi Interns, Politics Involves Paperwork and Occasional Screaming Protest
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Elections', 'Internships', 'Law Schools', 'Mentors', 'Parties (Social)', 'Social Media']
abstract: The promise of a good internship experience has drawn over 200 students to the party’s Mumbai chapter since November.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI – In the second week of his internship with the Aam Aadmi Party, Nitish Sharma, a final-year law student, found himself in a crowd of men wearing white Gandhi caps at the gates of Raj Bhavan, the Maharashtra state governor’s sparkling mansion perched on the edge of the Arabian Sea.

headline: For Micah’s Birthday, His Grandfather’s Blessing
keywords: ['Dementia', 'Families and Family Life', 'Grandparents', 'Baby Boomers', 'Retirement Communities and Assisted Living']
abstract: Irving and his grandson Micah share a special bond that Irving’s age and dementia cannot break.
lead_paragraph: At 91, my father, Irving Effron, can barely remember his children’s names, though he has acute recollections of long-forgotten battles that he fought as a Marine in the Philippines during World War II. My mother, Ruth, grieves for the loss of the guy who swept her off her feet on a Rockaway beach the summer after he came home from the war. That guy was here up until a few years ago, when dementia set in and Irving’s rare good days became something to cherish, even as his bad days became more numerous.

headline: In China, a Week Full of Trials Over Dissent
abstract: At least seven citizens are due to stand trial for participating in the New Citizens Movement and other protest groups.

headline: 32 Arrests at Rally for Airport Workers Near La Guardia
abstract: Demonstrators called for a paid holiday for airport workers on Martin Luther King Jr.’s birthday.
lead_paragraph: The police arrested 32 people outside La Guardia Airport on Monday afternoon at a march in support of airport contract workers having a paid holiday on Martin Luther King Jr.’s birthday.

headline: Pakistan Goes After Militants in Northwest
abstract: The Pakistani government has come under increasing pressure to destroy militant bases after a series of recent attacks.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistani jets pounded suspected militant hide-outs in North Waziristan on Monday night for the first time in years, signaling that the government was prepared to take the fight to the center of the insurgency that has racked Pakistan. There were at least 40 casualties in the airstrikes.

headline: A Conversation With: Author Jerry Pinto
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Language and Languages', 'Man Booker Prize', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Mr. Pinto spoke with India Ink at the Jaipur Literature Festival about the long process of writing his first novel, “Em and the Big Hoom,” and how mental illnesses are treated in India.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Pinto’s first novel, “Em and the Big Hoom,” referring to the narrator’s nicknames for his parents, was released last year after decades of introspection and dozens of scrapped drafts. In the years he was working on the novel, he also published 14 works of nonfiction and poetry, as well as worked as a journalist in his native city of Mumbai. India’s biggest names in literature have heaped praise upon his fiction debut, although in reality his novel straddles an immensely porous border between fiction and memoir.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Reconsidering Life Sentences for Juvenile Offenders
abstract: How have state justice systems responded to two recent Supreme Court rulings about the use of mandatory life sentences for juveniles convicted of crimes like murder?
lead_paragraph: In “Juveniles Facing Lifelong Terms Despite Rulings,” Erik Eckholm writes about the question of mandatory life sentences for juveniles convicted of murder in the United States.

headline: Human Rights Watch Criticizes Inaction on Syria
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Torture', 'International Relations']
abstract: In its annual report, Human Rights Watch said the desire to bring the Syrian government to peace talks should not be a pretext for failure to shield civilians.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The advocacy group Human Rights Watch sharply criticized international powers on Tuesday for the way they are dealing with the civil war in Syria, saying that the desire to bring President Bashar al-Assad’s government to the negotiating table should not become a pretext for failing to protect civilians caught in the conflict, which has claimed more than 100,000 lives.

headline: Agitating for Justice and Freedom With a Camera
abstract: Over the course of his photographic career, Danny Lyon has seen his role as coaxing his fellow man to pursue justice and freedom, whether or not it’s popular or lucrative.
lead_paragraph: Like an Old Testament prophet, the photographer Danny Lyon has agitated for his fellow man to pursue justice and freedom. This was not always a popular message, nor a lucrative one, but that wasn’t how he saw his role.

headline: Do You Apologize Too Much?
abstract: How can you break a speech pattern like constantly saying, “I’m sorry”?
lead_paragraph: Most of us say things like “um,” “you know” and “like” as meaningless conversational filler, but in a recent essay, one woman writes in The Times about realizing how often she said “sorry” — and how she broke the habit.

keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Bombs and Explosives']

lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A suicide bomber blew himself up early Tuesday in a neighborhood in south Beirut where the Shiite militia and political party Hezbollah holds sway, the most recent in a series of such attacks that have targeted civilian areas across Lebanon in recent months.

headline: In Files, a History of Sexual Abuse by Priests in Chicago Archdiocese
abstract: Most of the abuse was alleged to have taken place years ago and about half of the accused priests are dead, but the victims have argued that the documents will provide a public reckoning.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — One priest, the Rev. William J. Cloutier, was accused of raping a boy in his summer cottage, locking the door when the 13-year-old started screaming, and then brandishing a handgun while threatening to kill him if he told anyone. Another, the Rev. Robert C. Becker, would take boys to a trailer where, they said, he slept beside them and molested them. And the Rev. Joseph R. Bennett was accused of raping a girl with the handle of a paten, a plate used to hold eucharistic bread.

headline: Bosnia’s Lessons for Syria
abstract: Civil war is hard to end. Before Dayton, there were four failed peace plans.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — DESPITE the last-minute diplomatic row over the cancellation of the United Nations’ invitation to Iran, the “Geneva II” peace talks between the government of Bashar al-Assad and the Syrian opposition are scheduled to start today, with support from NATO members and Russia. But the process faces daunting challenges.

headline: Daily Report: Homegrown Social App Dominates Chinese Market
abstract: Weixin, a fast-growing app from the Chinese Internet company Tencent, is no mere copy of any existing service, and its success may thwart Facebook’s ambitions in China.
lead_paragraph: Weixin (pronounced way-shin) is this country’s killer app, a highly addictive social networking tool that allows smartphone users to send messages and share news, photos, videos and web links, much like America’s WhatsApp, or Line, a Japanese communications and messaging app. In the United States, a similar version is known as WeChat, David Barboza reports.

headline: Peaceful Swiss Resort Takes On Troubles of Syrian War
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'International Relations']
abstract: The expectant melancholy typical of resort towns in the winter has given way in Montreux to something edgier as it gears up for Syrian peace talks.
lead_paragraph: MONTREUX, Switzerland — The expectant melancholy typical of resort towns in the winter has given way here, at least in the center of this lakeside village, to something edgier, as if a piece of the Green Zone had levitated here from Baghdad.

headline: Why 2013 Was Our Best Year Ever (Except for One Crucial Metric)
abstract: We ended the year with less cash on hand than when we started, and that was thanks to the government shutdown.
lead_paragraph: January has rolled around again, and it’s time for me to take stock of how my business performed in 2013. This has been an annual event for me (these are my corresponding posts for 2012, 2011, and 2010).  And this is the executive summary: great year! In fact, it was the best ever — with the exception of one important metric.

headline: Work Weekends and Long Hours, Fund Manager Advises Young Bankers
abstract: Randall Dillard, managing director and chief investment officer at Liongate Capital Management, offered this advice to young bankers: be ready to work incredibly hard, but steer clear of private equity.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Credit Suisse may be encouraging its young bankers to shun the office on weekends if they are not working on a big deal. And Goldman Sachs might have a “junior banker task force” to examine how to make the lives of lower-ranking analysts and associates more efficient and humane.

headline: The Nobility of Men’s Wear
abstract: Hermès, Berluti and Dior Homme blend the traditional with the technical skills of today.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “Noble” is a weird word to use for a modern male wardrobe. Some of the clothes are bound to be sporty, rather than the familiar uniform of smart suits and military coats once associated with a nobleman.

headline: Who’s In and Who’s Out at Davos
abstract: The World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, is as notable for its absentees as for its attendees. | Deutsche Bank’s $1 billion fourth-quarter loss has European markets on edge. | IBM is renewing efforts to sell its server business. | Anheuser-Busch buys back s South Korean brewer.
lead_paragraph: The World Economic Forum in Davos, which begins this Wednesday, is as notable for its attendees as for its absentees, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column. While this year’s guest list includes prime ministers, chief executives of some of the largest financial institutions and at least one movie star, others in the financial world’s inner circle are, perhaps surprisingly, electing not to go to Switzerland.

headline: A Conversation With: Graphic Novelist Vishwajyoti Ghosh
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Comic Books and Strips', 'Graphic Novels', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: At the Jaipur Literature Festival, Mr. Ghosh spoke with India Ink about what it means for younger generations to retell the history of Partition in a graphic format.
lead_paragraph: Vishwajyoti Ghosh, a graphic novelist and artist based in Delhi, is curator of the book “This Side That Side: Restorying Partition,” an anthology of graphic narratives from India, Pakistan and Bangladesh. His first graphic novel, “Delhi Calm,” was published in 2010. At the Jaipur Literature Festival, Mr. Ghosh spoke with India Ink about the significance of collaborating with 48 different contributors, and what it means for younger generations to retell the history of Partition in a graphic format.

headline: Apax Partners to Acquire All of Online Auto Sales Company Trader Media
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Computers and the Internet', 'E-Commerce', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity']

headline: Amid Scandal, Christie Sounds Note of Optimism at Inauguration
abstract: With state and federal inquiries of his administration underway, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey started his second term with a sober tone and a reminder of his bipartisan appeal.

Chris Christie, bedeviled by doubts about his leadership style and political tactics, took the oath of office on Tuesday at the lowest point in his governorship, determined to re-establish a bond with scandal-weary citizens of New Jersey and remind them of what it was they liked about him.

headline: Activists Accuse Tech Community of Throwing San Francisco Under the Bus
abstract: The fight over where the tech buses should load passengers is likely to flare up again Tuesday as San Francisco transit officials struggle to find a solution.
lead_paragraph: The luxury buses that ferry tech workers from San Francisco to Silicon Valley every morning were originally a solution to several problems: how to painlessly get workers to their jobs while being environmentally conscious while getting another two hours of work out of everyone. The Wi-Fi password on Google’s buses was Don’tBeEvil.

headline: Wawrinka Outlasts Djokovic in a Marathon Match
abstract: Switzerland’s Stanislas Wawrinka, seeded eighth, outlasted Novak Djokovic, the defending champion, in a grueling five-set thriller on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Stanislas Wawrinka’s forehand sailed wide on break point in the fourth set, and Novak Djokovic screamed. Then he screamed again. Then he screamed once more. He screamed as if he won the tournament. He screamed as if he won the lottery. He screamed so loud for so long the chair umpire issued a warning.

headline: At Chanel Couture, Running Shoes and Dancing

It felt as if we were entering an upscale nightclub, perhaps one that might have been featured in a Busby Berkeley film.

headline: Pre-K Plan Puts Cuomo at Odds With de Blasio on Funding
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s offer of $1.5 billion to expand prekindergarten is likely to be seen as an attempt to outmaneuver Mayor Bill de Blasio, who said on Tuesday he would still seek to tax the rich to pay for the program.

abstract: The World Economic Forum will tackle a wide range of issues, but an Oxfam report put income inequality in the spotlight ahead of the gabfest of the global elite.
