headline: Activist Investor Rewards Streamlining at Dow Chemical by Taking a Big Stake
keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Daniel Loeb took a stake of about $1.3 billion in Dow Chemical, which has pre-empted activist ambushes by getting ahead of them.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:34 p.m. | When the activist investor Daniel S. Loeb met with representatives of Dow Chemical in December, the company had already stolen his thunder.

headline: Finding a Doctor Who Supports Genetic Screening During I.V.F.
keywords: ['Genetics and Heredity', 'In Vitro Fertilization', 'Infertility', 'Parenting', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: Genetic screening of embryos during our I.V.F. procedures may not increase my chances of having a baby, but it would greatly reduce my chances of miscarrying or bearing a baby with genetic defects.
lead_paragraph: “Now remember, we’re not judging doctors based on personality,” Solomon reminded me for the gazillionth time. I nodded. “We’re looking for the best treatment plan.”

headline: Top Wonkblog Columnist to Leave Washington Post
abstract: Ezra Klein, who is said to have been rebuffed by The Post when he asked it to back an online venture, oversaw the blog about government policy and wrote a column for it.
lead_paragraph: Ezra Klein, an analyst, columnist and pundit who runs The Washington Post’s Wonkblog, will leave the newspaper, taking two of his colleagues with him, according to an internal memo sent on Tuesday.

headline: At Chanel, Look at the Shoes!
abstract: Karl Lagerfeld showcased embroidered and chiffon-wrapped sneakers with his cloud-soft collection.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Look at the shoes!

headline: Man Arrested in the Killings of His Wife and Children
abstract: Miguel Mejia-Ramos, 28, was arrested on Monday night in Texas, a day after his wife and their two young daughters were found dead in their Queens home.
lead_paragraph: A man wanted in the stabbing deaths of his wife and two young daughters over the weekend has been arrested in Texas, the New York Police Department said on Tuesday.

headline: Vivendi Said to Consider Sale of SFR to Numericable
abstract: Vivendi, the French conglomerate that once owned Universal Studios, is considering selling its mobile and Internet unit to the cable operator Numericable, according to Bloomberg News.
lead_paragraph: Vivendi, the French conglomerate that once owned Universal Studios, is considering selling its mobile and Internet unit to the cable operator Numericable, according to a report from Bloomberg News on Tuesday.

headline: The Read Around: Rebecca Mead
abstract: Rebecca Mead, author of “My Life in Middlemarch,” says that reading and rereading George Eliot’s masterpiece has helped shape her own life.
lead_paragraph: Rebecca Mead, author of “My Life in Middlemarch,” says that reading and rereading George Eliot’s masterpiece has helped shape her own life.

headline: The Read Around: Video of Rebecca Mead
abstract: Ms. Mead discusses her new book, “My Life in Middlemarch.”
lead_paragraph: In “The Read Around,” a weekly video feature, authors discuss the when, where and how behind their books. Above, Rebecca Mead discusses “My Life in Middlemarch,” a combination of biography, literary criticism and memoir about George Eliot’s masterpiece.

headline: Three’s a Trend | Two-Faced Coats
abstract: Made with luxurious cashmere on the inside and out, these coats with soft silhouettes are the ultimate in luxury.
lead_paragraph: Double-faced cashmere is one of the softest, most luxurious fabrics around — specially woven with two “right” sides, or faces, so that the wearer feels the ultrasoft fiber both on the inside and out. It’s a hallmark of many high-end fashion collections, as there’s no difference in quality between the front and the back of the fabric. And the drape of a coat made with this material, unencumbered by the usual structure, is loose and fluid, like a bathrobe. At Valentino, a new capsule, haute couture collection for men included a classic, double-faced cashmere coat in camel that looks as luxurious as it feels. Varied versions of the high-class standby included Tomas Maier’s olive offering at Bottega Veneta, which he layered over equally cozy, athletic-style pants and zip top. And at Louis Vuitton, the designer Kim Jones draped a gray, peaked lapel coat over the shoulders of a suit and tank top, for the height of elegance.

headline: Which Authors or Books Have Worked on You as ‘Negative Influences’?
abstract: Thomas Mallon and Daniel Mendelsohn discuss the works that have inspired them to take an opposite approach.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Thomas Mallon and Daniel Mendelsohn discuss their “negative influences”: works that have inspired them to take an opposing approach in their own writing.

headline: Encore, for the Norwegian Curlers and Their Pants
abstract: Norway’s curlers, who won silver at the Vancouver Games in 2010, broke tradition by wearing loud, colorful pants and then made them part of their identity.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The sun had set on the Strip and some members of the Norwegian curling team were taking a break from competing in a tournament here. They were ready to hit the town, the Bellagio, perhaps, and maybe dinner at Caesars Palace. But the men knew that tourists would not recognize them as Scandinavian stars of an obscure sport.

headline: JPMorgan Is Said to Drop Out of Another Offering in China
abstract: JPMorgan withdrew as a potential underwriter of a stock offering for Tianhe Chemicals. The bank once employed the daughter of Tianhe’s chairman.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:16 p.m. | JPMorgan Chase has removed itself from a potential $1 billion share sale by a Chinese chemical company as an investigation in the United States into hiring practices in China by JPMorgan and other Wall Street banks moves forward, people with direct knowledge of the matter said on Tuesday.

headline: Thai Leaders Declare State of Emergency in Bangkok
abstract: The emergency decree gives the government broad powers against protesters, but Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra seemed to be moving cautiously.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — The embattled government of Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra declared the imposition of emergency rule in Bangkok and surrounding areas on Tuesday, suggesting a more aggressive posture toward protesters who have occupied parts of the city during the past two months and are seeking to overthrow the government.

headline: How to Unblock Adobe Reader in Safari
abstract: Plus, checking compatibility in Windows 8.1, and customizing lists in Twitter.
lead_paragraph: Unblocking Adobe Reader in Safari

headline: English F.A. Charges Anelka Over Contentious Gesture
abstract: After a delay of more than three weeks, the governing body of English soccer said on Tuesday that it had charged a French player for a salute that is widely seen as anti-Semitic in France.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After a delay of more than three weeks, the governing body of English professional soccer said Tuesday that it had formally charged a French player, Nicolas Anelka, with making a racially or religiously abusive gesture when he celebrated a goal for his club, West Bromwich Albion, with the so-called quenelle salute, which is widely criticized as anti-Semitic.

headline: Interview: Bradley Cooper
abstract: At the Critics' Choice awards, Bradley Cooper talks with Melena Ryzik about the performances and hairstyles of "American Hustle."
lead_paragraph: At the Critics' Choice awards, Bradley Cooper talks with Melena Ryzik about the performances and hairstyles of "American Hustle."

headline: Why Bitcoin Matters
abstract: Bitcoin is the first practical solution to a longstanding problem in computer science, Marc Andreessen writes in Another View.
lead_paragraph: Editor’s note: Marc Andreessen’s venture capital firm, Andreessen Horowitz, has invested just under $50 million in Bitcoin-related start-ups. The firm is actively searching for more Bitcoin-based investment opportunities. He does not personally own more than a de minimis amount of Bitcoin.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Public Relations and Publicity']
abstract: Crispin Porter & Bogusky lays off about 10 percent of its United States employees after losing the Arby’s account. The chairman and founder of Rosetta steps down.
lead_paragraph: John Anicker, president for operations at Hornall Anderson, Seattle, was promoted to president and chief executive. Jack Anderson, who had been chief executive, becomes chairman, a new post. Hornall Anderson is part of the Diversified Agency Services division of the Omnicom Group.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: How much is real in those disaster-filled Farmers Insurance commercials?
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Activist Investor Joins Mondelez International Board
abstract: Mondelez International, the snack company that Kraft Foods spun off in 2012, announced on Tuesday that it had added the activist investor Nelson Peltz to its board.
lead_paragraph: Mondelez International, the snack company that Kraft Foods spun off in 2012, announced on Tuesday that it had added the activist investor Nelson Peltz to its board, as Mr. Peltz seemed to end his push for a merger between Mondelez and PepsiCo.

abstract: Also on the Minute, abortion in politics and Japan's dolphin hunt.
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, abortion in politics and Japan's dolphin hunt.

headline: Obama Evolves on Marijuana
abstract: “Middle-class kids don’t get locked up for smoking pot, and poor kids do,” he said in an interview.
lead_paragraph: In 2010, the White House’s National Drug Control Strategy memo included a reminder that the Obama administration “firmly opposes the legalization of marijuana or any other illicit drug.” The 2013 update of that memo reiterated that the administration rejects legalization.

headline: Breaking Free From Winter’s Hold With a Lemony Escarole Soup
abstract: Based on a Greek avgolemono, this soup is familiar and comforting, and fresh lemon adds a sunny brightness.
lead_paragraph: As winter tightens its frigid grip, I turn to chicken soup for consolation.

headline: The Twist to This Pro Bono Campaign? The Rights are Priced
abstract: A North Carolina charity that fights homelessness and poverty urges donors to purchase naming rights to everything it needs, from a can of corn to caseworkers. Donors receive personalized certificates that can be shared in social media or printed as posters.
lead_paragraph: Among the marketing tactics most criticized — and mocked — for their excesses, perhaps Public Enemy No. 1 is when corporations pay outsize sums for naming rights to stadiums, ballparks, arenas, lounges and other facilities. Now a nonprofit organization has adapted the practice for its own charitable purposes.

headline: Running Economies Into the Sand
abstract: About that UK triumphalism.
lead_paragraph: Hmm. Allies of the Cameron government are now taunting Hollande as having run the French economy “into the sand” — presumably by contrast with the British triumph. How does that look in terms of, you know, actual numbers?

headline: Today in Small Business: ‘Letmein’
abstract: New York’s small businesses look to score with the Super Bowl. Where to find the world’s biggest tea drinkers. And a shortage of car-charging stations in Silicon Valley.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Video: Bradley Cooper and That Perm
abstract: The co-star of “American Hustle” explains what effect his hair choices had on his performance.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Quick, viewers of “American Hustle”: can you separate Christian Bale’s swindler Irving Rosenfeld from his elaborate comb-over or Bradley Cooper’s tightly wound F.B.I. agent from his coiled perm? (To say nothing of high-maintenance wife Jennifer Lawrence’s towering updo.) The David O. Russell film was nominated for an Academy Award for its costume design but, in a highly noted snub, not for its hair or makeup.

headline: Paris Couture Week: Dior Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Schohaja.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Schohaja.

headline: A Dylan Tribute Concert Is Getting New Life
abstract: A 1992 concert honoring Bob Dylan is coming out in video and a refreshed CD edition.
lead_paragraph: The Bob Dylan reissue machine has already refurbished Mr. Dylan’s complete catalog and has regularly revisited the vaults to offer compilations of outtakes and rarities. Now, Columbia Records’ historical division, Legacy Recordings, has turned its attention to a Dylan footnote, though a hefty one, the concert the label presented at Madison Square Garden on Oct. 16, 1992, to commemorate the 30th anniversary of its relationship with Mr. Dylan. A remastered high-definition video version, on DVD and Blu-ray, and a refreshed two-CD edition, are due out March 4. Both versions will include extra performances and rehearsal material.

headline: Protesters Make Do with Donated Snacks and Lack of Toilets
keywords: ['Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Police', 'Restaurants', 'Transit Systems']
abstract: Despite having few amenities at the site of the Aam Aadmi sit-in demonstration on Tuesday, supporters were determined to stay as long as it took until the party’s demands were met.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Since he began his protest on Monday, coughs and sniffles have punctuated the speeches by Arvind Kejriwal, Delhi’s chief minister and leader of the Aam Aadmi, or Common Man, Party. A thin gray scarf, tied around his head vertically, protected his ears in a minimalistic way, reminiscent of a lonely security guard. He was the Common Man with the common cold.

headline: Delhi Chief Minister Calls Off Protest After Deal to Put Two Police Officials on Leave
keywords: ['Delays (Transportation)', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Transit Systems', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Arvind Kejriwal and his Aam Aadmi Party had been demanding the suspension of three Delhi station house officers who they accused of failing to protect women.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Arvind Kejriwal, Delhi’s chief minister, called off his party’s sit-in protest over women’s safety on Tuesday night after the central government agreed to place on leave two police officials who the Aam Aadmi Party accused of failing to protect women.

headline: Vitter to Run for Louisiana Governor
abstract: A Republican once tarred by a prostitution scandal, Senator David Vitter announced he will run to succeed Gov. Bobby Jindal in 2015.
lead_paragraph: Senator David Vitter, a Republican once tarred by scandal, announced on Tuesday that he will run for governor of Louisiana.

headline: Apple Wins Temporary Stay on Court Monitor
abstract: Apple won a small victory in its attempt to oust a court-appointed monitor. The court ruling sets the stage for more legal battles to come.
lead_paragraph: Apple won a small victory on Tuesday in its attempt to oust a court-appointed monitor who is responsible for overseeing the company’s compliance with federal antitrust laws.

headline: Fiat Completes Acquisition of Chrysler
abstract: The Italian automobile manufacturer Fiat announced it had completed its deal to purchase the 41 percent it did not already own of Chrysler, the once-troubled American car company.
lead_paragraph: A classic American car manufacturer has officially become 100 percent Italian.

headline: The Collections | The Top Five Fall/Winter 2014 Men’s Wear Shows in Paris
abstract: Our men’s fashion director shares his favorites from the runways in Paris.
lead_paragraph: It was another great season for men’s wear in Paris, which wrapped up over the weekend. Some credit has to be handed to the beautiful City of Lights itself, a stunning backdrop for the Fall/Winter 2014 collections. Some of the designers presented their most thoughtful and memorable shows yet, including the following top five.

headline: Readers Respond: Managing an Overflowing Inbox
abstract: Readers offer solutions for email anxiety, sharing websites they rely on and suggesting restraint — don’t continually look at the inbox every few minutes.
lead_paragraph: If you were one of the people who sent me an email last year and I didn’t respond, I’m sorry. As I noted in my column this week, I probably deleted it.

headline: Image of the Day: January 21
abstract: Tata Motors launched a new car Vista Tech in Bangalore, Karnataka.

headline: Urban Grit in Philly’s Fishtown
abstract: In the Fishtown area of Philadelphia, Sarah Anderson, a boutique owner, says her style is inspired by ’70s B-level horror movies.
lead_paragraph: In the Fishtown area of Philadelphia, Sarah Anderson, a boutique owner, says her style is inspired by ’70s B-level horror movies.

headline: The Trap of Too Many Choices
abstract: With a surfeit of investment choices, it may be better to choose an option that’s good enough, rather than keep looking for perfection.
lead_paragraph: I recently got a new smartphone. In the setup process, I was presented with all sorts of options. Selecting a language was pretty easy, but I had to think harder about some of the other ones. Did I want the phone to use my location? Did I want to share data anonymously? Did I want to log in with an existing account or did I need to set up a new one?

headline: Turkish Leader, Amid Scandal at Home, Visits Brussels to Try to Repair Ties
abstract: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan, facing a corruption scandal, is hoping to revive Turkey’s bid for European Union membership.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Buffeted by a corruption scandal and accusations of creeping authoritarianism, Turkey faces long odds in its bid to join the European Union even as the country’s prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, visited Brussels on Tuesday to try to repair a badly frayed relationship with Europe.

headline: Bouchra Jarrar: Spring 2014 Couture
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: Gay Couple? Are You Amending a Tax Return?
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: The Times is seeking gay couples who are considering filing amended tax returns to interview for a coming article.
lead_paragraph: Tax season is not traditionally a time of year Americans look forward to. But this year may be different – at least for some.

headline: Horizon:  Artifacts of the Mayans; ‘Tales of the City’ Finale
abstract: In Denver, an exhibition on the Maya civilization; Armistead Maupin touring to promote his latest and last book in the “Tales of the City” series.
lead_paragraph: ART

headline: More Producers’ Secrets: ‘Captain Phillips’ and the Defining Screen Test
abstract: A producer explains how the production team needed just one test audience to know they had made the right decision about tone.
lead_paragraph: The producer Michael De Luca let an audience of indie filmmakers and wannabes in on some secrets at a discussion at Sundance on Tuesday morning. But Mr. De Luca, whose credits include “The Social Network,” “Moneyball,” “Magnolia” and the coming film adaptation of “50 Shades of Grey,” already revealed some secrets at the Producers Guild nominee panel in Los Angeles, which he attended last week as a producer of “Captain Phillips,” a contender for the best picture Oscar.

headline: Caramoor Sets Lineup for Summer Festival
abstract: A variety of classical music and opera programming will be offered at the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts in Katonah, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: The Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts has announced the classical music and opera programming for this summer’s festival, which will open on June 21 and run through Aug. 6. The performances, held on a 90-acre estate in Katonah, N.Y., include an opening-night concert in which the violinist Joshua Bell will be the soloist in the Sibelius concerto, part of a program by the Orchestra of St. Luke’s, Cristian Macelaru conducting.

headline: A Paul Taylor Dance Reunion at Koch Theater
abstract: The Paul Taylor Dance Company has added a performance to its season at the David H. Koch Theater that will include many of the company’s alumni.
lead_paragraph: The Paul Taylor Dance Company has announced that it has added an extra performance to its season at the David H. Koch Theater, on March 23 at 6 p.m., for which 46 of the company’s alumni have accepted Mr. Taylor’s invitation to appear onstage beside members of the current company.

headline: Ars Nova to Stage New Play From Debate Society
abstract: “Jacuzzi” is set in a Colorado ski resort.
lead_paragraph: The Debate Society, the quirky three-person theater troupe, will follow up its breakthrough hits “Buddy Cop 2” and “Blood Play” with “Jacuzzi,” which focuses on a group of characters who populate the “7th-best ski resort in southwest central Colorado.”

headline: DNA Confirms Body Parts Belong to Missing Boy With Autism
abstract: The New York City medical examiner said DNA tests confirmed that remains found last week were of Avonte Oquendo, 14, who disappeared last fall in Queens.
lead_paragraph: First there was the disappearance: a 14-year-old boy with autism last seen walking out of his school by the Queens waterfront last fall. Then there were the months of searching, the posters of a fresh-faced teenager that a city came to know simply as Avonte.

headline: France to Return 3 Artworks Looted in World War II
abstract: The French culture minister says that three works will be returned, and that France would try to find the owners of others.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France’s culture minister, Aurélie Filippetti, on Tuesday pledged to return three artworks looted in World War II “without delay,” including a 17th-century landscape by the Flemish painter Joos de Momper.

headline: Funds Created to Offload Credit Risk From Big Projects
abstract: UniCredit, the large Italian bank, is the first to take advantage of the funds from the Mariner Investment Group, which will help European banks and other financial institutions free up capital.
lead_paragraph: The Mariner Investment Group, a $10 billion global alternative investment firm, has created two funds that will buy up credit risk from deals used to finance large projects in areas like infrastructure, transportation and energy, allowing financial institutions, including European banks, to free up capital they would otherwise need to hold under regulatory requirements.

headline: Martoma Defense Walks a Tightrope
abstract: Lawyers for Mathew Martoma, a former portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors who is accused of with insider trading, want to portray the trades in question as routine. But they do not want the jury to hear about the firm’s own guilty plea to insider trading, Peter Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: The trial of Mathew Martoma presents a challenge often seen in recent insider trading prosecutions: how to mount a defense denying any wrongdoing when the defendant is unlikely to testify. One way to persuade a jury to return a not-guilty verdict is by focusing on the ordinary nature of the trading to raise questions about whether any confidential information was even used.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Jan. 14-Jan. 20, 2014
abstract: Droughts, dogs, football, movies and more: how many of the 10 questions below can you answer correctly?
lead_paragraph: Droughts, dogs, football, movies and more: how many of the 10 questions below can you answer correctly?

headline: After Hours | At Town Hall, A Chance to Shamelessly Worship the Indomitable Carol Channing
abstract: To toast her 93rd birthday, the Broadway icon brought down the house in a show with the cabaret performer Justin Vivian Bond.
lead_paragraph: Gay men of a certain age have strong feelings about Broadway divas, who modeled an outsize swagger in an era when they themselves couldn’t. Of all the give-’em-heck floorboard belters in this particular canon, few have attained the sainted status of Carol Channing, the blond-mopped, lisping “Hello Dolly” icon who turns 93 next week with her stage brio intact. When she was helped onstage last night at Town Hall for a special birthday tribute, grinning widely and wearing a white bouclé jacket and slacks, the cavernous house, packed mostly with middle-aged and older gay men, jumped to its feet and, for 10 minutes straight, released the sort of primal roar that might have accompanied a winning Superbowl pass.

headline: Bananas are Chemicals, Too
abstract: A chemistry teacher reminds students and the rest of us that natural foods are made of chemicals, too.
lead_paragraph: Via a Facebook post by longtime science writer Boyce Rensberger of a piece on the science and technology website IO9, I found a set of clever and provocative illustrations created by James Kennedy, a high school chemistry teacher in Melbourne, Australia.

headline: U.S. and Russia Discuss Olympic Security
abstract: Military officials from both countries are talking about the use of sophisticated American equipment designed to counter homemade bombs.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Even as Russia imposes the most intensive security apparatus in Olympic history, the top military officers from the United States and Russia have opened discussions about using sophisticated American electronic equipment in a new effort to help secure the Winter Games in Sochi next month.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Christie Sworn In for Second Term
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey took the oath of office at the War Memorial Theater in Trenton on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey took the oath of office at the War Memorial Theater in Trenton on Tuesday.

headline: America to Obama: We’re Not Listening
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: The president has vowed to create a rational policy on spying so many times that no one seems to be paying attention anymore.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has come before the American people so many times now to promise transparency, declare his respect for civil rights and privacy, and vow to create a rational policy on government spying, that no one seems to be listening anymore.

headline: Everything Is Strange, and Therein Lies the Point
abstract: “Ghosts of Love: Songs from the Reel World of David Lynch,” a theatrical cabaret at Stage 72, features Lauren Fox and Ritt Henn performing tunes from Mr. Lynch’s films.
lead_paragraph: Romantic love in the films of David Lynch is more than passion; as often as not, it is a dangerously morbid obsession expressed in songs that thread through the soundtracks like the tempting voices of sirens. The title song of “Blue Velvet”; Roy Orbison’s “In Dreams,” from the same movie; and Chris Isaak’s “Wicked Game,” from “Wild at Heart,” are prime examples of songs that dangle the keys to supernatural mysteries.

headline: Conjuring the Global Dangers of Water
abstract: Hurricane Sandy involved a gradual storm surge, over 24 hours, a “Nova” program says, while the surge of Haiyan, in the Philippines, occurred in just minutes.
lead_paragraph: The PBS science program “Nova” has been trying to quicken its pace lately, generating episodes pegged to newsmaking events like Hurricane Sandy and the Boston Marathon bombing. “Killer Typhoon,” about the catastrophic storm in the Philippines in November, is the latest, and from it we learn once again that water is something to be feared.

headline: Data Breaches Are Scary, but Don’t Panic. React.
keywords: ['Identity Theft', 'Debit Cards', 'Credit Cards', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: People, like those affected by the Target breach, who believe their data was stolen have many defenses, including simply changing their passwords.
lead_paragraph: It’s always upsetting when you are notified by a business, whether it is a credit card issuer or a retailer, that your personal or financial information may have been stolen in a data breach. The recent incident at Target stores, one of the largest corporate breaches in recent years, affected millions of people.

headline: ‘Here Lies Love’ Will Return to the Public Theater
abstract: The disco-inflected musical about Imelda Marcos will be a commercial production in space rented from the Public.
lead_paragraph: The critically acclaimed musical “Here Lies Love,” which uses discotheque atmospherics to explore the celebrity life of former first lady of the Philippines, Imelda Marcos, will return starting March 24 to the Public Theater for an open-ended run, one of the producers, Joey Parnes, said on Tuesday.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: MLK Edition
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Friday marked the 25th anniversary of the Cleveland Elementary School shooting in Stockton, Calif., the first mass shooting of schoolchildren in American history. In the space of three minutes, five kids ranging in age from 6 to 9 were killed and 29 others were wounded, as was a teacher.

headline: As Images of Attacker are Shared, Thai Government Issues Emergency Rule
abstract: The government in Thailand imposed emergency rule over protests, and law enforcement authorities circulated images of a man alleged to be behind a recent grenade attack.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Thomas Fuller reported from Bangkok on Tuesday, the government in Thailand has declared the imposition of emergency rule to start on Wednesday.

headline: Wheelies: The More Emotional Camry Edition
abstract: Toyota’s president calls for an emotional Camry design; ADAC, the German car club, is embroiled in scandal over falsified contest results.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: At Rao’s in Los Angeles, Red Sauce and Rivalry
abstract: A storied New York restaurant makes a move on Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Seward Street runs through a patch of film production studios and empty lots in Hollywood. It is dimly lit, usually deserted and a little spooky at night. But the other Friday evening, the red glow of a neon sign splashed across the road. A security guard and a parking valet stood out front, and a steady stream of people walked into what is, as it turns out, a restaurant, a Rat Pack outpost of dark wood, red leather booths and twinkling year-round Christmas lights.

headline: Discovery Takes Controlling Stake in Eurosport
abstract: Eurosport, which is vying to become the Europe version of American sports behemoth ESPN, reaches 133 million homes, and the company is growing as it acquires additional rights to more games.
lead_paragraph: Discovery Communications on Tuesday said it had taken a controlling 51 percent stake in Eurosport International, a pan-European sports media group, in a deal that values the company at $1.2 billion.

headline: Numb to Violence? Fans, Maybe, but Not Players
abstract: Fans at home run the risk of being desensitized to football’s endless stream of injuries, but safety issues seem to have made players more compassionate toward one another.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The National Football League markets and manufactures controlled violence and mayhem better than any other league in the history of organized sports.

headline: Catching the Olympic Spirit in Lake Placid, N.Y.
abstract: Can’t make it to Sochi next month? You can create your own Olympic memories in and around this Adirondack village that hosted the 1980 Winter Games.
lead_paragraph: The Sochi Winter Olympics in Russia open in about two weeks with peerless sports pageantry and a cavalcade of athletic accomplishment that will captivate the world. Sitting at home, it will be easy to get caught up in the Olympic spirit gazing from afar at what seems like a picture-perfect snow globe setting where various acts of derring-do and stylish grace are celebrated with medals and everlasting tribute.

headline: An LED Bulb Is Both Dimmable and Affordable
abstract: The Philips SlimStyle looks like a lollipop, but it meets Energy Start requirements and costs less than $10.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a bulb you might think about licking rather than lighting. Philips’s cut the weight of its new SlimStyle lamp down to about three ounces by eliminating the heat sink found in most other LED lamps.

headline: J. Mendel | The Company
abstract: Gilles Mendel on the history and heritage of J. Mendel.
lead_paragraph: Gilles Mendel on the history and heritage of J. Mendel.

headline: Pussy Riot Coming to Brooklyn
abstract: Nadezhda Tolokonnikova and Maria Alyokhina, who were released from a Russian prison last month, will appear at an Amnesty International concert at Barclays Center on Feb. 5.
lead_paragraph: Pussy Riot is coming to Brooklyn.

headline: Sundance: A Veteran’s First Visit
abstract: The photographer turned filmmaker Anton Corbijn explains why he wanted to bring his third film to a festival known for debuts.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — Though he’s only made three features, Anton Corbijn could be considered something of a veteran filmmaker here at Sundance, where indie directors borrowing favors from family rule the scene.

headline: J. Mendel | The Fur
abstract: Gilles Mendel discusses the making of a fur dress for his Spring 2014 show.

lead_paragraph: General Electric announced on Tuesday that it had agreed to purchase API Healthcare, a software and analytics firm that helps medical companies manage their work force.

lead_paragraph: To mark the conclusion of Paris Men's Fashion Week, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 15 fashion visionaries.

headline: A Welcome Formula for Dow Chemical
abstract: A rough calculation suggests breaking up Dow Chemical could increase its value, so investors reacted favorably to a suggestion that the company split off its petrochemicals business, writes Kevin Allison in Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: The activist investor Daniel S. Loeb is putting the right accelerant into Dow Chemical. Shares of Dow jumped more than 7 percent at one point on Tuesday after Mr. Loeb called for a split of its petrochemicals and specialty chemicals businesses. He may be overly optimistic about the financial benefits, but a rough sum of the parts suggests merely breaking up Dow, a $52 billion company, could increase its value by a fifth.

headline: German Energy Official Sounds a Warning
keywords: ['Energy and Power', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: The minister Sigmar Gabriel said rising costs for the shift to renewable energy might sap public support and jeopardize Germany’s industrial base.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany’s new energy minister on Tuesday struck a sobering tone about the country’s ambitious goals for making its energy sector more reliant on renewable sources, saying that rising costs risked losing public support and jeopardizing the powerful German industrial base.

headline: A Rare View of Wildebeest Calves
abstract: Serengeti Safari Camp is offering trips to see wildebeests during calving season.
lead_paragraph: August is the prime month for safarigoers to visit the Serengeti in Tanzania for the migration of the wildebeest, but travelers who want to escape the crowds during this peak time and still want to see these animals would do well to head to the southern Serengeti during calving season.

headline: ‘Are You Lonesome Tonight?’ From Elvis Presley to Kacey Musgraves
abstract: One of the hottest singles of 1960, this Elvis Presley hit was written by Roy Turk and Lou Handman in 1926.
lead_paragraph: “Are You Lonesome Tonight?”

headline: Narcissa Opens in the Standard East Village
abstract: John Fraser, who opened Dovetail on the Upper West Side in 2007, has a new restaurant in André Balazs’s hotel.
lead_paragraph: Headliners

headline: East Coast Storm Brings Snow and Disruptions to the New York Region
abstract: A winter storm that swept up the East Coast seemed to catch many by surprise, but New York City officials announced that public schools would be open Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers are used to a lot of overheated discussion about impending snow.

headline: He Is the Captain Now (at Least Everyone Tells Him So)
abstract: Barkhad Abdi, nominated for his turn as a Somali pirate in “Captain Phillips,” discusses his first scene as a first-time actor.
lead_paragraph: As far as film debuts go, it’s hard to find a more auspicious one than that of Barkhad Abdi, playing the Somali pirate who kidnaps Tom Hanks in “Captain Phillips.” Mr. Abdi, a limo driver in Minneapolis when he was cast from an open call, learned about acting on the fly from the director, Paul Greengrass, whom he credited with helping craft his performance.

headline: Play against the Clock
abstract: Solve Crosswords against the clock
lead_paragraph: Solve Crosswords against the clock

headline: A Miniaturized Controller for iOS Games
abstract: The Stratus game controller from SteelSeries is a stand-alone gadget that connects to mobile devices via Bluetooth.
lead_paragraph: Entrepreneurs are bringing gaming accessories into the world of apps.

headline: Paris Couture Week: Chanel Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Pictures of the Day: New Jersey and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from New Jersey, South Sudan, Central African Republic and Bulgaria.
lead_paragraph: Photos from New Jersey, South Sudan, Central African Republic and Bulgaria.

headline: Justices Appear Divided on a Sweeping Challenge to Public Workers’ Unions
abstract: The Supreme Court’s questioning fell largely on ideological lines over an effort to allow government workers to opt out of paying union dues in collective bargaining negotiations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A broad challenge to public sector unions was met with a mixed response on Tuesday at the Supreme Court.

headline: Heir Apparent at Pimco to Step Down
abstract: Mohamed El-Erian is unexpectedly resigning from the giant asset manager Pimco, dashing expectations that he would take over management of the firm.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:36 p.m. | The giant asset manager Pimco lost its heir apparent and most prominent spokesman on Tuesday when Mohamed A. El-Erian unexpectedly announced that he was stepping down from the company.

headline: Excluded Iran Says Its Role at Talks on Syria Will Be Missed
abstract: After Iran was invited to and then disinvited from a coming peace conference on Syria, Iranian officials and commentators said it was the attendees who would be missing out.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — After Iran was invited to and then disinvited from a coming peace conference on Syria within the span of 24 hours, Iranian officials and commentators said on Tuesday that it was the attendees who would be missing out.

headline: Language by the Book, but the Book Is Evolving
abstract: The Oxford English Dictionary, now under the leadership of Michael Proffitt, is looking to serve traditionalists and the users to come.
lead_paragraph: OXFORD, England — To compile a dictionary of nearly every word in the English language was an endeavor typical of Victorian times, complete with white-bearded gentlemen, utter confidence and an endearingly plodding pace. After a quarter-century, the first installment emerged in 1884. Its contents? “A to Ant.”

headline: Ex-Governor of Virginia Is Indicted on Charges Over Loans and Gifts
abstract: Former Gov. Bob McDonnell and his wife, Maureen, are accused of accepting some $135,000 in cash and thousands more in other gifts from a political patron and lying about it.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia and his wife, Maureen, were indicted Tuesday by a federal grand jury on charges of accepting more than $140,000 in loans and gifts in exchange for promoting the business of a political patron who was seeking special favors from the state government.

headline: They’re Young, Female and, Darn It, Need to Work
abstract: “Broad City,” starting Wednesday on Comedy Central, skewers the millennial generation as hapless, with no ambition, talent or self-respect. But these slackers happen to be women.
lead_paragraph: For so long, women tried to succeed as much as men.

headline: A New York Home for Riis’s ‘Other Half’
abstract: Jacob Riis’s copy of “How the Other Half Lives,” with his signature and annotations, has been donated to the New-York Historical Society by Ted Gup, a journalism professor.
lead_paragraph: Ted Gup, a professor of journalism at Emerson College, has donated a first edition copy of Jacob Riis’s “How the Other Half Lives” — a searing exposé of life in New York tenements, published in 1890 — to the New-York Historical Society, the society announced on Tuesday. The copy was owned by Riis, who not only wrote for “How the Other Half Lives,” but also illustrated it with his own photographs. It includes his signature and a date (Nov. 15, 1890), as well as marginal annotations that expand on some of the ideas in the text.

headline: Factoring in the Mystique of Long Lines
abstract: How long you wait for a table doesn’t always say much about the winningness of the food.
lead_paragraph: Independent thinkers find this hard to admit, but when you see crowds of New Yorkers standing outside a bakery or putting their names on the list at the door of a restaurant, more often than not the food they’re hanging around for is worth eating.

headline: A Change in the Kitchen
abstract: A new vanguard of women emerges as the next generation of leaders in the nation’s best restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Last week at Marea, a New York haunt of the powerful and the polished, Lauren DeSteno moved up from executive sous-chef to chef de cuisine. It may sound like a mere tweak of a title, but in a small way it is revolutionary.

headline: Taking On a Master and His Many Complexities
abstract: The Takacs Quartet’s musicianship was on display during a recent two-concert Bartok program at Zankel Hall.
lead_paragraph: The Takacs Quartet played Bartok, long one of its specialties, in two superb concerts over the weekend at Zankel Hall. Not only was the music making excellent, but I was also reminded throughout the performances of the clean, resonant acoustics of this subterranean space, which is celebrating its 10th season.

headline: Two Troupes Evoke Endlessness in Words and Movement
abstract: Eleanor Bauer’s “Midday and Eternity” and Jillian Peña’s “Polly Pocket” were performed on Thursday at the Abrons Arts Center.
lead_paragraph: In an attempt to evoke eternity, three dancers play triangles, chant overlapping phrases and contort themselves into elaborate yoga poses. Later, three other dancers count to 3,000, as they go through ballet steps and banal conversations that strive for Freudian uncanniness. It’s another evening at the American Realness Festival, the experimental performance series that closed on Sunday.

headline: Recession’s True Cost Is Still Being Tallied
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Unemployment', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: Last year, the Government Accountability Office estimated that the price tag could range from a few trillion dollars to over $10 trillion.
lead_paragraph: On Sept. 15, 2008, the investment bank Lehman Brothers collapsed after a long struggle to avoid bankruptcy, paralyzing the world’s financial networks and tipping the United States economy into an abyss from which it has not yet fully emerged.

headline: Trotsky’s Pursuer Finds a Pursuer to Call His Own
abstract: The Cuban writer Leonardo Padura’s novel “The Man Who Loved Dogs” weaves the story of Trotsky, his murder and his murderer.
lead_paragraph: If Gabriel García Márquez’s “Love in the Time of Cholera” turned the romance novel into literature, and Mario Vargas Llosa, with “Conversation in the Cathedral,” applied French 1950s nouveau roman techniques to the political thriller, the Cuban writer Leonardo Padura, known for detective thrillers, has made his entrance to the Latin American Modernist canon by writing a Russian novel.

headline: American Starts a Luxury Resort to Share the Argentina He Loves
keywords: ['Wines', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: Michael Evans came to Argentina on vacation and stayed, leaving his career as a political consultant to go into the vineyard business.
lead_paragraph: VISTA FLORES, Argentina — It is hard to find fault with lunch at Siete Fuegos, the restaurant at the new Vines Resort & Spa in the Mendoza province. The steak is grilled to medium-rare perfection. The sparkling torrontés wine nicely complements the homemade dulce de leche ice cream. The open-air dining room looks upon acres of vineyards set against the snow-capped Andes.

headline: 2 Friends Reach Across the Aisle on Immigration
abstract: If there is any way to unlock the immigration stalemate in Washington, colleagues say that Esther Olavarria, a Democrat, and Rebecca Tallent, a Republican, might find it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The two women might at first seem more like political rivals than a reminder of the way things used to work in Washington.

headline: To See or Not to See? A Season for High Art
abstract: The glut of Shakespeare plays and other star-studded classical productions has led to happily overwhelmed theatergoers and to marketing challenges for theater companies.
lead_paragraph: Not all potential theatergoers look to New York’s stages hoping to see singing Mormons or the warbling witches of Oz, and this season, producers would give their horses, if not their kingdoms, for their attention and ticket-buying dollars.

keywords: ['Kitchens', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']

headline: Hotel Review: Arts Boutique Hotel B in Lima, Peru
abstract: This property, which opened in July, is like a trip back to the Peru of the 1920s — complete with striking artwork, stellar service and romantic interiors.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: Search for the ‘Next Big Thing’ Yields Soaring Valuations
abstract: Everyone wins in technology deals like Google’s $3.2 billion purchase of Nest Labs, at least until the bubble bursts, the Deal Professor writes.
lead_paragraph: You probably saw that Google is paying $3.2 billion in cash for Nest Labs, a maker of smart thermostats that has no profit and perhaps $300 million in revenue.

headline: Kasparov’s Moves in Run for Chess Office Raise Ethical Concerns
abstract: Garry Kasparov promised money to a supporter who was expected to deliver votes needed for Kasparov’s election as president of the World Chess Federation, according to a draft contract reviewed by The Times.
lead_paragraph: Garry Kasparov, the former chess world champion, announced in October that he was running for president of the World Chess Federation, the game’s governing body. He also announced a slate of candidates who were his nominees to lead the organization in various geographic regions.

headline: Homes a Short Walk From Princeton Prove a Tough Sell
abstract: A residential development near the university has attracted renters, but few buyers as yet at prices that exceed $1 million.
lead_paragraph: A development in Princeton, N.J., was intended to entice wealthy buyers with the promise of luxury living in a vibrant downtown setting.

headline: Key Witness in Martoma Trial Says He Lied to F.B.I.
abstract: Dr. Sidney Gilman, the government’s star witness in its case against Mathew Martoma, testified on Tuesday that he lied to the authorities for nearly a year about passing inside information to Mr. Martoma.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Sidney Gilman, the government’s star witness in its case against Mathew Martoma, a former SAC Capital Advisors portfolio manager, testified on Tuesday that he lied to F.B.I. agents and regulators for nearly a year about passing inside information to Mr. Martoma.

headline: Puzzles, Mysteries and a Dragon
abstract: Reviews of the new video games The Room Two, Nidhogg, République and Cut the Rope 2.
lead_paragraph: THE ROOM TWO

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate
abstract: Notable properties that have been recently listed for sale, sold or leased.
lead_paragraph: Recent Sale

headline: $1 Billion for a Perfect N.C.A.A. Bracket, Courtesy of Warren Buffett
abstract: Don’t bet on anyone winning the $1 billion being offered by Quicken Loans, the Detroit-based mortgage lender, with the backing of Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway, to anyone who fills out a perfect 2014 tournament bracket.
lead_paragraph: Each March, tens of millions of brackets are filled out in the hopes of predicting the outcome of the N.C.A.A.’s men’s basketball tournament. But the odds that a bracket will be perfect, that is, every game guessed correctly, are long — to the tune of 9.2 quintillion to one.

headline: Several Chefs Cooking a Latin Recipe, Blending Melodies and Genres
abstract: Musicians from Brazil, Uruguay and Peru were among the players in Guitar Marathon: Las Americas, part of the New York Guitar Festival.
lead_paragraph: Folk, pop and classical music meet in unlikely places in South America. That was one recurring motif, along with nimble fingers, attention to detail and a sense of humor, in Monday night’s concert at Merkin Concert Hall. It was the evening half of the New York Guitar Festival’s free pair of concerts, “Guitar Marathon: Las Americas,” which was recorded for WNYC’s Soundcheck. The afternoon show had featured North American music, down through Mexico. The evening concert was a quintuple bill largely chosen by its headliner, the Brazilian guitarist Badi Assad, with musicians from Brazil, Uruguay and Peru and a repertoire that also embraced Argentina and Venezuela.

headline: Jonathan J. Landau
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Mr. Landau is the chief executive of the Fortis Property Group, a private real estate development and investment company based in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Landau, 39, is the chief executive of the Fortis Property Group, a private real estate development and investment company based in Brooklyn that focuses mainly on office and residential properties. The company is involved in several multifamily projects in the New York area, including condominium buildings in North Williamsburg and Brooklyn Heights.

headline: ‘Joplin’ Will Make Way For ‘Joneses’ on Broadway
abstract: Will Eno’s Broadway debut will go into the theater where the Janis Joplin biomusical is now playing.
lead_paragraph: “A Night With Janis Joplin,” a Broadway musical that has been a modest seller at the box office, will close in February and then aim to reopen in March at another space in New York City, the producers announced on Tuesday evening. They declined to specify a closing date or identify the possible new space, only saying in a statement that they were “finalizing a wonderful option to move to another venue.”

headline: Pope Urges Davos Notables to Remember the Less Fortunate
abstract: The speech was careful to praise the work of business as a “noble vocation,” but Pope Francis went on to discuss the many people left behind.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — Participants of the World Economic Forum, from corporate chieftains to government ministers, are expected — encouraged, actually — to spend their time amid the snowy hills of Davos networking and talking shop.

headline: Woman Posts Video of Phone Confrontation Accusing Ex-Teacher of Sexual Abuse
abstract: A California high school vice principal resigned after a former student accused her of sexual abuse and posted their recorded conversation on YouTube.
lead_paragraph: A 28-year-old California woman posted on YouTube last week a secret telephone recording of her confrontation with a former middle school teacher who acknowledged sexually abusing her as a 12-year-old. The former teacher expressed regret for her actions during the recorded conversation, which has gone viral online.

abstract: The following are updates on basic services following the snowstorm.
lead_paragraph: The following are updates on basic services following the snowstorm.

keywords: ['Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: Two months after he claimed to have embraced sobriety, Mayor Rob Ford was caught on video Monday complaining about police surveillance of him and his associates in a drunken, obscenity-laced rant.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, 7:23 p.m. | Two months after he claimed to have embraced sobriety, Mayor Rob Ford of Toronto was caught on video late Monday complaining about police surveillance of him and his associates in a drunken, obscenity-laced rant peppered with Jamaican patois.

abstract: Dermatologists and other specialists respond to an article in the “Paying Till It Hurts” series.

headline: Curtain Call | The Designers of Paris Men’s Fashion Week Take Their Bows
abstract: To mark the conclusion of Paris Men’s Fashion Week, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 15 fashion visionaries.
lead_paragraph: Designers project their personalities not only through their collections but also in their appearances at the end of their runway shows. To mark the conclusion of Paris Men’s Fashion Week, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 15 fashion visionaries.

headline: Excerpt: ‘Broad City’
abstract: The new Comedy Central series features Ilana Glazer and Abbi Jacobson, two popular online comedians. Amy Poehler is a producer.
lead_paragraph: The new Comedy Central series features Ilana Glazer and Abbi Jacobson, two popular online comedians. Amy Poehler is a producer.

headline: Twitter Q. and A. on Syria Peace Talks
abstract: Anne Barnard of The Times answered readers’ questions on the conflict in Syria and Wednesday’s peace conference.
lead_paragraph: As diplomats and politicians gathered in Switzerland for a highly anticipated peace conference on Syria, Anne Barnard, The Times's Beirut bureau chief, answered readers’ questions via Twitter on the continuing conflict and the expectations for the talks. She discussed the exclusion of Iran from the conference, opportunities to improve the delivery of humanitarian aid and prospects for the future.

headline: Abundance Doesn’t Mean Health
abstract: We need a national policy that sets goals for smart eating first — and only then determines how to produce the food to meet those goals.
lead_paragraph: The relatively new notion that around a third or more of the world’s population is badly (“mal”) nourished conflates hunger and diet-spawned illnesses like diabetes, both of which are preventable.

headline: The Holes in a Theory of Suicide
abstract: Forensic experts said a theory that Michelle O’Connell shot herself with her boyfriend’s gun lacked credibility.
lead_paragraph: Forensic experts said a theory that Michelle O’Connell shot herself with her boyfriend’s gun lacked credibility.

headline: WikiLeaks, Drought and Syria
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Drought', 'Global Warming', 'Population']
abstract: You can’t understand the Arab awakenings, or their solutions, without considering climate, environment and population stresses.
lead_paragraph: In the 1970s, I got both my bachelor’s and master’s degrees in modern Middle East studies, and I can assure you that at no time did environmental or climate issues appear anywhere in the syllabi of my courses. Today, you can’t understand the Arab awakenings — or their solutions — without considering climate, environment and population stresses.

headline: S.&P.’s Account of an Irate Treasury Secretary
keywords: ['Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Standard & Poor’s is using an account of a conversation between Timothy F. Geithner and the chairman of S.&P.’s parent company to bolster its argument that a government lawsuit amounted to retaliation.
lead_paragraph: Government officials made no secret of their displeasure when Standard & Poor’s downgraded the debt of the United States in 2011.

headline: Lex Fenwick, Dow Jones Chief, Resigns in Shift by News Corp.
abstract: News Corporation, which owns Dow Jones, said it was reviewing the unit’s “institutional strategy.” Mr. Fenwick will be replaced temporarily by William Lewis.
lead_paragraph: Lex Fenwick, the hard-driving chief executive who stumbled in his efforts to transform Dow Jones, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, has resigned effective immediately as the company rethinks its strategy.

headline: IBM: The Cloud Taketh Away
abstract: Changes in computing have led to sales of business units and layoffs, while the “giveth” part remains to be seen for Big Blue. IBM is trying to recover by moving its own businesses to the cloud.
lead_paragraph: If you wondered why IBM has moved so fast on cloud computing in the past couple of months, look at Tuesday’s earnings report. Then get ready for even more action, including sales of business units and staff cuts.

headline: Sarah's Uncertain Path
abstract: Profiling a pregnant teenager in Missouri, this short documentary provides a window into rural poverty in America's heartland.
lead_paragraph: Profiling a pregnant teenager in Missouri, this short documentary provides a window into rural poverty in America's heartland.

headline: Apple iPhone Sales Expected to Break Records
abstract: Apple is expected to announce record iPhone sales for the last quarter of 2013, according to analyst estimates.
lead_paragraph: Last year analysts and critics said Apple iPhone sales would continue to drop. Some said this was because the phone’s design wasn’t different enough from previous models. Others predicted declines because of the iPhone’s screen size, saying it was too small compared with all those XL and XXL Android smartphones.

headline: Same-Sex Newlyweds Sue Utah After Series of Rulings
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Four same-sex couples have sued the State of Utah over its decision not to recognize their marriages or provide any new benefits to them.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — The legal saga in Utah over same-sex marriage grew even more complicated on Tuesday as four couples who had married during the brief window they could do so sued the state over its recent decision not to recognize their marriages or provide any new state benefits to same-sex newlyweds.

headline: ‘Sarah’s Uncertain Path’
abstract: Profiling a pregnant teenager in Missouri, this short documentary provides a window into rural poverty in America’s heartland.
lead_paragraph: Sarah, the subject of this Op-Doc video, lives in a rural town in western Missouri. She is in 10th grade. For generations almost no one in Sarah’s family has finished high school. Sarah vows that she does not want to follow in those footsteps. But how will her life be different? She became pregnant at 15. Her son will be born in February.

headline: The Women in the Kitchen
abstract: A wave of female chefs like Lauren DeSteno is rising through the culinary ranks. More than ever, women fill the jobs that will produce the next generation of restaurant leaders.
lead_paragraph: A wave of female chefs like Lauren DeSteno is rising through the culinary ranks. More than ever, women fill the jobs that will produce the next generation of restaurant leaders.

headline: States Cutting Weeks of Aid to the Jobless
abstract: The rest of the country is following North Carolina’s lead by sharply cutting the maximum number of weeks of unemployment benefits available, transforming the country’s safety net for jobless workers.
lead_paragraph: RIEGELWOOD, N.C. — After losing her job as a security guard in June, Alnetta McKnight turned to food stamps and unemployment insurance to support herself and her 14-year-old son. But her jobless payments ran out after 20 weeks, and now they are living on close to nothing.

headline: Disarming the White House
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Why the president must be able to make recess appointments.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — AMID the coverage of the Christie controversy and the latest budget deal, it was easy to miss the news about last week’s oral arguments before the Supreme Court in the case of National Labor Relations Board v. Noel Canning. And yet the Canning case represents the biggest threat to presidential power in decades, and the stakes in the decision are extremely high.

headline: Tennis’s New Concern: Data Harvesting
abstract: The gambling boom around professional tennis has introduced the public to a new term: courtsiding, which is described as a “type of cheating and betting on sports.”
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — The strangest story of this Australian Open so far involved a man, a smartphone, a consultant service for online gambling, a tennis match, an arrest, allegations of corruption, a new law and much confusion. Naturally, it unfolded without precedent.

headline: Verizon Plans to Buy Intel Media Division to Expand Its Television Services
keywords: ['Cable Television', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Television', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Intel Media was acquired by Verizon, which wants to add TV everywhere there is an Internet connection.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Verizon Communications wants to make TV available whenever customers have an Internet connection, and on whatever screen they are looking at. On Tuesday, the company announced a shot in the arm for those ambitions.

headline: Bee Deaths May Stem From Virus, Study Says
abstract: The mysterious die-offs of honeybees known as colony collapse disorder may be linked to a rapidly mutating virus that jumped to bees from tobacco and soy plants.
lead_paragraph: The mysterious mass die-offs of honeybees that have wiped out roughly a third of commercial colonies each year since 2006 may be linked to a rapidly mutating virus that jumped from tobacco plants to soy plants to bees, according to a new study.

headline: Investors Seek Yields in Europe, but Analysts Warn of Risk
abstract: Investors are piling into the government debt of bailed-out countries like Ireland. But the demand comes despite the problems still plaguing the euro zone.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Ireland recently made its first offering of new debt since leaving its bailout program, the Irish prime minister, Enda Kenny, was already focused on where the money would come from next.

headline: Trying to Control Nerves That Conjure Up Threats
abstract: After some shattering experiences, Khristina Olivo developed a persistent anxiety that can become panic attacks and makes it difficult to find work.
lead_paragraph: There are triggers everywhere, Khristina Olivo said. They surround her.

headline: Banks Take On European Debt, Despite Underlying Problems
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Interest Rates', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Reassured by austerity programs, investors are again loading up on European sovereign debt, despite deep recessions across Southern Europe.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — A wave of euphoria has swept over financial markets because investors now think Europe’s sovereign debt crisis may be ending. But the enthusiasm masks a lingering problem. The harsh austerity programs used to regain their confidence have fanned deep recessions and high unemployment across Southern Europe.

headline: Visiting Scene, Court Calls Forth Memories of Massacre at a Mall
abstract: A chief magistrate led a grim field trip to the Westgate mall in Nairobi, Kenya, the scene of a massacre, bringing along prosecutors, defense lawyers and even the suspects.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Stephen Juma stood in front of the Westgate shopping mall on Tuesday for the first time since the haunting Saturday four months ago when he was directing traffic outside the parking lot. He spoke flatly as he recalled how three gunmen leapt from a car and began shooting, shattering a nation’s sense of security.

headline: Texas Prepares to Execute Mexican Despite Concerns That His Arrest Violated Law
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Capital Punishment']
abstract: The guilt of Edgar Arias Tamayo, who was convicted of killing a police officer in Texas, is not in doubt, but the legality of his arrest is.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Texas officials moved ahead with their plans to execute a Mexican citizen convicted of killing a police officer, even as pressure continued to mount from the State Department, the Mexican government and an international human rights commission to halt the execution because the arrest 20 years ago violated international law.

headline: $2 Billion Deal in Works for Puerto Rico
abstract: Puerto Rico is battling a financial crisis that includes high unemployment and a crushing debt load.
lead_paragraph: Puerto Rico, which is battling a financial crisis of high unemployment and a crushing debt load, is under pressure to show investors and credit-rating agencies that it can still borrow money from the capital markets.

headline: As Losses Mount, Knicks Play Down Pointed Remarks
abstract: Coach Mike Woodson said Tuesday that he was unfazed by Tyson Chandler’s pointed remarks about the Knicks’ defensive schemes after a blowout loss to the Nets on Monday.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Coach Mike Woodson said Tuesday that he was unfazed by Tyson Chandler’s pointed remarks about the Knicks’ defensive schemes after a blowout loss to the Nets on Monday. Having players publicly voice their frustrations is less than ideal, he said, but at least it shows that they care.

headline: Wartime Claim to Fame Divides 2 Italian Towns
keywords: ['World War II (1939-45)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Anzio is engraved in history books as the main landing site of forces that went on to liberate Rome. Now nearby Nettuno is seeking to stake its claim.
lead_paragraph: NETTUNO, Italy — The landing of Allied forces 70 years ago who went on to liberate Rome in World War II is now the focus of a conflict between two seaside towns over which one has the right to commemorate the event.

headline: The Washington Post is De-Kleining
abstract: Does it know what it’s losing?
lead_paragraph: Ezra Klein of Wonkblog is leaving the Washington Post. Not news, exactly — the impending move has been all over the blogs for a while. But now it’s official. And may I say respectfully to the Post: You idiots!

headline: Knicks Not a Pretty Picture When Painted by Numbers
abstract: The Knicks are bad on the road (8-12), at home (7-14), against teams with winning records (7-17), against teams with losing records (8-9) and when they wear orange (0-6).
lead_paragraph: An old Johnny Mercer song said you should “accentuate the positive” and “eliminate the negative.” For the Knicks, at the season’s midpoint, that is proving to be a difficult task.

headline: Old McDonald’s
abstract: Fast-food joints provide the elderly with a cosmopolitan alternative to senior centers.
lead_paragraph: THERE’S an old Italian saying, “A tavola non si invecchia,” which means: At the table, you don’t grow old. All of us, of whatever age, need to socialize in public places to feel connected and alive.

headline: Yale Students Tangle With University Over Website
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The shutdown of a course comparison website built by two students turned into something of a free speech cause.
lead_paragraph: The idea did not seem controversial at first: Peter Xu and Harry Yu, twin brothers who are seniors at Yale University, set out to build a better, more user-friendly version of the university’s online course catalog. But as Mark Zuckerberg found when he decided to build a better version of Harvard’s undergraduate student directory, these things can take on a life of their own.

headline: How Gov. Christie Moves Forward
abstract: It will take more than talk of political harmony to wipe away the mounting evidence of bullying by his administration.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, in his second inaugural address on Tuesday, promised to avoid what he called the “attitude of Washington, D.C.” Those in the nation’s government, he said, believe that “I am always right and you are always wrong.”

headline: Sexual Orientation Is No Basis for Jury Exclusion, a Federal Appeals Court Rules
abstract: In a unanimous three-judge panel, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled that a lawyer could not exclude potential jurors simply based on their sexual orientation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gay men and lesbians may not be excluded from juries based on their sexual orientation, the federal appeals court in San Francisco ruled on Tuesday.

headline: A Cap on Wall Street Bonuses?
abstract: The European Union is trying to limit pay that rewards excessive risk by banks. Should the United States do the same?

headline: A Rebuff to Overbroad Watch Lists
abstract: A federal judge finds that mistaken inclusion on the no-fly list violated a Malaysian academic’s due process rights.
lead_paragraph: Public trials are a cornerstone of a democratic society. But in the looking-glass world of legal challenges to the federal government’s terror watch lists, even people who succeed in showing that they were mistakenly included on such a list have no easy path around the walls of official secrecy and obstruction.

headline: Another Syria Peace Conference
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Editorials']
abstract: The lives of millions of civilians depend on an end to the war and the deliveries of humanitarian supplies.
lead_paragraph: Few peace conferences have been set up amid the unrelenting pessimism that surrounds the talks involving Syria that open Wednesday in Switzerland. But while a peace agreement is unlikely to be reached anytime soon, the meeting can still produce useful results. That has to be the approach of the conveners, including the United States, Russia and the United Nations. Crucial early goals should include a cease-fire and the delivery of humanitarian assistance to millions of desperate civilians.

headline: At Senior Bowl, the Focus Is on the Ground Game

lead_paragraph: MOBILE, Ala. — If the playoff performances of the bruising Seattle Seahawks running back Marshawn Lynch did not illuminate how much the N.F.L. still values the rushing game, the scene Monday at Senior Bowl practices brightened the picture even more.

Snowden on Tuesday adamantly denied as “absurd” and “smears” the suggestion by the leaders of the House and Senate Intelligence Committees that he might have been a Russian spy when he downloaded archives of classified National Security Agency documents and leaked them to journalists.

He choreographed a precise diplomatic sequence on Syria that relied on others to perform their roles equally precisely. The choreography did not go as planned, and Mr. Ban stumbled under the spotlight.

headline: 2013 Listed as One of the Warmest Years on Record
abstract: Two government agencies said Tuesday that 2013 was among the warmest years in the global temperature record, though they differed on exactly where it ranked.
lead_paragraph: Two government agencies said Tuesday that 2013 was among the warmest years in the global temperature record, though they differed on exactly where it ranked. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration ranked it as the fourth-warmest year since 1880, tied with 2003. NASA, which uses slightly different methods to compile global temperatures, ranked 2013 as the seventh-warmest year, tied with both 2006 and 2009. Both agencies say that the 14 warmest years in the historical record have all occurred since 1998. Australia was a global hot spot in 2013, suffering the warmest year on record in 104 years. But the United States, which had set a record in 2012, had only its 37th warmest year on record in 2013.

headline: Out of Hamlet’s Shadow Again, and Into the Spotlight
abstract: “Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead” is being presented by the Acting Company, along with “Hamlet.”

headline: Indonesia: Leader Expresses Support for Abused Maid
abstract: President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono joined thousands of Indonesian migrant workers abroad and at home on Tuesday in expressing outrage at the alleged torture of an Indonesian maid by her Hong Kong employer.
lead_paragraph: President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono joined thousands of Indonesian migrant workers abroad and at home on Tuesday in expressing outrage at the alleged torture of an Indonesian maid by her Hong Kong employer. In his first publicized comments on the case, Mr. Yudhoyono insisted that “the law will be upheld” during a phone call with the maid, Erwiana Sulistyaningsih. Ms. Erwiana, 23, returned to Indonesia this month and is being treated at a hospital in the central Java town of Sragen for physical abuse. Mr. Yudhoyono’s comments came a day after the police in Hong Kong arrested a 44-year-old woman in connection with the alleged abuse of Ms. Erwiana. On Sunday, thousands of foreign domestic workers rallied in support of her in the city.

lead_paragraph: Vikram Chandra, a writer and professor at the University of California, Berkeley, explored the underworld of Bombay, now known as Mumbai, in his 2006 novel “Sacred Games.” In it, he looked at the links between organized crime, Bollywood stars, beggars and spies, and his book demonstrated how, despite problems like caste wars and corruption, India manages to hold itself together.

headline: Your Next Job Application Could Involve a Video Game
keywords: ['Hiring and Promotion', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Careers and Professions', 'Tests and Examinations']
abstract: Employers are adopting “Moneyball”-style hiring approaches. But what are they measuring, exactly?
lead_paragraph: Brittni Daron jumped through a lot of hoops before she landed her job as a solution consultant at Oracle. At the tech giant, as at other firms in Silicon Valley to which she applied, she endured weeks ­ — and occasionally months — of phone interviews, in-person interviews, mock presentations, personality tests and technical tests for both the skills she claimed to have and those she didn’t. This might sound a little ridiculous, but it’s not unusual. I’ve met lots of job seekers in the last few years who underwent a similar form of H.R. torture — spelling quizzes, math exams and oddball brainteasers (“If you were a pizza-delivery man, how would you benefit from scissors?”) — only to walk out of the interview room wondering what they’d really just been tested for. “Basically, I could never figure out what they got out of it that qualified or disqualified me for the job,” Daron told me.

headline: Do Parents Have Different Hopes and Standards for Their Sons Than for Their Daughters?
abstract: Do you feel you are treated differently than your siblings of a different sex? In what ways?
lead_paragraph: Parents want all their children, whether they are boys or girls, to be happy and successful. Yet a recent study of Internet search data suggests that American parents do in fact hold different expectations for their children based on sex. For one, they want their boys to be smarter and their girls skinnier.

keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Wills and Estates', 'ANGER (EMOTION)', 'Dementia', 'Baby Boomers']
abstract: Writing or executing a will may mean resolving some familial issues beforehand, rather than having sibling rivalries dominate afterward.
lead_paragraph: Sheila Heen, an expert in negotiation and difficult conversations, is answering reader questions about how to resolve disputes within families and in other parts of life.

headline: Hit 60 and the Must-Have Lists Change
abstract: A plastic pill box with the days of the week becomes one of the hottest — and strangest — things to own when you reach a certain age.
lead_paragraph: There was a lot of old lady stuff I swore years ago I would never do: Take an aqua exercise class, bring groceries home in a wheelie cart, address a waiter as “Young Man,” own a plastic pill box with the days of the week on it. And I am proud to say I have yet to address a waiter as “Young Man.”

headline: Why Rovio Looks to Coca-Cola For Inspiration
abstract: The Finnish gaming company rode Angry Birds to international success. Next up: the dream of interacting with one billion customers.
lead_paragraph: Peter Vesterbacka is the chief marketing officer for Rovio, the Finnish gaming and entertainment company behind the Angry Birds franchise. A former executive at Hewlett-Packard, he joined Rovio in 2010, and has helped to steer the company from its Finnish roots to become a global brand with more than two billion downloads for its Angry Birds games. Mr. Vesterbacka is now in charge of expanding Rovio’s brand, including a push into emerging markets like China and new areas like movies and theme parks. The following is an edited interview.

headline: The Start-Up Vortex of Doom
abstract: Introducing a new You’re the Boss blogger, Rebekah Campbell, who will be writing about her efforts to build a tech start-up.
lead_paragraph: Starting a tech company is expensive. That’s why those who start one — unless they can do everything themselves, including designing, coding and selling — must accept fund-raising as an early goal.

headline: Big Web Crash in China: Experts Suspect Great Firewall
abstract: Technology experts say China’s own Great Firewall — the country’s vast collection of censors and snooping technology used to control Internet traffic in and out of China — was most likely to blame for a huge Internet failure, mistakenly redirecting the country’s traffic.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:30 p.m. |

headline: The Old King of the New Spain
abstract: Spain has changed so dramatically that it is perhaps unsurprising the monarchy has failed to keep pace.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — You know a monarchy is in trouble when the queen is jeered at the Royal Theater, of all places, and by a classical music audience. This happened to Queen Sofía of Spain last year in Madrid — a scene then repeated elsewhere with other members of the royal family.

headline: SkyBridge Capital’s Founder Sees Potential of Activist Investors
