abstract: For Anthony Scaramucci of SkyBridge Capital, whose firm has about $6.3 billion invested in hedge funds, there is perhaps no more prominent trend than investors trying to get companies to make better use of their cash reserves.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland – The official themes of the World Economic Forum this year may include innovation and sustainability.

headline: Chinese Web Outage Blamed on Censorship Glitch
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Domain Names (Internet)', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: Chinese authorities suggested the massive disruption was the work of hackers. But others cited a malfunction of the government’s Great Firewall, the sprawling, hidden infrastructure used to restrict what ordinary Chinese can see online.
lead_paragraph: Chinese authorities on Wednesday suggested that a major disruption of the Internet in China this week was the work of hackers. But others blamed the massive outage on a malfunction of the government’s own Great Firewall, the sprawling, hidden infrastructure used to restrict what ordinary Chinese can see online.

headline: How Inactivity Changes the Brain
abstract: Being sedentary appears to alter the brain in ways that may affect heart health, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: A number of studies have shown that exercise can remodel the brain by prompting the creation of new brain cells and inducing other changes. Now it appears that inactivity, too, can remodel the brain, according to a notable new report.

headline: On Davos Panel, Calls to Curb Government Data Collection
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The intersection of technology and privacy issues presents a unique challenge for businesses as governments increasingly seek to collect vast amounts of data on the public, a group of business and political leaders said on Wednesday at the World Economic Forum.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland – The intersection of technology and privacy issues presents a unique challenge for businesses as governments increasingly seek to collect vast amounts of data on the public, a group of business and political leaders said on Wednesday.

headline: Weak I.P.O. a Seeming Setback for Hong Kong’s Superman
abstract: Li Ka-shing’s Hong Kong Electric Investments priced its initial public offering at the bottom of the marketed range, at a time of speculation that he is selling down his investments in Asia in favor of new acquisitions in Europe.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG – Is Hong Kong’s Man of Steel getting a bit rusty?

headline: Europe, Facing Economic Pain, May Ease Climate Rules
keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming']
abstract: The European Union proposed to end binding national targets for renewable energy production, substituting a goal likely to be much harder to enforce.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For years, Europe has tried to set the global standard for climate-change regulation, creating tough rules on emissions, mandating more use of renewable energy sources and arguably sacrificing some economic growth in the name of saving the planet.

headline: Daily Report: San Francisco to Charge Tech Buses a Fee in Pilot Program
abstract: The luxury buses that ferry tech industry workers from San Francisco to the Silicon Valley campuses of their employers are a sore point in the city, where they are forced to use public bus stops, creating traffic congestion.
lead_paragraph: A San Francisco transit agency voted unanimously on Tuesday to start a pilot program to oversee tech company buses, but the volatile issue is a long way from being defused, Malia Wollan and David Streitfeld report.

headline: El-Erian Resigns From Pimco
abstract: Mohamed A. El-Erian is resigning from Pimco. | Morgan Stanley bankers are gauging investor interest in providing $2 billion in financing to Puerto Rico. | Google’s $3.2 billion deal for Nest Labs spurs fears of a tech bubble. | A doctor in former SAC trader’s trial lied to F.B.I.
lead_paragraph: In 2012, William H. Gross, the founder and co-chief investment officer of the Pacific Investment Management Company, known as Pimco, called Mohamed A. El-Erian his “heir apparent.” But on Tuesday, Mr. El-Erian, Pimco’s chief executive and co-chief investment officer, unexpectedly announced that he would step down from his position in March, Nathaniel Popper and Matthew Goldstein write in DealBook. The news shattered any hope that Mr. El-Erian would be the firm’s next leader and called into question who would become the public face of the asset manager.

headline: Poem for a Snowy Winter
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A poem for a chilly January day, with bare branches, restless crows shaking their wings, and rime-covered shrubs.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: VMware Buys Mobile Security Firm for $1.54 Billion
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: The company’s deal for AirWatch is intended to bolster its mobile portfolio in response to a changed technology landscape.
lead_paragraph: Looking to shift its software offerings, VMware has struck a $1.54 billion deal to bolster its mobile technology.

headline: Manuela Frey Transforms Backstage at Bouchra Jarrar
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2014 Couture Collections in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of the Spring 2014 Couture Collections in Paris. Here, the model Manuela Frey before (left) and after (right) makeup by Tom Pecheux and hair by Madeleine Cofano.

headline: Music Directors Named for Ojai Festival
abstract: The Ojai Music Festival’s artistic director, Thomas W. Morris, is looking ahead. Mr. Morris announced the music directors for the next three years.
lead_paragraph: Presumably this year’s Ojai Music Festival in California, scheduled for June 12 to 15, with Jeremy Denk as its music director, is sufficiently settled that its artistic director, Thomas W. Morris, is looking ahead. Mr. Morris announced on Tuesday afternoon the music directors for the next three years. Steven Schick, the percussionist and conductor, will oversee the 2015 festival. The opera and theater director Peter Sellars, who has staged several productions at Ojai, will take over in 2016. And the conductor Esa-Pekka Salonen, who was the festival’s music director in 2001, will return to lead the festival in 2017.

headline: In an Emergency, Call 100. Or is it 1098? Or 103?
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Emergency Telephone Numbers', 'Police', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Robberies and Thefts']
abstract: In big Indian cities like Bangalore, the lack of a unified first-responder system and the inability to crack down on crank calls are endangering people who need help quickly.
lead_paragraph: BANGALORE — “Have you had lunch?” the caller inquired solicitously of the Bangalore police constable who was answering calls on the emergency hotline, and then wanted to know what she had eaten. The constable told him to hang up.

headline: Party City to Try Again to Go Public
abstract: The party-supply retailer Party City Holdco, which runs about 850 stores, has filed documents for an initial offering, but it did not specify how many shares the company’s majority owner, the private equity firm Thomas H. Lee Partners, plans to sell.
lead_paragraph: Party City Holdco Inc., the party supply retailer that runs about 850 stores, has filed documents to raise as much as $500 million through an initial public offering.

headline: It Is Time to Rethink Insurance Regulation
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Insurance', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Treasury Department’s call for a stronger federal role in insurance regulation while preserving states’ regulatory missions, makes sense, writes David Zaring in Another View.
lead_paragraph: David Zaring is assistant professor of legal studies at the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania.

headline: Sold on Yankees, Masahiro Tanaka Gets $155 Million
abstract: About two weeks after a nearly three-hour meeting in Beverly Hills, Calif., the Yankees and Tanaka, a prized pitcher from Japan, agreed to a seven-year, $155 million contract.
lead_paragraph: They met with Masahiro Tanaka for almost three hours at a private residence in Beverly Hills, Calif., on Jan. 8, and the length of the session left the Yankees feeling encouraged. After all, their eight-member delegation had been allotted only one hour to meet with Tanaka, the prized Japanese right-handed pitcher, and his agent, Casey Close, but instead the give-and-take kept going and the Yankees kept making their pitch.

headline: ‘Another Terrible Day for Pakistan’ as Polio Workers Shot
abstract: With the murder of three more vaccine workers in Pakistan comes another set back for the global effort to eliminate polio.
lead_paragraph: Just days after India was declared polio-free, three health workers vaccinating against the disease in neighboring Pakistan were shot and killed. According to the group Human Rights Watch, at least 22 polio vaccination workers were killed and 14 wounded there in 2012 and 2013. Working as part of a team is hazardous duty in Pakistan, where (as the Times reported earlier this year) anger over American foreign policy has led to a “disastrous setback for the global effort against polio.” This summer, Pakistan was believed to be “closer than ever” to eliminating the disease with only 21 reported cases as of July 2013, but by the end of the year that number had risen to 85 for the year, up from 58 in 2012.

headline: Muddy Waters Turns Up Heat on Auditor of Chinese Firm
abstract: Carson C. Block has sent a letter to senior executives of PricewaterhouseCoopers, urging the accounting giant to take a closer look at the books of NQ Mobile, a Chinese security company, which Mr. Block contends is a “massive fraud.”
lead_paragraph: Carson C. Block has already issued a blistering critique of NQ Mobile, a Chinese mobile security company. Now, he is going after NQ Mobile’s auditor.

headline: The First Amendment Protects Abortion Providers, Too
abstract: A judge in North Carolina blocked the state’s ultrasound law from going into effect.
lead_paragraph: On Friday a district court judge in North Carolina issued a ruling that blocked the state’s ultrasound law from going into effect — a move worth celebrating on the 41st anniversary of Roe v. Wade, and at a time when Republican-led states are rushing to enact aggressive new abortion restrictions.

headline: Financial Sector Can Help Bolster Africa’s Economy, Panelists Say
abstract: At a panel looking at Africa in 2015, several speakers argued that opening and supporting more foreign investment would naturally trickle down to the populace.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland – One of the stated aims of this year’s World Economic Forum is inclusion. A panel discussion on Africa’s future, one that included two sitting presidents from that continent, did its best to emphasize that theme.

headline: How to Help Homeless Families
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Homeless Persons', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: There are programs out there, in the city and around the country, with an encouraging success rate.
lead_paragraph: Seeing Dasani Coates standing alongside the dignitaries at Mayor Bill de Blasio’s inauguration earlier this month was a heartening sign. In December, the 12-year-old girl’s struggles living with her family in a decrepit city shelter had been vividly captured in this newspaper in Andrea Elliott’s series “Invisible Child.”  Dasani’s story struck a chord. More than 2,200 readers commented online, expressing sentiments that ranged from admiration for her grit to outrage at the Dickensian circumstances in which she lived. De Blasio had laid out an aggressive agenda to help the city’s most vulnerable residents, promising to expand affordable housing and revive rental-assistance programs for homeless families. Here was a gesture to suggest he was serious.

headline: Trove Is a Treasure for News Junkies
abstract: Graham Holdings, the education and media company left after The Washington Post Company sold its namesake newspaper, is venturing back into news with a new app, Trove, that makes it easy for users to find and curate articles on their favorite topics.
lead_paragraph: Donald E. Graham has sold The Washington Post, but he’s not quite done shaking up the news business.

headline: Image of the Day: January 22
abstract: India celebrates its annual republic day on Jan. 26.

headline: Outside the Fall/Winter 2014 Paris Men’s Shows
abstract: A glimpse at what guys are wearing this season.
lead_paragraph: A glimpse at what guys are wearing this season.

headline: Bitcoin a Fool’s Gold Standard
abstract: The underlying problem in a virtual currency, Edward Hadas of Reuters Breakingviews argues, is the belief that the electronic token’s independence from government is a good thing.
lead_paragraph: I cannot judge whether Bitcoin represents a technological breakthrough, but I am confident that the pseudocurrency’s popularity shows widespread economic amnesia. If Bitcoin ever became a real currency, it would suffer from the crippling problems of the gold standard.

headline: In Our Pages: January 23
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Medicine and Health', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Serial Murders']
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: 1889: A Parisian ‘Jack the Ripper’

headline: Armani Celebrates His Couture Line
abstract: The designer stages a two-day exhibition, while the summer Privé collection reflects his spirit of controlled softness.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — For “One Night Only” — though actually for two days, ending Thursday — Giorgio Armani is displaying the progress of his Armani Privé line.

headline: Ex-Goldman Trader Tourre Fights S.E.C. Penalties in Fraud Case
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mortgages', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: In a court filing, lawyers for Fabrice Tourre attacked the Securities and Exchange Commission’s pursuit of more than $1 million in penalties over his role in creating a soured mortgage deal, calling it “unreasonably severe.”
lead_paragraph: Fabrice Tourre’s Wall Street career is over.

headline: Arizona’s First Concours Crowns a ’25 Hispano-Suiza Best in Show
abstract: Once owned by Andrew Mellon, the car was eventually pushed into an alley and forgotten until its current owner came to the rescue.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Amid the madness of the annual Scottsdale auctions, Arizona held its inaugural concours d'élégance on Jan. 12, giving the state a chance to show its stuff in the elite realm of high-end classic cars. When all the gleaming cars had been judged, a 1925 Hispano-Suiza H6B Cabriolet de Ville won the best in show at the 2014 Arizona Concours d'Élégance.

headline: Letters: ‘Little Failure’ and More
abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of Gary Shteyngart’s memoir, Stephen Burt’s poetry, Frederick Busch’s stories and more.
lead_paragraph: Curses, Hopes and Fears

headline: What Handel Heard on the Way to the Forum
abstract: Operamission performs Handel’s rarely heard “Agrippina” in the Renaissance-style House of the Redeemer.
lead_paragraph: In the era of Netflix’s acerbic political satire “House of Cards,” it’s not hard to see the appeal of Handel’s “Agrippina,” which made its composer’s international reputation when it opened in Venice in 1709. The opera’s ancient Rome is a hotbed of deception and infighting, but music of dazzling variety and eloquence shoots it through with humanity.

headline: Some Businesses Go Creative on Prices, Applying Technology
abstract: Figuring what to charge customers for a product or service can be difficult, but some entrepreneurs are using pricing software or time discounts to their advantage.
lead_paragraph: Many business owners struggle with pricing. Should their first concern be covering costs or figuring out what the market will bear? How do they determine what the market will pay without raising prices high enough that some customers flee? And can they offer discounts without damaging their price brand?

headline: Today in Small Business: ‘Anticipatory Shipping’
abstract: Marijuana ads have been banned by Google and Facebook. The limits of shipping insurance. Is 2014 the year of free hardware?
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Have You Tried Any New Pricing Strategies?
abstract: More small businesses are using software to adjust prices as demand rises and falls.
lead_paragraph: We’ve just published an article about how small companies are starting to use pricing strategies and technologies that previously had been available only to large companies.

headline: Philharmonic Lines Up ‘Joan’ and a Dvorak Festival
abstract: The New York Philharmonic says its 2014-15 season will include a Dvorak festival, new music, film scores, Verdi’s Requiem and Honegger’s “Joan of Arc at the Stake.”
lead_paragraph: There will be new music and world premieres, and not just in the Contact! series of contemporary music. There will be a week of film scores, and a festival devoted to Dvorak. And Avery Fisher Hall will once again be adapted to present a staged event: Arthur Honegger’s dramatic oratorio “Joan of Arc at the Stake.”

headline: What Would Ron Woodroof think?
abstract: The nominated screenwriters of “Dallas Buyers Club” talk about their memories of the real man at the heart of their story.
lead_paragraph: Hell yeah!

headline: A Gilded Goddess Would Rather Be in Philadelphia
abstract: Saint-Gaudens’s 13-foot statue of Diana, admired for decades in New York but moved to a Pennsylvania museum in 1932, has a new coat of gold.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Can we speak frankly? New York really didn’t deserve Diana.

headline: Einhorn Discloses Stakes in BP and Anadarko
abstract: David Einhorn’s firm, Greenlight Capital, said in a quarterly letter to investors on Tuesday that it had taken stakes in BP of Britain and Anadarko Petroleum, which is based in Houston.
lead_paragraph: The hedge fund manager David Einhorn has made a pair of bets on the oil sector.

headline: At Davos, Debate on Whether Banks Have Learned Their Lessons
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Hedge Funds', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Paul Singer, the founder of the hedge fund Elliott Management, said on Wednesday that he remained skeptical of claims that banks “unquestionably understand” the risks on their balance sheets. Two banking executives disagreed.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — Paul Singer, the founder of the hedge fund Elliott Management, said on Wednesday that he remained skeptical that the financial markets were safer despite the changes enacted in the banking industry and by regulators after the financial crisis.

headline: Times Minute | Inactivity and the Brain
keywords: ['Cable Television', 'Geneva Conventions', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Also on the Minute, peace talks on Syria and “Broad City” premieres.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Times Minute | Inactivity and the Brain
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Heart Disease', 'Television']
abstract: Also on the Minute, peace talks on Syria and "Broad City" premieres.
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, peace talks on Syria and "Broad City" premieres.

headline: What’s in Your Fish Oil Supplements?
keywords: ['Dietary Supplements and Herbal Remedies', 'Labeling and Labels', 'Medicine and Health', 'Omega-3 Fatty Acids']
abstract: Millions of Americans take fish oil supplements to promote heart and vascular health. But a new analysis suggests that some consumers may not always get what they are paying for.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans take fish oil supplements to promote heart and vascular health. But a new analysis suggests that some consumers may not always get what they are paying for.

headline: Conservatives and the CBO
abstract: Read the report before you start citing it.
lead_paragraph: Conservatives have recently made a horrifying discovery: if you look not at nominal but at real incomes, Census data do not show a rising tide raising all boats — they show income actually falling for the bottom quintile. Some of them have responded by turning to a CBO report that took account of transfers and taxes, and shows the income of the bottom fifth rising a bit — 18 percent — between 1979 and 2007.

headline: On Drones, Keeping the Public in the Dark
abstract: The 2014 spending bill contained a secret deal on drones.
lead_paragraph: We don’t get to say this very often on The Times editorial page, but Senator John McCain was absolutely right last week to decry a secret deal in the 2014 spending bill. He pointed out that the bill contained a classified section that prohibited the Pentagon from taking over the C.I.A.’s role in carrying out drone strikes, as President Obama has proposed.

headline: Ominous Text Message Sent to Protesters in Kiev Sends Chills Around the Internet
abstract: As the Orwellian text message sent to protesters in Ukraine on Tuesday chills the Internet, it seems worth asking if it is really that unusual.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Andrew Kramer reported, protesters and journalists standing in the vicinity of fighting between the riot police and demonstrators in Kiev on Tuesday received an ominous text message on their phones: “Dear subscriber, you are registered as a participant in a mass disturbance.”

headline: Between Couture Shows, a Fashionable Party
abstract: During a break in the schedule, many in the fashion crowd gathered at the American ambassador’s residence for a party hosted by Anna Wintour.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday evening, in the break in the couture schedule between Bouchra Jarrar that afternoon and Armani Privé that night, many in the fashion crowd gathered at the residence of the United States ambassador on the Rue du Faubourg St.-Honoré (currently without an actual ambassador since Charles Rivkin ended his tenure this summer) for a party to honor Richard Baker, the chief executive of Hudson’s Bay Company, which recently acquired Saks Fifth Avenue. That morning, Mr. Baker had been to the Chanel show, his first time at couture.

headline: A Safe Harbor Without Full Protection
abstract: Systemic risk has been cited as the rationale for special treatment of certain transactions under the bankruptcy code, but the failure to extend these “safe harbors” to actions under state law calls that rationale into question.
lead_paragraph: A recent ruling by a bankruptcy judge in New York adds to a growing body of opinions that appear to leave the door open for actions under state law that would normally be prohibited in federal bankruptcy proceedings.

headline: A Young Picky Eater Surprises His Parents in the Kitchen
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Food', 'Parenting', 'Vegetables']
abstract: During week one of the Picky Eater Project, 4-year-old twins who’d once demanded that their parents serve as short-order toast chefs during meals prove surprisingly willing to eat what they help prepare.
lead_paragraph: Have a picky eater? Christine Zanchi and her husband, Fran Nostrame, an I.T. operations engineer at I.B.M., do. They have twin 4-year-old sons, both of whom critiqued what was on the table before they even sat down. They considered one twin, Andrew, the picky one. He turned his nose up at most everything while his brother Nathaniel ate and tried more foods.

headline: Talent Agency Specializing in TV News Is Acquired
keywords: ['Television', 'News and News Media', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: With its acquisition of N. S. Bienstock, the United Talent Agency is adding more than 600 clients, including Bill O’Reilly and Robin Roberts.
lead_paragraph: N. S. Bienstock, the best-known and largest agency serving television news personalities and producers, including Anderson Cooper and Bill O’Reilly, has become a unit of the United Talent Agency, the major Hollywood representation firm.

headline: Caroline Shaw: 'Improvisation'
abstract: The Pulitzer Prize-winning composer Caroline Shaw performs an improvised piece with violin, voice and a loop station.
lead_paragraph: The Pulitzer Prize-winning composer Caroline Shaw performs an improvised piece with violin, voice and a loop station.

headline: Feeling For | A Modern Heirloom from Fine Jewelry’s Heiress Apparent
abstract: The designer and aristocrat Charlotte Dauphin de la Rochefoucauld launches a new line of delicate baubles — featuring one covetable collar.
lead_paragraph: Among the usual presentations by the fine-jewelry stalwarts of the Place Vendôme happening this couture week, one newcomer stands out. This Thursday, the young designer Charlotte Dauphin de la Rochefoucauld — of the aristocratic French family — will debut her label, Dauphin, with a collection of 21 sparkling yet streamlined styles that she describes as “an ode to a contemporary woman.” Her pieces have a pared-down, architectural quality, with contours molded to accommodate the body’s movements; this standout rose-gold-and-diamond collar took nine months to shape so that it sits on the shoulders and collarbone just so. It’s a marvel of minimalism — yet totally regal.

headline: Renée Fleming to Sing National Anthem at Super Bowl
abstract: The soprano Renée Fleming will be the first opera superstar to sing the anthem at the Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: When the soprano Renée Fleming steps up to the microphone at MetLife Stadium to sing “The Star-Spangled Banner” on Feb. 2, she will be the first opera singer ever to sing the anthem at the Super Bowl. That’s odd, given the song’s range (an octave and a half) and difficulty, but so far the closest the NFL has come to having an opera star sing the anthem was in 2002, when it tapped Mariah Carey, whose mother was an opera singer (and who had the necessary range).

headline: An Old Tale for a New Year
abstract: “The Race for the Chinese Zodiac” recounts the legend of how the Jade Emperor assigned each of 12 animals a different year.
lead_paragraph: New York City, which has the largest Chinese population of any city outside Asia, will celebrate the Lunar New Year with a bang on Jan. 31, heralding the start of the Year of the Horse. According to “The Race for the Chinese Zodiac,” by Gabrielle Wang, with illustrations by Sally Rippin, “horses are funny, popular, fearless and hard-working. … They are also confident, spirited, honest, sensitive and brave.” Those born in 1930, 1942, 1954, 1966, 1978, 1990 and 2002 (and any babies expected in 2014) can count themselves lucky to be born under the energetic Equus.

headline: Chilean League Fines Club for Map of Palestine on Jersey
abstract: Palestino, a soccer club popular with Chile’s Palestinian population, was fined for wearing jerseys that depicted a map of Palestine before the creation of Israel.
lead_paragraph: A club in Chile that is popular among fans of Palestinian descent has been fined by the country’s soccer league for wearing game jerseys in which the No. 1 was depicted by a 1947 map of Palestine before the creation of Israel.

headline: Violent Protests in Ukraine
abstract: Scenes from Kiev, where two protesters were killed during clashes with the police.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from Kiev, where two protesters were killed during clashes with the police.

headline: Quiet in the Caribbean
abstract: On a family trip to a remote Colombian territory, the author finds spots for swimming and serenity — just not excitement.
lead_paragraph: I wrapped my arms around Leonardo, our “moto” driver, as he pushed our overloaded Yamaha across the hot, potholed concrete.

headline: Restaurant Report: Fishing With Dynamite in Manhattan Beach, Calif.
abstract: This spot, which opened in April, serves serious seafood with a side of humor.
lead_paragraph: When putting together Fishing With Dynamite, David LeFevre had a specific sort of nostalgia in mind. The floor tiles are stripes of red, orange and blue; the chef and owner said they reminded him of the classic Ocean Pacific T-shirt with a sunset emblazoned across the chest. Beneath the bar, skateboard trucks have been repurposed as hooks for purses, and Japanese lobster buoys hang from the ceiling. “It took probably 50 visits to flea markets over two years,” said Mr. LeFevre about compiling items to decorate his East Coast-meets-West Coast seafood restaurant, which opened in April. “It was tough to describe, but I knew when people saw it, they would be like, ‘Oh, God, the space is so comfortable and right.’ ”

headline: Singing, Dancing and Economics
abstract: “Stop Hitting Yourself” views “late-stage capitalism” through the prism of the Busby Berkeley musicals of the 1930s.
lead_paragraph: January is a heady, if exhausting, month in New York for lovers of experimental theater. If you didn’t get your fill at the Under the Radar or the Coil festivals, fear not. Just around the corner is more venturesome theater, this time from the acclaimed collective Rude Mechanicals from Austin, Tex. The company has previously presented its productions “The Method Gun” and “Dionysus in 69” in the city. Those shows illustrated the company’s interest in exploring the history of theater making; the latest production tilts toward Hollywood.

headline: A Note on the Political Economy of Populism
abstract: Why focus on inequality?
lead_paragraph: All indications are that President Obama will make inequality the central theme of his State of the Union address. Assuming he does, he will face two different kinds of sniping. One will come from the usual suspects on the right, shrieking “class warfare”. The other will come from a variety of people, some of them well-intentioned, arguing that while sure, inequality is an issue, the crucial thing now is to get the economy growing and create more jobs; these people will argue that populism is a diversion from the main issue.

headline: VMware Looks to Improve Its Cloud With AirWatch
abstract: Patrick Gelsinger, the chief executive of VMWare, believes some older companies are moving into cloud computing and others are retrenching as customers demand new sorts of technologies.
lead_paragraph: For the technology world, 2014 has become momentous quickly, with billions of dollars moving around and thousands of people losing their jobs. It is all happening as the industry builds for the dominant feature of the next few decades: supercomputing everywhere.

headline: Video of Vigil for Purdue Student Shot and Killed in Classroom
abstract: A vigil was held for a 21-year-old Purdue University student who was killed in the school’s engineering building on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: More than 1,000 students and staff members at Purdue University gathered in the bitter cold for a candlelight vigil Tuesday night to remember 21-year-old Andrew Boldt, who was shot and killed inside a classroom in the university’s Electrical Engineering Building by a fellow teaching assistant.

headline: London Theater Journal: Running Their Mouths
abstract: A revival of Jez Butterworth’s 1995 “Mojo,” with Ben Whishaw, and three Beckett monologues “Not I/Footfalls/Rockaby” are reminders of the complex artistry required to distill words into live theater, and the importance of getting rhythms right.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For all those arriving here limply from distant shores, there’s a guaranteed cure for jet lag at the Harold Pinter Theater. It’s called “Mojo,” and it turns out to be the West End’s version of a quad espresso, laced with steroids.

headline: Car Seats to Face Crash-Test Standards
keywords: ['Child Car Seats', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: A proposed rule to require child-seat manufacturers to meet minimum federal standards for side-impact crashes has been added to the Federal Register.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Federal regulators moved on Wednesday to address a glaring hole in auto safety rules by proposing new crash-test standards to better protect children in car seats.

headline: Jean Paul Gaultier: Spring 2014 Couture
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: In Performance: Caroline Shaw
abstract: In a video, Ms. Shaw performs an improvisational work with violin, voice and a loop station.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t really call myself a composer,” Caroline Shaw told Zachary Woolfe, writing for The Times, despite the fact that she won the 2013 Pulitzer Prize in Music for “Partita for Eight Voices,” a vocal work that Mr. Woolfe described as a “dazzling, emotionally generous take on a Baroque dance suite.”

headline: Chinese Activist’s Lawyers Call His Trial Unfair
abstract: The two lawyers defending Xu Zhiyong were silent in court, saying there was no point waging a legal fight against the prosecution.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The central actors in the trial of one of China’s most influential legal activists remained largely silent on Wednesday morning to protest what they said were flaws in the country’s politicized judiciary.

headline: At a Mexican Hotel, Plump a Pillow, Adopt a Pet
abstract: The Hacienda San Angel hotel in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, offers guests a night’s stay if they adopt a dog or cat from the local Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.
lead_paragraph: Travelers don’t need frequent flyer points to get a free night at an upscale hotel in Mexico. They just need to be willing to go home with a little extra baggage.

headline: Snow Jobs
abstract: Brooks and Collins on the politics of plowing and friendship.
lead_paragraph: David Brooks: Gail, I’m starting this conversation off on a train leaving a very snowy New Haven. The original plan was to make it home to Washington, but I’m pretty sure that in an hour or so the train will be inundated by snow. Mass panic will overtake the passengers. There will be an apocalyptic war of all against all in the snack car, as various passengers claw for the few remaining turkey sandwiches while I am scrunched over in the corner hoarding the little bottles of Chablis. Picture that Cormac McCarthy novel, “The Road.” You’ll have the general idea.

headline: Former Foxconn Managers Detained in a Bribery Case
abstract: Authorities are investigating whether several former managers accepted millions of dollars in bribes from partners of the electronics maker, which is a main supplier to Apple.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Authorities in Taiwan detained several former managers of Foxconn Technology on Wednesday as part of a widening investigation into whether they accepted millions of dollars in bribes from the company’s supply-chain partners.

headline: Japan’s Leader Revels in Limelight at Davos
abstract: Comparing himself to a drill bit ready to bore through Japan’s entrenched systems, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe spoke of the successes that his economic changes have brought to the long-moribund Japanese economy.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — Few of the panels organized by the World Economic Forum this year had drawn as much anticipation as the one featuring Japan’s prime minister, Shinzo Abe.

headline: U.S. Panel Suggests Ways to Reduce Voting Delays
abstract: The recommendations were sought after voters in some locations waited hours to cast ballots in the 2012 presidential election.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan panel created by President Obama after many voters waited hours to cast ballots in 2012 on Wednesday recommended ways to keep delays to no more than a half-hour. But changes are up to the states and 8,000 local jurisdictions, where voting laws have been a partisan battleground since the 2000 presidential recount.

headline: Classical Playlist: Olivia Block, William Christie, Raschèr Saxophone Quartet and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: BLOCK: ‘Karren’Olivia Block, electronics, field recordings(Sedimental)Known as a designer of aural environments, the Chicago musician Olivia Block gets lumped together with electronic improvisers and installation artists. That might not be altogether wrong, but the two tremendous pieces that constitute her newest LP are as rigorously assembled, finely detailed and dramatically taut as any modern composition you might care to name, each evoking a dreamlike story without words. (Steve Smith)

headline: Bankers Urge Britain to Remain Part of European Union
abstract: Though there is ample popular sentiment in Britain for withdrawing from the European Union, the British Bankers’ Association and Citigroup are supporting keeping the country as part of the bloc.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British Bankers’ Association and Citigroup have filed notice with the British government strongly backing a single market, the European Union. The two are emphatically encouraging Britain to step up its influence in Brussels rather than pull back as public sentiment in Britain for inclusion in the European Union wanes.

headline: When They Don’t Know They Are Ill
abstract: Frequently a result of dementia, anosognosia is the inability to recognize one’s own impairment — a phenomenon caregivers know too well.
lead_paragraph: Soon after his wife was diagnosed with frontotemporal dementia, Bill Floyd consulted a neurologist who had been a member of his church. People with this illness don’t know they have it, the doctor warned. They don’t understand that anything is wrong.

headline: Obama Seeks to Raise Awareness of Rape on Campus
abstract: The president created a task force of senior officials to coordinate federal enforcement efforts regarding sexual assault, particularly on college campuses.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Wednesday renewed pressure on colleges and universities to prevent and police sexual assaults on their campuses, creating a task force of senior administration officials to coordinate federal enforcement efforts.

headline: Art About Nothing. No, Really.
abstract: Eszter Salamon performed her solo “Dance for Nothing,” which includes her recital of John Cage’s “Lecture on Nothing,” at the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: The acoustics in the Werner and Elaine Dannheisser Lobby Gallery, on the fourth floor of the Museum of Modern Art, aren’t so great — or not ideal, at least, for dancing nonstop while reciting John Cage’s seminal “Lecture on Nothing,” as Eszter Salamon does in her 2010 solo “Dance for Nothing.”

headline: Paris Couture Week: Alexandre Vauthier Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Erin Baiano.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Erin Baiano.

headline: Crowdfunding Tips for Turning Inspiration Into Reality
abstract: Planning and promoting your idea are critical precursors to beginning an online campaign.
lead_paragraph: MIKE WHITEHEAD’S big idea was to design a better cast-iron skillet. Stephanie Turenko’s big idea was to make an animated short film about her Ukrainian grandmother. Colin Owen’s big idea was to manufacture a hard-to-steal bike light.

headline: Skier Flirts With Danger
abstract: In this episode of Teton Gravity Research’s “Behind The Line,” professional skiers Todd Ligare and others discover a technical line in Alaska that requires jumping two crevasses.
lead_paragraph: In this episode of Teton Gravity Research’s “Behind The Line,” professional skiers Todd Ligare and others discover a technical line in Alaska that requires jumping two crevasses.

headline: Americans Scramble for Propane Amid High Prices and Bitter Cold
abstract: Distribution problems have left swaths of the rural Midwest vulnerable to the cold, and governors in states from New Mexico to Maine have issued decrees to hasten propane delivery.
lead_paragraph: As a second arctic blast barreled through most of the Midwest and Northeast this week, Americans who use propane to heat their homes are scrambling to deal with sharply higher prices and a limited access to the fuel.

headline: Nuclear Corps, Sidelined in Terror Fight, Produces a Culture of Cheating
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Cheating', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Military officials voiced outrage at recent revelations that officers responsible for launching nuclear missiles cheated on tests, but cheating has been a fact of life among the officers for decades, crew members and instructors said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Top military officials were quick to voice outrage over revelations last week that 34 officers responsible for launching the nation’s nuclear missiles cheated on monthly proficiency tests, but few expressed surprise.

headline: Bigger Role for Video Games Is Planned at Tribeca Film Festival
abstract: The Games for Change festival, which promotes the development and distribution of video games with an educational or social-minded focus, will partner with the 2014 Tribeca Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: The annual Games for Change festival, which promotes the development and distribution of video games with an educational or social-minded focus, will partner with the 2014 Tribeca Film Festival, the organizers announced this week. While video games have had a presence at the film festival — Rockstar’s “L.A. Noire” was featured in 2011, and Sony’s “Beyond: Two Souls” was included in 2013 — this partnership represents a more formal integration of games and films.

headline: Shifts in Art Market at Center of Loeb-Sotheby’s Debate
abstract: Both Sotheby’s and its archrival Christie’s are pursuing customers in new markets, especially China. Where there’s more of a difference is in how broadly the two firms go about attracting new buyers and sellers, writes Richard Beales in Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Daniel S. Loeb is wrestling with Sotheby’s over a new art paradigm. Mr. Loeb, the founder of the hedge fund Third Point, is essentially estimating the the auction house should be more like its privately held archrival Christie’s.

headline: Next for Tony-Winning Actor Porter: Writing a New Play
abstract: Works by Mr. Ives (“Venus in Fur”), Theresa Rebeck (“Smash”) and Billy Porter (who starred in “Kinky Boots”) will be part of the company’s 2014-15 season.
lead_paragraph: New works by Billy Porter (the star of “Kinky Boots”), David Ives (“Venus in Fur”) and the New York premiere of a comedy by Theresa Rebeck (“Smash”) will make up the 2014-15 season at Primary Stages, the Off Broadway company announced on Wednesday. Casting and run dates are to be announced.

headline: Pain Relievers May Amplify Flu Spread
abstract: Taking drugs like aspirin, acetaminophen or ibuprofen when you have the flu reduces fever and makes you feel better, but it may increase disease transmission, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: Taking drugs like aspirin, acetaminophen or ibuprofen when you have the flu reduces fever and makes you feel better, but it may have unintended consequences.

headline: Video: Skier Flirts With Danger, and Almost Pays
abstract: In this episode of Teton Gravity Research’s “Behind The Line,” professional skiers Todd Ligare and others discover a technical line in Alaska that requires jumping two crevasses.
lead_paragraph: Behind the Line is a video series produced by Teton Gravity Research that takes you into the minds of skiers. In each episode, the athletes will look back on a line, a jump or a session, and discuss the moment.

headline: Goodyear Reaches Severance Deal With French Union
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Organized Labor', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions']
abstract: Workers at a Goodyear tire plant agreed to accept severance pay that they said was three times as much as the company had initially offered.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Striking workers at a Goodyear tire plant in France agreed on Wednesday to accept severance pay that they said was three times as much as the company had initially offered, clearing the way for the facility to close after a bitter conflict that escalated into a “boss-napping.”

headline: Santander Consumer Prices I.P.O. at $24 a Share
abstract: Private equity investors in Santander Consumer USA, the American auto-lending arm of the Spanish banking giant Grupo Santander, plan to sell about 75 million shares at $24 each, which would raise $1.8 billion.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:10 p.m. | Santander Consumer USA, the American auto-lending arm of the Spanish banking giant Grupo Santander, priced its initial public offering at $24 a share, a person briefed on the process said late Wednesday.

headline: Andreessen Horowitz Invests in Human Resources Firm Zenefits
keywords: ['Cloud Computing', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Human Resources', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: The start-up, whose cloud-based software helps small businesses manage compliance and human resources-related tasks, said on Wednesday that it had raised $15 million in a financing round.
lead_paragraph: Venture capitalists, it seems, are crazy about human resources software.

headline: The Gun Report: January 22, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Dinyal New, 41, lost her only children to gun violence in the span of 19 days. Lee Weathersby, 13, who was a strong student at Alliance Academy in east Oakland, Calif., was gunned down as he made his way home from a party at the Boys & Girls Club on New Year’s Eve.

headline: App Smart: Tracking Food Intake
abstract: The Times’s Kit Eaton discusses three apps to help you keep tabs on what you eat.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Kit Eaton discusses three apps to help you keep tabs on what you eat.

headline: Watch What You Eat, Using Your Phone as a Guide
abstract: Apps estimate calorie intake from the bar code information on a food package, or even a photo.
lead_paragraph: I have always been skinny, but I do need to watch what I eat. So I count my calories — with the help of smartphone and tablet apps.

headline: Dabbling in Microsoft Is Enough for Gates
abstract: Bill Gates, the chairman and former chief executive of Microsoft, is said to be willing to adjust his role at the company based on the new chief executive’s wishes.
lead_paragraph: Bill Gates, the chairman and former chief executive of Microsoft, is more involved with the company now than he has been in years. But he does not — repeat, not — want to run it.

headline: Report Says China’s Elite Use Offshore Companies
keywords: ['Foreign Investments', 'News and News Media', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Tax Shelters']
abstract: Leaked documents show that thousands of wealthy, well-connected Chinese have set up companies in tax-haven countries to hold assets, an investigative reporting group says.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Members of the Chinese elite, including some of the country’s most politically connected figures, have set up a large number of offshore companies that allow them to conceal billions of dollars abroad, according to a report released Wednesday by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists, a Washington-based group that works with a number of news organizations around the world.

headline: Springsteen Is No. 1
abstract: Bruce Springsteen’s latest, “High Hopes,” opened at the top of the album chart. Pitbull’s song “Timber,” featuring Kesha, remains the No. 1 single.
lead_paragraph: This week on the music charts, Bruce Springsteen has racked up yet another No. 1.

headline: Below the Line: Production Design on ‘12 Years a Slave’
abstract: The production designer Adam Stockhausen discusses his work on Steve McQueen’s film, and how it is different (and similar) to working on Wes Anderson’s movies.
lead_paragraph: After envisioning larger-than-life sets for Wes Anderson, the production designer Adam Stockhausen had to make the transition from whimsical to historical for “12 Years a Slave.” The designer, who along with the set decorator Alice Baker, is up for an Oscar for the film, said that there are similarities between Mr. Anderson’s more upbeat projects (“Moonrise Kingdom,” the upcoming “Grand Budapest Hotel”) and Steve McQueen’s somber slave drama.

headline: Vintage Tools Help Turn Appetizers Into a Meal
abstract: The London Haydn Quartet, a period ensemble that uses gut strings, offered exquisite renderings of Haydn and Beethoven works at the Morgan Library & Museum.
lead_paragraph: Like a glass of prosecco before a more robust wine, Haydn’s sunny string quartets are often served as an appetizer to a weightier work. But the London Haydn Quartet  has sought to elevate the status of Haydn’s some 75 string quartets, exploring the many neglected gems of his vast catalog.

headline: NBC Looks to Cosby to Revive Its Comedy Prospects
abstract: Network executives say a “multigenerational comedy” starring Bill Cosby is only in the planning stages, but the hope is to restore the luster of NBC comedies.
lead_paragraph: Few performers in history have meant more to a network than Bill Cosby has to NBC, so it is hardly surprising that NBC has reached out again to the famous comic in what appears to be another hour of comedy need.

headline: Living in Manhasset, N.Y.
abstract: An affluent Nassau County hamlet within the Town of North Hempstead is an easy commute from Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: An affluent Nassau County hamlet within the Town of North Hempstead is an easy commute from Manhattan.

headline: Couture in Paris
abstract: Couture designers show their collections in Paris
lead_paragraph: Couture designers show their collections in Paris

headline: A Place on Manhattanites’ Map
abstract: The market remains strong in this hamlet, though agents say that homes are often more affordable than those in surrounding villages.
lead_paragraph: Patrice Burke and her husband, Tim, are on the verge of moving into a two-bedroom two-and-a-half-bath house across from a small park in the heart of Manhasset, steps from the train station. “It’s a wonderful neighborhood, where people really care about their kids, and other people’s kids,” said Ms. Burke, who has a 2-year-old son but has had longer experience with child care in the community as an occasional babysitter for her brother’s children, now 8 and 11.

headline: Renowned Scholar in Egypt Charged With Espionage
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Emad Shahin, a political scientist, was charged along with senior leaders of the Muslim Brotherhood with conspiring to undermine Egypt’s security.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — An internationally respected Egyptian political scientist said Wednesday that prosecutors had filed espionage charges against him, making him the second such scholar targeted this month in a widening crackdown on dissent against last summer’s military takeover.

headline: New Forces Join Lawsuit Fighting Palisades Tower
abstract: Robert F. Kennedy, the Natural Resources Defense Council and the New Jersey Conservation Foundation plan to join a lawsuit challenging the construction of an LG Electronics USA headquarters across the Hudson from the Cloisters.
lead_paragraph: Two months after work began on LG Electronics USA’s new headquarters in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., new opponents have jumped in the battle to scale back the project, which they see as a blight on the Hudson River landscape.

headline: Yanks on a Budget? Yeah, Right
abstract: The Yankees understand there are better and cheaper ways to win, but they shelled out about $500 million this off-season after declines in attendance, television ratings and performance.
lead_paragraph: You’re rich and you’re famished and you’re eager for something new. You find the fanciest restaurant, order everything on the menu and raise a toast. Problems solved. This is going to cost you, but you knew that when you walked in.

headline: A Race Against Time for a Second Child
keywords: ['Biorhythms', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Birth Rates', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Zhejiang Province has become the first to implement legal changes permitting many couples to have two children, after decades of only one. But elsewhere the wait is agonizing for many couples whose biological clock is ticking.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:27 a.m. |

headline: Scene City: Another Night for Armani
abstract: Giorgio Armani hosts “Only Night Only” fete during Paris Couture Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Giorgio Armani hosts “Only Night Only” fete during Paris Couture Fashion Week.

headline: Justices Seem Stumped on Calculating Damages Over Child Pornography
abstract: Three lawyers who appeared before the Supreme Court offered varying answers to the question of what a man owes a woman who was sexually assaulted and depicted in child pornography.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a Supreme Court argument on Wednesday that was part math problem and part seminar on the nature of culpability, the justices seemed to agree on just two things.

headline: A Long and Winding Road
abstract: Washington is the latest stop on the global soccer odyssey of midfielder Yael Averbuch.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes when I’m facing uncertainty or upheaval, I try to think back to what I expected life to be like as a professional soccer player when I first made that my goal.

headline: An Upbeat Brown Urges California to Save Surplus
abstract: In his State of the State speech, Gov. Jerry Brown of California quoted the book of Genesis to stress the state’s need for prudence with its $4.2 billion surplus.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — When Gov. Jerry Brown stepped up on Wednesday to deliver his 11th State of the State speech — a record for California, he was told — the governor momentarily put aside his prepared remarks to offer a more casual greeting.

headline: Airy Enough to Take Flight
abstract: At the Paris Couture shows, designers featured elegantly simple shapes and ethereal fabrics.
lead_paragraph: Magical handwork separates haute couture from the rest of fashion, but it depends on modern ideas to be relevant. Looking at the Paris spring shows online, what stands out are lightness and agility, soothing colors and a reductive view of luxury that feels unusually sensitive to the times.

headline: Putin’s Olympic Fever Dream
abstract: In the Russian city of Sochi, the grandiose and economically dubious megaproject has returned — another Soviet legacy pursued by the singular will of President Vladimir V. Putin.
lead_paragraph: Anatoly Pakhomov was elected mayor of Sochi after the type of ersatz campaign that passes for democracy in Russia. It was 2009, and he had been appointed acting mayor — effectively the local manager of the massive construction project already underway — and in Russia incumbency means victory. His many prospective challengers included a K.G.B. veteran accused of poisoning the fugitive secret-service officer Aleksandr Litvinenko with polonium; a prima ballerina who had become even more famous after the Bolshoi dismissed her for being overweight; and a pornographic actress, Yelena Berkova, who ran a campaign ad that showed her gamboling topless along one of the Black Sea beaches that first made Sochi popular in the early 20th century.

headline: Treasury Secretary Sends Warning on Debt Limit
keywords: ['National Debt (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: The warning by Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew sets up another fiscal showdown, and earlier than congressional leaders had anticipated.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew warned Congress on Wednesday that the government would most likely exhaust its ability to borrow in late February, setting up yet another fiscal showdown with Republicans, and this time earlier than congressional leaders had anticipated.

headline: Absence of Snow Brings Out Hikers and Horses in Yosemite
keywords: ['Hikes and Hiking', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Because of the drought in California, trail rides and hiking are now being offered at Yosemite National Park.
lead_paragraph: One skier’s drought is a potential hiker’s gift.

headline: Expanding the Meaning of ‘One Night’
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Couture Fashion Week', 'Couture (Fashion)', 'Parties (Social)', 'Paris Fashion Week']
abstract: Giorgio Armani’s “One Night” party in Paris goes into overtime.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “One night only?” the editor of a prominent fashion magazine asked as she glanced at the invitation summoning her and practically the entire fashion crowd gathered in Paris for the couture shows this week to a dinner party being hosted by the designer Giorgio Armani. “If so, it must be the longest night in history.”

headline: Rangers Trade Del Zotto to Predators
abstract: Defenseman Michael Del Zotto, once regarded as one of the Rangers’ most promising prospects, had fallen out of favor under Coach Alain Vigneault.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers traded defenseman Michael Del Zotto, who was once considered one of their most promising prospects, to the Nashville Predators on Wednesday for defenseman Kevin Klein.

headline: “I Watched The Film The Song Remains The Same”
abstract: A new song by Sun Kil Moon.
lead_paragraph: A new song by Sun Kil Moon.

headline: The Tea Party and Conservative Reform
keywords: ['Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A response to Michael Needham on populism and conservative policy ideas.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column hailed recent forays by Senators Mike Lee and Marco Rubio as evidence that finally, finally, the ideas that conservative policy reformers have been batting around for a few years may be getting some traction in actual Republican politics. Along the way, I briefly characterized the Tea Party-versus-establishment battle that’s dominated G.O.P. politics as having a “policy substrate,” but too often just being “about posturing and score-settling.” This was, of course, a simplification of a more complex story, and I appreciate the response from Mike Needham of Heritage Action — a figure, it’s fair to say, much involved in the grassroots-establishment fight — because it gives me an opportunity to expand and clarify a bit.

headline: Ready to Strut in Ready-to-Rent
abstract: Invited to the ball but not a thing in the closet? For some women, Rent the Runway’s frills and frocks on loan are the answer.
lead_paragraph: All the world is, alas, no longer a stage. ’Tis a red carpet.

headline: Interpreting the Data: 10 Ways to Teach Math and More Using Infographics
abstract: In this lesson we offer a math-focused list of 10 ways students can learn from and tell stories with the numbers in some recent charts, tables and interactives found in The Times.
lead_paragraph: From stock prices and unemployment rates to trends in tuition and quality of life, the ability to understand and interpret quantitative data is more important than ever in understanding the world.

headline: Traveling Back in Time From the Left, With Context
abstract: “East Towards Home,” a Billy Yalowitz play, features a Jewish New Yorker’s 20th-century mix of storytelling, memories and Woody Guthrie songs.
lead_paragraph: Billy Yalowitz is a young man caught between generations. In “East Towards Home,” his one-act musical drama, the fictional Billy is a Jewish New Yorker, a self-described red-diaper baby (Mommy and Daddy were Communists) born too late for his parents’ revolution. Mostly he’s a Woodstock-era kid who gets stuck regularly in the apartment-building elevator being interrogated by old ladies whose distinguishing accessory is an omnipresent shopping cart.

headline: Paris Couture Week: Giorgio Armani Privé Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Louise Damgaard.

headline: Robot Vacuum Makes War on Cat Hair
abstract: The Roomba 880 from iRobot has the same hockey-puck look as the previous models, but does a superior job in cleaning dust bunnies and pet hair. But the cost may scare off prospective buyers.
lead_paragraph: The robots are coming. Every week, it seems, announcements hail a coming era of personal robots: machines that will ingratiate themselves into our homes by liberating us from despised chores like folding fitted sheets.

headline: Roomba 880: A Clean Sweep
abstract: The Times’s Damon Darlin tests out the Roomba 880, which is quite an expensive vacuum cleaner that is worth the premium.
lead_paragraph: The Times’s Damon Darlin tests out the Roomba 880, which is quite an expensive vacuum cleaner that is worth the premium.

headline: Hints of Sierra Leone’s Progress From an Unexpected Source
abstract: While waiting for Sierra Leone’s president, one of his liaisons entertained us by quoting Russian poetry. There was something magical in that.
lead_paragraph: One morning last April I was in Freetown, Sierra Leone’s capital, reporting the story that ran in the magazine this past weekend about Jeffrey Wright’s attempt to mine gold in the country’s hinterlands. I first spent time in Sierra Leone 14 years ago, during its horrific civil war. Now I followed Wright — along with a team from a major expat mining company that he hoped would become his partner — into Sierra Leone’s statehouse. They were going to meet with the country’s president, Ernest Bai Koroma, to make sure they had the government’s support.

headline: New Products for Aging Hair
abstract: Keratin, a protein found in hair, is the star ingredient of many anti-aging products, but an expert has some additional advice.
lead_paragraph: Keratin, a protein found in hair, is the star ingredient of many anti-aging products, though Dr. Alan J. Bauman, a hair expert, pointed out that “you can’t put keratin back into hair; you can only fill it in temporarily.” Here are a few recommendations.

headline: In Cape Town, Fashion With a Side of Fries
abstract: The South African city is dotted with hybrid businesses, from clothing shops that serve food to a laundry that doubles as a dim sum bar.
lead_paragraph: Step in to I Love My Laundry in Heritage Square in Cape Town, and you’ll think you’ve entered a glamorous wine bar or supper club. You’d be only partly right. The narrow room is dominated by a communal table flanked by 16 upholstered high-back chairs, and at a glance it seems that the only nod to the location’s peculiar name is the clotheslines strung with artwork, prints and pillowcases for sale, or the price tags attached to wine bottles with clothespins. But listen closely and you just might hear the whir of washing machines. I Love My Laundry is a dim sum bar. And an art and wine shop. And a weekly private fondue party. It’s also a front — literally — for a laundromat. In fact, laundry delivery is the core business.

headline: Valentino: Spring 2014 Couture
abstract: Paris
lead_paragraph: Paris

headline: In Milwaukee, a District for a Bite or a Brew
abstract: Walker’s Point, now the city’s go-to neighborhood for innovative artisanal food, is also home to brewery tours and antiques shops.
lead_paragraph: Walker’s Point is historically a factory ward and still home to a sprawling Allen-Bradley plant, operated by Rockwell Automation, and its landmark clock tower. In the past two years, small start-ups have re-energized this working-class neighborhood south of the Milwaukee River. Its cache of brick warehouses has drawn transplants including public Radio Milwaukee, which moved in last fall, and an outpost of the local Stone Creek Coffee. Now the city’s go-to district for innovative artisanal food, it also has a nice smattering of antiques shops for between-bites browsing.

headline: Icahn Adds eBay to His Targets in Technology
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: The activist investor called on eBay to spin off its PayPal business as he nominated two of his employees as candidates for the board.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:08 p.m. | As if taking on Apple wasn’t enough, the activist investor Carl C. Icahn has another big technology company in his sights: eBay.

headline: Bunking With the Stars at Sundance
keywords: ['Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)', 'Movies', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Parties (Social)', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Celebrities']
abstract: With hotel beds scarce at Sundance, some turn to rented group houses. With predictable results.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — The leftover lobster was up to no good.

headline: An Extra 2 Seconds Means the World
abstract: “Perfect” by Rachel Joyce covers a lot of ground: a beautiful, obeisant mother, two kids, a car accident and maybe a scam.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Joyce’s second novel, “Perfect,” is better and less treacly than her first, “The Unlikely Pilgrimage of Harold Fry.” It is eerier, too. Ms. Joyce builds her novel around two 11-year-old English boys who have heard that the year 1972 will be two seconds longer than other years and wonder about the cosmic consequences this change may have. It should go without saying that Ms. Joyce makes the two seconds matter a great deal.

headline: Times Minute | Deadly Protests in Kiev
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Snow and Snowstorms', 'Celebrities', 'Attacks on Police', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Also on the Minute, Mayor Bill de Blasio responds to snowplowing complaints, and a pair of unlikely celebrities.
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, Mayor Bill de Blasio responds to snowplowing complaints, and a pair of unlikely celebrities.

headline: Times Minute | Deadly Protests in Kiev
abstract: Also on the Minute, Mayor Bill de Blasio responds to snowplowing complaints, and a pair of unlikely celebrities.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Tempting and Dangerous. They Sing, Too.
abstract: Kate Soper plays a murderess in “Here Be Sirens,” a blend of an opera and a play.
lead_paragraph: “Do you know what it means to be the insensate apparatus of a homicidal mythological order?” The composer and soprano Kate Soper, portraying Polyxo, one of three mellifluous murderesses of ancient legend, poses that question not long into “Here Be Sirens,” her substantial new musical-theater piece. The Morningside Opera is presenting the work’s premiere engagement at Dixon Place on the Lower East Side.

headline: Portable Charger Adds New Feature: Speakers
abstract: PowerStick.com, the Canadian company behind the handy PowerStick charger, has ventured into new territory: portable speakers.
lead_paragraph: Typically, when a technology company expands its product line, it sticks to its strengths. PowerStick.com, the Canadian company behind the handy PowerStick portable charger, has lately been upgrading its line to offer new features, like increased battery life and solar technology.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Gaza Strip, Pakistan and Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Gaza Strip, Pakistan and Philadelphia.

headline: Push Comes to Shove in Brooklyn
abstract: Shuffleboard comes out of retirement for the younger set.
lead_paragraph: Snow fell at a punishing slant across the darkened warehouses along Union Street in Gowanus, Brooklyn. It couldn’t be further from the sunny retirement communities of Florida, but inside one former factory, the spirit of St. Petersburg lived on.

headline: Caucus Click: Ruing Roe
abstract: Despite the exceptional cold, hundreds of thousands of abortion opponents gathered for the annual March for Life.
lead_paragraph: On the anniversary of the Supreme Court’s Roe v. Wade decision, abortion opponents gather in Washington for the annual March for Life, and, despite the exceptional cold, this year was no exception as hundreds of thousands marched through the capital.

headline: Sundance: Reactions From the Secret Screening of ‘Nymphomaniac’
abstract: A top-secret surprise screening had everyone talking at Sundance.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — It was the whisper heard up and down the mountains and across the packed restaurants and pop-up lounges of Main Street here — which film would be the top-secret surprise screening that publicists and festival organizers at Sundance started touting early this week? Promising a “highly anticipated film by a major filmmaker” that should not be missed, the guesses included Wes Anderson’s “Grand Budapest Hotel,” Lars von Trier’s epic “Nymphomaniac” and — jokingly — the next Tyler Perry or Muppets movie.

headline: England’s Angry Young Man Returns as a Live Wire With Attitude
abstract: In the new adaptation of “The Loneliness of the Long Distance Runner,” blacks and immigrants in Britain face the barriers that a white lower class did in the 1950s.
lead_paragraph: A sense of isolation seems an unlikely affliction for the protagonist of the new stage adaptation of “The Loneliness of the Long Distance Runner,” the story by Alan Sillitoe that was made into a classic 1962 British movie. As portrayed by a dynamic Sheldon Best in Roy Williams’s contemporary rewrite, at the Atlantic Theater Company’s Stage 2, the disaffected Colin bounces around the stage with a buoyant energy that’s matched by his assertiveness and his verbal agility. Far from being a moody sort festering with grievances against a culture determined to put him in a box, this Colin seems to have enough drive to punch his way through any barriers.

headline: For Tresses Feeling Their Age
abstract: Pills with fish protein, laser treatments, even plasma injections are promoted to help keep hair looking its best as it ages.
lead_paragraph: Is hair the new skin? Serums, BB creams, massages and lasers are among the new products and services addressing the issue of women’s aging locks. Many go well beyond covering the gray, which has been the market’s focus (indeed, Diane Keaton let her gray shine, to widespread acclaim, at the Golden Globes).

headline: A Vogue Alum Dives Into Digital With Zappos
abstract: For Zappos Couture, the former Vogue editor André Leon Talley, with his impressive Rolodex, is a welcome presence.
lead_paragraph: IN THE 11 MONTHS since the fashion eminence André Leon Talley parted company with Vogue, he has pursued a number of new gigs. Since February, he has been an editor at large for the Russian version of Numéro magazine. There was talk of a late-night TV show, which has not gotten off the ground. “Nothing has happened with that recently, no meetings, nothing is happening,” Mr. Talley said. (“My Ed McMahon would be Gloria von Thurn und Taxis,” he joked.) Recently he interviewed Diane von Furstenberg for “Entertainment Tonight.”

headline: A Tudor Soap Opera Fills a Stage
abstract: Hilary Mantel’s best-selling novels about Thomas Cromwell and Henry VIII have been adapted for the stage at the Royal Shakespeare Company.
lead_paragraph: STRATFORD-UPON-AVON, England — Thomas Cromwell, the guileful right hand to King Henry VIII, was said to be fluent in many tongues and adept at double talk in all of them. But I imagine even he would be impressed by the act of translation that is taking place in his name at the Swan Theater here.

headline: A How-Not-To Manual for Working Politicians
abstract: Former Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia and his wife, Maureen, stand accused of taking more than $160,000 in loans and gifts in a quid-pro-quo relationship with a favored campaign donor.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia and his wife, Maureen, were accused Tuesday of taking more than $160,000 in loans and gifts in a quid-pro-quo relationship with a favored campaign donor, Jonnie R. Williams, Sr. The couple denied the charges and the courts will ultimately settle the accusation of criminality. Still, the federal indictment, with its glittery descriptions, reads as a How-Not-To manual for working politicians.

headline: The Women’s Under-26 Trial for World Youth Teams
abstract: Only three teams entered the women’s under-26 trial in Atlanta at the beginning of this month.
lead_paragraph: Only three teams entered the women’s under-26 trial in Atlanta at the beginning of this month. A round robin eliminated one, and the other two played a 96-board match to determine the American entry in the World Youth Teams Championships.

headline: Feeling For | An Eco-Lightbulb that Looks Better Naked
abstract: The latest offering from the British design firm Plumen reinvents the reviled (but energy-efficient) compact fluorescent.
lead_paragraph: Old-fashioned filament bulbs may cast a warm, flattering light, but their century-old technology leaves a substantial carbon footprint. What’s more, they’re in trouble with the law. A federal regulation passed in 2007 calls for the production of energy-wasting incandescents to effectively cease as of Jan. 1 of this year — though existing bulbs will remain on store shelves, and ambience-minded interior designers aware of the regulation have for several years been furtively stockpiling them. Last week, Congressional Republicans — apparently not fans themselves of the ghoulish glow of energy-efficient compact fluorescent (C.F.L.) bulbs — attached a provision to the new spending bill that eliminates funding for the law’s enforcement.

headline: The Bubble Canard
abstract: Things I didn’t say.
lead_paragraph: Ah, this one never goes away. I’ll leave the cleanup in the excellent hands of Dean Baker. He’s right to say that anyone trying to make this particular claim is revealing what’s wrong with them, not with me. But I’d quarrel with his “either a fool or a liar” line; why not both?

headline: In the Founder’s Footsteps
abstract: New York City Ballet begins its six-week winter season at the David H. Koch Theater.
lead_paragraph: The experience of Balanchine choreography in performance is as intensely multilayered as anything in the arts. A little ballet, less than 20 minutes long, can plunge us into consuming revelations of style, expression, drama, history, morality, entertainment; into a demonstration of dancing to music as the most exciting interconnection of time and space possible; into complex overlaps among classicism, Romanticism and modernism; into the tension between pure form and poetic communication. And into the capacity of human beings to demonstrate the ideal.

headline: Wells Fargo Sells Servicing Rights on $39 Billion in Mortgages
abstract: Wells Fargo said on Wednesday that it sold the rights to service 184,000 mortgages to Ocwen Financial Corporation, a rapidly expanding company known for its expertise in dealing with subprime borrowers.
lead_paragraph: In another sign of the banking industry’s retreat from the mortgage market, Wells Fargo is selling servicing rights on $39 billion of home loans to a nonbanking firm.

headline: Bugs in Chrome Browser Could Give Access to Microphones
abstract: A software developer discovered a way for malicious websites to use Chrome to listen to conversations happening near a computer, even after the website has been closed.
lead_paragraph: Web developers can exploit bugs in Google’s Chrome browser to listen through a computer’s microphone — even if the browser window is not open, according to a developer who publicly reported the vulnerability Wednesday.

headline: Gaining Accolades, Friends and Steam
abstract: Lupita Nyong’o, who is nominated for an Oscar for her role in “12 Years a Slave,” is this year’s most traditional ingénue and a front-runner for the prize.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Lupita Nyong’o was giving a surprise birthday party for her best friend, Ben Kahn. She pulled out a tray of sweets — “vegan, gluten free,” she noted — and organized a rendition of “Happy Birthday” as Mr. Kahn, 32, who has known Ms. Nyong’o since their college days, grinned. He was being feted at a glittery, exclusive soiree here, surrounded by Hollywood luminaries.

headline: When Your Smartphone Shuts Down From the Cold
abstract: As the winter weather batters the Northeast, people are discovering that their smartphones can shut down in extreme cold. Can these conditions affect the life of your smartphone’s battery?
lead_paragraph: Imagine this: You’re shoveling snow in the blistering cold from another arctic blast. You stop for a moment and pull out your smartphone to see the temperature — “Is it minus 10 degrees yet? It feels like minus 30.” — then your phone shuts off. You frantically press the power button a few times. Nothing. It’s dead, or at least it seems that way.

headline: Excerpt: 'Rake'
abstract: Greg Kinnear stars as a troubled lawyer in this new Fox comedy.
lead_paragraph: Greg Kinnear stars as a troubled lawyer in this new Fox comedy.

headline: The Euthanasia of the Rentier
abstract: Not if the rentiers can help it.
lead_paragraph: A commenter quotes John Maynard Keynes:

headline: He’s a Train Wreck, but Still Kinda Cute
abstract: In “Rake,” on Fox, Greg Kinnear stars as a smart lawyer whose life just doesn’t work.
lead_paragraph: He is late, yes, but he is under a lot of pressure. He can’t understand why she can’t understand.

headline: A Stifled Soul Toughs It Out With At-Home Acts
abstract: “Towheads,” written and directed by and starring Shannon Plumb, focuses on physical comedy as a woman, alienated, tries to keep it all together.
lead_paragraph: “Towheads,” a film written and directed by and starring Shannon Plumb, is a whimsical yet deeply disturbing story about the infantilization and isolation of a stay-at-home mom in Brooklyn. Penelope (Ms. Plumb) is a creative woman with two young children who is trapped under the economic thumb of her husband, Matt, a film director (played by Ms. Plumb’s husband, the director Derek Cianfrance). Matt’s face is not shown, a treatment similar to the handling of adults in a “Peanuts” animated special.

headline: Openings, Events and Sales Starting the Week of Jan. 23
abstract: In need of a little shopping pick-me-up? It’s January in New York City — the answer is yes.
lead_paragraph: Hitting the Racks

headline: Verizon Publishes First Transparency Report on Data Requests
abstract: Verizon Communications on Wednesday published a so-called transparency report describing when and why it receives requests for customer data, like phone records or emails, from law enforcement and government agencies.
lead_paragraph: Verizon Communications on Wednesday published a so-called transparency report describing when and why it receives requests for customer data, like phone records or emails, from law enforcement and government agencies.

headline: The Source | Theaster Gates
abstract: Doug Aitken interviews the artist Theaster Gates.
lead_paragraph: Doug Aitken interviews the artist Theaster Gates.

headline: Paris Couture Week: Valentino Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Alfredo Piola.

headline: Snowfall in New York
