abstract: After a foot of snow hit New York City overnight, travelers complained of canceled journeys and uncleared streets. In his first major test the new mayor, Bill de Blasio, defended the city's response.
lead_paragraph: After a foot of snow hit New York City overnight, travelers complained of canceled journeys and uncleared streets. In his first major test the new mayor, Bill de Blasio, defended the city's response.

headline: Fraternity Suspended After King Day-Themed Party Mocks Blacks
abstract: Civil rights advocates called on Arizona State University to ban the Tau Kappa Epsilon fraternity for hosting a party that mocked blacks.
lead_paragraph: Arizona State University suspended a fraternity, Tau Kappa Epsilon, after members organized a Martin Luther King Day “Black Party,” mocking African-Americans. The fraternity urged guests to show up wearing hoodies, baggy basketball jerseys and bandannas and then share photos of themselves on social media platforms, using hashtags #blackoutformlk, #ihaveadream and #mlkparty.

headline: A Chat With Greenpeace’s Departing U.S. Chief on Old and New Environmentalism
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Environment', 'Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Whales and Whaling']
abstract: A departing Greenpeace leader explores shifts and hard lines in tactics and goals.
lead_paragraph: I was able to fit in 15 minutes this afternoon for an “exit interview,” in essence, with Phil Radford, who is leaving Greenpeace after 10 years of old-fashioned and innovative environmental activism, five at the helm of the organization’s American branch.

headline: Lenovo Near Deal for IBM’s Server Business
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: A deal for the unit could be announced on Thursday, and would represent the successful completion of a deal that almost got done last year.
lead_paragraph: Lenovo is close to finalizing a deal for IBM’s low-end server business, according to people briefed on the process.

headline: Footage of Mayhem on the Streets of Kiev
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Journalists who have been covering the standoff in Kiev for weeks uploaded dramatic images of the spiraling conflict to social networks from the streets on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague David Herszenhorn reports from Kiev, at least two protesters were shot to death on the streets of the Ukrainian capital on Wednesday during pitched battles between the riot police and demonstrators.

headline: When Making Money Is an Obsession
abstract: Readers respond to a Sunday Review article by Sam Polk, a former hedge-fund trader.

headline: Tsongas’s Cancer Battle
abstract: Niki Tsongas, the widow of Paul Tsongas, a 1992 Democratic candidate for president, responds to a column by Maureen Dowd.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,293 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 2,293 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: The Middle-Class Squeeze
abstract: The political economist Robert B. Reich responds to a column by David Brooks.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Occupy Starbucks?
abstract: A reader, 94, writes that the elderly aren’t the only ones who wear out their welcome at cafe tables.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: At Resting Place for France’s ‘Great Men,’ Calls to Include More Women
abstract: Officials have been barraged with suggestions to add a woman to the greats buried in the Panthéon, where Marie Curie is the only woman interred on her own merit.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — As the builders were putting the final stones in place on the Panthéon, France’s monument to some of its most important figures, a young Napoleon wrote, “Men of genius are meteors destined to burn to light their century.”

headline: Purpose After the War
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: A reader offers suggestions for returning soldiers who want to be useful.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Child Hunger in Afghanistan
abstract: Werner Schultink, the chief of nutrition for Unicef, responds to a news article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Strong Finish to 2013 for Netflix as Profit and Subscriptions Soar
keywords: ['Company Reports', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: The company predicted continued growth through the first quarter of this year.
lead_paragraph: Netflix racked up another quarter of impressive growth to finish 2013, surpassing 30 million paid subscribers in the United States for the first time and predicting continued growth through the first quarter of this year.

headline: A New World Around Every Corner
abstract: For a couple of dealers in antique maps, there is only one place that really counts.
lead_paragraph: Not unlike Christopher Columbus, Joseph Gonzalez is in search of the New World. And he has found it some 480 times.

headline: Finding a Needle in a Digital Haystack
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: To stop hackers, companies must be able to visualize data.
lead_paragraph: PLEASANTON, Calif. — LAST year the private sector spent $67.2 billion on cybersecurity services. Nevertheless, according to a recent investigation by Verizon, 60 percent of successful hacks were not detected until months after the attacks began. In the wake of recent high-profile hacker attacks against Target, Neiman Marcus and other retailers, the obvious question is: Why hasn’t all that money done any good?

headline: A Second Chemical Was Part of West Virginia Chemical Spill, Company Reveals
abstract: Freedom Industries revealed this week that the chemical spill in West Virginia on Jan. 9 contained an additional chemical, one that had not been disclosed before.
lead_paragraph: The chemical spill that left 300,000 West Virginia residents without usable water involved more chemicals than the company responsible had previously reported, officials revealed this week, leading the state’s Department of Environmental Protection to order that company to give a full accounting of the chemicals that had leaked into the Elk River.

headline: Abortion Opponents March in Washington on Anniversary of Roe v. Wade Decision
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision)']
abstract: Abortion opponents, trying out a humbler, more inclusive strategy, toned down the rhetoric as they marched on the 41st anniversary of the Supreme Court’s decision in Roe v. Wade.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of abortion opponents descended on Washington for the annual March for Life rally on Wednesday on the 41st anniversary of the decision in Roe v. Wade, the landmark Supreme Court case that legalized abortion.

headline: Owning Up to Being a Home-Schooling Parent
abstract: My corporation values diversity, but somehow being a home-schooling parent felt so far outside the norm that I couldn’t talk about it.
lead_paragraph: Sitting across from the principal, I tried to argue — in a logical, lawyerly way — that my third grader’s standardized test scores were compelling evidence that she needed more than “Clifford, the Big Red Dog.” Although my daughter was bored to distraction by the simple books the teacher assigned, maybe I should have thought twice before requesting special treatment.

headline: U.S. Offshore Wind Farm, Made in Europe
abstract: The promise of new jobs and work failed to come true, revealing shortcomings in the American offshore wind industry.
lead_paragraph: MIDDLEBOROUGH, Mass. — Carl Horstmann strode around the floor of his factory here, passing welders honing head-high metal tubes as sparks flew. He is one of a dying breed: the owner of Mass Tank, a steel tank manufacturer in a down-at-the-heels region that was once a hub of the craft.

headline: Serena Williams May End Boycott of Event at Indian Wells
abstract: Serena Williams said she was considering playing in a tournament at Indian Wells, Calif., where she and her family were jeered in 2001.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — Thanks in part to a movie about Nelson Mandela, Serena Williams has moved toward ending her more than decade-long absence from a high-profile tour event in Indian Wells, Calif.

headline: Own Less, Live More
abstract: An Oregon couple is liberated by a house that is cheap to operate and small enough to vacuum in five minutes.
lead_paragraph: An Oregon couple is liberated by a house that is cheap to operate and small enough to vacuum in five minutes.

headline: Freedom in 704 Square Feet
abstract: An Oregon couple is liberated by a house that is cheap to operate and small enough to vacuum in five minutes.
lead_paragraph: Early in their marriage, Lily Copenagle and Jamie Kennel began crafting a plan for living, scribbling house designs and lists of must-haves on notepads and paper napkins.

headline: We’ve Got Your Number
keywords: ['Search and Seizure', 'Fourth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Gun Control', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Wireless Communications', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Privacy']
abstract: The Supreme Court must decide how old precedents fit with new realities in cases involving cellphones and their users’ privacy.
lead_paragraph: A generation ago, the Supreme Court was faced with deciding whether the police needed a warrant before installing a newfangled device at a telephone company switching office that could record the numbers dialed from a particular telephone. The answer the court gave was no.

headline: The Source | Theaster Gates in Conversation With Doug Aitken
abstract: In our latest installment of this exclusive series of interviews by Doug Aitken, the artist interviews the artist and urban planner Theaster Gates.
lead_paragraph: “I have this great problem of space,” Theaster Gates says. “When planners use words like blight and underdeveloped, it’s like actually what you are talking about is available land.” The artist and urban planner talks to Doug Aitken in an abandoned property on Chicago’s South Side that he calls the Archive House. By adding a reading room and a space for records, Gates has reimagined the property as a hub for artists. Gates (who chatted with Perry Chen of Kickstarter in a conversation published by T last year) has made it his mission to repurpose unused buildings to transform local communities. The interview is part of the Source, a series of candid video conversations with several dozen noteworthy figures about their creative process, currently on view in a custom pavilion at the Sundance Film Festival.

headline: Michigan Governor Asks State Lawmakers to Provide $350 Million for Detroit
abstract: Gov. Rick Snyder urged Michigan’s Legislature to provide $350 million to lessen possible cuts to the pensions of Detroit retirees and save the city’s art collection from the threat of sale.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — With time growing short for leaders here to file a plan for this city’s emergence from bankruptcy, Gov. Rick Snyder on Wednesday urged Michigan’s Legislature to provide $350 million to lessen possible cuts to the pensions of Detroit retirees and save the city’s art collection from the threat of sale.

headline: A Tell-All Born From Goldman Gossip
abstract: Comments heard in the Goldman Sachs elevators are making it into a book.
lead_paragraph: The parody Twitter account @GSElevator, a stream of darkly funny, frequently callous anonymous snippets purportedly overheard in elevators at Goldman Sachs, has offered comments on a dizzying range of topics to its more than 600,000 followers.

headline: Reading Books Is Fundamental
abstract: I enjoy social media, but there is no intellectual equivalent to allowing oneself the time and space to get lost in another person’s mind.
lead_paragraph: The first thing I can remember buying for myself, aside from candy, of course, was not a toy. It was a book.

headline: The Luck of the Pontiff
abstract: The man everybody loves to love is going to be greeting the American president in a matter of weeks. And we have a scandal already.
lead_paragraph: President Obama is going to visit the pope! He’s been to the Vatican before, but not with this pope, who is perhaps the only person in the world almost everybody likes.

headline: Lessons Learned, H&M Returns to Super Bowl With New Beckham Spot
keywords: ['Super Bowl', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Football']
abstract: H&M will poll the public about how its commercial should end in an effort to make the spot more effective and engaging.
lead_paragraph: THE Seattle Seahawks are not the only ones returning to the Super Bowl for a second appearance. So, too, is the retailer H&M, coming back with a commercial that seeks to build on what the company learned two years ago.

headline: Tiger Woods’s Schedule Is Unexpectedly Open After Lindsey Vonn’s Season-Ending Injury
abstract: Woods had planned to step aside from the PGA Tour to watch Vonn, his girlfriend, at the Olympics, but injuries sidelined her.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — For someone who feels as much at home here as a Torrey pine, Tiger Woods enters this week’s Farmers Insurance Open feeling strangely out of sorts. Because of the PGA Tour’s switch to a wraparound schedule that began in October instead of January, Woods, the world’s top-ranked player and the reigning player of the year, will make his season debut Thursday from a pot-bunker-size hole in the FedEx Cup playoff race.

headline: Gay Marriages Confront Catholic School Rules
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Discrimination', 'Education (K-12)', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Homosexuality']
abstract: Some young Catholics have been mystified by a wave of firings and forced resignations at Roman Catholic institutions around the country, most often over gay educators’ decisions to marry.
lead_paragraph: SAMMAMISH, Wash. — Eastside Catholic prides itself on teaching acceptance. At the end of Crusader Way, by the school’s entrance, banners hang celebrating “relationships” and exhorting passers-by to “remember to take care of each other.” Students use a sign-language gesture to remind one another of the school’s emphasis on unconditional love.

headline: Martha Beck, Who Founded the Drawing Center in New York, Dies at 75
abstract: Ms. Beck established the small alternative museum the Drawing Center in SoHo in 1977, and marshaled modest grants to organize exhibitions of major-museum quality.
lead_paragraph: Martha Beck, an art curator who made use of a converted warehouse to found the Drawing Center, an alternative museum in downtown Manhattan that provided a first showplace for emerging artists and an unlikely setting for rarely seen drawings by the likes of Michelangelo, Rembrandt and Cézanne, was found dead on Jan. 6 in her apartment in Manhattan. She was 75.

headline: Giants Hire Another Assistant for Offense
abstract: For the second time this month, the Giants hired a quarterbacks coach from the N.F.C. North, naming Craig Johnson, previously with Minnesota, their running backs coach.
lead_paragraph: For the second time this month, the Giants hired a quarterbacks coach from the N.F.C. North to help resurrect their downtrodden offense.

headline: Modern Family Matters
abstract: The next ‘neglected topic’ suggested by you loyal readers is family breakdown and the rise of single-parent households.
lead_paragraph: When I asked readers for “neglected topics” that journalists should cover more in 2014, one of the suggestions was a delicate but vital topic: family breakdown and the rise of single-parent households.

headline: ‘No Luck’ for a Growing Family
abstract: A father who was unemployed recently got a new job, but it does not pay enough to take care of his wife, baby girl and a baby on the way.
lead_paragraph: It all started with small talk.

headline: Exporting U.S. Rules for Foreign Banks
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Overseas banks like Barclays, Deutsche Bank and Credit Suisse have not had to comply with parts of the Dodd-Frank Act that aim to strengthen the capital they must maintain to absorb losses.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest loopholes on Wall Street may soon close.

headline: Ukrainian Standoff
abstract: Tensions are at a dangerous level. The United States and the European Union need to be doing more than handing out treats to find a peaceful solution.
lead_paragraph: The standoff in Kiev, Ukraine, is now two months old, and it has claimed its first fatalities: two men who died of bullet wounds and a third who fell to his death. With tensions at a dangerous level, and Ukraine’s citizens inflamed by both economic policy and new laws against public assembly, President Viktor Yanukovich met with the three most prominent opposition leaders: the popular boxer Vitali Klitschko, the former economics minister Arseniy Yatsenyuk, and the far-right nationalist Oleg Tyagnibok.

headline: Details Slip By Insider Trial’s Main Witness
abstract: The trial of Mathew Martoma, a former SAC Capital Advisors portfolio manager, took a turn on Wednesday when Dr. Sidney Gilman, the government’s most important witness, showed signs of forgetfulness.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Sidney Gilman, the government’s most important witness in the insider trading trial of Mathew Martoma, a former SAC Capital Advisors portfolio manager, showed signs of a faulty memory on the stand on Wednesday.

headline: A Plan to Make Voting Easier
keywords: ['Voting and Voters', 'Elections', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: A bipartisan commission created by President Obama makes important suggestions for increasing ballot access.
lead_paragraph: A superb report released Wednesday by the Presidential Commission on Election Administration can be summarized in one quick sentence: There are many ways to make voting easier in America. There shouldn’t be the slightest whiff of controversy or partisanship about that concept, or the important suggestions made in the report. But, of course, there is, and that makes the commission’s persuasive logic and research all the more valuable.

headline: Heavy Load in Japan, but a Star Is Used to It
abstract: Tales of ridiculous pitch counts are nothing new in regard to Japanese pitchers, and Masahiro Tanaka’s career is no exception.
lead_paragraph: When a high-profile Japanese pitcher comes to the United States, the news cycle breaks down into three parts: How good is he? How much will he cost? How much has his arm been abused?

headline: Leaning Right in Hollywood, Under a Lens
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Movies', 'Political Action Committees', 'Campaign Finance', 'Elections', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: The Internal Revenue Service is reviewing the activities of the conservative group Friends of Abe in connection with its application for tax-exempt status.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In a famously left-leaning Hollywood, where Democratic fund-raisers fill the social calendar, Friends of Abe stands out as a conservative group that bucks the prevailing political winds.

headline: Political Rumble Over Pre-K
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio would be smart to accept Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s offer to pay for his signature education initiative.
lead_paragraph: Leave it to New York’s top two political alpha males: Gov. Andrew Cuomo and Mayor Bill de Blasio are locked in a contest over something they both agree on. Mr. de Blasio wants to offer free, full-day prekindergarten to every 4-year-old in New York City and pay for it by raising taxes on wealthy residents. Mr. Cuomo is promising to pay for full-day prekindergarten across the entire state, without any tax increase.

headline: State Dept. Learned in November of Photos Said to Show Torture in Syria
keywords: ['Torture', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'United States International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The photos seem unlikely to change the American policy of seeking a settlement to remove President Bashar al-Assad but avoiding direct military action.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration first learned last November about a harrowing trove of photographs that were said to document widespread torture and executions in Syrian prisons when a State Department official viewed some of the images on a laptop belonging to an antigovernment activist, a senior official said Wednesday.

headline: De Blasio Sets Ambitious Goal for Affordable Apartments
keywords: ['Affordable Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Promising to build or preserve 200,000 affordable units over 10 years, Mayor Bill de Blasio seeks to do more than his predecessors in New York City.
lead_paragraph: After Mayor Edward I. Koch instituted his housing plan in the 1980s, New York City created tens of thousands of affordable apartments by renovating vacant buildings in neighborhoods that had been ravaged by arson and abandonment.

abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

abstract: Advocates argue that a diplomatic window created by the nuclear deal is a new opportunity to push for the release of the former Marine, Amir Hekmati.
lead_paragraph: Advocates for a former Marine imprisoned in Tehran more than two years ago are seeking to use a diplomatic window created by the temporary nuclear agreement with Iran to gain his release.

headline: Cousins, Across the Color Line
abstract: Descendants of slave owners and of slaves are recognizing their connections. In my family, it’s especially complicated.
lead_paragraph: EL CERRITO, Calif. — I learned about her through the comments section of an article in Publisher’s Weekly. I had recently published a book of poems crafted out of family stories, and it had been written up, along with a brief interview. In the interview, I reckon with the complicated history of my family — I am a white descendant of Thomas Jefferson — and the fact that some of my ancestors were slave owners from 1670 until the Civil War.

headline: Seahawks’ Richard Sherman, Like Cornerbacks Before Him, Plays Man-to-Man and Goes Toe to Toe
abstract: Anyone who has played cornerback at any level, who has had to play man-to-man with no help, can identify with Sherman, the Seahawks’ dynamic, breast-beating All-Pro.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — I spent three seasons of my college football career at Morgan State University backpedaling.

headline: Enjoying a Total Meltdown
abstract: The glass artist Jeff Zimmerman talks about his interest in performance and why “handblown” is an odd way to describe his work.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Zimmerman, 45, a glass artist, has described his work as a series of “controlled accidents.” The latest results of his live-and-let-melt sensibility went on display this week at R & Company (formerly R 20th Century) in TriBeCa. It is Mr. Zimmerman’s fourth solo show, and it features the crinkled vessels he’s become known for, along with mirrors embedded with reflective glass orbs, geometric pendant lamps and a giant undulating chandelier.

headline: Fighting Extremism on a Broader Level
abstract: Instead of putting out fires following every disaster fueled by sectarian violence, what can world leaders do to fight extremism on a more permanent, global level?

headline: Helping Poor Defendants Post Bail in Backlogged Bronx
abstract: A nonprofit group, the Freedom Fund, helps inmates avoid being coerced into guilty pleas by the criminal court’s notorious trial delays.
lead_paragraph: In October, James Broadus II, then 31, was arrested in Co-op City, the Bronx, and charged with petty larceny and assault. He was accused of taking a book bag from one man and choking another. A judge set bail at $1,000.

headline: Comment by Cuomo Outrages Republicans
abstract: The governor was criticized for saying that candidates who are “extreme conservatives” — which he defined as pro-assault weapon and anti-abortion — have “no place in the state of New York.”
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Still searching for a way, and a person, to beat Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo this fall, the state’s Republican Party may have, at least temporarily, found a talking point: comments by the governor that candidates who are “extreme conservatives” — which he defined as pro-assault weapon and anti-abortion — have “no place in the state of New York.”

headline: When Political Spouse Helps Cause a Downfall
abstract: In most tales of political careers destroyed by personal weaknesses, it is the officeholder’s spouse who winds up humiliated. But there is another drama that plays out, too.
lead_paragraph: Virginia’s first lady needed a designer dress for her husband’s inauguration.

abstract: Competitor Group said last fall that paying such fees no longer made sense from a business perspective.
lead_paragraph: In a reversal, Competitor Group, the organizer of dozens of high-profile running events around the world, said it would immediately reinstate appearance fees for elite athletes.

abstract: Dawn Zimmer, the Hoboken mayor who accused aides to Gov. Chris Christie of making political threats, drifted into politics without a plan only to be vaulted to national attention.
lead_paragraph: Friends call Dawn Zimmer the “accidental politician.”

lead_paragraph: Valley Stream, N.Y. — “I was retired for 30 years, until at the age of 90 I got swept up in this commercial bit,” Morty Kaufman said.

headline: Turkey: More Police Are Fired or Reassigned
abstract: Nearly 500 police officers were either fired or reassigned Wednesday in what appears to be a purge related to a graft inquiry that has already ensnared many of the prime minister’s allies.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 500 police officers were either fired or reassigned on Wednesday, local news outlets said, part of what appears to be a purge related to a graft inquiry that has already ensnared many of the prime minister’s allies. News reports said at least some of the reassigned officers took part in the large corruption investigation. Government critics fear the continuing changes in personnel — hundreds of police officers have already been purged — are meant to derail the investigation. Government officials insist, however, that the changes are legitimate efforts to eliminate what they call a “parallel state.” That refers to those in the judiciary and the police force loyal to a rival of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan. Wednesday’s reshuffle followed the relocation on Tuesday of nearly 100 judges and prosecutors, a move made during Mr. Erdogan’s first visit in five years to Brussels, where he confronted European Union officials’ concerns about the separation of powers and a free judiciary in Turkey.

headline: If You Want to Be Loved, Be Lovable
abstract: Michael Hawkins gets in his own way.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Alert!In today’s (Thursday, Jan. 23, 2014) puzzle, there are elements in the print version that cannot be replicated electronically. We recommend using the PDF for the best solving experience.

headline: Family of South Carolina Boy Put to Death Seeks Exoneration 70 Years Later
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Capital Punishment', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: The family of George J. Stinney Jr., who was put to death at 14 for the murder of two white girls, is seeking exoneration in South Carolina, a state where racial matters still simmer.
lead_paragraph: SUMTER, S.C. — After South Carolina electrocuted George J. Stinney Jr. in 1944, his family buried his burned, 14-year-old body in an unmarked grave in the hopes the anonymity would allow him to rest in peace.

headline: Iran: Surge in Executions Worries Rights Experts
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Iran reportedly hanged 40 people in the first two weeks of January, 33 of them in the last week, leading United Nations human rights experts to call for a halt to the executions.
lead_paragraph: United Nations human rights experts called on Wednesday for an urgent halt to a surge in executions in Iran in recent weeks, observing that the more moderate tone adopted on human rights since President Hassan Rouhani’s election last year has yet to yield any moderation in the country’s punitive practices. Iran reportedly hanged 40 people in the first two weeks of January, 33 of them in the last week, Ahmed Shaheed, the United Nations expert monitoring human rights in Iran, and Christof Heyns, the organization’s expert dealing with summary executions, said in a joint statement released in Geneva. The hangings carried out by Iran since the start of the year follow the execution of 625 people, including 28 women, and a number of political detainees in 2013, an increase of more than 100 over the number of recorded executions the previous year, Mr. Shaheed said.

headline: South Korea: Kidnapped Trade Official Is Rescued
abstract: Local security forces raided the kidnappers’ hide-out in the Libyan capital of Tripoli, the South Korean Foreign Ministry said.
lead_paragraph: A South Korean trade official kidnapped by gunmen in the Libyan capital of Tripoli was rescued on Wednesday by local security forces, who raided the kidnappers’ hide-out, the South Korean Foreign Ministry said on Thursday. The official, Han Seok-woo, the head of the Tripoli office of the government-financed Korea Trade-Investment Promotion Agency, suffered no injuries during the rescue operation, the ministry said in a statement. “The four kidnappers were arrested by the Libyan security officials,” the statement added. Mr. Han, 39, was on his way home from work on Sunday afternoon when four gunmen stopped his car. South Korea then issued a warning against traveling to Libya and asked the 551 South Korean nationals there to leave.

headline: With ‘Virginia Way,’ State Thought It Didn’t Need Rules
abstract: No Virginia laws bar elected officials from taking gifts, nor are there restrictions on what gifts family members of officeholders can take.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The gift-giving scandal that federal prosecutors described in evocative detail in their indictment on corruption charges Tuesday of former Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia and his wife, Maureen, would be ample evidence of a possible crime in some states.

headline: New Speaker Gives Her Allies Plum Posts
abstract: Melissa Mark-Viverito, who won a bitter race two weeks ago for City Council speaker, rewarded her supporters with lucrative Council posts and punished a few adversaries.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks after prevailing in a bitter race for City Council speaker, Melissa Mark-Viverito on Wednesday distributed the spoils of her victory, rewarding allies and punishing at least a few adversaries as she assigned plum Council posts.

headline: Some Parents Bemoan Icy Treks as de Blasio Stands by Choice to Keep Schools Open
abstract: Across New York City on Wednesday, schools grappled with anemic attendance and complaints that Mayor Bill de Blasio had erred by holding class on a day of subzero winds and frozen streets.
lead_paragraph: Anthony M. Armstrong, principal of Middle School 74 in Bayside, Queens, was having a miserable morning. He was groggy from a night of worrying about slippery sidewalks, and a tire on his Chevrolet Equinox had nearly gone flat on his way to work.

headline: Arizona Fraternity Party Stirs Concerns of Racism
keywords: ['Fraternities and Sororities', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Discrimination', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: Online images of students prompted anger and calls for disciplinary action at Arizona State University.
lead_paragraph: TEMPE, Ariz. — Arizona State University is investigating accusations that members of a fraternity gave a party to commemorate Martin Luther King’s Birthday at which nonblack students mocked blacks by donning loose basketball jerseys, flashing gang signs and drinking from hollowed-out watermelons.

headline: Fire Destroys Biodiesel Refinery in Mississippi
abstract: A plant that turns chicken fat into truck fuel burned to the ground after explosions created a fire that was too hot for firefighters to touch.
lead_paragraph: A small biodiesel refinery that turns chicken fat into truck fuel was reduced to ashes on Wednesday by powerful explosions and a huge fire.

lead_paragraph: Sarah Hendrickson, the reigning world champion in the women’s ski jump, was named to the United States Olympic team Wednesday even though she has not competed this season.

headline: Douglas Davis, Newsweek Critic and Internet Artist, Dies at 80
abstract: Mr. Davis was a critic, an author and an artist, whose work explored the possibilities of video and the Internet as creative and interactive mediums.
lead_paragraph: Douglas Davis, who had parallel careers as an art critic for Newsweek and as an artist himself, doing work that explored the possibilities of video and the Internet as creative and interactive mediums, died on Jan. 16 in Queens. He was 80.

headline: Knicks’ Defensive Disarray in Loss to 76ers Puts Woodson on the Spot
abstract: Coach Mike Woodson has dismissed concerns about his defensive schemes, but the problems were glaring in the loss to Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: The list of items that have haunted Knicks Coach Mike Woodson started early this season — practically from opening night. There were personality conflicts with Iman Shumpert, then J. R. Smith, then Chris Smith, then Beno Udrih. Critics nitpicked Woodson’s lineup choices before games and then admonished him over his time management at the end of games. Woodson was not being tough enough on players. He was being too tough on players.

headline: Philadelphia Principals Fired in Cheating Scandal
abstract: Three principals were fired last week after an investigation into test cheating that has implicated about 140 teachers and administrators, a spokesman for the Philadelphia school district said.
lead_paragraph: Three Philadelphia Public Schools principals were fired last week after an investigation into test cheating that has implicated about 140 teachers and administrators, a spokesman for the district said Wednesday.

headline: Leslie Lee, Playwright Who Enlarged Black Life Onstage, Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Lee wrote more than a dozen stage works, but his best-known play was “The First Breeze of Summer,” which was nominated for a Tony Award.
lead_paragraph: Leslie Lee, a playwright whose award-winning work, much of it with the Negro Ensemble Company, focused on stretching the boundaries of the African-American experience as it was portrayed on the stage, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 83.

headline: Sugar Bowls and Creamers: Adding Sweetness and Light
abstract: These dishes bring a lot to the table.
lead_paragraph: Like many people, Jane Kim enjoys a good cup of coffee. But as an architect who has designed several coffee shops, she has given more thought than most to what makes for a satisfying coffee-drinking experience.

headline: John J. McGinty III, Who Gave Away His Medal of Honor, Dies at 73
abstract: Mr. McGinty, a retired Marine Corps officer, received the Medal of Honor for saving the lives of dozens of his men during an enemy attack in Vietnam.
lead_paragraph: John J. McGinty III, a retired Marine Corps officer who received the Medal of Honor for saving the lives of dozens of his men during an enemy attack in Vietnam, but later relinquished it for religious reasons, died on Friday in Beaufort, S.C. He was 73.

headline: These Can Go Anywhere
abstract: Seventy-three dealers will participate in the 60th Winter Antiques Show, including R & Company, which is offering an unusual work by Wendell Castle.
lead_paragraph: Among the eclectic goods at the 60th Winter Antiques Show, which opens Friday, will be a set of library steps. “It’s an unusual piece of furniture,” said Wendell Castle, 81, who designed the piece in 1977 as a departure from staircases, which were more his usual thing. Speaking from his studio in Scottsville, N.Y., he added: “You don’t have to have a specific site. I always like to make things that can go anywhere.”

headline: A Niche for Oomph
abstract: PIQ, a gift shop with something for everyone (no, really), opens in Grand Central Terminal.
lead_paragraph: PIQ, a gift shop that opened last week at Grand Central Terminal, in a space formerly occupied by Pylones, is, like its predecessor, wildly colorful. But the similarities end there. “The Pylones look was about cuteness, and I was tired of cuteness,” said Frédéric A. Rambaud, a founder of the Sarut Group, which manages Pylones stores in New York (two remain) and an owner of the new PIQ. “There’s a new aspect in retail that’s a mix of day-to-day with designer toys. So the grandmother can come in and find something for the grandchildren, and at the same time find something for herself.”

headline: Sales at Canvas, From the Source and Others
abstract: Bargains on cutlery, furniture and more.
lead_paragraph: Everything on Arcadia Home’s website is 30 percent off, through Jan. 31 (a reverse painted mirror jewelry box, regularly $260, is $182; a hand-felted wool flowers tree skirt, regularly $340, is $238); use code HAPPY at checkout, arcadiahomeinc.com.

headline: Into Everyday Life, a Few Drops Fall
abstract: Anthropologie introduces designs by the South African artist Ruan Hoffmann.
lead_paragraph: Ruan Hoffmann, who was born in Pretoria, South Africa, did not set out to be a product designer. He considers his expressionistic ceramic pieces to be art, not craft, and has shown them in galleries and museums throughout Africa and Europe. But after an exhibition of his work at the Anthropologie store in Rockefeller Center in 2011, the retailer encouraged him to create for a mass audience. Mr. Hoffmann set about designing everyday products that would enhance people’s lives. “It’s a big thing to ask of ordinary objects,” he said. “It’s a lot to wish for from a shower curtain, for instance, but then again it could be the catalyst for a daydream.” The Jardin Des Plantes collection, which will be introduced on Thursday, includes dinnerware, bedding, curtains, hardware, wallpaper, vases and, yes, a shower curtain ($108). The rest of the items are from $10 to $1,298. Information: 800-309-2500 or anthropologie.com.

headline: For the Laid-Back, a Limited Edition
abstract: David Weeks is finally producing his Semana lounge chair.
lead_paragraph: David Weeks designed Semana, a leather-and-steel lounge chair, in 1999, but couldn’t find sturdy enough fabric for its production. (Habitat in London was able to solve that problem and sold the chair for 10 years, paying Mr. Weeks a royalty.) Then, while vacationing in Marfa, Tex., last year, he discovered Big Bend Saddlery, whose eighth-of-an-inch-thick leather had the heft he had long sought.

headline: Host’s Pride Rests on an Aging, and Aching, Star Skater
abstract: Russia named Yevgeny Plushenko, who has been struggling after surgery for back injuries, to its only men’s singles spot for the Sochi Games after a closed-door session.
lead_paragraph: It has long been difficult to imagine Russia’s first Winter Olympics without Yevgeny Plushenko, and now that will no longer be necessary.

headline: Texas Executes Mexican Man for Murder
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Capital Punishment', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The state put Edgar Arias Tamayo to death on Wednesday, despite the stated concerns of Mexican officials, Latino advocates and Secretary of State John Kerry that the execution could harm international relations.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — Despite opposition from the State Department, Mexican officials and Latino advocates, Texas executed Edgar Arias Tamayo on Wednesday night, putting to death a Mexican citizen whose case raised questions about the state’s duty to abide by international law.

headline: Resort’s Artistic Streak
abstract: Scribbled-on separates and accessories are sure to draw attention.
lead_paragraph: Usually, we see a designer’s sketches as insight into the creative process behind the final product. But in the resort collections, scribbles are front and center on statement garments and accessories. Chicken scratch has become a new way of coloring inside the lines, like on a Cedric Charlier shirt with a black scribbled collar set atop a salmon sketch pattern, or on a leather Balenciaga dress covered entirely in childlike scrawl. And as one standout piece — a herringbone-scribbled Marc Jacobs bag with a cheetah-print flap and pink-and-white handle — proves, these artistic accessories look best paired with other eye-catching patterns and colors.

headline: A Swede’s Second Set of Heartfelt Electronic Beats
abstract: Eric Berglund, who creates synth-pop music under the name CEO, debuts a track from his upcoming sophomore album.
lead_paragraph: “My music is the opposite of an escape,” says Eric Berglund, the mastermind and sole member of the Swedish synth-pop act CEO. Over the years, Berglund has become an iconic figure in the Swedish musical landscape, creating glossy arrangements equally indebted to Top 40 and experimental dance music. Before striking out on his own, Berglund was one half of the alt-pop duo The Tough Alliance, which during the mid-2000s helped to popularize the Balearic style, a more chilled-out, polycultural brand of dance pop inspired by Ibiza’s club D.J.s. The two also founded the Gothenburg-based record label Sincerely Yours, whose signees — including jj, Air France and The Honeydrips — share a similar sensibility.

headline: Financial Reform Remains a Work in Progress
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: While progress has been made, crucial battle are ahead in bringing the biggest banks under effective control, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz professor of entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

abstract: Li Na, who reached the Australian Open final in 2011 and 2013, beat Eugenie Bouchard in straight sets. On the men’s side, Stanislas Wawrinka reached his first Grand Slam final.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — The Li Na experience continued Thursday afternoon in what was billed as a news conference but came across more like a one-woman show. Li alternated between funny, introspective, philosophical and bemused.

keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'USA PATRIOT Act', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Electronic Communications Privacy Act', 'Privacy']
abstract: The 238-page report is likely to inject a significant new voice into the debate over surveillance, underscoring that the issue was not settled by a speech President Obama gave last week.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An independent federal privacy watchdog has concluded that the National Security Agency’s program to collect bulk phone call records has provided only “minimal” benefits in counterterrorism efforts, is illegal and should be shut down.

headline: Upward Mobility Has Not Declined, Study Says
abstract: The study, which contradicts claims by politicians in both parties, used more data than previous ones.
lead_paragraph: The odds of moving up — or down — the income ladder in the United States have not changed appreciably in the last 20 years, according to a large new academic study that contradicts politicians in both parties who have claimed that income mobility is falling.

headline: Hoboken Mayor Is Said to Have Told of Threat
abstract: Federal authorities have interviewed witnesses who said Dawn Zimmer told them about Lt. Gov. Kim Guadagno’s threat to withhold hurricane recovery funds if she did not support a development project.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities in New Jersey have interviewed several witnesses who said the mayor of Hoboken told them in May about a state official’s threat to withhold hurricane recovery funds if the mayor did not support a development project favored by the governor, people briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

headline: Security Check Firm Said to Have Defrauded U.S.
abstract: The company that conducted a background investigation of Edward J. Snowden fraudulently signed off on hundreds of thousands of incomplete security checks in recent years, the Justice Department said.
lead_paragraph: The company that conducted a background investigation on the contractor Edward J. Snowden fraudulently signed off on hundreds of thousands of incomplete security checks in recent years, the Justice Department said Wednesday.

headline: A Japanese Thread in the Bronx
abstract: Here are snapshots of all six Japanese Yankees, with Masahiro Tanaka set to become No. 7.
lead_paragraph: It all began with Hideki Irabu, who joined the Yankees in 1997 but never lived up to the initial fanfare that greeted him. Hideki Matsui did fulfill expectations, arriving in 2003 and becoming a steady and admirable presence in the Yankee lineup through 2009. After Matsui came Kei Igawa, a left-hander who was unable to pitch effectively in the major leagues.

headline: What’s on Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Discovery) THE FIGHTERS In the gritty neighborhood of South Boston, boxing has a rich heritage as not merely a pastime but a way of life. But the sport’s popularity has declined over the past 20 years, and Peter Welch, the gym owner and former fighter above, is determined to bring it back. In this new series, Mr. Welch works with trainers from rival boxing gyms across the city, who will choose their top amateur fighters to represent them in bouts. After seven days of intensive training, the fighters will take their professional futures — and their reputations — to the ring.

headline: Governor Says It’s All Settled but the Money
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s staff claims that $100 million next year will jump-start prekindergarten, but most estimates indicate that New York City alone needs much more than that.
lead_paragraph: Andrew M. Cuomo arrived at The New York Times in an expansive mood on Wednesday.

headline: Cuomo Sweetens Pre-K Deal: ‘Whatever’ Mayor Needs
abstract: After Mayor Bill de Blasio rebuffed his proposal of $1.5 billion for prekindergarten education, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo offered New York communities a blank check.
lead_paragraph: A day after Mayor Bill de Blasio rebuffed his proposal to set aside $1.5 billion to pay for prekindergarten classes, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo came back on Wednesday with a new offer: a blank check.

headline: A Conversation With: Pankaj Ghemawat, IESE Business School Professor
keywords: ['Business Schools', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Foreign Investments', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: India Ink spoke with Mr. Ghemawat, who co-authored a study that measured the globalization levels of 139 countries, about why India ranked near the bottom of his rankings.
lead_paragraph: Pankaj Ghemawat, a professor of global strategy at the IESE business school in Madrid, and Steven Altman, a senior research associate at IESE, released the 2013 Depth of Globalization report in November, which measures the globalization levels of 139 countries based on flows of trade, capital, information and people. The study found that India, ranked 123rd, was one of the least globalized economies.

lead_paragraph: This year’s Oscar ingenue is Ms. Nyong’o of “12 Years a Slave.” She says it took encouragement to get over the feeling of being an outsider, a phenomenon she dubs “acute impostor syndrome.”

headline: Chinese Rights Advocate Releases Statement on Goals
abstract: Xu Zhiyong, who is on trial in Beijing and accused of disturbing order by organizing public gatherings calling for equal rights to education and for officials to reveal their wealth, laid out his ideas for the New Citizens Movement.
lead_paragraph: One of China’s best-known human rights advocates, Xu Zhiyong, went on trial in Beijing on Wednesday, accused of disturbing order by organizing public gatherings calling for equal rights to education and for officials to reveal their wealth. Mr. Xu remained silent in protest for much of the prosecution’s case, but then tried to defend himself in a statement to the court.

lead_paragraph: In “A Change in the Kitchen,” Julia Moskin writes about how a new vanguard of women is emerging as the next generation of leaders in the nation’s best restaurants.

headline: U.S. and Iran Offer Clashing Accounts of the Civil War in Syria
abstract: The contrasting descriptions illustrated the chasm that still separates the United States and Iran on Middle East issues even as they have agreed on a temporary nuclear accord.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — Secretary of State John Kerry and President Hassan Rouhani of Iran offered clashing accounts on Thursday of the civil war in Syria, and the role that Tehran is playing in the conflict.

headline: Lonnie Holley, the Insider’s Outsider
abstract: Discovered as an artist at 29 and rediscovered as a musician at 62, the Alabama native is never not performing.
lead_paragraph: One night in October, just a couple blocks from Harvard Square, a young crowd gathered at a music space called the Sinclair to catch a performance by Bill Callahan, the meticulous indie-rock lyricist who has been playing to bookish collegiate types since the early ‘90s. Callahan’s opening act, Lonnie Holley, had been playing to similar audiences for two years. A number of details about Holley made this fact surprising: He was decades older than just about everyone in the club and one of the few African-Americans. He says he grew up the seventh of 27 children in Jim Crow-era Alabama, where his schooling stopped around seventh grade. In his own, possibly unreliable telling, he says the woman who informally adopted him as an infant eventually traded him to another family for a pint of whiskey when he was 4. Holley also says he dug graves, picked trash at a drive-in, drank too much gin, was run over by a car and pronounced brain-dead, picked cotton, became a father at 15 (Holley now has 15 children), worked as a short-order cook at Disney World and did time at a notoriously brutal juvenile facility, the Alabama Industrial School for Negro Children in Mount Meigs.

headline: Where the Ice, and the Population, Is Thinning
abstract: The Slovenian photographer Ciril Jazbec, awed by the subsistence hunters of remote northern Greenland, trekked there to document their lives even though he knows only one word in Greenlandic.
lead_paragraph: The landscape in Ciril Jazbec’s photographs of the Arctic is impressive, but not nearly as captivating to him as the people whose daily routines have been affected by rising temperatures and tides. “I am interested in the people,” he said. “Climate change is merely in the background.”

headline: Why Do We Like to Watch Rich People on TV and in the Movies?
abstract: Why are we so obsessed with watching the antics of the 1 percent?
lead_paragraph: A recent Room for Debate post begins, “Several Academy Award contenders like ‘The Wolf of Wall Street’ and ‘American Hustle’ glorify white-collar criminals and scammers, and many reality TV shows embrace the wealthy, too. A new series, ‘#RichKids of Beverly Hills,’ is the latest example of our enthusiasm for ‘ogling the filthy rich.’ Why are we so obsessed with watching the antics of the 1 percent?”

headline: Lenovo Agrees to Buy IBM Server Business for $2.3 Billion
abstract: A disagreement over the price had held up the sale of the division a year earlier.
lead_paragraph: Lenovo said on Thursday that it would pay $2.3 billion for IBM’s low-end server business, successfully concluding a deal that had fizzled a year earlier after the two parties failed to agree on a price.

headline: China Tries to Close Provincial-Sized Hole in Economic Statistics
abstract: A combination of accounting methods and local boosterism may be behind the sum of provincial economic figures repeatedly outperforming the national G.D.P.
lead_paragraph: The growth figures for China’s provinces add up to more than the national total with several yet to report, a discrepancy that experts say can be chalked up to politics and poor bookkeeping.

headline: Man Posts Bail Amid Claims He Relayed Scores to Bettors
abstract: The arrest of a British man represents a rare attempt to prosecute a person for relaying information from a live sports event.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — A British man facing charges that he illegally relayed information from the Australian Open was allowed to post $9,000 bail Thursday to get his passport back.

keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Consumer Protection', 'Privacy', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Maintaining the trust of consumers is imperative as technology makes advertising more tailored and intrusive, Doug McMillon, the incoming chief executive of Wal-Mart, said at Davos.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland – As technology rapidly increases the amount of personal data that is readily available, companies are trying to strike a balance between better tailoring their message to consumers and protecting an individual’s privacy, said Doug McMillon, the incoming chief executive of Wal-Mart Stores said on Thursday.

headline: New York Today: Deep Freeze
abstract: What you need to know for Thursday: the cold snap continues, more commuting headaches and a look back at the Bernhard Goetz case.
lead_paragraph: Updated 11:07 a.m.

headline: A French Clown’s Hateful Gesture
abstract: Behind a provocative comedian’s defiant salute lies a swirl of ugly prejudice that is roiling France.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Sixteen years ago, the leader of the far-right National Front, Jean-Marie Le Pen, deemed the Holocaust a “detail in the history of the Second World War.” Today, a popular comic known as Dieudonné M’Bala M’Bala (his stage name is simply Dieudonné) claims “not to know, between the Jews and Germans,” who’s telling the truth — “but I have my own little ideas on the subject.” We know what those ideas are: Dieudonné invited onstage at one of his shows Robert Faurisson, a “theorist” of Holocaust denial, who argues that the extermination of the European Jews is a Jewish invention.

headline: Tanaka Heads for a Strange Land With a Title in His Sights
abstract: A day after agreeing to a $155 million contract with the Yankees, Masahiro Tanaka said, “I’m going there to win the World Series.”
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Major league sluggers hit hard. Coaches are careful with pitch counts. And New York has bad weather.

headline: 2 Wall Street Moguls Champion Gay Rights
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Daniel S. Loeb of Third Point and Paul E. Singer of Elliott Management spoke of the seeming unlikelihood that prominent investors would take a stand on gay rights.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland – When the World Economic Forum made “inclusiveness” one of its pillar themes, it was safe to assume the assembled corporate leaders would discuss economic issues.

headline: Caution in Davos Over Report of Growth in Europe
abstract: A poll of purchasing managers showed factory output rising at the fastest rate in nearly three years, but many experts remain wary.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — An index of industrial activity in the euro zone has reached its highest level since mid-2011, according to a report released on Thursday. But policy makers, business leaders and economists gathered at the World Economic Forum here seem deeply skeptical about whether growth will be strong enough to cut high levels of youth unemployment in the bloc.

headline: Deciding How Much Employees and Owners Should Make
abstract: While profit-sharing is almost always a popular topic, I don’t remember ever hearing anyone talk about loss-sharing.
lead_paragraph: In my last post, I wrote about my decision not to pay year-end bonuses. As usual, I received some insightful comments in response, including several suggesting that I start sharing more information with my employees so that they have a better sense of how the company is doing. This is something I have thought about quite a bit and I intend to do.

headline: Investigative Stories Delve Into the Use of Offshore Companies by Chinese
abstract: The first big stories of the year have come from the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists, which had received a trove of financial documents on activity mostly in the British Virgin Islands.
lead_paragraph: The first big China investigative story of the year has come from the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists, which on Tuesday published, in tandem with several Western news organizations, a detailed look at the widespread use of offshore companies and tax havens by Chinese businesspeople and relatives of Communist Party leaders.

headline: Bolshoi Theater Names New Music Director
abstract: Tugan Sokhiev of the Orchestre National du Capitole in Toulouse, France, will take over from Vassily Sinaisky, who resigned abruptly last month.
lead_paragraph: The Bolshoi Theater has named Tugan Sokhiev of the Orchestre National du Capitole in Toulouse, France, as its new music director and chief conductor, the theater announced earlier this week. He fills the vacancy left by Vassily Sinaisky, who resigned abruptly last month.

headline: Daily Report: N.S.A. Surveillance Program Is Illegal, Watchdog Says
abstract: The findings are laid out in a report that represent the first major public statement by the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board, which Congress made an independent agency in 2007 and which only recently became fully operational.
lead_paragraph: An independent federal privacy watchdog has concluded that the National Security Agency’s program to collect bulk phone call records has provided only “minimal” benefits in counterterrorism efforts, is illegal and should be shut down, Charlie Savage reports.

headline: Abe’s Version of History Doesn’t Sit Well With Chinese
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan, in his appearance Wednesday at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, said he saw comparisons between Britain and a rising Germany in 1914 and the current tensions between Japan and China.
lead_paragraph: Historians and columnists have made comparisons between Britain and a rising Germany in 1914 and the current tensions between Japan and China; a hot topic at the start of the centenary year of World War I.

headline: When One Person Lives a Lie
keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'Marriages', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Baby Boomers', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments']
abstract: James Guay, a marriage counselor, believes the shift in sexual mores helps break apart relationships couples were once willing to maintain.
lead_paragraph: In the Jan. 16 Unhitched column (“In a Confrontation, a Secret Is Revealed”), Deborah Wells-Clinton and Phil Clinton discussed their 28-year marriage and the enormous secret he had kept from her: Mr. Clinton is gay. Their split, after such a long union, was difficult, but they were able to retain a friendship.

headline: Staring at You, Staring at Me
abstract: Godfrey Reggio’s brooding “Visitors” peers into humanity’s troubled soul with the help of a sober, churning score by Philip Glass.
lead_paragraph: What’s in a face? The first and final images in Godfrey Reggio’s brooding, wordless film “Visitors” are of a gorilla staring into the camera. You can read anything you want into the beast’s inscrutable gaze. Its deep-set eyes may convey primeval wisdom or atavistic aggression, or both, depending on your mood and the impulse to anthropomorphize what you see.

headline: AOL Buys Gravity, a Firm That Personalizes Web Searches
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']

headline: Another Rights Advocate, Hou Xin, Is Tried in Beijing
abstract: Hou Xin, a former journalist who participated in a protest against official corruption, is one of at least eight activists in China being tried this week.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese rights advocate who was part of a group calling for an end to corruption and for officials to disclose their financial assets was tried in Beijing on Thursday on charges of “gathering a crowd to disturb public order,” her lawyer said.

lead_paragraph: Lenovo announced on Thursday that it would acquire IBM’s low-end server business for $2.3 billion, signaling the successful completion of a deal that fell through a year ago, Neil Gough and David Gelles write in DealBook. The server unit, which includes IBM’s x86 server business, brings in an estimated $5 billion in revenue a year.

lead_paragraph: Doug Pepper, a venture capitalist, spent two years researching one particular type of start-up, those that help companies find articles and other content to use in marketing.

headline: As Seen in ‘Goodfellas’: Arrest Is Made in ’78 Lufthansa Robbery
abstract: Vincent Asaro, 78, was accused of playing a role in the robbery at Kennedy International Airport during which a group made away with about $5 million in cash and nearly $1 million in jewels.
lead_paragraph: The crime gripped the public’s imagination, for both its magnitude and its moxie: In the predawn hours of Dec. 11, 1978, a group of masked gunmen seized about $6 million in cash and jewels from a cargo building at Kennedy International Airport.

abstract: The order to free Platon A. Lebedev, a business associate of the recently pardoned oil tycoon Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, was in step with a series of amnesties and pardons before the Winter Olympics.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Taking a cue from President Vladimir V. Putin’s support of amnesties and pardons before the Winter Olympics, the Russian Supreme Court ruled Thursday that the business partner of the former oil tycoon Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky should be released from prison.

headline: Apprenticeships Could Help Reduce Youth Unemployment, Business Leaders Say
abstract: Leaders of manufacturing companies, facing an aging population of skilled employees, say apprenticeships and internships can help society avoid a “lost generation” of workers.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland – An old concept may be coming back into vogue as business leaders and governments struggle with ways to address high unemployment rates among young people after the financial crisis: the apprenticeship.

headline: South Sudan Cease-Fire Signed After More Than a Month of Fighting
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION']
abstract: An agreement between the government and rebels loyal to the ousted vice president raised hopes of peace after more than a month of fighting.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The government of South Sudan and rebels loyal to the country’s ousted former vice president signed a cease-fire agreement on Thursday, holding out the prospect of peace after more than a month of fighting that has torn the new nation apart.

headline: Sundance: The One Filmmaker Who Doesn’t Want a Distribution Deal
abstract: Sam Green’s live documentary about record setters is part performance piece, part multimedia experience.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — Distribution is typically the much-sought-after prize for filmmakers here at the Sundance Film Festival, and the higher the price, the better. Not so for the director Sam Green, whose unusual film, “The Measure of All Things” is billed as a “live documentary.”

Yanukovich to defuse Ukraine’s violent civil uprising, new evidence emerged of brutality by the authorities, including a video of a protester stripped naked except for boots by a group of officers from the feared Berkut riot police.

keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Attorneys General', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The decision by Attorney General Mark R. Herring is an abrupt shift from positions taken by Virginia’s socially conservative elected officials.
lead_paragraph: Asserting that Virginia had too often been on the “wrong side” of justice on civil rights matters, the state attorney general asked a federal court on Thursday to invalidate the state’s ban on same-sex marriage, calling the law unconstitutional and oppressive.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Permission to Use Water Cannons
abstract: The British police expect that austerity measures will lead to continued protest.
lead_paragraph: A British police association wants the home secretary, Theresa May, to authorize the use of water cannons by any police force in England and Wales — as a way to deal with possible protests against austerity measures.

headline: Snow Rhino, Fort Greene
abstract: A frozen ungulate has taken up residence in front of a Brooklyn bodega.

abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. is to decide this month if he will seek the death penalty for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who is awaiting trial.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Since the federal death penalty was reinstated, in 1988, attorneys general have authorized it for about 500 defendants. By the end of the month there may be yet another: the accused Boston Marathon bomber, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev.

headline: Bixi Stumbles, but Bikes May Still Benefit Bank Sponsors
abstract: Bixi, the Canadian company behind bike-sharing programs in several cities, has filed for bankruptcy, but Citigroup and Barclays care more about the programs’ popularity among riders.

headline: The Next Big Picture
abstract: “What is a photograph?” asks a show at the International Center of Photography, a question echoed by curators navigating a flood of new works that are far from documentary.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, viewers of “What Is a Photograph?” opening on Jan. 31 at the International Center of Photography, will not even recognize the work on the wall as photographic. There is no easily identifiable subject, no clear representational form.

headline: Asia Is No. 1 Market for Mobile Apps, Study Says

lead_paragraph: The smartphone and tablet phenomena began in the United States, after Apple introduced the iPhone and the iPad. But most of the sales from mobile software are coming from Asia.

headline: Huge ‘Super PAC’ Is Moving Early to Back Clinton
abstract: Priorities USA Action, which played a pivotal role in President Obama’s re-election, formally aligned itself with Hillary Rodham Clinton’s undeclared presidential ambitions.
lead_paragraph: The Obama political operation that once buried Hillary Rodham Clinton’s White House ambitions is now rapidly converging around her possible 2016 presidential bid, conferring on Mrs. Clinton enormous early advantages in money, expertise and voter targeting techniques.

headline: Kerry Cooper of Choose Energy, on Career Management
abstract: The chief executive of Choose Energy, an energy marketplace, says it is a mistake to become good at something you don’t love to do.

abstract: Regulatory demands and related costs remain too high, Bill Gross, chairman of the technology incubator Idealab, said at the World Economic Forum.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland – Government efforts to protect the investing public have had the unanticipated consequence of making it prohibitive for start-ups to seek a public offering, said Bill Gross, chairman of the technology incubator Idealab.

headline: Amid Debate on Migrants, Norway Party Comes to Fore
abstract: A nation that has long prided itself on its liberal sensibilities is divided by a discussion about immigration and its effects on national identity and the country’s social welfare system.
lead_paragraph: MORTENSRUD, Norway — Lise and Kjetil Ulvestrand came to this town south of Oslo in 2005 for the space, the views, the forest and the cheaper rents. Ms. Ulvestrand, a former development worker in Latin America and a social worker with Norway’s immigrants, says she is comfortable around foreigners and different cultures.

headline: Senator Is Lobbying for Inquiry on Herbalife
keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Ponzi and Pyramid Schemes', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Senator Edward J. Markey has asked regulators to look into the business practices of Herbalife, the nutritional supplements company that has long been in the cross hairs of the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman.
lead_paragraph: The hedge fund manager William A. Ackman walked the halls of Congress last year, telling any lawmaker who would listen that he believed Herbalife, a nutritional supplements company, was a fraud. He finally got a break on Thursday, when Senator Edward J. Markey of Massachusetts sent letters to federal regulators urging them to investigate the company.

headline: Universal Plans to Expand Harry Potter Theme Park
abstract: Scheduled to open in June, the expansion will include two major rides, eight stores and a sprawling Leaky Cauldron restaurant.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Forget the long lines for the rides at Universal’s Wizarding World of Harry Potter here. Nearly four years after opening, the attraction is still so popular that visitors routinely wait more than an hour just to get into a shop that sells wands.

headline: Everything New Is Old Again
abstract: Neo-Paleo-Keynesians of the world, unite!
lead_paragraph: Logistical note: I’ll be traveling the next couple of days — family, not work — so little if any blogging. Also, for those who like to plan their TV viewing far in advance, next week I’ll be doing SOTU commentary on CNN. I believe I’ve been assigned to discuss Michelle Obama’s wardrobe, or something.

headline: Much Transformed, Jersey City Is Ready to House Super Bowl Teams
abstract: The two teams in Super Bowl XLVIII will be billeted in two of the hotels that have remade the skyline of this old manufacturing city.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — In recent years, the Jersey City waterfront, with its sweeping view of Manhattan, has gone from a scruffy ne’er-do-well near the wrong end of a Hudson River tunnel to a gentrifying bedroom community for younger Wall Street commuters, who say it is more convenient than Brooklyn neighborhoods like Williamsburg or Fort Greene, and also more affordable.

headline: 1924: Black Flags Fly All Over Russia To Mourn Lenin
abstract: 90 years ago, Lenin’s death was treated at length in The New York Herald, European Edition.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Lenin, the founder of Bolshevism, died this morning [Jan. 22]. After an illness lasting nearly two years, his condition became suddenly worse yesterday, and at five this morning  he lost consciousness, death following two hours later from paralysis of the nerve centres. He was fifty three years old.

headline: After Shaky Beginning, Sides Report Progress at Syria Peace Talks
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: A mediator was laying the ground for face-to-face talks, reflecting the daunting challenges of seeking a political resolution to the conflict.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The fragile efforts to begin a diplomatic process to end the war in Syria seemed on Thursday night to be on track to produce a first round of negotiations, even though the two sides did not appear ready to meet face to face as had initially been hoped.

headline: Fashion, Fairness and the Olympics
abstract: The clever Principle 6 campaign for gay rights catches fire and the attention of the fashion designer Alexander Wang.
lead_paragraph: The February issue of Vogue, which will begin to show up on newsstands this week, includes details and a photo of something new from the celebrated fashion designer Alexander Wang, but it’s not quite like anything he’s done before, and it’s more than a piece of apparel. It’s a statement of solidarity, a cry of protest and a sign of just how many people from just how many walks of life are determined not to let the Olympics come and go without shining a light on Russia’s discrimination against, and persecution of, L.G.B.T. people.

headline: “Mirage” by CEO
abstract: The worldwide premiere of CEO’s single from their sophomore album, “Wonderland.”
lead_paragraph: The worldwide premiere of CEO’s single from their sophomore album, “Wonderland.”

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Winter: A Dirge’
abstract: This Poetry Pairing features “Winter: A Dirge” by Robert Burns and the Opinion article “A Year in Trees” by Bill Hayes.
lead_paragraph: This Poetry Pairing features “Winter: A Dirge” by Robert Burns and the Opinion article “A Year in Trees” by Bill Hayes.

headline: English National Opera Music Director to Depart
abstract: Edward Gardner will leave after the 2014-15 season to become chief conductor of the Bergen Philharmonic. Mark Wigglesworth will take his place.
lead_paragraph: The English National Opera announced a surprise shakeup of its artistic administration on Thursday morning. Edward Gardner, the 39-year-old conductor who has been the company’s music director since 2007, and whose work has been highly regarded critically and successful with audiences, will leave the company after the 2014-15 season to become chief conductor of the Bergen Philharmonic Orchestra in Norway. He will return to the company as a guest conductor in 2016.

headline: Village Council in India Accused of Ordering Rape
abstract: Thirteen people, including the village chief who ordered and participated in the rape, have been arrested in West Bengal, the Indian police said.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A young woman in West Bengal was gang-raped this week on the order of a village council, to punish her for planning to marry a man from outside the village, according to the Indian police.

headline: CreatureCast: Swimming With Cilia
abstract: Cilia are hairlike structures that project from cells. They can move in coordinated, rhythmic waves that propel organisms through water.
lead_paragraph: Cilia are hairlike structures that project from cells. They can move in coordinated, rhythmic waves that propel organisms through water.

headline: Moving, Without Feet to Do So
abstract: This episode of CreatureCast presents two organisms that use cilia for locomotion. One is small and unicellular, the other is a much larger animal.
lead_paragraph: Cilia are hairlike structures that project from cells. They can move in coordinated, rhythmic waves that sweep fluid across the cell surface. If cells are fixed in place, this creates a current of fluid; the cilia that line our respiratory tract remove mucus and debris in this way. If the cilia are on the outside of the organism, the current they create can move the entire organism. This episode of CreatureCast presents two organisms that use cilia for locomotion. One is small and unicellular, the other is a much larger animal.

headline: Video: Lupita Nyong’o
abstract: This season’s breakout ingenue reports that while she felt ready for her role in “12 Years a Slave,” nothing prepared her for the red carpet.
lead_paragraph: Lupita Nyong’o, the actress who plays the tortured slave Patsey in “12 Years a Slave,” is this season’s classic ingenue: nominated for an Oscar for her very first feature film role. But as the Bagger writes Thursday, Ms. Nyongo’o has at times felt overwhelmed by the red-carpet attention: “I think everything in my life has prepared me for this,” she said of playing Patsey, “and then nothing has prepared me for the red carpet.” Read what else she had to say here.
