headline: 36 Hours in Basel, Switzerland
abstract: From bars and boutiques to culture and cuisine, this small city near France and Germany offers plenty to pack into a weekend.
lead_paragraph: For a few days each year, Basel briefly turns into the capital of the world — or at least of the art world. But even when the giant Art Basel fair isn’t taking place (June 19 to 22 this year), this small city in northwest Switzerland offers plenty of pluses for fans of culture: wonderful museums, world-class architecture, quirky bars and polished restaurants, as well as easy access to France and Germany, its two neighbors in the so-called Dreiländereck, or “three-country region.” Fly into Basel’s airport, technically situated on French soil, and take the public transportation links out to Weil am Rhein, a German suburb. While many of the traditional timbered houses proudly display 13th-century construction dates, many of the best attractions arrived just in the past few years.

headline: Behind Staid Steel, a Percolating Boardroom Drama
abstract: The story of GrafTech illustrates the complex dynamics when relations between directors and management turn sour. It also highlights the sensitivity inside the boardroom in an era of activist investors and insider trading.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:57 p.m. | When Craig S. Shular, the chief executive of a small steel company called GrafTech International, retired on Tuesday, it looked like just another management changeover at a midmarket industrial company.

headline: Putting New Spin on Sin City, Las Vegas Woos G.O.P. for 2016 Convention
abstract: The incongruity of the party associated with Christian conservatism gathering in Sin City may be too much for even the most energetic lobbying to overcome.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Almost every imaginable convention has found its way to the Strip. There have been gatherings devoted to electronics, pizza, computers, kitchen equipment and concrete — not to mention guns, butter and pornography. But in the more than a century that there has been a Las Vegas, the city has never hosted a national political convention. Republicans and Democrats have kept their distance from a place that proudly has claimed the mantle of Sin City.

headline: Santander Consumer Shares Rise in Debut
abstract: Santander Consumer USA’s new deal with Chrysler may have helped the company’s debut on the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday, as shares closed up 5 percent on their first day of trading.
lead_paragraph: Santander Consumer USA’s new deal with Chrysler may have helped the company’s debut on the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday, as shares rose 5 percent, closing at $25.20.

headline: London Theater Journal: Stripped of Illusions, but Still Glittering and Gay
abstract: The Menier Chocolate Factory’s production of the famously hard-to-stage musical “Candide” suggests that life may just be endurable — as long as we have the pluck to put on a show about how awful it is.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — This is not perhaps a moment — is it ever? — that you need to be reminded that the world can be cruel and dangerous. The various screens in your life — television, laptop, smartphone — will readily confirm this observation at the push of a button. The dire news they offer is unlikely to make you feel good.

headline: Smut, Refreshed for a New Generation
abstract: Vintage pornography, from hard core’s “golden age” in the 1970s and ’80s, is being restored and featured at art-film houses.
lead_paragraph: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. — Between a detention center and a post office here, there’s a large, unremarkable building on a corner. Other than a few parked cars near a loading dock, there’s not much life outside its off-white walls. But walk through the rickety front door and up the concrete stairs, and what’s inside makes the old Times Square look like Mayberry: thousands of boxes filled to overflowing with sexually explicit films and artifacts.

headline: Quantifying Europe’s ‘Too Big to Fail’ Problem
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Despite recent efforts to overhaul the financial system, analysts from the Royal Bank of Scotland say, European taxpayers may still have to fork out huge sums to rescue the Continent’s banks in a crisis.
lead_paragraph: Blistering complaints that banks are too big to fail are usually heard from the Occupy Wall Street side of the barricades.

headline: Teaching Doctors the Art of Negotiation
abstract: Doctors negotiate every day, almost constantly, yet they receive almost no formal instruction in how to do so.
lead_paragraph: By the time I rushed to his room, my patient had already ripped out his I.V., packed his knapsack and was making his way to the door, his hospital gown, on backward, flapping like a cape over the jeans he had hurriedly slipped on. He told me he felt fine now, after coming in feverish and sweating a few nights back, and despite his poorly controlled H.I.V. and the strong possibility that the lump in his neck was lymphoma. We had been waiting several days for the biopsy results, but now he had had enough.

lead_paragraph: Exposure to sunlight may be a factor in lowering blood pressure.

lead_paragraph: Lorne Michaels, executive producer of “Saturday Night Live,” on Thursday named Colin Jost to be the new co-anchor of the program’s Weekend Update segment, replacing Seth Meyers.

abstract: Announcing five winners and 13 runners-up in our December 2013 contest.
lead_paragraph: In December, we invited students to write raps about the news of 2013.

abstract: Is there a tsunami of retail closings on the way? How one video store stays open.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Healthier Options in the Air
abstract: Delta and American are offering fliers heallhier snack choices.
lead_paragraph: Health-conscious fliers trapped at 30,000 feet no longer have to slim-pick between cans of Pringles and bags of Chex Mix, at least on Delta Air Lines. On transcontinental flights, the carrier recently added wraps made by Luvo, a packaged food maker that uses natural ingredients.

headline: Penguin Announces a Makeover for Inspector Maigret
abstract: Penguin will issue new translations of Georges Simenon’s novels about Jules Maigret, the stolid Parisian detective.
lead_paragraph: Sherlock Holmes isn’t the only pipe-smoking classic detective getting a 21st-century reboot. Inspector Jules Maigret, the stolid Parisian gumshoe created by the Belgian writer Georges Simenon, is about to get his own brand makeover, thanks to a joint effort by Penguin Books and Penguin UK to release all 75 Maigret novels in new English versions by leading literary translators.

headline: Long Live “The Little Prince”
abstract: The classic French novella, currently being made into an animated film, was written entirely in New York — a little-known fact being that’s being celebrated in a new exhibition.
lead_paragraph: The little-known New York roots of a French classic are unearthed in “The Little Prince: A New York Story,” a Morgan Library exhibition that explores the origins of the deceptively profound children’s book. Exiled from France after the German occupation, the author and pilot Antoine de Saint-Exupéry spent the early 1940s in Manhattan, where he gave life to the story of a stranded pilot’s friendship with an otherworldly little boy. He wrote and illustrated “The Little Prince” in homes on Central Park South and Beekman Place and at a Long Island summer retreat and the 52nd Street studio of a friend that later became the French restaurant La Grenouille. The slim novella — which is being adapted for an upcoming 3-D animated film voiced by Rachel McAdams, James Franco and Marion Cotillard — celebrated its 70th anniversary last April and is France’s most-read work. But its undeniable New York influences are rarely explored.

headline: Carlyle Co-Founder’s Formula for Success: Study the Humanities
abstract: American policy makers and educators have put too much of a focus on technical fields and not enough on teaching critical thinking, David M. Rubenstein said during a panel discussion on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland – David M. Rubenstein, the co-founder of the Carlyle Group, believes American students have lost a valuable skill that can help them succeed in business and life: critical thinking.

headline: NT Live: Rory Kinnear in 'Hamlet'
abstract: Rory Kinnear as the title character in the National Theater's production of "Hamlet," which was first broadcast in December 2010.
lead_paragraph: Rory Kinnear as the title character in the National Theater's production of "Hamlet," which was first broadcast in December 2010.

headline: Off Off Off Broadway (at Your Multiplex)

lead_paragraph: Coming soon to a movie theater near you: Orlando Bloom!

headline: U.S. and Canada Urge New Safety Rules for Crude Oil Rail Shipments
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Railroad Accidents and Safety', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: The recommendations by the National Transportation Safety Board and the Transportation Safety Board of Canada come after a series of catastrophic accidents and derailments.
lead_paragraph: In a joint move that highlighted growing concerns about the safety of crude oil transportation by rail, officials from the United States and Canada issued a series of recommendations on Thursday, including that oil-laden trains avoid populated and sensitive areas.

headline: Line Cook’s Pâté
abstract: A chicken-liver spread that is luxurious, inexpensive and easy to make.
lead_paragraph: St. John Frizell runs a small bar and restaurant, Fort Defiance, in the Brooklyn waterfront neighborhood of Red Hook. He is a bartender of the sort often referred to as a mixologist and a restaurateur of skill and passion. His customers are local sharpies and art producers, date-nighters who’ve driven in from Park Slope, families with three generations in tow. The restaurant is a warm destination for those seeking a good drink and a simple meal amid people with similar desires.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘Stranger by the Lake’
abstract: The director Alain Guiraudie narrates a scene from his film.
lead_paragraph: The French director Alain Guiraudie has been making films for two decades, but his latest, “Stranger by the Lake,” is the only one to receive distribution in the United States. It opens Friday at the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the IFC Center. The Lincoln Center organization is also presenting a film series centered on the filmmaker, which will include a comprehensive survey of his work. In this video, he narrates a scene from his new film, where a playful lake swim turns into something much darker.

headline: Excerpt: 'Outside Mullingar'
abstract: Brian F. O’Byrne and Debra Messing in a scene from John Patrick Shanley’s play “Outside Mullingar,” on Broadway at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater.
lead_paragraph: Brian F. O’Byrne and Debra Messing in a scene from John Patrick Shanley’s play “Outside Mullingar,” on Broadway at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater.

headline: Video From NASA on 10th Anniversary of Mars Rover Program
abstract: On the 10th anniversary of the landing of the rover Opportunity, a look at what has been learned from its Martian adventures.
lead_paragraph: When the Mars rovers Spirit and Opportunity landed 10 years ago to explore the Martian surface and geology, they were supposed to spend only three months on the job. But, year after year, the rovers exceeded expectations as they steadily provided NASA scientists with evidence that Mars once had plentiful water at its surface.

headline: Lessons From Blackstone for BlackRock
abstract: BlackRock, the investment company run by Laurence Fink, could return its private equity roots by acquiring a major industry player, writes Jeffrey Goldfarb of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Is it time for BlackRock to revisit its Blackstone heritage?

headline: In Lengthy Session, House Lives Up to ‘Do-Nothing’ Label
abstract: The House had one of its most time-intensive sessions in months this week, even though no legislative business was accomplished.
lead_paragraph: The House held one of its longest sessions in months this week, even though no legislative business was accomplished.

headline: ‘Bacharach Reimagined’ Extends Run
abstract: “What’s It All About? Bacharach Reimagined” will now play through February 16 at New York Theater Workshop.
lead_paragraph: The Off Broadway premiere of “What’s It All About? Bacharach Reimagined” will be extended a second time in its current run at New York Theater Workshop, the theater has announced.

headline: A Loophole for Rapists Is Eliminated in Morocco
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Women and Girls', 'Law and Legislation', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: The Moroccan Parliament voted unanimously to change a law that allows a man convicted of statutory rape to escape punishment if he marries his under-age victim.
lead_paragraph: Two years after a 16-year-old Moroccan girl who was forced to marry the man accused of raping her committed suicide, opening a fierce debate in Morocco, the Islamist-led government has answered calls for change.

headline: Modern Love | Star-Struck
abstract: An entertainment reporter infatuated with Hollywood's most famous starlets has difficulty finding real love.
lead_paragraph: An entertainment reporter infatuated with Hollywood's most famous starlets has difficulty finding real love.

headline: Amazon Publishing Starts a Christian Imprint
abstract: Waterfall Press will publish fiction and nonfiction titles to “provide spiritual refreshment and inspiration,” Amazon announced on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Amazon Publishing on Thursday announced that its book empire was expanding to include Waterfall Press, a Christian imprint to “provide spiritual refreshment and inspiration,” according to a statement announcing the new imprint. The Waterfall titles, fiction and nonfiction in several genres, will be put out by Brilliance Publishing, part of the Amazon.com group of companies.

headline: IBM Happy to Be Rid of Low-End Server Business
abstract: Cheap servers were a drag on Big Blue. Now the company plans to focus on computer hardware with better profit margins.
lead_paragraph: Lenovo of China, already the world’s largest maker of personal computers, has purchased from IBM one of the world’s largest computer server businesses, for what seems like a rock-bottom price. Lenovo gets market share in an area where it is a small player. IBM is shedding a business that was killing its profitability in higher-margin software and services.

headline: U.S. Attorney Subpoenas Christie’s Campaign and New Jersey G.O.P.
abstract: The office is seeking a broad range of records, including emails, text messages, other correspondence and memorandums, calendar entries, spreadsheets and voice mail messages.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors in New Jersey have issued grand jury subpoenas to Gov. Chris Christie’s re-election campaign and to the state Republican Party as part of a preliminary inquiry into accusations that aides to Mr. Christie shut down access lanes to the George Washington Bridge as political retribution, the lawyer for the campaign and the party said Thursday.

headline: Bristling Interrupts Amity in Panel on U.S.-China-Europe Ties
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: In a talk on global relations, tensions briefly flared as a Chinese billionaire took umbrage over an American scholar’s invocations of the troubles over the South China Sea.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — When asked whether China, the United States and Europe can all play nicely together, attendees of the World Economic Forum would be expected to be largely optimistic, even if they disagreed on a few particulars.

headline: If Justin Bieber Weren’t Famous
abstract: The singer, a foreign national, was arrested on suspicion of driving under the influence. Less famous people in his situation would face deportation.
lead_paragraph: A foreign national living in the United States on a work visa is arrested on suspicion of driving under the influence of marijuana, alcohol and prescription drugs, while drag racing in a residential area. Given the climate of hostility toward immigrants in many parts of the country, and the Obama administration’s love affair with deportation, you’d expect him to be sitting in a holding cell awaiting a one-way trip out of the country.

headline: Administration Is Finalizing Budget
abstract: President Obama will send his annual budget to Congress on March 4.
lead_paragraph: President Obama will send his annual budget to Congress on March 4, about a month late because of lawmakers’ tardy agreement on the current fiscal year’s federal spending.

headline: Reading Club | Our Favorite Comments on ‘Invisible Child: Dasani’s Homeless Life’
abstract: Our favorite student comments from a lively discussion about homelessness and a girl named Dasani.
lead_paragraph: Sadness, anger, hope and the desire to “stop talking and start doing something” about homelessness: these were the dominant reactions to the series “Invisible Child: Dasani’s Homeless Life” among the 190 students who participated in our most recent installment of The Learning Network’s Reading Club.

headline: Stolen Landolfi Violin Is Recovered
abstract: A violin made by the Italian luthier Carlo Ferdinando Landolfi was recovered on Thursday in the Hague.
lead_paragraph: A rare violin by the Italian luthier Carlo Ferdinando Landolfi, one of three instruments stolen last week from a house in Abcoude, a small town in the Netherlands, was recovered on Thursday, when two men tried to sell it to a violin maker in The Hague, a Dutch news site reported. The violin dates from 1731, although there are few extant Landolfi instruments from before around 1750. It is said to be worth about $205,000. The owner of the violin shop, who had heard about the burglary, notified the police when he was offered the violin. The police arrested the two men, but the other two stolen violins have not yet been found.

headline: How Hollywood Ruined Me for Romance
keywords: ['Modern Love (Times Column)', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Celebrities', 'Dating and Courtship', 'News and News Media']
abstract: It was easy to forget that actresses were professional charmers with a vested interest in making journalists like them.

abstract: Like many medical products or procedures, joint implants cost far more in the United States than in many other developed countries.
lead_paragraph: Like many medical products or procedures, joint implants cost far more in the United States than in many other developed countries.

headline: 3 Dead in Clash at Police Station in Western China, Report Says
abstract: Three ethnic Uighurs were shot and killed in the Xinjiang region during a fight with security guards, Radio Free Asia reported.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Three ethnic Uighurs were shot and killed last week outside a police station in China’s far west Xinjiang region during a fight with security guards who blocked them from entering the building, Radio Free Asia reported Thursday.

headline: Blues Help Honor Teammate’s Sister
abstract: Jaden Schwartz and his N.H.L. teammates on Friday will help honor Mandi Schwartz, a former Yale hockey player who died of acute myeloid leukemia.
lead_paragraph: The St. Louis Blues, making their only trip to the New York metropolitan area this season, arrived Tuesday. They played the Devils in Newark that night, faced the Rangers in Manhattan on Thursday night and were to play the Islanders on Long Island on Saturday afternoon.

keywords: ['Constitutions', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Marriages', 'Women and Girls', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: The minimum age to marry in Yemen may be set at 18.
lead_paragraph: Yemen has taken a step toward outlawing child marriages.

headline: A Soup Saved From the Cold
abstract: Yun Nan Flavour Garden, in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, is one of the few places in New York where you can find crossing-the-bridge noodles.
lead_paragraph: First comes the giant bowl of broth, sallow, glazed with oil and flecked with what looks like soot. Then the waiter, holding a small saucer in one hand, tips in a raw quail egg.

headline: Living With Cancer: Life of the Party
abstract: Let there be trombones and guitars, flutes and pianos, singing and, especially, cellos for the sick and the dying.
lead_paragraph: The prospect of a party frightened me — probably because the enforced isolation of cancer treatments has rendered me hypersensitive. It was raining outside and festivities would not begin until after 8 p.m. But my husband and I had promised to attend the celebration of a book publication. So we dragged ourselves to Judith and Aidan’s house where I hoped to find a comfortable chair in which I would not look like the battle-ax at Mrs. Dalloway’s party whom everyone had thought long dead.

headline: E.V.’s Could Be Key Part of a Changing Electrical Grid
abstract: As more electricity generation sources, like wind energy, become intermittent ones, E.V. charging could be a way to stabilize demand.
lead_paragraph: Electricity, like gasoline, is mostly available at whenever the customer wants it, in whatever quantity is needed. But as their numbers increase, electric cars could potentially demand enormous amounts of power. Meeting that demand at a time when the electric system is already fully loaded could be expensive if it requires construction of new power plants – specially purposed for handling peak demand – that would be needed only a few hundred hours a year.

headline: Sikhs Fight Back Against New Pentagon Dress Code
keywords: ['Sikhs and Sikhism', 'Turbans', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: New rules require service members to get an exception from the military to have a beard or wear a turban.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American Sikh leaders, disappointed that new Pentagon dress code requirements released on Wednesday do not go as far as the Sikhs would like, are turning to Congress to increase the pressure on the military.

headline: An Online Test Suggests You Could Have A.D.H.D., Too
abstract: Even some of the field’s longtime advocates say the zeal to find and treat every A.D.H.D. child has led to too many people with scant symptoms receiving the diagnosis and medication.
lead_paragraph: Even some of the field’s longtime advocates say the zeal to find and treat every A.D.H.D. child has led to too many people with scant symptoms receiving the diagnosis and medication.

lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — For the third time in the last four years, Li Na is one of the last two women standing at the Australian Open.

abstract: In the news: smoking, fishy fish oils and highway safety.
lead_paragraph: In the news: smoking, fishy fish oils and highway safety.

headline: Key Witness Says Leader of SAC Was F.B.I. Target
abstract: The prosecution’s top witness said F.B.I. agents told him the government’s true target was Steven A. Cohen, SAC’s billionaire founder.
lead_paragraph: The man whose shadow has been hanging over the insider trading trial of Mathew Martoma, the former SAC Capital Advisors trader, took center stage on Thursday when the prosecution’s top witness said F.B.I. agents told him the government’s true target was Steven A. Cohen, SAC’s billionaire founder.

headline: Art Meets Environmental Activism in ‘The Crossroads Project’
abstract: A performance piece at Purchase College uses music, painting, photography and scientific research to address climate change.
lead_paragraph: This month’s blast of arctic air may have roused climate-change skeptics. But the composer Laura Kaminsky and the painter Rebecca Allan were unfazed. Holed up in their apartment in Riverdale in the Bronx on one of the coldest days in decades, these longtime artist-activists were doing what came naturally: fighting the planet’s warming.

headline: From Upstate to the West Village
abstract: Phyllis and Fred Erikson missed the city adventures of their youth. It was time for a pied-à-terre.
lead_paragraph: Back when Phyllis Erikson, formerly Phyllis Ricciardi, was growing up on Staten Island, “there was nothing there except houses,” she said, “so we came into the city a lot.” She remembers cutting class at Curtis High School for an adventure in Greenwich Village.

headline: The Gun Report: January 23, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Republican South Carolina Senator Lindsey Graham was in the state capital on Tuesday advocating for child gun locks, just as lawmakers there are contemplating two bills aimed at increasing gun rights.

headline: Savannah Starts a Bike Program
abstract: Savannah, Ga., will launch a public bicycle sharing program this week.
lead_paragraph: Savannah’s Chatham Area Transit (CAT) will officially begin its new public bicycle sharing program on Friday, making it one of a growing number of major metropolitan areas in the United States to do so in recent years, and the first in Georgia.

headline: On the Amend
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Addressing matters of disclosures that hurt, embarrassing photographs, annoying parents of friends and unwanted desserts.
lead_paragraph: Years ago, as an unmarried woman, I lived with a man but had a brief affair with a younger man while we were together. My partner never knew about it — really — and we stayed together for many years. Ultimately, we broke up but remain friends. Recently, my former partner received an “amends letter” from my young fling, who is now in a 12-step recovery program. (Apologizing to those you have wronged is one of the steps.) In his letter, he outed me by apologizing for our affair. This has caused significant awkwardness in my friendship with my former lover. Does the fling’s recovery trump my private life?

headline: A Fearsome Portrayal of a Powerful, Angry Man
abstract: August Wilson’s “Fences” explores the passions and problems of masculinity and the tension between a father and his sons.
lead_paragraph: “Here is a man that you can open yourself up to and be filled to bursting,” Rose Maxson says in August Wilson’s “Fences,” recalling her reaction to meeting her future husband, Troy. “Here is a man that can fill all them empty spaces” in her heart. Indeed, Troy is a physical and emotional titan. There’s no empty space he can’t fill, except for the one inside his own soul.

headline: Argentina’s Currency Falls Sharply Against the Dollar, Stirring Inflation Fears
abstract: The peso lost 8 percent of its value relative to the American dollar in one day, the worst performance since Argentina’s 2002 financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Argentina’s currency, the peso, plunged more than 8 percent on Thursday against the dollar after the country’s central bank tried to stem a decline in international reserves. The sharp decline, with the peso dropping the most since Argentina’s 2002 financial crisis, raises concerns that inflation could accelerate even further.

headline: At World Economic Forum, Even the Serious-Minded Like to Party
abstract: The bacchanalian revelry during the parties in Davos include over-the-top affairs, celebrity chefs and A-list guests.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — For a certain crowd, the big topic in Davos this year has nothing to do with Syrian peace talks, cybersecurity issues or other geopolitical gravitas.

headline: Curtain Call | Paris Couture Collections
abstract: To mark the conclusion of the Paris Couture collections, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 11 fashion visionaries.
lead_paragraph: To mark the conclusion of the Paris Couture collections, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 11 fashion visionaries.

headline: Shanghai Test Scores and the Mystery of the Missing Children
abstract: China’s restrictions on internal migration serve to drive migrant children out of the city as early as primary school, statistics show, and critics say that skews testing results indicating its education system’s equity and superiority.
lead_paragraph: Is the education system in Shanghai, China’s largest and most internationalized city, really a paradigm of academic excellence and educational equity, or does its stellar performance mask a grimmer reality, in which one of the world’s largest barriers to education opportunities plagues tens of thousands of its residents?

headline: Interview: Nick Cave
abstract: Nick Cave, the subject of the documentary “20,000 Days on Earth,” speaks with Melena Ryzik at the Sundance Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: Nick Cave, the subject of the documentary “20,000 Days on Earth,” speaks with Melena Ryzik at the Sundance Film Festival.

headline: Contrasting Big and Little at a Tapas Bar
abstract: A newcomer, from the couple who opened Salumi in Massapequa in 2011, offers eclectic meat and cheese offerings to go with reasonably priced wine.
lead_paragraph: With its warm, cozy atmosphere, Plancha Tapas and Wine Bar is the kind of place where diners settle in enjoying table conversation as they sip their wine, nibble cheeses and meats from overflowing boards, and anticipate the often innovative small plates to come.

headline: Whom to Follow, Mr. Commissioner? Don’t Mind if We Do!
abstract: Hours after Police Commissioner William J. Bratton joined Twitter he still was not following a single account. Here we offer up a few suggestions.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Twitter, Police Commissioner William J. Bratton — or shall we say @CommissBratton. Soon you’ll forget how you ever wasted time without it.

headline: Barcelona President Quits Amid Lawsuit
abstract: Sandro Rosell is accused of misappropriating funds as part of the $78 million transfer of Neymar, the Brazilian soccer star, last summer.
lead_paragraph: The president of F.C. Barcelona, Sandro Rosell, resigned on Thursday, a day after a Spanish court accepted a lawsuit accusing him of misappropriating funds as part of the $78 million transfer of the Brazilian soccer star Neymar last summer.

headline: Introducing Erica Bell and Katie Finnegan, New Business Group Members
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'E-Commerce', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Small Business', 'Start-ups']
abstract: Their company makes an online shopping tool that notifies users when a product they want to buy has gone on sale.
lead_paragraph: Three new business owners have joined the She Owns It business group. This post introduces two of them.

headline: New Enlistee to Ezra Klein’s Journalism Venture
abstract: Matt Yglesias is leaving Slate to join Mr. Klein, a departing Washington Post analyst at Wonkblog, for a project that has not yet been announced.
lead_paragraph: Matt Yglesias, an influential commentator on politics and economics, will leave Slate to join the new venture of the departing Washington Post analyst Ezra Klein, Slate’s editor, David Plotz, said Thursday.

headline: Deficits and Conservative Reform
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Would a reformist G.O.P. just end up repeating the profligacy of the Bush era?
lead_paragraph: Turning from Mike Needham’s critique to the other end of the political spectrum, I see that Jonathan Chait used my column on reform conservatism to take a break from his usual pattern of explaining why the Republican Party is necessarily a tool of plutocratic interests, now and forever, world without end, and to allow that yes, maybe the next Republican president might do something that might conceivably benefit someone other than the super-rich … but that this would only happen in a replay of the George W. Bush administration, where Republicans learned to stop worrying and love deficit spending once again:

headline: Video: Nick Cave at Sundance
abstract: Nick Cave, the subject of the documentary “20,000 Days on Earth,” speaks with Melena Ryzik at the Sundance Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — Sundance is as much a home for musical performances as movies. At this year’s festival there have been buzzed-about shows by Rick Ross; Damon Albarn of Blur and Gorillaz; Stuart Murdoch, of Belle & Sebastian, who made his directorial debut here with “God Help the Girl,” a musical about the indie scene in Glasgow; and Jenny Lewis, also here with a film, “Song One,” the Anne Hathaway vehicle for which Ms. Lewis, late of Rilo Kiley, co-wrote music. And Nick Cave, the Australian rocker, is the subject of an unusual documentary, “20,000 Days on Earth.”

headline: The Thinking Person’s White Wine
abstract: Savennières is not easy to love, but the effort is worth it.
lead_paragraph: If you’re looking for a winter-weight white wine, one that’s substantial enough to warm the insides yet elegant enough to dance intimately with many different foods, I’ve got a name for you: Savennières.

headline: A Code of Honor, Not a Referee, Keeps Curlers Honest
abstract: Even at the Olympics, with world recognition at stake, curling largely relies on athletes to police themselves and call their own fouls.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The curling stones were aligned, brooms were in hand, and the three ice sheets were spritzed with deionized water. Forty-eight curlers were set to compete in the World Continental Cup here last weekend, a critical warm-up for many who were bound for the Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia.

headline: Korean Dishes, Mild, Medium and Fiery
abstract: Korea Garden in lower Westchester serves dishes at different heat levels inside a roomy dining hall.
lead_paragraph: In the space once occupied by the Aria and Kang Suh restaurants, Korea Garden continues to bring to lower Westchester the flavors of increasingly popular Korean food in a vast, roomy dining hall.

headline: Advertising Disorder
abstract: Even some of the field’s longtime advocates say the zeal to find and treat every A.D.H.D. child has led to too many people with scant symptoms receiving the diagnosis and medication.
lead_paragraph: Even some of the field’s longtime advocates say the zeal to find and treat every A.D.H.D. child has led to too many people with scant symptoms receiving the diagnosis and medication.

headline: Neiman Marcus Data Breach Worse Than First Said
abstract: The theft of consumer data from the luxury retailer appears to have involved 1.1 million credit and debit cards.
lead_paragraph: The theft of consumer data from Neiman Marcus appears far deeper than had been disclosed originally, with the luxury retailer now saying that hackers invaded its systems for several months in a breach that involved 1.1 million credit and debit cards.

headline: Police Commissioner’s Tweet Sends a Message of Contrast
abstract: Commissioner William J. Bratton posted on his own Twitter account, breaking a tradition that eschewed social media.
lead_paragraph: The messages appeared unexpectedly, live missives posted online from inside one of the New York Police Department’s most cloistered gatherings: a weekly, closed-door CompStat meeting at 1 Police Plaza.

headline: Microsoft Earnings Illustrate Move to Devices and Services From Software
abstract: The company said its second-quarter profit rose 3 percent, ahead of analysts’ forecasts, with strong sales of its Xbox consoles and Surface tablets.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — A picture of the new Microsoft, one transformed from a software factory into a maker of devices and online services, came into sharper focus on Thursday.

headline: Larry Poons: ‘New Paintings’
abstract: It’s daunting to think of the paintings and painters passing through Larry Poons’s mind these days.
lead_paragraph: Danese/Corey

headline: Davina Semo: ‘Ruder Forms Survive’
abstract: Ms. Semo is a promising young artist with a great love of industrial-strength materials trying to strike out in new directions.
lead_paragraph: Marlborough Chelsea

headline: Jackie Nickerson: ‘Terrain’
abstract: Ms. Nickerson upsets one of documentary’s central tenets.
lead_paragraph: Jack Shainman

headline: ‘American Beauty’
abstract: The idea of this group show, organized by the artist William Villalongo, is that art can look good and think tough at the same time, and so it can.
lead_paragraph: Susan Inglett Gallery

headline: ‘Simplest Means’
abstract: This show presents works by eight contemporary artists along with a selection of useful objects produced by Shakers, mostly in the 19th century.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Bailey Gallery

headline: What’s Behind Time Warner Cable’s Response to Charter’s Offer
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: In rejecting Charter Communications’ $37.8 billion offer, Time Warner Cable set a price it would accept. Why did Time Warner Cable even announce a price it was willing to sell at? That is where subtlety comes in.
lead_paragraph: Time Warner Cable’s response to Charter Communications’ $37.8 billion offer is all about subtlety.

headline: An Office, and Its Staff, at the Edge
abstract: In Heidi Schreck’s new play, at Long Wharf Theater Stage II, mismatched colleagues try to find their way through the 2008 financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: They say politics makes strange bedfellows, but surely that’s because politics is just another kind of job. For most of us, the strange bedfellows we’re most likely to encounter are the ones at the office or the plant or wherever it is we happen to work.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Syria, South Africa, Ukraine and Virginia.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, South Africa, Ukraine and Virginia.

headline: Paris Couture Week: Elie Saab Spring/Summer 2014
abstract: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Sonny Vandevelde.

headline: Robert Browning to Present New Series of Concerts
abstract: The founder of the World Music Institute has started a new venture to present concerts.
lead_paragraph: Robert Browning, the entrepreneur who almost single-handedly created and filled New Yorkers’ passion for world music, had an idea in 2011 that it might be fitting to retire. He was 70, and had presented over 1,800 concerts of virtually every imaginable variety of ethnic music, first for the Alternative Center (which was later called the Alternative Museum) and later at the World Music Institute, which he founded in 1986.

headline: Microsoft Suggests Wider Options for Foreign Data
abstract: In a published interview, Microsoft’s general counsel said the company’s customers should be able to “make an informed choice of where their data resides.”
lead_paragraph: For years, Microsoft has let its customers in Europe, including businesses and organizations, keep their online data close to them. The company operates big data centers in Amsterdam and Dublin for that very purpose.

headline: F.T.C. Chides Nissan Over Deceptive Truck Ad
abstract: The commercial shows a Nissan Frontier pickup pushing a stuck dune buggy up a sand hill, but in reality both vehicles were pulled up the hill by cables.
lead_paragraph: Everyone knows by now — if there ever was a question — that “cars can’t jump on trains.” It says so right at the bottom of the screen during those Nissan Rogue ads, which also carry the label, “Fantasy. Do not attempt.”

headline: Brevan Howard, Europe’s Largest Hedge Fund, Apologizes for Poor Results
abstract: In a letter to investors, Brevan Howard told investors it was sorry for its 2.6 percent return.
lead_paragraph: For at least one hedge fund, sorry does not seem to be the hardest word.

headline: Sounds to Complement Red and White at Long Island Wineries
abstract: In the slow season, Long Island wineries hope a concert festival gives customers a reason to linger.
lead_paragraph: The weather was frigid and the vines around the Raphael winery in Peconic were bare, but flames crackled in a fireplace inside the spacious beamed tasting room as more than 100 people gathered on a recent Saturday afternoon to sip wine and listen to Rob Europe, a guitarist and singer, perform along with several other musicians.

headline: A Class Where Recess Never Ends
abstract: Some fitness centers have introduced “recess” classes that aim to make a trip to the gym more of a romp on the playground.
lead_paragraph: FORGET about the treadmill, the stair climber, the boot camp torture sessions. Exercise should be fun. To prove it, some fitness centers have introduced “recess” classes that aim to make a trip to the gym less of a chore and more of a romp on the playground.

headline: Live From Canada, It’s Alice Munro
abstract: Ms. Munro appeared by video during an event at Symphony Space on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: Two literary giants loomed over the crowd at Symphony Space on Wednesday night, and I don’t mean that metaphorically. Alice Munro and Margaret Atwood conversed on a large screen during an installment of the Selected Shorts series devoted to Ms. Munro, who won the Nobel Prize in Literature in October.

headline: With No Regrets, Living Her Life as a Bossa Nova
abstract: In the Chilean film “Gloria,” directed by Sebastián Lelio, a heroine in her late 50s embraces passion and romance.
lead_paragraph: “Are you always this happy?” Rodolfo asks Gloria, shortly after catching her eye. They are at a nightclub where middle-aged residents of Santiago, Chile, dance and flirt, and where Gloria, in her 50s and long divorced, occasionally goes to attract the attention of a silver-haired Romeo. Rodolfo, who has a kind, crumpled face and a winningly uncertain manner, makes Gloria laugh with this pickup line. No, she says, sometimes in the mornings she is sad, and in the afternoons, too.

headline: Don’t Expect Job Data Alone to Persuade Fed on Rates
abstract: As the Fed grew more optimistic about the unemployment rate, it grew less optimistic about overall economic growth.
lead_paragraph: Just over a year ago, the Federal Reserve changed its guidance on how long it planned to keep interest rates very low.

headline: The Look of Afrofuturism in Harlem
abstract: “The Shadows Took Shape,” an exhibition in Harlem looking at the visual side of Afrofuturism, is featuring special tours this weekend, including events specifically for children.
lead_paragraph: A certain strain of late-20th-century pop music, pioneered by artists like Sun Ra, George Clinton and Lee (Scratch) Perry, drew on science fiction, electronic instruments and experiences of racial marginalization to forge an aesthetic called Afrofuturism.

headline: A History of Misunderstandings, Lies and Violence
abstract: “Magnificent Delusions,” by Husain Haqqani, looks at United States-Pakistan relations, and “Getting Away With Murder,” by Heraldo Muñoz, recounts the inquiry into Benazir Bhutto’s assassination.
lead_paragraph: Gen. Muhammad Zia ul-Haq, the wily military dictator who ruled Pakistan for much of the 1980s, was famous for, among other things, his gleaming teeth, which he used to dazzle visitors with a smile that left them guessing about his true intentions.

headline: Complaints About Closings
abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau actively solicits comments from consumers and industry professionals about problems in the closing process.
lead_paragraph: If you, like so many others, have a gripe about your last mortgage closing, federal regulators want to hear about it.

headline: Food Fresh and Local at Farmers’ Markets, Well After the Frost
abstract: More farmers’ markets are opening in winter, a time when their farmers tend to lose money and their patrons go back to grocery stores.
lead_paragraph: Kendrya Close approached the first installment of the Morris County Winter Farmers’ Market with a little trepidation.

headline: Walmart Fund to Support U.S. Manufacturing
abstract: The retailer will award grants for new production processes as it pushes for more American-made products.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — William S. Simon, chief executive of Walmart for the United States, said on Thursday at the United States Conference of Mayors that the company was providing a $10 million fund to promote American manufacturing in a public push to sell more American-made products.

headline: Acrostic
abstract: Acrostic puzzle for January 26, 2014
lead_paragraph: Acrostic puzzle for January 26, 2014

headline: Deep Reader
abstract: In her book about George Eliot’s masterpiece, “Middlemarch,” Rebecca Mead combines criticism and biography with the intimate tone of autobiography.
lead_paragraph: Rarely attempted, and still more rarely successful, is the bibliomemoir — a subspecies of literature combining criticism and biography with the intimate, confessional tone of autobiography.

headline: If It Pleases the Gods
abstract: The Parthenon is our shrine to Western civilization, but what did it mean to those who made it?
lead_paragraph: The myths of Greek antiquity are shot through with stories of murder, rape, incest and cannibalism. On Mount Lykaion (“wolf mountain”) in Arcadia, annual traditions honoring Zeus re-enacted a seminal rite of human sacrifice. In Plato’s “Republic,” the casual observation is made that in Athens anyone who wished to injure an enemy could commission a magician to cast a harmful spell; “for with their incantations and magic formulas they say they can persuade the gods to serve their will.” Similarly, archaeologists have discovered grotesque little voodoo-like figures bristling with spikes, and curse tablets that were inscribed with malevolent prayers during this Golden Age of humanism and reason. Spirits and dark ancestral memories haunted the landscape of enlightened Athens.

headline: With Brother in Big Game, Eli Manning Plays Concierge
abstract: Eli Manning offered Peyton Manning some tips on playing at MetLife Stadium, Eli’s home field, in the Super Bowl. Peyton said thanks but that he needed tickets.
lead_paragraph: What do two N.F.L. quarterbacks who happen to be brothers talk about when one of them is playing in the Super Bowl at the other’s home stadium?

headline: The Big Uneasy
abstract: Scott Stossel examines the painful mystery of anxiety.
lead_paragraph: As a young boy, Scott Stossel, the editor of The Atlantic magazine, worried every time his parents left: They’d die, he would think, or else abandon him. Years later, wild with stage fright, he hid in a bathroom to avoid getting a trophy on the dais. By adulthood, Stossel was saddled with often incapacitating nerves. His new book, “My Age of Anxiety,” uses his experience as a guide through the disorder, tracing its legacy in thought and culture. He seeks to understand what anxiety is and what it means; he probes the condition’s ambiguities. The result is ambitious, and bravely intimate: a ruminative book that often breaks into a thrilling intellectual chase.

headline: The Golden Girls, in a Shade of Pink
abstract: “Thank You for Being a Friend,” directed by Nick Brennan, is a raunchy and overwrought drag parody of “The Golden Girls.”
lead_paragraph: To feel the love for “The Golden Girls,” one of the best-written and -acted sitcoms of the ’80s and ’90s, you have only to see the capacity crowd gathered for “Thank You for Being a Friend,” at the Laurie Beechman Theater on Wednesdays. A woman at my table announced before the show that she could recite whole passages from the series. So you have to wonder what that audience takes away from this drag parody, directed by Nick Brennan, which is so raunchy and overwrought, it’s hard to call it affectionate.

headline: Landlords Seek the Upper Hand
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Evictions']
abstract: Answers to questions about deadbeat tenants, lease guarantors and broker fees.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a new weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Mirror, Mirror: Sundance Hits 30
abstract: Richard Linklater’s “Boyhood,” shot over 12 years and screened at the Sundance Film Festival, could be a metaphor for the maturation of the director and the festival itself.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — It was a blast from the indie past to watch Richard Linklater soak in the applause of the Sundance Film Festival audience on Sunday after the premiere of his transporting new movie, “Boyhood.” Mr. Linklater’s first official Sundance appearance was in 1991, with “Slacker,” one of the emblematic titles of the American independent scene of that period. Since then, he has repeatedly returned to this festival, which, like Mr. Linklater, has pushed boundaries, experimented with form and transcended setbacks. When he was called to the stage by John Cooper, the festival’s director, it felt as if Sundance was both mining its history and looking ahead to a new age.

headline: Robots in Attendance
abstract: Using cheaper parts and improved technology, some enterprising couples are rewiring robots to make an entrance at their weddings.
lead_paragraph: Using cheaper parts and improved technology, some enterprising couples are rewiring robots to make an entrance at their weddings.

headline: Pleasures of Utility, Comfort and Decoration
abstract: The 60th annual Winter Antiques Show has objects as diverse as American limner portraits to a modernist lacquer panel from 18th-century Japan.
lead_paragraph: Polar vortex or not, a great many artworks, artifacts and the like have taken up temporary residence on the Upper East Side over the last few days. Cozily ensconced in the Park Avenue Armory, they form the Winter Antiques Show, which is celebrating its 60th anniversary.

headline: An Elegant Space, Cocktails to Match
abstract: The restaurant Del Posto has plenty of room for a comfortable bar with piano music and impressive, if expensive, drinks.
lead_paragraph: Del Posto, the Italian restaurant owned by Mario Batali, Lidia Bastianich and Joe Bastianich, is inarguably spacious: 18-foot-high ceilings, 11,000 square feet for dining, only 35 tables in the main rooms, all of them seemingly occupied throughout the night by guests venturing through tasting menus of five and eight courses.

headline: Heritage, Still Hackish
abstract: A pox on your fancy theories.
lead_paragraph: Suddenly the buzz is that the Heritage Foundation is coming back to its senses. The supposed evidence of this shift is the foundation’s decision to hire Stephen Moore, formerly of the WSJ editorial page, as its chief economist.

headline: Pottery, the Paranormal and Other Visions
abstract: The New York Ceramics Fair and the Metro Show offer recent objects thrown by potters or old ones culled from attics and storerooms.
lead_paragraph: New York’s art fairs are often filled with work by contemporary artists, but here are two that artists themselves might like to attend. With objects culled from attics, forgotten storerooms and the bottom of the sea, or thrown more recently by potters, the fairs this year also seem marked by the marvelous, fantastical and paranormal.

headline: In Ukraine, the Chilling Winds of Change
abstract: “Boris Mikhailov: Four Decades,” at the Dominique Lévy gallery, is a mini-survey of this photographer’s challenging Ukraine work made before, during and after the collapse of the Soviet Union.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Boris Mikhailov, born in Ukraine in 1938, has become widely known in late career for his wry and wrenching pictures of post-Soviet life. His series “Case History” (seen at MoMA in 2011) unnerved viewers with large-scale color portraits of homeless people in Ukraine, pictures that seemed to violate the codes of serious documentary photography. The subjects flashed naked flesh to the camera and had been paid and fed by the photographer.

headline: A Sensualist Finds Religion
abstract: “Antonio Canova: The Seven Last Works,” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, exhibits plaster reliefs that represent scenes from the Old and New Testaments.
lead_paragraph: Antonio Canova (1757-1822) produced some of the sexiest sculptures in the history of European art. A good example is in the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s European sculpture court: “Reclining Naiad,” a life-size marble representation of a fit young woman lying naked on a sheet over a bearskin, her most impressive feature being her exquisitely supple backside. But if that’s how you think of this artist, you may be shocked by the museum’s exhibition “Antonio Canova: The Seven Last Works.”

headline: Times Minute | Real-Life 'Goodfellas'
abstract: Also on the Minute, collecting cash in protests in Thailand and an overachieving Mars rover.
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, collecting cash in protests in Thailand and an overachieving Mars rover.

headline: Times Minute | Real-Life ‘Goodfellas’
abstract: Also on the Minute, collecting cash in protests in Thailand and an overachieving Mars rover.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: 9/11 Museum to Charge $24 Admission
abstract: Admission to the memorial at the World Trade Center will remain free, and families of victims will not be charged admission, the museum foundation said.
lead_paragraph: The foundation that oversees the National September 11 Memorial Museum at the World Trade Center voted on Thursday to charge visitors $24 for admission to the underground museum that is scheduled to open this spring. The above-ground memorial that occupies the footprints of the twin towers — and has hosted 11.5 million visitors since it opened two years ago — will continue to be free.

headline: Exhibition’s Final Stop After Cold War Shutdown
abstract: “Art Interrupted,” opening at the Georgia Museum of Art, includes work that was prevented from making a national tour during the Cold War.
lead_paragraph: A short-lived traveling art show that caused an outcry in 1946 but that now looks tame has been meticulously reinstalled with documentation about how government maneuverings shut it down. “Art Interrupted: Advancing American Art and the Politics of Cultural Diplomacy,” an exhibition of paintings that the United States government briefly owned at the outset of the Cold War, opens on Saturday at the Georgia Museum of Art in Athens in the final stop of a tour.

headline: After a Failed Tender Offer, McKesson Clinches Deal
abstract: The health care company McKesson announced that it had gained enough shareholder support to push through a deal for the German pharmaceutical wholesaler Celesio.
lead_paragraph: After a failed bid to gain control of the German pharmaceutical wholesaler Celesio, the health care company McKesson Corporation announced on Thursday that it had gained enough shareholder support to push a deal through.

headline: McMorris Rodgers to Deliver Republican Response to State of the Union
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers of Washington State, the highest-ranking Republican woman in Congress, was chosen to deliver the rebuttal to President Obama’s State of the Union address.
lead_paragraph: Republicans have selected their official responder to President Obama’s State of the Union address on Tuesday night: Representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers, a member of the party leadership from Washington State.

headline: Seized by Nazis, Now for Sale
keywords: ['Art', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting']
abstract: Sotheby’s is auctioning off three works that were seized from their French owners by the Nazis and then saved by the Monuments Men.
lead_paragraph: First came the book, and now, on the eve of “The Monuments Men” the movie, Sotheby’s in New York is selling three paintings recovered by this fabled group of experts who rescued artworks stolen or confiscated by the Nazis during World War II.

headline: Why So Little on the March for Life in Thursday’s Times?
abstract: The anti-abortion protest got only photo coverage in Thursday’s print edition.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds, if not thousands, of New Yorkers – many of them Catholics – piled onto buses in the freezing cold and headed down to Washington this week for the 41st annual March for Life, the world’s largest anti-abortion gathering.

headline: T. Rowe Price Wants Time Warner Cable and Charter to Talk
abstract: The mutual fund giant is one of only a couple shareholders that have stakes in both Time Warner Cable and Charter.
lead_paragraph: T. Rowe Price, one of the biggest investors in the country, wants Time Warner Cable and Charter Communications to sit down at the bargaining table.

headline: The Grammys, a Night for Cheers (and Often Gasps)
abstract: The 56th annual Grammys ceremony is likely to present a few upsets, as it has in the past.
lead_paragraph: THE Grammy Awards are so predictable. Except when they’re unpredictable.

headline: Sundance Q. and A. | Shailene Woodley
abstract: This series introduces some of the standout, rising stars from the 2014 Sundance Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: This series introduces some of the standout, rising stars from the 2014 Sundance Film Festival.

headline: An Ex-Byrd’s Album Is Given New Flight
abstract: An indie-rock supergroup has joined to perform a concert version of Gene Clark’s 1974 album, “No Other.”
lead_paragraph: Some albums find an unexpected afterlife. They may have been ignored or reviled upon release; they may have been out of sync with the trend of the moment; they may have had bad business luck. Then, years or decades later, word of mouth and word of Internet start to bubble up from musicians, collectors, longtime fans and new acquaintances. It doesn’t hurt if the songs are oblique and tormented, if the album and musician have troubled back stories or if newer music has vindicated sounds that went unappreciated at the time.

headline: Mix and Match for a Savory Taste of Korea
abstract: Yama Dora offers a delightful introduction to Korean cuisine by combining foods and flavors for groups to share.
lead_paragraph: Yama Dora, a neighborhood Korean restaurant and sushi bar in East Haven, specializes in Korean barbecue, which is an event as much as a dish. Your choice of beef, pork, chicken or shrimp, soaked in a robust marinade, is grilled in the center of the table. A collection of flavorful side dishes (banshan) such as kimchi, pickled daikon and sesame-and-garlic-sautéed spinach is brought to the table along with the barbecue. Diners wrap the grilled meat in lettuce leaves with a dab of pungent and salty fermented bean paste, and share the side dishes.

headline: The Bahamas on the Radar
abstract: Many buyers of high-end condos in Manhattan have started shopping for beachfront retreats in the Bahamas, some developed by New Yorkers.
lead_paragraph: For several years, wealthy New Yorkers, even those relatively unscathed by the financial crisis, seemed to put their second-home dreams on hold. But as the real estate market in the city has strengthened, many of these high-end buyers have started shopping for beachfront retreats again.

headline: Dangerous Undertow in a Cruisers’ Haven
abstract: A stretch of beach and its adjoining woods, which serve as a gay cruising spot, become a crime scene in “Stranger by the Lake,” by the French filmmaker Alain Guiraudie.
lead_paragraph: Not every mystery is a whodunit. In Alain Guiraudie’s “Stranger by the Lake,” a murder takes place early on, in full view of the audience and a crucial witness, a young man named Franck (Pierre Deladonchamps). Franck has spent the afternoon — as he apparently spends many afternoons — on a stretch of beach that serves as a gay cruising spot. Earlier, he had a brief flirtation with a muscular, mustachioed swimmer, only to be shooed away by someone who seemed to be a jealous boyfriend. Now, from behind a scrim of trees, just before darkness falls, Franck sees the two men together in the water and watches as horseplay turns to homicide.

headline: At Times, Nice Guys Finish Second
abstract: Greg Whiteley’s “Mitt” is a behind-the-scenes look at a likable but failed presidential candidate.
lead_paragraph: Voters will learn a lot about Mitt Romney from “Mitt,” a new documentary having its premiere on Netflix on Friday.

headline: Play with a Friend
abstract: Solve Crosswords with a friend
lead_paragraph: Solve Crosswords with a friend

headline: Still Revealing New Facets, After Sparkling for Half a Century
abstract: “Jewels,” George Balanchine’s three-part ballet from 1967, returns to the New York City Ballet repertory, with nine company principals among the first leads.
lead_paragraph: George Balanchine’s full-length “Jewels,” new in 1967, remains a perfect education in the art of ballet — in particular the diversity of ballet as he refashioned it in the mid-20th century. I go on learning from it myself. Part of its fascination is that its three parts — “Emeralds” (to pieces by Fauré), “Rubies” (to Stravinsky’s Capriccio for Piano and Orchestra) and “Diamonds” (to the last four movements of Tchaikovsky’s Third Symphony) — are so unalike. “Emeralds” is Romantic-medievalist, French, seeming to occur in a large garden, deep glade or forest. “Rubies” is 20th-century American, indeed New York: merry, hard, dense, high-rise. “Diamonds” is imperial Russian, courtly.

headline: What Would Truly Honest Movie Posters Look Like?
abstract: The humor site Uproxx offers alternative ideas for “Gravity” and other awards season contenders.
lead_paragraph: “Don’t Torrent It. Don’t Watch It On Your Phone”

headline: A Duo Face Off While Staying on the Same Page
abstract: Brad Mehldau and Mark Guiliana, known together as Mehliana, promoted their debut album at the Highline Ballroom in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Brad Mehldau, the casually graceful post-bop pianist, and Mark Guiliana, the gracefully casual deep-groove drummer, faced each other across the stage at the Highline Ballroom on Wednesday night, as if to give shape to the idea of back-and-forth exchange. Things didn’t shake out that neatly or equitably. But the duo, which goes by Mehliana, delivered a credible mash-up of sensibilities in the show, an experiment in the emerging field of beat science and a treatise on the ageless art of tension and release.

headline: ‘I Now Present Mr. and Mrs. Jetson’
keywords: ['Weddings and Engagements', 'Robots and Robotics', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: With robots taking on more and more everyday tasks, incidents of robot-assisted weddings or receptions may not be that surprising.
lead_paragraph: In the world of the future, science-fiction movies tell us, robots may do just about everything. But you might figure that the business of marrying would be an exception and remain the province of the heart and soul rather than of sensors and circuit boards.

headline: Events in Westchester for Jan. 26 to Feb. 1
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Swashbuckling Beneath a Not-So-Jolly Roger
abstract: There are no parrots or eye patches in “Black Sails,” a Starz pirate drama scheduled for Saturday nights.
lead_paragraph: With Michael Bay’s name in the credits as an executive producer, you’d expect “Black Sails” to be big and loud, if nothing else. And this new pirate drama, beginning Saturday on Starz, does boast an imposing 140-foot facsimile of a sailing ship, which makes a particular impression when it’s beached for some early-18th-century nautical maintenance.

headline: With Strain on Electric Grid, a Push to Prioritize Conservation
keywords: ['Energy Efficiency', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Heating']
abstract: As Texas’ soaring population strains utilities, the companies are pressing regulators to embrace a model that would pay power plants to maintain reserves to meet need when demand peaks.
lead_paragraph: The “polar vortex” that swept across much of the nation early this month knocked two North Texas power plants offline just as residents began turning up the heat and revving up power use. Grid operators fixed the problem, but not before warning consumers that they were a step away from resorting to shutdowns.

headline: Hispanic Groups Start $5 Million Voter Registration Drive
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: NCLR, also known as the National Council of La Raza, hopes to register a quarter of a million new Hispanic voters by the midterm elections in November.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The nation’s largest Hispanic group kicked off an effort on Thursday to register a quarter of a million new Hispanic voters by the midterm elections in November.

abstract: The New York Times movie critics on "Gloria," "Visitors" and "Stranger by the Lake."
lead_paragraph: The New York Times movie critics on "Gloria," "Visitors" and "Stranger by the Lake."

headline: Bradley Cooper Will Play ‘Elephant Man’ on Broadway
abstract: The actor will star opposite Patricia Clarkson and Alessandro Nivola in a revival of Bernard Pomerance’s play.
lead_paragraph: Bradley Cooper, whose movie career has boomed since he was last on Broadway, will return to the New York stage this fall in the title role of “The Elephant Man,” the show’s producer confirmed on Thursday.

headline: Testimony of a Cleareyed Witness
abstract: The photographer Carrie Mae Weems charts her exploration of the African-American experience in a traveling 30-year retrospective now at the Guggenheim Museum.
lead_paragraph: Color and class are still the great divides in American culture, and few artists have surveyed them as subtly and incisively as Carrie Mae Weems, whose traveling 30-year retrospective has arrived at the Guggenheim Museum. From its early candid family photographs, through series of pictures that track the Africa in African-America, to work that explores, over decades, what it means to be black, female and in charge of your life, it’s a ripe, questioning and beautiful show.

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Google Tools for Globetrotters
abstract: Here’s a guide to some of the search giant’s products that could help travelers, from Glass to Voice Search to Gmail Offline.
lead_paragraph: “O.K., Glass,” I said, peering at a photo of a Spanish street sign through Google Glass, the lens-less augmented-reality “glasses.” “Translate this.” I gently tapped, then swiped my pointer finger along a narrow touch pad on the side of the Glass frame as if scrolling through the contact list on my iPhone — only I was scrolling through the names of romance languages, each of which appeared on a tiny virtual screen in the distance, in line with my right eye. When the word “Spanish” materialized, I tapped the side of the glasses to select it, a process you need do only once to lock in a language for an entire trip. Seconds later, the street sign was in English: “Attention, area of construction. No trespassing.”

headline: Capturing the New York of the 1960s and ’70s
abstract: Fred W. McDarrah, who for decades was The Village Voice’s only staff photographer, had access to his subjects that photographers could only dream of today.
lead_paragraph: If we had known that the scrawny guy onstage at that Greenwich Village folk club might someday amount to something, we’d have all been there, camera in hand, to document the event. But we didn’t, so we weren’t. Fred W. McDarrah, on the other hand, made it a point to be there: when Bob Dylan first performed in New York; when Jack Kerouac and Allen Ginsberg held court at house parties in Greenwich Village, or Andy Warhol at his studio, the Factory; when the hippies or the gay liberation movement found their voices; when downtown New York was the incubator for the cultural movements that shook the world. Mr. McDarrah, who died in 2007, was the first photo editor and for decades the only staff photographer of The Village Voice. He had a front-row seat for multiple revolutions, with access that photographers today cannot imagine. “You could be standing three feet from Jimi Hendrix at a cocktail party and start shooting,” said Mr. McDarrah’s son Patrick, 47. “You could never just do that now with Jay Z.” Back then, said Mr. McDarrah’s other son, Timothy, 51, “We’d answer the phone and it would be, ‘Hi, it’s Andy, is Freddie there?’ ”

headline: Should Pope Francis Rethink Abortion?
abstract: Doctrinal revision needn’t contradict his commitment to the “value of the human person.”
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis has raised expectations of a turn away from the dogmatic intransigence that has long cast a pall over the religious life of many Roman Catholics. His question “Who am I to judge?” suggested a new attitude toward homosexuality, and he is apparently willing to consider allowing the use of contraceptives to prevent sexually transmitted diseases. But his position on what has come to be the hierarchy’s signature issue — abortion — seems unyielding. “Reason alone is sufficient to recognize the inviolable value of each single human life,” he declared in his recent apostolic exhortation, “Evangelii Gaudium,” adding: “Precisely because this involves the internal consistency of our message about the value of the human person, the church cannot be expected to change her position on this question.”I want to explore the possibility, however, that the pope might be open to significant revision of the absolute ban on abortion by asking what happens if we take seriously his claim that “reason alone is sufficient” to adjudicate this issue. What actually follows regarding abortion once we accept the “inviolable value of each single human life”? This appeal to rational reflection has been a central feature of the tradition of Catholic moral teaching. I put forward the following reflections in the spirit of this tradition.There is considerable rational basis for moral concern about abortions. In many (probably most) cases, it would be immoral to abort a pregnancy. (Note, however, that this by no means implies that most abortions actually performed are immoral.) Late-term fetuses, for example, are no different biologically or psychologically from babies born prematurely at the same stage of development. It’s hard to see how killing a premature baby is immoral but killing an identical late-term fetus isn’t. At a minimum, aborting a healthy late-term fetus would, except when the mother’s life is at risk, be immoral — which is no doubt why it is seldom, if ever, done.

headline: In a Teenage Snake Pit, a Chance to Be Trendy
abstract: Every mean girl needs a gay male best friend; at least that’s what the teenagers in “G.B.F.” believe.
lead_paragraph: “Never in the history of North Gateway High had any student admitted out loud to being an honest-to-goodness, proud or even slightly modest homosexual, including me and my best friend,” announces Tanner (Michael J. Willett), the gay teenager who narrates the satirical farce “G.B.F.” Tanner and his best friend, Brent (Paul Iacono), are classmates in an upscale suburban hotbed of adolescent social warfare that might as well be on Planet Q, for all its resemblance to an actual high school.

headline: Sundance Diary | The Sun Sets Early on Park City
abstract: A look back at the best — and more bizarre — happenings and offerings during this year’s film extravaganza.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 Sundance Film Festival may not be over yet, but with most of its high-profile premieres wrapped up and a large portion of the celebrity contingent already back in their L.A. and New York enclaves, Park City, Utah, certainly has the feel of a circus ready to leave town. The festival, which officially concludes on Sunday, had a strong lineup this year and featured a total of 118 feature-length films from 37 different countries and 54 first-time filmmakers. And while film sales have been relatively quiet — the reported $3 million that Sony Pictures Classics paid for the opening-night film, “Whiplash,” pales in comparison to the $9.75 million that Fox Searchlight shelled out for “The Way, Way Back” last year — the creative output has been promising.

headline: An ‘Off the Wall’ Experience at Don Pedro
abstract: Don Pedro is all about alcohol, football on the TVs, video games and Mexican food until midnight on Wednesdays, when glamour, anarchy and subversion reign.
lead_paragraph: By 11 p.m. on a recent Wednesday, it looked as if Don Pedro was pretty much done for the night. A group of maybe a dozen people were scattered around the place, watching the credits roll on “American Horror Story.” The bartender took the opportunity to head outside for a smoke. Sitting at a table with drinks and a couple of friends was Joe Kennedy, 24, who moved to New York five months ago from a college town in Missouri. A friend recommended that he check out the place (90 Manhattan Avenue in Brooklyn; there was some debate at the table whether this was East Williamsburg or Bushwick). Mr. Kennedy had been assured that Wednesdays at Don Pedro were “off the wall.”

headline: A Pregnant Teenager Finds Her Way, in Spite of Her Parents
abstract: “Gimme Shelter,” written and directed by Ronald Krauss and based on a true story, follows Apple, a teenager who has a drug-addicted mother and a father who’s not in the picture.
lead_paragraph: “Gimme Shelter,” written and directed by Ronald Krauss, begins with the familiar “based on a true story” note and ends with side-by-side photographs of actors from the movie and some of the real-life characters they portray. What comes in between is a crude, earnest parable that uses some of the techniques of indie filmmaking to deliver a culturally conservative message.

headline: Books About Builders, Bootleggers and Bosses
abstract: New books by Doug Most, Ellen NicKenzie Lawson and Steven Hart examine the New York subway’s birth, Prohibition in the city and the mayors of two New Jersey cities 80 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Aside from some overlooked plaques in the City Hall subway station and elsewhere, names like Barclay, Hewitt, McDonald, Parsons, Pearson, Sprague, Steinway, even Belmont — much less the Whitney brothers — have been all but forgotten. Doug Most, an editor at The Boston Globe, remedies that oversight in “The Race Underground: Boston, New York and the Incredible Rivalry That Built America’s First Subway” (St. Martin’s Press).

headline: How Love Survives Altered Expectations
abstract: When an Irish husband, father and craftsman suffers a stroke, his family, and an outsider, reflect the changed balance of the household.
lead_paragraph: Vanetia Casey (Maxine Peake), the plucky, flame-haired central character of “Run & Jump,” infuses this Irish family drama with a snapping, whooshing electricity. The wife of Conor (Edward MacLiam), a 38-year-old carpenter who was seriously disabled by a stroke, she is a sexy, spirited dynamo who has all she can handle raising their two children while Conor lumbers around the house in a partial fog.

headline: Dinesh D’Souza Is Charged With Using Straw Donors
abstract: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan said that Dinesh D’Souza, the conservative author and filmmaker, encouraged others to give $20,000 to a Senate candidate and reimbursed them for the donations.
lead_paragraph: Dinesh D’Souza, a best-selling conservative author and filmmaker, was indicted on Thursday on charges that he used straw donors to illegally donate to a 2012 Senate campaign.

headline: A Skylark Who Sang Truth to Power in Argentina
abstract: Rodrigo H. Vila’s documentary “Mercedes Sosa: The Voice of Latin America,” looks at a singer who spoke for the oppressed during Argentina’s period of dictatorship.
lead_paragraph: Bereaved but resilient, the sound of the monumental Argentine folk singer heard in Rodrigo H. Vila’s biographical documentary “Mercedes Sosa: The Voice of Latin America” conveys eons of suffering and survival. You don’t have to understand Spanish, Sosa’s primary language, to be moved by an instrument that expressed the sorrows and hopes of the world’s poor and downtrodden with a profound empathy.

headline: Number of Darfur’s Displaced Surged in 2013
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: A report by the top United Nations peacekeeping official to the Security Council presented a pessimistic picture of the decade-old Darfur conflict.
lead_paragraph: An estimated 400,000 people fled violence afflicting the Darfur region of Sudan last year, more than the number of those displaced in the previous two years combined, the top United Nations peacekeeping official said Thursday in an appraisal that suggested the decade-old conflict there had taken a turn for the worse.

headline: Who’s the Bad Guy Here? It Depends
abstract: In “Enemies Closer,” a park ranger and a disgruntled foe team up to survive an onslaught from a drug runner.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday.

headline: Starting to Build a Credit History
abstract: Lenders are wary of people without much personal credit history, but there are some ways to build such a record.
lead_paragraph: Katie Brown, a 25-year-old horse trainer in Parkland, Fla., had never given much thought to whether she needed to establish credit. With her parents’ help, she avoided student loans. And she used a checking account and debit card to pay for what she needed.

lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: 70 Years on, Magic Concocted in Exile
abstract: In “The Little Prince: A New York Story,” the Morgan Library & Museum examines the making of Saint-Exupéry’s classic when he was in exile in New York during World War II.
lead_paragraph: If you are one of those people who, on looking up at the heavens, wonder whether a sheep on a particular asteroid has eaten a certain flower, or if you already know the fox’s solemn secret — “Anything essential is invisible to the eyes” — then no new incentives will be required to visit the exhibition that opens Friday at the Morgan Library & Museum, “The Little Prince: A New York Story.” You are already an initiate.

lead_paragraph: The general counsel of Rackspace, a web-hosting company in San Antonio, does not mince words when he discusses patent litigation.
