headline: Spare Times for Jan. 24-30
abstract: A listing of author discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.
lead_paragraph: ‘Putting It All on the Table’ (through next Friday) When is candy corn not just a sugary morsel to pop in your mouth? When it is the building block for “Caught in a Maize,” below, an art piece by Gina Kim focusing on the prominence of corn — good and bad — in our diets. It is among the 24 works by graduate students in the School of Visual Art’s Design for Social Innovation Program that are currently on view at the school’s Gramercy Gallery, 209 East 23rd Street, Manhattan.

headline: Pentagon Study Finds Agencies Ill Equipped to Detect Foreign Nuclear Efforts
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A report by the Defense Science Board suggests using some of the techniques that the National Security Agency has employed against terrorists.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A three-year study by the Pentagon has concluded that American intelligence agencies are “not yet organized or fully equipped” to detect when foreign powers are developing nuclear weapons or ramping up their existing arsenals, and calls for using some of the same techniques that the National Security Agency has developed against terrorists.

headline: It’s a Guy Thing
abstract: A photographer who takes what he calls “fetish photos” is the subject of “24 Exposures.”
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Court hearings over Texas public schools began this week with a familiar debate as the state’s lawyers defended the system’s fairness and districts cited limited resources.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for The Tribune.

abstract: “Old Goats,” which was made on a shoestring budget, looks at aging through the eyes of three elderly friends.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: Gun Maker Will Limit Sales in Protest of California Law
abstract: Smith & Wesson objects to a technology called microstamping, which prints a unique code on shell casings to make it easier to trace weapons used in crimes.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Smith & Wesson, the firearms manufacturer, announced Thursday that it would not sell new semiautomatic pistols in California because of its objections to a gun safety law that took effect in the state last May.

headline: Bill O’Reilly to Interview President Obama Before Super Bowl
abstract: As he has each year of his presidency, Mr. Obama made himself available to the news department affiliated with the network covering the Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: In what has now become a Super Bowl tradition, President Obama will sit for an interview to be broadcast during Fox’s pregame coverage on Feb. 2. And for the second time he will speak with Bill O’Reilly of the Fox News Channel.

headline: Michael Sporn, 67, Dies; Film Animator Adapted Beloved Children’s Books
abstract: His work focused on adaptations of children’s books and included an Emmy-winning collaboration with Ntozake Shange.
lead_paragraph: Michael Sporn, an animation artist whose award-winning work included film adaptations of beloved children’s books like “Lyle, Lyle, Crocodile” and “Goodnight Moon” as well as stories he conceived, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 67.

headline: Speeding Up G.M.’s Comeback
abstract: In her first extended public comments since taking over General Motors, Mary Barra vowed to quicken its comeback with improved products, better brands and consistently profitable operations around the world.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — No matter how much attention she draws as the auto industry’s first female chief executive, Mary T. Barra is determined to keep the focus on cars and trucks at General Motors.

headline: Greetings, From Around the World
abstract: Readers respond to an Op-Ed article, “The ‘How Are You?’ Culture Clash.”

headline: On Moroccan Hill, Villagers Make Stand Against a Mine
keywords: ['Mines and Mining', 'Water', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Poverty', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: An unlikely spot for a settlement was established to protest a mining company’s expropriation of precious water supplies, as well as the pollution that results from the mining.
lead_paragraph: IMIDER, Morocco — On a hilltop nearly 5,000 feet high in the Atlas Mountains here, a tiny outpost has taken shape over the past two years. The small stone buildings are decorated gaily with graffiti, and there is an open-air gallery. Many doors bear inspirational inscriptions from people like the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Mother Teresa. On the dam of a nearby reservoir, someone has painted the face of a local activist, now in jail on what the locals regard as trumped-up charges.

abstract: Gov. Rick Snyder has proposed bringing in 50,000 immigrants over five years as part of a visa program aimed at those with advanced degrees or exceptional abilities.
lead_paragraph: For Detroit, a city that has watched a population in free fall, officials have a new antidote: immigrants.

headline: Super Bowl Ads to Help Start Busy Season
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Super Bowl', 'Grammy Awards', 'Golden Globes (Awards)', 'Olympic Games (2010)', 'Television']
abstract: The power of big-event television is on display as perhaps never before.
lead_paragraph: IN a world where television viewers routinely zip through or zap commercials, advertisers crave big-event television — live events that viewers watch in real time. And the power of those big events is now on display as perhaps never before.

headline: Billionaires and Boasts
abstract: A football player’s swagger turned all eyes to Seattle, but it was a claim by that city’s most famous billionaire that deserved more attention.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — My city is famous for its retail exports: coffee and Costco, Microsoft and Macklemore, Boeing’s jetliners and Jeff Bezos’s business model. This week, a boast by a man with number 25 on his chest turned all eyes to Seattle. But it should have been the claim by the city’s most famous billionaire that got more attention.

headline: Hospital Chain Said to Scheme to Inflate Bills
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Hospitals', 'Medicaid', 'Medicare', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Whistle-blower suits claim Health Management Associates tried to inflate its Medicare and Medicaid payments by admitting more patients.
lead_paragraph: Every day the scorecards went up, where they could be seen by all of the hospital’s emergency room doctors.

headline: Tea Party Donors Exploit Followers, Schumer Says
keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicare']
abstract: Senator Charles E. Schumer says Democrats are not doing enough to counter the Tea Party, and one way would be to drive a wedge between the elite and the middle-income members.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Charles E. Schumer on Thursday called on Democrats to try to reduce the Tea Party’s political influence by driving a wedge between the movement’s elite leaders and its middle-income followers who depend on popular government programs like Medicare.

headline: Perverse Primaries
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: Sore-loser laws favor partisan extremists and disempower voters.
lead_paragraph: OBSERVERS of our polarized democracy often blame party primaries for producing some of our most extreme politicians. It’s well known that the most vociferous and partisan activists have a disproportionate influence in primaries.

headline: The Populist Imperative
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Unemployment']
abstract: This is why we’re likely to hear a lot about inequality and social justice from President Obama next week.
lead_paragraph: “The outstanding faults of the economic society in which we live are its failure to provide for full employment and its arbitrary and inequitable distribution of wealth and incomes.”

headline: Politics on the Strip
abstract: Does it send a wrong message to hold a national political convention amid the gambling houses of Las Vegas?

headline: Mars Rover Marks an Unexpected Anniversary With a Mysterious Discovery
abstract: NASA’s Opportunity rover bounded to the surface of Mars for what was planned to be a three-month exploration, but 10 years later, it’s still there making discoveries.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, NASA’s Opportunity rover bounded to the surface of Mars for what was planned to be a three-month exploration.

headline: Progress on Predatory Lending
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Payday Loans', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Consumer Protection', 'Personal Finances', 'Editorials']
abstract: Rules issued in November to protect unsuspecting borrowers are helping to keep vulnerable Americans from being ambushed by debt.
lead_paragraph: Rules issued in November to stop banks from emulating predatory payday lenders have yielded promising results. The rules, issued by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, have led several banks to discontinue “deposit advance” loans that are specifically designed to trap people in debt. But consumers will remain vulnerable to versions of the debt trap until another agency, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, issues rules of its own to protect consumers of small loans from excessive and unaffordable costs.

headline: Still Surging, Stanislas Wawrinka Reaches Australian Open Final
abstract: Wawrinka continued the best stretch of his career with a four-set victory over Tomas Berdych, setting up a possible final against his Swiss countryman Roger Federer.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — More than an hour after Stanislas Wawrinka’s match ended, after he had advanced to his first Grand Slam final, he sat down in front of reporters. He was smiling. He kept smiling.

headline: Cuban Vendors, in Rare Move, Stage a Protest
abstract: In a rare demonstration of dissent, dozens of Cuban artisans and vendors protested government inspectors in the city of Holguín, witnesses said.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — In a rare demonstration of public dissent, dozens of Cuban artisans and vendors protested in the city of Holguín this week, marching to local government offices and demanding the right to work without government harassment, witnesses said.

headline: An Unassuming Liberal Makes a Rapid Ascent to Power Broker
abstract: Brad Lander, a Brooklyn Democrat who is the City Council’s new deputy leader for policy, is being called a “shadow speaker.”
lead_paragraph: Brad Lander, a cerebral and unassuming city councilman from Brooklyn with a degree in anthropology, has abruptly become the sort of person who endlessly fascinates scholars of the modern metropolis: a power broker.

headline: Even More Addictive Cigarettes
abstract: Manufacturers are designing cigarettes to deliver more nicotine to the lungs. That devious tactic requires a strong response by regulators.
lead_paragraph: It was a shock to learn from the latest surgeon general’s report that, because of changes in the design and composition of cigarettes, smokers today face a higher risk of lung cancer and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease than smokers in 1964, despite smoking fewer cigarettes. It is equally shocking to learn now that some of today’s cigarettes may be more addictive than those smoked in past years, most likely because the manufacturers are designing them to deliver more nicotine to the lungs to induce and sustain addiction. That devious tactic requires a strong response by regulators.

headline: Quick Work on Paid Sick Leave
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio swiftly delivers on a campaign promise to expand paid time off for sick workers.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio, swiftly delivering on a campaign promise, joined the City Council speaker, Melissa Mark-Viverito, last week in offering a bill to revise New York City’s law on paid sick leave. Their bill is broader than one that passed last year after much delay and political spatting. It’s also better.

headline: End the Phone Data Sweeps
abstract: Why continue a program that invades privacy, violates the law, and doesn’t even work?
lead_paragraph: Once again, a thorough and independent analysis of the government’s dragnet surveillance of Americans’ phone records has found the bulk data collection to be illegal and probably unconstitutional. Just as troubling, the program was found to be virtually useless at stopping terrorism, raising the obvious question: Why does President Obama insist on continuing a costly, legally dubious program when his own appointees repeatedly find that it doesn’t work?

headline: It Takes a Generation
keywords: ['Youth', 'Children and Childhood', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: A real national social mobility strategy must address youth development from ages 0 to 25.
lead_paragraph: Over the past decade we’ve had a rich debate on how to expand opportunity for underprivileged children. But we’ve probably made two mistakes.

headline: Industry Awakens to Threat of Climate Change
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Drought', 'Shortages', 'Air Pollution', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Corporations']
abstract: Coca-Cola and other corporations are starting to see global warming as an economically disruptive force affecting commodity costs and supply chains.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Coca-Cola has always been more focused on its economic bottom line than on global warming, but when the company lost a lucrative operating license in India because of a serious water shortage there in 2004, things began to change.

headline: In Halfpipe and Slopestyle, Freeskiing Challenges Snowboarding
abstract: Olympic freeskiers will compete in halfpipe and slopestyle, just as snowboarders do. The differences between the two- and one-plank disciplines, aside from the equipment, may be most apparent in the air.
lead_paragraph: David Wise may be the best halfpipe skier in the world. He is a favorite to win a gold medal in the event’s debut in Sochi, Russia, where it will be compared with the better-known version performed by snowboarders like Shaun White.

headline: U.S. Warns Against Business With Iran
keywords: ['Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The warning came as the Treasury announced a settlement with a European bank for having allowed Iran to bypass sanctions by using the company’s access to American banks.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration intensified efforts on Thursday to counter what officials called a misimpression that the six-month nuclear agreement with Iran had opened the door to new economic opportunities with the country, emphasizing that nearly all sanctions remained in force and warning businesses not to engage in any deals still pending after the accord’s July 20 expiration.

headline: Dead Developer’s Accounts Missing $2 Million
keywords: ['Kidnapping', 'Bankruptcies', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Filings in a Brooklyn bankruptcy case show that the money had “recently been improperly taken” from accounts of the victim, Menachem Stark.
lead_paragraph: As detectives pressed their search for culprits in the kidnapping and killing of a Brooklyn real estate developer this month, filings this week in a bankruptcy case in Brooklyn revealed that nearly $2 million had been improperly removed from accounts in the developer’s name.

headline: Metro-North Grinds to Halt for 2 Hours
abstract: The trains were stopped around 7:45 p.m. on the Hudson, Harlem and New Haven lines, stranding thousands of commuters.
lead_paragraph: A power failure at Metro-North Railroad’s control center at Grand Central Terminal cut service to its three main lines on Thursday night, stranding thousands of passengers across the metropolitan region for nearly two hours and setting off a chaotic scene as the hub swelled with bemused commuters.

headline: A Case of Innocence, With Missteps Seemingly at Every Turn
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Robberies and Thefts']
abstract: After a man was shot, the police traced a cellphone number and arrested a woman. But the victim himself had misdialed the number.
lead_paragraph: It began in September 2005 with a man in a hospital bed, just out of a coma but floating on a lake of morphine for the pain from the bullets he took in the stomach during a push-in robbery. A detective asked the man to check his cellphone records because the robbers had made some calls before he was shot.

headline: New York City Sanitation Chief Finds That When It Snows, It Pours
abstract: After Mayor Bill de Blasio acknowledged that plowing lagged on Manhattan’s Upper East Side, he directed Commissioner John J. Doherty to review the management of the storm there.
lead_paragraph: John J. Doherty, New York City’s sanitation commissioner, has had better weeks.

headline: Scarlett Johansson’s SodaStream Endorsement Deal Conflicts With Charity Work, Aid Group Says
abstract: Oxfam has distanced itself from one of its global ambassadors, Scarlett Johansson, since she agreed to become the face of SodaStream, an Israeli firm that makes products in a settlement in the occupied West Bank.
lead_paragraph: The international aid and development group Oxfam has distanced itself from one of its own global ambassadors, the actress Scarlett Johansson, since she agreed to become the face of SodaStream, an Israeli company that makes products in a settlement built on West Bank territory Israel has occupied since 1967.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 23, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: U.S. Olympic Outfits Worthy of Stares, if Not Medals
abstract: Professional critics weigh in on the United States team’s outfits for the Olympic opening and closing ceremonies, with some seeing a bold, patriotic statement and others seeing garish Christmas sweaters.
lead_paragraph: The most passive-aggressive reviews of the United States Olympic team’s new gear from Ralph Lauren were probably those directed at Zach Parise by his Minnesota Wild teammates. They stashed dozens of 8-by-10-inch photos of Parise wearing the Olympic team’s garish new sweater around the Wild’s locker room before he arrived for work Thursday. “I got a lot of requests,” Parise said with a sheepish smile, “from guys who want to get that sweater.” The best part of his public — at least on Twitter — humiliation? He may never get another chance to wear the outfit. The United States hockey team will arrive at the Sochi Olympics after the opening ceremony, at which the sweater will make its runway debut, and will depart before the Games end. But since Parise’s teammates are only amateur critics, The New York Times asked some professionals to weigh in.

headline: In Rural Jails, E-Cigarettes Are a Calming Vapor
abstract: Cash-strapped county jails are finding that the sale of e-cigarettes to inmates can provide a lucrative source of income.
lead_paragraph: LAFAYETTE, Tenn. — As city governments and schools across the country move to ban or restrict the use of electronic cigarettes, one place increasingly welcomes the devices: the rural county jail.

headline: Corrections: January 24, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on January 24, 2014.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: Weary, Brooding and Made for Each Other
abstract: In John Patrick Shanley’s “Outside Mullingar,” an Irish father and son and their neighbors, consider questions of life, death, love and the family farm.
lead_paragraph: The rain pours down in steady streams, shrouding in gloom the Irish countryside of “Outside Mullingar,” the new play by John Patrick Shanley that opened on Thursday night at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater. Gloomy, too, is the talk of lost loves, deaths and other grim subjects dear to the hearts of the Irish, or at least those who populate Broadway stages. As is also regularly the case in plays set there, the reaper will pay a house call before the curtain has fallen.

headline: Instruments Played With Mizraabs
abstract: Ian Livengood introduces a new phrase to The New York Times crossword puzzle, and we may never be the same.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Alert! Because of a production error last Friday, the crossword puzzle that was published in the Jan. 17 print issue, by Ian Livengood, was published in error. The correct puzzle for this date, by Kevin G. Der, appeared online that day. The Livengood puzzle appears online today and the Der puzzle will appear in print. If you would like to join in the Wordplay discussion for the Der puzzle, please click here.

headline: Erased Answers on Tests in Philadelphia Lead to a Three-Year Cheating Scandal
abstract: Answer keys were passed to students. Principals doctored answer sheets. At some schools, teachers and administrators gathered to change test answers. The episode in Pennsylvania has again raised questions about standardized testing.
lead_paragraph: The first sign that something was wrong appeared more than two years ago when a company grading student tests from Philadelphia noticed that erasures from wrong to right answers showed what investigators delicately called “statistical evidence of improbable results.”

headline: Not Living in the Past, but Going for Visits
abstract: Jessica Dickey’s “Row After Row” tells the story of three Civil War re-enactors in Gettysburg.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve ever been curious about the motivations of the people who spend their weekends — and sometimes healthy chunks of their lives — participating in meticulous re-enactments of famous Civil War battles, revelations can be found at City Center, where “Row After Row,” a new play by Jessica Dickey, is being presented by the Women’s Project. Ms. Dickey’s likable comedy-drama reveals that these hyperactive history buffs are just normal folk like the rest of us, with job troubles, love troubles, life troubles — but with a predictable quirk or two.

headline: Soldier’s Family Found Dead in Apparent Murder-Suicide
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Families and Family Life', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The bodies of the soldier’s husband and two daughters were found at home at Fort Hood, where suicide involving service members has been a persistent problem.
lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex. — An apparent murder-suicide involving the husband and the two children of a soldier who had recently returned from a deployment to Afghanistan is providing a new twist to a persistent problem at the sprawling Fort Hood Army base here.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, January 24, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, January 24, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “I look at this as something to control their moods. And so if they’re not a good boy or girl, I’m going to take them away, just like I do with the TVs.”

headline: Samsung’s Profit Drops as Apple Squeezes Mobile Sales
abstract: The company cited a range of factors, including the recent strength of the won currency and concerns that economic growth would slow.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Samsung Electronics, the largest maker of smartphones, confirmed on Friday that growth in sales and earnings slowed sharply in the fourth quarter of 2013, and the company said business conditions would remain challenging in the first few months of the year.

headline: Address May Hint at Compromise on Ways to Fight Inequality
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: Some in both parties see a chance for compromises — perhaps on tax policy, education and even the minimum wage.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than he might have imagined just a month ago, President Obama has an opening with Tuesday’s State of the Union address to advance his argument to Congress that the rising inequality of economic opportunities is America’s “defining challenge of our time.”

headline: Legal Marijuana Businesses Should Have Access to Banks, Holder Says
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Marijuana', 'Law and Legislation', 'Medical Marijuana']
abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said that lawful marijuana businesses should have access to the American banking system and that the government would soon offer rules to help them gain it.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said Thursday that lawful marijuana businesses should have access to the American banking system and that the government would soon offer rules to help them gain it. The rules are not expected to give banks a green light to accept deposits and provide other services, but would tell prosecutors not to prioritize cases involving legal marijuana businesses that use banks.

headline: Phil Mickelson’s Toughness Tested at Hometown Event
abstract: Phil Mickelson’s first round in his hometown tournament, the Farmers Insurance Open, turned into a test of grit when his back locked up, making every downswing an exercise in pain control.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Phil Mickelson talked on Wednesday about the extra attention he must pay to his diet, his workouts and his health — particularly his psoriatic arthritis — now that he is a golfer of a certain age. On Thursday, he endured five hours of backtalk from his 43-year-old body.

headline: Reports of Cheating Prompt Review of U.S. Nuclear Launch Crews
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Cheating']
abstract: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel ordered a review of the military’s nuclear force after reports of cheating and low morale among Air Force nuclear launch officers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel on Thursday ordered an independent review of the military’s nuclear force and summoned top officials to the Pentagon to discuss personnel issues after reports of cheating and low morale among Air Force nuclear launch officers.

headline: Missouri Obstructing Health Law, Judge Rules
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: A federal court found that the state imposed onerous restrictions on people helping consumers navigate the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal district judge declared Thursday that the State of Missouri was illegally obstructing the activities of insurance counselors appointed by the federal government to inform consumers of their options under the Affordable Care Act.

headline: De Blasio Urges Mayors to Forge an ‘Urban Consensus’
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio promoted his priorities — free prekindergarten paid for by a tax on the wealthy, an expansion of paid sick leave — at the United States Conference of Mayors on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Bill de Blasio was the mayor of the moment on Thursday.

headline: Bargnani’s Injury Adds to Knicks’ Frustration
abstract: The Knicks’ Andrea Bargnani has been sidelined indefinitely with an elbow injury, and Coach Mike Woodson suggested that the news media is manufacturing controversy.
lead_paragraph: Andrea Bargnani attempted to dunk over two defenders late in the third quarter of Wednesday’s game against the Philadelphia 76ers, and it did not go well. Bargnani was fouled and fell about three feet short of the basket, with his left arm absorbing the brunt of the blow.

headline: Hoping to Leave Loved Ones With Only Memories, Not Debt
abstract: Frank Costanza has had three heart attacks and a heart transplant, and does not want to burden his loved ones with his debts after he is dead.
lead_paragraph: Troublesome hearts run in Frank Costanza’s family.

headline: Colorado: Columbine High Takes Precautions After Threats
abstract: Columbine High School, where 13 people were killed in a shooting in 1999, was sealed off for several hours on Thursday after receiving three phone threats, school and law enforcement officials said.
lead_paragraph: Columbine High School, where 13 people were killed in a shooting in 1999, was sealed off for several hours on Thursday after receiving three phone threats, school and law enforcement officials said. As the authorities investigated the threats, the suburban Denver school and seven others in the area were put on a lockout for about four hours, meaning that classes continued inside the schools, but outside doors were locked and people were not allowed to enter or leave. Officials with the Jefferson County sheriff’s office did not describe the threats, but said they did not appear to be “local or credible.” School officials said in a Facebook message to parents that all students were safe inside the school. The lockout was lifted about 2 p.m.

headline: Rangers Enter Outdoor Series on Down Note
abstract: Kevin Shattenkirk’s tiebreaking power-play goal at 3 minutes 9 seconds of the third period lifted the Blues past the Rangers at the Garden.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers are headed to Yankee Stadium to play their next two games, but Thursday’s match did not end well, a 2-1 loss to the St. Louis Blues at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Fined Billions, JPMorgan Chase Will Give Dimon a Raise
abstract: In a series of contentious meetings, JPMorgan Chase’s board voted to give Jamie Dimon a new pay package after his pay was cut in half last year, to $11.5 million.
lead_paragraph: A year after an embarrassing trading blowup led to millions of dollars being docked from Jamie Dimon’s paycheck, the chairman and chief executive of JPMorgan Chase is getting a raise.

headline: Chet Curtis, Half of Married News Team Whose Divorce Made News, Dies at 74
abstract: Mr. Curtis and his wife and co-anchor on WCVB, Channel 5, Natalie Jacobson, delivered the news nightly to Bostonians for 18 years before they split up.
lead_paragraph: Chet Curtis, for decades half of a high-wattage husband-and-wife news anchor team in Boston whose personal and professional breakup caused wide distress in the city, died there on Wednesday. He was 74.

headline: U.S. Willing to Hold Talks if Snowden Pleads Guilty
abstract: The United States did not specify the guilty pleas it would expect from Edward J. Snowden before opening talks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said Thursday that the United States was willing to discuss how the criminal case against Edward J. Snowden would be handled, but only if Mr. Snowden pleaded guilty first.

headline: Japan’s Leader Compares Strain With China to Germany and Britain in 1914
abstract: The blunt remarks, which concurred with others made recently by prominent historians, provoked an angry response from Beijing.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Relations between Asia’s two biggest powers, Japan and China, have been strained for months, with near-constant sniping over a territorial dispute and the two countries’ fraught history.

headline: Al Qaeda Calls for Rebel Unity in Syria
abstract: In an audio recording released Thursday, the leader of Al Qaeda called on Islamist brigades in northern Syria to stop fighting one another.
lead_paragraph: In an audio recording released Thursday, the leader of Al Qaeda, Ayman al-Zawahri, called on Islamist brigades in northern Syria to stop fighting one another, to focus on toppling President Bashar al-Assad and to form an Islamic court to arbitrate disputes. Fifteen days of infighting between rebel brigades and fighters from the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, which is inspired by Al Qaeda, had killed nearly 1,400 people as of Wednesday, according to a count kept by the opposition Syrian Observatory for Human Rights. Mr. Zawahri has little sway over most of the groups fighting in Syria.

headline: Deadly Fire at a Nursing Home in Canada
abstract: The fire in Quebec killed at least five people and left 30 missing, all of them believed to be 80 or older and many with limited mobility.
lead_paragraph: Five people were confirmed dead and 30 were missing after a fire destroyed much of a nursing home in L’Isle-Verte, Quebec, early Thursday morning. The missing and dead are all believed to be 80 or older, many with limited mobility, and were residents of the home, which is in a village of about 1,400 northeast of the city of Quebec. “We can keep a bit of hope, but in reality there seems to have been a considerable loss of life,” Prime Minister Stephen Harper said. The fire destroyed the three-story, wooden portion of the home, La Résidence du Havre, which opened in 1997. A newer wing of the building that was equipped with sprinklers remained standing. Unusually cold weather hampered firefighters and restricted fire investigators.

headline: Artist Testifies That a Reproduction of a Famous Work Wasn’t Authorized
abstract: Jasper Johns took the stand in the case of Brian Ramnarine, a former owner of a Queens foundry who is accused of creating at least 13 fake sculptures.
lead_paragraph: It was not quite a lecture on contemporary art or postmodern sensibility, but in Federal District Court in Manhattan on Thursday, the painter and sculptor Jasper Johns discussed his methodology, corrected a lawyer on the pronunciation of the artist Robert Rauschenberg’s name and said, quite firmly, that he had never authorized a foundry owner to reproduce one of his famous works depicting the American flag.

headline: New York City’s Jobless Rate Falls to 8.1%
abstract: The city’s unemployment rate fell to 8.1 percent in December, and the number of jobs passed four million for the first time.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s unemployment rate fell to 8.1 percent in December, the lowest it has been in five years, the state Labor Department reported on Thursday.

headline: The Younger the Child, the More ‘Educational’ the Screen. Maybe.
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Families and Family Life', 'Mobile Applications', 'Parenting', 'Television']
abstract: The older a child is, the less of her screen time her parents are likely to consider educational, a study finds.
lead_paragraph: Two- to 10-year-old children spend about two hours interacting with various screens on an average day. According to a new survey from the Joan Ganz Cooney Center, a nonprofit research institute affiliated with the Sesame Workshop, the nonprofit producer of “Sesame Street,” and reported on for The Times by Motoko Rich, we parents at least think some of that time is spent on “educational” games and programming.

headline: Ask Well: Stairs and Knee Pain
abstract: Most people with knee arthritis experience pain when they go down stairs. A few simple measures may help.
lead_paragraph: Question:

headline: Huckabee Criticizes Required Coverage of Birth Control
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas minced no words in criticizing requirements that health insurance pay for birth control.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas minced no words on Thursday in criticizing requirements that health insurance pay for birth control. The reasoning behind the idea, he said, was that women “cannot control their libidos or their reproductive systems without the help of the government.”

headline: Screen Time Study Finds Education Drop-Off
abstract: According to a new study, less than half the time that children age 2 to 10 watch or interact with electronic screens is spent on what parents consider “educational” material.
lead_paragraph: With children spending more time in front of screens than ever, parents sometimes try to convince themselves that playing Angry Birds teaches physics, or that assembling outfits on a shopping app like Polyvore fires creativity.

headline: Report on Unrest Is at Odds With Account of Myanmar
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Human rights groups say that with this latest round of anti-Muslim violence, Myanmar’s government appears to be trying to cover up the problem.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The United Nations report this week that rampaging mobs in western Myanmar killed at least four dozen people, mostly Muslims, did more than contradict the government’s official stance. It also put a spotlight on the country’s continuing religious and ethnic strife — and what some say is a flawed government response — even as Myanmar tries to burnish its international image.

headline: What’s On Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 11:45 A.M. (Starz) FINDING NEVERLAND (2004) Johnny Depp, in an Oscar-nominated role, portrays J. M. Barrie, the author of “Peter Pan, or the Boy Who Wouldn’t Grow Up,” and Kate Winslet (above, with Mr. Depp) is Sylvia Llewelyn Davies, the widow whose four young sons inspired the masterpiece in this best picture nominee directed by Marc Forster. “The problem isn’t the liberties the filmmakers take with reality, but that this isn’t an engaging bowdlerization,” Manhola Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “Barrie and Sylvia don’t have to tussle like Halle Berry and Billy Bob Thornton in ‘Monster’s Ball,’ Mr. Forster’s last feature, but it would have been nice if they trembled once or twice.” She added: “Only once does ‘Finding Neverland’ grasp both the writer and his play’s dark undertow, when the wonderful Scottish actress Kelly Macdonald, in the role of Peter, realizes that Tinker Bell may die. Rousing all the heartbreak and deep feeling in Barrie’s world, she entreats us to believe and, for one glorious moment, you do.”

headline: Vanska to Conduct Minnesota Orchestra Concerts
abstract: Osmo Vanska, who resigned as music director during the Minnesota Orchestra’s 15-month lockout, will conduct several concerts this spring.
lead_paragraph: There is no word as to whether Osmo Vanska will be returning as music director to help nurse the Minnesota Orchestra back to artistic health now that its 15-month lockout is over, but the orchestra announced on Friday that Mr. Vanska would conduct several concerts this spring.

headline: The Journey of ‘Miss Lovely’ from Cannes to the Censors
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Cannes International Film Festival', 'Censorship', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Movies', 'Nineteen Hundred Eighties', 'Pornography']
abstract: The director Ashim Ahluwalia said he never thought his movie about the sex-horror film industry of 1980s Mumbai would get past the Indian review board, much less draw an enthusiastic response from local audiences.
lead_paragraph: BANGALORE — For the director Ashim Ahluwalia, “Miss Lovely,” his movie about the soft-core pornography business in Mumbai, has led to a series of delightful surprises: Last year, it won the award for the best film at the 14th Mumbai International Film Festival, the award for best feature film at the 11th Indian Film Festival of Los Angeles and was included in the Un Certain Regard section at the Cannes Film Festival.

headline: Investment by Alibaba Creates Frenzy Over Chinese Pharmaceutical Data Firm
abstract: Citic 21CN’s shares rose by as much as 500 percent as investors bet Alibaba might try to use the company as a shell for a “backdoor” listing in Hong Kong, but the trades may prove overly optimistic.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Shares in the state-backed company Citic 21CN soared as much as 500 percent in Hong Kong on Friday after it said that the Alibaba Group, the Chinese Internet behemoth, had acquired a controlling stake in it for 1.3 billion Hong Kong dollars, or $170 million.

headline: Test Yourself | Editing Practice, Jan. 24, 2014
abstract: Can you identify the subject of a sentence from the article?
lead_paragraph: Take the Quiz

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Gay Marriages Confront Catholic School Rules
abstract: How is the legalization of same-sex marriage in many states affecting Roman Catholic schools across the nation?
lead_paragraph: In “Gay Marriages Confront Catholic School Rules,” Michael Paulson writes about a wave of firings and forced resignations of gay men and lesbians from Roman Catholic institutions across the country.

headline: Planet Hillary
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The gravitational pull of a possible 2016 campaign is bringing all the old Clinton characters into her orbit. Can she make the stars align, or will chaos prevail?
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton was nodding solemnly to the mother of a 9/11 victim when Huma Abedin, standing across the room, called out, “Let’s load!” to the staff members and bodyguards. The former secretary of state had yet to pick up her award from the Voices of September 11th, but her entourage was already preparing to shuttle her off to the next event, a benefit for God’s Love We Deliver, which was co-hosted by the designer Michael Kors and where she would sit next to the Vogue editor and former Obama bundler Anna Wintour. It was just another hectic fall evening in Manhattan for Clinton, and she was keeping herself busy as usual in the “is she or isn’t she” interim. There were paid speeches to give (at $200,000 a pop) to the American Society of Travel Agents and the National Association of Realtors, filled with the wisdom gleaned from being the nation’s top diplomat (“leadership is a team sport” was one favorite; “you can’t win if you don’t show up” was another). There were awards to receive, like the one from Chatham House, a think tank in London, to which Clinton traveled on a commercial 757 like the one she used to command while working at the State Department. (“That was fun!” she said of the flight.) And there were Beverly Hills galas to attend, which soon turned into schmooze sessions, like the ones with Harvey Weinstein and Richard Plepler and Jeffrey Katzenberg, yet another major Obama bundler.

headline: Do Laws That Ban Offensive Words Make the World a Better Place?
abstract: Should the right to free speech trump our desire to end the use of hateful words?
lead_paragraph: Israeli politicians are considering a ban on the word “Nazi” in any setting except for educational purposes. Backers of the law say they want to combat everything from rising anti-Semitism to teenage trash talk. But should the right to free speech trump our desire to end the use of hateful words?

headline: Exposing the Legacy of Operation Condor
keywords: ['Archives and Records', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Missing Persons', 'Operation Condor', 'Photography', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: Operation Condor, the secret plan carried out by several South American dictatorships to eliminate left-wing opponents, killed as many as 60,000 people. The photographer João Pina has spent a decade unearthing its mysteries.
lead_paragraph: In 1975, six South American military dictatorships conspired to concoct a secret plan to eliminate their left-wing opponents. Not only would the intelligence services of Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Paraguay and Uruguay trade information with each other and kidnap, disappear and kill their own domestic foes, they would also cooperate in identifying and killing exiles from partner countries who had taken refuge elsewhere.

headline: A New Vionnet
abstract: Suzy Menkes speaks with Hussein Chalayan and Goga Ashkenazi about the designer’s first collection for Vionnet.
lead_paragraph: Suzy Menkes speaks with Hussein Chalayan and Goga Ashkenazi about the designer’s first collection for Vionnet.

headline: When It Comes to Nymphs and Princes, Water and Earth Don’t Mix
abstract: A decidedly mixed revival of Dvorak’s “Rusalka” opened at the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday evening.
lead_paragraph: Dvorak’s “Rusalka,” about a water nymph doomed by her love for a human prince, is a fairy tale. But is it polite and placid, or savage and strange?

headline: Times Minute | Jamie Dimon's Raise
abstract: Also on the Minute, e-cigarettes in county jails and a Carrie Mae Weems retrospective.
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, e-cigarettes in county jails and a Carrie Mae Weems retrospective.

headline: Defying Economy, Chinese Hit the Road
abstract: While Hong Kong continues to shine for mainland Chinese shoppers, travelers are venturing farther and leaving deeper economic tracks.
lead_paragraph: Joe Tsoi Chun-Kin, a 17-year-old student from the southern Chinese city of Dongguan, visits Hong Kong about every two weeks to shop for clothes and other items, spending a few thousand renminbi per trip.
