headline: New York Today: Waiting Out the Cold
abstract: What you need to know for Friday and the weekend: freezing temperatures continue, more commuting woes and, oddly, the sculptures of Herb Alpert.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:32 a.m.

headline: Prolonged Fight Feared in Egypt After Bombings
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: Four deadly bombings left a grim realization that a cycle of terrorism and repression is hardening the wills of the military-backed government and a growing Islamist insurgency to fight to the death.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Three years after the start of its revolt for democracy, the capital was shaken Friday by four deadly bombings, in the clearest sign yet that Egypt is entering a prolonged and violent struggle between the military-backed government and a growing Islamist insurgency.

headline: North Korea Agrees to Proposal to Resume Family Reunions, Reversing Stance
abstract: South Korea and the United States remained skeptical over North Korea’s motives after it agreed to resume family reunions for those divided 60 years ago by the Korean War.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Reversing its earlier stance, North Korea on Friday agreed to a South Korean proposal to resume a long-suspended humanitarian program that arranges reunions of elderly relatives separated six decades ago by the Korean War.

headline: How Long Have I Got Left?
abstract: I always knew I’d die, without knowing when. But now I knew it acutely.
lead_paragraph: AS soon as the CT scan was done, I began reviewing the images. The diagnosis was immediate: Masses matting the lungs and deforming the spine. Cancer. In my neurosurgical training, I had reviewed hundreds of scans for fellow doctors to see if surgery offered any hope. I’d scribble in the chart “Widely metastatic disease — no role for surgery,” and move on. But this scan was different: It was my own.

headline: Violent Protests in Ukraine
abstract: The European Union weighs in.
lead_paragraph: The European Union weighs in.

headline: Chip Profits Help Soften Other Losses at Samsung
abstract: A slide in smartphone sales was partly offset by the company’s hold on vital handset components, which are often sold to Apple and other competitors.
lead_paragraph: In the marketplace, Samsung Electronics and Apple battle for customers. In the courts, they fight over patents. Yet every time Apple sells an iPhone, Samsung quietly cheers, too.

headline: A Racist Turn in India
abstract: After the murder of a Nigerian man, hostility toward Africans in India has bubbled up like dirty water.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Africans — Nigerians, Ghanaians, Ugandans — began leaving my neighborhood in New Delhi around December. Each week, more and more families exited. Some went to parts of Delhi considered more accepting of Africans; others to areas where the residents were thought to be less interfering in general. I have heard that some of the Ghanaian families had gone back to Africa, but I don’t know that for sure.

headline: Daily Report: Microsoft’s Earnings Indicate a Shift to Devices and Services
abstract: The company said its second-quarter profit rose 3 percent, ahead of analysts’ forecasts, with strong sales of its Xbox consoles and Surface tablets.
lead_paragraph: A picture of the new Microsoft, one transformed from a software factory into a maker of devices and online services, came into sharper focus on Thursday, Nick Wingfield reports.

headline: Lunch-Hour ‘I Do’s,’ and They’re Working Together Still
abstract: Susan and Angelo Costanzo met when he was her employer, but they let their lives blend; And despite a 25-year age difference, they eloped.
lead_paragraph: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together for more than two decades.

headline: 10 Reasons Performance Reviews Don’t Work
abstract: The reviews would be done only because I demanded them. And when they were done, the paperwork was put in a drawer and ignored.
lead_paragraph: Most business owners think they should do performance reviews. Often, though, they fail to find the time and they question the value of the reviews. Employees rarely like the process, which typically feels more like an evaluation than a constructive conversation.

headline: Rafael Nadal Dismantles Roger Federer Once Again to Advance to Final
abstract: Nadal continued to dominate Federer, setting up a championship match against Stanislas Wawrinka of Switzerland.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — For all of Roger Federer’s accomplishments, for the 17 Grand Slam singles titles and the 302 weeks spent atop the rankings, there remains one serious issue with his greatest-of-all-time résumé. That issue is Rafael Nadal.

headline: JPMorgan’s Chief Gets a Pay Raise
abstract: Jamie Dimon, the chairman and chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, will get a pay raise. | Doctor in SAC trial says F.B.I. was after Steven A. Cohen, SAC’s founder. | The ongoing saga between Time Warner Cable and Charter Communications is heating up. | Herbalife is facing a new foe in a freshman senator. | Goldman Sachs considers a ban on chats.
lead_paragraph: JPMORGAN’S DIMON TO GET RAISE  |  Despite the legal troubles that JPMorgan Chases faced in 2013, which amounted to more than $20 billion in fines, Jamie Dimon, the bank’s chairman and chief executive, is getting a raise, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Susanne Craig write in DealBook. The pay increase follows the board’s move last year to cut Mr. Dimon’s compensation in half, to $11.5 million as reprimand for allowing a multibillion-dollar trading mistake known as the London Whale.

headline: Jana Partners Presses Juniper Networks to Cut Costs and  Make Other Changes
abstract: Jana accused Juniper of having an “unfocused product line up, a lazy balance sheet and share price underperformance.” The pressure bolsters efforts started by Elliott Management a week ago.
lead_paragraph: The activist hedge fund Jana Partners has set its sights on Juniper Networks, calling on the networking company to tighten its belt and give more money back to shareholders.

headline: New Law to Ban Manual Removal of Human Waste Disappoints
keywords: ['Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Discrimination', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Law and Legislation', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: India enacted its most stringent law yet against the dehumanizing task known as manual scavenging, which is exclusively done by Dalits, but human rights activists say the law has no teeth.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Last month, human rights advocates should have rejoiced after the central government enacted the most stringent law against what is euphemistically called manual scavenging, which is the removal of human waste with bare hands.

headline: Apollo Tyres Open to Transactions Despite Cooper Tire Deal Collapse
abstract: Apollo Tyres of India is looking for future strategic acquisitions, possibly in growth markets like Brazil, Africa and parts of Asia, its vice chairman said.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland – Apollo Tyres of India remains open to future strategic acquisitions despite the collapse last year of a potential $2.5 billion deal with the Cooper Tire and Rubber Company, its vice chairman said Friday.

headline: U.N. Leader Says Banks Should Finance More Sustainable Businesses
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: At the World Economic Forum, Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, said he wanted banks and other financial companies to focus their lending in the future on the development of sustainable energy sources and businesses with low carbon footprints.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland – Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, on Friday called on banks and other financial companies to increase financing for development of sustainable energy sources and businesses with low carbon footprints.

headline: A Man Without a Nation, in Italy
keywords: ['Movies', 'DVD (Digital Versatile Disc)', 'Video Releases (Entertainment)', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: “Nostalghia,” Andrei Tarkovsky’s penultimate film, is releasing on Blu-ray.
lead_paragraph: “What’s missing from movies nowadays is the beauty of the moving wind in the trees,” D. W. Griffith told The American Mercury, not long before he died in 1948. Griffith made his reputation with blockbusters like “The Birth of a Nation” and “Intolerance,” but in the end, his sense of the medium was founded on the sense of physical reality that the first motion pictures afforded.

headline: In a Blizzard of Sounds, the Intuitive Maestro
abstract: Ariel Rechtshaid, a Grammy nominee who has collaborated with a dizzying variety of pop performers, talks about his evolution as a producer and listener.
lead_paragraph: BURBANK, Calif. — On Sunday’s Grammy Awards ballot for producer of the year, next to four names that have been well known and well rewarded for 10 to 15 years — Pharrell Williams, Dr. Luke, Jeff Tweedy, Rob Cavallo — is Ariel Rechtshaid. He is pop’s sudden question mark, both for his profusion of good-to-great work over the last year or two and for the dissociative confusion you might experience when scanning the list of albums he’s worked on as a producer or a songwriter in that period.

headline: 2 Sides in Syria Peace Talks Agree to Meet in the Same Room, Averting a Breakdown
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'International Relations']
abstract: The sides were expected to spend much of Saturday trying to agree on a cease-fire to allow aid to reach areas blockaded by the government in Homs.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The participants in the fragile Syrian peace conference agreed on Friday to meet in the same room for the first time, in a last ditch agreement that averted a potential collapse.

headline: Geopolitical Tensions Fly During Panel on American Interests
abstract: Syria, the Iraq war and other trouble spots were hot-button issues in a panel that included Senator John McCain, the Republican from Arizona, and Aleksei K. Pushkov, the head of Russia’s parliamentary Foreign Affairs Committee.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland – The World Economic Forum is usually considered a big networking event, where high-powered people schmooze in relatively cozy comfort.

headline: In Our Pages: January 25
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: 1914: Liner Set for 3rd-Class Traffic

headline: Thai Court Says Delay of Elections Is Constitutional
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Elections', 'Constitutions', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: The ruling surprised scholars and was seen as a setback for Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra, the target of protesters who want to stop the vote.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — A Thai court ruled Friday that a postponement of coming elections, which protesters have worked feverishly to block, is lawful under the country’s Constitution.

headline: A Spilled Cup on the No. 1 Train
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A spilled beverage on a white dress turned a woman irate on the subway.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Financial Companies in ‘Street Fight’ With Cybercriminals
abstract: In a panel discussion at the World Economic Forum on Friday, the top executives of MasterCard and the Western Union Company spoke about the escalating battle to keep financial transaction systems secure.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland – Financial companies are engaged in a escalating battle with increasingly sophisticated criminal organizations and some governments trying to hack into electronic payment systems, MasterCard’s top executive said Friday.

headline: Sundance: The Plastic Surgeon and the Actor, a new Comedy Team
abstract: “Land Ho!” stars an An ocular plastic surgeon from Kentucky and a veteran actor from Australia, and the two had a lot to say about their casting.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah — “Did you like our movie?” Earl Lynn Nelson boomed point-blank from the stage, after a screening of the comedy “Land Ho!” in which he stars. The audience in the Egyptian Theater here on Wednesday evening cheered and applauded, then lined up to pose for photos with him.

headline: Victoire de Castellane’s Blinged-Out Sculptures at Gagosian
abstract: The beloved Dior fine jewelry designer exhibits a new series of small-scale works.
lead_paragraph: As the head of Dior’s haute joaillerie division since 1998, Victoire de Castellane has infused the luxury brand’s precious offerings with a signature pop whimsy. In 2007, she began toying with sculpture in the form of small-scale works festooned with jewels and anchored by sand-cast silver bases. Beginning January 28, they will be on display at Gagosian’s London gallery in her latest fine-art exhibition, “animalvegetablemineral,” which takes its name from a parlor game. The works incorporate flora and fauna motifs, as well as rough, unpolished geodes — the raw material for the precious stones de Castellane knows and loves. Each is presented beneath a glass globe (“as they would in a natural history museum,” she explains) and christened with a girlish name (Cana Glitter Night Baby, Lunae Lumen Holly Clorum). And although the pieces are art, de Castellane couldn’t help but incorporate a sparkling bauble, to be detached and worn, into each one. “Creating jewelry is my way of expressing myself,” she says. “It’s like a language.”

headline: Treat Reckless Driving Like Drunk Driving
keywords: ['Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: The first question everyone asked after my nephew was killed after being struck by a car was whether the driver was drunk. Yet merely looking for alcohol or drug involvement by the driver misses the point.
lead_paragraph: On a rainy, foggy night earlier this month, a New York City taxi driver making a left turn at a light apparently did not see my 9-year-old nephew and his 6-foot-3 father crossing the street at a crosswalk, beckoned by a lighted “walk” sign. Whether because of haste, inattention, cellphone use or perhaps the poor weather conditions, the cab driver drove directly into them. My beloved nephew, Cooper Stock, died instantly. His father suffered minor injuries. The Manhattan District Attorney’s office is investigating the circumstances of Cooper’s death.

headline: U.N. Sounds Alarm as Iraqis Flee Violence
abstract: The number of people fleeing their homes in Anbar Province is bigger than at the height of sectarian violence years ago, the United Nations said.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations sounded an alarm Friday over the deepening conflict involving militants linked to Al Qaeda in Iraq’s Anbar Province, saying the number of people forced to flee their homes was the highest since the sectarian violence of 2006-8, during the American-led occupation.

headline: Umit Benan’s Homage and Thom Browne’s Nature Trail
abstract: Winter 2014 collections range from ’40s-inspired tailoring to bloated suits.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — With heads down and shoulders hunched, the models trooped across an earthen floor behind a wire mesh screen.

headline: Kris Van Assche: A Bolt of Lightning
abstract: Mixing casual and formal was the designer’s message for the season.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — At the Krisvanassche show, the designer put what looked like a bolt of lightning on the lapel of a jacket or at the breast of a coat — which could have been a reminder of the arrow-straight tailoring in which he excels.

headline: Seeing My Friend Depicted in ‘Lone Survivor’
keywords: ['ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Movies', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: John Ismay, a former Navy officer, meets with the actor Eric Bana, who plays the role of his friend in the movie “Lone Survivor.”
lead_paragraph: I dreaded the idea of seeing my old roommate’s death depicted on screen in the movie “Lone Survivor.” But when I saw a pair of Birkenstocks walking away from the camera on the big screen, I knew someone had taken the time to get the details right. Someone really cared about this story.

headline: Germany’s Finance Minister Praises Progress Made in Crisis Countries
abstract: Wolfgang Schäuble, the German finance minister, offered unusually generous praise for efforts being made in Greece, and also cited progress in Portugal and Ireland.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — One of Germany’s top political leaders on Friday offered unusually generous praise for Greece’s efforts to deal with its economic crisis, and said that other European countries should help Greece deal with an influx of immigrants to prevent them from becoming fodder for right-wing parties.

headline: U.S. Oil Production Keeps Rising Beyond the Forecasts
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Production of oil in the United States rose by a record amount in 2013, the International Energy Agency said, and it is expected to rise again in 2014.
lead_paragraph: OIL production in the United States rose by a record 992,000 barrels a day in 2013, the International Energy Agency estimated this week.

headline: Skills Practice | Creating ‘Character Recipes’
abstract: What “ingredients” might go into Lady Macbeth Soup? A pinch of paranoia and a pint of blood? In this writing prompt, students use recipes from The New York Times as templates for writing about characters in novels.
lead_paragraph: Onion, tomatoes and ground beef are a few of the many ingredients Adam Nagourney includes in his recipe for meatballs with marinara sauce. Pretty straightforward. But what if you wanted to take the recipe format and use it to illustrate how to “cook up” a character like Huckleberry Finn or Lady Macbeth? What “ingredients” would you need? A dash of courage for Huck? A pinch of paranoia and a pint of blood for Lady Macbeth?

headline: Sharing an Android Tablet
abstract: Separating apps and settings on an Android device, and adding photos to email on an iPhone.
lead_paragraph: Q. Is it possible for two people to use one Android tablet and keep their apps and settings separate?

headline: Aftermath of Explosions in Egypt
abstract: Scenes from Cairo, where at least six people were killed in four bombings. Demonstrations broke out in support of Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi and against the Muslim Brotherhood hours later.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from Cairo, where at least six people were killed in four bombings. Demonstrations broke out in support of Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi and against the Muslim Brotherhood hours later.

headline: Is It Immoral to Watch the Super Bowl?
abstract: The industry and the players may have grown too large for the game to be played safely.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1978, during a preseason game, a wide receiver for the New England Patriots named Darryl Stingley lunged for a pass just out of his reach. Before he could regain his balance, he was hit by Jack Tatum, an Oakland Raiders defensive back. It was clear at once that Stingley was, in gridiron parlance, “shaken up on the play.” Team doctors rushed to his side.

headline: After Private Speech on Israel, de Blasio Is Pressed on Openness Pledge
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio offered a measured mea culpa in responding to inquiries about the seemingly secretive nature of his appearance at an American Israel Public Affairs Committee gala.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio gave an unannounced speech at a Manhattan gala of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, the leading pro-Israel lobbying group, assuring its members that “part of my job description is to be a defender of Israel.”

headline: Photographs of the Old Penn Station
abstract: What New York’s Penn Station looked like before it was torn down in 1963.
lead_paragraph: The razing of New York’s Penn Station in 1963 still ranks as one of the city’s great architectural disasters. At the time, The New York Times wrote, “We will probably be judged not by the monuments we build but by those we have destroyed.” Walter Chandoha, a photographer who is now 93, remembers the old train station fondly. He was living in New York in the late 1940s and studying at N.Y.U. on the G.I. Bill when he would duck out between classes, Rolleiflex in hand, and wander around the city. Penn Station was a cherished spot, even before it was slated for demolition. “When I look at the pictures now and I see the magnificence of it, I think, How could anybody knock this thing down?” Chandoha says. “It’s like knocking down the Colosseum or the Brandenburg Gate. It’s impossible to imagine.” Julie Bosman

headline: The Buyback
abstract: We gave up our guns — and a bit of our past.
lead_paragraph: On a rainy Saturday afternoon, my husband and I finally gave up our guns. How we came to possess a small arsenal speaks to a past, though, not a predilection. We’re neither hunters nor collectors; we sign petitions demanding stricter controls and call our congressmen to do likewise. But throughout the years of my husband’s career as a diplomat, spent mostly in chaotic corners of Africa and Latin America, we acquired guns: mementos of the often-turbulent history that we witnessed. Strange as it was to have the weapons among our possessions, we could no more part with them than, say, burn an old photo album.

headline: Reply All: The 1.12.14 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: FUTURE BOY GROWS UP

headline: Discrimination at the Barber Shop?
keywords: ['Hair', 'Barbers and Barbering', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Wills and Estates', 'AIRPORTS', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)']
abstract: Sisters act; shuttle tact.
lead_paragraph: I am a woman with a short, boyish hairstyle. Is it unfair that I am charged more for a haircut than a man with similarly short hair? Different prices for different genders seems to me like a sexist relic from a less enlightened time. When I called local salons to find a new stylist (mine moved away), many of them balked when I said I should be charged the men’s rate because I have short hair. Many salons claim that “it has always been done that way.” This seems like a very bad excuse for an antiquated and discriminatory policy. YUKI MURATA, SANTA FE, N.M.

headline: Magnus Carlsen, Chess Champion: ‘My Moves Speak for Themselves’
abstract: The Norwegian 23-year-old on intimidating (and dating) the competition.
lead_paragraph: You became the world chess champion after a win in November. How did you go about training for the big match? The most important thing to study is opening theory, but I also study the latest trends to try to stay ahead, discovering new schemes and doing tactical exercises. I try to get into a chess mood.

headline: Curtain Call | The Designers of Paris Couture Collections Take Their Bows
abstract: To mark the conclusion of the Paris Couture collections, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 11 fashion visionaries.
lead_paragraph: Designers project their personalities not only through their collections but also in their appearances at the end of their runway shows. To mark the conclusion of the Spring 2014 Paris Couture Collections, we catalog the bows — some proud, some playful, some humble, some all of the above — of 11 fashion visionaries.

headline: The Guns of the Hudson
abstract: How a sleepy New York State town armed the Union.
lead_paragraph: The sleepy Hudson River Valley community of Cold Spring, N.Y., is arguably one of the most idyllic villages in the state. Sitting on the east bank of the Hudson, it offers spectacular views of the Highlands across the river, including the United States Military Academy at West Point. Its art galleries, antique shops, and fine restaurants make for a delightful weekend getaway for residents of New York City, an hour to the south.

headline: The Year in Adaptation
abstract: A look back at the books that made it to the big screen.
lead_paragraph: Cinematic book adaptations dominated 2012, with “Life of Pi,” “Silver Linings Playbook” and “Anna Karenina” springing from novels, and “Lincoln” and “Argo” drawing their stories from the nonfiction shelves. There was plenty of bookish inspiration in 2013, but the results elicited less enthusiasm. Martin Scorsese’s Oscar contender, “The Wolf of Wall Street,” was adapted from a memoir by Jordan Belfort. (The book begins: “You’re lower than pond scum.”) The movie’s leading man, Leonardo DiCaprio, also played the most famous literary character brought to the screen in 2013: Jay Gatsby. In The New Republic, David Thomson wrote his review in the form of a letter from Jay himself, who judged: “It’s stupefying, it’s vulgar, it’s demeaning.”

headline: Economic Shifts in U.S. and China Batter Markets
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Economy']
abstract: With China’s rise and the Federal Reserve’s economic action both in retreat, investors have been heading for the exits in markets as far removed as Buenos Aires, Istanbul and Beijing, with effects spilling over into the rest of the world.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:20 p.m. | The ascent of developing countries over the last decade has been fueled by two global trends: the steady rise of China and the willingness of the Federal Reserve to stimulate the economy.

headline: There Must Be Some Misunderstanding
abstract: Navigating the terrors of adulthood, the characters in Ben Marcus’s story collection resort to extreme survival strategies.
lead_paragraph: Ben Marcus achieved the startling visions of his first story collection, “The Age of Wire and String,” and the novels “Notable American Women” and “The Flame Alphabet” largely by placing the reader in strange and unfamiliar worlds that turned out to be our world after all. The stories of his new collection, “Leaving the Sea,” still contain peculiar linguistic and perceptual tics, but he has added to his arsenal narratives that are less relentlessly unfamiliar, less rigorously dis-enchanted, populated by characters full of longing and visible regret, though for what is not always clear. For fans of the old style, like me, there are still plenty of messed-up points of view, and we can be reassured that while most of the work in this collection begins on familiar ground, it happily disintegrates into confusion and dread. In the end Marcus presents a deeper range of identification for the reader, more emotional complexity, but still plenty of the chair-gripping alienation that marked his previous books.

headline: Writer of a Certain Age
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Books and Literature', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The author remembers when looks started to matter in publishing.
lead_paragraph: When I started out as a television dramatist in the ’60s, it was a truism that the more fanciable the female lead, the higher the ratings. Casting was a simple matter of sitting by the director while he flipped through acting photo directories and selected his preference. Theater was no different. When I took to writing plays in the ’70s, it was understood that if two mature women were talking onstage, audience members would cough and shift in their seats, but if two men of any age were talking, the audience would pay some attention. And if a man of any age and a young woman were alone onstage, you could hear a pin drop.

headline: Possession
abstract: In this novel, a girl left with the Shakers begins to see angels.
lead_paragraph: If, as the Shaker lyrics suggest, it truly is a gift to be simple, consider the emotional intricacies of Rachel Urquhart’s transfixing debut novel, “The Visionist.” Urquhart’s characters, many of them Shakers or Shakers-to-be, lead lives gifted with devastating complexity. Their paths resemble not the austere angles of a Shaker meetinghouse but rather the rapturous choreography of the dances Shakers were known for and named after.

headline: Taking Flight
abstract: Two women, white and black, strive for freedom in Sue Monk Kidd’s novel.
lead_paragraph: Unlikely alliances are a staple of fiction, and the unlikelier the better, from Huck and Jim floating down the Mississippi to Frodo and Gollum creeping toward Mordor — because the real drama lies in watching how dissimilar characters turn out to be brothers (or sisters) under the skin. Sue Monk Kidd followed this principle in her best-selling first novel, “The Secret Life of Bees,” in which a 14-year-old white girl and her family’s black servant join in fleeing abuse in the South Carolina of the civil rights era. Kidd’s latest novel, “The Invention of Wings,” also set largely in South Carolina, involves another unusual duo, in this case a slave and a daughter of the family that owns her.

headline: The Vanishing
abstract: Valerie Martin’s novel explores the enduring enigma of a 19th-century ship found floating in the Atlantic without captain or crew.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 4, 1872, the brigantine Mary ­Celeste was discovered abandoned, adrift in the North Atlantic near the Azores. The ship was empty and its crew missing, although its cargo and provisions were intact, as were the crew’s possessions. The weather was calm and the ship was seaworthy, but no trace of the crew — or of the captain’s wife and 2-year-old child — was ever found. Newspapers around the world carried the story, and it inspired one of Arthur Conan Doyle’s first published pieces of fiction, “J. Habakuk Jephson’s Statement,” printed anonymously in the British journal Cornhill. From then until the present, dozens of other investigations, novels, historical accounts, television documentaries and movies have been devoted to what has become the prototypical ghost ship. Given this background, what could Valerie Martin possibly contribute to the story in her new novel?

headline: The Anti-Snuggle Task Force
abstract: The funny side of Sandy; Agatha Christie vs. Chris Christie.
lead_paragraph: The funny side of Sandy; Agatha Christie vs. Chris Christie.

headline: Unreconciled
abstract: Conjoined twins, a spate of murders and the legacy of South African apartheid all factor into Chris Abani’s Las Vegas thriller.
lead_paragraph: Given the extraordinary truth of Las Vegas, a city that began after all as a glint in a mobster’s eye, you might wonder what possible iniquities are stored up in a novel purporting to tell its secret history. Is it, perhaps, a double-bluff, in which the real life of the city is one of stable communities and spiritual growth — Marilynne Robinson’s “Gilead” with slot machines?

headline: Commitment
abstract: Roddy Doyle’s Jimmy Rabbitte reappears, dealing with cancer, mortality and love.
lead_paragraph: Roddy Doyle’s new novel, “The Guts,” begins with a conversation about Facebook. Jimmy Rabbitte, the hero of Doyle’s 1987 novel, “The Commitments,” and a key figure in that book’s two successors, “The Snapper” and “The Van,” sits in a pub with his father, Jimmy Sr. The two men are arguing (or simply talking; it can be difficult to tell in Doyle’s starkly profane dialect), and the son explains social networking thus to his dad: “It’s like a club but yeh have your own room, for the people yeh want to meet. Except there’s no room an’ yeh meet no one. Unless yeh want to.” For a moment, perhaps, we think we know what to expect: a rambunctious comedy about aging musicians, working-class life, rock ’n’ roll, something fundamentally upbeat, because that’s what Doyle does. Even his darker books — “The Woman Who Walked Into Doors,” say, that raw tale of a woman’s abuse at the hands of her alcoholic husband — have a way of seeming spry, sunny underneath their patina of hardscrabble realism. So we’re ready for the comedy of crusty ­middle-aged Jimmy and his father navigating the dubious world of text messaging and mobile phones (after all, we haven’t seen them fleshed out in a novel since the 1990 of “The Van”). But the younger Jimmy has something else on his mind.

headline: Under the Covers
abstract: Wendy Lesser on the delights of a lifetime with books.
lead_paragraph: For writers, literature is a talent show: Those with the most talent win. Readers are more fortunate: Everybody wins. Quality reading exercises the crucial dialogue with yourself, the dialogue you must undergo to become yourself, to know where on the vista of existence you can place your own identity and awareness.

headline: Private Life
abstract: Janette Jenkins imagines Noël Coward’s last years.
lead_paragraph: Oh, how taxing it is to be Noël Coward in his declining years, trundling between two homes in Jamaica with only one servant to pour the brandy. (The other, alas, is off for the week.)

headline: Grand Illusions
abstract: Jean Echenoz’s novel follows five soldiers in the Great War.
lead_paragraph: The story could hardly be simpler. Five young Frenchmen leave their village to fight in the Great War. Some will be grievously injured, some won’t return.

headline: Albee’s ‘Death of Bessie Smith’ Is Extended in Brooklyn Run
abstract: Edward Albee’s early play, “The Death of Bessie Smith,” will now run through Feb. 9 at the Interfaith Medical Center, a hospital in Bedford-Stuyvesant that is on the verge of closing.
lead_paragraph: A community theater in Brooklyn has extended its run of Edward Albee’s early play, “The Death of Bessie Smith,” which is being staged inside the Interfaith Medical Center, a hospital in Bedford-Stuyvesant that is on the verge of closing.

headline: Then We Came to the End
abstract: In the courtroom and the classroom, two authors explore the complicated nature of death.
lead_paragraph: Nonfiction books about death tend to skew toward self-help (grieving, coping), spirituality (is heaven real?) and last lessons (“Tuesdays With Morrie”). In The New York Times Book Review last summer, Meghan O’Rourke noted a surge of writers chronicling their own decline and suggested that the trend represents a “natural outgrowth of significant social changes in how we experience disease and death.”

headline: A Sense of Snow
abstract: A drama of revenge plays out in wintry upstate New York.
lead_paragraph: Winter and discontent. The future Richard III pairs those elements in the first line of Shakespeare’s play, and they are also paired, with piercing chill, in James Scott’s debut novel, “The Kept.” It is 1897. Elspeth Howell is making her way to an isolated cabin in upstate New York. Elspeth is pursued by cruel weather and her past as “a sinner,” a woman besieged by “anger, covetousness, thievery.” Unlike “false and treacherous” Richard, she believes she has conquered her worst impulses. She bears gifts for her five children and her husband, Jorah. She longs for the comforts of home. What she discovers, instead, is the worst kind of retribution — a slaughter of innocents triggered by her own compulsive history.

headline: Ex-Governor of Virginia Is Released After Arraignment
abstract: Former Gov. Bob McDonnell and his wife were ordered not to leave the country after being arraigned on charges of accepting gifts in exchange for promoting a political patron’s business.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — The former governor of Virginia, Bob McDonnell, and his wife, Maureen, will remain free pending their trial on corruption charges after being arraigned Friday in Federal District Court in Richmond.

headline: What I Love | Anna Netrebko
abstract: The soprano’s brightly painted Upper West Side apartment has commanding views of the Hudson River.
lead_paragraph: The soprano’s brightly painted Upper West Side apartment has commanding views of the Hudson River.

headline: Anna Netrebko Decorates
abstract: The soprano lives in a condominium near the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: The Russian-born soprano Anna Netrebko lives with her son, Tiago (and sometimes with her sister,  Natalia), in a condominium high above Lincoln Square. The terraces, the high ceilings, the line of windows with sweeping views of the Hudson River, the quick walk to work at the Metropolitan Opera, the gym and swimming pool on-site — all are worth singing about.

headline: Who Made That Tricycle?
abstract: The history of two-wheeled vehicles starts in 1817, but inventors had long been much more forward-thinking when it came to trikes.
lead_paragraph: In March 1877, James Starley, a sewing-machine maker in Coventry, England, unveiled a strange offshoot of the tricycle. It had one large wheel on the left and two much smaller ones on the right. The rider sat between the wheels, driving with a pair of levers and steering on a crank. A few years later, Starley’s new designs had grown so popular that the queen bought two for herself.

headline: Pipeline Fight Lifts Environmental Movement
abstract: While it remains unclear whether President Obama will approve a 1,700-mile oil pipeline from Canada, the fight has changed environmental politics.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Environmentalists have spent the past two years fighting the Keystone XL pipeline: They have built a human chain around the White House, clogged the State Department’s public comment system with more than a million emails and letters, and gotten themselves arrested at protests across the country.

headline: Image of the Day: January 24
abstract: Indian tennis player Sania Mirza during a mixed doubles semi final match at the Australian Open tournament in Melbourne.

headline: The Doctor-Go-Round

lead_paragraph: When each new test finds a new problem.

headline: In Russia, Couriers Halt Parcel Delivery
abstract: Because of new customs restrictions, several major express delivery services have stopped delivering packages to individual clients.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia has never been an easy country in which to deliver packages because of its vast size. The government just made it a lot harder for anyone buying things online.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Gabriel Sherman, whose unauthorized biography of Roger Ailes is No. 9 on the hardcover nonfiction list, tried hard to secure his subject’s participation.
lead_paragraph: Roger and Me: Gabriel Sherman’s unauthorized biography of Roger Ailes, “The Loudest Voice in the Room,” saunters onto the hardcover nonfiction list this week at No. 9. The book doesn’t arrive without controversy: Ailes, the founder and president of Fox News Channel, refused to cooperate with Sherman and went so far as to grant exclusive access to a rival journalist, the Rush Limbaugh biographer Zev Chafets, in evident hopes of pre-empting Sherman with a friendlier account. (Chafets’s book, “Roger Ailes: Off Camera,” was published in March 2013 and spent a week on the e-book nonfiction list.) On NPR’s “Fresh Air” last month, Sherman described his efforts to interview Ailes in terms that called to mind Michael Moore’s early documentary “Roger and Me,” about the General Motors chief executive Roger Smith. “I reached out to Roger Ailes more than a dozen times in the two and a half years I was doing the researching and writing, both in person and in writing,” he said. “I traveled to different states to see him at public events to tell him I was eager to sit down and discuss every fact in the book. Ultimately, it was his decision not to participate.” Ailes’s opposition, he continued, had provided “a crash course in what it must be like to be involved in a political campaign. . . . I’m not the story. Roger Ailes is the story. But he has elevated me to a place where it’s this kind of me-­versus-him dynamic.”

headline: Lessons From a Master Cat Photographer
abstract: Walter Chandoha, who has been mastering the art of cat and dog photography for more than 60 years, shares some of his secrets.
lead_paragraph: Walter Chandoha, who has been mastering the art of cat and dog photography for more than 60 years, shares some of his secrets.

headline: Sundance: A Dark Mood Pervades This Edition
abstract: Though there were breakout films, festivalgoers left with a downbeat sense of the offerings this year.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah – As always, cineastes spent Sundance on a cloud. They marveled at “Calvary,” a blackly comedic exploration of religion, and lit up over emerging talents like Alex Ross Perry, director of the acerbic “Listen Up Philip.”

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Bitcoin (Currency)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']

lead_paragraph: Mark T. Williams, a former commodities trading floor senior executive and Federal Reserve Bank examiner, teaches banking, finance and risk management at Boston University School of Management.

lead_paragraph: On a late-November day in 1983, Steven Levy, then a freelance journalist for Rolling Stone, got into a car outside 10460 Bandley Drive, in Cupertino, Calif.

headline: In the Alps, a Walk in the Sky
abstract: A new glass enclosure at the tip of the Aiguille du Midi mountain peak in France offers a stunning view (and sensation) from 12,605 feet.
lead_paragraph: Visitors will feel like they’re floating above the Alps with “Step Into the Void,” a new five-sided tempered-glass enclosure located at the tip of the Aiguille du Midi mountain peak. The enclosure lies at one end of the world’s tallest skywalk structure, which stands at 3,842 meters (12,605 feet) and overlooks the French commune of Chamonix.

headline: Truth and Consequences for a War Photographer
keywords: ['Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'News and News Media', 'Newspapers', 'Photography']
abstract: The Associated Press has severed its relationship with Narciso Contreras, a Pulitzer Prize-winning photographer, for digitally altering a picture, an ethical lapse with severe consequences.
lead_paragraph: The ethical commandments on the digital manipulation of photographs in journalism are simple and direct: you do not add or subtract any element of an image in post processing. Ever. If a photo didn’t turn out exactly how you had imagined, there is no laptop digital do-over.

lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — Russia plans to extend its offer of asylum to Edward J. Snowden beyond August, a Russian lawmaker said Friday at the World Economic Forum here.

headline: Some States Are Moving to Loosen Their Estate Taxes
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Inheritance and Estate Taxes', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Wills and Estates', 'Taxation', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Capital Gains Tax', 'States (US)']
abstract: In 16 states, mostly in the North, state estate taxes ensnare the people the high federal exemption intended to protect.
lead_paragraph: FOR most of the United States, the estate tax is now something only the very wealthy have to plan for. The federal exemption for an individual this year is now $5.34 million, or $10.68 million for a married couple. And that amount is indexed to inflation, so it will continue to rise.

headline: Following Your Dream Brings Bliss, but Not Always Money
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions']
abstract: Many people who lose their jobs, decide to start a business, but find it isn’t always easy.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Trent Brown was laid off from his job as a sales representative in 2010, he chose to view it as an opportunity to make a life change. Instead of searching for some other company job, he decided to help his wife, Janell, expand her cupcake and cake-making hobby into a business. Just six months after he lost his job, they opened One Sweet Slice in the Salt Lake City area where they lived.

As Eric Schmidt of Google put it: “The jobs problem is going to be the defining problem of the next two to three decades.”

keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Energy and Power', 'Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Nuclear Energy']

lead_paragraph: Here’s another round in a continuing exploration of views on next steps for nuclear power. Earlier this week, I received a letter arguing for a fresh push on nuclear technologies, building on the argument of James Hansen and three other climate researchers that I wrote about last fall.

headline: Former Interpreter for The Times Is Killed in Afghanistan
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Terrorism', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The former interpreter, Noor Ahmad Noori, was found beaten, stabbed and possibly suffocated on a roadside near Lashkar Gah, where he lived.
lead_paragraph: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — Noor Ahmad Noori, an Afghan interpreter who formerly worked for The New York Times in Afghanistan, was found beaten and stabbed to death, wrapped in a sack and dumped on a roadside late Thursday outside Lashkar Gah, the capital of Helmand Province, where he lived, government officials and family members reported.

headline: Big Raise for JPMorgan’s Dimon Despite a Rough Year
abstract: The bank’s chief executive will receive $20 million in compensation for 2013, a raise of 74 percent over the previous year, despite a series of bruising legal setbacks.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:09 p.m. | JPMorgan Chase, after a year marred by scandal and stiff regulatory penalties, has decided to award its chief executive, Jamie Dimon, $20 million in compensation for 2013, an amount that will further inflame the debate over the accountability of senior bank executives.

lead_paragraph: LOVE IS A CANOE,  by Ben Schrank. (Picador/Sarah Crichton, $16.) Her marriage in trouble, the heroine of Schrank’s novel — a crackling sendup of the New York publishing industry and an inquiry into the fragility of human relationships — turns for help to the author of “Marriage Is a Canoe,” a classic self-help book she read as a child.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: DUTY: Memoirs of a Secretary at War,  by Robert M. Gates. (Knopf, $35.) One of the few Obama administration members who come off well in this frank account — probably one of the best Washington memoirs ever — is Hillary Clinton.

headline: Co-ops Chill, Condos Don’t
abstract: As co-ops become more applicant-friendly, condos enact more rules.
lead_paragraph: The phrase “white-glove Manhattan co-op” has invariably conjured the image of a fortresslike residence whose precincts could be stormed only via a gantlet distinguished by mountains of paperwork and a daunting personal interview. The New York condominium, the relatively new kid on the block, has seemed the opposite: laissez-faire in everything, from rules governing pets and smoking to regulations determining who could rent an apartment.

headline: Matsuev Postpones Carnegie Hall Concert
abstract: The pianist Denis Matsuev has postponed a Carnegie Hall concert scheduled for next Thursday because he is being treated for pneumonia.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 1:17 p.m. | The pianist Denis Matsuev has postponed a Carnegie Hall concert scheduled for Thursday, Jan. 30, because he is being treated for pneumonia, the hall announced. It said in a statement that Mr. Matsuev is “currently in Moscow under doctor’s care and not permitted to travel,’’ and that he had been forced to cancel or reschedule a number of concerts in the United States, Israel and Russia. Mr. Matsuev, who has been active in cultural preparations for the Winter Olympics in Sochi, is scheduled to play a concert there on Feb. 6 at the  Zimniy Theater. One of his representatives, Silke Zimmermann, said that “we firmly count on his participation” at the Sochi games. Mr. Matsuev’s Carnegie Hall appearance — which was to feature the music of Schumann, Rachmaninoff and Tchaikovsky — has been rescheduled for June 15.

lead_paragraph: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews "Visitors."

lead_paragraph: Two condominiums high in the north tower of the venerable Century at 25 Central Park West that were marketed as a single entity — to assemble a full-floor residence with panoramic views — sold for $14 million, the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

lead_paragraph: I’m not a doctor, but I’ve figured out that the birth control pill is a form of contraception. Take the pill daily; don’t get pregnant.

lead_paragraph: Duck season is proving a bit hit and miss so far this year.

headline: Claudio Abbado Commemoration at La Scala to Be Live Streamed
abstract: The event will be live streamed from Milan’s La Scala Opera House on Jan. 27.
lead_paragraph: A public commemoration of the conductor Claudio Abbado, who died on Monday at 80, will be live-streamed from Milan’s La Scala Opera House on Jan. 27 to allow “the global audience of the web” to participate, the theater announced on Monday. Daniel Barenboim will conduct the “Funeral March” from Beethoven’s third Symphony at 6 P.M. in Milan, noon Eastern Standard Time, and the event will be streamed on the theater’s website and on Youtube.

headline: Paris Couture Week: Maison Martin Margiela Spring/Summer 2014
