lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Paris Couture Week photo diary of Schohaja.

headline: Requiem for a Minivan
abstract: Our 2003 minivan saw us through 10 years of family life. It was our concession — our submission — to life as parents. Recently we realized we didn’t need it anymore.
lead_paragraph: Stella, my 8-year-old, was crying. Her little shoulders heaved with sobs. Her face, buried into my belly, left streaks of tears on my T-shirt. Her grief was acute. I helplessly rubbed her back, murmuring soothing sounds.

headline: Banker Says Letting Banks Fail Is Essential to Rebuilding Public Trust
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: “Too big to fail” is no longer needed in some parts of the world in the wake of banking reforms, said Urs Rohner, the chairman of the Swiss bank Credit Suisse. But, he said, “people have to be convinced there may be banks that fail.”
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — Rules enacted since the financial crisis have eliminated the need to designate banks as “too big to fail” in a number of countries in the next economic disruption, said Urs Rohner, the chairman of the Swiss bank Credit Suisse.

headline: Homies in Verona, Gangstas in Elsinore
abstract: Websites like Thug-Notes make points, and humor, by translating high literature and political speech into short-form raps
lead_paragraph: In 1848, a reviewer for Graham’s Magazine described “Wuthering Heights” as “a compound of vulgar depravity and unnatural horrors, such as we might suppose a person, inspired by a mixture of brandy and gunpowder, might write for the edification of fifth-rate blackguards.” Presumably, this grumpy writer would have cared even less for the Thug Notes version.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘My Age of Anxiety’
abstract: Scott Stossel talks about his new memoir, and Rebecca Mead discusses “My Life in Middlemarch.”
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Nathan Heller reviews “My Age of Anxiety,” Scott Stossel’s memoir about his own incapacitating nerves and the larger legacy of the disorder. Mr. Heller writes:

headline: A Lawyer and Partner, and Also Bankrupt
abstract: Gregory M. Owens is an extreme but vivid illustration of the economic factors roiling the legal profession.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who wonders why law school applications are plunging and there’s widespread malaise in many big law firms might consider the case of Gregory M. Owens.

headline: Shulamit Aloni, Outspoken Israeli Lawmaker, Dies at 86
abstract: Mrs. Aloni was an early champion of civil liberties, challenger of religious hegemony and outspoken opponent of Israel’s occupation of the Palestinian territories.
lead_paragraph: Shulamit Aloni, a longtime left-wing Israeli minister and Parliament member who was an early champion of civil liberties, challenger of religious hegemony and outspoken opponent of Israel’s occupation of the Palestinian territories, died Friday at her home in Kfar Shmaryahu, a Tel Aviv suburb. She was 86.

headline: Aide Arrested in Child Pornography Case Is Found Dead
abstract: Ryan Loskarn, a former chief of staff for Senator Lamar Alexander, Republican of Tennessee, was found dead in his parents’ home, apparently in a suicide.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A former chief of staff for Senator Lamar Alexander, Republican of Tennessee, who was arrested last month on charges stemming from his possession of child pornography was found dead on Thursday in the basement of his parents’ home in Maryland, apparently in a suicide, according to law enforcement officials.

headline: Gates and Summers Push Global Health Drive as Moral Imperative
abstract: Bill Gates and Lawrence H. Summers presented a new initiative, Global Health 2035, that aims to reduce deaths and improve health for low- and lower-middle-income countries within 21 years.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — Pouring money into improving health care in developing countries is a profound moral mission, according to Bill Gates and Lawrence H. Summers — and huge achievements are well in reach.

headline: Alfonso Cuarón May Be a DGA Favorite, but ‘Philomena’ Is Rising Fast
abstract: The Directors Guild Awards on Saturday will help awards watchers figure out whether there’s a three-way race, a situation the Weinstein Company could exploit to “Philomena’s” advantage.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – The Directors Guild Awards, to be held here on Saturday, are usually a reliable barometer of which way the wind is blowing, best picture-wise. Even last year, when the guild saw fit to give its top prize to Ben Affleck, who had been famously snubbed in the directing category by the Academy, it was an indication of how much love there was for his movie “Argo,” which went on to win best picture.

headline: Opossums Are Unloved, Yet Hard to Resist
abstract: The opossum is North America’s only native marsupial, with a short and difficult life.
lead_paragraph: The Virginia opossum is more closely related to kangaroos and koalas than to the rats and rodents with which it is frequently compared. North America’s only native marsupial, the opossum is probably more frequently observed in New York City trash cans than in New York City parks.

headline: Erosion of Argentine Peso Sends a Shudder Through Latin America
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Currency']
abstract: The decline in Argentina’s currency is the steepest since the country’s economic collapse in 2002, and it is raising fears of a global slump in developing countries.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Cities across Argentina are still unnerved by all the looting that broke out last month after police officers went on strike, protesting salaries eroded by rampant inflation. Residents fumed over blackouts that left them sweltering during a recent heat wave. Then the currency plunged this week, the steepest decline since the nation’s economic collapse in 2002, stirring fears that another major financial crisis could be around the corner.

headline: The Gun Report: January 24, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: As regular readers of this blog know, Chicago has the highest toll of gun violence in the nation. Which is why a billboard there equating an AR-15 with baseball and apple pie strikes many as tone-deaf.

headline: Review: 2014 Land Rover Range Rover HSE
abstract: Land Rover’s fourth-generation Range Rover has an familiar silhouette, a sumptuous interior and a price as steep as the hills it can conquer.
lead_paragraph: Land Rover’s fourth-generation Range Rover has an familiar silhouette, a sumptuous interior and a price as steep as the hills it can conquer.

headline: Not Your Grandmother’s Gratin
abstract: A vegetable gratin is a casserole that is baked in the oven in a heavy baking dish until the top and sides are browned, or gratinéed.
lead_paragraph: In my kitchen, leftovers often become the inspiration for a week of Recipes for Health. This happened last week. If you had opened my refrigerator on Sunday you would have found a selection of roasted vegetables, which I had prepared over the weekend for various dinners and recipe tests. By Tuesday those vegetables had found their way into three winter gratins.

headline: ‘Grace of Monaco’ Will Open the Cannes Film Festival
abstract: The film, featuring Nicole Kidman as Grace Kelly, will lead 12 days of festival programming.
lead_paragraph: Olivier Dahan’s film “Grace of Monaco,” featuring Nicole Kidman as the actress Grace Kelly, is the opening-night selection for the 67th Cannes Film Festival, its organizers announced today.

headline: How to Take a Perfect Cat Photo (or at Least Make a Living as an Artist)
abstract: Advice from Walter Chandoha, who has been photographing cats for decades.
lead_paragraph: The Look pages in this weekend’s magazine feature Walter Chandoha’s pictures of the old Penn Station, which he took in the late 1940s in between classes at N.Y.U.’s School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance (now the Stern School of Business). After one of these photographic excursions, Chandoha found a stray kitten in the Village and took it back to his home in Astoria, Queens.

headline: Video: Range Rover Offers Off-Road Capability in an Opulent Package
abstract: Range Rovers have a well-deserved reputation for on- and off-road driving manners, and few can do fancy as well as Land Rover.
lead_paragraph: The luxury off-road mission of Jaguar Land Rover’s Range Rover is a curious thing. Last time I checked, polar fleece formal wear never made it big, not even in Seattle. And yet, everywhere I go, people fawn over this opulent S.U.V.

headline: After a Long Trip, a Good Predators Debut for Del Zotto
abstract: Michael Del Zotto helped the Nashville Predators beat the Canucks in Vancouver on Thursday, one day after being traded by the Rangers for Kevin Klein.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — Michael Del Zotto made his debut with the Nashville Predators on a good note with a 2-1 road win over the Vancouver Canucks on Thursday night. A former Rangers defenseman, Del Zotto is hoping to tune up his N.H.L. career in Music City after being traded on Wednesday for Kevin Klein.

headline: Running Wild, Wheelies to the Wind
abstract: “12 O’Clock Boys” is a documentary examining Baltimore dirt-bike aficionados who gather once a week to ride en masse and perform stunts like wheelies.
lead_paragraph: They gather usually once a week on dirt bikes of all varieties, cruising down the road, engines revved, wheelies popped as they turn the streets of Baltimore into an urban playground. They are called the 12 o’clock boys, and they are the subject of a new documentary of the same name opening Friday. They are also seen as a menace by some in the city’s Police Department and as a danger by some residents.

headline: A Template 007 Named Fleming
abstract: Next to James Bond, Ian Fleming’s greatest creation may have been himself.
lead_paragraph: “Everything I write has a precedent in truth,” Ian Fleming once said, and next to James Bond, his greatest creation may have been himself. A failed stockbroker, the rakish Fleming imbibed drink, women and the family fortune as he tried to escape the shadow of his adventurous older brother Peter and the disappointment of his formidable mother. Then the Naval Intelligence Division cornered him, using his talent for spinning a tale in the World War II effort.

headline: Hardware Shop Owner Sculpts Art From Odds and Ends
abstract: John DeLuca runs a hardware store on Staten Island that doubles as a quirkly gallery for his collection of handmade planes, ships and other figures.
lead_paragraph: DeLuca General Store, an old-style hardware shop on Bay Street in the Rosebank section of Staten Island, has a Norman Rockwell-looking storefront with windows displaying garden tools and plumbing supplies.

headline: Bragging Rights of an Up-and-Comer
abstract: Martin Garrix became dance music’s boy wonder last year, but, in fact, the kid is a veteran.
lead_paragraph: Martin Garrix became dance music’s boy wonder last year, thanks to “Animals,” a springy and chipper slice of progressive house with just a touch of attitude. It made him, at 17, the youngest D.J. with a No. 1 chart hit at Beatport, the online electronic music store.

headline: Like John Wayne, but in Anoraks
abstract: A film follows a crew herding reindeer in Finnish Lapland, inside the Arctic Circle.
lead_paragraph: The doldrums of winter in the city can really get to you. What could be worse? The filmmaker Jessica Oreck, with her Kickstarter-financed documentary “Aatsinki: The Story of Arctic Cowboys” (at IFC Center through Thursday), has an idea. Her film follows the brothers Aarne and Lasse Aatsinki and their crew over one year as they herd reindeer in Finnish Lapland, inside the Arctic Circle.

headline: Star-Crossed Meets Hip-Hop
abstract: Beginning on Tuesday, Rennie Harris Puremovement is back at the Joyce Theater with a selection of repertory favorites.
lead_paragraph: A decade has passed since Rennie Harris Puremovement graced the stage of the Joyce Theater. In dance, that’s practically forever. Beginning on Tuesday, the company, led by the astute and poetic hip-hop choreographer Mr. Harris, is back with a selection of repertory favorites, including a newly excerpted and remounted version of “Rome and Jewels.” That Bessie Award-winning work from 2000 — created in collaboration with the dramaturge Ozzie Jonesand the composer Darin Ross — transfers Shakespeare’s “Romeo and Juliet” and “West Side Story” to a captivating b-boy world pitting the Monster Q’s (the Montagues) against the Caps (the Capulets). Mr. Jones reprises his role as narrator, while the astonishing Rodney Mason returns to star as Rome.

headline: Art of Collision, Sticks to Cymbals
abstract: Steven Schick, a star in the world of solo percussion music and the author of “The Percussionist’s Art,” celebrates his 60th birthday.
lead_paragraph: Steven Schick, a star in the world of solo percussion music and the author of “The Percussionist’s Art,” celebrates his 60th birthday with two concerts at Miller Theater that trace the trajectory of this repertory.

headline: Before and After, Paris in the 1800s
abstract: Two exhibitions opening this week sample opposite ends of the history of photography.
lead_paragraph: Two exhibitions opening this week sample opposite ends of the history of photography. First is Charles Marville, appointed official photographer of Paris in 1862. Over the next eight years, he documented old parts of the city destined for a drastic makeover, then photographed the new boulevards, gas lamps, pissoirs and other amenities that transformed Paris into a modern metropolis. “Charles Marville: Photographer of Paris,” opening Wednesday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, presents about 100 of his lucid and evocative photographs. (Through May 4, 212-535-7710, metmuseum.org.)

headline: The Source | Aaron Koblin in Conversation With Doug Aitken
abstract: In our latest installment of this exclusive series of interviews by Doug Aitken, the artist interviews the digital media and visualization artist Aaron Koblin.
lead_paragraph: “There’s all this invisible infrastructure that’s surrounding us,” says the digital media artist Aaron Koblin, who serves as the Creative Director of the Data Arts Team at Google. With visualization projects such as “Flight Patterns,” he has sought to bring that hidden world to light. Koblin speaks with the artist Doug Aitken about the intersection of art and technology as part of the Source, a series of candid video conversations with several dozen noteworthy figures about their creative processes, currently on view in a custom pavilion at the Sundance Film Festival.

headline: Making Waves at Sea, and in the Studio
abstract: The frontwomen of Warpaint agree: In the event of an apocalypse, they would outfit themselves more sensibly than Beyoncé.
lead_paragraph: The frontwomen of Warpaint agree: In the event of an apocalypse, they would outfit themselves more sensibly than Beyoncé. “You’re not going to be wearing a shirt” that is “just barely covering your nipples,” Theresa Wayman said of the futuristic video for the recent Beyoncé song “Superpower.” Emily Kokal added, “You’re going to be covering yourself from the elements.”

headline: Jemaine Clement and Taika Waititi
abstract: The co-directors and co-writers discuss their vampire film "What We Do in the Shadows" at Sundance.
lead_paragraph: The co-directors and co-writers discuss their vampire film "What We Do in the Shadows" at Sundance.

headline: Love That Dare Not Sing Its Name
abstract: The composer Charles Wuorinen has adapted “Brokeback Mountain” into an opera, collaborating with Annie Proulx, who wrote the story that inspired the 2005 movie.
lead_paragraph: In the acclaimed 2005 film “Brokeback Mountain,” based on the short story by Annie Proulx, Heath Ledger played Ennis Del Mar, a Wyoming ranch hand in a furtive, decades-long gay affair. He kept his words gravelly, mumbling and few, as if he’d been blocked up by a life of secrets. It was a voice powerfully affecting in the quiet close-ups possible in the movies, but it wouldn’t register in the grandeur of an opera house.

headline: Draghi Sees Progress in Euro Zone, but Puts Banks on Notice
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Deflation (Economics)', 'Euro (Currency)', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Some banks in the euro zone could go out of business as a result of intense official scrutiny they will face this year, Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, said Friday as he presented a generally upbeat view of the European economy.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, SWITZERLAND — Some banks in the euro zone could go out of business as a result of intense official scrutiny they will face this year, Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, said Friday as he presented a generally upbeat view of the European economy that was, however, laced with warnings.

headline: Old Democratic Name (Nunn) Stakes Bid on Shifting Georgia
abstract: Michelle Nunn, the daughter of a former senator, is running for the Senate in a campaign that is testing whether the state’s shifting demographics can send a Democrat to Washington.
lead_paragraph: PERRY, Ga. — As a little girl, Michelle Nunn clutched her father’s hand as they strolled the pecan groves of the family’s 2,400-acre farm, a moment captured in a black-and-white photograph that Sam Nunn used to help win election to the Senate. It hangs in a Sam Nunn exhibit in this small city south of Macon, where the main thoroughfare is Sam Nunn Boulevard.

headline: An Old-Style Jazzman, and Voices of Iran’s Past
abstract: New music from George Cables, Zara McFarlane and Ex-Easter Island Head, and a collection of Iranian songs from 1933 and before.
lead_paragraph: George Cables

headline: Sundance Video:  Jemaine Clement and Taika Waititi Are Onto Something
abstract: The writer-director-stars of a film about a New Zealand “undead community” think vampires might be big.
lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah – Vampires have finally descended on Sundance. In its 30th year the festival may be, as Manohla Dargis writes more vital than ever to the indie film scene. But that doesn’t mean it’s immune to the lure of big thrill entertainment that the undead provide. This year’s festival had not one but three vampire flicks: the high-profile “Only Lovers Left Alive,” from Jim Jarmusch, starring Tilda Swinton and Tom Hiddleston; “Girl Walks Home Alone at Night,” billed as “cinema’s first Iranian vampire western;” and “What We Do in the Shadows,” from writer-director-stars Taika Waititi and Jemaine Clement.

headline: Small-Town Crank Finds His Following
abstract: America’s love affair with British TV may have reached a peak with “Downton Abbey,” but viewers are also finding plenty of room in their hearts for “Doc Martin.”
lead_paragraph: America’s love affair with British TV may have reached a peak with “Downton Abbey,” but viewers are also finding plenty of room in their hearts for the decidedly different “Doc Martin,” a decade-old series about a cantankerous doctor and the ensemble of quirky neighbors and patients he looks down on in the fictional Cornwall coastal village of Portwenn.

headline: Gestures of a Hot Hand
abstract: Liam Scarlett of the Royal Ballet, a dance maker in demand, makes one for the New York City Ballet.
lead_paragraph: “Ooooooh!” shrieked the New York City Ballet dancer Tiler Peck, held high in the air, her body bent into a backward arch, her feet almost touching her head, as her partner, Robert Fairchild, ran across the studio. “Ooooooh!” shrieked the dancers in the room, half-laughing, some hiding their faces in their hands, as Ms. Peck rocked dangerously forward, almost toppling over his head.

headline: The 2015 Lincoln Navigator: A Familiar Shape With a New Face
abstract: With a body similar to the original 1998 Navigator, the refreshed 2015 model gets a more potent, more efficient EcoBoost engine and an updated grille.
lead_paragraph: The Lincoln Navigator first appeared in 1998 as an upscale Ford Expedition, which in turn was a larger version of that era’s Ford Explorer. If you saw the 2015 model coming from far away, or in low light, you might not be able to tell that anything had changed over the last decade and a half. But the Lincoln Motor Company assures us that the Navigator, familiar in profile as it is, is better than ever.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Topping Up
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Men and Boys', 'Coats', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Winter (Season)']
abstract: Many men are stubborn about dressing for the cold and snow.
lead_paragraph: Many men are stubborn about dressing for the cold and snow.

headline: Dismay for Pay at JPMorgan Chase
abstract: The board’s decision to give Jamie Dimon, its chairman and chief executive, a 73 percent raise is unjustifiable after last year’s performance, Antony Currie writes for Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Jamie Dimon’s bonus represents another whale of a fail for JPMorgan Chase. The board’s decision to give its chairman and chief executive a 73 percent raise, to $20 million, is unjustifiable after last year’s performance. Shareholders should have a loud say against this pay – and the lead director, Lee Raymond.

headline: Portrait of a Wily Holocaust Survivor
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Movies']
abstract: Claude Lanzmann’s documentary “The Last of the Unjust” centers on a rabbi who served as the head of the Jewish council at the Theresienstadt concentration camp.
lead_paragraph: Theresienstadt was called Hitler’s “gift to the Jews.” In an 18th-century military town some 40 miles north of Prague, this “model ghetto” was established to show the world that life in a concentration camp was practically halcyon. Grown-ups lingered over delicious meals between fulfilling workdays and evening concerts or lectures. Children devoured sweets. Soccer matches were played in the town square.

headline: Republicans Vote to Streamline Nominating Process
abstract: The move is intended to produce a nominee earlier in the process, preventing bruising and costly primary battles.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Republican National Committee moved Friday to consolidate its presidential nominating process in 2016, a pre-emptive effort to avoid a drawn-out campaign that many in the party say could imperil their effort to reclaim the White House.

headline: All Together Now, Eyes on the Screen
abstract: On Sundays, Michael Dorf, founder of the Knitting Factory music club and the City Winery restaurant, hangs out with his family, without the music he can’t get his children to love.
lead_paragraph: You start off a brash outsider, testing the limits of acceptability, and if you’re good enough and lucky enough, you eventually become the Establishment, explaining to your children why the things you’re passionate about aren’t too boring for words. Such is the trajectory of Michael Dorf, who founded the edgy music club Knitting Factory in 1986 and, 22 years later, City Winery, where middle-aged singer-songwriter types pluck and warble for patrons having braised rabbit and merlot-cabernet blends. Mr. Dorf, 51, plans to open City Winery outposts this year in Nashville and Napa Valley, Calif. On March 31 he will present his 10th annual benefit concert at Carnegie Hall to raise money for music education, this one dedicated to the songs of Paul Simon. He lives in TriBeCa with his wife, Sarah Connors, 49, a film producer, and their children, Sophia, 10, and 15-year-old twins, Eli and Zachary (who was away on a recent Sunday). The family has a rescue mutt and a rabbit.

headline: Wheelies: The Muppet Toyota Edition
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A Super Bowl car ad stars include the Muppets for Toyota and James Franco for Ford; Justin Bieber gets a D.U.I. after racing in a Lamborghini in Miami.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Cowboy Poetry and Rodeos
keywords: ['Cowboys and Cowgirls', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The National Cowboy Poetry Gathering celebrates its 30th anniversary this month, and the National Western Stock Show offers five rodeos and art exhibitions.
lead_paragraph: Next week marks the 30th anniversary of the National Cowboy Poetry Gathering, in Elko, Nev., a tradition sponsored by the Western Folklife Center in that city. Poets, storytellers, musicians, radio personalities and now even bloggers come together to promote the occupational and artistic traditions of the rural West.

headline: Seven Days of Style | Dior’s Didactic Runway, Chanel’s Couture Sneakers and Kanye’s Latest Designs
abstract: Plus, Burberry’s toxic shirt, André Leon Talley’s new online magazine and more, as we run the numbers from the last week in style and culture.
lead_paragraph: ALL THE NUMBERS THAT MATTER FROM THE WEEK IN STYLE AND CULTUREJan. 18 – 24

headline: Don’t Blame the Maps
keywords: ['Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Gerrymandering isn’t the Democrats’ real problem.
lead_paragraph: DO the Republicans owe their current congressional majority to gerrymandering? At first glance, it seems self-evident that they do. In the 2012 election, the Democrats won the popular votes for the presidency, the Senate and the House of Representatives. But somehow in the House — for whose seats Republicans controlled the redistricting process in many crucial states — the Republicans managed to end up with a 16-seat majority despite losing the popular vote.

headline: Pasta With Parsnips and Bacon
abstract: Parsnips add a certain sweetness to a cozy winter pasta dish thick with cream and bacon.
lead_paragraph: Parsnips add a certain sweetness to a cozy winter pasta dish thick with cream and bacon.

headline: Mutually Beneficial to Pasta and Parsnip
abstract: Two starches make a surprisingly good pair, and heavy cream binds the sauce.
lead_paragraph: PAIRING PASTA WITH PARSNIPS is not one of the more obvious matches. Their starchy natures make them seem too similar, the kind of couple that finishes each other’s sentences, which can be dull company indeed.

headline: Washington Theaters to Produce Women’s Theater Festival
abstract: Nearly four dozen theaters will work together to produce the Women’s Voices Theater Festival, showcasing contemporary female playwrights.
lead_paragraph: Nearly four dozen theaters in the Washington D.C. area are joining forces to produce the Women’s Voices Theater Festival, a celebration of contemporary female playwrights that will take over the Washington theater world for eight weeks starting on September 14, 2015. The festival is being organized by Molly Smith, the artistic director of Arena Stage, and Eric Schaeffer, the artistic director of Signature Theater, who announced the project on Thursday.

headline: Bach Inventions and a Monk Tribute, Using All of the Piano
abstract: In her recital on Thursday, for a piece by George Crumb, Simone Dinnerstein stood up and scratched the piano strings, as if playing a harp, and tapped rhythms on the instrument’s inside.
lead_paragraph: Bach wrote his set of 15 Two-Part Inventions as teaching pieces for amateurs of the keyboard, as he put it in a preface. Each work unfolds as just two contrapuntal lines, two voices, one for each hand.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: A Midtown co-op with a fireplace in every room; an Upper West Side condo in a full-service building; and a Midwood Park home with a circular staircase.
lead_paragraph: A Midtown co-op with a fireplace in every room; an Upper West Side condo in a full-service building; and a Midwood Park home with a circular staircase.

headline: Serendipity: 1. Spreadsheet: 0.
abstract: A subway ride, and all the bride’s careful searching went out the window.
lead_paragraph: Wherever she goes, Jennifer Lee Illes carries a big, black North Face backpack bulging with items like workout clothes, mint tea bags, sheet music from her a cappella singing group and aviation cards from the flying lessons she has been taking. Ms. Illes, a strategy and operations manager for Google in Ann Arbor, Mich., likes to be overprepared.

headline: In the Ghost With the Most, Drivers May Haunt the Back Seat
abstract: The Ghost is the sportier, entry-level Rolls-Royce sedan, and the Extended Wheelbase version adds 6.7 inches to its length, resulting in a huge back seat.
lead_paragraph: It’s a great time to sell fancy cars. At the Hilton Head Island Concours d’Elegance last fall, I met a Rolls-Royce salesman who was on his way to Atlanta to deliver a Wraith to a customer. The factor that limits sales of Rollses, he told me, is the factory itself: It literally can’t build them fast enough to satisfy demand.

headline: Duel at the Old Fulton Fish Market
keywords: ['Restoration and Renovation', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: Robert LaValva wants to use the site of the former Fulton Fish Market for more public food markets, while the Howard Hughes Corporation wants to build a 50-story hotel-residential complex.
lead_paragraph: Robert LaValva’s epiphany came early one February morning in 2005, as he watched London’s Borough Market come alive.

headline: On the Market in the Region
abstract: A colonial in Syosset, N.Y., with four bedrooms, each with a bath; and a Hillsborough, N.J., home built around the core of a 1920 farmhouse.
lead_paragraph: A colonial in Syosset, N.Y., with four bedrooms, each with a bath; and a Hillsborough, N.J., home built around the core of a 1920 farmhouse.

headline: Chinatown Revisited
abstract: What does an American Chinatown look like today? Going from New York to Southern California, Austin to Las Vegas, reveals the answer: It all depends on where you are.
lead_paragraph: My mother is the oldest of five siblings, most of whom grew up in New York’s Chinatown. They are voracious eaters and bargain hunters, and lifelong visitors to Chinese neighborhoods everywhere. When we talk about a good Chinatown, we point to certain signs: live fish for sale, dragon eyes in sidewalk produce displays, smokers, crowds.

headline: Amy Tan’s Evolving Sense of China
abstract: The writer talks about discovering secrets from her family’s past and what she’s found on trips to China.
lead_paragraph: In 1949, Amy Tan’s mother boarded one of the last ships heading from Shanghai to San Francisco before “China became Red China and the bamboo curtain descended.” There, her mother reunited with her husband and the couple relocated to Oakland, where a couple of years later she was born.

headline: The Ecstasy of Excess, the Agony of the Sticker
abstract: The Roll-Royce Wraith, derived from the Ghost sedan, offers an almost $400,000 driving experience that seems to avoid compromises.
lead_paragraph: BIG SUR, Calif. — Every carmaker makes compromises. Feature enhancements, like a little more legroom or a touch more horsepower, are weighed against the effect on a model’s sticker price. But what if, in an alternative universe, money could bend the laws of physics, and vehicles were created only to transport mortals to the highest state of driving satisfaction?

headline: Not Your Average Spirit
abstract: The Wraith, named for a soul-sucking ghost that casts spells and cannot be vanquished, is the most powerful Rolls-Royce ever produced.
lead_paragraph: The Wraith, named for a soul-sucking ghost that casts spells and cannot be vanquished, is the most powerful Rolls-Royce ever produced.

headline: Kiev Truce Falls Apart, and Unrest Resurges
abstract: Protests have spread to cities across the nation, even as a cease-fire disintegrated in the Ukrainian capital.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — With President Viktor F. Yanukovych and antigovernment demonstrators at an impasse here, a cease-fire disintegrated on Friday night as the Ukrainian capital convulsed in renewed violence and fire bombs lit up the night sky.

headline: Modern Civility, Retail Division
abstract: Experts weigh in on cellphone use at the cash register and being called “Honey.”
lead_paragraph: Retail is not without its dark alleys. As with those other public areas prone to a high incidence of bad manners (airplanes and restaurants), stores can be breeding grounds for the impulsive and the exigent. Enter the customer who greets unexpected delays with donkeylike braying. Enter the salespeople who clump idly in lush profusion but who then atomize upon approach.

headline: Weekend Reading: Looking Back at Our View From the Alps
abstract: As the World Economic Forum concludes in Davos, Switzerland, we’re looking back at some of our past coverage of the elite gathering.
lead_paragraph: As the World Economic Forum concludes in Davos, Switzerland, we’re looking back at some of our past coverage of the elite gathering.

headline: Loehmann’s, Out of Step and Closing Down
abstract: The demise of the discount chain after 94 years shows the shift in the way people shop for designer clothing.
lead_paragraph: Whenever a store, bar, restaurant or other institution closes in New York after decades, there’s a tendency to mourn the loss of an entire way of life, a vanished style of inhabiting the city that can no longer flourish in the context of new economies with new people too young, too preoccupied, too cavalier to appreciate the old and intrinsically superior, more genuine folkways. It is hard to mine the same kind of resonance from the closing of Loehmann’s, now shutting down after 94 years, if only because the hunger for discount would seem to be eternal. And yet the end of Loehmann’s still says something about our altered expectations of the retail experience.

headline: Goldman’s Cautious Approach to Hiring the Well-Connected
abstract: Goldman’s chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein, said Friday that the bank had a procedure to ensure that hiring of relatives of powerful people doesn’t cross a line into becoming bribes.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs, like other big banks, has been scrutinized for its hiring practices in China. The question federal authorities are investigating is whether banks hired the children of powerful Chinese officials in an attempt to win lucrative business.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Jeep Struggles to Repair Vehicles 14 Months After Recall
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Only 47,000 of the 745,000 S.U.V.’s Jeep recalled 14 months ago for an air-bag problem have been repaired. Jeep says parts are scarce.
lead_paragraph: Fourteen months after Chrysler said it would recall about 745,000 Jeep Grand Cherokee and Jeep Liberty sport utility vehicles because the front or side air bags might deploy without the vehicle being in a crash, about 94 percent of them had not been repaired, leaving some owners angry and scared.

headline: Officials Blame Human Error for the Latest Blow to the Reputation of Metro-North
abstract: A day after evening commutes halted across the railroad, transportation officials said technicians had mistakenly taken out a power supply while a backup source was unavailable.
lead_paragraph: The sprawling shutdown that halted commutes for nearly two hours across Metro-North Railroad on Thursday night was traced to a simple disconnected wire — overlooked by technicians who were trying to replace a power supply unit, transportation officials said.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Egypt, Central African Republic and Thailand.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Egypt, Central African Republic and Thailand.

headline: Emery Roth Lived Here
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: An Upper West Side penthouse that the prolific architect designed for himself and his family can be rented for the first time in nearly a decade.
lead_paragraph: Renowned for elegant prewar Manhattan apartment buildings like the Beresford and the San Remo, Emery Roth, the prolific New York City architect, designed many distinctive buildings in the 1920s and ’30s. His body of work is so rich that today an apartment listing in an “Emery Roth-designed building” invokes a certain cachet that is not lost on brokers.

headline: After a Son’s Death, Parents Channel Their Grief Into Activism
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Speed Limits and Speeding']
abstract: Since Sammy Cohen Eckstein, 12, was hit by a van and killed in Brooklyn in October, his parents have become devoted to the cause for safer streets.
lead_paragraph: They had not been like this. They rarely signed petitions or spoke at public hearings. They did not write imploring letters to elected officials, push to see the mayor, go before legislative bodies to speak. They did not do those sorts of things.

headline: Humor, Locked and Loaded
abstract: “American Hustle” and “The Wolf of Wall Street,” two prestige films this awards season, are brutal comedies masquerading as dramas.
lead_paragraph: Is this the year the Academy Awards finally gave comedy some respect?

headline: Evening Hours | Out in the Snow
abstract: The weather didn’t keep partygoers at home.
lead_paragraph: The weather didn’t keep partygoers at home.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Topping Up
abstract: Men on their way to work started out with no hats, no scarves and coats flapping open.
lead_paragraph: Topping Up Many men are stubborn about dressing for the cold and snow. Early last week, men on their way to work started out with no hats, no scarves and coats flapping open. By Friday, you could only see their eyes. One man wore fur trousers, top left. Another wrapped himself in a carpet, while the garment district tailor continued to stitch away. In Bryant Park, a man stood over the open fire pit. For some, a fedora was enough, and a black topcoat set off red kid gloves.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials in Merger Talks With Texas Industries
abstract: A deal for Texas Industries, a construction supplies company with a market value of more than $2 billion, could be announced early next week, people briefed on the matter said.
lead_paragraph: Martin Marietta Materials, a big producer of sand and gravel, is in late-stage talks to acquire Texas Industries, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Fruit Fly Brothers Tend to Cooperate
abstract: Exposing female flies to different sets of males, researchers found the most peaceful groups contained the most brothers.
lead_paragraph: In pursuit of a mate, male fruit flies often engage in combat, battling one another with their front legs.

headline: For Sea Scallops, the Bare Minimum
abstract: Adding chopped garlic and parsley helps keep things simple and flavorful.
lead_paragraph: Sea scallops are one of winter’s divine treats, and one of the best places to enjoy them is Paris. In every fish market there, you see great piles of them on display, still in the shell, ready to be shucked to order.

headline: Submerging Markets
abstract: Currencies in formerly fast-growing emerging markets have been falling sharply this week.
lead_paragraph: Currencies in formerly fast-growing emerging markets have been falling sharply this week. The Argentine peso and the Turkish lira, for example, were each down more than 1 percent against the dollar on Friday afternoon.

headline: That Positive Feeling, and Why It’s Shared
abstract: These fashion brand collections share certain qualities that may help them go viral.
lead_paragraph: AFTER READING Maria Konnikova’s fascinating post in The New Yorker about what makes stories go viral, I wondered if designers were thinking more and more along the lines she described when they create collections.

headline: Flood Ebbs, Insurance Woes Don’t
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Insurance', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Floods', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Disasters and Emergencies']
abstract: The deadline to submit final flood insurance claims is approaching. Some tips to avoid the minefields.
lead_paragraph: The mayor of Hoboken, N.J., isn’t the only one complaining that her Hurricane Sandy relief money has been held hostage.

headline: Architect Goes Home, to Recall and to Work
abstract: The architect Richard Meier has just installed an exhibition in Jersey City with some 400 handmade models of projects he’s designed, while helping to redevelop a section of downtown Newark.
lead_paragraph: Richard Meier is returning to his roots with two new developments in New Jersey, where he grew up.

headline: In Nuns’ Suit, Justices Block Key Mandate in Health Law
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The Supreme Court granted an injunction sought by an order of Roman Catholic nuns who object to the requirement to cover contraception.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday extended a temporary order from Justice Sonia Sotomayor barring the Obama administration from enforcing the contraception coverage requirement of the Affordable Care Act against an order of Roman Catholic nuns.

headline: How Henry Hudson Got His Perch
abstract: A selection of readers’ questions about New York City monuments and the stories behind them.
lead_paragraph: In the Jan. 12 Metropolitan section, Lisa W. Foderaro wrote a guide to some of the more obscure historical markers that dot New York City. We asked readers to post their comments and questions about New York monuments on the City Room blog, and enlisted Jonathan Kuhn, NYC Parks director of art and antiquities, to answer the queries. Here, a selection from the online conversation, edited and condensed.

headline: The Sexual Healer
abstract: Esther Perel has become a go-to speaker on sexuality and relationships in the world of couples therapy as well as in the luxury self-actualization set.
lead_paragraph: On the subject of sex, a subject that makes so many stammer, clam up or crack wise, Esther Perel, a couples therapist and author, is uncommonly eloquent, even rhapsodic. That particular rhetorical gift is apparently in high demand: Last July, Ms. Perel gave an opening talk at Summit Outside, a three-day meeting of 900 entrepreneurs and creative types held on Powder Mountain in Eden, Utah.

headline: A Firebird, a Mermaid and a Bit of Mozart
abstract: The conductor Andrey Boreyko returns to the New York Philharmonic with interesting ideas about repertory.
lead_paragraph: The Russian conductor Andrey Boreyko’s stock is evidently riding high at the New York Philharmonic. Mr. Boreyko, 56, who made his debut with the orchestra in 2007 and has since returned regularly, is about to complete his second consecutive subscription week at Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: Let’s Change the World. Cheers!
abstract: Part religious pilgrimage, part political convention, above all, the World Economic Forum is a glorified four-day-long cocktail party for titans of business and politics.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — Around midnight on Wednesday, Nicolas Berggruen, the billionaire investor, philanthropist and art collector, walked into a loud party in a cozy Swiss chalet co-hosted by Jimmy Wales, a founder of Wikipedia. As dance music blared and colored lights played on the ceiling, Mr. Berggruen greeted Boris Johnson, the mayor of London.

headline: The Hillary Clinton Cover’s Planetary Disruption
abstract: A magazine editor said the idea was actually flattering – at least conceptually.
lead_paragraph: For The Times, the good news is that its magazine cover featuring Hillary Rodham Clinton as a planet is generating all kinds of buzz even before its distribution with Sunday’s paper.

headline: After Hours | An Opera Finds Pathos in the Milli Vanilli Saga
abstract: The multi-room production in Brooklyn uses dance and the music of Richard Wagner to recast the story of the braided lip-syncing duo as a classical tragedy.
lead_paragraph: The deconstructed, multiroom opera “Wow (Work in Progress)” at BRIC Arts in Brooklyn, about the late-’80s rise and fall of Milli Vanilli, isn’t the first to wring classical tragedy from modern-day cultural calamity — the composer Mark-Anthony Turnage did it with pieces about Anna Nicole Smith and Jerry Springer — but it might be the strangest. The creative trio of Joe Diebes, Christian Hawkey and David Levine cast the story of the braided European pop duo, who fell from grace when it was revealed that they’d been lip-syncing all along, as a postmodern tragedy about two handsome naïfs devoured by the pop-culture machine.

headline: Unreleased Miles Davis Performances to Be Released
abstract: “Miles at the Fillmore – Miles Davis 1970: The Bootleg Series, Vol. 3,” a four-CD set, includes unreleased performances by Davis with Chick Corea, Keith Jarrett, Dave Holland, Airto Moreira and Steve Grossman.
lead_paragraph: Two hours of previously unreleased performances by Miles Davis, leading a band that included Chick Corea, Keith Jarrett, Dave Holland, Airto Moreira and Steve Grossman, will be included in “Miles at the Fillmore – Miles Davis 1970: The Bootleg Series, Vol. 3,” a four-CD set to be released by Columbia/Legacy on March 25.

headline: Ales of The Times: Belgian Pale Ales
abstract: The Belgians make a lot of beers that defy categorization. The tasting panel gathered 23 that have one thing in common: they are excellent summer quenchers.
lead_paragraph: The Belgians make a lot of beers that defy categorization. The tasting panel gathered 23 that have one thing in common: they are excellent summer quenchers.

headline: Pastoral Icon or Woolly Menace?
abstract: Sheep. They’re not as harmless as they seem.
lead_paragraph: YOU don’t have to look far to see the woolly influence of sheep on our cultural lives. They turn up as symbols of peace and a vaguely remembered pastoral way of life in our poetry, our art and our Christmas pageants. Wolves also rank high among our cultural icons, usually in connection with the words “big” and “bad.” And yet there is now a debate underway about substituting the wolf for the sheep on the (also iconic) green hills of Britain.

headline: Judge Orders Hospital to Remove Pregnant Woman From Life Support
keywords: ['Life-Sustaining Support Systems, Withdrawal Of', 'ABORTION', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth']
abstract: Doctors had cited a Texas law that prevents them from withdrawing or withholding “life-sustaining treatment” from a pregnant patient.
lead_paragraph: FORT WORTH — A Texas judge ruled Friday that a Fort Worth hospital may not keep a brain-dead pregnant woman on life support against her family’s wishes, and ordered doctors to take her off the machines by 5 p.m. on Monday.

headline: For Banking Group, Australian Open Becomes a Marketing Opportunity in China
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Australian Open (Tennis)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Tennis']
abstract: The Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, known as ANZ, is making big bets to court China, including Chinese-language signage and displays at the Australian Open tournament.
lead_paragraph: An avid tennis fan and amateur player, Katrina Taylor was watching the fourth-seeded Li Na at the Australian Open when she noticed something odd: The courtside signage was in Chinese.

headline: Everyone Wants a Piece of This Wandering Monster
abstract: Aaron Eckhart plays a version of Mary Shelley’s monster in the new film “I, Frankenstein,” also starring Bill Nighy.
lead_paragraph: Mary Shelley’s famous motherless child enters the angels-and-demons world of an apparent franchise bid in “I, Frankenstein.” Stuart Beattie’s solemn, ho-hum film largely shuns Shelley’s anguished creator as a character and turns his lonely monster into a football between the forces of good and evil: protective gargoyles and demons who covet his secret to immortality.

headline: Quietly Ascending Rock’s Peaks
abstract: In recent New York City concerts, Bastille and St. Lucia trod different, if equally familiar, musical routes on their way up.
lead_paragraph: How things become popular is never less than a mystery, and in the age of the post-genre ecosystem, of the YouTube sensation, what becomes popular isn’t nearly as legible as it once was. What was once fringe is now mainstream, what was mainstream is now fringe.

headline: Collector Auctions Suggest Recovery Is Nearly Complete
abstract: While no single sale overwhelmed car collectors at the Scottsdale, Ariz., auctions, there was a respectable gain in sales, which were up some 10 percent from 2013.
lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, ARIZ. — The classic-car auctions here last week were remarkable for not being especially remarkable: No bubbles burst, and neither did the market make another vertical leap.

headline: ‘Needs Some T.L.C.’ Proves a Powerful Boost to Prices
abstract: The sales results from the major collector-car auctions in Arizona included record prices and indications that the market’s recovery was nearly complete.
lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, ARIZ. — The sales results from the major collector-car auctions that wrapped up here last week included a long list of record prices and strong indications that the recovery of a market battered by the recession was nearly complete.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Max Roach, the great drummer and bandleader and paradigm-shifter of jazz, though he disliked that word, never finished an autobiography.

headline: Museums Follow the Call of a Clooney Movie
abstract: Both the Smithsonian Institution and the National WWII Museum in New Orleans announced new ventures to coincide with the Feb. 7 release of “The Monuments Men.”
lead_paragraph: There’s nothing like the advent of a George Clooney movie to put historical institutions on a war footing. Timed to coincide with the Feb. 7 release of “The Monuments Men,” about the heroics of the soldiers and scholars who chased after European cultural treasures plundered by the Nazis, both the Smithsonian Institution and the National WWII Museum in New Orleans announced new ventures. The New Orleans museum said it would open a permanent gallery about the unit in 2016. It will show, among other things, how the soldiers descended into an Austrian salt mine to recover masterpieces hoarded there by Germans. The exhibition will highlight the recovery of works by Rembrandt, Vermeer, Picasso and Leonardo da Vinci and the continuing search for works like Raphael’s “Portrait of a Young Man” and Michelangelo’s marble “Mask of a Faun.” Meanwhile in Washington on Feb. 7, the Smithsonian Institution’s Archives of American Art will open an exhibition called “Monuments Men: On the Frontline to Save Europe’s Art, 1942-1946.” It will showcase the work of the scholars in the original unit, one of whom is played by Mr. Clooney.

lead_paragraph: The very title of this blog suggests the continual shifting of ground underneath all of us of a certain age. Whatever we thought old age meant yesterday, it means something different today.

headline: On the Horizon: Berlin International Film Festival; ‘This Is Not a Silent Movie’
abstract: A weekly capsule of travel news curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Film On Feb. 6, the 64th Berlin International Film Festival, or Berlinale, will begin . The film festival will award lifetime honors to the British director Ken Loach and feature over 400 films, including the world premiere of “The Monuments Men,” about an Allied group who recovered stolen artworks from the Nazis, with George Clooney and Matt Damon.

headline: Sympathy for the Toffs
keywords: ['Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: Loving ‘Downton Abbey’ in the new Gilded Age.
lead_paragraph: Last year, we turned on the plutocrats. Everyone from Pope Francis to Bill de Blasio denounced them. Even Bill and Hillary Clinton, erstwhile champions of pro-business centrism and donor sleepovers at the White House, decided it was prudent to jump on the populist bandwagon. So why are we still smitten with the toffs of “Downton Abbey”?

headline: The Collections | The Top 10 Items from Fall/Winter 2014 Men’s Trade Shows
abstract: These must-have pieces were introduced at the MAN, Capsule and Project shows in New York earlier this week.
lead_paragraph: The polar vortex’s return this week was a nuisance to most New Yorkers, but it provided optimal conditions for appreciating the Fall/Winter 2014 wares on offer at the men’s clothing and lifestyle trade shows MAN, Capsule and Project. Among the heritage and camping-supply items that usually abound at these events, a few new lines stood out. Below are the 10 best pieces — some basic, some inclement-weather specific, but all refreshingly new.

headline: Google Pushes Back Against Data Localization
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Data Storage', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Though Microsoft allows customers to choose to store their data outside the United States, Google has warned against data localization and said it would be nearly impossible to carry out.
lead_paragraph: The big tech companies have put forth a united front when it comes to pushing back against the government after revelations of mass surveillance. But their cooperation goes only so far.

headline: Letter to Obama From American Detained in Egypt
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: The complete text of a letter to President Obama from an American citizen who has been detained in Egypt since August.
lead_paragraph: Mohamed Soltan, an American citizen whose Egyptian father belongs to the Muslim Brotherhood, was detained in Cairo in August, as our colleague David Kirkpatrick reported last year.

headline: Distrust in America, War in Syria and Protests in Ukraine
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: On contractors and our secrets, Syrian peace talks and the standoff in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: In a speech on Jan. 17, President Obama spoke of the challenge of a world “that is remaking itself at a dizzying speed.” The subject of his address at the Justice Department was the complex issues of security, privacy and the limits of government power raised by revelations about the National Security Agency’s spying. That debate continued to rage through the last week. But Mr. Obama could have been speaking as well about conflicts in places like Syria and Ukraine, which seemed to become more intractable with every effort at resolution.

headline: Video of Deadly Bombing in Cairo
abstract: A closed-circuit television camera captured video of the largest of four bombings in Cairo, killing four and injuring 70 outside the city’s police headquarters, and the bombers responsible for it.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reported, at least six people were killed and 70 injured in a string of four bombings that targeted police installations across Cairo on Friday. A closed-circuit television camera captured video of the largest blast, a car bomb, which exploded outside the city’s main police headquarters, killing four and badly damaging a museum and library. The bombers responsible for the attack were also briefly captured on video.

headline: Natural Gas Prices Soar as Mercury Plummets
abstract: Prices spiked by nearly 10 percent on Friday to the highest levels since 2010, as continuing frigid weather drove demand for heating and electricity.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Natural gas prices spiked by nearly 10 percent on Friday to levels not seen since 2010 as another wave of freezing weather brought surges of heating and electricity demand.

lead_paragraph: Last week, before a senator released letters that sent the shares of Herbalife into a tailspin, certain investors were positioning themselves to make money if the stock fell.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner will seek to emerge from a three-day House Republican retreat next week with a diminished opposition inside his party to avoid a showdown in the 11 legislative days that remain before the federal government exhausts its borrowing authority.

lead_paragraph: Garry Kasparov, a former chess world champion who is running for president of the World Chess Federation, released previously confidential agreements Friday involving himself and one of the officials who is part of his slate of candidates to lead the organization.

headline: Writer Tells Africa What He Couldn’t Tell ‘Mum’
abstract: The Kenyan author Binyavanga Wainaina’s decision to come out as gay had added to the fierce debate over homosexuality in sub-Saharan Africa.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — WHEN the Kenyan author Binyavanga Wainaina published his acclaimed memoir three years ago, he concealed an important part of his life from the public eye. Last Saturday, he unveiled “a lost chapter” of the book on the Internet titled, “I am a homosexual, mum.”

abstract: White House officials said the reopening of the Office of Political Affairs will help the administration better respond to requests from lawmakers during the forthcoming midterm battles.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama has decided to bring politics back into the White House.

headline: The Elders of Organic Farming
abstract: For nearly a week, two dozen pioneers of sustainable agriculture from the United States and Canada shared decades’ worth of stories, secrets and anxieties.
lead_paragraph: BIG SUR, Calif. — Among the sleek guests who meditate and do Downward Facing Dog here at the Esalen Institute, the farmers appeared to be out of place. They wore baggy jeans, suspenders and work boots and had long ago let their hair go gray.

headline: New Commissioner Has Ties to ‘Sherlock,’ via Barbados
abstract: Stacey Cumberbatch, appointed as New York’s commissioner of citywide administrative services, shares some history with the British actor Benedict Cumberbatch.
lead_paragraph: Stacey Cumberbatch, New York’s new commissioner of citywide administrative services, is great at untangling bureaucratic knots and a proud granddaughter of Caribbean immigrants, Mayor Bill de Blasio said in naming her to the job on Friday.

headline: Northwestern Coach Returns to His Roots
abstract: Chris Collins grew up in the Chicago area while his father was coaching the Bulls. After spending 13 years as an assistant at Duke, Collins is now tasked with leading a program that has never reached the N.C.A.A. tournament.
lead_paragraph: EVANSTON, Ill. — On the morning after he earned his first Big Ten Conference win last week, Northwestern Coach Chris Collins sat in his office, a sparsely decorated room that overlooks a practice court inside Welsh-Ryan Arena.

headline: South Sudanese Rebels Accuse Government of Ignoring Day-Old Cease-Fire
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: A government spokesman denies the claims that opposition positions were attacked, while analysts say that enforcing the cease-fire will prove more difficult than signing it.
lead_paragraph: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — South Sudanese rebels said that government forces had attacked several of their positions on Friday, a day after a cease-fire was signed that was supposed to bring an end to a monthlong conflict that shook the new country and displaced hundreds of thousands of its citizens.
