keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Children and Childhood', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The National Security Agency uses cartoon characters to try to teach young people about its work, and to encourage them to someday join the agency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The turtle wearing a hat backward, baggy jeans and purple sunglasses looks just like other cartoon characters that marketers use to make products like cereal and toys appealing to children.

headline: Do Not Adjust Your Set: Super Bowl Snow May Be Real
abstract: The Super Bowl is during the New York area’s coldest time of year, so meteorologists said the possibility of frigid temperatures and snow should come as no surprise.
lead_paragraph: For months, N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell has urged football fans to “embrace the cold” and has all but dared the weather gods to make it snow on Super Bowl Sunday.

headline: Iran’s Message at Davos Has Eerie Echo
abstract: President Hassan Rouhani’s speech this week, professing peaceful intentions and a desire for dialogue, invited comparisons to Mohammad Khatami’s attempt at change 10 years ago.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Hassan Rouhani of Iran commandeered the spotlight this week in Davos, Switzerland, with a message of peaceful intentions and a desire for dialogue, it was an eerie echo of 10 years ago, when Iran’s last would-be change agent, Mohammad Khatami, delivered the very same message at the World Economic Forum.

headline: Ex-Governor of Virginia and Wife Plead Not Guilty to Corruption
abstract: Former Gov. Bob McDonnell and his wife, Maureen, pleaded not guilty in federal court to corruption charges that could send them to prison for more than 20 years if they are convicted.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — Former Gov. Bob McDonnell of Virginia and his wife, Maureen, emerged hand in hand from federal court after pleading not guilty on Friday to corruption charges that could send them to prison for more than 20 years if they are convicted.

headline: When ‘Long-Form’ Is Bad Form
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Magazines', 'Computers and the Internet', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Too often, the writer is the hero of his own story.
lead_paragraph: LAST week, the sports and pop culture website Grantland published a story called “Dr. V’s Magical Putter” — a piece of “long-form,” as we now call multi-thousand-word, narrative-driven reported articles — about a woman named Essay Anne Vanderbilt, who claimed to have invented a golf putter of unsurpassed excellence.

headline: F.B.I. Audit of Database That Indexes DNA Finds Errors in Profiles
abstract: Nearly 170 criminal cases had genetic results that were wrong, some the result of handwriting mistakes or interpretation errors by lab technicians.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Bureau of Investigation, in a review of a national DNA database, has identified nearly 170 profiles that probably contain errors, some the result of handwriting mistakes or interpretation errors by lab technicians, while New York State authorities have turned up mistakes in DNA profiles in New York’s database.

headline: Kerry Presses Iranians to Prove Nuclear Work Is for Peaceful Purposes
abstract: John Kerry told the World Economic Forum that Iran must accept extensive verification of its nuclear program, abandon plans for a plutonium-producing reactor, and resolve inspectors’ concerns about past compliance.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — One day after Iran’s president took the stage here seeking to assure the world that his country did not aspire to develop nuclear weapons, Secretary of State John Kerry pushed back on Friday, challenging him to demonstrate that the Iranian nuclear program was peaceful.

headline: Greek Orthodox Rally Support for Troubled Home
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Greek-Americans', 'Greek Orthodox Church', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Philanthropy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: With their country facing a continuing financial crisis, Greeks living in America are offering financial help by way of the church, long a superhighway connecting Greece and its diaspora.
lead_paragraph: Dosed up on Tylenol and Advil after three days in bed with the flu, Valerie Markou paced the terrazzo floor of a catering hall in Queens. She carried a gold paper shopping bag, selling the raffle tickets it contained and tucking away the $20 bills she received in return.

headline: Michigan: University Names New President
abstract: The University of Michigan regents named the university’s next president, Mark S. Schlissel, the provost of Brown University and a former dean of biological sciences at the University of California, Berkeley.
lead_paragraph: The University of Michigan regents on Friday named the university’s next president, Mark S. Schlissel, the provost of Brown University and a former dean of biological sciences at the University of California, Berkeley. Dr. Schlissel, 56, a biomedical researcher specializing in immunology, will take over one of the nation’s largest and most prestigious universities, which ranks second in research spending, behind only Johns Hopkins University. He will succeed Mary Sue Coleman, who is retiring after 12 years as president, on July 1. Dr. Schlissel graduated from Princeton and earned M.D. and Ph.D. degrees at Johns Hopkins.

headline: Huckabee Spills the Beans
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The former Republican presidential candidate is back to talking his way into a controversy. Well, now we know what he’s been up to lately.
lead_paragraph: It’s not often we think about Mike Huckabee. True, he has a talk show. But so does half the world. Kelly Ripa has a talk show. Geraldo Rivera has a talk show. How often do they come up in conversation?

headline: Star Envoy’s Frankness Puts Kennedy Mystique to Test in Japan
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Dolphins and Porpoises', 'Hunting and Trapping', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare']
abstract: Japan swooned when Caroline Kennedy arrived as the United States’ ambassador, but she has surprised her hosts with her frankness on delicate issues, including a controversial dolphin hunt.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan went into a collective swoon two months ago when Caroline Kennedy arrived as the United States’ ambassador. The appointment of someone with such celebrity appeal — who offered a living link to a golden age when America was still reassuringly strong and confident — appeared to be proof that Washington was finally giving Japan the embrace it craved.

headline: Arizona: Challenge to Housing for the Deaf Is Dropped
abstract: The federal Department of Housing and Urban Development ended a two-year legal dispute on Friday with the state and a private developer of subsidized housing, which it had accused of discrimination for favoring the deaf and the hard-of-hearing over others seeking to live in a 75-unit complex for the elderly built to fit the needs of the deaf.
lead_paragraph: The federal Department of Housing and Urban Development ended a two-year legal dispute on Friday with the state and a private developer of subsidized housing, which it had accused of discrimination for favoring the deaf and the hard-of-hearing over others seeking to live in a 75-unit complex for the elderly built to fit the needs of the deaf. In a letter, HUD officials said that the type of federal funding used to build the complex, Apache ASL Trails, in Tempe, did not prevent it from giving preference to a specific group of disabled individuals. The agency closed its investigation and removed its legal challenges against the development, which was designed by a deaf architect and offers video phones and lights that flash when the phone or doorbell rings at each unit, among other features.

headline: Kiev Cease-Fire Ends
abstract: David Herszenhorn reports from Kiev, Ukraine, where fighting has resumed between antigovernment protestors and the riot police, not far from the Dynamo soccer stadium.
lead_paragraph: David Herszenhorn reports from Kiev, Ukraine, where fighting has resumed between antigovernment protestors and the riot police, not far from the Dynamo soccer stadium.

headline: The Song Remains the Same (and Kind of Blue)
abstract: In this new Sun Kil Moon song, you’ll hear the melancholy I’ve carried around with me since I was young.
lead_paragraph: If you grew up in the 1970s and you loved ’70s rock as much as I did, then there is a good chance you saw the Led Zeppelin concert film, “The Song Remains the Same.” The film documents a 1973 Zeppelin concert at Madison Square Garden and played in theaters throughout the late ’70s and after. It became an almost instant cult classic, bringing my favorite rock band ever to life, with only a trip to the local theater.

headline: Iran’s Charm Offensive
abstract: After reaching a nuclear deal, President Hassan Rouhani now needs to help stop the catastrophic civil war in Syria.
lead_paragraph: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran made his debut this week at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, where he expanded on his government’s charm offensive by wooing investors and reassuring political leaders of his determination to complete a comprehensive nuclear deal with the major powers. But his benign image and deft political skills could not erase or excuse the ugly fact that Iran remains the main ally of Syria’s president, Bashar al-Assad, in the destruction of Syria and its people.

headline: Dividing the Bank Settlement
abstract: In New York, all the money from mortgage deals should go to help homeowners.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has deservedly lost Round 1 of the unnecessary fight he picked recently with the New York State attorney general, Eric Schneiderman, over the distribution of proceeds from a bank settlement. To persist in his pique could hurt all New Yorkers.

headline: A Hidden Threat in the Farm Bill
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Farm Bill (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials', 'States (US)']
abstract: Representative Steve King’s broadly written amendment would jeopardize states’ powers to enact their own agricultural standards.
lead_paragraph: The mammoth farm bill is reportedly near a conference compromise in Congress, bristling with more tragic cuts in the food stamp program for the needy and a revision of lucrative commodity subsidies for mostly big farmers. Running below the radar is a dangerous, broadly written amendment that would threaten states’ current powers to enact their own agricultural standards — standards that can extend far beyond farmyards to consumer, worker and environmental safety.

headline: Carmelo Anthony Scores 62 Points, Setting a Knicks Record
abstract: Anthony, saying he was “locked in,” had the N.B.A.’s highest single-game total since 2007, leading the Knicks to a rout at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: Carmelo Anthony did not need to scream, dance, pump his fists or point skyward after his 45-foot heave at the halftime buzzer went through the net at Madison Square Garden on Friday. His expression — eyes staring ahead, lips slightly puckered, nostrils flaring — said enough about his emotions on this night.

headline: Zero Traffic Fatalities
keywords: ['Roads and Traffic', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'State Legislatures', 'Speed Limits and Speeding', 'Law and Legislation', 'Editorials', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Mayor de Blasio has a plan to reduce the number of traffic deaths in New York City, but he will have to go through Albany first.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio wants to bring the number of traffic deaths in New York City from just short of 300 a year to zero, or close to zero, in 10 years. That’s a laudable and ambitious goal, and he’s willing to change lots of things to get there: lower speed limits, more rigorous enforcement of existing laws, better street engineering to slow traffic.

headline: Spread the Happy
abstract: The return of James Mulhern.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Alert! If you thought the Kevin G. Der puzzle that ran on the web on January 17 and in print on January 24 was just any old themeless puzzle, guess again. Mr. Der’s puzzle was part of a much larger puzzle in the M.I.T. Mystery Hunt, and the idea behind it was quite elegant. You can read about his nefarious plans here.

headline: Gaza Man Shot to Death in Border Clash With Israeli Military, Palestinians Say
abstract: It was the latest in a series of violent exchanges that have frayed a fragile 14-month-old cease-fire between Israel and Hamas.
lead_paragraph: GAZA — Palestinian officials said that the Israeli military killed a 20-year-old Gaza man and wounded six others near the border fence on Friday evening, the latest in a series of violent exchanges that have frayed a fragile 14-month-old cease-fire between Israel and Hamas, the militant Islamic faction that rules the Gaza Strip.

headline: A Mob Life, on the Margins and Out of Favor
abstract: Vincent Asaro, who was arrested on Thursday in connection with the Lufthansa heist in 1978, has a messy history in organized crime.
lead_paragraph: You think you’ve got problems?

headline: Olympic Fears Rattle Athletes and Families
abstract: With the Sochi Olympics only weeks away, American athletes and their families are increasingly concerned about the security preparations in Russia.
lead_paragraph: Athletes and their families are becoming increasingly anxious about possible terrorist attacks at the Winter Olympics in Sochi, so much so that some families have decided not to attend and others plan to curtail their activities once they get to the Games in Russia.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, January 25, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, January 25, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “The timing is a message that the third anniversary of the revolution will not be a celebration; they want to color it with blood.”

headline: The Penance of Glenn Beck
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: The former Fox News host made a meaningful confession, but the damage remains.
lead_paragraph: This week Glenn Beck said something I agree with. (Now, there’s a line I never thought I’d write.) During an interview on Tuesday with Megyn Kelly of Fox News, Beck reflected on his time at Fox this way:

headline: Welcome or Not, 4,000 Football Fans Will Be Afloat at a Hudson River Pier
abstract: For five days next week a Norwegian Cruise ship will dock on the West Side of Manhattan to serve as a hotel for 4,000 Super Bowl fans.
lead_paragraph: For five days next week — before, during and after Super Bowl XLVIII — the roster of hotels in New York will grow by one. The city’s newest hotel will have almost as many rooms for guests as the New York Hilton or the Marriott Marquis, two of the largest hotels in the city.

headline: For the Mentally Ill, It’s Worse
abstract: Taking stock 30 years after the powerful story of a severe schizophrenic was told.
lead_paragraph: Last week, one of the landmark nonfiction books of the last 50 years was reissued by Vintage Books. “Is There No Place on Earth for Me?” by Susan Sheehan began in 1981 as a four-part series in The New Yorker; in 1982, it came out as a book, winning the Pulitzer Prize.

headline: U.S. Catholics Hope for 2015 Papal Visit
abstract: A spokesman for the archdiocese of Philadelphia said he expects Pope Francis to attend an event there in September 2015, although the Vatican has not given official word.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis may make his first trip as pope to the United States in September 2015 to attend the Roman Catholic Church’s World Meeting of Families in Philadelphia. Popes traditionally attend these events, which have been held every three years since 1994. “We are planning as if Pope Francis will be with us and have no indication that he will not attend,” said Kenneth A. Gavin, a spokesman for the archdiocese of Philadelphia. But he added that any reports that Francis would make the trip “are not official.” There is speculation that Francis would stop in New York on that same trip to speak to the United Nations General Assembly, but Joseph Zwilling, a spokesman for the archdiocese of New York, said the archdiocese had not heard anything from the Vatican. The last papal visit to the United States was in April 2008, when Pope Benedict XVI traveled to Washington and New York.

headline: Corrections: January 25, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on January 25, 2014.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: N.H.L. Expanding Outdoor Boundaries With Game at Dodger Stadium
abstract: The Ducks-Kings matchup Saturday will be the southernmost and westernmost outdoor N.H.L. game played in the United States.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the N.H.L.’s latest outdoor affair, there will be few tuques on heads and plenty of sweaters tied around waists when the Los Angeles Kings and the Anaheim Ducks square off at Dodger Stadium on Saturday night.

headline: At Yankee Stadium, Rangers Will Share Glamour With Rivals
abstract: The Devils and the Islanders have never played outdoors, and they rarely draw national attention. That will change when they face off against the Rangers at the Stadium.
lead_paragraph: A giant New York City subway map adorns the outfield grass. A children’s hockey rink bounded by blocks of ice covers the home-plate area. Large crests of the Rangers and Devils rest atop the two dugouts. Stretching between first base and third is the rink itself, glinting bright under a cold winter sun.

headline: In the Absence of Their Owner, the Nets Hang On
abstract: Mark Cuban, the Mavericks’ owner, was at Barclays Center. Mikhail D. Prokhorov, the Nets’ owner, wasn’t. It didn’t seem to matter as the Nets improved their January record to 9-1.
lead_paragraph: Early Friday night, Mark Cuban, the outspoken and seemingly omnipresent owner of the Dallas Mavericks, directed some thinly veiled criticisms toward Mikhail D. Prokhorov, his Nets counterpart, saying he could not imagine how anyone could manage a team from thousands of miles away.

headline: Simmering Tension on a Corner, and Then a Fire
abstract: The owner of a bus company in Gowanus, Brooklyn, who clashed with neighbors, is accused of hiring a man to burn down a potter’s studio.
lead_paragraph: The potter opened the door of her studio in Gowanus, Brooklyn, one morning eight months ago, as she had for decades, but this time she stopped short. Something was wrong — black smudges marked her wooden floor, and a thick stench hung in the big room.

headline: Rangers on Road in the Bronx? Money May Be Why
abstract: A 1982 state law that let Madison Square Garden off the hook in paying property taxes came with a caveat: Both the Rangers and the Knicks could never be the home team when playing away from it, or the exemption ended.
lead_paragraph: An unusual aspect of the N.H.L.’s two outdoor games at Yankee Stadium is that the Rangers have been designated the road team for both games, even though their opponents, the Devils and the Islanders, come from outside New York City.

headline: Golf Trade Show Bounces Back With the Economy
abstract: After 2001, many exhibitors at the P.G.A. Merchandise Show scaled back, but the event, seen as a barometer of golf’s health, has shown renewed energy.
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — When six salesmen arrived for the 1954 P.G.A. Senior Championship in Dunedin, Fla., they lined up their products around a practice green for the pros to see. They had no idea that what they were doing would someday become the world’s largest annual golf trade show.

headline: A Fit of Jealousy, a Lack of Child Car Seats, and Then Three Deadly Stabbings
abstract: Miguel Mejia-Ramos said he had attacked his wife and, not having car seats, stabbed his daughters rather than flee with them, according to court papers.
lead_paragraph: After killing his wife in a jealous rage, officials said, Miguel Mejia-Ramos went over to his two young daughters, still lying in their beds at the family’s home in Queens. His intention, he would tell detectives, was to spare the children.

headline: The Mets Sign Matsuzaka to a Minor League Deal
abstract: The Mets will bring the Japanese right-hander Daisuke Matsuzaka to training camp, where he will compete for the fifth spot in the starting rotation.
lead_paragraph: Two days after the Yankees snared Masahiro Tanaka with a seven-year, $155 million contract, the Mets announced Friday that they, too, had signed a Japanese right-hander, but for a lot less money.

headline: Breaking It Down: Nadal vs. Federer
abstract: In a semifinal victory at the Australian Open, Rafael Nadal attacked Roger Federer’s backhand and extracted errors from Federer’s forehand.
lead_paragraph: Rafael Nadal would make an excellent stone cutter. He is incredibly gifted at first finding a crack and then unceasingly hammering away at it until he finally breaks the stone in victory.

headline: Bicyclist Killed by a Bus Rose Above Usual Anonymity of Deliverymen in the City
keywords: ['Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Delivery Services']
abstract: Pedro Santiago was known as a gregarious deliveryman who befriended customers, helped his family in Mexico and dreamed of becoming an engineer.
lead_paragraph: In life, he was another anonymous bicycle deliveryman who traveled the streets of New York City. To many pedestrians he was no more than a nuisance, and to his customers, never fast enough.

headline: U.S. Cites Evidence of Anti-Semitism in School District
abstract: A United States attorney’s office said evidence in a lawsuit filed by Jewish families “could support a conclusion” that authorities in Pine Bush, N.Y., were ineffective in ending harassment.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities say evidence collected in a lawsuit filed by three Jewish families against an upstate New York school district “is sufficient for a jury to find that the district failed to respond to pervasive anti-Semitic harassment in its schools” by taking required action under a civil rights law.

headline: South Bronx Students May Have Found Site of Slave Burial Ground
abstract: Using census data, maps, photographs and wills, elementary school pupils and teachers singled out a site in what is now Joseph Rodman Drake Park.
lead_paragraph: In a snow-covered park in the Hunts Point section of the South Bronx, an enclosed cemetery in the park’s center evokes a much different neighborhood from the one now jammed with auto-glass shops and wholesale produce markets. Headstones engraved with “Hunt” and “Leggett” hark back to the 18th and 19th centuries, when prominent New York families had mansions in the still-rural Bronx.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 24, 2014
abstract: Winning combinations for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
abstract: An unexpected loss at Deutsche Bank, new safety guidelines for transporting crude oil by rail and states cutting extended unemployment benefits.
lead_paragraph: An unexpected loss at Deutsche Bank, new safety guidelines for transporting crude oil by rail and states cutting extended unemployment benefits.

headline: Ed Hookstratten, Forceful Advocate for the Stars, Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Hookstratten was an unapologetically aggressive lawyer and agent for entertainers and sports figures including Elvis Presley, Johnny Carson, Tom Brokaw and the football coach George Allen.
lead_paragraph: Ed Hookstratten, an unapologetically aggressive lawyer and agent for entertainers and sports figures including Elvis Presley, Johnny Carson, Tom Brokaw and the football coach George Allen, died on Tuesday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 83.

headline: Sarah Marshall, Actress in ‘Twilight Zone’ and ‘Star Trek’, Dies at 80
abstract: Ms. Marshall also appeared in films like “The Long, Hot Summer” and was nominated for a Tony for “Goodbye, Charlie.”
lead_paragraph: Sarah Marshall, an actress who was born into show business and worked on Broadway, in film and on television, perhaps most memorably in episodes of “The Twilight Zone” and “Star Trek,” died on Jan. 18 at her home in Los Angeles. She was 80.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7 P.M. (Starz) THIS IS THE END (2013) A group of funny guys — among them, from left above, James Franco, Jonah Hill, Craig Robinson, Seth Rogen, Jay Baruchel and Danny McBride, each playing himself — gather at a party at Mr. Franco’s house in Los Angeles, during which events foretold in the Book of Revelation occur. The righteous are raptured up to heaven; the rest, including many of the most famous people in Hollywood, are swallowed into fiery pits or pursued by horned demons. The movie, written and directed by Mr. Rogen and Evan Goldberg, “at its phoned-in worst and also at its riotous best, has a terminal feeling,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “It suggests that a comic subgenre based on the immaturity, sexual panic and self-mocking tendencies of men who should be old enough to know better has reached its expiration date.” But, “as crude as the movie’s humor often is, its spirit is sweet, sensitive and innocuous. In their script for ‘Superbad,’ Mr. Rogen and Mr. Goldberg zeroed in on the tenderness and vulnerability that lie at the heart of male friendship, and here they go even further, using the prospect of global annihilation as an occasion for some touchy-feely relationship workshopping.”

headline: A Scene to Warm a Penguin’s Heart
abstract: The high temperature of 23 degrees in New York City on Friday left no chance that the ice floes in the Hudson River would melt.

headline: Wawrinka Savors Advance to Australian Open Final
abstract: After beating Novak Djokovic in the semifinals, Stanislas Wawrinka kicked back and visited a James Bond exhibit at a local museum.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — On Friday, the day after Stanislas Wawrinka advanced to his first-ever Grand Slam final, he visited a museum here. He sought out one exhibit: Designing 007, Fifty Years of Bond Style.

headline: Clashes Kill 49 Egyptians on Uprising’s Anniversary
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: At least 49 people died in clashes with security forces at rival antigovernment protests organized by Islamists and left-leaning activists.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Thousands of Egyptians celebrated the third anniversary of their revolt against autocracy on Saturday by holding a rally for the military leader who ousted the country’s first democratically elected president. Elsewhere, at least 49 people died in clashes with security forces at rival antigovernment protests organized by Islamists and left-leaning activists.

headline: Li Wins Australian Title in Battle of Baseline, Then Serves Up Punch Lines
abstract: The Chinese tennis star returned to the final to claim her second Grand Slam title with a commanding 7-6 (3), 6-0 victory over 20th-seeded Dominika Cibulkova.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — In the immediate aftermath of most Grand Slam championships, the winners spout the usual clichés, shed a few tears and thank everyone they ever met and some people they do not know. There must be a manual for such occasions: thank, cry, cliché, repeat.

headline: China Accuses Uighur Intellectual of Separatism for His Advocacy Work
abstract: A statement from security officials in the Xinjiang region accused Ilham Tohti, an economics professor who advocates on behalf of Uighurs, of separatism and inciting ethnic hatred.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In an ominous sign of the fate awaiting one of China’s best-known Uighur intellectuals, security officials in the far western region of Xinjiang issued a statement on Saturday that accused him of separatism and inciting ethnic hatred.

headline: Valley of the Blahs: How Justin Bieber’s Troubles Exposed Twitter’s Achilles’ Heel
abstract: Twitter seems to have reached a turning point, a phase in which its contributors have stopped trying to make the service as useful as possible for the crowd, and are instead trying to distinguish themselves from one another.
lead_paragraph: At some point, Twitter and the rest of social media became less about wanting to share the news and more about wanting to be the news.

headline: Lonnie Holley, in His Alabama Yard-Art Element
abstract: A video by George King, who has been filming Lonnie Holley for 18 years.
lead_paragraph: For 18 years, the Atlanta-based documentary filmmaker George King has been shooting Lonnie Holley, an artist and musician that I write about in this weekend’s magazine. King has mined the footage to make a video for “Looking for All (All Rendered Truth),” a song from Holley’s 2012 debut album, “Just Before Music.” If, like me, you’ve met Holley only recently, the footage is fascinating to watch, offering glimpses of the artist as a young man: showing off his intricate sandstone sculptures or wandering amid the scavenged materials — a baby doll, a “Dead End” sign, a lawn jockey, a wrecked car, a child’s dress — in his Alabama yard-art environment. (There are also shots of a bulldozer tearing the place down, after it was condemned by the airport authority.)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Joe on WNYC’s “Money Talking”: January 24, 2014
abstract: This week, Joe talks Bitcoin.
lead_paragraph: Digital currency is inching its way onto Wall Street, with a new “Bitcoin center” next door to the New York Stock Exchange. As the currency gains prominence and popularity, regulators—like New York’s Department of Financial Services, which is holding hearings next week—are trying to work out where they figure in. Joe talks about the future of Bitcoin, while Rana Foroohar of Time magazine reports from the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

headline: Variety: A Surprising Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon spin a brand new puzzle for us.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — My goodness, what a surprising quote. The next time I go to buy a silk blouse, I’ll have to remember to check to see if it smells like goat.

headline: Syria’s Shaky Peace Talks Move Toward Solid Ground in Effort to Aid Homs
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'International Relations', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: The Syrian government and opposition met face to face in Geneva for the first time to try to win government approval for an aid convoy to parts of Homs.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The Syrian government and opposition moved their fragile peace talks to a newly concrete phase on Saturday, meeting face to face here for the first time in an attempt to win government approval for an aid convoy to neighborhoods in the city of Homs long blockaded by the army.

headline: In a Transition Game, David Stern Is Passing the N.B.A. Commissioner’s Hat to Adam Silver
abstract: After 30 years on the job, Stern is retiring as N.B.A. commissioner on Saturday, and he will be succeeded by Silver.
lead_paragraph: David Stern stepped into a conference room through a side door from his office. He carried a can of soda and a small plate of tortilla chips.

headline: Doctors Abusing Medicare Face Fines and Expulsion
abstract: The Obama administration is cracking down on doctors who repeatedly overcharge Medicare patients; the government may even disclose how much individual physicians are paid for treating Medicare patients.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is cracking down on doctors who repeatedly overcharge Medicare patients, and for the first time in more than 30 years the government may disclose how much is paid to individual doctors treating Medicare patients.

headline: A Different Game, but the Knicks’ Present Resembles Its Past
abstract: This season’s Knicks resemble their 1984-85 counterparts in their reliance on one player for the bulk of their offense.
lead_paragraph: On Christmas night 1984, Bernard King set a Knicks record by scoring 60 points against the New Jersey Nets at Madison Square Garden. The N.B.A. game then was quite different from the one Carmelo Anthony toyed with while breaking King’s mark with 62 points in Friday night’s victory against Charlotte.

headline: Three Dead in Shooting at Maryland Mall; Police Call the Episode Isolated
abstract: Three people were killed in a shooting at The Mall in Columbia in suburban Maryland, and the police said they believe that the suspect died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound, and had acted alone.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, Md. — Shots rang out at a popular shopping mall in this suburb between Washington and Baltimore on Saturday morning, sending shoppers running from stores and hiding under tables in the food court.

headline: The Tale of a House, and an Entire Market
abstract: The history of 12204 Backus Drive in Bowie, Md., is in many ways the history of the American housing market over the last two decades.
lead_paragraph: In 1990, almost a million houses were built in the United States. One of them, at 12204 Backus Drive in Bowie, Md., was a four-bedroom colonial with a bay window. The average home price that year was $150,000; this house, in a desirable middle-class suburb of Washington, sold for $227,140.

headline: In Six Houses, a Market Mirror
abstract: All over the country, house prices are rising. But in some regions, prices are recovering from much deeper troughs. Below are six houses that were sold several times in the last few years, reflecting the overall market trends in their metropolitan areas.
lead_paragraph: All over the country, house prices are rising. But in some regions, prices are recovering from much deeper troughs. Below are six houses that were sold several times in the last few years, reflecting the overall market trends in their metropolitan areas.

headline: The Chatter for Sunday, Jan. 26
abstract: Notable quotes from business articles that appeared in The New York Times last week.
lead_paragraph: “For a nine-month-old company to buy a 93-year-old one is a lot to bite off.”

headline: The Insufferable Colleague
abstract: A reader asks the Workologist what to do when one co-worker makes life absolutely miserable.
lead_paragraph: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

headline: I’ll Be Your Billboard
abstract: Jason Sadler appears on social media, wearing corporate T-shirts for a fee.

headline: A Super Bowl Estimate With a Life of Its Own
abstract: Many say that the 2014 Super Bowl will have grand economic benefits for New York and New Jersey, even if they can’t define what those benefits are.
lead_paragraph: The Super Bowl will be just great for New York and New Jersey! That’s what the National Football League and local tourism officials and politicians say, anyway.

headline: Noreen Beaman of Brinker Capital, on Accountability
abstract: “Sometimes you’ll make a mistake,” a chief executive says. “Life happens. But let’s not do it again. One of our mantras is ‘Find it, fix it, prevent it.’”
lead_paragraph: This interview with  Noreen D. Beaman, chief executive of Brinker Capital, based in Berwyn, Pa., was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Seahawks’ Richard Sherman Is Much More Than Just Talk
abstract: Sherman, the Seahawks’ All-Pro cornerback, has been loud and proud and proving himself to the world since childhood.
lead_paragraph: COMPTON, Calif. — Darryl Smith was dividing the pizzas among the boys’ track and field athletes of Dominguez High School when he first heard the voice he would never forget. It belonged to this scrawny, knock-kneed eighth grader who had tagged along with his older brother, who was eating all the slices and dominating all the conversations and somehow, it seemed, doing both at once.

headline: Asking Banks to Reveal Where Their High Rollers Are
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The New York State comptroller wants banks to take an inventory of their risk-taking employees.
lead_paragraph: For investors who held stakes in large and complex financial institutions in 2008, the perils lurking inside these behemoths came as a costly shock.

headline: Caption This Photo: Richard Sherman
abstract: To friends and family, Richard Sherman has always been a talker, which brings us to this photo of Sherman as a toddler. What’s young Richard thinking or saying in this moment?
lead_paragraph: After the N.F.C. Championship game, Richard Sherman’s postgame rant drew comparisons to the sports world’s biggest talkers, from John McEnroe to Muhammad Ali. If Sherman truly is one of the greats in that category, he has probably been honing the skill his entire life. Help us conjure what Sherman the toddler, shown in this photo, was saying as the photographer took the shot.

headline: The Gadfly of Greenwich Real Estate
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate Brokers', 'Mortgages', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: Amid dozens of unsold mega-mansions, a real estate agent sees a glut of greed.
lead_paragraph: As he drives his white pickup truck past the manors that crowd the hills and meadows along Round Hill Road in Greenwich, Conn. — a town that has long signified what it means to be rich in America — Christopher Fountain snorts.

headline: The Tale of the $8 Million ‘Bargain’ House in Greenwich
abstract: In the always fraught market for over-the-top mansions in Greenwich, one man’s pain can quickly become another man’s gain.
lead_paragraph: GREENWICH, Conn. — In the always fraught market for over-the-top mansions in Greenwich, one man’s pain can quickly become another man’s gain.

headline: In Housing, Big Is Back (Not Counting the Extras)
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Mortgages', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The bursting of the housing bubble didn’t deter affluent buyers for long. They’re pouring back into the market, and adding options galore to their new homes.
lead_paragraph: Katie Sleep and her husband, Jonathan, lived in the same four-bedroom home in a Washington suburb for 23 years. After Ms. Sleep decided to retire, they began looking for a new house, and, after viewing a model home in a new development, decided to move to Leesburg, Va., about 40 miles from the city. In having their new home built, they saw an opportunity — not to downsize, but to create a far larger home catering to their every need.

headline: A Lawyer Who Lets the Funkiness In
abstract: David M. Zornow’s law office includes a couch where he can take naps — helpful for his long working hours — as well as a shrine of sorts to Bob Dylan.
lead_paragraph: A study in orange

headline: Video and Tweets on Maryland Shopping Mall Shooting
abstract: Video and social media updates in the aftermath of shooting at a shopping mall in Columbia, Md.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 4:48 p.m. As my colleagues, Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Jada F. Smith, reported, the police say three people died in a shooting, including the gunman, at a shopping mall in Columbia, Md.

headline: Delivering Passes, if Not Wins, at L.I.U. Brooklyn
abstract: Jason Brickman, who at 5-foot-11 may not be too small for the N.B.A., leads Division I in assists with 9.7 a game.
lead_paragraph: Jason Brickman, a 5-foot-11 senior point guard for Long Island University Brooklyn, burst toward midcourt and bounced a perfect diagonal pass to D. J. Griggs between two Fairleigh Dickinson defenders running full speed. Griggs, surprised when the basketball reached his hands just outside the lane, made a layup. But he was called for traveling, negating the basket.

headline: Rand Paul Making Headlines
keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Senator Rand Paul has established himself as a national figure over the past 12 months, raising the question of whether he will campaign for the Republican nomination for president in 2016.
lead_paragraph: Senator Rand Paul has established himself as a national figure over the past 12 months, raising the question of whether he will campaign for the Republican nomination for president in 2016.

headline: Opposition Says No to Ukraine on Power Share
abstract: President Viktor F. Yanukovych offered to install opposition leaders in top government posts, but they swiftly rebuffed the offer, to the delight of thousands of protesters on the street.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — In a striking concession aimed at defusing Ukraine’s civil uprising and preserving his own grip on power, President Viktor F. Yanukovych on Saturday offered to install opposition leaders in top posts in a reshaped government, but they swiftly rebuffed the offer to the delight of thousands of protesters on the street craving a fuller victory in the days ahead.

headline: Once Successful as a Player, but More Fulfilled as a Father
abstract: Before Thursday, Chris Riley’s previous start on the PGA Tour was in August. But he says he has no regrets about leaving to spend more time with his wife and two daughters.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — After his opening round at the Farmers Insurance Open, Chris Riley joked that he felt like the San Diego Chargers backup quarterback Charlie Whitehurst being thrust into action in the postseason. If Riley felt rusty, and a little rattled, it was understandable. Before Thursday, his last PGA Tour start was in August.

headline: Social Responsibility Weighs Heavy on Economic Chieftains at Davos
abstract: The attendees at this year’s World Economic Forum have been hearing a consistent message: share your riches.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — With all that vexing talk about inequality, do the world’s plutocrats need a cuddle?

headline: Preventing the Next Data Breach
abstract: The Target attack shows that companies can do a lot more to reduce the risk of theft and fraud.
lead_paragraph: The alarming discovery that hackers stole the credit card and personal information of tens of millions of Americans from Target’s computers is yet another reminder of human vulnerability in the digital age. The more practical and immediate lesson, however, is that retailers, banks and other corporations can do far more than they have done so far to protect customers from identity theft and financial fraud.

headline: More Imperfect Unions
keywords: ['Marriages', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'ABORTION', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Marriage in America has been on the decline, but there is little honest talk about the root causes.
lead_paragraph: WHENEVER the subject turns to inequality and opportunity in America, the same political conversation repeats itself.

headline: Talking Sexual Violence Without Giving Offense
keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Women and Girls', 'Colleges and Universities', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: It’s rare to hear politicians discuss rape and assault with real sensitivity, but that’s just what President Obama and Vice President Biden did.
lead_paragraph: It’s rare to hear politicians at the national level discuss sexual violence. It’s even rarer to hear them discuss it with real sensitivity. Yet President Obama and Vice President Joseph Biden Jr. managed exactly that last Wednesday, when they announced a task force on campus rape — an area of particular concern. A 2007 study found that one in five women had been sexually assaulted in college.

headline: Yancey Strickler
abstract: The chief executive of Kickstarter on economics blogs, Dungeons & Dragons and Jeremy Lin.
lead_paragraph: Yancey Strickler is the chief executive of the crowdfunding site Kickstarter, which raises more than $1 million a day to pay for various posted projects.

abstract: Here are the 3 most important numbers to keep in mind when thinking about the Arab world today.
lead_paragraph: IF you’re confused about all the turmoil in the Arab world and asking how the United States should respond, I find it useful to consider three questions:

headline: ‘Just the Facts, Ma’am’ No More
abstract: A front page of The New York Times that is short on hard news and long on analysis and features is troubling to some readers.
lead_paragraph: IT’S a Monday morning in mid-January. Your print edition of The Times is at hand, along with your coffee. You scan it for news. But, for the most part, you scan in vain.

headline: The Koch Party
abstract: A new ad campaign of distortion is the vanguard of a sophisticated secret-money operation.
lead_paragraph: Only a few weeks into this midterm election year, the right-wing political zeppelin is fully inflated with secret cash and is firing malicious falsehoods at supporters of health care reform.

headline: 3 Enemas Later, Still No Drugs
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Search and Seizure']
abstract: Inequality in America is much more than just an income issue. It’s also about our dignity and access to justice.
lead_paragraph: IF you think that protests about overzealous law enforcement are over the top, listen to what unfolded when the police suspected that David Eckert, 54, was hiding drugs in his rectum.

headline: The Myth of Industrial Rebound
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'United States Economy', 'Automobiles', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Service Industries']
abstract: Don’t buy the hype about a manufacturing revival. It’s not enough to restore the U.S. economy.
lead_paragraph: WITH metronomic regularity, gauzy accounts extol the return of manufacturing jobs to the United States.

headline: Revealed: The Actual Fort Lee Traffic Study
abstract: What if the George Washington Bridge traffic study were to miraculously come to light?

headline: Too Many Slackers?
abstract: Readers respond to a column that said many students today don’t make the effort to excel.
lead_paragraph: Readers respond to a column that said many students today don’t make the effort to excel.

headline: Now Playing in Denver: Reefer Gladness
abstract: Denver pot entrepreneurs are so determined to set a good example, they’re acting like Shakers.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — SO you want to get high in a high-end way in the Mile High City.

headline: The Franchising of Al Qaeda
abstract: Without Bin Laden, the terrorist group is no longer cohesive, with a clear purpose.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — THE letter bore the corporate tone of a C.E.O. resolving a turf dispute between two middle managers. In formal prose and numbered lists, Ayman al-Zawahri, the leader of Al Qaeda, directed one of the group’s affiliates in Syria to withdraw to Iraq and leave operations in Syria to someone else.

headline: The Shopping List as Policy Tool
keywords: ['Government Procurement', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Minimum Wage']
abstract: The government can use its purchasing power to promote social goals.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THE federal government spends around $500 billion annually on goods and services. So when Uncle Sam throws his weight around, markets move.

headline: Having the Right Size, Not the Most Size, Fuels the Nets
abstract: The Nets are playing without Brook Lopez but have improved their defense and 3-point output behind an unorthodox starting lineup.
lead_paragraph: Last season, no factor correlated more to Nets victories than whether Brook Lopez played. On both sides of the court, the Nets never found a way to suitably replace him. When Lopez was injured last December, the Nets lost five straight and Coach Avery Johnson was fired.

headline: China’s New Obsession: French Wine
abstract: Globalization stirs the fears and hopes of oenophiles.
lead_paragraph: BORDEAUX, France — WHEN the Bordeaux International Wine Institute, which offers business management training in the oenological arts, opened its doors in 2004, it had 20 students, mostly from domestic French wineries. Today it has 105.

headline: None So Blind, Macroeconomics Division
abstract: If only this were a normal scholarly field …
lead_paragraph: Noah Smith reminds us of a quarter-century-old diatribe by Robert Barro against the New Keynesian economics, which is notable for its bitterness. You can sort of see why: people like Barro had triumphantly declared Keynes dead a decade earlier, and were evidently horrified to see even a mild version of Keynesian ideas making a comeback.

headline: With Some Investing Help, Huffington Unveils a New International Venture
abstract: Arianna Huffington and Nicolas Berggruen, a billionaire investor, announced the creation of WorldPost, a new website under the Huffington Post umbrella aimed at international issues.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — Arianna Huffington has long labored to make her online media empire a truly global one. Now she has enlisted an old friend with deep pockets to make a big step in that direction.

headline: Red Bulls Stay the Same, for a Change
abstract: In the past, the Red Bulls seemed to change coaches and players without a second thought, but this off-season the team adopted a mantra of continuity.
lead_paragraph: HARRISON, N.J. — Given their past record of tumult and turnover, the Red Bulls’ off-season was most unlikely.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Jan. 26
abstract: The State of the Union address is next week, and both Democrats and Republicans will appear on the Sunday shows to preview and predict what President Obama will say.
lead_paragraph: President Obama will deliver his sixth State of the Union address on Tuesday, most likely tackling agenda-setting topics for 2014, like income inequality and immigration. Representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers, Republican of Washington, will give the official Republican response following the president’s speech. Senators Mike Lee, Republican of Utah, and Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, will each give their own rebuttals.

headline: A Met Who Can Reach Base Is Trying to Stretch
abstract: Josh Satin has worked this offseason to expand his repertory as a utility man and pinch-hitter that the Mets would not want to be without.
lead_paragraph: After last season, the Mets did not define Josh Satin’s role. Not that he was surprised. A sixth-round draft pick in 2008, he hit for average but not for power in the minor leagues and never really seemed to be in the Mets’ plans.

headline: Sufficient Financing to Aid Troubled Banks, European Officials Say
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: If banks were not able to raise capital, they would draw it from their governments or European bailout fund, the president of the Eurogroup said.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — There will be enough money to recapitalize banks that fail a review by the European Central Bank later this year, top European leaders said on Saturday, seeking to assuage lingering doubts whether policy makers will succeed in cleaning up the financial system and restoring the flow of credit.

headline: On Comeback Trail in Downhill, Miller Is Third but Disappointed
abstract: Bode Miller, who missed the 2012-13 season, said he had been working toward winning the Hahnenkamm downhill for the first time.
lead_paragraph: KITZBÜHEL, Austria — Less than two weeks before the Winter Olympics, Bode Miller continued his comeback from a knee injury by placing third Saturday in the Hahnenkamm downhill, his best result in a World Cup speed event in almost two years.

headline: A Blow to the N.H.L.’s Positive Buzz
abstract: The brawl in a recent N.H.L. game between the Flames and Canucks reignited the debate about hockey’s place in American sports.
lead_paragraph: The N.H.L.’s slate of six outdoor games this season, including two at Yankee Stadium, should be a good indication of fans’ receptiveness to expanding the format.

headline: False Claims in Afghan Accusations on U.S. Raid Add to Doubts on Karzai
abstract: The government of President Hamid Karzai handed out an inflammatory dossier about airstrikes on Jan. 15 on a remote village and the supposed American cover-up that followed.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — It was the kind of dossier that the Taliban often publish, purporting to show the carnage inflicted during a raid by American forces: photographs of shattered houses and bloodied, broken bodies, and video images of anguish at a village funeral, all with gut-churning impact and no proof of authenticity.

headline: Michaels Stores Is Investigating Data Breach
abstract: The arts and crafts retailer based in Texas said that it was looking into a potential cyberattack involving its customers’ credit card information.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In what may be the latest in a continuing spate of cyberattacks on American retailers, Michaels Stores said Saturday that it was investigating a potential security breach involving customers’ credit card information.

headline: Seahawks Mania Bigger Than U.S. Can Contain
abstract: Along with the team’s well-documented 12th Man fan group in their home state, Washington, the Seahawks have found similar allies north of the border in Vancouver.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — During the N.F.C. championship game last Sunday, die-hard fans draped in navy blue and neon green, part of a group collectively known as the 12th Man, stood, yelled and chanted their Seahawks on to another victory, reaching excruciatingly high decibel levels in the process.

headline: An Outpouring of Support as Avonte Oquendo Is Laid to Rest
abstract: Scores of New Yorkers joined the family of Avonte Oquendo, who disappeared in October, in paying their respects at the boy’s funeral on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Avonte Oquendo’s smiling school portrait was on display next to the white coffin, decorated with four carved angels, that held his remains during his funeral on Saturday. It was also on the mourners’ lapels and the screens of cellphones clutched by the scores of New Yorkers who came to pay their respects but who had never met him.

headline: New York Area Weather Has a History with the Super Bowl
abstract: Teams playing in title games in the New York area have battled not only their opponents but wind, ice or mud.
lead_paragraph: In the countdowns to each of the previous 47 Super Bowls, the primary question was, quite simply, Which team will win? But as Denver and Seattle await XLVIII next Sunday at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., questions about the weather for the first outdoor cold-climate Super Bowl have upstaged even the point spread.

headline: Extra Virgin Suicide
abstract: The adulteration of Italian olive oil.
lead_paragraph: The adulteration of Italian olive oil.

headline: Russians With Deep Pockets Adopt Teams Going for Gold
abstract: Several high-powered Russian tycoons, including the Nets owner Mikhail D. Prokhorov, have lent their expertise and money to winter sports teams in anticipation of the Winter Olympics.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, Russia’s once-heralded biathlon program was in tatters. The team was plagued with doping violations. It was losing big competitions to countries it expected to beat, like Belarus and Kazakhstan. A top biathlon official was convicted of trying to arrange the murder of a local governor.

headline: Readers, Enemas and Inequality
abstract: Readers comment on my column about inequality before the law–as encountered, for example, by a man whom the police wrongly believed was hiding drugs internally.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column is about a man whom the police thought might be hiding drugs internally. After a series of forced rectal exams, x-rays, enemas and a colonoscopy, the police decided their hunch had been wrong. But more broadly, the column is about the way society has drawn tradeoffs in the last few decades so as to empower security over liberty, even when (as in the drug war and mass incarceration missteps) they haven’t done much to boost security. And in the final analysis, this seems to me to be a matter of profound social inequality. With President Obama’s State of the Union Address reportedly planning to focus on economic inequality, we tend to see the issue through the prism of wealth and income, and obviously that’s important. But inequality in America has other dimensions, not least how we’re treated by the criminal justice system.

headline: Snowballs at Giants Stadium, and Then Arrests
abstract: The elaborate plans for snow removal before or during Super Bowl XLVIII at MetLife Stadium, if necessary, stem from a dangerous and embarrassing scene at Giants Stadium on Dec. 23, 1995.
lead_paragraph: The elaborate plans for snow removal before or during Super Bowl XLVIII at MetLife Stadium, if necessary, stem from a dangerous and embarrassing scene at Giants Stadium on Dec. 23, 1995, during the Giants’ 27-17 loss to the San Diego Chargers.

headline: Venture Capitalist: Tech Activists Are Like Nazis
abstract: Simmering tensions between the tech elite and San Francisco activists are coming to a boil. Now a prominent financier has resorted to the ultimate in name-calling.
lead_paragraph: Tensions between the techno-elite and activists in San Francisco are racheting up every day.

headline: What Drives Success?
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Minorities', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: Culture pushes some groups to achieve. We can learn from them.
lead_paragraph: A SEEMINGLY un-American fact about America today is that for some groups, much more than others, upward mobility and the American dream are alive and well. It may be taboo to say it, but certain ethnic, religious and national-origin groups are doing strikingly better than Americans overall.

headline: Rand Paul’s Mixed Inheritance
keywords: ['Libertarianism (US Politics)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: As Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky tries to broaden his appeal, he is also trying to take libertarianism, an ideology long on the fringes of American politics, into the mainstream.
lead_paragraph: The libertarian faithful — antitax activists and war protesters, John Birch Society members and a smattering of “truthers” who suspect the government’s hand in the 2001 terrorist attacks — gathered last September, eager to see the rising star of their movement.

headline: It’s All Relative
abstract: Daniel A. Finan bets you can’t solve his puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — It took me a while to get the theme in this very clever puzzle by Daniel A. Finan, but when I did I was really impressed. You always have to really work for the good things in life, have you noticed that?

headline: Street Scenes From a Very Different Jan. 25 in Cairo
abstract: Dispatches from bloggers, activists and journalists on the streets of the Egyptian capital on Saturday offered a chronicle of a day that contrasted sharply, for supporters of the 2011 uprising, with the elation of that Jan. 25.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague David D. Kirkpatrick reports from Cairo, the third anniversary of Egypt’s uprising against autocracy was marked by a rally in favor of the new military leader, Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi, in Tahrir Square, while the security forces cracked down with deadly violence on protesters elsewhere.

headline: Beijing’s Bad Air Would Be Step Up for Smoggy Delhi
abstract: Researchers suspect that India’s unusual mix of polluted air, poor sanitation and contaminated water may make the country among the most dangerous in the world for lungs.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — In mid-January, air pollution in Beijing was so bad that the government issued urgent health warnings and closed four major highways, prompting the panicked buying of air filters and donning of face masks. But in New Delhi, where pea-soup smog created what was by some measurements even more dangerous air, there were few signs of alarm in the country’s boisterous news media, or on its effervescent Twittersphere.

headline: France’s President Announces Split With His Companion
abstract: President François Hollande announced Saturday that he and Valérie Trierweiler, who had served as France’s de facto first lady, had separated.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President François Hollande announced Saturday that he and his companion, Valérie Trierweiler, had formally ended their relationship, bringing to a close a two-week-long melodrama that began with a glossy magazine’s report of an affair with an actress and Ms. Trierweiler’s emotional collapse over the disclosure.

headline: Carmelo Anthony Hopes His 62-Point Explosion Propels the Knicks
abstract: Anthony and the Knicks are looking to use his performance in Friday’s victory over Charlotte as a springboard with four games left on their homestand.
lead_paragraph: A day after scoring 62 points, Carmelo Anthony rested.

headline: Rival Candidates Go After the Education Vote Differently
abstract: The two most likely candidates for governor are making education a talking point in their campaigns, with Attorney General Greg Abbott exploring charter schools and virtual learning while State Senator Wendy Davis focuses on teacher recruitment.
lead_paragraph: Less than two months before the March primary, Attorney General Greg Abbott of Texas, the leading Republican candidate for governor, can often be found on the campaign trail discussing an issue other statewide Republican candidates have mostly avoided: an overhaul of public education.

headline: House Republicans to Offer Broad Immigration Plan
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: The plan is expected to call for border security and enforcement measures, as well as providing a path to legal status — but not citizenship — for many undocumented immigrants.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republicans are preparing to unveil their own broad template for overhauling the nation’s immigration system this week, potentially offering a small opening for President Obama and congressional Democrats to pass bipartisan legislation before the end of the year.

headline: Alex Shear, Owner of 100,000 Pieces of American Kitsch, Dies at 73
abstract: Mr. Shear described his collection of pop-culture artifacts, which once spanned 11 storage facilities in three states, as a window into the American soul.
lead_paragraph: They were all his Rosebuds: the vacuum cleaner shaped like a rocket ship, the toaster shaped like a piece of toast, the suitcase with an electric iron in the handle, the potato mashers (he owned about 500), the tin soldiers, the fallout-shelter sign and the gasoline-powered pogo stick.

headline: Looking Back at 2013 State of Union
abstract: Times reporters review the State of the Union address from 2013 and preview this year’s speech.
lead_paragraph: Times reporters review the State of the Union address from 2013 and preview this year’s speech.

headline: Obama Pursuing a Modest Agenda in State of Union
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama has come to feel the constraints on his power acutely. He is set to announce executive actions on the environment and the economy that do not need the approval of Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — His ambitions in check and his eye on the calendar, President Obama intends to use his State of the Union address to put a difficult year behind him and reassert command before the capital is consumed with election-year politics.

headline: Philippines and Rebels Agree on Peace Accord to End Insurgency
abstract: The agreement will create an autonomous Muslim-dominated region in the restive south of the predominantly Christian country.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — The Philippine government and the country’s largest Muslim insurgency group negotiated the final details of a peace accord on Saturday that many hope will end more than 40 years of violence that has killed tens of thousands of people and helped nurture Islamic extremism in Southeast Asia.

headline: In North Dakota Town, Virtual Pipelines Prompt Concern
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Railroads', 'Railroad Accidents and Safety']

lead_paragraph: What was first seen as a stopgap measure in the absence of pipelines has become a fixture in the nation’s energy landscape.

headline: Romance of F.A. Cup, and the Reality
abstract: In England’s F.A. Cup, a complex calculus means that fans of smaller teams often hope for contests against top-tier clubs, despite the slim chances of victory.
lead_paragraph: STOKE-ON-TRENT, England — Soccer fans in England like to talk about the magic of the F.A. Cup, a single-elimination tournament that allows virtually every team in the land, from veritable pub teams to oligarch-owned monoliths, the chance to rise and fall in the same brackets. Some label it charming. Others call it romantic.

headline: Accidents Surge as Oil Industry Takes the Train
keywords: ['Railroad Accidents and Safety', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Railroads', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: Residents of Casselton, N.D., are concerned about the crude-oil convoys that roll through their town, as what was once a stopgap becomes commonplace and safety standards lag.
lead_paragraph: CASSELTON, N.D. — Kerry’s Kitchen is where Casselton residents gather for gossip and comfort food, especially the caramel rolls baked fresh every morning. But a fiery rail accident last month only a half mile down the tracks, which prompted residents to evacuate the town, has shattered this calm, along with people’s confidence in the crude-oil convoys that rumble past Kerry’s seven times a day.

headline: On a Trip to Boston, Unfolding Memories for Nets Players
abstract: The former Celtics Paul Pierce and Kevin Garnett expect emotions to be flowing when the Nets play at TD Garden on Sunday night.
lead_paragraph: With the Nets visiting the Celtics on Sunday night, Paul Pierce and Kevin Garnett were expecting their return to Boston to be an emotional one.

headline: Holocaust Told in One Word, 6 Million Times
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The book “And Every Single One Was Someone” — meant as a kind of coffee-table monument or conversation starter — consists of the single word “Jew,” printed six million times.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — There is no plot to speak of, and the characters are woefully undeveloped. On the upside, it can be a quick read — especially considering its 1,250 pages.

abstract: Cattle ranchers at the National Western Stock Show in Denver say their way of life is changing — and they have no choice but to keep up.

headline: A Harder Outlook for Today’s Cowboy
abstract: As new technology and changing demographics overtake an old calling, the herd of cattle — and ranchers — is declining in the United States.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Just a few miles from the midday bustle of this city’s hip downtown, a pen of black-hided yearlings trotted into a dusty arena, as a crowd of burly men in cowboy hats looked on silently.

headline: Nepal Lawmakers Move Closer to Choosing a Prime Minister
abstract: The country’s Supreme Court dismissed calls for an immediate election and allowed President Ram Baran Yadav to remain in office for now.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Nepal’s new Constituent Assembly is expected to begin the process of choosing a prime minister this week after the country’s Supreme Court dismissed calls for an immediate election to choose a president.

headline: India Dismisses Charges Against Soldiers in Killings
abstract: The army dismissed charges against five soldiers in a case from 2000 in which soldiers were accused of rounding up five Kashmiri men, then shooting and burning them.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Indian Army last week dismissed charges against five soldiers in a long-running, infamous case in which soldiers were accused of rounding up five Kashmiri men, dressing them in fatigues, then shooting and burning them. The soldiers said the men were Pakistani militants, but locals have insisted for years that they were innocent civilians — a claim lent support by an Indian government investigation.

headline: It Only Seems That Political Corruption Is Rampant
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Ethics (Institutional)']
abstract: It may seem that high-level scandal is breaking out all over, but analysts offer statistics that say otherwise.
lead_paragraph: With the indictment last week of the former Virginia governor Bob McDonnell on fraud and conspiracy charges, one might surmise that high-level political scandal is breaking out all over. And in a way, one would be right: It has been a good year, or perhaps a bad one, for hauling politicians before judges.

headline: Fissures in G.O.P. as Some Conservatives Embrace Renewable Energy

headline: Are You Getting Married on Super Bowl Sunday? Or Did You?
abstract: The Times is seeking couples who are tying the knot (or already did) on Super Bowl Sunday to interview for a coming article.
lead_paragraph: Wedding planners will tell you that they plan other events for Yom Kippur, Thanksgiving and Christmas, three holidays during which few couples, if any, get married. The fourth “holiday” where vows are rarely exchanged is Super Bowl Sunday, but wouldn’t it be interesting to find a couple who will tie the knot on the day of the big game, if for no other reason than to ask them ‘what were you thinking?’

lead_paragraph: Margaret Mary Ocampo and Benjamin Paul Scheck were married Saturday at St. Andrew Avellino Roman Catholic Church in Flushing, Queens. Msgr. Michael J. Brennan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Ducks Triumph at Dodger Stadium as Volleyballs and Frisbees Fly
abstract: The Anaheim Ducks beat the Los Angeles Kings at Dodger Stadium on Saturday night in the N.H.L.’s first warm-weather outdoor game.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Outdoor hockey, Southern California-style, debuted Saturday night with face-offs and Frisbees, spiked volleyballs and a stuffed penalty shot, Bob Miller partnering with Vin Scully and the iconoclastic pitcher Brian Wilson mingling with the icon Wayne Gretzky.

headline: What’s On Today?
abstract: Television highlights
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (CBS) THE 56TH ANNUAL GRAMMY AWARDS L L Cool J returns as host of this ceremony honoring artists in country, hip-hop, jazz, pop and rock, and broadcast live from the Staples Center in Los Angeles. Jay Z leads the pack with nine nominations; Kendrick Lamar, Macklemore (above) & Ryan Lewis, Justin Timberlake and Pharrell Williams follow with seven apiece; and Drake and the mastering engineer Bob Ludwig have five each. A “Grammy Moment” will feature Merle Haggard; Kris Kristofferson, a recipient of the 2014 Recording Academy Lifetime Achievement Award; Willie Nelson; and Blake Shelton. Billie Joe Armstrong and Miranda Lambert will perform a tribute to Phil Everly, who died on Jan. 3. Other sets will feature Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr, who will also receive lifetime achievement awards; Nile Rodgers, Mr. Williams and Stevie Wonder with Daft Punk; Pink and Nate Ruess; Metallica and Lang Lang; Madonna, Lorde, Katy Perry, John Legend, Kacey Musgraves, Taylor Swift and Keith Urban. Nine Inch Nails, Queens of the Stone Age, Dave Grohl and Lindsey Buckingham will rock the finale. Pre-event coverage begins at 4 on E!; TV Guide joins the red carpet at 5; and E! moves to the after-party at 11:30.

headline: Suicide Bomber Targets Afghan Army Vehicle
abstract: Four people were killed, including two civilians, in an attack on a shuttle bus transporting soldiers through Kabul.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A suicide attack Sunday morning on a shuttle bus transporting soldiers through Kabul killed at least four people, including two civilians, the first deadly assault in the Afghan capital since 21 civilians were killed in an attack at a popular restaurant on Jan. 17.

headline: A Little Less Tech Luster in Cambridge
abstract: Cambridge – home to one of the world’s oldest universities and some successful tech companies – remains one of Europe’s largest tech communities. But London’s rise has taken away some of the shine.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – On the streets of East London, signs of the city’s blossoming tech scene are hard to miss.

headline: Thai Protesters Disrupt Early Voting in South
abstract: Antigovernment demonstrators prevented hundreds of thousands of people from casting early ballots on Sunday for the Feb. 2 elections.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Hundreds of thousands of people were blocked from voting on Sunday as antigovernment demonstrators obstructed polling places in Bangkok and southern Thailand in a campaign to suspend democracy and replace Parliament with an unelected “people’s council.”

headline: A Bizarrely Fitting Finale Yields a Most Unexpected Champion
abstract: Stanislas Wawrinka defeated Rafael Nadal, bringing the strangest match of an odd tournament to a conclusion one couldn’t have expected.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — After two weeks of madness that included extreme temperatures, a player who hallucinated and saw Snoopy, a lightning strike, a rain delay, a prominent blister and back injury, new rackets, celebrity coaches and upsets galore, the Australian Open ended Sunday.

headline: China Sentences Xu Zhiyong, Legal Activist, to 4 Years in Prison
abstract: The case against Mr. Xu, who campaigned against corruption and injustice, was seen as a barometer of how China’s new leadership would respond to organized calls for reform.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A Chinese court sentenced a prominent legal activist to four years in prison Sunday in a case widely seen as a demonstration of the Communist Party leadership’s determination to quell any challenges to its hold on power.

headline: Freezing Eggs, and Hoarding My Fertility
abstract: For a year, I froze eggs in a frenzy, bloated in fat pants and cranky from hormones; $50,000 later, I had stashed away 70 eggs.
lead_paragraph: When I awoke in my fertility clinic’s recovery room after having nine eggs extracted and frozen, I felt a profound calm settle over my body. I could not make the man I had fallen in love with at the time want kids. But at age 36, I could soften the fallout. By stashing away some good eggs, I had found a way to keep alive my dream of having a family.

headline: Grammys to Feature On-Air Weddings of 34 Couples
keywords: ['Grammy Awards', 'Music', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Weddings and Engagements']
abstract: Queen Latifah will officiate a wedding for 34 gay and straight couples as part of the hip-hop duo Macklemore & Ryan Lewis’s performance of their song “Same Love.”
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:20 p.m. | LOS ANGELES — At the Grammy Awards on Sunday night, pop’s megastars will compete for the music industry’s most prestigious trophy, and put on flashy performances that are sure to ricochet through social media.

headline: Cuarón Wins Directors Guild Award
abstract: The director of “Gravity” takes a prize often seen as a harbinger of the best picture Oscar winner.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Directors Guild of America awarded its top feature film prize to Alfonso Cuarón, for “Gravity,” here on Saturday.

headline: Video from Police Briefing on Maryland Mall Shooting
abstract: Video from police update Sunday on the shooting at the Mall in Columbia, Md. Police identified the suspect as Darion Marcus Aguilar, 19, of College Park, Md.
lead_paragraph: The gunman in the shooting at a mall in Maryland Saturday was identified on Sunday as Darion Marcus Aguilar, 19, of College Park, Md.

headline: Motive Still Unclear, Details on Maryland Shooting Suspect Emerge
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: The police identified the gunman as Darion Marcus Aguilar, of College Park, Md., but could not determine what prompted the violence after interviews with his family and friends.
lead_paragraph: As the police investigated the shooting at a shopping mall in Maryland where three people died on Saturday to try to determine what prompted the violence, more information came to light on Sunday about the suspected gunman.

headline: Disruptions: The Holodeck Begins to Take Shape
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: Hollywood and computer and video game companies are working to move immersive virtual entertainment closer to reality.
lead_paragraph: Isaac Newton, Albert Einstein and Stephen Hawking are playing poker together.
