abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A waitress took direct action when she realized that a newcomer needed instructions in basic bagel etiquette.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Obama and the One Percent
abstract: Not Hitler, but a touch of FDR.
lead_paragraph: Another week, another outburst by a one-percenter comparing progressive taxation to Nazi atrocities. I particularly liked the end:

headline: ‘I, Frankenstein’ Disappoints at the Box Office
abstract: “I, Frankenstein” generated just $8.3 million in ticket sales — a terrible result for a movie that cost $65 million to make and tens of millions more to advertise.
lead_paragraph: Talk about a corpse. Moviegoers this weekend largely stayed away from the newly released “I, Frankenstein” (Lionsgate), which generated just $8.3 million in ticket sales, for sixth place — a terrible result for a movie that cost $65 million to make and tens of millions more to advertise. Lakeshore Entertainment and Hopscotch Features shouldered almost all costs. Box office analysts posited on Sunday that the target audience, young men, simply had little interest in seeing Mary Shelley’s undead monster re-imagined as an action hero; abysmal reviews didn’t help.

headline: Thai Protesters Block Polling Stations
abstract: In Bangkok, protesters padlocked gates and intimidated polling officials in an effort to prevent voting.
lead_paragraph: In Bangkok, protesters padlocked gates and intimidated polling officials in an effort to prevent voting.

headline: Himmler Papers Shed Light on Personal Life of a Nazi
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Archives and Records']
abstract: Excerpts from a collection of letters, diaries and photographs from Heinrich Himmler, chief of the Nazi Gestapo, and his family have been published for the first time.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — When Germany invaded the Soviet Union in June 1941, the wife of Heinrich Himmler, chief of the Nazi Gestapo and the SS and one of the main orchestrators of the Holocaust, sent him a message: “There is a can of caviar in the ice box. Take it.”

headline: Texas Woman Is Taken Off Life Support After Order
keywords: ['Life-Sustaining Support Systems, Withdrawal Of', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'ABORTION', 'Hospitals']
abstract: The Fort Worth hospital followed a judge’s order to remove the brain-dead woman, Marlise Muñoz, from machines, ending a battle that had sparked a debate over abortion and end-of-life care.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A Fort Worth hospital that kept a pregnant, brain-dead woman on life support for two months followed a judge’s order on Sunday and removed her from the machines, ending her family’s legal fight to have her pronounced dead and to challenge a Texas law that prohibits medical officials from cutting off life support to a pregnant woman.

headline: With Near-Misses, Miller Shows He's Back and Primed for the Olympics
abstract: Bode Miller, the American skier, showed this weekend in Austria that he has recovered from his injuries and is ready to take on the slopes at the Sochi Games.
lead_paragraph: KITZBÜHEL, Austria — Bode Miller of the United States rose from the ashes of his defeat in the downhill race here Saturday and skied a nearly flawless run to notch the runner-up position in the super-G on Sunday, his second top-three finish in two days.

headline: Maryland Shooting News Conference
abstract: The Howard County police chief, William J. McMahon, addressed the news media about the deadly shootings at the Mall in Columbia.
lead_paragraph: The Howard County police chief, William J. McMahon, addressed the news media about the deadly shootings at the Mall in Columbia.

headline: Taking on Beethoven, With an Assist
abstract: The Orpheus Chamber Orchestra’s Beethoven concert at Carnegie Hall featured the Japanese pianist Nobuyoki Tsujii.
lead_paragraph: The Orpheus Chamber Orchestra has a way with Beethoven, which makes it surprising that some people once thought the group should steer clear of his works.

headline: HSBC Apologizes After Cash Withdrawal Issue in Britain
keywords: ['Customer Relations', 'Money Laundering', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Some customers were prevented from making large cash withdrawals after they refused to present evidence about why they needed the money.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The British bank HSBC has apologized after reports that some customers were prevented from withdrawing large sums of cash from their accounts.

headline: Aides Say Obama Is Willing to Work With or Without Congress to Meet Goals
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Offering a preview of the State of the Union address, two aides to President Obama said on Sunday morning talk shows that Mr. Obama was willing to bypass a gridlocked Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Aides to President Obama on Sunday offered a preview of the strategy of the president’s State of the Union address, emphasizing Mr. Obama’s willingness to bypass a gridlocked Congress to achieve his goals.

headline: Meditations on Sadness and Solace
abstract: George Rothman conducted the Riverside Symphony at Alice Tully Hall in “Shadow and Light,” a program that included works by the composers Toru Takemitsu and Arthur Honegger.
lead_paragraph: The international career of the Japanese composer Toru Takemitsu began after Stravinsky heard one of his works in the late ’50s and began championing his music. Although Takemitsu initially resisted traditional music because of its association with Japanese militarism, which he loathed, he later included indigenous instruments and folk music in his understated, eloquent and coloristic works scores, influenced by European modernism and French composers like Debussy.

headline: Grammy Parties Aplenty Before the Big Party
abstract: There were some extraordinary musical events in the days leading up to the Grammy Awards.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Music, as you might expect, is everywhere in the parties, showcases and music-industry hobnobs leading up to the Grammy Awards. And while the sight of a person singing into a microphone is sometimes the cue for executives to reach for their smartphones, there were some extraordinary musical events over the last few days.

headline: My Kid’s Idle for a Second? Oh, Horrors!
abstract: In “All Joy and No Fun,” Jennifer Senior looks at overscheduling and other tendencies in contemporary middle-class child rearing.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Senior’s astute book about parents and children, “All Joy and No Fun,” is especially eye opening about how many prejudices are usually built into such studies. Take “parenting,” a word that invariably makes its way into books about parent-child dynamics: Ms. Senior would like to remind us that this was not always a verb, and that the emphasis on parents’ need to devote themselves 24/7 to their offspring is a relative novelty.

headline: Looking Inward, and Finding Inspiration
abstract: With her work “4,” the choreographer Sarah Michelson used many elements to continue her Devotion series.
lead_paragraph: A central problem with the choreographer Sarah Michelson is that the admirer who surrounds her with the greatest claims for Sarah Michelson’s greatness is Sarah Michelson herself. In the four works of hers I’ve seen since 2009, her dances strike me as obviously limited, largely unoriginal, though not devoid of interest. But as theater works, especially in their use of recorded speech and music, they’re vexing. And in “4,” her new piece now showing at the Whitney Museum of American Art, she emerges as the most pretentious artist of my entire experience, and among the most self-infatuated.

headline: Feeling Squeamish? Maybe You Shouldn’t Read Any Further
abstract: The second season of “The Following,” the Fox drama about a serial killer, picks up with the same kind of deaths seen in Season 1.
lead_paragraph: The Fox series “The Following” is essentially a cheap horror story tricked out with a laughable literary framework, and it likes to traffic in patterns and symbols, the more obvious the better.

headline: Open Swiss Teams at District 3 Winter Regional
abstract: The Thursday Open Swiss Teams at the District 3 Winter Regional in Rye, N.Y., on Jan. 16 was won by Jane Dillenberg, Jerry Goldberg, Gail Greenberg and Susan Picus of New York City.
lead_paragraph: The Thursday Open Swiss Teams at the District 3 Winter Regional in Rye, N.Y., on Jan. 16 was won by Jane Dillenberg, Jerry Goldberg, Gail Greenberg and Susan Picus of New York City.

headline: Gyrating His Way Through Country Beats
abstract: The country singer Luke Bryan performed at Madison Square Garden on Saturday, with the rising star Lee Brice opening the show.
lead_paragraph: Here are Luke Bryan’s moves: He waves his right hand in the air as if he’s riding a bull while his left hand caresses his rear end; he flattens his arms against himself and pumps his shoulders up and down; he stands firm, feet spread shoulderwide, and lets his waist go liquid, thrusting himself into the cheap seats.

headline: Shakespeare’s Raging Monarch as a Modern-Day Dictator
abstract: Sam Mendes sets his “King Lear,” starring Simon Russell Beale at the National Theater, in a modern dictatorship.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Could you ever find it in your heart to pity a mass-murdering dictator? What if you suddenly came upon Stalin, say, or Ceausescu in a storm-swept wilderness, and he had been stripped of his power, his sanity and most of his clothes? Might you muster a tiny tear of compassion, even knowing all you know about him?

headline: Daft Punk, Macklemore & Ryan Lewis and Lorde Prevail at the Grammys
abstract: Dave Itzkoff and Jon Caramanica live-blogged the ceremony, which saw major awards go to the French dance music duo Daft Punk and the upstarts Macklemore & Ryan Lewis and Lorde.
lead_paragraph: Dave Itzkoff and Jon Caramanica live-blogged the ceremony, which saw major awards go to the French dance music duo Daft Punk and the upstarts Macklemore & Ryan Lewis and Lorde.

headline: Countdown to Kickoff
abstract: The run-up this week to the Super Bowl, on Feb. 2, will include events around New Jersey like cooking demonstrations, concerts and appearances by football players past and present.
lead_paragraph: The run-up this week to the Super Bowl, on Feb. 2, will include events around New Jersey like cooking demonstrations, concerts and appearances by football players past and present.

headline: With Previews, Super Bowl Advertisers Borrow From Hollywood
abstract: Chatter on social media outlets like Twitter helps encourage Super Bowl advertisers to release commercials early to whet consumers’ appetite for the game-day ads.
lead_paragraph: ADVERTISERS that want commercials to be perceived as more than product pitches like to call them “films.” When it comes to Super Bowl commercials, the term may be appropriate rather than pretentious.

headline: A Troupe Without a Home Provides a Stage to Works in Search of One
abstract: New York Theater Ballet, still without a regular performance space, performed three premieres and revisited recent works at Florence Gould Hall.
lead_paragraph: New York Theater Ballet recently lost its home, when the building where its studios and offices had been since 1980 was sold. The search for a new space continues, but on Friday at Florence Gould Hall, the company mounted a program that in its variety and quality made a good advertisement for why the troupe merits support.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Jan. 27
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: On the Road, Actors Seek Higher Pay
abstract: Actors’ Equity members are organizing against a touring system for Broadway shows that treats and pays some members handsomely and others far less so.
lead_paragraph: Actors call them “luxury tours”: the road productions of “Wicked,” “The Lion King” and other blockbuster hit musicals with the money to bring Broadway across America in style. No tours pay better for Actors’ Equity union members — at least $1,807 a week, with leads earning up to $6,000 — and none have better perks, like physical therapy at a moment’s notice.

headline: Vacation Lodging Purchase
abstract: May I interest you in a puzzle by James Tuttle?
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Have a seat. I’m just going to put on a short presentation before we talk about the puzzle. No, you’ll love it, really. Well, if I have to be perfectly honest, it’s about these exclusive condos that you will absolutely l … hey, where’s everybody going?

headline: China’s Corruption Crackdown?
abstract: A report last week said that the country’s wealthy are storing billions of dollars abroad.
lead_paragraph: Xi Jinping has vowed to end corruption among China’s elite, but a report said that the country’s wealthy are storing billions of dollars abroad.

headline: In the Cold at Yankee Stadium, the Rangers Are in Their Element
abstract: Before a crowd announced at more than 50,000, the Rangers chased Martin Brodeur and beat the Devils soundly in the first hockey game played at Yankee Stadium.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it was the midwinter cold. Or maybe it was the chipped ice, or even the jovial atmosphere among the fans.

headline: Dresden Ballet Dancer Wins Lead Role in New Starz Series
abstract: Sarah Hay, an American member of the Semperoper Ballet in Dresden, Germany, has won the lead role in the upcoming Starz series, “Flesh and Bone.”
lead_paragraph: “Flesh and Bone,” a new drama series produced by Starz, starts shooting this spring and has the ballet world buzzing, especially since the cancellations of ABC Family’s “Bunheads” and, more recently, “Breaking Pointe,” the CW reality show about Ballet West. After an extensive search, the creator and writer Moira Walley-Beckett and the executive producers Lawrence Bender, Kevin Brown and John Melfi have found the show’s lead. Sarah Hay, an American member of the Semperoper Ballet in Dresden, Germany, won the part of Claire, a talented, emotionally troubled dancer from Pittsburgh who ends up in a New York City ballet company. At an open audition last fall, Ms. Walley-Beckett described the character as coming from “an abusive family life.”

headline: Ezra Klein Is Joining Vox Media as Web Journalism Asserts Itself
abstract: Mr. Klein’s departure from The Washington Post to Vox Media is just one more example of how digital publishing offers its own thing, not an additional platform for established news companies.
lead_paragraph: After a week of speculation, it turns out that Ezra Klein, the prolific creator of The Washington Post’s Wonkblog, will be going to Vox Media, the online home of SB Nation, a sports site, and The Verge, a fast-growing technology site.

headline: This Time, Anthony Has Just Enough to Carry the Shaky Knicks
abstract: Two days after scoring 62 points in a blowout victory over the Charlotte Bobcats, Carmelo Anthony had 35 hard-fought points as the Knicks edged the Lakers.
lead_paragraph: Carmelo Anthony got an early indication that Sunday’s game was not going to be like his last one. He was trying to work his way to the basket late in the second quarter when the Los Angeles Lakers’ Ryan Kelly used his 6-foot-11, 230-pound frame to impede Anthony’s progress like a cement-filled traffic barrier.

headline: Chairwoman of Universal Expands Her Portfolio
abstract: NBCUniversal announced it extended the contract of Donna Langley, chairwoman of Universal Pictures, through 2017 and handed her oversight of worldwide marketing and overseas production.
lead_paragraph: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif. — A drained Donna Langley, chairwoman of Universal Pictures, sat down for lunch in the studio’s executive dining room here last month and let loose a dramatic sigh. Who could blame her?

headline: The Age of ‘Infopolitics’
abstract: As digital persons, we’re vulnerable to new, digital injustices.
lead_paragraph: We are in the midst of a flood of alarming revelations about information sweeps conducted by government agencies and private corporations concerning the activities and habits of ordinary Americans. After the initial alarm that accompanies every leak and news report, many of us retreat to the status quo, quieting ourselves with the thought that these new surveillance strategies are not all that sinister, especially if, as we like to say, we have nothing to hide.

headline: Avoiding Faux Pas With the Grieving
abstract: Readers react to a column by David Brooks about a family that is dealing with two tragedies.

headline: Past Glories Resound in UMass Revival
abstract: Under the steady guidance of John Calipari disciple Derek Kellogg, a long-lost buzz has returned to the Massachusetts men’s basketball program that has cracked the top 25 and kept climbing.
lead_paragraph: AMHERST, Mass. — Shortly after Derek Kellogg was hired at Massachusetts in the summer of 2008, he toured the surrounding countryside, popping into restaurants, coffee shops and bars across the Pioneer Valley to shake hands, and to promote and reminisce about the Minutemen.

headline: U.N. Inquiry Criticizes Qatar’s Justice System
abstract: A critique concludes that prosecutors and judges need more autonomy, defense lawyers should have more access to evidence, and foreign suspects may be vulnerable to discrimination.
lead_paragraph: A United Nations investigator permitted by Qatar to examine its justice system delivered a blunt critique on Sunday, saying that prosecutors and judges need more autonomy and training, defense lawyers should have access to the evidence against their clients, and foreign suspects may be vulnerable to discrimination.

headline: Who Should Be Invited to the State of the Union?
abstract: To highlight certain priorities, the president invites a few guests each year to sit in the viewing gallery. Experts and readers can suggest who should be invited and why.

headline: A Race for a New Mayor; a Trial for an Old One
abstract: C. Ray Nagin, the embattled former mayor of New Orleans, has been largely forgotten by residents keen to leave the Katrina era behind.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Him again.

headline: Apple’s Earnings, Bernanke’s Farewell
keywords: ['Company Reports', 'United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: Highlights of the business week will include Ford and Chrysler earnings and the first look at fourth-quarter economic output.
lead_paragraph: WATCHING APPLE’S HOLIDAY QUARTER

headline: Militants Down Egyptian Helicopter, Killing 5 Soldiers
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Terrorism', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems']
abstract: Islamist militants shot down an Egyptian military helicopter in the Sinai Peninsula with a surface-to-air missile over the weekend, raising new alarms about the terrorist insurgency there.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Islamist militants shot down an Egyptian military helicopter in the Sinai Peninsula with a surface-to-air missile over the weekend, raising new alarms about the terrorist insurgency that developed there in response to the military takeover last summer.

headline: Intensive Small-Group Tutoring and Counseling Helps Struggling Students
abstract: A study of struggling African-American high school students in Chicago found that providing focused guidance sharply improved learning, but the approach is a costly one to replicate.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — By the time they reach eighth grade, according to federal tests, half of all African-American schoolboys have not mastered the most basic math skills that educators consider essential for their grade level.

headline: Despite Business Fears, Sick-Day Laws Like New York’s Work Well Elsewhere
abstract: San Francisco, Washington and Seattle indicated that their new policies did not hurt local economies or cause businesses to leave.
lead_paragraph: Donna Levitt was wrapping up an email in her office in San Francisco’s City Hall this month when she picked up the telephone. On the line was Mayor Bill de Blasio’s first deputy commissioner for consumer affairs, looking for insight and advice on carrying out New York City’s proposed paid sick-day law.

headline: Ukraine Protests Spread as Overture Is Spurned
abstract: The growing unrest raised the prospect of widening violence and deepening political chaos while leaders in Kiev, the capital, remain at an impasse.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — After President Viktor F. Yanukovych failed to defuse Ukraine’s political crisis by offering concessions to opposition leaders, antigovernment protests spread on Sunday into southern and eastern Ukraine, the heart of the embattled president’s political base.

headline: Peace Deal to End Insurgency Came After Philippine Leader’s Ultimatum to Rebels
abstract: President Benigno S. Aquino III made it clear to Muslim rebels that the peace deal he was offering was the best they could expect from any Philippine leader.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — After repeated frustrations in its efforts to end a long-running insurgency in the southern Philippines, the government had a message for rebels: now or never. It was an argument, analysts say, that helped President Benigno S. Aquino III finally reach a landmark peace deal over the weekend with the country’s largest Muslim rebel group.

headline: Three Years After Uprising, Tunisia Approves Constitution
abstract: The country’s Assembly voted its approval on Sunday, completing a two-year drafting process and ushering in a new democratic era.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — Members of Tunisia’s National Constituent Assembly voted overwhelmingly to approve the country’s new Constitution on Sunday night, finally completing a two-year drafting process and opening the way to a new democratic era three years after the uprising that set off the Arab Spring.

headline: Cannabis Legal, Localities Begin to Just Say No
abstract: Local resistance to legal marijuana signals a larger fight over whether it will be a national industry or a patchwork system.
lead_paragraph: YAKIMA, Wash. — The momentum toward legalized marijuana might seem like an inevitable tide, with states from Florida to New York considering easing laws for medical use, and a full-blown recreational industry rapidly emerging in Colorado and here in Washington State.

headline: America on Probation
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Probation and Parole', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Mandatory Sentencing', 'States (US)']
abstract: We may be getting over our peculiar love of prisons. But if not prisons, what?
lead_paragraph: IN recent years Americans have begun to wise up to the idea that our overstuffed prisons are a shameful waste of lives and money. Lawmakers have recoiled from the high price of mass incarceration (the annual per-inmate cost of prison approaches the tuition at a good college) and some have recognized that our prisons feed a pathological cycle of poverty, community dysfunction, crime and hopelessness. As crime rates have dropped, the public has registered support for reforms that would have fewer nonviolent offenders languishing in prison. For three years in a row, the population of America’s prisons has inched down; 13 states closed prisons last year. Efforts to fix the perpetual misery machine that is our criminal justice system have won support not only from progressives and academics but from conservatives (both fiscal and evangelical), from enlightened law enforcement groups, from business and even from advocates for crime victims.

headline: Syria Willing to Let Some Leave Area It Barricaded
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'International Relations', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: A plan by the government to allow women and children to leave the city of Homs raised concerns that men who try to do so would be arrested.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The Syrian government said on Sunday at peace talks here that it was willing to allow women and children to leave a blockaded area of the city of Homs at any time, suggesting a small step forward in confidence-building measures that the sponsors of the talks hope will build toward a political resolution of Syria’s war.

headline: Paranoia of the Plutocrats
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: Extreme inequality, it turns out, creates a class of insecure but powerful people who are alarmingly detached from reality.
lead_paragraph: Rising inequality has obvious economic costs: stagnant wages despite rising productivity, rising debt that makes us more vulnerable to financial crisis. It also has big social and human costs. There is, for example, strong evidence that high inequality leads to worse health and higher mortality.

headline: A Coach Returns, and the Questions Linger
abstract: Mike D’Antoni’s return to New York, this time with the Los Angeles Lakers, brought back questions about why he and Carmelo Anthony failed as a tandem in New York.
lead_paragraph: Welcome back, Mike D’Antoni. Did you hear that Carmelo Anthony scored 62 points?

headline: For Obama, Investing in Brighter Futures Remains a Tough Sell
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Economy', 'Law and Legislation', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: The president’s State of the Union address could underscore his inability so far to achieve the taxpayer-financed investments that he believes can lift the middle class and the poor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Whatever President Obama has accomplished, he has made little headway on the goal he values most: government action to lift long-term economic prospects for average Americans.

headline: Afghan Villagers Brought to Back Airstrike Report
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Civilian Casualties', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: At a news conference to bolster the Afghan government’s account of an American airstrike, villagers identified a 2009 photo as one from this month.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan government brought the seven men to a news conference Sunday morning to bolster its claims that American forces were responsible for the deaths of civilians in a remote village last week. In addition to a dossier of grisly photographs and video clips released earlier, reporters would now hear firsthand accounts from residents of the village.

headline: A Formula for Repelling Women Voters
keywords: ["Women's Rights", 'ABORTION', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Editorials', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The Republican obsession with undermining Roe V. Wade won’t build the party.
lead_paragraph: Republican leaders have chosen an odd way to try to win back female voters alienated by relentless G.O.P. attacks on women’s health care and freedoms. Instead of backing off, they’re digging in, clinging to an approach that gave President Obama a 12-point advantage among women in the 2012 election and provided the slim margin of victory for Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic candidate for governor in Virginia, in 2013. On the national level and even in some red states, the party’s stance on women’s rights is plainly not helping it.

headline: The Expanding Power of U.S. v. Windsor
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Homosexuality', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)', 'Jury System', 'States (US)', 'Editorials', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: The Supreme Court’s momentous ruling on same-sex marriage is used to protect gay jurors.
lead_paragraph: The heartening effects of the Supreme Court’s landmark ruling last June striking down the core of the Defense of Marriage Act, or DOMA, continue to ripple outward. On Jan. 21, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit held that gays and lesbians may not be excluded from juries on the basis of their sexual orientation.

headline: Afghanistan Exit Is Seen as Peril to C.I.A. Drone Mission
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Military Bases and Installations']
abstract: American intelligence agencies are concerned that they could lose their air bases used for drone strikes if a final security deal cannot be struck with the Afghan president, Hamid Karzai.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The risk that President Obama may be forced to pull all American troops out of Afghanistan by the end of the year has set off concerns inside the American intelligence agencies that they could lose their air bases used for drone strikes against Al Qaeda in Pakistan and for responding to a nuclear crisis in the region.

headline: First Came the Sun, and Then Came the Snow
abstract: Yankee Stadium’s first N.H.L. game got off to a late start, but even the losing team had good things to say about the event.
lead_paragraph: Yankee Stadium, and its predecessor across the street, have combined to host 40 World Series and thousands of other events throughout the decades, dealing often with challenges like capacity crowds and weather-related delays.

headline: Getting an Accurate Fix on Schools
abstract: The de Blasio administration should mend, not end, the Bloomberg evaluation system.
lead_paragraph: New York state test data to be released later this spring will include sobering news for Mayor Bill de Blasio and his new schools chancellor, Carmen Fariña. The data show that only one in four New York City students who started high school in 2009 and graduated in 2013 performed well enough on the Regents exams to meet the state definition of college readiness. Racial and ethnic breakdowns are not yet available. But they are likely to mirror last year’s statistics, which showed striking racial disparities: Only about 11 percent of black and about 12 percent of Hispanic graduates were deemed college-ready.

headline: 2014 Elections Likely to Keep Capital’s Split
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections', 'Tea Party Movement']
abstract: A review of competitive congressional contests suggests that Republicans will hold on to the House, while Senate Democrats will almost certainly see their majority narrowed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the 2014 political landscape becoming more defined, it is increasingly likely that the midterm elections in November will maintain divided government in the capital for the final two years of President Obama’s second term, with the chief unknown being exactly how divided it will be.

headline: Lessons for de Blasio in New Jersey’s Free Pre-K
abstract: Officials across the country, including Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York, are studying successful programs in New Jersey as they seek to expand access to preschool.
lead_paragraph: UNION CITY, N.J. — Teddy Lin’s teachers were worried.

lead_paragraph: In January, The New York Times interviewed Uber’s C.E.O., Travis Kalanick, about the ride-sharing company’s business practices, including liability in accidents.

keywords: ['Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs']
abstract: Uber, the hot start-up whose software allows anyone with a smartphone to get a cab ride, is suddenly facing trouble.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It’s Travis Kalanick versus the world, and recently the world seems to be winning.

headline: Hoping to Sail to Glory, the Broncos First Board a Ship
abstract: Denver’s news media headquarters for the Super Bowl is the Cornucopia Majesty, a cruise liner docked in New York Harbor.
lead_paragraph: ABOARD THE CORNUCOPIA MAJESTY, near Jersey City — The light snow and bitter chill that enveloped New York Harbor on Sunday evening might not have meant much to the Denver Broncos, comfortable in the cold. They have been reminded often, however, that this Super Bowl week would be different.

headline: The Influential Minister Behind Argentina’s Economic Shift
abstract: Axel Kicillof, appointed as Argentina’s economy minister in November, has been thrust into the spotlight as much for his sense of style as his policies.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — As Argentina absorbs the shock from a sharp plunge in its currency, President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner’s mercurial young economy minister, Axel Kicillof, a scholar with rockabilly-style sideburns and an aversion to business suits, is emerging as the face of policy shifts that are sending tremors through financial markets around the developing world.

lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Paul Pierce and Kevin Garnett knew what was coming. There would be standing ovations and video tributes. There would be emotional reunions with Celtics officials and former teammates. There might even be a tear shed.

keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Tea Party Movement', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'Computers and the Internet']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The protocol is staid and formulaic. The president addresses Congress on the State of the Union, then the opposition party’s designee follows with a reply.

headline: In South Korea, Spam Is the Stuff Gifts Are Made Of
abstract: With the Korean War, the gelatinous meat began an unlikely journey to South Korea, where it is now so much a part of culinary life that many people have no idea of its origins.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — As the Lunar New Year holiday approaches, Seoul’s increasingly well-heeled residents are scouring store shelves for tastefully wrapped boxes of culinary specialties. Among their favorite choices: imported wines, choice cuts of beef, rare herbal teas. And Spam.

headline: Justice Department Inquiry Takes Aim at Banks’ Business With Payday Lenders
abstract: Federal prosecutors are scrutinizing whether banks have allowed businesses to siphon billions of dollars from consumers’ accounts.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors are trying to thwart the easy access that predatory lenders and dubious online merchants have to Americans’ bank accounts by going after banks that fail to meet their obligations as gatekeepers to the United States financial system.

headline: ‘Downton Abbey’ Recap: A Warning From Mr. Bates
abstract: Daydreaming about an escape to a new job in the kitchen of the Ritz hotel.
lead_paragraph: There are times when recapping “Downton Abbey” can feel a bit like what it must have been like to work at Downton Abbey: events and actions are not necessarily tedious or repetitive, but they start to get … familiar, and you find yourself daydreaming that you too could escape to a new job in the kitchen of the Ritz hotel.

headline: For a Cowboys Star With Dementia, Time Is Running Out
abstract: Rayfield Wright, who sustained countless blows to the head during 13 seasons with the Cowboys, said N.F.L. players do not know what awaits in retirement.
lead_paragraph: WILLOW PARK, Tex. — The Hall of Famer Rayfield Wright’s increasingly imperfect memory retains an indelible image of his first N.F.L. start.

headline: After President’s Breakup, French Wonder if Role of First Lady Is Passé
abstract: The French are sounding fed up with the idea of a first lady in the days after François Hollande’s announcement of the end of his relationship with his longtime companion.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Does it matter if the French president decides to go it alone, without a partner, spouse or female companion by his side, a situation that seems likely to be the next chapter in the messy personal life of François Hollande?

headline: A Giant Photo Connects Fans to Ballet Stars
abstract: A 6,500-square-foot photograph of more than 80 ballet dancers graces the promenade of the David H. Koch Theater. Some guests tiptoed by; others took to posing on the floor.
lead_paragraph: Some richly attired New York City Ballet fans have taken to lying down on the floor at intermissions. Other well-heeled patrons are making the climb from the orchestra to the Fourth Ring for a better view. And social media sites are beginning to fill up with odd images, including several that appear to show Sébastien Marcovici, a principal dancer, partnering perfect strangers.

headline: ‘Girls’ Recap: A Death and Hannah
abstract: After her editor dies, Hannah seems to care only about the fate of her book.

lead_paragraph: SANFORD, Fla. — Before Haley Berg was done with middle school, she had the numbers for 16 college soccer coaches programmed into the iPhone she protected with a Justin Bieber case.

lead_paragraph: Nearly 50 years ago, federal law created a lower minimum wage for workers who receive tips. Congress decreed that it could not be less than 50 percent of the federal minimum wage.

headline: U.S. Market Slump Easing; Europe and Asia Still Sliding
abstract: Stocks continued to fall in Europe and in emerging Asia-Pacific markets as slowing growth in China and the prospect of less stimulus in the United States raised the specter of capital flight.
lead_paragraph: Stocks remained under considerable pressure on Monday after a steep sell-off late last week. Key indexes around the world continued to fall and emerging markets lost more ground in the face of fears of capital flight.

abstract: A meteorologist hired by the National Football League will meet every day this week with its executives, who will expect ever more precision.
lead_paragraph: There comes a moment in so many memorable games when a team will turn its anxious gaze to one player and ask a simple question: You got this covered?

headline: Fighting for Liberal Agenda, Assembly Speaker Finds New Ally in Mayor
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'State Legislatures', 'Law and Legislation', 'Education (Pre-School)', 'Income Tax']
abstract: The relationship between Mayor Bill de Blasio and Sheldon Silver, the Assembly speaker, could help advance their common goals that have become stalled in Albany in recent years.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Sheldon Silver, the speaker of the New York State Assembly, spent more than a decade pushing back against a Republican governor. For even longer, he tangled with a Republican-controlled State Senate. And for the past year, he has fended off withering criticism about his handling of accusations of sexual misconduct in his caucus.

headline: Schumer Proposes ‘Avonte’s Law’ to Protect Children With Autism
abstract: A day after the funeral for Avonte Oquendo, Senator Charles E. Schumer pushed for a new law that would finance a program to provide optional electronic tracking devices for children with autism.
lead_paragraph: The day after the funeral of Avonte Oquendo, the boy with autism whose remains were found this month after he disappeared at age 14 from his school in October, his mother and grandmother stood with Senator Charles E. Schumer as he announced a proposal for a new law. Called “Avonte’s law,” it would finance a program to provide optional electronic tracking devices to be worn by children with autism.

headline: Deputy Mayor for Social Services Now Has a Boss Who Shares Her Agenda
abstract: Lilliam Barrios-Paoli, the new head of health and human services, has a long and respected record of commitment to equality and social justice, and to speaking her mind.
lead_paragraph: Judging from the pictures around her old office last month, there is no question which New York City mayor Lilliam Barrios-Paoli has been most fond of. There was Edward I. Koch sitting pensively at his desk. There he was sitting on a sofa holding hands with her.

lead_paragraph: Several hours after his arrest on burglary charges, a 51-year-old man died in the custody of the New York Police Department on Sunday morning. The police said that initial indications were that he hanged himself in his cell.

abstract: Mr. Haber was the chief labor negotiator for the City of New York from 1966 to 1973, when labor strikes tested the balance of power between the city and its municipal unions.
lead_paragraph: Herbert L. Haber, the chief labor negotiator for the City of New York from 1966 to 1973, when strikes by transit workers, firefighters, the police, teachers and garbage collectors tested the balance of power between the city and its municipal unions, died on Jan. 20 in Auburndale, Mass. He was 89.

headline: Makers Pack New Cars With Technology, but Younger Buyers Shrug
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'North American International Auto Show', 'Small Cars (Compact, Subcompact and Microcars)']
abstract: Manufacturers have produced vehicles more loaded with technology to draw in younger drivers, but those drivers say price and fuel economy remain their prime motivators.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Young, educated and upwardly mobile, Kristin Winn represents the ideal target for automakers trying to reach young buyers. Ms. Winn, a 24-year-old technician for an ophthalmologist, says she plans to replace her nine-year-old Chevrolet Cobalt this year.

headline: Japanese Owner of Uniqlo Aims for Secondary Listing in Hong Kong

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Fast Retailing, the owner of the Japanese apparel retailer Uniqlo, said Monday that it planned to pursue a secondary stock market listing in Hong Kong.

headline: Martin S. Bergmann, Psychoanalyst and an On-Screen Philosopher, Dies at 100
abstract: Mr. Bergmann became known to a wide general audience for his unplanned, much-praised role as a philosopher in Woody Allen’s 1989 film, “Crimes and Misdemeanors.”
lead_paragraph: Martin S. Bergmann, a psychoanalyst, author and educator who became known to a wide general audience for his unplanned, much-praised role as a philosopher in Woody Allen’s 1989 film, “Crimes and Misdemeanors,” died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 100.

headline: Helping Smokers Quit, or Not Start in the First Place
abstract: Images on television and the availability of electronic cigarettes are among the temptations that attract new smokers and weaken the willpower of those who want to quit.
lead_paragraph: “Even 50 years after the first surgeon general’s report on smoking and health, we’re still finding out new ways that tobacco kills and maims people,” Dr. Thomas Frieden, director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, recently told me. “It’s astonishing how bad it is.”

headline: A Night of Music Marked by Some Wild Mood Swings
abstract: The 56th annual Grammy Awards featured jarring shifts in tone and some strange partnerships.
lead_paragraph: The Grammy Awards broadcast, live on CBS from the Staples Center in Los Angeles, cautiously waited until after 11 p.m. to present its segment by Macklemore & Ryan Lewis, a rapper-and-producer team from Seattle. As they performed their song supporting same-sex marriage, “Same Love,” 33 couples, gay and straight, got married; perhaps the worrisome content was not the marriages but an antigay epithet amid the rhymes. It had been a good night for the duo, which was named best new artist and won three rap categories (only the Grammys don’t call it hip-hop). They were joined onstage by Madonna, singing “Open Your Heart”; by Queen Latifah presiding over the vows; and by the song’s chorus singer, Mary Lambert.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Flix) A ROOM WITH A VIEW (1986) An Englishwoman (Helena Bonham Carter, above left with Judi Dench)) is torn between her strait-laced fiancé (Daniel Day-Lewis) and a young bohemian (Julian Sands) in this Merchant-Ivory adaptation of E. M. Forster’s 1908 novel, with an Oscar-winning screenplay by Ruth Prawer Jhabvala. Writing in The New York Times, Vincent Canby said the film “is like a holiday out of time.” In Robert Altman’s “Gosford Park” (2001), at 10, a coterie of aristocrats and their servants gather for a weekend shooting party at a grand English country estate in November 1932, during which their host, Sir William McCordle (Michael Gambon) is murdered. Whodunit? The suspects include Sir William’s chilly wife, Lady Sylvia (Kristin Scott Thomas), and her younger sister (Geraldine Somerville), with whom she cut cards to determine who would snag the man and his millions; the handsome young valet (Ryan Phillippe) on whom Lady Sylvia has set her sights; a gay American movie producer (Bob Balaban, who devised the movie’s concept with Mr. Altman) researching his latest project; the head housemaid (Emily Watson), whose affair with Sir William is common knowledge though never spoken of; and Lady Sylvia’s aunt, the imperious Countess of Trentham (Maggie Smith), whose livelihood is dependent on the allowance that Sir William has threatened to take away. Writing in The Times, Stephen Holden called the film, for which Julian Fellowes won an Oscar for best screenplay, “a melt-in-your-mouth hunk of 12-layer English spice cake.”

headline: Grammys Laud Giants and Upstarts
keywords: ['Grammy Awards', 'Music', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Weddings and Engagements']
abstract: Daft Punk, the French electronic music duo, won album of the year at a ceremony whose celebration of both establishment stars and newcomers reflected a changed music business.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Newcomers, establishment stars and even a pair of French “robots” shared the spotlight at the 56th annual Grammy Awards ceremony on Sunday night, reflecting a changed music business in which top celebrities command constant attention yet a monster hit can come from anywhere.

headline: Japan Official Under Fire for Saying Public Broadcaster Won’t Criticize Government
abstract: Some members of the news media questioned whether NHK, Japan’s influential public broadcaster, was under political pressure to adhere to the views of the right-leaning government.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The head of Japan’s influential public broadcaster drew sharp criticism on Sunday for saying that the broadcaster would refrain from criticizing the right-leaning government on such delicate issues as visits to a controversial shrine honoring war dead. He also said his nation should not be singled out for forcing women into sexual servitude during World War II.

headline: Inside New York City’s Water Towers
abstract: Rooftop water towers are the primary source of drinking water for many New Yorkers, yet frequently they are poorly maintained, and present a potential health hazard.
lead_paragraph: Rooftop water towers are the primary source of drinking water for many New Yorkers, yet frequently they are poorly maintained, and present a potential health hazard.

headline: Wawrinka, Nadal and Two Unforeseen Opponents: Fear and Pain

lead_paragraph: Pain and fear are two subplots that can lurk in the background for athletes.

headline: Inside City’s Water Tanks, Layers of Neglect
abstract: Many of New York City’s iconic water towers have not been cleaned or inspected in years, and regulations governing the tanks are rarely enforced, an examination shows.
lead_paragraph: With their quaint barrel-like contours and weathered cedar-plank sides, rooftop water towers are a constant on the New York City skyline. And though they may look like relics of a past age, millions of residents get their drinking water from the tanks every day.

headline: 30 Seconds With Boomer Esiason
abstract: Former quarterback and current commentator Boomer Esiason weighs in on the Super Bowl, Rex Ryan’s contract extension and the N.F.L.’s concussion settlement.
lead_paragraph: After an all-American career at Maryland, Boomer Esiason played 14 seasons in the N.F.L. as a quarterback for the Cincinnati Bengals, the Jets and the Arizona Cardinals. He was selected to the Pro Bowl four times and he was named the league’s most valuable player in 1988. Esiason ended his career with 2,969 completions, 5,205 pass attempts, a 57 percent completion mark , 247 touchdown passes and 37,920 yards passing.

headline: The Friend, Till I Was Widowed
abstract: He seemed like such a good friend to my husband and me, and then when I was widowed, there were some things I decidedly didn’t like.
lead_paragraph: You couldn’t ask for a more helpful friend. If my husband had trouble with the lawn mower, our friend would say, “I’ll take a look,” and after tinkering for a few minutes, the mower would be humming — put, put, put — away.

headline: South Korea Proposes Dates to North for Family Reunions

headline: On Bad Air Days in India, Staying Inside Doesn’t Help
abstract: Poor indoor air quality, along with outdoor pollution, may help explain why Indians have among the weakest lungs in the world.

headline: A Sudanese Refugee Crisis, Photographed From the Ground Up
keywords: ['Humanitarian Aid', 'Photography', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Walking']
abstract: The photographer Shannon Jensen struggled to make pictures as vivid and dramatic as the stories of the refugees she met in South Sudan, until she realized she needed to simplify.
lead_paragraph: Shannon Jensen traveled to South Sudan almost two years ago intent on drawing global attention to the country’s refugee crisis, where more than 100,000 people had walked hundreds of miles to escape Sudan’s brutal war.

headline: What Is Your Reaction to Richard Sherman’s Postgame Interview?

headline: Moody’s Cuts Rating on Sony to Junk
abstract: The agency suggested that the prospects for a turnaround in the Japanese company’s electronics business were poor.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Moody’s said Monday that it had downgraded its credit rating on Sony to junk status, citing the deepening woes of the company’s consumer electronics business.

headline: India and China, Besieged by Air Pollution
abstract: India’s air pollution is often worse than the levels recorded in China, but in China there’s much more awareness of the problem.
lead_paragraph: The United States space agency published a map in September that showed how rates of premature deaths from air pollution vary around the world. It indicated that northern China has one of the worst rates, attributed to the density of a deadly fine particulate matter, known as PM 2.5, that often results from coal burning. The map was based on data collected by a research team led by Jason West, an earth scientist at the University of North Carolina.

headline: Don’t Undermine the Iran Deal
abstract: New sanctions will alienate our allies and embolden hard-liners.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THERE are only two ways to keep Iran from developing a nuclear weapon: negotiations or military action.

headline: Turkey’s Wrong Turn
abstract: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan is leading the country on a risky path.
lead_paragraph: Turkey’s prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, was in Brussels last week seeking to repair relations with Europe, but the first place to look for a solution is within himself. Once hailed as the leader of a model Muslim democracy, he has created a political disaster at home, transforming Turkey into an authoritarian state that poses dangers not just for itself but for its allies in NATO, including the United States.

headline: New York Today: Signing On
abstract: What you need to know for Monday: city signs get the new mayor’s name, weirdly normal weather and Super Bowl week descends on the city.

headline: Warburg Pincus Hires Former Mining Chief at ArcelorMittal
abstract: As part of a push into mining investments, the private equity firm Warburg Pincus has hired a former top executive in ArcelorMittal’s mining operations, Peter Kukielski.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The private equity firm Warburg Pincus has hired Peter Kukielski, a former chief executive of ArcelorMittal’s mining business, as it examines potential investments in that industry.

headline: Ryno: Electric, Urban Transportation on One Wheel
abstract: With an electric unicycle occupying a niche between a motor scooter and a Segway, Ryno Motors hopes to change urban transportation.
lead_paragraph: When was the last time you saw a mall security officer on a Segway? The two-wheel, gyroscopically balanced personal transporters certainly make officers taller, but whether standing on a Segway makes the rider look imposing or goofy is a matter of interpretation.

headline: Super Bowl XLVIII, by the Numbers
abstract: There is a lot you can learn about the Super Bowl in just over two minutes. Here are the most important figures to know about the big game.
lead_paragraph: There is a lot you can learn about the Super Bowl in just over two minutes. Here are the most important figures to know about the big game.

headline: Uber and a Child’s Death
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Driver Distraction and Fatigue', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: A lawsuit set to be filed on Monday seeks to unravel the biggest question of the so-called sharing economy: Who is responsible when things go wrong?
lead_paragraph: Travis Kalanick, chief executive of the on-demand transportation service Uber, originally used “The Fountainhead” as his Twitter icon. It was viewed by many as a proclamation: Ayn Rand’s novel is beloved by Silicon Valley’s regulation-is-useless crowd, and Uber is in too much of a hurry to want anyone slowing it down with questions about safety and responsibility.

headline: How We Increased Productivity on the Shop Floor
abstract: For 27 years, my main worry has been whether we will find new customers. At the beginning of 2013 I realized that selling was no longer my biggest problem — that I needed to turn my attention to making sure the shop floor could keep up with the sales team.
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of last year, I started using a new technique to analyze my numbers: the trailing sum or average. In a nutshell, you track a set of numbers looking back from the present, at regular intervals, and see how the results change over time. Doing so shows patterns that can be hard to see if you are used to looking at calendar years — it’s as if every month represents the end of the year. It also smooths out variations in shorter time periods. Over all, I find it a useful way to track progress.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Jan. 27, 2014
abstract: On Mondays, we publish a Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by posting about what you see, and why. A live discussion is offered from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. Eastern time.
lead_paragraph: Update: Jan. 28, 2014

abstract: The deal for Sedgwick Claims Management Services is the latest multibillion-dollar transaction by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts in recent months.
lead_paragraph: The private equity giant Kohlberg Kravis Roberts agreed on Monday to buy Sedgwick Claims Management Services, a provider of insurance claims processing, for $2.4 billion.

headline: Daily Report: Uber’s Challenge to Taxis Runs Afoul of Lawsuits and Regulators
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Smartphones', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Uber, the hot start-up whose software allows anyone with a smartphone to get a cab ride, is suddenly facing trouble.
lead_paragraph: Travis Kalanick, who is brash and aggressive even by the standards of Silicon Valley, created Uber four years ago to blow up the traditional taxi business. In more than 60 cities, from San Francisco to Berlin, it is doing just that, David Streitfeld reports.

headline: AT&T Denies Pursuit of Vodafone
abstract: The denial came after speculation over the weekend that AT&T might be looking to acquire Vodafone, which agreed last year to sell its 45 percent stake in Verizon Wireless to Verizon Communications for $130 billion.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – AT&T announced on Monday that it was not in talks to buy the European telecommunications giant Vodafone.

lead_paragraph: Suzy Menkes talks to designer Paul Smith about his latest collection and his recent museum exhibit.

headline: Anger Over Venture Capitalist’s Letter
abstract: A venture capitalist’s letter in The Wall Street Journal spurs outrage and confusion. | The Justice Department takes aim at banks’ business with payday lenders. | Dimon’s pay increase gets mixed reactions. | Liberty Global to buy Ziggo. | Google gets into artificial intelligence for $400 million.
lead_paragraph: The San Francisco techno-elite and local activists have not been on good terms in recent weeks, but it may be wise to tread carefully when writing about the latest tensions. In a letter published in The Wall Street Journal on Saturday, Tom Perkins, a founder of the venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, wondered if “progressive radicalism” indicated the possibility of a new Kristallnacht.

headline: Finding a Place in the Hip-Hop Ecosystem
abstract: The rapper Macklemore’s apology to Kendrick Lamar for winning best rap album at the Grammys flamed a debate over the genre’s boundaries.
lead_paragraph: A couple of hours after the Grammys on Sunday night, Macklemore sent a text to Kendrick Lamar, whom he had just beaten for best rap album.

headline: Two Relief Camps in Uttar Pradesh Settle Into Permanency
keywords: ['Brick and Tile', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Hinduism', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Indian Rupee (Currency)', 'Land Use Policies', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: Muslims who fled religious violence in the western part of the state have started building brick houses, having resisted all efforts by the local authorities to get them to move on.
lead_paragraph: BHURA CAMP, Uttar Pradesh — The Bhura relief camp set up for Muslims who were fleeing violent clashes with Hindu-Jats in western Uttar Pradesh over four months ago is starting to look more like permanent settlements, despite the local authorities’ efforts to force residents to move out. Residents here say this is the first camp to become a colony.

headline: BG Group Warns of Gas Problems in Egypt
abstract: The company shocked financial markets by announcing it was unable to export enough liquefied natural gas from Egypt.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The BG Group, the large British oil and gas producer, shocked financial markets on Monday by announcing that it was breaking contracts with customers and lenders because it was unable to export enough liquefied natural gas from Egypt, its largest producing area.

headline: Journalists on the Environment Beat Look Ahead
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Biodiversity', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Clean Air Act', 'Coal', 'Corporations', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Energy and Power', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Invasive Species', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Typhoon Haiyan (2013)']
abstract: Seasoned journalists covering the environment explore themes that will be in headlines this year, and some that won’t, but should be.
lead_paragraph: I was invited by the Wilson Center to participate on Friday in a discussion with other journalists of environmental issues that will be in the headlines this year and going forward. (The session was co-sponsored by the Society of Environmental Journalists.)

headline: Study Puts Price Tag on ‘Too Big to Fail’
abstract: An analysis commissioned by the Green Party in the European Parliament estimates that the cost of the implicit guarantee that governments will back large financial institutions was about 234 billion euros in 2012.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – An analysis commissioned by the Green Party in the European Parliament estimates that the cost of the implicit guarantee that governments will back large financial institutions, known as “too big to fail,” was about 234 billion euros in 2012.

headline: Syria Talks Appear Deadlocked as Sides Disagree Over Goals
abstract: Differences over the basic purpose of negotiations, as well as a government relief gesture for civilians that the opposition denounced as a ploy, hampered the talks.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The first face-to-face peace talks by antagonists in the Syria conflict appeared to deadlock on Monday, with enormous differences over the basic purpose of negotiations as well as a government relief gesture for civilians that the opposition denounced as a ploy. But both sides expressed willingness to resume talking.

headline: Dancers at Their Feet
abstract: City Ballet fans posed with their favorite dancers in a giant photo installation on the floor of the David H. Koch Theater.
lead_paragraph: City Ballet fans posed with their favorite dancers in a giant photo installation on the floor of the David H. Koch Theater.

headline: 2014 Grammy Awards: Big Winners
keywords: ['Grammy Awards', 'Music', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Times reporter Jon Pareles discusses the 56th annual Grammy Awards ceremony.
lead_paragraph: Times reporter Jon Pareles discusses the 56th annual Grammy Awards ceremony.

headline: Bitcoin and the Fictions of Money
abstract: Beyond the basics, all money is make-believe. We turn paper dollars into grilled steaks when both trust the United States government. That makes Bitcoin the latest sign that its tech elite believers want something beyond the old nation state. Other math-based borderless currencies, and likely more to come, signify their own values.
lead_paragraph: How should we think about a currency like Bitcoin? The first thing to remember is this: Money is a sort of collective fiction. What money we choose to trust says much about how we see the world.

headline: New G.M. Chief Vows to Support Opel
abstract: Mary Barra said the company would invest in the Opel flagship factory near Frankfurt by adding a third model line.
lead_paragraph: RÜSSELSHEIM, Germany — In her first trip abroad since becoming chief executive of General Motors in mid-January, Mary T. Barra on Monday underscored the company’s commitment to its troubled Opel unit. She promised to invest in the flagship factory in this city near Frankfurt by adding a third, unspecified, model line.

headline: Ukraine’s Leader to Revoke Curbs on Dissent, but Opposition Remains Wary
abstract: President Viktor F. Yanukovych agreed to revoke new laws restricting political dissent, but two opposition leaders rebuffed his offer to be named prime minister and vice prime minister.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Still struggling to contain a national civil uprising, President Viktor F. Yanukovych of Ukraine agreed late Monday to revoke a package of new laws severely restricting political dissent, but a wider accord to defuse the crisis remained out of reach, officials said.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
abstract: Glenmorangie named BSUR, Amsterdam, to handle the global communications account for its whisky, and Moddern Marketing, New York, opened its doors.
lead_paragraph: Stan Adler Associates, New York, part of the CHR Group, opened an office in Toronto.

headline: Congressman in Drug Case Resigns Seat in Florida
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: A growing number of prominent Republicans had urged the resignation of their fellow party member, Representative Trey Radel, who pleaded guilty last year to buying cocaine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Trey Radel, Republican of Florida, who pleaded guilty in November to a misdemeanor charge of buying 3.5 grams of cocaine and was sentenced to a year of probation, resigned from Congress effective Monday evening.

headline: Cabbage and Pepper Chakchoukah
abstract: This is a spicy Tunisian pepper stew with poached eggs.
lead_paragraph: I love the spicy Tunisian pepper stew with eggs poached in it, called chakchoukah. I substituted cabbage for some of the peppers and love this new version.

headline: Bruschetta With Cabbage Braised in Wine
abstract: Long-simmered cabbage provides a sweet flavor for this bruschetta.
lead_paragraph: The wine-braised cabbage is adapted from a recipe in “Cooking From an Italian Garden,” by Paola Scaravelli and Jon Cohen. If you don’t cook with wine, substitute vegetable stock, chicken stock or water for the wine. You could also top the bruschetta with a simpler cabbage sauté, but I love the sweet flavor of the long-simmered cabbage.

headline: Cabbage and Parmesan Soup With Barley
abstract: A comforting soup with texture and bulk provided by barley.
lead_paragraph: Parmesan rinds, simmered here in the same way that a ham bone might be used in France or Italy, contribute great depth of flavor to this wonderful, comforting soup. I love the added texture and bulk provided by the barley.

headline: Cabbage Pirozhki
abstract: A rich-tasting Eastern European pastry that isn’t rich at all.
lead_paragraph: Of all the different fillings for the small oval Russian pies called pirozhki, cabbage has always been my favorite. The filling is a simple mixture of onions and cabbage, cooked in butter (traditionally in much more than I use here), until soft and sweet but not browned, then seasoned with dill, salt and pepper, and enriched with chopped hard-boiled eggs. I sometimes add a little ricotta to the mix. Traditional pirozhki dough is a rich pastry made with butter and sour cream. I tried my yeasted whole wheat olive oil pastry and it worked beautifully.

headline: Cabbage and Ricotta Timbale
abstract: A light timbale with a sweet, delicate flavor.
lead_paragraph: I use the same filling that I used for pirozhkis in this light timbale. You can make the timbales in individual molds or make one larger mold.

headline: Jane Lynch on the Delicate Art of Awards Humor
abstract: At the Directors Guild of America awards, Alfonso Cuarón took home the prize for “Gravity” but the host, Jane Lynch, pulled off the difficult rick of joking about “12 Years a Slave,”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — All season long, awards show hosts, tasked with being flip about this year’s cinematic hopefuls, have faced the major comedic stumbling block of “12 Years a Slave.” How to make light of one of the most grotesque periods of humanity? Amy Poehler, at the Golden Globes, quipped that after seeing the movie, she “would never look at slavery the same way again.” (Tina Fey: “Wait, how were you looking at it?”) At the Directors Guild awards on Saturday, the M.C., Jane Lynch, handled it this way: “12 Years a Slave,” she said, is “the story of an educated black man trying to prove his real identity to those that wanted to bring him down — or as Barack Obama calls it, ‘Tuesday.’”

headline: Goodbye to the Doctor’s White Coat?
abstract: New recommendations on what health care workers should wear may signal an end to the doctor’s white coat.
lead_paragraph: New recommendations on what health care workers should wear may mean an end to the doctor’s white coat.

headline: Even With Changes, Pro Bowl Is Tough to Watch. And Commentate.
abstract: Rules changes and celebrity captains cannot change the essence of what remains a meaningless, but well-watched, affair.
lead_paragraph: Late in Sunday’s Pro Bowl broadcast, NBC’s Cris Collinsworth credited the intensity of Deion Sanders and Jerry Rice, who selected the teams in a draft on the NFL Network, for the better-than-usual level of play in a game often known for minimal effort.

headline: Irving Milchberg, Who Smuggled Guns Under Nazis’ Noses, Dies at 86
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Concentration Camps']
abstract: As a street urchin in Warsaw, Mr. Milchberg managed to escape being sent to concentration camps while he smuggled guns and food to the resistance.
lead_paragraph: Irving Milchberg, who as a plucky Jewish street urchin escaped transport to concentration camps three times and sold cigarettes to Nazis in the heart of occupied Warsaw while smuggling guns and food to resistance fighters, died on Sunday in Toronto. He was 86.

headline: Egypt’s Ruler Eyes Riskier Role: The Presidency
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi, who ousted Egypt’s first freely elected president, Mohamed Morsi, said he was yielding to the will of the people in taking the first formal step to run for the office himself.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — When Egypt’s first freely elected president, Mohamed Morsi, named Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi defense minister, the officer pledged to keep the military out of politics and make way for civilian democracy.

headline: Tale of Magical Squirrel Takes Newbery Medal
abstract: Kate DiCamillo’s “Flora and Ulysses” won this year’s Newbery Medal, and the Randolph Caldecott Medal went to Brian Floca’s “Locomotive.”
lead_paragraph: Kate DiCamillo, who was recently named the national ambassador for young people’s literature, received another one of the field’s highest honors on Monday: The John Newbery Medal went to her book “Flora and Ulysses” (Candlewick Press), the story of a girl who befriends a squirrel with magical powers.

headline: Profits Up, Wages Down: What Economics Has to Say
keywords: ['Income', 'Income Inequality', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Productivity', 'United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: A slack labor market and its constraints on employees’ bargaining power — not a slackening of productivity — are primarily responsible for the both the lag in wages and the surge in profits, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: Image of the Day: January 27
abstract: Folk dancers during a reception at Rashtrapati Bhawan in New Delhi.

headline: German at Center of Looted-Art Case Is Said to Consider Restitution Claims
abstract: Hannes Hartung, a Munich-based attorney who began representing Mr. Gurlitt earlier this month, said in a telephone interview on Monday that his client was interested in a “fair and just solution.”
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Cornelius Gurlitt, the elderly German owner of a trove of artworks that include works by Chagall, Picasso and Munch, is willing to consider restitution claims for pieces in the collection that may have been stolen by the Nazis, his lawyer said.

headline: Egyptian Journalist Explains Hunger Strike in Prison Letter
abstract: An Egyptian journalist for Al Jazeera who was detained in August while covering the bloody crackdown on an Islamist sit-in in Cairo has embarked on a hunger strike, according to a letter from prison posted online by his family on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Abdullah Elshamy, an Egyptian journalist for Al Jazeera who was detained in August while covering the bloody crackdown on an Islamist sit-in in Cairo, has embarked on a hunger strike, according to a letter from prison that was posted online by his family on Monday.

abstract: In “All Joy and No Fun,” Jennifer Senior looks at the finding that children do not improve their parents’ happiness.
lead_paragraph: In “All Joy and No Fun,” Jennifer Senior looks at the finding that children do not improve their parents’ happiness.

headline: The Source | Alice Waters
abstract: Doug Aitken interviews Alice Waters.
lead_paragraph: Doug Aitken interviews Alice Waters.

headline: Nazi Remarks Make Perkins Persona Non Grata in Silicon Valley
abstract: Amid the blog posts and tweets condemning Thomas J. Perkins for comparing criticism of the wealthy in America to Nazi attacks on Jews, some commentators saw evidence of a more widespread attitude among the very rich.
lead_paragraph: Thomas J. Perkins, an elite investor in Silicon Valley, provoked outrage and shock over the weekend when he compared criticism of the wealthy to Nazi attacks on Jews.

headline: Age-Appropriate Chores for Children (and Why They’re Not Doing Them)
abstract: Of all the things I thought might be difficult about having children, I never realized it would be so much work to get them to do any work.
lead_paragraph: This Montessori chart of “Age-Appropriate Chores for Children” is making the Facebook rounds. (The shares on my page came from  the Facebook page of “Maria Montessori.”) With it, the commentary. Apparently, a lot of “other parents” have complained about this list. Those “other parents” say things like “children aren’t slaves” and “carrying firewood is dangerous!” Scroll down, and you do find those parents, noting that the label on the cleaning supplies says to “keep away from children,” and so they do, and what 10-year-old can mow the lawn? Who would trust a 12-year-old with hedge clippers?

headline: The Source | Alice Waters in Conversation With Doug Aitken
abstract: In our latest installment of this exclusive series of interviews by Doug Aitken, the artist interviews the chef and food activist Alice Waters.
lead_paragraph: “I think if you buy from people who are taking care of the land,” Alice Waters says, “you’re supporting the future of this country.” The chef activist speaks to Doug Aitken in Berkeley, Calif., at an Edible Schoolyard, her project to educate students about agriculture, economy and the environment. The interview is part of the Source, a series of candid video conversations with several dozen noteworthy figures about their creative processes, currently on view in a custom pavilion at the Sundance Film Festival.

headline: Wawrinka’s Title Shakes Up the Rankings, but Not the Hierarchy
abstract: Stanislas Wawrinka captured his first major title at the Australian Open, defeating Novak Djokovic and Rafael Nadal along the way. But his victory wasn’t enough to crack the Big Four.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — For nine years now, four players have defined an era of men’s tennis, their play so consistent the rest of the ATP World Tour seemed to exist on another planet. There was Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal, Novak Djokovic and Andy Murray, and then there was everybody else.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Corvettes Sweep Top Four Spots at Daytona 24-Hour
abstract: The Corvettes took the Daytona Prototype class in a race where a crash seriously injured one driver.
lead_paragraph: Chevrolet Corvettes in the Daytona Prototype class swept the top four positions in the Rolex 24 endurance race, which ended Sunday at Daytona Beach, Fla. João Barbosa managed to hold off Max Angelelli to take the checkered flag by just 1.5 seconds after 695 laps in 24 hours.

headline: Senior Justice Department Attorney to Join Morrison & Foerster
abstract: Charles Duross, who led the Justice Department’s unit that enforces the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, is joining the law firm Morrison & Foerster as head of its global anticorruption practice.
lead_paragraph: Charles Duross, a senior attorney at the Justice Department who once prosecuted a congressman who hid $90,000 in his freezer, has decided to join the law firm of Morrison & Foerster as head of its global anticorruption practice.

headline: Tom Gola, a Philadelphia Basketball Legend, Dies at 81
abstract: Gola, still the Division I record-holder in career rebounds, led La Salle to the National Invitation Tournament title in 1952 and the N.C.A.A. title in 1954 before helping the Philadelphia Warriors to the N.B.A. title in 1956.
lead_paragraph: Tom Gola, a virtual folk hero in Philadelphia for his basketball exploits there in high school, college and the pros in the 1950s, died on Sunday in Meadowbrook, Pa. He was 81.

headline: De Blasio, on Cuomo’s Turf, Stands By Pre-K Strategy
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio testified before the State Legislature, saying a city-specific income tax increase would be “predictable and consistent,” unlike Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s promise of state financing.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — He did not plead for money. He did not seek to extract promises about a long list of legislation. And he was not interested in picking a fight.

headline: Bair, Critic of the Revolving Door, Joins Board of Santander
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Sheila C. Bair, who ran the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, once argued that former regulators should be barred from joining the banks they oversaw.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:37 p.m. | Sheila C. Bair, a former head of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation who once argued that former regulators should be barred from joining the banks they oversaw, is joining the board of Banco Santander, the Spanish bank said on Monday.

headline: The Princess Problem
abstract: Can a prince meet his true love within 30 days?
lead_paragraph: This week’s puzzle was suggested by Dave Penneys, a mathematics postdoctoral fellow at the University of Toronto.

headline: Of Course the Condo Has a Gym, but What About a Personal Shopper?
abstract: As developers compete over ultra-wealthy home buyers in New York, the list of building amenities is growing longer and quirkier.
lead_paragraph: On Central Park South, a luxury building is offering its residents direct access to Bergdorf Goodman’s buyers, who can find them that special accessory from Paris. In TriBeCa, a developer hired educators from the 92nd Street Y to design the basement playroom.

headline: A Discredited Supreme Court Ruling That Still, Technically, Stands
keywords: ['Detainees', 'Japanese-Americans', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Korematsu v United States (Supreme Court Decision)']
abstract: Korematsu v. United States, the 1944 decision endorsing the mass detention of Japanese-Americans during World War II, has long been thoroughly discredited — but the court has not yet repudiated it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court’s 1944 decision in Korematsu v. United States was a disaster. In endorsing an executive order that required 110,000 Americans of Japanese ancestry to be removed from their homes and confined in detention camps, the court relied on wartime hysteria streaked with racism, sullying its reputation and damaging the constitutional principles it was meant to uphold.

headline: The Read Around: Video of Jennifer Senior
abstract: Ms. Senior discusses her new book, “All Joy and No Fun: The Paradox of Modern Parenthood.”
lead_paragraph: In “The Read Around,” a weekly video feature, authors discuss the when, where and how behind their books. Above, Jennifer Senior discusses “All Joy and No Fun,” her investigation into how children affect their parents’ happiness.

abstract: Also on the Minute, the U.S. drone mission at risk and the cost of the Sochi Games.
