headline: At New York Hotel, a Crowd-Sourced Lego Project
abstract: At the Yotel New York, guests are invited to work on a collaborative art project that features Lego bricks.
lead_paragraph: In a lemonade-from-lemons move, Yotel New York, the capsule hotel near Times Square, has turned a construction-masking wall into a 30-foot collaborative art project using Lego building blocks.

headline: New Running Shoe Line Says, ‘Come Fly With Me’
abstract: The Great Society is the creative agency for the lighthearted Brooks Sports campaign, which is scheduled to introduce the Transcend line of footwear Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, phrases like “ultimate plush ride,” “smooth ride” and “softest ride” were routinely found in ads for luxury automobiles. Now, a leading brand of running shoe is borrowing them for a campaign for a new product line.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
abstract: A push to get everyone on the Internet, and the story behind Wendy’s redheaded pitchwoman.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week.

headline: The Stealth ‘Saturday Night Live’ Oscar Campaign
abstract: Jonah Hill’s turn as host was a savvy way to endear himself to audiences and Academy voters at the same time.
lead_paragraph: Comedy may only get respect at the Academy Awards when it’s dressed up as drama, but the most memorable moments in “American Hustle” and “The Wolf of Wall Street” are the ones played for laughs. And the savviest awards players know that poking fun at themselves is a surefire way to endear themselves to audiences (and Academy voters).

headline: Artistic Director Extends Contract for Mozart Week in Salzburg
abstract: Marc Minkowski is to lead the annual celebration of Mozart’s music, presented by the Salzburg Mozarteum Foundation, through 2017.
lead_paragraph: The French conductor Marc Minkowski has renewed his term as artistic director of Mozart Week, the annual celebration of Mozart’s music presented by the Salzburg Mozarteum Foundation, the foundation announced on Monday. The festival typically runs during the week that includes Mozart’s birthday (Jan. 27) in Salzburg, the Austrian city where he was born. Mr. Minkowski’s term will run through the 2017 festival.

headline: Spy Agencies Tap Data Streaming From Phone Apps
abstract: As personal data pour onto mobile networks, American and British eavesdroppers are prying into so-called leaky apps to extract geographical data, address books and phone logs, secret documents show.
lead_paragraph: When a smartphone user opens Angry Birds, the popular game application, and starts slinging birds at chortling green pigs, spies could be lurking in the background to snatch data revealing the player’s location, age, sex and other personal information, according to secret British intelligence documents.

headline: In Recruiting Game, Wall Street Still Competes
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Careers and Professions', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: As this year’s recruiting season begins, some college students say they are drawn to the challenge and fast-paced environment. Still others are, naturally, motivated by the high salaries that Wall Street offers.
lead_paragraph: Despite the refrain that the financial crisis has discouraged students from pursuing jobs in finance, the number of elite students who continue to seek lucrative positions at financial firms indicates that Wall Street has not yet lost its luster.

headline: A Fed Policy Maker, Changing His Mind, Urges More Stimulus
abstract: Narayana Kocherlakota, president of the Minneapolis Fed, said the central bank should increase its efforts to stimulate the economy.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Narayana R. Kocherlakota, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, was once a leading opponent of the Federal Reserve’s efforts to stimulate the economy. Today, he has emerged as the only senior official arguing publicly that the Fed should do even more.

headline: European Telecommunications Companies May Follow Cable’s Lead
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: The latest in a string of cable tie-ups sees Liberty Global, John Malone’s company, take full control of its Dutch rival Ziggo. Deal making has proved trickier for telecommunications companies, but activity should start to rise, Quentin Webb writes in Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: European telecommunications companies may well follow cable’s lead on acquisitions. The latest in a string of cable tie-ups involved Liberty Global, John Malone’s consolidator, which took full control of its Dutch rival Ziggo for 10 billion euros, or $13.7 billion, including debt. Among telecommunications companies, deal-making has proved trickier. But here, too, activity should start to rise.

headline: Afghanistan Moves Closer to Freeing 37 Detainees
keywords: ['Detainees', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Despite renewed efforts by American officials to stop the process, the Afghan government issued formal release orders for dozens of detainees regarded as dangerous insurgents.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Despite American protests, the Afghan government has issued formal release orders for 37 prisoners who are regarded by the NATO-led coalition as dangerous insurgents responsible for the deaths of Americans and Afghans. The release orders set the stage for a renewed confrontation between President Hamid Karzai and the United States.

headline: Today in Small Business: Data Breaches
abstract: Gas prices fall. How PayPal is changing. Another retailer may have had a data breach.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: For the Unemployed, State Help Isn’t Enough
abstract: When federal jobless benefits expired on Dec. 28, 1.3 million long-term unemployed Americans were abruptly cut off.
lead_paragraph: Congressional Republicans who oppose extending federal unemployment benefits are saying, in effect, that state-provided jobless benefits are adequate.

headline: U.N. Council Resolution Urges No Ransom to Terrorists
abstract: The Security Council unanimously passed a resolution pressing governments around the world not to pay ransom money to terrorist kidnappers.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations Security Council on Monday pressed governments around the world not to pay ransom money to terrorist kidnappers. The resolution, submitted by Britain and unanimously passed by the 15-member Council, is not enforceable, nor does it resolve the longstanding dispute at the United Nations over the definition of a terrorist. The British ambassador to the United Nations, Mark Lyall Grant, told reporters the resolution was intended to send a message to terrorist organizations like Al Qaeda that rely on ransom payments as a major source of financing. “We need to be honest about the impact ransoms have in sustaining terrorist activity,” the ambassador said. Governments rarely confirm, let alone publicly discuss, the details of ransom payments to kidnappers. The resolution applies only to payments to terrorist organizations, not other types of kidnappers.

headline: With Flowers and Security, Maryland Mall Reopens
abstract: The Mall in Columbia reopened with tight security as the police continued to investigate the background of the suspect in the shooting there, Darion Aguilar.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, Md. — Shoppers returned on Monday to the Maryland mall where a shooting two days earlier in a skateboard and apparel store left three people dead.

headline: Past Sins Haunting Royal Bank of Scotland
abstract: The bank said it would set aside £3 billion, or nearly $5 billion, to cover litigation losses tied to soured mortgage-backed securities and other assets sold before the financial crisis began.
lead_paragraph: Nearly six years after the financial crisis, the sins of the past still weigh heavily on the Royal Bank of Scotland.

headline: Why I Use Snapchat: It’s Fast, Ugly and Ephemeral
abstract: Adults often wonder why children use Snapchat. The answer is partly because the service is intended to be incredibly quick and really ugly.
lead_paragraph: “Question: Do you use Snapchat?” a friend asked me in a text message last week. “I can’t find anyone that actually uses it.”

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Amy Chozick on Her Adventures in Hillaryland
abstract: The writer of this week’s cover story explains how she navigates the innerworkings of Hillary Clinton’s political circle.
lead_paragraph: Amy Chozick, a political reporter for The Times, wrote this week’s cover story about the people who are readying themselves for Hillary Clinton‘s possible run for the presidency in 2016.Since July, your full-time beat at The Times has been the Clintons. How did you choose this aspect of Hillary Clinton’s political future for lengthier treatment?When I moved onto this beat, friends and colleagues said, “You’re going to cover one person for the next four years?!” But with Hillary Clinton, it’s never just one person (or even three people, with President Clinton and Chelsea). I found out that there is a huge cast of characters the Clintons have collected over the years. Their perspective and place in this world is an essential part of who Hillary is and what her future might look like. A person who went to Georgetown with Bill Clinton told me lots of his classmates were thinking about running for president, but only Clinton was building his cabinet. They’re unique in American politics in that they’ve collected so many people over the years — from Arkansas to the White House and to whatever she does in the future. I wanted to explore that dynamic, and the benefits of having such an enormous brain trust, but also the downside to having so many voices who all have a stake in 2016.

headline: Portraits at Sundance
keywords: ['Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Movies']
abstract: The photographer Henny Garfunkel worked with actors and directors at this year’s film festival.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Henny Garfunkel worked with actors and directors at this year’s film festival.

headline: Judge Throws Out Racketeering Claims Filed by Cohen’s Ex-Wife
abstract: A judge narrowed the scope of a civil lawsuit filed by Patricia Cohen, Steven A. Cohen’s ex-wife. He said the legal squabbles restore “faith in the old-fashioned idea that divorce is something that lasts forever.”
lead_paragraph: A legal battle between the billionaire investor Steven A. Cohen and his ex-wife, Patricia, will continue for a while longer, but a federal judge considerably narrowed the scope of a civil lawsuit filed by the former Mrs. Cohen, who is seeking millions of dollars in damages.

headline: Grammys Broadcast Draws More Than 28 Million Viewers
abstract: The awards show was moved up from February to avoid the Winter Olympics and the Super Bowl, a strategy that paid off for CBS.
lead_paragraph: Live events continue to defy the general drift of viewers away from network television as this year’s edition of the Grammy Awards proved convincingly.

headline: The Endless Interview Process
abstract: A variety of reports indicate that the job interview process is lengthier than it was four years ago, even as jobs remain vacant longer.
lead_paragraph: In my “It’s the Economy” on Sunday, I mentioned that the job application process has dragged on and on for many Americans. This is a subject I wrote about last year. I’ve heard anecdotes about very long hoop-jumping processes, and so I asked Glassdoor, a site that collects user-submitted information on hiring at different companies, to check for any discernible trends in the duration of the job application gantlet.

headline: Holocaust Scholar Returns Top Award to Hungary in Protest
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: Randolph L. Braham, a Holocaust survivor and professor, said the government’s effort to whitewash the country’s role in the death of Jews had shocked him.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A prominent Hungarian-American Holocaust scholar, Randolph L. Braham, said on Sunday he is returning a high state award to Hungary to protest what he called the government’s efforts to whitewash the country’s collusion in the murder of hundreds of thousands of Jews during the Second World War.

headline: Google Acquires British Artificial Intelligence Developer
abstract: Google has acquired DeepMind, a British start-up whose founders include Demis Hassabis, a computer game designer, neuroscientist and former child chess prodigy.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As it aims to build driverless cars and the next generation of robots, Google said on Monday that it had acquired the British artificial intelligence developer DeepMind.

headline: Photos, Fun and a Free Lunch
abstract: The deadline to apply for the second annual — and still free — New York Portfolio Review is Feb. 10. We have an updated list of reviewers, and answers to some of your questions.
lead_paragraph: There’s no such thing as a free lunch, you say?

headline: Weekend Gun Report: January 24-26, 2014
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday morning, Brianna Benlolo, 21, and Tyler Johnson, 25, were shot and killed as they worked at a skate shop at the Mall in Columbia in suburban Baltimore, Md. The suspected shooter, Darion Marcus Aguilar, 19, then killed himself.

headline: Seen on the Street | High-Altitude Style at the Sundance Film Festival
abstract: This year’s event brought a preponderance of rugged looks, including burly boots and Western-style outerwear.
lead_paragraph: This year’s event brought a preponderance of rugged looks, including burly boots and Western-style outerwear.

headline: The Strange (and Welcome) Case of a Political Story With No Anonymity
abstract: A profile of Senator Rand Paul names every source, a praiseworthy change of pace.
lead_paragraph: The profile of Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky in Sunday’s Times was notable for many reasons. It was a fascinating and well-researched read on the libertarian Republican who could prove to be an important figure as 2016 nears. It quotes Mitt Romney as calling him “a serious contender for the Republican nomination.”

headline: Au Revoir, Valérie
abstract: Valérie Trierweiler is in India on a two-day charity trip, appearing perfectly poised days after her breakup with the French president, François Hollande.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Just hours after President François Hollande announced over the weekend that he had split up with Valérie Trierweiler, de facto first lady of France, Ms. Trierweiler arrived in the Indian city of Mumbai on Sunday, looking composed, perfectly coiffed and resolute, even as she was swarmed by paparazzi.

headline: Scarlett Johansson’s Defense of SodaStream Factory in Occupied West Bank Fails to Sway Critics
abstract: In a statement released late Friday, the actress Scarlett Johansson rejected criticism of her new endorsement deal with SodaStream, which manufactures home carbonation systems in an Israeli settlement on occupied West Bank territory.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:30 p.m. | In a statement released late Friday, the actress Scarlett Johansson rejected criticism of her new endorsement deal with SodaStream, which manufactures home carbonation systems in an Israeli settlement, from opponents of Israel’s continued occupation of the West Bank territory it seized in 1967.

headline: Scientists’ Anxieties and Sonic Wonders
abstract: Events and reading matter at the intersection of science and culture.
lead_paragraph: Events and reading matter at the intersection of science and culture.

headline: Behind the Poster: ‘Yentl’
abstract: A look at the poster design for the Cleveland Play House production of the play “Yentl,” about a young Jewish girl who disguises herself as a boy.
lead_paragraph: Gender and Judaism clash in Isaac Bashevis Singer’s story “Yentl the Yeshiva Boy,” about a young Jewish girl who cuts off her hair and disguises herself as a boy to study. But gender and Judaism come together in a bold statement in the Cleveland Play House’s poster for its new production of the stage adaptation, written by Leah Napolin and Mr. Singer.

headline: In Assad Government Communiqué, a Clue to Syria Peace Talks’ Hurdles
abstract: A document released by the Syrian government made no mention of the words “transition” or “reform” and appeared to suggest that the country was already a rule-of-law democracy.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — As we reported, a tenuous peace conference in Geneva between the Syrian opposition and the government has yet to produce concrete results, and on Monday, the third day of face-to-face talks, a communiqué released by President Bashar al-Assad’s government showed just how far apart they are from any agreement.

headline: Bitcoin Figure Is Accused of Conspiring to Launder Money
abstract: One of the most prominent players in the Bitcoin universe, Charles Shrem, was arrested on Sunday, accused of conspiring to facilitate drug transactions on the now-defunct online bazaar Silk Road.
lead_paragraph: One of the most prominent players in the Bitcoin universe, Charles Shrem, was arrested by federal authorities on Sunday and accused of helping smooth the way for drug transactions on the now-defunct online bazaar Silk Road.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Jan. 21-Jan. 27, 2014
abstract: Technology, sports, politics and Justin Bieber: How many of the 10 questions below can you answer correctly?
lead_paragraph: Technology, sports, politics and Justin Bieber: How many of the 10 questions below can you answer correctly?

headline: Q&A: A Voice for an Activist Fed
abstract: A conversation with Narayana Kocherlakota, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, who wants the Fed to expand its efforts to reduce unemployment.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve is often described as if it were a person – just one person – but it actually makes decisions by committee, and that committee is in flux. Only six of the 12 officials who voted on policy last January will still be voting when the Federal Open Market Committee holds its first meeting of 2014 this week.

headline: Stealth Oscar Campaigns, Grammy Edition
abstract: A number of Oscar contenders made their way to the Grammys stage.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Julia Roberts introduced a musical number on her first-ever appearance at the Oscars (for which she was deathly nervous) and on Sunday night she reprised that awards gig, introducing some little-known fellows called Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr at the Grammys.

headline: 1846 by Ferran Adrià
abstract: A video of each of the dishes Adrià and his team created over the six-year run of his restaurant El Bulli.
lead_paragraph: A video of each of the dishes Adrià and his team created over the six-year run of his restaurant El Bulli.

headline: Why Chris Christie Could Have Been an Entrepreneur
abstract: If you really want to know how to become a leader and how to accomplish big things that others say are crazy even to try, look no further than one big trait: force of personality.
lead_paragraph: What I see in the rise of Chris Christie, and now his recent crisis, is the same thing that I have long seen in the rise and fall (and often rise again) of fast-growth entrepreneurs. Through sheer force of personality, they rise up and get market-changing results over people, over bureaucracies, over anything that gets in their way.

headline: United Technologies Considers Sale or Spin-Off of Sikorsky
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: United Technologies is considering Sikorsky, the maker of the Black Hawk helicopter, as a candidate for a tax-free spinoff or potentially a sale to a rival.
lead_paragraph: The United Technologies Corporation is considering a spin-off or sale of Sikorsky, the maker of the Black Hawk helicopters favored by the United States military, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: An Extra Step Worth Taking
abstract: Thick pork chops are pan-seared, then finished in the oven, resulting in a deeply browned crust that reveals soft, juicy flesh.
lead_paragraph: The Restaurant Takeaway column is devoted to restaurant dishes you can make in your own kitchen, tested and tweaked for home cooks.

headline: Nevada’s Argument Against Same-Sex Marriage ‘No Longer Tenable’
keywords: ['Defense of Marriage Act (1996)', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The lower courts continue to expand Windsor’s legacy.
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 21, Nevada’s Attorney General, Catherine Cortez Masto, filed a brief strongly defending the state’s ban on same-sex marriage, which is being challenged in federal court by a group of same-sex couples.

headline: Trusting a Baby to Know How to Eat
abstract: Forgoing the baby food in favor of letting a baby feed herself means more mess. It also means parents can enjoy their meals while baby eats, too.
lead_paragraph: “You need a class to tell you how to feed your baby?” my dad laughed down the line to London, where I live. I was en route to a workshop on introducing my six-month-old daughter to solid food and was hoping to find clarity on which approach to use: traditional purées or this thing called “baby-led weaning” I’d heard English moms chatting about. Some swore by it, but others derided it as just another silly offshoot of bohemian urban parenting. It was like breast versus bottle 2.0, and I wanted to know more.

headline: Budget-Friendly and (Almost) Dracula-Free Transylvania
abstract: The sightseeing mix for a trip to this Romanian region went heavier on castles and churches, lighter on vampire encounters.
lead_paragraph: “Our ways are not your ways, and there shall be to you many strange things,” said a certain sharp-fanged count to his English visitor, freshly arrived by train to Transylvania.

headline: From the National Security Agency
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: This document from 2010, redacted in places, is one of several undisclosed classified documents provided by Edward J. Snowden, the former N.S.A. contractor, and shared by The New York Times, The Guardian and ProPublica.
lead_paragraph: This document from 2010, redacted in places, is one of several undisclosed classified documents provided by Edward J. Snowden, the former N.S.A. contractor, and shared by The New York Times, The Guardian and ProPublica.

headline: Charlie Brown and the Gang Take Shape
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Comic Books and Strips']
abstract: “Peanuts Every Sunday: 1952-1955” collects the first four years of Charles M. Schulz’s Sunday strips.
lead_paragraph: Part of an occasional series on vintage comics.

headline: Your Mars Training Program, a Three-Toed Ecosystem, Memory as We Age
abstract: Michael J. Massimino, a NASA astronaut, talks about how space changes our bodies and minds; we look at the (slowly) moveable habitat known as the sloth; a new study uses the web to model our brain’s memory — and why it appears to fail as we age.
lead_paragraph: Michael J. Massimino, a NASA astronaut, talks about how space changes our bodies and minds; we look at the (slowly) moveable habitat known as the sloth; a new study uses the web to model our brain’s memory — and why it appears to fail as we age.

headline: Tiger Global to Invest in Brazilian Online Retailer
abstract: Tiger Global Management, a New York-based investment firm, will invest nearly $520 million in Brazilian online retailer B2W Companhia Digital, the company said, a sign that it continues to see promise in Brazil’s vibrant Internet sector.
lead_paragraph: SAO PAULO — Tiger Global Management will invest nearly $520 million in Brazilian online retailer B2W Companhia Digital, the New York investment fund said, a sign that it continues to see promise in Brazil’s vibrant Internet sector.

headline: From Britain’s Government Communications Headquarters
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: This document from May 2010, redacted in places, is one of several undisclosed classified documents provided by Edward J. Snowden, the former N.S.A contractor, and shared by The New York Times, The Guardian and ProPublica.
lead_paragraph: This document from May 2010, redacted in places, is one of several undisclosed classified documents provided by Edward J. Snowden, the former N.S.A contractor, and shared by The New York Times, The Guardian and ProPublica.

headline: The Older Mind May Just Be a Fuller Mind
abstract: It’s not so much that the mental faculties of older people are rapidly declining, it’s that their databases are fuller, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: People of a certain age (and we know who we are) don’t spend much leisure time reviewing the research into cognitive performance and aging. The story is grim, for one thing: Memory’s speed and accuracy begin to slip around age 25 and keep on slipping.

headline: Sundance Fashion
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Sundance Film Festival (Park City, Utah)', 'Movies']
abstract: Stars from the film festival who pushed the style envelope past snow boots and beanies.
lead_paragraph: Stars from the film festival who pushed the style envelope past snow boots and beanies.

headline: The Sloth’s Busy Inner Life
abstract: The sloth, known for its sluggishness, has carved out a clever mode of life as a kind of walking ecosystem, but its lifestyle does constrain its energy level.
lead_paragraph: Spare a minute from your frenetically busy day to consider the quite different life of the three-toed sloth.

headline: Yes, We Believe That Pizza Is Meh
abstract: The categorical error New Yorkers make is mistaking ubiquity for superiority. Just because something is everywhere, it doesn’t mean it’s all that great.
lead_paragraph: As expected, some people were furious about pizza’s inclusion on this past weekend’s Meh List, a much-beloved and -maligned part of the One-Page Magazine. Even our own colleagues rethought their opinions of Samantha Henig, fellow Meh Lister, and me. But now that we’ve said it, we’re standing by it. Pizza is meh. This was not a mistake. My own philosophy of the mehness of pizza has been brewing for a long time. Let’s start with a mental exercise.

headline: Beings Not Made for Space
keywords: ['Space Stations', 'International Space Station', 'Medicine and Health', 'Gravitation and Gravity', 'Space and Astronomy']
abstract: Swelled heads, atrophied legs, radiation threats — space takes a toll on the human body, and some health problems still elude doctors more than 50 years after the first spaceflight.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — In space, heads swell.

headline: Thousands Pay Tribute to Abbado in Front of La Scala
abstract: A heartfelt homage to Claudio Abbado, one of La Scala’s most revered former musical directors, was held in Milan.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — Thousands of people packed into the square in front of La Scala on Monday to pay silent but heartfelt homage to one of the opera theater’s most revered musical directors, Claudio Abbado, who died on Jan. 20 at the age of 80.

headline: Scene City: After the Grammys, Dancing All Night
abstract: Warner Music Group held its annual post-award-ceremony party at the Sunset Tower Hotel in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Warner Music Group held its annual post-award-ceremony party at the Sunset Tower Hotel in Los Angeles.

headline: Europe Puts Pressure on Greece to Meet Budget Targets
abstract: The push by European officials comes as Athens wrestles with a funding gap that could reach €15 billion over the next two years.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European officials sought on Monday to keep the pressure on Greece to honor its previously agreed spending and privatization targets as they wrestled with the need to help Athens bridge a funding gap that could reach €15 billion over the next two years.

headline: Q&A: An Advocate for a Quicker Taper
abstract: A conversation with Richard W. Fisher, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, who has been critical of the Fed’s stimulus campaign and gains a policy-making vote this year.
lead_paragraph: As the voting membership of the Federal Reserve’s policy-making committee, the Federal Open Market Committee, turns over at a meeting this week, one of the new votes will be cast by Richard W. Fisher, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas.

headline: China Appears Set to Force Times Reporter to Leave
keywords: ['Visas', 'News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Austin Ramzy would be the second Times correspondent obliged to leave mainland China in 13 months because of an unprocessed visa application.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Despite objections raised by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. in meetings with its top leaders, China appears set to force a correspondent for The New York Times to leave the country this week. It is also continuing to block a number of other journalists working for The Times and for Bloomberg News from taking up assignments in Beijing.

headline: Outbreak Brings Royal Caribbean Cruise to an Early End
abstract: Gastrointestinal illness affecting passengers and crew members has cut short a cruise on a Royal Caribbean ship.
lead_paragraph: An outbreak of gastrointestinal illness suspected to be the norovirus has forced a Royal Caribbean cruise ship to return to port two days before the end of its scheduled 10-day voyage.

headline: At an Exhibition From the Master of El Bulli, Food Becomes Art
abstract: “Ferran Adrià: Notes on Creativity” at the Drawing Center uses drawings, paintings, documents and films to delve into the renowned Catalan chef’s intensely visual worldview.
lead_paragraph: Ferran Adrià made food into art at El Bulli, his renowned, now-shuttered restaurant near the town of Roses on the Catalan coast of Spain. Now, “Ferran Adrià: Notes on Creativity” at the Drawing Center in New York offers a peek behind the curtain of the world’s most celebrated culinary laboratory, and a glimpse at what Adrià is cooking up next.

headline: Shedding Light on a Vast Toll of Jews Killed Away From the Death Camps
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: The huge numbers killed in what some call a “Holocaust by bullets” have garnered greater attention as historians sift through records that became available after the fall of the Soviet Union.
lead_paragraph: OSWIECIM, Poland — As one gazes out from the main watchtower at the grim desert that is the crumbling chimneys and crematories, vanished prisoners’ huts, barbed wire and ditches of Auschwitz-Birkenau, it is hard to fathom that there were corners of the Nazi realm where, collectively, more killing occurred than at Auschwitz.

headline: Examining the Square Root of D’oh!
abstract: Math is everywhere in “The Simpsons,” from references that flash across the screen in an eye blink to entire segments that explore deep mathematical concepts.
lead_paragraph: Did you know that Homer Simpson disproved Fermat’s last theorem? He did, or so it seemed, when he scribbled “398712+436512=447212” on a blackboard in a 1998 episode of “The Simpsons.”

headline: It’s Not Just a Job, It’s an Adventure. In a Dying Industry, Sure. But Still.
abstract: “Craving for Travel,” at the Peter J. Sharp Theater, is a comedy about two rival travel agents dealing with dozens of difficult clients.
lead_paragraph: Considering what a lightweight piece of twaddle it is, “Craving for Travel,” at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater, sure gives you a lot to think about. Can a piece so blatantly promotional rightly be called theater? If I laugh at any of it, should I feel guilty? If this play succeeds, can similar works about elevator operators, owners of independent bookstores and other imperiled jobs be far behind?

headline: Foundry Owner Accused of Forging Johns’s Sculptures Pleads Guilty to Wire Fraud
abstract: A man accused of making forged copies of a sculpture by Jasper Johns pleaded guilty on Monday to federal wire fraud charges.
lead_paragraph: A Queens foundry owner who was accused of trying to sell fake Jasper Johns works for millions of dollars pleaded guilty on Monday to three counts of wire fraud in Manhattan federal court, according to The Associated Press. In 1990, Mr. Johns had entrusted Brian Ramnarine, the owner of Empire Bronze Art Foundry, to make a wax cast of the mold for his 1960 metallic collage “Flag.” Mr. Ramnarine kept the mold and was accused of secretly creating copies of Mr. Johns’s work that he later tried to sell as originals. Mr. Ramnarine, who was in the middle of a trial, made a deal with federal prosecutors that he would not challenge any sentence of 10 years or less in prison. Last week, Mr. Johns took a turn on the witness stand, testifying that he had cut ties with Mr. Ramnarine after seeing a copy of his sculpture. “I was shown the cast of a flag I had never authorized,” he told the court. “And it had come from Brian.”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, the Philippines, Thailand and Syria.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, the Philippines, Thailand and Syria.

headline: Taking a Restful Position
abstract: Deciding which sleep position is most comfortable is most important, unless sleep apnea is a factor, experts say.
lead_paragraph: Q. Is it best to sleep on your back, side or stomach?

headline: Former JPMorgan Executive Said to Settle Hiring Dispute
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: JPMorgan Chase appears to have settled a dispute with Frank Bisignano, a former close confidant of its chairman, Jamie Dimon, the latest reminder that the inner circle that helped the bank weather the financial crisis is no more.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase appears to have settled a dispute with a former close confidant of its chairman, Jamie Dimon, the latest reminder that the inner circle that helped the bank weather the financial crisis is no more.

headline: Me Versus the Scale
abstract: Many of us can recite the intimate details of our friends’ sex lives, their pharmacological habits, their rents. But question their weights and their mouths clamp shut.
lead_paragraph: The scale and I have reached détente. That is: I leave it alone, and it affords me the same courtesy. I rarely step on it, and we’re both better off.

headline: Bill to Offer an Option to Give Vouchers
abstract: Senator Lamar Alexander’s bill would give low-income families federal money for their children to attend any accredited school.
lead_paragraph: Senator Lamar Alexander, who served as secretary of education under President George Bush in the early 1990s, plans to introduce a bill on Tuesday that would give 11 million children from low-income families federal money to spend on any kind of schooling their parents choose, as long as it is in an accredited institution.

headline: After Complaints, ‘Millie’ Gets Thoroughly Modern Makeover for Dalton School
abstract: An adjusted version of the Tony-winning musical will play down Asian stereotypes that caused concern.
lead_paragraph: Leaders of the Dalton School, one of Manhattan’s top private schools, this month canceled a student production of the musical “Thoroughly Modern Millie” over concerns about the show’s use of Asian stereotypes and a subplot involving a white slavery ring in China, planning to replace it with a revue of the show’s songs instead.

headline: Second Grand Jury Indicts Officer in Shooting Death
keywords: ['Police', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: A grand jury indicted Randall Kerrick, a white officer, on voluntary manslaughter charges for firing 10 shots into a young black man who had driven off the road and was apparently looking for help.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Three times since a police officer fired 10 bullets into her son Jonathan last September, Georgia Ferrell has made the long journey from the family home in Tallahassee, Fla. Each time, she sought to understand why her son, a former Florida A&M football star and a homebody who wanted to take his mother with him to the junior prom, was gunned down when he was just asking for help.

headline: Looking for Insight Among the World’s Irks and Quirks
abstract: “One More Thing,” a story collection by B. J. Novak, the actor and writer (“The Office”), captures the rhythms of contemporary conversations.
lead_paragraph: In one of the longer entries in his very funny debut collection of stories, B. J. Novak describes a writer and translator named J. C. Audetat, who has a gift for “the off-the-cuff vernacular of his day” — or what might be called “the poetry of everyday conversations.”

headline: Soup Kitchens Caused the Great Depression, AFF Edition
abstract: It’s always because we’re too nice to the unemployed.
lead_paragraph: That’s AFF for “Austrian founding fathers.”

headline: Sales of iPhones Set Record for Quarter: 51 Million
abstract: Apple’s blockbuster phone sales helped the company post a profit of $13.1 billion on revenue of $57.6 billion.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple’s iPhone is still defying a long-held rule of the cellphone business: What goes up must come down.

headline: Giants Hire Danny Langsdorf to Coach Quarterbacks
abstract: With resurrecting the offense an off-season priority, the club hired Danny Langsdorf to tutor quarterbacks, replacing Sean Ryan, who will coach receivers.
lead_paragraph: For the third time this month, the Giants have hired an assistant coach with a background as an offensive coordinator or quarterbacks coach, another indication that the resurrection of the team’s offense — and the rejuvenation of quarterback Eli Manning — is an off-season priority.

headline: U.S. Relaxes Some Data Disclosure Rules
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Privacy', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)']
abstract: The Obama administration will allow Internet companies to talk more specifically about when they are forced to turn over customer data to the government, the Justice Department said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration says it will allow Internet companies to give customers a better idea of how often the government demands their information, but will not allow companies to disclose what is being collected or how much.

headline: Forget Market Timing, and Stick to a Balanced Fund
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Asset Allocation (Personal Finances)', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Mutual Funds']
abstract: Buy low and sell high is a great concept, but few people know when that moment occurs.
lead_paragraph: Investors were stung, badly, by the financial crisis of 2008. No one wants to go through an experience like that again, which has led to renewed interest in an investing approach called tactical asset allocation.

headline: Martin Marietta Materials Reaches Deal to Acquire Texas Industries
abstract: The acquisition of the construction supplies company for about $72 a share will allow Martin Marietta to move past its failed bid for Vulcan Materials two years ago.
lead_paragraph: Martin Marietta Materials has agreed to acquire Texas Industries in an all stock deal worth more than $2 billion, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: In Performance: Okwui Okpokwasili
abstract: The actress performs a scene from her solo show “Bronx Gothic,” which grew out of a series of notes passed between two 11-year-old girls. The show is at Danspace Project at St. Mark’s Church.
lead_paragraph: The actress performs a scene from her solo show “Bronx Gothic,” which grew out of a series of notes passed between two 11-year-old girls. The show is at Danspace Project at St. Mark’s Church.

headline: From Warheads to Cheap Energy
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Nuclear Energy', 'United States International Relations', 'Cold War Era', 'Uranium']
abstract: In all, over two decades, the program known as Megatons to Megawatts turned 20,000 Russian warheads into electricity that has illuminated one in 10 American light bulbs.
lead_paragraph: As the Cold War ended in the late 1980s and early ’90s, a new fear arose amid the rejoicing and relief: that atomic security might fail in the disintegrating Soviet Union, allowing its huge stockpile of nuclear warheads to fall into unfriendly hands.

headline: MSNBC Makes Room for Ronan Farrow, Rearranging the Schedule
abstract: The 26-year-old will host an hour show on 1 p.m. as the network changes its daily lineup.
lead_paragraph: MSNBC revised its daytime lineup on Monday, opening up an hour for its much-talked about recent hire, Ronan Farrow.

headline: The Realities of Class Begin To Sink In
abstract: The great middle-class myth fades.
lead_paragraph: One of the odd things about America has long been the immense range of people who consider themselves middle class — and are deluding themselves. Low-paid workers who would be considered poor by international standards, say with incomes below half the median, nonetheless considered themselves lower-middle class; people with incomes four or five times the median considered themselves, at most, upper-middle class.

headline: Justices Allow a Bit of License in Choice of Words During a Possible Air Emergency
keywords: ['Airport Security', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Mandatory Sentencing', 'Protective Clothing']
abstract: Airlines may not be held liable for minor falsehoods in warning the authorities about potential threats to air security, the Supreme Court ruled.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Airlines may not be held liable for minor falsehoods in warning the authorities about potential threats to air security, the Supreme Court ruled on Monday. The court also issued decisions on whether workers must be paid for time spent changing into protective gear and on enhanced sentences for drug dealers whose products result in death.

headline: Low-Status Symbols for One and All
abstract: “Billy Bob’s Gags to Riches” follows entrepreneurs of down-market gear as they hope for a big break.
lead_paragraph: A lot of odd inventions are featured in “Billy Bob’s Gags to Riches,” but none are what the world really needs. What it really needs is a television filter that automatically blocks any show using the word “redneck” more than once per episode.

headline: Income Inequality in the U.S. Means Princes Don’t Go After Cinderellas
abstract: Americans have tended to marry someone whose economic status is about the same as theirs, and that has contributed to growing income inequality in the United States.
lead_paragraph: You can tax the rich, you can educate the poor, but there is another way to reduce the nation’s growing income inequality: Marry your scullery maid.

headline: Flitting Through Fleeting Encounters
abstract: The David H. Koch Theater was transformed by an installation by the artist JR in its foyer, and the troupe introduced a new program.
lead_paragraph: The installation by the artist JR at the David H. Koch Theater has transformed that building’s greatest glory, its tall, spacious first-floor foyer. Unlike the 2013 cartoon tower by the Brooklyn art collective Faile, it doesn’t spoil or invade the space; it both deepens and teases it. Go up to the fourth ring, and, from above, it looks like a Baroque ceiling. Virtually life-size images of New York City Ballet dancers are arrayed in rings, whorls and patterns around the floor in various trompe l’oeil effects.

headline: Minnesota Orchestra, Rebuilding After Lockout, Celebrates a Grammy Win
abstract: The Minnesota Orchestra, which just ended a bitter 15-month lockout and plans to get back to business next month, won the Grammy Award for best orchestral performance.
lead_paragraph: The Minnesota Orchestra, which just ended a bitter 16-month lockout and plans to get back to business next month, won the Grammy Award for “best orchestral performance” on Sunday for a recording of Sibelius symphonies with its former music director, Osmo Vanska.

headline: As Loehmann’s Liquidates, Bargains Get Bigger as Shelves Get Emptier
abstract: Loehmann’s, which filed for bankruptcy last year, began liquidating its discount clothes earlier this month. But some customers may have been dismayed to see markdowns that averaged just 30 percent.
lead_paragraph: The Bronx-based department store Loehmann’s may be in the process of a fire sale, but when, oh when, will the deep discounts begin?

headline: Dum Dum Girls, Peggy Sue and Helen Sung Release Albums
abstract: Dum Dum Girls and Peggy Sue are heavy on the reverb in new albums, and Helen Sung makes her major-label debut.
lead_paragraph: DUM DUM GIRLS

headline: It All Started With a 12-Year-Old Cousin
keywords: ['E-Learning', 'Mathematics', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Tutors and Tutoring', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: Salman Khan’s first student was a family member. Now his free electronic schoolhouse reaches more than 10 million users around the world.
lead_paragraph: In 2008, Salman Khan, then a young hedge-fund analyst with a master’s in computer science from M.I.T., started the Khan Academy, offering free online courses mainly in the STEM subjects — science, technology, engineering and mathematics.

headline: All This and a Bag of Chips
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Super Bowl', 'Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Football']
abstract: A Super Bowl spread should strive to reach the level of a holiday feast.
lead_paragraph: The Super Bowl, to be played this year with the Seattle Seahawks facing the Denver Broncos on Sunday night at MetLife Stadium, is for all intents and purposes a national holiday.

headline: So Much for Mayor de Blasio’s Transparency Pledge
abstract: On Thursday night he spoke to a closed-door meeting of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee.
lead_paragraph: For a guy who ran on a platform of transparency, inclusiveness and progressive new thinking, it hasn’t taken New York Mayor Bill de Blasio long to clam up.  On Thursday night he spoke to a closed-door meeting of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, the leading pro-Israel lobbying group. The event, at the New York Hilton in Manhattan, was not listed on the mayor’s public schedule and a reporter who tried to attend was escorted away by AIPAC security staff.

headline: Slavery as New Focus for a Game
abstract: The video game Assassin’s Creed: Liberation, now available on several platforms, takes on slavery and liberation in the 18th century.
lead_paragraph: In what sounds like a joke by a stand-up comic — Chris Rock? Dave Chappelle? — with a fondness for PlayStation, the greatest black heroine in the history of video games was forced to live for more than a year in the ghetto of Sony’s faltering hand-held console, the Vita.

headline: Beyond Early Childhood Education
abstract: Readers react to David Brooks’s assertion that too much emphasis has been put on early education and school reform.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Moment in the Sun for Each and Every Instrument
abstract: At Alice Tully Hall, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center presented a program of early-19th-century pieces that experiment with instrumentation and style.
lead_paragraph: In the program notes for the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center’s concert on Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall, the Adagio of Spohr’s Grand Nonetto in F is described as “beautiful and attractive without stirring any deep emotions.” That observation could easily have been applied to all the genial works in this lineup of cocktail party pleasantries.

headline: Polar Bears Turn to Snow-Goose Egg Diet
abstract: As polar bears spend more time on land in a warming climate, they are adapting their diets, eating more snow-goose eggs and caribou instead of ringed seal pups.
lead_paragraph: As a warming climate causes sea ice in the Arctic to melt earlier each year, polar bears are spending more time on land — and changing their diets accordingly. A new study shows that the bears, whose traditional prey is ringed seal pups, are now eating more snow-goose eggs and caribou.

headline: Artifacts | The Sensual, Suggestive Appeal of Keith Sonnier’s Neon Sculptures
abstract: At an exhibition at Pace Gallery in Chelsea featuring work both old and new, the veteran artist revels in the “perversity” of his materials.
lead_paragraph: When the sculptor Keith Sonnier arrived in the late 1960s, he was identified with other young radicals like Richard Serra, Eva Hesse, Bruce Nauman and Lynda Benglis as “Post-Minimalist,” a catchall term that immediately wrote them into history books. The label was meant to distinguish them from their slightly older, Minimalist contemporaries, including Sol Lewitt, Carl Andre, Donald Judd and Dan Flavin, all of whom used inflexible materials for impersonal, geometric objects manufactured by others.

headline: Aid to Syrian Survivors
keywords: ['Torture', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Curt Goering of the Center for Victims of Torture responds to a news article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A High-Priced Rhino Hunt
abstract: Wayne Pacelle, president of the Humane Society of the United States, condemns the sale of hunting rights.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Up in the Air on Sunday? JetBlue Has a Super Bowl Plan
abstract: Those flying on JetBlue during the Super Bowl on Sunday will be able to watch the game with a Buffalo-wings-flavored snack and an inexpensive drink.
lead_paragraph: Any true football fan wouldn’t be caught anywhere near an airport on Super Bowl Sunday, but just in case, JetBlue Airways is at the ready, with in-flight viewing options to watch the game, cheap beer and a snack that tastes like wings.

headline: New Lead in Honeybee Deaths and Another Hot Year on Earth
abstract: A team of bee investigators say the dying species may be passing around a virus, while two government agencies say 2013 was among the hottest ever recorded.
lead_paragraph: In a satisfying twist, meteorologists called out the public last week for being inaccurate. Weeks after introducing us to “polar vortex” — the term for a weather pattern that typically swirls above northern Canada or Siberia and sometimes sends cold air south — the nation’s forecasters grew tired of hearing it. The Weather Channel meteorologists Chris Dolce and Nick Wiltgen complained on their Weather Underground blog that the word had become a catchphrase, mistakenly used to refer to the cold air itself, and not the vortex, which “never really moves through the atmosphere above the United States.” So please, everybody. Chill.

lead_paragraph: The British telecommunications giant Vodafone is at a crossroads.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Benghazi Attack (2012)']
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton’s comments on the attack on the United States Mission in Libya in 2012 that left four Americans dead represent some of her most candid remarks about the episode.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton on Monday called the deadly attack on the United States mission in Benghazi, Libya, in 2012 her “biggest regret” in the four years she served as secretary of state.

headline: Herbalife Shares Rise After Bullish Analyst Takes New Job
abstract: Timothy Ramey has resigned from his job as an analyst at D.A. Davidson to serve as a consultant for Post Holdings, the parent company of the maker of cereals and other foods.
lead_paragraph: Shares of Herbalife rose 6.7 percent on Monday after a report that an analyst covering the stock had gone to work for a major shareholder.

headline: Distressed Debt Hedge Fund Commits $530 Million to Europe
abstract: Marathon Asset Management has gained a reputation for finding opportunities by picking over what is left in the aftermath of financial disaster. It’s starting a new fund dedicated to distressed debt in Europe.
lead_paragraph: Marathon Asset Management has gained a reputation for being a rag-and-bone picker, finding opportunities in the aftermath of financial disaster.

headline: No Longer Leading Killer, Plague Still Raises Fears
abstract: History tells us that the Plague of Justinian and the Black Death each took a large fraction of the earth’s population. Science tells us that the plague is still out there.
lead_paragraph: Bubonic plague, caused by the rodent-borne bacterium Yersinia pestis, has killed a large fraction of the earth’s population at least twice — most famously in the medieval Black Death, but before that in the Plague of Justinian, which began in A.D. 541. That pandemic, named for the Byzantine emperor, may have killed half of Europe and Asia; it hastened the collapse of the Roman Empire’s remnants and ushered in the Dark Ages.

headline: As Gunmen Kill 45 in Nigeria, Suspicion Falls on Militants
abstract: The attack on a village in northeastern Nigeria was attributed to the Islamist group Boko Haram, which had lately regrouped in a rural area of the country.
lead_paragraph: ABUJA, Nigeria — Gunmen stormed a village in northeastern Nigeria late Sunday afternoon, shooting down traders and shoppers and killing at least 45 people on a busy market day, the police and witnesses said on Monday. The attack was one of the deadliest yet to be attributed to the militant Islamist group Boko Haram.

headline: The Collections | The Top 10 Moments in Spring 2014 Paris Couture Week
abstract: Our deputy editor shares her favorite moments from Paris Couture Week.
lead_paragraph: Last week, on the heels of Paris Men’s Fashion Week, the City of Light set the scene for the spring 2014 women’s couture shows. From the fashion to the haute joaillerie to off-the-runway hilarity, these are some of the season’s most memorable moments.

headline: Farm Bill Compromise Will Change Programs and Reduce Spending
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Farm Bill (US)', 'Crop Controls and Subsidies', 'Food Stamps']
abstract: Antihunger advocates are critical, pointing to $8 billion in food stamp cuts over the next decade.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House and Senate negotiators on Monday agreed on a new five-year farm bill that will eliminate or consolidate dozens of agriculture subsidy programs, expand government-subsidized crop insurance and cut about $8 billion from the food stamp program over the next decade.

headline: Jersey City, Where Seahawks and Broncos Roam
abstract: A Jersey City native describes the changed city where the Super Bowl teams are staying this week.

headline: Betting on Conversation With the Person in the Window Seat
abstract: Jeff Kaye of Kaye/Bassman-Sanford Rose Associates and Next Level Exchange enjoys focusing on a plane — but he also likes to talk to people.
lead_paragraph: I ENJOY business travel when it gives me the opportunity to visit with other cultures. Those cultures don’t have to be found in foreign lands. In the United States, there are so many different and wonderful cultural experiences you can have just traveling between Washington, Michigan and Kentucky, for example.

headline: Airport Forecast for 2014: More Guns, Faster Security
abstract: The T.S.A. expects to find more guns in carry-ons, and it expects enrollment in its PreCheck program to grow.
lead_paragraph: THE T.S.A. Blog, a chatty official newsletter run by a small group of Transportation Security Administration employees, offers a nice window into what is most likely ahead in air travel.

headline: Emilio’s Great Race
abstract: In Chapel Hill, a student government race is partly about the sense, generosity and meaning of America.
lead_paragraph: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — The campaign for student body president at the University of North Carolina here has just begun, and there’s nothing unusual in the number of candidates — five — or the fact that two are Morehead-Cain scholars, an elite designation.

headline: Lebanese Cringe as a Breakdown in Government Wafts Uphill
keywords: ['Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Since the government resigned 10 months ago, Parliament has scarcely convened, no major laws have been passed and trash overflows in Beirut — forcing residents to live with the stench.
lead_paragraph: BAAOUARTA, Lebanon — Standing near his home in this hilltop village, a local real estate agent angrily listed the drawbacks of living uphill — and downwind — from Lebanon’s largest landfill.

headline: Tom Perkins Again Discusses Nazis, Class Warfare and Now, Watches
abstract: Tom Perkins has certainly taken heat for his recent comments. And he continued his spirited defense in a TV interview on Monday, saying, “It’s absurd to demonize the rich for being rich and doing what the rich do.”
lead_paragraph: Tom Perkins certainly has taken heat for his recent letter to the editor in The Wall Street Journal. If he was trying to turn down the temperature, however, his interview with Bloomberg Television on Monday did not quite cut it.

abstract: Tory Johnson of the Friends Committee on National Legislation responds to a news article.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Actors’ Equity Members Discuss Tour Wages
abstract: A town hall meeting was called in response to frustration with the preponderance of lower-paying tours for musicals.
lead_paragraph: The Actors’ Equity union, which represents thousands of theater performers, laid groundwork on Monday afternoon for its next round of contract negotiations with producers, in 2015, by holding a town hall meeting about rank-and-file concerns over low salaries for several Equity tours of Broadway musicals.

headline: Think Back: The State of the Response
abstract: The president’s State of the Union address may look the same on television year after year, but the responses usually offer more variety and entertainment, says The Times’s Sam Tanenhaus.
lead_paragraph: The president’s State of the Union address may look the same on television year after year, but the responses usually offer more variety and entertainment, says The Times’s Sam Tanenhaus.

headline: With Better Security Technology, Hotels Shore Up Blind Spots
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Computer Security', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Security and Warning Systems']
abstract: Hotels are beefing up security with new key cards, smaller cameras and employee training.
lead_paragraph: At a poker tournament in Barcelona last September, Jens Kyllönen, a professional player, said that his room at Hotel Arts was broken into and malware was installed on his computer to transmit anything he saw on his screen as he played. Despite video camera systems and electronic key card entry logs, no one was caught.

headline: Former Exit Port for a Wave of Cubans Hopes to Attract Global Shipping
keywords: ['Ports', 'Ships and Shipping', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Foreign Investments', 'International Relations', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The Mariel port, where desperate refugees once crammed onto boats to flee the country, has been upgraded at a cost of about $900 million and holds the government’s hopes of connecting Cuba and the rest of the world.
lead_paragraph: MARIEL, Cuba — The images of desperate refugees crammed onto boats have defined this bay outside Havana for decades. About 125,000 Cubans left from here in 1980 after Fidel Castro, facing growing discontent, announced that anyone who wanted to leave should just go to Mariel and get out.

headline: California Denies Scorned Journalist Stephen Glass Right to Practice Law
abstract: More than 15 years after the revelation that Mr. Glass had partly or wholly fabricated dozens of magazine articles, the high court denied his request to practice law in the state.
lead_paragraph: In 1998, Stephen Glass was all but banished from the profession of journalism. On Monday, the California Supreme Court ruled that he was not welcome as a lawyer, either.

headline: The Friendly Derby? Well, Everton-Liverpool Is Friendlier
abstract: If the standard-issue European soccer rivalry is something akin to street-gang warfare, the Liverpool-Everton relationship is more like two brothers who constantly bicker over who has the better car.
lead_paragraph: LIVERPOOL, England — European soccer rivalries have long been blamed for a variety of extreme circumstances, from deaths and vandalism to the lobbing of flares and the occasional appearance of a pig’s severed head. Rarely, however, do they split a family at Sunday dinner. Except here.

headline: Activists Try to Hijack Promotions by Sponsors of Sochi Olympics
keywords: ['Olympic Games (2014)', 'Online Advertising', 'Social Media', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Discrimination', 'Homosexuality', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Activists protesting antigay policies in Russia have tried to turn Olympic promotions by major companies to their own purposes.
lead_paragraph: IT is the closest thing to a sure bet in advertising — associating with the Olympic athletes who train for years with the chance of winning a gold medal. And corporations are paying big money to align themselves with the Olympians competing at next month’s Winter Olympics in Sochi.

headline: Addicted to I.V.F., or Addicted to Hope?
abstract: Who gets to decide when another round of IVF is too much?
lead_paragraph: “You know, some people here get addicted to I.V.F.,” a friend of a friend said when I mentioned to her that I was going to be doing fertility treatments in Israel, after my attempts in America.

headline: Company Struggles to Keep U.S. in the Uranium Enrichment Game
abstract: The only American-owned uranium-enrichment company is struggling to raise billions to construct a modern centrifuge facility, while a European-owned rival thrives in New Mexico.
lead_paragraph: EUNICE, N.M. — While the only American-owned company that enriches uranium prepares for bankruptcy, its competitor is zooming ahead with construction of what it describes as a cluster of far more economical and efficient new centrifuges.

headline: Stewart Is Back, With Confidence and Pain
abstract: Tony Stewart is still not fully healed from three operations on his right leg, but he sees no reason he could not return to the form that earned him three Sprint Cup championships.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Aerosmith’s “Back in the Saddle” was playing over the loudspeaker during introductions as Tony Stewart strode into a news conference at the Charlotte Convention Center on Monday with a noticeable limp. No, he is not 100 percent after fracturing the tibia and fibula in his right leg in a racing accident last August.

headline: Alone, Yet Not Alone
abstract: How does the inner experience of faith differ from popular perceptions of religion?
lead_paragraph: There is a strong vein of hostility against orthodox religious believers in America today, especially among the young. When secular or mostly secular people are asked by researchers to give their impression of the devoutly faithful, whether Jewish, Christian or other, the words that come up commonly include “judgmental,” “hypocritical,” “old-fashioned” and “out of touch.”

headline: Ticket Prices Fall on the Resale Market, Brokers Say
abstract: The asking price of Super Bowl tickets being resold has fallen nearly 25 percent since the game’s participants became known, according to a market tracker, though a surge is expected.
lead_paragraph: New York is filled with firsts and superlatives, and this year’s Super Bowl is providing more. The first outdoor Super Bowl in a cold climate. The first mass transit Super Bowl. A fanfest staged in the heart of Manhattan.

headline: From Your Friends at the N.R.A.
abstract: Membership has its perks.
lead_paragraph: The following are verbatim excerpts from emails sent by the National Rifle Association.

headline: Translation as a Performing Art
abstract: Any word can be translated. But there is no way of dealing with the larger problem: untranslatable worlds.
lead_paragraph: Thirty years ago I moved to Milan to work for an Italian art magazine called FMR. It was an odd and ambitious enterprise: FMR started publishing in the United States a year later with the slogan “the most beautiful magazine in the world.” The offices hardly seemed like offices at all: they were located in Palazzo Visconti di Modrone, an exceptionally fine piece of Milanese rococo architecture. The building was Luchino Visconti’s childhood home, and it was a gorgeous and dramatic workplace. When it was time for coffee, we ordered in rounds of espressos, which were brought by a white-coated young man carrying a silver trayful of demitasse thermoses. Every few months, one of the magazine’s production managers would take orders for prosciutto from his hometown, Parma — the whole ham, what they thin-slice in an Italian gastronomia. Price: about $20.

headline: West to East Coast: Voyage of a Crane
abstract: On its 6,000-mile journey from San Francisco to New York, the 328-foot Left Coast Lifter crane traveled through the Panama Canal on its way to build the new Tappan Zee Bridge across the Hudson River.
lead_paragraph: On its 6,000-mile journey from San Francisco to New York, the 328-foot Left Coast Lifter crane traveled through the Panama Canal on its way to build the new Tappan Zee Bridge across the Hudson River.

headline: Muscular West Coast Worker Is on Way to Build New Tappan Zee
keywords: ['Bridges and Tunnels', 'Ships and Shipping', 'Canals', 'Tappan Zee Bridge', 'Derricks and Cranes']
abstract: The Left Coast Lifter, a floating crane that can hoist 1,900 tons at a time, passed through the Panama Canal this month. Its use will save time and money in replacing the Tappan Zee Bridge.
lead_paragraph: PANAMA — The Left Coast Lifter is the Superman of floating cranes.

headline: Job Aid Zones Face a New Test in Coal Country
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Enterprise Zones', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'Poverty', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: Experts are skeptical that any federal initiative can combat the upheaval of lost coal jobs or the economic woes caused by remoteness, poor infrastructure and undereducated workers.
lead_paragraph: HAZARD, Ky. — Joseph Nantz still looks back fondly at his job as a heavy machinery operator at the mountaintop coal mine here, helping to blast and cart away layers of rock to reveal seams of coal and then restore the rubble for a handsome $24 an hour.

headline: The House Targets Superfund
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Superfund', 'Editorials', 'States (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Environment']
abstract: A package of bills approved by the House is the latest Republican proposal designed to undermine environmental protections.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, the House approved a package of bills that could undercut an environmental law that has helped clean some of the most polluted places in the nation. The measures would allow states to apply their own standards to the cleanup of hazardous waste sites — standards that in most cases are likely to be considerably weaker than those governing the federal Superfund program, the 1980 program that has identified thousands of toxic waste sites and cleaned up many of them.

headline: Contraception Before the Court
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Editorials', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The justices’ order extending a bar on the Obama administration’s enforcement of paperwork rules is disappointing.
lead_paragraph: In a disappointing order on Friday, the Supreme Court extended a temporary injunction barring the Obama administration from enforcing paperwork rules against a Colorado nuns’ group in connection with a federal law that requires employer health plans to cover birth control without a co-payment.

headline: Genetic Weapon Against Insects Raises Hope and Fear in Farming
abstract: Scientists, looking for new weapons against insect pests in farming, have developed gene-silencing agents. But skeptics are concerned about potential threats to nontarget insects and even humans.
lead_paragraph: Scientists and biotechnology companies are developing what could become the next powerful weapon in the war on pests — one that harnesses a Nobel Prize-winning discovery to kill insects and pathogens by disabling their genes.

headline: Syria Talks Fail to Yield Pact to Lift Aid Blockade
keywords: ['Evacuations and Evacuees', 'Foreign Aid', 'International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: Little progress was seen in the third day of talks on authorizing an international convoy to enter blockaded areas in the city of Homs.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The Syrian government on Monday failed to authorize an international aid convoy to enter blockaded areas in the city of Homs, as the opposition’s Western backers declared that if the delivery was not allowed by next week they would be likely to challenge the government in the United Nations Security Council.

headline: At Neutral Site, Syrians Feel Free to Confront the Other Side
abstract: Frank, even tense, encounters in Geneva have in some ways been the most significant action at peace talks that have been more about optics than results.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — For Syrian officials, a lakeside idyll here, far from their country’s war, has been marred by what plainly feels to them like an endless stream of impertinent questions.

headline: Two Islanders Who Keep the Hits Coming
abstract: In the years since the N.H.L. started counting body checks, no players have run into other players as often as Matt Martin and Cal Clutterbuck have.
lead_paragraph: They glide in from all angles seeking crashes and pileups, a human demolition derby in blue. Wherever they go, bodies go tumbling, hockey sticks go flying through the air, and the Plexiglas panels atop the boards undulate in concussive waves from the collisions they engineer.

headline: Anxiety Rising Over Relations Between Japan and China
abstract: A major topic of discussion at the World Economic Forum was the ties of two Asian neighbors with a long history of strained interactions.
lead_paragraph: DAVOS, Switzerland — Even with all the optimism about the global economy here last week at the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum, there was a remarkable economic and political risk that appeared to have been largely overlooked: The long-simmering battle between China and Japan may be close to boiling over. One top executive went so far as to describe the nations’ relationship as a “stealth war.”

headline: The Mayor Pushes Back, for Pre-K
abstract: Against long odds, Mayor Bill de Blasio made a strong case in Albany for his prekindergarten plan and his tax on wealthy residents.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio went to Albany on Monday to answer the naysayers and skeptics — chief among them, Gov. Andrew Cuomo — who want him to abandon his prekindergarten plan and his tax on wealthy residents. Mr. de Blasio was there to make an ambitious case: to extend free, full-day, “high-quality” pre-K across the city in two years, eventually to reach more than 73,000 4-year-olds.

headline: Second Cargo of Chemical Agents Leaves Syria as Pace Is Criticized
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Freight (Cargo)', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The concern is that the schedule of deadlines to destroy the weapons stockpile is falling dangerously behind.
lead_paragraph: The second cargo of Syria’s most toxic chemical weapons was exported by ship on Monday for eventual destruction at sea, officials overseeing the effort reported. But the slow pace of removal, which is way behind schedule and has missed one deadline already, is causing increased concern and threatening to violate another deadline in less than two weeks.

headline: Japan: Broadcast Chief Apologizes for Comment on ‘Comfort Women’
abstract: The chairman of Japan’s public broadcaster apologized Monday after drawing criticism for saying that his nation should not be singled out for forcing women into sexual servitude during World War II.
lead_paragraph: The new chairman of Japan’s public broadcaster apologized Monday after drawing sharp criticism for saying that his nation should not be singled out for forcing women into sexual servitude during World War II. Katsuto Momii, the newly appointed chairman of the public broadcaster, NHK, also was criticized for saying that the broadcaster would refrain from criticizing the government on such delicate issues as visits to a controversial shrine honoring war dead. On Monday, Mr. Momii said his comments on Sunday about the so-called comfort women forced to work in wartime military brothels were “personal opinions that were not appropriate to say.”

headline: Iraq: United States to Deliver Helicopters
keywords: ['Helicopters', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Military Aircraft']
abstract: Congress has approved the delivery of six Apache attack helicopters to the Iraqi military, Pentagon and congressional officials said Monday.
lead_paragraph: Congress has approved the delivery of six Apache attack helicopters to the Iraqi military, Pentagon and congressional officials said Monday. The leased Apaches will not arrive in Iraq until this summer after they have been equipped and Iraqi pilots have been trained. The transfer had been held up for months until members of Congress were assured that the helicopters would be used for national security purposes, and not for Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki to employ against his political enemies. Iraqi troops have been locked in a standoff with militants in the western province of Anbar in recent weeks, and insurgents in other parts of the country have been carrying out a campaign of attacks for months. The United States has also agreed to sell Iraq 24 new Apaches, but that delivery is still three years away.

headline: Did Big Internet Companies Handicap Start-Ups in FISA Rule Changes?
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Industrial Espionage', 'Search Engines', 'Start-ups', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: A small but significant caveat, in a new agreement brokered between the Obama administration and Google, Facebook, Yahoo and Microsoft could cast a long shadow over America’s technology start-ups.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A small but significant caveat in a new agreement brokered between the Obama administration and Google, Facebook, Yahoo and Microsoft could cast a long shadow over America’s technology start-ups.

headline: Mexico: Gang Leader Is Arrested
abstract: Dionisio Loya Plancarte, who is believed to handle public relations for the Knights Templar, was found hiding in a closet in Michoacán and arrested, Mexican authorities said Monday.
lead_paragraph: Mexican authorities said Monday that they had arrested one of the top leaders of the Knights Templar, the organized crime gang that has spread such terror in the western state of Michoacán that citizens have formed vigilante groups to fight it. Dionisio Loya Plancarte, who is believed to handle the gang’s public relations, was found hiding in a closet in Michoacán and arrested. He faces charges related to organized crime and drug trafficking, the Interior Ministry said. President Enrique Peña Nieto sent troops and more police officers into Michoacán two weeks ago, but the self-defense groups refused to lay down their arms. On Monday, they agreed to work under military command, but they will not disband.

headline: Diamonds in Rough Shrug Off the Cut of Rejection
abstract: Broncos receiver Wes Welker and his Seahawks counterpart Doug Baldwin lacked the size and the blazing speed to play in the N.F.L., but try telling them that.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — Wes Welker of the Denver Broncos and Doug Baldwin of the Seattle Seahawks are productive wide receivers who have more than relative lack of size in common. Both are driven by rejection.

headline: Stability Versus Democracy in Egypt
abstract: Is a military government the best path to stability and progress in Egypt?

abstract: Quotation of the day for Tuesday, January 28, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “By having these devices in our pockets and using them more and more, you’re somehow becoming a sensor for the world intelligence community.”

headline: Court Grants Peru Ocean Territory Claimed by Chile
abstract: The International Court of Justice settled a six-year maritime dispute, slicing about 8,000 square miles of the Pacific Ocean from Chile’s territory.
lead_paragraph: SANTIAGO, Chile — A six-year maritime dispute between Chile and Peru was settled on Monday when the International Court of Justice in The Hague ruled largely in favor of Peru, stripping Chile of economic rights over a swath of the Pacific Ocean.

headline: Obama’s Puzzle: Economy Rarely Better, Approval Rarely Worse
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Never during President Obama’s time in office has the state of the economy been better. Yet, as he prepares to deliver his fifth State of the Union address, rarely has he gotten such low marks from the public for his handling of it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will pronounce on the state of the union for the fifth time on Tuesday, and never during his time in office has the state of the economy been better — yet rarely has he gotten such low marks from the public for his handling of it.

headline: The Food May Be Fast, but These Customers Won’t Be Rushed
abstract: Restaurant managers are often frustrated by elderly people who buy a cup of coffee and stay in their seats all day.
lead_paragraph: With its low coffee prices, plentiful tables and available bathrooms, McDonald’s restaurants all over the country, and even all over the world, have been adopted by a cost-conscious set as a coffeehouse for the people, a sort of everyman’s Starbucks.
