headline: The Rats Take the Nacho Cheese
abstract: “Stop Hitting Yourself,” created by the Texas ensemble Rude Mechs, brings lots of tacky glitter to Lincoln Center along with ethical questions.
lead_paragraph: A little bit of Las Vegas has splashed down on the campus of Lincoln Center, of all unlikely places. To enter the Claire Tow Theater, where “Stop Hitting Yourself,” the frisky new show from the adventurous theater collective Rude Mechs is being presented, feels like stepping into one of the gaudier suites at Caesar’s Palace.

headline: Goddess of the Hunt
abstract: A bodacious debut by Jeff Stillman.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — What word would you use to describe this debut by Jeff Stillman?

headline: Antibiotics in Animals Tied to Risk of Human Infection
abstract: A federal analysis of 30 antibiotics used in animal feed found that the majority of them were likely to be contributing to bacterial infections that are resistant to treatment in people, according to documents released by a health advocacy group.
lead_paragraph: A federal analysis of 30 antibiotics used in animal feed found that the majority of them were likely to be contributing to the growing problem of bacterial infections that are resistant to treatment in people, according to documents released Monday by a health advocacy group.

headline: A Lieutenant Governor, an Artist and a Portrait of a Smear
abstract: In her first year in office, Lt. Gov. Kim Guadagno opened a frontal attack on an unlikely target, the New Jersey State Council on the Arts.
lead_paragraph: TRENTON — In her first year in office, Lt. Gov. Kim Guadagno opened a frontal attack on an unlikely target, the New Jersey State Council on the Arts.

headline: Judge Rejects Execution Delay Over Use of Compounded Drug
abstract: Lawyers for an inmate in Missouri said the drug to be used was likely to be substandard because it was produced in a compounding pharmacy not subject to federal drug safety regulations.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for a Missouri inmate said Monday that they would appeal a decision not to grant a delay in his execution, arguing that the drug to be used was likely to be substandard, and thus could cause him severe pain, because it was produced in a compounding pharmacy not subject to federal drug safety regulations.

headline: Advertisements for Death
abstract: The Syrian civil war has turned photojournalism on its head.
lead_paragraph: The recently released images from a cache of 55,000 photographs depicting emaciated, strangled and beaten corpses — allegedly taken in the jails of the Syrian president Bashar al-Assad — are terrible to view. They are also bewildering. The photographs, which document the deaths of some 11,000 detainees, were taken not by the opposition but at the behest of Mr. Assad’s regime. Wouldn’t such a government — wouldn’t any government — want to hide its crimes rather than record them?

headline: Midtown Attack Investigated as Hate Crime
abstract: Randy Gener, an openly gay Filipino journalist, was attacked in Midtown on Jan. 17, his skull cracked, but his wallet and other possessions were not taken.
lead_paragraph: Ten days after being attacked, Randy Gener can talk again. He also now recognizes his husband and his sister, seated at his hospital bedside.

headline: De Blasio and Cuomo Team Up to Save Brooklyn Hospitals
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo have asked the Obama administration to allow the state to use $10 billion in Medicaid money in a way that could help troubled hospitals in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, at odds over how to pay for prekindergarten, showed a unified front on Monday on helping distressed Brooklyn hospitals and said that without immediate federal support, “there will be closures.”

headline: Stabbing Suspect Found to Be Unfit to Continue Case
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: If he is committed as expected after the next court hearing, on Feb. 6, the prosecution will pause indefinitely until Mindong Chen is found fit to proceed.
lead_paragraph: Two court-appointed doctors found that a Chinese immigrant accused of stabbing his cousin’s wife and the couple’s four children to death in October was too mentally ill to continue with his criminal case. A judge is expected to commit him to a psychiatric facility for treatment, a spokeswoman for the Brooklyn district attorney’s office said.

headline: Motions Denied in Yonkers Corruption Case
abstract: A federal judge refused to set aside the 2012 convictions of two former political figures on grounds that a prosecution witness had bribed a municipal employee while he was assisting the authorities.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Monday denied motions by two former Yonkers political figures to set aside their convictions in a 2012 corruption trial on grounds that a prosecution witness had not disclosed that he paid a $5,000 bribe to a municipal employee while he was assisting the authorities.

headline: Pennsylvania Deaths of 22 Linked to Batch of Heroin
abstract: State officials warned users about the dangerous drug as the number of deaths mounted over the weekend.
lead_paragraph: Pennsylvania officials warned residents on Monday about a dangerous batch of heroin that has caused 22 deaths.

headline: In Las Vegas, Putting a Lot on the Line for the Super Bowl
abstract: The oddsmakers who decide the numbers and proposition bets for football’s biggest game affect everything from office pools to bets made with neighborhood bookies.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Johnny Avello has a big title, executive director of race and sports operations at Wynn Las Vegas — but in a town that talks about point spreads with the same intensity that farmers discuss the weather, he has an even bigger reputation. He is considered a Don in one of this town’s most respected fraternities, the brotherhood of bookies. Call him a wizard, a Wizard of Odds.

abstract: The Nets allowed an opportunity to win their 11th game of the month slip from their grasp as they fell to the Raptors for the second time in January.
lead_paragraph: Deron Williams wiped his hands against his shorts before taking a bounce pass from the referee near midcourt. Williams toed the sideline, readying to inbound the ball as the Nets’ clung to a 1-point lead over the Toronto Raptors.

abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Anthony Says Winning Title Is Sole Focus
abstract: The Knicks’ Carmelo Anthony refused to elaborate on free agency, but he did make clear that he wants to be in a situation where he feels he can vie for a title.
lead_paragraph: Carmelo Anthony told reporters Monday that he wants to win an N.B.A. championship, which seemed like a totally reasonable thing for him to say. But given Anthony’s stated plan to declare for free agency next summer, it instantly led to wild speculation about his future with the Knicks: Is he staying or going?

headline: Luis Ávalos, Actor on ‘The Electric Company,’ Dies at 67
abstract: Mr. Ávalos, a Cuban-born actor, began a long tenure on the PBS children’s program “The Electric Company” in 1972, when there were few Hispanic faces on television.
lead_paragraph: Luis Ávalos, a Cuban-born actor known for his long tenure on “The Electric Company,” the popular PBS children’s program of the 1970s, died on Wednesday in Burbank, Calif. He was 67.

headline: José Emilio Pacheco, Honored Writer Who Wrote of Social Ills, Dies at 74
keywords: ['Poetry and Poets', 'Writing and Writers', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Mr. Pacheco, who emerged as a poet of note in the 1960s, won many awards.
lead_paragraph: José Emilio Pacheco, a Mexican poet and author who achieved renown throughout the Spanish-speaking world with highly literate poems, essays and novels that used an array of styles to explore profound questions, died on Sunday in Mexico City. He was 74.

headline: Crackdowns on Live Poultry Sales Mar Holiday Season
abstract: Hong Kong began culling 20,000 live chickens just days before the Lunar New Year, and several areas of China are banning the trading of the live birds.
lead_paragraph: As Chinese get ready for their Lunar New Year feasts, several areas in China have banned the sale of live chickens, and the Hong Kong government started culling 20,000 of the birds on Tuesday as fears grew about the spread of avian influenza.

headline: Archie Manning Envisions Peyton Playing Past Super Bowl
abstract: Peyton Manning’s father said his son was “not chasing records” and “still enjoys” football.
lead_paragraph: Peyton Manning’s father, Archie Manning, said he expected his son to continue to play for the Denver Broncos beyond this season, even if he added a second Super Bowl championship to his long list of accomplishments.

headline: More Delays and Rising Cost for Project Connecting L.I.R.R. to Grand Central Terminal
abstract: Estimates from transit officials on Monday stated that the long-awaited plan would be delayed until at least 2020 with costs that could exceed $10 billion.
lead_paragraph: Commuters looking forward to the long-awaited project that will connect the Long Island Rail Road to Grand Central Terminal may now have to wait until 2023.

headline: Google Glass to Be Covered by Vision Care Insurer VSP
abstract: In a sign of how wearable devices are entering the mainstream, a major optical insurance provider will subsidize frames and prescription lenses for customers buying Google Glass.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google and VSP, the nation’s biggest optical health insurance provider, have struck a deal to offer subsidized frames and prescription lenses for Google Glass, the Internet-connected eyewear.

headline: Securities Class-Action Suits Up Slightly in 2013
keywords: ['Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: More class-action lawsuits were filed against public companies in 2013 than in the previous year, but the filers were seeking billions less in damages than they have on average.
lead_paragraph: Angry investors filed more federal class-action securities lawsuits last year than in 2012. But investors have been angrier.

headline: The Roots of the Tax Reform Act of 1986, Part II
abstract: The dynamics that led to the Tax Reform Act of 1986 shed light on what it would take to achieve tax reform in this era, but the absence of bipartisanship makes short-term prospects dim, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform — Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Jason Calacanis Shoots for Human Moments in News Feeds
abstract: A rush of new entrants to new media involves people. The latest, called Inside, is a news aggregator that aims to ignore news aggregators and point people to original content (if they want more after reading a 40-word digest.) Other new business, even possibly one at Facebook, are also using humans over machines.
lead_paragraph: This must be the fastest-moving month in the history of new media. The latest entrant features yet one more familiar face.

headline: Top Republicans to Call for Legal Status for Some Immigrants
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Illegal Immigration', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: House leaders’ ideas include a path to legal status — but not citizenship — for many of the 11 million adult immigrants who are in the country illegally.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House Republican leadership’s broad framework for overhauling the nation’s immigration laws will call this week for a path to legal status — but not citizenship — for many of the 11 million adult immigrants who are in the country illegally, according to aides who have seen the party’s statement of principles. For immigrants brought to the United States illegally as young children, the Republicans would offer a path to citizenship.

headline: Hong Kong Man Seeking to Issue Book About Xi Is Held in China
keywords: ['Censorship', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Relatives and friends of Yiu Mantin believe he was singled out for arrest because of his plans to distribute a withering denunciation of President Xi Jinping.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Three months ago, Yiu Mantin, a retired engineer from Hong Kong, crossed into mainland China for a short visit, as he had done many times. But this time he disappeared into the hands of the police, and his family and friends believe he was singled out because of his second career — book publishing — and especially because he planned to distribute a withering denunciation of President Xi Jinping.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 6 P.M. (Starz Cinema) ORANGES AND SUNSHINE (2011) Emily Watson, above, portrays Margaret Humphreys, a social worker in Nottingham, England, who, starting in 1986, exposed the deportation of as many as 130,000 children from orphanages and group homes in Britain to Australia between the 1940s and 1967. One deportee, now an adult, recalls that he was told, at 10, that he was being sent to a sunny paradise where he could pick oranges off trees. Instead, many of the youngsters found themselves forced into hard labor and enduring physical cruelty and sexual abuse at places like the Bindoon Boys Town, presided over by the Christian Brothers, a Roman Catholic order. The victims were informed that their parents were dead, while their parents — mainly unwed mothers deemed unfit — were told that their children had been placed for adoption in better homes. “This film presents a chilling portrait of bureaucratic stonewalling and denial as Margaret presents her evidence to politicians who meet her accusations with indifference and skepticism, express only a vague regret and assume no responsibility,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times about this drama, directed by Jim Loach from Ms. Humphreys’s 1994 book, “Empty Cradles.”

headline: Pete Seeger, Champion of Folk Music and Social Change, Dies at 94
abstract: Mr. Seeger, who spearheaded the folk revival that transformed popular music in the 1950s, spent a long career championing song as both a vital heritage and a catalyst for political action.
lead_paragraph: Pete Seeger, the singer, folk-song collector and songwriter who spearheaded an American folk revival and spent a long career championing folk music as both a vital heritage and a catalyst for social change, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 94.

headline: How Rahul Gandhi Did in His First TV Interview
abstract: Political analysts weighed in on the Congress Party vice president’s handling of pointed questions by Arnab Goswami of Times Now.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — It was a highly anticipated TV event on Monday night: Rahul Gandhi, the leader of the Congress Party’s election campaign, sat down with Arnab Goswami of Times Now, the most aggressive journalist on an English-language television network in India, for the politician’s first formal TV interview.

headline: Mass Slaughter of Vulnerable Shark Species in China, Wildlife Group Says
keywords: ['Conservation of Resources', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Sharks']
abstract: A wildlife group says businesses in China are slaughtering and processing hundreds of sharks yearly, including members of the whale, basking and great white species, in contravention of international wildlife trade laws.
lead_paragraph: Tipped off by a Chinese wildlife protection group that a “shark slaughterhouse” of vulnerable species, including the whale shark, was operating in a town in Zhejiang Province on China’s eastern seaboard, the activists Alex Hofford and Paul Hilton traveled there to take a look.

headline: Former Military Chief Refuses to Testify in Bosnia Genocide Trial
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The military chief, Ratko Mladic, referred to the Hague court as “satanic” and said he was medically unfit to testify at the trial of Radovan Karadzic, the former Bosnian Serb political leader.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Ratko Mladic, the former Bosnian Serb military commander facing war crimes charges in The Hague, refused to testify on Tuesday at the trial of his former political ally, Radovan Karadzic, saying he did not wish to prejudice his own case and was medically unfit to give evidence.

lead_paragraph: In “South Bronx Students May Have Found Site of Slave Burial Ground,” Lisa W. Foderaro writes about a student project that may have uncovered forgotten history.

headline: Building a Harley Faster
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'United States Economy', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: A modern manufacturing morality tale in which workers and management came together to save an American icon.
lead_paragraph: While working the line at Harley-Davidson’s factory in York, Pa., Mark Dettinger noticed a small problem. The plastic piece that held electrical parts to the front of a motorcycle, a piece about the size of a hardcover book, wasn’t fitting correctly. Every time a new bike came down the line, it took a few extra shoves to push it into place. In fact, it took an extra 1.2 seconds. But Dettinger, who had spent some 20 years at the York plant, knew that every second counted. With 400 motorcycles built each shift, on two shifts a day, an extra 1.2 seconds per bike added up to 2,200 lost bikes annually. Millions could be lost in revenue. Maybe it wasn’t such a small problem.

headline: Making Pictures, Finding Solutions in Nicaragua
abstract: Dismayed by the prevalence of kidney disease among Nicaraguan sugar cane workers, Ed Kashi is raising money to document the crisis and to spur dialogue.
lead_paragraph: The health crisis Ed Kashi encountered among sugar cane workers in Chichigalpa, Nicaragua, last year was stark. Over the course of two weeks he spent in the area, there was a funeral every day for workers who had died of chronic kidney disease. Though he had gone there on a commission for a nongovernmental organization that was helping the workers, he left convinced that he had to continue his documentation on his own.

headline: The Crowdfunding Site Indiegogo Raises $40 Million
abstract: The infusion of money adds another notch of credibility and legitimacy to crowdfunding and the expanding ways the financing platform can be applied.
lead_paragraph: Several years ago, the notion of crowdfunding — asking strangers to contribute money to help and idea or project become a tangible reality — seemed like a far-fetched way to successfully and repeatedly finance creative and business ventures.

headline: Who Does Hip-Hop Belong To?
abstract: Are white artists who prosper in hip-hop robbing from black musicians? Or is music fair game for all true fans?
lead_paragraph: After Sunday’s Grammy Awards, Macklemore sent a public apology via text to Kendrick Lamar, whom he had just beaten out for best rap album. Macklemore, who is white, bested four black musicians, including Mr. Lamar, in winning his award in this historically black music genre. Should Macklemore be apologizing? Did he “rob” the other award contenders? Is this just another example of whites appropriating and profiting from historically black music, as some might say Elvis Presley and other early rock ’n’ roll musicians did in the 1950s? Can music transcend race or ethnicity to belong to its fans? Or is our history too scarred by inequality?

headline: Ukrainian Prime Minister Resigns as Parliament Repeals Restrictive Laws
abstract: Prime Minister Mykola Azarov’s exit, along with the reversal of legislation restricting speech and assembly, represented significant concessions by President Viktor F. Yanukovych.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Mykola Azarov, the prime minister of Ukraine, resigned on Tuesday, hours before a planned vote of no confidence by Parliament that could have stripped him of his powers.

headline: What Does It Mean When a Gay Son Takes His Husband’s Surname?
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Homosexuality', 'Names, Personal', 'Baby Boomers', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Discrimination', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Parents of a gay son who will be marrying his boyfriend are thrilled by the marriage, but less so that their son is dropping their last name.
lead_paragraph: Q. Dear Civil Behavior: My husband and I are thrilled that our son, who is in his late 20s, will be marrying his boyfriend in California this spring. I was not so happy, however, when he told me he’ll be dropping our last name and taking his fiancé's. When I married my husband in the early ‘80s I hyphenated my name, which felt like a good compromise. My husband and I are very hurt by our son’s decision, particularly since neither of us know any other same-sex couples who have chosen to do this (and we’d hoped to have grandchildren that carry on our family name). I also worry what this says about the dynamics of their relationship. I don’t want to be the mom who meddles with her son’s happiness, but am I right to be concerned? And how should I go about expressing my feelings? — Anonymous

headline: The Contract Is Signed. And Now the Negotiation Begins.
abstract: When the inventory was to be delivered for auction, the client came by with his watches and said he couldn’t abide the starting price we had agreed upon. He had changed his mind and decided that he needed the starting price to be 50 percent off retail.
lead_paragraph: We are trained in business that the ultimate goal is to get our client to sign on the dotted line. Once there’s a signature on a contract, our job as deal maker is done. All that’s left is to deliver on our end of the agreement.

headline: Daily Report: U.S. Eases Some Rules on Data Disclosure
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: The Obama administration will allow Internet companies to talk more specifically about when they are forced to turn over customer data to government agents, the Justice Department said Monday.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration says it will allow Internet companies to give customers a better idea of how often the government demands their information, but will not allow companies to disclose what is being collected or how much, Matt Apuzzo and Nicole Perlroth report.

headline: A Top Manager Resigns From China’s Foreign Exchange Agency
abstract: The government did not explain why Zhu Changhong, a former fund manager at Pimco, was no longer the chief investment officer at the State Administration of Foreign Exchange.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI – An American-trained fund manager who returned to China to help invest the world’s largest foreign exchange reserves has left his government position, the Chinese state-run news media reported on Tuesday.

headline: Bank of Montreal Parent Acquires British Asset Manager for $1.2 Billion
abstract: The BMO Financial Group will buy F&C Asset Management of Britain for 708 million pounds in a deal to merge F&C with BMO Global Asset Management, creating a combined business with £162 billion in assets under management.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – In a bid to expand its wealth management offerings in Europe, the Bank of Montreal’s parent company said on Tuesday that it would acquire F&C Asset Management of Britain for 708 million pounds, or about $1.2 billion.

headline: Tunisians Take a Step Forward
abstract: The country unveils an inclusive new constitution.
lead_paragraph: The country unveils an inclusive new constitution.

headline: Palestinian Leader Says He Can Accept Israeli Military in West Bank for 3 Years
abstract: President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority said he could accept an Israeli military presence in the West Bank for a transition period, a central issue in peace talks.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority said in an interview shown Tuesday that he could accept an Israeli military presence in the West Bank for a three-year transition period as part of a peace deal. But Mr. Abbas said “whoever proposes 10 or 15 years for a transition” was not serious about an agreement.

headline: Protest Songs, From Seeger to Sting to Springsteen
abstract: Pete Seeger on the importance of protest songs, with samples from later generations.
lead_paragraph: Val Haller, a music-obsessed baby boomer and the founder of the website Valslist.com, matches tracks from her generation to those of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: ScienceTake: Moles on the Move
abstract: The terrors of the lawn look as though they are swimming as they tunnel, but they put a lot of force behind their shovel-like paws.
lead_paragraph: The terrors of the lawn look as though they are swimming as they tunnel, but they put a lot of force behind their shovel-like paws.

headline: Uncovering the Secrets of Mole Motion
abstract: Scientists at the University of Massachusetts and Brown University are studying just how moles move all that dirt when they tunnel under the surface of lawns.
lead_paragraph: The question of how moles move all that dirt when they tunnel just under the surface of lawns has never attracted the extensive study that other forms of locomotion — like the flight of birds and insects, or even the jet-propulsion of jellyfish — have.

headline: Can You Spell That, Please?
abstract: Always double-check the spelling of names, our most common source of errors. And let’s triple-check names with multiple popular versions — like “Katherine,” “Katharine,” Catherine,” “Cathryn” and “Kathryn.”
lead_paragraph: Publishing tens of thousands of words a day, on tight deadlines, we know we can’t avoid all errors. But it’s frustrating to run correction after correction for certain mistakes that are predictable and therefore eminently avoidable. In my last post, I talked about millions and billions. This week, consider Katherine and Katharine.

headline: In Performance: Okwui Okpokwasili of ‘Bronx Gothic’
abstract: The actress performs a scene from her solo show based on notes passed between two 11-year-old girls.
lead_paragraph: This week’s video features Okwui Okpokwasili in a scene from “Bronx Gothic,” her solo show which grew out of a series of notes passed between two 11-year-old girls. Directed by Peter Born, the piece, which Ms. Okpokwasili wrote and stars in, continues through Feb. 1 at Danspace Project at St. Mark’s Church.

headline: Operas Filled With Forbidden Love in Madrid
abstract: Teatro Real’s production of Wagner’s “Tristan und Isolde” by Peter Sellars features video by Bill Viola.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Wagner’s “Tristan und Isolde,” a tale of forbidden, ill-fated love, was presented at the Teatro Real this week when one of the major events of the international opera season was also taking place at the theater: the Tuesday premiere of the composer Charles Wuorinen’s “Brokeback Mountain,” an adaptation of the acclaimed short story by Annie Proulx, who wrote the libretto. The “Tristan,” in a production by Peter Sellars, with video by Bill Viola, is a powerful staging that is new to Madrid. On Monday, the house was packed for the fifth performance of the run, attended by Queen Sofía of Spain, who waved to onlookers from the royal box, though among the applause there were scattered boos that could have been motivated by any number of political and economic issues.

headline: Lawmakers Go on the Record for Clinton
abstract: A new survey finds 56 Democratic lawmakers on Capitol Hill already committing to support Hillary Rodham Clinton if she runs for president in 2016.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Hillary Rodham Clinton again said she had not yet decided whether she would run for president in 2016. That has not stopped the Democratic Party from coalescing around her.

headline: Casablanca Capital Urges Changes at Cliffs Natural Resources
abstract: Casablanca Capital, an activist hedge fund, disclosed on Tuesday that it had taken a 5.2 percent stake in Cliffs Natural Resources, while urging the mining company to spin off its international assets and make other changes.
lead_paragraph: The activist hedge fund Casablanca Capital disclosed on Tuesday that it had taken a 5.2 percent stake in the mining company Cliffs Natural Resources and urged it to spin off its international assets and make other changes.

headline: Time Warner Cable Can Take Heart in History of Failed Hostile Bids
abstract: A review of many of the most prominent failed hostile bids suggests that targets that avoided being pressured into an unwanted deal often came out ahead.
lead_paragraph: If Time Warner Cable manages to avoid a takeover by Charter Communications, will its stock price plummet?

headline: French Court Rejects Residency Request by Roma Family
abstract: The case of Leonarda Dibrani, 15, and her family set off protests and debate after she was pulled off a school bus and expelled to Kosovo.

headline: Egypt Locks Morsi in Soundproof Cage During Trial
abstract: The soundproof enclosure, unheard-of in Egyptian courts, showed the extraordinary measures that the new government is using to silence the deposed President Mohamed Morsi.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Mohamed Morsi, the deposed Egyptian president, appeared in public on Tuesday for the second time since his detention after the military takeover in July, this time locked in a soundproof glass cage as the defendant at a criminal trial.

headline: A Romance 38 Years in the Making
abstract: Spike Jonze says his film “Her” began as a vague idea about a technological relationship.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — One of the surest signs of a film’s front-runner status is its ability to be parodied. So it’s got to be good news for Spike Jonze and the team behind “Her” that the film has attracted plenty of knock-offs, from “Saturday Night Live’s” version with Jonah Hill, “Me,” to the countless takes on YouTube, like “Troubleshooting her,” which imagines a software upgrade that helps fix the problems that develop when you fall for your computer. (“Would you like Element Software to send you a new OS1 that is not looking for anything serious right now? Reassure you that your ex-OS1 didn’t deserve you, and that you’ll meet someone new, besides he or she was, like, crazy anyway”?)

headline: Tension Grows Between Japan and China
abstract: Global implications in strained relations between Japan and China. | A Bitcoin exchange executive is charged with conspiring to launder money. | Venture capitalist Tom Perkins says he regrets his word choice, but not his message. | Vodafone as a possible takeover target.
lead_paragraph: Relations between China and Japan have been strained since World War II. But now, the regional clash is having a global economic effect, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column. The battle was on full display last week at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, setting off fears that the souring relationship could pose direct economic risk to businesses across the globe. And there may be no one to defuse the situation.

abstract: The lower costs of open-source operating systems and nonspecialized semiconductors destroyed the old computer server business and made cloud computing possible. Now Dell, which felt the pain of that, wants to do the same thing to the networking business.

Putin of Russia has for years trumpeted grand ambitions for Moscow’s relations with the European Union, pushing to break down visa barriers and urging the creation of what he calls a “harmonious economic community stretching from Lisbon to Vladivostok.”

headline: Tax Gains in Europe Lift Profit 90% at Ford

lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Ford Motor, the nation’s No. 2 automaker, said on Tuesday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 90 percent, to $3 billion, mostly because of favorable tax benefits related to investments in its European operations.

abstract: Fantex, a start-up looking to sell stocks tied to athletes’ earnings, said on Tuesday that it was moving forward with a planned initial public offering of stock linked to Vernon Davis, the star tight end of the San Francisco 49ers who experienced a concussion last fall.
lead_paragraph: Fantex, a start-up looking to sell stocks tied to athletes’ future earnings, is getting back in the game after taking a couple of hits.

headline: Adding Up the Costs of Data Breaches
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Credit Cards', 'Customer Relations', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Identity Theft', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Prosecutors often need secrecy to track down those behind cyberattacks, Peter J. Henning writes in his White Collar Watch column. But the need for a company victimized by hacking to disclose information – both to the victims and to shareholders – can be just as great.
lead_paragraph: There seems to be an announcement almost weekly that a retailer has been the victim of a cyberattack in which consumer information has been stolen. Has this become the next wave of 21st century white-collar crime as the world of electronic credit and payments opens up companies to more and more thefts of financial information?

headline: Food Matters | A Paris Restaurant Where Dessert Is What’s for Dinner
abstract: A new Marais hot spot serves multicourse meals of sweet (and not-so-sweet) treats.
lead_paragraph: “It’s time to rethink the conventions of a meal,” says the French restauranteur Philippe Baranes. That’s just what he’s done with Paris’s first all-desserts restaurant, Dessance — the name is a neologism that combines ‘dessert’ with the French word for birth, ‘naissance’ — which recently opened in a 17th-century townhouse in the city’s Marais district. “Some people find it confusing or even disturbing, but there’s no reason a dish can’t be savory and sweet at the same time,” he says. “My idea was to break the cloisonnéd way in which we think about food.” The menu at Dessance doesn’t run toward the pastries, cakes and tarts that a desserts-only concept might imply, but rather offers a small but intriguing collection of dishes that can be eaten as both desserts and main courses, including, for example, a surprising combination of violet-colored vitelotte potato purée with raw and poached apples, arugula and marjoram granité.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival Starts a Music Video Contest
abstract: Filmmakers are invited to submit music videos for one of three recently released songs to win a prize of $10,000.
lead_paragraph: The Tribeca Film Festival is collaborating with Genero, a company that makes connections between musicians and filmmakers on a contest that it is calling “Tribeca Interactive & Interlude: A Music Film Challenge.” The idea: make a music video for one of three recently released songs — Damon Albarn’s “Heavy Seas of Love,” Aloe Blacc’s “Ticking Bomb” or Ellie Goulding’s “Dead in the Water.” The prize, one for each song, is $10,000 and a trip to New York to attend the festival, which runs April 16 to 27. And the videos will be used in the promotional campaigns for the recordings.

headline: R.B.S. to Reduce Foreign Exchange Benchmark Offerings
abstract: The Royal Bank of Scotland will reduce the range of foreign exchange benchmarks it offers to clients amid investigations by regulators into whether traders at some of the world’s largest banks colluded to manipulate the $5-trillion-a-day currency markets.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Tuesday that it would reduce the range of foreign exchange benchmarks it offers to clients who trade currency markets.

headline: The Editorial Board’s SOTU Wish List
abstract: What the president should say in tonight’s speech.
lead_paragraph: President Obama will deliver the annual State of the Union address tonight at 9 p.m. As someone who has covered these speeches since 1989, I sometimes wish the president would just send a written report up to Congress, which is all that is required by the Constitution, instead of giving a speech that is too politically massaged, filled with too much ritualistic applause, goes on too long and is watched by a dwindling number of Americans.

headline: Tarantino Sues Gawker for Posting Film Script

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Quentin Tarantino filed a suit against Gawker Media, accusing the web news service of illegally posting on its Defamer site a link to his unproduced script titled “The Hateful Eight,” The Hollywood Reporter said on Monday.

headline: Share Your Story About Postpartum Depression
abstract: Have you faced problems related to pregnancy or the birth of a child? We’d like to hear your story.
lead_paragraph: Setting up a nursery and bringing home a newborn evokes images of blissful mothers, delighting in the joys of parenthood. But the experience of pregnancy and caring for a baby can also cause feelings of depression, anxiety and, in rare cases, psychosis. Pam Belluck, a New York Times health reporter, will be examining new efforts by scientists and doctors to better understand the causes and consequences of postpartum mood disorders.

headline: Challenges for the Yellen Fed
abstract: As Federal Reserve chief, Janet Yellen faces the task of tightening monetary policy without choking off the domestic recovery or causing upheaval overseas that could rebound on the United States, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant secretary for economic policy at the Treasury Department from 2006 to 2009.

headline: Albert Cashier’s Secret
abstract: Like hundreds of women during the Civil War, Jennie Hodgers disguised herself as a man in order to fight. Unlike most others, though, after the war ended, her cover remained.
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 1914, a Civil War veteran named Albert Cashier arrived at the Illinois state hospital for the insane with symptoms of advanced dementia. As a young private, Cashier had fought at the siege of Vicksburg, where he and his comrades broke the spine of the Confederacy, and his name was inscribed on the Illinois victory monument there. He had lived out the intervening years in modest circumstances, working as a farm hand, a laborer and, on occasion, a street lamplighter, one of the many former soldiers whose civilian lives never achieve the glory of their wartime service. He was destined for the same obscurity in death, had it not been for a secret that the state hospital made public: Albert Cashier was actually a woman named Jennie Hodgers.

headline: More Ships Sailing the Caribbean
abstract: More choice for travelers, and perhaps some good deals.
lead_paragraph: A fleet of new ships in the Caribbean could mean not just greater selection but better deals for tropics-bound sailors. In November, the year-old, 3,502-guest MSC Divina began sailing year-round to the Caribbean from Miami. The new 4,000-passenger Norwegian Getaway launches Feb. 8, offering Caribbean itineraries from its home port, also Miami. In May, Princess Cruises introduces the 3,560-passenger Regal Princess in the Mediterranean; it will move to Fort Lauderdale in November to serve the eastern Caribbean. Making its debut in November, Royal Caribbean International’s 4,905-passenger Quantum of the Seas will offer regular Caribbean and Bahamas sailings from Cape Liberty, N.J.

headline: Cherished Beams of Sunlight, as Captured by Readers
abstract: In New York, a city forever sprouting new buildings, natural sunlight can often disappear. Here, readers submitted their experiences of light and shadow in the city.
lead_paragraph: As New York City grows ever more vertical, sprouting fresh batches of breathtakingly high towers by the year, one of the casualties has been natural sunlight. Streets, stoops and parks are growing darker, and people’s apartments are too, which we explored in an article last month. We asked readers to submit their experiences of light and shadow in New York City, and discovered anew how deeply personal light, and its absence, is for people living in this space-deprived town.

headline: Smear Today, Gone Tomorrow?
abstract: Kim Guadagno versus the arts.
lead_paragraph: Last week I mentioned local news reports about the bizarre and vicious smear campaign Kim Guadagno, Chris Christie’s lieutenant governor, waged against an artist involved with the New Jersey Arts Council. Today the story is in the Times. Ms. Guadagno sure seems like a real piece of work — as do several other close associates of governor yells-at-people.

headline: Pushing Inaction on Immigration
abstract: Some conservatives think real reform would be tactically foolish.
lead_paragraph: Some moderate Republicans are finally worried enough about alienating large chunks of the American electorate that they are considering the idea of giving legal status to millions of undocumented immigrants in the United States – and even citizenship to a much smaller group.

headline: Teach the Super Bowl: Ideas for Subjects Across the Curriculum
abstract: How can you make this week’s Super Bowl relevant to your curriculum? Whether debating football-related controversies, making predictions, analyzing ads, writing descriptions, understanding data and statistics or learning about head trauma, we have ideas for using The Times and the Learning Network to do it.
lead_paragraph: How can you make this week’s Super Bowl relevant to your curriculum? Whether debating football-related controversies, making predictions, analyzing ads, writing descriptions, understanding data and statistics or learning about head trauma, we have ideas for using The Times and the Learning Network to do it.

headline: Video of Palestinian President is Shown at Tel Aviv Conference
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Palestinians', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: President Mahmoud Abbas said that he could accept an Israeli military presence in the West Bank for a three-year transition period as part of a peace deal.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Jodi Rudoren reported, the Palestinian president has said in a recorded interview that he could accept an Israeli military presence in the West Bank for a three-year transition period as part of a peace deal.

headline: On the Problem of Defining Upper Class
abstract: Working Wall Street stiffs, unite!
lead_paragraph: Aha. When I wrote about the problem of saying where upper class begins, I somehow forgot that the whole thing was explained long ago by Gordon Gekko:

headline: Louis C. K. to Release His First Feature Film Online
abstract: The film, “Tomorrow Night,” played at Sundance in 1998, but never got distribution. It will be available on the Louis C. K.’s website for $5.
lead_paragraph: The great white whale for Louis C. K. completists is now in sight. On Wednesday at noon, he will release “Tomorrow Night,” his rarely seen first feature film (which he wrote, directed and played a cameo role in) on his website where it will be available for $5. The movie was shown at the Sundance Film Festival in 1998 but never got distribution.

headline: Jimmy Carter Book on Women’s Rights Is Set for March Release
abstract: Simon & Schuster said the book, “A Call to Action: Women, Religion, Violence and Power,” would be based on Mr. Carter’s world travels.
lead_paragraph: Simon & Schuster will publish a new book by Jimmy Carter on the treatment of women, the publisher said on Tuesday.

headline: Ukraine’s Uncertainties Include Financial Aid
keywords: ['Government Bonds', 'Credit and Debt', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Politics and Government', 'Foreign Aid']
abstract: In the middle of political unrest, Ukraine’s opposition appears closer to forcing the rejection of agreements with Russia and turning to the West.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — As Ukraine’s political crisis has deepened, an economic question looms: Will Russia continue to bail out the country if it again tilts to the West?

headline: A Video Lesson in Picture Framing
abstract: T’s European editor, Rita Konig, offers subtle insights into packaging and hanging art.
lead_paragraph: “Each frame does something different to the picture,” says Rita Konig, T’s European editor. In this new video for T, she takes a trip to the Lacy Gallery in West London to have a print of a red onion by the artist Rory McEwen framed. Along the way, she shares her sometimes unorthodox philosophy on picture framing, then goes on to offer a few thoughtful pointers on picture hanging as well.

headline: Reflections on Falluja and the Impermanence of Victory
keywords: ['Darts (Game)', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Though an affiliate of Al Qaeda has taken control of much of Falluja, Iraq, in recent weeks, a Marine officer refuses to believe that her service in the country was for nothing.
lead_paragraph: Before there was a battle for Falluja, we threw darts.

headline: Kocherlakota and the Cultists
abstract: No more Kool-Aid.
lead_paragraph: Narayana Kocherlakota, president of the Minneapolis Fed, is the prodigal son of monetary stimulus. He was the Fed’s leading hawk a few years ago, reflecting in part the ultra-freshwater macro doctrines of the Minnesota econ department and his bank’s closely associated research department. But he did something amazing: he looked at evidence, listened to his critics, and changed his views — becoming the Fed’s leading dove.

headline: Serbian Ex-Fugitives Mladic and Karadzic Reunite in Court
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Ratko Mladic, a Bosnian Serb former general, was reunited with his old political boss, Radovan Karadzic, in court in The Hague. Both are accused of war crimes, including helping to engineer the 1995 massacre at Srebrenica.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — One is a former warrior known as the Butcher of Bosnia who spent more than 15 years on the run in his native Serbia, where he was finally captured.

headline: Super Bowl Attracts a Marijuana Message
abstract: The Marijuana Policy Project, a group that is asking the N.F.L. to change its rules on marijuana, has spent $5,000 to rent billboards near MetLife Stadium.
lead_paragraph: New Jersey probably looks a lot like home to the Denver Broncos. The billboards, anyway.

headline: With Eye on Spain, Liberty Said to Join Hunt for ONO
abstract: The Spanish cable operator ONO, an enticing prospect for any large telecommunications firm looking to expand in Europe, has reportedly drawn interest from John C. Malone’s Liberty Global media company as well as the British cellphone giant Vodafone.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — On the heels of its $13.7 billion deal on Monday to buy the Dutch cable operator Ziggo, John C. Malone’s Liberty Global media company is now reported to be in talks to acquire the Spanish telecoms operator ONO, according to The Financial Times.

headline: The Gun Report: January 28, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: More than 7,000 children and teenagers were hospitalized for firearm injuries in 2009, according to a study in February’s Pediatrics. That works out to twenty young people per day. Six percent of those hospitalizations resulted in a death.

headline: A Familiar Trip for a Pre-Crisis Buyout
abstract: Seven years after taking airline reservations operator Sabre private, TPG and Silver Lake are returning to the public markets. It’s one of many big buyouts that should land safely, says Jeffrey Goldfarb of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Another big pre-crisis buyout is heading for an unexpectedly safe landing. Seven years after taking travel technology company Sabre private for $5 billion, owners TPG and Silver Lake Partners are making the round-trip return to public markets. It’s one of many boom-time deals whose badly timed takeoff led to a bumpy ride.

headline: Second Outdoor N.H.L. Game in the Bronx Is a Hot Ticket
abstract: Wednesday’s Rangers-Islanders game at Yankee Stadium is now sold out, the N.H.L. said, and ticket prices on the secondary market have risen sharply since Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Ticket demand for the Rangers-Islanders game at Yankee Stadium on Wednesday night has increased, a sign that the N.H.L.’s strategy of staging two outdoor games in the metropolitan area during Super Bowl week is succeeding.

headline: State of the States
keywords: ['Governors (US)', 'Speeches and Statements', 'States (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The State of the State speech, that annual display of policy and pride, can be a call to action, plea for patience and, in some cases, an early look at a re-election platform.
lead_paragraph: The State of the State speech, that annual display of policy and pride, can be a call to action, plea for patience and, in some cases, an early look at a re-election platform.

headline: Report Says BBC Executives’ Oversight of Digital Project Was Flawed
abstract: The independent British report does not single out any executives. The BBC’s director general at the time was Mark Thompson, now chief executive of The Times.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — An independent report published on Tuesday accused the BBC of significant management failings in connection with an abandoned 126 million pound digital project, saying the broadcaster failed to assess the initiative properly or provide adequate oversight of its progress.

headline: Pakistani University Cancels Event Promoting Teenager’s Memoir
abstract: Officials at Peshawar University said the provincial government of Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa had forced them to cancel a ceremony honoring Malala Yousafzai, the Pakistani education advocate.
lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — Malala Yousafzai may be a global celebrity, but in her home province, she remains a focus of controversy.

headline: Thai Aristocrat Joins Political Fray, Backing Elections
abstract: Malinee Chakrabandhu is a champion of elections at a time when many in Thailand’s upper classes are calling for the overthrow of the government and a suspension of democracy.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — With a buzzer installed in her house to summon her servants and a royal title that helps secure choice tables at Bangkok restaurants, Malinee Chakrabandhu is a bona fide member of the Thai aristocracy.

headline: Complete Ben Jonson Released Online
abstract: The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Ben Jonson online offers plays, masques, poems, letters, criticism and more.
lead_paragraph: Shakespeare may get all the love on the modern stage, but his contemporary Ben Jonson has just grabbed a share of the limelight in cyberspace.

headline: A Small Window Into Apple, Courtesy of Tim Cook
abstract: Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, offered some valuable insights about the company during the question and answer segment of Monday’s earnings call.
lead_paragraph: Apple sold more iPhones and iPads over the last quarter than any other quarter. Yet Apple’s profit was flat compared with last year, and iPhone sales were down in North America, raising questions among investors about how much room Apple has to grow.

headline: Pigs in Blankets, Artful Pie Pans, Gluten-Free Cakes and More
abstract: Recommendations for the week of Jan. 28.
lead_paragraph: To Snack: Wee Pigs Till the Wee Hours

headline: Beyoncé Doesn’t Faze ‘Frozen’s’ Songwriters
abstract: The married couple who came up with the smash soundtrack were surprised their music beat the superstar’s surprise December album. Then again, they, say, “We imagine that if she meets us, she won’t be that mad at us.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “Frozen,” the Disney-animated and Oscar-nominated hit, is also one of the longest-running blockbusters of the season, with a 10-week streak at or near the top of the box office. The company announced that a sing-along version of the film would be shown at more than 1,000 theaters around the country on Friday even as its directors, Jennifer Lee and Chris Buck, are in Japan, in advance of its March 15 opening there. (That’s more international dollars for Disney, if the popularity of a foreign language-version of the film’s theme song, “Let It Go,” is to be believed. )

headline: What We’re Reading Now
abstract: An assortment of sub-zero links.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Department of Agriculture briefly suspended poultry processing at one of the biggest Foster Farms plants in California because it was infested with live cockroaches. But Bill Marler asks, why does the U.S.D.A. and its food inspection service have the authority to shutter a plant for cockroaches but not for salmonella?

headline: Introducing Jennifer Blumin, New Business Group Member
abstract: Skylight Group creates event spaces in large, distinctive, typically historic locations for corporate clients that include Google, Ralph Lauren and Nike.
lead_paragraph: In my last post, we met two of three new members to join the She Owns It business group. This post introduces the third.

headline: For Fliers, a Month Marked by Cancellations
abstract: Weather has led to more than 33,000 canceled flights in January.
lead_paragraph: The new year has gotten off to a rough start for fliers, with winter storms causing tens of thousands canceled flights in the first few weeks of 2014 (more than in January 2012 and January 2013 combined) and a forecast that has both airlines and passengers bracing for another blow this week.

headline: Pete Seeger
abstract: The folk musician and activist at the Beacon Sloop Club.
lead_paragraph: The folk musician and activist at the Beacon Sloop Club.

headline: Super Bowl Teams Meet the Media
abstract: Images from the N.F.L.’s Super Bowl media day on Tuesday at the Prudential Center in Newark, where hundreds of reporters interviewed players from the Seattle Seahawks and the Denver Broncos.
lead_paragraph: Images from the N.F.L.’s Super Bowl media day on Tuesday at the Prudential Center in Newark, where hundreds of reporters interviewed players from the Seattle Seahawks and the Denver Broncos.

headline: A Softer Front Page: The Readers React
abstract: Plenty of disagreement about a shift away from hard news.
lead_paragraph: Consider the media habits of Mathew Ingram, a senior writer on media and technology at GigaOm, the online news site.

headline: Robert Diamond’s New Firm Hires Executive From J. C. Flowers
abstract: Atlas Merchant Capital, the firm that Robert E. Diamond Jr. founded last year, said late on Monday that it had hired David Schamis from J. C. Flowers & Company as a founding partner.
lead_paragraph: As Robert E. Diamond Jr.  builds his new firm — his latest venture since leaving Barclays as chief executive — he has hired some experienced help to serve by his side.

headline: Times Minute | State of Union Preview
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'State of the Union Message', 'Law and Legislation', 'Immigration']

lead_paragraph: On the Minute, a look ahead to this evening’s State of the Union address — from President Obama’s tone to the expected Republican response.

headline: Harkness Foundation for Dance Names New Director
abstract: Joan Finkelstein will succeed Theodore S. Bartwink at the Harkness Foundation, which distributes grants to dance companies.
lead_paragraph: For more than three decades, Theodore S. Bartwink, the executive director of the Harkness Foundation for Dance, has helped distribute millions of dollars in grants to scores of dance companies. But with Mr. Bartwink now 85, and recovering from injuries he sustained when he was struck by a car last year, the foundation announced that he would be retiring.

headline: Living in Mendham Borough , N.J.
abstract: A Morris County town with a direct train line to Manhattan and nearby corporate employers.
lead_paragraph: A Morris County town with a direct train line to Manhattan and nearby corporate employers.

headline: An Outpost of New England
abstract: Mendham Borough, N.J., in western Morris County, offers a quiet lifestyle and a diverse housing stock, from rentals to multimillion-dollar estates.
lead_paragraph: Does it still exist, the town with a mud hole for fishing, a four-lane bowling alley, and Labor Day festivities with a 70-year history? A place where the schools and the scenery are far above average?

headline: Printing a Photo From a Phone
abstract: Once a photo is transferred from a smartphone, the user has a number of options for making a copy.
lead_paragraph: Q. I have a photo on my phone that I want to print out and give to a friend, but how do I get it off my phone? Do I need a special photo printer or can the regular printer I use do it?

headline: Keep the Joy, Take Back the Fun
abstract: Jennifer Senior’s “All Joy and No Fun” answers why being a parent doesn’t tend to offer much immediate pleasure. How can I get the fun back?
lead_paragraph: Is life as a parent “all joy and no fun”? That’s the premise, or at least the title, of Jennifer Senior’s book on “The Paradox of Modern Parenthood.” Janet Maslin reviewed the book for The Times under the wonderful headline “My Kid’s Idle for a Second? Oh, Horrors!” (You can hear Ms. Senior talk about the book in the video below this post.)

headline: Nocturnalist at the Super Bowl | First Stop, the Barker Bowl
abstract: The Nocturnalist checks out an athletic spectacle rivaling the big game itself: Barker Bowl, a dog football match at the Morris Animal Inn, an ultra luxury pet boardinghouse in Morristown.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a while since we dusted off the gowns and hit a party in the name of journalism; too long, 760 days too long in fact — not that we’ve been counting every agonizingly boring night since we last assumed our alter ego Nocturnalist and hit the town, notebook in hand.

headline: Dreaming About a Summer Rental? Act Soon
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Coastal Areas']
abstract: Sure, it’s winter now, but if you want to enjoy the warm weather ahead in a vacation home, you may want to get moving.
lead_paragraph: The race is on. There may be snow on the ground but if you want to rent a summer house in some of the most competitive markets in the northeast — the Hamptons, Cape Cod, the Jersey Shore — it’s time to put down your shovel and pick up your checkbook. Novice renter? Not to worry. Here’s a primer.

headline: Hotel Review: Lumeria Maui
abstract: Renovated in 2012 with a New Age aesthetic, the Lumeria bills itself as a “sanctuary for authentic transformational travel.”
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: Restaurant Report: Tosca Cafe in San Francisco
abstract: The team behind the Spotted Pig in New York has turned a 95-year-old spot into San Francisco’s restaurant of the moment.
lead_paragraph: After working our way through gridlock around the bar, my husband and I reached the gatekeeper at the dining room. It was 7:15 on a Wednesday evening, and the wait for a table, we were told, would be “45 minutes to an hour and a half.”

headline: TV Stations in Los Angeles to Share a Channel to Free Up Spectrum
abstract: The experiment is intended to show the extent to which broadcast channels can be squeezed together on the electromagnetic spectrum without degrading signal quality.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two broadcast television stations in Los Angeles will become the first participants in a pilot test of the government’s plans to eventually free up and auction off more airwaves for use in wireless broadband, officials said on Tuesday.

headline: U.N. Takes New Steps in Central African Republic
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The United Nations Security Council approved a resolution aimed at people suspected of committing war crimes in Central African Republic, which has been upended by sectarian violence.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The United Nations Security Council voted unanimously on Tuesday to impose a travel ban on and freeze the assets of people suspected of war crimes in Central African Republic, as the European Union prepared to send a battalion to protect civilians from an unrelenting sectarian war there.

headline: A Swipe at Traditional Banking at a Forum Illuminating Bitcoin
abstract: A hearing on the regulatory future of Bitcoin gave advocates the chance to enumerate what they view as the advantages Bitcoin could provide over current systems of moving money around the world.
lead_paragraph: A hearing Tuesday on the regulatory future of Bitcoin instead turned into a forum on the shortcomings of the traditional banking industry.

headline: Prince Files Lawsuit Over Links to Music File-Sharing Sites
abstract: Lawyers for Prince filed suit against 22 Internet users who posted links to file-sharing sites on Facebook or in blogs.
lead_paragraph: Prince Rogers Nelson — the artist known as the artist formerly known as Prince — has filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court in San Francisco against 22 Internet users who, the singer’s lawyers say, are responsible for posting links to unauthorized recordings of his concerts. The filing, which was first reported on Torrent Freak, a website devoted to file sharing and copyright issues, describes the 22 bloggers as part of a network who used their blogs and Facebook pages to distribute the recordings. Prince hopes to recover $1 million from each. Only two of the 22 — Dan Chodera and Karina Jindrova — are listed by their real names. The others are listed by Internet handles like PurpleHouse2, PurpleKissTwo and TheUltimateBootlegExperience.

abstract: On the Minute, a look ahead to this evening’s State of the Union address — from President Obama’s tone to the expected Republican online response.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Irish Government Ordered to Compensate Abuse Victim
abstract: A human rights court ruled that a woman should be compensated for the government’s failure to protect her from sexual abuse as a child at a state-funded Roman Catholic school in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — The European Court of Human Rights ruled on Tuesday that a 49-year-old Irish woman was entitled to compensation for the government’s failure to protect her from sexual abuse as a child when she attended a publicly financed Roman Catholic primary school in the 1970s.

headline: More Than Just a Pretty Seed
abstract: Pomegranate seeds and their juice can be used in meat dishes, herb salads, vinaigrettes and, of course, cocktails.
lead_paragraph: Pomegranates are beautiful, of course, but they can seem more suitable for garnishing than gratification.

headline: Clip: 'Charlie Victor Romeo'
abstract: A scene from the film directed by Robert Berger, Patrick Daniels, and Karlyn Michelson.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film directed by Robert Berger, Patrick Daniels, and Karlyn Michelson.

lead_paragraph: A guide to all things Super Bowl XLVIII around the New York/New Jersey metro area.

abstract: Photos from Central African Republic, Syria, China and Greece.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Central African Republic, Syria, China and Greece.

headline: From a Nest of Rhythm, Teaching the Young to Fly
abstract: The National Dance Institute’s Celebration Team performed on Monday in a benefit, “Jacques’ Art Nest: The DNA of Choreography.”
lead_paragraph: Many ballet dancers, after retiring, go on to start their own schools. Jacques d’Amboise, who had a celebrated career of almost 35 years with New York City Ballet, found his second calling even before he left the company, when he established the National Dance Institute in 1976. This is no elite ballet academy but a far-reaching nonprofit that teaches kids about the joy of movement (something that strict classical training can’t always claim to do). The real lessons, of course, are in areas like self-confidence and teamwork.

headline: The Price for Super Bowl Volunteers
abstract: Aware of litigation against Major League Baseball, the N.F.L. this year hired some paid workers for positions normally filled by volunteers, making some wonder why it is not paying all of the workers.
lead_paragraph: Volunteerism has become as much a part of the Super Bowl as the Roman numeral identification of games, allowing those who cannot attend the games to be a part of the festivities by welcoming those who can.

headline: A Critique of an Upbeat Assessment of Nuclear Power’s Prospects
abstract: The Union of Concerned Scientists finds big holes in the argument of four scientists seeking a fresh push on nuclear energy.
lead_paragraph: The Union of Concerned Scientists, a nonprofit group long focused on risks attending the use of nuclear energy, has posted a critique of the pro-nuclear letter from four longtime analysts that was the focus of a recent piece here titled “More Views on Nuclear Power, Waste, Safety and Cost.”

headline: Moscow 57 on Delancey Street and More Restaurant Openings
abstract: Borscht and blini in the shadow of the Williamsburg Bridge; an Indian spot in Chelsea; and a sushi restaurant branches out.
lead_paragraph: Headliner Moscow 57

headline: Fine Tempura, Piece by Delectable Piece
abstract: A memorable meal in Tokyo, but not easily found at home.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Last year at a counter in a small restaurant here, I ate tempura that seemed elevated to an art form, like the finest sushi.

headline: What’s In It | Protein Bars
abstract: Protein bars offer convenience, but they can also contain as much sugar as a candy bar and the calorie count of an entire meal.
lead_paragraph: Protein bars offer convenience, but they can also contain as much sugar as a candy bar and the calorie count of an entire meal.

headline: A Look Inside the Protein Bar
abstract: A closer examination of these energy-boosting snacks shows that their blessings are mixed.
lead_paragraph: Protein is the hot ingredient of the moment in processed foods, joining the terms organic and low-fat as a major selling point to pitch to health-conscious shoppers. While carbohydrates and many fats are still widely regarded as suspect, protein is being proudly added to products throughout the grocery store, especially the snack aisle, which has made way for a new star: the protein bar. But a closer look shows that its blessings are mixed.

headline: With Social Media’s Rise, the Pulpit Isn’t Just the President’s Anymore
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'Social Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The State of the Union address on Tuesday spawned a bipartisan embrace of photo- and video-sharing platforms, and a rush to create tweetable graphics and hashtags to amplify party messages.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Twitter has fast become the conventional-wisdom clearinghouse and real-time echo chamber for major political events, so it was not surprising Tuesday evening when Twitter also became the forum where opinion on President Obama’s State of the Union address seemed to crystallize before he had even finished speaking.

headline: Profit Surges for AT&T, Outstripping Expectations
abstract: For its wireless business, AT&T said it added 566,000 contract subscribers, the most valuable type of customers.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — AT&T finished 2013 strong despite aggressive moves from T-Mobile US, the smaller wireless carrier.

headline: New York Property Managers Devise Survival Plans for the Next Disaster
abstract: Caught short by the 2012 hurricane that slammed into the region, building owners are rethinking their preparedness, stocking up and creating checklists.
lead_paragraph: In the hectic days that followed Hurricane Sandy, the only place that John Ambrosini could find cell service was on a hill near his home on the North Shore of Long Island.

headline: Fred and Barney Would Feel Right at Home
abstract: Going back to the cave, M. Wells Steakhouse offers a feast of prehistoric proportions.
lead_paragraph: The steakhouse is in trouble. Not financial trouble, because new ones keep opening, but spiritual trouble. Its soul is unwell. Because many other restaurants now offer better beef, the steakhouse serves little purpose except as a stage set for the dwindling number of occasions that require men to bond by spending money and consuming red meat together.

headline: With Ad Dollars Elusive, Yahoo’s Revenue Falls
abstract: The Internet portal and web publisher said its fourth-quarter revenue was $1.27 billion, down 6 percent from the same quarter a year ago.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Under the turnaround plan devised by Yahoo’s chief executive, Marissa Mayer, the company gained traffic and mobile users in 2013 and introduced a bevy of products, like a slick digital food magazine and a mobile weather app.

headline: Wall Street Listens for Litigation and Tax Clues in Obama’s Speech
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'State of the Union Message (US)']
abstract: Like last year, Wall Street might not be at the top of President Obama’s agenda in tonight’s State of the Union Address. But that doesn’t mean the financial community won’t be listening for certain cues.
lead_paragraph: Like last year, Wall Street might not be at the top of President Obama’s agenda in his State of the Union address on Tuesday night. But that doesn’t mean the financial community won’t be listening for certain cues.

headline: Severe Cold Moves New York’s Homeless to Seek Help
abstract: Frigid temperatures have led to greater outreach efforts and some people who live on the streets and in parks to accept beds, even if temporarily.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Scott managed to survive in the nooks and crannies of Manhattan for two winters, burrowing under piles of blankets and cardboard on West 31st Street if he could not find a spot at Pennsylvania Station, the Port Authority Bus Terminal or on the E train.

headline: The Star Treatment for a Little-Known Work
abstract: Marc-André Hamelin gave a rare performance on Monday of the Sonata in E Minor (Op. 25, No. 2) by Nicolas Medtner in a recital at Zankel Hall.
lead_paragraph: I’m a little ashamed to admit I wasn’t entirely looking forward to the pianist Marc-André Hamelin’s recital on Monday evening at Zankel Hall. The centerpiece was a rare performance of the Sonata in E minor (Op. 25, No. 2) by Nicolas Medtner (1880-1951), a Russian composer — well known neither in his time nor ours — championed by Mr. Hamelin.

headline: Kellogg Foundation to Give  $40 Million to Aid Detroit Institute of Arts
abstract: The pledge brings the overall amount promised by an array of national and local foundations to $370 million.
lead_paragraph: The W.K. Kellogg Foundation announced Tuesday that it would contribute $40 million toward the broad philanthropic effort announced earlier this month to try to save the collection of the Detroit Institute of Arts and to avoid cuts to municipal pensions in Detroit’s federal bankruptcy case.

headline: Lower Manhattan Landlords Compete for BNY Mellon
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Towers on and near the World Trade Center site and on the Jersey City waterfront hope to lure a bank planning to lease at least 350,000 square feet.
lead_paragraph: A venerable Wall Street firm’s search for a new home has set off a fierce competition among developers in Lower Manhattan, highlighting the challenges in a commercial district that has acres of vacant office space even as towers are under construction.

headline: The Urban Home Away From Home
abstract: The clash between a McDonald’s in Queens and elderly Koreans who like congregating there offers lessons about aging communities’ needs.
lead_paragraph: But why that McDonald’s?

headline: Marinara Sauce
