lead_paragraph: Every home cook should have a basic marinara sauce in his or her repertoire. Julia Moskin makes a simple recipe from Lidia Bastianich’s book, “Lidia’s Commonsense Italian Cooking.”

headline: It’s Not About 007, but It Sort of Is
abstract: “Fleming: The Man Who Would Be Bond” chronicles the World War II years of Ian Fleming, who created James Bond.
lead_paragraph: To answer your main question first: about 10 minutes.

headline: Marinara Worth Mastering
abstract: No jar sauce can mimic the fresh tomato, the velvety texture and the rich bite of olive oil.
lead_paragraph: The first thing to know about marinara: it’s not a synonym for tomato sauce.

headline: Erskine Bowles to Lead Morgan Stanley Board
abstract: Erskine Bowles, who has served as a director of the board since 2005, has been named as lead director, replacing C. Robert Kidder.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley announced Tuesday that Erskine Bowles, who has served as a director of the board since 2005, had been named as lead director.

headline: Yahoo Earnings Shed More Light on Alibaba’s Growth
abstract: Yahoo is nominally the focus of its fourth-quarter earnings report, but another company is receiving just as much scrutiny: Alibaba of China, the Chinese e-commerce behemoth that is still growing fast.
lead_paragraph: Yahoo is nominally the focus of its fourth-quarter earnings report, but another company is receiving just as much scrutiny: Alibaba of China.

headline: Interview: Alfre Woodard
abstract: Melena Ryzik speaks to the actress at the Screen Actors Guild awards.
lead_paragraph: Melena Ryzik speaks to the actress at the Screen Actors Guild awards.

headline: In Search of Confidence
abstract: Though consumer confidence increased in the latest Conference Board survey, optimism about an upturn in one’s own financial circumstances remains at historical lows.
lead_paragraph: The consumer confidence figures just released showed an increase, but they remain at a level that is historically low.

headline: Video: Alfre Woodard’s Sole Scene
abstract: The actress explains how physicality, not historical research, was essential to her turn in “12 Years a Slave.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Alfre Woodard has just one scene in “12 Years a Slave,” but it is a pivotal one for the film and for the screenwriter, John Ridley. The moment, which was not in the Solomon Northup memoir on which the film is based, involves the slaves Patsey (Lupita Nyong’o) and Solomon (Chiwetel Ejiofor) visiting another plantation for a tea party of sorts held by a slave turned favored lady, Mistress Shaw (played by Ms. Woodard). Mr. Ridley invented the scene, and it was the most difficult thing he wrote, he said, containing one of the few touches of humor in the film.

headline: For Soggy Everton, No Bright Side in Loss to Liverpool
abstract: Daniel Sturridge scored twice and Luis Suárez got his 23rd goal of the Premier League season as Liverpool ran over Everton, 4-0, in the Merseyside Derby.
lead_paragraph: LIVERPOOL, England — Everton Manager Roberto Martínez is a genuinely upbeat man, a coach who can seemingly find positives in anything. When his former team, Wigan, was relegated from the Premier League last year, he admitted to disappointment, but noted that the club was on “fantastic financial footing” and had a promising “football philosophy.”

headline: An Iraq Blasted Open, Sketched From the Inside
abstract: In his short-story collection “The Corpse Exhibition,” Hassan Blasim describes the casual fatalism of life in an Iraq torn by war and terrorism.
lead_paragraph: The literature of American warfare tends to land in overlapping waves, like an invasion. First come the novels by the war correspondents. Then, in time, fiction begins to arrive from the returning combatants. Only later, like cries of the wounded after a barrage subsides, can the other side finally make itself heard.

headline: Comparing Obamacare to Its Alternative
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Income Tax', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: The Republicans have been promising to “repeal and replace” the health law for years. Now we know what they want to replace it with.
lead_paragraph: FROM the moment the ink dried on March 23, 2010, Republicans said they intended to “repeal and replace” the Affordable Care Act. They have voted more than 40 times to wipe the law from the books. But Republicans have never gotten around to describing, in detail, the set of policies they believe should replace Obamacare. That is, until yesterday.

headline: An Artistic Life Retraced, in Fantasy and Memory
abstract: Douglas Dunn’s troupe is presenting “Aubade,” his autobiographical but enigmatic dance work, at the Alexander Kasser Theater in Montclair, N.J.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — The best thing about Douglas Dunn’s dances is how they are unlike anyone else’s. His eclectic works also differ from one another, but they all seem to express a particular, peculiar sensibility: elegant, eccentric, serious, wry, fascinated by contradictions, susceptible to beauty but skeptical, too.

headline: In a First, Northwestern Players Seek Unionization
abstract: The former Wildcats quarterback Kain Colter joined executives of the newly formed College Athletes Players Association and the United Steel Workers in order to be granted “a seat at the table.”
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The increasingly contentious and complicated relationship between the N.C.A.A. and its top amateur athletes took another step toward a legal showdown on Tuesday when a group of Northwestern football players appealed to the National Labor Relations Board with the first effort by college athletes to join a labor union.

headline: A Medici to Spray Paint and Graffiti Artists
abstract: Martin Wong, a collector of New York graffiti art, is being commemorated through “City as Canvas” at the Museum of the City of New York.
lead_paragraph: “Times have changed,” Aaron Goodstone said stoically, eyeing the spruced-up brick tenement at Ridge and Stanton Streets on the Lower East Side, now hip, where his friend Martin Wong once lived. Thirty years ago, when Mr. Goodstone was a teenage graffiti artist, he vied with drug dealers for the corner pay phone to reach Wong in his buzzerless sixth-floor walk-up: a salon, a studio, an archive and a refuge among the crumbling buildings and gated storefronts.

headline: Live Coverage of Obama’s 2014 State of the Union Address
abstract: President Obama delivers his State of the Union address Tuesday night and Times reporters and editors are providing analysis during the speech.
lead_paragraph: President Obama delivers his State of the Union address Tuesday night, and Times reporters and editors are providing analysis during the speech.

headline: House Votes to Restrict Payments for Abortions
abstract: The vote, mainly along party lines, stands no chance in the Senate, but thrust the issue into the polarizing politics of an election year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House of Representatives voted on Tuesday to impose tighter restrictions on federal payments for abortions, thrusting the issue of a woman’s right to terminate a pregnancy into the polarizing politics of an election year.

headline: Agnes Varis Trust to Give $3 Million to Gibney Dance
abstract: The gift is earmarked to fund the restoration of 36,000 square feet at 280 Broadway in Lower Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The Agnes Varis Trust will give $3 million to Gibney Dance, the formerly all-women dance troupe that is known for its social activism and is about to expand its operations to 280 Broadway in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Answers to a Puzzling Deal at Alibaba Remain in the Shadows
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Alibaba’s acquisition of a sleepy technology company set of a flurry of speculation. After Alibaba’s public debut, scrutiny of its deals will only intensify, the Deal Professor writes.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese Internet giant Alibaba is looking to join the ranks of Google and Microsoft with an initial public offering that could give it a value of more than $100 billion. But the company’s recent acquisition of the Hong Kong-listed company Citic 21CN shows just how much we still don’t know about Alibaba and its business.

headline: Military Is Asked to Return Guantánamo Inmate to Yemen
abstract: A lawyer for Abdel Malik Ahmed Abdel Wahab al-Rahabi, a Guantánamo inmate for 12 years, sought his return to Yemen, but a military profile said there were risks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A lawyer for a Yemeni man who has been held for 12 years without trial at the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, asked a parole-style military board on Tuesday to recommend that he be sent home, where he planned to teach and possibly start a “milk and honey farm” or work for his father’s tailoring business, according to a prepared statement.

headline: Met Opera Reports Falling Attendance
abstract: The company sold just 79 percent of its seats in the 2012-13 season, a fall it attributes to higher prices and Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: Although the Metropolitan Opera is raising more money from donors and earning more from its “Live in HD” movie theater presentations, it is making less at the box office, selling just 79 percent of its seats in the 2012-13 season, it announced in a financial filing.

headline: Capturing Football’s Snaps, Crackles and Pops in Madden NFL
abstract: While the National Football League season is about to end, EA Sports is preparing the next version of its Madden NFL video game, adding new movements recorded using stunt players.
lead_paragraph: BURNABY, British Columbia — The football players strutted down a 40-yard strip of synthetic turf, yelling, jumping and flailing their arms to whip the fans into a frenzy. But there was no stadium and no crowd here on this recent day, only a barnlike studio with an animator directing the mock celebration and a few computer technicians recording the movements with dozens of high-speed motion-capture cameras that zero in on 65 reflective markers Velcroed to the players’ uniforms.

headline: Examining the Timing of J.C. Penney’s Poison Pill Change
abstract: The struggling retailer could have adopted a lower threshold for its poison pill at any time. The Deal Professor wonders why it is doing so when it appears that the threat from hedge funds is receding.
lead_paragraph: J.C. Penney’s announcement on Tuesday that it had set a new, lower threshold for its poison pill raises the question: Why now?

headline: Gallery | A New Book Looks Back at Miami Beach’s Legendary, Soon-to-Be-Revived Surf Club
abstract: On the eve of its rebirth as a Richard Meier-designed Four Seasons, the iconic society retreat is the subject of a new coffee-table tome.

headline: Drama Where You’d Want It the Least: In the Cockpit
abstract: The film adaptation of “Charlie Victor Romeo” uses dialogue drawn from the cockpit voice recorders in six airline emergencies.
lead_paragraph: The visible action in “Charlie Victor Romeo,” a new 3-D film adaptation of a stage play first performed in 1999, consists of unfamiliar actors in familiar uniforms reciting verbatim dialogue from official transcripts. Directed by Robert Berger, Patrick Daniels and Karlyn Michelson, it is a curious hybrid of documentary and experimental theater. It is also one of the most terrifying movies I have ever seen.

headline: The Source | Beck
abstract: Doug Aitken interviews the musician and singer Beck.
lead_paragraph: Doug Aitken interviews the musician and singer Beck.

headline: Improving Care of the Mentally Ill
abstract: Readers react to a column by Joe Nocera about problems in the wake of deinstitutionalization.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: For the Elderly, a Welcome Place to Meet
abstract: Readers discuss places that serve as social hubs: McDonald’s, libraries and the Automat of yesteryear.

headline: For a Better Family Life
abstract: A reader writes that government programs need to be seen as investments.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What Private Equity Is Listening for in the State of the Union
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'Private Equity', 'State of the Union Message (US)']
abstract: The Obama administration has an opportunity, stemming from a recent court decision, to try to change the tax treatment of private equity earnings, a tax expert says.
lead_paragraph: In his State of the Union speech on Tuesday night, President Obama is expected to highlight a willingness to bypass Congress to get things done. That new stance could make private equity bosses nervous.

headline: ‘To Hear Your Banjo Play’
abstract: Pete Seeger plays at a square dance in an edited clip of the 1946 film, “To Hear Your Banjo Play.”
lead_paragraph: Pete Seeger plays at a square dance in an edited clip of the 1946 film, “To Hear Your Banjo Play.”

headline: Planned Comcast Tech Center Raises Sights in Philadelphia
abstract: A planned 59-story technology center for the media company is being welcomed as a lift for the office market nearby, and for the city’s economy.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The city that once boasted that no building would be higher than William Penn’s hat atop City Hall is getting a new skyscraper, to be the city’s tallest and more than twice as high as the iconic statue.

headline: Alan B. Abramson
abstract: Mr. Abramson is the president and chief executive of Abramson Brothers, a family owned commercial real estate company.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Abramson, 67, is the president and chief executive of Abramson Brothers, a family owned commercial real estate company that owns and manages office buildings, mainly in Midtown. The company was founded in 1957 by Mr. Abramson’s father and uncle, Manville and Junius Abramson.

headline: Meeting the Cost of Conceiving
keywords: ['In Vitro Fertilization', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Debt can pile up quickly for couples trying in-vitro fertilization and other assisted reproductive technologies.
lead_paragraph: Melanie Martin, a surgical nurse in San Diego, said she and her husband cut every corner they could think of to save up enough money to pay for conceiving a child through the technique known as in vitro fertilization.

headline: Seeking Better Legal Help for Immigrants
abstract: Following the model of programs like AmeriCorps, the Immigrant Justice Corps will train 25 lawyers a year to address immigration issues.
lead_paragraph: In the next several days, the deans of the nation’s top law schools will be notified of a new job opportunity for their graduating students. Applicants must be high achievers who want to be part of a groundbreaking start-up, live in New York City, train with veteran lawyers and help create a new paradigm in immigration representation.

headline: Confronting Old Problem May Require a New Deal
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Recession and Depression', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Unemployment', "New Deal (1930's)", "Great Depression (1930's)"]
abstract: Just as now, some in the 1930s feared that unemployment would remain stubbornly high, permanently; the response 80 years ago was the New Deal.
lead_paragraph: We look back upon the Great Depression as a discrete event with a beginning and an end; a long and profound economic shock but one that turned out to be nonetheless temporary. In the 1930s, however, many feared that what John Maynard Keynes clinically called “equilibrium at less than full employment” might, in fact, be the new normal — forever.

headline: The Next Accident Awaits
keywords: ['Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Chemicals', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Safety rules over hazardous chemicals must be tightened.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THE United States is facing an industrial chemical safety crisis. The horrifying chemical spill that recently contaminated the drinking water of hundreds of thousands of people in West Virginia is the latest in a relentless series of disasters and near-misses across the country.

headline: Madden NFL: The 33rd Team
abstract: A group of athletes, animators and technicians use motion capture technology to make the football video game Madden NFL as realistic as possible from every tackle to scrimmage line fidget.
lead_paragraph: A group of athletes, animators and technicians use motion capture technology to make the football video game Madden NFL as realistic as possible from every tackle to scrimmage line fidget.

headline: After Crisis, Greeks Work to Promote ‘Social’ Economy
keywords: ['Nonprofit Organizations', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: Businesses tired of dealing with bureaucrats and failing corporations are relying on volunteer networks to provide cheaper goods and to sell directly to customers.
lead_paragraph: ALONIA, Greece — The feisty owner of a small family business that makes detergents has never had time for anticapitalist firebrands. So he was suspicious and skeptical when he was approached by left-leaning activists campaigning to purge “profiteers” from the market.

headline: Texas: Woman at Center of Struggle Will Be Cremated
abstract: The brain-dead pregnant woman who was taken off life support after her family’s battle to gain custody of her body from a Fort Worth hospital will be cremated, her mother said Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The brain-dead pregnant woman who was taken off life support after her family’s battle to gain custody of her body from a Fort Worth hospital will be cremated, her mother said Tuesday. Marlise Muñoz, 33, had been on life support since November against her family’s wishes. The hospital had refused to disconnect her, citing a Texas law that prohibits doctors from withdrawing life support to pregnant patients. The hospital removed her from the machines on Sunday after a judge’s order. She was 22 weeks pregnant. Her fetus, which the hospital said was not viable, was a girl.

headline: An American Family Returns to the Table
abstract: Among the Super Bowl commercials is a sequel to a Cheerios ad that received baldly racist online condemnation for the interracial family at its heart.
lead_paragraph: A brand that garnered brickbats — and bouquets — last year for its take on modern family life is returning with another 30-second parable about diversity, this time during Super Bowl XLVIII, the year’s biggest showcase for advertising.

headline: Hedge Funds Sniff for Even Bigger Payouts From Banks
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Hedge Funds', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: One hedge fund, Fir Tree Partners, is even trying to coax other investors out of participating in the $4.5 billion JPMorgan Chase settlement with private investors.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest bets on Wall Street rests on a theory that also deeply unsettles Wall Street.

headline: Morrie Turner Dies at 90; Broke Race Barriers in Comics
keywords: ['Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Comic Books and Strips']
abstract: Mr. Turner was the first African-American cartoonist to be widely syndicated, and his “Wee Pals” comic strip featured a group of racially mixed characters.
lead_paragraph: Morrie Turner, a cartoonist who broke the color barrier twice — as the first African-American comic strip artist whose work was widely syndicated in mainstream newspapers, and as the creator of the first syndicated strip with a racially and ethnically mixed cast of characters — died on Saturday in Sacramento. He was 90.

headline: Text and Video of Obama’s State of the Union Address
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: The transcript of President Obama’s State of the Union speech, as transcribed by the Federal News Service.
lead_paragraph: Following is the transcript of President Obama’s State of the Union address, as transcribed by the Federal News Service.

headline: Afghan Justice Proves Complicated in Killing of 9-Year-Old Boy
abstract: The rule of law is a fragile concept in Afghanistan as shown in a case involving a prominent businessman, his friend on the court, and support from both the government and the Taliban.
lead_paragraph: HERAT, Afghanistan — The case has consumed this city in western Afghanistan for over a year: A 9-year-old boy, Ali Sena Nowruzi, is kidnapped on his way to school by his trusted friend and bodyguard, and then is found beaten to death.

headline: A Man of No Words, the Seahawks’ Lynch Finally Delivers a Few
abstract: Marshawn Lynch, who did not talk to the news media this season, spoke to reporters for all of six minutes on media day. Performance, he said, is what counts.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — The mercurial Seattle Seahawks running back Marshawn Lynch was fined $50,000 by the N.F.L. this month for declining to speak with the news media this season.

headline: Prisoner of the Green Room
abstract: Long periods of boredom, punctuated by short intervals of head talking.
lead_paragraph: Well, I’m at CNN; said my pre-SOTU piece. Now to sit through the speech, and comment after. Unfortunately, it seems that nobody brought the bourbon. .

headline: ‘Fragile Five’ Is the Latest Club of Emerging Nations in Turmoil
keywords: ['Foreign Investments', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The name identifies Turkey, Brazil, India, South Africa and Indonesia as economies too dependent on skittish foreign investment to finance their growth ambitions.
lead_paragraph: The long-running boom in emerging markets came to be identified, if not propped up, by wide acceptance of the term BRICs, shorthand for the fast-growing countries Brazil, Russia, India and China. Recent turmoil in these and similar markets has produced a rival expression: the Fragile Five.

headline: SAC’s Counsel Testifies at Insider Trading Trial in Unexpected Move by the Defense
abstract: Testimony by the chief counsel at SAC could allow prosecutors to scrutinize compliance at the multibillion-dollar hedge fund founded by Steven A. Cohen.
lead_paragraph: Peter Nussbaum, the general counsel of SAC Capital Advisors, took the witness stand on Tuesday in a bold and surprising move by the defense at the insider trading case of Mathew Martoma, a former SAC trader.

headline: Frigid Blast Disrupts Life in South and Midwest as Emergencies Are Declared
abstract: In Alabama, snow made roads impassable and forced some schools to prepare to keep students overnight. Even in the Midwest, the coldest stretch in decades started to wear some families down.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — In Alabama, snow made roads impassable and forced some schools to prepare to keep students overnight. Many people in metro Atlanta planned to sleep in offices and hotels. And here in Chicago, where winter usually brings a shrug, parents scrambled to find day care after public school classes were canceled Tuesday for the fourth day this month.

headline: Rebels in Syria Claim Control of Resources
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Natural Gas']
abstract: Islamist rebels and extremists are using oil and gas proceeds to underwrite their fights against one another as well as President Bashar al-Assad, American officials said.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Islamist rebels and extremist groups have seized control of most of Syria’s oil and gas resources, a rare generator of cash in the country’s war-battered economy, and are now using the proceeds to underwrite their fights against one another as well as President Bashar al-Assad, American officials say.

headline: Pete Seeger, Neil Young and the Importance of Letting Go
abstract: His friend Neil Young recounts how they both learned the hard way that not everyone can be persuaded.
lead_paragraph: Four decades later, Pete Seeger couldn’t let it go.

headline: Video Notebook: Fans at Media Day
abstract: Fans who attended media day on Tuesday shared their impressions.
lead_paragraph: Fans who attended media day on Tuesday shared their impressions.

headline: For $28.50, All the Super Bowl Hype a Fan Could Stand
abstract: News is rarely made at the Super Bowl’s media day, where players field questions from the serious to the inane.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Super Bowl media day has its traditions. Reporters and other credentialed people, some in character costumes, ask the teams’ players serious and inane questions.

headline: Roadblocks on Health Reform
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Editorials']
abstract: A judge rightfully blocked onerous restrictions imposed by Missouri on counselors who help people enroll in health insurance plans.
lead_paragraph: Onerous restrictions imposed by Missouri on federally approved counselors who help people understand and enroll in health insurance plans under the Affordable Care Act have rightly been blocked by a federal district judge in Kansas City. Although the ruling by Judge Ortrie Smith applies only to Missouri, its reasoning applies to similar laws or regulations adopted by more than a dozen Republican-led states that are doing their best to sabotage health care reform.

headline: Iran: U.N. to Visit Uranium Mine
abstract: The visit by United Nations inspectors is part of a temporary international agreement aimed at resolving the longstanding dispute over the Iranian nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: United Nations nuclear inspectors arrived in Iran on Tuesday to examine a uranium mine in the southern part of the country, Iranian news agencies reported. Their visit is part of a temporary international agreement aimed at resolving the longstanding dispute over the Iranian nuclear program, which Iran says is for energy and medical use but which Western nations and Israel suspect is a cloak for developing the ability to make bombs. Under the accord, which took effect on Jan. 20, Iran agreed to freeze most uranium-enrichment activities for six months and allow inspectors more intrusive access, in return for a relaxation of some Western economic sanctions. An exact date and a location have not been set for talks aimed at achieving a permanent agreement.

headline: More Winter, Less School
abstract: Snow days: celebrated and rued by kids and parents everywhere, in that order.
lead_paragraph: “Schools open. I’m cheering, kids aren’t. I just went over to the dark side.”

headline: A Court’s All-Hands Approach Aids Girls Most at Risk
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Women and Girls', 'Sex Crimes', 'Juvenile Delinquency', 'Human Trafficking', 'Prostitution']
abstract: Girls Court, a special tribunal that is part of a network across the country, aims to nurture vulnerable young women — especially those forced into prostitution — instead of treating them as criminals.
lead_paragraph: SAN LEANDRO, Calif. — Toni J., an effervescent 16-year-old who talks on speed-dial, lives with 11 family members in West Oakland, on a street buffeted by gang activity and poverty. Her mother died of an overdose, her father in a revenge shooting. In ninth grade, she was raped while on probation for shoplifting.

headline: China: Chicken Sales Suspended Over Concerns About Avian Flu
abstract: As the Chinese get ready for Lunar New Year feasts, several areas in China have banned the sale of live chickens, as fears grew over the spread of avian influenza.
lead_paragraph: As the Chinese get ready for Lunar New Year feasts, several areas in China have banned the sale of live chickens, and the Hong Kong government started culling 20,000 of the birds on Tuesday, as fears grew over the spread of avian influenza. The decision to kill the chickens, all from a single Hong Kong market, came after officials detected a new case of the deadly H7N9 virus in a bird imported from mainland China, across the border from Hong Kong in Guangdong Province. In southeastern China, New Year’s festivities often include the killing of a chicken. Contact with live poultry remains the main means of transmission for the virus. The H7N9 virus was first detected in March, and more than 200 cases have been reported so far, with roughly 50 deaths tied to the flu.

headline: Video Notebook: Richard Sherman
abstract: Richard Sherman of the Seattle Seahawks spoke to the media on Tuesday about being at media day and his reputation as a talker.
lead_paragraph: Richard Sherman of the Seattle Seahawks spoke to the media on Tuesday about being at media day and his reputation as a talker.

headline: Outsiders, Not Auto Plant, Battle U.A.W. in Tennessee
abstract: A unionization drive has drawn national attention as business groups worry about organized labor’s efforts to gain its first foothold at a foreign-owned automobile plant in the South.
lead_paragraph: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — At the Volkswagen plant nestled in Tennessee’s rolling hills, a unionization drive has drawn national attention as business groups worry about organized labor’s efforts to gain its first foothold at a foreign-owned automobile plant in the South. In a region known as anti-union, many view VW’s response as unusual, if not topsy-turvy.

headline: Prisoner of the Green Room 2
abstract: No bourbon, so I’ll live-blog a bit.
lead_paragraph: OK, since there isn’t any bourbon I guess I’ll try some live-blogging.

headline: Japan: Report of Possible Talks With North Korea to Thaw Ties
abstract: Japanese and North Korean officials may have held secret talks over the weekend in Vietnam, Kyodo News reported Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Japanese and North Korean officials may have held secret talks over the weekend in Vietnam, Kyodo News reported Tuesday, in an attempt to thaw frozen ties between the two nations. The Japanese news agency cited an unnamed Japanese diplomat as saying officials from the two nations were in Hanoi on Saturday and Sunday and may have met there. However, the top Japanese government spokesman, Yoshihide Suga, denied Tuesday that a meeting had taken place. Japan cut off talks in 2012 after North Korea launched a rocket over Japan.

headline: Any Question Thrown at Him, Richard Sherman Has It Covered
abstract: Sherman, the Seattle Seahawks cornerback, was asked about his tirade after the N.F.C. championship game, but this being media day, he was asked some other questions, too.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — The spectacle within the spectacle began at 12:45 p.m. Tuesday, when Richard Sherman, escorted by security through a horde of photographers, arrived at his podium. Over the next hour he answered questions from Deion Sanders and Randy Moss. He finished lyrics to Beyoncé songs and was given an Xbox One.

headline: Comcast Profits Up Sharply, Along With TV Subscribers
abstract: Comcast, the nation’s largest cable provider and the owner of NBCUniversal, increased its net income 26 percent, to $1.9 billion, compared with a year ago.
lead_paragraph: Comcast, the nation’s largest cable provider and the owner of NBCUniversal, on Tuesday reported a sharp increase in profit for the fourth quarter of 2013, helped by an increase in television subscribers after six years of decline.

headline: Why Kerry Is Scary
abstract: The secretary of state is daring to test a question about the Israelis and Palestinians that everyone has wanted to avoid.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — It is pretty clear now that Secretary of State John Kerry will either be Israel’s diplomatic salvation or the most dangerous diplomatic fanatic Israel has ever encountered. But there isn’t much room anymore for anything in between. This is one of those rare pay-per-view foreign policy moments. Pull up a chair. You don’t see this every day.

headline: Dealing With Pot
abstract: As Coloradans break out the Cheetohs and Goldfish, the state’s politicians become wary chaperones.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — There’s a lot of giggling in Colorado, and about Colorado, these days.

headline: Drug Shows Promise in Advanced Prostate Cancer When Used Before Chemotherapy
abstract: The drug Xtandi, already on the market for post-chemotherapy use, could open a new front in its competition with Johnson & Johnson’s Zytiga.
lead_paragraph: The prostate cancer drug Xtandi prolonged lives and delayed tumor progression when used before chemotherapy in a study of men with advanced cases of the disease, researchers said on Tuesday.

headline: Remembering a Sharp-Witted Academy Veteran
abstract: Tom Sherak was a member of the Hollywood generation that sometimes actually said what it was thinking.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:12 a.m. | LOS ANGELES — “I’d vote for “Anchorman 2,’ but they’d know the ballot was mine.”

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
abstract: Notable properties that have been recently listed for sale, sold or leased.
lead_paragraph: RECENT SALE

headline: Popular Flood Insurance Law Is Target of Both Political Parties
abstract: A measure supported by conservatives and environmentalists may fall victim to unintended consequences and is a warning, some say, of the rising costs of climate change.
lead_paragraph: A major flood insurance bill was a rarity when it passed what is widely derided as a do-nothing Congress in 2012, but a year and a half later, there is now an enthusiastic bipartisan effort to gut it.

headline: Using His Voice to Bring Out a Nation’s
abstract: Mr. Seeger sang until his voice wore out, and then he kept on singing, decade upon decade.
lead_paragraph: Pete Seeger sang until his voice wore out, and then he kept on singing, decade upon decade. Mr. Seeger, who died on Monday at 94, sang for children, folk-music devotees, union members, civil-rights marchers, antiwar protesters, environmentalists and everyone else drawn to a repertoire that extended from ancient ballads to brand-new songs about every cause that moved him. But it wasn’t his own voice he wanted to hear. He wanted everyone to sing along.

headline: Open-Source System to Be Offered by Dell
abstract: Dell said it would offer networking equipment that was built with nonspecialized semiconductors and an open-source operating system, as opposed to the highly proprietary gear.
lead_paragraph: Dell said it would offer networking equipment that was built with nonspecialized semiconductors and an open-source operating system, as opposed to the highly proprietary gear and software from like Cisco Systems and Hewlett-Packard. While that is unlikely to be a huge business soon for Dell, it lends credibility and muscle to what has been a growing effort to dislodge these incumbents through cheaper, easier-to-build equipment. If Dell and others can do that, a result would be lower costs at the large data centers run by Google, Facebook and large banks and companies. Cheaper networking could also make the Internet even more ubiquitous.

headline: DeVry Becomes an Unlikely Olympic Powerhouse
abstract: DeVry University, a for-profit institution, has landed 15 students on the United States team heading to the Sochi Games.
lead_paragraph: They have no mascot or motto, no home rink, oval or stadium. They have no hockey team, curling squad or figure skaters. They have no coaches, no athletic director, and their basketball team once lost by 117 points.

headline: Pitcher Refuses to Wear Cap That His Injury Helped to Bring About
abstract: Major League Baseball has approved a padded cap for pitchers, but Brandon McCarthy, whose injury spurred the design, said he would not use it.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to protect pitchers from line drives, Major League Baseball approved a padded-cap design Tuesday for optional use this season. But a pitcher whose injury helped accelerate the effort, Brandon McCarthy of the Arizona Diamondbacks, deflated much of the excitement by declaring he would not use it.

headline: Similar to a Yodel
abstract: Michael Black tells people where to go.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s always fascinating how word people tend to “see” things that I would bet many people might overlook. It just so happens that somewhere there exists a whole list of people whose names contain letters that spell out something they are connected to, and Michael Black has found four of them.

headline: For Seeger, Years of Singing and Sailing to Save His Hudson River
abstract: From his home in Beacon, N.Y., where most everybody knew him, Pete Seeger worked relentlessly to raise public consciousness about the Hudson’s pollution.
lead_paragraph: As much as he was known around the world as a troubadour of idealism, Pete Seeger was at bottom a plain-spoken citizen of Beacon, N.Y.

abstract: In his State of the Union address, President Obama said that 2014 could be “a breakthrough year for America,” but that Washington needed to rebuild trust with Americans.
lead_paragraph: In his State of the Union address, President Obama said that 2014 could be “a breakthrough year for America,” but that Washington needed to rebuild trust with Americans.

headline: Principles? What Principles?
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'State of the Union Message (US)']
abstract: To help appreciate the president’s speech, let’s take a preliminary visit to that citadel of reason, the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: To help appreciate President Obama’s fifth State of the Union address, with its to-do list of executive actions and its implicit fatalism about working with Congress, I suggest a preliminary visit to that citadel of reason, the Republican Party. There, the great minds and loud voices of the right are debating whether to adhere to the strategy of confrontation and sabotage that appeases the radicals in the conservative base, or to introduce a measure of pragmatism that might broaden the party’s appeal.

headline: Looking Callous at the SOTU
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'State of the Union Message (US)']
abstract: When the president mentioned the benefits of health care reform, Democrats cheered and Republicans grimaced.
lead_paragraph: Having covered more State of the Union addresses than I care to count, I know perfectly well that the applause breaks are ritualistic. But during tonight’s speech, there were several moments that were emblematic of the partisan divides in this country, and the callous nature of Republican domestic policy.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, January 29, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Wednesday, January 29, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “I’m eager to work with all of you. But America does not stand still — and neither will I. So wherever and whenever I can take steps without legislation to expand opportunity for more American families, that’s what I’m going to do.”

headline: Capitalism vs. Democracy
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Is deepening inequality inevitable? The case for a global wealth tax.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Piketty’s new book, “Capital in the Twenty-First Century,” described by one French newspaper as a “a political and theoretical bulldozer,” defies left and right orthodoxy by arguing that worsening inequality is an inevitable outcome of free market capitalism.

headline: The Diminished State of the Union
keywords: ['Executive Orders', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Minimum Wage', 'Editorials']
abstract: With no cooperation from Congress for enacting good policy, President Obama is being forced to govern by executive order.
lead_paragraph: Every winter since 2009, President Obama has stood at the podium of the House and pleaded for the cooperation of Congress. For the last three State of the Union speeches, he has largely been ignored. That has left a growing trail of unfinished business: background checks for gun buyers, immigration reform, a higher minimum wage, tax fairness, universal preschool.

lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Mark Zuckerberg was in his element.

headline: Knicks Are Tough to Figure Out, and on This Night, Tough to Stop

lead_paragraph: Everything was open for the Knicks on Tuesday night: backdoor layups, 3-pointers, the lane. After Tyson Chandler converted an alley-oop dunk in the second quarter, he gave himself a good three seconds to stare menacingly at the crowd before retreating on defense.

lead_paragraph: New York State’s top education official was caught in a battle between city and state leaders on Tuesday after he suggested that providing universal access to prekindergarten would cost substantially more than what Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo had proposed.

lead_paragraph: PARIS — Sit down at a cute Parisian bistro and the chances are the onion soup, the paté and the boudin blanc set before you weren’t prepared from fresh ingredients delivered that morning.

abstract: The N.F.L. may have built a fan-dazzling roadway in Midtown Manhattan called Super Bowl Boulevard, but the big game, and some of the big names, remain west of the Hudson.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — As the rest of the world streamed into the colossal Prudential Center on Tuesday for a religious service known as Super Bowl media day, a singular, defiant voice called from black loudspeakers propped outside a nearby tractor-trailer.

lead_paragraph: It was easy to imagine the blue bikes in fair weather, spinning over the East River during the morning commute, or toward the sidewalk cafes of SoHo for a twilight meal.

headline: Dashing for Big Yardage, Not for Shot at Medals

lead_paragraph: Denver Broncos kick returner Trindon Holliday could not help wondering what might have been had he pursued his dream of competing in the Summer Olympics.

headline: Texas: Candidate’s Daughters Respond to Criticism
abstract: The two daughters of Wendy Davis, a candidate for governor, put out an open letter in response to a newspaper article questioning aspects of her account of rising from teenage mother to Harvard Law School graduate.
lead_paragraph: The two daughters of Wendy Davis, a candidate for governor, put out an open letter on Tuesday in response to a newspaper article questioning aspects of her account of rising from teenage mother to Harvard Law School graduate. The Dallas Morning News reported this month that the daughters of the Democratic candidate stayed with her second husband in Texas while she attended school and that he won custody when the couple divorced. Ms. Davis’s campaign has said the couple had joint custody. Republicans and conservatives accused her of misleading voters. Dru Davis, 25, said in her letter, “Sadly I feel the need to be crystal clear on the malicious and false charge of abandonment as nothing could be further from the truth.”

headline: Bernard Perlin, a New York Painter of Varied Styles, Dies at 95
abstract: Mr. Perlin was an American painter who displayed a mastery of light and line across a wide range of work, including wartime propaganda posters, street scenes of New York and effervescent views of Italy.
lead_paragraph: Bernard Perlin, an American painter who displayed a mastery of light and line across seven decades and a wide range of work, including wartime propaganda posters, street scenes of New York and effervescent views of Italy, died on Jan. 14 at his home in Ridgefield, Conn. He was 95.

headline: What the State of the Union Address Means for 2014
abstract: What President Obama’s speech means for the midterms, his agenda and his relationship with Congress.
lead_paragraph: What President Obama’s speech means for the midterms, his agenda and his relationship with Congress.

headline: I’m Looking Through You
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A muscular speech from the president that put an irrelevant Congress on notice.
lead_paragraph: The least productive Congress in nearly half a century has rarely looked more out-of-sorts than during the speech that put its members on notice for their irrelevance. That, essentially, was the triumph of the rhetorical trick President Obama employed in his fifth State of the Union address.

headline: Big and Fast Tight End Poses a Threat to an Intimidating Secondary
abstract: Broncos tight end Julius Thomas, who switched from basketball to football at Portland State, will be a key player for Denver as it takes on Seattle’s No. 1-ranked defense.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — To find the end zone against a hard-hitting Seattle secondary known as the Legion of Boom, the Denver Broncos may have to rely on a player some call Mr. Red Zone. The name sounds like a comic book character, but Sunday in Super Bowl XLVIII, the performance of Julius Thomas, the Broncos’ tight end, will go a long way in determining how well Denver’s offense fares against the N.F.L.’s No. 1 defense.

headline: In L.A., Blurring the Line Between Art and Housewares
abstract: An emerging group of young Los Angeles sculptors are branching out into functional pieces for the home.
lead_paragraph: It’s no surprise that many sculptors have a yen for making furniture. After all, the tools are right within reach, and the process isn’t that different. In Los Angeles, which has a long history of furniture manufacturing and an abundance of interior spaces to fill, a growing number of young artists are making forays into the realm of domestic utility. “There’s a lot of sculpture out there that doesn’t want to admit to being furniture,” says the local artist Michael Rey, who has of late branched into objects that retain his affinity for the visual language of cartoons and ’90s pop culture.

headline: Exercise to Age Well, Whatever Your Age
abstract: Becoming physically active in middle age, even if someone has been sedentary for years, substantially reduces the likelihood that he or she will become seriously ill or physically disabled in retirement, new research shows.
lead_paragraph: Offering hope and encouragement to the many adults who have somehow neglected to exercise for the past few decades, a new study suggests that becoming physically active in middle age, even if someone has been sedentary for years, substantially reduces the likelihood that he or she will become seriously ill or physically disabled in retirement.

headline: State of the Union, as It Was Spoken and as Decoded
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A reporter offers his best translation of what President Obama really meant as he addressed Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an excellent scene from “Mitt,” the new documentary about the former Massachusetts governor Mitt Romney’s two presidential campaigns, the filmmaker asks one of Mr. Romney’s sons, Josh, whether all the hassle and indignity of campaigning is worth it. Josh Romney hesitates, saying that he had been so “trained” to deliver scripted happy talk in media interviews, that this might be hard. “To actually speak my mind is very different,” he finally says.

headline: What’s on Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (ABC) NASHVILLE Juliette (Hayden Panettiere) surprises Jeff (Oliver Hudson) by refusing to apologize for her behavior during her induction into the Grand Ole Opry. Luke (Will Chase) introduces Rayna (Connie Britton, above) to someone who could help make her distribution deal a reality and then surprises her with a Nascar vehicle promoting her brand. And Deacon (Charles Esten) discovers that his own deal might not be what he anticipated.

headline: Air Force Expands Inquiry Into Cheating
keywords: ['Cheating', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Defense Department officials said on Tuesday that 30 more Air Force members had cheated on tests of their knowledge of how to launch nuclear missiles.
lead_paragraph: Defense Department officials said on Tuesday that 30 more Air Force members had cheated on tests of their knowledge of how to launch nuclear missiles, doubling the number caught up in the scandal. The expanded list comes two weeks after the Air Force announced that a drug inquiry had been widened to include a scandal in which 34 officers responsible for safeguarding nuclear weapons had cheated, or were aware of cheating, on monthly tests.

headline: Rep. Michael Grimm Threatens an NY1 Reporter
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The Staten Island lawmaker can be heard telling Michael Scotto, a reporter for NY1, “I’ll break you in half” in footage broadcast by the network.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Footage showed Representative Michael G. Grimm physically threatening a reporter in the Capitol, shining a harsh light on the embattled Staten Island Republican in the hours after President Obama’s State of the Union address here on Tuesday.

headline: McCain Calls China a ‘Rising Threat’ in Baucus Confirmation Hearing
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Max Baucus, who was nominated as the new United States ambassador to China, responded diplomatically to assertions that China represented a rising threat to the United States.
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s choice to be ambassador to China sat through a tough-sounding lecture in Washington on Tuesday from a Senate colleague who accused Beijing of regularly abusing human rights and planning to reassert its historic regional dominance. He then said that he largely agreed.

headline: Islamist Party in Tunisia Hands Power to Caretaker Government
abstract: Ennahda, an Islamist party, ended two strife-ridden years as Tunisia’s first elected government, ceding power to a government of technocrats that will preside over elections this year.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — Tunisia’s Islamist party Ennahda ceded power on Tuesday to a caretaker government, ending a strife-ridden two years as the country’s first elected government after the Arab Spring of 2011. The government departed under pressure, criticized for failing to halt rising terrorism and steady a faltering economy, but Ennahda was nevertheless assured of its place in Tunisian politics.

headline: A Pocket Guide to the 2014 Kolkata Book Fair
keywords: ['Book Fairs', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', 'Festivals', 'Language and Languages', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: The largest retail book fair, which begins Wednesday in West Bengal’s capital, also features the three-day Kolkata Language and Literary Festival.
lead_paragraph: KOLKATA — The 38th Kolkata Book Fair may have lost the Kolkata Literary Meet, which has spun off into a standalone event, but it has filled the void by adding the three-day Kolkata Language and Literary Festival, which is set to be inaugurated by Shashi Tharoor, the minister of state for human resource development.

headline: 2014: Paul’s State of the Union Response
abstract: The Republican senator from Kentucky released his own response to the State of the Union address.
lead_paragraph: The Republican senator from Kentucky released his own response to the State of the Union address.

headline: A Soprano Is Facing ‘Star-Spangled’ Jitters
abstract: The soprano Renée Fleming is the first opera singer invited to sing the national anthem at a Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: The soprano Renée Fleming — who has sung at the World Series, at the Queen Elizabeth II Diamond Jubilee Concert in front of Buckingham Palace and at a gala before President Obama’s 2009 inauguration — sounded awed. “If you’d said six months ago, ‘You’re going to be singing in the Super Bowl,' ” she said, “I’d have said, ‘Not possible, no way.’ ”

headline: For Christie, Politics Team Kept a Focus on Two Races
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'George Washington Bridge', 'Elections, Governors', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Based in the New Jersey State House, Gov. Chris Christie’s aides assembled dossiers on communities and officials deemed critical to his re-election and a prospective 2016 presidential run.
lead_paragraph: His campaign called them “the Top 100,” the swing towns that Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey wanted to win as he prepared for a re-election campaign. Capturing these towns, sometimes referred to as mini-Ohios or mini-Floridas, would validate the governor’s argument that he would be the most broadly appealing Republican choice for president in 2016.

headline: European Deal on Winding Down Failed Banks in Peril
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Negotiators from Parliament, the European Commission and the European Council are holding talks to reconcile their demands.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Barely a month after European officials announced the creation of a system for winding down failed banks, it appears the plan could fall victim to a disagreement between member states on the European Council and the European Parliament.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Jan. 29, 2014
abstract: Can you calculate the approximate area of the roadway of the bridge that will replace the Tappan Zee?
lead_paragraph: Our weekly math problems are written by teachers at Math for America.

headline: 6 Q’s About the News | Beings Not Made for Space
abstract: What are some ways that space affects the human body?
lead_paragraph: In “Beings Not Made for Space,” Kenneth Chang writes about the health challenges of human spaceflight.

headline: Operatic Cowboys in Love, Onstage
abstract: The opera “Brokeback Mountain,” based on the short story by Annie Proulx, opened at the Teatro Real in Madrid.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — When the news came five years ago that Charles Wuorinen was writing an opera based on “Brokeback Mountain,” the 1997 Annie Proulx short story that was made into an Oscar-winning film in 2005, it seemed at first a baffling mismatch of composer and subject. Mr. Wuorinen, 75, built his reputation as and remains an unabashedly complex Modernist. “Brokeback Mountain” is the immensely sad tale of the impossible love between two Wyoming cowboys.

headline: Dozens of Rebels Killed After Philippine Peace Deal Is Struck
abstract: The rebels belonged to a group that did not sign on to the recent pact reached between the Philippine government and insurgents.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — More than 40 people were killed and a school district supervisor was kidnapped in separate episodes around the island of Mindanao, days after a landmark peace deal was struck with the largest Muslim insurgency group in the Philippines, officials said Wednesday.

headline: Confessions of a Tiger Couple
abstract: Amy Chua and her husband, Jed Rubenfeld, have a new book about why certain cultural groups tend to succeed more than others. They have no idea why this might be controversial.
lead_paragraph: One gray afternoon in November, on the eve of the Harvard-Yale football game, Amy Chua and Jed Rubenfeld were preparing for their postgame party. Furniture had been moved, vulnerable rugs had been rolled into corners. Their older daughter, Sophia, a junior at Harvard, had just called, and Chua returned to the living room bearing some news for her husband.

headline: Just When You Thought Quinoa Couldn’t Be Crunchier
abstract: The real reward of this “supergrain” awaits those who cook it till it crisps.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, quinoa was as mysterious as dark matter. Few could even pronounce the name of this ancient, disk-shaped “super grain” from the Andes, mistakenly calling it kwih-NO-ah (it’s KEEN-wah). It tasted a little strange, home cooks didn’t know what to do with it and only vegan restaurants put it on menus.

headline: Scars, Visible and Invisible, in Bosnia
abstract: The emotional wounds of the 1992-95 war in Bosnia are still so deep that even an ostensibly simple question, “How old are you?,” produces fraught answers.
lead_paragraph: It seemed like a simple question: How old are you?

headline: How Long Is It O.K. to Linger in a Cafe or Restaurant?
abstract: Should patrons be considerate of a business’s need to make money? Should they make room for other customers? Or should a public space like McDonald’s be available for everyone as long as they want?
lead_paragraph: McDonald’s, Starbucks and other cafes and restaurants have become popular gathering spots for everyone from teenagers to the elderly. This month a McDonald’s in Queens finally arranged a truce after months of mounting tension with a group of elderly Korean patrons who have been using the restaurant as a meeting place for several hours each day. Do you ever think about overstaying your welcome in a public space?

headline: Shell Selling a Stake in Brazilian Oil Project
abstract: Shell is selling 23 percent of the Brazilian project to Qatar for about $1 billion. The offshore project is the type of asset Shell and other large oil companies are looking to dispose of as investors demand better returns.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Royal Dutch Shell said on Wednesday that it had agreed to sell a minority interest in an offshore Brazilian oil project to Qatar Petroleum International, the emirate’s vehicle for oil and gas investments abroad, for about $1 billion.

headline: President Karzai’s Perfidies
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Civilian Casualties', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Afghan leader seems to have decided that there is something to be gained in destroying his relationship with the United States.
lead_paragraph: President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan seems to have decided that there is nothing lost, and maybe something to be gained, in destroying his relationship with the United States. While such behavior may serve his interests, it does not serve his long-suffering country’s.
