headline: Touring States, Obama Pushes Modest Agenda
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'Executive Orders', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Income Inequality', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Individual Retirement Accounts', 'Minimum Wage']
abstract: President Obama began a two-day, four-state tour to build support for a series of executive actions on wages, retirement and education.
lead_paragraph: WEST MIFFLIN, Pa. — As President Obama took to the road on Wednesday to promote an “opportunity agenda” that he vowed to enact with or without Congress, lawmakers began sorting through issues on which they may yet come together during what promises to be a treacherous midterm election year.

headline: U.N. Inspectors Visit Uranium Mine in Iran, Media Report
abstract: The inspection followed a temporary agreement with world powers to freeze most uranium-enrichment activities in return for loosening sanctions.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — United Nations nuclear inspectors began a visit on Wednesday to a uranium mine in southern Iran, state media reported, describing Tehran’s readiness for the scrutiny as a good-will gesture to demonstrate peaceful intent.

headline: The Co-Founder Dilemma
abstract: At the start, no one wants to haggle over shares because, at this stage, the company isn’t worth anything. Right?
lead_paragraph: The idea for Posse struck me while relaxing in my apartment one Sunday afternoon. I didn’t know how to run a technology company, wasn’t at all confident the idea would work, and feared I might end up with egg on my face. In the interests of spreading the personal and financial risk, I asked a few friends to help.

headline: Fido Prefers Organic
abstract: Those exotic doggy treats may come back to haunt you.
lead_paragraph: I was invited for dinner at some old friends’ place the other day and I thought it would be nice to go to my local Greenwich Village pet store and pick up a treat for their dog, Manny. It is not that I am so crazy about Manny, who is a mix of a poodle and something even more annoying; I have had mixed feelings about him ever since he ate one of my sneakers. I just thought I would get him something he might enjoy chewing on as a diversionary tactic.

headline: The State of the Union, by the Numbers
abstract: The figures behind the language of this year's State of the Union address.
lead_paragraph: The figures behind the language of this year's State of the Union address.

headline: Daily Report: Yahoo’s Revenue Falls, Though Alibaba’s Rises On
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Company Reports', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The Internet portal and web publisher said its fourth-quarter revenue was $1.27 billion, down 6 percent from the same quarter a year ago.
lead_paragraph: Despite the turnaround effort led its chief, Marissa Mayer, Yahoo is still falling further and further behind in the race for Internet advertising. The company said on Tuesday that revenue and operating profits declined in the fourth quarter of 2013 and would continue dropping in the first quarter of this year, Vindu Goel reports.

headline: Apple Store Update: Is It a Clue That a New Apple TV Is on the Way?
abstract: Apple on Tuesday updated its website to give the Apple TV its own section of the Apple Store. This comes after speculation that the company is working on an update to the TV box that could include apps and hardware upgrades.
lead_paragraph: When most companies add a new section to their website, few people notice. But most companies aren’t Apple.

headline: Ruling Looms in Italy for Amanda Knox in ’07 Killing
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: Ms. Knox, the American student accused of killing her roommate Meredith Kercher in 2007, will await the verdict in Seattle after deciding not to be present at the proceedings.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, Italy — For years, the fate of Amanda Knox has been in the hands of a succession of Italian courts, called on to determine whether on the night of Nov. 1, 2007, she killed Meredith Kercher, her roommate and fellow foreign exchange student in the university town of Perugia. On Thursday, a court in Florence is expected to present its ruling.

headline: Russia Defers Aid to Ukraine, and Unrest Persists
abstract: A former Ukrainian president warned on Wednesday that the country is now on “the brink of civil war,” and five protesters were wounded in scuffles between two factions of antigovernment demonstrators.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — A former Ukrainian president warned on Wednesday that the country is now on “the brink of civil war,” and Russia added to the gloom by announcing the suspension of its financial aid package, which was all that had been keeping Ukraine solvent.

headline: Strong Chrysler Earnings Help Fiat Turn Profit
keywords: ['Company Reports', 'Automobiles', 'Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks']
abstract: Fiat, the American automaker’s owner, said it would organize its joint operation in the Netherlands and its primary listing would in New York.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The world’s newest auto giant on Wednesday chose a formal name, Fiat Chrysler Automobiles, and a borderless corporate structure that spans the Netherlands, Britain, Italy and the United States.

headline: Can Accessories Make Google Glass More Stylish?
abstract: Google hopes third-party accessories will make Google Glass attractive to a wider variety of people. But accessories draw attention to gadgets, and many Glass owners want the device to stand out less, not more.
lead_paragraph: Even self-described tech geeks want to make Google Glass look a little less geeky before they wear it.

headline: State of the Union Highlights Economic Inequality
abstract: President Obama promises to address economic inequality. | Hedge funds are betting banks will pay more for their role in shoddy mortgage practices. | Alibaba’s decisions face scrutiny as it prepares for I.P.O. | J.C. Penney lowers its poison pill threshold, but its reason for doing so is unclear.
lead_paragraph: In his State of the Union address before Congress on Tuesday night, President Obama promised to do something about economic disparity in a “year of action,” vowing to act alone if necessary. While Mr. Obama covered a broad swath of issues, his message centered on income inequality. “Those at the top have never done better,” he said. “But average wages have barely budged. Inequality has deepened. Upward mobility has stalled.”

headline: Barclays to Cut Up to 400 Jobs in Its Investment Bank to Trim Costs
abstract: Barclays is preparing to eliminate up to 400 jobs in its investment bank as part of its restructuring effort, according to a person familiar with the matter. The bank is trying to reduce its annual costs by 1.7 billion pounds by 2015.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The British bank Barclays is preparing to eliminate as many as 400 jobs in its investment bank as part of an effort to trim costs, according to a person familiar with the matter.

headline: Hedgies Versus Teachers
abstract: The 40 versus the 300,000.
lead_paragraph: So one thing I learned last night is that the right has a new meme: inequality is the fault of the government — you see, it’s all those overpaid government workers.

headline: Get Your Hot Chocolate Here!
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: A mother was showing her little girl how to express thanks, in a twist on the lemonade stand.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Video: Proud of ‘Wolf’s’ Language
abstract: Terence Winter, who is up for an Oscar for his “Wolf of Wall Street” screenplay, talks about the film’s record-setting explicit language.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Terence Winter read “The Wolf of Wall Street,” Jordan Belfort’s memoir of his shady financial, narcotic and sexual dealings, before it was even published. “I got the book when it was still in galley form” from the producer Alexandra Milchan, he said. “I could not put it down. I read it in one sitting.”

headline: Sotheby’s, Under Pressure, to Pay Special Dividend and Buy Back Shares
abstract: Sotheby’s outlined plans to pay $300 million to shareholders in the form of a special dividend, and said it would begin a $150 million share repurchase program.
lead_paragraph: When the billionaire hedge fund manager Daniel S. Loeb and a group of activist investors emerged as the biggest shareholders in Sotheby’s last year, it looked as if a battle was brewing at the auction house.

headline: German Leader Criticizes U.S. Over Pervasive Surveillance
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Speeches and Statements', 'United States International Relations', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: In a speech to the German Parliament, Chancellor Angela Merkel on Wednesday said that Washington had undermined its international standing.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel took perhaps her sharpest swipe yet at pervasive American intelligence surveillance, saying on Wednesday that Washington had endangered its standing by violating the freedom of the individual, a value for which it is admired abroad.

headline: Whatever It Takes? No, It Takes Whatever
abstract: The secret of Obama’s serenity.
lead_paragraph: I think Josh Marshall gets this right. Obama came across relatively relaxed last night, basically because he knows two things: he isn’t getting anything substantive out of the GOP, but he’s achieved a lot, and his signature achievement is looking increasingly secure. The real theme of the SOTU was “Whatever.”

headline: Reader Idea | Writing Book Reports With Help From New York Times Book Reviews
abstract: This Reader Idea uses a New York Times book review by popular Young Adult author John Green as a mentor text to show students that book reports can go far beyond plot summaries.
lead_paragraph: All this week, we are featuring Great Ideas From Readers, lesson plans from teachers who teach with The Times. If you’ve used The Times in your classroom and would like to see your idea on our blog, write in and tell us what you’ve done.

headline: Dow Chemical Resists Spinoff Proposal and Increases Stock Buybacks
abstract: The company appeared to rebuff a proposal by the activist hedge fund manager Daniel S. Loeb, as it also announced measures intended to make shareholders happy.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:48 a.m. | Dow Chemical on Wednesday appeared to rebuff a proposal by an activist hedge fund manager, as it also announced measures intended to make shareholders happy.

headline: Making the Case for Ambitious Diplomacy
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: For a few moments during President Obama’s State of the Union address on Tuesday, he sounded as if he was channeling Secretary of State John Kerry.
lead_paragraph: For a few moments during President Obama’s State of the Union address on Tuesday evening, he sounded as if he was channeling Secretary of State John Kerry.

headline: Atlanta Officials Gamble on Storm and Lose, and Others Pay the Price
keywords: ['Snow and Snowstorms', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Weather', 'Roads and Traffic']
abstract: A storm deposited less than three inches of snow throughout the Atlanta region, but it left roads impassable, drivers trapped in cars and children stuck in schools.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — There are bad commutes, and then there is what happened here this week.

headline: After ‘I’ll Break You in Half,’ Grimm Apologizes
abstract: Representative Michael G. Grimm, a Republican from Staten Island, threatened a reporter for asking an unwelcome question.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Michael G. Grimm of Staten Island, once considered a rising star in the Republican Party, touched off a political firestorm after delivering unusually vitriolic threats against a reporter inside the United States Capitol building on Tuesday night, just moments after the State of the Union speech.

headline: Playing With Toys and Saving Lives
abstract: There’s nothing new about do-it-yourself — D.I.Y. is how medical products used to be invented.
lead_paragraph: “Apollo 13” is a good movie, but one 95-second stretch is what turned it into it a geek classic.   Their Command Module disabled, three astronauts use the Lunar Module as a lifeboat. Carbon dioxide is building up. The Command Module’s filters are available to scrub the air, but they’re square, and the receptacles for them on the Lunar Module are round. “Well, I suggest you gentleman invent a way to put a square peg in a round hole … rapidly,” the flight director Gene Kranz in Houston tells his engineers.

headline: Attack on Gay Journalist Not a Hate Crime, Police Say
abstract: A 24-year-old man was charged in the beating of Randy Gener, a Filipino journalist, in Manhattan, but the police said the attack had not been motivated by bias.
lead_paragraph: The police on Wednesday charged a Queens man in the beating of a gay journalist in Midtown Manhattan but said the attack was not a hate crime.

headline: Rep. Grimm Threatens NY1 Reporter
abstract: Following Tuesday’s State of the Union address, Representative Michael Grimm of Staten Island threatened an NY1 political reporter, Michael Scotto.
lead_paragraph: Following Tuesday’s State of the Union address, Representative Michael Grimm of Staten Island threatened an NY1 political reporter, Michael Scotto.

headline: The Sunny Side of the Unemployment Report
abstract: An economist once considered too negative by some has offered an upbeat interpretation of the most recent jobs report.
lead_paragraph: David A. Rosenberg, the chief economist at Gluskin Sheff, a Canadian research firm, is not known for his rose-colored glasses. Indeed, when he was at Merrill Lynch in New York, there were complaints that he was too negative.

headline: Tension Builds in Israeli Coalition at a Critical Juncture in Peace Talks
abstract: The office of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu issued a warning to a right-wing political partner, Naftali Bennett, over his harsh criticism of Mr. Netanyahu’s positions in recent days.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Simmering tension between Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and one of his right-wing political partners boiled into open hostility on Wednesday, threatening to reshape Israel’s governing coalition at a critical juncture of the American-brokered peace talks with the Palestinians.

headline: My Coach, the Bully
abstract: Athletic coaches wield enormous power, and traditionally their toughness has been upheld as a virtue. But when does it cross over into bullying?
lead_paragraph: When Dr. Nancy Swigonski, a pediatrician who often talks with families about bullying, saw a local high school coach yelling at players, calling them stupid and lazy, she tried to speak with her.

headline: The Source | Beck in Conversation With Doug Aitken
abstract: In our latest installment of this exclusive series of interviews by Doug Aitken, the artist interviews the genre-hopping musician Beck.
lead_paragraph: “It’s such a dispersal, making a song,” Beck says. “Hoping something works, or connects, somewhere, with somebody.” In conversation with Doug Aitken, the genre-hopping 43-year-old musician and producer likens songwriting to sculpture, calling it “just shaped chaos.” The interview is part of the Source, a series of candid video conversations with several dozen noteworthy figures about their creative processes, currently on view in a custom pavilion at the Sundance Film Festival.

headline: Justice Dept. Vows to Find Hackers of Target
abstract: Hours after the attorney general confirmed that the government was investigating the data breach, Target said that the hackers used a vendor’s credentials in the attack.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said Wednesday that the Justice Department was committed to finding the hackers behind the holiday season theft of credit card data from millions of Target customers.

headline: Flipping the Switches on Facebook’s Privacy Controls
abstract: If you value your privacy, using the service means determining not only what you want to share, but also who gets to see it.
lead_paragraph: FACEBOOK is all about sharing.

headline: A Trainer and Father, Supporting Both Sides of a Rivalry
abstract: Ian Gallagher will have much to cheer, inwardly, at least, when the Canadiens meet the Bruins on Thursday night: the game will feature his son, Brendan, and Milan Lucic, whom he trains in the off-season.
lead_paragraph: The Montreal Canadiens and the Boston Bruins will meet at TD Garden on Thursday night in the 723rd regular-season game between the two Original Six franchises.

headline: Social Liberalism as Class Warfare
keywords: ['Dating and Courtship', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Families and Family Life', 'Income Inequality', 'Marriages', 'Sex', 'United States Economy']
abstract: More thoughts on liberalism and the decline of marriage.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column tried to take the ongoing debate over marriage and upward mobility in a slightly different direction, by prodding social liberals to acknowledge the ways in which their own ideological vision and its victories – legal and cultural both – have played a role in the married, two-parent family’s decline. I don’t think my argument has won many converts, but rather than respond to the responses right now I wanted to highlight one of the arguments that inspired the column in the first place: This essay from Steve Randy Waldman (the brother, I believe, of the novelist Adelle Waldman, familiar to my readers from an earlier round of kulturdebating), which makes the case that “marriage promotion” as social conservatives often describe it is “a destructive cargo cult,” with altars and rings standing in for the runways and tarmacs that World War II-era South Sea Islanders allegedly built in the hopes of attracting military airplanes.

headline: Movement Seen in Talks Over Syria, Despite Gap
abstract: The top United Nations diplomat overseeing the talks, Lakhdar Brahimi, said that he expected little progress in the final few days of talks.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — After five days of deadlock and dispute in the Syrian peace talks, opposition negotiators on Wednesday seized on hints of government willingness to discuss political transition as evidence of progress. Yet the United Nations mediator dampened expectations, saying he did not anticipate any substantial result from the current round of talks, which are scheduled to end Friday.

headline: Thomas M. Sherak, Head of the House of Oscar, Dies at 68
abstract: During a three-year term as president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, Mr. Sherak sought younger and more diverse members and began a drive to build a museum of world film.
lead_paragraph: Thomas M. Sherak, a film studio executive who as president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences helped expand its mission beyond the annual awarding of Oscar statuettes, died on Tuesday at his home in Calabasas, Calif. He was 68.

headline: As I Was Saying About Web Journalism ... a Bubble, or a Lasting Business?
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Ezra Klein’s decision to leave The Washington Post for Vox Media reflects the growing influence of new players in online journalism.
lead_paragraph: Last week, it occurred to me that the departure of Ezra Klein, the creator of The Washington Post’s influential Wonkblog, to join the young company Vox Media was a bit of a moment — an inflection point in the emergence of a news economy online. When I pitched a column about it, my long-suffering editor said, “Please don’t explain the Internet to people, David.”

headline: Fed Decision Day: What to Watch For
abstract: As the Federal Reserve’s policy-making board wraps up its last meeting under Ben S. Bernanke, there are questions about its bond buying, its unemployment target and the inflation outlook.
lead_paragraph: President Obama gave a long speech Tuesday night about the things government can do to help the economy without ever mentioning the Federal Reserve. Presidents rarely do. But it’s also the case that folks at the White House, like most Fed officials, think the central bank already has done as much as it should.

headline: Portrait of the Artist as a Child
abstract: Three new books, one each on Vasily Kandinsky, Alexander Calder and Pablo Picasso, present the artists in imaginative and appealing ways.
lead_paragraph: Why is it that little children, who romp gleefully though museum halls in their preschool years, grow into kids who would rather do anything than walk through an exhibition? If only they knew how much they have in common with the men and women who made the work on the gallery walls, rebels all. Three new books, one each on Vasily Kandinsky, Alexander Calder and Pablo Picasso, present the artists in imaginative and appealing ways that should leave adults surprised by what they learn and children feeling they’ve encountered brilliant kindred spirits.

headline: Carnegie Hall Plans South Africa Festival This Fall
abstract: Carnegie Hall announced Wednesday that its 2014-15 season would include an eclectic South Africa festival, a monthlong early-music series and four performances by the mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato.
lead_paragraph: A three-week festival of the music and arts of South Africa, a series featuring the mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato and a monthlong Before Bach celebration of early music will be among the highlights of Carnegie Hall’s 2014-15 season, announced on Wednesday.

headline: Life Story of Wendy Davis Swings From Strength to Flash Point in Texas Campaign
abstract: A race for governor has led to second-guessing over the candidate’s biographical omissions and has sparked a debate about a woman’s balance of work, ambition and parenthood.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Wendy Davis is learning the perils of campaigning on her personal biography.

headline: Today in Small Business: 51 Start-Up Failures
abstract: How to trigger a tax audit. And what poor email etiquette says about your business.
lead_paragraph: Washington

headline: At Restored Landmark in Times Square, Mixing ‘Brash and Beautiful’
abstract: The restored I. Miller Building on West 46th Street has its statues of four beloved actresses back, in addition to 8,500 square feet of LED video screens.
lead_paragraph: Who are America’s four best-loved actresses?

headline: House Approves Farm Bill, Ending a 2-Year Impasse
abstract: The measure calls for cuts in food stamps, affecting more than 800,000 households, and in some subsidies for farmers.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House of Representatives on Wednesday passed a bill authorizing nearly $1 trillion in spending on farm subsidies and nutrition programs, setting the stage for final passage of a new five-year farm bill that has been stalled for more than two years.

headline: Wall Street Is a Short-Attention-Span Theater for Obama’s Speech
abstract: A muted stock reaction to a State of the Union address is fairly typical, and the one given to President Obama’s speech on Tuesday night was no different.
lead_paragraph: Investors had a there’s-not-much-to-see-here reaction to the president’s State of the Union address and turned their focus quickly to something else on Wednesday morning

headline: In Our Pages: January 30
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: 1939: William B. Yeats, Poet, Dies

headline: On Losing It (or Not)
abstract: As I get older, I collect examples of others’ memory lapses, as signs that anyone can misplace things without fear of showing mental decline.
lead_paragraph: I’m always on the alert for any proof I can muster that my missteps, mistakes, misunderstandings and failures of memory are just the stuff of normal human-being-ness — and not the signs of mental decline as I age.

headline: Analyst Who Worked on Herbalife Leaves Pershing Square
abstract: An investment analyst who played a leading role in Pershing Square Capital Management’s bet against Herbalife has decided to leave the hedge fund to pursue his own interests.
lead_paragraph: An investment analyst who played a leading role in Pershing Square Capital Management’s bet against Herbalife has decided to leave the hedge fund, according to a letter sent to its investors.

headline: Atlanta’s Residents and Officials Turn to Social Media Amid Snowstorm Chaos
abstract: With snow and ice paralyzing Atlanta and other parts of the Southeast, people turned to social media to make pleas for help and offer assistance.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:08 p.m. A few inches of snow continued to paralyze Atlanta and other parts of the southeastern United States on Wednesday, as my colleagues Kim Severson and Alan Blinder reported. Thousands of motorists were stranded in their cars overnight, while others abandoned their vehicles and slept in shopping centers. Hundreds of accidents were reported. Some schools kept students through the night, scrambling to feed them.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Rag & Bone Men’s Fall/Winter 2014
abstract: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the New York Fashion Week photo diary of Kevin Tachman.

headline: ‘Big Block of Cheese’ Day: The White House Offers a Chance to Ask Questions
abstract: After the State of the Union address, White House officials are hosting a day of social media engagement via Twitter, Facebook and a Google Hangout. If you have questions about how this year’s agenda will affect your family, here’s how to ask.
lead_paragraph: After the State of the Union Address, the White House is embarking on a day of social media outreach: “The First-Ever Virtual ‘Big Block of Cheese Day.'” First, a brief history lesson: according to the current administration, President Andrew Jackson in 1837 placed an ad announcing an open house at the White House — an opportunity for any and all to mingle with the president and his staff. The event featured a 1,400-pound block of cheese that sat in the main foyer of the White House.

headline: Classical Playlist: Zuill Bailey, Natasha Paremski, Leon Kirchner and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: BRITTEN: Cello Symphony and Cello SonataZuill Bailey, cellist; North Carolina Symphony, Grant Llewellyn, conductor; Natasha Paremski, pianist(Telarc)Benjamin Britten composed several important works for his younger friend and colleague the cellist Mstislav Rostropovich. The longest, most substantial score was the Symphony for Cello and Orchestra (1963), a dark, wrenching and overpowering piece that Britten once called “the finest thing I’ve written.” An exciting new recording — a live performance in vivid sound — couples the brilliant, searching American cellist Zuill Bailey with the fine conductor Grant Llewellyn and the North Carolina Symphony. The CD includes Mr. Bailey’s gripping account of Britten’s 1961 Cello Sonata, with the pianist Natasha Paremski. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: China’s Biggest Bank Gains Entree Into Trading in London
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Renminbi (Currency)']
abstract: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China is buying a controlling interest in Standard Bank’s global markets business in London, making it the first large Chinese lender to have a substantial trading operation in London.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:19 p.m. | LONDON — The Industrial and Commercial Bank of China agreed on Wednesday to buy a controlling interest in Standard Bank’s global markets business in London for $765 million.

headline: Making Consignment Stores Destination Shopping
abstract: Thirty-four years ago, Donna Speigel opened a consignment store in Cincinnati. Today she has 11 stores, 90 employees and annual revenue that she said exceeds $5 million.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps fittingly for a onetime director of guest relations at an amusement park, Donna Speigel has turned the Snooty Fox chain of shops — consignment shops, no less — into Cincinnati destinations. Her customers come from as far away as Indianapolis and Louisville, even paying $25 to reserve a seat on “Fox Hunt” tour buses, where they are served boxed lunches and company lore. At the stores, they get wine and dessert and typically shop, if not until they drop, at least until they have taxed the bus’s overhead racks and lower storage compartments with their purchases.

headline: Unpopularity of the House Could Turn Senate Races
abstract: To win control of the Senate, Republicans need to net six seats, and they will probably need to do it with candidates currently serving in the politically unpopular House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — To Representative Steve Daines, Republican of Montana, his vote this month against a 1,582-page, $1.1 trillion spending bill was at once a stand for fiscal sanity and a protest against spending cuts to rural communities, a “constructive no,” as he put it last week.

headline: Investors Still Wary of Efforts to Shore Up Currencies
abstract: Turkish and South African currencies plummeted on Wednesday, despite emergency measures by their central banks.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Emergency measures by Turkey and South Africa to stop a headlong flight of foreign investors had little effect on Wednesday. The financial markets all but ignored increases in official interest rates aimed at strengthening the countries’ currencies.

headline: He Was Deadly in Cha-Cha, Too
abstract: David Henry Hwang’s new play, “Kung Fu,” uses martial arts, Chinese opera and dance to tell the story of Bruce Lee’s life.
lead_paragraph: It should surprise no one that the actor Cole Horibe, cast as Bruce Lee in David Henry Hwang’s new play, “Kung Fu,” about Lee’s remarkable career, was a contestant on the reality show “So You Think You Can Dance.” Lee’s fighting in movies like “Enter the Dragon” that established him as a martial arts legend always mixed brutality with a balletic elegance. And Lee himself was a dancer, even, believe it or not, winning a cha-cha competition in 1958.

headline: A Decision Deferred: Turning Off the Pacemaker
abstract: Few older adults with pacemakers and defibrillators have thought about when the devices should be deactivated.
lead_paragraph: Nobody really knows exactly how many Americans are walking around with pacemakers and defibrillators. But with surgeons implanting at least 225,000 pacemakers and 133,000 defibrillators each year, “there probably are a couple of million” out there now, said Dr. Paul S. Mueller, a Mayo Clinic general internist and bioethicist.

headline: A Conversation With: Times Now Editor in Chief Arnab Goswami
abstract: India Ink spoke with the journalist, who landed the first TV interview with Rahul Gandhi of the Congress Party, about the reasons behind his line of questioning and why the interview was important to the public.
lead_paragraph: Arnab Goswami, editor in chief of the Times Now television news channel in Mumbai, landed one of the biggest interviews in Indian journalism in recent years when he spoke with Rahul Gandhi, the Congress Party vice president.

headline: Below the Line: Shooting ‘The Grandmaster’
abstract: The cinematographer Philippe Le Sourd discusses shooting “The Grandmaster.”
lead_paragraph: When the cinematographer Philippe Le Sourd teamed up with the director Wong Kar-wai to make “The Grandmaster,” he was expecting a six-month project. Those six months turned into three years, making the production felt as epic as the life story at the heart of the film: that of the kung fu master Ip Man. Mr. Le Sourd, nominated for his work on the film, shot in various locations and sometimes in extreme weather conditions.

headline: Ice Strands Thousands in South
abstract: Thousands of commuters were trapped in cars overnight on highways in the greater Atlanta area and hundreds of students remained inside dozens of schools Wednesday morning.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of commuters were trapped in cars overnight on highways in the greater Atlanta area and hundreds of students remained inside dozens of schools Wednesday morning.

headline: Top Intelligence Official Assails Snowden and Seeks Return of N.S.A. Documents
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: A scorching attack on Edward J. Snowden also cites unnamed accomplices in the disclosure of intelligence secrets.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The nation’s top intelligence official on Wednesday delivered a scorching attack on Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor, and called on him and his “accomplices” to return the trove of classified documents he took from the N.S.A.

headline: Enough With the Teaspoon Approach
abstract: Brooks and Collins on the big stuff missing from the State of the Union.
lead_paragraph: David Brooks: Gail, back in the early 1980s, I bought my first computer, a Kaypro. It was big, clunky, slow and by today’s standards, unbelievably primitive. Let’s face it, the State of the Union address is the Kaypro of political events. We ought to totally re-engineer the whole enterprise.

headline: Snowden Speaks to German Television
abstract: In an interview with German television, Edward J. Snowden said that despite feeling threatened, he does not lose sleep because he still believes that what he did was “the right thing to do.”
lead_paragraph: In an interview with German television, Edward J. Snowden said that despite feeling threatened, he does not lose sleep because he still believes that what he did was “the right thing to do.”

headline: Study Says New Method Could Be a Quicker Source of Stem Cells
abstract: The new technique — a simple acid bath — has so far been used successfully only with cells from mice, but some researchers see human potential.
lead_paragraph: A surprising study has found that a simple acid bath might turn cells in the body into stem cells that could one day be used for tissue repair and other medical treatments.

headline: Jessica Alba’s Edgy Elegance
abstract: At the Hollywood Stands Up to Cancer event last night, the actress donned a one-of-a-kind leather dress.
lead_paragraph: The Girl: The actress paired her one-of-a-kind floral motif white-leather dress with layers of rock and roll — tousled tresses, a dark cranberry lip, black strappy sandals and edgy jewelry — at last night’s Hollywood Stands Up to Cancer event.

headline: A Mafia Legacy Taints the Earth in Southern Italy
keywords: ['Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Organized Crime', 'Cancer']
abstract: The Camorra mafia is believed to have buried millions of tons of toxic garbage in a region near Naples, known as the Triangle of Death because of an alarming rise in cancer cases.
lead_paragraph: CASAL DI PRINCIPE, Italy — The Italian state arrived in the heartland of the Camorra mafia this month bearing a backhoe. Police officers in polished black boots posed for television cameras as the backhoe clawed into an overgrown field, searching for barrels of toxic waste or some other illegal industrial sarcophagi.

headline: Not All Monuments Men Were Men
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Movies', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Dozens of women contributed to the recovery of looted art during World War II, though their stories aren’t as well known as those of the Monuments Men.
lead_paragraph: In February 1952, as Europe rebuilt after World War II, Ardelia Ripley Hall arrived in Bonn, Germany, to play her part in a bold American military mission that had begun about a decade earlier.

headline: History, Yes, but Movie History
keywords: ['Movies', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Art', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'History (Academic Subject)']
abstract: To make a historical film like “The Monuments Men” sometimes requires that history be fudged.
lead_paragraph: In a lighthearted scene in “The Monuments Men,” an Army officer played by Bill Murray gleans clues about stolen art from a German dentist while getting a tooth yanked.

headline: A Culinary Trip to Cape Town
abstract: The firm Red Savannah is offering a food-focused trip to Cape Town and surrounding areas.
lead_paragraph: Red Savannah, an upscale travel company in Cheltenham, England, founded by the ex-Abercrombie & Kent chief executive George Morgan-Grenville, recently introduced a seven-night culinary trip to Cape Town and surrounding areas.

headline: Image of the Day: January 29
abstract: A member of a wedding band at a roadside in New Delhi.

headline: More Vegetables, Please (But Hold the Red Peppers)
abstract: In the third installment of the Picky Eater Project, parents of 4-year-old twins work to expand the boys’ food choices.
lead_paragraph: The “picky eater” ate broccoli pizza!

headline: Why the Owner of a Growing Business Found Time to Start a School
abstract: For Donna Speigel, the interest in special education started with her grandson, Dayton.
lead_paragraph: We just published an interview with Donna Speigel, owner of the Snooty Fox chain of consignment shops. Last year, the 11 stores rang up more than $5 million in sales. As Ms. Speigel explains in the interview, she has turned her Cincinnati-area shops into destinations that routinely lure people on tour buses from as far away as Louisville and Indianapolis. But Ms. Speigel has also been creative on another front. In 2006, she opened a nonprofit school for people with special needs in Covington, Ky. called the Conductive Learning Center of Greater Cincinnati. Moreover, the school is largely funded through special Snooty Fox initiatives, notably a popular platinum credit card.

headline: What You Get for ... $1,500,000
abstract: This week’s properties include a house with a Pacific view in California, a Creole house in Louisiana and a townhouse in Virginia.
lead_paragraph: BIG SUR, CALIF.

headline: Homes for $1,500,000
abstract: This week’s properties include a house with a Pacific view in California, a townhouse in Virginia and a Creole home in Louisiana.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a house with a Pacific view in California, a townhouse in Virginia and a Creole home in Louisiana.

headline: Why Is Latin America So Progressive on Gay Rights?
abstract: Defying stereotypes, the region is ahead of the U.S. and Western Europe. What explains Latin Americans' support for gay rights?

headline: Man Admits Killing 2 Women With Hammer, Officials Say
abstract: A law enforcement official said Carlos Amarillo confessed to attacking his live-in girlfriend and her daughter because he believed they were witches.
lead_paragraph: A woman and her daughter were bludgeoned to death in their Queens home by the woman’s live-in boyfriend, who called 911 and confessed that he had “killed them because they are witches,” law enforcement officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Pete Seeger, Jamming at the Beacon Sloop Club
abstract: A video of Pete Seeger at The Beacon Sloop Club, taken not long ago.
lead_paragraph: The folk musician and activist Pete Seeger played a lively role in the Beacon Sloop Club, which he helped start in 1969. It started as a campaign to clean up the Hudson River — the group’s symbol is a sloop that Seeger built called the Clearwater — and has continued as a monthly part-advocacy, part-fellowship gathering to which people bring food, talk and make music. At the meetings, Seeger would call out, “Now everyone get in a circle, make it big for everyone.” Chairs would scoot around. “No, it’s not big enough. It has to include everybody.”

headline: App Smart: Job Hunting
abstract: Today you only have to look as far as your pocket to find new work because there are many apps for mobile devices that can help.
lead_paragraph: Today you only have to look as far as your pocket to find new work because there are many apps for mobile devices that can help.

headline: Remember Want Ads for Jobs? Now You Find Them on a Phone
abstract: Glassdoor, LinkedIn, CareerBuilder and Twitter apps could help make job searching more convenient.
lead_paragraph: What do you do when you lose a job or need bigger challenges than your present one offers? Start that job hunt. You could earn more money or even prove the person who fired you wrong by landing a better job elsewhere.

headline: A Dutch Jihadist in Syria Speaks, and Blogs
abstract: A Dutchman who quit the Royal Netherlands Army to join the jihad in Syria explains himself on Tumblr and in an English-language interview this week on Dutch television.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, a Dutch public television producer scanning the Internet for information on foreign fighters in Syria stumbled on something he had never seen before: Instagram photos of a man wearing the uniform of the Royal Netherlands Army who appeared to be fighting alongside Islamist rebels against government forces.

headline: An Advanced Degree in Quiet
abstract: Vanessa Csordas-Jenkins needed a quiet place near New York University.
lead_paragraph: As she began her junior year at New York University, Vanessa Csordas-Jenkins planned to live with two friends. But the plan fell through, and she and her friends ended up in the Broome Street dorm along with four strangers.

headline: Citing Growth, Fed Again Cuts Monthly Bond Purchases
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Quantitative Easing', 'United States Economy']
abstract: In a unanimous decision, the Federal Reserve said it would pull back on its stimulus program by another $10 billion, pointing to an improving economy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In its final major decision under the leadership of Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve said on Wednesday that it would continue to slowly dismantle its stimulus campaign, citing “growing underlying strength in the broader economy.”

headline: The Gun Report: January 29, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: • Having a gun range on your property is legal in Florida, thanks to a 1987 law allowing anyone to fire anything they want on their own land. Doug Varrieur, who has turned the front yard of his home on Big Pine Key into a makeshift range, was looking for a way to teach his eyesight-impaired wife how to shoot her self-defense pistol without the inconvenience of going to a commercial gun range, “which is 50 miles round trip, costs $45 an hour and is enclosed in a building with people shooting around you that you don’t know,” he told the Miami Herald. The only rules to discharging firearms on residential property are that you can’t fire over a paved public road, highway or street, or occupied dwelling.

headline: In Rare Public Forum, Architect Defends Decision to Take Down Former Folk Art Museum
abstract: The architects whose design for an expanded Museum of Modern Art calls for the demolition of the former home of the American Folk Art Museum defended their decision at a public forum in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: An architect typically doesn’t go before the public to defend a private project. But on Tuesday night Liz Diller of Diller Scofidio & Renfro stood before a crowd of 650 people, many of them her peers, to explain in detail the six-month process by which her firm tried to save the former home of the American Folk Art Museum before deciding it was impossible.

headline: And the Grammy-Goers Go to ...
abstract: After the Grammys, a party where winners and losers get down.
lead_paragraph: After Beyoncé shook her booty, Lorde took selfies with Taylor Swift, and Madonna wobbled offstage, the real partying began Sunday night, as Grammy winners and losers decamped to various after-parties across Los Angeles.

headline: Crime Writer Henning Mankell Says He Has Cancer
abstract: Mr. Mankell, 65, is author of a series of novels with the detective Kurt Wallander. He says he will write about his experiences in a newspaper column.
lead_paragraph: Henning Mankell, a master of Scandinavian crime literature, has been diagnosed with cancer, he said Wednesday in a Swedish newspaper.

headline: Neanderthals Leave Their Mark on Us
abstract: Two studies show how the legacy of Neanderthals endures 30,000 years after their extinction, finding Neanderthal genes in skin and hair that may have helped humans evolve.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the discovery in 2010 that Neanderthals interbred with the ancestors of living humans, scientists have been trying to determine how their DNA affects people today. Now two new studies have traced the history of Neanderthal DNA, and have pinpointed a number of genes that may have medical importance today.

headline: 20 Al Jazeera Journalists Face Charges in Egypt
abstract: Egyptian prosecutors said that the journalists, all employees of the Al Jazeera television network, worked to help and spread propaganda for the Muslim Brotherhood.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egyptian prosecutors said on Wednesday that they were charging 20 journalists working for the Al Jazeera television network with conspiring with a terrorist group and broadcasting false images of “a civil war that raises alarms about the state’s collapse.”

headline: All Right, There Are Two Republican Parties
abstract: There were three organized responses—one official, one Tea Party, one libertarian—to the State of the Union.
lead_paragraph: Republican pundits have been arguing recently that immigration reform could splinter the party ahead of the 2014 elections. They shouldn’t be worrying about immigration. The Republicans’ response to President Obama’s State of the Union showed that the G.O.P. is actually two parties, or perhaps even more.

headline: Grammys Spur Streaming; Katy Perry Single Hits No. 1
abstract: Daft Punk and Paul McCartney saw gains in music streaming after the awards show; Katy Perry’s song “Dark Horse” topped the singles chart.
lead_paragraph: Lorde may have been the Grammy Awards’ most talked-about artist on Sunday night — more of the 15.2 million Grammy tweets were about her than any other act, Twitter reported — but when it came to streaming music, Daft Punk appears to have gotten the biggest early lift.

headline: Applaud, Tweet and Repeat at the State of the Union
keywords: ['Social Media', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: During Tuesday night’s State of the Union address, representatives and senators – or members of their staffs sent just under 1,500 tweets while President Obama was speaking.
lead_paragraph: Immediately after a president’s State of the Union address is delivered, news organizations frequently seek to answer a question: How many times did members of Congress stand and applaud? In this era when social media has become an important arena for politics, and in some ways eclipses the statements and interviews representatives and senators issue after an address like the State of the Union, another question may be more important: How many tweets did members of Congress send during the speech?

headline: Dow Chief Says Buffett Supports Him in Loeb Fight
abstract: Dow Chemical may have expanded its stock buyback program and dividend, but it showed little inclination to make further concessions to activist investors like Daniel S. Loeb. And that suits one major shareholder — Warren E. Buffett — just fine.
lead_paragraph: Dow Chemical may have expanded its stock buyback program and dividend, but it showed little inclination to make further concessions to activist investors like Daniel S. Loeb.

headline: Migration of Monarch Butterflies Shrinks Again Under Inhospitable Conditions
abstract: The number of butterflies making a migration widely called one of the world’s great natural spectacles has become so small that the prospects of its rebounding are diminishing, scientists said.
lead_paragraph: Faltering under extreme weather and vanishing habitats, the yearly winter migration of monarch butterflies to a handful of forested Mexican mountains dwindled precipitously in December, continuing what scientists said was an increasingly alarming decline.

headline: “The Sound of a Tree Falling”
abstract: The title song from Terry Roche’s album.
lead_paragraph: The title song from Terry Roche’s album.

headline: State of the Union: Few Horatio Alger Stories
abstract: Those examples in the State of the Union address of people who achieved success despite being the child of a barkeeper or a single mother were indeed impressive — partly because income mobility has remained stagnant.
lead_paragraph: There were a lot of pedigree shout-outs Tuesday night in the State of the Union address and the responses, generally in reference to humble beginnings.

headline: “Francis”
abstract: A song by Terre Roche.
lead_paragraph: A song by Terre Roche.

headline: New Owner of Patch Lays Off Hundreds
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Hale Global, which acquired a majority share of the local news enterprise from AOL, cut jobs from a staff of 450.
lead_paragraph: Just two weeks ago, AOL announced that it was handing over the majority stake in Patch, its troubled local news enterprise, to Hale Global, an investment company that specializes in turning around troubled companies through technological innovation. Hale said at the time that its intention was to keep operating all of Patch’s 900 sites and that no staffing decision had been made.

headline: Sotheby’s Sets Financial Path. Now, for the Art.
abstract: Sotheby’s plan addresses some aspects of the critique by the activist investor Daniel S. Loeb, says Richard Beales of Reuters Breakingviews. But governance and broader strategy remain at issue.
lead_paragraph: Sotheby’s is revamping its financial science — now, for the art. The auctioneer’s stock popped, at least initially, on the news on Wednesday of a $300 million special dividend and new criteria for investment. The plan addresses some aspects of the critique by the activist investor Daniel S. Loeb. But governance and broader strategy remain at issue.

headline: Messages of ‘Relentless, Spiraling Bloodshed’ from the Central African Republic
abstract: The emergency director for Human Rights Watch warns that sectarian violence in the African country has become a horrific back-and-forth of retaliation.
lead_paragraph: The emergency director for Human Rights Watch, Peter Bouckaert, has documented some of his most vivid warnings yet on the killing in the Central African Republic, describing a country in the “relentless, spiraling bloodshed” of sectarian retaliation on the civilians left behind as rebels withdraw.

headline: Decoding the Fed’s Statement
abstract: The statement Wednesday from the Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making group of the Federal Reserve, offers its assessment of current economic conditions.
lead_paragraph: The statement Wednesday from the Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making group of the Federal Reserve, offers its assessment of current economic conditions.

headline: Dining in Dublin, From Boxty to Blaa
abstract: A restaurant crawl across the capital reveals a tasty mix of locally sourced ingredients, Irish classics and contemporary takes on the country’s cuisine.
lead_paragraph: Manor Street, the main street that runs through the neighborhood of Stoneybatter in north Dublin, is lined with traditional pubs. L. Mulligan Grocer, as its name suggests, is housed in a former pub and food shop. And it fits right in: A long bar, lined with taps, dominates the right side of the room.

headline: Dublin, Beyond the Guinness Storehouse
abstract: The alternative R & B artist James Vincent McMorrow gives a local’s view of the city’s music scene and burgeoning coffee culture.
lead_paragraph: For the alternative R & B artist James Vincent McMorrow, the world’s image of Dublin fails to capture what makes the city special for locals.

headline: House Hunting in ... Austria
abstract: The Austrian market remains strong, buoyed by investors who sought a safe haven after the financial volatility of the last several years.
lead_paragraph: A RESTORED FARMHOUSE OUTSIDE SALZBURG

headline: A Farmhouse Outside Salzburg
abstract: A four-bedroom home built in 1890 is on the market for $1 million.
lead_paragraph: A four-bedroom home built in 1890 is on the market for $1 million.

headline: Military Plans Reflect Afghanistan Uncertainty
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Military planners, facing continued political uncertainty, have set in motion a plan designed to give NATO’s political leadership maximum flexibility, senior officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American and NATO military planners, facing continued political uncertainty about whether foreign troops will remain in Afghanistan after December, have drawn up plans to deploy a force this summer that is tailored to assume a training mission in 2015 but is also small enough to withdraw if no deal for an enduring presence is reached, alliance officials said.

headline: Wry Hybrid of Debonair and Tetchy
abstract: James Naughton opened Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series on Tuesday with a selection of Randy Newman’s songs.
lead_paragraph: Debonair, an adjective that fits the actor and singer James Naughton to a T, isn’t a word that describes the despairing, grandiose and perverse fantasists who inhabit the songs of Randy Newman. But Mr. Naughton, 68, whose anthology of Mr. Newman’s work opened the 16th season of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series at the Allen Room on Tuesday evening, persuasively empathized with Mr. Newman’s cranky, woebegone characters. Typical is the narrator of “You Can Leave Your Hat On.” Addressing a woman who may be a prostitute as she strips and shakes her breasts, he grunts, “You give me reason to live.”

headline: Grammy Producer Responds to Trent Reznor’s Angry Critique
abstract: Trent Reznor was not pleased when his band was cut off from the broadcast while performing at the end of the Grammy Awards.
lead_paragraph: The executive producer of the Grammy Awards has responded to a public complaint by Trent Reznor that his performance at the show was “disrespected.”

headline: Pet Owners Brace for Chinese New Year Fireworks
abstract: Although Lunar New Year fireworks are considered a sound of celebration and a deterrent to evil spirits, many pet owners say their dogs and cats are terrified during the two-week barrage of pyrotechnics.
lead_paragraph: The explosions of Lunar New Year fireworks are considered a sound of celebration and a deterrent to evil spirits. But they also are responsible for injuries and fires and cause air quality, which is already poor in many parts of China, to worsen.

headline: Palestinian Shot Dead by Israeli Forces in West Bank
abstract: The Israeli military said the man opened fire first at a military post north of Ramallah; a Palestinian official said he was carrying a sign to redirect traffic.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A Palestinian man, Muhammad Mahmoud Mubarak, 21, was fatally shot on Wednesday by Israeli forces in the West Bank. The Israeli military said in a statement that Mr. Mubarak opened fire first at a military post north of Ramallah and that soldiers fired back “to eliminate the imminent threat to their lives.” There were no casualties among the soldiers.

headline: Apps With No Rules? No Problem
abstract: Toca Boca, a Swedish app developer, says its apps are intended to help children develop in a noncompetitive environment.
lead_paragraph: Toca Boca, the Swedish app developer that makes digital products for children, is slowly building a formidable library of apps.

headline: What Would You Do With Eight Tiny Subarus?
abstract: Among the stars of American automotive history, the Subaru 360 squats out of sight, a sales failure. But a few survived.
lead_paragraph: Look through the automotive listings on any city’s Craigslist page, and you’re bound to find a fairly predictable list of vehicles like pickups, S.U.V.'s and late-model sedans from Detroit and Japan. But once in awhile you come across something unique.

headline: Video From Snowden’s German TV Interview
abstract: In excerpts from an interview with German television, the former National Security Agency contractor, Edward Snowden, dismissed President Obama’s proposed reforms and threats to his life published in Buzzfeed.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:12 p.m. | In excerpts from an interview with German television made available to The Lede on Wednesday, the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden said that he sleeps well in Russia, where he enjoys temporary asylum, despite reading recently on Buzzfeed that some of his former colleagues in United States intelligence would like to kill him. “I don’t lose sleep because I’ve done what I feel I needed to do,” Mr. Snowden said. “It was the right thing to do and I’m not going to be afraid.”

headline: Excerpt From 'Brokeback Mountain'
abstract: A scene from the opera.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the opera.

headline: Obama Kicks Off His ‘Opportunity Agenda’
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Minimum Wage', 'State of the Union Message (US)']
abstract: A day after his State of the Union address, the president visited a Costco warehouse in Maryland to promote his economic plan and discuss raising the minimum wage.
lead_paragraph: A day after his State of the Union address, the president visited a Costco warehouse in Maryland to promote his economic plan and discuss raising the minimum wage.

headline: On View | Frank Lloyd Wright’s Love-Hate Relationship With the American City
abstract: A new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art captures the architect’s ambivalence toward urbanism by contrasting his unrealized plans for a suburban utopia with several proposals for massive skyscrapers.
lead_paragraph: Frank Lloyd Wright was generally not a fan of cities. He thought them dirty, congested and hollow. In his 1932 book, “The Disappearing City,” he wrote of the American metropolis: “A parasite of the spirit is here, a whirling dervish in a whirling vortex.” The exhibition “Frank Lloyd Wright and the City: Density vs. Dispersal,” which opens this Saturday at the Museum of Modern Art, examines the legendary architect’s feelings about urbanism through his plans for a horizontal anti-metropolis he called Broadacre City, a lifelong project that some consider to have been a blueprint for suburbia. Perhaps surprisingly, there are also schemes for several unrealized skyscrapers, the very icons of the cities he held in such noisy contempt.

headline: Europe’s Banking Risk Plan Is a Long Shot
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The European Union revealed a long-awaited proposal to reduce the systemic risk posed by big banks like the Volcker Rule in the United States, but it may be a long time before the European Parliament considers it.
lead_paragraph: The European Union on Wednesday revealed a long-awaited proposal to reduce the systemic risk posed by big banks, a measure that would bring the bloc’s regulations more closely into line with those of the United States. But it is unlikely to become law anytime soon.

headline: For a Wife, the Musing Never Stops
abstract: A wife ruminates big and small in “Dept. of Speculation,” Jenny Offill’s latest novel.
lead_paragraph: Two innovative books published in the 1970s used fragmentation and discontinuity to create kaleidoscopic portraits of their heroines’ lives. Renata Adler’s “Speedboat,” narrated by a woman who worked at a tabloid newspaper, jump-cut among vignettes from her life to capture the incongruities of her experience and the larger incongruities of American life in the ’60s and ’70s. Elizabeth Hardwick’s “Sleepless Nights,” whose narrator bore more than a passing resemblance to the author, mapped the contours of her life by putting memories, aphorisms and observations on shuffle.

headline: Below the Bikini Line, a Growing Trend
abstract: Women are increasingly going with the natural look when it comes to their nether regions.
lead_paragraph: For the last decade, the Brazilian bikini wax has seemed to dominate salons and popular culture alike, leaving its adherents completely bare (or with just a suggestion of hair) in their nether regions.

headline: Daring to Be Free, in a Story Line and in the Marketplace
abstract: Double Fine’s new Broken Age, for Windows PC, Mac and Linux, follows two characters feeling closed in.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the most impressive thing about Broken Age, an enchanting, imaginative fable from Double Fine Productions, is that its makers have created a video game that is at least as interesting as the story of how it was made.

headline: Wendy Davis Responds to Criticism
abstract: In a speech Tuesday night, the Texas state senator and Democratic candidate for governor responded to accusations that she has misstated details of her experience as a single mother.
lead_paragraph: In a speech Tuesday night, the Texas state senator and Democratic candidate for governor responded to accusations that she has misstated details of her experience as a single mother.

headline: Singing of Toilets, Instead of for Tonys
abstract: Industrials musicals, which have long since disappeared, were once professional shows that featured impressive talent.
lead_paragraph: In 1956, Hank Beebe was a young composer just getting started in the New York theater when he auditioned for something his agent had called “the Chevy show.” It sounded like a big break. “I thought he meant the television show with Dinah Shore,” Mr. Beebe said.

headline: In TriBeCa, a Savile Row Fantasy
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Men and Boys', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Coats']
abstract: The Armoury brings advanced men’s wear to a neighborhood that had lacked it.
lead_paragraph: THERE ARE ONLY a few ways to utter the sentence “I’ve seen a lot of hand-rolled pocket square edges, and those are by far the best,” and most of them are awful, pretentious, smug. Nick had it down, though.

headline: Loving Ice Cream and an Older Woman
abstract: Louis C. K. has made available online “Tomorrow Night,” a movie he made in the late 1990s.
lead_paragraph: Wednesday was the day that the world had no idea it had been waiting for: the day that Louis C. K. made available online a movie that has gone virtually unseen since he filmed it a decade and a half ago. The movie, which he wrote and directed, is called “Tomorrow Night,” and he has described it as having been living in film cans since receiving a few festival screenings way back when.

headline: Blending In With Her Environment
abstract: Chelsea Darling, a hairstylist in New Orleans, has a look that is a combination of sexy and tough.
lead_paragraph: Chelsea Darling’s look begins with her name. The 24-year-old New Orleans hairstylist was born Chelsea Martin, but then she read an article about how choosing a name was a way to shape an identity. So she adopted the moniker Chelsea Darling, inspired in part by the ’60s and ’70s style she favors, the era of Candy Darling and Sid Vicious.

headline: Obama on Foreign Policy
abstract: In his State of the Union address, President Obama addressed crucial foreign policy issues.
lead_paragraph: In his State of the Union address, President Obama addressed crucial foreign policy issues.

headline: From the Wetlands to Williamsburg, the Zen Tricksters Ride Again
abstract: The live-music legacy of the Grateful Dead is still out there, and every once in a while, one of the great tribute bands gets together to let it shine.
lead_paragraph: It could have been the Wetlands circa 1994, except that it was Brooklyn Bowl in 2014. Which doesn’t seem possible, since that would make me … hmm … carry the 1 … and. Really? You know what they say: All the years combine. …

headline: Attorney General on Target Data Breach
abstract: Speaking before the Senate Judiciary Committee, Eric H. Holder Jr. confirmed that the Justice Department was investigating the credit card data theft that affected millions of Target customers.
lead_paragraph: Speaking before the Senate Judiciary Committee, Eric H. Holder Jr. confirmed that the Justice Department was investigating the credit card data theft that affected millions of Target customers.

headline: After Big Bet, Google Is to Sell Motorola Unit
abstract: Though not a total financial loss, the announced sale of the smartphone unit for $2.91 billion, less than two years after Google paid $12.5 billion for it, is a sign of fits and starts at the company in the mobile age.
lead_paragraph: Larry Page, Google’s co-founder and chief executive, likes to talk about “big bets” and “moonshots.” But the thing about moonshots is that they can crash into earth.

headline: Law Enforcement Strikes Back in Bitcoin Hearing
abstract: Government officials testified on Wednesday that virtual currencies like Bitcoin had opened up new avenues for crime that the authorities had not been able to keep up with.
lead_paragraph: Law enforcement officials testified on Wednesday that virtual currencies like Bitcoin had opened up new avenues for crime that government has not been able to keep up with.

headline: Top Russian Biathlete Reportedly Fails Doping Test
abstract: The revelation regarding Irina Starykh, the reigning women’s European champion in one of Russia’s signature sports, dealt a blow to the Olympics host country.
lead_paragraph: A Russian biathlete who is the reigning women’s European champion has been suspended for a doping violation just a week before the Olympic opening ceremony in Sochi, according to Russian reports. The suspension dealt a blow to the Olympics host country and cast a pall over one of Russia’s signature sports.

headline: Leaping Uncontained by the Stage or the Screen
abstract: The Royal Opera House’s production of the ballet “Giselle” was broadcast from London to movie theaters around the world.
lead_paragraph: When the Russian ballerina Natalia Osipova announced last year that she would be joining the Royal Ballet, many New Yorkers were disappointed, fearing that a commitment to London would mean that we would see less of her here, where she has danced superlatively with American Ballet Theater. And indeed Ms. Osipova is not scheduled for Ballet Theater’s 2014 Metropolitan Opera House season. Yet on Monday, New Yorkers could watch her with her new colleagues in “Giselle,” via one of the Royal Opera House’s cinema broadcasts.

headline: For a New Jersey Mayor, a Surprise Invitation to the Super Bowl
abstract: Mayor James L. Cassella of East Rutherford, where Super Bowl XLVIII will be played Sunday, was invited by the owner of the Indianapolis Colts to watch the game from a suite at MetLife Stadium.
lead_paragraph: The mayor of East Rutherford, N.J., the town in which Super Bowl XLVIII will be played on Sunday, finally has a ticket to the game.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Central African Republic and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Central African Republic, Syria, Gaza City and Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Central African Republic, Syria, Gaza City and Atlanta.

headline: Check-In by Smartphone
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Mobile Applications', 'Smartphones', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Aloft hotels will offer keyless check-ins for guests using smartphones at two locations before expanding the program in 2015.
lead_paragraph: Aiming for efficiency, two Aloft hotels will begin offering keyless check-ins, allowing smartphone-equipped guests to bypass the front desk and proceed directly to their rooms, where doors will open when activated via Bluetooth technology and the phone is held in front of the lock.

headline: Be Careful at the Book Club, the Author Might Be There
abstract: Book the Writer, a new service, brings authors to book clubs.
lead_paragraph: The living room in the plush apartment on Central Park West was filled with all the trappings of a traditional book club.

headline: Snowboarders Explore Their Backyard
abstract: Jeremy Jones, a professional snowboarder, built a career on exploring remote mountains by helicopter and snowboarding down them. Then he began to discover his backyard under the power of his own feet.
lead_paragraph: Jeremy Jones, a professional snowboarder, built a career on exploring remote mountains by helicopter and snowboarding down them. Then he began to discover his backyard under the power of his own feet.

headline: Obesity Is Found to Gain Its Hold in Earliest Years
abstract: Experts say the results of a major new study may reshape approaches to combating the nation’s obesity epidemic, suggesting that efforts must start much earlier and focus more on the children at greatest risk.
lead_paragraph: For many obese adults, the die was cast by the time they were 5 years old. A major new study of more than 7,000 children has found that a third of children who were overweight in kindergarten were obese by eighth grade. And almost every child who was very obese remained that way.

headline: Video: Snowboarder Explores His Own Backyard
abstract: In a companion piece to its “Higher Unplugged” series, Teton Gravity Research and the snowboarder Jeremy Jones explore Jones’s own backyard as a snowboarding destination.
lead_paragraph: In the past six years, Jeremy Jones has collaborated with Teton Gravity Research to create a trilogy of films: “Deeper,” “Further” and now “Higher.” These films document his efforts to explore and snowboard remote mountains under his own power.

headline: Itaú Unibanco Buys Controlling Stake in CorpBanca of Chile
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Itaú Unibanco plans to combine CorpBanca with its Chilean unit, Itaú Chile, in one of the largest financial transactions in Latin America in years.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The Brazilian bank Itaú Unibanco has acquired a controlling stake in the Chilean bank CorpBanca, a move that follows its growing ambitions to expand in Latin America.

headline: Big Profit at Facebook as It Tilts to Mobile
abstract: The social networking giant reported that 53 percent of its advertising revenue in the fourth quarter came from mobile devices.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Ten years after its founding as a simple website for a few thousand Harvard undergraduates to manage their social lives, Facebook is a far different company.

headline: A Whirl of Memories and Ardent Invention, From Nureyev to Now
keywords: ['Dance on Camera Festival', 'Dancing', 'Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: Lincoln Center’s Dance on Camera festival returns with films focusing on luminaries like Paul Taylor and Rudolf Nureyev that wrap in intriguing interviews, rehearsals and performances.
lead_paragraph: New York’s Dance on Camera festival has now reached its 42nd edition. Started as a Dance Films Association initiative and itinerant for its first 25 years, it found a home at the Film Society of Lincoln Center in 1996. The schedule for the 2014 season, which runs from Friday through Tuesday, is crowded.

headline: ‘American Idol,’ at 13, Is Trying to Stay Relevant
abstract: “American Idol,” now old enough to have the children of earlier contestants performing, tries to maintain its relevance and vitality.
lead_paragraph: Audiences, like French presidents, can’t always be trusted.

headline: District 3 Winter Regional’s Friday Open Pairs
abstract: At the District 3 Winter Regional in Rye Brook, N.Y., two weeks ago, the winners of the Friday Open Pairs were Bjorn Fallenius and Andrew Rosenthal of New York City.
lead_paragraph: At the District 3 Winter Regional in Rye Brook, N.Y., two weeks ago, the winners of the Friday Open Pairs were Bjorn Fallenius and Andrew Rosenthal of New York City. They were originally announced as second, but a score correction moved them into first by 0.84 match points ahead of Gail Greenberg and Jeff Hand of New York City. Third were Ann Borgschulte of Lexington, Mass., and Stephen Gladyszak of Chelsea, Mass.

headline: A Soviet Composer’s Circle of Friends
abstract: Juilliard students paid tribute to Alfred Schnittke at the Focus! festival on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: It takes a village to raise some composers to prominence. That was the lesson to be learned from an onstage discussion on Tuesday evening at the Juilliard School that preceded one of the six free concerts in the school’s remarkable Focus! festival.

headline: For Already Vulnerable Penguins, Study Finds Climate Change Is Another Danger
abstract: Intense rainfall and extreme heat combined with predation and starvation make life difficult for penguins, a University of Washington scientist says.
lead_paragraph: Life has never been easy for just-hatched Magellanic penguins, but climate change is making it worse, according to a decades-long study of the largest breeding colony of the birds.

headline: Newly Released Books
abstract: New fiction includes story collections by Christopher Merkner and D. W. Wilson and novels by Magdalena Zyzak and Gaute Heivoll.
lead_paragraph: This month, three novels and three collections of stories, each with a vivid sense of place, including an absurdist version of the Midwest, a gritty corner of British Columbia and a fictional Eastern European country in 1939.

headline: Industry in North Dakota to Cut Flared Natural Gas
abstract: Facing criticism and legal trouble, companies working in the Bakken shale field said they would try to recapture more of the natural gas now burned as waste.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Faced with growing criticism and lawsuits, an oil industry task force representing hundreds of companies in North Dakota pledged on Wednesday to make an all-out effort to capture almost all the natural gas that is being flared in the Bakken shale oil field by the end of the decade.

headline: Obama’s Call for a ‘Year of Action’
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Readers react to his State of the Union address.

headline: As China’s Economy Slows, the Pain Hits Home
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Commodities']
abstract: Emerging markets are heavily exposed to any economic slowdown in China, but the most vulnerable producers may be the mines and farms in China itself.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Piles of unsold coal line rural roads in north-central China. Some iron ore mines near Beijing are operating at a fraction of capacity. Chinese farm products are even increasingly scorned by the Chinese consumer.

headline: The Prognosis Is Grim, but I’m Living My Life
abstract: A woman with lung cancer and a nurse practitioner react to a Sunday Review essay about terminal illnesses.

headline: He Had a Hammer, and His Hammer Was Song
abstract: Readers react to the death of Pete Seeger.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Citigroup Joins Rivals in Permitting Junior Bankers to Take Saturdays Off
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Paid Time Off', 'Working Hours']
abstract: Citigroup says that junior bankers are now encouraged to stay out of the office from 10 p.m. on Friday through 10 a.m. on Sunday. It is also telling them to take all of their annual vacation days.
lead_paragraph: Memo to junior bankers at Citigroup: You can soon join your friends at other Wall Street banks in taking Saturdays off.

headline: Which Vision for Oscar?
abstract: Will Alfonso Cuarón’s deep dive into space, David O. Russell’s ’70s nostalgia or Steve McQueen’s history capture the Academy Award?
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — At some point, deep in the four and a half years it took to make “Gravity,” Alfonso Cuarón, the director and co-writer, screened his lost-in-space saga for a test audience. And? “It was a disaster,” he said.

headline: Why Are We Talking About Wendy Davis’s Choices?
abstract: As of 2009, more than half of all children born to women under 30 in the United States were born to unmarried women. So why is Wendy Davis, a Texas gubernatorial candidate, being singled out for criticism?
lead_paragraph: Wendy Davis, a Texas state senator and Democratic candidate in the race to become governor of Texas in 2015, has been under attack for blurring and misstating details of her story as a single mother. If Wendy Davis were Henry Davis, would the national media — including The New York Times (Texas Democrat Defends Back Story Under Criticism) — be covering the attacks on her as she and her opponents battle to define her personal and family history?

headline: C.I.A. Drone Bases
abstract: Representative Rush Holt, Democrat of New Jersey, responds to an article about the possible loss of bases in Afghanistan from which to launch drones.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Jobless in North Carolina
abstract: Alexandra Sirota of the North Carolina Budget and Tax Center discusses the harm done in her state.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Nederlander Organization Agrees to Improve Disability Access at Its Theaters
abstract: The Nederlander Organization has agreed to improve disability access at its theaters in Manhattan as part of a settlement to a suit that had been brought by the federal government.
lead_paragraph: The Nederlander Organization has agreed to increase access for disabled people at the nine theaters it operates on Broadway, lawyers for the federal government said Wednesday.

keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Penguins', 'Environment', 'Animal Migration', 'Newspapers', 'Babies and Infants', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Global Warming', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
