headline: Q. and A. | Playwright Thomas Bradshaw on Race, Porn and Suburbia
abstract: The controversial young star discusses his new play, “Intimacy,” which opens tonight, adapting “Uncle Tom’s Cabin” and how ethnic slurs are different in New Jersey and Chicago.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Bradshaw’s plays have elicited belly laughs from some viewers and disgust from others. Naysayers have called the 33-year-old playwright’s shows, which include “Purity,” “Burning” and “Job,” “ugly fantasies” and “horror shows.” One Chicago theater critic went so far as to warn Bradshaw to get out of town. The reactions are due to the fact that Bradshaw, who is black, stages outrageous behavior — including child rape, racially charged sex and modern-day slavery — in casual, conversational ways.

headline: Aiming for Recognition, Axa Trims Its Name
abstract: Axa Equitable, the insurance company, is shortening its name, and also starting an ad campaign aiming to keep pace with competing insurers and improve name recognition.
lead_paragraph: AXA EQUITABLE is taking an ax to its name, trimming it to Axa so it will conform in the United States with the French-based company’s brand elsewhere.

headline: On Any Given Night Out
abstract: For those attending benefits, their sense of having arrived is seldom in doubt.
lead_paragraph: “It’s just supper, baby,” the celebrity chef Mario Batali said merrily on a frigid Friday evening, surveying a dinner-party scene of the sort some would give their eye teeth to join.

headline: A Sporty Classic With Fresh Detailing
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Shoes and Boots', 'Jewels and Jewelry']
abstract: Bomber jackets in luxe fabrics with cool embellishments are plentiful for spring.
lead_paragraph: Flip through any of the latest fashion magazines and you’ll be struck by the ubiquity of the sports influences for spring: loads of mesh, track pants, crunchy Teva-style sandals — remember those sparkly numbers at Prada? — and athletic bomber jackets like the ones here, any of which will raise your outerwear game. No everyday bombers, these jackets are reimagined with luxe fabrics and cool embellishments. Another reason to like them: their versatility. Wear over sporty looks, like a mesh top and silk track pants; or as Elettra Wiedemann (shown here) did, wearing her Giambattista Valli as a statement piece over trousers and a print top.

headline: In London, Fashion History Up Close
abstract: Exploring the intersection of two lives: Isabella Blow’s and Alexander McQueen’s.
lead_paragraph: For those who were shut out of the blockbuster “Savage Beauty” show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 2011 or, because of the crowds, couldn’t get close enough to the Alexander McQueen clothes to actually see them, a trip to London may be in order.

headline: Standing Tall on Its Own
abstract: Pharrell Williams’s hat, which invited comparisons with the Royal Canadian Mounties, Smokey Bear and the Arby’s logo, has its own Twitter account.
lead_paragraph: On the Grammys red carpet on Sunday, there were plenty of notable outfits, like Katy Perry’s Valentino couture dress and Taylor Swift’s all-grown-up Gucci gown, and some genuine moments of oddness. (Madonna. Enough said.) But perhaps no single sartorial touch drew as much attention as did the oversize hat Pharrell Williams wore as he jauntily walked past the paparazzi and chatted with Ryan Seacrest, who, strangely, never thought to ask, “What are you wearing?” (Mr. Williams later told another interviewer it was vintage Vivienne Westwood.) The hat invited comparisons to the Royal Canadian Mounties, Smokey Bear and even the Arby’s logo. And, inevitably, within minutes of its appearance, the hat had its own Twitter account, @Pharrellhat, and, by the next morning, more than 16,000 followers.

headline: Anything but Uniform
abstract: The Seahawks and the Broncos are carrying the flag for Nike in the Super Bowl. Here, Marshawn Lynch in a Seahawks uniform designed by Nike.
lead_paragraph: No matter what happens Sunday in the Super Bowl between the Seattle Seahawks and the Denver Broncos, there will be one West Coast team that comes out a winner: Nike.

headline: Winter-White Makeup
abstract: New products in the shade of the season.
lead_paragraph: Winter white is a fresh choice for clothing, but the dry-cleaning bills can be downright chilling. This season, the shade is also widely available in makeup, with somewhat less risk to your pocketbook.

headline: Did Google Really Lose on Its Original Motorola Deal?
abstract: Breaking down the admittedly messy math for the original Motorola deal shows that Google didn’t exactly lose nearly $10 billion on that transaction.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:57 p.m. |

headline: Personal Trainer, Worn on a Wrist
abstract: The Force, new from Fitbit, opens a window on your exercise habits. But it still requires a good bit of work from you.
lead_paragraph: My first experience with a fitness tracker was memorable. It fit snugly in my pocket and estimated the number of steps I took and the calories I burned each day. There was just one problem: It seemed to think I was getting roughly the same amount of exercise regardless of whether I was jogging around a track or eating French fries in a diner. After about two weeks, I stopped wearing it, most likely because I lost it.

headline: ‘Loud, Strong, Committed and Always in Search of America’
abstract: Musicians and others who were inspired by Pete Seeger recalled their experiences with the folk singer and activist, who died on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Pete Seeger, who died at 94 on Monday, inspired generations of musicians to think about music in a particular way – or, it turns out, many particular ways, depending on the musician. Some were inspired to consider the nature of the instruments they played, and for banjo players in particular, Mr. Seeger was a role model and a master teacher. For most, though, he was the consummate political singer, a campaigner for free speech and the right to protest, whether the cause was personal rights or the state of the environment. Since Mr. Seeger’s death, several musicians and others who were inspired by him spoke about their experiences with Mr. Seeger.

headline: A Super Bowl View in the Meatpacking District
abstract: FC Gotham projects the atmosphere of a British club, with wood, sofas and Oriental rugs.
lead_paragraph: With prices for a luxury box at the Super Bowl hovering at $500,000, some New Yorkers may be wondering where they can toss back a few glasses of Dom and enjoy this all-American pastime with other well moisturized types who aspire to be high rollers. Enter FC Gotham, a flashy sports lounge that opened recently in the meatpacking district.

headline: Super Bowling Down Broadway
abstract: Super Bowl sideshows have taken over 13 blocks of Broadway, building up to Sunday's game. A toboggan run, goal-kicking nets and autograph hunters now jostle with New Yorkers along the fabled street.
lead_paragraph: Super Bowl sideshows have taken over 13 blocks of Broadway, building up to Sunday's game. A toboggan run, goal-kicking nets and autograph hunters now jostle with New Yorkers along the fabled street.

headline: Obama’s Speech Raises Hopes of Advocates of Mortgage Finance Overhaul
keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'State of the Union Message (US)']
abstract: The president’s State of the Union address on Tuesday provided a glimmer of hope for those looking for action to revamp America’s mortgage system.
lead_paragraph: The president’s State of the Union address on Tuesday provided a glimmer of hope for those looking for action to revamp America’s mortgage system.

headline: New Concern About Testosterone and Heart Risks
abstract: A large new study found that prescription testosterone raised the risk of heart attacks in older men and in middle aged men with a history of heart disease, prompting some experts on Wednesday to call for more extensive warning labels on the drugs.
lead_paragraph: A large new study found that prescription testosterone raised the risk of heart attacks in older men and in middle-aged men with a history of heart disease, prompting some experts on Wednesday to call for more extensive warning labels on the drugs.

headline: Dynamic Duo: Alfonso and Jonás Cuarón
abstract: The father-son filmmaking team Alfonso and Jonás Cuarón talk about the draw of space, character and their Oscar-nominated film, “Gravity.”
lead_paragraph: The father-son filmmaking team Alfonso and Jonás Cuarón talk about the draw of space, character and their Oscar-nominated film, “Gravity.”

headline: A Barneys Campaign Embraces a Gender Identity Issue
abstract: Bruce Weber photographed nearly 20 transgender models for a catalog and magazines.
lead_paragraph: Arin Andrews and Katie Hill do not look out of place in the new Barneys New York campaign. Both have nonexistent hips, are right in the ballpark of six feet tall and aren’t yet old enough for a legal drink. But there’s one marked difference between them and the models you ordinarily see on runways and in the pages of Vogue and Elle: Mr. Andrews, 17, was born a girl, and Ms. Hill, 19, a boy.

headline: Address by Obama Drew Fewest Viewers Since 2000
abstract: The State of the Union speech was seen by 33.3 million viewers, a slight dip from last year’s 33.5 million, but far off President Obama’s 2009 speech.
lead_paragraph: More networks than ever before covered the State of the Union address Tuesday night, but the total audience still came in lower than any year since 2000.

headline: Sales at Metropolitan Window Fashions and Others
abstract: Bargains on fabricating custom draperies, Roman shades and bedding, and more.
lead_paragraph: Sight Unseen is discounting everything on its site by 20 percent, through Saturday (the Pyramid lamp by Bzippy & Co., usually $275, is $220); 347-748-1231, shop.sightunseen.com.

headline: A Hotel That Takes in the Neighborhood
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Furniture', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: The Broome opens in SoHo in February with furnishings supplied mostly by locals.
lead_paragraph: When the Broome hotel opens on Feb. 14 in SoHo, it will have a European look, but the furnishings will be mostly homegrown. “We wanted local artisans and vendors,” said Vincent Boitier, one of the four French partners and a previous owner of L’Orange Bleue, the SoHo restaurant that closed in 2012.

headline: Marcel Wanders’s Wonders
abstract: The Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam has opened a major retrospective of the Dutch designer.
lead_paragraph: It took some time for the Dutch designer Marcel Wanders to get his professional bearings. He attended four art and design schools, ultimately graduating from one in Arnhem, in the Netherlands, in 1988 (with honors). Then his career took off. In the 1990s, he joined the influential collective Droog Design, and in 2001 he was a founder of the furniture company Moooi.

headline: A Model Instrument
abstract: A pen heats and extrudes plastic, allowing users to transform lines into shapes.
lead_paragraph: Peter Dilworth, a graduate of the Media Lab at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and Maxwell Bogue, a toy inventor, have put the idea of 3-D printing into the hands of everyday users without the need for software or even a computer.

headline: A Mystery at the Bend
abstract: Clinging to a hill is a little-known architect’s masterwork that looks as if it were designed for a Bond villain.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — New arrivals to this city are often told by locals to hop in the car and take Sunset Boulevard to the Pacific Ocean. It is a beautiful drive, world famous. It is also an initiation into the California myth without the downsides: you glide past the traffic-clogged 405 freeway, wind through rustic canyons where movie stars live and breathe in the ocean breezes west of Brentwood, as if nature had provided Angelenos with free air-conditioning.

headline: Sometimes Asparagus Is More Than Asparagus
abstract: Helen Yoest wrote a book about natural aphrodisiacs called “Plants With Benefits.”
lead_paragraph: Helen Yoest didn’t set out, as she said recently, to write a horticultural Kama Sutra. It was sort of an accident. Ms. Yoest, a garden writer, was researching an article on avocados when she learned that the fruit was considered an aphrodisiac. What makes it so, she wondered: The nutrients? The shape? Bingo. Turns out their reputation dates to the Aztecs, who marveled at how avocados grew in pairs, and named the plant “the testicle tree.”

headline: Blue Bottle Raises $25.75 Million, Including From High-Powered Friends
abstract: The chief executive of Blue Bottle, a gourmet coffee purveyor, confirmed that his company had raised $25.75 million in a new round of financing, including from co-founders of Instagram and Twitter.
lead_paragraph: Few brands are as beloved in the tech community as the Blue Bottle Coffee Company, a nearly 12-year-old purveyor of gourmet brews made in painstakingly detailed fashion.

headline: Major Expansion Ahead at The Washington Post
abstract: The budget at the newspaper owned by Jeffrey Bezos, the founder of Amazon.com, will be increased and dozens of new employees will be hired for the newsroom.
lead_paragraph: The Washington Post has significantly increased its budget and plans to make dozens of newsroom hires under its new owner, the Amazon founder Jeffrey P. Bezos, the paper’s executive editor, Marty Baron, said in an interview on Wednesday.

headline: Planters: Best Supporting Actors
abstract: When choosing containers, the garden designer Jon Carloftis said, remember that the plants are the “real stars,” and the planter is just the “vessel.”
lead_paragraph: It may seem like an odd time to be thinking about planters, with signs of the polar vortex still in evidence. But as Jon Carloftis, a garden designer with clients like Google and Maker’s Mark, said, “Now is the time everyone needs something green in their life.”

headline: Boeing Shares Fall as It Cautions on Its Profits in 2014
abstract: The plane maker’s stock dropped 5.3 percent on Wednesday following projections that its revenue would increase less than expected in 2014.
lead_paragraph: After doubling over the last year, Boeing’s stock dropped 5.3 percent on Wednesday when the plane maker projected flattening profits in 2014.

headline: Music Data Firms to Collaborate on Internet Radio Platform
abstract: Gracenote will work with the data company Next Big Sound as it develops a system that would let almost any anyone create an Internet radio service.
lead_paragraph: Gracenote, a digital music data service that the Tribune Company bought last month for $170 million, is quickly moving forward with its plans for a customizable Internet radio program that would let consumer brands, car companies and anyone else have their own music app.

headline: Extra Arms (and Teeth) for Wrangling Firewood
abstract: Do Grill Daddy’s King Tong fire tongs really help you manipulate smoldering logs? The jury is still out.
lead_paragraph: In our family, it is my job to build and poke at fires in our wood-burning fireplace. I use wrought-iron tools I bought on eBay, and they have served me well. But this winter, I tested something new: Grill Daddy King Tong fire tongs (about $45), which promised to let me manipulate smoldering logs with less effort.

headline: Should I Update the Flooring in My Entry Hall?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Floors and Flooring', 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: That depends on the condition of the rest of your home.
lead_paragraph: Q. The floors in our home are mostly hardwood except for the entry hall, which is dated tile. Is it worth replacing?

headline: If You Can Make It Here...
abstract: Sure, a Super Bowl always produces a hero or two, but William C. Rhoden says a Super Bowl hero made in New York carries a little something special.
lead_paragraph: Sure, a Super Bowl always produces a hero or two, but William C. Rhoden says a Super Bowl hero made in New York carries a little something special.

headline: Video Sports of The Times: If You Can Make It Here …
abstract: Sure, a Super Bowl always produces a hero or two, but a Super Bowl hero made in New York carries a little something special.

headline: Get Game-Ready with Shopping Events Starting the Week of Jan. 30
abstract: Fashion and football converge on Super Bowl weekend.
lead_paragraph: Get Game-Ready

headline: Despite Decades of Enmity, Israel Quietly Aids Syrian Civilians
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The humanitarian disaster in Syria is eroding once-impervious psychological barriers between citizens of two bordering nations still technically at war.
lead_paragraph: NAHARIYA, Israel — Two brothers, ages 10 and 8, were playing marbles outside their home in a town in Syria when a rocket decapitated the older one and critically wounded his sibling. Having rushed the surviving child to a local hospital, the mother recalled, medics told her: “If you want to save your son, you should take him to Israel.”

headline: Knicks’ Shumpert Is ‘Day to Day’ After Shoulder Injury
abstract: Knicks Coach Mike Woodson said Iman Shumpert, who was injured in Tuesday’s win over Boston, will have his sprained right shoulder re-evaluated Thursday morning.
lead_paragraph: Knicks Coach Mike Woodson said the sprained right shoulder Iman Shumpert sustained in Tuesday’s victory over the Boston Celtics would be re-evaluated Thursday morning. Appearing Wednesday on ESPN Radio, Woodson said Shumpert was “day to day” but cast doubt over his availability for Thursday’s game against the Cleveland Cavaliers.

headline: Obama’s Free-Trade Conundrum
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'Labor and Jobs', 'North American Free Trade Agreement', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The president cannot both open markets and close the wage gap.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — IN his State of the Union address on Tuesday, President Obama focused on reversing the growth of economic inequality in the United States and restoring the American dream. At the same time, he also announced his support for fast track authority that would limit Congress’s role in determining the content of trade agreements.

headline: Syrian Opposition’s Calm at Talks Surprises as Officials Falter
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: A turnabout has the exile coalition and its Western backers declaring an early, if modest, victory.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The Syrian government officials were expected to present themselves as the grown-ups at the peace conference here, representatives of a capable, sovereign government facing opponents they call political amateurs at best, and at worst, terrorist rabble.

headline: New York Wants to Banish a Symbol of Love: Mute Swans
abstract: White, long-necked mute swans, the state’s largest birds, hurt water quality and threaten people and jets, environmental officials say.
lead_paragraph: In the war against invasive species, the targets are typically unappealing. Think feral pigs, snakehead fish, Asian long-horned beetles and emerald ash borers. But now, the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation has declared war on mute swans — the jumbo, snow-white waterfowl with the long, graceful necks — which were introduced from Europe in the late 1800s for their aesthetic appeal.

headline: John R. Huizenga, Physicist at Fore of Nuclear Era, Dies at 92
abstract: Dr. Huizenga was drafted into the Manhattan Project to help build the world’s first atom bomb and was part of the scientific team that discovered two elements in the periodic table.
lead_paragraph: John R. Huizenga, a physicist who helped build the world’s first atom bomb, solve dozens of atomic riddles and debunk claims that scientists in Utah had achieved nuclear fusion in a jar of water, died on Saturday in San Diego. He was 92.

headline: Obama Orders Creation of ‘MyRA’ Savings Accounts
keywords: ['Individual Retirement Accounts', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'Asset Allocation (Personal Finances)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The accounts, which are intended for people who do not now have employer-sponsored savings plans, will operate much like Roth I.R.A.’s, according to Treasury officials.
lead_paragraph: Making good on a State of the Union address promise, President Obama on Wednesday ordered the creation of new employer-sponsored savings accounts intended to help more people get started saving for retirement.

headline: Detroit Art Museum Offers Plan to Avoid Sale of Art
abstract: The plan would relieve the city of any future financial responsibility for the art institute while also shielding the institute from future municipal threats.
lead_paragraph: The Detroit Institute of Arts, whose world-class collection has been targeted as a potential source of cash to help dig Detroit out of federal bankruptcy, announced Wednesday that it would raise $100 million to help save itself, joining a group of private foundations that have already pledged $370 million toward the effort.

headline: A Checkered History
abstract: Americare Certified Special Services, the home health care agency seeking to expand its role, has faced lawsuits and federal and state inquiries.
lead_paragraph: Americare Certified Special Services, the home health care agency seeking to expand its role, has faced lawsuits and federal and state inquiries.

headline: Maryland Gunman Wrote in Diary About Killing People
abstract: The gunman at a Maryland shopping mall kept a journal where he expressed hatred for people, but it did not offer a clear motive for the shooting that killed two mall employees.
lead_paragraph: For more than a year, the 19-year-old gunman who opened fire at a shopping mall in Columbia, Md., last Saturday, killing two skateboard store employees, made sporadic references in his journal about killing people and showed awareness that he struggled with mental illness, police officials said Wednesday.

headline: New York State Recommends Expanding License of Health Agency With Checkered Past
keywords: ['Home Health Care', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Medicaid', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The Health Department has recommended that Americare be given an unrestricted home health care license in 14 counties, including all of New York City.
lead_paragraph: It was a medical scheme that shocked the public conscience when it came to light in 2001: Two dozen mentally ill residents of a Queens adult home were forced to have unnecessary prostate surgery that generated tens of thousands of dollars in government fees.

headline: A Pioneering Black Quarterback’s Lasting Legacy
abstract: Marlin Briscoe, the first African-American to start at quarterback in the A.F.L. or the modern N.F.L., can watch with pride as Russell Wilson takes the field with the Seahawks on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: LONG BEACH, Calif. — President Obama, hosting the undefeated 1972 Dolphins at the White House last summer, made his way around the green room before moving out for a public ceremony.

headline: Plan on Repaying Debt Is Presented to Detroit’s Creditors
abstract: Leaders in Detroit have said they hope by fall to reach plans to pay off portions of the city’s debts and to emerge from bankruptcy court.
lead_paragraph: Drawing the bankrupt city of Detroit a step closer to remaking itself, the city’s emergency manager on Wednesday provided creditors with a detailed proposal for how much of the city’s $18 billion debt Detroit intended to pay back.

headline: Threat by Staten Island Lawmaker Adds to a Reputation as Hot-Tempered
abstract: Politicians and journalists who have tangled with Representative Michael G. Grimm of Staten Island have maintained for years that he is short-tempered.
lead_paragraph: Representative Michael G. Grimm is a hothead.

headline: How to Get More Early Bloomers
abstract: Pre-K funding should include money to study what actually works.
lead_paragraph: WHEN New York City’s mayor, Bill de Blasio, went to Albany earlier this week to talk about his program for universal preschool, the discussion reportedly focused on funding, not on whether or how preschool would actually help children. President Obama seemed equally confident when he introduced his plan for universal preschool last year, flatly stating, “We know this works.” But the state of research is actually much murkier. And unless policy makers begin to design preschool programs in ways that can be evaluated later, the situation won’t get any clearer.

headline: The Incredible Shrinking Presidency
keywords: ['State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Concentrating on what can be done instead of what should be done is a rational reaction to irrational opposition, but a sad indictment of our politics.
lead_paragraph: It was hard to watch President Obama during Tuesday’s State of the Union address and not see a man who has had his coat trimmed and his ambitions adjusted.

headline: Wall Street’s New Housing Bonanza
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Banks have begun selling bonds backed by foreclosed homes turned into rentals in the United States, bringing calls for Congress to look into the deals.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street’s latest trillion-dollar idea involves slicing and dicing debt tied to single-family homes and selling the bonds to investors around the world.

headline: How Preschool Got Hot
abstract: The biggest buzz of the week isn’t about Beyoncé at the Grammys or Peyton Manning and the Super Bowl. It’s all about pre-K for everyone!
lead_paragraph: All of a sudden, early childhood education is really, really popular. Everybody’s favorite. If early childhood education were an actor, it would be Tom Hanks or Meryl Streep. If it were a video game, it would be Candy Crush or Angry Birds, minus the spyware.

headline: Tests Said to Find Formaldehyde in West Virginia Tap Water
abstract: Nearly three weeks after a chemical spill left 300,000 people without water in Charleston, W.Va., an environmental expert said he found traces of formaldehyde.
lead_paragraph: Tests on the water supply in Charleston, W. Va., a week after a chemical spill tainted the city’s water system turned up traces of formaldehyde, suggesting that “there’s a lot more we don’t know” about the consequences of the spill, an environmental expert told a state legislative committee on Wednesday.

headline: How Pressure Mounted for Development in Hoboken
abstract: Emails and interviews make clear that the development-wary mayor of Hoboken, N.J., Dawn Zimmer, was under pressure from the Christie administration and lawyers working for a developer.
lead_paragraph: HOBOKEN, N.J. — Last May 8, a severe rainstorm left the streets of this city flooded once again, causing the mayor, Dawn Zimmer, to recall the inundation from Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Pre-K, the Great Debate
keywords: ['Education (Pre-School)', 'Head Start Program', 'State of the Union Message (US)']
abstract: Government-financed preschool shouldn’t be controversial. It’s an investment that pays a great return.
lead_paragraph: Against all odds, prekindergarten is gaining ground.

headline: U.S. Says Russia Tested Missile, Despite Treaty
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT']
abstract: American officials believe Russia tested a new ground-launched cruise missile, raising concerns about Moscow’s compliance with an arms deal that has been viewed as a bedrock accord in ending the Cold War.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States informed its NATO allies this month that Russia had tested a new ground-launched cruise missile, raising concerns about Moscow’s compliance with a landmark arms control accord.

headline: Colleague of SAC Leader Was Not Alerted to Trades
abstract: An associate of Steven A. Cohen said at the trial of Mathew Martoma, a former SAC Capital Advisors trader, that he was told of drug stock sales after the fact.
lead_paragraph: The billionaire investor Steven A. Cohen kept one of his closest associates at SAC Capital Advisors in the dark about the hedge fund’s rapid selling of a substantial stock position in two drug companies, just days before the companies reported disappointing results of a clinical trial for an Alzheimer’s drug.

headline: The Farm Bill Could Have Been Worse
abstract: Though the legislation made some useful reforms, it would still reduce food-stamp benefits for too many families in need.
lead_paragraph: Few bills of real substance emerge from today’s polarized Congress, and those that do tend to be misshapen lumps. They have enough useful provisions to win approval from Democrats, but are weighed down by the dangerous and occasionally bizarre demands of the many branches of the Republican Party.

headline: Uncertainty Over Whether N.F.L. Settlement’s Money Will Last
abstract: Because the N.F.L.’s recent settlement promises payments to an unknown number of players, the $765 million called for in the deal could run out faster than expected.
lead_paragraph: As intriguing football matchups go, Sunday’s Super Bowl has nothing on one looming down the turnpike in federal court in Philadelphia — with Judge Anita B. Brody the ultimate referee.

headline: Secrecy Behind Executions
abstract: A terrible ruling involving a case in Missouri allows states to hide the untested drugs they use to put inmates to death.
lead_paragraph: It is bad enough that the death penalty is barbaric, racist and arbitrary in its application, but it is also becoming less transparent as the dwindling number of death-penalty states work to hide the means by which they kill people.

headline: New Government for Czech Republic
abstract: President Milos Zeman of the Czech Republic appointed a new center-left government on Wednesday, ending a protracted period of political paralysis that has destabilized the country.
lead_paragraph: President Milos Zeman of the Czech Republic appointed a new center-left government on Wednesday, ending a protracted period of political paralysis that has destabilized the country. The freshly installed prime minister, Bohuslav Sobotka, 42, has pledged to shepherd the country toward stability following a corruption scandal last summer that forced Prime Minister Petr Necas to resign. A subsequent interim government failed to win parliament’s confidence. Mr. Sobotka, a Social Democrat, has pledged to combat some austerity measures of previous conservative governments.

headline: Academy Rescinds Song Nomination for ‘Alone Yet Not Alone’
abstract: The song’s composer, who serves on the executive committee of the Academy’s music branch, emailed branch members, which was considered a violation of rules on promotions.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES —The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said its governors had voted to rescind an Oscar nomination for the song “Alone Yet Not Alone,” from the movie of the same title, because one of its creators, Bruce Broughton, had improperly advised fellow members of the Academy’s music branch that he was in the running for a nomination.

headline: Presidential Power vs. Congressional Inertia
abstract: In his State of the Union address, Obama said he would work around Congress. What are the strengths and risks of such action?

headline: After Keeping Company With Mobsters, Politician Now Speaks Their Language
abstract: After threatening an NY1 reporter, Representative Michael G. Grimm, who once infiltrated the Gambino crime family as an undercover F.B.I. agent, appears to be fluent in mob-style chitchat.
lead_paragraph: Years ago, a Newsday editor had a great idea for a young reporter. Go, he told me, to the Bergin Hunt and Fish Club and see what the boys are doing on the first day of deer-hunting season.

headline: Iraq: More Violence in Baghdad
abstract: Car bombings and shootings in Baghdad on Wednesday killed at least 19 people, according to security and medical officials, adding to a death toll that has been rising quickly.
lead_paragraph: Car bombings and shootings in Baghdad on Wednesday killed at least 19 people, according to security and medical officials, adding to a death toll that has been rising quickly. The four car bombs targeted Shiite neighborhoods. Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, meanwhile, called on Sunni tribes in Falluja to support the Shiite-led government’s forces so they can storm it and clear out antigovernment Sunni militants.

headline: The Siren Song of the Hebrides
abstract: Lured by the beaches and the otherworldly light on a Scottish island, a family builds an unconventional beach house there.
lead_paragraph: Lured by the beaches and the otherworldly light on a Scottish island, a family builds an unconventional beach house there.

headline: Warrantless Surveillance Challenged by Defendant
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)']
abstract: The challenge by a Colorado resident who was charged with terrorism-related offenses could lead to a Supreme Court test of a National Security Agency program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Colorado resident charged with terrorism-related offenses challenged the constitutionality on Wednesday of a 2008 law allowing the National Security Agency to conduct a sweeping program of surveillance without warrants on American soil. The challenge — the first of its kind — could lead to a Supreme Court test of the program.

headline: Jump in Prostitution Arrests in Super Bowl Week
abstract: Nearly 20 women were arraigned at Manhattan Community Court on Wednesday on prostitution charges, far more than the court ordinarily handles in one day.
lead_paragraph: Four days before the Super Bowl, just a few blocks from the N.F.L. extravaganza known as Super Bowl Boulevard on Broadway in Midtown Manhattan, a different scene was playing out Wednesday at Midtown Community Court on West 54th Street.

headline: Senator Asks Veterans Agency to Review How Financial Advisers Are Accredited
abstract: A lax accreditation process is effectively giving “unscrupulous or unqualified individuals” an opportunity to waste taxpayer money and harm veterans, Senator Claire McCaskill said.
lead_paragraph: Senator Claire McCaskill of Missouri is asking the Department of Veteran Affairs to examine its process for accrediting thousands of financial advisers in the face of concerns over abuses of veterans’ benefits.

headline: Winning Powerball and Lottery Numbers for Jan. 29, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Remembering My Mother’s Obsession
abstract: I visited him in prison when I was 9. Then I went back as an adult.
lead_paragraph: Of all the troubling events from my childhood, one of the most enduring remains the afternoon I visited a prisoner serving a life sentence for murder. It was 1978 and I was 9 years old, escorted to Western Penitentiary in Pittsburgh by my mother, who, compelled by a lifelong objective of raising her son’s awareness of injustice in the world, no doubt considered this to be a well-suited occasion.

headline: Russell Wilson, a Standout Who’s Easy to Miss
abstract: The Seahawks’ Richard Sherman has received the most attention during Super Bowl week, but Wilson, Seattle’s 5-foot-11 quarterback, has a story that’s just as compelling.
lead_paragraph: It was no surprise that Super Bowl week launched with a frantic rush to surround Richard Sherman but with plenty of good space available in the presence of Russell Wilson. That injustice of unbalanced attention revealed far more about the malleability of the news media — especially during the long, news-starved run-up to the game — than it did about either player.

headline: Obama to Meet Jordanian King
abstract: President Obama host King Abdullah II of Jordan next month at Sunnylands, a sprawling desert estate in Rancho Mirage, Calif.
lead_paragraph: President Obama host King Abdullah II of Jordan next month at Sunnylands, a sprawling desert estate in Rancho Mirage, Calif. The White House said Mr. Obama and the king would discuss the Middle East peace process and the Syrian civil war, which has sent a wave of refugees into Jordan.

lead_paragraph: “It was like something you would see if they told you the plague broke out and you had to run for your life.”

headline: Pakistani Premier Forms Group to Start Talks With Taliban
abstract: The move, coming soon after terrorist attacks and government retaliation, was a surprise to many, and there was doubt about the group’s prospects for success.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif named a four-member commission on Wednesday to initiate peace talks with the Pakistani Taliban, saying he would pursue a dialogue with the militants despite recent terrorist attacks that have left the country reeling.

headline: Maryland: Shooting Suspect Wrote of Death
abstract: Darion Aguilar, the suspect in a deadly shooting at a mall, wrote about killing people in his journal and said that he was ready to die.
lead_paragraph: The suspect in a deadly shooting at a mall wrote about killing people in his journal and said that he was ready to die, the police said Wednesday. The man, Darion Aguilar, 19, “expressed a general hatred of others” in entries over the past year, the Howard County police department said. Mr. Aguilar wrote that his plan was set, but did not say what that meant, and apologized to his family for what he was about to do, the police said. The police said Mr. Aguilar wrote that he might need help for a mental health problem, but never told his family. The police believe Mr. Aguilar killed two employees of the skate shop Zumiez on Saturday at the Mall in Columbia before killing himself.

headline: Facing Complaints, Columbia’s President Calls for Transparency in Assault Inquiries
abstract: Lee C. Bollinger announced new guidelines following a review of the way Columbia University handled the sexual assault complaints of three women.
lead_paragraph: Columbia University’s president, responding to complaints about how the institution investigates and punishes sexual assaults on campus, announced new policies on Wednesday intended to make its procedures more transparent.

headline: Chancellor, a Lover of Collisions, Has the Seahawks Ready for a Final Clash
abstract: Even as concerns grow about the impact of concussions on players’ long-term health, Kam Chancellor, a Seahawks safety, relishes big hits, the more violent the better.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY — Kam Chancellor, a safety for the Seattle Seahawks who is known as one of the N.F.L.’s most punishing hitters, proclaims his bad intentions on his shoulders, both tattooed with the word “Bam.”

headline: Stringer to Unveil Changes for New York City’s Pension System
abstract: New proposals by Comptroller Scott M. Stringer means dozens of pension managers would have to regularly report their personal trades and placement agents for investment managers would be banned.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of city pension managers would have to regularly report their personal investment transactions, and placement agents for investment managers would be banned from doing any business with New York City’s $150 billion retirement system, under a reform plan to be announced on Thursday.

headline: Foundations Band Together to Get Rid of Fossil-Fuel Investments
abstract: Taking cues from old fights to end apartheid and oppose tobacco, several foundations are addressing the warming of the planet.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:08 p.m. | Seventeen foundations controlling nearly $1.8 billion in investments have united to commit to pulling their money out of companies that do business in fossil fuels, the group announced on Thursday.

headline: Global Design Du Jour
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Maison Et Objet (Trade Show)']
abstract: The Maison et Objet fair in Paris was a showcase of grace under economic pressure.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On Sunday, the British designer Tom Dixon was a guest of honor at a cocktail party at Eclectic, a new restaurant in the 15th Arrondissement here. Mr. Dixon had designed the space, with his usual flair for muscular materials (in this case, concrete warmed by splashes of gleaming metal). He was being feted by Maison et Objet, a trade fair held every January and September, which had anointed him, along with Philippe Nigro of Paris and Dimore Studio of Milan, a “designer of the year.”

headline: Sure, Son, I’ll Be in Your Skin Flick
abstract: In its breezy blandness, Thomas Bradshaw’s new play, “Intimacy,” is neither your everyday sex comedy nor a sendup of one.
lead_paragraph: The land of id is flooded with sunshine in Thomas Bradshaw’s “Intimacy,” the sensationally square new play that is putting the X (make that triple X) back into sex on 42nd Street. Pornography is the subject of this sui generis comedy from the New Group, which opened on Wednesday night on Theater Row. You might even say that porn is its form.

headline: Riddled With Spelling Problems
abstract: Dan Schoenholz digs up an old one.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — Before we discuss today’s puzzle, I’d like to take a moment to talk about the format changes in our commenting system, as well as the issues that have occurred as a result. The Times is well aware of the general reaction that readers across the website, not just on Wordplay, have had to the changes, as well as the specific bugs you have reported.

headline: California: Charges Against Bus Company Dropped
abstract: State labor officials have dropped charges that a Chinese high-tech bus company was paying a handful of workers below minimum wage.
lead_paragraph: State labor officials have dropped charges that a Chinese high-tech bus company was paying a handful of workers below minimum wage. Last fall, investigators said that the company, Build Your Dreams, was paying workers here temporarily from China in Chinese currency equivalent to less than $8 an hour, the state’s minimum wage. But the company, known as BYD, has provided bank documents that showed the workers were paid the equivalent of $12 to $17 an hour in California. On Tuesday, lawyers for the state labor agency removed citations that ordered nearly $12,000 in back wages. The company agreed to pay $1,900 in penalties for paying the workers in Chinese currency rather than dollars. The company has won several contracts to create electric buses across the country, including in Los Angeles. It operates its American headquarters in downtown Los Angeles and a manufacturing plant in northeast Los Angeles County.

headline: Four Airlines Are Told to Raise Some Wages by $1 an Hour
keywords: ['Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Minimum Wage', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'AIRPORTS']

lead_paragraph: After a lengthy campaign by airport contract workers to receive better wages, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey sent a letter to several airlines late Tuesday ordering them to increase pay for some employees.

headline: Jason Kidd Grows in Role, Along With Beard
abstract: It appears Kidd’s self-assurance has improved from the start of the season, as has the Nets’ once hideous record, which is now a more respectable 20-23.
lead_paragraph: While Nets players have made strides this month forming a team identity, they have seen Jason Kidd take steps to fine-tune his identity as their coach.

lead_paragraph: American markets bounced back on Thursday, buoyed by relatively strong economic growth in the United States.

headline: A Huge N.B.A. Rivalry: Sneaker Collections
abstract: More and more N.B.A. players are slipping into something fashionable as they compete with one another in the sneaker department.
lead_paragraph: P. J. Tucker, a forward with the Phoenix Suns, really likes sneakers. He likes them so much, in fact, that he needs four locations to store his collection.

headline: Judge Limits Expert Testimony on Terrorism in Manhattan Bomb Case
abstract: The judge said he wanted to keep the focus on the evidence against Jose Pimentel, accused of plotting to set off pipe bombs, rather than on testimony about organizations and websites linked to Al Qaeda.
lead_paragraph: Saying he wanted to avoid turning the trial into a “referendum on terrorism,” a state judge handling the case of a Manhattan man accused of planning pipe bombings said on Wednesday he sees no need for an expert on Islamic terrorism to testify at the defendant’s coming trial.

headline: Riz Ortolani, Film Composer Who Wrote a Love Anthem, Dies at 87
abstract: Mr. Ortolani was among Italy’s busiest film composers for almost half a century and his music set the tone for everything from erotic films to spaghetti westerns.
lead_paragraph: Riz Ortolani, an Italian composer of dozens of film scores, whose Grammy-winning instrumental melody featured in the 1962 film “Mondo Cane” evolved into “More,” the celebrated anthem of love covered by sensuous crooners around the globe, died on Jan. 23 at his villa outside Rome. He was 87.

headline: Set to Play, Harvin Is Drawing Attention
abstract: Declared healthy for the Super Bowl after sustaining a concussion in the divisional round, Percy Harvin, a versatile Seahawks receiver, will now get a chance to deliver on the hype.
lead_paragraph: For a player who tied for 392nd in the N.F.L. in receptions this season, Percy Harvin is getting an awful lot of attention in the lead-up to Super Bowl XLVIII.

headline: Rangers Beat Another Rival, Completing a Double Play in the Bronx
abstract: Daniel Carcillo’s third goal of the season broke a third-period tie and lifted the Rangers to their second straight win at a frigid Yankee Stadium.
lead_paragraph: An intense game at Yankee Stadium between two longtime rivals, the Rangers and the Islanders, ended on Wednesday night with the fans on their feet, gasping as the Islanders’ Kyle Okposo, bidding for the tying goal, shot the puck inches wide of the net.

headline: For Organist, the Best of Both Worlds
abstract: For the Islanders’ organist, Paul Cartier, the surreal novelty of an outdoor hockey game at Yankee Stadium put him in a completely familiar place.
lead_paragraph: For the Islanders’ organist, Paul Cartier, the surreal novelty of an outdoor hockey game at Yankee Stadium put him in a completely familiar place.

headline: Before Big Game, Stepping Into Media’s Big Top on Radio Row
abstract: This year, there are 104 radio stations broadcasting live from Radio Row, the mecca for sports talk radio stations from around the world during Super Bowl week.
lead_paragraph: Within minutes of one another, Dan Marino, Darryl Strawberry and Mark Messier walked through the crowd of tables in the Metropolitan Ballroom on the second floor of the Sheraton Times Square Hotel on Wednesday.

headline: Failed EuroVegas Bid Was Still a Boon for Spanish Casinos
abstract: A ban on casino gambling in Madrid was lifted in effect when the city started to compete against Barcelona to host the mega-resort project.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Even though Sheldon G. Adelson, the American billionaire casino magnate, abandoned his plans for a $30 billion casino and leisure resort on the outskirts of Madrid last month, he has nevertheless helped get the roulette wheels spinning here for the first time in almost a century.

headline: Suede Safari Style
abstract: Monochromatic pieces, in shades from light camel to dark mahogany, add velvety softness to the resort collections.
lead_paragraph: In 1968, Yves Saint Laurent introduced its first belted safari jacket, which propelled the hunting-expedition look into mainstream fashion. This season, Saint Laurent’s designer Hedi Slimane updated the original, introducing a more polished, shorter version in solid suede. And the safari legacy lives on in other designers’ resort collections, where monochromatic, all-suede staples abound in shades ranging from light camel to dark mahogany. The thick buckle strap becomes a simple, yet sleek design element on an Alexander McQueen skirt, Calvin Klein halter and Gucci boot — a nod to the practical, waist-cinching detail of the trench. And the velvety skin adds sturdy softness to a pair of Jimmy Choo sandals and a Proenza Schouler cross-body bag.

headline: U.S. Aid to Afghans Flows On Despite Warnings of Misuse
abstract: Auditors’ admonishments about the risks of theft and waste have raised new questions about the wisdom of giving huge amounts of aid directly to a government known for corruption.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — With billions of dollars in American aid increasingly flowing straight into Afghan government coffers, the United States hired two global auditing firms three years ago to determine whether Afghanistan could be trusted to safeguard the money.

headline: Be-Bopera: ‘Charlie Parker’s Yardbird’ Coming From Opera Philadelphia
abstract: An opera about the jazz musician Charlie Parker has been commissioned by Opera Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: Opera Philadelphia has commissioned Daniel Schnyder, a composer and saxophonist who works in jazz and classical music, to compose a chamber opera about the jazz saxophonist Charlie Parker, the company is expected to announce Thursday. The work will have a libretto by Bridgette A. Wimberly, and is being produced in a partnership with Gotham Chamber Opera, in New York. It is expected to have its world premiere in Philadelphia in June 2015 in a production directed by Ron Daniels, with later performances by Gotham Chamber Opera.

keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)']
abstract: The Treasury’s Office of Financial Research seems to have little gusto for taking on the biggest banks and the dangers they pose, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Simon Johnson, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund, is the Ronald A. Kurtz professor of entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Wireless Mergers Will Draw Scrutiny, Antitrust Chief Says
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Cable Television', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: William J. Baer, assistant attorney general for the Justice Department’s antitrust division, also said any proposed merger among cable television companies would face similar scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The nation’s leading antitrust enforcer said this week that it would be difficult for the Justice Department to approve a merger among any of the top four wireless phone companies, casting doubt on recent speculation that T-Mobile and Sprint might consummate a deal in coming months.

headline: New York City Council Gets a New Speaker
abstract: Melissa Mark-Viverito was sworn in as speaker on Wednesday.

headline: 3 Injured in Staten Island Gas Explosion
abstract: Firefighters had been checking reports of a gas leak at a home in Dongan Hills for about two hours when an explosion occurred there shortly before 7 p.m. Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: A gas explosion and fire Wednesday night at a house on Staten Island injured three people — one critically — and forced the evacuation of more than a dozen homes, according to the Fire Department.

headline: A Pioneer of Street Photography Leaves Behind Strong Images of Indian Women
keywords: ['Art', 'Indian Rupee (Currency)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Photography', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Pranlal Patel, who recently died at the age of 104 in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, was one of the first photographers in India to capture women at work in the public space.
lead_paragraph: AHMEDABAD, Gujarat — A little over five weeks before his first exhibition in the United States, one of India’s first street photographers sat crossed-legged on a bed in his home in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, and pulled out one of his favorite photographs. It was an image taken in 1937 of women washing clothes on the banks of the Sabarmati river that cuts through Ahmedabad.

headline: What’s on Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (CNN) THE SIXTIES: THE BRITISH INVASION Tom Hanks is among the executive producers for this special, which looks at the quest by British bands to conquer the American music scene, starting with the breakthrough performance of the Beatles, above, on “The Ed Sullivan Show” on Feb. 9, 1964. It also examines the revolution in fashion, advertising, politics and sexual mores, and looks at groups that followed, like the Animals, the Kinks, the Hollies, the Dave Clark Five, the Who and the Rolling Stones. Comments by Smokey Robinson; Graham Nash; Ahmir Thompson, a.k.a. Questlove; and Micky Dolenz make the case that the British invasion was actually a reciprocal flow of influences back and forth with American artists like Bob Dylan, the Beach Boys and Motown musicians.

abstract: The company will step up its sales of oil and gas fields and sharply cut capital investment.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Royal Dutch Shell said on Thursday that it would not pursue its contentious and accident-plagued effort to drill in Alaska this year as it confirmed a steep fall in profit in the fourth quarter.

headline: Santander’s Profit Doubles but Misses Expectations
abstract: Banco Santander of Spain benefited from lower charges for bad loans as its profit rose to 1.06 billion euros in the fourth quarter, but earnings declined in Spain and Latin America.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – The Spanish lender Banco Santander reported on Thursday that its profit more than doubled to 1.06 billion euros in the fourth quarter as it continued to benefit from declining charges for bad loans. But the earnings still came in below analysts’ expectations.

abstract: Why did so many problems occur if the region knew the storm was coming?
lead_paragraph: In “Ice Storm Ambushes South, Stranding Thousands,” Kim Severson and Alan Blinder report on the unusual weather event that paralyzed parts of the Deep South.

abstract: A private collector of historical images and postcards from Africa’s colonial era shows how imperialists constructed stereotypes to shape and distort Western views.
lead_paragraph: We highly recommend viewing this slideshow in “full-screen” mode.

headline: Do You Ever Feel Overlooked and Underappreciated?
abstract: Do you ever feel as if you play second fiddle to a friend, sibling or someone else?
lead_paragraph: New Jersey has long suffered from an inferiority complex and found itself the butt of one too many jokes. Even now, as the host to Super Bowl XLVIII this weekend, the state still worries it is playing second fiddle to New York City. Have you ever felt like New Jersey — that you didn’t get the respect you deserved?

headline: Continuing Unrest Could Undermine Thailand’s Economy
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Companies are reconsidering investments in light of the protests and political gridlock the economy has normally shrugged off in past years.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Thailand’s economy tends to bounce back vigorously from the coups, street protests and natural disasters that trouble it every few years. This time, however, could be different: As the nation’s once buoyant growth is slowing, investors and businesses are growing increasingly frustrated with the current political gridlock.

lead_paragraph: LONDON – Dassault Systèmes of France said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire the San Diego-based scientific software company Accelrys in an all-cash deal for about $750 million.
