headline: Talks Stall as President of Ukraine Calls in Sick
abstract: Viktor F. Yanukovych, saddled by respiratory issues, went on leave even as talks remained unsettled and the repeal of new curbs on speech and assembly was yet to be signed into law.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Critical negotiations between the embattled Ukrainian government and opposition leaders were thrown into disarray on Thursday when President Viktor F. Yanukovych went on sick leave, complaining of a respiratory infection.

headline: Notes on a Tour of the Indian Women’s Movement
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Books and Literature', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Education (K-12)', 'Human Trafficking', 'Prostitution', 'Sex Crimes', 'Women and Girls', "Women's Rights", 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: As the women’s rights activists Gloria Steinem and Ruchira Gupta travel around the country meeting young feminists, writers and thought leaders, they are keeping a diary of their journey for India Ink. Their first stop: Delhi.
lead_paragraph: MS. GUPTA : Walking through the red-light areas of Sonagachi or lobbying in Albany for the New York State laws against human trafficking, Gloria and my life have interwoven into shared writing sessions,  rallies, meetings, dinners, books, conversations, late night phone calls across continents, brainstorming and sometimes movies. With her, I have experienced how movements move and how immense the feminist movement is.

headline: Super Bowl Prediction: Slight Edge to Seahawks
abstract: In a statistical analysis, the hidden difference between the two Super Bowl opponents is their résumés. Seattle has achieved its numbers along a tougher road than Denver.
lead_paragraph: Football fans should be in for a treat Sunday, as Denver and Seattle ended the season ranked No. 1 and 2 in the Advanced NFL Stats efficiency model by virtue of each team’s dominance on one side of the ball. For the Broncos, that side is obviously offense, led by quarterback Peyton Manning. And for the Seahawks, it is defense, led by their smothering secondary.

headline: Suggesting an Alternative to Performance Reviews
abstract: I can hear what you’re thinking: “There’s no way I have time to do this.”
lead_paragraph: My last post documented my frustration with the performance-review process. But I don’t like to complain about something that doesn’t work without thinking of a replacement, so over the last several years, I’ve developed a new model I call performance coaching.

headline: Facebook Unveils New Tool to Read Posts and News
abstract: The social network is introducing Paper, a visually focused iPhone application that makes it easier for a user to scan a news feed and discover new content on the service.
lead_paragraph: Users of Apple’s iPhone are about to get a new way to browse their Facebook feeds and find other interesting articles that have been posted on the service: a visually focused application called Paper.

headline: Daily Report: Cutting Losses, Google to Sell Motorola Unit
keywords: ['Cellular Telephones', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Software']
abstract: The deal is not a total financial loss for Google, which retains patents worth billions of dollars, but it is a sign of the fits and starts the company is experiencing as it navigates business in the mobile age.
lead_paragraph: Google announced on Wednesday that it would sell Motorola Mobility to Lenovo for $2.91 billion, less than two years after paying $12.5 billion to acquire it, Claire Cain Miller and David Gelles report.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘O Me! O Life!’
abstract: “O Me! O Life!” by Walt Whitman and “Finding Purpose After Living With Delusion,” an article by Benedict Carey, appear in this Poetry Pairing.
lead_paragraph: Related Article

headline: Why the U.S. Embassy Releases Pollution Data in Beijing But Not in Delhi
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Indian-Americans', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: A State Department representative cited the availability of such information in English in India’s capital, but doubts have been cast on the reliability of those reports.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The United States government measures air quality levels in both its Beijing and Delhi embassies, but it only publicizes the results from its Beijing monitor. Why?

headline: In Motorola Purchase, Lenovo Gains Big Footprint in Smartphones
abstract: The Chinese PC giant’s purchase of Motorola Mobility from Google has vaulted it into the field’s top three, though it has a long way to go to catch Apple or Samsung.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Apple and Samsung Electronics dominate the smartphone business, controlling about half of the sales and most of the profits. An ever-changing roster of also-rans has struggled to close the gap.

headline: Google Sells Motorola Unit to Lenovo
abstract: The sale of Google’s smartphone unit less than two years after it was acquired is a sign of fits and starts at Google. | Wall Street’s latest trillion-dollar idea on single-family homes. | Sotheby’s to pay dividend and buy back shares. | SAC leader’s colleague testifies he did not know about trades.
lead_paragraph: Lenovo seems to be on a buying binge, and not even Google can escape. In its second deal in a week, the Chinese company, once best known for making personal computers, announced that it was buying Google’s Motorola Mobility smartphone unit for $2.91 billion. Last week, Lenovo acquired IBM’s low-end server business for $2.3 billion.

headline: Wizard Who Made Art Jump Off the Page
abstract: At the Grolier Club, the show “Pop-Ups From Prague” pays tribute to Vojtech Kubasta, a Czech architect, graphic artist and master of the pop-up book.
lead_paragraph: TWENTY years ago, while browsing in an antiques store near Phoenix, Ellen G. K. Rubin, a book collector, spied something intriguing at the top of a rickety shelf. It was a pop-up book, “Moko and Koko in the Jungle,” that had been opened up to reveal a stand of banana trees, more than a foot tall, teeming with animal life.

headline: Trapped by A.L.S., He Urged His Daughter to Fly Free
keywords: ['AMYOTROPHIC LATERAL SCLEROSIS', 'Families and Family Life', 'Children and Childhood', 'Movies']
abstract: With my dad’s disease in focus, to cope with things I could not control, I set out to write a screenplay, determined to make the most of the time.
lead_paragraph: When I was 18 I watched my father perform what would be his final surgery.

headline: Loot No Longer
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Art', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: A reporter in France traces orphaned art, looted by the Nazis, to connect it to its rightful owners. A maze of information later, she has had some success.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — I worked nights from a leather chair in my living room, armed with an iPad, a telephone and a notebook. My mission was to see if I could reconnect Jewish families and others with fine art pillaged from their relatives during World War II.

headline: Blackstone Earnings More Than Doubled in Fourth Quarter
abstract: The Blackstone Group’s results handily beat Wall Street forecasts as it reaped big gains on its investments in private equity and real estate.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:00 p.m. | The soaring stock market was a boon last year to private equity firms looking to sell their holdings to investors. For the Blackstone Group in particular, a series of well-timed sales helped the firm double its profit in the fourth quarter.

headline: Reader Idea | Using Times Articles for ‘Copy-Change’ Text Collaborations
abstract: In this idea, students collaborate to write a piece about “To Kill a Mockingbird” by “copy-changing” the words, sentences and paragraphs of a Times article into a version that is entirely new.
lead_paragraph: All this week, we are featuring Great Ideas From Readers, lesson plans from teachers who teach with The Times. If you have used The Times in your classroom and would like to see your idea on our blog, write in and tell us what you’ve done.

headline: Former Chief of Akamai Joins General Catalyst as Partner
abstract: The venture capital firm General Catalyst Partners named Paul Sagan, a former chief executive of Akamai Technologies, as a partner who will act as a hands-on adviser to young companies in which the firm is invested.
lead_paragraph: Paul Sagan, a former chief executive of Akamai Technologies, is starting a new chapter as a venture capitalist.

headline: ‘Gravity’ and the Directors’ Contest
abstract: Alfonso and Jonas Cuarón recall the disastrous test screening for “Gravity” that led to audience suggestions for improvements. Among the ideas: add an alien or create a love story between the lead astronaut and mission control
lead_paragraph: Major industry awards like those handed out by the Screen Actors Guild and the Producers Guild usually offer clues to the eventual best picture Oscar winner. But with “American Hustle,” “12 Years a Slave” and “Gravity” each collecting a big precursor prize, it’s turned into a three-way race. That was confirmed when the Directors Guild honored “Gravity” and its filmmaker, Alfonso Cuarón, a prize he couldn’t have expected after one disastrous test screening.

headline: A Passenger, a Cabdriver and a Missing $10 Bill
keywords: ['Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers']
abstract: Metropolitan Diary: An argument over a missing $10 turned into a scam accusation, with a surprising ending and a show of honesty.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: U.S. Envoy to Visit Sri Lanka as Pressure Builds for War Crimes Inquiry
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Tamils (Ethnic Group)']
abstract: Relations with Sri Lanka have become increasingly frosty, largely because of the government’s reluctance to investigate reports of abuses from a civil war that ended five years ago.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A top State Department official is expected to arrive in Sri Lanka on Friday, just three days after the United States announced that it would again seek a resolution at the United Nations Human Rights Council pressing for an investigation into allegations of war crimes in Sri Lanka.

headline: A Case for Cheaper Broadband in Schools
abstract: Are America’s schools getting a bad deal from government broadband regulation? A group of chief executives and venture capitalists is telling the F.C.C. that schools don’t have enough broadband to meet future educational needs, and they are overpaying for what they get. But the group is avoiding criticizing the companies providing those services.
lead_paragraph: A nonprofit organization with its roots in the high-tech industry has gathered some 40 executives to demand that the Federal Communications Commission change how it is wiring America’s schools.

headline: Economy Is Expanding, but Obama’s Legacy May Be Slipping Away
abstract: As the economy shrugged off the effects of the government shutdown and debt standoff, economists said President Obama faced an uphill battle to burnish his economic legacy before leaving office.
lead_paragraph: Five years into the Obama presidency, the American economy is finally showing some momentum.

headline: Men’s Wearhouse Willing to Raise Offer for Jos. A. Bank
abstract: Men’s Wearhouse, in a letter to the board of Jos. A. Bank released on Thursday, reiterated its offer to buy Jos. A. Bank at $57.50 a share, but added that “we are prepared to increase our offer price” under certain conditions.
lead_paragraph: Men’s Wearhouse may be willing to increase its bid for Jos. A. Bank in the continuing takeover battle between the two men’s suit retailers.

headline: Talking Talent | Sarah Jessica Parker, Star of the Off-Broadway Play ‘The Commons of Pensacola’
abstract: The actress opens up about performing opposite Blythe Danner, her new namesake shoe line and life in New York City.
lead_paragraph: The Emmy Award-winning actress Sarah Jessica Parker is just a month away from seeing her new shoe line, SJP, hit Nordstrom stores on Feb. 28. She designed the 25 made-in-Italy styles alongside George Malkemus, the C.E.O. of Manolo Blahnik — whose heels carried Carrie around Manhattan for the six seasons of “Sex and the City” — but the SJP collection will fall at a more affordable price point, ranging from $195 to $500. Before she kicks off a multicity tour for SJP, Parker will take her final bow as Becca in the Manhattan Theatre Club production of “The Commons of Pensacola,” on Feb. 9. Last week, she chatted about the Lynne Meadow-directed play — in which she stars alongside Blythe Danner, who plays her mother — the much-anticipated heels and what she does when she sees the “Sex and the City” tour bus go by.

headline: A Big Advocate of French in New York’s Schools: France
abstract: A campaign to nurture French language studies in New York City seems to resonate with a certain existential urgency for France, whose vast empire once stretched around the globe.
lead_paragraph: In the fugue of tongues on New York’s streets, French has never been a dominant voice. And as surging numbers of Asian and Latino immigrants continue to tip the balance of foreign languages toward Chinese and Spanish, the idea of learning French, to some, may seem kind of quaint, even anachronistic.

headline: Militants Attack Transportation Ministry in Baghdad
abstract: Seven people and all seven attackers were killed in the attack on Thursday, according to security officials. Separately, 10 civilians were killed in car bombings at two markets in the Iraqi capital.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Militants attacked the Transportation Ministry compound in Baghdad on Thursday morning, killing seven people, according to security officials.

headline: Amanda Knox Is Re-Convicted of Murder in Italy
abstract: Ms. Knox and her former boyfriend Raffaele Sollecito were found guilty of killing her roommate in 2007, a case that had already gone through three levels of judgment and produced mixed verdicts.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, Italy — Amanda Knox and her former boyfriend were convicted on Thursday for a second time in the 2007 murder of Meredith Kercher, who shared an apartment with Ms. Knox in the university town of Perugia, where both women were exchange students. The presiding judge in the Florence court sentenced Ms. Knox to 28½ years in prison and the boyfriend, Raffaele Sollecito, to 25 years.

headline: Andhra Pradesh Assembly Rejects New Delhi’s Proposal to Create New State
abstract: However, the vote on a resolution that criticized the formation of Telangana is not binding on Parliament.
lead_paragraph: HYDERABAD, Andhra Pradesh — After two months of contentious debate, often interrupted by protests, the Andhra Pradesh Legislative Assembly on Thursday rejected New Delhi’s proposal to create a new state of Telangana out of Andhra Pradesh.

headline: Obama and G.O.P. Facing Opposition to Trade Pacts
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: President Obama, supported by many Republicans and business groups, has met opposition from labor and many Democrats on his push for fast-track approval of trade deals with Pacific Rim nations and Europe.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For companies like General Electric and Honeywell, it would help open untapped global markets, lift exports and create middle-class American jobs. For labor groups like the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the Teamsters, it is a threat to American workers, bound to lead to lost jobs and lower wages, as well as rising corporate profits.

headline: Low Vitamin D Tied to a Pregnancy Risk
abstract: Low vitamin D levels were associated with an increased risk for severe preeclampsia, a serious and sometimes fatal disorder of pregnancy.
lead_paragraph: Using preserved blood samples of pregnant women, researchers have found that low vitamin D levels are associated with an increased risk for severe preeclampsia, a serious and sometimes fatal disorder of pregnancy.

headline: Officials Remain in the Hot Seat as the South Thaws
abstract: Two days after a winter storm crippled stretches of the Deep South, life eased back toward normal, students slept in their homes again and drivers sought abandoned cars.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Parts of the Deep South sputtered slowly toward normalcy on Thursday, two days after a winter storm crippled vast stretches of the region and created unprecedented gridlock in its most populated areas.

headline: Istanbearish
abstract: Oh noes, another crisis!
lead_paragraph: OK, did we need this? Turkey? Who was paying attention to Turkey?

headline: This Star of England, in Person
abstract: Jude Law, David Tennant and Tom Hiddleston have recently lent a screen-god glow to Shakespeare’s portraits of uncommon men, creating the hardest tickets to get in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Along St. Martin’s Lane, the girls are lining up for their “little touch of Harry in the night.” No, that is not a snarky reference to another case of untoward groping by a member of Parliament, a subject of much conversation here. The exchange these young women are awaiting is something more, shall we say, celestial.

headline: Gary Shteyngart: By the Book
abstract: The author of the novel “Super Sad True Love Story” and, most recently, the memoir “Little Failure” likes books in which people suffer. “If there’s no suffering, I kind of tune out.”
lead_paragraph: The author of the novel “Super Sad True Love Story” and, most recently, the memoir “Little Failure” likes books in which people suffer. “If there’s no suffering, I kind of tune out.”

headline: Activists Solicit Shareholders to Replace Board at CommonWealth REIT
abstract: Corvex Management and Related Fund Management are frustrated with the Portnoy family, which controls CommonWealth REIT, and the firms have begun a consent solicitation process aimed at replacing the CommonWealth board.
lead_paragraph: CommonWealth REIT, the embattled real estate trust, recently extended an olive branch to the activist shareholders pressing the company for change.

headline: A Real-Life ‘Wolf of Wall Street’ Reunion, Minus the Wolf
abstract: The movie left out some of the intriguing details of Jordan Belfort’s crimes, a group of men who had front-row seats to the real thing said at a law school event in Manhattan on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Moviegoers cringed at the many scenes of debauchery and dishonesty in “The Wolf of Wall Street,” a film based on the real-life shenanigans of the boiler room kingpin Jordan Belfort.

headline: Image of the Day: January 30
abstract: President Pranab Mukherjee at the memorial of Mohandas K. Gandhi at Rajghat in New Delhi.

headline: Dawn Zier of Nutrisystem on When Your Company Is Adrift
abstract: This chief executive looks for employees who step up in times of change.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Dawn M. Zier, chief executive of Nutrisystem, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Justice Dept. Starts Quest for Inmates to Be Freed
keywords: ['Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Mandatory Sentencing']
abstract: The Obama administration, in an effort to curtail severe penalties in low-level drug cases, is encouraging defense lawyers to suggest inmates whom the president might let out of prison early.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department wants low-level drug criminals who were sentenced under tough laws from the days of the crack epidemic to ask the president for early release from prison.

headline: Really Counting the Epithets in ‘Wolf’
abstract: Diligent sleuths tally the oaths and come up with an even higher number than prevously suggested.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — So just exactly how many four-letter epithets are there in “The Wolf of Wall Street”? (You know which one we mean.) For weeks, the number floating around the Internet has been 506: that’s a count promoted by Variety and other outlets, and trumpeted as the highest number for an R-rated movie. But the sleuths at Slate did a little investigating and, as it turns out, that figure is based on — at best — a blog estimate amplified by Wikipedia. And what’s more, it’s a lowball.

headline: Broncos vs. Seahawks, Atop the Empire State Building
abstract: In a campaign that began Monday, the building is putting on a light show generated by football fans on Twitter who will be asked to make Super Bowl predictions.
lead_paragraph: The world’s most colorful football debate began on Monday evening — at the top of the Empire State Building.

headline: In Our Pages: January 31
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Royal Family']
abstract: From The International Herald Tribune.
lead_paragraph: 1889: Prince Rudolf Dead

headline: Landed at the Wrong Airport? Imagining a P.R. Response
abstract: After an airline plane landed at the wrong airport recently, a humorist offers a four-step public relations campaign designed to spin such an event.
lead_paragraph: A Southwest Airlines jet touched down at the wrong Missouri airport this month, a mix-up that comes two months after a cargo jet landed at the wrong airport in Kansas. How will the industry bounce back from the embarrassing publicity? Herewith, some suggestions for an emergency P.R. campaign.

headline: Why the Homeownership Rate Is Misleading
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: At this stage of the housing recovery, the falling homeownership rate might be misleading, masking a possible increase in household formation because of young renters, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Jed Kolko is chief economist and vice president for analytics at Trulia, an online marketplace for residential real estate.

headline: An Alibaba Rival Plans Its Own I.P.O. This Year
abstract: JD.com, one of China’s biggest e-commerce companies, said in a regulatory filing on Thursday that it planned to raise $1.5 billion this year in an initial public offering in the United States.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI – JD.com, one of China’s biggest e-commerce companies, said in a regulatory filing on Thursday that it planned to raise $1.5 billion this year in an initial public offering in the United States.

headline: Henry Waxman, Key Democrat and Force for Health Care Law, Is to Retire
abstract: The congressman joins a growing list of House members calling it quits, despairing of political gridlock.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Md. — Representative Henry A. Waxman of California, a diminutive Democratic giant whose 40 years in the House produced some of the most important legislation of the era, announced Thursday that he would retire at the end of the year.

headline: Diageo Reports Slower Growth
abstract: The world’s biggest distiller joined other consumer brands in saying that slower growth in developing economies last year hurt its business.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Selling beer and liquor in emerging markets has for a long time been investors’ main attraction to Diageo. On Thursday, some investors sold their shares because of it.

headline: Viacom Quarterly Profit Rises 16%, Lifted by Cable Fees and Lower Costs
abstract: The company said fourth-quarter earnings were aided by higher subscriber fees and an increase in cable advertising, and that Paramount Pictures narrowed its loss from a year ago.
lead_paragraph: Lower costs at Paramount Pictures and higher subscriber fees at cable networks like Nickelodeon, Comedy Central and VH1 helped Viacom report a 16 percent increase in fourth-quarter net income on Thursday.

headline: Can You Tie Them in a Knot?
abstract: N.B.A. sneakers have become a way for players to express themselves within league guidelines. So try and match the player with his footwear.
lead_paragraph: N.B.A. sneakers have become a way for players to express themselves within league guidelines. So try and match the player with his footwear.

headline: When Doctors Give Patients Money
abstract: Recently a few of my colleagues were sitting together and one asked if any of us had ever given money to a patient. There was an awkward pause, and then the stories starting coming out.
lead_paragraph: Recently a few of my colleagues were sitting together and one asked if any of us had ever given money to a patient. There was an awkward pause, and then the stories starting coming out — a few dollars for a co-pay, or to help a frail patient take a cab instead of a bus; a bag of food or an extra meal. “How could I not,” one doctor said, “when my patient’s immediate need could be solved by the small change in my coat pocket?”

headline: Amy Chua and Jed Rubenfeld, ‘Tiger Couple’
abstract: Amy Chua’s new book, written with her husband, explores the same cultural minefield as “Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother,” yet both say they’re hoping for a different kind of reader response.
lead_paragraph: “Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother” was Amy Chua’s first real foray into pop-cultural polemics. Her new book, written with her husband Jed Rubenfeld, enters the same cultural minefield.

headline: Bieber Faces Assault Charge in Toronto
abstract: Justin Bieber was charged with assaulting a limousine driver in December, the police said.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s episode of the Justin Bieber Show, the 19-year-old Canadian singer has returned to his homeland, only to find himself once more chatting with the police. This time, he went to the Toronto police voluntarily, a stark contrast with last week’s installment, in which Mr. Bieber was arrested in Miami Beach and charged with driving under the influence, resisting arrest and driving without a valid license.

headline: Mayor Says New York City Will Settle Suits on Stop-and-Frisk Tactics
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Thursday that the city would ends its battle over the Police Department’s aggressive practice by agreeing to reforms.
lead_paragraph: New York City will settle its long-running legal battle over the Police Department’s practice of stopping, questioning and often frisking people on the street — a divisive issue at the heart of the mayoral race last year — by agreeing to reforms that a judge ordered in August, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Thursday.

headline: Lauder Calls for New Panel to Resolve Nazi Art-Looting Restitution Issues
keywords: ['Art', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Jews and Judaism', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: The President of World Jewish Congress on Thursday called for the creation of a new panel that resolve the issue of how to resolve the issue of art that was looted by the Nazis from Jewish families and dealers.
lead_paragraph: Ronald S. Lauder, an art collector and philanthropist who is president of the World Jewish Congress, called on Thursday for the establishment of a new commission, made up of German and foreign experts, that would resolve once and for all the issue of art looted from Jews by the Nazis. Some of these works, Mr. Lauder said, still hang in German museums and even government offices.

headline: Today in Small Business: Joke Products
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Small Business', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Things you can 3-D print right now. What mall stores need to know. Why businesses probably won’t increase salaries.
lead_paragraph: • Here are seven policy initiatives from the president’s State of the Union address that could affect small businesses.

headline: Southwest Will Begin Flights to Caribbean
abstract: Southwest Airlines will offer service to Aruba, the Bahamas, and Jamaica beginning in July.
lead_paragraph: Southwest Airlines took a step toward becoming an international carrier this week with the announcement that it would begin daily service to Aruba, the Bahamas and Jamaica this summer.

headline: Playwright Sues to Salvage Play Deconstructing ‘Three’s Company’
abstract: The playwright David Adjmi went to federal court on Thursday to try to salvage his play “3C,” which ran Off Broadway in 2012 but has been tied up by the copyright owner of the TV show “Three’s Company.”
lead_paragraph: The New York playwright David Adjmi, best known for Off Broadway satirical works like “Marie Antoinette,” went to federal court on Thursday to try to salvage his play “3C,” which has been tied up by the copyright owner of “Three’s Company,” the landmark television comedy that Mr. Adjmi deconstructs through a dark lens in “3C.”

headline: Wheelies: The Retooling for the F-150 Edition
abstract: Ford announces a factory shutdown for aluminum F-150 retooling; a chance to drive the Oscar Mayer Weinermobile.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

headline: Quarterly Earnings Fall at Exxon Mobil and Shell
abstract: The oil giants’ reactions differed sharply: Shell plans to step up asset sales and cut investment, while Exxon Mobil pointed to its numerous projects.
lead_paragraph: For the second quarter in a row, Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch Shell on Thursday reported sharply lower earnings because of a decrease in oil prices, declining production and soaring expenses for megaprojects around the globe.

headline: Lenovo’s Merger Spree Challenges Investors’ Faith
abstract: Lenovo’s recently announced acquisitions of two unprofitable businesses show some strategic logic, but shareholders have little way of working out whether the deals stack up, Ethan Bilby and Peter Thal Larsen write in Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Lenovo prides itself on being a modern multinational, but its approach to divulging information remains frustratingly old school.

headline: A Copy of David Adjmi’s Legal Complaint Filed in Federal Court
abstract: The playwright David Adjmi asked the Southern District Court of New York to declare that his play “3C” does not infringe on the copyright of “Three’s Company,” the television comedy that ran from 1977 to 1984.
lead_paragraph: The playwright David Adjmi asked the Southern District Court of New York to declare that his play “3C” does not infringe on the copyright of “Three’s Company,” the television comedy that ran from 1977 to 1984.

headline: Showing Deaf Players They Fit In, Too
abstract: Adham Talaat, who played football at Gallaudet, said he was sure the success of the Seahawks’ Derrick Coleman would help pave the way for his own.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Hearing aids in, lip-reading skill at the ready, Derrick Coleman, a Seattle Seahawks fullback, fielded question after question from reporters at Super Bowl media day. Most of them were about his hearing loss.

headline: Equality as Handout
abstract: Republicans say they support equal pay for equal work, but won’t pass legislation to help close the gender pay gap.
lead_paragraph: In his State of the Union address, President Obama endorsed a basic feminist concept that no national politician would dare contradict: “A woman deserves equal pay for equal work.” Representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers, who delivered the official Republican response to the president’s speech, didn’t hesitate to endorse the principle in a Wednesday CNN interview: “Republicans and I support equal pay for equal work,” she said.

headline: Another Super Bowl Ad Fest, This Time on the Cellphone
abstract: This year, a new kind of advertising — personalized and based on physical location down to a matter of feet — will greet fans in Times Square and MetLife Stadium, where the Super Bowl will be played this weekend.
lead_paragraph: Want to see the Vince Lombardi Trophy that goes to the Super Bowl winner? Take a left in 15 feet. Looking to buy some Super Bowl merchandise? Try the fourth floor of Macy’s, straight ahead.

headline: Times Minute | Henry Waxman Retires
abstract: Also on the Minute, an audit of U.S. aid to Afghanistan and Barneys New York launches a transgender ad campaign.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: The Combination Drawing Club and Taco Bell
abstract: Jason Polan spent so much time drawing in Taco Bell that he decided to invite other people to join him.
lead_paragraph: If the cold New York weather has you looking for indoor activities, a little-known (and free) drawing club is held most Wednesdays from 4:30 p.m. to 6 p.m. at the Taco Bell on 14th Street just west of Union Square. The artist Jason Polan started the Taco Bell Drawing Club nine years ago and still attends many of the weekly meetings. Polan is a prolific artist; he has drawn every piece of art in the Museum of Modern Art (not once but twice) and is currently on a mission to draw every person in New York. The club meetings are open to anyone who wants to show up and draw. Having visited recently, I decided to ask Polan some questions about the group.

lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, an audit of U.S. aid to Afghanistan and Barneys New York launches a transgender ad campaign.
