abstract: The Libyan Investment Authority claims that Goldman Sachs made more than $1 billion in derivatives trades that became worthless in value but left the bank with a profit of $350 million.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:01 p.m. | Libya’s sovereign investment fund has filed a lawsuit against Goldman Sachs in London’s High Court, claiming that the bank made more than $1 billion in derivatives trades that became worthless, but left Goldman with a profit of $350 million.

headline: 18 Charged With Operating Prostitution and Drug Ring
abstract: The investigation began 11 months ago, but Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman said the timing of the arrests was intended to raise awareness of the issue of sex trafficking before the Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: Just days before the kickoff of Super Bowl XLVIII, Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman on Thursday announced charges against 18 people for operating a high-end prostitution and drug trafficking ring.

headline: Shopping Cart Injuries Remain Common
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Falls', 'Hospitals', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Shopping carts might not seem a particularly dangerous place for a child, but from 1990 to 2011, an average of 66 children a day wound up in emergency rooms after injuries sustained in and near them.
lead_paragraph: Shopping carts might not seem like a particularly dangerous place for a child, but from 1990 to 2011, an average of 66 children a day wound up in emergency rooms after injuries sustained in and near them.

headline: Biathlete Leaves Russian Team After Testing Positive
abstract: Irina Starykh, an Olympic medal hopeful, said Thursday that she would step down from the team, a blow to the country and its biathlon program, which is backed by Mikhail D. Prokhorov.
lead_paragraph: Irina Starykh, a biathlete who was one of Russia’s brightest hopes for an Olympic medal in Sochi, announced Thursday that she was stepping down from the team because of a doping violation.

headline: Delay in Chemical Arms Pledge Criticized
keywords: ['Biological and Chemical Warfare', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: The United States sharply criticized Syria for what it called serious and unjustifiable delays in the export of the Syrian chemical weapons stockpile.
lead_paragraph: The United States sharply criticized Syria on Thursday over delays in the timetable for eliminating its chemical weapons, accusing the Syrian government of deliberately stalling their removal from the country to gain bargaining leverage and — in a new complaint — reneging on a pledge to destroy the 12 facilities that produced them.

headline: Dark Side of Capital in Emerging Markets
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Interest Rates', 'Foreign Investments', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: For countries like Turkey, the tide of investment from abroad has turned.
lead_paragraph: It is no fun to be a central banker in an emerging-market country when investors suddenly grow doubtful.

headline: As Gaza Tunnels Closed, Hamas Lost Cash, Israeli Official Says
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Smuggling']
abstract: The Islamic militant group lost a major source of income because of an Egyptian clampdown on smuggling tunnels, an Israeli military official said.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Hamas, the Islamic militant group that controls Gaza, is in severe economic straits, having lost a major source of income in recent months because of an Egyptian clampdown on hundreds of smuggling tunnels, a high-ranking Israeli military official told reporters at army headquarters here on Thursday.

headline: Another Way to Think of ‘Captain Phillips': 2 Guys at Work
abstract: The screenwriter says he saw the drama as an examination of leadership, by a ship’s captain and a pirate.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — There aren’t too many quotable lines in movies this season, but one that could have legs is “I am the captain now,” from “Captain Phillips.” At a Writers Guild panel here this week, the Oscar- and guild-nominated screenwriter Billy Ray, whose credits include little flicks like “The Hunger Games,” discussed his approach to shaping the true story of the hostage situation aboard the Maersk Alabama.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Dallas Buyers Club’
abstract: Jean-Marc Vallée narrates a scene from his film featuring Matthew McConaughey and Jared Leto.
lead_paragraph: Jean-Marc Vallée narrates a scene from his film featuring Matthew McConaughey and Jared Leto.

headline: Wintertime Bargains in Budapest
abstract: Tickets to an opera house. A “luxury boutique” hotel. Picking up the check. Wait — this is frugal travel?
lead_paragraph: On a drizzly mid-January evening, I stood at the arches of the wall of Buda Castle, overlooking the Danube and the 19th-century Chain Bridge that links Buda with Pest. Beyond the bridge, the mist turned the Hungarian parliament into a glowworm.

headline: Obama Once Disdained Clinton’s Small Steps and Now Takes His Own
keywords: ['Vocational Training', 'United States Economy', 'State of the Union Message (US)']
abstract: With a new appreciation for Bill Clinton’s leadership style, and more of Mr. Clinton’s former advisers on his team, President Obama is embracing a modest approach to getting things done.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — In the summer of his first year in power, President Obama made clear that he envisioned a lofty mission. “I wasn’t sent here to do school uniforms,” he told aides one day in the Oval Office. The implication was clear: He did not want to govern like Bill Clinton.

headline: U.S. Is Seeking Death Penalty in Boston Case
abstract: The decision against Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, accused of killing and maiming people with homemade bombs at the Boston Marathon last year, is not necessarily final, because such cases often end in plea deals.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department said Thursday that it would seek the death penalty against Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the man accused of killing and maiming people with homemade bombs at the Boston Marathon finish line last year.

headline: The Super Bowl of Sports Gambling
abstract: Inside the world’s biggest football-betting contest, where squares and sharps and amateur data crunchers are all trying to beat the spread — and Vegas Runner’s reputation is on the line.
lead_paragraph: Vegas Runner strode into the sports book of the Las Vegas Hotel & Casino, a fat diamond stud glittering in his left earlobe. Moving through the cavernous room as though it belonged to him, he reached a bar table where his friend R. J. Bell was waiting and flashed a smile. “My man!” Vegas Runner bellowed.

headline: The Power Breakfast Starts a New Day
abstract: The birthplace of the power breakfast, the Loews Regency Hotel in Manhattan, has renovated and hired a new executive chef.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK is filled with enterprising women eager to turn up for breakfast at 8 a.m., decked out in eye shadow and Akris. They sip green tea and push a spoon around a bowl of oatmeal while speaking fervently of “protecting the brand.”

headline: Senate Passes Bill to Delay Spike in Flood Insurance Rates
abstract: The bill would effectively gut a 2012 law that had aimed to overhaul the nearly bankrupt National Flood Insurance Program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday passed a bill to delay sharp increases in flood insurance rates for millions of property owners in coastal and flood-prone areas.

headline: An Artistic Celebration of the Beauty, Spectacle and Masculinity of Soccer
abstract: On Super Bowl Sunday, the Los Angeles County Museum of Art is opening an exhibition dedicated to the other kind of football, “Fútbol: The Beautiful Game,” which examines the sport through various media.
lead_paragraph: This Sunday might be the big game, but the Los Angeles County Museum of Art (LACMA) hasn’t forgotten about the other football — or soccer, as we refer to it in the United States. Opening the day of the Super Bowl, “Fútbol: The Beautiful Game” examines the sport through works of art ranging from video and photography to painting, sculpture and large-scale installation.

headline: Fitness Trackers: Lifeline or Flatline?
abstract: Readers share their thoughts on the latest generation of fitness devices, like the Fitbit Force.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s personal technology column, I reviewed the Fitbit Force, a sleek new personal fitness tracker that is worn on the wrist. My feelings were mixed. I thoroughly enjoyed tracking my daily and weekly activity levels, and looking at the pretty visualizations that the Fitbit software creates from that data, but it was hard to parse deep insights from that information. The software, which is fairly sophisticated, still seems like it is not quite smart enough to help me figure out how to change my personal habits to be more healthy. I couldn’t recommend spending $130 on a rubber bracelet that tells me what I already know works — eat less, move more — to live well and stay in shape.

headline: Celebrating Sestinas at Poets House
abstract: Poets will be reading their sestinas at Poets House, and “The Wonderful Wizard of Odd” features clowns at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: Followers of contemporary American poetry can’t fail to notice that traditional forms, employing rhymes and recognizable meters, are pretty firmly out of fashion. Browsing through the January issue of Poetry magazine, an admittedly unscientific but fairly typical sampling, you find almost exclusively free verse. Most of today’s poets, to paraphrase Robert Frost, seem to be quite happy playing tennis without a net.

headline: The Gun Report: January 30, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: While President Obama spoke about the need for gun control in his State of the Union address on Tuesday, there was a shooting at Tennessee State University. A 20-year-old man was shot in the leg during an argument over a gambling debt following an intramural basketball game. Neither the shooter nor the victim were students.

headline: Another Option for an Upgrade From Windows XP
abstract: Plus, working with multiple Apple ID accounts.
lead_paragraph: Q. I’m still running Windows XP on my computer; can I upgrade to Windows 7 instead of Windows 8?

headline: South by Southwest Festival Adds a TV Section
keywords: ['South by Southwest Music and Media Conference', 'Television']
abstract: The Austin, Tex., festival will preview six series, including HBO’s “Silicon Valley” and a pilot for El Rey Network from Robert Rodriguez.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After dabbling with previews of TV series like “Girls” and “Bates Motel,” the South by Southwest festival will add a television tier to its annual film programming, the festival said on Thursday.

headline: Banks Could Still Face Tougher Capital Requirements to Prevent Crises
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Although central bankers and national regulators agreed to support a low leverage ratio for banks, the chairman of the Basel Committee on Bank Supervision suggested that the panel could still recommend stiffer requirements.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Ever since the end of the 2008 financial crisis, the world’s leaders have searched for ways to shore up the banking system.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘Dallas Buyers Club’
abstract: Jean-Marc Vallée narrates a scene from his film.
lead_paragraph: In this video, the director Jean-Marc Vallée narrates a scene from his period film about Ron Woodroof, a Texas rodeo rider who is diagnosed with H.I.V. The scene features Matthew McConaughey as Ron, Jared Leto as his business partner, Rayon, and Kevin Rankin as Ron’s old friend T. J. “Dallas Buyers Club” received six Oscar nominations and arrives on DVD Feb. 4.

headline: A Dive Into the Arts for Black History Month
abstract: Jazz, swing and soul concerts, African and gospel music, illustrated talks on slavery, and films and plays about famous African-Americans abound on Long Island in February.
lead_paragraph: When Frank Owens, a seasoned Broadway pianist and onetime musical director for David Letterman, was invited to play music by the jazz composer Mary Lou Williams at a Hofstra University concert celebrating Black History Month, he saw it as a new challenge.

headline: Problem In the Classroom? Tread Lightly
abstract: What is the best way to handle a parent-teacher conference with an ineffective teacher?
lead_paragraph: This week’s question is from a parent seeking advice on how to handle a conference with an ineffective teacher.

headline: Boston Ballet to Conclude 50th Anniversary Tour at Lincoln Center
abstract: The program in late June will include new work by José Martinez and classics like “Afternoon of a Faun.”
lead_paragraph: The Boston Ballet has chosen Lincoln Center as the place where it will wrap up its 50th anniversary tour. The program, which is scheduled to run from June 25 through June 29 at the David H. Koch Theater, will include a new work by José Martinez; Alexander Ekman’s “Cacti”; and classics like Nijinsky’s “Afternoon of a Faun,” William Forsythe’s “The Second Detail” and George Balanchine’s “Symphony in Three Movements.” “This tour will be the grand finale to our 50th season,” said Mikko Nissinen, the company’s artistic director. “Many of the pieces we’re presenting are new to the United States.”

headline: Video Notebook: Russell Wilson
abstract: Seattle Seahawks quarterback Russell Wilson spoke to the media about his teammate Derrick Coleman.
lead_paragraph: Seattle Seahawks quarterback Russell Wilson spoke to the media about his teammate Derrick Coleman.

headline: A Comedy That Plays to the Home Crowd
abstract: Wendy Yondorf’s play is a good-natured comedy that pokes fun at several prestigious American institutions of higher learning as well as New Jersey in general.
lead_paragraph: It’s a good thing that “Admit One” is such a good-natured comedy. Otherwise, several prestigious American institutions of higher learning might sue.

headline: Annual Profit Nearly Flat for Luxury Group LVMH
abstract: Results for the world's largest luxury goods company reflected a slowdown in demand for some key brands as well as the impact of a stronger euro.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the world’s largest luxury goods group, said Thursday that its profit was almost flat last year amid flagging demand for some of its core fashion brands in key markets like China and the impact of weaker currencies in its main overseas markets.

headline: Shoulder Pads Slim Down in Faster, Sleeker N.F.L.
abstract: Football shoulder pads have become lighter by as much as 50 percent over the past 10 to 15 years, manufacturers said, thanks to advances in technology and players’ preferences.
lead_paragraph: Terrance Knighton, a 6-foot-3, 335-pound defensive tackle for the Denver Broncos, has the sumptuous nickname of Pot Roast. Perched on such a massive frame, his shoulder pads appear almost decorative, as if they were tassels on a drum major.

headline: Husband-and-Wife Chefs Split From Calliope
abstract: Eric Korsh and Ginevra Iverson have left the popular country-French bistro in the East Village.
lead_paragraph: Nearly two years after opening Calliope, the popular country-French bistro in the East Village, Eric Korsh and his wife, Ginevra Iverson, the chefs and partners, have left the restaurant in a split with Eric Anderson, the other owner. The couple told Mr. Anderson of their departure Thursday morning.

headline: With Disaster Near, Debating God’s Existence
abstract: In “Freud’s Last Session,” a meeting in London between the psychoanalyst and the author C. S. Lewis turns personal.
lead_paragraph: Now, this is what a psychiatrist’s office should look like. The wall of books; the African art; the Greek, Roman and Egyptian artifacts on the desk; the Oriental rugs; and the imposing, tapestry-draped couch. This is the sunlit London study of Dr. Sigmund Freud in TheaterWorks Hartford’s decidedly satisfying new production of “Freud’s Last Session,” and what better place to debate the existence of God?

headline: Lawsuit Questions Square’s Start-Up Story
abstract: A professor at Washington University in St. Louis filed suit against Square and its co-founders, including Jack Dorsey of Twitter, contending that he was unfairly cut out of a start-up that is now valued at about $5 billion.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 4:55 p.m. | Included comment from a spokesman from Square.

headline: New Ambitions for the Symphony of Westchester
abstract: The symphony has committed to hiring up to 70 musicians for its regular-season concerts and has programmed works like Beethoven’s Fifth Symphony.
lead_paragraph: What’s in a name? Plenty, according to the conductor Barry Hoffman.

headline: ‘Super PAC’ Is Formed in Mississippi to Protect 6-Term Senator in G.O.P. Primary
keywords: ['Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Political Action Committees', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: A group of Mississippi Republicans, moving to counter spending from out-of-state conservative groups, are moving to help Senator Thad Cochran fend off a primary challenge.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A group of Mississippi Republicans, moving to counter spending from out-of-state conservative groups, have created a “super PAC” to help Senator Thad Cochran fend off a primary challenge and will begin airing a television ad on Friday.

headline: Razed Neighborhoods in Syria
abstract: The Syrian government has used explosives and bulldozers to demolish thousands of residential buildings to punish civilians in neighborhoods where the army has clashed with opposition fighters, Human Rights Watch said in a report on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The Syrian government has used explosives and bulldozers to demolish thousands of residential buildings to punish civilians in neighborhoods where the army has clashed with opposition fighters, Human Rights Watch said in a report on Thursday.

headline: N.S.A. Choice Is Navy Expert on Cyberwar
abstract: Vice Adm. Michael S. Rogers, a cryptologist by training, will become the public face of the N.S.A. at a moment that it is caught in the cross hairs of a roiling debate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In nominating Vice Adm. Michael S. Rogers as the new director of the National Security Agency on Thursday, President Obama chose a recognized expert in the new art of designing cyberweapons, but someone with no public track record in addressing the kinds of privacy concerns that have put the agency under a harsh spotlight.

headline: Human Rights Watch Shares Images of Razed Neighborhoods in Syria
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Demolition', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The government used explosives and bulldozers to demolish thousands of residential buildings to punish civilians in neighborhoods where the army has clashed with opposition fighters, the group said.
lead_paragraph: The Syrian government has used explosives and bulldozers to demolish thousands of residential buildings to punish civilians in neighborhoods where the army has clashed with opposition fighters, Human Rights Watch said in a report on Thursday.

headline: Beatles ’14: Two Hotels Celebrate an Anniversary
abstract: The Deauville Beach Resort in Miami Beach and the Plaza in New York will commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Beatles’ first trip to the United States.
lead_paragraph: In February 1964, the Beatles made their first trip to the United States, igniting Beatlemania stateside from New York to Miami. Fifty years later, hotels the band visited then are marking the anniversary in ways small and large.

headline: Homing In on a Couple’s Basquiat Drawings
abstract: An exhibition of Jean-Michel Basquiat drawings at Acquavella; Christie’s released details on the art it will auction from Huguette Clark’s estate.
lead_paragraph: Longtime collectors like Herbert and Lenore Schorr are luckier than most. In 1981, while visiting the Annina Nosei Gallery, which was then on Prince Street in SoHo, the couple met Jean-Michel Basquiat, fell in love with his work and bought one of his paintings. That purchase was quickly followed by others — drawings as well as canvases — and, over the years, the Schorrs amassed one of the most important Basquiat collections in the country. The Schorrs also became friends with the artist, who died of a drug overdose at 27 in 1988, and occasionally bought a painting or drawing right out of his Manhattan studio.

headline: Gallery | The Pioneers of Graffiti Art, Through the Eyes of KAWS
abstract: The artist discusses 10 favorite works in an exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York that gathers the biggest names of ’80s street art.
lead_paragraph: When the painter Martin Wong moved to New York in the late 1970s, the colorful graffiti around his new hometown so enthralled him that he began collecting and archiving what he knew would soon become historically significant art. He spent the next decade gathering pictures of the artists and their now painted-over masterpieces from photographers like Martha Cooper, who famously documented the emerging art form. In the ’80s, when gallerists began commissioning various mixed-media paintings from the graffiti artists — which were easier to display than tagged subway cars or building facades — Wong began to collect those too.

headline: For the Super Bowl, a Cruise Ship Becomes a Shrine to Beer
abstract: What had arrived in New York as the Norwegian Getaway, a 1,062-foot-long ship, is now the Bud Light Hotel.
lead_paragraph: When doors finally opened to the newly christened Bud Light Hotel on Thursday, visitors saw more than the luxurious inside of a new cruise ship. They entered a floating shrine to the beer.

headline: What Republicans Say Versus What Republicans Mean
abstract: A letter to the president from the top four House officials is a classic exercise in political disguise and deceit.
lead_paragraph: Now that the State-of-the-Union cameras are off, House Republicans are eager to discard their frozen smiles and return to their jobs of undermining virtually every goal President Obama set out in his speech on Tuesday night. They made that clear in a letter that the top four House officials sent to the president today, which purports to seek agreement on four points in the speech. It actually does quite the opposite.

headline: Super Bowl Will Again Be a Showcase for Automakers
abstract: Chevrolet, Audi, Kia and Toyota are among repeat Super Bowl advertisers, but Jaguar will be a first timer.
lead_paragraph: As the Denver Broncos and Seattle Seahawks get ready for the Super Bowl, automakers have also prepared for their own game-day competition: television ads.

headline: Revenue and Profit Rise at Google, but Mobile Is a Persistent Challenge
abstract: The company reported fourth-quarter revenue of $16.86 billion, an increase of 17 percent over a year ago. Net income rose 17 percent to $3.38 billion.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — There is no denying that Google has become a mobile company. Now, Google — along with shareholders, industry partners and advertisers — is trying to figure out what that means.

headline: With California Syrahs, an Asian-Accented Chili
abstract: This chili is more evocative of Shanghai than the Southwest.
lead_paragraph: Entering the room with a firm handshake, the enjoyably earthy and assertive California syrahs we tasted require food that will not back off.

headline: The Real Challenge for Reform Conservatism
keywords: ['Federal Taxes (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Why limited-government ideology isn’t necessarily the biggest hurdle facing Republican reformers.
lead_paragraph: I wrote a post last week about whether a conservative reform project would necessitate a return to Bush-era deficit spending, or whether there’s any space available between “deficits don’t matter” Republicanism and Tea Party-era austerity. Since then, a number of writers have looked at the emerging conservative policy blueprints — which now include, mirabile dictu, an actual health care reform proposal! — and argued that their core weaknesses is an unwillingness to endorse new spending. Thus Danny Vinik, in a fair-minded post for Business Insider:

headline: Republicans’ Immigration Blueprint Leaves Party at Odds and Democrats Hopeful
keywords: ['Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Illegal Immigration', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The plan includes “an opportunity for legal residence and citizenship” for young immigrants brought here illegally by their parents, but it does not offer citizenship to many undocumented immigrants.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Md. — The House Republican leadership’s call on Thursday to provide legal status for 11 million undocumented workers, and possible citizenship for those brought to this country as children, caused sharp division within the party even as it provided a starting point for negotiations with Democrats on overhauling the nation’s immigration system.

headline: Text of Republicans’ Principles on Immigration
abstract: On Thursday, Congressional Republicans released a one-page document outlining their blueprint for immigration overhaul.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Congressional Republicans released a one-page document, obtained by The New York Times, outlining their blueprint for immigration overhaul.

headline: Arahmaiani: ‘Fertility of the Mind’
abstract: The Indonesian artist Arahmaiani Feisal, who uses only her first name, has forthrightly waded into political hot water.
lead_paragraph: Tyler Rollins

headline: Sue Williams: ‘WTC, WWIII, Couch Size’
abstract: The puzzling title of this effervescent exhibition refers to the World Trade Center attacks, the various wars since, and the idea of painting as a decorative commodity.
lead_paragraph: 303 Gallery

headline: Guy Ben Ner: ‘Soundtrack’
abstract: Mr. Ben Ner takes a scene from the 2005 movie “War of the Worlds” as a “ready-made” soundtrack and pairs it with footage shot in his kitchen.
lead_paragraph: Postmasters

headline: Saul Fletcher
abstract: Mr. Fletcher’s latest photographs, small, scrappily poetic, mainly black-and-white prints, look much like his earlier works.
lead_paragraph: Anton Kern Gallery

headline: Amazon to Raise Fees as Revenue Disappoints
abstract: Revenue rose 20 percent, but the online retailer said it was considering raising prices by as much as 50 percent on its $79 Prime shipping program.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon investors might have finally heard the news they have been waiting for: The retailer is raising shipping fees.

headline: Senator’s Son, 26, Arrested in Colorado on Drug Charge
abstract: The police in Boulder County, Colo., said the 26-year-old son of Senator Mark Udall was caught trying to break into cars and charged with trespassing and drug possession.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The son of Senator Mark Udall, Democrat of Colorado, was arrested this week on drug possession and trespassing charges, the Boulder County sheriff’s office said Thursday.

headline: It Started With Charcuterie
abstract: Matthew Ridgway’s restaurant, resembling a French roadhouse and charcuterie, serves whimsical and delicious dishes at low prices.
lead_paragraph: The mounted, tusked boar’s head on the wall immediately sets the Pass, Matthew Ridgway’s restaurant, apart. The table near the entrance with artisanal products for sale — honey, olive oil and what looked to be house-canned produce — takes it a step farther from the mainstream.

headline: Obama on Job-Driven Training
abstract: At a General Electric plant in Wisconsin, the president spoke about finding better ways to help Americans learn skills and signed an executive order for a review of federal job-training programs.
lead_paragraph: At a General Electric plant in Wisconsin, the president spoke about finding better ways to help Americans learn skills and signed an executive order for a review of federal job-training programs.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Central African Republic, Syria and Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Central African Republic, Syria and Afghanistan.

headline: Nocturnalist at the Super Bowl | Where Food and Football Intersect
abstract: The 50 Yard Lounge, in a tent wedged between two restaurants in Midtown Manhattan, is a weeklong event intended to bring together the worlds of food and sports.
lead_paragraph: It was billed as an evening fusing football with flavors of New York, but the pastrami on rye could have been a monarch’s take on that city signature – a jewel-like gobbet of meat with caraway-scented brown butter – the kegs were filled with wine, and the hot dogs (brace yourself, oh true New Yorkers) were of a variety from Puerto Rico.

headline: Dave Pasternack to Open a Restaurant in Chelsea
abstract: The new restaurant, Barchetta, will open in the spring and emphasize seafood.
lead_paragraph: Dave Pasternack, the chef and a partner at Esca, the Italian seafood restaurant in Hell’s Kitchen, is planning to open another restaurant come spring. This time it’s without B & B Hospitality, the Bastianich-Batali group, which owns Esca.

headline: Saying Goodbye to a City and Its Characters
abstract: In “The Days of Anna Madrigal,” Armistead Maupin wraps up the stories of the San Francisco friends he began in 1976.
lead_paragraph: The hills are still firmly in place, the Golden Gate Bridge remains a bright symbol of welcome, but San Francisco has changed radically since Armistead Maupin began charting the interlocking lives of a handful of its colorful fictional denizens in 1976. The city that was once a beacon for people looking to escape the strictures of conformity — and the puritanical streak in American culture — has now become a high-amenity bedroom community for the epicenter of the tech universe, Silicon Valley. And so the bohemian aerie at the center of Mr. Maupin’s beloved “Tales of the City” novels, 28 Barbary Lane, has now passed from the hands of Anna Madrigal, the one-woman marijuana dispensary who presided over her tenants as both a spiritual guru and a surrogate mother. Now, the building belongs to dot-commers who, in the words of one of the characters from Mr. Maupin’s new novel, “The Days of Anna Madrigal,” have “made it look like a five-star B and B.”

headline: My Invisible Head Not Talking Economics
abstract: Three tunes, discussed.
lead_paragraph: Soundcheck on WNYC, talking musical tastes.

headline: Beyond the Large TVs, a Dancing Dragon
abstract: A four-month-old pan-Asian lounge on Merrick Road offers sushi, cooked dishes and some unexpected textures.
lead_paragraph: Patrons at 2one2, a pan-Asian restaurant named for its address on Merrick Road in Rockville Centre, enter through the bar. And it’s quite a bar, too, taking up almost half the space, with five large televisions, a 90-inch screen on another wall and plenty of room for a mingling crowd.

headline: Georgia Storm Response ‘Not Fast Enough’
abstract: Gov. Nathan Deal said that he was not satisfied with the response to this week’s winter storm and that an internal review would be conducted.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Nathan Deal said that he was not satisfied with the response to this week’s winter storm and that an internal review would be conducted.

headline: Scarlett Johansson Chooses SodaStream Over Oxfam After Dispute About West Bank Factory
abstract: Forced to choose, Scarlett Johansson decided to end her charitable work on behalf of Oxfam, which opposes trade with Israeli settlements, and continue as a paid “brand ambassador” for SodaStream, which makes products in the occupied West Bank.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 5:49 p.m. | Forced to choose between two endorsement deals, the actress Scarlett Johansson decided Wednesday to end her charitable work on behalf of Oxfam, an antipoverty group that opposes trade with Israeli settlements, and continue as a paid “brand ambassador” for SodaStream, a company that manufactures products in the occupied West Bank.

headline: Williamstown Theater Festival to Feature Renée Fleming and Chita Rivera
abstract: Ms. Fleming and Ms. Rivera will make their debuts at the theater festival in the Berkshires.
lead_paragraph: The soprano Renée Fleming and the Tony Award-winning actress Chita Rivera will be part of the 2014 main-stage season at the Williamstown Theater Festival in Massachusetts, the company announced on Thursday.

headline: For Blackstone, a Pot of Gold Remains Out of Reach
abstract: The world’s biggest private equity fund, known as Blackstone Capital Partners V, represents a potentially lucrative source of profit for Blackstone — but one that remains locked up for the immediate future.
lead_paragraph: Eight years after its inception, the biggest private equity fund in history has yet to meet its own minimum expectations.

headline: California Syrahs, on Such a Winter’s Day
abstract: With a nod to France, these wines show growth in both character and power.
lead_paragraph: California syrah seemed like a losing proposition back in 2010. Through the 1990s, growers had bet big on the grape. Plantings of syrah in California increased from fewer than 200 acres in 1990 to more than 17,000 by 2004. But sales of syrah wines crashed, and the pace of planting slowed to a trickle.

headline: Race Gap on Conventional Loans
abstract: A new report finds that minority borrowers have been largely shut out of the conventional mortgage market.
lead_paragraph: African-American and Hispanic borrowers have been largely shut out of the conventional mortgage market, according to a new report from Zillow and the National Urban League. Citing 2012 loan data reported under the Home Mortgage Disclosure Act, along with results from a Zillow poll of 700 mortgage applicants in December, the analysis found that whites accounted for about 69 percent of all conventional mortgage applications. The share of applications filed by blacks was under 3 percent; Hispanics represented only 5 percent.

headline: Bette in Spokane Blogging
abstract: The anti-SOTU story, debunked.
lead_paragraph: So, I wondered about “Bette in Spokane”, mentioned in the official GOP SOTU response. I wondered how she could face a $700 a month increase in premiums, and speculated that she must have had “a really bare-bones policy offering hardly any protection.”

headline: Finding Common Ground on the State of the Union
keywords: ['Education (Pre-School)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Law and Legislation', 'Minimum Wage', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Two economists of different persuasions see opportunities for bipartisan progress – and some areas of contention — in President Obama’s speech.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant Treasury secretary for economic policy from 2006 to 2009.

headline: An Employer Tells Congress the Health Care Mandate Could Triple His Costs
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business', 'United States Economy', 'Working Hours']
abstract: The issue, as the Republicans and their witnesses at the hearing they convened see it, is that the law defines full-time employment as working 30 hours a week, rather than 40.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, while many were preparing for President Obama’s State of the Union address, Republican members of the House Ways and Means Committee dived deep into the Affordable Care Act’s employer mandate.

headline: Goldman Awards Blankfein $14.7 Million in Stock Bonus
abstract: Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, was awarded company stock worth $14.7 million as part of his 2013 package, about 10.5 percent more than in the previous year.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:20 p.m. |  Goldman Sachs’s board granted its chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein, restricted shares worth $14.7 million as part of his pay package for 2013, according to a filing made public on Thursday.

headline: Japanese Cuisine, From Scratch
abstract: RameNesque, a Japanese cafe, fits right in with the homespun gestalt that is part of Peekskill’s charm.
lead_paragraph: On two different visits to RameNesque, a new Japanese cafe with a brisk takeout business in downtown Peekskill, we couldn’t get our table to stand still. Despite our best efforts — jamming folded paper napkins under the stand, jostling the table this way and that — the wobbles won out. Chopsticks, water glasses, ramen bowls, ramekins — all skittered around on the high-gloss wooden table top like so many pointers on a Ouija board.

headline: Maher Wants His Show to Decide a House Race
abstract: The viewers of “Real Time With Bill Maher” will be asked which member of the House deserves most to lose in November.
lead_paragraph: Bill Maher makes little effort to hide his own contempt for many politicians, most of them Republicans. Now, he wants to take it to the next level: finding one he might be able to help oust from office.

headline: Two Takes on a Tiger Couple
abstract: How the photographer Barbara Probst captured Amy Chua and Jed Rubenfeld from two cameras at the same moment.
lead_paragraph: The two photographs above, which accompany Jennifer Szalai’s article about Amy Chua and Jed Rubenfeld in this weekend’s magazine, weren’t made with mirrors or by changing their poses — they were produced by two separate cameras that fired at the same moment. The photographer Barbara Probst, who shot the couple (authors of the new book “Triple Threat: How Three Unlikely Traits Explain the Rise and Fall of Cultural Groups in America”) in her first effort for the magazine, is known for her simultaneous exposures. Recently, I asked her some questions about her work.

headline: Vintage Auction Catalogs With Personal Provenance
abstract: A repository for old auction catalogs, and George D. Horst’s private art collection in Reading, Pa., goes to auction.
lead_paragraph: MORRISTOWN, N.J. — Vintage auction catalogs, despite competition from growing online databases, still sell by the tens of thousands a year from the offices here of the specialist dealer Jeffrey Eger. Well, not quite offices.

headline: Emerging Markets Inflow Numbers Point to Exit by Bond Investors
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: When bond investors pull out — as they have been doing in Turkey, Brazil, India and other such countries, according to data from a financial trade group — the broader economic effect could be pronounced, a new paper argues.
lead_paragraph: With investors on edge following the recent weeks of turmoil in emerging markets, the release this week of updated capital inflow data by the Institute of International Finance could not have been better timed.

headline: When the Prescription Is Fresh Air
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: At the innovative 1912 Cherokee Apartments on the Upper East Side, many windows double as doors to the outside.
lead_paragraph: Can a tenement window be “truly magnificent”? That’s what the architect Dan Allen says about the newly installed windows at the 1912 Cherokee Apartments, just off York Avenue, between East 77th and East 78th Streets.

headline: Godwin Help Us
abstract: Criticism is persecution.
lead_paragraph: Not my line, alas — Jonathan Chait uses it as the excerpt for his report on the WSJ’s editorial defending Tom Perkins, now famed for comparing criticism of the one percent to Kristallnacht. And boy, am I jealous.

headline: Google’s Sale of Motorola Could Help Samsung
abstract: Google’s imminent sale of Motorola Mobility to the Chinese computer maker Lenovo will probably bolster Samsung Electronics while putting other makers of Android phones, like HTC, Sony and Huawei, in a tough spot.
lead_paragraph: Google’s imminent sale of its handset business to the Chinese computer maker Lenovo could benefit Samsung Electronics more than Lenovo and make life more difficult for other Android manufacturers.

headline: An Education in India’s Diverse Cuisines
abstract: Kolam’s menu provides an excellent introduction to the regional diversity of the country’s food, touching down in places that span the subcontinent from the Goa coast north to Kashmir.
lead_paragraph: In India, kolam is the decorative practice of stenciling rice-flour patterns on the ground. In Newtown, Kolam is a restaurant, one that evokes that art form in a combination of geometric designs that color its dark velour wall coverings and valances.

headline: The Source | James Turrell
abstract: Doug Aitken interviews the artist James Turrell.
lead_paragraph: Doug Aitken interviews the artist James Turrell.

headline: Tappan Zee Crane Arrives by Boat
abstract: A huge crane arrived in New York Harbor in January, after a 6,000-mile ocean journey from San Francisco. It will be used to build the new Tappan Zee Bridge across the Hudson River.
lead_paragraph: A huge crane arrived in New York Harbor in January, after a 6,000-mile ocean journey from San Francisco. It will be used to build the new Tappan Zee Bridge across the Hudson River.

headline: Times Minute | Ads That Track You
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Derricks and Cranes', 'Tappan Zee Bridge', 'Super Bowl', 'Bridges and Tunnels']
abstract: Also on the Minute, Ukraine's president goes on sick leave and a 400-foot crane arrives in New York.
lead_paragraph: Also on the Minute, Ukraine's president goes on sick leave and a 400-foot crane arrives in New York.

headline: ‘Whoever’ Ad
abstract: The organization Mississippi Conservatives released an attack ad against State Senator Chris McDaniel, who is running against Senator Thad Cochran in a Republican primary.
lead_paragraph: The organization Mississippi Conservatives released an attack ad against State Senator Chris McDaniel, who is running against Senator Thad Cochran in a Republican primary.

headline: Oscar Shorts, From Surreal to Oh So Real
abstract: The short-film nominees for Oscars — animated, live action and documentaries, from around the world — can be viewed together in three collections.
lead_paragraph: You may have seen the eye-popping 3-D animated Disney short “Get a Horse!” In this spicy visual appetizer, which accompanies the megahit “Frozen,” Mickey and Minnie Mouse and their friends Horace Horsecollar and Clarabelle Cow enjoy a hayride until the appearance of Peg-Leg Pete, who tries to run them off the road. As Mickey and Horace fight with Pete, these hand-drawn, black-and-white animated characters are forced through the screen, emerging as colorful CGI versions of themselves. A frantic battle royal ensues as a raft of Disney characters jump in and out of the screen and chase one another in circles.

headline: The Mythic and Heroic, Just Inches Tall
abstract: “Renaissance and Baroque Bronzes From the Hill Collection,” at the Frick Collection, is a sensational show of big-statement bronzes.
lead_paragraph: In case you haven’t noticed, the Frick Collection has been on something of a bronze statuette kick over the last decade. During that time, it has mounted five monographic or survey shows of these small collectibles, all organized by the estimable curator Denise Allen.

headline: Times Minute | Ads That Track You
abstract: Also on the Minute, Ukraine’s president goes on sick leave and a 400-foot crane arrives in New York.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Southwest and JetBlue Buy Washington Airport Rights
abstract: The airlines acquired the takeoff and landing rights that the Justice Department required American and US Airways to sell before they completed their merger.
lead_paragraph: Southwest Airlines and JetBlue Airways said on Thursday that they had bought the takeoff and landing rights at Ronald Reagan National Airport in Washington that the Justice Department required American Airlines and US Airways to sell as a condition of their merger.

headline: It’s Him, Not Her
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Families and Family Life', 'Children and Childhood', 'Parenting', 'Dating and Courtship']
abstract: Addressing a child’s angry interface with a smartphone, amorous sounds, a tight guest list and unwanted child care duties.
lead_paragraph: I have a mostly sweet and fairly well-behaved 10-year-old son. But sometimes he is really mean to Siri (the simulated assistant on my phone’s operating system). He’ll say things like, “You’re a stupid idiot, Siri.” Do you think we should punish him for statements like these? If he ever called an actual person a stupid idiot, he would be in huge trouble.

headline: How Much Is Too Much to Pay for Jos. A. Bank?
abstract: Men’s Wearhouse has said it is prepared to raise its bid to buy Jos. A. Bank, but analysts caution that the retailer can overpay.
lead_paragraph: Men’s Wearhouse may be willing to raise its bid to buy its rival, the men’s suit retailer Jos. A. Bank, but analysts on Wall Street are wondering: How much is too much?

headline: Is It Love, or Stockholm Syndrome?
abstract: In “Labor Day,” set in a small town in 1987, an escaped criminal takes shelter with a woman and her son and soon wins them over.
lead_paragraph: The heaving, bubbling euphemism driving Jason Reitman’s “Labor Day” is a juicy homemade peach pie just out of the oven. Its creator, Frank (Josh Brolin), is an escaped prisoner who shows Adele (Kate Winslet), a single mother held captive in her own home, the secrets of baking. That lesson takes place over a sleepy holiday weekend in September 1987. Carefully noting every detail is her nerdy 13-year-old son, Henry (Gattlin Griffith).

headline: Why Can’t I Have a Washing Machine?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Cooperatives', 'Washing Machines and Dryers', 'Plumbing']
abstract: Questions about laundry equipment; an heir’s access to a deceased shareholder’s apartment; and who pays for window replacement in a co-op.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a new weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: The Source | Liz Glynn
abstract: Doug Aitken interviews the artist Liz Glynn.
lead_paragraph: Doug Aitken interviews the artist Liz Glynn.

headline: Dutch Masterwork, Under Reconstruction
abstract: The documentary “Tim’s Vermeer” tracks one inventor’s bid to determine whether the Dutch master had used optical devices to paint “The Music Lesson” and his own effort to recreate it.
lead_paragraph: “Tim’s Vermeer” is a little documentary that tracks how one man’s love turned into revenge. The title figure — well, one, anyway — is Tim Jenison, a scientist, inventor and restless hobbyist with deep pockets and famous friends, including Penn Jillette, who produced the movie, and Teller, who directed. In the 1980s, Mr. Jenison founded NewTek, a hardware and software company that scored an early success with the creation of Video Toaster, an affordable desktop video-production tool. Since then, this autodidact, now in his late 50s, has done this and that, including embarking on a multiyear odyssey to discover whether the movie’s other, better-known, subject, the Dutch master Johannes Vermeer (1632-75), used any kind of optical tools when he created his extraordinary paintings.

headline: It Started With a $2 Poster
abstract: A couple’s Japanese period paintings, collected on instinct and put in context by a wise curator, are on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: The Japanese galleries at the Metropolitan Museum have been pulling crowds since John T. Carpenter became curator in 2011. He has taken the permanent collection, shaken it up, threaded it through with strategic loans and, like a good teacher, unfurled it logically around graspable themes. Who could resist a show that tells the art history of a complex culture, as Mr. Carpenter did last year, entirely in images of birds?

headline: Box, an Online Storage Start-Up, Is Said to File for an I.P.O.
abstract: Box, the online storage and document-sharing company, was able to file its I.P.O. paperwork confidentially because of the JOBS Act, a law meant to make it easier for companies to go public.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:21 p.m. | Box, an online storage and document-sharing provider, has filed confidential paperwork to go public, a person briefed on the matter said on Thursday.

headline: Food Matters | The Godfather of Hipster American Dining Serves Up a Fresh Dish: Enlightenment
abstract: Taavo Somer, the co-founder of Freemans Restaurant, is playing against his reputation by turning his Williamsburg eatery Isa into a sort of New Age community center, complete with Buddhist wine tastings and classes in wind-sock-making.
lead_paragraph: It’s been almost a decade since Taavo Somer co-opened Freemans, the seminal Lower East Side gastropub that ushered in a new epoch of American comfort food and rustic, taxidermy-heavy restaurant design. Since then, he’s launched several other restaurants and expanded his atavistic men’s wear line, Freemans Sporting Club. The man once described as the “patron saint of hipsters” also became a dad, trimmed his beard, began spending more time at his farmhouse upstate and loudly proclaimed his distaste for the culture he’d come to represent.

headline: Crystalline Glory, Frozen in Time
keywords: ['Movies', 'Ice Dancing', 'Figure Skating', 'Dance on Camera Festival', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Dancing']
abstract: Lincoln Center’s Dance on Camera festival revisits the choreographic glories of the old ice-skating extravaganzas.
lead_paragraph: Before she directed “The Fabulous Ice Age,” Keri Pickett was a photographer who had never contemplated making a film. Her uncle, the former figure skater Roy Blakey — an avid collector of ice-show memorabilia — changed all that.

headline: Yahoo Reports Attack on Mail Accounts
abstract: In yet another reminder of the importance of using different passwords across different websites, Yahoo said that attackers had attempted to gain access to Yahoo Mail accounts using usernames and passwords collected from a breach on a third party site.
lead_paragraph: Another day, another breach.

headline: Do Not Look Down in This Class
abstract: “Peter Brook: The Tightrope,” a documentary directed by the subject’s son, peeks in on the theatrical sage as he teaches a class of actors.
lead_paragraph: “The actor’s gift,” according to the director and theatrical sage Peter Brook, “is the connection between pure imagination and the body itself.” For him, the technique of acting is at once physical and metaphysical, a discipline of the face, limbs, voice and spirit. “Peter Brook: The Tightrope,” a concise new documentary directed by Simon Brook, offers a rare glimpse behind the scenes as its subject (who happens to be the filmmaker’s father) instructs a group of actors in the rigor and simplicity of his method.

headline: Comedy Listings for Jan. 31-Feb. 6
abstract: A guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Theater Listings for Jan. 31-Feb. 6
abstract: A guide to theater productions in New York City, with a special note of shows in previews or about to open.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: childhood obesity, testosterone therapy and the amount of exercise that might save you from an early death.
lead_paragraph: In the news: childhood obesity, testosterone therapy and the amount of exercise that might save you from an early death.

headline: Movie Listings for Jan. 31-Feb. 6
abstract: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select film series.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings for Jan. 31-Feb. 6
abstract: A selected guide to performances of indie rock, electro-pop, pop-punk and more in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Obama Reaches Out After Shooting of Nashville Student
abstract: The president called “heartbreaking” the killing of a 15-year-old with a handgun less than 48 hours before the president’s visit.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — President Obama sought on Thursday to comfort a high school community devastated by the death of a 15-year-old student who was killed with a handgun less than 48 hours before the president’s arrival here.

headline: Gospel Without Hallelujahs
abstract: The operatic tenor Lawrence Brownlee performed works from his “Spiritual Sketches” album on Wednesday at the Allen Room.
lead_paragraph: Anyone unfamiliar with the traditional African-American spirituals that the great operatic tenor Lawrence Brownlee performed on Wednesday at the Allen Room can be forgiven for mistaking them for concert art songs. If Mr. Brownlee and his accompanist and arranger Damien Sneed didn’t tell you, you might not realize that beloved spirituals like “There Is a Balm in Gilead,” “Sometimes I Feel Like a Motherless Child” and “Down by the Riverside” belong to an oral tradition of gospel music distinct from carefully notated classical art songs.

headline: Super Bowl Fever Hits Midtown, but Many There Aren’t Catching It
abstract: Traffic jams and a clog of pedestrians on the sidewalks this week are frustrating drivers, delaying students and costing vendors business.
lead_paragraph: The orchids are dying, and Cliff Jacobs blames the Super Bowl.

headline: The Other Super Bowl Underdog
abstract: Compared with previous artists who have played to the huge television audiences on the coveted Super Bowl stage, Bruno Mars seemed to some to lack stature and longevity.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Bruno Mars takes the stage at MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., this chilly Sunday evening to perform at the Super Bowl halftime show, in front of the biggest audience he’s ever played to, he can take some solace that his set only needs to be about 12 minutes long.

headline: A Clarinet Does Scenes
abstract: The clarinetist David Krakauer oversees a multimedia tribute to music drawn from movies with Jewish themes at the Museum of Jewish Heritage.
lead_paragraph: The formal and emotional crux of “The Big Picture,” David Krakauer’s 90-minute multimedia tribute to movie music at the Museum of Jewish Heritage, is “Shoah Trilogy,” a medley of themes from films about the Holocaust. Mr. Krakauer’s clarinet girded each with a piercing wail in the premiere on Wednesday night, communicating anguish, outrage and catharsis.

headline: De Blasio to Settle Stop-and-Frisk Suit
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced that the city had reached an agreement with civil rights lawyers who argued that the Police Department’s policy violated minorities’ rights.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced that the city had reached an agreement with civil rights lawyers who argued that the Police Department’s policy violated minorities’ rights.

headline: Need the Best for Your Next Occasion? Call Westminster Palace
abstract: In a fund-raising effort, the authorities at Britain’s Parliament have decided to rent out some of its premises to keep the building in shape.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Overindulgence in food and drink has long been one of the hazards of political life for members of Britain’s Parliament. But no longer. Abstemiousness seems to be the order of the day.

headline: Digital, Analog and Waterlogged
abstract: A new show at the International Center of Photography examines the evolution of an art in asking, “What is a photograph?”
lead_paragraph: “What Is a Photograph?” asks the title of a disappointing exhibition at the International Center of Photography.

headline: A Woman Whose Ecstasy Ignited a Riot
abstract: Marielle Nitoslawska’s documentary “Breaking the Frame” chronicles the life and achievements of the avant-garde artist Carolee Schneemann.
lead_paragraph: Nicely immersive if largely uninformative, “Breaking the Frame” is best appreciated as a chance to spend time with the painter, filmmaker, author, performance artist and epic cat lover Carolee Schneemann (born 1939). One of the leading female figures of American avant-garde cinema, Ms. Schneemann is best known for “Fuses” (1965), a gorgeous onetime scandal that features explicit images of her having sex with her partner, the composer James Tenney. “I can consider ‘Fuses,’ ” Ms. Schneemann once wrote, “not simply as a film but in its revelatory cultural erotic intrusion — a vision (message) of genital sexuality and female pleasure which vitalized and agitated the art world.”

headline: Jazz Listings for Jan. 31-Feb. 6
abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: A Last Look at Old Paris, Before Demolition
abstract: Charles Marville, a 19th-century photographer, captured hundreds of picturesque street views of Paris before the Haussmann Plan obliterated them.
lead_paragraph: In the massive construction site that was late-19th-century Paris, the photographer Charles Marville was just a few steps ahead of the wrecking ball. As an official city photographer working under Napoleon III and his controversial urban planner, Baron Haussmann, Marville recorded some 425 views of narrow, picturesque streets that were to be replaced by Haussmann’s grand boulevards.

headline: Opera and Classical Music Listings for Jan. 31-Feb. 6
abstract: A selected guide to performances of classical music in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Casting a Documentarian’s Eye on Dance’s Past and Its Future
keywords: ['Dancing', 'Dance on Camera Festival', 'Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: Among the films in the Dance on Camera festival are those chronicling the life of Martha Hill and a ballet school in Havana.
lead_paragraph: Dance class: It’s a place that we rarely associate with political skirmishes, cultural upheavals or socioeconomic pressures. But two films in the 42nd Dance on Camera festival, which begins on Friday at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center, remind us that the studio, the ballet barre, the halls of college dance departments — just like any social space — are realms where all of these tensions play out, in both quiet and dramatic ways.

headline: Dance Listings for Jan. 31-Feb. 6
abstract: A selected guide to dance performances in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Foreigners Behaving Badly
abstract: Should it be easier to revoke green cards? Does mild criminal behavior warrant some sort of punishment?

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for Jan. 31-Feb. 6
abstract: A critical guide to the visual arts in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Jan. 31-Feb. 6
abstract: A listing of cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: ‘You Make the Call’

headline: For One-Night Lotharios, It’s Time to Face the Truth
abstract: In the sex comedy “That Awkward Moment,” three best buddies make a pact not to be emotionally tangled with women, but then proceed to break the rules.
lead_paragraph: Are you dating or just hooking up? According to Jason (Zac Efron), who narrates “That Awkward Moment,” a vile, witless sex comedy set in contemporary Manhattan, the dreaded word that signals danger to a smug, self-imagined stud is a post-coital “So?” Spoken by a woman wondering if their casual relationship will proceed to the next level — dating — it is a clear warning that the time has come to run for the hills.

headline: Goldman Deal Threatens Danish Government
abstract: When Denmark gave the company approval to buy a stake in its state utility, the Socialist People’s Party withdrew its ministers from the country’s governing coalition.
lead_paragraph: There are groundbreaking business deals. And then there are ones that threaten to break up governments.

headline: Spare Times for Jan. 31-Feb. 6
abstract: A listing of cultural activities, with special note of Black History Month and Super Bowl events, in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Lunar New Year Celebrations (Friday and Sunday) This weekend, not all the talk about the Year of the Horse will be referring to the Denver Broncos’ showdown with the Seattle Seahawks. For Friday is the first day of the Lunar New Year — this year in celebration of the horse — and events are scheduled all weekend in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Charge Sheet Against Al Jazeera Journalists in Egypt
abstract: A translation of the complete statement by Egyptian prosecutors charging 20 journalists working for Al Jazeera with joining a terrorist group and broadcasting false news.
lead_paragraph: As our colleague David Kirkpatrick reported, Egyptian prosecutors said on Wednesday that they were charging 20 journalists working for Al Jazeera with conspiring with a terrorist group and broadcasting false images.

headline: Thrilling to the Brrroom of a Renegade Cohort
abstract: The documentary “12 O’Clock Boys” follows a youth through his initiation into a group of dirt bike riders who like to taunt the police.
lead_paragraph: “12 O’Clock Boys” packs more life into its 72 minutes than many longer documentaries do. But in the movie’s compressed experience, the director, Lotfy Nathan, takes cues from his roving subjects: young dirt bike daredevils who pour into Baltimore streets en masse for the fleeting thrills of speed, danger and the perfect wheelie.

headline: Former Chief of S.E.C. to Shift Consulting Job
abstract: Mary L. Schapiro said her time would be spent on an array of university lectures, speaking engagements and corporate board work.
lead_paragraph: Mary L. Schapiro spent four years as head of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Her next act was far shorter.

headline: Syria Talks May Yield Little, but Give Cover to Those Defying Hard-Liners
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'International Relations']
abstract: Government supporters complained that the opposition delegation could not claim to represent all opponents, let alone all Syrians, while opposition activists said they would look weak if they failed to win concessions.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The images from spotless, quiet Geneva were striking — Syrian government and opposition figures sitting down together for the first time to discuss ending their country’s war — but inside war-torn Syria, patience wore thin as the talks dragged on with few results.

headline: Libya Says Goldman Didn’t Explain Options
abstract: The Libyan Investment Authority says Goldman did not provide confirmations of trades until weeks, or in some cases months, after they were made, or require the authority to sign the normal agreement required to trade in derivatives.
lead_paragraph: In early 2008 — months before the financial crisis began — Goldman Sachs put $1.2 billion of Libyan money into leveraged bets that six stocks would rise over the next three years.

headline: Some Toyota Model Sales Halted Over Seat Problem
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: Toyota has told its dealers to stop selling about 36,000 vehicles because a component on the heated seats does not comply with a federal safety standard for flame retardants.
lead_paragraph: Toyota has told its dealers to stop selling about 36,000 vehicles of its most popular models because a component on the heated seats does not comply with a federal safety standard for flame retardants, the automaker said on Thursday.

headline: Your Child Is Choosing a College; Time to Tag Along
abstract: The romantic comedy “At Middleton” is also a delicate film about two people confronting their flawed marriages.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in Manhattan.

headline: Its Great Lake Shriveled, Iran Confronts Crisis of Water Supply
abstract: President Hassan Rouhani has identified water as a national security issue, and nowhere is the crisis more pronounced than at Lake Urmia, once one of the largest salt lakes in the world.
lead_paragraph: LAKE URMIA, Iran — After driving for 15 minutes over the bottom of what was once Iran’s largest lake, a local environmental official stepped out of his truck, pushed his hands deep into his pockets and silently wandered into the great dry plain, as if searching for water he knew he would never find.

headline: The Road to Reinvention
abstract: “Somewhere Slow” centers on a woman who impulsively abandons her home and family after witnessing a convenience store robbery.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in Brooklyn and Los Angeles.

headline: Pulling Apart the Numbers on Women in the Texas Legislature
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: While Wendy Davis’s run for governor of Texas has drawn a lot of attention, only 21 percent of the state’s legislators there are women, and the number of female candidates nationwide has stagnated.
lead_paragraph: State Senator Wendy Davis has used her 11-hour filibuster against abortion-restricting legislation to propel a run for governor, and Texas’ hottest political race centers on whether her supporters can usher a Democratic woman into a governor’s mansion occupied by Republican men for two decades.

headline: He’s in Love, but No Closer to Figuring It Out
abstract: The drama “Brightest Star” focuses on romantic relationships, using a young man as the focus.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday.

headline: Nassau County District Attorney Upends Race for House Seat
abstract: Kathleen M. Rice, who has won national attention with crackdowns on drunken driving, said on Wednesday that she would seek the seat being vacated by Carolyn McCarthy.
lead_paragraph: When Carolyn McCarthy, among the nation’s most recognizable champions of gun control, announced this month that she would be retiring from Congress after 18 years, a number of names of possible Democratic successors were floated in Nassau County political circles. But the woman who stepped into the race this week may be too formidable to stop.

headline: Oil Takes Off as One-Firehouse County Plays Catch-Up
keywords: ['Fires and Firefighters', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Growth in the energy industry has come with increased traffic accidents in La Salle County, and the fire department is now being bolstered with professionals to provide relief to its volunteers.
lead_paragraph: COTULLA — Richard Prado has learned a number of rules in his six years as a firefighter. Among the most important, he says, is to know your equipment.

headline: In the Event of an Air Emergency, Remember What Alf Said
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety']
abstract: You’ve heard it all before, so airlines are enlivening their in-flight safety videos, while bringing buzz to their brands.
lead_paragraph: The spoof movie “Airplane!” is becoming the basis for something real, 34 years after its release.

headline: Four Ignore the Election at Road’s End
abstract: The Republican candidates for lieutenant governor in Texas are not yet worried about the Democratic opponent. They are worried about each other, and fighting to stay to the right.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for The Tribune.

headline: Hong Kong Paper Ousts Top Editor, Stirring Concern
abstract: Ming Pao’s history as a serious, independent paper has given it outsize influence, but it might be the latest victim of the mainland’s effort to rein in the media here.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — This city’s Ming Pao newspaper has long stood for sober independence in a media market that is both brashly commercial and buffeted by political winds from China, its reporters pursuing and often breaking stories that irk the territory’s overseers in Beijing.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: A Central Player in the Financial Crisis Speaks
abstract: In Joe Berlinger’s documentary “Hank: Five Years from the Brink,” Henry M. Paulson Jr., the former Treasury secretary, works his way through a timeline.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in New York and Los Angeles.

headline: When Biography Trumps Substance
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: People in Representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers’s own district are flocking to Obamacare, which she opposes. How ... awkward.
lead_paragraph: SPOKANE, Wa. — Only the snarkiest would not be open to the likable life story of Representative Cathy McMorris Rodgers, the Eastern Washington politician who gave the “official” Republican response to the president’s State of the Union speech. She’s a farm girl from a big empty county just north of here, first in her family to attend college, mother of three, a rare woman in the retrograde men’s club of her party’s leadership.

headline: High Stakes for Agencies, and Products, at Super Bowl
abstract: Sponsors hope to win attention and praise for their expensive ads, but the commercials also have to sell something.
lead_paragraph: REMEMBER the line from “Animal Farm” that “all animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others”? On Sunday, the stakes will be high for the sponsors of Super Bowl XLVIII, but for some the stakes are higher than for others.

headline: 92 Air Force Officers Suspended for Cheating on Their Missile Exam
keywords: ['Cheating', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Air Force officials say they have retested about 500 launch officers at the nation’s three bases that oversee the country’s arsenal of 450 intercontinental ballistic missiles, and that all but 22 of them passed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Air Force said Thursday that it had now suspended 92 officers at Malmstrom Air Force Base — nearly half of the nuclear launch crew there — in a cheating scandal, and it acknowledged a “systemic problem” in the culture of the team that is entrusted to launch intercontinental ballistic missiles.

lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in Queens; Los Angeles; and Edgewater, N.J.

headline: Panama: 32 of 35 Detained North Koreans to Be Freed
abstract: The crew members of a North Korean freighter have been held since July, when Soviet-era jets, engines and antiaircraft missiles from Cuba were found on board.
lead_paragraph: After months of investigation, Panama’s chief prosecutor said Thursday that she would not file charges against 32 of 35 crew members of a North Korean freighter that was seized in July when Soviet-era jets, engines and antiaircraft missiles from Cuba were found on board. Immigration authorities are preparing to return most of the crew members to North Korea. But the captain, first officer and political officer will remain in Panama and face arms trafficking charges. Panamanian officials indicated in October that most of the crew would be released, but the prosecutor’s office completed its investigation only this week. The seizure of the freighter, the 450-foot Chong Chon Gang, near the Panama Canal caused a diplomatic quarrel among Panama, Cuba and North Korea. A United Nations Security Council committee has been investigating whether the shipment violated sanctions against North Korea over its nuclear weapons program.

headline: Staking Out Her Place Among Men Atop N.F.L.
abstract: Tracy Perlman turned her love of sports into a marketing career and became a member of the very small club of women in senior positions in major professional leagues.
lead_paragraph: When Tracy Perlman started working for the N.F.L. the day after graduating from Hofstra in 1992, she could hardly have imagined what she sees now as she winds her way to her office: Midtown’s streets clogged with redirected traffic as banners and video boards pay homage to this year’s big game, the first outdoor cold-weather Super Bowl.

headline: Egypt Tries to Reassure Journalists From Abroad
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: The government told foreign correspondents that they are free to work in Egypt after prosecutors accused 20 journalists for Al Jazeera television of conspiring with the Muslim Brotherhood.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The government on Thursday tried to reassure foreign correspondents that they are free to report in Egypt after prosecutors filed criminal charges accusing 20 journalists for Al Jazeera television of conspiring with the Muslim Brotherhood.

lead_paragraph: The haul of counterfeit swag sprawled across 15 feet of prime display table in a Midtown Manhattan hotel.

headline: Concussions Show Decline Of 13 Percent, N.F.L. Says
abstract: Players had 228 concussions in the preseason and the regular season, down from 261 in 2012, but some experts questioned the numbers.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. said that the number of concussions in the league had declined 13 percent this season thanks to improved medical diagnoses, stiffer penalties for striking with a helmet and fewer practices.

headline: Dalton School Apologizes for Screening Slavery Satire
keywords: ['Slavery', 'Apologies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Movies', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: The edgy and comical treatment of slavery in the mockumentary, “C.S.A.,” provoked complaints, and the private school organized meetings to apologize.
lead_paragraph: The Dalton School, one of New York City’s most prestigious private schools, has apologized after screening a satirical movie about a world in which the South won the Civil War.

headline: Responding to Critics, Gynecology Board Reverses Ban on Treating Male Patients
abstract: The decision by the American Board of Obstetrics and Gynecology was a reversal of a September ban and followed partial concessions it had made in an effort to mollify critics.
lead_paragraph: After months of protest from doctors and patients, a professional group that certifies obstetrician-gynecologists has lifted a ban it imposed in September and now says its members are free to treat men.

abstract: In “The Wait,” a call from a stranger unsettles a family whose mother recently died.
lead_paragraph: Opens on Friday in New York and Los Angeles.

headline: Pete Burns, Rodeo Cowboy Who Coached Champions, Dies at 85
abstract: Burns also owned a company that supplied one of the meanest bucking bulls in the history of the sport.
lead_paragraph: Pete Burns, a former professional rodeo cowboy and nationally known college rodeo coach who owned one of the most intractable bucking bulls of the 20th century, died on Sunday at his home in Laramie, Wyo. He was 85.

headline: Scarlett Johansson and Oxfam, Torn Apart by Israeli Company Deal
abstract: The actress’s endorsement of a company with a factory in an area of the West Bank that Palestinians envision as part of a future independent state has created an international political storm.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — “Start with plain water and bubbles. Mix in the perfect flavor,” suggests Scarlett Johansson in the ad that is part of her new endorsement deal with SodaStream, the Israeli company that manufactures home carbonation systems.

headline: The Young White Faces of Slavery
abstract: The pale skin and smooth hair of the children overturned a set of Northern expectations about the appearance of people enslaved in the South.
lead_paragraph: For Northern readers scanning the Jan. 30, 1864, issue of Harper’s Weekly for news from the South, a large engraving on page 69 brought the war home in an unexpected way. Drawn from a photograph, it featured eight recently freed slaves from Union-occupied New Orleans. At the back of the portrait stood three adults, Wilson Chinn, Mary Johnson and Robert Whitehead. In the foreground were five children — Charles Taylor, Rebecca Huger, Rosa Downs, Augusta Broujey and Isaac White — ranging in age from 7 to 11. Their gaze was trained on the camera, but in the context of the magazine, the effect was that they all seemed to be looking at the reader.

headline: ‘Framework’ for Talks on Mideast in Progress
abstract: The Obama administration, seeking to jump-start negotiations between Israelis and Palestinians, hopes to complete an accord that would set terms for final talks, a State Department official said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Seeking to jump-start peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians, the Obama administration hopes to complete a “framework” accord within a few weeks, which would set the terms for a final negotiation, a senior State Department official said in a conference call with Jewish leaders on Thursday.
