abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Questions Fly in Storm That Stopped Atlanta
abstract: While Gov. Nathan Deal of Georgia has been contrite after Atlanta was gripped by an icy paralysis during a snowstorm this week, Mayor Kasim Reed has rejected criticism.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Anyone who has listened to Kasim Reed, the former entertainment lawyer who became Atlanta’s mayor in 2010, knows the man who calls himself a street fighter likes to be forceful when he makes a point.

headline: White House Urges China to Act on Journalists’ Visas
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Newspapers', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: The statement was the latest public effort on behalf of reporters for Bloomberg and The New York Times thwarted in their work by visa delays.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House said Thursday that it is “deeply concerned” with China’s treatment of foreign journalists and expressed disappointment that Austin Ramzy, a New York Times reporter, had been forced to leave the country.

headline: Second-Class Noncitizens
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Legal status without the option of naturalization is un-American.
lead_paragraph: REPUBLICAN leaders in the House of Representatives on Thursday unveiled an agenda for immigration reform. It is a welcome sign that seven months after the Senate passed a comprehensive bill that included a path to citizenship for the 11 million immigrants now in the country illegally, there might be movement on the issue this year.

headline: The Matrix of Manning
abstract: Peyton Manning uses series of terms linked to common words to call and disguise plays, signals that can change week to week or even during games.
lead_paragraph: Peyton Manning is a cerebral leader who has more authority than any other N.F.L. quarterback to call his own plays. Even casual fans cannot fail to notice how he waves his arms, screams and points before each play to communicate with his teammates and simultaneously try to deceive defenses.

headline: Prosecutors Lay Out List of Ex-Mayor’s Schemes
abstract: As the trial of C. Ray Nagin began Thursday, federal prosecutors presented evidence of a series of bribes and kickbacks, all of which, Mr. Nagin’s lawyer said, could be explained.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — In the opening salvos of the trial of C. Ray Nagin, this city’s former mayor, federal prosecutors described on Thursday a series of kickback schemes they say Mr. Nagin engaged in over the course of his two terms, setting up what promises to be a thorough dissection of the way business was done at City Hall during the Nagin years.

headline: Hoboken Site Developer Dismisses Law Firm
abstract: Rockefeller Group said it had terminated its contract with the firm, Wolff & Samson, thus ending a relationship that began in 2007.
lead_paragraph: Rockefeller Group, a real estate developer whose proposed office complex in Hoboken, N.J., is at the center of allegations that associates of Gov. Chris Christie threatened to withhold Hurricane Sandy relief money from the city unless the project received approval, has severed its connections with a law firm with close ties to the governor.

headline: We Are Giving Ourselves Cancer
abstract: Overused CT scans are exposing patients to dangerous levels of radiation.
lead_paragraph: DESPITE great strides in prevention and treatment, cancer rates remain stubbornly high and may soon surpass heart disease as the leading cause of death in the United States. Increasingly, we and many other experts believe that an important culprit may be our own medical practices: We are silently irradiating ourselves to death.

headline: Anti-Republican Group Digs Into Lane Closings
abstract: American Bridge 21st Century, a well-funded organization that rakes up muck on Republican politicians, is sparing no expense to investigate the bridge scandal involving Gov. Chris Christie.
lead_paragraph: The roster of organizations seeking documents related to the scheme to tie up traffic near the George Washington Bridge includes many of the usual suspects: newspapers, local broadcasters and TV networks.

headline: The Opportunity Coalition
abstract: President Obama should devote the remainder of his term to building governing structures for future presidents for years to come.
lead_paragraph: President Obama can spend the remainder of his term planting a few more high-tech hubs, working on reforming the patent law and doing the other modest things he mentioned in his State of the Union address. And if he did that, he might do some marginal good, and he would manage the stately decline of his presidency during its final few years.

headline: Gary Arlington, a Force in Underground Comic Books, Is Dead at 75
abstract: Mr. Arlington was a young man armed with thousands of comics when he opened his San Francisco Comic Book Company.
lead_paragraph: Gary Arlington, who died this month at 75, did not open the San Francisco Comic Book Company because he wanted to create a place where the city’s underground comic artists could meet to mine one another’s unusual minds. He really just needed money, and he hoped to make some by selling thousands of comic books he had been hoarding in his parents’ basement since he was a little boy.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Jan. 30, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Reliving the Invasion of the Beatles
abstract: Shows and film and television screenings are among the activities planned in Brookville, Dix Hills, Port Washington and Sag Harbor in February.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Pomes, who performs John Lennon’s part in Mostly Moptop, the Long Island Beatles tribute band, started planning nearly a year ago for “The Fab ’64 Show,” to take place Feb. 8 at Dix Hills Performing Arts Center.

headline: Talking Troubled Turkey
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Recession and Depression', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The last thing we needed right now was a new economic crisis in a country overwhelmed with political turmoil. Haven’t we heard this one before?
lead_paragraph: O.K., who ordered that? With everything else going on, the last thing we needed was a new economic crisis in a country already racked by political turmoil. True, the direct global spillovers from Turkey, with its Los Angeles-sized economy, won’t be large. But we’re hearing that dreaded word “contagion” — the kind of contagion that once caused a crisis in Thailand to spread across Asia, more recently caused a crisis in Greece to spread across Europe, and now, everyone worries, might cause Turkey’s troubles to spread across the world’s emerging markets.

headline: Wind Simulator? Fox Has Innovations Lined Up for Super Bowl Broadcast
abstract: Software that will be able to show the breezy patterns at MetLife Stadium is among the technologies Fox will use in covering Super Bowl XLVIII.
lead_paragraph: Outside the 21st Century Fox building in Manhattan on Thursday, Terry Bradshaw and the Naked Cowboy were taping a commercial for Pizza Hut that will run Sunday before the Super Bowl.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, January 31, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the day for Friday, January 31, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “We kept waiting for the water to return, but it never did.”

headline: 50 Years Later, the Tributes to the Beatles Still Twist and Shout
abstract: Half a century after the Beatles’ first performance on “The Ed Sullivan Show,” an abundance of concerts and performances around the state will mark the anniversary.
lead_paragraph: The abundance of “Rain” in New Jersey’s entertainment forecast this month is the result of a pop music milestone: Feb. 9, 2014, is the 50th anniversary of the Beatles’ first performance on “The Ed Sullivan Show.”

headline: Bernanke Should Be Thanked
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Emergency Economic Stabilization Act (2008)', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: The departing chairman of the Federal Reserve played a central role in averting a financial meltdown and lifting the nation out of recession.
lead_paragraph: Ben S. Bernanke ascended to the chairmanship of the Federal Reserve eight years ago as a little-known — albeit distinguished — Princeton economics professor who had notched just three years of federal public service.

headline: Beatles Music Without the Moptops
abstract: On the 50th anniversary of the Beatles’ invasion of America, the non-look-alike performers in “All You Need Is Love” will focus on the music.
lead_paragraph: Next weekend will be the 50th anniversary of the Beatles’ invasion of America, and two camps of tribute bands are gearing up to celebrate: the look-alikes (like the Fab Four, who will perform in New Jersey and on Long Island) and those who evoke the sound and spirit but not necessarily the look of the four Liverpudlians (like Mostly Moptop, who will play a set on Long Island that focuses on the group’s early years).

headline: For Christie, a Governor Under Fire, Super Bowl Brings Glee
abstract: The sports marketing extravaganza has marked the re-emergence of the familiar wisecracking, boastful and emotive Chris Christie after weeks of grimaces and apologies.
lead_paragraph: It took the Super Bowl to unleash the old Chris Christie.

headline: A Focus on Insiders in Search for Microsoft C.E.O.
abstract: Microsoft’s search for a new leader appears to be focusing increasingly on internal candidates, including Satya Nadella, a longtime executive who has led the company’s cloud computing initiatives. But the company’s board has not decided yet on a replacement for the departing chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer, according to people briefed on the discussions.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Microsoft’s search for a new leader appears to be focusing increasingly on internal candidates from the company, including Satya Nadella, a longtime executive who has led the company’s initiatives in cloud computing.

headline: Fixing Immigration, in Principle
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Law and Legislation', 'Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Editorials']
abstract: As Republicans creep in the right direction, here’s hoping against hope for a breakthrough on immigration reform this year.
lead_paragraph: What you need to know now that House Republican leaders have unveiled a list of “principles” that have raised hopes for a breakthrough on immigration reform this year:

headline: Salvage Drive for Rare Jewish Mural in Vermont
abstract: The work in Burlington, created in 1910, is among the most complete existing examples of this kind of folk art — and few people knew it existed.
lead_paragraph: BURLINGTON, Vt. — The mural was created inside a synagogue in 1910 by a sign painter named Ben Zion Black, who had just moved to this city’s growing Jewish community from Lithuania. He was paid $200 by the Chai Adam congregation for what became a two-story artwork in a style that was common in Eastern Europe’s painted wooden synagogues. Most vanished in the Holocaust.

headline: A New Day for New Yorkers
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio acted on his promise to reform the abusive and illegal stop-and-frisk program.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio closed a divisive chapter in New York City history Thursday when he announced that his administration had reached an agreement with the civil rights lawyers who challenged the Police Department’s abusive and racially discriminatory stop-and-frisk program in federal court.

headline: Riding a Van to Soccer Practice, With a U.S. Player at the Wheel
abstract: For years when the United States men’s and women’s soccer teams convene for training camps, the players have rolled up in rented vans, almost always driven by a teammate.
lead_paragraph: CARSON, Calif. — One by one, they arrived, a fleet of minivans gliding around the corner and sliding neatly into the enormous parking lot with nary a skid mark. As the vehicles emptied, players in shorts, workout shirts and sweats shook out any kinks and walked down a ramp that led to the fields where they would spend most of the next two hours practicing.

headline: In Boston, Mixed Reaction to Death Penalty Decision in Marathon Bombings Case
abstract: Mayor Martin Walsh opposes the death penalty but said he supported the Justice Department’s decision in the case. Family members of victims offered conflicting reaction.
lead_paragraph: When he was a state lawmaker, Martin J. Walsh, the mayor of Boston, voted against the death penalty. On Thursday, he said that he would vote the same way today.

headline: Football, Pain and Marijuana
abstract: The National Football League should follow the shift in state laws and let players deal with pain as they, and their doctors, see fit.
lead_paragraph: The National Football League prohibits the use of marijuana as part of its broader, longstanding program to prevent substance abuse. It also imposes stiff penalties on players caught breaking the rules.

headline: Corrections: January 31, 2014
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on January 31, 2014.
lead_paragraph: NATIONAL: The Texas Tribune

headline: Who Do You Think You Are? Wrong!
abstract: The Classic Stage Company’s “A Man’s a Man” is a hard-working though uninvolving production of this early work by Bertolt Brecht.
lead_paragraph: Galy Gay, the hapless protagonist of Bertolt Brecht’s 1925 play “A Man’s a Man,” falls victim to several mind games during the course of his brainwashing at the hands of British soldiers stationed in India. But perhaps the most unhappily symbolic trick played upon him, in the Classic Stage Company’s new production of this rarely seen play, is his coerced belief that a pile of barrels draped with a sari is actually an elephant, one that he is duped into trying to sell, thus falling into hot water with the authorities. For despite its often broadly comic tone, this hard-working but uninvolving production moves with the lumbering tread of a pachyderm in no hurry to get to the watering hole.

headline: No More Wasting Time
abstract: An enthusiastic Friday puzzle by Chris A. McGlothlin.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — You don’t get much more “rah-rah” in a puzzle than this. Opening at 1 Across with LET’S DO THIS THING is pretty motivating, so let’s dive in and take a look at what Chris A. McGlothlin hath wrought.

headline: A Year After a Sensational First Round, Mickelson Settles for a So-So One
abstract: Phil Mickelson, who is dealing with a bad back, shot a par 71 in the Phoenix Open, 11 shots higher than his opening 60 in 2013.
lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — He started on the 10th hole, same as last year, but little else about Phil Mickelson’s par 71 in the first round of the Phoenix Open conjured memories of his sterling opening 60 a year ago.

headline: A Violinist’s Triumph Is Ruined by Thieves
abstract: A 1715 Stradivarius violin, valued in “the high seven figures,” was snatched from the arms of Frank Almond, a violinist in the Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra, after a concert this week.
lead_paragraph: It should have been one of those nights musicians live for. Frank Almond, the concertmaster of the Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra for nearly two decades, had just closed a chamber concert in his own “Frankly Music” series with Messiaen’s hushed, eerily intense “Quartet for the End of Time.” Mr. Almond drew the graceful, ringing high notes of the finale from his prized 1715 Stradivarius violin, producing a tone so intensely focused that the audience in the Wisconsin Lutheran College’s 388-seat auditorium sat in awed silence for 20 seconds before applauding.

headline: In Search of Drama, Nascar Alters Playoff Race Again
abstract: The new process ends with a winner-take-all final race among four drivers who survive a series of eliminations.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — In Nascar’s seemingly never-ending search for a playoff system that delivers Game 7 drama and resonates with fans, officials have once again decided to revamp the 10-race Chase for the Sprint Cup.

headline: Half of Class Takes Holiday Off? Soon Whole City May
abstract: Many Asian students will be skipping school in New York on Friday to celebrate the Lunar New Year, and Mayor Bill de Blasio is open to making it an official school holiday.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, Sui Ling Tsang, 49, plans to dress herself and her daughter, Xola, 7, in new red outfits, go out for a special dim sum brunch, and walk around their Chinatown neighborhood looking for the elaborate papier-mâché lion puppets that neighborhood associations parade around from store to store.

headline: In Landrieu Races, Obama Helps and Hinders
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Endorsements', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Elections, Senate', 'Elections, Mayors']
abstract: Two Landrieus face re-election in campaigns that are complicated by the currents of race and history that run through Louisiana, but also by national factors, chief among which is President Obama.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — On a recent morning, Senator Mary L. Landrieu of Louisiana woke up in her childhood bedroom, drank coffee with her parents and headed downtown to help her little brother Mitch keep his job.

headline: Super Bowl Performers Try to Keep Focus on Music
abstract: Renée Fleming, who will perform the national anthem, and Bruno Mars, who will perform during halftime, are hoping their performances are less about spectacle.
lead_paragraph: At a casual glance, Renée Fleming and Bruno Mars may not appear especially similar, but they share common ground in hoping their performances at Sunday’s Super Bowl are more about music and less about spectacle.

headline: Citing Misconduct, Lawyer Seeks Review of Conviction in ’03 Brooklyn Killing
abstract: A lawyer for a man imprisoned for the murder of 19-year-old Mark Fisher cites prosecutorial misconduct in the case and flaws in the highly publicized trial.
lead_paragraph: The murder riveted New York City and stymied detectives for months: What chance meetings and turns of fate led Mark Fisher, a photogenic 19-year-old college football player from New Jersey, to end up shot dead on a quiet Brooklyn street, his body wrapped in a yellow blanket?

headline: Judge Dismisses Suit Accusing Yeshiva University of Hiding Abuse
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Sex Crimes', 'Statutes of Limitations', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Judge John G. Koeltl ruled on Thursday that the lawsuit could not proceed because too many years had elapsed since the abuse took place.
lead_paragraph: A federal lawsuit accusing Yeshiva University of covering up the sexual abuse of dozens of high school students has been thrown out by the judge hearing the case.

headline: Only a Few Miles Separate Manhattan and Iona in a Special Rivalry
abstract: The Gaels host the Jaspers on Friday in the renewal of a rivalry between Catholic universities in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference.
lead_paragraph: The bus ride has not changed since 1946: 8.6 miles, out of the Bronx and up into Westchester County, where one small Catholic university awaits another small Catholic university in perhaps the best basketball rivalry running in New York.

headline: State Health Dept. Defers Action on Troubled Agency
abstract: The New York State Department of Health rescinded its recommendation that a home health care agency, Americare Certified Special Services, be granted an expanded license.
lead_paragraph: The New York State Department of Health on Thursday abruptly withdrew its recommendation that a home health care agency with a checkered past be granted an expanded license, saying that new information had come to its attention and that officials needed more time to evaluate it before a vote on the license.

headline: GoPro Sees Opportunity in Its Amateur Daredevils
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The company, whose camera has become a tool of choice for recording skiing, surfing and other adrenaline-soaked exploits, is now setting its sights on becoming a media company.
lead_paragraph: SAN MATEO, Calif. — Inside the headquarters of GoPro, the video camera maker, there is a racing car, a collection of motorcycles, and drones outfitted with the company’s products. All of them are reminders of the niche that GoPro has carved out as the camera of choice for recording skiing, surfing and other experiences too gnarly for dainty smartphones.

headline: Ailing Knicks Prevail by Thinking Small
abstract: The injury-depleted Knicks went with a small lineup Thursday night, and easily won their fourth straight game.
lead_paragraph: During a 40-second span early Thursday night, Mike Woodson used the phrase “day to day” five times. It was a rapid-fire outpouring from the Knicks’ coach that symbolized the team’s pervasive injuries.

headline: Detroit Plan Is Said to Split Creditors Into 2 Groups
abstract: The city was preparing to resolve its bankruptcy case by dividing its unsecured creditors and treating them differently, according to people briefed on the proposal.
lead_paragraph: Detroit is preparing to resolve its bankruptcy case by splitting its unsecured creditors into two groups and treating them differently, according to people briefed on the city’s plan.

headline: Nets’ Blatche May Represent Philippines, a Nation That’s Foreign Even to Him
abstract: Andray Blatche casually and rather comically confirmed an international report that he was being recruited to join the Philippine national basketball team before the FIBA World Cup.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The world of Andray Blatche — an often colorfully odd place — is expanding.

headline: Thieves Steal $700,000 in Watches From Cartier
abstract: Five men entered the boutique, on Fifth Avenue at 52nd Street, in broad daylight and smashed open a glass display case with hammers, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A gang of thieves used hammers to stage a jewelry theft at Cartier’s flagship store in Midtown Manhattan in broad daylight on Wednesday, making off with more than a dozen luxury watches, the police said.

headline: The Moral Hazard of the All-Volunteer Army
keywords: ['Draft and Recruitment (Military)', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']

headline: What’s on Friday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13) BARRYMORE In this “Great Performances” presentation, Christopher Plummer, above, recreates his 1997 Tony Award-winning portrayal of the actor John Barrymore as a boozy, physical wreck struggling in the final weeks of his life in 1942 to revive his Broadway triumph in “Richard III” from two decades earlier. “Barrymore’s memory sometimes fails him, but the words never do, or rather he never fails them: He grabs at their prose and poetry with force, flinging away some, caressing others,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this film adaptation by Érik Canuel of the William Luce play. “Mr. Plummer stumbles beautifully, poignantly and often, leering and searching through a haze of memory or, with concern edged with panic, calling for ‘a line, a line’ much as Richard III calls for a horse. From smile to sneer, he captures Barrymore’s majesty and grandiloquence, recites his triumphs and humiliations.”

headline: What Are Your Secret Survival Strategies?
abstract: When do you use these strategies — in school, home, with friends or elsewhere? Are they effective?
lead_paragraph: Three-toed sloths have some hidden survival strategies that you wouldn’t know just by looking at them. After all, it’s not so easy to survive in the jungles of Central and South America. The same might be said about adolescence, which has its own share of dangers lurking in the complex world of school, friendships, social media and family.

headline: ‘I Am Hello Kitty’
keywords: ['Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Mickey Mouse (Fictional Character)', 'Photography']
abstract: The photographer Joana Toro, who worked as Hello Kitty in Times Square, reveals her fellow Elmos and Mickeys to be immigrants like her, looking to make an extra dollar.
lead_paragraph: For a good part of 2012, smiling tourists surrounded Joana Toro in Times Square. Strangers hugged her. Some even gave her a few dollars. Talk about getting a big head. Actually, it was all because of her big head, an oversize Hello Kitty mask she wore while working among the costumed characters that have become familiar denizens of the Crossroads of the World.

headline: The Post-Hope Politics of ‘House of Cards’
abstract: Every generation gets the Washington TV show it deserves — and Beau Willimon’s Washington is only getting darker.
lead_paragraph: At 6:45 a.m. on a September day in Baltimore, when the heat was already loitering in the 80s and would eventually flirt with 100 degrees, Beau Willimon, the show runner for “House of Cards,” finished his first — or maybe second, or actually probably his third — cigarette of the day and stalked onto the show’s outdoor set. Every set of a TV show is a little reminiscent of a ragged Civil War camp, with its provisional tents and huddled groups of conferring higher-ups and wandering assistants tending to disparate needs. But on the “House of Cards” set — temporarily erected in a small park adjacent to a block of Baltimore townhouses — this feeling was heightened by the presence of Willimon, with his facial hair that might be best described as “sort-of mutton chops”; his beeline intensity; and, of course, that name: Beau Willimon, which seems perfectly suited to a brass plaque in the South somewhere, commemorating a particularly brave or foolhardy general. His hair was an unkempt pompadour, and he wore an untucked work shirt, unlaced work boots and jeans with a back pocket so tattered that it barely cradled his wallet, a situation that at least three people, including me, felt moved to warn him about it, though he waved each of us off in turn. He had the haunted look of a man who’s worried about something much more important, and he’d only just arrived on set.

headline: Bratton Says Rookies’ Role in Anticrime Effort Will End
abstract: Police Commissioner William J. Bratton said that rather than thrusting inexperienced officers into highly charged situations, rookies would first be placed in local precincts.
lead_paragraph: In a sharp break with New York’s crime-fighting policies of the last decade, Police Commissioner William J. Bratton has told his top chiefs that he intends to fundamentally alter a program that sent waves of rookie officers into crime-ridden neighborhoods, while also inflaming tensions in those communities.

headline: Ireland and Child Abuse
abstract: A European court holds Dublin responsible for failing to keep students safe.
lead_paragraph: For years, the government of Ireland has denied liability for child sexual abuse by teachers in state-financed schools managed by the Roman Catholic Church. The European Court of Human Rights punctured this denial Tuesday with a finding that the Irish government, in financing and regulating the education of youngsters, had “an inherent obligation” to protect them, and owed compensation to a victim whose case was rejected as groundless by Ireland’s highest court.

headline: Inflation in Euro Zone Falls, and a 12% Jobless Rate Doesn’t Budge
abstract: Joblessness remained at 12 percent in December while inflation dipped, suggesting the central bank will be under pressure to provide more stimulus.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Europe’s labor market remained in the doldrums in December, while the inflation rate ticked back down to the same level that recently led the European Central Bank to cut interest rates, official data showed on Friday. The reports suggested that the central bank would be under pressure to provide more monetary stimulus to keep a nascent recovery alive.

All of them, Nick Wingfield reports, are reminders of the niche that GoPro has carved out as the camera of choice for recording skiing, surfing and other experiences too gnarly for dainty smartphones.

headline: My Grandfather’s Last Battle
keywords: ['World War I (1914-18)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Great War and a Brooklyn deliveryman.
lead_paragraph: RONSSOY, France — ABOUT 95 years ago, my grandfather spent the night near here. I doubt he slept much. For starters, he was probably in a trench. And by 4:30 a.m., he and other members of the United States Army’s 106th Infantry were assembled along a strip of tape on the ground. They were facing the outer edge of the Hindenburg Line, one of the most fortified German positions on the Western Front of World War I.

headline: All Quiet on the Amazon Front
abstract: Amazon is one of the most highly valued, most innovative and just plain most interesting companies in the country. It is also one that places a premium on saying nothing.
lead_paragraph: Amazon is one of the most exciting companies in the country, redefining retail, web hosting, publishing and a bunch of other enterprises. When it says it is merely thinking of doing something — as it did Thursday with the first-ever price increase for Amazon Prime shipping service — it makes news. It also makes news when it talks about something that it is planning to do, maybe, a bunch of years from now, in the unlikely event everything works out. Yes, we’re talking drones.

headline: Prescriptions for a Cinema Refuge
abstract: The Film Society of Lincoln Center faces internal flux and competition in New York City. Industry figures and The Times’s chief film critics weigh in.
lead_paragraph: The Film Society of Lincoln Center was born 45 years ago in an age when screenings of foreign and other nonstudio films weren’t easily found. It was given the task of overseeing the New York Film Festival, a fledgling annual event at the time, but also with fostering what were described as “movie activities.” In the decades since, that nebulous term has been interpreted to mean a lively variety of repertory programs, retrospectives and, in the last few years, even first-run releases. While the annual festival has thrived, the fortunes of this nonprofit society have ebbed and flowed. In 2011, the organization expanded its footprint with the addition of the Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center. But the society also recently underwent a leadership shake-up, its second in three years, and its year-round offerings face stiff competition from other screens around the city and online. A new executive director has yet to be named, and in this interim period, it seemed like the time to ask what a 21st-century Film Society should look like.

headline: Write What You Know, Especially if It’s Difficult Family

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – Violet Weston, the horrifying matriarch of “August: Osage County” who got Meryl Streep her 18th Oscar nomination, is famously based on the screenwriter Tracy Letts’s own grandmother. Mr. Letts’s characterization of her, he has said, was kinder than she was in real life.

headline: Audit Planned in Fraud Case as Navy Reinstates Shipper
keywords: ['Defense Contracts', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Inchcape Shipping Services was reinstated after a judge questioned whether the Navy had adequately examined the evidence.
lead_paragraph: The Navy has quietly lifted the suspension of a shipping contractor under investigation for possible fraud, allowing the company to compete for new work. In exchange, the company has agreed to pay for an independent audit that could help the Justice Department determine how much it may have overcharged the government.

headline: Determined Voters in Thailand Ready to Repel Protesters
abstract: Supporters of Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra are preparing to push back against antigovernment demonstrators aiming to hinder Sunday’s election.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — All of the extreme emotions, the fears of lawlessness and the concerns about violence breaking out in Sunday’s election in Thailand are on display in a community called Lat Krabang, a few minutes’ drive from the main international airport here.

headline: The Source | Liz Glynn in Conversation With Doug Aitken
abstract: In our latest installment of this exclusive series of interviews by Doug Aitken, the artist interviews the Los Angeles-based installation artist Liz Glynn.
lead_paragraph: “I think about functioning as somewhere between an architect and a scientist,” says Liz Glynn. “So I create the space and set up an experiment, but then I get out of the way and sort of see what happens.” In conversation with Doug Aitken, the 32-year-old artist from Los Angeles talks about her work, which includes site-specific installations for performances and collective happenings as well as modern-day monuments and handmade sculptural objects. The interview is part of the Source, a series of candid video conversations with several dozen noteworthy figures about their creative processes, currently on view in a custom pavilion at the Sundance Film Festival.

headline: Elaine Stritch, Broadway Legend: ‘Entertaining Is Hard’
abstract: On moving to Michigan and how to lunch with the ladies.
lead_paragraph: After years of vowing to retire, you gave up your cabaret act at the Cafe Carlyle and your apartment at the Carlyle Hotel and moved to Birmingham, Mich. What made you finally take the leap? I wasn’t getting the quality of work that I wanted to get. I’m a funny age — funny ha-ha, funny peculiar, funny, funny. I could hardly open my mouth on the stage without getting a laugh. That’s a pretty sensational thing to brag about, but it’s also dangerous. I had a great time, and I’m very glad it’s over. Oh, my God, it’s hard. Entertaining is hard.

headline: Our Young-Adult Dystopia
abstract: In the bleak wasteland of 21st-century publishing, there is only one hope: The young-adult novel. That’s a problem.
lead_paragraph: I sometimes wonder what Dante or Milton or any of those guys would make of the modern appetite for the young-adult epic. It wasn’t always a lucrative thing, writing grand, sweeping, fantastical stories, you know. It was a job for nose-to-the-grindstone, writing-for-the-ages types, and worldly rewards were low. Milton died in penury, blind and obscure; Dante met his maker in literal exile. Would they look with envy upon their celebrated and moneyed modern analogues — your J. K. Rowlings, your Suzanne Collinses?

headline: Reply All: The 1.19.14 Issue
abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: THE ONLINE AVENGERS

headline: Grown-Up Clothes
abstract: A first summer in New York, and the promise of a life to grow into.
lead_paragraph: When I was 19, I went to New York City, my first trip East. I’d won a Mademoiselle contest and would be one of 20 young women working at the magazine for a month in the summer. It was 1953, and I was excited but also frightened and daunted; I hadn’t been on an airliner before, and no one I knew had been to New York except my Sioux Falls uncle, Bill, a buyer for a department store. In case of difficulties, I was to call my Uncle Bill’s New York friend, Mr. Herbert Solomon.

headline: Who Made That First-Person-Shooter Game?
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Inventions and Patents', '3-D Devices and Effects', 'Computer and Video Games']
abstract: And the surprising long-term benefits of playing them.
lead_paragraph: “It was like playing with dolls,” says the video-game designer and 3-D graphics creator John Carmack, thinking back to the computer entertainments before Call of Duty, Halo, Doom and all the other “first-person-shooter” games. “In a typical game of that time, your character was maybe 16-by-16 pixels in an overhead view. Maybe it did some cute things that made you smile. But you were still controlling a tiny little thing on the screen.”

headline: Breaking: Kids Are Obnoxious
abstract: Rachael Ray violates the Third Commandment; Richard Sherman takes on “Peanuts.”
lead_paragraph: Rachael Ray violates the Third Commandment; Richard Sherman takes on “Peanuts.”

headline: Get Out of My Subconscious!
abstract: The ethics of advertising.
lead_paragraph: Our subconscious beliefs, which we cannot easily understand or change, motivate many of the decisions we make. Some companies use manipulative branding techniques that create untrue associations between their products and some deep human desires   —   like sex or social status   —   with the goal of having the viewer establish this connection unconsciously. The desired result, presumably, is that the consumer will then buy the product with the misguided intent of fulfilling said desire. Is this practice unethical? ADAM GIDDING, NEW YORK

headline: There’s a Reason That Rye Is Having a Moment
abstract: And it’s not just as a reaction against the snootiness of Scottish single malts.
lead_paragraph: If we were playing a round of word association a few years ago and you said, “Rye,” I wouldn’t have skipped a beat before saying, “Pastrami.” For most of my drinking life, rye whiskey seemed like tough-guy stuff, cowboy stuff. And to drink as they drank (or at least as I imagined they did) seemed affected or unduly performative. Why would I replace my everyday Irish whiskey with rye? Why trade the bourbon in my manhattan for another brown American spirit?

headline: The Empire State Building in Ice
abstract: The Harbin Ice and Snow World in northeast China.
lead_paragraph: Every winter, hundreds of thousands of tourists visit the Harbin Ice and Snow World in northeast China, near the Songhua River, to see its vast collection of elaborately carved ice structures, many of them illuminated with colorful LEDs. The arduous task of quickly collecting all that ice for an exhibition that opens in early January begins in mid-December, and the ice city has been getting bigger every year. This time around, 180,000 cubic meters of ice were used. Some of the finished sculptures this year, which remain in place until March, are a homage to structures around the world, from the Colosseum to the Empire State Building. Zengyu Wang, the executive manager of the event, says the local government in Harbin dreamed up the festival as a lure to promote winter tourism. When visitors see the ice for the first time, he says, they have one reaction: “Very shocked.” Julie Bosman

headline: Japan’s Public Broadcaster Faces Accusations of Shift to the Right
abstract: NHK is under criticism amid signs it is hewing to an agenda approved by the rightist government of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — First, there was the abrupt resignation of a president accused by governing party politicians of allowing an overly liberal tone to news coverage. Then, his newly appointed successor immediately drew public ire when he seemed to proclaim that he would loyally toe the line of the current conservative government.

headline: Judge’s Family Denies Pride Was Behind Rejection of 3rd-Highest Award
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The survivors of Jagdish Sharan Verma, who was instrumental in strengthening laws protecting women, said he wouldn’t have accepted any award had he been alive.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The family of the late Jagdish Sharan Verma, the former Supreme Court chief justice whose report helped strengthen Indian sexual assault laws, said it had rejected one of India’s top awards for the judge because he would have never accepted it had he been alive.

headline: Investors and Customers Yearn for an Apple iThingamajig
abstract: Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, keeps promising a new product category from Apple, but investors are getting antsy as other product sales start to slow.
lead_paragraph: Let’s play a little game. If you were Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, and you could have any gadget in the world that you wanted, what would it be? Forget that such a gadget doesn’t exist yet. Remember, you’re the chief executive. of Apple — you can just pick up your iPhone 10, scroll down to Jony Ive’s number and tell him to build you an iThingamajig.

headline: Clamor Grows for Syria to Deliver on Chemical Arms Pledge
abstract: A top United Nations official has added his voice to American concerns that the Syrian government is deliberately stalling the removal of chemical weapons.
lead_paragraph: The head of the United Nations chemical weapons watchdog added his voice on Friday to calls on Syria to accelerate the elimination of its chemical weapons, a day after Washington accused the Syrian government of deliberately stalling the weapons’ removal from the country to gain bargaining leverage and — in a new complaint — reneging on a pledge to destroy the 12 facilities that produced them.

headline: Putting Prestige in Service of Comedy
abstract: Andre Braugher, long used to critically acclaimed but unsuccessful dramas, has found both laughs and luck with the comedy “Brooklyn Nine-Nine.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Before his name appeared, however incongruously, on a list of possible cast members for a new Fox comedy set in a fictional Brooklyn police precinct, Andre Braugher had an epiphany.

headline: Oscar Shorts on View
abstract: Images from the “Oscar Nominated Shorts 2014″ program.
lead_paragraph: What will take home the Oscar in the documentary short subject category? Will it be “Cavedigger,” Jeffrey Karoff’s film about a cave artist in New Mexico? Or “The Lady in Number 6,” Malcolm Clarke’s portrait of a 109-year old Holocaust survivor? For those looking to make an educated guess on their Oscar ballot, a series of programs featuring this year’s nominees is in theaters nationwide today. The series has become an annual event, with the shorts programs divided into three feature-length compilations: animated, live-action and documentary.

headline: Walmart Trims Its Profit Forecast for the 4th Quarter
abstract: The giant retailer said winter storms and cuts in food stamps would affect its bottom line when it reports earnings in February.

headline: Abuse Claims in Ukraine Rise Among Protesters
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Torture']
abstract: After being missing for a week, an antigovernment protest leader stumbled out of a forest and said he had been crucified, raising concerns over abuses in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Alarm mounted on Friday among Western diplomats and rights groups over the scale and severity of abuses during the civil unrest in Ukraine after an antigovernment protest leader who had been missing for a week stumbled out of a snowy forest to say he had been crucified.

headline: The Force of Japanese Exports Is Weakening
abstract: A softer yen has not increased Japan’s exports as much as expected, and growing imports — especially of oil — are increasing its trade deficits.
lead_paragraph: JAPAN posted a third consecutive trade deficit in 2013, providing more evidence that the power of the Japanese export machine has faded.

headline: With Persistence, He Caught the Girl Next Door
keywords: ['Marriages', 'Children and Childhood', 'Baby Boomers', 'Parenting', 'Dating and Courtship', 'Weddings and Engagements']
abstract: Through four decades of marriage, Angela and Curtiss Anderson have learned to enjoy the journey.
lead_paragraph: Booming’s “Making It Last” column profiles baby boomer couples who have been together 25 years or more.

headline: Under Pressure
abstract: Jennifer Senior’s “All Joy and No Fun,” about the state of modern parenthood, weaves together philosophy, psychology and social science.
lead_paragraph: Parenthood as we know it — predicated on the unconditional exaltation of our children — is no more than 70 years old, and it has gone through radical readjustments over the past two generations. As children went from helping on the farm to being the focus of relentless cosseting, they shifted “from being our employees to our bosses,” Jennifer Senior observes in her trenchant and engrossing first book, “All Joy and No Fun: The Paradox of Modern Parenthood.” Senior, a contributing editor at New York magazine, examines what it means to be a parent, through interviews with a handful of families who are neither typical nor extraordinary. These are snapshots, not longitudinal documentaries, but in the way of good snapshots, they tell more than one might notice at first glance, and they allow for cautious universalizing. She supplements these vignettes with extremely impressive research, weaving in insights from philosophy, psychology and an occasionally overwhelming mélange of social science reports.

headline: The Badger With a Comb-Over
abstract: The writers of “American Hustle” explain the roots of Christian Bale’s con-man character.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – David O. Russell had a nickname for Christian Bale’s character in “American Hustle,” the combed-over, paunchy yet confident swindler Irving Rosenfeld.

headline: He Accused
abstract: The protagonist of this novel about the Dreyfus case is the French Army officer who identified the real traitor.
lead_paragraph: The Dreyfus Affair, which splintered French society of the fin de siècle and continued to divide it well into the 20th century, began on the morning of Oct. 15, 1894, with the arrest for high treason of Capt. Alfred Dreyfus. Dreyfus was a 35-year-old artillery officer, a high-ranking graduate of the elite École Polytechnique and the École de Guerre (the French Army’s war college), and was chosen on the basis of his grades and overall performance to train with the army’s general staff. Robert Harris, in his fine novel “An Officer and a Spy,” lucidly retells the famous, bizarrely complicated and chilling story. His narrator is Lt. Col. Georges Picquart, who was promoted to that grade six months after Dreyfus’s arrest and put in charge of the general staff’s statistical section (the coy sobriquet of a counter­intelligence unit), and went on to become one of Dreyfus’s improbable and indispensable saviors.

headline: Parenthood
abstract: New books by Theresa Morris, Catherine Steiner-Adair with Teresa H. Barker, and Lori Duron.
lead_paragraph: CUT IT OUT

headline: A Brooklyn Artery in Transition
abstract: A new wave of residential development has come to a ragtag stretch of Fourth Avenue that borders Park Slope and Gowanus/Boerum Hill.
lead_paragraph: The dream of turning Fourth Avenue in Brooklyn into a grand residential boulevard is still just that — a dream. Even so, residential development along the thoroughfare took off about a decade ago when the area was rezoned, and now, after a recession-induced break, construction has begun again at a somewhat frenzied pace.

headline: Affordable Housing Conundrum
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Rent Control and Stabilization']
abstract: New Yorkers in truly affordable apartments sometimes find their sweet deals come with sacrifices.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers in truly affordable apartments sometimes find their sweet deals come with sacrifices.

headline: A Bookstore on the Brink
abstract: A group called Save Rizzoli hopes to preserve the visually stunning bookstore on 57th Street.
lead_paragraph: Last month, The Times reported that the Manhattan home of Rizzoli Bookstore, a visually stunning literary outpost in an old limestone mansion on 57th Street, was to make way for a high-rise development. The news galvanized two passionate and beleaguered groups: readers and preservationists.

headline: The Truly Affordable New York Apartment
keywords: ['Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Those who take over their parents’ rent-regulated units or limited-equity co-ops experience the city differently from those who pay market rate.
lead_paragraph: In a city of soaring real estate prices, New Yorkers love to hear the tales of people who found the Promised Land: a truly affordable apartment.

headline: Letters: Robert Gates’s ‘Duty’ and More
abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of Robert M. Gates’s memoir and Gabriel Sherman’s biography of Roger Ailes.
lead_paragraph: Robert Gates’s ‘Duty’

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: MY LIFE IN MIDDLEMARCH,  by Rebecca Mead. (Crown, $25.) A beguilingly straightforward account of Mead’s lifelong admiration for George Eliot as a novelist and as a role model for bright, provincially born girls like herself.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE REAL JANE AUSTEN: A Life in Small Things,  by Paula Byrne. (Harper Perennial, $16.99.) Contrary to Virginia Woolf’s pronouncement, in 1928, that “we have lives enough of Jane Austen,” Austen’s appeal has proved irresistible. Byrne’s vividly persuasive biography shirks chronological constraints, using objects of special significance to Austen — an East Indian shawl, an ivory miniature, velvet cushions — to depict her as an exuberant, worldly woman of fierce convictions.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Sarah Addison Allen’s novel “Lost Lake,” No. 5 on the hardcover fiction list, is her first book since she announced, in a 2011 Facebook post, that she had advanced-stage breast cancer.
lead_paragraph: Healthy Distance: Sarah Addison Allen’s “Lost Lake,” about a young widow trying to recover from grief at a magical Georgia resort, is new on the hardcover fiction list at No. 5. It’s Allen’s fifth novel — or sixth, if you count the early romance she wrote under a pseudonym — but her first since announcing, in a 2011 Facebook post, that she had advanced-stage breast cancer. (“For those of you who don’t want to read the word ‘boob,’ ‘breast’ or ‘bazookas’ a gazillion times,” she wrote, “I’ll let you know how it ends: I’m going to be fine. Now, for the rest of you, I’m going to reveal more about my cleavage than I think I’ve ever told anyone.”)

headline: Breaking In
abstract: The story of a 1971 raid on an F.B.I. office and what it revealed about bureau practices.
lead_paragraph: On a March evening in 1971, eight antiwar protesters burglarized an F.B.I. office in Media, Pa., just outside Philadelphia, with astonishing ease. A few weeks of elementary surveillance had shown them the vulnerability of the target: There were no cameras to elude, no alarms to disconnect. Because the building contained residential apartments, the group chose the night of the first Joe Frazier-­Muhammad Ali heavyweight championship fight, an ideal distraction. It turned out that the Pennsylvania office, like so many others across the country, had almost no physical protection. Security was largely symbolic, resting on the bureau’s carefully buffed reputation for efficiency in tracking down America’s “most wanted” criminals, from bank robbers to atomic spies. Put simply, no one messed with J. Edgar Hoover’s F.B.I.

headline: Secrets of Success
abstract: Two new books examine whether cultural traits underlie the success of certain overachieving subgroups.
lead_paragraph: Quanyu Huang’s new book, “The Hybrid Tiger: Secrets of the Extraordinary Success of Asian-­American Kids,” may sound like yet another flogging for hapless Western parents, but it’s not.

headline: The Marriage Plod
abstract: In Jude Cook’s novel, a failed poet relives his calamitous relationship with his wife.
lead_paragraph: How disgusting the British find themselves! Let me rephrase that. If you were to go by the output of a certain strand of young, male British fiction writer, you could easily be forgiven for thinking the main activity of British life is being disgusted by the physical form of oneself and one’s fellows. Ian McEwan began a short story noting the peculiar smell asparagus lends the urine (“it suggests sexual activity of some kind between exotic creatures”). Martin Amis spent large parts of his early career detailing his characters’ bleeding gums and cracked molars. Will Self’s books come so awash in bodily fluids that if you were to throw them against a wall they’d most likely stick. Male self-disgust, rooted in the moist tumult of adolescence, and extended into one’s 20s and 30s under cover of literary careers aping the clinical imperturbability of Nabokov and Joyce, has almost bequeathed us its own genre. We might call it, in the manner of those outraged letters to British broadsheets, “Disgusted of Tunbridge Wells.”

headline: In the Grip of Madness
abstract: Dasa Drndic blends fact and fiction in this novel of the Holocaust and its aftermath.
lead_paragraph: July 2006: Haya Tedeschi, 83, waits at her home in Gorizia, on the Italian-Slovenian border, northwest of Trieste, for the arrival of the son who was stolen from her 62 years earlier, during the war.

headline: Winter Cabbage With a Mediterranean Flair
abstract: Martha Rose Shulman provides five new ways to make cabbage in this week’s Recipes for Health.
lead_paragraph: One of the things I appreciate about this produce-limited time of year is that it forces me to devote a week of Recipes for Health to cabbage. I love this nutrient-dense cruciferous vegetable for many reasons: the way it sweetens as it cooks in the pan; the price per pound; the way it is comfortable in a soup or a pie, a stew, a gratin or a salad, a stir-fry or a timbale. Yet I sometimes forget to pay attention to cabbage. It can be overshadowed by other winter vegetables like kale, its more fashionable cousin.

headline: Start-Up Aims to Circumvent Rules on Private Stock Sales
abstract: Employees who hold shares in start-ups are often wealthy on paper, but have few ways to access that wealth. A new company, Equidate, is trying to get around rules that restrict employees’ ability to sell their shares with a novel way to provide liquidity.
lead_paragraph: You have likely heard of “first world problems.” But here is a Silicon Valley problem — and a company trying to solve it.

headline: Lonely Hunter
abstract: A young woman disappears and evidence points to a troubled war veteran in Joyce Carol Oates’s novel.
lead_paragraph: At the Brooklyn Museum, an exhibit called “War/Photography: Images of Armed Conflict and Its Aftermath,” which went up in November, featured a photograph by Nina Berman of a young Marine sergeant, Ty Ziegel, who was horrifically injured and disfigured by a suicide bomb in Iraq in 2004. Returning home, he underwent scores of surgeries and in 2006 married his sweetheart in Illinois. The marriage didn’t last, and Ziegel died in December 2012. But nobody who saw the “Marine Wedding” series will be able to forget him — or the damage wrought by war on his body, his life and his family. Joyce Carol Oates’s new novel puts the homecoming of a similarly wounded warrior at its center, doing with words what the Berman portraits did with images.

headline: Liberated and Unfree
abstract: Douglas R. Egerton argues that the view of Reconstruction as a failure overlooks the era’s progressive reforms.
lead_paragraph: As the 150th anniversary of the Civil War heads toward its conclusion, the anniversary of Reconstruction, the turbulent era that followed, looms on the horizon. Properly commemorating it poses a challenge, since for no period of American history does a wider gap exist between scholarly understanding and public consciousness.

headline: The Unknown War
abstract: A novel about the World War II Japanese invasion of Alaska.
lead_paragraph: They called it the “Aleutian stare.” During World War II, American soldiers stationed in the remote, windswept archipelago stretching for 1,100 miles west of the Alaskan mainland fought a secret war against Japanese invaders. Driven mad by the cold, the isolation and the “dim, colorless light,” some were taken away in straitjackets, gazing into the distance, “unfocused, unspeaking.” The rest of the country didn’t even know they were there.

headline: Are We There Yet?
abstract: In Mary Miller’s first novel, a teenage girl and her fractured family travel cross-country in preparation for the rapture.
lead_paragraph: Just as Arthur Phillips’s “Prague” follows a group of Americans living not in the title city but in less trendy Budapest, Mary Miller’s terrific first novel, “The Last Days of California,” never quite makes it to the Golden State. And I don’t think it’s giving anything away to say it doesn’t turn out to be the last days, either.

headline: Limits of Endurance
abstract: The plight of 11 American P.O.W.’s in North Vietnam.
lead_paragraph: Alvin Townley, the author of books about naval aviation and Eagle Scouts, has written a gripping account of the “Alcatraz Eleven,” a group of American prisoners of war in North Vietnam who formed a tough core of heroic resisters despite brutal and relentless efforts to break them and convert them into fodder for the Communist propaganda machine. Readers of even passing acquaintance with the Vietnam War will most likely know of Jeremiah Denton’s televised 1966 interview — one of the first glimpses of the life of United States military pilots who had been shot down and captured. American viewers watched in horror and puzzlement as Denton, an emaciated, hunched figure dressed in gray prison garb, defiantly telegraphed the word t-o-r-t-u-r-e by blinking out the letters in Morse code. His brave act was followed by yet more torture, and some time later Vietnamese authorities bundled him along with 10 other men out of the infamous Hanoi Hilton, as Hoa Lo prison in the North Vietnamese capital was known (and where John McCain, probably the most famous P.O.W. of the war, would be held). The destination of the Eleven was an even filthier hellhole a few miles away, which they nicknamed Alcatraz.

headline: At a Distance
abstract: Penelope Lively looks back on a life of reading and writing.
lead_paragraph: Penelope Lively is writing from another country, a place she calls “old age.” She is 80, and so, she assures us, she is now “a native” of this territory, an “authority.” “Dancing Fish and Ammonites” is about growing old, about memory and history, about reading and writing and the way experiences become associated with certain objects — with a book, say, or a piece of pottery. Lively has explored these themes before, in her many novels and in a handful of previous memoirs. This time, though, she says she wants to address them more abstractly: “I find myself thinking less about what has happened to me but interested in this lifetime context, in the times of my life.” She’s not trying to tell us a story.

headline: Stab in the Dark
abstract: In Isabel Allende’s “Ripper,” a teenage sleuth investigates a series of killings with the help of an interactive mystery game she plays online.
lead_paragraph: Isabel Allende says that RIPPER (Harper, $28.99) is her first murder mystery, and that it was a lot of fun to write. It’s probably more accurate to say that this ungainly but thoroughly charming book is the author’s own eccentric notion of a murder mystery, and that it’s a lot of fun to read. Also, it features a teenage sleuth — “idiosyncratic of appearance, timorous of character, but magnificent of mind,” according to her besotted grandfather — who is pretty much irresistible.

headline: Boy Trouble
abstract: The only son of Chinese immigrants longs to be a girl.
lead_paragraph: Peter Huang, the worshiped son in a family of daughters, has just one wish: to be a girl. His father, a Chinese immigrant, has another: to erase completely, and by force if necessary, evidence of his Asian heritage. Father and son have almost nothing in common except for the belief that self-acceptance is anathema.

headline: This Week's Movies: Jan. 31, 2014
abstract: The New York Times film critics on "Tim's Vermeer," "That Awkward Moment" and "Labor Day."
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics on "Tim's Vermeer," "That Awkward Moment" and "Labor Day."

headline: De Blasio on Hot 97: New Sound for Mayoral Radio
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio, in his on-air debut, took questions on marijuana, police tactics and the governor, often while speaking over the soft strains of a rap track.
lead_paragraph: The interview ended with a pulsating reggae track, its lyrics an ode to the pleasures of high-quality cannabis.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Secrets to Success
abstract: This week, Sandra Tsing Loh discusses “The Hybrid Tiger” and “The Triple Package”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Betty Medsger talks about “The Burglary”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Sandra Tsing Loh discusses “The Hybrid Tiger” and “The Triple Package”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Betty Medsger talks about “The Burglary”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Secrets to Success
abstract: This week, Sandra Tsing Loh and Betty Medsger.
lead_paragraph: This week, Sandra Tsing Loh and Betty Medsger.

headline: When Buying Stock in Gluttony Is a Good Investment
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Motif, an investment site, tries to help small investors buy collections of stock based on long-term themes or trends.
lead_paragraph: ARTHUR LEVITT JR., the former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, acknowledged that he found “The Seven Deadly Sins” irresistible — so much so that he plunked down $5,000 as an initial investment and has since put in more.

headline: Cheerios: Hard for Racists to Swallow
abstract: A cereal ad that triggered a torrent of hatred on line is coming back for the Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: Never mind the point-spread, New Jersey weather, momentum shifts and Newtonian replays. Just keep an eye out for the Super Bowl’s first unscheduled time out, when the huge television audience can catch that famous Cheerios commercial family — the one that so enraged racist Americans several months ago, featuring a manly black actor as father, a serene white mother and their charming interracial seven-year-old, Gracie.

headline: A Perfectionist Does Opera His Way
abstract: No detail is left untouched for the Russian director Dmitri Tcherniakov, who makes his Metropolitan Opera debut on Thursday with Borodin’s “Prince Igor.”
lead_paragraph: Every once in a while, the Russian stage director Dmitri Tcherniakov has a nightmare. He’s ready to go to the theater and run a rehearsal when he realizes he has forgotten what he is supposed to do there, what he wants to tell the performers.

headline: Not Easygoing, and Not Sure About a Donkey
abstract: The composer Leonid Desyatnikov and the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky have been collaborators four times — and counting, they hope.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The choreographer Alexei Ratmansky has created four ballets to music by Leonid Desyatnikov: “Russian Seasons” (New York City Ballet, 2006), “Old Ladies Falling Out” (Territory festival in Moscow, 2007), “Lost Illusions” (Bolshoi Ballet, 2011) and “Opera” (La Scala Ballet, 2013). Both men are Russian, and both have worked at the Bolshoi in Moscow, where Mr. Ratmansky, 45, now artist in residence at American Ballet Theater, was the artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet from 2004 to 2008, and Mr. Desyatnikov, 58, was music director from 2009 to 2010.

headline: A Songbird Finding Strength in Her Nest
abstract: The mezzo-soprano Sasha Cooke talks about self-image and the value of family and gut instincts.
lead_paragraph: While other students at Juilliard wanted to sing Verdi and Rossini, the mezzo-soprano Sasha Cooke, 31, gained a reputation as a quick study willing to learn new pieces written by her composer colleagues.

headline: Beatle Fans Hear Yesterday Again
abstract: Half a century ago this week, the Beatles arrived in New York and changed popular culture. Now, dozens of concerts, exhibitions, discussions, books and albums are celebrating what happened in 1964.
lead_paragraph: It was inevitable, time marching on as it does, and yet it also hard to believe: Half a century has passed since the Beatles touched down in New York for the first time, on Feb. 7, 1964, and seduced the country with three performances on “The Ed Sullivan Show” and three concerts, one at the Washington Coliseum and two at Carnegie Hall. Everything about them — their pudding basin haircuts, their Cardin suits and pointed boots, their sharp, irreverent sense of humor — seemed outlandish, compared with American pop groups. And though their music was firmly rooted — as they were always quick to point out — in American rhythm and blues, soul and rock, they produced a sound that was fresh, energetic and unmistakably their own.

headline: Jelly vs. Need, Comparing Two New Social Q & A Apps
abstract: A reporter tore a ligament in her knee and began the hunt for an orthopedist with Jelly and Need, two new social question-and-answer smartphone apps. It turned out that the audiences, and advice, were quite different.
lead_paragraph: In case anyone was looking for further evidence that the five-star rating system is broken, I heard a horrific story the other day from someone who used Yelp to select a five-star-rated veterinarian when his vet was out of town, only to get stuck with a $10,000 vet bill and a dead pet.

headline: Clothes and Character: ‘Gravity’
abstract: The costume designer explains the challenge of designing a realistic spacesuit that does unrealistic things, like unzip in the front.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:26 a.m. | Jany Temime, the costume designer of Alfonso Cuarón’s space thriller “Gravity,” was scared. After a 40-year career packed with period pieces and one of the biggest fantasy franchises in movies (“Harry Potter”), she was facing the great unknown: space. In 3-D, no less.

headline: Walter De Maria’s Grand and Gritty Home
abstract: A former utility substation on the Lower East Side reimagined by the sculptor and composer as a home studio, storage facility, and dedicated laboratory for his works.
lead_paragraph: A former Con Edison substation on the Lower East Side reimagined by the internationally renowned artist/sculptor/composer Walter De Maria as a cavernous home studio, storage facility, and dedicated laboratory for the gestation of his monumental works, is about to enter the market at $25 million.

headline: Exclusive | 421 East 6th Street
abstract: The sculptor and artist Walter De Maria, who died last summer at age 77, was drawn to the building by its lofty ceiling heights, unusual windows, and absolute privacy.
lead_paragraph: The sculptor and artist Walter De Maria, who died last summer at age 77, was drawn to the building by its lofty ceiling heights, unusual windows, and absolute privacy.

headline: Times Fashion Critic Cathy Horyn to Retire
abstract: Ms. Horyn had been with The Times since 1998, and the paper’s chief fashion critic since 1999.
lead_paragraph: Cathy Horyn, The New York Times’s chief fashion critic, is retiring, the paper said Friday. Ms. Horyn has been with The Times since 1998 and has been in her current position since 1999.

headline: Navigating an Informant’s Shadow World
abstract: The dramas “Bethlehem” and the Oscar-nominated “Omar,” as well as the documentary “The Green Prince,” examine the cost of spying in Israeli-Palestinian relations.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Ten years ago, Yuval Adler, an aspiring Israeli filmmaker, chanced upon a video on a Middle East website that captured one of the most brutal moments of the Palestinian uprising. The footage showed a gang of militants dragging a suspected collaborator through the streets of Bethlehem, and shooting him dead before a crowd of onlookers. “I remember thinking: ‘What is going on there? How does somebody get into that situation?’ ” Mr. Adler said. “If these are the stakes in becoming an informant, how would the Israelis manage to recruit somebody?”

headline: At a Concert Full of Musical Stars, a Spotlight on Their Teacher
abstract: Gabriel Kosakoff, 87, worked for decades as a music teacher, inspiring generations of future classical and jazz headliners set to salute him at a concert at the LaGuardia High School of Music and Art and the Performing Arts.
lead_paragraph: It’ll be 70 years this spring since a 17-year-old Gabriel Kosakoff shouldered his trombone and marched out of the High School of Music and Art, dreaming of fame and fortune in the world’s top concert halls.

headline: An App to Search for Street Art
abstract: A mobile app provides a museum’s worth of information on topics like graffiti and more than 150 artists involved in the scene.
lead_paragraph: The destruction of the graffiti mecca 5Pointz, in Long Island City, last fall was a devastating blow to the community of street art in New York City and around the world.

headline: As Facebook Turns 10, How Has It Transformed Your Life?
abstract: Did you meet your mate through the site? Start a business? Reconnect with an old friend? Tell us how Facebook has changed your life.
lead_paragraph: In February, Facebook will be 10 years old.

headline: Accounting for Dimon’s Big Jump in Pay
abstract: In the world of Wall Street executive compensation, the pay raise recommended for Jamie Dimon, chief of JPMorgan Chase, is not only defensible, but laudable.
lead_paragraph: The compensation and management development committee of JPMorgan Chase’s board has three members, all seasoned business luminaries in their own right. Lee R. Raymond, the chairman, is the former long-serving chairman and chief executive of Exxon Mobil. Stephen B. Burke is chief executive of NBCUniversal. William C. Weldon is the former chairman and chief executive of Johnson & Johnson.

headline: This Week’s Cover Accurately Predicts the Super Bowl Winner (Half of the Time)
abstract: Behind the making of the two different covers of this week’s magazine, which will be distributed randomly to Times subscribers.
lead_paragraph: The cover of the magazine that you get in your Sunday Times may not be the same as your neighbor’s. In an effort to be equally supportive of (or offensive to) Seahawks and Broncos fans, we printed two covers, which will be distributed randomly to Times subscribers.

headline: Times Minute | Tray Tables Up
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Computer and Video Games', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Aviation Accidents and Safety', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: Airlines remake the staid in-flight safety video. Also on the Minute, the immigration debate and the origin of the first, first-person shooter game.
lead_paragraph: Airlines remake the staid in-flight safety video. Also on the Minute, the immigration debate and the origin of the first, first-person shooter game.

headline: Times Minute | Tray Tables Up
abstract: Airlines remake the staid in-flight safety video. Also on the Minute, the immigration debate and the origin of the first, first-person-shooter game.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: No Help for Farm Bill From Miffed Kansans in the House
abstract: Though the new farm bill passed, it did so without the help of the Kansas congressional delegation, which voted unanimously against it.
lead_paragraph: Few states are as identified with farming as Kansas. Among its nicknames are the “The Wheat State” and “American’s Bread Basket.” And Kansas’s lawmakers are quick to point out the importance of agriculture to the state’s economy.

headline: Days Before the Kickoff, a Timeout at Forty Ate
abstract: A couple from Interlaken, N.J., refueled over lunch at Forty Ate, a pop-up restaurant in the Renaissance New York Times Square Hotel, overlooking the Super Bowl festivities.
lead_paragraph: There were moments last week, during the run-up to Sunday’s Super Bowl, when the hordes of football fans thronging Broadway for the N.F.L.’s pregame festivities appeared to outnumber even the characters handing out fliers and asking, “Do you like comedy?” During one such moment, as others rode toboggans down a snowless slope, a couple from Interlaken, N.J., made their way to the second floor of the Renaissance New York Times Square Hotel, overlooking the madness, to refuel over lunch at Forty Ate, a pop-up restaurant conceived by the football league and the restaurateur Danny Meyer’s Union Square Hospitality Group. The hosts offered Thursday-to-Saturday ownership of choice tables for $50,000 (drinks not included), but found only four takers. The rest of the restaurant’s 72 seats went to ordinary reservation-makers and walk-ins.

headline: Image of the Day: January 31
abstract: Members of the Chinese community performing a lion dance as part of Chinese New Year celebrations in Kolkata, West Bengal.

headline: Bank of America Settlement on Bonds That Soured Is Approved
keywords: ['Decisions and Verdicts', 'Mortgage-Backed Securities', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A New York State judge blessed the 2011 agreement to cover some of the investors’ mortgage losses, but she also said that some of the legal claims by the investors were excluded from the settlement.
lead_paragraph: A New York State Supreme Court justice on Friday approved an $8.5 billion settlement between Bank of America and a group of mortgage securities investors, but the ruling contained a caveat that could create new problems for the bank.

headline: Landrieu Patriarch Talks About Family’s Political Prospects
abstract: Moon Landrieu discusses his family’s life in politics.
lead_paragraph: In an interview  for Friday’s article about the fortunes of his political family business in Louisiana, Moon Landrieu, the former New Orleans mayor and patriarch of the Landrieu family,  weighed in on its prospects. His son, Mayor Mitch Landrieu of New Orleans, has a Democratic primary on Saturday and his daughter, Senator Mary Landrieu, also a Democrat, is facing a grueling re-election race later this year in increasingly Republican Louisiana.

headline: Art Reaches New Heights in Alps
abstract: The art exhibition “Elevation 1049: Between Heaven and Hell” adds one more engaging distraction to Gstaad, which already has a fair share.
lead_paragraph: GSTAAD, Switzerland — In the summer of 2012, the London-based artist Christian Marclay was scouting locations around this postcard-perfect ski resort town in the Swiss Alps, looking for inspiration.

headline: ‘Back to the Future’ Musical Planned for London Opening
abstract: The production, being adapted by Robert Zemeckis, Bob Gale and Jamie Lloyd, will include new music as well as songs from the 1985 film.
lead_paragraph: “Back to the Future,” Robert Zemeckis’s 1985 comedy starring Michael J. Fox as Marty McFly, a teenager zapped from the 1980s back to the 1950s, is being transformed into a musical.  It is expected to have its premiere in London in 2015, a spokesman for Colin Ingram, one of the show’s producers, said on Friday.

headline: Investing in Safety
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: An oil boom in La Salle County, Texas has created a growing need for emergency workers.
lead_paragraph: An oil boom in La Salle County, Texas has created a growing need for emergency workers.

headline: A Concession Worker Is Ready for Super Bowl Duty
abstract: Inez Keyes, who has been working at Giants and Jets games for 22 years, said her job is like being a performer. “When you go in there, it’s showtime,” she said.
lead_paragraph: Not everyone in a uniform at MetLife Stadium on Super Bowl Sunday will wear a helmet. Inez Keyes will wear a smile. High-fiving fans and co-workers while serving beer, she is the Peyton Manning of hospitality. (“Go Beertenders!”) Ms. Keyes, 55, one of nearly 3,000 concession workers for Delaware North Companies, has brought her A-game to Giants and Jets games in the Meadowlands for 22 years, going from counter worker to cashier to beertender on the 100 Concourse. (She also supervises a concession stand at the Izod Center.) Ms. Keyes commutes two hours from Canarsie, Brooklyn, taking two subways and two buses to New Jersey; her routine will vary slightly on Super Bowl Sunday, but despite the later kickoff, she will still leave the house early to be in place for the big game.

headline: Big Ticket | Glass Aerie at a Record $50.9 Million
keywords: ['Luxury Goods and Services', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A full-floor penthouse in the Walker Tower condominium in Chelsea is the most expensive home ever sold downtown.
lead_paragraph: A stunning glass-sheathed penthouse at the pinnacle of Chelsea’s Walker Tower, the 1929 Art Deco skyscraper that underwent a ballyhooed conversion from iconic office building to 47 luxury condominiums, sold for $50,912,500 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The asking price was $55 million; monthly carrying costs are $9,361.81.

headline: “Where the Hell Is Robert E. Lee”
abstract: A song by Chelsea Crowell.
lead_paragraph: A song by Chelsea Crowell.

headline: Prince Said to Drop Suit Against Fans
abstract: Prince had filed a lawsuit against 22 fans, saying they had illegally posted videos of his concerts.
lead_paragraph: Prince has apparently thought better of the lawsuit he filed against 22 of his fans earlier this month, seeking $1 million from each for posting video recordings of his concert performances. Or perhaps the lawsuit was simply a shot across the bow, meant as a reminder that Prince – who has threatened his fans and collectors with legal action in the past – would not tolerate trading in unauthorized recordings of his work.

headline: Obama Outlines Plan to Help Unemployed
abstract: President Obama announced initiatives to help the long-term unemployed get jobs from both the private and public sectors.
lead_paragraph: President Obama announced initiatives to help the long-term unemployed get jobs from both the private and public sectors.

headline: Today in Small Business: the Most Promising Companies
abstract: Amazon considers raising its fees. And two business owners debate the merits of the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Seen on the Street | Outside the Fall/Winter 2014 Copenhagen Women’s Shows
abstract: A glimpse at what guys and gals are wearing this season.
lead_paragraph: A glimpse at what guys and gals are wearing this season.

headline: Artist Files Suit Over Missing Empire State Building Paintings
abstract: The artist Kysa Johnson created paintings for the concourse level of the Empire State Building that were installed in 2000. The building’s owner cannot locate them and says they were “likely destroyed.”
lead_paragraph: For many years, visitors to the concourse level of the Empire State Building walked by a series of large, lush paintings that seemed to be abstractions but that actually represented the atomic or molecular structure of the materials — brick, steel, cement, aluminum — used in the skyscraper’s construction.

headline: More Mindfulness, Less Meditation
