abstract: The practice has benefits, but it is far more effective as a technique of self-management than as a means of personal transformation, Tony Schwartz writes in the Life@Work column.
lead_paragraph: Here’s the promise: Meditation – and mindfulness meditation, in particular – will reduce your cortisol level, blood pressure, social anxiety and depression. It will increase your immune response, resilience and focus and improve your relationships — including with yourself. It will also bolster your performance at work and provide inner peace. It may even cure psoriasis.

headline: Teacher and Troll Both Start With ‘T’
abstract: By all accounts, young people are gravitating away from watching television in the traditional way, but that’s not stopping Nickelodeon.
lead_paragraph: By all accounts, young people are gravitating away from watching television in the traditional way, but that’s not stopping Nickelodeon from going after very young people. On Monday afternoon at 1, the channel unveils “Wallykazam!,” an animated series full of early literacy lessons for preschoolers. It’s a “Sesame Street” approach transplanted to a land of magic and kid-friendly mythical beings.

headline: Harmonic Requiem for a Genre
abstract: “Roadshow: The Fall of Film Musicals in the 1960s,” through Friday, has five Hollywood musicals on the screen at the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: It won’t be grand: no overtures or entr’actes or glossy souvenir programs for sale in the lobby. But “Roadshow: The Fall of Film Musicals in the 1960s,” through Friday, has five of those rare birds — Hollywood musicals — glittering and strutting across the screen at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: What Lives On After Death
abstract: Since it began organizing exhibitions in 2012, the Robert Rauschenberg Foundation has looked far and wide for artists, staying mostly clear of the career of its famous founder.
lead_paragraph: Since it began organizing exhibitions in 2012, the Robert Rauschenberg Foundation has looked far and wide for artists, staying mostly clear of the career of its famous founder, who died in 2008 and wanted the foundation to serve as a home for idiosyncratic, politically vocal work.

headline: Translations That Move
abstract: Ballet and modern dance once were bitter enemies, but ballet dancers sneaked off to modern classes, and modern dancers turned up in ballet studios.
lead_paragraph: Ballet and modern dance once were bitter enemies. Yet because dancers tend to be blessed with curiosity, ballet dancers sneaked off to modern classes, and modern dancers turned up in ballet studios.

headline: Three Composers Basking in Bach
abstract: Although the Miller Theater at Columbia University is indelibly tied to contemporary composers and early music, the Bach canon has long formed a third pillar.
lead_paragraph: Although the Miller Theater at Columbia University is indelibly tied to contemporary composers and early music, the voluminous canon of Johann Sebastian Bach has long formed a third pillar of that institution’s programming. But this season, the theater’s customary Bach series gets an intriguing overhaul with Bach, Revisited, a three-concert sequence in which prominent living composers pair selections by Bach with their own works to try to illuminate connections.

headline: The Musical Trail of an Explorer
abstract: The Panamanian pianist Danilo Pérez is an exceptional musician, even without much framework.
lead_paragraph: The Panamanian pianist Danilo Pérez is an exceptional musician, even without much framework, as in the loosest, most intuitive moments of Wayne Shorter’s current band, of which he’s been a member since 2000. But he puts a lot of framework in his own music: He wants to represent jazz within its broadest possible contexts of place and history. He’s about to release a new record, “Panama 500” (Mack Avenue), which integrates Panamanian folklore, European classical music and jazz. Some of it describes the Spanish explorer Vasco Núñez de Balboa’s crossing the isthmus of Panama in 1513.

headline: Did George Washington Want to Burn New York City?
abstract: Readers asked questions about George Washington’s desire to burn Lower Manhattan and why some Long Island Rail Road trains go to the West Side Yard.
lead_paragraph: Q. As George Washington’s birthday nears, I recall a story that he tried to burn New York City during the Revolution. Really?

headline: Orhan Pamuk’s Istanbul
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Mosques', 'Books and Literature', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Ottoman Empire']
abstract: “I belong to this city,” says the writer about his birthplace and longtime home. Join him on a deeply personal tour through Istanbul’s neighborhoods and his memories.
lead_paragraph: On a windswept afternoon in mid-December, the writer Orhan Pamuk stood in a leafy square around the corner from Istanbul University, absorbed in a 40-year-old memory. He walked past parked motorcycles, sturdy oaks and a stone fountain, browsing through secondhand books in front of cluttered shops occupying the bottom floors of a quadrangle of pale yellow buildings. Sahaflar Carsisi, Istanbul’s used-book bazaar, has been a magnet for literary types since the Byzantine era.

headline: 36 Hours in Manchester, Vt.
abstract: From sleigh rides to shopping, crafts to cuisine, you can find it during a weekend in this southern Vermont town.
lead_paragraph: Manchester may never be the ultimate Ski Town, U.S.A. Its gilded mansions and upscale factory outlets continue to draw more shoppers than ski bums. But this bucolic town in southern Vermont, blessed with two nearby ski resorts and backcountry trails that meander through the picturesque Battenkill Valley, is emerging as a popular winter getaway among Bostonians, New Yorkers and even Europeans looking to get acquainted with Vermont’s unspoiled Green Mountains, while also exploring Manchester’s bounty of local arts-and-crafts shops and artisanal restaurants. Its most recognizable property, the stately Equinox Hotel, underwent a major overhaul a few years ago. And the town just installed a pair of traffic roundabouts along the main strip to ease congestion. Don’t expect Aspen, or even Stowe. But Manchester has its own relaxed, if sophisticated, ambience that is making it a popular four-season destination.

headline: In East Africa, Safaris That Leave a Lighter Footprint
abstract: On visits to eco-friendly camps in Kenya and Tanzania, the author has lunch with the elephants and takes in scenes dotted with zebras, giraffes and wildebeests.
lead_paragraph: “Want to have lunch with the elephants?” That sounded like an offer we couldn’t refuse — even if at least half the menu was bound to consist of hunks of grass and splintered acacia branches. Luckily, the human side of the invitation included gazpacho, zucchini frittata and salad. My husband and I did mind our manners, keeping our picnic well inside the Land Rover while a herd of our multi-ton hostesses grazed peacefully a few yards away, surrounded by children of all sizes. Introductions were made by our guide, Seronoi, and his spotter, Jackson, who identified our companions by the distinctive shape of their heads, ears and tusks. What better welcome to Samburu National Park, and to the sort of experience we’d hoped to find on safari in East Africa.

headline: Eclectic East Austin
abstract: A mile from downtown, this newly fashionable arts district is home to everything from cafes to carwashes, bookstores to barbecue joints.
lead_paragraph: A mile from downtown, East Austin has historically been a working-class neighborhood, a vibrant enclave heavily populated by African-Americans because of an earlier era of segregationist laws — and later, a home to Mexican-American residents. These days, it’s also the city’s newly fashionable arts district, with studios, galleries, cocktail bars, cafes and all manner of food trucks popping up on most every block. Beloved taquerias and barbecue joints, ramshackle carwashes and Christian outreach ministries now jostle against shiny condos, fancy restaurants and, in refurbished bungalows, groovy hair salons with names like Peacock and Orbit.

headline: A New Delhi Market for Savvy Shoppers
abstract: Mehar Chand Market has emerged as a hot shopping spot, with merchants selling everything from fashion to food.
lead_paragraph: Mehar Chand Market, a bustling stretch of road in the heart of New Delhi, India’s capital, has recently emerged as the hottest shopping area in the city among cognoscenti on the hunt for one-of-a-kind finds. Gone are the longtime drugstores, tailors and small groceries that catered to nearby residents, many of them government workers. Today, young designers have opened boutiques along this half-mile strip on Lodhi Road, selling everything from home goods to the latest fashions. The wares all have a distinct Indian touch, whether it’s a silk sari fashioned in bright colors or a bright pillowcase shot through with an ethnic pattern. And their reasonable prices compared with other upscale retail districts in town stand out.

headline: Russia’s Ice Skating Resurgence
abstract: After almost a decade without any top-level women’s figure skaters, Russia suddenly has more than it can use.
lead_paragraph: After almost a decade without any top-level women’s figure skaters, Russia suddenly has more than it can use.

headline: In Russia, Skating Booms Again
abstract: After a long fallow period, Russia suddenly has more top-level female figure skaters than it can fit on its Olympic team.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — After almost a decade without any top-level women’s figure skaters, Russia suddenly has more than it can use.

headline: K.K.R. Buys Stake in German Soccer Club
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company has agreed to buy a 9.7 percent stake in Hertha BSC, a soccer club in Berlin. It is virtually unheard of for an American private equity firm to buy a stake in German soccer.
lead_paragraph: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, a private equity giant with its hands in a range of businesses, from natural gas to maritime finance, has bought into a new sector: German soccer.

headline: Security Concerns on a Honduran Island
abstract: A string of recent crimes on Roatán, the largest of the Bay Islands, has prompted outrage, and efforts are underway to improve safety.
lead_paragraph: Honduras has the highest murder rate in the world, but the country’s idyllic Bay Islands have long been considered a safe haven, largely immune from the drug-fueled violence that has plagued the Honduran mainland. However, a string of recent crimes on Roatán, the largest of the Bay Islands, has prompted outrage, with some residents calling for greater autonomy and more effective policing for the islands.

headline: A Bird Flies South, and It’s News
abstract: A large, charismatic white owl has been seen far from its usual wintering zones, even as far south as Florida. But what does it mean?
lead_paragraph: DUXBURY, Mass. — The snowy owl seemed almost complacent, showing the confidence of a top predator whose bright yellow eyes suggested she might be sizing you up as a weaker combatant — or perhaps a large snack.

headline: Renaming the Tappan Zee After Pete Seeger Is a Terrible Idea
abstract: The singer would probably have hated the gesture.
lead_paragraph: Pete Seeger, who died this week at 94, was not only a folk singer of near-mythic status but also an ardent environmentalist who helped save the Hudson from turning into New York’s Cuyahoga.

headline: Powder in Letters Near Super Bowl Site Is Not Hazardous, Authorities Say
abstract: After reports of suspicious packages, at least one of which turned out to contain cornstarch, the authorities were sent to several hotels near MetLife Stadium.
lead_paragraph: Several letters containing a suspicious substance sent to locations in New York City and New Jersey, causing a large-scale response by the authorities, have been found not to be hazardous after preliminary testing, according to a statement issued by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

headline: Giving Credit: A Work in Progress at The Times
abstract: Complaints from McClatchy News and the Washington Post spur discussion.
lead_paragraph: Curtis Tate, a reporter for McClatchy News’s Washington bureau, spent a recent weekend generating spreadsheets from a database on hazardous materials for his story on the increasing amount of crude oil spilled in rail accidents.

headline: A Leader Shows Vulnerability in Turkey’s Cash Crisis
abstract: Turkey’s problems extend past bond purchases and interest rates to questions about the stability of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s government.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — First, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan criticized the bold move by Turkey’s central bank this week to raise interest rates sharply to halt the decline in the country’s currency, telling reporters that higher borrowing costs would lead to inflation — an argument that contravenes accepted economic logic.

headline: Need Tax Help? I.R.S. May Not Be the Best Place to Go
abstract: Consumers will have to wait longer for help over the phone and help at its walk-in centers will be reduced because of budget and staff cuts.
lead_paragraph: IF you’re ready to file your 2013 federal income tax return, you can do so starting now. The official start of tax-filing season arrived later than anticipated because of a delay caused by last year’s government shutdown.

headline: A Parting Gift as Ben Bernanke Hangs Up His Cleats
abstract: As he departs the Federal Reserve chairmanship, Ben S. Bernanke has something for the highlight reel: his own baseball card.
lead_paragraph: Ben S. Bernanke now has his own baseball card.

headline: New York Court Archivist Isn’t Letting Retirement Stop Him
abstract: After 30 years retrieving court files and organizing archival material, Bruce Abrams retired. A couple of days later, he was back.
lead_paragraph: It was just another day at the old grind on Wednesday for Bruce Abrams, 66, an archivist at the Division of Old Records in Manhattan: the rat race commute, a brown-bag lunch and eight hours retrieving files and organizing archival material, as he has done for 30 years.

headline: What I Love | Dan Kainen
abstract: The artist, author and inventor lives in an East 12th Street apartment featuring his custom designs and furnishings.
lead_paragraph: The artist, author and inventor lives in an East 12th Street apartment featuring his custom designs and furnishings.

headline: Space-Saving D.I.Y. in the DNA
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Dan Kainen, an artist/author/inventor, has customized his apartment in innovative ways.
lead_paragraph: Dan Kainen’s pride and joy is his broom closet. It’s an amenity that’s not normally found in a 750-square-foot apartment, but Mr. Kainen has cleverly created and camouflaged storage units throughout his miniloft in Greenwich Village.

headline: Classically Trained
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Dresses', 'Academy Awards (Oscars)', 'Golden Globes (Awards)', 'Movies']
abstract: What the actress Sally Hawkins has been wearing during premiere and awards season.
lead_paragraph: WHOSally Hawkins

headline: Red Carpet Watch: Sally Hawkins’s Fashion Choices
abstract: The English actress, who is nominated for an Oscar for Best Supporting Actress, has an eclectic style.
lead_paragraph: The English actress, who is nominated for an Oscar for Best Supporting Actress, has an eclectic style.

headline: “When the Master Calls the Roll”
abstract: A song by Rosanne Cash.
lead_paragraph: A song by Rosanne Cash.

headline: Petite Crevette, the House of the Flying Lobster
abstract: Petite Crevette, in its third location in Brooklyn, is owned by Neil Ganic, notorious for a legendary quarrel with a patron about lobster.
lead_paragraph: On a mild night in January, Neil Ganic, wearing a white chef’s coat, his signature porkpie hat tilted low, greeted customers at his restaurant, Petite Crevette. The room appears to be the foyer or staging area of a larger place, but this is pretty much it: maritime curios, tight tables, original artwork and framed photos below an aqua-green ceiling. Two line chefs, sequestered in the minuscule kitchen behind a barricade of coolers and counter space and hanging bric-a-brac, conjure aromas of grilled fish and saffron amid the soft sound of Latin jazz. Most who enter either know Mr. Ganic personally or know of him and his rather formidable reputation.

headline: First, You Must Kill Your Inner Movie Star
abstract: Tess Dworman and Niv Acosta presented new works at New York Live Arts, one about the body, the other about identity.
lead_paragraph: When dance artists share an evening, it’s natural to want to know what they’re doing in the same place. Who put them together and why? On Thursday, the choreographers Niv Acosta and Tess Dworman presented new works at New York Live Arts, and the junction was worrying: They brought out the superficial in each other.

headline: I Am Not A Wise Man
abstract: And a prize doesn’t make me one.
lead_paragraph: A wise guy, yes. And maybe — I like to think so — someone with a pretty good though by no means error-free track record on depression economics. But Chris House is right, even though he refuses to say what nutty things I’ve said that come remotely close to Ed Prescott.

headline: New York Hotels Have Rooms for Super Bowl Weekend
keywords: ['Football', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Super Bowl', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: A number of New York hotels are promoting the availability of rooms for Super Bowl weekend.
lead_paragraph: It’s not too late to book a room in New York for Super Bowl weekend. In fact, many hotels are still advertising availability, attempting to entice last-minute travelers with tailgate party packages and post-game “detox” deals.

headline: The Policy Lapsed, but No One Knew
abstract: The price of long-term care insurance? Eternal vigilance.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes you do everything right and it still goes wrong.

headline: Report Opens Way to Approval for Keystone Pipeline
keywords: ['Keystone Pipeline System', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Secretary of State John Kerry, who has never publicly offered his personal views on the Keystone XL oil pipeline, now must make a recommendation on the international project to President Obama.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department released a report on Friday concluding that the Keystone XL pipeline would not substantially worsen carbon pollution, leaving an opening for President Obama to approve the politically divisive project.

headline: The Best Special Effects of the Last 35 Years
abstract: The video essayist Nelson Carvajal surveys the Oscar winners from “Star Wars” on.
lead_paragraph: We hardly need proof of how quickly technology is moving, but sometimes it’s nice to get a refresher.

headline: Microsoft Said to Be Close to Naming a New Chief
abstract: Satya Nadella, a 22-year Microsoft employee, has been in charge of its cloud computing business; a change in Bill Gates’s role is also under discussion.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Microsoft has spent five months looking for a new face to help the company evolve along with the mobile age. Turns out, it seems to be choosing a familiar face and largely sticking to its current path.

headline: Lone Fan Tackles the N.F.L. Over Super Bowl Ticket Prices
keywords: ['Football', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Super Bowl', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Consumer Protection', 'Series']
abstract: Josh Finkelman, 28, of New Brunswick, N.J., is the Erin Brockovich of Super Bowl tickets: Frustrated by their prices, he filed a class-action lawsuit against the N.F.L.
lead_paragraph: Josh Finkelman’s quest for Super Bowl justice began on a Monday in December with the click of a computer mouse. The day before, a busy football Sunday, the Seattle Seahawks had demolished the St. Louis Rams and the sport’s postseason landscape was finally shaping up.

headline: Signs Point to a ‘Seinfeld’ Reunion, if Ever So Brief
abstract: Among the clues: a sighting of Jerry Seinfeld and Jason Alexander at Tom’s Restaurant, their characters’ favorite meeting place.
lead_paragraph: It may be all about nothing, but that would only be appropriate.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Google’s Stock Split Comes as Shares Hit Record Highs
abstract: Remember when Google announced plans to split its stock, creating a third class of shares? Now the company’s board has finally cleared the way for the stock division.
lead_paragraph: Remember when Google announced plans to split its stock, creating a third class of shares? No worries if you couldn’t; the technology titan announced it in the spring of 2012.

headline: Winter Olympians to Follow on Instagram
abstract: Many Olympians have mastered the art of capturing extraordinary tricks on camera from their point of view. Here are some of the best on Instagram.
lead_paragraph: The Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, are bound to include plenty of “How’d they do that?” moments. Athletes have perfected moves that demand a double-take: gravity-defying ski jumps, jaw-dropping snowboarding tricks on the halfpipe, flawless ice dancing routines.

headline: After Meeting, Republicans Seem Unsure of Way Forward
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'National Debt (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: A three-day discussion of issues that ended Friday did not result in concrete decisions on pressing matters facing lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Md. — House Republicans ended a three-day retreat here united in their division. They agreed they wanted to “go big” with a midterm election agenda that would give voters a clear choice, and not simply be a campaign focused on their criticism of President Obama.

headline: The Gun Report: January 31, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 6, Todd Kuchman and his brother, Jaye, founders of the Denver-based Advanced Ballistic Concepts, launched the multiple impact bullet, a 3-shots-in-1 round that splits into several fragments. Meant for self-defense, the shrapnel is held together by a Y-shaped ballistic-strength fiber, which makes for better accuracy than a shotgun’s blast of pellets, thus minimizing the chances of hitting unintended people or things. The company’s slogans include, “Because you can’t afford to miss” and “First hit advantage is everything!”

headline: Book Review Podcast: Secrets of Success
abstract: Sandra Tsing Loh discusses “The Hybrid Tiger” by Quanyu Huang and “The Triple Package” by Amy Chua and Jed Rubenfeld
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Sandra Tsing Loh reviews two new books about success in America: “The Hybrid Tiger” by Quanyu Huang and “The Triple Package” by Amy Chua and Jed Rubenfeld. Ms. Loh writes:

headline: The Low-inflationary Trap
abstract: In this case, zero is irrelevant.
lead_paragraph: Dean Baker is, of course, completely right here. There isn’t a red line you cross when going from positive to negative inflation, with all sorts of bad things suddenly happening. What matters is inflation relative to the rate that best suits your circumstances. Since the euro area would clearly be best off with an inflation rate well above current levels, this is a disastrous report:

headline: A Campaign for Mayor, and for a Mate
abstract: Chris Coffey and Adam Riff fell in love while working on Bloomberg’s 2009 re-election campaign.
lead_paragraph: When Chris Coffey talks about love, he often talks about New York.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Jan. 31
abstract: Subjects include the frozen Hudson River, a giant crane on its way to New York and scenes from Super Bowl Boulevard.
lead_paragraph: Subjects include the frozen Hudson River, a giant crane on its way to New York and scenes from Super Bowl Boulevard.

headline: About That Coin
abstract: Not ridiculous.
lead_paragraph: Some comments I’ve seen indicate that people still think the trillion-dollar platinum coin idea was self-evidently ridiculous. Guys, you missed the memo — literally. From last month:

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Tim’s Vermeer,’ ‘That Awkward Moment’ and ‘Labor Day’
abstract: Times critics on “Tim’s Vermeer,” “That Awkward Moment” and “Labor Day.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on the documentary “Tim’s Vermeer,” the romantic comedy “That Awkward Moment” and the drama “Labor Day.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Are They Selling Sex or Beer? It’s Super Bowl Media Literacy Bingo!
abstract: The Super Bowl is the perfect time for a rousing family game of Media Literacy Bingo.
lead_paragraph: My children (12, 9, 8 and 7) all fully understand that one watches the Super Bowl as much for the advertisements as for the game, especially when one’s team isn’t playing. And here on the East Coast, Super Bowl watching tends to be a family affair for people with young children. (As my husband said when I mentioned missing Super Bowl parties, “You want to take the kids to a party at 6:30 on a school night?”)

headline: You Can’t Beat These Wedding Singers
keywords: ['Weddings and Engagements', 'Grammy Awards', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: A first-person account of getting married at the 56th Grammy Awards. Queen Latifah makes it official, with Macklemore and Madonna providing the vocals for a ceremony with 32 other couples.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — My fiancée, Robyn Monks, and I were standing in a row with 32 other couples at the Grammys last Sunday night in one of those cavernous entryways to the Staples Center arena (the kind through which beasts and fighters might have passed in Rome’s Colosseum), and we were about to enter and be married by Queen Latifah on live television.

headline: From High Above Times Square, a Super Bowl Tease
abstract: Millions of dollars’ worth of financial transactions are flowing in conference rooms above Times Square, while Super Bowl revelers gather on the streets. And the financial workers are mostly just annoyed with the hubbub..
lead_paragraph: The football carnival that has taken over 14 blocks of Broadway around Times Square may be fun for Super Bowl crowds, but those who work in the surrounding buildings are growing weary.

headline: Passions in a Pastor’s Wake
abstract: Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church chose not to renew the contract of its interim pastor, the Rev. Carmen Mason-Browne. Some say her race and her gender influenced the decision.
lead_paragraph: At the Rev. Carmen Mason-Browne’s farewell party in January, many supporters stood to give impassioned testimonials to the profound effect she had had on them in her two years as interim pastor at Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church in Fort Greene, Brooklyn. One spoke of her poetic sermons, another of her initiative to include children in the service, and another of her commitment to social justice.

headline: Contender for Microsoft Helm Seen as Unlikely to Shake It Up
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Cloud Computing', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: As Microsoft hunts for its new chief executive, the company is said to have zeroed in on a company man who’s spearheaded Microsoft’s efforts to stay on the cutting edge. But Satya Nadella probably isn’t the man for drastic action.
lead_paragraph: As Microsoft hunts for its new chief executive, the firm appears to have zeroed in on a true company man who has spearheaded Microsoft’s efforts to stay on the cutting edge.

headline: Syrian Talks, Ending First Round, Fail Even to Agree on Easing Aid Blockade
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The first round of peace negotiations ended without agreement over the easing of the Syrian government’s blockade of humanitarian aid to besieged communities.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The first round of the Syria peace talks ended on Friday without achieving even its most modest goal: easing the Syrian government’s blockade on the delivery of food and medicine to besieged communities.

headline: A Super Bowl Party Briefly Interrupted by ‘I Dos’
abstract: It is unusual but some couples end up getting married on Super Bowl Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Most engaged couples who are planning a wedding date usually pass on Super Bowl Sunday, but Rachel Graham and Julian Ho have a different game plan, as do Shawna Cook and Brian Mascarelli.

headline: Verizon Wireless Prepares Network for TV Broadcasting
abstract: Verizon expects to upgrade its network with the new broadcasting technology by the third quarter this year.
lead_paragraph: Cord cutters, the people who cancel their cable TV subscriptions in favor of Internet-based alternatives, are a looming threat for the television industry. Verizon Wireless wants to capitalize on that.

headline: A Couple of Contradictions
abstract: A lot of articles have been written about Amy Chua and Jed Rubenfeld — some of them so contradictory that they almost cancel each other out.
lead_paragraph: In the course of working on the profile of Amy Chua and Jed Rubenfeld that I wrote for this weekend’s magazine, I came across many things that had been written about the couple — some of them so contradictory that they almost canceled each other out. Chua’s supporters see her as a courageous truth-teller, willing to sacrifice her good name to show how permissive parenting has put American children in peril; her critics see her as a cynical pop-cultural savant, exploiting stereotypes and anxieties to sell some books. Reactions to Rubenfeld have been similarly erratic, though less extreme. Here is a sliver of what’s out there.

headline: Jennifer Lawrence’s Big Dior Contract, Transgender and 62-Year-Old Models and the Next Dame of the British Empire
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'State of the Union Message (US)']
abstract: Plus, Victoria Beckham’s “interactive editorial,” a new Marie-Antoinette Diet and more, as we run the numbers from the last week in style and culture.
lead_paragraph: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: A Beekman area co-op with a garden; a Battery Park City condo with many amenities; and a Ditmas Park Victorian built in 1910.
lead_paragraph: A Beekman area co-op with a garden; a Battery Park City condo with many amenities; and a Ditmas Park Victorian built in 1910.

headline: Christie Linked to Knowledge of Shut Lanes
abstract: David Wildstein, a former Port Authority official, says there is evidence to prove the New Jersey governor knew about the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge, which the governor has denied.
lead_paragraph: The former Port Authority official who personally oversaw the lane closings at the George Washington Bridge, central to the scandal now swirling around Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, said on Friday that “evidence exists” that the governor knew about the closings when they were happening.

headline: On the Market in the Region
abstract: A Huntington Bay cottage on a wooded half-acre and a Greenwich colonial with a stone fence and heated pool.
lead_paragraph: A Huntington Bay cottage on a wooded half-acre and a Greenwich colonial with a stone fence and heated pool.

headline: Triage for Treasures After a Bomb Blast
keywords: ['Museums', 'Art', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: Experts sort painstakingly through the Museum of Islamic Art in Cairo, devastated by a truck bomb attack last month at police headquarters across the street.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A man in a white lab coat sat alone among piles of blown-off ceiling, mangled metal and splintered wood here on Thursday inside the Museum of Islamic Art — home to a world-renowned collection that covers centuries of art from countries across the Islamic world. He carefully separated ochre-tinted pieces of old glass from the clear shards of modern showcases.

headline: “Hardin Wouldn’t Run”
abstract: A song by Johnny Cash.
lead_paragraph: A song by Johnny Cash.

headline: When Owning a Home Is Cold Comfort
abstract: A federal heating assistance program illuminates the problems that arise when real estate is the only significant asset a family holds.
lead_paragraph: The declining fortunes of the middle class in New York City are often most easily observed in the context of gentrification and soaring real estate valuations. There is an obvious doom that befalls anyone renting long-term in a neighborhood on a rapid trajectory to preciousness. This doom, or fear of it, in turn leads to an intensified idealization of homeownership — though the ownership rate in the city, at just over 30 percent, is less than half the figure for the country over all — a sense that there could be few problems immune to solution had one had the foresight (and resourcefulness) to a buy a brownstone in Brooklyn for $400,000 in 1995.

headline: Letter From Wildstein’s Lawyer on Lane Closings
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey knew about the lane closings as they were happening, a letter released on Friday by the lawyer of David Wildstein said.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey knew about the lane closings as they were happening, a letter released on Friday by the lawyer of David Wildstein said.

headline: A Cadillac That Says ‘Achtung’
abstract: Cadillac still has a ways to go to match the cachet of German luxury brands, but the third-generation CTS puts Cadillac firmly in the conversation.
lead_paragraph: Cadillac still has a ways to go to match the cachet of German luxury brands, but the third-generation CTS puts Cadillac firmly in the conversation.

headline: Finally, Real Diva in Lineup for Game
abstract: Renée Fleming will sing “The Star-Spangled Banner” at the Super Bowl on Sunday, a first for an opera star.
lead_paragraph: Since 1967, the national anthem has been sung at the Super Bowl by a boy band and a college a cappella group. It has been belted by a morning-TV host and bugled by a trumpeter (four times!).

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Ukraine, Syria, Sri Lanka and China.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Ukraine, Syria, Sri Lanka and China.

headline: Lives of the After-Party
abstract: The drugs and alcohol may not be as free-flowing, but the cast of “Saturday Night Live” continues to star in one of the longest-running soirees in the city.
lead_paragraph: “Got the boss coming!” a security worker shouted.

headline: Nocturnalist at the Super Bowl | A Near-Cigar With Mike Ditka
abstract: At “Mike, Mike and Mike,” Mike Ditka joined the ESPN talk show hosts Mike Greenberg and Mike Golic to discuss the Super Bowl and answer questions from the audience.
lead_paragraph: The air pooled with machine-generated smoke, wisps rising into the rafters of the cabaret bar, where the presently chic tropes of such places — taxidermy creatures like a fox and a crow — peered down into the audience. But onstage, flanked by velvet curtains, in place of a sultry singer was a very different sort of star: the septuagenarian former football coach Mike Ditka.

headline: Weekend Reading: Super Bowl Quotes for Wall Street
abstract: Big banks are giving their junior workers time off just in time for the Super Bowl. This week we’re looking at quotable National Football League stars and Wall Street financier counterparts.
lead_paragraph: Big banks are giving their junior workers time off just in time for the Super Bowl. This week we’re looking at quotable National Football League stars and Wall Street financier counterparts.

headline: Since They Lost Sammy
abstract: A reader responds to an article about a boy’s parents who became activists for safer streets after their son was struck and killed by a van in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: In last Sunday’s Metropolitan section, N.R. Kleinfield wrote about Gary Eckstein and Amy Cohen, who became activists for safer streets after their son, Sammy, was struck and killed by a van in Brooklyn. A reader responded via email:

headline: The Stakes Off the Field
abstract: Should states be able to legalize sports betting and would that be worthwhile?

headline: Taking Aim at Android, After a Jilting at Nokia
abstract: Former employees of Nokia have built a new smartphone using open-source software to compete with phones running the Android operating system.
lead_paragraph: HELSINKI, Finland — Marc Dillon still remembers the sick feeling that overcame him when Nokia announced it was scrapping a software project that he and hundreds of other developers had spent years creating.

headline: A Break From Opera for Orchestra in Madrid
abstract: The Orquesta Sinfónica de Madrid put on a program of Boulez and Mahler after performing in two operas at Teatro Real this week.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — In keeping with a long tradition in classical music, the Orquesta Sinfónica de Madrid is an ensemble with two identities. It is the official orchestra of the Teatro Real, this city’s major opera company, and as such has been working hard of late, especially this week.

headline: Good Enough? That’s Great
abstract: How couples deal with long-term relationships that inevitably grow short on excitement.
lead_paragraph: What’s the best way to recalibrate a marriage as the years pass? I wish I had the answer, because clearly millions of us would like to know.

headline: Anti-Gay Policies Chill Viewers’ Interest
abstract: Because of the anti-gay statements of the Russian president, gays are divided about watching the Sochi Olympics.
lead_paragraph: Outraged by a new Russian law that outlaws “homosexual propaganda” and by President Vladimir Putin’s recent remarks that gays who go to Sochi for the Olympic Winter Games should “stay away from children,” some gays and lesbians are planning to boycott watching the Olympics on TV.

headline: At First, Love Runs Hot, but Then It Always Cools
abstract: The mezzo-soprano Alice Coote traversed an emotional arc in a recital of French works at Zankel Hall on Thursday evening.
lead_paragraph: During her recital at Zankel Hall on Thursday evening the mezzo-soprano Alice Coote explored “Les chemins de l’amour” (“The Paths of Love”), tracing a romantic arc of bliss, ambiguity and despair. “Les Chemins,” the title of the Poulenc song that opened the program, set the mood for an evening of mélodie, beautifully accompanied by the eminent British pianist Graham Johnson.

headline: Scientific Pride and Prejudice
keywords: ['Science and Technology', 'Research', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Researchers can learn from literary critics how to confront their own biases.
lead_paragraph: SCIENCE is in crisis, just when we need it most. Two years ago, C. Glenn Begley and Lee M. Ellis reported in Nature that they were able to replicate only six out of 53 “landmark” cancer studies. Scientists now worry that many published scientific results are simply not true. The natural sciences often offer themselves as a model to other disciplines. But this time science might look for help to the humanities, and to literary criticism in particular.

headline: The Transformation of Lady Edith
abstract: Season 4 of “Downton Abbey” introduces a major shift in plot, as well as a shift in style, evident in the fashion of the character Lady Edith Crawley, played by Laura Carmichael.
lead_paragraph: Poor, sad Lady Edith. Early on in “Downton Abbey,” the PBS “Masterpiece Classic” family saga, it seemed that the much-overlooked, undervalued middle sister of the Crawley clan had been dealt a rough hand. Her assertive nose, wan manner and decorously dowdy wardrobe had apparently rendered her marriage prospects slim to nil. Be kind to her, she has so few advantages, Lady Cora, her mother, urges Edith’s sister Mary. To which Mary peevishly replies that Edith has none at all.

headline: Get Them While They’re Green
abstract: Fresh green peppercorns add a kicky, herbaceous flavor to tender seared veal chops.
lead_paragraph: The first time I went to Thailand, of the various unfamiliar items in the vegetable market, it was glossy bright green peppercorns, fresh ones, in juicy clusters, that were the most exciting.

headline: The German Lessons Are Paying Off
abstract: Cadillac is becoming the mobile version of a gentrified neighborhood: The old-timers have begun to move out, replaced by younger buyers. The new CTS should speed the process.
lead_paragraph: When Cadillac set out to revive its arthritic cars and unfashionable image, beginning with the original CTS sedan of 2003, the brand seemed as retirement-ready as many of its customers.

headline: CTS Vsport: The BMW Beater
abstract: Cadillac offers the CTS Vsport sedan in a version that trades some luxury for lavish mechanicals and bracing performance.
lead_paragraph: A $60,000 sticker price rarely suggests a bargain among automobiles.

headline: Cadillac Lays Its Wreath to Rest
abstract: Cadillac has changed its logo again, this time dropping the laurel wreath. Years ago, the brand had also dispensed with the ducks.
lead_paragraph: Cadillac takes its insignia, which it calls “the crest,” very seriously. But that doesn’t keep it from tinkering with the logo every now and then.

headline: Review: 2014 Cadillac CTS
abstract: The last two generations of Cadillac’s CTS have come close to running with the best Germany has to offer. G.M.’s third try confidently drives to the front of the pack.
lead_paragraph: The last two generations of Cadillac’s CTS have come close to running with the best Germany has to offer. G.M.’s third try confidently drives to the front of the pack.

headline: Musharraf’s Request to Leave Pakistan for Treatment Is Rejected
abstract: Lawyers said a special court issued arrest warrants in the treason case against the former leader Pervez Musharraf and directed him to appear in court to be formally charged.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A special court on Friday rejected a request by the former military ruler Pervez Musharraf to leave Pakistan for medical treatment and instead issued arrest warrants in the treason case against him, according to lawyers in the case.

headline: Critic of Online Ad Firm Blinkx Is Part of the Controversy
abstract: Benjamin Edelman, a Harvard Business School professor whose blog post set off a plunge in a company’s share price, has declined to identify the client who paid him to write the post.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A Harvard Business School professor has raised pointed questions in an article about an Internet advertising company, prompting a plunge in its stock price. He himself, though, is now a subject of controversy.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Game On
abstract: An infectious exuberance has taken over Broadway in Midtown Manhattan, transformed by Super Bowl events into a winter carnival.
lead_paragraph: An infectious exuberance has taken over Broadway in Midtown Manhattan, transformed by Super Bowl events into a winter carnival.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Game On
abstract: Scenes of Super Bowl celebrations in midtown.
lead_paragraph: An infectious exuberance has taken over Broadway in Midtown, transformed by Super Bowl events into a winter carnival. For the well-bundled fans: marching bands, cheerleaders, uniforms of the Broncos and Seahawks. For thrill seekers: a toboggan slide. As cameras click everywhere, police and their mounts remain vigilant. The sharp-eyed spied an actual football player, on his way to a broadcast booth.

headline: Movie Review: 'That Awkward Moment'
abstract: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews "That Awkward Moment."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews "That Awkward Moment."

headline: Movie Review: 'Labor Day'
abstract: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews "Labor Day."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews "Labor Day."

headline: "Building" by Steven and William Ladd
abstract: Steven and William Ladd's magical, whimsical worlds are the subject of a new show at the Mingei International Museum. This video illuminates the brothers’ inspirations and creative process.
lead_paragraph: Steven and William Ladd's magical, whimsical worlds are the subject of a new show at the Mingei International Museum. This video illuminates the brothers’ inspirations and creative process.

headline: Movie Review: 'Tim's Vermeer'
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Tim's Vermeer."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Tim's Vermeer."

headline: Week in Pictures for Jan. 31
abstract: A slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the frozen Hudson River, a giant crane on its way to New York and scenes from Super Bowl Boulevard.
lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the frozen Hudson River, a giant crane on its way to New York and scenes from Super Bowl Boulevard.

headline: The Magical World of Steven and William Ladd
abstract: The designing brothers’ fantastically detailed fine-art installations arrive at San Diego’s Mingei International Museum.
lead_paragraph: The magical, whimsical worlds created by the artists Steven and William Ladd are the subject of “Function and Fantasy,” a new exhibition at the Mingei International Museum in San Diego. The brothers, who work out of a studio in New York City’s Chelsea neighborhood, brought their individual practices together more than a decade ago, when Steven was designing clothes and William was making intricate beadwork. Soon William’s beadwork found its way onto Steven’s clothes, and a deep collaboration began to evolve. They formed an accessories company, incorporating work so complex that it takes them up to three years to complete a single handbag. Ideas for packaging led them to the tower installations that now lie at the heart of their artistic practice.

headline: In North Carolina, Sites That Honor Black History
abstract: The new African American Heritage guide offers information on significant sites in the history of Wilmington, N.C.
lead_paragraph: Thirty-seven sites that highlight the contributions of African-Americans to the  business, spiritual, educational and civic life of   Wilmington, N.C.,  are detailed in the recently published African American Heritage guide.

headline: No Timetable for Relocating a Franchise to Los Angeles, Goodell Says
abstract: Commissioner Roger Goodell made his remarks in the wake of a news report that the owner of the St. Louis Rams had purchased 60 acres in central Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell said Friday that there was no timetable for putting a team in Los Angeles despite news reports that the owner of the St. Louis Rams, Stan Kroenke, had bought 60 acres in central Los Angeles, which presumably could hold a stadium.

headline: Apple Executives Met With F.D.A. to Discuss Mobile Medical Applications
abstract: A group of senior Apple executives met with directors from the Food and Drug Administration last month to discuss mobile medical applications. These meetings could involve the coming Apple smartwatch.
lead_paragraph: Apple has signaled strong interest in health-monitoring technology, which could wind up in a widely anticipated smartwatch.

headline: $100,000 Reward Is Set for Stolen Stradivarius Violin
abstract: The Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra announced that the reward was being offered for information that leads to the safe return of a 1715 Stradivarius violin stolen from the orchestra’s concertmaster.
lead_paragraph: The Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra announced late Friday afternoon that a $100,000 reward was being offered to anyone who provides information that leads to the safe return of the 1715 Stradivarius violin stolen from the orchestra’s concertmaster, Frank Almond, after a chamber concert in Milwaukee on Monday evening. Susan Loris, a spokeswoman for the orchestra said she was unable to identify the source of the reward money. It could be the orchestra, the anonymous owner of the violin (it was given to Mr. Almond as a permanent loan in 2008) or others.

headline: When Simplicity Trumps Complexity
abstract: The Focus! Festival at the Juilliard School continued its celebration of Alfred Schnittke with works by him and members of his circle, including Arvo Pärt.
lead_paragraph: The notion of stealing a show through simplicity and understatement may seem counterintuitive if not oxymoronic. But your intuition and mine are not Arvo Pärt’s, and this is a feat Mr. Pärt achieves with some regularity, as he did on Wednesday evening in the fourth program of the annual Focus! festival of contemporary music at the Juilliard School.

headline: Parched, California Cuts Off Tap to Agencies
abstract: Determined to use their water as cautiously as possible, state officials say they will cut off the water provided to local agencies serving 25 million residents. Those agencies will have to rely on other sources.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Responding to one of the worst droughts in California’s history, state officials announced on Friday that they would cut off the water to local agencies serving 25 million residents and about 750,000 acres of farmland.

headline: Going Off the Grid, and Being Showy About It
abstract: Four Houstonians are pulled back to nature in surprising ways in “Cherokee,” Lisa D’Amour’s new play, having its premiere at the Wilma Theater in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — A newbie camper wanders off into the woods in “Cherokee,” the new play by Lisa D’Amour having its premiere at the Wilma Theater here. His subsequent disappearance sparks a strange series of events, as his wife and the two friends joining him on a back-to-nature spree find themselves gradually acclimatizing to their radically altered lives as they spend days and weeks hoping for his return.

headline: Red Carpet Project
abstract: Of all the fashionable events that take place during awards season, the red carpet at the Academy Awards remains the main attraction. Explore an archive of Oscar red carpet looks that spans 17 years by name, designer, color, silhouette and year.
lead_paragraph: Of all the fashionable events that take place during awards season, the red carpet at the Academy Awards remains the main attraction. Explore an archive of Oscar red carpet looks that spans 17 years by name, designer, color, silhouette and year.

headline: Morgan Stanley’s Stock Bet Yields Windfall on Paper
abstract: Purchases of Morgan Stanley stock made by the firm’s chief executive years ago, when the Wall Street bank’s shares was trading far lower, have paid off extremely well for his portfolio.
lead_paragraph: When Morgan Stanley’s share price fell to $20 in 2011, the bank’s chief executive, James P. Gorman, and several of his top lieutenants tried to encourage investors by buying up stock with their own money. Now, that put-your-money-where-your-mouth-is approach appears to have paid off.

headline: A Hand-Me-Down With a History
abstract: About 40 years ago, the uncle of a New Jersey man taught his nephew how to drive in a 1952 MG TD. Now, the nephew owns the car.
lead_paragraph: Rambling over the back roads that neighbor Duke Farms, a 2,700-acre estate and nature preserve in central New Jersey, the 1952 MG TD called to mind a little pooch eager to impress the big hounds at the dog park: The confident bark of its exhaust belied the timid 55-horsepower bite of its tiny 4-cylinder engine.

headline: Keeping It in the Family
abstract: Randy Mehrberg’s 1952 MG TD was a gift from his uncle Morty, who taught Randy to drive in the MG decades ago.
lead_paragraph: Randy Mehrberg’s 1952 MG TD was a gift from his uncle Morty, who taught Randy to drive in the MG decades ago.

headline: Injured Actor Is Suing ‘Spider-Man’ Producers
abstract: Daniel Curry, who was seriously injured during a performance of “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” has filed a lawsuit charging the producers with negligence.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Curry, a young actor who was seriously injured in August while performing in the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” filed a lawsuit this week accusing the show’s producers, engineering consultants, and others of negligence in the design and operation of a mechanical lift that Mr. Curry was using onstage when he was hurt.

headline: You Are Like the People These Guys Make Up
abstract: The improv duo TJ Jagodowski and David Pasquesi specialize in sympathetic characters.
lead_paragraph: “TJ and Dave,” the hourlong improv show by the Second City veterans TJ Jagodowski and David Pasquesi, the premier improv duo working today, unfolds so seamlessly that it makes you wonder: Are these guys really making all this up on the spot?

headline: Jointly Forging a Movement, Cheek by Jowl
abstract: Two dissimilar founders of the N.A.A.C.P. collaborate in “Dr. Du Bois and Miss Ovington,” from Woodie King Jr.’s New Federal Theater.
lead_paragraph: She is a white Unitarian activist spinster from a good family in Brooklyn. He is one of the greatest African-American intellectuals of the 20th century. “Dr. Du Bois and Miss Ovington” finds them on a Sunday afternoon in 1915, and the burning question is supposedly whether she can talk him out of resigning from the N.A.A.C.P., of which they are both founders.

headline: Carmakers to Share Repair Data
abstract: An agreement signed in January ends a long fight between automakers and aftermarket groups that should make more repair information available to independent shops.
lead_paragraph: There is good news for motorists who have been turned away from local independent repair shops with an explanation that only the automaker’s dealership can correct a particular problem.

headline: Flitting Between Watery Dream and Reality
abstract: The Mariinsky Ballet presented its legendary production of “Swan Lake” at the Kennedy Center with three couples alternating in the lead roles.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The consistent visual beauty of the Mariinsky Ballet’s production of “Swan Lake,” which opened at the Kennedy Center this week, is astonishing. No other staging today so perfectly locates this ballet in the medieval age of chivalry; no other sets, costumes and lighting are so ravishingly satisfying in terms of color, style, period, atmosphere.

headline: Bridge at the District 3 Winter Regional
abstract: The winners of the Sunday A/X Swiss Teams were Jeff Aker of Briarcliff, N.Y., Victor King of Hartford, Conn., and Glenn Milgrim and Barry Rigal of New York City.
lead_paragraph: At the District 3 Winter Regional in Rye Brook, N.Y., two weeks ago, the winners of the Sunday A/X Swiss Teams were Jeff Aker of Briarcliff, N.Y., Victor King of Hartford, Conn., and Glenn Milgrim and Barry Rigal of New York City. They finished 8 victory points ahead of Dori Cohen of Woodbury, N.Y., Robert Gordon of Northport, N.Y., Kelley Hwang of New York City, and Richard Popper of Wilmington, Del. Third were Sue Picus, Alex Ornstein and Craig Ganzer of New York City, and Gene Saxe of Briarcliff, N.Y.

headline: True South | New Orleans Dining
abstract: T’s contributing editor Sara Ruffin Costello recommends Marti’s, which is off North Rampart Street, and Killer Poboys in the Erin Rose Bar on Conti Street, both in the French Quarter.
lead_paragraph: T’s contributing editor Sara Ruffin Costello recommends Marti’s, which is off North Rampart Street, and Killer Poboys in the Erin Rose Bar on Conti Street, both in the French Quarter.

headline: For a Silky Hip-Hop Romeo, a Juliet of His Own Making
abstract: The hip-hop choreographer Rennie Harris has brought his company Puremovement to the Joyce Theater for the first time in 10 years.
lead_paragraph: The beloved hip-hop choreographer Rennie Harris returned to the Joyce Theater for the first time in 10 years on Tuesday night, and the two-hour program — even one frustratingly made up of older dances and excerpts — was worth the wait. The prolific Mr. Harris works like a fiend. To all the nervous producers in the world: it’s O.K. to take a chance on Mr. Harris’s sophisticated view of hip-hop. We could have handled something new, something untested.

headline: BowlesSimpsonism
abstract: Yep, that’s what we need more of.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Chait — who’s been on a roll — has fun with the idea that the Bowles-Simpson commission is a model for, well, anything:

headline: Evening Hours | Keeping Warm
abstract: Even frigid weather could not halt the party circuit.
lead_paragraph: Even frigid weather could not halt the party circuit.

headline: Times Minute | Did Christie Know?
keywords: ['Dow Jones Stock Average', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Super Bowl', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'George Washington Bridge', 'Football']
abstract: A former aide claims that Gov. Chris Christie was aware of the lane closings while they were happening. Also on the Minute, the end of a rough month on Wall Street and this year's Super Bowl ads.
lead_paragraph: A former aide claims that Gov. Chris Christie was aware of the lane closings while they were happening. Also on the Minute, the end of a rough month on Wall Street and this year's Super Bowl ads.

headline: Times Minute | Did Christie Know?
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Dow Jones Stock Average', 'George Washington Bridge', 'Super Bowl']
abstract: A former aide claims that Gov. Chris Christie was aware of the lane closings while they were happening. Also on the Minute, the end of a rough month on Wall Street and this year’s Super Bowl ads.
lead_paragraph: In the Video

headline: Fashion’s Fertile Ground for Inspiration: Gardens
abstract: In a new exhibition at London’s Garden Museum, the historian Nicola Shulman traces connections between botanical trends and runway looks.
lead_paragraph: Seasons, colors, lighting and scale are no less important in building a good garden than they are in designing a good fashion collection. The two subjects, which have more crossover than some might realize, are explored in a show at the Garden Museum in London that opens Friday, aptly titled “Fashion & Gardens.” “Our national obsession with gardens and landscape is the greatest contribution England has brought to the world of fashion,” says the British writer and historian Nicola Shulman, a trustee of the Garden Museum in London, who leaped at the opportunity to curate the exhibition. Through art, historical photographs, artifacts and a look back at notable runways from designers like Yves Saint Laurent and Valentino, Shulman explores the intricate relationship between the two design genres from the days of Elizabeth I up to recent runway shows.

headline: Super Bowl Sideshows Starring Puppies, Kittens and Fish
abstract: The Puppy Bowl, now in its 10th year as counterprogramming to the Super Bowl, is joined this year by the Kitten Bowl and the Fish Bowl.
lead_paragraph: The Puppy Bowl has long been the big dog when it comes to alternative programming during the Super Bowl. When the stadium lights went out at the big game last year, more than a million viewers filled the time by flocking to the canine contest.

headline: Friday Night Music: Arcade Fire, Normal Person
abstract: Stripped down in Australia.
lead_paragraph: I have to admit, I had a hard time warming up to Arcade Fire’s new album. It was a break from the previous sound, and it’s taken me a while to find the thread of continuity. But I have been listening, and am increasingly getting it. As I mentioned on WNYC (btw, I start at around the 25-minute mark) my appreciation of their music grows when I get a chance to hear them do stripped-down performances, like this one just up, which among other things shows that the intensity and commitment is undiminished. Also that they’re having fun:

headline: As Argentine Peso Falters, President Keeps a Low Profile
abstract: President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner has said very little about the crisis that has led the nation’s currency to plunge.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — As Argentines stew over a currency crisis that has shaken markets around the world, many residents here are asking the same question: Where is the president?

headline: Domino’s Delivery Workers Settle Suit for $1.3 Million
keywords: ['Delivery Services', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Minimum Wage', 'Overtime']
abstract: Dozens of employees had accused a Manhattan franchisee of the pizza company of violating minimum wage and overtime laws.
lead_paragraph: Carlos Rodriguez Herrera said he often worked 65 hours a week as a deliveryman for a Domino’s pizza shop on East 89th Street in Manhattan but was paid for just 45 hours. A co-worker, Anatole Yameogo, remembers working from 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. one Saturday, but his pay stub said he worked just five hours that day.
